title: EQUITABLE LIFE MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct
CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $37,000 for the qr and $157,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after $104,000 tax charge...D-Including $922,000 gain on release of contingent liabilities

title: MAYOR TAKES EXPRESS FOR 'REGRETTABLE' RIDE
description: From about 5:40 to 6 P.M. yesterday, Mayor Koch took a ride on the subway.

title: Talking Business with Goizueta and Keough of Coca-Cola; Keeping Alert In Cola Market
description: Last March the Coca-Cola Company got a new management team: Roberto Goizueta, chairman and chief executive officer, and Donald Keough, president and chief operating officer. On a recent visit to New York, they discussed their plans for the Atlanta-based company, which earned $422.1 million last year on sales of $5.9 billion.

title: SHE HELPS YOUTHS BLOCK OUT GHETTO
description: The volleyball net, suspended from the ceiling, hangs ominously low over the middle of the court and makes line drives of jump shots from the top of the key.

title: The Tremor in Britain
description: The startling news of the election of Shirley Williams to Britain's Parliament needs a cautionary footnote. Americans have reason to welcome the dramatic rise of a left-of-center party that, unlike Labor, is committed to NATO and opposed to unilateral disarmament. And it could be, as the polls predict, that the newborn Social Democratic Party can win the next general election some years hence. But last week's special election in Crosby, a Liverpool suburb, can also be read as a vote for ''None of the Above'' - an expression of the discontent of many Americans who flocked to John Anderson last year. His final modest showing makes the point.

title: CORRECTION
description: A sports article on Sunday about Olympic board sailing omitted attri- bution for an assessment that a licens- ing agreement prevented the West German-produced Windglider from being imported into the United States. It should have been attributed to Tom Ehman, executive director of the United States Yacht Racing Union, and Robert Bavier, a United States delegate to the International Yacht Racing Union's permanent commit- tee. M&L Imports of Gloucester, Mass., says it began importing the Windglider in June, and disputes the account of Mr. Ehman and Mr. Ba- vier.

title: Virginia Coach Departs
description: Virginia won only one of 11 football games this season, and had a 16-49-1 record under Dick Bestwick the last six years.

title: Obscure Reserve Will Face the Jets
description: Until today, the Jets had known all about the quarterbacks they face this year -and the quarterbacks have known about them.

title: Customs Officer Slain in Shootout
description: An off-duty Customs officer was shot in the face and killed in Queens last night while trying to catch some men who had broken into his car, the police said.

title: Carolina Policeman Kills Thief Holding Hostage
description: A thief who held a shotgun to the head of a restaurant manager and threatened to fire was shot to death by a police officer early today.

title: What's Really Alien on Campus
description: The most cost-effective way Americans can help developing countries raise their standards of living is to welcome their students of technology. The students and their governments cover most of the cost and, in fact, bring some $2.5 billion to the United States. More important still, they often learn to appreciate American society as well as hardware.

title: BOOKS: BEST FOR CHILDREN
description: By George A. Woods

title: 'DRUG COURIER PROFILE' FACING REVIEW
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to try again to decide whether the police may rely on a ''profile'' of suspicious characteristics to pick out for further questioning airline passengers who are most likely to be carrying narcotics.

title: Offshore Oil Incentives Set
description: The Government will discount its standard 16.7 percent production royalty for companies willing to bid cash bonuses to win certain oil and gas leases off the mid-Atlantic coast, the Interior Department said today.

title: MAKING DO WITH SCHOOL LUNCH CUTS
description: It is lunchtime here at the Seymour Smith Elementary School, and the fourth grade is lined up against the wall. The kitchen staff is busy loading gravy-smothered pork onto rice, the kind of dish that has been served up in the immaculately scrubbed cafeteria for years.

title: WHY A BLOODBANK BUYS 'EUROBLOOD'
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 1, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
ABOUT EDUCATION
description: industry cooperation,'' says James Meindl, codirector of Stanford University's new Center for Integrated Systems (C.I.S.). He was talking about what, for better or for worse, seems to be a preview of the future of the nation's research universities.

title: FORMER CUOMO AIDE GETS 7 YEARS FOR LARCENY IN PADDING OF PAYROLL
description: The former chief of staff to Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was sentenced today to up to seven years in prison for cheating New York State of about $178,000.

title: ARMS TALKS OPEN IN 'CORDIAL' TONE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union began talks today on reducing nuclear weapons in Europe, and spokesmen for both sides expressed satisfaction with the results of the first meeting.

title: COURT ENDS LONG ROLE IN LOS ANGELES SCHOOLS
description: A school integration case that led to three years of busing here has been formally terminated, ending 18 years of court jurisdiction over the nation's second largest school system, it was disclosed today.

title: Liggett Chief Elected
description: Jonathan W. Old Jr., the 57-year-old executive vice president of the Liggett Group, has been elected president and chief executive officer, effective Feb. 1, 1982. He will succeed Raymond J. Mulligan, who will retire at age 60 from Liggett, the American consumer products subsidiary of Britain's Grand Metropolitan.

title: Accounts
description: * Children's Television Workshop to Lansdowne Advertising for its computer software division.

title: A.T.& T. PLANS START OF SUBSIDIARY
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company notified the Federal Communications Commission today that it wanted to start a long-awaited data communications network within six months as the initial offering of a separate subsidiary for unregulated, competitive services.

title: DISFRANCHISED FEET
description: To the Editor:

title: RONSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $18,030,000 in the latest 9 mos and $8,792,000 for the earlier period; the 1980 amounts restated; the 1981 periods include a gain of $828,000 or 19 cents a shr on the sale of land in Woodbridge, N.J. and a gain of $545,000 or 12 cents a shr from a positive adjustment on the sale of assets of the California subsidiary

title: ROBERT MILLER, PIANIST-LAWYER
description: Robert Miller, a pianist who championed contemporary music, died yesterday of cancer at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 50 years old.

title: FOR THE U.S., A HARD-LINER
description: Paul Henry Nitze's career as a maker and a critic of foreign policy has spanned the entire period of the cold war and, as an unrelenting hard-liner for all of that era, Mr. Nitze has at regular intervals warned that the United States was entering a period of maximum danger from the Soviet Union, requiring vast rearmament. But he has also spent a significant part of his career in the role of an arms control negotiator.

title: Chess: Another World Champion Keeps Her Title in a Draw
description: Maya Chiburdanidze of the Soviet Union retained her women's world championship by holding her countrywoman, Nana Aleksandriya, to an 8-8 tie in their match in Borzhomi and Tbilisi in the Georgian Republic.

title: REAGAN VOWS TO 'NOT RETREAT ONE INCH' ON POLICIES
description: President Reagan told 250 Republicans here tonight that he would ''not retreat one inch'' in the pursuit of his program of deep budget cuts and tax cuts even though he conceded that the United States was in a recession and that unemployment had risen.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. said it will file later this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $50 million in convertible subordinated debentures.

title: GREYHOUND COMPUTER OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLE SCORNS MOVE TO CURTAIL STRIKES
description: A principal leader of the Solidarity free trade union movement said today that he doubted the Communist Party and the Government seriously intended to ban strikes and curtail the civil liberties gained by Poles in the last year.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results have been reclassified for comparative purposes

title: The Wrong Way With Trucks
description: Since President Reagan is no friend of big government, one might have expected his appointees to seize on any opening to promote competition in excessively regulated industries. But at the Interstate Commerce Commission, Mr. Reagan's new chairman, Reese Taylor, is busily retying the regulatory knots that Congress thought it had loosened for the $50 billion trucking industry.

title: Israel to Request a Revision In Statement on Sinai Force
description: Israel's Cabinet decided today to request a change in the draft of the proposed American-Israeli statement on the Sinai peacekeeping force.

title: Elections Stir Dispute At Chicago Trade Board
description: Every year about this time the tumult on the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade spills over into the politics of the 2,000-member exchange: the exchange's nominating committee divulges its slate for the mid-January election of officers and controversy usually swirls around the choices until that time.

title: STOCK PRICES ARE CONTINUING RECOVERY
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday on the heels of last week's sharp rally touched off by declining interest rates. Energy and railroad issues ranked among the better performers.

title: Gould in Agreement For Microsystems
description: Gould Inc., which tried unsuccessfully to acquire two semiconductor companies in 1979, announced yesterday that it would buy American Microsystems Inc., a leading manufacturer of customized integrated circuits, in a transaction valued at roughly $200 million.

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Zaire's President Meets Haig at Start of Visit
description: As President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire began a three-day visit here, the United States today confirmed its offer to increase military and economic aid to the country to $45 million from $31 million last year.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The people have selected Tom Kean'' - Representative James J. Florio conceding New Jersey gubernatorial election. (A1:2.)

title: MEETING ON AGING HEARS SCHWEIKER
description: The 1981 White House Conference on Aging, which promises to provide a political testing ground for some of the social programs of the Reagan Administration, got off to a relatively smooth start today.

title: STRIKE BY COLLECTORS HALTS TRASH PICKUPS BY PRIVATE CONCERNS
description: Union workers for the private trash-collecting companies that serve the greater New York City area struck their employers at 12:01 A.M., and the carting companies said they would not pick up from any of their customers, beginning this morning. Negotiations were scheduled to resume at 11 A.M. today.

title: 'MAXIMUM' RESULTS REPORTED FROM SHUTTLE
description: The two astronauts who flew the space shuttle in its curtailed second flight said today that they had met nearly all their goals and that there were no plans to shorten the third flight from its scheduled seven days.

title: ERRORS SCUTTLED GIANTS
description: Mathematically, the Giants are not out of the National Football League's playoff picture. Realistically, after their 17-10 loss to the 49ers Sunday in San Francisco, they are.

title: Jazz Promotion Set For Kool Cigarettes
description: The Kool brand of cigarettes from Brown & Williamson Tobacco, which are in a toe-to-toe struggle with R.J. Reynolds's Salem brand for the lead slot in the menthol market, will latch onto jazz for its 1982 promotion.

title: Vickers Returns
description: There was a light in the Rangers' window for Steve Vickers, and the veteran left wing came in from the cold -- which is to say the farm club at Springfield, Mass. Vickers, who had played with the Rangers from the 1972-73 season through 1980-81, was recalled Sunday night and worked out yesterday.

title: Judge Declines to Lift Sinett Yacht-Racing Bar
description: NEWARK Nov. 30 - A Federal judge declined today to grant Seymore Sinett's request for a preliminary injunction that would have lifted Sinett's suspension from yacht racing until his suit for damages against the United States Yacht Racing Union is heard.

title: OFFICIAL DENIES C.I.A. EMPLOYED MAN ACCUSED OF SHOOTING LIBYAN
description: A Government official testified today that Eugene A. Tafoya was never employed by the Central Intelligence Agency, although he has maintained he was acting on agency orders when he shot a Libyan dissident.

title: COURT, CITING ANTITRUST ISSUE, BARS MOBIL MOVE TO BUY MARATHON OIL
description: A Federal judge ruled late yesterday that the Mobil Corporation's bid to acquire the Marathon Oil Company would violate antitrust law. As a result, a preliminary injunction was granted in Federal District Court in Cleveland that blocked Mobil's $6.5 billion takeover attempt.

title: A VOICE OF RATIONALITY
description: As theater missile negotiations begin in Europe, neither the Soviet Union nor the United States has categorically rejected the proposals of the other, and both say they seek substantial reductions.

title: A PICTURE OVER THE SOFA
description: Carol Zimmerman's husband has become one with the couch on this Sunday afternoon of televised professional football and she has left home seeking art.

title: TRASHING OLD PEOPLE (2)
description: Donald E. Crown is a landlord who specializes in emptying buildings of old and otherwise defenseless people in order to upgrade the property and make millions very quickly.

title: U.S. STEEL DEMANDED OPTION ON YATES OILFIELD
description: The United States Steel Corporation demanded during negotiations with the Marathon Oil Company that it be given an exclusive option to buy Marathon's large Yates oilfield if its takeover of the entire company fell through, David M. Roderick, the steelmaker's chairman, testified today.

title: ALLIED TO WRITE OFF NUCLEAR FUEL PLANT
description: The Allied Corporation, which disclosed that it had unsuccessfully bid $6.5 billion to acquire the Marathon Oil Company, said today it would take an $87 million writeoff to shut its nuclear fuel processing plant in Barnwell, S.C.

title: Belgium's Effort to Form New Cabinet Collapses
description: Efforts to form a new Government collapsed today after the French-language Social Christian Party refused to join in a center-right coalition proposed by the Flemish Liberal leader, Willy de Clercq.

title: FARM PRICE INDEX OFF 0.8% LAST MONTH
description: Prices paid to farmers for raw products dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent in November and for the fourth consecutive month averaged below levels for the same 1980 month, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Ciba Geigy In Alza Move
description: Ciba Geigy, a leading international pharmaceutical company based in Switzerland, said it would relinquish voting control of the Alza Corporation of Palo Alto, Calif., in which it acquired a majority stake in 1978.

title: Boy, 12, Admits Arson, Police Say
description: A 12-year-old boy, upset by his poor grades, has admitted slipping out of his home to set four predawn fires in the Queens parochial school he attends, the police said.

title: TV: MARVA COLLINS, UNUSUAL TEACHER
description: TIS the television season for inspirational stories, and it would be difficult to devise a more auspicious beginning than that being offered by CBS-TV tonight at 9 o'clock. The star is Cicely Tyson, whose outstanding inspiration record includes ''The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman,'' ''Sounder'' and ''A Woman Called Moses.'' The vehicle is ''The Marva Collins Story,'' which focuses on a Chicago teacher passionately concerned about underprivileged children who have been deemed ''unteachable'' by the school system.

title: ABDUL-JABBAR KEEPS ROLLING
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who has attained almost every honor in his 13 seasons as a pro, is expected to become the league's second highest career scorer tonight when Los Angeles plays host to the Utah Jazz. The center, six times the league's most valuable player, has 26,703 points, 7 behind Oscar Robertson, who played 14 seasons. Wilt Chamberlain is the leader with 31,419, and Abdul-Jabbar, 34 years old, would have to play several more seasons, scoring at his accustomed pace, to surpass that total. ... Toby Knight, the Knicks' forward who underwent extensive knee reconstruction surgery in September 1980 after a preseason injury, has begun to scrimmage with the team. ''It won't be long before I'm back, maybe by Christmas,'' he said.

title: Parents Protest DelBello Aid Cuts
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - About 100 parents brought their handicapped children in wheelchairs to protest the decision by Alfred B. DelBello, Westchester County Executive, to cut outpatient programs for handicapped children.

title: MUSIC: BERNSTEIN AND AN ORCHESTRA FROM FRANCE
description: THERE was a time, before technology made neighbors of us all, when almost every orchestra had its own characteristic sound. Instrumental and ensemble quality varied, not only from country to country but often from city to city. Now, however, all orchestral musicians, no matter where they live and work, benefit from the same internationally recognized teaching methods and other forces that press certain standards of excellence on them.

title: Lester Biederman Dies at 74; Former Sports Writer-Editor
description: Lester J. Biederman, retired sports editor of The Pittsburgh Press, died of cancer today in Fort Myers, Fla.

title: TV: CAGNEY IS PROFILED
description: THE arrival of ''Ragtime'' is the occasion for ''James Cagney: That Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' an admiring 90-minute documentary to be shown tonight at 9 o'clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13. Mr. Cagney is seen in clips from his various films and in interviews with Richard Schickel, who wrote, produced and directed the program.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A woman died in a fire that swept through her Queens apartment at about 8:30 A.M. yesterday.

title: A BALLOON DEVICE AVERTS SURGERY FOR CORONARY DISORDERS
description: TO spare many patients painful and costly surgery, doctors are turning to a technique that involves inflating a balloon in arteries clogged by fatty deposits from arteriosclerosis.

title: Machine Tool Orders Down
description: New orders for machine tools fell by 35 percent in October, compared with the comparable period a year ago, according to the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

title: Creamer Dickson Offers Women's Clubs Report
description: Since 1945 Creamer Dickson Basford, or its predecesor public relations firms, has found the women's clubs of the nation an ideal outlet for ''business-sponsored materials.''

title: Moral Majority Ousts State Chief
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Rev. Daniel Fore, whose controversial statements as chairman of the New York State chapter of the Moral Majority often embarrassed the religious group's national leadership, was ousted from his post Monday.

title: Witnesses Cite Horse Trainer's Neglect
description: Three trainers and the New York Racing Association's chief veterinarian were among six witnesses who cited a pattern of neglect in testifying yesterday at a hearing that could result in David Jacobson's losing his racing owner's and trainer's licenses.

title: JERSEY PANEL PROPOSES 2 ORCHESTRAS BE UNITED
description: A committee appointed by Governor Byrne to examine the financial plight of the performing arts in New Jersey recommended today that as an economy measure a single orchestra serve the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, the New Jersey State Opera and major ballet companies.

title: A $5-MILLION BLOW AGAINST NUCLEAR PROLIFERATION
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1981; Companies
description: The Marathon Oil Company won a preliminary injunction blocking a $6.5 billion takeover attempt by the Mobil Corporation on antitrust grounds. The Federal District Court in Cleveland ruled that Marathon had shown ''a reasonable probability that it will succeed at trial'' in proving that the merger would reduce competition in gasoline sales in some states. Mobil said that it had already appealed the ruling to a higher court. (Page A1.)

title: IS LEBANON DESTINED TO BE MOSCOW'S SATELLITE?
description: To the Editor:

title: MILITARY AIDES: OUT OF SPOTLIGHT AND IN ON POWER
description: Newspaper readers have probably seen pictures of Maj. Gen. Carl R. Smith a dozen times over the past couple of years without being aware of it. But today, if the pattern holds, may be the only time his name appears in the paper.

title: MEESE WARNS ANEW ON SALVADOR ARMS
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, reinforced the Administration's warnings on Central America today by asserting that President Reagan has not ruled out a blockade or other strong actions aimed at halting the flow of arms into El Salvador.

title: CITY HAD 4,099 FEWER EMPLOYEES THAN PLANNED AT END OF OCTOBER
description: Although the Koch administration says that no slowdown in hiring is under way, New York City had 4,099 fewer employees at the end of October than originally planned.

title: SALVADORAN GUERRILLAS' UNLIKELY INCLINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ATGET DISCOVERED

title: CITY PLANS TO EXPAND USE OF ARMORIES TO HOUSE HOMELESS MEN
description: New York City officials, under a court order to produce a plan today for expanding the city's shelters for homeless men, said yesterday that state armories would be used as winter weather drove more vagrants to seek warmth.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX OFF BY 1.8%
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators declined 1.8 percent in October, the Government reported today, indicating that there is no immediate hope of a recovery from the recession.

title: H. VICTOR GROHMANN, RAN AN AD CONCERN FOR 50 YEARS
description: H. Victor Grohmann, who retired last March as chairman of Needham & Grohmann Advertising Inc., which he founded 50 years ago with William H. Needham, died Saturday while visiting his daughter in Lincoln, Mass. He was 78 years old and lived in Sussex, N.J.

title: TELEPROMPTER RETRACTS BIDS FOR CABLE TV
description: Teleprompter announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from competition for the city's remaining cable television franchises. It complained that it wanted a larger share of two boroughs than it seemed likely to get.

title: GENE SPLICING: LEGAL PITFALLS
description: After unlocking some of the most basic laws of nature in less than a decade of research, gene-splicing companies are now looking at more mundane laws - those governing property rights, contracts and liability for injury.

title: HONDURAN VICTOR IN OVERTURE TO FOES
description: Caravans of cars and buses, blowing their horns and trailing red-and-white flags, converged on the small town of La Paz today to celebrate the victory of a native son, Dr. Roberto Suazo Cordova, in the Honduran presidential election.

title: Two to Get Literature Awards
description: The second annual Common Wealth Awards for distinguished service in literature will be presented today to Nadine Gordimer, a South African novelist, and Milan Kundera, a Czech-born playwright and novelist who lives in Paris.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.75-16.00** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Q&A
description: Q. Since the body's temperature is 98.6 degrees, why does a spring day of 70 degrees feel pleasant, while a 98 degree summer day seems stifling?

title: Bench Beckons Jones
description: Coach Mike McCormack of the Baltimore Colts said he was ''giving some consideration'' to benching Bert Jones in favor of David Humm for Sunday's game against Dallas. ''We'll know by Thursday,'' the coach said.

title: COURT TO RULE IN LIQUOR CURB
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the legality of a California law that allows liquor distillers to decide which wholesalers may bring each distiller's brand into the state.

title: Airline Fare Talks Are Set
description: Officials of 25 United States and European airlines will meet here on Wednesday to try to cut their losses on the North Atlantic route, possibly by raising fares up to 15 percent next year.

title: MISS WOOD'S DEATH CALLED ACCIDENTAL
description: Natalie Wood drowned in what Thomas T. Noguchi, the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner, called a ''tragic accident while slightly intoxicated.'' According to the re-creation of the accident by the coroner's office, the 43-year-old actress drowned shortly after midnight Sunday after falling while trying to get from her yacht into a rubber dinghy. According to Dr. Noguchi, the actress slipped and fell into the water off Santa Catalina Island, 22 miles from the California coast.

title: MARSHALL FIELD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Arafat Telegram Backs Group In Israel That Opposes Nation
description: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has sent a telegram of support to an Orthodox Jewish group that opposes the nation of Israel, a spokesman for the group said today.

title: Lewis Campaign For Tabatchnick
description: Among the biggest nonfamily fans of Campbell's new Backer & Spielvogel ''Soup is good food'' campaign are William and Carol Lewis and their client, Tabatchnick-Millburn, maker of Tabatchnick soup, a frozen food product in national distribution.

title: Islander Dissension Brewing
description: Has dissension arisen among the tightly knit Islanders? Unbeaten in their first eight road games, the Islanders have lost four of their last five away from home. After Sunday night's 5-2 loss to the Buffalo Sabres, the players began to question not only themselves, but also one another and the coaching.

title: Restaurant Closes After 2-Alarm Fire
description: A fire caused heavy damage early Sunday to Artist and Writers, a popular midtown restaurant, forcing it to close indefinitely, fire officials said.

title: SCM Announces Plant Shutdowns
description: The SCM Corporation announced that its Smith-Corona typewriter group planned to suspend production at its manufacturing plants in Cortland and Groton, N.Y., for three weeks beginning Dec. 24, idling 500 of its 4,000 employees.

title: Israeli Enemy of Camp David Is Reported to Be Next Envoy
description: The Israeli Cabinet today named Moshe Arens, who voted against the Camp David accords and the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty, as Ambassador-designate to the United States, Cabinet sources said.

title: BRITISH CAR BUYERS SAVE BY TRAVELING TO THE CONTINENT
description: One day last month, J.B. Fuller took a day off from work to save more than $1,100 on a new car by visiting Belgium, buying an auto there and driving it back to Britain via the car ferry. He did so on the advice of a friend who had done the same.

title: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio - U.S. Steel has offered $6.3 billion for the Marathon Oil Company. That sum would build a new steel mill.  Alternatively, $6.3 billion could pay for modernization of U.S.  Steel's existing facilities. Why has a leading firm of an industry desperately needing modernization decided, instead, to buy an oil company?
description: The answer is simple. Steel is a very capital-intensive business, and, for this reason, investment in steel is not as profitable as investment in downtown real estate, or chemicals, or, apparently, oil. Therefore, American steel companies have been reducing their steelmaking capacity and investing elsewhere. For American society, which needs a steel industry to retain its economic independence, this raises the question of whether the profit motive can be relied on to reindustrialize steel.

title: CONFERENCE ON AGING VIEWS OLDER WOMEN
description: For the first time in the history of White House Conferences on Aging, the concerns of older women were discussed here today.

title: Sports of The Times; Rare Film for A Rare Trophy
description: SHORTLY after Les Horvath married, his wife, Shirley, asked him about a bronze trophy of a football player that he had put up on their mantel.

title: Death Toll in Syria Explosion Put at 90 Killed and 135 Hurt
description: The death toll in Syria's worst car bomb attack climbed to 90 today as more bodies were recovered from debris and several injured victims died in the hospital, medical sources said.

title: ENERGY CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PETER WEIR'S 'THE PLUMBER'
description: ''THE PLUMBER,'' which originated as an Australian television film and has its theatrical premiere today at the Bleecker Street Cinema's James Agee Room, is more evidence of the versatility of Peter Weir. Mr. Weir, who directed the sweeping ''Gallipoli'' and the smaller, more delicate ''Picnic at Hanging Rock'' and ''The Last Wave,'' this time turns his attention, with much success, to a droll, claustrophobic work of absurdist humor.

title: DOLPHINS BEAT EAGLES ON LATE FIELD GOAL
description: The Miami Dolphins defeated the Philadelphia Eagles tonight, 13-10, on a 27-yard field goal by Uwe von Schamann 66 seconds before the end of the game.

title: FILMS DOWN UNDER IMPERILED BY CASH UP HERE
description: Margaret Fink, the movie producer, had wanted Don McAlpine, the cinematographer on more than a dozen Australian films including ''My Brilliant Career'' and ''Breaker Morant,'' to work on her new $3 million to $4 million film, ''For Love Alone.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE ROYAL GAME. And Other Stories. By Stefan Zweig. Introduction by John Fowles. Translated from the German by Jill Sutcliffe. 250 pages. Harmony Books. $12.95.

title: ASTRO DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1,150,000 gain on the sale of drilling rig

title: M.T.A. REPORT: TRAINS UP, BUT RIDERS DOWN
description: Subway ridership in New York City decreased in September, more trains got out of the yards each day and crime on the system increased, according to the first comprehensive monthly report issued by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Jamaican Flour Loan
description: The International Finance Corporation, an affiliate of the World Bank, said today that it had approved a $5 million loan to Jamaica Flour Mills Ltd. as part of a $20.6 million expansion project to more than double the company's grinding capacity. The expansion will allow the island nation to become virtually self-sufficient in the milling of flour, the agency said.

title: LEAFY SPURGE IS RUNNING WILD
description: Leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula), a weed that was a pest in several North Central and Western areas of the United States 25 years ago, has marched across some 3,000,000 acres of range and croplands since that time and now threatens 3,000,000 additional acres, the United States Department of Agriculture reports.

title: Diana Player of Year In E.C.A.C. Football
description: Yale's tailback, Rich Diana, was named player of the year, and two freshmen quarterbacks, Doug Flutie of Boston College and Steve Calabria of Colgate, shared rookie honors as the Eastern College Athletic Conference announced its Division I all-star football team today.

title: SENATE POSTPONES THE WILLIAMS CASE
description: Senate leaders agreed today to postpone until January efforts to expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., the New Jersey Democrat who has been convicted of bribery and conspiracy charges in Government's undercover Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: No Headline
description: TARHEELS SUBDUE U.S.C.

title: Righetti Gets Rookie Prize
description: Dave Righetti, a left-handed pitcher who had an 8-4 record for the Yankees after coming up from Columbus, was named the American League rookie of the year yesterday.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP; RATES RISE
description: Interest rates rose yesterday, with as much as half the increase coming late in the day after the Federal Reserve announced a $1.7 billion increase in the nation's money supply.

title: Penn Central And Bally Pact
description: The Penn Central Corporation and the Bally Manufacturing Corporation said they had signed a definitive agreement for Bally to buy the Six Flags Corporation for an estimated price of $142 million.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 1, 1981
description: International An American-Israeli agreement that strengthens their strategic cooperation was announced in Washington. The understanding, which does not require Senate approval, is directed against threats to the Middle East ''caused by the Soviet Union or Soviet-controlled forces from outside the region.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Nuclear arms talks began in Geneva. The first meeting on efforts to reduce the weapons in Europe was characterized by Paul H. Nitze, the chief American negotiator, as ''cordial and businesslike,'' and by a Soviet spokesman as ''very constructive, with both sides striving for agreement.'' (A1:5.)

title: Mercedes Output Cut
description: The Brazilian subsidiary of Mercedes-Benz, the West German auto maker, today put 5,000 of its 15,000 employees on paid holiday for a minimum of 48 days and ceased most production to reduce inventories. A spokesman said that the unit, Mercedes-Benz do Brasil S.A., which makes trucks and buses, has 4,000 vehicles in stock at the factory, where normal operating inventory is 1,500. The company said that its sales fell to 43,000 units in the first 10 months of 1981 from 48,305 in the comparable period in 1980.

title: Outlaw Pickles
description: Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, in a letter to constituents: If you like thin pickles and fast ketchup, you're in trouble. Government regulations have outlawed pickle slices that are too thin or too wide, and ketchup that flows faster than nine centimeters in 30 seconds.

title: CHINA'S ECONOMIC SHIFT SAID TO NEED MORE TIME
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang said today that China might need five more years to finish readjusting its economy. Mr. Zhao told the opening session of the National People's Congress, the nominal parliament, that corrections in China's economic imbalance would take longer than expected because their extent was far broader than envisaged under the three-year objectives set in April 1979.

title: Leonard Friedman Memorial Will Be Conducted Tomorrow
description: A memorial service for Leonard Friedman, former president and chief executive officer of the Colonial Corporation of America, will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, at 2 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Benefit for Tennessee Williams Put Off to Spring
description: A benefit for the National Committee for the Literary Arts, planned for tomorrow night at Avery Fisher Hall, has been rescheduled for the spring.

title: MARMON GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1981 periods reflect the reversal of approximately $11 million of previously provided deferred income taxes as a result of changes in Britain's tax law with respect to stock relief

title: No Headline
description: NATIVITY SCENE IN CAPITOL STIRS SOUTH DAKOTA RIGHTS PROTEST

title: JAPAN'S NEW CABINET TO TACKLE TRADE SURPLUS
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki said today that the chief task of his reorganized 20-member Cabinet, in which only five ministers retained their posts, was to reduce Japan's record trade surpluses with the United States and Western Europe.

title: CHROMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LIL' CHAMP FOOD STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The 1980 qr and 6 mos shr earnings are restated to reflect 5 percent stock dividend paid Dec 1980 and include 5 cents a shr net profit on sale of real estate

title: No Headline
description: UPSETS IN AUSSIE TENNIS

title: THE DEBACLE AT FEZ
description: The defeat of Crown Prince Fahd's Middle East peace plan here stemmed primarily from Saudi Arabia's failure to deliver American support for it. The decisive moment came in the foreign ministers' meeting, which preceded the Arab League summit conference - which collapsed in four hours last week - when Prince Saud al-Faisal was asked: ''If the summit approved the Fahd points, do you believe the United States would accept them and if so induce Israel to negotiate on those terms?'' To everyone's amazement, the Prince remained silent.

title: ISRAEL IS CULTIVATING SOME UNLIKELY NEW FRIENDS
description: A most unlikely visitor is scheduled to arrive in Israel on Tuesday under the auspieces of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith: the Rev. Bailey E. Smith, president of the Southern Baptist Convention, who said last year that ''God Almighty does not hear the prayer of a Jew.''

title: Woolworth Loans
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said that it had arranged two standby revolving credit agreements totaling $225 million that could be used principally to replace its short-term debt.

title: BYRD OF VIRGINIA IS RETIRING AFTER 3 TERMS IN THE SENATE
description: Harry F. Byrd Jr., the only independent in the United States Senate, said today that he would not seek reelection next year. The announcement opens what promises to be a tough fight for the seat he has held since 1965.

title: AIRLINE SCHEDULES REDUCED ANOTHER NOTCH TODAY
description: With the curtailment of air traffic services about to enter its fifth month, airline schedules will be cut back another notch today in the busiest hours at the nation's 22 main airports.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American General Corp. said it had sold most of its stake in USLife Corp., amounting to 1,289,500 shares, or 5.8 percent, for $36,358,000. American said it now owned no USLife common stock, but still held 191,800 shares of preferred stock.

title: TWO SCHOOLS VIE FOR VOICE IN CAPITAL
description: It was back in 1963. George S. Springsteen Jr., one of George W. Ball's deputies at the State Department, was looking for an aide, someone trained in the arts of diplomacy, young, quick-witted, tireless, omniscient.

title: Topics Bragging Greater Glens Falls
description: First there was ''city,'' a term everyone understood, and if there was the least doubt about the fringe area, one inserted ''Greater'' before the name of the place in question. Then, after World War II, came fringe-area growth so explosive that in some places the suburban population shot far ahead of the urban; a new vocabulary was needed. ''City,'' for instance, became C.B.D., Central Business District, or central city. ''Greater'' became S.M.S.A., Standard Metropolitan Statistical Area.

title: JUDGE TELLS CITY BUS DIVISION TO ALTER ITS HIRING PRACTICES
description: The Transit Authority's Manhattan and Bronx bus division, which has been accused of nepotism and other questionable personnel practices, must start using competitive examinations to hire and promote its 6,000 non-management employees, a State Supreme Court justice held yesterday.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Widened in October
description: The nation's trade deficit widened in October to $5.3 billion, the third month this year of deficits higher than $5 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Index; International
description: Odd friends: Israel and the evangelical Protestants A2 Honduran election victor makes overture to foes A3 Meese warns anew on flow of Cuban arms into El Salvador A3 Canada sending a new ambassador to Washington A3 Around the World A4 Solidarity spokesman doubts gov- ernment will try to ban strikes A5 Japan cabinet will try to reduce trade surplus with West A11 Twenty-four plead not guilty to charges of killing Sadat A12 Text of U.S.-Israeli memorandum of understanding A14 Government/Politics Court ends 18-year role in Los Angeles school system A18 Virginian pleads not guilty in Libya terrorist conspiracy A21 Supreme Court Roundup A23 O'Neill vows to speed foreign aid measure in House A25 City plans to place homeless men in armories B1 City had 4,099 fewer employees at end of October than planned. B3 Washington Talk Two schools of diplomacy vie for influence in capital A28 Military assistants keep the Pentagon running smoothly A28 Required reading A28 Briefing A28 General Around the Nation A16 Blizzard hits Nebraska; storms cause damage in Texas A16 Nativity scene stirs dispute in South Dakota A17 Natalie Wood's death called accidental, says medical examiner A25 Talks break off on sale of U.P.I. to Reuters A27 Drug executive resigns over disputed insomnia program B3 Science Times Chemists race to save old books from acids C1 Inflating a balloon averts coro- nary surgery C1 One gorilla, symbol of the past, gets some freedom C1 Education: Federal courts differ on tenure cases C1 Science Library C2 Science Watch C3 Q&A C4 About education: Stanford gears up with electronics C6 Arts/Entertainment Lure of foreign cash threatens Australian film industry C7 Peter Weir's ''Plumber'' at Bleecker Street Cinema C8 New Jersey panel urges unification of two orchestras C8 ''Royal Game,'' five stories by Stefan Zweig, is reviewed C9 ''Square Business'' is danced by Bebe Miller C9 A roundup of the year's best books for children C9 L'Orchestre National de France at Fisher Hall C9 Style Notes on Fashion A28 Improvisations for a chilly day A28 Conference on Aging views older women A28 Sports Jackson meets with Braves and Angels B5 Righetti voted rookie of the year B5 Dolphins rally to beat Eagles B5 With Zorn hurt, Jets will face a little-known quarterback B5 Female basketball coach helps boys block out the ghetto B5 Dave Anderson on the Heisman Trophy B6 Giants were scuttled by their er rors against 49ers B6 Signs of dissension on Islanders B6 Princeton thwarts stall by Princeton and wins, 48-46 B7 Obituaries Robert Miller, pianist who championed contemporary music D31 Features/Notes Man in the News: Paul Henry Nitze, U.S. arms negotiator A6 Man in the News: Yuli A. Kvitsinsky, Soviet arms negotiator A6 Notes on People B4 Sports People B8 News Analysis Howell Raines surveys the inves- tigation of Richard Allen A10 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A30

title: CHEM-TRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
White House 'Tablecloth Crisis' Discounted
description: Much was made over the weekend about reports from Muffy Brandon, the White House social secretary, that the First Family was down to its last six tablecloths, and some of them were pretty threadbare at that.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE SOVIET STATE VERSUS ONE COUPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Says U.S. Seeks Military Edge at Talks
description: As Soviet-American talks opened today in Geneva on the reduction of medium-range nuclear arms in Europe, Soviet leaders issued a statement accusing the United States and its NATO allies of entering the negotiations with a plan to obtain ''military advantages.''

title: CITY TO STEP UP ITS ENFORCEMENT OF THE FIRE LAWS
description: New York City will seek to have owners of high-rise office buildings held in contempt and jailed for any continued violations of fire-safety laws, Deputy Mayor Nathan Leventhal said yesterday.

title: Market Place; Low-Cost Play In Robotics
description: TRADERS who looked for speculative gains in shares of Condec following the Unimation offering last Wednesday are still wondering what went wrong.

title: DRUG EXECUTIVE RESIGNS OVER INSOMNIA PROGRAM
description: A research director for one of the nation's largest pharmaceutical companies resigned yesterday following the disclosure that he was operating an insomnia program that gave most of its clients prescriptions for the depressant methaqualone.

title: BRIEFING
description: A GROUP of ''atomic veterans'' has quietly filed suit against the Government in an effort to learn the names of some of the tens of thousands of men who participated in the atmospheric nuclear detonations conducted from 1945 to 1963. Besides the two wartime uses of atomic weapons, at Hiroshima and Nagasaki, there were approximately 235 nuclear tests, mostly in Nevada and in the Marshall Islands in the Pacific.

title: Boss Relents on United Way
description: Richard Deckerhoff, a bank president who dismissed a teller last week because she refused to donate to United Way, says he regrets the action and wants her to return to work. But Terri Ware, 24 years old, said today that she had hired an attorney and had no plans to come back. She said she refused to give to the annual fund-raising drive because she opposed groups it supported.

title: F.B.I. Is Hunting for Pair Who Abducted Three
description: Federal agents continued their search today for a man and woman accused of abducting three Maryland residents and leaving them bound in a motel.

title: EDUCATION
description: CONTRADICTORY decisions last month by Federal courts in New York and Georgia in two parallel discrimination cases have added new uncertainty to the question of whether faculty members can be forced to disclose their votes on tenure and promotion decisions.

title: MIAMI
description: RAMAR, a lowland gorilla weighing more than 350 pounds, was eased out of a holding area at Miami's new Metro zoo last week for his first taste of life in the open since he was born 13 years ago.

title: GOVERNMENT ENDS CASE IN MARGIOTTA FRAUD TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors completed their case today against Joseph M. Margiotta on fraud and extortion charges involving municipal insurance commissions in Nassau County.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cineplex Corporation, Toronto, has appointed Charles J. Wesoky a senior vice president.

title: Bridge: California Foursome Wins Reisinger at Fall Nationals
description: A California foursome scored an overwhelming victory in the Reisinger board-a-match team championship here Sunday night at the conclusion of the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: O'NEILL SAYS HE WILL PRESS HOUSE FOREIGN AID BILL
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House, pledged today to bring the $11.1 billion foreign aid appropriation bill to the House floor before the Christmas recess, but he warned that the Reagan Administration would have to provide 100 Republican votes to assure passage.

title: A WOULD-BE M.P.'S DEBT TO MONTY PYTHON
description: To the Editor:

title: PRINCETON THWARTS RUTGERS FREEZE, 48-46
description: Bill Ryan, a sophomore from Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens, drove in with the winning basket and added the foul shot with four seconds to play tonight as Princeton rallied to defeat Rutgers, 48-46, before a crowd of 2,589 at Jadwin Gym.

title: SOME STATES ACT TO CUT BUSINESS TAX LOSSES
description: A number of states, perhaps as many as 19, are taking steps to diminish revenue losses that would result from the more generous depreciation allowances for business adopted by Congress this year, according to a survey released today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Sampson Breaks Finger And Is Out Indefinitely
description: Virginia's star center, Ralph Sampson, has a broken finger and will be out indefinitely, Coach Terry Holland said today.

title: Selection of Jury Begins In Coast Bribery Trial
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of three reputed figures in organized crime accused of conspiring to fix another trial by bribing a Federal district judge.

title: FOR RUSSIANS, A GERMANIST
description: When Yuli Aleksandrovich Kvitsinsky was named this fall as chief Soviet negotiator for the Geneva nuclear arms reduction talks, American officials reacted at first with surprise, and then, after a quick intellectual double-take, with total comprehension.

title: TV TAPING BILL ARGUED
description: Senator Dennis DeConcini called today for support of a bill he has introduced that would let owners of video cassette recorders tape television programs for home use. A court recently ruled that such taping violated copyright laws.

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Commonwealth And Hess Talks
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company, a Puerto Rican refinery operator that recently emerged from voluntary bankruptcy reorganization, said it was holding ''operating cooperation'' talks with the Amerada Hess Corporation.

title: IDEAL TOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: B-Including $1,856,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: Death Penalty Bill Stalled in Jersey
description: TRENTON (AP) - A proposal to reinstitute the death penalty was withdrawn from consideration by Assembly Democratic leaders. The Assembly's majority leader, Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville, said a floor vote on the bill would be a ''waste of time because the Governor has said he will veto the bill.''

title: AN ACID DEVOURS MANY OLD BOOKS, CHEMISTS RACE TO STOP DECAY
description: FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT was mistaken when he observed that ''People die, but books never die.'' A third to a half of the five million books at the New York Public Library are dying right now.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After an extraordinary gain of $654,000

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: L AST week, fashionable New Yorkers did what they always do. They went to parties, wore fur and smiled evenly when they passed each other on Madison Avenue. Even Erte, the legendary artist, was in town shopping and wearing his mink on Madison, where he dropped into Rita's Blue Tent at 65th Street, the store that always has at least one gold mesh halter in the window. But conversations with businessmen and a weekend walk through the stores revealed signs of a troubled economy and a flagging business at retail, with heavy markdowns the order of the day.

title: Text of memorandum is on page A14.
description: The United States and Israel announced agreement on a memorandum of understanding today to strengthen their strategic cooperation against threats to the Middle East ''caused by the Soviet Union or Soviet-controlled forces from outside the region.''

title: Cavaliers Searching
description: Ted Stepien, owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, who are afflicted with a 4-11 record and dwindling attendance, said after meeting with Don Delaney yesterday that Delaney would be removed as coach within the next few days, as soon as Stepien can find someone else, but would stay on ''in some capacity.'' Delaney was general manager last season when Stepien felt that he had had enough of Coach Bill Musselman and named Delaney to succeed him.

title: ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Better Auto Sales Seen DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP)
description: New-car sales could increase 16 percent and truck sales could jump 30 percent in 1982 if the overall economy grows and interest rates continue their decline, the president of the Ford Motor Company, Donald E. Petersen, said today.

title: CUTS BY AIR FORCE CITED
description: The Fairchild Republic Company said yesterday that it will lay off 330 employees this week, and as many as 1,000 more early next year, because the Air Force has reduced the number of A-10 jet fighter planes it plans to buy from Fairchild between now and 1984.

title: FLORIO CONCEDES GOVERNOR'S RACE TO KEAN IN JERSEY
description: After 27 days of uncertainty, Representative James J. Florio conceded defeat today in the close gubernatorial election held Nov. 3.

title: WORLD NUCLEAR SAFEGUARDS WEAK, U.S. REGULATORY AGENCY CONCLUDES
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has concluded that the international system of safeguards intended to prevent the diversion of nuclear materials to atomic weapons ''would not detect a diversion in at least some types of facilities.''

title: IMPROVISATIONS FOR A CHILLY DAY
description: Thermometers had dropped, bringing thoughts of Yule logs and Christmas stockings, but the air was bracing, not bitter. So there was no need just yet to bundle into the massive coverings that weigh heavily on the shoulders and impede movement.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $1,750,000 nonrecurring pretax charge associated with organization changes at the company's Acme Markets Inc subsidiary; the company had pretax LIFO charges of $3 million and $12.7 million for the latest qr and $12.7 million for the l qr and 9 mos and $5 million and $13,750,000 for the previous qr and 9 mos

title: Comings and Goings
description: By reaching the quarterfinals at Sydney, Australia, last week, 16-year-old Andrea Jaeger has accumulated enough points to become the fourth player to qualify for the $250,000 Toyota tennis championships for women, to be held Dec. 15-20 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. She joins fellow Americans Chris Evert Lloyd, Martina Navratilova and Tracy Austin. The final four qualifiers will be determined this week at the Australian Women's Open in Melbourne.

title: Smoking by Eyesight
description: Writers of memoirs from Casanova to B.@F. Skinner have pondered the pleasures of smoking. The Italian adventurer reported that the sight of the smoke was a great part of the enjoyment, offering as evidence his own observations that the blind did not smoke and that smokers avoided smoking in the dark. Some two centuries later, the American psychologist concurred: Darkness prevented the pipe smoker from being able to judge the state of the fire in the bowl by the density of smoke in the air.

title: I.B.M. Aide to Head Prime Computer
description: The four-month search for a new head of Prime Computer Inc., one of the fastest-growing small computer concerns in the country, ended yesterday with the appointment of an executive who has spent his entire career at the biggest company in the business.

title: SCRIPPS COMPANY ENDS TALKS ON SELLING U.P.I. TO REUTERS
description: The E.W. Scripps Company said yesterday that it was discontinuing talks on selling United Press International, the second-largest news service in the United States, to the London-based Reuters news agency.

title: Cowboys Gain Playoff Spot
description: The Dallas Cowboys discovered today that not only had they clinched a spot in the playoffs, but that they - and not the San Francisco 49ers - had been the first to do it.

title: FOE OF VIOLENT TV AND COMICS
description: Dr. Fredric Wertham, an internationally known psychiatrist who believed that comic books, movies and television shows that featured crime, violence and horror exerted a damaging influence on many juveniles and young adults, died Nov. 18 at his retirement home in Kempton, Pa. He was 86 years old.

title: More County Aides Quit In Oklahoma Scandal
description: Three more county commissioners resigned today in an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into a kickback scheme, the office of Gov. George Nigh said.

title: STUDENT IS INDICTED IN BOOK THEFT
description: A Federal grand jury yesterday indicted a Columbia University graduate student who had been arrested Oct. 2 in the theft of antique books from a London library. The books included a copy of Galileo's ''Discorsi'' printed in 1638.

title: NEW ENVOY FROM CANADA OFFERS FRESH APPROACH
description: Canada is sending a new ambassador to Washington Tuesday with an enhanced role in handling what he calls his country's ''dominant bilateral relationship.''

title: Escaped Spy, in Court, Refuses to Enter Plea
description: Christopher Boyce, convicted of spying, stood mute in Federal court today and refused to enter a plea to a charge he escaped from prison while serving a 40-year sentence for selling secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: Peak Wheat Crop Seen
description: The world will harvest a record wheat crop of 453 million metric tons this year, the International Wheat Council predicted today.

title: News Analysis
description: The protracted and politically sensitive investigation into Richard V. Allen's affairs, which has produced the most embarrassing publicity of President Reagan's first year in office, is nearing a turning point.

title: ALICO INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Turkey Opens the Trial Of 500 Leftist Militants
description: More than 500 left-wing militants went on trial in the eastern Turkish city of Erzurum today on charges of waging a violent anti-Government campaign in the remote region close to the Soviet border.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
LANE BRYANT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DISCORD OVER MOBILE PHONES
description: A compromise by the Federal Communications Commission that, in effect, gave the Bell System an upper hand in marketing a new mobile telephone service now seems to be falling apart.

title: Angolan Rebel Leader Reports Refinery Raid
description: Jonas Savimbi, leader of the pro-Western insurgent forces in Angola, said in New York yesterday that his guerillas had set an oil refinery on fire near Luanda, the capital.

title: VIRGINIAN DENIES GUILT IN LIBYA TERRORIST PLOT
description: Douglas M. Schlachter Sr. pleaded not guilty today on charges of illegally shipping explosives to Libya and training terrorists there as part of a conspiracy headed by Edwin P. Wilson and Frank E. Terpil, both former agents of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: New School Board Member
description: Stephen Franse, a former teacher and currently an official with the New York City Board of Education, was appointed yesterday to serve as a member of the board. Mr. Franse, 34 years old, will be the Bronx representative on the seven-member board. His appointment was announced by the Bronx Borough President, Stanley Simon.

title: Protest Group Gets a Permit To Put Tents by White House
description: The Federal Park Police issued a oneweek permit today allowing a social-action group to put up nine tents across the street from the White House to dramatize the plight of the homeless.

title: TEXT OF AMERICAN-ISRAELI AGREEMENT
description: Following is the text of a memorandum of understanding signed today by the Israeli Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger: Preamble

title: JERSEY WORKERS REJECT MILKPACT AND START STRIKE
description: Workers of the New Jersey milk industry walked off the job today after union members rejected a contract offer from the New Jersey Milk Industry Association.

title: TURNER READIES OFFER TOJACKSON
description: Ted Turner, the owner of the Atlanta Braves, began his pursuit of Reggie Jackson yesterday and today will jump into the second part of his sales pitch by making Jackson an offer.

title: Thrift Units Make Gains
description: Ending a seven-month loss record, savers put $1.5 billion more into savings and loan associations last month than they took out, the Government said today. The gain was attributed mostly to the new tax-exempt ''All Savers'' certificates, which attracted $16.5 billion in accounts in savings and loans last month.

title: FIVE GIFTS SHOWN TO F.B.I. BY ALLEN
description: Richard V. Allen, who is on administrative leave as the President's national security adviser, said today that he had opened five gifts in the presence of Federal agents that were in the same safe as the $1,000 he received from a Japanese magazine.

title: Big Board Firms' Net Off
description: After-tax profits of brokerage firms belonging to the New York Stock Exchange fell to $50 million in the third quarter of 1981 from $243 million a year ago, the exchange said yesterday.

title: 2 BANKS CUT PRIME TO 15 1/2%
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago and the Crocker National Bank in California announced yesterday that they would reduce their prime rate to 15 1/2 percent today.

title: Advertising
description: THOSE of us whose memories retain the vision of the old-time candy shop's crammed glass case of penny candy, are likely also to remember - closer to the cash register - a display of white packs of butterscotch each with the picture of a green thistle on it. Great buttery butterscotch, as memory serves.

title: Mine Reopening
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation and Verde Explorations Ltd. said they would reopen the Little Daisy Mine, near Jerome State Park, in an attempt to extract more gold from the long-unused shaft. A Phelps Dodge spokesman said that workers would open the mine for the first time in 43 years after a new hoist was installed. The cost of the venture was not disclosed.

title: Judge Paves Way for Getty v. Getty
description: A follow-up: J. Paul Getty 3d, the stricken 25-year-old grandson of the late oil billionaire, won a legal round yesterday in his effort to force his father, J. Paul Getty Jr., to pay his son's $28,000 in monthly medical expenses.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: The Enchanted Loom: Mind in the Universe By Robert Jastrow. 183 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster, New York. $13.95.

title: ONE BLURTS OUT HE KILLED SADAT
description: All 24 defendants charged with the death of President Anwar el-Sadat pleaded not guilty today, although the chief suspect in the assassination told a three-judge military court that he was ''guilty of killing Sadat.''

title: Diesel Car Sales Increase 32.1%
description: Sales of diesel-powered cars through October 1981 rose 32.1 percent compared with the first 10 months of 1980, providing one of the few bright spots for the automobile industry, a trade publication said today.

title: SSC&B Wins; Homelite
description: SSC&B, a subsidiary of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has become the first ad agency to be assigned both the Homelite and Jacobsen product lines by the Homelite division of Textron. And the promotion budget for the coming year, according to the company, is $11 million, more than $4 million of which will be for media advertising.

title: Perkin-Elmer Sale
description: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation, a manufacturer of analytical instruments and optics, said it had agreed to sell substantially all of the assets of its memory products division to Cipher Data Products Inc. Terms were not disclosed. Cipher Data Products, based in San Diego, is a producer of tape drive peripherals for the minicomputer industry. Perkin-Elmer's memory products division is in Garden Grove, Calif.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INTERNATIONAL STRETCH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Soviet-India Pact
description: India and the Soviet Union signed an initial agreement today for Soviet technical aid to help India nearly double its oil production by 1984-85.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Judge Changes Floors, Robes and Courts
description: Judge Lawrence W. Pierce slipped into a new set of judicial robes yesterday when he moved up from the United States District Court to the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: HARVESTER'S PLANT TECHNOLOGY APPROVED FOR SALE TO RUSSIANS
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it would permit the ailing International Harvester Company to sell technological expertise for a combine production plant to the Soviet Union.

title: Ashland to Buy Pipeline System
description: The Ashland Oil Company said it had agreed in principle to acquire the crude oil gathering and transportation system and related assets of the Scurlock Oil Company of Houston.

title: NIXON ATTORNEYS URGE HIGH COURT TO GIVE HIM IMMUNITY FROM SUIT
description: Attorneys for former President Richard M. Nixon and two of his top White House aides today sought to convince the Supreme Court that a President and his close advisers are entitled to absolute immunity from lawsuits by private citizens.

title: BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The yr-ago net income figures restated for conversion to LIFO in fourth qr of fiscal 1981

title: TENNESSEE SUIT FOR PARDONS AGAINST GOVERNOR DISMISSED
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed by two former convicts who charged that Gov. Lamar Alexander had violated their civil rights by refusing to free them after his predecessor ordered them released.

title: Fore 'Going Back To Preach Gospel'
description: The former head of Moral Majority's New York chapter denied yesterday that he had been dismissed, but he acknowledged that the parent national group had bought his local corporation to put it out of business.

title: RESERVE OIL & MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition accounted for on a pooling of interests basis; this yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Mar 1981 and for 575,434 shrs issued in the poolings

title: Track Star Arrested
description: Adrian Ward, a 19-year-old track star attending Villanova on an athletic scholarship, has been arrested on a charge of rape in Baltimore, his hometown, for the second time in a little more than a year. The second charge, involving an attack on Aug. 6 of this year, was leveled about an hour after a hearing Monday to determine whether Ward should be released on bail in the original case, which dates from September 1980. Bail was denied, and Ward was remanded to jail.

title: DIDN'T ARRANGE FOR KICKBACKS, MARGIOTTA SAYS
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the chairman of the Republican Party in Nassau County, testified today that he had never made a ''secret agreement'' to obtain insurance commissions for political supporters.

title: U.C.L.A. Gets Report On N.C.A.A. Inquiry
description: An official at U.C.L.A. said today that the university had received the National Collegiate Athletic Association's report of an investigation into its athletic program and would have 15 days to decide whether to appeal.

title: RMI Expansion
description: The RMI Company said that it will build a $20 million titanium melt shop here next year as part of a $50 million, two-and-a-half-year modernization program. RMI, a leading producer of titanium for aerospace and non-aerospace applications, said construction on the plant is to start by the end of 1982. The computerized mill will give the company the latest state-of-the-art equipment for its production line, RMI said.

title: Personal Health; REMOVING BARRIERS IN RELATIONSHIPS WITH THE DISABLED
description: TO a healthy, active 24-year-old, the visit 16 years ago to the Sister Kenny Institute's annual art show was both a shock and an inspiration. There I met a 35-year-old woman in an iron lung; paralyzed by poliomyelitis from the neck down, she was holding a paintbrush in her teeth to execute a delicate watercolor of a meadow she would never walk through again.

title: Jeep Drivers to Get Warning About Handling of CJ Models
description: The Jeep Corporation will put stickers on its CJ models to warn drivers that the vehicle does not handle like an ordinary automobile and that sudden turns could cause the driver to lose control, the Federal Trade Commission said Monday.

title: First Penn Sets Shift From Foreign Lending
description: The First Pennsylvania Bank, the cornerstone holding of the financially troubled First Pennsylvania Corporation, said today that it would move away from foreign lending activity over the next five years in favor of providing international banking services for corporations.

title: Pilobolus Dancers Plan 3-Week Program
description: The Pilobolus Dance Theater will celebrate its 10th anniversary with a three-week engagement at the ANTA Theater, from Dec. 20 through Jan. 9. (Previews begin Dec. 17.)

title: New Jersey's Governor, at Last
description: The concession by James Florio, Democratic candidate for Governor of New Jersey, removes the larger shadow over the victory of the Republican, Thomas Kean, whose minuscule 1,677-vote election margin hung in the balance for 27 days. But a smaller shadow remains: reports of voter intimidation that arose right after Election Day.

title: DAHLBERG ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
New Yorkers, etc.; 'LIVE A YEAR WITH A MILLIONAIRE!': IT'S ONE MAN'S STORY
description: ONE of the most unusual Christmas greetings in many a year - the ultimate in family newsletters - has just arrived, or is en route, to 626 homes across the country and abroad. It is a slim paperback book called ''Live a Year With a Millionaire!'' and is written by Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, a man who refers to himself as an ''alleged'' millionaire but doesn't expect anyone to take the alleged too seriously.

title: OPERA: 'RAKE'S PROGRESS' IN CAPITAL
description: ''The Rake's Progress'' at the Washington Opera is a delight. First of all, Stravinsky has written an opera that works on every level. It is melodious in the composer's intense, if somewhat distant, way. Its libretto by W.H. Auden and Chester Kallman not only makes sense, but it is also a pleasure to hear. And finally, ''The Rake's'' private and public moments - Nick Shadow descending into hell, the auctioneer bandying with his clientele - all constitute great music and powerful theater.

title: 2 SIDES AT GENEVA BEGIN TO NEGOTIATE
description: The United States and the Soviet Union held their first full-scale negotiating session on intermediate-range nuclear weapons today. Each side presented its starting position outlined over the last two weeks by President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Harvester Extends Plants' Shutdown
description: The winter shutdown of two International Harvester Company plants at Rock Island and East Moline will be extended again, this time by two weeks in January, company officials said.

title: Saudi Aide Visiting Pakistan
description: Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, whose country is underwriting much of the cost of Pakistan's purchase of United States F-16 fighter jets, arrived here today for a four-day visit. He was met at the airport by the Pakistani Defense Minister, Ali Ahmed Talpur.

title: RCA Presents A New Camera
description: The RCA Corporation displayed an experimental camera that can take television pictures in total darkness.

title: Federal Judge Quitting, Citing Pay as a Reason
description: Federal District Judge Frank H. McFadden is resigning Jan. 1 partly because he does not think he is paid enough.

title: Lowering of U.S. Flag For Gorilla Defended
description: The Milwaukee County Zoo director, Gilbert Boese, said today that he meant no insult when he ordered the American Flag at the zoo lowered to half-staff to mark the death of Samson, its famed gorilla.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SPRING MOON. A Novel of China. By Bette Bao Lord. 464 pages. Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: SAKAROVS BEARING UP IN THEIR HUNGER STRIKE
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, said today that he and his wife, Yelena Bonner, were ''holding on cheerfully'' after 10 days of a hunger strike.

title: Advertising; People
description: * John H. Newhall has been appointed chief executive officer of the Aitkin-Kynett Company, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding.

title: Arrested Liquor OfficialSays He Was Entrapped
description: The executive director of the New Hampshire Liquor Commission was arrested and jailed overnight after he threatened to lift a hotel's liquor license when he was refused an additional drink, the police said today.

title: UTILITY THREATENS TO DARKEN A TOWN
description: Street lights, traffic signals and other municipal lights will be shut off unless this financially pressed mill town pays its monthly utility bill, the Duquesne Light Company warned today.

title: Outland to Rimington
description: David Rimington, the center at Nebraska, yesterday won the Outland Trophy, presented annually by the Football Writers Association of America to the player whom the association considers the nation's top collegiate lineman. Rimington, a 6-foot-2-inch, 283-pound junior, is only the second center to receive the award in its 36-year history, following Jim Richter of North Carolina State, who won it in 1979.

title: MUM'S NOT THE WORD
description: It was not until 1966 that citizens won from their Government a muscular statutory right to inspect Federal records. This landmark legislation, the Freedom of Information Act, was overhauled in 1974 to somewhat strengthen the sections dealing with access, for bureaucrats had learned to stall and otherwise get around many of its provisions.

title: LUCAS EXCELS AS KNICKS TOP PISTONS FOR 3D IN ROW
description: The combination of Maurice Lucas at power forward and Reggie Carter at point guard was too much for the Detroit Pistons last night and the Knicks came away with a 112-100 victory at Madison Square Garden. The victory, the Knicks' third straight, brought their record to 7-8 and dropped the Pistons to 8-8.

title: CARTING UNION, WITH CHANGE IN MEMBERSHIP, STRIKES AGAIN
description: The 2,000 men who have stopped loading and driving trucks that haul refuse away from commercial establishments in New York City last walked out three years ago. That strike lasted a week and left thousands of tons of piled garbage rotting in the unseasonably warm weather, in some places almost blocking sidewalks.

title: CAVANAGH COMMUNITIES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
SETON HALL TOPPLES FORDHAM
description: With 31 seconds remaining, the lights went out tonight in Seton Hall's Walsh Auditorium. For Fordham, it was just as well because the Rams were behind the Pirates, 69-62. After a 10-minute delay, the lights returned and Seton Hall went on to a 71-64 basketball victory.

title: TIMELY PROGRAM NOTE
description: The first thing Claudio Arrau did yesterday in preparing for his stint last night with the Philadelphia Orchestra at Carnegie Hall was make sure that the concert really was scheduled to start at 8 P.M.

title: MR. CHOW'S SUES GUIDE FOR LIBEL
description: A scathing restaurant review in the Guide Gault-Millau has prompted a lawsuit seeking damages on behalf of Mr. Chow's, a restaurant on East 57th Street that features Chinese dishes.

title: CAROLINA VOTING LAW OPPOSED
description: The Justice Department, citing the Voting Rights Act, today objected to a 1968 amendment to North Carolina's Constitution prohibiting the division of counties for state legislative districts.

title: De Paul Wins Family Affair
description: A coaching matchup between Ray Meyer and his son Tom turned out to be a mismatch tonight. Ray Meyer was beginning his 40th season at De Paul, while his son saw his team fall to 0-2 in his fifth year as head coach of Illinois-Chicago Circle, and Circle's first in Division I. With Terry Cummings scoring a game-high 20 points and Bernard Randolph adding 13, the Blue Demons scored a 78-53 victory.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Nov. 23 incorrectly stated the size of Po- land's debt to the Dresdner Bank in West Germany. It is $180.2 million at current exchange rates.

title: Bankers Trust Selling 2 Units
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that it had reached agreement in principle to sell two of its four upstate banking subsidiaries for an undisclosed price.

title: UBIQUITOUS ALLEN TAKES HIS CASE TO THE PUBLIC
description: Richard V. Allen, whose name was hardly a household word when accusations of improprieties against him began to emerge, has suddenly become a household face.

title: Group to Distribute the Text Of Equal Rights Amendment
description: Supporters of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment plan to take to street corners in major cities this week, passing out leaflets and cards containing the text of the proposed amendment.

title: SPACE LAW'S BUSINESS IMPACT
description: Last month, as the space shuttle raced through a mission cut short by a fuel cell failure, lawyers, insurers and executives gathered at a Washington hotel to discuss the hurdles to doing business in space.

title: HOW M-G-M PROTECTED $12 MILLION NATALIE WOOD FILM
description: When Natalie Wood drowned Sunday, she was two weeks away from finishing a $12 million movie. With the completion in jeopardy, it might have seemed that the $12 million would go down the drain. But Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, producer of the science fantasy ''Brainstorm,'' is at risk for only a few thousand dollars.

title: Scottish Islanders Lose Fight Against Air Base
description: Britain gave the go-ahead for a North Atlantic Treaty Organization emergency air base on the island of Lewis off the west coast of Scotland today despite objections from islanders who fear for their quiet way of life.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After net from discontinued operations of $25,016 and extraordinary credit of $20,000

title: Japan Timber Unit Bankrupt
description: A major Japanese timber importing company was declared bankrupt today, another victim of a slowdown in some sectors of the economy that is expected to make 1981 the third-worst year on record for business failures in Japan.

title: Ex-Foreign Minister To Seek Belgian Cabinet
description: King Baudouin named Charles-Ferdinand Nothomb as Prime Minister-designate today in the second attempt to form a Government since inconclusive elections last month.

title: Advertising; Ogilvy & Mather Acquires A. Eicoff
description: Ogilvy & Mather International, which already has a direct marketing unit of its own, announced yesterday its acquisition of A. Eicoff & Company, a Chicago-based agency with that specialty in the broadcast field.

title: ARGENTINA REPORTED TO TRAIN SALVADORAN OFFICERS
description: Diplomatic and military sources here say Argentina has been providing training for some Salvadoran intelligence officers over the last two years.

title: FIRE CADETS' SIT-IN IS WORRYING POLES
description: Policemen surrounded a firefighters' academy here today as more than 300 cadets defied demands that they end a sit-in strike they began last Wednesday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bank of New York is selling $75 million of 12 percent convertible debentures due 2006 at a price of par though underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The debentures are convertible into common stock at $49 1/4 per share, an 11 percent premium over yesterday's closing price of 44 3/8.

title: Jersey Panel Finds More Prison Space
description: TRENTON (AP) - Parts of nine state buildings can be used to provide space for up to 1,500 prison inmates, but extensive renovations would be required, according to a state panel on prison overcrowding.

title: Canadian Airline Fares
description: Three major Canadian airlines said today that they had applied for government permission to raise domestic fares by 9.5 percent, effective Jan. 11.

title: Penn Central
