description: The Penn Central Corporation said it had acquired Willis Drilling Company Inc., a privately held company based in Edinburgh, Tex., for undisclosed terms. Penn Central said the acquisition would increase the number of drilling rigs it owns to 32. Willis owns six drilling rigs and has a seventh on order that will become operational next year, Penn Central said.

title: Business People; FINANCE OFFICIAL RISES TO PRESIDENCY OF FUQUA
description: The presidency of Fuqua Industries, which became vacant with the resignation last week of Kay W. Slayden, 47, was filled yesterday with the appointment of Lawrence P. Klamon, a 44-year-old lawyer who had been senior vice president for finance and administration. J.B. Fuqua, founder of the Atlanta-based conglomerate, continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: A CHAMPION AT BACKGAMMON
description: Barclay Cooke, a world-class backgammon player and author of books on the game, died Sunday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 69 years old.

title: No Headline
description: GRETZKY COLLECTS 3 ASSISTS

title: MAN WITH 2 IDENTITIES IS CHARGED IN $1.5 MILLION PARIS JEWEL THEFT
description: A Brooklyn man was charged in Newark yesterday with having received stolen property two years ago in the theft of $1.5 million in gems from a Paris jewelry store.

title: THE DANCE: AN EVENING OF BEBE MILLER
description: ON Sunday afternoon at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, Bebe Miller and Dancers offered a crackling good program of solos and group works choreographed by Miss Miller.

title: 5 New Fires Set in Lynn As King Seeks U.S. Aid
description: Five new fires were set in Lynn today as Gov. Edward J. King flew to Washington seeking Federal funds to help the city recover from weekend fires that destroyed four blocks of the downtown area.

title: JEWISH BUSINESSMAN GETS HATE MAIL
description: Victor Weiss, a Jewish businessman in Kenilworth, a suburban village north of Chicago, and members of his family are being victimized by a series of pranks and Mailgrams with Nazi overtones.

title: DANKER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $80,332 gain

title: JILTING AN OLD FLAME
description: The day President Reagan shut down the nonessential side of Government last week was a revelation to the Statue of Liberty. Some Federal people came over to the island and one of them said, ''O.K., tootsie, drop the torch. You're being shut down by order of the President.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Stores has appointed Leonard M. Snyder president and chief executive officer of its Donaldson's division. * Brown & Root, Houston, has named Janet Bush corporate secretary.

title: SAVING BOND SHIFT WEIGHED
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that he would seek Congressional approval for a new floating interest rate on savings bonds, in an effort to make them attractive and competitive in a time of high interest rates.

title: Best Buys; A POSTHOLIDAY PRICE RESPITE
description: NOW that Thanksgiving is over, it is time to take advantage of lower food prices before the Christmas buying season begins. ''After Thanksgiving there are doldrums,'' said Mike Pflueger, a spokesman for the United States Department of Agriculture. ''For the following couple of weeks things are kind of slow, people are eating on the run and spending their time worrying about Christmas presents. This is a trend we see every year until Christmas comes and everyone starts eating again.''

title: Blazers 121, Nuggets 113
description: DENVER (UPI) - Calvin Natt scored 19 of his 30 points in the second half and Mychal Thompson broke a late Denver rally as Portland snapped Denver's five-game winning streak.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Contran Corp. said it and other entities had increased their stake in Keystone Consolidated Industries to 682,961 shares, or 36.5 percent, through the acquisition of 146,661 shares bought on Nov. 24 by a Contran subsidiary for an aggregate price of $3,666,525.

title: CHINA VOTES TO CUT BUREAUCRATIC FAT
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang pledged today that China's Government bureaucracy would be reduced in size to make it more efficient.

title: ASSOCIATES CORP OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company is a unit of Gulf & Western Industries

title: International Loans Up
description: New funds raised on international capital markets totaled $15.1 billion in November, up from $11.7 billion in October but below September's $16.4 billion, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development said today. The rise from October to November was because of a $2.1 billion increase in the volume of external bond offerings and a $1.3 billion rise in completions for medium-term and long-term syndicated Euroloans, the O.E.C.D. said. The November figures bring the total of new funds raised so far this year to $171 billion, the organization added, but gave no comparative 1980 figures.

title: SANDERS, R C, TECHNOLOGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After extraordinary losses of $640,000 for the qr and $62,000 for the 9 mos

title: A Real Middle East Strategy
description: The United States is proclaiming so much consensus in the Middle East these days there's no telling what it is trying to achieve.

title: G.M. STAFF MAY BE CUT BY 13,000
description: The General Motors Corporation might lay off 13,000 of its 190,000 white-collar workers worldwide, company officials said today.

title: Dr. Sanborn C. Brown, Expert on Ionized Gas
description: Dr. Sanborn C. Brown, professor emeritus of physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and former associate dean of its graduate school, died Saturday at his home in Henniker, N.H., after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: DISCONTENT SPREADING IN LIBYA AS OIL BOOM FADES
description: Libya's oil boom, long the source of well-being and a high standard of living, has been eroded by the glut on world markets. Foreign analysts say that the resultant economic plight coincides with other indications of discontent springing from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's authoritarian rule.

title: New Offering By Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, which is trying to broaden its activities in the housing finance market, is making its first-ever sale of pass-through securities today.

title: SUBLETTING OFFICE SPACE STIRS MANHATTAN CONTROVERSY
description: With office rents rising, a small law firm, Solin & Breindel at 530 Fifth Avenue, saw the chance to make money by subletting its offices. The same vision has captivated businessmen from Manhattan to Los Angeles, as the price of some office space has doubled or tripled in recent years.

title: Carl T. Gossett Strike Said to Have Little Effect on Milk Delivery in Jersey In a variety of raingear, striking workers stood around an open fire yesterday as they tried to keep warm on a picket line outside the Farmland-Fairlawn Dairy in Wallington, N.J. Members of Teamster Local 680, rep-resenting drivers and plant workers, walked off the job
description: Monday at six northern New Jersey dairies after rejecting a contract proposal. Industry officials said deliveries to about 8,000 stores had not been seriously hampered.

title: Takeover Doubts Depress Oil Stocks
description: The stock prices of 11 middle-size oil and gas companies declined sharply yesterday amid growing investor sentiment that interest in oil company takeovers may be subsiding because of the antitrust problems in Mobil's bid to acquire the Marathon Oil Company.

title: Curbs on Oil Imports Urged
description: Democrats introduced legislation in the House and Senate today to ban Government imports of Libyan oil in retaliation for what they say is Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's support for international terrorism. The legislation would affect only Libyan oil bought for the Government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Chancellor Ousts A School Board
description: Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola yesterday suspended a community school board in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, charging that there were serious administrative problems in the district and an ''intolerable education condition'' in one intermediate school.

title: Mets Call Top-Flight Pitcher Major Need
description: Frank Cashen, the general manager of the Mets, said yesterday that the team's most urgent need was pitching, and he promised to give top priority to that need next week in the trading market at baseball's annual business meeting.

title: ABOUT CONSERVATISM, REAGAN AND POLITICS
description: Lyn Nofziger is one of the most durable political figures in President Reagan's political entourage, with ties going back to 1966. The rumpled former newspaper reporter has been Assistant to the President for Political Affairs since the inauguration, but plans to leave next month, to do some writing and consulting, and perhaps to get involved, eventually, in Mr. Reagan's re-election campaign. ''I'm not much of an organization man,'' he explained. ''I can do some things on the outside that I can't do on the inside.'' Here, in an interview conducted earlier this week that is unique for its absence of Mr. Nofziger's normally constant punning, he discusses the political scene, for the Administration and the country.

title: Advertising; McCann-Erickson Unit Gets Colonial Penn Job
description: McCann-Erickson March, a direct-marketing specialty unit within the largest component in the Interpublic Group of Companies, has become an agency for the Colonial Penn Insurance Company and will be handling TV direct-response advertising for its auto and homeowner insurance.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The-yr-ago results have been restated to comply with F.A.S.B. Statement No 43 covering compensated absences; the yr-ago shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split declared in Feb 1981

title: Weaver Convicted
description: Earl Weaver, manager of the Baltimore Orioles, was convicted of drunken driving by a judge in Towson, Md., who deferred sentence pending an evaluation to see if Weaver needed professional counseling. Weaver was arrested Aug. 31, and on Nov. 3 his driver's license was suspended for 60 days.

title: Advertising; Showtime Switches To B.& B.
description: BENTON & BOWLES has become the advertising agency for Showtime Entertainment, the pay cable television network that last week decided to leave Scali, McCabe, Sloves after a brief stay.

title: 'CONFLICT OF INTEREST' LAID TO NUCLEAR CONSULTANTS
description: The head of New York State's Consumer Protection Board said today that the consulting firm that looked into escalating costs at the Nine Mile Point Two nuclear power plant upstate had also received a $25,000 consulting contract from one of the five utilities involved in building the plant.

title: Q&A
description: Q. A short while ago you wrote about those two Marseilles-type aperitifs called Pernod and Ricard and indicated that they could be used interchangeably in certain dishes, Mediterranean fish soup, for instance. Are the two drinks identical in composition?

title: MITTERRAND PRAISES ALGERIANS
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France addressed the Algerian Parliament today and praised as heroes the men who fought France for independence.

title: U.S. HAS 'A SINGLE' ARMS PROPOSAL
description: Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard N. Perle said today that the United States had no compromise position prepared for the talks now under way in Geneva on reducing intermediate-range nuclear arms in Europe.

title: IN THE INNER SANCTUM OF THE FEDERAL RESERVE
description: The room is 56 feet long but seems larger, perhaps because of the two-story ceiling, the high windows draped in gold and the eight-foot-high fireplace of Tavernelle Fleuri marble from Italy.

title: SEAL FLEET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $872,000 income from an accounting change

title: Radioactive Water Spilled
description: About 1,500 gallons of slightly radioactive water spilled inside the H.B. Robinson nuclear plant Monday, officials said. No workers were exposed and the radioactivity did not leak outside the plant, according to Wayne Ennis, spokesman for the Carolina Power and Light Company, which owns the plant.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS U.S. OIL LEASING
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal Government was not legally required to make it easier for small oil companies to compete for offshore oil and gas leases.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan's Bid To Calm Labor
description: AFTER meeting with the leaders of the teamsters yesterday, President Reagan will sit down today, on his own invitation, with Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and the members of the federation's executive council. The President would like to cool labor's anger over his economic program.

title: Warsaw Pact Ministers Meet On Arms and Foreign Affairs
description: The defense ministers of the seven Warsaw Pact nations met today in Moscow, according to Soviet television.

title: REAGAN'S POLICIES 'SHAM AND SHAME,' KOCH SAYS IN TALK
description: Mayor Koch today denounced President Reagan's domestic policy as ''a sham and a shame'' that threatens the wellbeing of American cities.

title: DECISION FILE
description: Everyday Federal agencies and courts make decisions that affect the lives of Americans. Here are some recent cases: Taxation And Penalization

title: PIANIST: GOLDSAND'S VARIETY
description: A PIANIST'S recital program can be a self-portrait. Its works reveal the extent of the performer's powers and the range of his vision.

title: Genentech Sees Insulin Marketing
description: Genentech Inc., a leading factor in the application of genesplicing technology to the development of commercial products, said the company's first product, synthetic human insulin, ''should be marketed late next year depending on Government approvals.''

title: HELEN OF TROY (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND THE WORLD
description: Jesuit leaders have been summoned to Rome for a special meeting next year at which they will be told that they should accept Pope John Paul II's edicts or leave the order, Vatican sources said today

title: Dismembering Liberty Park
description: Liberty State Park along the New Jersey side of New York Harbor offers 700 green acres and waterfront walks with spectacular views of the Statue of Liberty and the Lower Manhattan skyline. It is, in other words, a priceless asset for the densely populated New York-New Jersey region.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 2, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Space Shuttle Crew Gave Sleep a Fast Shuffle
description: Their flight in the space shuttle Columbia had been cut back from five days to two, so Col. Joe H. Engle and Capt. Richard H. Truly decided to do some cutting back of their own - on their sleep schedules.

title: BUS DEPOT FIRE
description: A smoky fire in the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan led to the removal of 10,000 early morning commuters, the police said. Eight police officers and two civilians were treated at hospitals for smoke inhalation, but their conditions were described as not serious. (AP)

title: PARENTS OF MISSING CHILDREN UNITE IN PLEA FOR HELP
description: A panel of parents whose young children were abducted or murdered called on Congress and the state legislatures today to establish a nationwide computer clearinghouse to help find missing children and to identify bodies.

title: SANTA FE APPROVES KUWAIT CORP. OFFER
description: Shareholders of the Santa Fe International Corporation today overwhelmingly approved the $2.5 billion sale of the company to the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation.

title: JEAN MARSH'S ENGLISH 'NICKLEBY' PICNIC
description: JEAN MARSH, the actress, recently prepared a lavish meal of veal and pork Melton Mowbray pie, cold root vegetable salad and curried remoulade, with raspberry sandwiches for dessert.

title: BUILDING RATE DOWN IN OCTOBER
description: Spending for new construction plunged by 1.6 percent in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $230.83 billion, the lowest level in a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: KEY U.S. REPORT DETAILS WOES OF AUTO INDUSTRY
description: The financial strength of the American automobile industry has been sharply eroded, and it is questionable whether the industry, hit by weak sales and aggressive marketing from Japan, can restore its long-run competitiveness, the Commerce Department told Congress today.

title: TAPAS BARS: A MOVABLE FEAST IN SPAIN
description: ONE of the engimas of history for me is why, in the 16th century when Spain was imposing its religion and culture on half of the New World, it never transplanted one of its most characteristic and sustaining traditions: the tapas bar. Tapas have been described in some guidebooks as ''hors d'oeuvres served in Spanish bars,'' which is a designation akin to calling the Prado ''one of the many art museums in Madrid.''

title: MAN KISSES WIFE AND KILLS HIMSELF
description: A 33-year-old man kissed his wife and then leaped into the path of an oncoming train in an elevated subway station in the Bronx, the transit police reported.

title: Armco to Lay Off 200 Ohio Workers
description: Armco Inc. said it was laying off 200 hourly employees indefinitely at its Middletown Works.

title: RECEPTION COOL
description: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy, arrived in Damascus today and was greeted by Syrian attacks on the strategic cooperation agreement that the United States and Israel signed on Monday.

title: Protest Tents Put Up Again
description: Nine tents were put up again today in a park facing the White House as part of an effort to dramatize the plight of the homeless and to protest cuts by the Reagan Administration in expenditures for social programs. The park police removed the tents last week and arrested six persons who had spent the night in Lafayette Park.

title: CITY COUNCIL IS ALLOWED TO CONTINUE LEGISLATING
description: A Federal judge said yesterday that the City Council could continue to legislate and that all its members could keep their seats while the Council appealed his recent decision invalidating the system of electing the body's 10 at-large members.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $3,754,000 loss from foreign currency translations... C-Including $2,208,000 gain from foreign currency translations

title: Blizzard in Middle West Kills 4 and Shuts Roads
description: By The Asssociated Press A blizzard driving blinding snow across the Middle West with winds of 50 miles an hour crippled cities and closed highways yesterday, stranding hundreds of travelers and shutting down schools.

title: AGED AT PARLEY BACK SOCIAL SECURITY VIEW ESPOSED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan paid a courtesy call on the White House Conference on Aging today and was rewarded with a series of votes by its committee on Social Security that reflected the Administration's position and confounded Mr. Reagan's critics.

title: 'THE PROBLEMS OF THE AGED ARE NOT MYTHS'
description: I was distressed by a Nov. 19 news article, ''Pollster Detects 'Myths' on Problems of Aged,'' about a $400,000 Harris poll conducted in preparation for the White House Conference on the Aged (to which I am a delegate).

title: November U.S. Auto Output Fell 25.6%
description: November car production by the nation's five domestic auto makers plunged 25.6 percent from its 1980 level, the manufacturers reported today.

title: VOTERS REJECT TAXES TO RESTORE SERVICES IN MICHIGAN SCHOOLS
description: Voters today rejected two tax proposals that would have raised enough money to allow the financially ailing Alpena school district to resume busing and other services for its 6,800 pupils.

title: NEW CLIMATE CENTER PREDICTS STUNNING COLD FOR NORTHEAST
description: This winter will be unusually cold in the Northeastern states but with light to normal precipitation, according to a forecast by Dr. Jerome Namias, an experienced long-range forecaster now at the newly created Experimental Climate Forecast Center in La Jolla, Calif.

title: Alberta Energy
description: Alberta Energy Ltd. said that it and Gulf Canada Resources Inc., a unit of Gulf Canada Ltd., had agreed to a $133 million (Canadian currency) joint exploration drilling venture for oil on western Canadian lands. The agreement covers 1.3 million gross acres in Alberta and British Columbia. Alberta Energy said its contribution to the program, before allowances for Alberta drilling incentives and federal petroleum incentive payments, would be $100 million.

title: JURORS TO BEGIN DELIBRATIONS IN SHOOTING OF LIBYAN IN 1980
description: The defense and prosecution completed their cases today in the trial of a former Green Beret who contends that he shot a Libyan dissident in self-defense while on a mission for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: When Valerie Clarebout is asked whether she has children, she will say that she has angels instead, and that in some ways she finds them just as rewarding, and as taxing.

title: NEW DEAN AT HARVARD
description: Patricia Albjerg Graham, who has been named dean of the Graduate School of Education. She is the first woman to hold that post.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Rangers signed Steve Ulseth, a free agent wing, and assigned him to the Springfield farm club.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Discoveries; FOR CHILDREN'S CHRISTMAS, TRADITIONAL GIFTS
description: An Old-Time Christmas Parents, doting grandmothers, rich uncles and sentimental aunts - almost everyone who isn't a Scrooge - has a child at or near the top of a shopping list this Christmas. And though television advertising is inundating us with electronic games, there are toys and clothes and puzzles enough in stores for shoppers who prefer a child's Christmas to be traditional. 1. For Horsing Around A rocking horse doesn't have to be an equine. It can be a giraffe or an elephant or a bull. A child should love the rocking animals made by Walter Rivera, who is the chief carpenter and exhibition builder at the Manhattan Laboratory Museum Center. Mr. Rivera and two of his friends have handcrafted the animals of unpainted wood, adding saddles and ears (floppy for the elephant, pointed for the others) of vinyl. The toys are sturdy and will take on the most active of equestrians. The elephant is $60, the bull $55 and the giraffe $50 at the center, 314 West 54th Street.

title: 'GREAT WHITE FLEET' OF THE CITY SUBWAY NO LONGER UNSCATHED
description: The New York Transit Authority's ''great white fleet,'' the first of the Flushing-line subway trains to be painted completely white, suffered a minor graffiti attack Monday. But the agency said yesterday that its plans to repaint all 419 of the Flushing cars were unchanged.

title: How to Protect the Homeowner
description: To the Editor:

title: IS ITS DUTY TO STOCKHOLDERS OR OTHERS?
description: Does the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steelmaker, have a special duty to concentrate its energies and its full financial resources on making steel? Or is it free to look for profits wherever opportunity beckons, even if this means borrowing several billion dollars to buy an oil company?

title: TEXTS OF JUSTICE DEPARTMENT STATEMENT ON ALLEN AND SUMMARY OF FINDINGS
description: Following are the texts of the statement issued by the Justice Department today on the investigation of Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, and the summary of the findings of the department's Criminal Division on the matter: The Statement

title: EXXON CLOSES PLANT AND LAYS OFF 1,100 IN OFFICE COMPANY
description: The Exxon Office Systems Company yesterday dismissed about a fifth of its work force and closed a manufacturing plant as part of what it called an effort to streamline operations.

title: STOCKMAN SAID TO END HOUSING SUBSIDIES BY NEXT FALL
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, wants to end Federal subsidies for low-income housing construction by next fall as part of new group of spending cuts, sources in the Reagan Administration and lobbyists involved in urban development said today.

title: The Pop Life; IS PRINCE LEADING MUSIC TO A TRUE BIRACISM?
description: ELVIS PRESLEY'S first national television appearances and hit records were controversial because they challenged the conventional sexual and racial attitudes of the mid-50's. Mr. Presley flaunted his sex appeal more flagrantly than any white pop performer before him, and he introduced black rhythms and inflections into the American pop mainstream, making it possible for black rockers like Little Richard and Chuck Berry to appeal to white teen-agers directly. Today, of course, attitudes toward race and sex tend to be considerably more liberal. Or do they?

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. Steel Will Defer Import Suits
description: The United States Steel Corporation, which had earlier stated its intent to file antidumping suits today against several nations, said it would defer filing pending a meeting on Friday with Administration officials.

title: Wine Talk
description: DESPITE LAST YEAR'S FREEZE, NEW YORK WILL PRODUCE SOME DECENT 1981 By Terry Robards WINES.

title: Chinese Granted Asylum
description: A Chinese interpreter traveling with the Peking Opera company has been granted political asylum in Denmark, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. The interpreter arrived with the troupe Oct. 30 and requested asylum two days later.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the 15 most popular television shows of the last week (Monday, Nov. 23, to Sunday, Nov. 29) according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the number of households with television sets. Rating Program Network 1 29.8 60 Minutes CBS 2 28.8 Dallas CBS 3 24.3 Dukes of Hazard CBS 4 23.6 Three's Company ABC 5 23.4 N.F.L. Football CBS 6 23.2 The Jeffersons CBS 7 23.1 One Day at a Time CBS 8 22.8 Alice CBS 9 22.6 Archie Bunker's Place CBS 10 22.5 Too Close for Comfort ABC 11 21.7 Movie: "Sizzle" ABC 12 21.4 M*A*S*H CBS 13 21.4 Love Boat ABC 14 21.3 N.F.L. Football ABC 15 20.7 Hart to Hart ABC

title: Protesters Say French Told Yacht to Shun Atoll
description: France warned a group of environmentalists to stay away from its underground nuclear test site at Mururoa Atoll in the Pacific, the Greenpeace movement said today.

title: SEYCHELLES EXILE TELLS PLOT
description: Two months before mercenaries failed in their coup attempt in the Seychelles last week, James R.M. Mancham, the deposed President of the island chain, recorded a message for the plotters announcing that he was ready to resume his former post.

title: SENEGAMBIA: A PRODUCT OF 'ANNEXATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF-DUTY CUSTOMS OFFICER IS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: An off-duty United States Customs Service officer who had earned 12 commendations for arresting drug smugglers at Kennedy International Airport was shot to death in a gun battle in a Queens alley Monday night when he tried to stop two men from stealing his car.

title: TESTING RECIPES ORDERED BY MAIL
description: A compulsive reader, I am addicted to the classified sections of newspapers and magazines. Here one can find the stuff of real life often glossed over in the main sections of the publications: items lost, found or for sale; messages to errant spouses and lovers; offers to act as discreet business agents in remote corners of the world, and pleas for companionship -or more - from glamorous and wealthy but inexplicably lonely people.

title: Vatican Will Issue 11 Stamps On Pope's Trips Outside Italy
description: The Vatican Post Office will issue 11 stamps on the travels Pope John Paul II outside Italy, the Vatican announced today.

title: Imasco Plans Bonds
description: Imasco Ltd., a Canadian-based consumer products company, is raising $50 million through a seven-year Eurobond, Wood Gundy Ltd., the lead manager, said here today. The indicated interest rate coupon on the issue is 15 1/4 percent, with open pricing to be set next Tuesday, it added. Noncallable for five years, the bonds can then be redeemed at 101 percent of face value.

title: DOLPHINS SAVED BY AUDIBLE
description: The conception that dynamic football coaches, like Don Shula of the Dolphins, have a hand in controlling the outcome of games can be misleading, as Shula acknowledged after Miami's 13-10 victory here Monday night over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Classen Suit in Trial
description: A $250,000 lawsuit brought against the city and its medical examiner by the widow of Willie Classen, a middleweight fighter who died of brain injuries suffered in a bout at Madison Square Garden two years ago, has gone to trial at State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Marilyn Classen's lawyer, Michael Capriano, told the jury yesterday that specimens taken in an autopsy from Classen's body had been mistakenly mixed with those of another body, causing Mrs. Classen to suffer ''beyond the normal bereavement period.''

title: Ski-Mask Rape Suspect Is Indicted in Louisiana
description: John B. Simonis, 30 years old, of Lake Charles, La., was indicted Monday night on seven counts of rape and burglary for a June 7 attack on a suburban Baton Rouge woman and her family.

title: Trainer Said to Delay Destruction Decision
description: Charles R. Allen, the veterinarian who treated Hugable Tom while the terminally ill gelding was stabled in David Jacobson's barn at Aqueduct, testified yesterday that he recommended destroying the horse on Sept. 21 but that Jacobson kept delaying.

title: Hoechst Earnings Off
description: Worldwide profits before taxes of the Hoechst Group in the third quarter of 1981 slipped 13.8 percent, to $94 million, from $109 million, the company said yesterday.

title: Burt Reynolds a Role Model for Eighth Graders
description: Who do America's children most admire and most want to be like when they grow up? Ronald Reagan, perhaps? Or Sandra Day O'Connor? According to a poll of 2,000 eighth graders, the leading role model is Burt Reynolds.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MAYOR'S ADDRESS IN DETROIT BEFORE NATIONAL LEAGUE OF CITIES
description: Following are excerpts from the text of Mayor Koch's address to the National League of Cities yesterday in Detroit as released by City Hall:

title: BRIEFING
description: IN a recent communication error, the White House mailed out a recipe for crab-meat casserole, two 8-by-10 glossy photos of the Reagans, and a form letter on voluntarism to an Illinois housewife who had written a personal plea to the President to spare special education for the handicapped from budget cuts.

title: Marathon Oil Ends Test
description: The Marathon Oil Company said today that its West German subsidiary, Deutsche Marathon Petroleum, had abandoned an exploratory well in the North Sea. The J-11-1 well, in 90 feet of water 30 miles northwest of the island of Helgoland, was drilled to 17,924 feet, but no significant hydrocarbons were found, Marathon said.

title: Business People; OVERSEAS EXECUTIVE JOINING I.B.M. HUB
description: Jacques G. Maisonrouge, a 56-year-old senior vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation, has been named to the company's powerful corporate office as well as to the corporate management committee. When he moves to the I.B.M. corporate office at Armonk, N.Y., he will be succeeded in Paris as chairman and chief executive officer of the IBM World Trade-Europe/Middle East/Africa Corporation by Kaspar V. Cassani, 52, president of the unit since last year.

title: Prince at Controls in Near Miss at Heathrow
description: All the pilot of the Boeing 747 said he saw when he took off from London's Heathrow Airport last Friday was a ''black silhouette'' that flashed across his path. But he knew it was a small plane and that he had come close to a midair collision.

title: Kitchen Equipment; PROPER CONTAINERS
description: ILIKE to think of myself as a good-natured, even-tempered man - even in the kitchen, where the most stable of people have been known to go berserk. But, as everyone in my family knows, one thing that makes me tense in the kitchen is to discover that my equipment is not in place.

title: WASTED HOSPITAL STAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: A Long-Distance View Future
description: When it comes to long-range planning, some ranges are longer than others, and the one Thomas A. Sebeok has his eye on is 10,000 years down the road.

title: Senator Removed From Post Sues
description: NEWARK (UPI) - State Senator Walter N. Sheil filed a $4 million lawsuit against his legislative colleagues on the ground that they removed him from the Senate Judiciary Committee last week for having supported Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 17
description: B-Net loss after $445,000 tax credit; the yr-ago results include operations of Margo's La Mode Inc, a specialty store chain which was sold in July

title: TV: DOBSON'S 'SHANNON' ENDS BRIEF RUN TONIGHT
description: TV's ''Shannon.''

title: Miss Goolagong Gains 3d Round in Australia
description: Evonne Goolagong Cawley, seeking her fifth Australian Open title, received strong partisan support and moved into the third round of this year's $228,000 event today by ousting Leslie Allen of New York, 5-7, 6-3, 6-4.

title: Suburban Utility Gets Rate Rises
description: ALBANY (AP) - The Public Service Commission granted Orange and Rockland Utilities a $19.7 million, or 9 percent, rate increase for its 130,000 electricity customers.

title: HIGH COURT HEARS VIEWS ON FREE SCHOOLING FOR ALIEN CHILDREN
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether alien children who are in the United States illegally have a constitutional right to a free public education.

title: JACKSON'S TALKS LAG, GUIDRY'S PICK UP
description: With an expected offer from Ted Turner of the Atlanta Braves not forthcoming, the chase for Reggie Jackson lagged yesterday. However, the Ron Guidry sweepstakes could reach an end next week.

title: LOUIS WEINER
description: Louis Weiner, former director of records and health of the New York City Department of Health, died yesterday in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital.

title: PENNZOIL UNIT SUSPENDS MINE OPERATIONS
description: Battered by depressed metals prices, the Pennzoil Company announced yesterday that its mining subsidiary is shutting down all of its copper and molybdenum operations for three months beginning Dec. 14.

title: CLARINETIST: STOLTZMAN
description: RICHARD STOLTZMAN is one of those inventive, highly original musicians around whom opposing camps spring up. One view is that his extreme dynamic shadings and prominent vibrato draw too much attention to themselves.

title: Executives Expect Gains
description: Most of the nation's corporate chief executives expect the economy to slowly but steadily improve and inflation to drop in 1982, according to a national study conducted by Industry Week magazine.

title: No Headline
description: 76ers (14-1) WIN 10th STRAIGHT

title: PSYCHEDELIA AND ORIGINALITY FROM A NEW WHITE-FUNK GROUP
description: PRINCE has had a difficult time breaking down pop's racial barriers because white rock fans tend to perceive him and his music as ''black,'' not because he's the only artist working on the blackwhite borderline. It's symptomatic of the racism that inheres in today's pop scene that when white rock stars borrow black disco and funk rhythms, the results are readily accepted by white radio programmers, and by many black stations, as well.

title: Index; International
description: Discontent appears on rise in Libya as oil boom fades A2 West Germans hint at possible missile deployment delay A3 U.S. says it has no compromise position for arms talks A4 Mitterrand ends Algerian visit with reconciliation A5 Around the World A6 Ex-President of Seychelles gives detail of failed coup plot A8 Former Prime Minister is keep- ing Spaniards guessing A9 Sakharovs doing well in hunger strike A10 India says it is reacting to U.S. arms sale to Pakistan A12 Christian Democratic Party scrambles to restore its image A13 Government/Politics Government Agency scales down handicap access rules A16 Senate defeats move to shift funds from B-1 fleet A22 Supreme Court hears case on free schooling for alien children A28 Margiotta takes the stand and denies arranging for kickbacks B2 Washington Talk Briefing A24 Decision File: a round-up of rul- ings by agencies and courts A24 A glimpse of the inner sanctum of the Federal Reserve A24 General Around the Nation A16 Parents of murdered children speak at Louisville symposium A17 Jury to begin deliberations in shooting of Libyan student A20 Off-duty customs officer shot to death in Queens alley A32 Consulting firm on nuclear plant criticized on private job B2 Brooklyn man charged in 1979 Paris jewel theft B12 Living Section Food Gifts for a well-done Christmas C1

title: SENATE BARS SHIFT IN MILITARY FUNDS
description: The Senate today rejected a move to speed development of the Stealth plane instead of building the B-1 bomber proposed by President Reagan.

title: ESTONIANS DISREGARD STRIKE CALL TO PROTEST SOVIET DOMINATION
description: A call for workers to strike to protest Soviet rule in Estonia went unheeded in this Baltic port city today as shops, factories and public transportation appeared to be functioning normally.

title: KEY SUPPORTERS OF REAGAN ASSAIL HIS CONCEPT OF 'NEW FEDERALISM'
description: A number of state and local officials served notice on President Reagan today that they had all but lost faith in his ''new federalism.''

title: ALLEN IS CLEARED BY INVESTIGATION ON GIFT OF $1,000
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had closed its investigation into Richard V. Allen's receipt of $1,000 from a Japanese magazine and that it had found no evidence of criminal wrongdoing.

title: JETS DOING IT MICHAEL'S WAY
description: Proudly, and defiantly, Walt Michaels evaluated himself today: ''I'm never going to change.'' And in many ways he hasn't - even while the Jets have progressed from an 0-3 start, to a guaranteed winning season for the first time in 12 years, to the top of the American Conference East with a playoff spot looming.

title: Italian Publisher Is Struck
description: Editors and printers protesting announced dismissals of hundreds of employees struck the newspapers of the Rizzoli chain today, including Italy's most widely circulated daily, Corriere della Sera.

title: KEAN GIVES VOW HE WON'T RAISE TAX ON INCOMES
description: Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean said today he would seek no increase in the state income tax over the next four years.Despite predictions of increased demands for services because of budget cuts by the Reagan Administration and the state's own fiscal problems, the Livingston Republican said at a news conference that he still intended to ask the Democratic-controlled State Legislature for business tax cuts to stimulate economic activity.

title: GALAXY CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
SPICE WITH THE PRICE OF GOLD
description: NEW DELHI Wading steadily through a sea of purple, windswept fields in India's northern state of Kashmir, women in baggy pants have recently been harvesting the world's most expensive legal crop - saffron.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
The Police Blotter
description: Daren Sanders, 12 years old, was shot in the back about 5 P.M. by one of three teen-agers who accosted him while he played with a friend on the stoop of his apartment building at 85 Tompkins Avenue in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. He was reported in serious but stable condition at Cumberland Hospital. ... A 75-year-old woman was struck over the head and killed in a mugging at 1:15 P.M. in the lobby of her sister's building at 660 East 242d Street in the Wakefield section of the Bronx. The victim was identified as Mary Heslin of 118-04 Rockaway Boulevard in South Ozone Park, Queens.

title: U.N. Adopts a Day of Peace
description: The third Tuesday in September, the day the General Assembly opens its regular session every year, was declared International Day of Peace in a resolution adopted Monday.

title: Rose Landver-Davison, 79, Opera Singer and Teacher
description: Rose Landver-Davison, an opera singer in Europe before World War II and a former teacher of operatic acting, died Saturday at her home in Rockville Centre, L.I. She was 79 years old.

title: Experiment on Shuttle Termed Disappointing
description: Dr. Bernard Vonnegut says the thunderstormfilming experiment he placed aboard the space shuttle Columbia on its second mission was more or less a failure.

title: Business Digest; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1981; The Economy
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the Federal Government is not legally required to make it easier for small oil companies to compete for offshore leases, reversing an appeals court decision. Nearly all such leases are currently won by the major companies, which have the capital available to make the initial cash payments required under the bidding system in use now. In another ruling, the Justices held that Missouri taxpayers could not challenge local property assessments in a Federal court. (D1.)

title: 60-Minute Gourmet; A BLEND OF FRENCH AND ITALIAN DISHES
description: BACK in the days of my apprenticeship in the basics of traditional or classic French cooking there was a tendency to cook almost all vegetables for a considerable time. That has given way today to ''modern'' techniques in which vegetables are cooked a short time so that they retain their crisp or crisp-tender texture.

title: Walter H. Conklin Dies at 77; Former Judge in New Jersey
description: Walter H. Conklin, a former judge of Superior Court in New Jersey, died Saturday at Point Pleasant (N.J.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Point Pleasant.

title: REAGAN HINTING END TO JOB BAN FOR CONTROLLERS
description: President Reagan today began a campaign to repair his frayed relations with organized labor by saying he might reconsider his three-year ban on hiring dismissed air traffic controllers for any Federal job.

title: BATTLE IS JOINED OVER HOME 'HOME BIRTHING'
description: A disciplinary proceeding here against an upstate doctor has focused attention on a controversy over the practice of ''home birthing,'' a relatively small but growing area of medical practice.

title: 'WHOSE LIFE IS IT ANYWAY?'
description: IN a successful production of Brian Clark's ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?,'' such as the film version that stars Richard Dreyfuss and opens at the Beekman today, there's a great deal of gamesmanship involved. How can this story be kept moving, in both senses of that word? The fact that its hero is immobilized presents an enormous staging problem. So does the structure of Mr. Clark's play, which is somewhat diffuse, and which allows the audience to become more and more acclimated to the very limited life of Ken Harrison, the disabled young sculptor, just as Ken himself is deciding he would rather die.

title: WHY TOP U.S. OFFICIALS WELCOME RETIREMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our armaments may grow stronger through President Reagan's defense budget - and I believe in a strong national defense - but a nation of only armaments can survive only an attack from abroad, it cannot survive a surrender from within.

title: Going Out Guide
description: REMEMBER WHEN

title: DOW ADDS 1.24
description: The Dow Jones industrial average edged 1.24 points higher yesterday, extending its gain in five sessions to more than 38 points. But, over all, declines outnumbered advances by 4-to-3 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Moves to No.2
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar became the second-leading scorer in league history tonight, surpassing Oscar Robertson in a game against the Utah Jazz

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: knock joke. ''Knock-knock jokes are basically puns, that's all, and you've got to have a feel for the ludicrous,'' he says. Mr. Cole's grasp of the ludicrous is so firm that he has perpetrated two collections of knock-knock jokes, (''Knock-Knocks You've Never Heard Before'' and ''Knock-Knocks: The Most Ever''), with two more imminent.

title: THE BRITISH PARADOX
description: Are the British in trouble these days? Yes, they say, but trouble is what we handle best. Are they tired of the ideological arguments and failures of the Conservative and Labor Parties? Yes, they add, so let's try the new Social Democrat-Liberal coalition. Do they know what that new coalition would do? No, but they insist, let's give them a chance.

title: OLDER WOMEN: NO LONGER 'INVISIBLE'
description: Older women often use the word ''invisible'' when talking about themselves because they believe that society has largely ignored them and their concerns. But at the White House Conference on Aging, going on here this week, they are a highly visible force.

title: Chinese Going to Antarctica
description: Six Chinese scientists have left for short training courses in Australia and New Zealand and will go to Antarctica soon for research, The People's Daily reported today.

title: 178 ARE KILLED IN CRASH OF YUGOSLAV JET IN CORSICA
description: A chartered Yugoslav DC-9 jetliner smashed into a mountain today while approaching an airport listed as unsafe by pilots, killing all 178 people aboard.

title: New Plant Spending Up
description: Spending by the nation's largest manufacturers on new plants and equipment jumped 10.4 percent in the third quarter, but authorizations to spend money in the future slipped, the Conference Board said in a survey released yesterday.

title: THEATER: 'SALT SPEAKS,' SCIENCE AS STAGE SEES IT
description: AN average husband and wife sit at a kitchen table, momentarily forsaking their marriage-dominating television set to listen halfheartedly to a radio program entitled ''Science and the Masses.'' On the table are a salt shaker, a pepper mill and a coffee mug, and the three objects are soon aquiver with excitement. Jumping up and down, they are like midget runaways from television's Mr. Bill show. Alerted by the science report, the salt shaker begins to talk (voice supplied by Rachelle Bornstein who is crouching under the table). With increasing enthusiasm, the shaker embarks on a search for knowledge and the secret of life. All sorts of questions arise, including, why does salt have more intellectual curiosity than pepper?

title: Vermont's Bar Exam Was Graded in Error
description: A confused examiner correcting the Vermont bar exam for the state's latest crop of lawyers gave the highest mark to the worst answers and the lowest mark to the best answers, officials have discovered.

title: Advertising; Magazine Planned On Trade Shows
description: There is a new Show magazine on the horizon, this time a trade publication that will be offered by National Trade Productions of Lanham, Md.

title: No Headline
description: INDIANA SETS BACK NOTRE DAME, 69-55

title: CANCER STUDY INDICATES SURVIVAL RATE INCREASE
description: The survival rate for cancer patients has increased substantially, according to preliminary data just reported by the National Cancer Institute. But the significance of these apparent gains is questioned by some experts who would prefer to await the complete data and more detailed analysis.

title: Schwab & Co.  To Add Letterman
description: Charles Schwab & Company, a subsidiary of the nation's largest discount brokerage firm, said it would acquire Letterman Transaction Services Inc., a discount brokerage house based in Irvine, Calif., for an undisclosed price.

title: SPAIN'S CHIEF NAMES NEW AIDES IN A BID TO END PARTY STRIFE
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo shuffled his Cabinet tonight in an attempt to patch up quarrels in the governing party. He appointed two deputy prime ministers, brought in six new ministers and replaced two ministers given top party jobs.

title: Bridge: Grand Nationals Tourney For '82 Starts This Month
description: For those who compete in the Grand National Team Championship, 1982 begins a little early. Five thousand teams throughout the United States begin play at grass-roots level this month hoping to be the national winner when the event concludes next July in Albuquerque, N.M.

title: Market Place; High Yields In Municipals
description: SELECTED municipals still offer near-record yields, though the much-improved bond market has trimmed a full percentage point from yields of high-grade, long-term taxable issues.

title: Brown, Stepien to Talk
description: Hubie Brown, former coach of the Atlanta Hawks, said he would confer today with Ted Stepien, owner of the Cavaliers, on the coaching vacancy in Cleveland. Stepien said Monday that Don Delaney would stay with the team in some position but would be removed as coach as soon as the Cavs, who are off to a woeful start, could find someone else.

title: GIFTS FOR A WELL-DONE CHRISTMAS
description: DETERMINING the perfect food or cooking gift for those on your Christmas list is enough to make some people swear off Christmas. In desperation, one man I know gave his wife kitchen curtains. She thanked him politely and bided her time. The following year she gave him a lawnmower.

title: ITALIAN PARTY SCRAMBLING TO RESTORE ITS IMAGE
description: Italy's Christian Democrats, who lost the Prime Ministership last summer for the first time in 36 years, have just concluded a General Assembly at which speaker after speaker called for the rejuvenation of the party, a ''new morality'' and an end to scandals and corruption.

title: PANEL FINDS CASEY NOT UNFIT FOR JOB
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence will issue a report Wednesday stating that it has found no basis for concluding that William J. Casey is unfit to serve as Director of Central Intelligence, according to Senator Harrison Schmitt, Republican of New Mexico.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NUCLEAR MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Careers; Convention Jobs: Focus On Growth
description: EVERY big city wants a piece of the nation's convention business. It brings dollars to hotels, restaurants, bars, department stores, theaters and sports arenas.

title: Xerox Lifts Prices
description: The Xerox Corporation said it will raise the price of medium- and high-volume copiers and duplicators an average of about 9 percent in the United States effective Jan. 4. Xerox said the sales price of its 2300 low-volume copier will also be raised to $3,295 from $2,995. Prices of other low-volume copiers will not be changed, it added.

title: COMPACT VIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WEST GERMANS HINT AT DELAY ON MISSILES
description: High-ranking officials of West Germany's governing Social Democratic Party have suggested in public that the deployment of medium-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe might be postponed beyond 1983.

title: STATUS OF ARMS NEGOTIATIONS
description: Following is a list of arms control negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union either in progress, in abeyance or scheduled. Intermediate nuclear forces - Negotiations on reducing or eliminating medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe opened yesterday in Geneva.

title: Doubled Gasoline Tax Urged
description: The Federal Highway Administrator, Ray A. Barnhart, today proposed doubling the 4-cent gasoline tax to pay for the increasing costs of maintaining the nation's highways.

title: AT ARMORY, WRAM BED FOR A NIGHT
description: Another bone-chilling night has fallen in the city, and a mass of men, smells, tattered coats, frayed parcels and confusion fills the dim reception room of the Men's Shelter on East Third Street, just off the Bowery.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The sales for the latest third qr include a $500,000 approximat gain from the sale of Canadian operations which increased net income by 4 cents a shr; sales for the latest 9 mos include a $2.5 million approximate gain on the sale of an office building and $2.5 million approximate gain on the sale of photo finishin operations in Canada which increased net income by about 21 cen a shr

title: BANKS CUT PRIME RATE TO 15 3/4%
description: Most major banks, led by Citibank, lowered their prime lending rates by a quarter of a point yesterday, to 15 3/4 percent, from 16 percent.

title: ONE DEAD IN PITTSBURGH CRASH
description: Rescue workers tending to the injured after a bus was struck by a car and smashed against a building. One bus passenger died, and 42 persons were injured.

title: 'THE PROBLEMS OF THE AGED ARE NOT MYTHS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; NEW DIVISION PRESIDENT AT ENGELHARD INDUSTRIES
description: About seven months after the Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation was split into two companies -the Phibro Corporation, a commodity trader and marketer, and the Engelhard Corporation, an industrial and precious metals company - Engelhard has named a new president of a major operation.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for elimination 2 percent convertible subordinat

title: Litton's Net Rises 26.4%
description: Litton Industries said yesterday that net income in the first quarter of the fiscal year 1982 increased 26.4 percent, as sales advanced 11.6 percent.

title: 'THE PROBLEMS OF THE AGED ARE NOT MYTHS'
description: To the Editor:

title: ELLMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Irish Refinery Planned
description: Aran Energy Ltd. said today that it had applied for permission to build a 120,000-barrel-a-day oil refinery at Tarbert, Ireland, with construction to begin as early as 1983. Aran said the refinery could cost as much as $500 million.

title: Advertising; Kraft Is Evaluating A La Cart Expansion
description: The management of Kraft is currently evaluating the various factors involved in extending the marketing area of its innovative A La Cart brand of entrees.

title: AMTRAK AND FIVE EMPLOYEES REACH ACCORD IN TB LAWSUIT
description: A settlement has been reached in a $400,000 lawsuit filed by five Amtrak dining car workers who said they had contracted tuberculosis from a head chef, an attorney for the employees says.

title: RELIGIOUS LEADERS ASSAIL REAGAN POLICIES
description: In a blunt letter to President Reagan, religious leaders in the Baltimore area today attacked the Administration's social and military spending policies.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Added Niagara Falls a s minor league affiliate; promoted Dave D ombrowski, director of minor league o perations, to assistant general manager; s igned Fred Schaffer as special assign- m ents scout and Jim Busby and Mark Ser- v ais as full-time scouts; waived Rod Allen, o utfielder, outright to Edmonton farm t eam. NEW YORK (NL) - Named Frank H oward as third base coach and Al Jack- s on as minor league pitching coach.

title: MOFFETT DECLARES SENATE CANDIDACY IN CONNECTICUT
description: Representative Anthony Toby Moffett, who began his career as a consumer advocate working from outside to influence the political system, announced his candidacy today for the nomination for the United States Senate seat held by Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican.

title: Sports of The Times; The Deacon and His Dad
description: HIS father called him The Deacon. There was a slight edge of teasing to it, a tone that said, ''My son is different from me.'' In the ring they can spar like equals, throwing hooks and jabs to ''wreck'' each other into shape. But sitting together in a hotel suite Tuesday, one was Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion, and the other was his son, Marvis. The Deacon.

title: Credit Markets; SLOWING OF RATE DECLINE SEEN
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fluctuated widely but closed little changed yesterday as traders concluded that the Federal Reserve was not likely to push rates down as fast as they had estimated earlier.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-the company said that the first qr results were reduced by $2.4 million before taxes due to unrealized losses on its securities portfolio and includes income tax reduction of $750,000 due to an I.R.S. settlement...C-Includes a pretax gain of $3 million

title: INDIA SAYS IT WILL COUNTER ARMS SALE TO PAKISTAN
description: A Defense Ministry official told Parliament today that India was increasing its military preparedness because of the American sale of F-16 fighters and other sophisticated arms to Pakistan.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1981
description: International The investigation on Richard V. Allen will now focus on an inaccurate financial disclosure statement that Mr. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, has filed with the White House. The Justice Department said it had closed its inquiry into Mr. Allen's receipt of $1,000 from a Japanese magazine, adding that it had found no evidence of criminal wrongdoing and that there was thus no reason to appoint a special prosecutor in the matter. (Page A1, Column 6.) All 178 people aboard were killed as a chartered Yugoslav DC-9 jetliner crashed into a mountain while approaching an airport in Corsica that pilots list as unsafe. (A12:4-6.)

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EX-PREMIER KEEPS ALL SPAIN GUESSING
description: Rarely has a politician who has supposedly left politics attracted such attention as Adolfo Suarez. He has lost a battle for control of the party he founded five years ago; his handpicked successor as Prime Minister, Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo, has won. Adolfo Suarez should be a political has-been.

title: A.T.& T. Told To Pay MCI
description: A Federal Communications Commission law judge today ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to pay almost $1 million to MCI Communications Inc. for refusing to lease certain phone circuits in 1975 when MCI was trying to start its long-distance service.

title: THE ZERO OPTION
description: President Reagan's announced ''zero option'' objective in the arms talks with the Soviet Union in Geneva would, if realized, benefit the West, but it also would carry serious risks.

title: WITH REFUSE PILING UP, MEDIATOR FINDS 'IMPASSE' IN CARTING TALKS
description: Trash began to pile up on sidewalks and in alleys yesterday as 2,000 private sanitation workers, seeking higher pay and improved benefits, struck in New York City.

title: HEARING SET ON COYOTE POISON
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, citing ''substantial new information,'' announced today that it would open formal hearings on whether to lift a nine-year ban on using a deadly rodent killer to poison coyotes in the West.

title: Article 114920 -- No Title
description: A $50,000 prize to an American composer for lifetime achievement, the William Schuman Award, has been created at Columbia University. Mr. Schuman, the 71-year-old composer, will be its first recipient.

title: RELIEF FOR LOAN SHARKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Great Basins Sells Holdings
description: The Great Basins Petroleum Company announced that it had agreed in principle to sell all of its producing and nonproducing oil and gas properties in the United States to a privately owned oil and gas company that it did not identify.

title: REAGAN ADMINISTRATION OUSTS U.S. ATTORNEY'S AIDE ON COAST
description: The Reagan Administration, in an apparently unusual action, has dismissed an Assistant United States Attorney in California.

title: The Outlook For Britain
description: British economists do not share the Government's optimism about the economic future of Britain, according to a survey published today.

title: NUCLEAR REGULATORY AGENCY CHIEF ASSAILS 'FAILURE' IN PLANTS' SAFETY
description: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told executives of the nation's utilities and builders of nuclear power plants today that he found the failure of their quality assurance programs ''inexcusable.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM REAGAN'S SPEECH TO THE WHITE HOUSE CONFERENCE ON AGING
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Reagan's address yesterday to the White House Conference on Aging, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: MET'S ROCKEFELLER WING SET TO OPEN
description: Four years later than planned, the Metropolitan Museum of Art will open its $18.3 million Michael C. Rockefeller Wing for the art of Africa, Oceania and the Americas on Feb. 3. The installation is on the first floor of a new construction on the Metropolitan's south side, which also contains the previously opened Andre Meyer Galleries on the second floor. The entire wing balances out the Sackler Wing, containing the Temple of Dendur, on the north side.

title: Offer for Diamond Made by Cavenham
description: Cavenham Holdings Inc., an affiliate of a British-French holding company controlled by Sir James Goldsmith, the international financier, said yesterday that it would offer the equivalent of $42 a share, or about $345 million, to acquire the 60 percent interest in the Diamond International Corporation that it does not already own.

title: BAKER WILL SEEK TO EXTEND VOTING ACT WITHOUT CHANGE
description: In a change of strategy, Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today that he would seek Senate approval this month of a 10-year extension of the Voting Rights Act in its present form, avoiding the need for long public hearings.

title: BUSES WASHINGTON LENT CITY TRICKLE HOME IN GOOD SHAPE
description: The red-white-and-blue buses that arrived in New York from Washington with considerable fanfare a year ago have been trickling back home, and transit officials say the last will be gone by the end of the year.

title: Gardening; DEFENDING PLANTS FROM INSECT ENEMIES
description: THE trouble with insect pests on house plants is that they're sneaky: No one knows that they're there until the damage is done. Suddenly, leaves have brown spots; some yellow and drop or become sticky and turn black; others may stop growing.

title: SHOPPING THE SMALLER STORES
description: WHEN it comes to home furnishings, there are many reliable sources in the city, and such places as Workbench, Conran's, Jensen-Lewis and the Pottery Barn are on almost every shopper's basic list.

title: ZAIRE MAY RENEW ISRAEL RELATIONS
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire said today that his Government was prepared to renew relations with Israel ''immediately'' but would not act until it saw how other black African countries handled the issue.

title: REAGAN NAMED 44 TO SPECIAL GROUP ON CHARITY
description: President Reagan established a Task Force on Private Sector Initiative today to seek ways to help take up the slack left by the deep cuts he has made in Federal spending.

title: WALDHEIM'S TERM MAY BE EXTENDED
description: With Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's term expiring on Dec. 31, several Security Council members now believe the calendar will compel them to break the continuing deadlock over choosing a successor by extending his tenure for a limited period, perhaps for two years.

title: AMID UNCERTAINTY, REVIVAL OF 125TH ST. PROCEEDS
description: An ambitious plan to change Harlem's 125th Street, long a declining thoroughfare of struggling shops and stores, continues to inch forward amid financial uncertainty.

title: Japanese Plan Sports Cars
description: Japanese auto makers are planning to introduce a series of lightweight, relatively low-priced sports cars in the United States in the next two years, a trade publication reported today.

title: BRITISH TAX LAW IS BOON TO 'REDS' FILM
description: When ''Reds,'' the $33.5 million Paramount film produced by Warren Beatty about the American John Reed who participated in the Russian Revolution, is released tomorrow, it may technically be the property of Barclays Bank in Britain.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We know about isolation, but when your best friend says, 'Don't count on me, except in the face of danger from North Korea,' it's hard to say that Israel's position in the area is strengthened.'' - Abba Eban. (A3:1.)

title: Home Beat
description: THE jaunty look of British pottery of the Art Deco period is displayed in a collection of over 80 pieces on view and for sale at Barney's, Seventh Avenue and 17th Street, until the end of the month. The hand-painted ceramic pieces by Clarice Cliff, Susie Cooper and from the Shelley Potteries Ltd. include cups and saucers, coffeepots, teapots and platters.

title: NBC AIDE ACQUITTED IN TAX CASE
description: A former unit manager for NBC News who was dismissed with others who were charged with embezzling expense-account funds has been acquitted of income-tax evasion charges by a Federal jury.

title: COUNT ALL THE ARMS
description: O ur President has asked for a reduction in existing Soviet t heater nuclear weapons without a reduction in our own. The proposal i s inequitable. If it is refused at Geneva, the President will then t ell the hundreds of thousands of Europeans demonstrating against t he Pershing 2's and Tomahawk cruise missiles that he tried to p revent their deployment but must now proceed.

title: THE CITY;
description: A jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan awarded $8.7 million yesterday to a former truck driver who was partly paralyzed in a collision with two speeding tow trucks.

title: Change Small Change
description: According to Gresham's Law, bad money drives good money out of circulation. According to what might be called Hillman's Law, bad coinage drives itself out of circulation.

title: Orpheus Orchestra Due
description: The conductorless Orpheus orchestra, which was founded eight years ago, will be performing in its sole New York appearance this season, at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 10. The program of the 26-member orchestra will consist of Mozart's Symphony No. 25, Richard Strauss's Serenade for Winds and the Divertimento for Strings by Bartok. In addition, the contralto Maureen Forrester will be the soloist in Berlioz's ''Les Nuits d'Ete.''

title: STOP SELLING MOROCCO U.S. ARMS
description: The six-year-old conflict between Morocco and the Polisario Front for control of the Western Sahara - the Front calls its nation the Sahara Arab Democratic Republic -is far from finished, despite the generous packages of American arms aid sent to to Morocco.

title: Notes on People; For Roberta Peters, a 'Hometown' Solo at Last
description: On the Metropolitan Opera stage, she has appeared as queens, pageboys, mad women, maids and mechanical dolls. She has appeared in movies, on radio and on television, and in many advertisements.

title: STOP & SHOP COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 7
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $3.6 million in the qr and $3.7 million for the 9 mos; the net income for both 1981 periods includes a gain from the divestiture of New Jersey supermarkets of $4.6 million or $1.63 a shr

title: MUSIC: ROREM'S 'NANTUCKET'
description: ''SURFACE is as telling as depth,'' Ned Rorem said Tuesday night at the Third Street Music School Settlement, explaining his preference for French music over German. ''Surgery clarifies, but it also kills.''

title: Miss Sukova Scores Upset
description: Helena Sukova, a 16-year-old Czechoslovak with no international ranking, upset Barbara Potter of the United States, ranked eighth in the world, 6-4, 6-3, today in the Australian Women's Open.

title: Cox to Return To Needham, Harper
description: Bob Cox is returning on Dec. 14 to Needham, Harper & Steers/New York where he is replacing Lois Korey, who has been executive creative director and an executive vice president since 1973.

title: Suspensions Voided
description: The New Jersey Racing Commission, saying there was insufficient evidence to warrant the punishment, voided today the 30-day suspensions imposed by Freehold Raceway judges on the harness drivers Ed Lohmeyer and George Smutz Jr.

title: OPERA: A NEW 'ELISIR'
description: The nicest things about the Washington Opera's new ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' are its good looks. Zack Brown's verdant little village scene is beautifully lighted by Peter Kaczorowski, and the director, Lou Galtiero, guides his chorus and principals through the limited space of the Kennedy Center's Terrace Theater stage without ever a sense of overcrowding.

title: Koch to Meet Minority Panels
description: Mayor Koch, who has said since his re-election last month that he wants to ''reach out'' to blacks and Hispanic people, has scheduled his first meeting with two advisory panels on minority affairs for this weekend.

title: Justice Dept. Proposes Parole for Mandel in '82
description: The Justice Department has recommended that President Reagan free former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland from Federal prison in January, four months before his three-year sentence for mail fraud and racketeering is up.

title: LONGER-TERM ISSUES WEAKEN
description: Weak investor demand for notes and bonds caused prices to drop as much as 2 points yesterday. As a result, some bond prices are now 4 1/4 points below their Nov. 27 peak. Short-term interest rates rose slightly, but securities dealers said the falloff in investor buying was most evident for longer-term maturities.

title: WARSAW PACT DENIES IT WANTS TO ACHIEVE FIRST-STRIKE CAPACITY
description: The Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies said today that they did not intend to be the first to make a nuclear strike.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE State Department is quietly and angrily protesting the treatment of Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist and Nobel Prize winner who is on a hunger strike in the industrial city of Gorky. Mr. Sakharov, who started his protest on Nov. 22, is pressing the Soviet Government to allow the woman who married his stepson by proxy to join her husband, who is a graduate student at Brandeis University.

title: Mint Receives Copper Bids
description: The Bureau of the Mint said today that it had received proposals ranging from 75.38 cents to 78.02 cents a pound at its offer to buy a total of 44.7 million pounds of copper to be processed into coins.

title: ALBANY IS ASKED TO PASS KOCH RENT PLAN FOR LOFTS
description: The Koch administration, in an attempt to end the feuds between loft tenants and landlords, proposed yesterday the creation of a panel to set rent increases and settle disputes.

title: HAIG ASSERTS THE NICARAGUANS DISPLAY INTEREST IN CLOSER TIES
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met today with Nicaragua's Foreign Minister, the Rev. Miguel d'Escoto Brockmann, and said that the Central American country ''may be interested'' in resuming discussions on relations with the United States.

title: Jack Manning A Foggy Day in New York
description: Paints a Surreal Seascape Moving slowly through yesterday morning's heavy fog, a freighter made its way down the East River past the Queensboro Bridge. The frontal system responsible for Tuesday's heavy rainfall left a legacy of unusually persistent thick mist that clung to the city's waterways and obscured building tops. A more palpable atmospheric phenomenon might appear by the weekend; weather service forecasters say snow is possibile then.

title: STUDY GROUP CALLS FOR U.S.-P.L.O. TALKS
description: A private study group, including a former senior State Department official, made public a report today that proposed new approaches to a Middle East settlement. The report called on the Reagan Administration to hold exploratory discussions with the Palestine Liberation Organization to determine if it was ready ''to negotiate peace'' with Israel.

title: Hers
description: IKNOW few other women who do what I do. What I do is write about science, mainly physics. And to do that, I spend a lot of time reading about science, talking to scientists and struggling to understand physics. In fact, most of the women (and men) I know think me quite queer for actually liking physics. ''How can you write about that stuff?'' they ask, always somewhat askance. ''I could never understand that in a million years.'' Or more simply, ''I hate science.''

title: ADDITIONAL TAX RISE SEEN IN WESTCHESTER AFTER AID IS RESTORED
description: Westchester County taxpayers, who learned last month that their county property taxes might go up 17 percent, the sharpest rise in five years, got more bad news today - a likely additional increase of 4 percentage points.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES VOTE ALLOTMENT ON A CITY BOARD
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union charged in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday that the voting structure of the city's Board of Estimate was unconstitutional because it violated the oneman, one-vote principle.

title: AMIC Sale Final
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that the previously announced sale of its AMIC Corporation subsidiary had been completed. AMIC, whose headquarters are in Raleigh, N.C., is the parent company of the American Mortgage Insurance Company, AMIC Title Insurance Company, AMIC Commercial Insurance Company and AMIC Mortgage Insurance Company. AMIC has been acquired, for an undisclosed amount, by a newly organized company owned by a group of AMIC management employees.

title: CONCERT: EDUARDO MATA DIRECTS PHILADELPHIANS
description: EDUARDO MATA has made a name for himself as music director of the Dallas Symphony and, locally, in three appearances with the Mostly Mozart Festival. But his concert Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, as guest conductor of the Philadelphia Orchestra, was not very impressive.

title: NEW YORK FINDS 'PRO BONO' CASE NOTE QUITE FREE
description: The question is: how free is free? Since the summer of 1980, the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore has been representing the City of New York in an effort to convince the courts that the 1980 census figures, which show a marked decrease in the city's population, were in error.

title: MARYLAND RALLIES AND BEATS L.I.U., 87-79
description: Jeff Adkins and Adrian Branch scored 9 points each in the second half tonight and led Maryland to an 87-79 victory over Long Island University.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SPANISH CHIEF SHUFFLES TEAM WITH OBJECT TO UNITING PARTY
description: Spain's newly shuffled Cabinet took its oath of office before King Juan Carlos today. For the first time since 1937 a woman was appointed to a Cabinet job, but aside from that the new Cabinet contains few novelties or surprises. Its composition appears dictated almost entirely by the need of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo to appease factions in his Union of the Democratic Center.

title: PIANO: ORTH FINDS A PATTERN
description: PETER ORTH, winner of the 1979 Naumburg competition for pianists, offered a program Tuesday evening in Alice Tully Hall that seemed, at first glance, to have little holding it together. On closer inspection, an interesting pattern appeared: of the five selections, the first and last were one - movement sonatas in B minor, while the middle three were ''fantasies,'' each of which incorporated, to a certain degree, elements of sonata structure.

title: Sports of The Times; The Skiing Twins
description: THEY always had each other and the snow. Their father still manages the ski area at White Pass, Wash., in the Cascade Mountains, where the Mahre twins grew up. From the beginning, Phil and Steve never had to search for somebody to ski with. Or against.

title: U.C.L.A. COMES EAST QUIETLY
description: Nearly 13 years have passed since U.C.L.A.'s basketball team last played in the New York area. The center's name was Lew Alcindor when the Bruins were last here, winning the 1968 Holiday Festival in what was then the new Madison Square Garden. Six championship banners have been hung at Pauley Pavilion since that trip, and three coaches have come and gone since John Wooden retired in 1975.

title: S.& P. Report On Dividends
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that the number of companies reporting increased dividends in November fell 7 percent from the same month in 1980.

title: STEEL CONCERNS ASK IMPORT PROCTECTION
description: Sixteen companies, accounting for most of the production of high-technology specialty steel, and the United Steelworkers of America asked President Reagan today for protection against surging imports of specialty steel products from seven countries, six in Western Europe.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's plan to create a ''new federalism'' appears to have reached a critical juncture. Over the past month, a number of the concept's strongest supporters have begun to waver and back away, voicing ever-louder cries that ''new federalism,'' however well-intentioned, is causing unbearable financial hardships for state and local governments.

title: A Disaster Area
description: ''From top to bottom, the Chicago Cub organization was a disaster area, even worse than I first thought when I took the job.'' Cub fans may have known it all along, and now they have confirmation from Dallas Green, Chicago's new general manager, who was describing the state of things as they appeared when he arrived from the Philadelphia Phillies six weeks ago.

title: FOREIGN ENVOYS TERMED 'BOON' TO CITY IN 1980
description: New York City's economy gained more than $690 million last year from the United Nations and the 35,000-member diplomatic community, a new study has concluded. At the same time, it found that the financial burden of international diplomacy on the city, in the form of tax exemptions and police protection, amounted to slightly more than $15 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. said it had decreased its holdings in Crown Zellerbach Corp. to 3.9 percent of the preferred stock, or 97,400 shares.

title: Home Improvement; A ROUNDUP OF HOW-TO BOOKS FOR THE HOME
description: TO books for do-it-yourselfers continue to proliferate as homeowners and apartment-dwellers alike keep on demanding information on such basic subjects as how to improve dwellings without a professional contractor, how to do their own maintenance and make essential repairs and how to keep energy costs at a minimum. Here is a roundup of some of the latest volumes in this category, many of which would make excellent gifts: The Energy Resources Center Illus- trated Guide to Home Retrofitting for Energy Savings, by Paul A. Knight (McGraw-Hill $14.95).

title: Index; International
