description: For a black ''homeland,'' sover- eignty and strife A2 Private study group calls for ex- ploratory U.S.-P.L.O. talks A3 Schmidt and Honecker to meet next week A4 South Africa frees 39 and charges 5 in Seychelles plot A9 Warsaw Pact ministers disavow first-strike intent A9 Spain gets new Cabinet aimed at ending party rift A10 Peking critical of Mao's views on the arts A11 Government/Politics Margiotta defends $5,000 pay- ment as share of commission B2 Regan urges Carey to intervene in M.T.A.'s ''paralysis'' B4 Westchester taxpayers face an additional tax rise B12 Reagan moves to re-establish ties with organized labor B18 Senate panel says Casey is not ''unfit'' for C.I.A. post B20 Washington Talk Briefing B16 Lobbyist finds White House friends are pluses and minuses B16 David Stockman is back on Capi- tol Hill as a budget expert B16 Lexicon, some language being bandied about in the capital B16 General Around the Nation A18 San Francisco dedicates George Moscone Convention Center A18 Spending by envoys termed a ''boon'' to New York City B5 Washington getting its buses back in good shape B10 Health/Science Prenatal test for a genetic disor- der found by state researchers A20 Four Brooklyn hospitals plan to merge into two new ones B8 Home Section Home Fear of entertaining: pre-party stategies C1

title: No Headline
description: NORDIQUES TOP OILERS, 9-8

title: 1918 WAS NOT THE YEAR OF POLAND'S
description: REBIRTHTo the Editor:

title: Day Care Center Owner Charged in Child's Death
description: A woman who ran an unlicensed day care center in her home for four years has been charged with murdering an 11-month-old child and physically and mentally torturing 20 other children.

title: Valenzuela Is Voted N.L. Rookie of Year
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, who have been celebrating their World Series victory for five weeks, threw another party today at Dodger Stadium after their left-handed pitcher, Fernando Valenzuela, was voted National League rookie of the year. He became the third straight Dodger pitcher accorded that honor, following Rick Sutcliffe in 1979 and Steve Howe last year.

title: NEW-HOME SALES ROSE IN OCTOBER
description: Sales of new single-family houses were up 15 percent in October, to an annual rate of 360,000, after plunging to their lowest level on record a month earlier, the Government said today.

title: PULASKI FURNITURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
Officer Of Braniff Quits Post
description: Russell Thayer, vice chairman at the Braniff International Corporation since his demotion from the presidency last January, will leave the troubled airline company to become president and chief executive officer of TexasAmerican Airlines Inc., a recently formed affiliate of Overseas National Airways.

title: G.E. to Cut Emphasis On Consumer Ads
description: When the ''General Electric Theater,'' long a broadcasting feature, returns Saturday in a two-hour format on the ABC-TV Network it will mark an important turning point in the corporation's advertising. Among the eight commercials by Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn will be two that will be promoting industrial products, instead of the consumer products with which the public is most familiar.

title: Rank Xerox Plans Unit in Europe
description: Rank Xerox, the French affiliate of the Xerox Corporation, said that it intended to set up a unit in Europe to manufacture electronic office equipment at a cost of about 100 million francs, or approximately $18 million.

title: RESCUERS REACH CRASH SITE
description: A portion of the fuselage of the chartered Yugoslav DC-9 jetliner that crashed into a mountain Tuesday, killing all 178 people aboard, while attempting to land at Ajaccio Airport in Corsica.

title: NATALIE WOOD BURIED IN HOLLYWOOD
description: Natasha, left, daughter of Natalie Wood, and Kate, Robert Wagner's daughter, leaving the actress's grave site yesterday after her funeral. Miss Wood drowned Sunday off Santa Catalina Island. About 120 family members and friends attended the service.

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER ARCHITECT
description: Wallace K. Harrison, the architect who played a major role in planning Rockefeller Center, the United Nations, Lincoln Center, the 1939 World's Fair and the Empire State Plaza in Albany, died yesterday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 86 years old.

title: AT PLAYBOY, AN EMPIRE RETRENCHES
description: Judging from the pace of recent events - a string of hasty divestitures, unpleasant management shuffles and dismissals - it would appear that Playboy Enterprises Inc. has lost much of its gloss.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: The weekly American Petroleum Institute statistics were not issued yesterday because of a delay in data collection during the Thanksgiving holiday. The data are to be issued today.

title: Sabres, Wings in 7-Man Deal
description: In a seven-player trade of proven veterans for talented newcomers, the Buffalo Sabres sent Danny Gare, their captain and holder of the club record for goals in a season; Bob Sauve, the league's third leading goalie, and two others to the Detroit Red Wings today.

title: NCR Charges A.T.&T.  Violated Antitrust Law
description: The NCR Corporation, a major manufacturer of business informationprocessing systems, charged the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and three of its subsidiaries yesterday with violations of Federal antitrust laws.

title: Mets Seeking Abbott
description: Lou Gorman, the Mets' vice president for baseball operations, said yesterday that he planned to make an offer today to Glenn Abbott, a right-handed free agent pitcher. Ron Shapiro, Abbott's agent, said he already had offers from three of the five teams that can negotiate with Abbott. The other four are Cleveland, the Chicago White Sox, Philadelphia and Seattle.

title: News of Music; CITY OPERA SINGS THE PRAISES OF PRICE-CUTTING
description: THE New York City Opera says that its price-cutting strategy is working. Several weeks ago the company announced a 20 percent reduction in subscription rates, in an effort to stimulate sagging business.

title: Frazier, Soon to Be 38, Re-enters the Ring Tonight
description: Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion, will enter the ring Thursday night for the first time in nearly five and a half years and about six weeks before his 38th birthday. Today he engaged in a raucous weigh-in ceremony with his opponent, Floyd (Jumbo) Cummings.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Misjudgment in the Senate
description: Senator Harrison Williams of New Jersey was to have faced a jury of Senate peers today for judgment on his fitness to continue in office. Another jury, in Federal court, has already found him guilty of offering that office for sale. And a Senate committee found ''ethically repugnant'' his secretly videotaped boasting that he could deliver political favors. But the full Senate has postponed judgment until next year, on two flimsy pretexts.

title: U.S. Group Arrives in Greece
description: Seven members of the United States House of Representatives arrived in Greece today for a one-day official visit and talks with Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou and finance officials. The delegation is headed by Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of New York.

title: A WEALTH OF HOME GIFTS FROM SOME SPECIAL STORES
description: THE idea of opening a store of one's own is probably the same kind of daydream as starting a restaurant. Sometimes, however, fantasy becomes reality for small entrepreneurs.

title: Nixon Library at Duke Won't Include Museum
description: Duke University negotiators have agreed that a Richard Nixon Presidential library proposed for the campus will not include a museum, officials say.

title: SURGERY SET TODAY FOR GOV. O'NEILL AFTER HE SUFFERS NEW CHEST PAINS
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill was scheduled for open-heart surgery at 8 A.M. today after he suffered three episodes of chest pain last night in the post-coronary care unit at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center here.

title: Critic's Notebook; GLASS OPERA ACCENTS RIGHTS STRUGGLE
description: AS Philip Glass's opera ''Satyagraha'' draws to a close, Mohandas K. Gandhi stands sad and beatific, engulfed in a turquoise haze, singing repeated scalar figures in Sanskrit. The Indian leader has survived three acts of encounters with prejudiced South Africans, and has founded a political movement that made its mark on the imperialist English oppressors. Meanwhile, seemingly suspended in midair above the white-robed Gandhi, Martin Luther King Jr. stands on a giant pyramid-pedestal addressing a crowd, illuminated by evening sunlight beaming from behind a scrim's scarlet clouds. In slow motion, a ne'er-do-well viscously seeps out of the crowd, lifts a gun as if in a television police show, steadies it with both arms, and fires. King's body jerks with the studied rebounds now made famous by films of the John F. Kennedy assassination, and falls across his podium.

title: CARIBBEAN PARLEY: HOPE IS TEMPERED
description: One of the delegates from the private sector in Nicaragua was unable to attend because he was in jail. The president of El Salvador was present, but a Salvadoran private-sector organization boycotted the meeting.

title: CBS Shuffles Producers For Its 'Evening News'
description: Howard Stringer, senior executive producer of ''CBS Reports,'' will become executive producer of ''The CBS Evening News With Dan Rather,'' CBS News announced yesterday.

title: Notes on People; New Bellamy Post
description: Mayor Koch may have made a riveting speech at the annual meeting of the National League of Cities in Detroit on Tuesday, but it was Carol Bellamy, the President of the New York City Council, who won the league's votes yesterday. She was one of a dozen urban officials elected to the 38-member board of the league, which represents 15,000 cities across the country.

title: FINANCIAL FUTURES TIE SOUGHT
description: Two of the nation's leading exchanges today presented a proposal for a joint trading venture on new financial instruments.

title: POLICE IN WARSAW RAID FIRE ACADEMY TO BREAK UP SIT-IN
description: Polish policemen backed by army units mounted a helicopter assault on the academy of striking fire cadets here today and removed the 300 students without bloodshed.

title: TEAMSTER STRESSES INDUSTRY VIABILITY
description: Bargainers for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and trucking companies are searching for a new national labor contract that will enable the industry to ''survive in the marketplace.''

title: LESSONS FOR A LOBBYIST WITH WHITE HOUSE TIES
description: In this city's influence bazaar, where political connections are the coin of public relations and lobbying, Peter D. Hannaford has a definite advantage.

title: THEATER: 2 BY SAUNDERS AT QUAIGH LUNCHTIME
description: LUNCHTIME Theater is an English invention, created in the late 60's and still thriving in London, serving an hour's theatrical repast in lieu of food. It offers actors an opportunity to experiment without sacrificing more remunerative assignments and it offers theatergoers an inexpensive and casual cultural experience. Presumably the short plays should be high in protein.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: HOLIDAY CRAFTS FAIR
description: WBAI Holiday Crafts Fair, Ferris Booth Hall, Columbia University, Broadway and 115th Street.

title: Bridge: Solodar Proved Effective As Title Play 'Swing Man'
description: A team seeking a major title normally consists of three partnerships with close-knit understandings. The United States team that won the world title in Port Chester, N.Y., this fall, departed from this plan. The team's New York member, John Solodar, was employed as a swing man, playing in turn with Bud Reinhold, Northbrook, Ill.; Bobby Levin, Miami Beach, and Russ Arnold, Miami.

title: Bill Would Ban Printing Odds
description: Acknowledging that the proposed law might be an unconstitutional prior restraint on the press, State Sen. Edward L. Burke filed a bill today that would bar publication of odds or point spreads on amateur athletic events.

title: STOCKMAN RE-EMERGES IN CAPITOL'S CORRIDORS
description: On his first visit to Capitol Hill after The Incident, David A. Stockman was the target of some friendly jabs and gibes.

title: THE FEAR OF ENTERTAINING: PRE-PARTY STRATEGIES
description: NOW that New York and its suburbs are awash with caterers and takeout food shops and party hands for hire, now that it is permissible to seat guests on fold-up plastic chairs and to feed them on little bamboo trays, now that entertaining has become so easy and so casual, what is there left for the host to do before the party but plump the pillows and pour a drink and contemplate a brilliant evening?

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our asphalt shingle roof is 15 years old and is basically in fine condition, except that the white shingles on just the north side are black with fungus. Should these be removed before new shingles are put on, and should we use a fungus-resistant type of shingle the next time? - E.E.R., Tazewell, Va.

title: FOUR BROOKLYN HOSPITALS PLAN TO MERGE INTO TWO NEW ONES
description: In what would constitute the largest consolidation of hospital beds in New York City's history, four private voluntary hospitals in Brooklyn have decided to merge into two new hospitals. All four hospitals would remain open at their present sites.

title: IN THE FAR SEYCHELLES, A TALE OF INTRIGUE
description: For a down payment of $1,000 and a slice of the action, Aubrey Brooks, a 38-year-old father of two, and Roger England, 26 and single, came here, they say, to overthrow a President. The two would then fade away, along with 50 other mercenaries.

title: DIRECTOR-WRITER
description: John L. Gerstad, who began a 40-year theater career by selling lemonade in Boston's Shubert Theater and later became a Broadway director, producer, actor and playwright, died of emphysema in Lenox Hill Hospital on Tuesday. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Design Notebook; REFURBISHING THE WALDORF'S 1930'S INTERIOR
description: IF the lot of the architectural gem in New York is not always a happy one, this seems particularly true when it comes to hotels. The Savoy-Plaza has disappeared altogether, along with the old Park Lane, the Ritz-Carlton and the Marguery; the Biltmore is in the process of coming down right now, and the Commodore was changed beyond recognition in the process of turning it into the Grand Hyatt.

title: Woolworth Fills Executive Post
description: Bruce G. Allbright, 53 years old, will join the F.W. Woolworth Company on Jan. 1 in the new position of chairman and chief executive officer of the United States Woolworth and Woolco division. As the head of the unit -which was responsible for more than half of the corporation's $7.2 billion volume last year - he will succeed George W. Nelson, who held the title of president and will take early retirement at the age of 62.

title: IF IT SQUEALS, IT'S PORK
description: If Ronald Reagan had a political mandate for any one thing, it was to reduce the role and the cost of the Federal Government -to get Americans out of the habit of relying on Washington for support and subsidies. As he nears the end of his first year in office, it is clear that he has muffed the opportunity to make that sea change.

title: REPAIRING VENEERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: REAGAN, AT MEETING WITH LABOR CHIEFS, URGES MUTUAL CONSULTATION
description: President Reagan acknowledged today that his Administration had become ''estranged'' from organized labor, and he appealed personally to Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and other leaders of the labor federation to ''consider starting over'' and establishing a new mechanism for mutual consultation on issues.

title: Ashland Sets Fuel Refunds
description: The Ashland Oil Company said today that it would refund $25 million to settle claims that it made overcharges for gasoline and other petroleum products.

title: Notes on People; Eased Rule Means Homecoming for Patient, 3
description: A 3-year-old girl singled out by President Reagan as an example as someone who has been kept hospitalized because of bureaucratic paper work will be able to go home for Christmas.

title: VICKERS GETS A GOAL
description: The Rangers won for the first time in two weeks tonight, defeating the Los Angeles Kings, 4-3, on two third-period goals.

title: A TV Throwback?
description: Last season NBC televised a Jets-Dolphins game sans announcers. The Silent Bowl was attacked by fans and TV critics, many of whom termed it a gimmick to lift ratings.

title: Awaiting Dismissal
description: Ron Erhardt said that he expected to lose his job as coach of the New England Patriots and that he did not know if victories in the final three games would save it. ''Probably the only guy that's going to go is the guy you're looking at,'' Erhardt said when asked if there was anyone on the team he would like to ship out.

title: TO MAKE THE DEFENSE BUDGET LOOK SMALL
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a previously reported debt offering of $50 million in convertible debentures due 2006.

title: NEW CONSTITUTION GAINING IN CANADA
description: After 18 months of national debate, the House of Commons gave final approval today to a motion aimed at giving Canada a new constitution and complete independence from Britain.

title: The Realty Tax Veto Should Stand
description: The New York Legislature has to choose today between pride and prudence. Pride would override Governor Carey's veto of its massive but chaotic new plan for real estate tax assessment. Prudence would recognize the opportunities that now exist for compromise and averting another costly intervention by the courts.

title: SILICON VALLEY'S 'UNDERWORLD'
description: The police are calling it the largest robbery of advanced computer chips in history. But for the semiconductor manufacturers of California's Silicon Valley, the Thanksgiving theft of $2.7 million worth of these tiny devices from Monolithic Memories Inc. was just the latest in a series perpetrated by a shadowy ''electronics underworld.''

title: WESTWAY FINANCING PLACED INTO FOCUS
description: To the Editor:

title: Chemical Raises Bank Card Rates
description: Chemical Bank said yesterday it would raise interest rates on its 750,000 credit cards and privileged checking accounts to 19.5 percent from 18 percent on Feb. 1, 1982.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Spain Prepares to Reopen Frontier With Gibraltar
description: Spain has begun preparations for the possible reopening of its frontier with the British colony of Gibraltar, closed 12 years ago by Gen. Francisco Franco, official sources said today.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; the shr earnings reflect a 3 percent stock divd paid in Apr 1981

title: WIND-ENERGY INQUIRIES SHOW MARKED INCREASE
description: A professional engineer, a Colorado entrepreneur, a New Hampshire storekeeper and a gift-shop owner in California are among the growing number of people seeking government information about wind energy.

title: PRETORIA FREES 39 IN SEYCHELLES PLOT
description: South Africa released without charges today 39 of the 44 white mercenaries who hijacked an Air India plane in the Seychelles last week after the collapse of an attempted coup. The other five, including the leader, Mike Hoare, were charged with kidnapping and set free on bail.

title: 38 Asian Seamen Are Missing In Rough Seas Around Japan
description: Thirty-eight Japanese and South Korean seamen were reported missing today as rough weather whipped up seas around Japan.

title: Advertising; Tarkenton's New Field
description: IF there were a Super Bowl for salesmen, Fran Tarkenton would play in it every year, if he weren't playing in the one for entrepreneurs. The 41-year-old former National Football League quarterback is a dynamo, a dynamo who has been frequently quoted as saying, ''I am a businessman.''

title: DRECO ENERGY SERVICES reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
SHAD BACKS EASED RULE ON BROKERS
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency's staff will recommend an action that could free $500 million in capital to expand the activities of Wall Street brokerage and investment houses.

title: JURY IN SHOOTING OF LIBYAN BEGINS ITS DELIBERATION
description: After nearly three weeks of testimony from 32 witnesses, the case against Eugene A. Tafoya, the former Green Beret accused of shooting of a Libyan student here last year, was presented to the Larimer County jury late this afternoon.

title: MARGIOTTA SAYS $5,000 HE GOT FROM COMMISSION WAS LEGAL
description: Joseph M. Margiotta testified at his retrial today that ''there was nothing illegal'' about $5,000 that he had accepted as his share of a politically arranged insurance commission.

title: DORADO MICRO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $176,400 for the qr and $200,000 for the yr...C-Including $919,700 extraordinary credit; the 1981 results include operations of Onyx Systems Inc acquired in 1980

title: BAILEY SCORES 16
description: The New Jersey Nets routed the Cleveland Cavaliers, 125-106, tonight, hardly a notable achievement in a matchup of last-place teams at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena. However, the home debut of James Bailey with the Nets was notable.

title: Liquid Air Unit
description: The Liquid Air Corporation, a unit of L'Air Liquide of France, one of the world's largest producers and marketers of industrial and medical gases, said it had formed a new industrial gas company, the Liquid Air Energy Corporation, with headquarters in Calgary, Alberta. The new company will serve energyrelated industries with engineering and construction of cryogenic plants, industrial gas application technology and supply of industrial gases. The new unit will more than double the company's production of liquid oxygen and nitrogen in Alberta, company officials said.

title: AM INTERNATIONAL IS TO REPORT UNAUDITED $250 MILLION DEFICIT
description: Troubled AM International Inc. said last night that its long overdue financial report for the fiscal year that ended last July 31 should be out next week and that it would show losses of about $250 million instead of the $175 million previously predicted.

title: A Son of Carey's Is Arrested
description: Governor Carey's 27-year-old son, Michael, was arrested today on a charge of driving while intoxicated after his car crashed into a fire hydrant several blocks from the Governor's mansion, authorities said. Mr. Carey, a lawyer, was released without bail after being arraigned in Albany Police Court. He pleaded not guilty, and Judge Morton Lynn adjourned the case until Tuesday. The Governor said his son would ''pay whatever penalty is required by law.''

title: HAROLD MCGUIRE, 75, LAWYER WHO SERVED ON COLUMBIA BOARD
description: Harold F. McGuire, former senior partner of the New York law firm of Wickes, Riddell, Bloomer, Jacobi & McGuire and a past vice chairman of the board of trustees of Columbia University, died Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 75 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: TIGHT BUDGET ANNOUNCED IN BRITAIN
description: The British Government today announced budget figures for next year that generally reaffirmed Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's commitment to controlling public spending.

title: TRW to End A Switch Line
description: TRW Inc. said that it had decided to discontinue its digital telephone switch business and had established a reserve to cover future losses on inventories, disposition of surplus equipment, severance pay and other expenses.

title: Kaiser Loses Antitrust Suit
description: A damages trial resulting from a 1974 antitrust suit against the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation by the Columbia Metal Culvert Company, a defunct Vineland, N.J., aluminum pipe fabricator, has resulted in a $9.6 million judgment in Columbia's favor. Kaiser had asked for a retrial after a jury had awarded Columbia $5.5 million.

title: Stevens Earnings Up
description: J.P. Stevens & Company said yesterday that it earned $8.4 million, or 58 cents a share, in its fourth fiscal quarter, ended Oct. 31, up 8.7 percent from $7.7 million, or 55 cents, in the comparable 1980 period. Sales rose 13.9 percent, to $574.5 million from $504.6 million. For the full year, the textile company lost $22.9 million on sales of $2.03 billion; the year before, it earned $20.3 million, or $1.43 a share, on sales of $1.92 billion.

title: ALLIED FOODS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 29
CAREY IS URGED TO INTERVENE TO HALT M.T.A.'S 'PARALYSIS'
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan called today for Governor Carey's ''direct intervention'' in the affairs of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: U.S. Rejects Silver Bids
description: For the third consecutive week, the General Services Administration today rejected all bids for silver at its seventh weekly auction of the metal from the National Defense Stockpile.

title: Gulf and Western Stake in Polaroid
description: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified New York-based manufacturer with extensive minority investments in other companies, said it had purchased 1.88 million shares, or 5.72 percent, of the common stock of the Polaroid Corporation in a transaction valued at $38.75 million.

title: Del Monte Ends Tie With an Agency
description: Del Monte Frozen Foods, until a week ago RJR Foods, is splitting with its agency, Advertising to Women, after three years, over a difference on strategy.

title: Gruner + Jahr Names Beni to New Role
description: Gruner + Jahr, the giant German publisher, has just named John J. Beni, 49, to the newly created position of president of Gruner + Jahr USA/ Publishing.

title: CALUMET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOCIAL SECURITY FIGHT THREATENS AGING REPORT
description: The White House Conference on Aging, deeply divided over benefits and financing for Social Security, worked its way toward a procedural impasse today.

title: FOR A BLACK 'HOMELAND,' SOVEREIGNTY AND STRIFE
description: The commander of the fledgling army, police and intelligence services of Ciskei, the black state that will be proclaimed independent Thursday night, can recall feeling a certain sympathy with the African National Congress when he was starting out as a constable in the South African security police.

title: News Analysis
description: A regulation by the Teaneck (N.J.) Board of Education that limits extracurricular events on the Sabbath has produced a constitutional confrontation over what the relationship between church and state should be.

title: DATA TERMINAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: CITY PICKING UP TRASH ON STREETS IN EMERGENCIES
description: At noon yesterday the pile of black plastic garbage bags outside the Hotel Berkshire Place at Madison Avenue and 52d Street was four feet high and more than 50 feet long.

title: RISE IS EXPECTED IN CARTING RATES AFTER THE STRIKE
description: New York City officials said yesterday that the carting companies that haul trash and garbage from commercial establishments would probably be awarded rate increases that would mean higher costs for their customers after the strike by private sanitation workers ends.

title: ARCHITECTURE: BUILDINGS IN CONTEXT
description: HOUSTON FOR some years now, architects have been expressing concern for the way in which a new building relates to its surround An Appraisal ngs. Whereas modern buildings once tended to be conceived as pure, abstract objects, independent of what was beside them, there is now much more attention paid to the notion of fitting a building into its architectural context - trying, in other words, to make certain that the building echoes many of the architectural themes of its neighbors. It is a philosophy of design that suggests, by implication at least, that it may be better to be discreet than to be original.

title: PAY 'N SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DOW OFF 7.61 AS ENERGY ISSUES RETREAT
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday, with energy issues continuing as the market's weakest group amid curtailed interest in possible takeover candidates. Precious-metal stocks, however, moved higher.

title: OIL PRODUCER WILL JOIN MOBIL IN MARATHON BID
description: In an attempt to overcome antitrust obstacles, the Mobil Corporation will shortly make a new offer to purchase the Marathon Oil Company, this time jointly with another leading oil company, a Mobil spokesman said yesterday.

title: ON THE FINE ART OF HAVING YOUR HOUSE'S PORTRAIT DONE
description: FEW people would be startled if a friend suddenly announced: ''I'm having my portrait painted.'' But the reaction might not be quite so matter-of-fact if the statement was: ''I'm having a portrait of my house painted,'' or ''I've just ordered a portrait of my favorite room.''

title: No Offers for Westphal
description: Paul Westphal, the 31-year-old free agent guard, says his ailing right foot has finally healed from three stress fractures, but no team appears interested in his services anymore. Westphal averaged 20 points or more in five seasons with the Phoenix Suns before he was traded to the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Suit by Deaf Wrestler
description: A 21-year-old student at Longmeadow (Mass.) High School filed a Federal class-action suit against state athletic regulations that bar anyone older than 19 from interscholastic competition.

title: Helpful Hardware; SPOT LIGHTING SOURCES
description: DIRECT lighting over a work area is a must, and lighting speciality shops and the lighting departments in department stores carry the wherewithal to provide spot illumination.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ASTROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
NICARAGUA ARMS CALLED PERIL TO AREA
description: The Reagan Administration is portraying Nicaragua as a serious threat to Central America because of a military buildup directed by Cuba and the Soviet Union.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT OF SENATE COMMITTEE ON CASEY INQUIRY
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a document entitled ''Report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence on the Casey Inquiry,'' issued today after a committee review of the affairs of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence:

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income; the 1981 fiscal yr results were restated to reflect revs reduction and increases in expenses due primarily to reclassification of geologic and other seismic costs

title: Broker Loan Rate Up
description: The United States Trust Company raised its broker loan rate to 13 1/2 percent from 13 1/4 percent, effective yesterday, a bank spokesman said. Broker rates, the charge on loans used to finance stock purchases on credit, now stand between 13 1/2 percent and 14 percent at major banks.

title: SENATORS REJECT PLAN FOR PLACING MX MISSILE IN SILOS
description: The Senate today rebuffed President Reagan on his proposal for deploying MX missiles in existing silos, a key element of the Administration's strategic weapons plan.

title: Which Constitution?
description: President Reagan's radical vision of American federalism is unfolding with alarming clarity. He said the other day that using Federal taxes to help the poorest places and people was a misuse of power. Relinquishing that power will ''take the country back to the Constitution.''

title: U.S. HIGH TECH NEEDS A COMMANDER IN CHIEF
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI OPPOSITION ASSAILS U.S. ACCORD
description: A furious debate over Israel's newly signed strategic agreement with the United States erupted today in Parliament.

title: Magruder Asks Pardon In His Watergate Case
description: Jeb Stuart Magruder, one of the first aides to President Nixon to cooperate with prosecutors in the Watergate scandals, is seeking a Presidential pardon for his subsequent conviction.

title: ALLEN IN DISPUTE ON WHY CLIENTS WEREN'T LISTED
description: One day after Richard V. Allen was cleared of wrongdoing for taking $1,000 from a Japanese magazine, he was embroiled today in a dispute with White House lawyers.

title: Allan Keller, 77, City Editor Of World-Telegram and Sun
description: Allan Keller, a writer and former city editor of The New York World-Telegram and The Sun, died Nov. 24 at Mount Carmel Hospital in Columbus, Ohio. He was 77 years old and had recently lived in Tuppers Plains, Ohio.

title: Packard Layoffs
description: The Packard Electric Company, a major supplier of electrical components to the automotive industry, said that it will indefinitely lay off 1,700 to 1,800 hourly workers at its plant here on Jan. 4. A Packard spokesman said that the company will also cut its staff of 2,500 salaried employees by 7 percent on Dec. 31. The personnel cuts in Warren are being accompanied by similar cutbacks of employees at Packard's Mississippi and Mexico facilities, the company said.

title: SONY, MATSUSHITA REALIGN U.S. UNITS
description: Undaunted by economic conditions in the United States, the Sony Corporation of America and the Matsushita Electric Corporation of America have both announced reorganization plans in anticipation of rapid growth.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Associated Dry Goods Corp. has appointed Leonard H. Levey president and chief executive officer of its Sibley, Lindsay & Curr division.

title: Hearst Newsreel Files Are Donated to U.C.L.A.
description: The Hearst Corporation yesterday donated its $62 million newsreel film library, said to be the world's last great privately owned film archives, to the College of Fine Arts of the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Ford Aerospace
description: The Ford Motor Company said that its Ford Motor Company said that its Ford Aerospace and Communications Corporation subsidiary had been awarded a $125 million contract to continue operating the Air Force Satellite Control Facility's network of tracking stations. Ford Aerospace has been supporting the Air Force Satellite Control Facility since 1957 through a unit in Sunnyvale, Calif. The facility controls six remote tracking stations, in California, New Hampshire, Hawaii, Greenland, Guam and the Indian Ocean, plus a British-operated ground station in England.

title: MUSIC: COMPOSERS HAIL THEIR OWN THOMSON
description: VIRGIL THOMSON has received a plethora of 85th-birthday tributes in recent weeks, and he received another Monday night in Alice Tully Hall, with the first program this season by the American Composers Orchestra. The entire second half of the concert was devoted to Mr. Thomson's Cello Concerto (1950) and two orchestral tone poems, ''The Seine at Night'' (1948) and ''Sea Piece With Birds'' (1952).

title: THE ARIK-CAP MEMO
description: Israel's Knesset is in an uproar about a m emorandum signed by the U.S. Defense Secretary, Caspar (Cap) W einberger, and Defense Minister Ariel (Arik) Sharon.

title: 7 Japanese Boats Missing
description: Seven ships and small fishing verssels with 40 crew members were reported scuttled or missing today during severe storms, maritime officials reported. One fisherman was reported dead and at least 16 others were reported missing.

title: Books of the Times
description: By John Leonard FUNERAL GAMES. By Mary Renault. 335 pages. Pantheon. $14.50.

title: Lexicon
description: Washington continually generates new words to express old ideas. Here are some examples of the parlance currently circulating in the capital:

title: AMERICAN MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HIGH COURT RULES IN LABOR'S FAVOR
description: The Supreme Court handed a significant victory to organized labor today, ruling that employees do not lose the protections of Federal labor law simply because their jobs give them access to information that their employers consider confidential.

title: INNOVATIVE BUILDING TO HOUSE ART COLLECTION
description: Renzo Piano, the Italian-born architect, says he has gone back to a basic problem in designing the building that will house the internationally renowned art collection of Dominique de Menil. He says he has ''reinvented architecture'' in fashioning a lighting system.

title: CARESSA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss...C-After $1.3 million writeoff and reserve for Don Sophisticates, a manufacturer of women's apparel operating under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code

title: New U.S. Envoy Hails Ties With the French
description: The new United States Ambassador to France, Evan G. Galbraith, presented his credentials to President Francois Mitterrand today at Elysee Palace.

title: Trainer Tells of Efforts To Save Hugable Tom
description: David Jacobson, a 24-year-old trainer who is accused of neglecting and mistreating a terminally ill gelding, Hugable Tom, testified yesterday that he had refused for seven days to humanely destroy the horse because he disagreed with a veterinarian's recommendation. The horse was destroyed last Sept. 28.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1981; The Economy
description: A free trade zone in international banking opens in New York today, and many bankers and state officials predict that the zones will make the city indisputably the world's foremost international financial center. Hundreds of billions of dollars now held by banks overseas are expected to return to New York, and officials predicted that thousands of jobs will be created. (A1.)

title: PRENATAL TEST FOR A GENETIC DISORDER IS FOUND
description: New York State health researchers announced yesterday that they had developed a prenatal test to identify a genetic disorder linked to a form of mental retardation that most often affects males. However, the applicability of the method remains uncertain.

title: To Report a Hazard, Telephone 267-9800
description: The Department of Sanitation said trash and garbage pileups that create a health or fire hazard should be reported through a special telephone number, 267-9800.

title: AND NOW , A CARTEL FOR NATURAL GAS
description: To the Editor:

title: CLARINET RECITAL: GENE COLLERD
description: GENE COLLERD, a clarinetist who teaches at the University of Illinois in Chicago, came to Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night for his second New York appearance, having made his debut here in 1979. Barbara Gorgol was the assisting pianist.

title: Boy Lost After Killings Found Unhurt in Miami
description: A 13-month-old boy, missing since his parents and four others found slain at his home Saturday, was found unharmed near a trash bin at a suburban shopping mall today after a relative received an anonymous tip from Colombia.

title: Technology; Measuring the 'Cutting Edge'
description: TO hear executives talk, the ''cutting edge'' of technology in most industries must be very crowded. One reason so many companies can claim this position may be that their audiences are generally too polite to laugh. Another explanation could be that the executives doing the talking do not know any better.

title: BAKER SEES TAX RISE BID IN '82
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today that he expected President Reagan to ask Congress next year for selective tax increases including some tightening of the controversial business-leasing tax breaks enacted in 1981.

title: ABC BUYS 30% OF U.P.I.'S TV NEWS
description: ABC News has purchased 30 percent of United Press International Television News, Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, announced yesterday. He said the purchase was ''a logical step in our very productive association with Upitn.''

title: 'DEPRESSION QUILTS': A RENEWED INTEREST
description: ''SECOND Annual Show and Sale of 115 Superb Handmade American Patchwork Quilts - from $19.98 to $64.54'' - so read a Macy's ad in The New York Times on May 1, 1938.

title: Bobby Jones is Often a Star but Always a Replacement for Jets
description: The Jet player defenses fear most, Wesley Walker, remained sidelined today with a calf injury. So once again, Bobby Jones trotted out as the split end.

title: Going Out Guide
description: CELLO FELLOW

title: Notes on People; United Press International THE CIRCUS COMES TO THE POPE
description: Pope John Paul II watching clowns box with a kangaroo at the end of yesterday's general audience at the Vatican. Members of Italy's Orfei Circus put on a 20-minute show for the Pontiff.

title: Golf's Fastest Round
description: In Anaheim, Calif., Steve Scott, the American record-holder in the mile and 1,500-meter run, shot a 92 in playing what is being called the fastest round of golf in history. Using only two clubs, Scott played the 6,025-yard, par-71 H.G. Miller Golf Course in 29 minutes 33.05 seconds, according to the course manager, Frank Pepito, who said that Scott was timed by two stopwatches and also clocked by Pepito.

title: Youth Held in Coast Slaying
description: A 19-year-old security guard has been charged with murdering Phillip Frandson, dean of the University of California at Los Angeles. Gregory L. Griffin of Compton pleaded not guilty at his arraignment Tuesday in Municipal Court and is being held without bail. The body of Mr. Frandson, who had been strangled, was found in his Hollywood Hills home Sept. 10.

title: FINAL REPORT FINDS CASEY 'INATTENTIVE' BUT NOT 'UNFIT' FOR C.I.A. JOB
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence released a final report today finding that William J. Casey had been ''at minimum inattentive to detail'' in complying with Government financial disclosure requirements but concluding that he was not ''unfit'' to be Director of Central Intelligence.

title: JAPAN SAID TO INFILTRATE CONSUMER GROUP
description: A few years ago, it was a struggling little public interest group seeking to promote the concept of free trade. Now, with its membership rolls swollen by the American employees of the Japanese automobile industry, Consumers for World Trade finds itself both increasingly influential -and controversial - with one United States Senator terming its activities ''an underhanded and dishonorable way for the Japanese to try to influence public opinion.''

title: No Headline
description: U.S. to Push for Conviction Of Salvadoran Killers of Nuns

title: Notes on People; Honor to Editor
description: The Society of the Silurians, an organization of veteran New York newspaper professionals, will give its 25-year News Achievement Award tonight to A. M. Rosenthal, the executive editor of The New York Times.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $100,187 for the qr and $181,487 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $161,000 for the qr and $323,000 for the 6 mos

title: Afghans Accused of Attacks
description: Two Afghan helicopter gunships crossed the Pakistani border and strafed a village, a frontier post and buses today, killing five people and wounding three, the Foreign Ministry said. It said a strong protest was filed.

title: MCRAE CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary gain of $353,000 from insurance proceeds...C-After an extraordinary gain of $1,183,700

title: 800 More Layoffs Planned by Deere
description: Deere & Company, a large manufacturer of farm equipment, diesel engines, transmissions and other major components for tractors and construction equipment, said it will place 800 more employees on indefinite layoff in the next four months as it reduces production of large farm tractors beginning in February.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Dorothy Johnson, 28 years old, of Far Rockaway, Queens, was fatally stabbed at 4 P.M. yesterday in the lobby of the building in which she worked by a man who first presented her with a bouquet of flowers. The assailant, who fled, was believed to be the victim's estranged husband. ... Five firemen were slightly injured at 8 A.M. when their fire truck skidded on the wet pavement and rammed into the pillar of an elevated subway at 86th Street and 21st Avenue, Brooklyn. ... The body of an unidentified woman was found at 1:30 P.M. in a garbage bag behind a private home at 164-22 78th Avenue in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens.

title: HUNGARY BUILDS LIVELY ECONOMY ON WEST'S IDEAS
description: At Vorosmarty's coffee shop, elegantly dressed shoppers, taking a midmorning break, were choosing from 15 kinds of chocolate cake on the little gold tables.

title: SAN FRANCISCO DEDICATES $126 MILLION CONVENTION CENTER IN MIDST OF A SLUM
description: City officials opened the new George Moscone Convention Center today, dedicating the $126 million structure to the further glory of the tourist business.

title: Amcon Names Head
description: Stephen R. Petschek, 50, whose career has spanned the law and investment banking, is moving into the natural resources business when he becomes president and chief financial officer on Jan. 1 of the Amcon Group. As president, he succeeds Robert L. Barbanell, 51, who resigned last September and is now a senior vice president of the Bankers Trust Company.

title: AGREEMENT REPORTED ON STOPGAP MEASURE FOR U.S. SPENDING
description: Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, said today that White House officials and Congressional aides had reached a tentative agreement on a new stopgap financing measure that would take effect after the present bill expires Dec. 15.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in October

title: A FREE-TRADE ZONE FOR BANKS OPENING IN NEW YORK TODAY
description: A free-trade zone in international banking will open in New York today, and many bankers and state officials say the move will make the city indisputably the world's foremost international financial center.

title: FOR BIG-STORE SHOPPERS, DIVERSITY AND BARGAINS
description: ESPECIALLY at Christmas, it seems, there's no beating the department stores for sheer diversity of merchandise. And this year, the sluggish economy has provided home fureconomy has provided home furnishings shoppers with an extra boon - chairs and blankets, china and glassware, pots and pans, even sofas and dining tables, are even sofas and dining tables, are on sale - at prices that even the most prudent homemakers will be hard-pressed to resist.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. Protests to Soviet In Berlin Espionage
description: The United States military government in West Berlin said today that it had protested to the Soviet Union about what it said was an espionage affair involving a prominent Soviet diplomat in East Berlin.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 3, 1981
description: A Warsaw sit-in ended peacefully as armed policemen seized the firefighters' academy from about 300 cadets demanding more autonomy. The policemen staged a helicopter assault on the building and removed the demonstrators without bloodshed. As bystanders jeered, the cadets were driven off in buses and freed at rail stations. (Page A1, Column 1.) Hungary is the economic showcase of the Communist world, with plenty of goods in the shops. Such abundance is goods in the shops. Such abundance is not found in other countries of Eastern Europe. Hungary has prospered with the policies of Janos Kadar, the nation's leader since the 1956 uprising. His strategy is to lean toward the West in economic matters while supporting Moscow in foreign policy. (A1:2.)

title: TV: A PARAPLEGIC PILOT
description: LAST year, a television movie called ''Skyward'' featured Bette Davis training a young paraplegic girl how to pilot a plane. The girl was played, quite affectingly, by Suzy Gilstrap, herself a paraplegic. Now, on NBC tonight at 8, the story of 16-year-old Julie Ward is being continued - some observers might say milked further - in ''Skyward Christmas.'' Ron Howard and Anson Williams, the executive producers, devised the story. Vincent McEveety directed.

title: SCHMIDT WILL MEET HONECKER IN EAST GERMANY NEXT WEEK
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Erich Honecker, the East German leader, will meet in East Germany next week, a Bonn Government spokesman said today.

title: U.S. SHALE LEASING MAY BE LIBERALIZED
description: The Senate Energy Committee began to draft legislation today that would substantially expand the amount of Federal land available for the mining and processing of oil shale.

title: PEKING QUESTIONS MAO'S VIEWS ON ROLE OF THE ARTS
description: The Chinese Communist Party has broadened the criticism of Mao Zedong that it voiced last summer to take fresh issue with his long inviolate pronouncements on literature and the arts.

title: Champion Rating Cut
description: The Standard and Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it had cut its rating on the Champion Spark Plug Company's 5 7/8 percent sinking fund debentures due 1992 to AA from AA. It said that it was leaving Champion's commercial paper rating unchanged at A1+. The corporate rating organization said that the change reflected Champion's declining level of profitability, which has resulted partly from attempts at diversification and from declines in the auto industry.

title: Herman's Appoints President
description: With the abolition of the jewelry and sporting goods division of W.R. Grace & Company's retail group, John L. Sisk, 53, who had been deputy group executive for the division, has been named president of Herman's World of Sporting Goods. The appointment follows the resignation of Bernard A. Cohen, 39, to become president and chief operating officer of the United States division of Consumer Distributing Company Ltd.

title: Dr. Jascalevich Settles A Malpractice Lawsuit
description: Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich has agreed to pay $150,000 to a Jersey City woman to settle a malpractice suit. The surgeon was acquitted in 1978 of charges that he murdered three hospital patients by injecting them with the muscular relaxant curare.

title: PENNY-WISDOM FOR THE ENVIRONMENT'S BENEFIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; How to Limit Stock Losses
description: WITH the economy sliding and discouraging new statistics arriving almost every day, it is entirely possible that the stock market will ease again, especially now that share prices generally are up 8 percent from the summer lows.

title: U.S. PLANS HIGH-LEVEL TALKS WITH ANGOLAN REBEL
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to hold high-level talks with Jonas M. Savimbi, the leader of Angola's chief insurgent group, despite expected criticism from African nations, State Department officials said today.

title: MEYER VS. MEYER: FATHER DOES BEST
description: They met at his sister's for Thanksgiving, halfway between Tommy Meyer's house in Oak Park and his father's house in Arlington Heights.

title: No Headline
description: SPURS DOWN 76ers

title: No Headline
description: Times's Equipment and Files Found After Theft in Houston

title: WHITE HOUSE UNABLE TO IDENTIFY LAWYER SAID TO HAVE ADVISED ALLEN
description: The White House said today that it had not been able to identify the White House lawyer who, according to Richard V. Allen, advised him that his financial disclosure form did not have to list clients who paid him more than $5,000 a year.

title: Norton Acquiring Chemplast Inc.
description: The Norton Company will acquire Chemplast Inc., a plastics processor based in Wayne, N.J., for $22.8 million in stock, the two companies announced.

title: FED DROPS DISCOUNT RATE TO 12%
description: The Federal Reserve Board today cut its discount rate to 12 percent from 13 percent, confirming a drop in interest rates as the economy continues to decline.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $177,000 for the qr and $360,000 for the 9 mos and $16,716 gain for the qr from the sale of real estate...C-Including tax credits of $66,000 for the qr and $150,000 for the 9 mos

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared in June 1981

title: Bid to Delay Dumping Suit
description: President Reagan on Friday will personally urge major domestic steelmakers to delay their plans to file charges with the Government that foreign steelmakers are selling steel here at cut-rate prices, a Commerce Department official said today.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ARMS CONTROL JOB TACKLED WITH ZEST
description: Last spring, when Eugene V. Rostow, the former Yale law professor and dean, was being asked to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, he had a tempting, competing offer to teach in England. But he took the Washington job, telling friends: ''The problems are insoluble. I'll be boiled in oil many times. But as a New England Puritan Jew, I find this irresistible.''

title: Clippers 113, Mavericks 111
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Jerome Whitehead scored 18 of his 20 points in the second half as San Diego handed Dallas its eighth consecutive road defeat.

title: WALDHEIM MOVES TO END DEADLOCK
description: In a move to break a deadlock in the Security Council on the election of a Secretary General, Kurt Waldheim said today that he would not compete in any further ballots for the position. But aides to Mr. Waldheim made it clear that he had not abandoned his hopes of being re-elected.

title: Cuts Reconsidered In Westchester
description: The budget committee of the Westchester Board of Legislators had second thoughts about helping the county's 33 daycare centers.

title: PLESSEY CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: B-Includes losses from minority interests of $982,000 for the qr and $1,839,000 for the 6 mos...C-Includes losses from minority interests of $830,000 for the qr and $1,350,000 for the 6 mos; the 1981 qr and 6 mos comprised of 13 weeks and 26 weeks respectively and the 1980 periods comprised of 14 weeks and 27 weeks; the translation from pounds sterling into dollars is at the rate of $1.86 to the pound the approximate rate on Oct 2; the 1980 fiscal period results have been restate to reflect the exchange rate of $1.86 to the pound

title: G.E. Pact Set in Japan
description: The General Electric Company announced yesterday that it had signed a contract worth more than $500 million with the Tokyo Electric Power Company to build a huge electric power plant on a landfill in Tokyo Bay.

title: Neal Boenzi Sidewalk Superintendents at Battery Park
description: City Mayor Koch and Governor Carey, their ears protected from the noise of piledrivers, watched construction yesterday at groundbreaking for the complex's commercial center. Mr. Carey's wife, Evangeline, is between them; Comptroller Edward V. Regan is at left. Four office buildings and a shopping plaza are planned for the site.

title: SALVADORAN PLAN SAID TO GAIN FAVOR
description: A United States official said today that support for El Salvador's plans to hold elections next spring is growing in the Americas.

title: Bridge: How to Confuse Defender: Lead an Unexpected Card
description: The order in which a declarer plays winning cards is often irrelevant. But even when it is irrelevant to him, it may have a considerable impact on the defense. A skillful declarer can sometimes contrive the play to give a defender a problem.

title: REAGAN'S CAPITOL LIAISON TAKES BERMUDA POST
description: Max L. Friedersdorf resigned today as assistant to the President for legislative affairs, becoming the first member of President Reagan's senior staff to leave the White House for another job.

title: WHITE HOUSE AGING PARLEY ADOPTS AGENDA FOR DECADE
description: After four days of sharp political infighting, the White House Conference on Aging closed on a relatively peaceful note today by adopting, without serious dissent, a long agenda of recommendations for the next decade.

title: Fed Avoids Aiding The Dollar
description: In keeping with the Reagan Administration's policy of not intervening in the foreign exchange markets unless they are exceptionally disorderly, the United States did not enter the foreign exchange markets for its own account in August, September or October, according to a report released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: B-There are no yr-ago figures because the company went public in Sept 1981...C-Including tax credit

title: U.S. GETS GOOD HEALTH REPORT
description: Americans are getting healthier and living longer, with fewer deaths from heart attack and stroke and a lower infant mortality rate pacing the improvement, the Government reported today.

title: Vintage Plane Sale
description: Vintage automobiles and airplanes from the Wings and Wheels Museum in Orlando, Fla., which is housed in a hangar at Orlando International Airport, will be auctioned there Sunday by Christie's of New York. A Sopwith Camel, the World War I British single-seater fighter plane, is expected to command a six-figure price. Also included are a 1934 Packard five-passenger dual-cowl Phaeton, which may sell for as much as $250,000; a 1945 Heinkel He.111, the World War II Luftwaffe medium bomber, up to $150,000, and a 1930 Duesenberg fivepassenger Berline, up to $150,000.

title: ALTEX OIL reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition

title: VIENNA TRAIN TAKES POLES TO NEW LIFE
description: The Chopin Express leaves for Vienna every day at 5:56 P.M., and, the conductor says, it is ''usually full in one direction - going.''

title: DRAMA LEAGUE AWARDS GIVEN TO 3 PLAYWRIGHTS
description: The Drama League of New York awarded a grant totaling $1,000 to three members of the National New Dramatists' program at the league's annual luncheon at Sardi's restaurant yesterday.

title: Illinois Ham Operator Relays Distress Call From California
description: A ham radio operator in Illinois picked up a citizens' band distress call 1,200 miles away in Lone Pine, enabling the rescue of four people stranded in a snowbound mountain pass.

title: The Shroud of Turin
description: Is the shroud of Turin the real burial cloth of Christ? The relic, which first appeared about 1350 and is now kept in the Cathedral of Turin, is fast becoming a wonder of this scientific age. There are regular reports, the latest in Harper's, about experts who have used the most sophisticated instruments to examine the material and its striking full-length back-and-front image of a crucified man. The scientists say they can neither prove the shroud to be a forgery nor account for how it was made, thus leaving the strong impression that it may be the real thing.

title: PICKING CHRISTMAS TREES STRAIGHT FROM THE FARM
description: Christmas-tree farms in nearby parts of New York State, New Jersey and Connecticut are ready for the annual visit of Americans nostalgic for an old-fashioned trip into the countryside to choose and cut their own trees for the holiday season.

title: LIBYA CASE: 'PRETTY BIG' FOR FT. COLLINS
description: At 7:32 P.M. on Oct. 14, 1980, the dispatcher at the Fort Collins Police Department received a call reporting a family disturbance at an apartment on South Shields Street, not far from the campus of Colorado State University.

title: New Kentucky Home?
description: There are mounting indications that Howard Schnellenberger, who has put together a winning football program as coach at the University of Miami, may be moving to Kentucky, his alma mater, to fill the vacancy created by last week's dismissal of Coach Fran Curci. Schnellenberger, who has just led the Hurricanes to a 9-2 season (they were 9-3 last year), has been interviewed by a screening committee at Kentucky and visited the university's president, Otis Singletary.

title: Suns 137, Nuggets 109
description: PHOENIX (AP) - Larry Nance scored 29 points and Truck Robinson added 27 as Phoenix won its fifth straight game.

title: WERBLIN ANGERED
description: The Knicks played so poorly last night in a 114-88 trouncing by the Washington Bullets that many in the crowd of 8,350 - the smallest turnout of the season at Madison Square Garden - left early. Sonny Werblin, however, stayed around.

title: IPM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Harvey L. Bilker Fire Damages Jersey Theme Park
description: Firemen battling a blaze yesterday in a game room of the arcade at the Great Adventure park in Jackson Township, N.J. The fire, believed to have been started by a heater, caused an estimated $700,000 in damage. There were no injuries. The park has been closed to the public since Oct. 25.

title: Ford Truck Plan
description: The Ford Motor Company said that it planned to spend about $2 billion between now and 1985 on developing new trucks. Ford is introducing a new compact pickup called ''Ranger,'' which it said will be in full production early next year.

title: ROCK: PRINCE AT PALLADIUM
description: based funk-rock star who appeared at the Palladium on Wednesday, appears to have reached a delicate crossroads in his career. Having achieved notoriety for his racy songs and flamboyantly erotic performing style, Prince has embraced controversy for its own sake.

title: President of Pratt & Lambert
description: Joseph J. Castiglia, 47, has been appointed president of Pratt & Lambert, effective March 1, 1982. He will succeed Henry E. Jones, 62, who will retire and become a consultant to the company.

title: GOLDIN SEEKING LIMIT ON HIRING CITY EMPLOYEES
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin called yesterday for a sharp slowdown in the hiring of New York City government employees to avoid tax increases that he said could hurt the city's economy.

title: THE RENEWAL OF BROOKLYN BROWNSTONES
description: It should not have been a surprise that the adjoining communities of Fort Greene and Clinton Hill in Brooklyn would one day be the new frontier for ''brownstoners'' with a pioneering spirit.

title: Bottoms's Brother to Take 'Fifth' Lead
description: Joseph Bottoms will take over from his brother Timothy the starring role in Lanford Wilson's hit play ''Fifth of July'' at the New Apollo Theater, probably on Dec. 15, according to a spokesman for the production.

title: U.S. REBUFFS CAMBODIAN ON ARMS
description: The leader of Cambodia's major non-Communist insurgent group met with State Department officials today in another effort to gain American financial and military help for his group's activities against the Vietnemese-backed Government in Phnom Penh.

title: Defense Rests In Margiotta Case
description: Lawyers for Joseph M. Margiotta rested the defense Thursday after calling 10 character witnesses at the Nassau Republican leader's retrial on fraud and extortion charges.

title: Dow Climbs 1.24; Trading Is Slow
description: The stock market ended practically unchanged yesterday in continued slow trading with some of the reported takeover candidates scoring the biggest gains.

title: Around the Nation; Ski-Mask Rapist Suspect Said to Admit 77 Crimes
description: A man suspected of being Louisiana's skimask rapist has confessed at least 77 crimes in 12 states, possibly including a sexual attack in Texas for which another man was convicted, the police said today.

title: BEATTY'S 'REDS,' WITH DIANE KEATON
description: THE Scott Joplin ragtime tune behind the opening credits of Warren Beatty's ''Reds'' recalls the sounds of pre-World War I America as they were heard then, when Greenwich Village was still a new Bohemia, free love was a way of life for the adventurous, new ideas were shaping the arts, and radical politics were more a matter of theory than practice. As the ragtime music fades out, voices fade in, contemporary voices that form a bridge to the past. ''Was that in 1917 or 1913?'' asks one. ''I'm beginning to forget.'' ''You know,'' another voice acknowledges, ''things go and come back.'' ''Were they Socialists?''

title: Union Rejects A.M.C. Plan
description: United Automobile Workers representatives from four Jeep Corporation plants today rejected a proposal from Jeep's parent company, the American Motors Corporation, that employees invest 10 percent of their wages and benefits in the company.

title: BAKER DROP PLAN ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., today dropped his plan, only one day old, to seek a quick Senate vote on a 10-year extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: No Headline
description: WINGS, WITH 3-GOAL 3D, SET BACK CANADIANS, 4-3

title: energywatch
description: NOV. 27, 1981 Crude oil stocks fell to 368.9 million barrels, down 3.2 million.

title: RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE CONFERENCE
description: Following is a summary of the major recommendations approved by the 1981 White House Conference on Aging, which closed here today: Social Security

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BALANCING CITIZEN'S NEED TO KNOW AND GOVERNMENT'S NEED TO KEEP SECRETS
description: How much is a citizen entitled to know about how the Federal Government works? Which of its records may the Government justifiably keep secret?

title: F.C.C. Extends Cereal Case Limit
description: The Federal Trade Commission ordered today that its nine-year antitrust case against the nation's principal cereal makers remain open for at least 15 more days to give the commissioners time to decide whether to put the case on their docket for review.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1981
description: International Plans for the Sinai peacekeeping force were pressed by the United States and Israel. They issued a joint statement in Washington governing participation in the projected force that American officials said should clear the way for four Western European nations to take part. But final Israeli acceptance of the formula appeared to be in doubt. (Page A1, Column 1.) A move to break a U.N. stalemate was initiated by Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, who said he would not compete in further Security Council voting on his post. The tactic was designed to introduce new candidates for consideration. If none is successful, aides to the Austrian diplomat said, he will be receptive to an offer to remain when his current term expires. (A1:2.)

title: Around the Nation; Two Sailors Die as Cable Snaps in Carrier Landing
description: An arresting cable snapped as a Navy light attack bomber attempted to land on the flight deck of the carrier U.S.S. John F. Kennedy today, killing two sailors on the deck and injuring three others.

title: SAUDIS FORGE FUTURE FROM AN EVER-PRESENT PAST
description: The chief administrator of Riyadh, a sprawling construction site of glistening offices and hotels, halfconnected highway overpasses, cranes and bulldozers, settled into his chair for his most important task of the day.

title: A POLICY OR $1,000?
description: Reporting from Washington on the latest in the Richard V. Allen affair, a French TV commentator called it an example of the ''American syndrome.''

title: CISKEI 'HOMELAND' DECLARED A SEPARATE NATION
description: A tribal homeland called Ciskei, which has some of the worst rates of unemployment and malnutrition in South Africa, was proclaimed independent early today with a 101-gun salute.

title: TURKISH EX-PREMIER IS IN JAIL
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit entered an Ankara prison today to serve a four-month jail sentence imposed by a military court for his defiance of a ban on political statements.

title: Lemon Is Summoned
description: Bob Lemon, the Yankee manager in waiting - he's waiting to find out if he will continue to be the Yankee manager - said he planned to meet with George Steinbrenner in Tampa, Fla., early next week. ''I'll stop there on my way to Hollywood for the winter meetings,'' Lemon said from his home in Long Beach, Calif. Steinbrenner, the team's principal owner, has said since the end of the World Series that he would have to meet with Lemon before deciding whether he would retain him.

title: C. TERENCE CLYNE, AD CREATOR
description: C. Terence Clyne, a retired advertising agency executive who participated in the development of radio and television advertising, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: RUTGERS UPSETS U.C.L.A. BY 57-54
description: A Rutgers guard who had not played this season until the frantic ending tonight, and a new college basketball rule advocated by the former U.C.L.A. coach John Wooden, helped give Rutgers a startling 57-54 victory over U.C.L.A. in the first college doubleheader at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: PROPERTY TAX BILL IS NOW LAW
description: The State Legislature voted tonight to override Governor Carey's veto of a bill to repeal a 193-year-old law requiring that all property be assessed at full value.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE UNIVERSITY AND THE PUBLIC IN- TEREST. By A. Bartlett Giamatti. 184 pages. Atheneum. $12.95.

title: STAGE: 'KEAN' BY DUMAS, AS REINVENTED BY SARTRE
description: Theater as a subject for theater has fascinated playwrights from Shakespeare to Bulgakov, with two examples now on the New York stage - Ronald Harwood's ''The Dresser'' and Christopher Durang's ''The Actor's Nightmare.'' But there has never been a backstage play quite in a class with ''Kean.'' A cross-century collaboration between two eminent French authors, Alexandre Dumas and Jean-Paul Sartre, ''Kean'' is a romance redolent with greasepaint and a philosophical dissertation on the art of artifice. Mark Lamos's production at the Hartford Stage Company reminds one that ''Kean'' is a marvelous charade overflowing with the life of the theater.

title: BY THEODORE W. LIBBEY Jr.
description: IGOR STRAVINSKY'S ''L'Histoire du Soldat'' (''The Soldier's Tale'') is one of those pieces everyone talks about but no one performs much. Yet in these days of mixed media, its combination of dance, music and dialogue makes it a natural vehicle for the small ensemble aiming to give audiences an event rather than another concert.

title: A Record Corrected
description: Steve Scott, the American mile record-holder, was given credit recently for playing the fastest round in golf history, but Steve Topping, an American-based editor for the Guinness Book of Records, says it isn't so.

title: People
description: * Arthur Bateman has joined FCB International, a subsidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, as an executive vice president.

title: THE SAUDIS'-AND SENATOR HATCH'S-ERROR ON MIDEAST PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: CAREY CRITICIZES PRESIDENT'S 'DENY SIDE' ECONOMICS
description: Governor Carey charged yesterday that the Reagan Administration was practicing a ''deny side'' brand of economics that poses a threat to the nation.

title: PUBLISHING: FOCUS ON SOUTH AFRICANS
description: SOUTH AFRICA'S system of apartheid, which segregates citizens along racial lines, has given rise to a vast network of censorship rules and regulations with which the nation's writers and publishers must contend. But the system has not yet managed to stifle all literary creativity, and American publishers continue to be attracted to books by South African writers and about the nation itself.

title: BRITISH PETROLEUM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After minority shareholders interest of $215 million for the qr and $748 million for the 9 mos...C-After minority shareholders interest of $134 million for the qr and $574 million for the 9 mos; shr earnings are per American Depositary Shrs

title: Around the Nation; Cries Reportedly Heard Near Actress's Yacht
description: A woman who was near Natalie Wood's yacht the night the actress drowned says she heard a female voice screaming for help and then heard someone say, ''We're coming to get you.''

title: Required Reading; Ships of States
description: Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas; Senator John Tower, Republican of Texas, and Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, in a Senate debate about appropriations for the refurbishing of two battleships, the New Jersey and the Iowa, Nov. 30:

title: ARMY ON A REVERSE MARCH IN FOOTBALL
description: Carl Ullrich hasn't said goodbye to anyone for a week. Instead, when visitors leave his office at the United States Military Academy, where he is the director of athletics, Ullrich looks them in the eye, tightens his firm handshake and slowly utters two words: Beat Navy.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World

title: 2 'Immortals'
description: Leonard Bernstein, the composer, and Arthur Schlesinger Jr., the historian, have been elected to the American Academy of Arts and Letters.

title: COMPUTER USAGE CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including $257,000 extraordinary credit

title: PHILIP HARRIS, HEADED S. KLEIN
description: Philip S. Harris, former president of S. Klein Department Stores Inc., died Wednesday in Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived. He was 71 years old.

title: Scovill Plans Loss
description: In a move designed to consolidate its operations, Scovill Inc., of Waterbury, Conn., said it would take a $35 million loss in the fourth quarter to sell some operations. William F. Andrews, company's chairman, said Scovill would create a reserve fund of $50 million as part of its plan. ''In 1982 we are planning to sell Ajax Hardware, Markel Electric, Lightcraft Lighting, Namm & Singer buttons, our sewing notions operation in Canada, our plastic zipper business and our Cox Line Electrical box business,'' he said.

title: REGAN BIDS WALL ST. BACK BANK ROLE IN SECURITIES
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan urged Wall Street leaders today to support a Reagan Administration proposal that would ease the entry of banks into the securities industry. The Regan suggestion drew cautious optimism from the heads of large brokerage firms and skepticism from many small regional firms.

title: Marriott Plans To Buy Host
description: The Marriott Corporation, the hotelrestaurant chain, said it had agreed to buy Host International Inc., a hotel and food services operator, in a deal worth some $120 million.

title: 48 Leftists Seized in Turkey
description: The police said today that they had arrested 48 leftists and charged them with involvement in the killing of 30 people. The authorities said the slayings took place before the military seized power 15 months ago.

title: CONTENDERS TO MEET PRETENDERS IN N.F.L.
description: What kind of a game are the Seattle Seahawks prepared to play against the Jets? And what of the Baltimore Colts against Dallas, the Washington Redskins against Philadelphia or the New England Patriots against Miami?

title: TOMLINSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SENATORS REJECT PLAN TO DROP B-1
description: After a long and often angry debate, the Senate tonight rejected a proposal to delete funds for the controversial B-1 bomber from the 1982 military appropriations bill. The vote was 66 to 28.

title: A TURNAROUND FOR CONRAIL
description: It was something out of the ''Perils of Pauline.'' There was Drew Lewis, the Secretary of Transportation, saying that time had run out for the loss-riddled Consolidated Rail Corporation, that it should be split up and sold piecemeal.

title: LET PARK RANGERS DO THE HUNTING
description: To the Editor:

title: Paton Lewis, 81, Dies; Builder of Model Ships
description: Paton Lewis, a builder of model trains and ships whose work is on display in the Smithsonian Institution, Mystic Seaport and many other museums and historical centers, died Tuesday in Boynton Beach, Fla., where he made his home after moving from Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: ART: CHINESE PAINITNG FROM EIGHT DYNASTIES
description: AMONG the important collections of Asian art to be found in American museums, two of the finest are those of the Cleveland Museum of Art and the Nelson Gallery-Atkins Museum in Kansas City. It was therefore something of an event last year when these two great institutions joined in mounting a major exhibition of their combined holdings in the masterworks of Chinese painting.

title: Auto Output Down 36.3%
description: Domestic auto production this week is 91,125, a drop of 36.3 percent from 142,988 produced in the comparable 1980 week, an industry journal reported today.

title: TERMS FOR JOINING MIDEAST FORCE SET BY ISRAEL AND U.S.
description: The United States and Israel issued a joint statement today concerning participation by four Western European nations in the projected Sinai peacekeeping force. American officials said the statement should clear the way for the European nations to take part.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * BarclaysAmerican Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $75 million of two-year extendable notes.

title: The New York Times/Fred R. Conrad; Room at the Top of the Waldorf for Uncollected Trash
description: Plastic bags of trash were stacked on the roof of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to keep the building clear of refuse. No progress was reported in the strike by teamsters against private carting companies.

title: America's Prisoners of Paralysis
description: Winter's coming in the Caribbean: the flow of little boats from Haiti is slowing almost to a halt. The currents and high seas make the 800-mile voyage too dangerous even for desperate people. In other words, some breathing space.

title: START OF TRIAL IN FIRE AT STOUFFER'S TO BE SET TODAY, ON ANNIVERSARY
description: Both sides in the Stouffer's arson-murder case will go before a State Supreme Court judge here Friday to set a date for the start of trial.

title: Fight at Pennsylvania Prison
description: A fight involving members of the radical group Move at Holmesburg Prison left at least three persons injured today, the authorities said. An officer said at least two Move members and a prison guard had been taken to hospitals.

title: Around the Nation; Reagan Orders Mandel Released From Prison
description: President Reagan commuted the prison sentence of former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland today and ordered him set free on Dec. 20, five months before he was due to be paroled.

title: HAMMER OFFERS $1 MILLION PRIZE FOR CANCER CURE
description: Armand Hammer, the industrialist, in a new effort to encourage cancer research, announced plans yesterday to award a $1 million prize to the scientist who finds a cure for some form of cancer in the next decade. Another $1 million in grants would be given to others who make significant gains in cancer studies.

title: Conference Board Head Is Selected
