description: At the Conference Board, the international nonprofit research organization that is financed by business, James T. Mills, a 58-yearold lawyer and businessman, has been elected to the full-time salaried position of president and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Kenneth A. Randall, 54, who has resigned.

title: AMERICAN METALS SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
HESS-MOBIL OFFER FOR MARATHON SEEN
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation, marketer of Hess-brand gasoline on the East Coast, will join with the Mobil Corporation in making a new takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company, industry sources said yesterday.

title: FEDERAL PROSECUTOR, DISMISSED ON COAST, IS REINSTATED TO POST
description: The Justice Department today reinstated Assistant United States Attorney Robert M. Smith, who contended that he had been removed from his job for political reasons.

title: Coaches Ousted Over Hazing Rite
description: The head coach and two assistant coaches of a high school soccer team have been dismissed because they allowed seniors to abuse freshmen physically in a hazing rite, officials of the school district said.

title: STATEMENT ON SINAI UNIT
description: Following is the text of the joint United States-Israeli statement on European participation in the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force as issued today by the State Department:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amcon Group Inc. said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that at the close of business on Nov.30 it owned 5,725,500 common shares of Newmont Mining Corp., or about 21 percent of the outstanding shares of the company.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Robbers shot and killed 28-year-old David Davidson during an attempted holdup of his father's self-service laundry at 1203 Bushwick Avenue in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn shortly after noon. Mr. Davidson's father, Haywood, grappled with one of the gunmen, Curtis Brown, 26, of Brooklyn, grabbed his gun and shot him in the leg. A bystander, Miguel Cartagena, 27, was shot in the left hand. ... Two students at Park West High School were shot outside the school on 50th Street near 10th Avenue in Manhattan at 2:45 P.M. during an altercation that started when some youths pelted another group with fruit.

title: Cavs' Coach Dropped
description: Ted Stepien, owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, made it official yesterday by dropping Don Delaney as head coach and retaining him as general manager.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The shr earnings were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock distribution in Oct 1981

title: AUSTRALIA'S DIAMOND DEBATE
description: Already a major producer of opals and sapphires, Australia is apparently about to become a major force in the world diamond business.

title: SAVIN BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $1.5 million loss for the qr and 6 mos from the disposal of operations and tax benefits of $1,230,000 for the qr and $1,907,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net income... D-Including $997,000 tax benefit

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY F.B.I. IS HUNTING TERRORISTS SEEKING TO KILL PRESIDENT
description: The Government has received detailed reports that five terrorists trained in Libya entered the United States last weekend with plans to assassinate President Reagan or other senior Administration officials, according to top Federal law-enforcement officials.

title: Crime and Punishment
description: Digger Phelps, Notre Dame's basketball coach, said he would like to see the National Collegiate Athletic Association impose four-year probation on schools that violate recruiting rules.

title: G.O.P. Aide Is Named Kean's Chief of Staff
description: Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean today appointed Lewis B. Thurston 3d, a top Republican legislative aide and former executive director of the state's Election Law Enforcement Commission, as chief of staff in his administration.

title: Strike Threat At Ford U.K.
description: Trade unions at the Ford Motor Company's British subsidiary threatened today to call a strike early next year after salary talks broke down last night.

title: Secret Service Chief Chosen
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 3 (AP) - John R. Simpson, an employee of the Secret Service for 19 years, was named Wednesday to head the agency, the Treasury Department announced. Mr. Simpson is to replace H. Stuart Knight, who stepped down Monday as director after eight years on the job. Mr. Simpson, 49 years old, is now assistant director for protective operations.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A.T.& T. ASKS CHANGES IN SOME OF ITS CHARGES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company proposed today to increase long-distance rates for certain business services for the second time this year and to reduce long-distance charges for customers who use credit cards.

title: Sports of The Times; The Pistons' New Attraction
description: ONE afternoon in 1975, during his freshman year at St. Joseph's High School, 14-year-old Isiah Lord Thomas 3d, distraught, phoned his mother, Mary. She was at the Chicago church where she worked as a cook and housekeeper.

title: Mike Merrick has plans for a musical and a thriller in '82.
description: NEXT season, Mike Merrick says, he will produce ''Sylvia,'' a musical, and ''House Guest,'' a thriller. Anyone can say he will produce shows, of course; on Broadway, good intentions must be taken at face value. Mr. Merrick, however, is a more active producer than most, and so his good intentions have more face value. ''Sylvia'' has book, music and lyrics - all three - by Gwen Davis and will be directed by Frank Dunlop. Miss Davis is mostly a novelist and screenwriter - her 13th book, ''Marriage,'' was published last month - but the Juilliard School of Music is in her past. Meanwhile, ''House Guest'' by Francis Durbridge is now running in London with a British cast. Mr. Merrick will do it with Americans.

title: PEAVEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Market Place; Mixing Hair Care With Software
description: EDIE ADAMS CUT & CURL is the nation's largest franchiser of hair care salons - and is highly profitable in a field that often breeds failure. The parent company - renamed Cutco Industries at the annual meeting yesterday - is also half-owner of Programs Unlimited, a start-up retailer of computer software whose shares have been among the most active on the over-the-counter market lately.

title: Gas Utility Refund
description: NEWARK (AP) - The South Jersey Gas Company will return $2.5 million to customers over three years under an agreement approved by the state's Board of Public Utilities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aileen Inc. has appointed Steven Matell president and chief executive officer of the Aileen Girl children's wear division.

title: John Houseman Gets Wharton Award
description: John Houseman, the 79-year-old director, actor, producer and drama teacher whose theatrical career has spanned 50 years, was presented yesterday with the Theater Development Fund's second John F. Wharton award of $5,000.

title: COMING UP FROM RANKS IN CONGRESS
description: If you want to see the Congressional chiefs of tomorrow, take a look at the Indians of today. Chances are, many of the men and women now working for senators and representatives will one day be members of Congress themselves.

title: NORTH AMERICAN ROYALTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WARSAW AND UNION TRADE CHARGES
description: In an atmosphere of heightened tension resulting from Wednesday's assault on striking cadets at the Warsaw fire academy, the Government and the independent trade union Solidarity bombarded the public today with a flow of speeches and announcements putting their conflicting views of how to pull their country out of its crisis.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The 1980 results adjusted for 5-for-4 stock split in 1981 and restated to reflect accounting change for inventories to LIFO from FIFO

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think we'll have to look forward to another shutdown of the Federal Government.'' - Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada. (A1:5)

title: Article 117504 -- No Title
description: Voters in this Detroit suburb today approved two tax issues expected to generate $16.4 million for their school district, meaning schools will not close at mid-December, as threatened.

title: Francis T. Hunter, 87; Tennis Star, Executive
description: Francis T. (Frank) Hunter, a onetime Davis Cup player and a member of the Tennis Hall of Fame, died Wednesday in a nursing home in Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Hunter, a retired business executive, was 87 years old.

title: ZOOLOGIST, TEACHER AND ADMINISTRATOR
description: James A. Oliver, director emeritus of the New York Zoological Society and the American Museum of Natural History and a retired director of the New York Aquarium, died Wednesday at Metropolitan Hospital following cardiac arrest. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: OPERA: 3 BY STRAVINSKY AT THE MET
description: THE Metropolitan Opera, which struck oil last season with the imaginatively staged and brilliantly designed triple bill, ''Parade,'' sank its drill in the same place last evening. For a long time it looked as if the result would be a dry hole. The same team that gave us the Satie-Poulenc-Ravel triumph put together a tripledecker this time entitled ''Stravinsky,'' consisting of his ''Sacre du Printemps,'' ''Le Rossignol'' and ''Oedipus Rex.''

title: NOV. 21-30 AUTO SALES DOWN 6.2%
description: Automobile sales by the nation's Big Three manufacturers declined 6.2 percent in the last 10 days of November - almost assuring that the nation's auto industry would once again fail to meet the sales goals it had set for financial recovery.

title: Municipal Priorities, Mayoral Ghosts
description: Each year two Columbia professors, Raymond Horton and Charles Brecher, assemble a volume of essays on the needs of the city in the year to come. Then they organize a conference of dignitaries to discuss them. This year's event, which begins today, has already stirred controversy: Mayor Koch, who considered last year's conference unfair, won't be there, nor will his commissioners.

title: Fonda at His Peak in 'On Golden Pond'
description: AS a successful Broadway play, Ernest Thompson's ''On Golden Pond'' was processed American cheese, smooth, infinitely spreadable and bland, with color added by the actors. The screen version, directed by Mark Rydell from Mr. Thompson's screenplay, is not much different in any superficial way.

title: GELMAN SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Pabst Dissident
description: A dissident stockholder who has threatened a proxy fight to take over the Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's No.4 brewer, has won a court order to obtain a list of the brewery's stockholders. Irwin Jacobs, a former Pabst director who owns 9.5 percent of Pabst's outstanding stock, won a Delaware state court decision ordering Pabst to turn over the names.

title: BALLET: WITH COREOGRAPHY BY BONNEFOUS AND ASHTON
description: THEATRICAL challenges abound in ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' ''Le Rossignol'' and ''Oedipus Rex,'' the works that made up the Metropolitan Opera's Stravinsky bill last night. And two choreographers faced these challenges most gallantly.

title: UNIVERSAL RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
POP: LEE HORWIN AT BALLROOM
description: LEE HORWIN, a veteran of the Ballroom when that cabaret was in SoHo in the 1970's, is singing at the newly opened Ballroom at 253 West 28th Street, where she will be performing only at 9 P.M. through Dec. 13.

title: ART: BOUDIN'S WORLD OF NATURE AT KNOEDLER'S
description: LANDSCAPE and marine paintings were unpopular in pre-Impressionist France, probably because they contained scant reference to the human figure. So Monet was to some extent following convention in disliking Boudin's seascape, which he first saw in a Le Havre frame store where his own early caricatures were on display.

title: Kramer Admonished
description: The National Football League said that Tommy Kramer, quarterback of the Minnesota Vikings, had shown poor judgment in making a $25 bet with his bartender on the Pittsburgh-Houston game of Monday night, Oct. 26, but that no disciplinary action would be taken against him. Joe Browne, a spokesman for Commissioner Pete Rozelle, said that the league office had talked about the matter with Viking management, that the team had told Kramer he had erred and that ''the matter is closed.''

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 4, 1981; Companies
description: Partners are being sought for three New York City savings banks in danger of failing, according to banking sources. The institutions that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reportedly believes need to merge are the New York Bank for Savings, the Union Dime Savings Bank and the Central Savings Bank. (Page A1.)

title: PEKING CALLS ITSELF PATIENT ON UNITY OFFER TO TAIWAN
description: A Communist official has cautioned Chinese not to expect immediate results from the overture to the Nationalists in Taiwan earlier this fall proposing reunification .

title: HOW LATINS WILL REACT TO U.S. MILITARY ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: SUIT BY 6 HAITIAN ALIENS TESTING DETENTION POLICY
description: The first legal test of the Reagan Administration's policy of detaining ''boat people'' from the embattled Caribbean island of Haiti will take place today in Manhattan.

title: FORMER NUCLEAR CHIEF ASSAILS PROJECTIONS ON A-PLANT COSTS
description: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission when the accident at Three Mile Island occurred today challenged as ''vastly overstated'' suggestions that the cost of constructing the Nine Mile Point Two nuclear plant in upstate New York would exceed projections by hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: Compromise Expected In N.C.A.A. Rift on TV
description: Just four months after threatening to break from the National Collegiate Athletic Association unless they got more control over television rights to their games, the nation's most powerful football colleges were talking compromise today. The N.C.A.A. was meeting at a special convention called with the intention of giving the football powers a bigger voice in the sale and scheduling of games.

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After tax credits of $1.5 million for the qr and $38 million for the yr...C-Net income; the 1980 yr net income reflects a charge of $2.2 million or 16 cents a shr for a change in certai inventory elements which was reflected in the first qr of 1980

title: BEELINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
Oilers Win, 17-13, Eliminate Browns
description: Gifford Nielsen, replacing Ken Stabler at quarterback to open the second half, threw a 30-yard scoring pass to Dave Casper tonight to spark the Houston Oilers to a 17-13 victory over the Cleveland Browns. The defeat eliminated the Browns, the defending American Conference Central Division champions, from playoff competition.

title: Index; International
description: Saudis forging future from the past A2 Austrian train takes Poles to a new life A3 Former Prime Minister in Tur- key begins prison term A4 Peking official counsels patience on Taiwan ties A6 Cambodian rebel leader appeals for U.S. aid A8 South African ''homeland'' of Cis- kei proclaimed independent A9 Text of U.S.-Israeli statement on Sinai force A11 Schmidt again defends plans for missile deployment A12 Around the World A13 For Zambia's white farmers, polo, cricket and memories A16 Government/Politics Arizona districting plan splits Morris Udall's district A19 Senate conferees back farm bill accepted by Reagan A22 Reagan's Capitol Hill liaison gets consul post in Bermuda A23 Senate rejects plan to delete funds for B-1 bomber A21 Meese orders review of National Security Council operations A25 Carol Bellamy attacks perform- ance of Governor Carey B3 Carey criticizes Reagan's 'deny side' fiscal policies B3 Washington Talk Profile: Eugene V. Rostow, disar- mament agency chief A28 Briefing A28 Many Congressmen trained on- the-job as aides and pages A28 General Around the Nation A18 Evolution of Tafoya case in Fort Collins, Colo. A26 Haitian aliens test U.S. detention policy B1 Trial date set in Stouffer's fire B9 Weekend Events: Weekender Guide C1 Big Apple Circus comes to Lin- coln Center C1 Farms where you pick your own Christmas tree C28 Theater: Broadway C2

title: TIME TO REMOVE THE FEDERAL MERGER INCENTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO SHOWS CAST NEW LIGHT ON THE RICHNESS OF FOLK ART
description: AS to what constitutes folk art, no two people are agreed. Sometimes the name is given to work in which the feelings and aspirations of a whole society find unmistakable expression. Sometimes it stands for the first stirrings of self-awareness in a society that has yet to have any professional artists of substance. Sometimes the name is claimed for work that is as inept as it is repetitious.

title: No Headline
description: North Carolina 78, Tulsa 70

title: A Check on Transit
description: Mayor Koch, who has criticized the management and employees of the Transit Authority, paid a surprise visit to a subway repair yard in Coney Island and said he had been impressed.

title: HEALTH CLUBS THRIVE AS MEETING PLACES FOR YOUNG SINGLE PEOPLE
description: Most evenings, hundreds of young men and women flock to the Holiday Health Spa on Olympic Boulevard, ostensibly to play racquetball, swim or lift weights.

title: No Headline
description: PENNSYLVANIA AID CUTS APPROVED

title: Around the World; Salvador Rebels Attack Area Claimed by Army
description: The Defense Ministry said today that guerrillas had opened new attacks 40 miles south of here in an area where the Government said that the rebels had been decisively defeated last month.

title: GRUMMAN OFFICIALS ARE FOUND 'REMISS'
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the three trustees of the Grumman Corporation's pension plan - all top company executives - had been ''woefully remiss'' in deciding to purchase more than a million shares of Grumman stock to avert a takeover.

title: Around the World; Angola Denounces Visit Of Rebel Leader to U.S.
description: Angola said today that the visit of its main opponent to the United States confirmed that the Reagan Administration was pursuing a policy of interfering in the African nation's internal affairs.

title: FEAR OF CRIME RESHAPING LIVES OF QUEENS ELDERLY
description: Inside the Senior Citizens Center at St. Mary Gate of Heaven Church in Ozone Park, Queens, the morning get-together is in full swing. A phonograph is playing ''When You Wish Upon a Star,'' and elderly couples sway gently around the dance floor.

title: FOR GOVERNOR'S DEPUTY, AN UNFORESEEN STEP UP
description: Early last year, when Joseph J. Fauliso was President pro tem of the State Senate, he told his close friend, Gov. Ella T. Grasso, that after seven terms he had decided not to seek reelection.

title: JETS' WALKER ENTERS HOSPITAL
description: Wesley Walker looked more perplexed than pained. ''I don't know what to think anymore,'' Walker, the Jet wide receiver, said today at the team's camp. ''I thought I was over all the injuries.''

title: BIG APPLE CIRCUS PITCHES A TENT IN LINCOLN CENTER
description: IT may not be spring, but the circus is back in town this weekend. Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey will be at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island. Yuri Belov, former director of clowning at the Moscow State Circus, and his Clown Conspiracy are presenting ''My Heart Is in Your Shoes'' at the Theater for the New City on the Lower East Side. And New York's own Big Apple Circus, as raffish and cocky as a New York street scene and as intensely personal as a dream, opens tonight at Lincoln Center.

title: SCHMIDT DEFENDS MISSILE PLAN
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany expressed concern today over the role that fear is playing among opponents of proposed nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS TENTATIVELY SET BILL ON SPENDING
description: White House officials and Republican Congressional leaders reached a tentative agreement tonight on an omnibus spending measure that would finance the Government for the rest of the 1982 fiscal year.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: BURGLAR ELUDES TIGHT SECURITY, SHOOTS AUTHOR
description: A 55-year-old author was shot yesterday by an intruder in her apartment at the Pavilion, an East Side luxury building with one of the most elaborate residential security systems in the city.

title: ALLEN'S OPERATION EXAMINED BY MEESE
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, disclosed today that he had ordered an internal review of the organization and operation of the National Security Council apparatus headed by Richard V. Allen.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 4, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: 1 House, 17 Trees
description: Nancy Reagan has ordered that, starting today, the White House be closed through the weekend so that it may be decorated for Christmas. The official unveiling of the decorations, including a 19 1/2-foot Christmas tree and 16 smaller ones, will take place Monday.

title: MISS BELLAMY CRITICIZES GOVERNOR'S PERFOMANCE
description: Carol Bellamy, New York's City Council President and a potential candidate for Governor in 1982, criticized Governor Carey today for his handling of this year's battle over aid to mass transit and for his dealings with the Legislature.

title: FRANCE AND THE U.S.
description: The French Socialist Government, which includes four Communist ministers, is devoted to nationalization and supports revolutionaries throughout the third world, including Central America. At the same time, there is an archconservative at the head of the United States Government. Logically, relations between France and the United States should be abominable. It is said that they are excellent.

title: ANGLO ENERGY LTD reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $131,000 or 2 cents a shr for the latest yr and $1,682,000 or 21 cents a shr for the previous yr

title: New Hiller Offer Rejected by Kaiser
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said that its directors had rejected a new offer from the Hiller Investment Company to acquire the company for $54 a share. Hiller, a private investment group based in Menlo Park, Calif., had previously offered $52 a share.

title: POP JAZZ
description: ROSCOE MITCHELL performed just one short composition at last summer's Kool Jazz Festival in New York City, but the performance provoked an uproar. It consisted of a single long, sustained tone that was passed back and forth between Mr. Mitchell's saxophone and Hugh Ragin's trumpet, and it drew impatient catcalls from an audience that had come to Carnegie Hall to hear traditional jazz, Chicago style. But the concert had been billed as a survey of Chicago's contributions to jazz, and Roscoe Mitchell, a 41-year-old composer and saxophonist, has affected the evolution of today's jazz more profoundly than any other Chicagoan of his generation.

title: BROWN FEELS TIES TO U.C.L.A.
description: On the afternoon of a game he had been looking forward to, Larry Brown, former U.C.L.A. coach, had other things on his mind.

title: Around the Nation
description: Five miners were trapped inside an underground coal mine after rock collapsed from the mine's ceiling late tonight, said Sheriff Gary A. Payne of Webster County.

title: Out-of-the-Mold Nose Tackle
description: Bill Neill of the Giants, a 22-year-old rookie, has heard all those stereotypes about nose tackles. He says he believes none of them.

title: Jury Acquits 3 of Conspiracy To Kill U.S. Critic of Khomeini
description: Three men were acquitted today of conspiring to kill a leading United States critic of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, but two of them were convicted on related charges.

title: Optimistic 'Annie'
description: When she played the title role in the Broadway musical ''Annie,'' Shelley Bruce used to sing ''The sun will come out, tomorrow,'' a paean to optimism, and she was talking that way yesterday about having completed radiation treatments for leukemia.

title: ROCKLAND INQUIRY ON ALCOHOL SALES USES 4 GIRLS TO HELP BRING CHARGES
description: After a six-month investigation in which four teen-age girls acted as undercover agents, the Rockland County District Attorney's office announced today that charges had been lodged against 11 stores for selling wine or beer to people under 18.

title: ISOLATED SAKHAROVS PERSIST IN THEIR FAST
description: After a decade together at the heart of the human rights struggle in the Soviet Union, Andrei D. Sakharov and Yelena G. Bonner have grown accustomed to the isolation and intimidation that descend on those confronting the system.

title: Funds' Assets Up $2.86 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $2.86 billion during the week ended Wednesday, to $182.85 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the 27th consecutive weekly increase.

title: Friday; A WRITERS CELEBRATION
description: In what they call a ''celebration of language,'' the actors Roscoe Lee Browne and Anthony Zerbe have fashioned a theater piece that joins the words of such writers as E.E. Cummings, Edna St. Vincent Millay, W.H. Auden, Dylan Thomas, T.S. Eliot, E.B. White and James Agee. The piece, ''Behind the Broken Words,'' is designed to offer ''an unbroken flow of commentary on modern life.'' Performances begin tonight at 8 at the American Place Theater, 111 West 46th Sreet. Tickets are $12 on Friday and Saturday nights; $10 for Tuesday through Thursday nights and for Wednesday, Saturday and Sunday matinees. For reservations, call 247-0393. WBAI FAIR AT COLUMBIA

title: Craig's Outlook Eases
description: Injury-beset Jim Craig, the Boston Bruin goaltender who has not played a regular-season game for nearly a year, has received permission to talk with other teams.

title: ENSIGN IS ACCUSED IN NAVY SPY CASE
description: A 21-year-old Navy ensign has been charged with passing military secrets to a foreign power by mailing electronic warfare data to the South African Embassy in Washington last September, a Navy spokesman said today.

title: FRAZIER RETURN A DRAW
description: Joe Frazier's Wrecking Machine sputtered and lurched tonight, but in the end the former heavyweight champion's comeback dreams were oiled by a 10-round draw decision against Floyd (Jumbo) Cummings after a five-and-one-half-year layoff.

title: Tough Bumpers
description: Should the Federal Government weaken its standards for auto bumpers? Federal regulators lean that way, arguing it doesn't pay to invest an extra $30 to $50 in bumpers to protect cars in 5-mile-anhour crashes.

title: MUSIC: JEWISH COMPOSERS
description: ''MUSIC of the Jewish people'' is the theme of the ''Heritage Concerts'' at the Merkin Concert Hall. In the first of the series on Wednesday night, the music was by Jewish composers - Felix Mendelssohn, Ernest Bloch, Leonard Bernstein, Meyer Kupferman and others.

title: TRANSFIGURATION
description: In the past, reading about our death was always edifying, and, in fact, this is why the Gospels were read with delight, even (especially?) by those who didn't overtly belong to any church -in other words, by truly Christian humanists.

title: Advertising; Things You Won't See In the Ads
description: THAT network commercial on television, the one you ignore with such ease, took the intense effort and soul searching of both the advertiser and his agency to put it there. And that didn't even count creating the message, the ad itself.

title: Argentine Chief Recovering
description: President Roberto Viola, recuperating from a cardiovascular illness, entered a hospital today for tests that will determine whether he is ready to return to work. An official bulletin said General Viola, 57 years old, would remain hospitalized until Friday. The presidential press office said Wednesday that the general ''has experienced an improvement in his clinical state.''

title: LOWER CANCER RISK TIED TO NUTRIENT
description: The risk of developing lung cancer, even among cigarette smokers, is less among men who eat large amounts of carrots, spinach and other vegetables that contain beta-carotene, according to a study in a recent issue of The Lancet, a British medical journal.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: A CCORDING to David Francis, who heads a band called Panama Francis and the Savoy Sultans, jazz has done nothing but go downhill in the last few decades. It is all, he said, the fault of intellectuals.

title: A FLIMSY LINK BETWEEN HOME PRICES AND SAVING
description: To the Editor:

title: FACTORY ORDERS OF IN OCTOBER
description: New orders for goods from the nation's factories tumbled 5.2 percent in October, the largest one-month decline since April 1980, when the nation was in a recession, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO SEEK NEW YORK MERGER OF 3 SAVINGS BANKS
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is seeking merger partners for three New York City savings banks that are in danger of failing, according to banking sources.

title: A VOICE OF 'SEXUAL LITERACY'
description: A tiny, middle-age women hailed a cab in the East 70's and, in a heavy German accent, asked to be taken to 30 Rockefeller Plaza. Hearing her voice, the cabby brightened. ''Dr. Ruth?''

title: 3 Seized in Plot To Steal Jewels
description: Three men were arrested yesterday on charges of plotting to steal up to $4 million in jewels from a pawnshop's safe deposit boxes at a Brooklyn bank.

title: ATYPICAL PRISON
description: To the Editor:

title: East Side Italian, Village Ukrainian.
description: EIGHTH STREET between Second and Third Avenues is fast becoming Italian Restaurant Row. The line of black and silver-gray Cadillacs has lengthened considerably there since La Camelia opened four months ago. Lunch, dinner and supper menus in this pleasantly plush if undistinguished new setting offer North Italian cooking with strong overtones of novella cucina, the Italian version of the French nouvelle cuisine. Kiwis are featured with prosciutto as well as in dessert tarts, and there are combinations such as oranges with shrimp cocktail in Russian dressing, strawberries doused with balsamic vinegar, smoked salmon folded into creamy fettuccine and chicken with a sauce of pistachio nuts. Some creations prove more successful than others.

title: FOR ZAMBIA'S WHITE PLANTERS, POLO, CRICKET AND MEMORIES
description: ''When we first arrived in Africa,'' the farmer said, ''we got off the train - it had taken three days from the Cape and we'd come from England by ship on the old Castle Line - and as the train pulled away and left us, my wife turned to me and said, 'Goodbye civilization.' ''

title: Another Dropout
description: And then there were six. Another leading New York Republican, State Senator Warren M. Anderson of Binghamton, took himself out of next year's race for the governorship yesterday, further thinning a field that once had nine major contenders for the party's nomination.

title: COVER-UP LAID TO HOTEL OWNER IN DEATH ON L.I.
description: The owner of a Long Beach, L.I., residential hotel has been charged with covering up the circumstances surrounding the death of a tenant who was found dead in his bed early Tuesday of multiple injuries and exposure, according to the Long Beach police.

title: Jeffrey Bell to Run
description: Jeffrey Bell, a former adviser to President Reagan, said he was planning to run for the seat held by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. Mr. Bell, who was an aide to Mr. Reagan in the 1976 campaign, lost to Bill Bradley in 1978 after defeating former Senator Clifford P. Case in the Republican primary.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $39,000 extraordinary credit for the qr and 9 mos and $33,000 income from discontinued operations for the 9 mos

title: High Praise
description: As the international leader of the Salvation Army, Gen. Arnold Brown makes a lot of speeches to a lot of august officials with a variety of high-sounding honorifics, but he stumbled a bit yesterday when he found himself addressing Mayor Koch.

title: JANE WYMAN IN PRIME-TIME SOAP OPERA
description: IN ''Falcon Crest,'' the new prime-time soap opera beginning on CBS at 10 tonight, the villainous centerpiece, the sort of function served by J.R. on the same network's ''Dallas,'' is a woman. Angie Channing is a California vintner, of all things, determined to maintain control of her Napa Valley wine empire. Adding a fillip of interest to the project, Angie is played by Jane Wyman, the former Mrs. Ronald Reagan.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
American art in two sales
description: GEORGIA O'KEEFFE, Andrew Wyeth, Edward Hopper, Maurice Prendergast and John Singer Sargent are among the major artists represented in sales of American Impressionist and 20th-century paintings next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries, at 76th Street, and at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street.

title: HUSTLING OFF TO DANCE CLASSES
description: While they were making out the guest list for their wedding next month, Fern Morgan, a student at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, and Charles J. Lindsay, a securities trader, realized with a rush of horror that families and friends expect brides and grooms to glide gracefully around the dance floor for the traditional leadoff waltz.

title: 9 Killed in Storm in Brazil
description: At least nine people were killed in a 20-hour rainstorm in the Rio de Janeiro area, the state Public Safety Department said today. Major highways were blocked by mudslides. The local airport for shuttle

title: Aide to Be Named To Top City Post
description: Joseph T. McGough Jr., the first deputy commissioner in the city's Department of Environmental Protection, is expected to be named acting commissioner of the agency. He will replace Francis X. McArdle, who is leaving the agency to take a position with Olympia & York, the Canadian-based real-estate developer.

title: Briefing
description: T HE provisions of last summer's package of budget cuts were so extensive and complicated that some of them are just now becoming known to the public and are being greeted by affected constituents as nasty little secrets. In one such delayed dawning, high school seniors in widowed families are about to lose four years of Social Security payments for their college years unless they somehow push up their schedule and begin attending college full time in the coming spring semester, even before their high school graduation. Some members of Congress might understandably not want to broadcast such bad news. But Representative Thomas J. Downey of Suffolk, spurred by Toby A. Meisel, a widow with teen-agers who is his legislative expert on Social Security intricacies, has been urgently warning high schools and widows, and fellow Congressmen, too, that such seniors can lose up to $2,400 a year while in college unless they act quickly.

title: O'NEILL REPORTED DOING VERY WELL AFTER OPERATION
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill underwent three hours of open-heart surgery this morning. His condition was described late today as ''excellent,'' but he was not expected to regain consciousness until Friday morning.

title: Around the World; The Two Yemens Agree To Set Up Closer Ties
description: Yemen and Southern Yemen said today that they had agreed on wide-ranging political and economic cooperation to follow up an unfulfilled merger agreement of two years ago.

title: BALLET: A LIVELY SEASON OPENER FOR AILEY TROUPE
description: THE Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater's winter season got off to a fine start on Wednesday night at the City Center. The company looked fresh and so did the program for, although it included an old favorite, there were also three works choreographed within the last two years.

title: DID SHOWS, BALLETS AND FILMS
description: Hershy Kay, whose breezy ballet scores and orchestrations of Leonard Bernstein's ''On the Town,'' ''Candide'' and ''Mass'' established him as one of music's foremost arrangers, died of heart failure in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital on Wednesday. He was 62 years old and had lived in Danbury.

title: Appeal by Rumanian Leader
description: Nicolae Ceausescu, Rumania's President and Communist Party leader, appealed today to President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, to insure the success of the Geneva negotiations for reduction of nuclear forces in Europe. Mr. Ceausescu has orchestrated a disarmament campaign of mass demonstrations across Rumania in recent weeks.

title: Bethlehem Layoffs
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it would idle 675 workers this coming Sunday for at least one week, and lay off 175 more workers for an indefinite period effective Dec.17.

title: PENSION FUND RULES EASED TO AID HOUSING
description: President Reagan today announced the liberalization of regulations governing private pension funds, permitting them to pump more of their growing assets, now estimated at more than $500 billion, into the sagging housing market.

title: GUATEMALAN ARMY AND LEFTIST REBELS LOCKED IN WAR
description: While international attention has been on the civil war in El Salvador, the insurgency neighboring Guatemala has grown to what many people believe is a revolutionary war.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Mrs. Lloyd In Semifinals
description: Chris Evert Lloyd beat Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, the defending champion, 6-4, 7-5, today in the quarterfinals of the $200,000 Australian Women's Open tennis tournament today.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Policy: Protests Grow
description: THE worsening recession, combined with the Reagan Administration's ''new federalism,'' is intensifying the economic and financial pressure on the nation's cities and states. At this week's conference of the National League of Cities, one conservative Republican, Gov. Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, warned that the President's program was leading the nation toward ''an economic Bay of Pigs.''

title: GUIDE TO TREE FARMS NEAR THE METROPOLITAN AREA
description: Following is a list of nearby Christmas tree farms in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Because hours and days vary, the tree farmers suggest you telephone for times, directions, varieties and prices: New York Columbia County: Alan Miller, Old Barrington Road, Hollowville, (518) 851-9080. Dutchess County: Vincent Abel, North Clove Road, Verbank, (914) 677-6395; Gordon Budd, Market Lane, Clinton Corners, (914) 266-3401; Amedeo Lalli, College Lane, Millbrook, (914) 677-5364; Elmer van Wagner, Albany Post Road, Hyde Park, (914) 229-2116; Allan Webster, Schultzville Road, Clinton Corners, (914) 266-3804. Sullivan County: Edward and Veronica Blass, Cochecton, (914) 482-4227; Peter Weiden, Narrowsburg, (914) 252-3293. Westchester County: Wilkens Fruit Farm, White Hill Road, Yorktown Heights, (914) 245-5111.

title: Ken Wahl chuckles at Hollywood.
description: THE ends of his fingers are stained with nicotine, his teeth have never been straightened, he wears clothes straight out of an armynavy store, and when he crashes a Hollywood party (''Don't they invite you?'' ''No more, they don't''), Ken Wahl heads straight for a pretty woman, because he says he finds all the other guests laughable.

title: Merrill to Acquire Advance Mortgage
description: To the deep chagrin of Citicorp, Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it planned to buy the Advance Mortgage Company Ltd., the nation's second-largest mortgage servicing concern, from Oppenheimer & Company.

title: COMPROMISE ON FARM SUBSIDY BILL APPROVED BY CONFEREES IN SENATE
description: Senate members of the conference committee on the farm bill accepted an Administration-backed compromise today, but there was no certainty that House conferees would do so when they consider the new proposal Monday.

title: After 'Little Harry'
description: This state's political buffs are in a state of shock, and no wonder. The announced retirement of Harry F. Byrd Jr. from the U.S. Senate will open his seat to someone outside his family for the first time in half a century, insure a Republican-Democratic donnybrook over the succession and perhaps move Virginia further toward genuine two-party politics.

title: STAGE: 'GHOSTS OF THE LOYAL OAKS'
description: LARRY KETRON'S ''Ghosts of the Loyal Oaks,'' at the WPA, is set ''outside a town near the Tennessee-North Carolina border,'' but let's not lose any sleep over that. Mr. Ketron's heart belongs to Burbank, and ''Ghosts'' is yet another synthetic situation comedy masquerading as a play. In every way - writing, acting and direction - this production is many rungs below the best standard of the Off Off Broadway company that has given us ''Album'' and ''Key Exchange.''

title: Golden Chance Farm Gets an Eclipse Award
description: The first Eclipse Award of the year, for outstanding breeder, yesterday went to Verna Lehmann's Golden Chance Farm of Paris, Ky. Golden Chance, which bred horses who won more than $2.4 million this year, was the unanimous choice of a six-person committee composed of representatives of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations, The Daily Racing Form and the National Turf Writers Association.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
B.P. Net Down 3%
description: The British Petroleum Company, a majority owner of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), announced today a 3 percent drop in profit in the third quarter, ended Sept. 30. Net income fell to $367 million, or 22 cents a share, from $378 million, or 24 cents, in the comparable 1980 period. Revenues rose to $11.6 billion from $8.7 billion.

title: F.C.C. MAY EXCLUDE THE ELECTRONIC PRESS FROM FAIRNESS RULES
description: Electronic newspapers delivered by means of broadcast televison should not be subject to the same fairness and equal time rules imposed on radio and television stations, the Federal Communications Commission says.

title: ARIZONA DISTRICTING PLAN SPLITS UDALL'S DISTRICT
description: Representative Morris K. Udall is embroiled in political battle over a state redistricting plan that divides his Tucson power base.

title: Ex-Cell-O President Also Named Chief
description: E. Paul Casey, the 51-year-old president of the Ex-Cell-O Corporation, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Edward J. Giblin, 64, who will continue as chairman of the diversified Troy, Mich., industrial products manufacturer until he retires at the end of 1982.

title: FONDA AT HIS PEAK IN 'ON GOLDEN POND'
description: AS a successful Broadway play, Ernest Thompson's ''On Golden Pond'' was processed American cheese, smooth, infinitely spreadable and bland, with color added by the actors. The screen version, directed by Mark Rydell from Mr. Thompson's screenplay, is not much different in any superficial way.

title: U.S. BONDS LEAP AS FED ACTS
description: Prices of Treasury bonds jumped sharply late yesterday as yields tumbled in response to the Federal Reserve Board's cut in the discount rate to 12 percent from 13 percent. ''It came as a very welcome development,'' one trader in Government securities said. ''Some people had just about given up hope that a reduction was coming soon.''

title: FOR THE JEFFERSON PAPERS, BUDGET PERIL FROM 40TH PRESIDENT
description: The scholars who are compiling a 65-volume edition of nearly everything the third American President ever wrote - from the Declaration of Independence to his recipe for macaroni - are concerned that their progress may be slowed by the 40th President's proposed budget cuts.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $920,000 net non-operating loss primarily associated with the closing of the company's Pueblo wholesale division in Puerto Rico; the 1980 figures were restated to reflect a change to LIFO method of inventory valuation

title: ARMY OF PICASSO AFICIONADOS PAINTS A LITTLE SPANISH TOWN
description: Until recently, few people had heard of Caltojar, a village in the north-central province of Soria with one telephone and 207 inhabitants. Then Angel Nuno, the secretary of Caltojar's Town Hall, got the idea of painting imitation Picassos on its white walls and low adobe buildings.

title: QUASAR MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Robert Flack to Appear In John Lennon Tribute
description: Roberta Flack and David Clayton-Thomas, who was a vocalist for the group Blood, Sweat and Tears, will perform Thursday at Radio City along with the Cincinnati Pops Orchestra conducted by Erich Kunzel and a rock band in ''A Tribute to John Lennon,'' featuring Lennon's music arranged by Frank Proto, a bass player with the orchestra.

title: Sanyo in England
description: The Sanyo Electric Company, the Japanese electrical equipment manufacturer, said it will establish a color television subsidiary, Sanyo Industries, in Lowestoft, in eastern England, next February. The subsidiary, to be capitalized at $7.4 million, will take over a plant from NV Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken to produce 60,000 television sets a year from next July, with capacity to be raised to 120,000 sets in three years, Sanyo officials said.

title: Allen Assails the News Media
description: Richard V. Allen today called off an appearance before the National Press Club after complaining that the news media had ''grossly exceeded'' the bounds of propriety in pursuing the case that forced him to take leave from his White House job.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: B-Including tax credits of $23,000 for the qr and $29,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $43,000 for the qr and $50,000 for the yr

title: Observer; SHORTAGE OF GUMPTION
description: Remember when we used to laugh at Communism because young Russians couldn't afford to own a house in the suburbs? They all had to pack in together with parents and grandparents in two-room apartments where they could never know the joy of mowing the lawn on Sunday morning. It showed you what a bust Communism was.

title: HEALTH EXTENSION SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $55,000 extraordinary credit

title: Notes on People; Philip Berrigan Keeps to the Activist Trail
description: Back in the 1960's and early 1970's, two of the most active of the antiwar, antinuclear activists were a priest and a nun, Philip Berrigan and Elizabeth McAllister.

title: AN AUTO WORKER'S UNEMPLOYMENT BENEFITS STOP
description: Donald Tarnoski made his last trip to the unemployment office yesterday. ''The girl came up to the window and said 'Tarnoski? You don't have anything coming. You're all through,' '' he said. ''That's a quote I'll never forget,'' he added. ''When they tell you, it's in front of 500 people: 'You're all through!' It's just embarassing as hell.''

title: THE FALL AND RISE OF THE CENTRAL PARK ZOO
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE ARIZONA WITH MR. AND MRS. NAGATA
description: We went out by Navy launch over the glittering waters of Pearl Harbor. About 40 other tourists and I, laden with cameras and maps, were about to ''board'' the U.S.S. Arizona, where she lay in her permanent berth. She rests on the bottom of the shallow harbor, seeming not to have tilted at all as she settled there about 8:25 A.M. on Dec. 7, 1941. By special act of Congress, she still flies our national flag.

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 14
A SURGE IN LAYOFFS LIFTS JOBLESS RATE TO A SIX-YEAR HIGH
description: A sharp rise in layoffs in heavy industry last month pushed the nation's unemployment rate up to 8.4 percent, from 8 percent in October. The November level was the highest since the severe recession of 1974-75, when it reached 9 percent.

title: Werblin Defends Talk to Team
description: Why did Sonny Werblin berate the Knicks after their 114-88 loss to the Washington Bullets Thursday night at Madison Square Garden? ''I was hurt,'' he said yesterday. ''It's not my style to hold dressing room meetings. But I wanted them to know that I was disappointed and aware of their lack of hustle and that they were not playing up to their potential.'' Werblin, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the Knicks, said he had been told that some of the players resented his appearance in the dressing room, but he did not care.

title: VAT FACTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO REASONS FOR RISE IN THE DIVORCE RATE
description: To the Editor:

title: ACTION ON GIBRALTAR IS REPORTED NEAR
description: After sparring over fine points for almost two years, Britain and Spain appear to be close to a breakthrough on one of Europe's oldest diplomatic disputes - the status of Gibraltar, which has been in British hands since 1704.

title: KUWAIT IS CLEARED IN BID FOR SANTA FE
description: The Kuwaiti Government's proposed $2.5 billion purchase of the Santa Fe International Corporation cleared its final Government hurdle today as the Justice Department terminated the mandatory waiting period for the deal.

title: U.S.-Canada Seaway Tolls
description: The United States and Canada have agreed on new tolls that will be charged vessels traveling the St. Lawrence Seaway, beginning with the 1982 navigation season.

title: WRONG SCHOOL FOR PRINCIPLE MACCHIAROLA
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S ADDRESS AT O.A.S. MEETING
description: Following are excerpts from an address today by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the General Assembly of the Organization of American States in Castries, St. Lucia. The prepared text was made public here by the State Department.

title: RUMANIA'S ECONOMIC PROBLEMS BRING OUSTER OF THREE AIDES
description: Faced with his country's worst economic crisis in decades and signs of political discontent, President Nicolae Ceausescu has dismissed three long-serving colleagues in the ruling Communist Party.

title: Senate Promises Early Look at Aging Conference Report
description: The Senate voted unanimously today to give ''early and careful consideration'' to the more than 600 recommendations approved this week by the White House Conference on Aging.

title: John J. McCarthy, 61; Ex-Dow Jones Official
description: John J. McCarthy, a former vice president of Dow Jones & Company, died Wednesday at Memorial General Hospital in Union, N.J. Mr. McCarthy, a resident of Cranford, N.J., was 61 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Carey has lost his fight to stop the Legislature from enacting a property-tax law of its own making. But there is much evidence that the loss may turn out to be a gain for Mr. Carey, who did not put up much of a fight.

title: TURKS REASSURED BY WEINBERGER'S VISIT
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger told Turkish leaders today that NATO would not accede to Greece's demands for ''guarantees'' against Turkey, according to United States Defense Department sources.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Baker International Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $150 million of notes due Dec. 15, 1991. Goldman, Sachs & Company and Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. have been designated managing underwriters.

title: WILSON, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid July 24

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $4,344,000 gain from the sale of a partial interest in the Randhurst Shopping Center...C-Net loss

title: SUMMONSES FAIL TO CONTROL MOUNTING TRASH IN WALKOUT
description: Sanitation summonses are being issued by New York City in record numbers, but only half are leading to fines, which average about $30, city officials said. The summonses appear to be having little impact on controlling mounting piles of garbage in the streets, they added.

title: Notes on People; In the Public Eye
description: When William Gadek believes passionately enough in a cause, he is willing to go to great lengths to back up his belief. For example, some years ago he went into battle against an ordinance in Woodbridge, N.J., that limited the hours nightclubs could operate. Mr. Gadek sued to test its constitutionality, and took the case all the way to the United States Supreme Court, which declined to hear it.

title: YESHIVA BASKETBALL HAS DIFFERENT LOOK
description: Underneath his yarmulke, Joey Eaves, a 5-foot-9-inch freshman guard for the Yeshiva University basketball team, is obviously different from his teammates. But then, a college team whose coach allows anyone who tries out to play is a bit different, too.

title: Bridge: 'Fix' May Be All Too Clear But at Any Rate It's Legal
description: On occasion a bridge player will wail to the nearest sympathetic ear, ''I was fixed.'' He does not mean that the result of the game was ''fixed'' in advance, nor, of course, is he using the word in any nefarious sense.

title: STRANGE ILLNESS HAS KILLED 38 ASIAN REFUGEES
description: An unexplained affliction is killing Laotian refugees in the United States at an extremely high rate, striking its victims quickly and without warning while they sleep, the national Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: Deputy to Reagan Aide Named Capitol Liaison
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan had named Kenneth M. Duberstein to fill the Congressional liaison job being given up by Max L. Friedersdorf.

title: FREED BY REAGAN
description: Marvin Mandel, former Governor of Maryland, leaving Federal prison near Pensacola, Fla., after serving 19 months of a three-year term for mail fraud and racketeering. He flew to Baltimore, ''delighted'' with his freedom. President Reagan commuted his sentence Thursday.

title: SOLIDARITY WARNS OF MAJOR STRIKES
description: The leadership of the independent trade union Solidarity issued a statement today threatening nationwide strikes if the Government sought to curb newly gained citizens' rights with a law giving itself extraordinary emergency powers.

title: JAPAN GREETS STRONGER YEN
description: The long-awaited strengthening of the yen has begun. Economists and currency traders say this trend should continue through 1982, despite daily and weekly fluctuations.

title: The City; Men Get Shelter On Short Notice
description: The Koch administration announced at 6 P.M. yesterday that it would immediately begin sheltering homeless men at a state armory in Upper Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's very much a blue-collar recession, and New York City is a white-collar town.'' - Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. (9:3.)

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After charges of $140,000 for the qr and 4704,000 in the 6 mos for currency translation ajdustments...C-Includes income of $131,000 from discontinued operations and a charge of $171,000 for currency translation adjustments...D-After currenc translation charges of $403,000 and income of $226,000 from discontinued operations

title: The Region; Inmate in Trenton Escapes Over Wall
description: TRENTON (AP) - Police searched wooded areas with helicopters and tracking dogs for a ''very dangerous'' inmate from Trenton State Prison who climbed to freedom over a 22-foot barbed-wire wall with a rope made of bed sheets.

title: Samuel B. Kluger, 74, Head Of Eagle Manufacturing Co.
description: Samuel B. Kluger, president and chief executive officer of the Eagle Manufacturing Company, one of New York's largest electrical specialty concerns, died Monday at the North Shore Hospital in Great Neck, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived in Great Neck.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. has increased its stake in Champion Parts Rebuilders to 17 percent, or 297,079 shares, through additional purchases of 67,627 shares between Nov. 19 and Nov. 23 on the open market at prices ranging from $4.15 a share to $4.92 a share.

title: COACH'S MAIN GOAL REACHED BY UCONN
description: Joe Morrone, the University of Connecticut soccer coach, has learned that success has a price, in this case a pair of broken glasses and a smashed pocket watch.

title: Youth Admits Holdup on L.I.
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn youth admitted today that he took part in a $10,300 holdup of a Rockville Centre jewelry store last Jan. 29.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 30. 1. To some people, this is ''Grandma Freud,'' the successful New York ''psych jockey.'' Identify her and explain. 2. ''Eighteen years is long enough,'' said a man who is the only independent in the United States Senate. Who is he, and what did he mean?

title: Uranium Mill Termed Cause of Kidney Injury
description: A Federal study has found evidence of kidney damage among workers at a uranium mill in Canon City, Colo., the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union has reported.

title: Patents; Liquid Heat Converted To Mechanical Energy
description: An engine invented for the Department of Energy converts heat from a liquid to mechanical energy by turning a wheel.

title: REALEX CORP reports earnings for 16 weeks to Oct 28
MID-AMERICA PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $900 MILLION
description: After three consecutive weeks of monetary growth totaling $6 billion, the basic money supply fell $900 million in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday.

title: Alcoa Unit's Eurobond
description: Alcoa of Australia Ltd. is raising $50 million through a seven-year Eurobond underwritten by Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. The issue carries an indicated coupon of 15 1/2 percent, with open pricing to be fixed by Thursday.

title: Small Quake in Honduras
description: Freely elected civilian Presidents are an endangered species in Central America. So the election in Honduras of Dr. Roberto Suazo Cordova, a physician, after nine years of military rule, is a gratifying event - especially since the military favored his rightwing opponent. Still, this modest political quake won't have much meaning without serious regional aid from Washington.

title: TAX-EXEMPTS BECKON PUBLIC
description: Dealers in municipal bonds had feared that the new one-year tax-exempt ''All Savers'' certificates would be a competitive threat to the tax-exempt securities market. Now, however, they say that the tax-exempt deposits have not injured their markets, and may even help business in the future.

title: PEARL HARBOR'S INFAMY, MY FATHER'S FAME
description: I cannot recall a time that I did not know that my father, Colin P. Kelly Jr., was a pilot shot down during the week of Pearl Harbor, the first graduate of the United States Military Academy to die in combat as my country entered World War II nearly 40 years ago.

title: WALTER KNOTT OF KNOTT'S BERRY FARM IS DEAD
description: Walter Knott, the founder of Knott's Berry Farm, the 150-acre, multimillion-dollar amusement complex in Buena Park, Calif, died Thursday of Parkinson's disease in his home at the park. He was 91 years old.

title: TV Notebook; CBS NEWS MAY SWITCH PERSONNEL ON 'MORNING'
description: Beleagured by declining audience-popularity ratings, ''Morning'' with Charles Kuralt and Diane Sawyer will be the next target in the extensive shakeups under way at CBS News.

title: FOR OLDER WOMEN, PARLEY RAISES HOPE
description: Tish Sommers, president of the Older Women's League, sat in a circle with a group of fellow delegates near the close of the l981 White House Conference on Aging here and assessed the 47 resolutions passed by the conference's committee on the concerns of older women.

title: The Waldheim Waltz
description: There's a touch of Sartre's ''No Exit'' in the affair. Fifteen fatigued members of the Security Council sit voting and voting for a United Nations Secretary General - with no result. Their best hope for release now is a looming deadline, Dec. 31, when Kurt Waldheim's second term expires. It's our guess that a winner will emerge at the last moment, if not Mr. Waldheim then a third-world clone of him. Not an enthralling prospect, but realistic.

title: Article 119285 -- No Title
description: By a vote of 84 to 5, the Senate today approved a $208 billion military appropriation bill, the largest financing measure ever to pass a chamber of Congress.

title: New York; TRASHING OLD PEOPLE (3)
description: This column has dealt in the last week with a particular landlord and the manner in which he has emptied his buildings of low-income tenants in order to convert the properties into high-cost housing and make astronomical profits. My phones, as a result, have rung constantly with calls from people who wish to report similar abuses by this landlord, Donald E. Crown, and many others.

title: Patents; Inventor Awards
description: Intellectual Property Owners Inc. has taken over management of the annual Inventor of the Year awards formerly handled by the Association for the Advancement of Invention and Innovation. Nominations for 1981 may be sent to Intellectual Property Owners, 1899 L Street Northwest, Suite 400, Washington, D.C. 20036, for the attention of Joseph P. Allen. The closing date is Dec. 31.

title: Study Finds Vitamin E Saving Infant Eyesight
description: High doses of vitamin E given to premature babies in the first 24 hours after birth can help prevent blindness sometimes caused by the extra oxygen they need to stay alive, researchers have reported.

title: DANCE: FESTIVE WORKS AT ALVIN AILEY GALA
description: The dictionary tells us the primary meaning of ''gala'' is ''a festive and lively celebration,'' and that is exactly what every gala by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater delivers.

title: 'Barnum' Cast Appears At Kennedy Center
description: The cast of ''Barnum,'' the musical at the St. James Theater, has been invited to perform tomorrow night at the annual Kennedy Center Honors presentation at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington.

title: Brazil Plans Better Wells
description: Brazil will close five oil-producing wells offshore next year for eight months to make equipment improvements, the state-owned oil company, Petrobras, announced today.

title: Noel to Defend Title
description: Claude Noel of Trinidad, who won the World Boxing Association's vacant lightweight title on Sept. 12 by beating Rodolfo (Gato) Gonzales, makes his first defense Saturday against Arturo Frias of Los Angeles, the W.B.A.'s ninth-ranked contender.
