title: No Headline
description: GERVIN SCORES 45 AS SPURS BEAT BLAZERS

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Sports People; Carter Close to Deal
description: Gary Carter, the Montreal Expos' all-star catcher, has only one year remaining on his contract and would like to be earning at least as much as Dave Winfield of the Yankees. Now Carter and the Expos are reported close to an agreement of seven or eight years that would pay, with cost-of-living escalations, about $2 million a year by the end of the pact.

title: REAGAN NAMES STANS TO OPIC BOARD
description: President Reagan today announced the nomination of Maurice H. Stans, a former Nixon Administration official who was convicted of election campaign violations during the Watergate years, to be a director of the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.

title: CELTICS SET BACK 76ERS BY 111-103
description: The Boston Celtics, sparked by Kevin McHale and Nate Archibald, defeated Philadelphia, 111-103, tonight and took over first place in the Atlantic Division from the 76ers.

title: ENTWISTLE CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 27
description: B-Including $3,558,000 income from discontinued operations

title: EX-CONTROLLERS FACING HARDSHIPS
description: In the last four months, Gary Pole has worked as a substitute teacher, custodian, auto parts clerk and warehouse assembler. He has earned $1,000, he says, $9,000 less than four months' salary from his old job.

title: RAGAN, BRAD, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EX-GREEN BERET IS CONVICTED OF ASSAULT ON LIBYAN STUDENT
description: A former Green Beret who said he was on a C.I.A. assignment when he shot a Libyan student here last year was convicted today of two misdemeanor charges of assault but acquitted of three charges of attempted murder.

title: VOTES IN ALBANY ON OVERRIDING VETO OF PROPERTY TAX MEASURE
description: Following is the vote by which the Legislature Thursday night overrode Governor Carey's veto of a bill revising the state's property-tax system.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; O.A.U. Assails Ciskei As a Bogus Nation

title: A NEW PRIEST LEAVES HOME FOR MINISTRY
description: Elizabeth Canham is to be ordained to the Episcopal priesthood Saturday morning, and the traditional rite at Holy Trinity Cathedral in Newark will make her something of an exile from her homeland and her church.

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $1.3 million extraordinary credit...C-Net loss... D-After $2.8 million extraordinary charge

title: CITY'S LABOR MARKET HOLDING UP
description: New York City's labor market does not show the weakening that is evident nationally, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday. "It's very much a blue-collar recession, and New York City is a w hitecollar town," said the commissioner, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt.

title: The Region; Tentative Accord At Entenmann's
description: A tentative agreement was reached in a three-day strike by 411 delivery-truck drivers for Entenmann's Bakery of Bay Shore, L.I. A Federal mediator, Hezekiah Brown, predicted that the agreement would be ratified by the members of Bakery Drivers' Local 802.

title: AT ARMS TALKS, SECRECY, SYMBOLS AND SPECULATION
description: The Avenue de la Paix offers no paradoxes. It is placid, clean, and sylvan. Not a leaf out of place, not a traffic jam in sight. If peace is order and stillness, then the avenue is well named.

title: Books of The Times; The Fiction of the City
description: LITERATURE AND THE URBAN EXPERIENCE. Edited by Michael C. Jaye and Ann Chalmers Watts. 256 pages. Rutgers University Press. $18 cloth; $7.95 paper.

title: SAL CABLE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Greece Termed Ready to Veto Spanish Membership in NATO
description: Greece is said to be ready to oppose Spain's admission to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and there were reports today that Western European leaders had asked Greece to refrain from using its veto against the Spanish.

title: CHAMBER OF COMMERCE PLANS TV NET
description: The United States Chamber of Commerce will soon begin beaming television programs to corporate offices around the nation to help business keep a closer watch on the Washington political scene.

title: FACELESS VOICES OF NCPAC VS. THE PUBLIC
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Premiere to Help American Place Theater
description: Patrons of the arts can attend the premiere of ''Four Friends,'' directed by Arthur Penn and written by Steve Tesich, and do a good deed for the American Place Theater, too.

title: Belgium Industrial Data
description: Belgium's industrial production index rose 14.6 percent in September over August but was up only 3.1 percent from September 1980, the National Statistics Institute said.

title: SKYE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $142,279 tax credit...C-Including $176,092 tax credit and $2,943,414 gain on the partial sale of a subsidiary; yr-ago results have been restated

title: Around the World; Pentagon Plans to Sell F-16 Jets to Venezuela
description: The Pentagon formally notified Congress today of plans to sell 24 F-16 jet fighters to Venezuela.

title: Around the World; Tanzanian to Try Again For Waldheim's Job
description: Salim A. Salim, Tanzania's Foreign Minister, said today that he would make one more effort to overcome the United States veto against his candidacy for Secretary General of the United Nations.

title: Court Upholds D.C.A. Decision
description: The Indiana Court of Appeals has ruled that Dynamics Corporation of America of Greenwich, Conn., did not violate Indiana laws by acquiring large quantities of stock in the CTS Corporation of Elkhart, Ind.

title: HUNGARIAN BUSES: NEW EXPORT ROLE
description: For the ancient Greeks, Icarus was a presumptuous mortal who wanted to fly like a bird. But he flew too close to the sun, melting the wax holding his homemade wings, and crashed into the sea.

title: INTRAUTERINE DEVICE FOUND A PERIL
description: Women who become pregnant while using an intrauterine birth control device and continue to wear the device during pregnancy run a significantly higher risk of miscarriage than women who do not, a medical journal has reported.

title: MASSMUTUAL MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $281,898...C-After gain of $14.2 million

title: METAL ARTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income and after an extraordinary tax credit of $25,000

title: Sports of The Times; The 'Celebration' for Joe Frazier
description: THEY lugged brown bags of pizza and orange-juice containers through the lobby of the hotel and carried them up to Joe Frazier's suite. Smokin' Joe used to party with soul bands and bright lights after his fights, and sometimes he even tried to sing, to prove nobody could hurt him, even when he lost. It used to be wine, women and song for Smokin' Joe, but on Thursday night, as the old joke goes, it was beer, mama and the radio.

title: Your Money; Safekeeping For Securities
description: SAFEKEEPING. The word conjures up an image of stocks and bonds neatly stacked in a granite room protected by guards and a heavily armored steel door.

title: THE RETURN OF PEARLS: A GUIDE FOR BUYERS
description: Once upon a time Pierre Cartier had a pearl necklace. It had taken him years to assemble all the big beautiful Oriental pearls. (This was before the time of cultured pearls.) Daisy Plant wanted the necklace. But, although her husband was very rich, she couldn't afford to spend $1.5 million, which is what Mr. Cartier wanted.

title: PAPERWORKITIS BUREAUCRATICUS
description: A number of Federal agencies in Washington have contracted for special programs to train their staffs how to write simply.

title: Court Will Hear Democrats On California Apportionment
description: The California Supreme Court announced today that it had voted unanimously to hear a Democratic lawsuit on reapportionment for legislative and Congressional districts.

title: DISPUTE IN TENNIS BALL SALES
description: Another big-name tennis match is shaping up. But this match is in the courts, rather than on the courts. The Dunlop Tire and Rubber Corporation has filed an antitrust suit here against Pepsico Inc.'s Wilson Sporting Goods Company, accusing Wilson of trying to drive its competitors out of the tennis ball market by selling balls to retailers at below cost.

title: Notes on People; Navy Rejects Criticism Over Naming of Submarine
description: A follow-up: It was requested by the Texas Congressional delegation and it won a resolution of appreciation from the city of Corpus Christi, but not everybody has been happy about the decision to name a new nuclear-powered submarine for the Texas city.

title: Patents; Oven Said To Save Energy
description: WASHINGTON AN oven that is open at the bottom and has no hinged door is regarded as offering substantial energy saving in food-producing facilities and homes. It was patented this week for DCA Food Industries of New York by Harold B. Kaufman Jr., manager of research engineering, and John P. McCarthy, a mechanical engineer.

title: HMW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $5,000 for the qr and $16,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of $85,000 for the qr and $1,268,000 for the 9 mos

title: HELEN F. BAUM
description: Helen F. Baum, an artist and writer on art and the environment, died of multiple myeloma Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Milton Klonsky, 60, Wrote Blake Books And 'Fabulous Ego'
description: Milton Klonsky, a writer of literary nonfiction, died of cancer Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.

title: The City; Dentist Robbed; Patient Attacked
description: A gunman burst into the office of a Queens dentist, robbed the dentist and his patients and sexually abused a woman before shooting her, the police said.

title: JETS HOPE SEAHAWKS HAVE NO MORE SURPRISES LEFT
description: In winning the five games played between the teams since they first met in 1977, the Seattle Seahawks have bedeviled the New York Jets in many ways.

title: Tracy Austin Bows, 7-5, 7-6
description: Chris Evert Lloyd ousted Hana Mandlikova, the defending champion, from the $200,000 Australian Women's Open tennis tournament today with a 6-4, 7-5 victory. Tracy Austin, the United States Open champion, was also eliminated, losing to Pam Shriver, 7-5, 7-6, in another quarterfinal match.

title: About New York; A TOUGH MONTH IN THE NEW LIFE OF A POLICEMAN
description: Charles H. Cochrane Jr. has been a police officer for 14 years, and it is apparent even when he is not in uniform. He talks of ''the department'' as though it is his life, not his work. He lapses in conversation into the convoluted, polysyllabic style that leads policemen to call thieves ''perpetrators'' and fights ''altercations.'' Even in describing the events of his life, he uses the stuff of which official reports are made - exact date, time, place of the occurrence. In just that way, Sergeant Cochrane remembers the events of the last month.

title: Classen Widow Reaches a Settlement With City
description: Willie Classen's widow, who asserted she developed psychiatric problems because of a mixup during an autopsy on the boxer's body two years ago, has reached a settlement of her lawsuit against New York City.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1981; Companies
description: The failing Central Savings Bank was merged into the Harlem Savings Bank, a slightly smaller but far sturdier institution. Under the merger, which was arranged by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, all Central Savings depositors have automatically become depositors of Harlem Savings. (Page 31.)

title: REAGAN BROADENS POWER OF C.I.A., ALLOWING SPYING ACTIVITIES IN U.S.
description: President Reagan issued an executive order today that broadens the authority of the nation's intelligence agencies to collect information from Americans at home and abroad. It authorizes the Central Intelligence Agency for the first time to conduct covert operations domestically. The 17-page order omits most of the provisions of an earlier draft that were opposed by members of the House Text of order, pages 18-19. House and Senate Intelligence committees and civil liberties groups, including a section that would have permitted the C.I.A. to infiltrate and influence American organizations without a court warrant.

title: JUDGE IN A LIBEL CASE BARS JURORS FROM SEEING COPIES OF PENTHOUSE
description: The judge in a libel suit against Penthouse magazine has termed the magazine ''nauseous'' and ''offensive'' to some groups and ruled that copies should not be distributed to the jury weighing evidence in the case. Instead, he ordered the article that is the subject of the suit to be removed from the March 1979 issue and given to the jurors.

title: Jack Manning Window Wonderland
description: Passers-by stopping to watch a Christmas display in the window of a department store on Fifth Avenue. The mechanical device displays a Christmas tale with music to entertain shoppers.

title: Israel Tells American Envoy Of Concerns About Lebanon
description: Israel expressed its concern today to Philip C. Habib, the United States special envoy, over what it called a heavy buildup of Palestinian guerrilla forces in Lebanon, Israeli officials said.

title: PRESS AND TV ARE ASKED TO CURB REPORTS ON PROTECTION FOR REAGAN
description: The White House has asked major news organizations to refrain from reporting details of measures taken to protect President Reagan.

title: WEST EUROPEANS CONSULTING ANEW ON SINAI FORCE
description: The Western European allies went back into urgent consultation today on the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force to try to salvage their participation in it in the face of new Israeli reservations.

title: SETON HALL AND VILLANOVA WIN
description: Villanova routed Boston College, the defending Big East champion, 97-75, in the first game of a doubleheader tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena. But it was Seton Hall's Pirates who supplied the 10,648 fans with the most excitement by defeating Houston, 87-85, in overtime.

title: The Region; Jersey Student, 25, Missing in Boston
description: The police in the Boston area were searching for Joan L. Webster, a 25-year-old graduate student at Harvard University, who disappeared while returning from her home in Glen Ridge, N.J., where she spent the Thanksgiving holiday.

title: YOUNG AND CRIMINAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Backs Ulster Efforts
description: President Reagan has endorsed joint efforts by the British and Irish Governments to help resolve the conflict in Northern Ireland. Irish officials said today that the endorsement was contained in a letter to Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald. London and Dublin are engaged in talks on ways to ease the strife in Ulster.

title: Around the Nation; Evidence of Promiscuity Barred From Rape Case
description: A Federal appellate court said today that evidence of a woman's sexual promiscuity could not be used as a rape defense if the defendant learned of the victim's behavior after the rape occurred.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 50 percent stock divd paid Nov 23

title: Briefing
description: A T the Peace Corps, employees are busily passing around William G. Sykes's parting letter - a letter that has angered Administration officials and plainly delighted some of the liberals within the troubled Corps.

title: Sports People; Ainge's First Test
description: Though Danny Ainge is finally a professional basketball player, his first workout with the Boston Celtics convinced him, not surprisingly, that he was not ready to join the team as a fullfledged member. ''I've got a lot to learn,'' he said, adding that he could not consider himself a Celtic ''until I prove I can beat someone out; that's the way it should be.''

title: DON'T REOPEN THE CHEMICAL WAR ON COYOTES
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNMENT CAR GUIDE IS PUBLISHED SECRETLY
description: ''The Car Book,'' the Government guide to automobile safety and economy that the Reagan Administration decided to let go out of print, is on its way to bookstores after being printed in secrecy in order to thwart possible attempts to halt its distribution.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the change from FIFO to LIFO inventory accounting effective Feb 1, 1980

title: O'S GOLD SEED CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: Tremors Shake Soviet Town
description: Earth tremors have destroyed buildings in and around the town of Ismailly, just west of the Caspian Sea, but caused no casualties, the official press agency, Tass, reported today.

title: Saudi Sells Hyatt Stake
description: Ghaith R. Pharaon, a Saudi Arabian businessman, has completed the $8.5 million sale of his 15 percent stake in the Hyatt International Corporation.

title: 'SMOOTH COURSE' IS REPORTED IN O'NEILL'S BYPASS RECOVERY
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill was reported today to be on a ''very smooth postoperative course'' after open-heart surgery Thursday.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL MINNESOTA (A.L.) - Signed Doug Corbett, relief pitcher, to a two-year con- tract reportedly worth $500,000.
description: OAKLAND (AL) - Signed Joe Rudi, o utfielder who had been a free agent, to a t wo-year contract. FOOTBALL NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Placed James Taylor, tackle, on the injured re- serve list and added Bob Young, guard, to the roster.

title: 5 Americans Withdraw From Paris Conference
description: A conference called to discuss alternatives to socialist philosophies that was to begin here Saturday has been set back by the withdrawal of five American participants, including Norman Podhoretz, editor of Commentary magazine.

title: STOCKS UP BROADLY IN HEAVIER TRADING
description: The stock market registered a broad advance yesterday in heavier trading, apparently because of Wall Street's growing conviction that interest rates would continue to decline.

title: STATE WILL HELP FREIGHT SERVICE KEEP OPERATING
description: Governor Carey announced today that the state would immediately make available $5 million to keep operating essential freight rail lines that the Consolidated Rail Corporation plans to abandon.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including gains of $264,000 for the qr and $415,000 for the 9 mos on the sale of rental properties...C-Including $1.1 milli gain on the sale of rental properties...D-Net income including $2.7 million gain on the sale of rental properties

title: BALLET: CHOREOGRAPHY FOR TRIPLE BILL
description: Theatrical challenges abound in ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' ''Le Rossignol'' and ''Oedipus Rex,'' the works that made up the Metropolitan Opera's Stravinsky bill Thursday night. And two choreographers faced these challenges most gallantly.

title: Sports People; Dolhpins' Strock Wary
description: Don Strock, the Miami Dolphins' backup quarterback, said yesterday that he wants the television commercials he and his wife did for a Miami restaurant taken off the air because the National Football League and F.B.I. have approached him about the restaurant's reputation as a meeting place for organized crime figures. ''I wouldn't do anything to jeopardize my career in the N.F.L.,'' Strock said.

title: Petro-Lewis Corp.
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation of Denver, which sought to acquire most of the oil and gas assets of the McRae Consolidated Oil and Gas Company, has discontinued the previously announced $76.9 million agreement. Petro-Lewis had offered $31 a share in cash for the reserves, which included two million barrels of oil and 27 billion cubic feet of gas.

title: Notes on People; Washington Sending Out Notes by the Foot
description: A simple letter in the mail from the United States Department of Labor would have told him what he needed to know, Mayor Patrick R. Fiorilli of Vineland, N.J., said with some exasperation yesterday.

title: IRENE EPPLE WINNER OF CUP RACE
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 4 -When Irene Epple of West Germany skied across the finish line today, she looked up and saw the outstretched hand of her younger sister, Maria, who had swerved down the giant slalom course moments before in the opening race of the World Cup season.

title: A NATIVE SON AND AN IOWAN TURN THEIR ANALYTICAL EYES ON NEW YORK CITY ; 'POLICIES, NOT PEOPLE,' FORM PROFESSOR BRECHER'S INTEREST
description: Charles M. Brecher was born in the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn. Now, 36 years later but never far from his roots, the professor of public administration at New York University has included the troubled facility in a project that will attempt to use business indicators to determine when a hospital is ailing financially.

title: Rangers to Start an 18-Year-Old Goalie
description: John Vanbiesbrouck, an 18-year-old rookie who has never played in a National Hockey League game, was designated today to start in the Ranger goal Saturday night against the Denver Rockies, the team with the worst record in the league.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF NEW STATE LAW ON PROPERTY TAX ASSESSMENT
description: Following are highlights of the new tax-assessment measure enacted by the Legislature Thursday over Governor Carey's veto:

title: De Gustibus; WHEN CHEFS DINE AT HOME
description: Anyone who doubts that true sophistication lies in simplicity should consider the tastes of most chefs and restaurant owners when they are planning their own meals. Having worked their way through gallons of sauces, miles of intricately devised galantines and drifts of airy quenelles and souffles, they generally lean toward the simplest dishes, which they regard with the greatest admiration.

title: DASHING THROUGH THE SILLY SEASON
description: Winter has finally arrived, and the atmosphere in the White House and Congress is filled with the sights and sounds of the season. Not Christmas, of course. It is the silly season of that annual ritual, the budget review.

title: HAIG PRESSES O.A.S. TO JOIN IN HALTING A LATIN ARMS RACE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. called on Western Hemisphere nations today to cooperate in stopping a regional arms race, accusing Nicaragua of a military buildup that ''is but a prelude to a widening war in Central America.''

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
7 GIVEN JAIL TERMS IN 'TOWN RIVALRY' DROWNINGS
description: For the sentencing this morning of the boys known here as the Lenox Seven, cars lined curbs for two blocks around the Berkshire County Courthouse. They filled the parking lots of the United Way office and the Women's Club.

title: MET OPERA: STRAVINSKY TRIPLE BILL
description: The Metropolitan Opera, which struck oil last season with the imaginatively staged and brilliantly designed triple bill, ''Parade,'' sank its drill in the same place Thursday evening. For a long time it looked as if the result would be a dry hole. The same team that gave us the Satie-Poulenc-Ravel triumph put together a triple-decker this time entitled ''Stravinsky,'' consisting of his ''Sacre du Printemps,'' ''Le Rossignol'' and ''Oedipus Rex.''

title: The Region; Kickback Jury Acquits Testa
description: NEWARK (AP) - A Federal jury acquitted former Councilman James Testa of Kearny Friday of charges that he had joined a pair of kickback schemes involving municipal sewage contracts.

title: Gerard-Imported Horse Is Barred From Racing
description: Stewards have revoked the certificate of registration of the horse As de Pique II, the Jockey Club announced yesterday. The action, taken early last month, followed reports in October that the 10-yearold horse is really an Argentine horse named Enchumao.

title: The City; Decision Delayed On Haitian Paroles
description: A Federal judge reserved decision on requests that eight Haitians be paroled as they await a ruling on their applications for political asylum.

title: HOLIDAY INNS TO ADD 25 HOTELS
description: Holiday Inns Inc., whose familiar neon sign has attracted a generation of economy-minded American travelers, announced yesterday that it was entering the luxury hotel market in New York, as well as in San Francisco, Los Angeles and other cities.

title: 1,000 Flee Ammonia Leak
description: An ammonia leak forced evacuation of at least 1,000 people from the 21-story downtown Amoco Building early today. No one was injured.

title: Rosalynn Carter's Secretary, Rita R. Merthan, Dead at 50
description: Rita Regina Merthan, who worked as Rosalynn Carter's personal secretary, died today at Georgetown University Hospital.

title: CENTRAL BANK IS MERGED
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation last night merged the failing Central Savings Bank into the Harlem Savings Bank, a slightly smaller but far stronger institution. The merger officially took place at 11:59 P.M.

title: Around the Nation; Arson Trial Defense Suggests a 2d Suspect
description: Attorneys for a busboy charged with murder and arson suggested today that someone else set the Las Vegas Hilton fires that killed eight persons on Feb. 10.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, DECEMBER 5, 1981
description: International Nicaragua's military buildup is ''but a prelude to a widening war in Central America,'' Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said in calling on Western Hemisphere nations to help stop a regional arms race. In an address to the Organization of American States General Assembly in Castries, St. Lucia, he also outlined a new economic assistance program for the Caribbean basin that contained proposals for one-way free trade agreements with small nations. This was the first concrete indication of the Administration's aid program for the Caribbean basin. (Page 1, Column 3.) The Sakharovs have been hospitalized, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, announced. They were taken to a hospital, apparently to bring an end to the hunger strike that the human rights activists began nearly two weeks ago. Andrei D. Sakharov, a physicist, and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, began their strike in their isolated apartment in Gorky, where they had been exiled, with only mineral water for sustenance. Tass said that physicians reported that ''medical assistance is being administered to them to prevent any complications in the state of their health.'' (1:2-4.)

title: Consumer Saturday; HOLIDAY PREVIEW OF TOYS
description: P ARENTS will question experts about buying toys, while their children get a chance to play with potential presents tomorrow at the 92d Street Y's Third Annual Toy Preview.

title: Going Out Guide
description: BRUNCHING

title: BILLY THE KID INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $730,000 gain on the sale of excess land and buildings; shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid Nov 4

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 17. 1. She is Dr. Ruth Westheimer, a professor of human sexuality, who is host of the radio call-in show, ''Sexually Speaking.'' 2. Harry F. Byrd Jr. announced his retirement after three terms in the Senate. 3. Firemen in Poland are a militarized force, wear military uniforms, and are under the authority of the Interior Ministry, the command center of internal security.

title: F.T.C. CLEARS U.S. STEEL ON ITS BID FOR MARATHON
description: The United States Steel Corporation won antitrust clearance yesterday from the Federal Trade Commission to proceed with its $6.3 billion takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company.

title: Continental Forest
description: Citing a decline in market conditions, Continental Forest Group said that its Port Wentworth paper plant had been closed for the third time this year.

title: A NATIVE SON AND AN IOWAN TURN THEIR ANALYTICAL EYES ON NEW YORK CITY ; RAYMOND D. HORTON FRAMES THE DEBATE ON PUBLIC POLICY
description: For a fellow who grew up in a farm town with fewer people than get stuck on the IRT each morning, Prof. Raymond D. Horton is making his mark on New York.

title: REAGAN AGREES WITH COMPROMISE SPENDING BILL
description: President Reagan today approved an agreement reached Thursday night between his aides and Republican congressional leaders concerning a spending bill to finance the Government for the rest of the 1982 fiscal year.

title: FILENE'S STORES SET IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Filene's, the Boston department-store chain that operates what may be the country's best-known bargain store, said yesterday that it will come to the metropolitan New York area next spring with four of its so-called basement stores - three on Long Island and one in Queens.

title: Rudi Rejoins Oakland A's
description: OAKLAND (AP), Dec. 4 - Joe Rudi, the outfielder whose defensive heroics and timely hitting helped the Athletics win the World Series from 1972 through 1974, returned to the team today after he was signed as a free agent.

title: POLES IN ACCORD ON BANK DEBT
description: Handlowy, Poland's state bank, reached an agreement this week to reschedule $2.4 billion in debt owed this year to 460 commercial banks in Western countries and Japan, the Dresdner Bank announced today.

title: TREE-TRIMMING TIME
description: Barefoot, Nancy Reagan helps decorate 19-foottall Christmas tree in the Blue Room of the White House.

title: DENIAL OF RKO LICENSE FOR BOSTON TV UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the Federal Communications Commission's denial of a license to RKO General Inc. to operate WNAC-TV, its Boston station. However, the court ordered the commission to reconsider its decision to deny RKO licenses in New York City and Los Angeles.

title: Garrard Dancers Plan Experimental Program
description: The Mimi Garrard Dance Theater will present four experimental works at the SoHo Loft Theater, 155 Wooster Street, on Dec. 18 and 19 at 8 P.M. and Dec. 20 at 2 P.M.

title: IVY LEAGUE IS FORCED TO LOSE MAJOR-TEAM FOOTBALL STATUS
description: The Ivy League, whose eight universities have football programs that are among the oldest in the nation, today lost a long battle to maintain its traditional place among the most powerful teams.

title: ITT Continental Trade Complaint
description: The ITT Continental Baking Company has been charged with violating fair trade laws in the operations of its former Gwaltney meatpacking division, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: New President At Texas Air
description: Robert D. Gallaway has been elected president of Texas International Airlines, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, airline officials said today.

title: Sports People; Ellis Named for '84
description: In a close vote, The Athletics Congress named Larry Ellis of Princeton as the men's track and field coach for the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles. Ellis edged Jim Bush of U.C.L.A., who had wanted to head the team because the Games will be held in his hometown. Also appointed were Brooks Johnson, to coach the women's Olympic team; Stan Huntsman of Tennessee, to coach the men's team that will compete at the world championships in Finland in 1983, and John Randolph of the University of Florida, as coach for the 1983 Pan American Games, in Venezuela.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Chinaglia Joins Indoor Team
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the leading scorer in the history of the North American Soccer League, decided yesterday to play with the Cosmos in their indoor season, which opens Tuesday night against the Chicago Sting at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: News Analysis
description: With the formation of a new Cabinet and a new hierarchy for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party last Monday, Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki has taken probably his most important step since he assumed office in July 1980.

title: Hard Words, Fair Deeds on Transit
description: The irrepressible Mayor Koch vents feelings in ways that often confuse those who take him literally. Having agitated for a law that would let him fire the managers of New York's subways, he has now assented to a much more conciliatory intervention. He has made room on the M.T.A.'s board for his new transit monitor, Ross Sandler, and given him a small staff for a full-time liaison mission.

title: Patents; New Ejection System For Naval Air Crews
description: A vertical ejection system for aircraft crews has been developed by the Naval Weapons Center, China Lake, Calif. Patent 4,303,212 was obtained for the Navy this week by W. James Stone and Ronald G. Stoutmeyer, project engineers.

title: No Headline
description: Maruk Scores 4 Goals As Capitals Top Jets, 7-3

title: South Africa Inmates in Fast
description: The South African prison on Robben Island, six miles northwest of Cape Town, has suspended once-a-month visits by relatives of political prisoners because some inmates have gone on a hunger strike. A statement today by the Commissioner of Prisons did not say how many prisoners were fasting or what they were demanding.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Paul (Bear) Bryant of Alabama, who has been applauded just about everywhere for winning more football games than any other college coach -315 - was cited yesterday in the United States Senate, which adopted a resolution commending him. ... John McEnroe said he was disappointed at Jimmy Connors's decision to bypass next week's Davis Cup final between the United States and Argentina in Cincinnati. ''I don't think it's right, but I don't want to get involved,'' McEnroe said.

title: MILWAUKEE WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After net from discontinued operations of $144,000 or 3 cents a shr for the qr and $249,000 or 6 cents a shr for the 6 mos; the Steego Corp owns 90.5 percent of the outstndg stock of the Milwaukee Western Corp

title: 3 TEAMS SHARE LEAD
description: Jane Blalock and Tom Purtzer birdied five holes on the front nine today en route to a seven-under-par 65 and a three-way share of the lead at the halfway point of the $500,000 Mixed Team Classic.Miss Blalock and Purtzer joined two teams with two-round totals of 134 at the top of the 48-team tournament. Sally Little and Andy Bean, the first-round leaders, shot a 68 for their 134 and the team of Amy Alcott and Mark O'Meara carded their second consecutive 67.

title: Around the World; 45 Killed in Stampede At Monument in India
description: Forty-five people, most of them schoolchildren, were killed here today when panicked sightseers stampeded down the narrow staircase of the Qutb Minar, a 12th-c@entury Islamic victory tower.

title: FIRST ARTISTS PRODUCTION CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOPE FADES FOR TRAPPED MINER
description: Cleo Hamrick, left, comforts Louise Arbogast, whose husband is still missing after a cave-in inside a coal mine in Bergoo, W. Va. Two other miners died in the accident, both found last night. A rescue worker held out little hope that Mr. Arbogast was alive.

title: SAKHAROVS, ON PROTEST FAST, HOSPITALIZED IN SOVIET
description: The official Soviet press reported today that Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist and human rights activist, and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, had been hospitalized, apparently because of a hunger strike they started 13 days ago.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
TESTIMONY HEARD IN ABBOTT CASE
description: A prosecution witness in the murder trial of Jack Henry Abbott, the convict-author, testified at a pretrial hearing yesterday that he saw Mr. Abbott point to the mortally wounded man he is accused of killing and warn him not to bother him.

title: Letter: On Federal Benefits; The Real Value of Congressional Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXT OF REAGAN STATEMENT ON ORDER
description: Following is the text of a statement by President Reagan on his intelligence orders issued today by the White House:

title: U.S. No.1 Beer Drinker
description: A survey by the Kirin Brewery Company, the world's second-largest beer producer behind Anheuser-Busch, showed that more than twice as much beer was consumed in the United States last year than in any other country in the world.

title: Around the Nation; Patricia Hearst Writes Of Role in Death at Bank
description: Patricia Hearst Shaw has disclosed that while she was a fugitive in 1975 living with a terrorist group she drove a getaway car after a bank robbery in which a woman was murdered.

title: M.I.T. APPROVES TIE WITH AN INSTITUTE
description: The corporation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, closely watched by major research institutions around the country, today approved a controversial plan to affiliate the institute with a multimillion-dollar, independent biomedical research institute.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S EXECUTIVE ORDER ON INTELLIGENCE ACTIVITIES
description: Following is the text of the executive order on United States Intelligence Activities issued today by the White House:

title: Linda Rothenberg Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee Rothenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Chicago, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Rothenberg, to Richard Gelfond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Gelfond of Plainview, L.I. The wedding is planned for June. Miss Rothenberg, an accountant, is with Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. Her fiance is an associate with the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton.

title: SOVIET IS PLANNING CUT IN OIL EXPORTS
description: A decline in Soviet oil exports, long predicted in the West, is now being officially projected by Moscow's economic planners themselves, the newly announced goals for the current five-year plan disclose.

title: 'Irresponsible Charges' Ruled a Citizen's Right
description: Contending that United States citizens have the right to make even ''irresponsible charges against public officials,'' a judge has thrown out a $10.2 million libel suit filed by a district attorney.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Missing Person
description: Dr. Margaret Kilcoyne, an assistant professor of medicine at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, vanished from her summer home in Nantucket, Mass., on Jan. 25, 1980.

title: C.W. Post Five Wins
description: Sue Salg, a junior forward, scored 23 points and grabbed 14 rebounds leading C.W. Post (1-2) to a 90-50 women's basketball victory over Molloy College (0-2) at Conolly Gymnasium.

title: A PERILOUS PASSAGE TO BIG-TIME BASKETBALL
description: James Reston Jr.'s stage adaptation of his book on Jim Jones, ''Our Father Who Art in Hell,'' will be presented next year at the Trinity Square Repertory Theater in Providence, R.I. By James Reston Jr. It is March 28, 1981 - the night of a college performance that could launch a pro career. Blue shirts of the University of North Carolina, often four at a time, surround 7-foot-4-inch Ralph Sampson of Virginia, frustrating him, keeping him to the outside, as the first half of the semifinal of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championships unfolds. Virginia retaliates with extra coverage on Al Wood, at 6-6 a superb shooter and perhaps one of the best team players North Carolina has ever had. The jockeying, the probing, the switching strategies result in a tie at halftime, 27 all. Wood has 14 points, Sampson 6, but the Virginia Cavaliers seem to have the edge. In their two regular-season victories over North Carolina, they have overcome large deficits.

title: Tips on Safety Offered In Purchasing of Toys
description: The New York State Consumer Protection Board issued a list of safety tips yesterday for parents and others buying toys for children for the holidays.

title: Joann Bonanno Will Be the Bride Of T.B. Walker 3d
description: The engagement of Joann Virginia Bonanno to Thomas Bidwell Walker 3d has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Bonanno of Garden City and Peconic, L.I., parents of the prospective bride. Mr. Walker is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Walker Jr. of Dallas.

title: Westchester Guide; ORCHESTRA'S UNVEILING
description: The Manhattanville College Community Orchestra will give a free concert at 8 P.M. Wednesday in the Benziger Building on the college's Purchase campus.

title: L.I. TAKES A CENTRAL ROLE IN B-1 PRODUCTION
description: AFTER postponing his vacation all summer so he would be around if President Reagan decided to go ahead with the B-1 bomber, Mike Philbin took his wife and four children to the Bahamas for one exactly one week in October. As luck would have it, that was the week Mr. Philbin had been waiting for.

title: Transactions; COLLEGE CALIFORNIA
description: Named Joe Kapp football coach to replace Roger Theder, who had been dismissed. SLIPPERY ROCK - Announced that Fred Goldsmith will leave his job as football coach, effective Dec. 31.; FOOTBALL SAN DIEGO (A.F.C.) - Activated James Harris, quarterback, from injured reserve and placed Jeff Williams, guard, on injured reserve.; HOCKEY HARTFORD (N.H.L.) - Sent Don Gil- len, wing, to Binghamton, N.Y., farm team.

title: Miss Jones to Wed Robert Armstrong
description: Dr. and James Monroe Jones of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwyneth Ann Jones, to Robert M. Armstrong, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Armstrong of Venice, Fla.

title: DELIGHTS FROM THE DISTAFF BACH
description: Every now and then even the most dogged music lover feels the need to relax with something a little less highly charged than the ''Eroica,'' ''Tristan und Isolde,'' ''Das Lied von der Erde'' or ''Wozzeck'' - especially at this time of year when tormented psyches wear out their welcome very quickly. Some turn to Gilbert and Sullivan for relief and some to Offenbach; others take advantage of ''The Nutcracker'' and unwind to Tchaikovsky's candy-cane music.

title: THE 70TH APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was established in 1912 by the late Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The Times. That year, 117 contributors donated a total of $3,630.88 to be distributed amont three private social-service agencies.

title: PLANNED PARENTHOOD GROUPS INVESTIGATED ON USE OF U.S. FUNDS
description: The Federal authorities are conducting a nationwide investigation of groups affiliated with the Planned Parenthood Federation of America to determine whether they illegally used Federal funds to promote abortion as a means of birth control or to finance political lobbying.

title: A Woman Reporter In Yankee Country
description: If Jane Gross gives up her assignment with the New York Yankees for next season, I will enthusiastically take over her spot and ''watch baseball games for seven months, spend hours each day dodging profanity in steamy clubhouses and sleep half my nights in ugly hotel rooms''! AMY LAINOFF Cortland, N.Y.

title: Mailbox; Yale Comeback Is Remembered
description: To the Sports Editor: Concerning the amusing Larry Kelley comment in Red Smith's column, ''Heismans Get a Home'' (The New York Times, Nov. 23, 1981), Mr. Smith mentions that Pennsylvania was leading, 20-6, in that 1935 game with Yale when Kelley ''learned'' that Penn football players spoke English, but Mr. Smith neglected to mention, and Yalies will be happy to know, that Yale rallied to win that game, 31-20. ROBERT JOHNSON

title: SUBMARINERS RECALL THE 'DAY OF INFAMY'
description: HACKENSACK ANDREW LINTHICUM JR., a young sailor from Jersey City, had just finished showering and was about to get dressed when he heard the hum of approaching aircraft.

title: BLAME THE POLITICIANS, NOT ECONOMISTS
description: R ONALD COASE, though not a household name, is a superstar in the economics profession. When he talks, economists listen. And when he recently delivered the Nutter Lecture at the American Enterprise Institute, he addressed the most important issue facing economists. He asked, how should economists choose between competing theories about how the world works?

title: FLORIE SHERTZER BETROTHED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Shertzer of Hawley, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Florie Sandra Shertzer, to Andrew Harrison Perellis, son of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Perellis of Louisville, Ky. A March wedding is planned. Miss Shertzer expects to receive a J.D. degree in May from the National Law Center of George Washington University, from which her fiance was graduated. Mr. Perellis is with the Chicago law firm of Rooks, Pitts, Fullagher & Poust.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: A LESSON FROM THE PAST
description: Exactly half a century ago, the bridge players of New York were agog with expectation. It was the eve of the great challenge match between Sidney Lenz, the leading player among the established authorities who had held sway in the days of auction bridge, and Ely Culbertson, the brash upstart who was reaching a mass audience with his books on the new game of contract.

title: JERSEY CASINOS LOOK TO SKIES FOR NEW PATRONS
description: This seashore and gambling resort, strictly a bus, train and automobile destination in the past, is now looking to the skies to lure new tourists from farther away.

title: Sara Gettys and Ernest W. Pierce 3d Are Married
description: Sara Elizabeth Gettys, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Smithwick Gettys of Rock Hill, S.C., was married there yesterday to Ernest Warren Pierce 3d, son of the late Marjorie Pierce Corey and the late Mr. Pierce Jr. of Braintree, Mass. The Rev. Robert J. Robinson performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of Sara Roddey Gettys, aunt of the bride.

title: Southwest Texas 62 Northern Michigan 0
description: Mike Miller hit Gary Peoples for two touchdown passes and ran for two more scores to lead Southwest Texas in an N.C.A.A. Division II semifinal.

title: De Paul Tops Purdue by 73-67
description: Terry Cummings scored 23 points and Bernard Randoph 20 to lead De Paul to a 73-67 victory over Purdue tonight.

title: Times Square East
description: To the Business Editor: I read with interest ''Forecast for New Year's Eve: A Rising Sun'' (Nov. 8), which remarked on the recent transformation of Times Square, that showcase of Madison Avenue's electronic pageantry, into a veritable ''Ginza West'' of Japanese advertising.

title: The Week in Business; MERGERS AHEAD FOR NEW YORK SAVINGS BANKS
description: Merger partners are being sought by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for the New York Bank for Savings, the Union Dime Savings Bank and the Central Savings Bank, banking sources say. All have been choked by the interest rate squeeze. Late Friday, it looked as though the Harlem Savings Bank would be taking over Central Savings.

title: Dining Out; A DISAPPOINTMENT IN JERSEY CITY
description: IT'S UNFORTUNATE that musical groups find it necessary to use amplifiers to increase the sound to a decibel level that is surely harmful to anyone constantly exposed to it. No where is this more unpleasant or more out of place than in a restaurant.

title: Wake Forest 66 American 63
description: SALEM, N.C. (AP) -Anthony Teachey made two free throws with three seconds left to help preserve the victory for Wake Forest. American (2-1) led by 34-33 at halftime and led by 8 points with 12 minutes to play before Wake Forest rallied.

title: FRIAS CAPTURES TITLE AS NOEL FALLS IN 8TH
description: Arturo Frias knocked out Claude Noel with a right to the chin at 1 minute 52 seconds of the eighth round today to capture the World Boxing Association lightweight title.

title: Kathy Sherman Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Kathy Lynne Sherman to Jonathan T. Suder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Suder of Teaneck, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Scott G. Sherman of Fort Worth. A May 30 wedding in Fort Worth is planned. Miss Sherman is an associate fashion editor of Glamour magazine. Mr. Suder is a student at the National Law Center of George Washington University.

title: A GUITAR DEVELOPED BY SPACE-AGE IDEAS
description: NEW HARTFORD ASK Charles H. Kaman of Farmington what he likes to do in his spare time and he will probably pick up a guitar and reply with a rousing rendition of ''Armenian Mama'' or ''Prattling Pond Blues.'' His sons, Bill and Steve, if they are around, might join in, as they did for the record album that the trio recorded in 1977.

title: COMING OF AGE
description: WASHINGTON FOR a quarter of a century and longer, the elderly have been trying to gain recognition as an entity in American life. They have formed organizations, hired lobbyists, boasted about their numbers and influence, elected friends and defeated enemies, sought and won special treatment from the Government.

title: POLISH JUDAICA ON VIEW AT HARVARD
description: A collection of Jewish artifacts from Poland, originally believed destroyed by the Nazis during World War II, went on exhibition this week in its first showing in the United States.

title: A REGAN-BELLAMY DEBATE OVER U.S. CUTS
description: Two potential rivals for statewide office next year, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and Carol Bellamy, the New York City Council President, disagreed strongly today on the effects of Federal cutbacks on New York's finances and social initiatives.

title: MISS ZABEL PLANS AUGUST WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Paul Zabel of Winnetka, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Blair Zabel, to Simon Sidamon-Eristoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff of New York and Highland Falls, N.Y.

title: Around the World; Khomeini Said to Order Release of 1,932 Prisoners
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has ordered the release of 1,932 prisoners, many of them arrested for political offenses, in the largest amnesty since dissent set off violent attacks on the clergy last June, the official Pars press agency reported today.

title: Maryland 74 George Mason 62
description: Adrian Branch and Jeff Adkins combined for 33 points as Maryland (4-0) held off two second-half rallies by George Mason.

title: JAZZ: ART HODES, PIANIST
description: Art Hodes, the Chicago pianist who made his debut at Hanratty's, Second Avenue near 92d Street, last February, has since become a regular on the select list of jazz pianists who perform as soloists there. He is now back for the fourth time this year and will continue through Dec. 19.

title: PAST THREATENS THE FUTURE OF INDIAN WOMEN
description: According to Manu, the codifier of ancient Hindu law, the proper role of women in society is clearly defined. ''In childhood,'' he wrote, ''she must be subject to her father, in youth to her husband and when her lord is dead, to her sons. A woman must never be independent.''

title: OREGON'S U.S. ATTORNEY SINCE '61 LEAVING JOB
description: Sidney I. Lezak, 56 years old, is resigning in his 21st year as United States Attorney for Oregon, a tenure remarked upon from coast to coast.

title: LIFE AMONG THE RUINS IN BEIRUT
description: John Kifner is the New York Times Bureau Chief in Beirut. By John Kifner Just driving across town can be a harrowing experience. These days, the best place to cross from predominately Moslem West Beirut to Christian East Beirut is at the port, where, in a pragmatic triumph of commerce over hate, shooting has become rare during the day. You ride down a twisting, rubble-strewn street, past the ruins of the once-luxurious Normandy Hotel. Soon, the hulks of crumblng buildings rise on either side of you, turning the road into a slender corridor. You sense, but usually do not see, the gunmen hiding within those ghostly buildings. You stop at a Syrian checkpoint, where, if luck is with you, a nod and a wave will signal you to continue on your way. You pass a dock; in the water nearby, rusted freighters lie on their sides. Driving on, you stay close to a line of cargo containers and away from the water's edge, where the snipers would have a better shot at you. Then, horn blaring to warn oncoming traffic, you drive through a dark and narrow abandoned cargo shed. When you re-emerge, you take a 90-degree turn that puts you, for the moment at least, in the clear.

title: HENRY COWELL-AN INFLUENTIAL 'AMERICAN ORIGINAL'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joan Peyser is the editor of The Musical Quarterly. By JOAN PEYSER

title: DIARY OF A GLAD HOUSEWIFE
description: Joyce Colony, the mother of four daughters, 18 to 25, writes from Alexandria, Va. By Joyce Colony It is quiet here this morning. Except for a squirrel chattering on the fence and a dog scratching at his locked door, the whole neighborhood is empty, all the children off to school, the fathers off to work, and the mothers, except for me, also off to work. I am alone on the block.

title: State Is Seeking a Rise in License Fees
description: INFLATION is eviscerating the Conservation Fund, which for years has provided most of the monies needed to operate the divisions of Fish and Wildlife and Law Enforcement of New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: December 6, 1981
description: NONFICTION AD REINHARDT. By Lucy R. Lippard. 87 AMERICAN FRONTIERS: The Photographs of Timothy H. O'Sullivan, 1867-74. Selected by Joel Snyder. 11 AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHERS AND THE NATIONAL PARKS. By Robert Cahn and Robert Glenn Ketchum. 76 THE AUTOCHROMES OF J.H. LARTIGUE: 1912-1927. 76 BACH AND THE DANCE OF GOD. title: Other World Events; A HAVEN IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: "Mad Mike" Hoare may have lost his touch as a mercenary, but he has not lost his appeal for white South Africa. A Pretoria court last week released without charge 39 of 44 men who, under his leadership, hijacked a plane to South Africa after a bungled coup attempt in the Indian Ocean island nation of Seychelles.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: NEW STUDY IS BEGUN BY U.S. ON RESIDENTS OF LOVE CANAL AREA
description: The Federal Government has begun a yearlong study to determine if residents of the Love Canal area suffered genetic damage from the chemical contamination there.

description: William Safire 22 On Language Splitting Heirs Russell Baker 36 Sunday Observer The Uncle Syndrome Zbigniew Brzezinski 40 What's Wrong With Reagan's Foreign Policy? Joyce Colony 44 Diary of a Glad Housewife James Reston Jr. 46 A Perilous Passage to Big-Time Basketball John Kifner 74 Life Among the Ruins in Beirut Walter Goodman 90 Irving Kristol: Patron Saint of the New Right Stephen Solomon 92 The Controversy Over Infant Formula Warren Hoge 110 A General Loosens the Reins in Brazil Arthur Levitt Jr. 136 In Praise of Small Business William Zinsser 154 Pearl Harbor: The Way It Was at Princeton Joanne A. title: Connecticut Gains Final
description: Connecticut scored two first-half goals to defeat Eastern Illinois, 2-1, today to move into the final Sunday with Alabama A & M.

title: UPSTATE CASE SEEN EXPANDING DEFINITION OF A DEADLY WEAPON
description: In what prosecutors and defense attorneys believe may be a precedent-setting case, a masonry contractor here has accepted criminal responsibility in a fire death that was caused by the improper installation of a fireplace home-heating unit.

title: KNICKS TROUNCE CELTICS, 103 to 83
description: Two nights after a 32-point loss to the Washington Bullets, one of the worst teams in the league, the unpredictable Knicks overwhelmed the Boston Celtics, the defending champions and one of the best teams, 103-83, at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: DANCE: ROOM TO MOVE
description: Sometimes guest artists on a dance program can provide delectable icing on an already rich choreographic cake. Sometimes they can seem like unnecessary intruders. And sometimes they can save the show from dullness.

title: Wichita St. 87, Cincinnati 67
description: Wichita State featured balanced scoring in winning the McDonald Classic tournament as Cincinnati lost for the first time this season.

title: Topics; GOOD NAMES AND BAD; Name Branded
description: The demise of a business often evokes regret over the loss of jobs and investment, occasionally over the disappearance of a favorite product, like the Packard. Not so with a restaurant chain called Sambo's, which recently declared bankruptcy.

title: REFUGEE AGENCY TO ASSIST 193,000 NEXT YEAR
description: An agency formed by 16 governments in 1951 to assist World War II refugees and displaced persons in Western Europe has approved plans to move about 193,000 victims of the world's continuing turmoils to new homelands next year.

title: Louisiana Schools Are Called Unready for Creationism Law
description: A state Education Department survey reports that Louisiana school systems have neither the knowledge nor the money required to carry out a new law on the teaching of creationism, a New Orleans newspaper reported today.

title: RULES ON TAX BREAKS WILL BE TOUGHENED BY NEW YORK PANEL
description: A state board that has given tax breaks to many New York companies for adding or retaining jobs will become tougher in its evaluation of applications, according to the officials who run the program.

title: Bruins 5, Nordiques 3
description: QUEBEC CITY (UPI) - Peter McNab scored two goals, including the eventual game-winner, to lead a rally by Boston.

title: Military Analysis
description: The United States cruise-missile program may develop into one of the biggest obstacles to conclusive results from the Geneva talks on limitation of intermediate-range nuclear arms in Europe.

title: FOR THE 'DOGS OF WAR,' A LOST AURA OF INVINCIBILITY
description: There was a time, not long ago, when mercenary soldiers, men seized with a vision of invincibility against ''third world'' forces, marched to the refrain: ''Vive la mort, vive la guerre, vive le sacre mercenaire'' - ''Long live death, long live war, long live the cursed mercenary.''

title: LAWYERS SAY TIGHT MARKET BRINGS RISE IN EVICTION ACTIONS
description: A shock awaited James Solomon when he returned to his Brooklyn apartment after a week away from the city last last winter: the lock on his door had been changed.

title: Carla Lynn Clay Is Married
description: The marriage of Carla Lynn Clay to Richard Kingsley Berry took place yesterday at the Immanuel Church-on-the Hill at the Virginia Theological Seminary in Alexandria. The Rev. Francis W. Hayes perfomed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: CITY IS SEEKING A LARGER PART OF STATE'S FEDERAL SCHOOL AID
description: A coalition of civic and parent groups is urging the State Legislature and the State Education Department to increase New York City's share of the shrinking Federal dollars allocated to the state for primary and secondary education.

title: LEGAL RIGHTS BEING ERODED, LAWYERS CHARGE
description: Vital constitutional rights regarding search and seizure, the right to counsel and a variety of fair-trial protections are being chipped away by the Supreme Court, Congress and public prosecutors, a group of prominent defense attorneys asserted last week before a gathering of lawyers at the New York City Bar Association.

title: RUMANIANS STAGE PROTEST ON A-ARMS
description: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators filled Palace Square in the heart of Bucharest today to demonstrate for the removal of all nuclear weapons from Europe.

title: BIG BLACK POP BANDS HAVE LOST EXCITEMENT AND ADVENTURE
description: Commercial pop music is perceived by one and all these days to be in trouble - ''trouble'' meaning not just the much-reported stagnation of record sales, but the seeming inability of the mainstream to renew itself creatively from vital tributaries. It is hardly time for cosmic doom-saying; the renewal will almost surely come one day. But for now, despite the undeniable spunk of some newwave rock, rapping, funk-jazz and what have you, most of the big older groups are producing recycled pap, and not that many younger bands show signs of being able to take over from them in a really dominant way.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; EARLIER WARNING ON GENETIC FLAW
description: Researchers are continually designing tests to identify genetic defects in a fetus that lead to disease in the adult. Now scientists at medical centers in New York State report they have successfully used a technique to detect the fragile X chromosome, a genetic disorder resulting in a form of mental retardation manifested primarily in males.

title: THE 'NEW FEDERALISM' LOOKS GOOD--FROM WASHINGTON
description: IT wasn't so surprising that when the National League of Cities gathered in Detroit last week, President Reagan's ''new federalism'' came in for plenty of flak. What was surprising perhaps was the intensity of the bipartisan attack. New York's Democratic Mayor Koch said the Administration's program to give local governments responsibility for scores of programs once supervised and largely underwritten by Washington was a ''sham and a shame.'' But many officials, some once regarded as influential supporters of the President, also complained bitterly about the financial strains on local governments. The League's departing president, Mayor William H. Hudnut 3d of Indianapolis, regarded as a Reagan ally not long ago, said ''too much has been asked of cities and other recipients of these Federal programs.''

title: CONFESSION URGED IN LINDBERGH CASE
description: Bruno Richard Hauptmann's lawyer pleaded with the convicted murderer to confess his role in the kidnapping of Charles A. Lindbergh's infant son during one of several jailhouse talks monitored by guards.

title: FUQUAY VARINA: WHY IT PAYS TO GROW TOBACCO
description: FUQUAY VARINA, N.C. I N the midst of the Depression, Congress allowed the nation's tobacco farmers to scrap the free market system and cut production by 25 percent. In so doing, the Government ended the volatile price swings of the 1920's and assured that tobacco farming would be a good business for decades to come.

title: CRITICISM MOUNTS ON G.O.P. GOVERNOR
description: In the Arkansas gubernatorial campaign last year, Frank D. White, a businessman running against Gov. Bill Clinton, a Democrat, played on what he took to be a widespread perception that the Governor had lost touch with the state's largely poor and increasingly conservative population.

title: New York Political Notes; PARTY'S OFFICE IS A SAFE ZONE AMID RANCOR; New York Political Notes
description: The Democratic National Committee's new office in New York City will be the political equivalent of a demilitarized zone. So fragmented is the New York party that national officials have moved in to provide officially neutral territory.

title: HEISMAN TROPHY TO ALLEN
description: Marcus Allen of Southern California, the first college player to run for more than 2,000 yards in a season, won the 47th Heisman Memorial Trophy yesterday as the nation's outstanding college football player.

title: Other World Events; COUP-CONSCIOUS SPAIN
description: Spanish Socialists have been giving the country's center-right Government the kid-glove treatment in Parliament lately because they fear its replacement could be far worse. Squabbles in the ruling Union of the Democratic Center, an uneasy blend of new-style democrats and old-style rightists, have given rise to new coup jitters only a month before 32 officers accused in the February coup attempt are due to be court-martialed.

title: On Language By William Safire Splitting Heirs Kimble Mead
description: ''The Pregnant Princess'' headlined People magazine. The Washington Post subheaded: ''The Heir Will Be Apparent in June.'' I am already knitting my linguistic booties. An heir apparent means more than ''next in line''; it means one whose right to title or property cannot be denied, if the heir outlives the ancestor. An heir presumptive is one who would inherit if the ancestor died, but whose claim would be defeated by someone else born in more direct descent.

title: IN PRAISE OF SMALL BUSINESS
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the American Stock Exchange, was also chairman of the 1980 White House Conference on Small Business. By Arthur Levitt Jr. As with most people who buy their own businesses, the odds against Robert Johnson were high. He was confronted at the start with an intimidating list of problems. He had no money, after laying out the purchase price, with which to start building up the business; he had no business experience or training, and he didn't know where to go for advice (beyond the help offered by the local Internal Revenue Service office on how to fill out 10 different Government reporting forms). There were no tax breaks, no Government loans, no expense accounts. Although he purchased the company from his uncle for what he thought was a good price, most everyone else would not have regarded it as a bargain. The Chicago business - Gamecraft of Illinois, which designed and produced board games - had been barely surviving since it was founded in 1968. Sales were declining, and stacks of bills were unpaid.

title: MODERN ART
description: PICASSO The Early Years, 1881-1907. By Joseph Palau i Fabre. Translated by Kenneth Lyons. Illustrated. 560 pp. New York: Rizzoli. $160 until Dec. 31; $175 thereafter.

title: ARTHUR PENN CONFRONTS THE PAST IN A NEW FILM
description: Adozen years ago, he was one of the hottest directors in Hollywood, with such recent triumphs as ''Bonnie and Clyde,'' ''Alice's Restaurant'' and ''Little Big Man'' to his credit. But in the last decade, Arthur Penn has made only two films, neither very successful, and although he has kept busy as a stage director, his name has faded in the minds of many American moviegoers.

title: Other World Events; Price of Punishment
description: Turkey last week jailed former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, but the ruling generals may regret it. After the Social Democratic leader began a four-month sentence for breaking a ban on political statements, the European Economic Community, already impatient at Turkey's postponement of promises to restore democracy, postponed $650 million in aid under a pact supposed to lead to Turkish entry into the E.E.C. Mr. Ecevit's jailing did not affect Caspar W. Weinberger's plans. The Defense Secretary visited Ankara, praised its law-and-order stand and agreed to establish a joint defense committee to strengthen military cooperation.

title: YEAR-END ISSUES ADDED
description: The United States is closing out the year by putting out more 20-cent stamps and a new bulk mailing issue to continue providing for the higher rates that went into effect last month. These stamps, plus a few stragglers coming out early in 1982, should end the period of make-do and let the American people adjust with equanimity to the fact that postage, like everything else, is costing more.

title: WOMEN OFFERING MUSIC FOR WOMEN
description: SPRAWLED out in a living room whose air was thick with cigarette smoke and floor was littered with empty coffee cups, the seven women in their late 20's could easily pass for graduate students cramming for exams.

title: The Region; Carey Can Stand The Pain of Veto
description: Sometimes the best way to get a thing done is to ask that it not be. The method works with recalcitrant children and, some observers suspect, state legislators.

title: Health; CAN SURGERY CURE MYOPIA?
description: Malcolm M. Manber is a senior writer for Medical World News. By Malcolm M. Manber

title: NEW RULES MANDATE POSTING RATES FOR HORSE-DRAWN CABS
description: No longer need the romance of a ride through the park in one of New York City's horse-drawn cabs be shattered at its conclusion by an unexpectedly, or illegally, high fare.

title: CAMPAIGN BY KOCH SHOWS BIG SURPLUS
description: Mayor Koch ended his New York City re-election campaign not only with a second term in City Hall but with a cash surplus of $135,000. The contrasts between the Mayor's opulent campaign and the efforts of his rivals were again underlined when fiscal reports for the final days before the city election were filed with the Board of Elections.

title: ANOTHER TILT IN THE 'ARENA' ARENA
description: AT LAST count, there seem to be about six people, all probably political or blood relatives of Brendan T. Byrne, who really support the naming of the arena in the Meadowlands Sports Complex in the Governor's honor. This may be an exaggeration.

title: NEW YORK F.B.I. CHIEF IS STREAMLINING OFFICE
description: There are days when Lee Laster gets up from the massive wooden desk that J. Edgar Hoover used on visits to New York City 40 years ago, and, looking out his 28th-floor window, surveys what looks to him like a ''maelstrom of criminal activity.''

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 7 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 12 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 3 4 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 4 5 17 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 5 7 31 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 6 8 5 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An Italian princess, in quest of romance, finds frustration, then fulfillment in America. 7 6 9 THE LEGACY, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The Lavette family of ''The Immigrants'' and ''The Establishment'' reaches the turbulent 60's.

title: But Why Punish the Flying Public?
description: Allowing the former air controllers to get other Federal jobs, as President Reagan has hinted, would be a humane gesture to an already severely punished group. The point that illegal strikes against the Government will not be tolerated has been made. Nothing more would be gained by denying those with transferable skills a chance to earn a living.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: Personal Finance; Q. & A.: HOUSING, DIVORCE, THE I.R.S.
description: T HE following are answers to some questions asked recently by readers. Q: I'd like to take advantage of the new rule that lets older people exclude from income up to $125,000 of their profits when they sell their home. I'm over 55 and have lived in my apartment for 15 years, but have only owned it the two years that it has been a cooperative. Do I qualify?

title: 100 M.P.G.
description: To the Business Editor: I heartily agree with Sherwood L. Fawcett that it's possible and practical to build a safe road vehicle that gets better than 100 miles to the gallon, ''The 100 M.P.G. Car'' (Nov. 22).

title: ARGENTINA'S ALPINE CHARMS
description: Along the eastern slopes of the Andes Mountains in southern Argentina is a region of fjord-like lakes and streams. The young, muscular mountains of the new world thrust skyward with awesome grandeur all around, while lakes that gleam like glass lure fly fishermen. There is gaiety, too, the gaiety of brightly colored parkas and sweaters of holiday skiers in winter, of wildflowers and splashing swimmers in summer.

title: ON LE MONDE STAFF, FRATERNITE IS GIVING WAY TO FRATRICIDE
description: If ever there was a newspaper for which the phrase Fourth Estate might have been designed, it is France's Le Monde. Stately it is, beyond question; and if its power is more spiritual than temporal - it spent 23 years largely disapproving of Gaullism and its heirs without doing them much harm - it does color the political and intellectual weather. Often gray.

title: Hofstra 50, Cornell 38
description: David Taylor, a forward who missed the first two games with a broken left hand, came off the bench and scored a game-high 11 points for Hofstra.

title: NURSING HOME LAW IS URGED
description: A special grand jury has called for laws that would make it a criminal offense for officials of nursing homes in New York State to solicit financial contributions from Medicaid patients or their relatives.

title: FOR BRITAIN'S SOCIAL DEMOCRATS, HEADY DAYS
description: Britain's new Social Democratic Party has spent the first days since its momentous by-election victory in a euphoric mood, its prospects brighter than ever.

title: NEW SPECIES OF FISH CAPTURED IN THE PACIFIC
description: Three fish that may represent a previously unknown species have been accidentally captured near the recently discovered hot springs on the Pacific Ocean floor and brought to the surface.

title: CAPITOL TRAUMA
description: HARTFORD IT was just a year ago last Friday that Connecticut was stunned by the announcement from Gov. Ella T. Grasso that she was resigning, effective Dec. 31, ''by reason of physical disability'' caused by her fight with cancer.

title: HELEN MOORE ENGAGED TO LIEUT. C.T. MILES
description: Dr. and Mrs. Peter Van Cortlandt Moore of Washington, formerly of New York, have accounced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Randolph Moore, to Lieut. Christian Thomas Miles, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ward Miles of Washington.

title: CONTEST FOR A HOUSE IS BARRED
description: A ''win a house'' contest constitutes a form of gambling prohibited by New Jersey law, a Superior Court judge has ruled.

title: Melanie Roden to Be Bride on May 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Roden 3d of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melanie Winner Roden, to Dr. Frederick Henry Bartlett 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bartlett also of Huntingdon Valley.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Hill, $22.95.) The most complete study of Pearl Harbor, laying to rest the theory that we were railroaded into war.

title: St. Bonaventure 49 Niagara 43
description: Unbeaten St. Bonaventure won its third game, led by Mark Jones, a guard, with 12 points. Trailing 24-19 at halftime, St. Bonaventure outscored Niagara, 16-2, during the first eight minutes of the second half for a 35-26 lead and was never headed.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT STARS, 8-5
description: Two short-handed goals by Butch Goring were just what the Islanders needed tonight to outscore the Minnesota North Stars, 8-5, at Metropolitan Center.

title: Spread of Gypsy Moths Stirs Federal Concern
description: Agriculture Department officials have expressed concern about the spread of gypsy moths outside the Northeast.

title: MUSIC: ENTREMONT, VIENNA CHAMBER
description: The Vienna Chamber Orchestra and its music director, the noted French pianist and conductor Philippe Entremont, brought an all-Austrian program to Carnegie Hall Friday night, offering compositions by two friends on the first half, and three members of a family on the second.

title: STUDY LAUDS NEW YORK STATE'S ENERGY OFFICE
description: The state's Energy Office has ''successfully filled its role'' in its first five years of existence and should be kept alive by the Legislature, according to a private report.

title: REMEMBERING FOOTBALL'S GRAND OLD MAN
description: IKNEW Amos Alonzo Stagg when I was a student at the University of Chicago, but at 135 pounds I was not one of Stagg's football players. I was on the track team while he was director of athletics. I was a cheerleader for Stagg's last three football teams at Chicago when the small size of our undergraduate body, and Stagg's soft recruiting, made it impossible to compete in the Big Ten. Things got so bad that on one morning of a game with Purdue, The Chicago Tribune ran a headline: ''Stagg Fears Purdue - And Everybody Else.''

title: STRIDING TOWARD RESPECT, THE CITY COUNCIL STUMBLES
description: Members of the New York City Council may have endured more than their share of derision over the years, but almost nothing could have prepared them for the recent turn of events.

title: Mandel Is Offered a Job
description: Former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland has been offered a job as a budget analyst for the city of Baltimore. Mr. Mandel was released Friday from a Federal prison where he had served 19 months of a three- year sentence for mail fraud and racketeering.

title: Major News in Summary; U.S. Turns Up The Heat on Central America
description: The Reagan Administration resumed ringing its Central America alarm bells last week, but for the first time tried to play a harmonious theme. Attempting to clear up confusion caused by months of contradictory statements, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig and other officials outlined an approach intended to gain regional support for moves to check alleged Nicaraguan and Cuban subversion and to minimize the need for American military involvement.

title: COMPUTER TO HELP IN TRANSIT REPAIRS
description: A new, $12.1 million computerized inventory system designed to speed repairs of the deteriorating subway fleet and increase workers' efficiency has been unveiled by the New York City Transit Authority.

title: Travel Advisory; PRESENTS PERFECT, ROMANTIC RHINE; Cottages in The Heart Of England
description: Some are rude, stone-walled farmhouses with huge fireplaces and leaded-glass windows overlooking the quiet pastures of Shakespeare's Warwickshire or the great Clee Hills of A.E. Housman's beloved Shropshire.

title: KEAN'S NO. 2 MAN AN ABLE POLITICAL OPERATIVE
description: During the fall campaign of Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean, Lewis B. Thurston 3d was anything but prominent in the day-today planning and operations. He stayed largely on the sidelines, away from the battle, and occasionally offered advice on issues for Mr. Kean's debates with his Democratic rival, Representative James J. Florio.

title: 35 CLAIMS SETTLED IN HYATT DISASTER
description: Four and a half months after 113 persons were killed in the collapse of two suspended walkways at the Hyatt Regency Hotel here, the survivors of the disaster and the relatives of the victims are beginning to settle their damage claims.

title: LISA HUNT PLANS BRIDAL IN SUMMER
description: Maj. Gen. Ira A. Hunt Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Hunt of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Merry Hunt, to John F. Batter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Batter Jr. of Rochester. The wedding is planned for next August.

title: The Careful Shopper; Shoe Bazaar Offers More Than Footwear
description: The Shoe Bazaar opened in 1968 in Briarcliff Manor and three years ago in Hartsdale Plaza on South Central Avenue. And there are Connecticut shops in Norwalk and in Stamford. The discount policy is 15 percent to 20 percent off list or department store advertised prices, and during this month's semiannual clearance footwear and handbags that are marked with red dots are further reduced, some by as much as 50 percent. The shoe sizes are mostly 5 1/2 to 10, with some size 5s; there are a few wides, but most are medium or narrow; and special orders from other branches are possible.

title: Other World Events; NEW TEAM FOR SUZUKI
description: American trade representatives will see some new faces in Tokyo next week when they resume talks on how to whittle down Japan's anticipated $15 billion trade surplus with the United States.
