Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki last week shuffled his Cabinet and said its main task would be to reduce the surplus by breaking down Japanese barriers to imports.

title: The Facts of Business
description: Sidney Blumenthal's article contains the following quotation from Alan Greenspan: ''We are now living in an economy whose evolution is based on the market's judgment of politics.

title: CHAMBER: KRABER PLAYS FLUTE
description: Karl Kraber's self-effacing concert Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall was correctly subtitled ''An Evening of Chamber Music with Flute.'' Mr. Kraber, who is the flutist in the Dorian Wind Quintet, modestly gathered some of his colleagues around. Singly and in pairs, they joined him in music by Hummel, Casella, Weber, Heiden and Prokofiev.

title: Theater; 'ST. LOUIS' TAKES A TRIP TO THE STAGE
description: G-M Story'' credits the 1944 film, ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' as the best picture of Judy Garland's career. Though it has an excellent musical score, the film was not so much a musical as a family album brought to cinematic life as it told the story of the Smith family in turn-of-the-century St. Louis at the time of its World's Fair. Agree with Mr. Eames or not, ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' has become a film classic, a movie buff's movie.

title: Scientific Fraud
description: Morton Hunt's article ''A Fraud That Shook the World of Science'' (Nov. 1) is a thought-provoking excursion to the nether side of scientific research. But one point that was made only briefly deserves a little more emphasis - the currently condoned practice of allowing an author to claim credit for research activities in which he has, very simply, not participated at all.

title: REDUCING AID FOR STUDENTS SHORTCHANGES NATION'S FUTURE
description: BUILDING an annual budget at the University of Hartford has never been easy, but this year it's a pip. The university is a modestly endowed, labor intensive, independent institution founded in 1877 but chartered as a university only 25 years ago, and a lot of fancy footwork and hard work is needed to keep its books in balance. But we've done so regularly for a long, long time. It's a tradition that we intend to maintain.

title: Westchester Housing; NEIGHBORS FIGHTING GARBAGE SITE
description: ''I'M not saying the garbage should be put in somebody else's backyard,'' said Albertha Thomas of Briarcliff Manor. ''I'm saying it shouldn't be in anybody's backyard.''

title: Lisa A. Castellani Becomes a Bride
description: Lisa Anne Castellani, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Attilio Castellani of Atlantic City, was married there yesterday to Oliver Knowlton, son of Winthrop Knowlton and Mrs. Thomas Wyman, both of New York. The Rev. Joseph Ferrara performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: St. Francis 62, Wagner 58
description: Darius Pearson made four free throws in the final 38 seconds in the game at Wagner's gymnasium on Staten Island. St. Francis, which had trailed since early in the first half, tied the score at 52-52 on a basket by Robert Jackson with 5 minutes 10 seconds to play. Pearson's first two free throws, with 38 seconds left, gave St. Francis a 58-56 lead.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Regrettably, poverty is Hispanic and black in the city of New York.'' -Mayor Koch. (48:5.)

title: PALMER IN TROUBLE
description: Playing in the Seniors championship Friday at Miami, Arnold Palmer hits from a difficult lie during the second round.

title: CONTROLLERS' PAY CAUSES DISSENSION
description: The Reagan Administration is spending tens of millions of dollars on its program to replace the striking air traffic controllers who were removed last summer.

title: Dining Out; GERMAN FARE EXPERTLY PREPARED
description: ON a chilly autumn evening, the substantial, honest fare that is served at the new Oak Chalet in Bellmore is enormously appealing. As an added welcome, the bright, spacious restaurant with its lofty wood ceiling usually has a fire glowing in the hearth near the entrance.

title: PRESSES RUN ON ENTHUSIASM
description: ''ISEEM to have a compulsive interest in printing,'' Ben Lieberman said, sitting near the historic printing press and the display cases tracing the history of letters that decorate the living room of his New Rochelle home. He added: ''I also love to get others interested in the hobby of private printing.''

title: WESTPORT'S DENIAL OF ARCADE BATTLED
description: WESTPORT I N Arnold Kaye's view, his proposal to open an electronic game room and pool parlor on Post Road here ''would provide good, clean and mind-stimulating fun in a well-supervised and elegant facility.''

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Certain photographs inevitably call to mind certain other photographs. Sometimes their subjects are alike, sometimes their styles seem to overlap, sometimes there is nothing but a certain feeling that unites these pictures taken at very different times under very different circumstances by very different people.

title: BLUE CROSS RATE RISE IN JERSEY
description: Individuals and small-group subscribers to the Blue Cross plan will begin paying more for the insurance beginning Jan. 1, according to the New Jersey Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran.

title: SUDDENLY THE ACCENT IS SOUTHERN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dan Hulbert is theater critic for The Dallas Times Herald. By DAN HULBERT DALLAS The Meadows School of the Arts at Southern Methodist University here has discovered an interesting formula for developing young playwrights - offer them degrees in every area of theater except playwriting, then send them out into the world as journeymen actors and directors.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE Some of the jolliest pagan dances in the world will make a comeback this week at the Symphony Space in a program called ''The Christmas Revels.'' The focus will be on old English ritual and country dances, now associated with Christmas but which go back to pre-Christian fertility and healing rites.

title: Sports of The Times; At 12, She Wants to Be a Celtic
description: KAREN O'CONNOR wants to play like Larry Bird. When she shoots baskets by herself, she admits, she dreams of wearing a green Boston Celtic uniform, throwing elegant passes and making jump shots just like No. 33. He is, she says, ''a complete player.''

title: Holy Cross 66, Xavier 60
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Kevin Greaney scored 14 points to lead Holy Cross (3-1).

title: News Analysis
description: After months of often contradictory signals, Reagan Administration officials say they have settled on a four-part approach to dealing with what they see as the problems of Cuban and Soviet intervention in Nicaragua and elsewhere in Central America.

title: SCHOOL STILL FEELS BAKKE AFTERMATH
description: Faced with a sharp decline in black enrollment since 1978, when the Supreme Court ordered Allan M. Bakke admitted to the medical school of the University of California at Davis, the school has hired a consultant and obtained a Federal grant to attract students from minority groups.

title: Deborah Conese Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene P. Conese of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Conese, to James Earle Eagan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Eagan of Stamford, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: 36 Dispensers of Food Cited on Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department last week cited 36 food establishments for violations of the city's Health Code. Six others were reopened after correcting previous violations and five were closed for failure to comply. VIOLATIONS Fong's, 124 Dyckman St. Bonjour Croissant, 701 Lexington Ave. Sun Sun, 1610 St. Nicholas Ave. 103 Second Ave. Restaurant, 103 Second Ave. Dakota, 550 Third Ave. Hernando Quiceno, 307 W. 39th St. John Markopolous, 252 W. 40th St. The Lord India, 102 W. 43d st. Shakti Foods, 359 W. 45th St. Bill Nolte, 258b W. 55th St. Cake Masters, 122 W. 72d St. F. B. Southern Soul Foods, 303 W. 116th St. Kentucky Fried Chicken, 280 W. 125th St. Jay's Bar, 307 W. 125th St. Lenox Lanes, 140 W. 146th St. Koroney's Pizza, 1761 University Ave. Bingo Snack Bar, 40 W. Burnside Ave., Bronx. Nick's Bar & Grill, 4031 Third Ave., Bronx. Angelo Pizza, 201 E. 163d St., BRonx. Oh Ho Kitchen, 35 E. 170th St. Bronx. Blimpie, 110 E. 170th St. Bronx. Green Leaf Pub, 216 W. 242d St., Bronx. Riviera Restaurant & Pizzeria, 1314 Cortelyou Rd., Brooklyn. Nino's Pizzeria, 1014 Flatbush Ave., Brooklyn. Golden Corner No. 5, 415 Halsey St., Brooklyn. Lechonera Las Delicias, 96 Manhattan Ave., Brooklyn. Julio's Coffee Shop, 55 Messerole Ave., Brooklyn. Evers, 1007 Winthrop St, Brooklyn. New McBride Deli Lunch, 595 Third Ave., Brooklyn.

title: IT WAS A TRANQUIL DAY AT PEARL HARBOR, AND THEN...
description: THE whipping sound of propellers, beating against moist ocean air, brought back memories for Joe Hydrusko of World War II and the day it began for the United States, Dec. 7, 1941. Joe, a former Navy seaman and now a resident of Massapequa, and I were out in eastern Long Island on Veterans Day, making a test flight in a 1929 Curtiss Robin. Every Dec. 7 for the last 11 years, Joe has been making a fly-by over the Statue of Liberty in remembrance of friends and fellow Americans who died on that day and in the war.

title: PIRAEUS: A PAUSE THAT REFRESHES
description: SHERRY MARKER is a writer who lives in Northampton, Mass. By SHERRY MARKER

title: AN OLD CEMETERY PLOT IS CENTER OF ONGOING DISPUTE
description: NEW ROCHELLE FOR more than 90 years, starting in 1800, members of the Flandreau family were laid to rest in a small plot on the rolling farmlands along Boston Post Road at what is now the eastern edge of this city.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Home Clinic; WHEN USING A WOOD-BURNING STOVE, ADD A DASH OF SAFETY
description: MANY homeowners in this area have, in the last few years, installed wood-burning stoves to provide heat for a newly added room, or to be used as a supplementary means of heating so they can keep the thermostat on the central system turned way down during a good part of the day.

title: DANCE: PREMIERE OF CHOO SAN GOH'S 'SPECTRUM'
description: In the 1920's, Ruth St. Denis composed dances she called ''synchoric,'' in which each dancer represented a separate instrument of the orchestra. Jerome Robbins used a similar method in his ballet ''Fanfare,'' whose music by Benjamin Britten was also charmingly didactic, having been conceived as ''a young person's guide to the orchestra.''

title: N.A.S.L. Is Going Indoors in Big Way
description: The North American Soccer League, which lost seven franchises since the end of the outdoor season last September, embarked on its third indoor venture last week.

title: 12 LAST-MINUTE HOLIDAY GETAWAYS
description: If you look at the top of this page, you will discover that it is Dec. 6. If you are already ticketed to go somewhere great for the holidays, read no further. (You are probably the sort who has not only bought but also wrapped his Christmas presents.) If, however, you are only now beginning to think about getting away, you may be in trouble. Help is at hand.

title: NEW U.S. ATTORNEY TAKES TOUGH STAND
description: NEWARK THE new United States Attorney for New Jersey, the son of a State Senator and one-time candidate for Governor, promises to step up the Government's fight against organized crime and political corruption.

title: Business Conditions; WORLD TRADE OFF SHARPLY
description: The deepening economic slump is putting strains on exporters throughout the world. For the first time since 1958, total world trade may show a decline in both current and inflation-adjusted dollars.

title: A COMPUTER THAT INSPIRES A MEETING OF MINDS
description: THE wave of interest in Japanese management philosophy is influencing the way American executives think. William W. Simmons, a Greenwich businessman, can attest to that fact.

title: Illinois 55, Kansas State 49
description: Craig Tucker scored 14 points and Perry Range and Derek Harper had 12 each to lead Illinois (2-0). Ed Nealy scored 10 of his game-high 17 points for Kansas State (3-1) in the first half.

title: E. KENTUCKY OUSTS DELAWARE
description: Chris Isaac's 32-yard scoring pass to Ranard McPhaul with 1 minute 8 seconds to play today lifted Eastern Kentucky to a 35-28 victory over Delaware in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I-AA playoffs.

title: Boise St. 19, Jackson St. 7
description: John Broadous ran for 75 yards, including a touchdown, and Rodney Webster rushed for 156 yards to lead Boise State in an opening-round N.C.A.A. Division I-AA playoff.

title: Major News in Summary; Kremlin Moves On Hunger Strike
description: In one respect, Andrei D. Sakharov's 12-day experiment in selfstarvation proved out last week. Soviet authorities announced they had ''hospitalized'' the 60-year-old physicist and winner of the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, 58.

title: LUCAS KEEPS THE HOUSE IN ORDER
description: THE question was posed to Bill Cartwright, a center for the New York Knicks, almost as an aside - as a means of keeping the conversation flowing in the players' lounge just about an hour before a recent game. Thus, it was almost startling that it would produce such a response at this quiet moment.

title: UTILITY CUTOFFS: NEW PROTECTION
description: MODIFICATIONS in the state's winter moratorium on utility shutoffs, which began last Tuesday, are expected to give additional protection not only to those utility customers who have trouble paying their bills, but also to the companies in trying to collect payments from those who really can afford to make them.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PUERTO RICO
description: MANUEL SUAREZ contributes to The Times from Puerto Rico. By MANUEL SUAREZ

title: EVICTION WARNINGS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Forty-one tenants of Carnegie Hall have just been warned that eviction proceedings will be initiated against them in 30 days unless they sign renewal leases at higher rents. The action was the latest in a continuing controversy that has raged over the last four years.

title: School Begun by a U.S. Saint Set to Close After 173 Years
description: St. Joseph's High School, one of the nation's oldest Roman Catholic schools in the United States, is to close next year because of increasing costs and declining enrollment, school officials say.

title: Fashion; VREELAND'S SHOW
description: Andre Leon Talley is a freelance reporter on fashion. Diana Vreeland, whose dictates have influenced fashion trends for nearly five decades, is very much a woman of the 20th century. She is also, it turns out, very much a woman of the 18th century.

title: SIGMUND FREUD'S 'PECULIAR' LIFE IN VIENNA
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Happier Holiday
description: It won't shorten his time in prison much, but last week President Reagan commuted the sentence of Marvin Mandel, the former Maryland Governor who, with five co-defendants, was convicted of mail fraud and racketeering. Under the Presidential order, Mr. Mandel would be released on Dec. 20 -five months before finishing his three-year sentence and just in time to get home for the holiday season.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Taxes. When the Economic Recovery Act of 1981 became law last August, the rules of the game were drastically changed for millions of taxpayers. A flash flood of books has resulted in which tax lawyers and newspaper financial writers explain how it's now played:

title: LETTERS REFLECT CONCERN FOR WILDLIFE
description: WASHINGTON WHEN he was President, Gerald R. Ford received a letter from a worried woman in New Jersey's Pine Barrens. She had the mistaken notion that Government scientists were planning to hunt and kill the legendary Jersey Devil, and she wanted the President to stop the expedition.

title: PINELANDS PANEL'S CHAIRMAN REFLECTS ON HIS STEWARDSHIP
description: NOTHING could be farther removed from the solitude and wilderness deep within the New Jersey pinelands than Rockefeller Center, deep within midtown Manhattan.

title: GIORGIO MORANDI: A QUALITY OF PRVATE MEDIATION
description: In a noisy and embattled world, where the agitations of the spirit keep the esthetic impulses in a continual state of exacerbation and upheaval, almost any art that strikes us as emanating from some inviolate zone of privacy, serenity and detachment is likely to exert an irresistible appeal. Upon the artists whose work provides us with this very special feeling of release from the wearying commotions of worldly events - in a culture like ours, there can never be very many of these exemplary figures - we are therefore inclined to confer a kind of sainthood. They seem to occupy a spiritual universe so very different from yours and mine.

title: A TRAVELER'S GUIDE FOR THE DISABLED
description: PRINCETON HANDICAPPED travelers considering a whirlwind wheelchair tour of American cities might first check a guide in the Princeton Public Library. It has navigational tips on everything from restful parks to restrooms.

title: Gardening; EVERGREENS OFFER BEAUTY AND PRACTICALITY
description: THE most attractive gardens are those planted with a combination of evergreen and deciduous plants, but one cannot deny that evergreens are indispensable during the winter. Many ancient Northern tribes considered these plants, which retain their leaves when all others appear to have died, the repository of life that would return again with the spring.

title: TWO ARE INDICTED IN TEAPOT DOME OIL INVESTIGATION
description: Two persons have been indicted and a number of others are being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the suspected theft of oil from the Federal Government's Teapot Dome oil reserve in central Wyoming.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1981
description: International A U.S.-Turkish joint defense group will be established to ''enlarge and improve defense cooperation,'' the two countries announced in Ankara after a visit by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. The announcement was the chief concrete result of Mr. Weinberger's threeday visit, but equally important was his endorsement of Turkey's military regime and its moves to restore democratic rule. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: New Jersey Guide; A NEW 'NUTCRAKER'
description: A glittering new ''Nutcracker'' -new sets, new choreography, everything - is being presented this year by the Princeton Ballet. And to celebrate the new production, a gala opening-night benefit performance at the McCarter Theater on Dec. 18 will feature Peter Martins and Darci Kistler as the Cavalier and the Sugar Plum Fairy.

title: WOMEN PICK DEMOCRATS OVER G.O.P. IN POLL
description: Three times as many Americans think the Democratic Party best serves the interests of women as do those who favor the Republican Party, according to a Gallup Poll.

title: CO-OPS ON LEASED LAND STIR IRE
description: It's a ''Cheshire cat'' situation, says Earlene Spellmann, but she isn't grinning. Her building at 207 West 106th Street has received a preliminary offering plan for conversion to a cooperative. But the sponsor is proposing a leasehold cooperative. The cooperative corporation would not own the building or the land under it outright, as is the usual case. Instead it would lease the land and building on a long-term basis. Land and building would revert to the owner when the lease expires, unless it is renewed.

title: ATHLETES TESTING ISSUE OF DISCIPLINE
description: S OMETIME in the next few weeks, Dolores Vorhies and her son Tim will submit a proposal to New Jersey legislators to ban physical punishment drills in sports throughout the state.

title: MUSIC
description: Of the many books on music published in the past year, none was more ambitious, monumental and expensive than the NEW GROVE DICTIONARY OF MUSIC AND MUSICIANS, edited by Stanley Sadie, in 20 volumes, priced at $1,900. Scholars will be picking over it for years to come, and there will be changes and additions (already under way), but that does not negate the sheer accomplishment of the undertaking. It is a triumph of modern musicology, representing the highest ideals.

title: THIRD WORLD OFFERS PLAN FOR RICH-POOR TALKS
description: Representatives of developing countries here have drafted a blueprint for making a start next year on the long-delayed talks between the industrialized and developing nations that would seek to shift wealth from the rich to the poor.

title: BRIDGE COLUMN CORRECTED
description: Because of a computer coding error, the Bridge column on page 43 of the Arts and Leisure section today includes an incorrect bidding sequence. The description of the beginning of the play of the hand is also incorrect. The play began with the lead of the three of hearts. The correct hand and bidding sequence are as follows: [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ]

title: INQUIRY REOPENED ON F.A.L.N. ACTIONS
description: New information provided by a convicted member of F.A.L.N., the terrorist group seeking independence for Puerto Rico, has led Federal authorities to revive their investigation into 31 unsolved bombings in New York City. These include the 1975 blast that killed four persons and injured more than 60 at the historic Fraunces Tavern in lower Manhattan.

title: GROWING GARDENIAS CAN BRING THE SWEET SMELL OF SUCCESS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Anna L. Wang is a writer, who with her husband, Hui-ming, translated ''The Chinese Ping Pong Book.'' By ANNA L. WANG

title: KLANSMEN DON'T SPEAK FOR 'WHITE AMERICA'
description: To the Editor:

title: PICKING UP THE PIECES AFTER A NIGHTMARE
description: TO Sarah, Far Rockaway in Queens is ''the country'' - or at least the most rural stretch of land she has ever known. ''I told all my friends who grew up in the South, 'I finally got to live in the country like all of you,' '' she said.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH REAGAN'S FOREIGN POLICY?
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's Assistant for National Security Affairs, is Herbert Lehman Professor of Government at Columbia University and senior adviser to the Center for Strategic Studies at Georgetown University. By Zbigniew Brzezinski If present trends continue, American foreign policy is likely to be in a state of general crisis by the spring of 1982. What makes matters potentially even worse is that this could coincide with a serious economic downturn, causing the overall global position of the United States to be placed in jeopardy. There is urgent need for President Reagan to take serious stock of the unfolding situation, so that the needed responses, both substantive and procedural, can be generated.

title: The Region; Moffett Begins Run for Senate
description: What the Government needs is ''new blood'' on the Senate floor, Representative Anthony Toby Moffett said last week. So he offered his own.

title: IN THE BATTLE OF THE MISSILE BOOKLETS, CHARTS AND FIGURES ARE THE WEAPONS
description: When President Reagan went on television to offer the Soviet Union a missile deal in Europe, Progress Publishers in Moscow was busy printing tens of thousands of copies of a small blue booklet designed to persuade Western Europeans that the real threat to their security came from the United States.

title: STAMFORD MACY'S A SIGNAL OF GROWTH
description: STAMFORD NEXT spring, R.H. Macy & Company, the largest retailer in the metropolitan area, will open the first new store in its New York division in eight years in the spanking new Stamford Town Center Mall. The three-story 266,000-square-foot store will be an anchor in the urban mall along with a large unit of J.C. Penney Company and later with a Saks Fifth Avenue branch store.

title: KENTUCKY DEFEATS OHIO STATE
description: Dirk Minniefeld made seven of eight shots from long range in the second half to help Kentucky to a 78-62 victory today over Ohio State. Minniefeld, a junior guard, led Kentucky (2-0) with 18 points.

title: LAWMAKER FACING QUERIES ON FUNDS
description: A takeover battle involving a company long controlled by Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn has raised questions about his relationship with the company, which pays him $100,000 a year and contributes to his private and political interests.

title: Ivy Coaches Resent Football Demotion
description: It is the football league with teams on which Amos Alonzo Stagg, Albie Booth and Sid Luckman played. It is the league in which Percy Haughton, Pop Warner and Lou Little coached, and where football was developed during the second half of the 19th century into the game that is now worth millions in television revenue and gate receipts to other colleges.

title: Business Conditions; INSULATION IN CHEMICALS
description: Although the recession is showing signs of spreading beyond the auto, housing and construction sectors, so far chemical companies seem relatively unscathed. In spite of sagging foreign and domestic demand, the major manufacturers have been protected from the ravages of the economic slump by price increases, lower costs for raw materials and rationalization of production.

title: EDUCATORS DISCUSS MUTUAL PROBLEMS
description: The differences that divide supporters of public and nonpublic education were largely set aside while high-ranking administrators from the two sectors discussed their mutual concerns, particularly how to improve classroom teaching.

title: No Headline
description: Helena Wachslicht-Rodbard's disappointment with the scientific community is comprehensible. It is tragic, however, that a talented, ethical physician should be turned away from her beautiful world of honest medical research.

title: A GENERAL LOOSENS THE REINS IN BRAZIL
description: Warren Hoge is chief of the New York Times bureau in Rio de Janeiro. By Warren Hoge He doesn't look like a president. He doesn't even look like a general, particularly of the showy Latin American variety. He is 63 years old, short, bowlegged, barrel-chested, and he never wears his uniform. He sits at the far end of an uncluttered, polished conference table in a drafty office in Brasilia, filled with oil portraits of royalty and busts of diplomats and war heroes but with no possessions of his own. ''I spend most of my leisure time trying to pretend that I am not President,'' he tells a visitor. Then he rubs a spot on his finger where nervous biting has raised a welt. ''I wish,'' he says, ''they had chosen someone else for this job.''

title: MINORITY STUDENTS OPTING FOR COLLEGE
description: THE number of minority students among the state's high-school seniors who decided to go to college rose from 6.2 percent to 9 percent in the last l0 years, according to a study published by the State Department of Education.

title: Around the World; 400 Workers Airlifted Off North Sea Oil Rig
description: Helicopters airlifted more than 400 construction workers off an oil rig in the North Sea today because of a crack on a supporting leg brace, company officials said.

title: Appalachian State 75 Duke 70
description: Phillip Jones made the last two Mountaineer baskets to clinch Appalachian State's first triumph in 20 games against Atlantic Coast Conference competition since joining the N.C.A.A.'s Division I in 1960.

title: THE NOOSE MEDIA BILL
description: of-agents'' bill that would make it a crime for anyone, even a journalist working from public sources, to expose undercover United States intelligence operatives. The question is, Why? Last year, the Supreme Court handed down a ruling against me, in U.S. v. Snepp, that makes the bill all but redundant.

title: City Council Schedules Meetings for the Week
description: The following activities of the City Council, all open to the public, are scheduled for this week: MONDAY - Committee on Consumer Affairs, 10 A.M., City Hall; Committee on Youth Services, 1:30 P.M., City Hall.

title: Art; DRAWINGS REACH FULL ESTHETIC FLOWER
description: PORT WASHINGTON THROUGHOUT the history of art, drawing has generally been considered a preliminary or transitional activity in the development of a grander, more complete work of art. Even today, it is often a medium of study, a tool for the working out of formal and compositional problems - in short, the means to an end, rather than an end in itself.

title: Hunt Is Ready and Willing
description: When the Giants play the Los Angeles Rams Sunday at Giants Stadium, Byron Hunt will probably start at left outside linebacker and Brad Van Pelt will probably be watching from the sidelines.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Riley Haws, Pianist In a Varied Program
description: Riley Haws's evening of piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall Friday was different, difficult and rarely very profound. The most unusual items were Rodion Shchedrin's Sonata for Piano (1962) and the Sonate pour Piano by Dutilleux.

title: Helen France, Banker, Married to Peter H. Calfee
description: Helen Way France and Peter Hass Calfee were married yesterday at the Fairmount Presbyterian Church in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Henry Anderson.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Please inform me about weather conditions and the climate in Asia; I am planning a trip to Japan and the Philippines in the spring or summer and would appreciate some guidance. -M.D., Cheshire, Conn. Answer:Etsuko Penner, public relations manager of the Japan National Tourist Organization, says: ''Tokyo's average temperature in April is 56 degrees Fahrenheit with some rainy days; it is about the same in Kyoto, the ancient capital that is a principal tourist destination. Generally the climate is similar to that of the warmer Middle Atlantic states such as Maryland.

title: Headliners Supporting Cast
description: Many mothers seem to love him; the authorities, for the moment, don't. When Dr. George A. Wootan of Kingston, N. Y., who specializes in delivering babies at home, had his license temporarily suspended on charges which included contributing to the deaths of an unborn fetus and a three-day-old infant, more than 100 mothers demonstrated in his support. ''There's not a shred of credibility to any of the charges,'' the ''home-birthing'' practitioner said.

title: CHARITIES ON ISLAND FEEL THE PINCH, TOO
description: AS the holiday season approaches, Long Island charities are bracing themselves for what they expect to be the heaviest demand on their resources to date. And though religious-affiliated organizations are in better shape financially than those dependent on community good will, all have felt the combined effects of inflation and proposed Government cutbacks this fall.

title: NEW CENTER FIGHTS BIG KILLER OF THE AGED
description: REGARDED until recently as rare, Alzheimer's disease is now considered by many to be the fourth-leading cause of death in the United States. Although the National Institutes of Health reported that the disease is the most common cause of severe intellectual impairment in older adults, few people who do not personally know someone afflicted have ever even heard of the ailment.

title: BRINE MAY IMPERIL ATOMIC WASTE SITE
description: A test shaft sunk in the salt beds in the southeastern part of the state has struck water, casting doubt on a Federal Energy Department plan to bury nuclear wastes in the area, according to state officials.

title: A LOOK AT KODAK'S NEW COLOR PRINTING SYSTEM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this newspaper, and the author of several books on photography.

title: WHAT WERE PEOPLE DOING ON DEC. 7, '41?
description: FORTY years ago tomorrow, on Dec. 7, 1941, Pearl Harbor was attacked, plunging the United States into World War II. What were New Jerseyans doing on that Sunday?

title: No Headline
description: We were gratified to read William D. Johnston's letter to the editor.

title: PEARL AMONG PORTUGAL'S POUSADAS
description: PAUL LEWIS is a Paris-based economic correspondent for The Times By PAUL LEWIS

title: About Westchester
description: GREENBURGH THE faces are like those in any hospital waiting room. There are mouths drawn tight with tension, and eyes red from weeping, or, for the lucky ones, toothy smiles of relief. The silence is the same, too, the tapping of fingers on table tops and the nervous turning of unread magazine pages.

title: THE 'BEST DEAL' DRAWS BUYERS DESPITE FEARS
description: Sometimes it seems as though everybody has at least one friend, co-worker, sister or neighbor who is having a terrible time trying to buy a house or sell one. Casual coversation turns with depressing regularity to accounts of the housing market.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; DOUBTS ABOUT NUCLEAR SAFETY HERE AND THERE
description: The Government Agency that ought to know whether all's well in the nuclear power industry said last week that all's not.

title: U.S. SCHOLARS TURN A COLDER EYE ON CHINESE REPRESSION
description: In the past two weeks, Americans followed with dismay the latest chapter in the plight of Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, the Russian dissidents who were conducting a hunger strike to protest Soviet authorities' refusal to allow their daughter-in-law to emigrate. In this country, persecution of Soviet dissidents frequently becomes front-page news. The Gulag Archipelago, the Soviet system of forced labor camps has become synonymous with the moral horrors of totalitarianism. Dissidents such as the Sakharovs, Alexandr Solzhenitsyn or Anatoly Shcharansky have at various times become practically household names and American groups often agitate on their behalf, sometimes with successful results.

title: Victoria Falls
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; DRIED FRUITS: DELICIOUS RESULTS IN MANY FORMS
description: DRIED fruits, recently harvested, are at their best now. Prunes, apricots, figs, apple rings, dates, pears, peaches, raisins, currants and sultanas, mostly imported from California, are available sold loose by the pound in many markets. They can be delicious combined with meat, fish or poultry, or simply stewed on their own for a winter dessert, with a dash of bourbon or rum. They are also good eaten raw.

title: Miss Clifford, W.B. Danner Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Burnett Clifford of New York and Duxbury, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Leggett Clifford, to William Brewster Danner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Danner of Duxbury.

title: Flames 7, Canadiens 4
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Kevin Lavallee celebrated his 100th N.H.L. game by scoring two goals, helping Calgary snap a 12-game road streak without a victory.

title: WHERE TIME STANDS STILL
description: T oday, when cultures around the world are being reduced to uniformity by an international flattening-out process, the area running roughly from Turkey to India remains a land where exotic and picturesque traditions persist, not against but within the forces of change.

title: FOR GUATEMALANS, A DANGEROUS VOTE
description: As men in blue jeans and corduroy jackets brandished shotguns outside, a politician in a brown business suit sat behind a metal desk in a crumbling one-story stucco building and talked about the importance of the presidential election scheduled for March 8.

title: A CHANCE TO REFORM THE ELECTION LAWS
description: LAW reform is a lackluster chore, seldom inspiring concern among legislators more tuned to high-visibility issues and constituent service.

title: REPUBLICANS HAVE DOUBTS OVER FUTURE BUDGET CUTS
description: Senator Jake Garn thought the plan was ''stupid.'' The conservative Republican from Utah, chairman of two committees that focus on urban problems, had read newspaper accounts of an Office of Management and Budget plan to kill subsidized housing for the poor, and eliminate urban development grant programs.

title: Antiques; SOCIAL STATUS IN THE COLONIES
description: IN early Colonial New England, whether at daily dinner or holiday feast, rank had its special privileges and perquisites. Guests of equal worth dined alongside the master and mistress of the manor house. They thus were seated ''above the salt'' and were offered choice slices cut by the master from the venison roast which, with any luck, had been ''done to a turn.''

title: Miss Groves Is Married
description: At the United Church of Rowayton, Conn., yesterday, Elizabeth Groves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Freeman Groves of Rumson, N.J., was married to John William Campo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Campo of Greenwich, Conn., and Hyannis Port, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald W. Emig, assisted by the Rev. Mark Connolly, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Long Island Journal
description: IN his 23 years at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, Dr. George H. Vineyard has never taken a sabbatical leave. ''But I plan to now,'' he said recently. After a nine-year tenure as director of the laboratory, Dr. Vineyard resigned that position in August and will formally step down at the end of the year. His resignation came at a time when the laboratory seems to have solved the technical problems with its $500 million intersecting storage accelerator (Isabelle) but faces grave financing problems.

title: COUNTY BUDGET PLAN IN THE BOARD'S HANDS
description: THE Budget Committee of the Board of Legislators, meeting last Wednesday, had listened for the better part of two weeks to many of the 1,300 angry and frustrated taxpayers at hearings in Mount Pleasant and Yonkers, to county commissioners and other employes and to telephone callers, all threatened by the proposed 1982 budget.

title: The Times of London Has $15 Million Loss
description: The Times of London has lost $15.5 million since July 1, the newspaper's managing director, Gerald Long, was quoted today as saying.

title: YOUNG AND BRILLIANT
description: Negotiations are now under way between the chess federations of the Soviet Union and the United States to arrange a match between two brilliant young grandmasters - 18-year-old Gari Kasparov of Baku and 21-year-old Yasser Seirawan of Seattle.

title: North Carolina State Wins
description: Thurl Bailey scored 15 points and Dereck Whittenburg 14 to lead North Carolina State to a 44-33 victory over St. Peter's tonight.

title: Other Business; RETURN OF THE EARTH SHOE
description: Remember the Earth Shoe? Unashamedly ugly and priced at a solid $38.50, it made a big splash in the 1970's with its backward-sloping heels and back-to-nature image. But Systemet Inc., producer of the shoe in this country, thought it could make the fad a national fashion; it poured money into a television ad campaign promoting the shoe.

title: FRANCE OF 200 YEARS AGO
description: OLIVIER BERNIER is the author of ''Pleasure and Privilege: Life in France, Naples and America, 1770-90'' and ''The 18th Century Woman'' to be published in February by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in conjunction with Doubleday. By OLIVIER BERNIER

title: FORMER INTELLIGENCE AIDES PROFITING FROM OLD TIES
description: Many former American intelligence agents have entered into profitable business arrangements based on the extraordinary secret access to foreign officials and to sensitive information they gained in Government service.

title: The World in Summary; Constitution Is A Step Nearer
description: In historic chorus, members of the House of Commons sang ''O Canada'' and his supporters gave Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau a standing ovation last week. They were celebrating final approval of a measure to give Canada a new constitution and end formal tutelage by London under the British North America Act of 1867.

title: Around the Nation; Third Body Is Recovered At West Virginia Mine
description: The body of a third man was pulled today from beneath a 35-foot block of slate, ending a 33-hour rescue mission.

title: CRUISE MISSILES: A RISK
description: .6,0,165.6,2,478.4,0BOSTON - Though public attention has focused on the MX missile and the B-1 bomber in President Reagan's comprehensive plan for developing our strategic nuclear forces, in the long run neither is likely to have as great an effect on our national security as his decision to deploy cruise missiles.

title: IN THE BRONX, LEADER PLAN FOR REBIRTH
description: The perception of widespread crime, abandonment and arson has long been a cloud over some areas of the Bronx when it came to attracting business investment and jobs.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: FILM The excellent Clark Gable-James Cagney series at the Regency concludes this week, with final selections to include Charles Vidor's ''Love Me or Leave Me'' (1955) and George Seaton's ''Teacher's Pet'' (1958). These two, to be shown Sunday and Monday, pair Mr. Cagney and Mr. Gable, respectively, with Doris Day.

title: Investing; WHERE TO OPEN A RETIREMENT ACCOUNT
description: T HE new laws governing Individual Retirement Accounts, which take effect Jan. 1, have made it extremely attractive for American wage earners to save money. And since insurance companies, commercial banks, thrifts, mutual funds and brokerage houses will all be allowed to offer their own I.R.A. plans in the coming year, consumers will be able to choose from a tempting smorgasbord of options. For that very reason, tax experts warn that they should be careful in deciding when to establish an I.R.A. account and in what form of investment.

title: U.S. AND THE TURKS AGREE TO CREATE JOINT DEFENSE UNIT
description: The United States and Turkey said today that they would establish a high-level joint defense group to ''enlarge and improve defense cooperation'' between the two nations.

title: Dining Out; A CHINESE CONTENDER ON THE BLOCK
description: THE county's newest restaurant to offer Chinese cuisine has joined the renowned cluster along lower Central Avenue. Any newcomer had best know what it is about, and New Garden in Yonkers, the young contender, clearly does. This restaurant is a surprisingly welcome addition to the well-established finest in Westchester, offering much that is new in Chinese cuisine.

title: Speaking Personally; WHAT SHOULD A CHRISTMAS TREE BE?
description: year-old daughter for a Christmas tree. No doubt, some unpolished December-only salesman will again present for my approval a noticeably dehydrated Scotch pine or an Olive Oil balsam, which he'll insist are bargains at $20. If the tree has a bare spot - or two or three - he'll assure me that I can easily hide them next to a wall.

title: Scientific Fraud
description: The truly scandalous fact is the acceptance - by Yale, National Institutes of Health, Dr. Felig, Columbia and Mr. Hunt - that it is all right for a sufficiently senior scholar to take credit for other people's work but selectively to shed all responsibility if it gets into trouble.

title: Georgetown 71 San Diego State 53
description: Eric Floyd, who scored 21 points, led the Hoyas on a 20-2 surge to open the second half. Georgetown (3-2) went from a 26-24 halftime lead to a 46-26 advantage. The Aztecs (2-2) went cold, hitting just one of their first 11 shots in the second half.

title: NETS FALL TO 76ERS, 114-105
description: For more than 47 minutes tonight, the Nets had a dream of defeating one of the National Basketball Association's hottest teams, the Philadelphia 76ers. But Philadelphia had Julius Erving.

title: ANDRE DERAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTINUCLEAR GROUPS SEEKING A GLOBAL NETWORK
description: Antinuclear activists in Europe and the United States are hoping to create international links among people concerned about the proliferation of nuclear weapons, according to three European antiwar leaders.

title: COMMON BOOT WITH NOBLE TOUCH
description: America may have Gloria Vanderbilt and her designer jeans but Britain now has the Marchioness of Northampton and her boot. Five months ago, the 37-year-old aristocrat started the Lady Northampton Boot Company, based on a firm conviction that all of England needed the full-length rubber and canvas boot to which she had become partial.

title: 1984 OLYMPICS TO RELY ON PRIVATE ENTERPRISE
description: The organizers of the 1984 Summer Olympic Games here, the first staged by a private rather than a government organization, say that they are convinced the games will show a sizable profit, not a large deficit as experienced by most Olympics in recent decades.

title: Fairfield 90, Maine 60
description: Bobby Hurt put in 18 points as Fairfield routed Maine. Clay Pickering of Maine was the high scorer with 22 points and the only Maine player to score in double figures.

title: TINA DAVIS AND JAMES SNYDER TO BE WED IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. David E. Davis of Beachwood, Ohio, and Casey Key, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tina Myriame Davis, to James Stewart Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Synder of Belle Vernon, Pa.

title: Other Business; UNEASY ACCESS
description: ''I'm sorry to say that the last Easy Access statement you received was incorrect. Since they're programmed by people, computers are only human...'' Thus began an early November letter from Citibank vice president Russel A. Herz.

title: Grand Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title: Reading and Writing; AMERIKA TO AMERICA
description: In the Kafka-Prague show at the Jewish Museum there is a 1915 picture of Kafka in a painted airplane, a photographer's prop in an amusement park. Kafka is smiling, and this smile has prompted me to put him on a 747 bound for America, which he never visited, although he wrote a novel called ''Amerika.''

title: FAMILY OF SOLDIER KILLED IN 1945 IS STILL SOUGHT
description: Nearly 37 years ago, Cpl. William Wo@h@lgemuth of the Army Air Corps died in a mysterious crash of a B-24 Liberator bomber in the jungles of New Guinea.

title: FORMER INSURANCE EXECUTIVE CARVES OUT A CAREER
description: ESSEX THERE was even a fish: A wooden cutout with its tail arched high like one of the idealized rainbow trout on the cover of a L.L. Bean catalogue. It was mounted on a stick and placed in a niche on the side of the stairs.

title: I WOULD HAVE LIKE TO HAVE WRITTEN...
description: For the Christmas issue the Book Review traditionally devises a question and puts it to writers and/or other thinking types. Last year, for instance, we asked for three books that President-elect Reagan might read to help him organize his Administration. It's difficult to say what effect, if any, the suggestions had; this year, we experienced a fleeting impulse to offer the President more help. But retreating from the practical to the playful, we instead asked a handful of writers to tell us which literary composition they would most like to have written and why. The responses, as you will see, range in temper from the humble to the grandiose. We were charmed to note that one of our respondents chose a work written by another respondent.

title: Theater in Review; 'WHOSE LIFE' EXUDES A NATURAL WARMTH
description: LINDENHURST THIS is the season for ''Whose Life Is It Anyway?'' In contrast to the recent Arena Players production, the Studio Theater staging, which runs through Saturday and coincides with the release of the film adaptation, proves positively that Brian Clark's serio-comic account of a quadriplegic's persuasive and eloquent death wish has to work as drama, not diatribe.

title: Politics; WHEN 'T. JAMES' DIED, AN ERA DIED WITH HIM
description: THERE are people in public life whose passing seems to lower the curtain on an entire era. This was what many people sensed in the last few days with the news that T. James Tumulty of Jersey City had died.

title: THE MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: 'NEGLIGIBLE' SENTENCES IN RAPE CASE ARE PROTESTED
description: The rape of a 17-year-old college student in a public park in Greenwich two years ago has provoked an intense protest over a plea-bargaining arrangement and demands for changes in the state's rape laws.

title: PENNY AT PREMIUM
description: SOME stores and commercial banks on the Island are experiencing a shortage of pennies, and some are offering a premium for them. Jack Kaufman, vice president of finance for Waldbaum's supermarkets, said some of the Island's 50 stores were offering $1.10 for $1 worth of pennies because they have had difficulty getting enough pennies from customers.

title: HIGH SCHOOL BASKETBALL FACES SEASON OF CHANGES
description: WHITE PLAINS THIS may be the season that a new schoolboy basketball champion will be crowned at Westchester's highest level. It is a possibility that is intruiging to those closely interested in the county's high school play.

title: St. John the Baptist a Winner
description: Although Bayside has won six Public Schools Athletic League titles in the 11 years of formal playoffs, the Commodores have had less success against their Catholic High Schools Football League counterparts. Yesterday Bayside suffered its third straight loss in the annual Metro Bowl game, this time by 22-21 to St. John the Baptist from West Islip, L.I., at Midwood field in Brooklyn.

title: OFFSHORE OIL RIGS?  THE VIEW FROM LONG ISLAND
description: There are a few strollers but no bathers on the sandy beaches here this time of year. The seagulls hover above the edge of the surf and an occasional fishing boat appears on the cold uncluttered horizon.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Zoo Stories
description: The hopes of animal-protection groups soared in April 1980 when the city agreed to turn over the operation of its three rundown zoos - in Central Park, Prospect Park in Brooklyn and Flushing Meadows in Queens - to the New York Zoological Society, which operates the Bronx Zoo and the acquarium at Coney Island.

title: KOCH CONFERS WITH HISPANIC LEADERS
description: Mayor Koch met yesterday with Hispanic leaders from the city as he continued his efforts to reach out to the more disaffected people in his constituency.

title: Soliciting Counselor Clarifies Fee Status
description: In the article ''Teaching How to Solicit Gifts'' (Nov. 15), the reporter states that my fee ''is turned over to United Presbyterian Church headquarters.'' This is in error.

title: EXEMPT TYRANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Women in Indiana Jail File Suit on Sex Bias
description: Four Indiana Women's Prison inmates, charging they are victims of sex discrimination in all aspects of prison life, have filed suit in Federal court against state and prison officials.

title: GO, SADIE LOU! GRIDIRON SPIRIT CATCHES
description: One Sarah Lawrence football fan to another, after the opening kickoff: ''Now the way I understand it, you get one down and if you make four yards, you automatically get another. I think.''

title: No Headline
description: Don Reid Jr., 74, a Publisher; Texas Foe of Death Penalty

title: Food; THE VERSATILE QUICHE IS READY FOR A PARTY OR A FAMILY SUPPER
description: NORTHPORT THE holiday season is now in full swing, and that means help may be needed for entertaining as well as for last-minute family meals. That is where La Bonne Quiche, a shop that opened in Northport last spring, comes in.

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker The Uncle Syndrome Patrick McDonnell
description: I've always been a pushover for uncles. Maybe that's why I've been watching so much television lately. After wasting 20 years with cops and cowboys, television has finally discovered that uncles are nicer.

title: California Names Kapp
description: The University of California today named Joe Kapp football coach. Kapp, 43 years old, is a former California and pro quarterback, but he has no coaching experience.

title: 5 Convicted in Florida In Pornography Inquiry
description: A Federal jury found five men guilty today in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's inquiry into distribution of sexually explicit films in southern Florida.

title: Mailbox; Cartier Too Easy On the Coaches
description: To the Sports Editor: In ''Running Away from Fantasies, and to Reality'' (The New York Times, Nov. 22, 1981), I am sure Vince Cartier's descriptions of the ecstasy, agony and eventual frustration of a scholastic distance runner rang true for many other young runners who also have been blinded by visions of athletic achievement. I went through a similar series of experiences in high school track and cross-country, followed by a college career cut short by illness and frequent injuries. Like Mr. Cartier, I also experienced a loss of self-image when I finally realized that my impulsive fantasies would never be actualized. Unlike Mr. Cartier, I do not absolve my coaches from their part in my physical breakdown simply because they were ''just doing their best to help me.''

title: CHINA TAKES ISSUE WITH DIPLOMATIC NICETIES
description: When a United States diplomatic courier arrived at Peking's international airport late last month with a load of baggage for the American Embassy here, he was detained for an hour and a half by Chinese customs officials who demanded to see what he was carrying.

title: Future Events All Around the Town
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. The Play's the Thing Dec. 8 - Supporters of the Play Schools Association, a loyal bunch if ever there was one, will dine at the St. Moritz, then take chartered buses to the Ethel Barrymore Theater for Katharine Hepburn's bravura performance in ''West Side Waltz.'' Evening is one of two major annual benefits for the 65-year old nonprofit educational-recreational agency serving schools, hospitals, special institutions, day-care centers, community and parent groups. Tickets, $75 to $150 for show alone, $105 to $180 for entire evening.

title: HOW A COACH'S DREAM WENT WRONG
description: Lambert Reed's dream was to make Morris Brown College ''the black Notre Dame,'' a collegiate football power. ''The reason I came back to coach at Morris Brown,'' Reed said the other day, ''was because it was my alma mater and I'm a member of the African Methodist Episcopal Church. We have over one million registered A.M.E. members. It's the only school in the church with a complete athletic program. I was trying to build a program on a national basis, where the entire church would get behind us.''

title: NUCLEAR ACCIDENT RAISES DOUBT ON SAFETY MARGINS
description: An accident that began when a technician dropped a light bulb has raised serious questions in the minds of nuclear experts about their ability to estimate accurately the likelihood of a disastrous failure in many of the nation's nuclear power plants.

title: SAN FRANCISCANS PUZZLED OVER MISSING KETCH
description: At first it appeared that the Freedom II, a 51-foot ketch, had been pounded to pieces, and that two women aboard had been lost at sea when a storm caught the vessel just outside the Golden Gate on the night of Nov. 12.

title: A Correction
description: The manager of the Nassau County Employees Federal Credit Union was incorrectly identified in an article last week in the Long Island Weekly. Warren Bower is treasurer-manager of the credit union.

title: THE GOING-NOWHERE MUSIC-AND WHERE IT CAME FROM
description: What do you suppose it means that so much serious music nowadays has taken to jogging in place or running around in circles? It is difficult to hear recent works by such composers as David Del Tredici or Philip Glass without being struck by their calculated lack of momentum. You may note and appreciate beautiful things in the course of the piece, but the overall impression is that you have watched someone bouncing on a trampoline: when the show is over, after all the tricks and stuntwork, the composer has improved his muscle tone and the listener has had a chance to meditate on sins, past and future. Beyond that, the point of the exercise is sometimes hard to make out.

title: Felice Blumenthal Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Ike Blumenthal of Merrick, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Felice Susan Blumenthal, to Richard C. Goldblatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Goldblatt of East Meadow, L.I. A spring wedding is planned.

title: GIURGOLA WINS AWARD
description: Romaldo Giurgola, partner in the New York and Philadelphia firm of Mitchell/Giurgola Architects and designer of the capital complex under construction in Canberra, Australia, will receive the American Institute of Architects Gold Medal for 1982.

title: Nancy Koelling Wed To Gordon Peterson
description: Nancy G. Koelling, creative services manager of the Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Company, a cable television concern, was married yesterday to Gordon D.S. Peterson, vice president-assistant to the president of Bozell & Jacobs Inc., an advertising agency.

title: Navy 69, Harvard 64
description: Navy, led by Bob Romaine and David Brooks, rallied from a 6-point deficit in the final five minutes.

title: Clairmarie Hanavan Is Married to Robert S. Field
description: Clairmarie Hanavan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor W. Hanavan of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Robert Sutherland Field, son of Mrs. J. Paul Skelly of West Chester, Pa., and the late Mr. Field. The bride's cousin, the Rev. Francis J. Evans, and Msgr.

title: Abbe D. Kligman, Steven R. Becker Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Kligman of West Hempstead, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Abbe Dale Kligman, to Steven Richard Becker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isadore A. Becker of New York and Bal Harbour, Fla. A February wedding is planned.

title: The Nation in Summary; Williams Wins Another Month
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. may not have persuaded his colleagues of his innocence last week but he did get them to at least postpone debate over the consequences of his guilt. The New Jersey Democrat's gain, however, may be his party's loss.

title: Politics; SENATE RACE TO HAVE NATIONAL AUDIENCE
description: HARTFORD WHEN United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. comes up for reelection in November, the 1.7 million voters registered in Connecticut will be eligible to vote in the contest. But many people outside the state will try to have a say in the outcome.

title: Joseph Robbie Fiance of Dwyn Daniels
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Daniels of Palos Verdes Estates, Calif. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dwyn Ann Daniels, to Joseph Michael Robbie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Robbie of Miami. A late March wedding is planned.

title: U.S. ENVOY CATCHES SYRIA AT A VERY BAD TIME
description: The wandering peacemaker Philip C. Habib could scarcely have chosen a less auspicious time to visit Syria. American hopes for an Arab-sponsored Middle East peace initiative had just collapsed, and as Washington's special envoy arrived in Damascus, rescue workers were still digging out bodies from the rubble of four apartment buildings leveled by a car bomb that killed more than 100 people.

title: Ranger Goalie, 18, Wins First Start, 2-1
description: John Vanbiesbrouck, a raw but gifted 18-year-old, made an auspicious debut in the Ranger goal tonight as New York defeated the Colorado Rockies, 2-1, at McNichols Arena.

title: Sports of The Times; The Millionaire Messenger
description: IN the Jets' locker room after their stirring 16-15 triumph over the Miami Dolphins two weeks ago that lifted them into first place in the American Conference East, a radio reporter thrust a microphone in front of Johnny (Lam) Jones.

title: Local Politicians And Foreign Affairs
description: In response to the recent letter to the editor by William D. Johnston: His letter stated that District Attorney Denis Dillon's urging the boycott and picketing of the appearance of two British Army bands at the Nassau Coliseum was ''irresponsible, in bad taste and nauseating to the majority of law-abiding citizens of Nassau County.''

title: WANTED: LEADERSHIP IN HOUSING
description: If the recent report of the President's Commission on Housing is any guide, the Reagan Administration is making no provision for the ''supply side'' in its housing policies.

title: NUMBER OF POLICE IN NEW YORK FORCE IS LOWEST IN YEARS
description: New York City's police force has dwindled to its smallest size since 1954 - when crime rates were less than half of today's - and hopes to rebuild the force have been thrown into doubt by new fiscal problems and unexpectedly high rates of attrition.

title: Westchester Journal
description: IN the Town of Bedford, where some residents are considering arranging to hire armed guards to patrol their properties at night, the local school district has beat them to the draw.

title: Art; VIEWS OF PEOPLE AND THE LAND
description: KATONAH THERE are those who relish autumn, exclaiming over its colors and the nip in the air. Others - a minority, one suspects - find it depressing, like the 80-year-old farmer's widow who yearly shakes her head at yellowing leaves and says ''it's like growing old.''

title: BOARD MAY URGE NEGOTIATED DEAL TO END DISPUTE IN DELANEY CASE
description: By James Feron

title: Food; OF CABBAGES AND COOKS
description: If we were to single out the one dish that we have created with the greatest flair, at the least cost and for the largest number of people, it would be our version of stuffed cabbage.

title: St. Joseph's 59, Syracuse 57
description: SYRACUSE (UPI) - Bryan Warrick made a 15-foot jump shot with four seconds left to give St. Joseph's the victory over Syracuse in the final game of the Carrier Classic. In the consolation game, North Texas State beat Central Michigan, 79-65.

title: MOTHERS LEARN TO BE 'TEACHERS'
description: THROUGH an unusual early education program geared primarily to low-income families, a number of mothers in White Plains and Port Chester are learning the importance of play and verbal interaction with preschool children.

title: WHY 'REDS' SUCCEEDS AND 'RAGTIME' DOESN'T
description: In his characteristically calm, reasoned way, Andre Bazin, the late French critic, once wrote of a treasured piece of literature, which had just been made into a film, that although the film might not be the perfect equivalent to the written work, it was really not that bad and, after all, it would serve its purpose if it sent any filmgoers whatsoever back to read the original.

title: AUCTIONS: CHINESE ART IS SOLD FOR $4.6 MILLION
description: A dragon-embellished Ming dish, on view until recently at the Harvard University's Fogg Art Museum, sold here Nov. 24 for $515,000. It went to one of Hong Kong's top collectors, B.L. Au, a printing magnate.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: ELECTRIC RATE INCREASE PART OF A CONTINUING PATTERN
description: NEW BRITAIN ELECTRIC rates will rise 17 to 20 percent this month for households served by Northeast Utilities, adding to an increase of nearly 13 percent just 14 months ago.

title: Wendy Wachenfeld Married to John Drummond
description: Wendy Hart Wachenfeld, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Gilmore Wachenfeld of South Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Alfred Drummond, son of Mrs. John Richard Drummond of New York, and the late Mr. Drummond. The Rev. Robert Wardrop performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's and Holy Communion Episcopal Church.

title: Clay Ann Lockett Soutar to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Douglas H. Soutar of Greenwich, Conn., and Dorset, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Clay Ann Lockett Soutar, to Courtland Van Rensselaer Halsey Jr. of New Haven. He is a son of Mr. Halsey of Rumson, N.J., and the late Ethel Simmons Halsey.

title: Filly Breaks Losing Streak
description: Tina Tina Too led all the way to win the $55,100 Firenze Handicap for fillies and mares at Aqueduct yesterday. The victory ended an 11-race losing streak for the filly, one of two 3-year-olds in the 34th running of the race.

title: Connecticut Housing; LEASING FURNITURE FOR STARTERS
description: AS an entry-level lawyer with the Hamden office of I.B.M., Melvin Reynolds could pay the rent last summer on a small one-bedroom apartment in nearby New Haven but was in no position to spend $1,000 or more on furniture.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: In recent weeks, publishers have released hundreds of paperbacks - albums, boxed sets and calendars -admirably suited to serve as holiday presents. Many will make ideal stocking stuffers. A number are so lavishly attractive that they deserve a place under the tree, gifts to be treasured for years to come. The following list merely suggests the diversity of their subjects and the variety of their formats.

title: Beauty; EXERCISING FOR HEALTHY SKIN
description: Hard work may be an underlying secret of healthy, good-looking skin. Not the kind of work that usually comes to mind when one is thinking about skin care and the daily, weekly and monthly rituals, but work in the sense of working out - vigorous physical activity.

title: REAGAN PANEL SEEKS CHANGE IN CHARITY EFFORT
description: A new Presidentially appointed group has outlined how it will go about its job of encouraging a bigger role for volunteers and the private sector in meeting public needs as the Federal budget is cut.

title: Theater; 'CHICKS' PLAYING IN FAIRFIELD
description: FAIRFIELD TO begin with, the Scenario Dinner Theater is not a dinner theater. It is a street-level restaurant named The Scenario with a theater upstairs. The theater is a small one, with seating at tables where drinks may be ordered. At capacity, the theater holds 60 to 70 persons. Since the floor is not raked I would not guarantee great visibility from a rear table. Furthermore, table seating, which leads to informality among the audience, can also lead to conversation, not a help if you are trying to hear what is occurring on stage.

title: Comment; WHERE RED INK IS A FALSE ALARM
description: P RESIDENT REAGAN'S doomsday prophecies about the budget deficits and the national debt are grossly exaggerated, but they are capable of immense damage to our economy by associated futile policies.

title: Long Island Housing; TIME GETTING SHORT FOR A FEDERAL MORTGAGE-INTEREST SUBSIDY
description: ''IT was a real blessing for us,'' said Robert Solomon, who, with his wife, Annie Mae, and their four children, hopes to move by Christmas into a new three-bedroom house in Long Beach.

title: WIDENER TOPS DAYTON FOR TITLE
description: Tony Britton scored a touchdown on a 20-yard run in the fourth quarter as top-ranked Widener defeated Dayton today, 17-10, and won the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III football title.

title: LAW AND ORDER WITH A VENGEANCE
description: Guess what's back in force on the television menu: Cops and robbers - or variations thereof. One of the most well-worn truisms about the television business is that sex and violence sell briskly. Another is that viewer groups objecting to sex are likely to be conservative in their general makeup, while those complaining about excessive violence tend to be liberal. With the ascendancy of Ronald Reagan to the Presidency, heavily endorsed by conservative groups such as the Moral Majority, it is perhaps inevitable that television, acutely sensitive to public trends, will reflect what the industry perceives to be the national mood.

title: Oklahoma State 73 Colorado State 71
description: Eddie Hannon made a 15-foot jump shot to send the game into overtime and his two free throws gave Oklahoma State (4-0) the victory.

title: THE CONTROVERSY OVER INFANT FORMULA
description: When the Jamaican woman brought her two babies to Alan Jackson's clinic at the University of the West Indies in Kingston, the pediatrician was shocked by their condition. Her 4-month-old son weighed only five pounds - two less than at birth - and her daughter was in even worse shape. At 18 months, she weighed only 12 pounds, and soon lost four more.

title: Middlesex Ends South River's Reign
description: Middlesex High School scored twice after fumble recoveries in the fourth quarter and defeated South River, the defending champion, 14-7, in the Central Jersey, Group 1 title game yesterday.

title: Mavericks 109, Nuggets 105
description: DALLAS (AP) - Jay Vincent, a rookie forward for Dallas sank two free throws with 36 seconds left, then blocked a layup to preserve the victory. Denver had run off 8 consecutive points and tied the game at 105 with 50 seconds remaining when Vincent converted the two foul shots.

title: SUZANNE REMY IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce T. Remy of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne Elizabeth Remy, to Scott Robert Colton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Colton of Halesite, L. I.

title: The Region; Looking Over Koch's Shoulder
description: Though few things would make Mayor Koch as happy as an improvement in city services, unsolicited suggestions on how this might be accomplished apparently leave him cold. Last week, he shrugged off a report challenging his plans to hire thousands of new workers and suggesting how those now on the payroll could be employed more productively.

title: The Second Green Revolution
description: Corn bred with self-fertilizing abilities (''The Second Green Revolution,'' by Peter Steinhart, Oct. 25).

title: VIRGIL THE GUIDE
description: A VIRGIL THOMSON READER By Virgil Thomson. Introduction by John Rockwell. 582 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $25.

title: FRENCH TOWN HONORS NEW JERSEY WAR HERO
description: The residents of Sarreguemines paid homage today to an American World War II hero, who kept their town on the German border alive during fighting at Christmas 36 years ago.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: MUSIC During the past two years, Chris Connor's singing career has hit its second peak. The first came almost 30 years ago when, after successfully following the footsteps of Anita O'Day and June Christy as a singer with Stan Kenton's band, she went out on a solo singing career.

title: IRVING KRISTOL: PATRON SAINT OF THE NEW RIGHT
description: The truth is that ideas are all-important.'' So wrote Irving Kristol a few years ago for the magazine of a small liberal-arts college in Michigan that won his heart when it spurned Federal aid. Similar tributes are wafted annually over green lawns by recipients of honorary degrees who wouldn't know an idea from a tax deduction, but the ideas that Kristol purveys can be felt today in tax cuts and budget cuts, in the movement toward deregulation and away from social programs, in breaks for the well-to-do and aches for the poor. The ideas that inspire the Reagan Administration are hardly the invention of Irving Kristol, as he would be the first to concede, but he has turned an assortment of academic propositions into justifications for a set of White House policies.

title: Practical Traveler; TIPS ON FIRE SAFETY
description: Despite several tragic hotel fires in the last couple of years, your chances of getting caught in one are slim. But Martin E. Grimes, a fire safety expert, says it is not a bad idea for a traveler to carry a portable smoke detector, which can be bought in many department and home furnishings stores for $20 to $30 and can easily be hooked over a door.

title: South Carolina State 26 Tennessee State 25
description: Ben Mungin connected with Andre Charlton on a 15-yard touchdown catch, and Al Gardner kicked the extra point for South Carolina State's overtime victory in a Division I-AA playoff.

title: Kodak's Quest for a New Camera
description: W HEN the Sony Corporation announced in October that it would introduce an all

title: A SALUTE TO THE MAN WHO CREATED SANTA
description: MORRISTOWN AMIXED bag of perceptions awaits visitors here next Sunday, when the second annual Thomas Nast Day is held from 1 to 5 P.M. within a three-block area of 50 Macculloch Avenue.

title: IS 'THE RITE' RIGHT FOR PIANO
description: Most of Igor Stravinsky's piano music is simple, unshowy and of little use to professional virtuosos. Stravinsky did, however, arrange his ballet, ''Petrouchka,'' into a gleaming piano suite, and since then pianists have yearned for more Stravinskyan virtuosity they might call their own. Unfortunately, Dag Achatz's solo piano version of ''Le Sacre du Printemps'' (BIS LP-188) labors under a self-defeating contradiction. Mr. Achatz's chosen instrument, his arrangement of Stravinsky's orchestral score and his way of playing - all stand for everything that ''Le Sacre'' so emphatically rejects.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Reunited Abandoned as children by their parents and separated by the police and social agencies, Donald Booth and his younger brother and sister were reunited 18 years later, ending the anguish he had grown up with. Mr. Booth's search for his siblings is the basis for the TVfilm ''A Long Way Home,'' which will be broadcast Sunday from 9 to 11 P.M on ABC. Timothy Hutton, who won an Academy Award for his portrayal of a troubled youth in ''Ordinary People,'' will play Mr. Booth. Brenda Vaccaro co-stars as the social worker who first separated and then helped to reunite the family.

title: TRAVEL
description: Having wasted roughly 16 hours since August in airports disrupted by the dispute between the President and the air traffic controllers' union, I am more than ready to follow Emily Dickinson's theory of travel. ''There is no frigate like a book/ To take us lands away,'' she wrote. Fortunately, this is a year particularly rich in books about far-off places, luxuriantly illustrated big books, some of which have texts that repay serious perusal. THE REDISCOVERY OF GREECE Travellers and Painters of the Romantic Era. By Fani-Maria Tsigakou. Illustrated. 208 pp. New Rochelle, N.Y.: Caratzas Brothers. $45.

title: NEW MILFORD DEBATES GATEWAY OF FUTURE
description: NEW MILFORD THE boarded-up railroad station on the west side of this quiet Litchfield County town seemed, until recently, but a tawdry relic of a vanished age. Its platforms, once crowded with commuters toting attache cases, were often dotted with the homeless hugging pint bottles.

title: CANADA'S NATIVE ART FORM
description: ANDREW H. MALCOLM is chief of The New York Times Bureau in Toronto. By ANDREW H.MALCOLM

title: Mrs. Lloyd in Final
description: Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova advanced today to the final of the $200,000 Australian Women's Open tennis championships.

title: RULING IS AWAITED ON CASINO UNIONS
description: CAMDEN FEDERAL District Judge Stanley S. Brotman is expected to rule soon whether the state's Casino Control Commission may regulate labor unions.

title: Antiques; SOMETHING OLD, YET NEW, FOR HIM
description: FAIR HAVEN ANY WOMAN pondering over what to give the man in her life this Christmas might do well to consider an antique as a gift rather than that same old shirt and tie. The offerings are not only endless, but also quite unusual.

title: COSTS CURB CABBAGE HARVEST
description: USUALLY at this time of year most farmers have finished picking their cabbage and are looking forward to retiring to the farmhouse, where they can gaze out the window at an expanse of barren brown soil while they make plans, perhaps, to winter in Florida. This season, however, there is a different view from the East End farmers' windows. Row after row on field after field, the cabbage is still in the ground.

title: Iona 110, Pace 64
description: Steve Burtt scored 26 points and Gary Springer 20 for Iona (3-1), which shot 58.5 percent from the field. Fred Oglesby's 25 points led Pace (2-2).

title: 'A CHRISTMAS CAROL' AT THE MCCARTER
description: PRINCETON THERE are several exceptionally talented child actors in the McCarter Theater's new production of ''A Christmas Carol,'' but the one you will cherish most is Herb Foster.

title: Mailbox; Isiah Thomas Shows His Class
description: To the Sports Editor: Isiah Thomas has always been a step ahead of his class. The summer of his graduation from high school, he led an American squad to a gold medal in basketball at the Pan American Games. Last March, as just a sophomore at Indiana, he led the Hoosiers to the collegiate title. And now, with little more than a month gone by in the new National Basketball Association season, Thomas, at age 20, has already made a significant contribution toward reviving the Detroit Pistons, the league's beleaguered, most hapless, and often quite hopeless franchise of recent years.

title: Yale 76, Brown 72
description: Steve Leondis halted a Brown comeback with two consecutive layups in the closing minutes in an Ivy League opener.

title: The Region; The M.T.A. Tells How It's Doing
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority released the first of its monthly performance reports ahead of schedule last week, but that same punctuality did not apply to other aspects of the agency's operations.

title: Columbia 40 Loyola (Balt.) 39
description: RICHMOND (AP) - A jump shot by Danny Armstrong at the buzzer gave Columbia (3-1) the victory in the consolation game of the Spider Classic.

title: Washington; REAGAN'S SECOND ACT
description: WASHINGTON O At the end of the old year, and looking forward to the problems of the next three years, the Reagan Administration is finally beginning to reappraise its policies and its personnel - not much but some.

title: BID TO FIX A TICKET ENDS IN CENSURE OF JUDGE
description: It was a private request from one upstate judge to another to fix a traffic ticket for a friend. But instead of the speeding charge being routinely dismissed or the fine reduced, the State Commission on Judicial Conduct said, the request led to the rare act of a judge turning in a colleague for misconduct.

title: Follow-Up on the News; The Snail Darter
description: The snail darter, a tiny fish whose presence in the Little Tennessee River halted the giant Tellico dam project for three years in the late 1970's, was found last year to be hardier than anyone had imagined.

title: SWIMWEAR EVOLUTION
description: At this time of year, bookstores are customarily inundated with new books on fashion. Two of the more interesting of the current crop have just been released by the Abbeville Press and are likely not only to please, but also to fascinate, educate and not cost either an arm or a leg.

title: Miss Bley Is Wed To Houston Winn
description: Catherine Bley, an art director with Young & Rubicam New York, the advertising agency, and Houston Greer Winn, a film and television producer, were married yesterday at the Burden Mansion. M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony.

title: A WHALE OF A COLLECTION
description: She fell in love with the sea when she was a child, and grew up to assemble the world's largest and most distinguished collection of whaling material. Barbara Johnson, a dynamic Swiss-born lawyer who was formerly married to J. Seward Johnson Jr. of the pharmaceutical family, began 20 years ago to acquire whaling material after a visit to Mystic Seaport, the Connecticut museum. This was the beginning of Mrs. Johnson's involvement with folk art that eventually led to her serving for several years as president, and now as a trustee, of the Museum of American Folk Art.

title: CASINOS HURTING AND HELPING HEALTH CARE
description: ATLANTIC CITY THIS city's gambling-casino boom is dramatically changing the face of health care in Atlantic County, encouraging the rapid growth of some services and threatening the existence of others.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:$

title: THE JOBS THAT WON'T COME BACK
