description: LIKE hypersensitive economic bellwethers, the old smokestack towns of the East and the Middle West have for many years foreshadowed what economists call America's ''slow economic rot.'' This sulfur-filled town 40 miles southwest of Chicago is no different. It emerges weaker from each recession than it did from the last, and it is likely to do the same this time around, too.

title: Crafts; SOME ALTERNATIVES FOR CHRISTMAS
description: IT is not hard for ''the-season-to-be-jolly'' to turn into the season to be grumpy. When the frazzled Christmas shopper is faced with a gift list five miles long, only 18 more shopping days until C-Day and no elves around to help wrap the goodies, Christmas spirit can fly right up the chimney and out of the house.

title: IRENE DONDLEY IS ENGAGED
description: The engagement of Irene Dondley to Robert Balaban, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Balaban of Great Neck, L.I., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Dondley of Springfield, Mass., parents of the future bride.

title: OPERA: CARLO BERGONZI 25TH ANNIVERSARY GALA
description: At the end of his engagement last season, Carlo Bergonzi had sung at the Metropolitan Opera for 24 years - 246 performances in 21 operas plus the Verdi Requiem. This season would be his 25th, yet the Met had nothing planned for him, and he was miffed. But then the company rallied. It announced a gala performance for him this fall, and that he would return in 1982-83 to sing both ''La Forza del Destino'' and ''Un Ballo in Maschera.''

title: John Sotomayor BRITON IS ORDAINED IN NEWARK
description: The Rev. Elizabeth Canham after becoming an Episcopal priest in ceremony at Holy Trinity Cathedral. Bishop John S. Spong is at left. Miss Canham sought ordination in the United States because the Church of England does not accept female priests.

title: THE SUN BELT HAS A LOBBYIST IN OUR MIDST
description: THE Sun Belt states have an unregistered lobbyist in Trenton, one that is expediting the flight of jobs and people out of New Jersey. The lobbyist is our own state government, which both pushes and pulls New Jersey-based manufacturing industries to the Sun Belt states.

title: Daniel Diamond, 52, Founder Of Ballet Troupe in Maryland
description: Daniel D. Diamond, the dancer who founded the Maryland Ballet Company and directed the Panamanian National Ballet, has died in an automobile accident in Panama. He was 52 years old.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; 45 PERCENT NOW SURVIVE CANCER
description: For cancer patients the news is good. At least 45 percent of those diagnosed with serious cancers in 1973 and 1974 survived for five years, the period used to indicate the probability of cure, according to preliminary results of a National Cancer Institute survey released last week. But the extent of improvement in the odds, and the reasons for it, aren't clear.

title: Business Conditions; LUMBER'S DEPRESSION
description: The multibillion-dollar timber industry continues to wallow in its worst depression since World War II, despite the fact that falling mortgage rates may bode of better times ahead.

title: 2 One-Acters to Have Premiere Thursday
description: ''Echoes,'' an evening of two one-act plays, will be given its American premiere Thursday by Jane Stanton's New World Theater as part of a one-act play festival, ''One by One.''

title: Ski Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTABLE BOOKS OF THE YEAR
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1980. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The New York Times Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: TREES AND FLOWERS, OR A NEW CITY LIFE?
description: MY friend Jessie and I drove into New York City one morning and met another friend, a widow who had recently moved from a turreted old Tudor in our town to a small, cozy apartment, where she gave us lunch and a lecture.

title: Baseball Meetings: The Swap Market
description: Still carrying the financial scars and perhaps the animosities of last summer's strike, more than 1,600 baseball officials will meet this week in Hollywood, Fla., in the sport's annual winter convention. And by the time they adjourn Friday, they may have decided the fate of split-season baseball and the futures of Dave Parker, Garry Templeton, Ron Guidry and even Commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

title: UConn 73, Boston U. 54
description: The forward Corny Thompson, returning to the Connecticut lineup after an injury, hit 11 of 15 field goal attempts for 22 points to lead the Huskies.

title: Manhattan 64 West Chester State 55
description: John Leonard scored 21 points and Tim Cain 19 to lead Manhattan over West Chester State of Pennsylvania in the Marist Invitational consolation game.

title: Around the Nation; 8 Bald Eagle Killings Reported in Maine in '81
description: At least eight bald eagles, protected from hunters by Federal law, have been killed in Maine this year, University of Maine researchers said today.

title: ABATE DRAWS LINE FOR BATTLE ON BUDGET CUTS IN LEGISLATURE
description: HARTFORD THE legislative battle over how to close Connecticut's $83 million budget deficit was joined last week when the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Ernest N. Abate, unveiled proposals that he said would not only erase the red ink, but would create a surplus.

title: Company and Worker Ruled at Fault in Suit
description: A six-member Federal jury found today that both sides in a negligence case involving exposure to asbestos were negligent.

title: 46 Cellists Are Entered In Naumburg Contest
description: Forty-six cellists will participate in the preliminary closed auditions of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation 1981 International Competition at the WQXR Auditorium in The New York Times building next weekend.

title: SALVADOR OPTIONS FEW AND FAR BETWEEN
description: Economies don't collapse, governments fall, a Western economic analyst said in San Salvador recently. His assessment of the crumbling economy was similar to the evaluation of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. Without substantial assistance from the United States, Mr. Haig has said, El Salvador's military-civilian Government is likely to topple and fall.

title: SENATE BILL EASES PATH TO COAL PORT
description: A United States Senate committee has acted favorably on a bill that would make it easier to build a coal-exporting facility in New York Harbor.

title: Private Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: FREELANCE DANCERS TEST THEIR WINGS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan Reiter is a freelance writer with special interest in the performing arts. By SUSAN REITER

title: CABARET: SUELLEN ESTEY SINGS
description: Suellen Estey, who is the standby for the two female leads in ''Barnum,'' introduced a cabaret act last week at Mickey's, 44 West 54th Street, that made good use of her sunny blond beauty, of a vocal range that moved easily from the tongue-tangling words written by Annie Ross for Wardell Gray's ''Twisted'' to the gently soaring lyricism of ''Coconut Sweet'' from the Harold Arlen-Yip Harburg score for ''Jamaica'' and of her Iowa background, which served as an unobtrusive framework for her performance.

title: CANONERO II BROUGHT OUT THE UNDERDOG IN ALL OF US
description: THERE never was such a crowd in New York State racing history. On June 5, 1971, 82,694 hesitant, concerned believers came out to Belmont Park to see if ''their'' horse, Canonero II, could achieve victory in the Belmont Stakes and become the first winner in 23 years of turfdom's holy grail, the Triple Crown.

title: LOS ANGELES
description: In an industry where the wolves often wear sheep's clothing, Billy Wilder has survived for 50 years without concealing his fangs. The movies' most colorful and reknowned cynic, Mr. Wilder has never surrendered to sentimentality or sanctimoniousness. Now 75 years old, he continues to needle the studio potentates with his tart, acerbic comments on the follies of the business.

title: Essay; THE CORPORATE FAUST
description: For $2.5 billion, the Government of Kuwait has just purchased an American oil driller and explorer with an engineering component that has been designing nuclear power plants for the U.S. Government. The Reagan Administration has announced that this unprecedented purchase of American know-how ''does not have major negative implications for U.S. national interests.''

title: MUSIC CELEBRATES THE HOLIDAYS
description: AS traditional as holiday celebrations tend to be - especially when it comes to music - the offerings this year could add a new wrinkle or two. True, there will be the customary attention paid to Handel's ''Messiah'' (nine different versions) and the usual array of ''Nutcrackers'' (balletomanes will be able to see Edward Villella dance in a film version of the classic, which his Eglevsky Ballet will perform at C.W. Post's Concert Theater), but there will also be some nods to innovation.

title: Topics Good Names and Bad One Man's City
description: Rockefeller Center is available -outlined in gilt on a felt pennant. So is the United Nations headquarters, on an ashtray. Lincoln Center can be found on a vinyl placemat.

title: LEARNING TO CONSERVE HOLIDAY WARMTH
description: IN the winter, my apartment in Danbury is very warm. Too warm. Sometimes I open a window, which makes me feel guilty. But when it gets really tropical and my two parrots are panting and holding their wings away from their bodies and I've had to change into a T-shirt and shorts, I don't know what else you're supposed to do. I've talked to the landlady, but she apparently doesn't mind feeding our rent checks directly to the furnace. All she said was, ''The fourth floor likes it fine and they've been here much longer than you.'' Under the terms of the lease, my parrots are illegal, so I have been reluctant to pursue the matter further.

title: 'First Cousins' In the Fishing World
description: The recent article by Shaun Assael entitled ''Larger Hauls Raise Fears of Depletion'' is, we fear, a healthy specimen of what every editor should most dread: propaganda presented as balanced news.

title: Simply a Man
description: To the Editor:

title: WALL STREET LAWYER FILLS U.S. POST AT UNESCO
description: Jean Gerard, the new United States delegate to Unesco moved quietly into her post here two weeks ago and said she planned to maintain a low profile for the foreseeable future.

title: The Nation in Summary; Tradesmen Use Front Entrance
description: When the White House finally threw open its door to big labor last week, it did so with a dramatic flourish. President Reagan told leaders of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters that he might reconsider his three-year ban on putting dismissed air controllers back on the Federal payroll. Apparently surprised, White House aides scrambled to explain what the boss really meant - he still doesn't want them back in control towers, it seems. But, technicalities aside, the change in tone was extraordinary. Last summer, when 11,500 controllers were discharged for taking part in an illegal strike, the Administration asserted that they had collected their last Government paycheck.

title: North Carolina 77; Yugoslav Nationals 70
description: North Carolina survived a 41-point performance by Drazen Dalipagic to win in overtime. The Tar Heels, who trailed, 38-34, at halftime and were behind for most of the second half, pulled to within a point at 64-63 on Matt Doherty's basket with 1:50 left. North Carolina finally gained the lead on Jim Braddock's layup 14 seconds later.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD UNITS URGED FOR FAMILY COURT
description: The Community Service Society, which five weeks ago issued a study critical of New York City's Family Court system, has proposed measures that it says would improve the manner in which troubled youths are treated.

title: NANCY FERRARA TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ferrara of Scotch Plains, N.J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Joan Ferrara, to Thomas O. Williams Jr., son of Patricia M. Williams of New York and Mr. Williams of Portland, Me. A February wedding is planned. Miss Farrara is a hospital representative with the U.S. Surgical Company.

title: COOKING
description: To judge by the current outpouring of new cookbooks, huge and hefty encyclopedic volumes seem to be on the wane. Whether this is a temporary lag or the result of the exhaustion of both authors and their markets, there are now many slim books that seem to be focusing on narrower aspects of particular cuisines .

title: FILM: 'EMMANUELLE' IN THE SEYCHELLES
description: The folks in ''Goodbye, Emmanuelle'' have sex not just in twos, but in threes and fours. It is wearisome after a while, for them and for us, but we have the advantage - we can look at the Seychelles, where the movie was filmed, while they, poor things, can only look at one another. The background of ''Goodbye, Emmanuelle'' is made up of lush, lazy pictures of the islands in the Indian Ocean; the foreground is made up of bodies, some of them positively acrobatic. The scenery wins every time.

title: ANTENNAS PROTESTED
description: PLANS by Home Box Office Inc. to construct seven microwave transmission antennas in the Hauppauge industrial park have drawn protests from a nearby residential community.

title: MUSIC: PURCELL MEDLEY AND SHOSTAKOVICH'S 5TH
description: Lovers of contrast may be pleased by the New York Philharmonic's current program, which pairs a medley of Purcell miniatures with Shostakovich's brassily martial Symphony No. 5. But at the first of the four performances Thursday night, neither half of the program worked as well as it might have.

title: Seton Hall Prep Downs Bergen Catholic
description: Pete Reavey, a senior quarterback, ran for 126 yards and one touchdown to lead Seton Hall Prep to a 20-12 victory over Bergen Catholic yesterday in the North Jersey, Parochial A state final.

title: CHAVEZ FACES INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL STRUGGLES
description: Battered by the aftermath of a quashed rebellion and a feud with some former highly placed leaders, Cesar Chavez and his United Farm Workers appear vulnerable as they head for a renewed organizing battle next year with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: HANDLING MARRIAGE PORTABLES
description: IF first marriages are made in heaven, then second marriages are made outside the gate where all the old baggage is stored. Here, disillusioned men and women, carrying all the baggage of their first marriages, are trying to make a new connection.

title: A 'FORMIDABLE CHALLENGE' FOR AGENCIES
description: By BERTRAM M. BECK General Director Community Service Society of New York

title: Kansas 74, Michigan St. 56
description: Jeff Dishman, David Magley and Kelly Knight combined for 54 points for Kansas. Dishman scored a career-high 21 points, Magley 18 and Knight 15 as Kansas (3-1) won its third straight.

title: I LOVE FREEPORT, AND HERE'S WHY
description: LIKE many another average theoretical white liberal, I just happened to live most of my life in a white neighborhood. Three years ago we sold our house, our family having dwindled to the two of us, and bought a condominium apartment in Freeport. The building is slightly integrated, but most of Freeport is more so. You can live here without feeling guilty, and it's only 40 minutes from Penn Station.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: LANDFILL OPERATOR IS SEEKING TO EXPAND
description: CHESTER TOWNSHIP THE operator of the defunct Kin Buc Landfill in Edison, who, Federal officials say, has long been associated with hazardous-waste dumping in New Jersey, has offered to buy the Coombe Fill South dump here and in Washington Township.

title: Long Islanders; HELPING THE ELDERLY TO ACHIEVE DIGNITY
description: ''SOMEHOW I had a feeling there was a book in me somewhere,'' Bernard Warach said. He was right. The book that was in him is now out - ''The Older American's Survival Guide for Better Health and a Longer Life'' (Spectrum Books, $14.95 hard-cover, $5.95 paperback).

title: CONSERVATION PLANS EVALUATED
description: NEW BRITAIN IN reviewing Northeast Utilities' request for a rate increase, the Department of Public Utilities Control decided that several of the company's conservation proposals were not worth the cost, while others should be larger.

title: RECESSION REPERCUSSIONS ARE MAKING EUROPE 'RUN
description: SCARED' By STEVEN RATTNER

title: Man Found Shot Dead At Central Park North
description: A man was found shot dead yesterday at the northern edge of Central Park near West 108th Street, the police said.

title: Thomas Drake Weds Martha Morrison
description: Martha Fairfield Morrison and Thomas Sherman Drake, who are with the Chase Manhattan Bank, were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. Ann B. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Connecticut Guide; 18TH-CENTURY CONCERT
description: Capitalizing on Connecticut's romance wirh its past, The Chamber Orchestra of New England will repeat its success of last year and simulate another brace of 18th-century concerts -costumed, candlelit, wigged and performed on hautboy, harpsichord, trumpets, tympani, strings, bassoon, flute and organ at 8:30 P.M. Thursday and Friday in the United Church on the New Haven green.

title: U.S. Donates Airport To Town in Missouri
description: A 98-acre airport once owned by a marijuana smuggling ring has been turned over by the Federal Government to this small southwest Missouri town of 6,000 people.

title: Two Fake Boxes at Bank Bilk Depositers in Massachusetts
description: Thieves who fooled bank customers with two fake deposit boxes may have made off with as much as $100,000, the police say.

title: LESS IS MORE PROTECTION, E.P.A. INSISTS
description: As environmental and public health groups tell it, the United States Environmental Protection Agency is being systematically reduced by the Reagan Administration from a shield to a hollow shell.

title: DAN FOGELBERG'S TIME HAS ARRIVED
description: The huge success of Dan Fogelberg's seventh album, ''The Innocent Age'' (Epic/ Full Moon KE 2 37393) runs against every trend of today's music business. Released at a time when the commercial chances of double-record albums are considered dubious, this lavish two-disk set, with its illustrated lyric booklet, is a big hit that has remained on the top 10 of the national album charts since its release nearly three months ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Bridge column in the Arts and Leisure section today includes several errors. Corrections appear in this sec- tion, on page 99.

title: Around the World; Gaza City Begins Strike Over Tax on Doctors
description: Gaza City began a second two-day commercial strike today in support of doctors who refuse to pay the Israeli Government a 12 percent tax on their income.

title: PANEL TO AID LAWYERS' VICTIMS
description: New York State has set up a panel to distribute money to clients victimized by dishonest lawyers, but the group has not yet decided how to give out the money.

title: Art; ESCHEWING BOOSTERISM IN JERSEY CITY
description: JERSEY CITY ASEQUEL to last year's ''Eight Painters,'' the Jersey City Museum's 1981 Invitational, provides another glimpse of artists who have spent time living and/or working in New Jersey.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: FINANCIAL problems are forcing some colleges in the state to consider mergers, revisions in curriculum and other economic overhauling for the 1982 school year. Most of what is being discussed is tentative but the indications are that change is on the way.

title: 'SIGNED' INTO DRAMA
description: WHEN Alan Champion arrived in New York from St. Louis a year and a half ago, he wanted to be a song-and-dance man, so he headed for Broadway. But Mr. Champion also brought with him the skill of sign language, and before long, he was auditioning as an interpreter of live theater performances for the deaf.

title: The Nation in Summary
description: Virginia has been represented by Byrds in the Senate for so long that it has sometimes seemed a seat was reserved strictly for them. That 50-year tradition apparently will end in 1983, for Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. announced last week that he would not seek reelection.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Radio Waves
description: Last December, the GAF Corporation announced it would sell WNCN-FM, the all-classical radio station in New York. GAF bought the station in 1976 from the Starr Broadcasting Group, which had converted WNCN to a rock-music format.

title: MEYERHOLD, DANCE AND AVANT-GARDE THEATER IN 1920'S RUSSIA
description: Among the world's great theatrical directors perhaps it was Vsevolod Meyerhold, best known for his radical productions in Moscow in the 1920's, who was the most interested in dance. Meyerhold himself appeared in a few ballets staged by Michel Fokine and other ballet choreographers and he collaborated with Fokine on a surprisingly wide range of productions. When he established his own experimental theater, the training system for his acting students included ballet and modern dance courses as well as his system of movement exercises known as Biomechanics. Like Konstantin Stanislavsky, his original mentor and against whom he rebelled, he was originally taken with Isadora Duncan in 1905. By the 1920's, his view that movement should reflect total control of the actor's body led him into a different opinion; ''The loose condition of a physically uncontrolled person (Duncanism) is inadmissable.''

title: HOMEMAKER FROM AN AGENCY HELPED HIM SAVE HIS SIGHT
description: WHEN asked how he feels, 82-year-old Pablo Felix A., (affectionately known as Mr. Felix to his caseworkers) usually answers, with a shrug, ''No bien o mal,'' and often adds, ''Four times around the world, and now I'm lucky if I can go around the block!''

title: Scientific Fraud
description: I was deeply shocked by Morton Hunt's article, as I was a graduate student at Yale Medical School, later a resident in internal medicine at a Physicians and Surgeons teaching hospital, and since then have worked at both M.I.T. and Harvard Medical School, while depending heavily on The New England Journal of Medicine. I venture the guess that too much emphasis on competitive research rather than solid ethical clinical teaching of medical students is at fault. These top medical schools now all overestimate ''brightness, competition and grantsmanship skills'' DOUGLAS BUCHANAN, M.D., Lowell, Mass.

title: Waltrip, Johnson Make a Good Team
description: The stock-car racing combination of Darrell Waltrip and Junior Johnson is a match that few people thought would work out. But it has, to the benefit of Waltrip, who won his first Nascar driving championship this season, and Johnson, who once again has a driver who complements the other elements of his racing team.

title: Anderson's FancyPassing Spurs Bengals
description: There are several distinctions with regard to Ken Anderson, the quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals, who is having an extraordinary season that should continue when the playoffs begin later this month.

title: Governor Byrne's Record
description: As Governor Byrne prepares to depart Trenton, his popularity is at rock bottom. People in New Jersey grumble about style and personality; many still smart over Mr. Byrne's tough decision to institute a state income tax. He supported casino gambling in Atlantic City, which may plague the state forever. Nevertheless, Brendan Byrne leaves office with an otherwise outstanding record.

title: WHEELCHAIR GUNMAN ROBS L.I. GAS STATION
description: An armed robber in a wheelchair rolled himself into a Freeport, L.I., gas station late Friday night, held it up for $487 and then fled into the night, pushed by a bystander who was forced to do so at gunpoint.

title: BIG SHOW OPENS FRIDAY
description: A foreign ''invasion'' of sorts will take place this week in New York as thousands of numismatists gather in the city for a series of special events spotlighting foreign coins.

title: Dr. Miriam A. Smith Wed to Dr. John A. Sorenson
description: Dr. Miriam A. Smith and Dr. John A. Sorenson were married yesterday at Hampshire House by Rabbi Robert Jacobs. Dr. Smith is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey E. Smith of Great Neck, L.I. Her father is vice president of operations of the Dolly Madison Ice Cream Company in New York. Dr. Sorenson is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lionel W. Sorenson of Orinda, Calif. His father is an ophthalmologist in Oakland, Calif.

title: Private Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: BYRD RETIREMENT STUNS VIRGINIANS
description: The unexpected announcement of the retirement of United States Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr. has thrown this capital into its second political convulsion in a month.

title: A Woman Reporter In Yankee Country
description: Thank you, Jane Gross, for your article on the Yankees (''A Woman Reporter in Yankee Country,'' Oct. 25). It was not only interesting, but brought out all the reasons I love sports.

title: Music Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUND IN 20TH-CENTURY ART; PURCHASE, N.Y.
description: The most inventive show of the fall season in the New York area is not, as might be expected, in Manhattan. It is in the Neuberger Museum on the SUNY campus in Purchase, N.Y., and it represents an exceptional effort of energy and imagination on the part both of Suzanne Delehanty, director of the museum, and of all the many other people who were concerned with it.

title: JOE KLECKO LEADING THE JETS, AND LEADING A GOOD LIFE, TOO
description: SEATTLE HE used to race his black '55 Chevy down Front Street near Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia. ''I'd crush guys,'' says Joe Klecko. Or, he worked as a bouncer in what he describes as ''an after-hours joint.'' ''I liked it,'' he says. ''It was satisfying in a way. It was an ego-builder. Everybody has an ego.'' Or, he is strict with his two children, one of whom is only 10 months old. ''I have two really good kids,'' he says. ''It's not just me saying it. People tell me that. I refuse to let them become brats.'' Or, from his defensive right end position with the New York Jets, he leads pro football with 18 sacks. That is as many as the Tampa Bay Buccaneers have produced. And there are three other N.F.L. clubs that haven't been able to produce as many as Klecko has by himself this season.

title: Timeless Omissions!
description: To the Editor:

title: DEFILING A PUEBLO 'CHURCH' FOR PROFIT
description: Smith 0.4,0,322,2,690,0The Jemez is a church. Generations of frustrated anthropologists have learned remarkably little about the religion of the Pueblo Indians of New Mexico, but all the monographs agree that, for the Pueblos, the summits of the Jemez Mountains comprise a living church with hidden shrines. The Pueblos could as easily imagine turning the Jemez into an industrial park as imagine a Roman Catholic running a pipeline out of the altar of St. Peter's, or a Jew razing the Wailing Wall for a gas station.

title: LEVELING OFF OF FIRES IS CITED AFTER A 3-YEAR DECLINE IN CITY
description: Three years of steady decline in the number of fires in New York City ended in 1980 when more than 127,000 were recorded - an increase of almost 12 percent over 1979, according to the Fire Department.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE 1981
description: For the 14th year in a row, the editors of The New York Times Book Review choose what they consider to be the best books published in the country during the preceding year. Although the final choice of 12 titles breaks down equally between fiction and nonfiction, this was not planned.

title: Shelagh Markey Banker's Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Markey Jr. of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Shelagh Marie Markey, to William Robert Maass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Maass of Madison and North Beach, N.J.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: ALCOHOL is the No.1 substance being abused by students and, says Francine Korman, the New Jersey Education Association's associate director of instruction, ''It's getting down very low, into the elementary schools.''

title: Other Business; BUSINESS ABROAD: A GUIDE TO GIVING
description: It's a sticky moment for the American businessman making a sales stop in Osaka. He sits down to talk through a deal, and his Japanese prospect hands him a gift. He thinks he should do likewise. So he gives the man a bottle of Kentucky bourbon. That was a mistake. The man wanted Scotch.

title: REVUE: 'THE CITY SUITE,' 21 SONGS BY LEVENSON
description: As the 11 energetic young performers crowd onto the tiny stage at the Westside Arts Theater and begin singing the songs in ''The City Suite,'' a new musical revue by Keith Levenson, anticipation is replaced by deja vu. Haven't we already visited some of this ''City Suite'' in the ''Company'' of Stephen Sondheim?

title: B-1: A HOT TARGET
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Tech 76 Salem State 70
description: Anthony Stacom, a 6-4 sophomore forward, sank four consecutive free throws in the final 38 seconds of play to assure the New York Tech victory in the consolation game of the Assumption College Classic.

title: A FINE NEW WORK FROM A FORCEFUL PLAYWRIGHT
description: Charles Fuller's ''A Soldier's Play'' begins with a killing and ends with a kind of confession. Its particular excitement, however, doesn't really stem from the traditional business of tracking down the identity of the criminal. It comes instead from tracking down the identity of the victim. Suddenly you realize that things just might work out that way. Figure out who the dead man is, or who he thought he was, and you're on your way to nailing the culprit. It's a startling process, and a satisfying one.

title: THEN CAME 4 YEARS OF PRAYER
description: I GUESS I was simply reminiscing that day when I happened to mention Pearl Harbor, and my 18-year-old nephew looked up from his chess game and asked:

title: WALESA HOLDS TALKS WITH POLISH ARCHBISHOP
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity union movement, met today with the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, apparently to discuss deteriorating relations between the independent union and the Government.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: ATHANSON'S STYLE EVIDENT IN FAREWELL
description: HARTFORD IN a last hurrah that seemed in keeping with the unorthodox behavior that brought him much attention during the 10 years he was Mayor, George A. Athanson said goodbye to the people of Hartford last week by walking six miles, from the Bloomfield town line on the north to the Wethersfield border on the south.

title: The World in Summary; Waldheim Offers Graceful Way Out
description: For 10 years as Secretary General of the United Nations, Kurt Waldheim has skipped nimbly among the conflicting demands of the rich and powerful countries that supply most of his organization's funds, and the third world members that dominate the General Assembly. Last week, after 16 rebuffs to his candidacy for a third term by African countries -backed by China's veto in the Security Council - the Austrian diplomat said he would step aside and let the Council try to agree on someone else.

title: Scientific Fraud
description: It seems to me there is a problem in the peer-review system itself. The train of events which led to Vijay Soman's unmasking began, after all, with Philip Felig's adverse review of Dr. Wachslicht-Rodbard's paper.

title: Major News in Summary; Allen Clears One Hurdle
description: The Justice Department cleared Richard V. Allen last week, at least as far as that $1,000 ''honorarium'' was concerned. The White House, though, may not be so willing to forgive, forget and welcome him back from the administrative leave President Reagan was probably glad to give him.

title: THEATER MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Crafts
description: TRENTON ''CLAY/SOUND/FORMS,'' an exhibition and performance co-created by Marion Held, a ceramic artist, and Norman Lowrey, a composer, is among an increasing number of collaborative works that combine the visual and performing arts.

title: OPERATIC HAWK IS REUNITED WITH KEEPER
description: Harry, the operatic hawk, came home in triumph today to the aviary where he was seized a month ago by wildlife conservation officers.

title: BEACH CENTER ATTRACTS ELDERLY
description: JONES BEACH STATE PARK AT the West Bath House here, neither wintry weather nor the recently announced prospect of Federal budget cuts can chill the Senior Citizens' Center, which, like many on the Island, gives the elderly a place to find the warmth of comradeship.

title: STALKING THE ELUSIVE BARGAIN AIRFARE
description: If air travelis involved in your last-minute holiday plans, you may be able to find a bargain fare, but don't count on it. To have any chance, act immediately. Many reduced-rate tickets must be purchased and reservations must be confirmed at least seven days before departure and often 14 days on domestic routes. On many flights, reduced-rate offerings are what the trade calls ''capacity controlled.'' This means that only a certain number of seats are available at that rate, and the airline keeps secret what that number is. There must be some, if the airline is advertising them, but that can be as few as five if the carrier feels it stands a good chance of selling the remaining seats at higher fares, or it can be 50 or more if the sales outlook is grim. It stands to reason, therefore, that at a time of peak travel, such as from Dec. 20 to 24 and Jan. 1 to 4, availability is likely to be at its lowest. Check all the airlines that fly the route you plan to use, or have a a travel agent do it for you. On some routes, fares and restrictions differ substantially among carriers. If you are lucky enough to find last-minute accommodations in a popular Caribbean or Mexican resort but are told by the airlines that all flights are full, ask your travel agent about packages. Some bare-bones packages obligate you to pay for nothing more than round-trip air transportation, transfers from and to the airport at your destination and a specified number of nights at a specified hotel, but they have the distinct holiday advantage of guaranteeing you an airline seat because the packager has reserved a block of them for his customers.

title: The World in Summary; Arms Negotiators In Geneva Begin To Chip the Ice
description: ''Come on in, it's cold outside.'' That was Yuli A. Kvitsinksy, overheard talking to Paul H. Nitze in Geneva last week, as they began the first Soviet-American talks on limiting medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: Miss Meeker And Surgeon Are Married
description: At St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday, Sarah Louise Meeker, daughter of Leonard Carpenter Meeker of Washington and the late Christine Halliday Meeker, was married to Dr. Jay Arthur Jensen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jay Monroe Jensen of Salt Lake City. Canon Charles Martin of the Washington Cathedral performed the ceremony.

title: NEED A YULE TREE? PICKINGS ARE GOOD
description: HILLSBOROUGH TOWNSHIP LONG before suburban sprawl and the resultant loss of natural forest lands, one of the earliest yuletide traditions was choosing and felling one's own Christmas tree.

title: New Jersey Housing; SUSSEX PROJECT IS STILL UNRESOLVED
description: THERE are ironies aplenty in the story of The Farm at Sussex, a development that has been proposed for the Sussex County community of Frankford Township.

title: The World in Summary; Israel and U.S. Partners in Arms
description: There were no photographers and no official briefings last week when Israel and the United States quietly signed a strategic cooperation agreement. But the event did not go unnoticed in Arab countries and by Israeli critics.

title: Miss Hopkins Fiancee Of James F. Clouse Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Appleton Hopkins of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah St. Clair Hopkins, to James Franklin Clouse Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clouse of Cheshire, Conn.

title: GOULD IS FINALLY AN ELECTRONICS COMPANY
description: CHICAGO L AST week, at long last, William T. Ylvisaker of Gould Inc., a company best known as a battery maker, could breathe easily. After having been repelled in two earlier attempts to buy his way into the semiconductor business, Mr. Ylvisaker announced that he would be taking over American Microsystems Inc., of Santa Clara, Calif., for stock valued at about $200 million. The move rounds out Mr. Ylvisaker's long push to make Gould a full-fledged electronics company.

title: MIDPRICED COMPONENTS-THE BEST BARGAINS IN STEREO
description: Having scanned the current crop of low-cost stereo components in last week's column, we now move our selective spotlight to the crowded field of medium-priced sound equipment. Confronted by the profusion of competitive products in this price range, and finding many rival designs similar in concept and performance, one can hardly avoid being arbitrary in the choosing. Even so, we tried to cut through the thickets of an almost absurdly oversupplied market by the dogged application of two selective criteria: 1) we looked for designs that in at least one vital aspect rise above the norms of their class. 2) We would not let any form of technical window dressing outweigh musical considerations.

title: SHORE HOUSING STIRS DISPUTE
description: SEA BRIGHT KATHI LEVINE gets enthusiastic when she talks about Land's End, a luxury condominium development that has been proposed for the northern end of this narrow, 2.5-mile-long Monmouth County borough.

title: PEARL HARBOR: THE WAY IT WAS AT PRINCETON
description: William Zinsser, executive editor of the Book-of-the-Month Club and author of ''On Writing Well,'' was master of Branford College at Yale from 1973 to 1979. This article was adapted from one that appeared in the Princeton Alumni Weekly. By William Zinsser I remember exactly what I was doing when I heard about the attack on Pearl Harbor, and I'll match my memory against anybody else's for uninteresting detail. What I prefer to recall about the day is a chain of events that it set in motion, pushing me out of college and into the Army but teaching me in return one of the most valuable lessons of my life.

title: William LaCasse to Wed Lucy Ogden Lee in June
description: The engagement of Lucy Ogden Lee to William O. LaCasse has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Lee Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., parents of the future bride. Mr. LaCasse is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph LaCasse of Skowhegan, Me.

title: ARMY, NAVY BATTLE TO A 3-3 TIE
description: The loud blast of cannon fire that traditionally signals victory exploded from both sides of the field at Veterans Stadium this evening after the 82d Army-Navy game ended in a 3-3 tie.

title: CHESAPEAKE BAY CRABS: STEAMED, BAKED, DEVILED
description: STEVEN V. ROBERTS is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. By STEVEN V.ROBERTS

title: PASTELS POSSESS AFFECTING LYRICISM
description: PORT WASHINGTON has lost one of its most important cultural institutions and Manhattan has gained it. After a group of women established a cooperative known as the Central Hall Gallery nine years ago, it became known as a showcase for talented Long Island artists who did not only quality work, but also work that was excitingly different and exploratory. Central Hall could generally be counted on for a good exhibition by any standards.

title: Blues 3, Penguins 1
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Jorgen Pettersson and Wayne Babych scored firstperiod goals to lift St. Louis and snap Pittsburgh's four-game winning streak.

title: Wendy Whiteman Plans May Nuptials
description: The engagement of Wendy Whiteman to William L. McLean 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. McLean 3d of Wynnewood, Pa., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Whiteman Jr. of Canaan, N.Y., parents of the future bride.

title: Virginia 76, V.M.I. 49
description: Othell Wilson scored a career-high 20 points to lead Virginia in the first game played in Virginia Military Institute's new 5,029-seat Cameron Hall.

title: The Nation in Summary; Libyan-Trained Assassin Squad Reported in U.S.
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has long been convinced that Washington is out to get him. Apparently, he has decided to get Washington first. According to information received by Federal law enforcement officials and reported by The New York Times, a hit squad of five Libyan-trained terrorists entered the United States last weekend with plans to assassinate President Reagan, other senior Administration officials and members of their families.

title: Clare Frances Sisson Is Wed in Capital To Capt. Theodore Barrow of Marines
description: The marriage of Clare Frances Sisson, a word-processing operator for Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, to Capt. Theodore Hood Barrow, U.S.M.C., a data-processing officer stationed in Washington, took place yesterday at the Washington Cathedral (Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul).

title: The Region; The Long Count Confirms Kean's Narrow Victory
description: In politics, it is whether you win or lose. So it was small consolation to Representative James J. Florio last week when a recount determined officially that no New Jersey gubernatorial candidate had ever lost by less.

title: Debra Wilson Rider Engaged to J. Tyler Campbell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Hull Rider of Granville, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Wilson Rider, to J. Tyler Campbell, son of Mrs. N. Page Worthington of Riderwood, Md., and the late Richard I. Campbell.

title: WILLIAMS STAYS ACTIVE AS HE AWAITS HEARING
description: On the day he was scheduled to begin fighting his expulsion from the Senate, Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. was voting Thursday with his colleagues on the fate of the B-1 bomber and the MX missile.

title: Microscope Photo Undergoes Scrutiny
description: On the Long Island Journal page of Nov. 15, there is a photograph under the headline ''Revealing Some Rock Secrets.'' The photograph is designated, ''Dr. Leonard Gorelick, left, and Dr. A. John Gwinnett with a scanning electron microscope at Stony Brook.''

title: HISPANIC RESEARCH CENTER PLANNED IN CHICAGO
description: A Hispanic Research Center is being planned to collect data and correct stereotypes about Hispanic-Americans. As an initial step, CBS Inc. has provided a $250,000 planning grant for Chicago's National Opinion Research Center, a 41-year-old organization affiliated with the University of Chicago. A number of private foundations have indicated they are prepared to support such an undertaking.

title: The Nation in Summary
description: After months of study, the White House has decided to give the Government's intelligence-gathering agencies a considerably longer leash.

title: Study in South Finds Decline In Areas of Black Majorities
description: The number of Southern counties populated mostly by blacks has declined at an average of more than two a year since the beginning of the century, according to a study released by the Voter Education Project.

title: FIRST PLAY IS LAST, SAYS YALE STUDENT
description: NEW HAVEN is a relatively easy commuting ride to New York - a daily hour and a half by train for many executives and professionals. In the theater, however, the move from Connecticut and community playhouses to New York can prove an endless struggle. For the cast and crew of ''Retreat,'' a ''musical play'' by Monica Teply Mills first performed at New Haven's Whitney Barn, the move this fall to Off Off Broadway did not bring acclaim. It did not even bring critical recognition.

title: DETROIT DEFEATS L.I.U. AT FOUL LINE, 73-72
description: Willie McCarter, the basketball coach at the University of Detroit, last night said he always wears a carnation in his lapel when his team plays ''because my wife told me it's either going to be a wedding or a wake, and you might as well be dressed for the occasion.''

title: Museum Receives Gifts
description: The Jewish Museum has received a gift of 180 artifacts from Max and Betty Ratner of Cleveland that details the culture of Israelites from the Neolithic to Byzantine period. Included among the antiquities are carnelian beads, silver bracelets, metal weapons and tools. The collection will play a role in a permanent biblical archeology exhibition scheduled to open at the museum in June.

title: IDAHO TOWNSPEOPLE STILL TALK ABOUT A SPY CALLED 'JIM'
description: At the Mint Cafe on Main Street here, people still talk about the spy they knew as ''Jim Namcek.'' They remember the cheers that sounded when Jim's face appeared on the bar's television screen, and how they turned to smile at Jim as he sipped a beer while a newscaster announced that Federal agents were hunting for him in South Africa, Costa Rica or some other faraway place.

title: LIBERALS CONSIDER BACKING MOYNIHAN
description: New York State's Liberal Party, which two years ago called Daniel Patrick Moynihan ''totally devoid of honesty and integrity,'' is preparing to endorse him for re-election next year.

title: WOMAN IN SAKHAROV'S PROTEST IS HELD BRIEFLY
description: A day after the hospitalization of Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights activist, the Soviet authorities today briefly detained the woman on behalf of whose emigration effort he declared a hunger strike two weeks ago.

title: OVERPASS DEBATED
description: A PROPOSAL by the New York State Department of Transportation to build an overpass at Washington Avenue in Patchogue as part of the reconstruction and widening of Sunrise Highway has stirred concern among homeowners who fear increased traffic in their residential community.

title: North Dakota State 18 Shippensburg State 6
description: Mike Kasowksi rushed for 142 yards and two touchdowns to lead North Dakota State (10-2).

title: Spain's King on Persian Gulf
description: King Juan Carlos of Spain arrived today on a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain.

title: Book of Kells
description: To the Editor:

title: REDISCOVERED VERDI TAKES STAGE
description: STONY BROOK ONE hundred thirty-three years after it opened to less than enthusiastic acclaim in Trieste, ''Il Corsaro,'' an early opera by Giuseppe Verdi that was not revived again in Europe for more than a century, will be performed for the first time in the United States on Saturday at 8 P.M. at the State University's Fine Arts Center.

title: ART HISTORY
description: MASTERPIECES FROM THE COLLECTION OF THE PRINCES OF LIECHTENSTEIN Text by Reinhold Baumstark. Introduction by Julius S. Held. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: Hudson Hills Press. $100.

title: Greenwich Wins Title
description: Greenwich High School defeated Trumbull, 14-0, yesterday at Kennedy Stadium in Bridgeport to win the Connecticut Interscholastic Athletic Conference Class L-1 football championship.

title: NEWARK'S FIRE REPORTING IS CALLED MISLEADING
description: NEWARK ALTHOUGH the Newark Fire Department's annual reports to City Hall indicated a steady decline in the number of fires from 1970 to 1980, some fire officials charge that the number actually grew in that decade.

title: Art; VICTORIAN DESIGN AND THE PALLISERS
description: BRIDGEPORT THE Museum of Art, Science and Industry (4450 Park Avenue) is starting to attract the notice of Connecticut companies, like those who lent work and support to its recent, very successful show, ''The Corporate Collectors.'' Nevertheless, and in spite of being situated in the state's largest city, the museum remains a struggling operation, understaffed and therefore more dependent than most on volunteers.

title: PROFESSIONALS FIND IT PAYS TO ADVERTISE
description: IT IS not unusual these days for professionals - doctors, lawyers, dentists - to advertise. Both Dr. William Lazar, an Englewood physician, and Dr. Lawrence Colbert, a Hackensack dentist, place large display ads in a daily newspaper, and an Elmwood Park lawyer, Howard Katz, has a large sign in his office listing his fees for bankruptcy and divorce cases.

title: Met Museum to Exhibit 18th-Century Costumes
description: The 18th-century woman needed a well-accessoried wardrobe of painted fans, jewelry, laces, hats, gloves and slippers to exercise her coquetries.

title: WOMEN'S PRISON AT BEDFORD: NEED FOR A DIALOGUE
description: DISCUSSION of the state prison bond issue in Westchester quite rightly focused on the conditions at the County Jail in Valhalla. The recent disturbances made it imperative to consider how much money to spend, and on what parts of the criminal-justice system in New York State. Beyond the County Jail, people looked at Attica, Greenhaven, Dannemora, and, closer to home, Ossining. But practically nobody talked about the other major prison in Westchester: the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility for Women.

title: HERE'S WHY DETROIT IS DEPRESSED
description: T HE following are excerpts from the Commerce Department's report on the future of the United States automobile industry released last week to the Senate trade subcommittee.

title: Long Island Guide; SOME BRASS
description: After years of neglect, brass ensembles are currently enjoying a renaissance, showing music lovers just what the brass instruments - usually hidden in the background - can do. Those who like their music with this stately beat can take advantage of five free concerts this week.

title: Teletext Test to Begin In Cincinnati Next Year
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company will begin a teletext experiment next year on WKRC-TV in Cincinnati. Text and graphics are transmitted on the unused part of a channel's signal.

title: Fairy Tales
description: To the Business Editor: William Nordhaus, in ''The King and His Gilded Counselors'' (Nov. 29), has chosen a most appropriate genre for economic exposition - the fairy tale.

title: PREVENTIVE MEDICINE FOR NUCLEAR WAR
description: Even before the first atomic bomb exploded at Hiroshima in 1945, thoughtful scientists began worrying over the moral and political implications of the awesome weapon they had created. Physicists took the lead, for as Robert Oppenheimer, scientific head of the Manhattan Project, later wrote, ''The physicists have known sin; and this is a knowledge which they cannot lose.''

title: Headliners; On the Ice
description: Last week, the chief executive of the New Hampshire Liquor Commission was in his cups, and suddenly things got very confusing.

title: U.C.L.A. Trounces Notre Dame, 75-49
description: Mike Sanders scored 24 points to lead U.C.L.A. to a 75-49 victory over Notre Dame today. The loss was the second in three games for Notre Dame, which is off to its worst start in nine years.

title: SHE SOLOS IN PRINCETON REVUE
description: PORT WASHINGTON ''The yearly Triangle tour of major cities got under way during our Christmas vacation. We were dragged out of our sleeping car berths by jovial alumni, driven in ornate limousines to the local Racquet, Athletic or University Club. We were plied with beer, fine bootleg liquor and a bite of dinner before being driven to the theatre. Our performance was only slightly affected by our semicomatose condition. After that, it was into white gloves, white tie and tails, and off to a huge decorated hotel ballroom or country club for a formal supper-dance where we had our choice of the finest debutantes and booze available.'' ''Josh: My Up and Down, In and Out Life'' by Joshua Logan

title: ST. JOHN'S SETS BACK PRINCETON BY 42-37
description: One look at those orange-and-black Princeton uniforms, and Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, becomes uneasy. To defeat that patient passing game, the carefully chosen shots, the intelligence, is an achievement.

title: Around the Nation; 17 Struck by Cholera At an Oil Rig in Texas
description: The largest outbreak of cholera in the United States in this century struck 17 men who worked on an oil rig in Texas, the national Centers for Disease Control said Friday.

title: A FRESH WIND FOR SAIL POWER
description: Joanne A. Fishman is the boating columnist for the sports section of The Times. By Joanne A. Fishman The whole thing started as a joke, explained Jesse Briggs, a Chesapeake Bay waterman. Six years ago, the local marina sponsored a sailing regatta and a crab feast for its patrons. The idea was that anyone who raced his boat around the course could return to the marina for free crabs and beer. But Briggs had no sailboat. Instead, he fashioned ''an old army-tent kind of a sail'' to fit between the mast and boom of his tugboat, and then he, too, ''sailed'' around the course.

title: Major News in Summary; Buying It All, Except MX Plan
description: The Senate last week gave President Reagan his military hardware money, but signaled near-unanimous disagreement with his plans to base MX missiles temporarily in hardened existing silos.

title: Music; 'SOUNDINGS': TWO ARTS FUSED AT THE NEUBERGER MUSEUM
description: IF you haven't yet visited ''Soundings'' at the Neuberger Museum, on campus at the State University of New York College at Purchase, you should. Not only are the exhibits fascinating, but - if you pick your days right - you can attend performances that intriguingly follow through on the overall concept of fused art, music and sound.

title: Walker Still in Hospital
description: The Jets' top receiver, Wesley Walker, remained in Lenox Hill Hospital in New York today, and will miss Sunday's game against Seattle.

title: THE LARGER FOCUS OF A BATTLE FOR HUMAN RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Celia T. Marks Married to George J. Zahringer 3-d
description: Celia Turner Marks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Goldberg of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to George J. Zahringer 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Zahringer of Rye, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by State Supreme Court Justice Jack Rosenberg at the University Club.

title: Around the World; Heng Samrin Is Named Cambodian Party Leader
description: President Heng Samrin of Cambodia has been appointed to the powerful post of secretary general of the governing People's Revolutionary Party, the Cambodian radio said today.

title: MEET THE 'GOLDEN BOYS' WHO MAKE ITALY'S NEW FILM COMEDIES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Melton S. Davis frequently reports on the arts in Italy. By MELTON S. DAVIS ROME Five men, taking a quick test for jobs as draftmen, must draw a tree. Four produce simple black and white sketches of shriveled little trees. The fifth turns in a small masterpiece of color and form: a luxuriant, flourishing tree. The first four are hired, the fifth is turned down.

title: MAURITIUS SEES SEYCHELLES MEDDLING
description: A spokesman for the Prime Minister of Mauritius has accused President France Albert Rene of the Seychelles of seeking to overthrow the Mauritian Government by ''actively promoting destabilization'' here.

title: Dining Out; STAFF TAKES CASUALNESS SERIOUSLY
description: HARTFORD THE Oyster Bar, in a ground-floor corner of the old Hotel Capitol, directly across the street from the Butler-McCook House on Main Street here, is a relatively new (one year old) restaurant, but one with the look of a turn-of-the-century saloon.

title: Flyers 5, Red Wings 2
description: DETROIT (UPI) - Ken Linseman scored one goal and assisted on two others, pacing Philadelphia in a game marred by a brawl.

title: SENSITIVE LANDS ARE LISTED
description: THE Nature Conservancy, a nationwide organization that buys and protects ecologically sensitive lands, has identified 20 of the rarest or most unusual natural areas in New Jersey that it says need special protection.

title: R.S. STEINBAUM FIANC E OF ROSEMARY KONNER
description: The engagement of Rosemary Konner to Robert S. Steinbaum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Steinbaum of Mantoloking, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Joan W. Konner of Palisades, N.Y., and Jack Konner of Ridgefield, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Mill Owner Facing Jail Under a Pollution Law
description: A co-owner of a Vermont paper mill has been sentenced to jail for pollution in the first use nationally of a criminal contempt provision in the law administered by the the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, the agency has reported.

title: Habib Makes Stop in Cairo
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special Middle East envoy, conferred here today with Ambassador Alfred L. Atherton Jr. An embassy spokesman, Darryl Daniels, said Mr. Habib met with Mr. Atherton at the airport while changing planes on his way from Israel to Saudi Arabia.

title: Movies Aloft
description: To the Editor:

title: Clemson 61 Arkansas-Little Rock 60
description: Clarke Bynam stole the ball and made a field goal with 1 minute 38 seconds to play to put Clemson (4-0) ahead, 59-58, and Vince Hamilton made two free throws with 29 seconds left for a 61-58 lead. Robert Walsh's field goal with 18 seconds left cut the margin to 1.

title: AIDES SAY THAT SEA PATROL HAS SLOWED HAITIAN ENTRIES
description: The Federal authorities say that the number of Haitian refugees headed for the United States has decreased dramatically in a year. They are crediting the Reagan Administration's decision to interdict these refugees at sea as well as widespread word in Haiti that coming to this country without proper documents means a loss of freedom.

title: TAXATION BY ANY OTHER NAME
description: HOW do you raise revenue without increasing taxes? Easy: Invent a new name for taxes. The need for creative legis-speak arises because taxpayers are also voters, and this is a particularly bad year for favorite programs and hopes of lower taxes. Home-grown red ink may reach $100 million before the year is over. Moreover, the Federal Government plans to send some $40 million less than we were planning on.

title: SOME RAIN, YES, BUT DROUGHT LINGERS
description: IN 1980, when less than three inches of rain fell on the Island over the summer, making it the worst such drought on record, farmers and homeowners were in a state of alarm. This year rainfall is up but the situation is ''probably worse,'' in the opinion of Joseph E. Savage, a Cooperative Extension Association agent in Nassau County, and his view is echoed by many others whose business it is to watch over the Island's water resources.

title: Zoe Caldwell to Present 'A Christmas Carol'
description: Zoe Caldwell, the actress and director, and a half-dozen others will present a reading of Dickens's ''A Christmas Carol,'' at the South Street Seaport Museum Gallery, 213 Water Street, on Dec. 14 at 7:30 P.M.

title: Tremor Shakes Italian Area
description: An earth tremor registering four on the open-ended Richter scale shook a wide area of the Friuli region in northeast Italy early today, causing alarm among residents of several towns but no injuries, the police reported. The Friuli region was devastated by a quake that took 946 lives in May 1976.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospects
description: Sagging Sales

title: CHRISTMAS IS A VIDEO GAME
description: L ITTLE round heads, pink, brown, freckled, frowning heads, pile up on trays at the East Aurora, N.Y., factory, where they are grafted - at a rate of 150 per minute - onto inch-high, peg-like bodies. These are the ''little people'' of Fisher-Price Toys, the characters who since 1968 have populated countless play-set farms, carousels and, lately, jetliners - all for the preschool crowd. ''We sell almost a predetermined amount each year,'' said Charles Riter, vice president of research and development.

title: FOR STRIKING STUDENTS IN WARSAW, NEW VISTAS
description: A leisurely game of badminton, without a net, was under way the other morning in the stately circular hall of the Warsaw Polytechnic, Poland's leading technical university.

title: MUSIC: 4 PIANO PIECES BY MORTON AT KITCHEN
description: Last season, in his first year as music director of the Kitchen, George Lewis was chastised for offering too narrow a range of music. This year he has positively wallowed in catholicity. Wednesday night, for instance, there was a young composer on hand named John Morton, who sounded like a perfectly conventional midtown contemporary-music composer.

title: A 'COMMUNICABLE' CONDUCTOR
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE New Jersey Mozart Orchestra was deep into the second movement of Schubert's ''Symphony in B Minor'' when Paavo Jarvi tapped his baton lightly. The 45 musicians stopped playing.

title: Negotiations Resumed In the Carting Walkout
description: Representatives of private garbage carting companies and their striking workers resumed negotiations under a state mediator yesterday afternoon as trash from restaurants and hotels continued to pile up on streets in the city and suburbs.

title: Headliners; Biggest Bucks
description: Cecil R. Haden, a Texan landowner and president of the Bay-Houston Towing Company, said last week that he's neither a Republican nor a Democrat, but supports ''the most qualified candidate.''

title: Planning Aide Explains His Role in Jersey City
description: I wish to clarify my relationship with the City of Jersey City, a subject mentioned in the Nov. 1 housing column. On Aug. 3, I attended a meeting in the office of Mark Munley, the newly appointed director of the city's Department of Housing and Economnic Development.

title: NEIGHBORS LESS HOSTILE TO THE SALE OF EMPTY SCHOOLS
description: When Wesley Springhorn decided to pursue a career as a public school administrator he never expected to be spending a large portion of his day figuring out how to market several million dollars' worth of real estate.

title: TASK FORCE ISSUES GLOOMY REPORT ON PRISON OVERCROWDING IN JERSEY
description: A task force on New Jersey's overcrowded prisons has devised a plan to provide room for 1,563 more state prisoners by next October, including housing 400 at an Army stockade at Fort Dix that is now vacant.

title: NEWARK GETS MANAGEMENT TRAINEE PROGRAM
description: Despite worsening economic conditions, more than a score of companies here have agreed to hire 75 college graduates a year from the Newark area for placement in their management training programs, Leonard S. Coleman Jr., president of the Greater Newark Urban Coalition, announced this week.

title: Environews
description: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY will be the host next Saturday for the premiere of ''In Our Water,'' a 60-minute documentary about toxic drinking water in the Middlesex County community of South Brunswick.

title: SECAUCUS HOSPITAL WEIGHS EXPANSION
description: SECAUCUS URBAN and health planners once called it ''an unneeded facility doomed to failure, a burden to the community.'' But five years after its opening, Riverside General Hospital here treats nearly 10,000 patients a year, has an occupancy rate close to 100 percent and a growing waiting list - and it plans to expand.

title: WIND-ENERGY PLAN STIRS EAST HAMPTON
description: THE desolate landscape at Montauk Point where the winter winds howl ferociously may soon be altered by the appearance of four 60-foottall wind turbines that will harness the wind with 18-foot blades to create electricity - if East Hampton Town officials can proceed with a project involving the Long Island Lighting Company and a Pennsylvania company that makes the turbines.

title: NO POINT IN TREASURING BILLY BEER CANS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Facts of Business
description: The matter-of-fact answer to Sidney Blumenthal's question, ''Whose Side Is Business on, Anyway?'' (Oct. 25), is now, as always, ''On its own side.''

title: COSTLY ECONOMIC-DEVELOPMENT LURES THAT DON'T PAY OFF
description: To the Editor:

title: PHOTOGRAPHY
description: THE WORK OF ATGET Volume One. Old France. By John Szarkowski and Maria Morris Hambourg. Illustrated. 177 pp. New York: The Museum of Modern Art/Distributed by New York Graphic Society. $40.

title: Lauren E. Gold To Be May Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burton M. Gold of Atlanta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauren Elizabeth Gold, to James Stephen Grien, son of Anita Grien-Medwin of New York and the late Alfred N. Grien of Tamarack, Fla.

title: About Long Island
description: PORT WASHINGTON HE had seen it all: Wilt Chamberlain, Billie Jean King, Reggie Jackson, Muhammad Ali. There were Stanley Cups, World Series, the Preakness. He had written nine books, contributed to encyclopedias, hosted a television show.

title: VISITING LONDON PAST
description: SUSAN GOODMAN is a writer who lives in London. By SUSAN GOODMAN

title: A Benefit for Yaddo Features Feiffer Play
description: Yaddo, the Saratoga Springs, N.Y., retreat for writers, artists and composers, will be host to a benefit Tuesday that will include a performance of Jules Feiffer's ''Grownups'' at the Lyceum Theater and ''Yaddo Salutes Jules Feiffer and Vice-Versa,'' an after-theater supper at Sardi's. Mr. Feiffer wrote his first play, ''Little Murders,'' at Yaddo in 1966.

title: The World in Summary; Ending a Strike, Lighting a Fuse
description: For the first time since it conceded the right to strike 16 months ago, the Polish Government last week exercised its power to break one. It chose a target that was both relatively easily and politically crucial, but the consequences could be painful.

title: LOCAL SCHOOL UNIT PENALIZED ON VOTE
description: A single abstention in a key community school board vote led the next day to an extreme action rarely resorted to - Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola suspended the board of District 16, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: A CUSTOM TILE SHOP GROWS WITH TIMES
description: THREE years ago, when Phyllis Traynor and Elizabeth Clay Biddle began their custom crafted ceramics business and named it Meshach Et Al, they sensed they were going in the right direction at the right time. Ceramic tile was becoming a popular home furnishings material and selling well, but tile distributors reported that customers often wanted ''the unusual or one-of-a-kind tile.''

title: By Theodore W. Libbey; Music: Debuts in Review
description: Before the Bohemian Virtuosi of Prague took the stage Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, the absence of chairs next to their music stands proclaimed that, as far as appearances were concerned, they meant to have their middle name taken seriously. Under Tomas Koutnik, conductor, their performances of works for strings by Handel, Carl Stamitz, Mozart, Wolf, Martinu and Suk tended to confirm the claim of virtuosity, even if, in a few of the accounts, the playing failed to demonstrate a sure sense of period style or a convincing expressive involvement in the music.

title: Topics; GOOD NAMES AND BAD; The Bribetaker
description: Marvin Mandel, the former Governor of Maryland, went through a lot befobe President Reagan commuted his prison sentence last week. Two trials, the first aborted when jurors learned about jury-tampering attempts, brought conviction for fraud and racketeering.

title: Freedom for the Sakharovs
description: Andrei Sakharov's greatness, as a humanist, is disputed only by the Soviet Government. And even his persecutors must still value his scientific gifts and wish him no personal ill.

title: Dutch Yacht First In Leg to Auckland
description: After racing neck and neck across much of the cold and stormy Southern Ocean, the Dutch yacht Flyer beat Ceramco New Zealand to its home port of Auckland, New Zealand, by eight hours last week, cutting 4 1/2 hours off the record for the second leg in the 27,000-mile Whitbread Round the World Race.

title: Cardinals 30, Saints 3
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Roy Green dashed 44 yards on a fake punt for a touchdown and Neil Lomax ran 22 yards for another score as they helped St. Louis post its fourth straight victory.

title: Gerhard Bleicken Dies; Ex-Insurance Executive
description: Gerhard D. Bleicken, retired chairman and chief executive officer of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, died Friday at Framingham Union Hospital in Massachusetts. Mr. Bleicken, a resident of Sherborn and Centerville, Mass., was 68 years old.

title: Miss McRae's Unobstructed Vantage Point
description: She was born in New York, she was raised in New York and she got her professional start in New York. But for the last 14 years Carmen McRae has lived in California, and last week, back in New York for a three-week singing engagement, she explained why.

title: CELLO RECITAL: LOW PLAYS BACH
description: Though the cellist Roger Low exhibited faultless intonation, a rich cantabile sound and firm musical ideas in his concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday evening, much of his playing did not spur wholehearted involvement.

title: By John Radosta
description: Sports World Specials Thrown for a Loss

title: BROOKLYN CEREMONY HONORS THOSE KILLED IN 1941 ATTACK
description: As a fierce wind blew across tiny John Paul Jones Park under the Brooklyn side of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, four Pearl Harbor veterans joined in a tribute yesterday to those who died on that Sunday 40 years ago in the attack that drew the United States into World War II.

title: Dr. Harley Shands, Professor
description: Dr. Harley C. Shands, chairman of the department of psychiatry at St. Lukes-Roosevelt Hospital Center, died Friday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center of a ruptured aortic aneurysm.He was 65 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: VICTIM OF SLAYING IN CENTRAL PARK IDENTIFIED AS ACTOR IN LIGHT OPERA
description: A man who was found shot to death on an isolated hilltop in Central Park was identified yesterday as a 42-year-old actor and principal performer with the Light Opera of Manhattan.

title: STATE URGED TO AID MADISON SQ. GARDEN SPORTS
description: New York State will have to provide help if the Rangers hockey team and the Knickerbockers basketball team are to be kept in New York City, according to the city's Corporation Counsel.

title: JETS BEAT ISLANDERS FOR THE FIRST TIME, 5-2
description: The Islanders ran out of patsies tonight. The Winnipeg Jets, the only team in the National Hockey League without a victory over New York, finally defeated the Stanley Cup champions, 5-2.

title: LIBRARY SHOW SALUTES ERA OF ACTOR-MANAGERS
description: AMONG the yellowing 18th-century London posters in an exhibition at the New York Public Library branch at Lincoln Center is a warning from a 19th-century actor-manager setting out a series of fines - up to 10 shillings - for the kinds of misdemeanors that may still arise in the theater today.

title: Texas International Has New President
description: Robert D. Gallaway, 47 years old, has returned to Texas International Airlines Inc. as president. Previously, he had worked there for three years as executive vice president. He succeeds Robert J. Carney, 41, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Houston-based carrier.

title: Plane Crashes Into Hospital
description: Two men survived with injuries tonight after their small turbo-prop plane crashed into a penthouse holding air-conditioning equipment on top of the Royal Alexandra Hospital, city officials said. There were no other injuries in the accident, but 120 patients were evacuated from the sixth floor of the hospital because of the danger from leaking fuel. The hospital, which is situated near the city's municipal airport, has 936 beds.

title: Bird to Sell Units
description: Bird & Company has agreed in principle to sell roofing plants in Franklin, Ohio, and Chicago and its Chicago felting mill to Goldis Enterprises Inc., the Delaware holding company for IKO Industries. Terms were not disclosed. Bird said it wished to concentrate its activities in other areas.

title: A World to Feed 17th and last of a series of articles that appeared periodically
description: Of all the ills afflicting the human race, none seems more soluble - and at the same time more intractable - than hunger. On the one hand, enough grain is produced now to provide every man, woman and child on earth with some 3,000 calories a day. That is more than the average level of consumption in the United States and about 50 percent above what is now considered to be a minimum acceptable level of caloric consumption. On the other hand, chronic malnutrition persists, often in countries where plenty of food is available, such as in India and Brazil. Uncertainty as to Numbers

title: CALIFORNIA SEX OFFENDERS FACE PRISON TERMS
description: Spurred by a surge of anti-crime sentiment and a spate of mental patient escapes, California legislators have scrapped a decades-old program under which some sex offenders were sent to hospitals instead of prison.

title: City Vanquishes Hunter, 84 to 71
description: Michael Richardson's 21 points led a balanced scoring attack as City College downed Hunter, 84-71, at Holman Gym yesterday. City raised its record to 3-2 and Hunter's fell to 2-3.

title: Soviet Mine Woes Cited WASHINGTON, Dec. 6
description: The Soviet Union's growing problems with its mining industry will lead to more Soviet mineral imports from the West in the 1980's, three American analysts said.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Two teams in the National Hockey League are involved in a sudden-death overtime game during the playoffs. As a player on Team A is advancing toward Team B's net, he is tripped from behind. The referee's arm goes up in the air, signaling a delayed penalty, as the fallen player bats the puck back to one of his teammates. Team A, still controlling the puck, removes its goalie for another skater and attempts to regroup. While doing so, a Team A player inadvertently deflects the puck into his own net. Does Team B win the game, and what happens to the delayed penalty?

title: Trove-Larida 1, 2
description: The Woody Stephens-trained entry of Trove and Larida finished first and second in the $55,900 Treetop Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: AT CONFERENCE ON THE CITY, THE SERVICE WAS CIVIL
description: It is 48 miles from Times Square to the hilltop mansion where conferees gathered over the weekend to ponder ways of improving city services and, generally, resolving urban ills. More than 100 guests were engaged in this work. They were tended to by some 50 staff members eager to carry bags, serve meals and pour drinks.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 7, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Military Analysis
description: About 1,000 United States Marines landed in an mock assault on the coast of Oman yesterday as part of Operation Bright Star, a joint Egyptian-American exercise in the Middle East.

title: Elaine Naramore Bride Of John Ellis, Architect
description: Elaine Hirschl Naramore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Hirschl of New York and West Stockbridge, Mass., was married at the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday to John Ellis, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leroy J. Ellis Jr. of Leonia, N.J. Robert Berson, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony.

title: RISING SENTIMENT AGAINST EUROPE
description: Almost totally unnoticed in the battle over budget cuts and military spending, an undercurrent of neoisolationism is developing in Congress in reaction to the wave of antinuclear protests and anti-American sentiments rolling across Western Europe this fall.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECTING MORE RATE DECLINES
description: With minor variations, credit market analysts continue to predict higher prices and lower interest rates for notes and bonds in the next few months.

title: Sentence Today in Spy Trial
description: Anatoli T. Maluta, 61 years old, of Redondo Beach, Calif., has been convicted of 15 counts of conspiracy for sending computer equipment to Soviet bloc nations and is to be sentenced Monday. by Federal District Judge William Matthew Bryne Jr.

title: STRESSFUL WORLD OF ADOLESCENT
description: A BOUT adolescence, the perennial question is, what is going on here? To anyone who has adolescents at home - or who ponders his own memories of the great teen miasma - there are all those mystifying manifestations: the abruptly dropped friendships; the need for confrontation balanced with the conflicting yearning for isolation, and the paradox of rebelliousness and slavish conformity to one's peers.

title: NORTH DAKOTA'S SILOS, GRIM REAPER'S CHAFF
description: The United States' nuclear frontier is neither Europe nor the Middle East but North Dakota, the geographical center of our continent. The wheatfields surrounding the town where I grew up, Michigan, N.D., (population 592), shelter the densest cluster of Minuteman missiles on our northern border.

title: UNPREDICTED STORM BRINGS NEW ENGLAND UP TO 2 FEET OF SNOW
description: The biggest snowstorm since early 1978 dumped up to two feet of snow on New England today, closing the Boston airport for most of the day, shutting off power to 92,000 people and causing at least three deaths.

title: PITTSBURGH CONFRONTS OIL BID
description: In this sprawling steel city, the slogan ''City of Champions'' has replaced ''Steel City'' as the preferred motto of the Chamber of Commerce. Local businessmen are now apt to direct a visitor's attention to the rash of modern downtown development rather than to the famous steel mills strung along the Monongahela River. And employees of the United States Steel Corporation, for many the cornerstone of this city's identity, can be seen at corporate headquarters here wearing Marathon Oil buttons pinned to their lapels.

title: THOMAS G. CORCORAN, AIDE TO ROOSEVELT, DIES
description: Thomas G. Corcoran, a prominent Washington lawyer and adviser in Franklin D. Roosevelt's Administration, died today at the Washington Hospital Center of a pulmonary blood clot after surgery. He was 80 years old. --- Key Strategist of New Deal By WOLFGANG SAXON

title: Joan A. Kanter Is Married To Steven Jeffrey Brown
description: Joan Aileen Kanter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Kanter of Stamford, Conn., was married at Temple Beth El there yesterday to Steven Jeffrey Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Brown of St. Louis.

title: FATHER DRINAN SHOWS POLITICS IS IN HIS BLOOD
description: You can take the man out of politics but you can't take politics out of the man. Or so it seems in the case of the Rev. Robert F. Drinan.

title: REP. RICHMOND SAYS HE'LL REVIEW OUTSIDE INCOME AND ETHICS RULE
description: Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he was reviewing his $100,000 outside annual income ''to make sure I am fully complying with all rules of the House Ethics Committee.''

title: PORT GIBSON, MISS., AWAITS RULING ON 60'S BOYCOTT
description: A decade after the boycott of white merchants by blacks here died down, the legal battle it spawned is building toward a Supreme Court decision that may help shape the legal limits of political protest.

title: Canada Finds a Way
description: Canada has proved Churchill right again; democracy is the worst political system, save for all the others.

title: GOVERNORS EXPECT NEW ERA OF LIMITS ON PUBLIC SERVICE
