description: Past and present leaders of the National Governors Association met here this weekend and agreed that an era of severe restraints on public services is ahead.

title: Miss Navratilova Takes Title
description: Martina Navratilova came back to beat Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-7, 6-4, 7-5, today and win the women's singles title of the $200,000 Australian Women's Open tennis championships.

title: Commodities; Oats Gain As Supply Tightens
description: NOT many people wax poetic about oats, a grain that goes into livestock food troughs and into breakfast cereal. But ACLI International Commodity Services does. ''Oats: Anything but a Nursery Rhyme'' is the headline on its report on oats.

title: Joan Salzburg Bride of Charles Rosner
description: Joan Ellen Salzburg, daughter of Joseph Salzburg of Sands Point, L.I., and Ethel Dudley of New York, was married yesterday to Charles Edward Rosner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Rosner of Philadelphia. Cantor Ellen Stetner performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy DuVal in Manhattan.

title: A DIVIDED SECURITIES INDUSTRY
description: The brokers and securities analysts at the annual meeting of the Securities Industry Association, who packed up their resort wear and gulf clubs here on Friday in preparation for a return to pinstripes and briefcases, were a troubled lot.

title: HUNTING CANVASBACKS NEAR NEW YORK
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y. POUNDING across the dark, choppy Hudson River a half-hour before dawn in a beamy skiff laden with three men, dozens of decoys and two dogs, I was intrigued by the lights that blazed along the western shore.

title: CONSTRUCTION WOES SLOWING FIRE-CODE COMPLIANCE
description: Implementation of a stringent fire code for high-rise office buildings in New York City, signed into law nine years ago and then held up by a six-year legal challenge, has been further delayed by construction difficulties encountered by building owners.

title: MAYOR MEETS BLACK LEADERS IN A PEACE BID
description: Mayor Koch's latest peace-keeping meeting with black leaders ended yesterday with participants agreeing that although it was helpful, differences on issues remained unresolved.

title: Jurate Kazickas Bride of Roger Altman
description: The marriage of Jurate Kristina Kazickas, a writer, to Roger Charles Altman, who was Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for domestic finance in the Carter Administration, took place yesterday on Cat Cay in the Bahamas. The Rev. James N. English of Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington performed the ceremony at the San Luis Rey Chapel.

title: BOSTON GETS CHANCE TO TEST SHOVELING TECHNOLOGY
description: All over Boston today and in the dozen old towns ringing the city, people slipped and slid in the heaviest snow in four winters, scrambling to make comparisons with the Great Blizzard of 1978, which paralyzed movement in New England for a week that February.

title: REPORTER QUITS FEDERAL POST TO AVOID CHARGES OF CONFLICT
description: A correspondent for The Union Leader of Manchester, N.H., who was also on the payroll of the Commerce Department, has resigned his Government job, the department says.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1981
description: International Muammar el-Qaddafi denied plotting to assassinate President Reagan or anyone else in an interview from Tripoli televised by ABC News. ''We are sure we haven't sent any people to kill Reagan or any other people in the world,'' said the Libyan leader. In Washington, the State Department responded with a statement that it had evidence of such plans, saying that ''Qaddafi has been planning the murder of American officials both here and overseas.'' (Page A1, Column 5.) Solidarity was again warned of a confrontation with the Government, which accused the union's leadership of breaking its agreements and refusing to negotiate for a national accord, choosing instead ''a road that may bring about confrontation.'' Nevertheless, Solidarity's Warsaw regional organization voted to call for a day of protest on Dec. 17 against the raid last Wednesday by policemen, backed by army units, on a firefighers' academy in Warsaw, breaking up a sit-in by cadets. (A1:4.)

title: 75,000 Protest in Spain
description: About 75,000 people demonstrated here today to protest Spain's plan to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and to call for European disarmament. The demonstration was organized by leftist labor groups and political parties and civil organizations.

title: Chad Troops and Rebels Are Reported to Clash
description: Government troops clashed with rebel forces near the town of Abeche in eastern Chad and were advancing on the town, the Chadian radio reported today.

title: British to Give Kirstein Franklin Arts Award
description: Lincoln Kirstein, co-founder and the general director of the New York City Ballet, will receive the 1981 Benjamin Franklin Medal of England's Royal Society of Arts next Monday in London at a dinner to be attended by Prince Philip, president of the society.

title: Coca-Cola Bottling Shifts Media Buying
description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, which owns four franchise areas, has just removed responsibility for its media buying for the Coca-Cola, Sprite and Tab brands from McCann-Erickson and assigned them to the Apple Agency, its own three-year old, in-house shop. As a result, media for all of its brands are now being bought by Apple.

title: THE DANCE: ROBERT SMALL AND COMPANY
description: BUT what does it mean? audiences new to dance often ask after seeing a piece. And why don't the dancers just say it? One could feel sympathy for that uncertainty after a mystifying concert by Robert Small and the Small Dance Company on Saturday at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: News Analysis
description: One recurring theme at a weekend conference here on municipal affairs is that New Yorkers, even while they look for better government service, probably ought to make fewer demands on their public officials.

title: JOBLESS RATE IS CUTTING INTO OREGON'S BUDGET
description: A recession that began with the collapse of the lumber and new housing markets in early 1980 has forced Oregon officials into an almost frenetic search for ways to cut back on a budget that has already been pruned.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: SOVIET SILENT ON SAKHAROVS' SITUATION
description: The whereabouts and condition of Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist and Nobel laureate who is a central figure in the human rights movement here, remained a mystery today, two days after Soviet authorities announced that they had moved him and his wife to a hospital.

title: WHALERS OVERCOME TIRED RANGERS, 5-3
description: The Rangers, too weary from their overnight charter flight from Denver to offer much resistance, lost to the Hartford Whalers, 5-3, at Madison Square Garden in a listless effort last night.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard NISA. The Life and Words of a !Kung Woman. By Marjorie Shostak. Illustrat- ed. 402 pages. Harvard. $20.

title: SOVIET SUB THREAT CITED BY U.S. NAVY
description: United States Navy officers say that Soviet submarines usually put to sea with nuclear weapons aboard and that they were thus not surprised when Sweden announced several weeks ago that a Russian submarine aground in Swedish waters was probably carrying such weapons.

title: Threlkeld Leaving CBS for ABC News
description: Richard Threlkeld, a correspondent for CBS News since 1966, made his last appearance on the network yesterday. He will join ABC News as a correspondent next month.

title: TV: 'MRS. REINHARDT,' EDNA O' BRIEN ADAPTATION
description: ''MRS. REINHARDT,'' the ''Great Performances'' presentation on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tonight at 8, has been adapted by Edna O'Brien, the Irish writer, from one of her own short stories. The BBC production, produced by Alan Shawcross (''Churchill and His Generals''), was directed by Piers Haggard (''Pennies From Heaven''). The cast includes Helen Mirren, Brad Davis and Ralph Bates. The ingredients, in other words, are quite promising. The result, however, is only disconcerting, if not downright irritating.

title: AS ISRAEL PULLS OUT OF SINAI, FEARS AND ANGER REMAIN
description: Occupied Sinai - The Sinai road north from Sharm el Sheik to the Israeli city of Eilat is busy with broad, flatbed trailer trucks hauling whole buildings out of Sinai into Israel proper. The Israeli Army is moving north.

title: Soccer Crown to Connecticut
description: Jim D'Orsaneo scored on a header 4 minutes 56 seconds into overtime to give Connecticut a 2-1 victory today over Alabama A & M and the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer championship.

title: BANK FOR SAVINGS FEELS SQUEEZE
description: For Thanksgiving this year, the New York Bank for Savings gave out special bonuses of up to $300 to each of its employees earning $30,000 a year or less. This was probably the last such bonus from the bank.

title: Hijacking at Cleveland Foiled by T.W.A. Aide
description: A Trans World Airlines employee was in fair condition today after grappling with a man who said he wanted to take control of a New York-bound flight, officials said.

title: DOLPHINS TRIUMPH
description: While their home stadium in Foxboro, Mass., was being buried under 24 inches of snow and buffeted by 50 mile-an-hour winds yesterday, the New England Patriots were being buried in sunny Miami by the Dolphins, 24-14, and buffeted by the passing and running of David Woodley. The victory, coupled with the Jets' loss in Seattle, gave Miami sole possession of first place in the American Conference East.

title: John Henry Loses - and Wins
description: Providential II took the lead coming round the final turn and held off Queen to Conquer to win the $550,500 Hollywood Turf Cup by a neck today. John Henry, thoroughbred racing's leading money-winner, faded to finish fourth but still surpassed $3 million in earnings.

title: RUSSELL AND KNICKS SHOW CELTICS HOW
description: Since Campy Russell came from the Cleveland Cavaliers to the Knicks, he has played in seven games against the Boston Celtics and their coach, Bill Fitch. The Knicks have won only two of those games, and Russell played key roles in both victories.

title: Topics; Two Kinds of Carrot; A Magic Bullet?
description: Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum, has offered a prize of $1 million for the scientist who develops a cure for cancer ''similar to that discovered by Dr. Jonas Salk with polio vaccine.'' Cancer is often described as a family of diseases, not a single entity, and it would be incautious to hope too hard for any magic bullet deadly to all its forms. Nor has the policy of throwing money at cancer research, initiated a decade ago by President Nixon, brought commensurate dividends.

title: Redskins Send Eagles to 3d Loss in Row
description: Stung by the Giants two weeks ago, and beaten by Miami last Monday night, the Philadelphia Eagles continue to struggle. Yesterday they lost their third consecutive game, a 15-13 setback at the hands of the Redskins at Washington.

title: WEST GERMAN PARTIES RESISTING NATO MISSILE PLAN
description: Regional conventions of both the Social Democratic and Free Democratic Parties passed resolutions over the weekend rejecting the planned deployment in Western Europe of new United States medium-range missiles.

title: MINING THE SEABED
description: President Reagan is soon to decide whether to continue United States participation in the Law of the Sea Conference. He may be inclined to pull the delegation out of the eight-year-old negotiations or demand fundamental changes in the nearly completed treaty, whose centerpiece deals with seabed mining. Either decision would hurt the American economy and exacerbate the country's already strained relations with the third world and Europe.

title: Gail Emily Josephson Married to H. Allan Lipsitz
description: The marriage of Gail Emily Josephson, who teaches English literature at the McDonogh School in Baltimore, to H. Allan Lipsitz, academic coordinator in the division of continuing studies at Towson (Md.) State University, took place in Vernon, Conn., yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Habib and Prince Fahd Discuss Saudi Peace Plan

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's a gold mine. We can see the green falling.'' - Russ Perry, ski resort operator, on the snowstorm.

title: PATERNITY LEAVE: A NEW ROLE FOR FATHERS
description: Vinny Parisi dandled his 10-month-old daughter, Dana, and talked about what it feels like to be studied by researchers, hailed as a pioneer and seen as the embodiment of a ''new phenomenon'' in fathering. ''I don't feel like a one-man trend,'' he said. ''It's just that my wife makes more than I do, and we couldn't live on my salary.''

title: 11 DIE IN PLANE CRASH
description: A victim of a Honolulu accident being placed in an ambulance.

title: GUATEMALAN JESUIT, EX-REBEL, NOW PREACHES RIGHTIST CAUSE
description: A Jesuit priest who was held incommunicado by the Guatemalan Government for more than three months is now traveling around Central America denouncing the involvement of liberal sectors of the Roman Catholic Church in the revolutionary movements of the region.

title: S.P.C.C. in Deal With RCA Astro
description: The Southern Pacific Communications Company has contracted with RCA Astro-Electronics for construction of three satellites, including one devoted to video transmissions for cable and broadcast markets.

title: Pope Calls for Equality Of Workers of Both Sexes
description: Pope John Paul II called today for equality between male and female workers, but said women who dedicated themselves to their families played an ''irreplaceable role'' and should not suffer discrimination.

title: Run for Congress Beckons Former Hostage of Iran
description: It would mean moving back across the country and changing parties, but Richard Morefield, a former hostage in Iran, says he might do just that to run for Congress.

title: CANCER STUDIES ONLY REINFORCE FEARS OF EMPLOYEES IN G.M.'S MODEL SHOP
description: The way Jim Bruce remembers it, he had just attended the funeral of a friend who worked with him at the General Motors Corporation's Fisher Body plant here, making precision wood models used in manufacturing car parts.

title: Hooked on Broadway
description: She's only a two-week replacement for the vacationing Lauren Bacall in ''Woman of the Year,'' but Raquel Welch is already looking for a script to give her a Broadway run of her own.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Air New Zealand Ltd., Los Angeles, has appointed Norman M.T. Geary chief executive officer.

title: U.S. Steel Passes 51% In Marathon Stock Bid
description: The United States Steel Corporation, currently battling the Mobil Corporation to buy the Marathon Oil Company, said yesterday that its offer to pay $125 a share for 30 million shares of Marathon was ''substantially oversubscribed.''

title: Peter Wiley Performs Cello Sonatas at Met
description: Without once abandonning himself to overstatement, the panacea of choice for many cellists, Peter Wiley offered fluent accounts of sonatas by Barber, Debussy and Brahms in a recital at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday afternoon, focusing his own attention and that of his listeners on the music rather than on displays of technique or personality.

title: ADMINISTRATION MOVING TO TRIM ITS DOMESTIC ROLE
description: The Reagan Administration has been moving pervasively toward its goal of reducing the Federal Government's domestic role.

title: Alfa Romeo, Fiat Layoffs
description: Italy's two leading auto makers, Fiat and Alfa Romeo, have announced plans for big layoffs next year.

title: From RCA to Sony
description: After 25 years with the RCA Corporation, where he rose to executive vice president, Neil R. Vander Dussen, 49, resigned to become president and chief executive officer of the newly established Sony Broadcast Products Company, a unit of the New York-based Sony Corporation of America.

title: Hanna Mining, Midland in Pact
description: The Hanna Mining Company said its board of directors had approved the purchase of about 50 percent of the outstanding stock of the Midland Southwest Corporation in a $46.5 million deal.

title: 100 SPANISH OFFICERS SIGN RIGHTIST LETTER
description: One hundred junior army officers made public a communique today that bitterly attacked the Spanish press, defended officers implicated in an attempted coup last February, and warned politicians not to meddle in the affairs of the armed forces.

title: '76 SLAYING STILL CASTS SHADOW ON FRENCH POLITICS
description: In December 1976, Jean de Broglie, a former Cabinet minister and political associate of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing who had fallen on hard times, was shot dead on a Paris street.

title: MISUNDERSTOOD U.S. CURBS ON VISITING CHINESE SCHOLARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Packers 31, Lions 17
description: Lynn Dickey passed for 279 yards and two touchdowns and Harlan Huckleby scored twice on 1-yard plunges in rallying the Packers.

title: Will of Edith Head Provides For Care of Her Cats and Dog
description: The will of Edith Head, the Oscarwinning costume designer who died Oct. 24, names Elizabeth Taylor, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, several cats and a Dalmatian named Boppo as beneficiaries of her $575,000 estate.

title: NEEDIEST FUND GETS GIFT IN MEMORY OF COMPOSER
description: Dorothy Rodgers, widow of the composer Richard Rodgers, who died two years ago this month, has contributed $10,000 to the 70th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which officially began last week.

title: PURCHASING MANAGERS PESSIMISTIC
description: Purchasing agents at many of the leading industrial companies in the United States believe that the economy is sliding deeper into recession but still has a long way to go before it hits bottom, according to the November survey of the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Florida Officers' Aid To Saudi Causes Stir
description: When Prince Turki bin Abdul Aziz of Saudi Arabia requested protection from the Hollywood Police Department, few realized the stir it would create.

title: China to Get Computers
description: A 15-nation export control panel has approved the sale of 20 United States computers to China for use in conducting that nation's population census, Government officials said Friday.

title: TOKEN BOOTH CLERK IS STABBED 14 TIMES AT BROOKLYN STATION
description: A subway token-booth clerk was stabbed 14 times early yesterday morning when he went to empty the turnstiles at his station in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, the Transit Authority police said.

title: Washington Watch; Harvard Unit Widens Study
description: WASHINGTON IT offers a neutral setting. Its hallmarks are fact and analysis. Its research efforts are well under way. And now, with some fresh funding, the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard is about to enlarge its program of improving communication between government officials and business executives.

title: STAGE: JOHN CULLUM AS WHISTLER IN ONE-MAN SHOW OF ARTIST'S LIFE
description: ''ART is life,'' says the title character of ''Whistler,'' a new one-man play starring John Cullum. Well, if art is life, then what is an exercise in philistinism like ''Whistler''? Judging from the evidence on stage at the Provincetown Playhouse, I'd say rigor mortis.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 7, 1981; The Economy
description: The economy is sliding deeper into recession, but still has a long way to go before reaching bottom, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its latest monthly survey. The members, who are the executives who buy goods and services for the nation's businesses, also said that falling prices from suppliers indicated more downward pressure on inflation. (Page D1.)

title: Viktor Friedman Offers Beethoven Variations
description: The last variation of Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Variations is passionately lyrical, teasing the ear with the sort of vocal acrobatics and suspensions that twist the experience of time in the composer's slow movements in aria form. At Viktor Friedman's piano recital at the 92d Street Y yesterday afternoon, the variation was a collection of details, projected with restrained tone, articulated with care, but whimsical in its dynamics and rubatos, lacking the drive and tensile pull latent in its ornamented lines.

title: SAVING CHATEAU AND WRITINGS OF MARQUIS DE SADE
description: EN-BRIE, France - Like many of the French nobility, the Comte de Sade returned to his family's castle after World War II to find it bombarded, sacked and riddled with shells. He has devoted the last 35 years, and some $500,000, to restoring the historic rooms where the Cardinal Richelieu slept and where Watteau and Oudry painted.

title: Richard Hugo Wins Fellowship for Poetry
description: The Academy of American Poets has awarded a fellowship for ''distinguished poetic achievement'' to Richard Hugo, author of several volumes of poetry, editor of the Yale Series of Younger Poets and director of creative writing at the University of Montana.

title: Economic Analysis
description: For the second time in two years, a recession has become the cutting edge in the battle to reduce inflation and interest rates. It is a painful medicine, and it comes with no promise of lasting recovery.

title: Robert Lukowsky Dies at 54; Kentucky High Court Justice
description: Kentucky Supreme Court Justice Robert O. Lukowsky died early Saturday at Good Samaritan Hospital here.

title: BRIEFING
description: I N one of the more poignant ironies of the Federal budget cuts, scores of Labor Department workers, who were to be trained as the supervising cadre in a new job-hunting program for the unemployed, are themselves being dismissed and are spending their final Government hours learning how to find a new job. The painful turnabout begins for some of them this morning as final ''RIF,'' or reduction-in-force, pink slips arrive from the paymaster.

title: A Chairman Is Appointed At Executone
description: George H. Zoffinger, 54, has been appointed chairman and chief executive officer of Executone Inc., a business telephone systems manufacturer based in Jericho, L.I. He succeeds Edward Brody, 64, who will retire from the company, a unit of the Continental Telephone Company since 1979.

title: Bears 10, Vikings 9
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Bob Avellini's 72-yard touchdown pass to Brian Baschnagel early in the fourth quarter gave the Bears the victory and dealt a serious blow to Minnesota's chances for a divisional title. It was Avellini's first touchdown pass in two years and came on the first play from scrimmage after the Vikings had taken a 7-3 lead on a 3-yard pass from Tommy Kramer to Ahmad Rashad.

title: FOR THE N.Y.U. PRESIDENT, A FAST PACE
description: John Brademas of South Bend, Ind., and Washington -Phi Beta Kappa from Harvard, Rhodes scholar, member of Congress for 22 years and former majority whip - is now Dr. John Brademas, president of New York University. It's as if he had been preparing himself all those years for the job.

title: FIRST-PLACE BRONCOS DEFEAT CHIEFS, 16-13
description: Craig Morton's passing set up short-yardage touchdown runs as Denver built a 16-0 first-half lead, and Bob Swenson's interception in the closing minutes shut off a Kansas City rally as the Broncos beat the Chiefs today, 16-13.

title: MALCOLM GOLDSTEIN AND SON MAKE MUSIC
description: MALCOLM GOLDSTEIN'S son Marin must have had a difficult time writing his name when he was 4 years old. At the Alternative Museum the results are on display - the awkward vertical strokes, smudged and indistinct letters, random lines - all indicating that this was a young man earnestly struggling with the alphabet.

title: MUSIC: RICHMAN CONDUCTS HARMONIE ENSEMBLE
description: Off all the works that Stravinsky left us when he died 10 years ago, ''L'Histoire du Soldat,'' the morality play in the form of a cabaret melodrama that he composed during World War I, is the one that sounds most like him to many listeners. It is hard to think of that thin, dapper little musician sitting down and turning out such an explosive piece as ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' for instance. Or, for that matter, any of the gaudily orchestrated ballet scores that his Diaghilev years produced. But ''L'Histoire,'' or ''The Soldier's Tale,'' as it is known in its English version, is the very portrait of Stravinsky, not only in its terse, acerbic sonorities but in the laconic way it approaches the tale itself.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OFF THE WALL

title: Peru Oil Output
description: The local manager for the Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that Peru's crude oil production would rise almost 20 percent next year. The official, Gerhard Jansen, told a business executives meeting that output would rise from 210,000 barrels a day to 250,000, and added that Occidental planned to invest $230 million in Peru next year.

title: Sabres 7, Penguins 4
description: BUFFALO (AP) - Ric Seiling scored twice for Buffalo, and Rick Kehoe scored two goals for the losers. Seiling scored on a power play in the opening period when his second stab at a rebound eluded the Penguin goalie, Paul Harrison.

title: MEDIATOR RENEWS BARGAINING IN STRIKE BY CARTING WORKERS
description: A second round of negotiations in the private sanitationmen's strike was started by a state mediator yesterday afternoon. The session, initiated by James McCabe of the State Mediation Board, followed a 14-hour meeting that ended at 3 A.M. yesterday - the first face-to-face bargaining since the walkout began last Tuesday.

title: BIG LOSS AT HOME IS UNUSUAL FOR IRISH
description: For Notre Dame, a basketball team unaccustomed to losing, the start of the current season has stirred memories of Digger Phelps's first year as coach in South Bend when the Fighting Irish struggled to a 6-20 record.

title: RIFT OVER UNDERAGE GYMNASTS
description: The phenomenal success of young female gymnasts, some of whom may have been illegally entered in last month's world championships, has created controversy and division within the fast-growing sport.

title: KENNEDY CENTER HONORS BASIE, GRANT, ROBBINS, SERKIN AND HELEN HAYES
description: Stars of theater, film, music and the dance joined with official Washington this evening to honor five giants of the performing arts: Count Basie, Cary Grant, Helen Hayes, Jerome Robbins and Rudolf Serkin. The occasion was the fourth annual Kennedy Center Honors, which is becoming the capital's most glittering extravaganza.

title: DEMOCRATS AND REPUBLICANS CONFER OVER ROLES OF PARTIES
description: The Republican and Democratic parties should ''move the American party system in the direction of party government'' but they must use a light rein on state parties to get there, a high-level informal conference of politicians and academics concluded today.

title: What Mr. Palladino Has Seen
description: When the new chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission describes as ''inexcusable'' the failure of the nuclear power industry's quality assurance programs, he is departing considerably in tone from the Reagan Administration script for revitalizing the industry.

title: SHCHARANSKY'S LOT
description: To the Editor:

title: The Secret War Over the Homeless
description: Twenty-four hours' notice, at most, is what officials will henceforth give to neighborhoods in which they intend to shelter some of the more than 10,000 people wandering the streets of New York. Given the public's resistance, you can hardly blame the officials. That may be the only way they can arrange to keep some of these wretched people from freezing to death this winter.

title: U.S. INQUIRY TERMS CONTROLLERS ABLE
description: Investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board have found that charges of Government use of unqualified or medically unfit air traffic controllers to replace those who struck on Aug. 3 were ''unfounded'' in every case they looked into.

title: FLAWS IN AN APPRAISAL OF AFRICAN FARMING
description: To the Editor:

title: 49ers SNAP BENGALS' STREAK
description: Winning today's game was not crucial to the San Francisco 49ers, but they did win it, and with ease. A Cincinnati victory would have assured the Bengals of a place in the playoffs. Now their future is clouded and their quarterback, Ken Anderson, is injured.

title: WARSAW ACCUSES UNION OF RENEGING ON ITS AGREEMENTS
description: The Government accused the leadership of the Solidarity labor union tonight of breaking its agreements by refusing to negotiate for a national accord and choosing ''a road that may bring about confrontation.''

title: RECITAL: ROBERTA PETERS
description: ROBERTA PETERS stood in the spotlight at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening and, without singing a note, received the kind of applause many sopranos would be content to hear after a full recital. While displays of this sort are not infrequently accorded to the latest flash in the pan, this one was clearly motivated by the audience's desire to show a versatile and consistent artist the esteem she has earned over a career spanning more than 30 years.

title: Pando Takes New Post
description: About a month ago, Alan O. Pando, 50, left Doyle Dane Bernbach, New York, as group senior vice president and board member after 13 years at the agency. He has turned up in Los Angeles as a senior vice president, management director and member of the newly created management committee of Della Femina, Travisano & zartners of California.

title: PREMIER OF QUEBEC THREATENS TO RESIGN OVER PARTY PROGRAM
description: Premier Rene Levesque stunned his Quebec separatist party today by rejecting the radical conclusions of its biannual convention and announcing he was on the point of resigning as the party's president.

title: New Members Elected To Pulitzer Prize Board
description: Two new members have been elected to fill vacancies on the 17-member Pulitzer Prize Board, which annually makes the recommendations on which Columbia University awards prizes in journalism, letters, drama and music.

title: 40 YEARS LATER, JAPANESE PILOT RECALLS PEARL HARBORA
description: Forty years ago Monday, Yoshio Shiga ate a breakfast of red beans with rice and tai, or red snapper. He then prayed before a Shinto shrine below deck on the aircraft carrier Kaga in a last vow to Emperor and nation. He did not expect to survive the day.

title: U.S. COURT TO HEAR ARGUMENTS ON CREATIONISM
description: A growing movement among religious fundamentalists to force public schools to teach creation-science theory is to meet its first judicial test Monday. Arguments will be heard in Federal District Court here on the constitutionality of an Arkansas law that requires ''balanced treatment'' in the teaching of the evolution and creation-science theories.

title: CHANGE OF STRATEGY FOR TALON ZIPPERS
description: The mechanics of making zippers haven't changed much. Coils of monofilament polyester spew from machines looking like miniature Slinkys. The endless coils are sewn onto a continuous tape and a slicing arrangement chops them into appropriate-sized pieces. Bottom stops define the zipper lengths, and sliders, the things that go up and down, are slipped on and zipped up.

title: TOURISTS ON NANTUCKET ARE STRANDED BY STORM
description: About 200 people who had expected to be here for only a few hours of Christmas shopping Saturday were stranded when a severe winter storm that swept across New England cut off transportation back to the mainland.

title: TV: 'CHILD BRIDE,' STORY OF A CULT IN ARIZONA
description: THE tragedy of a cultish life that becomes institutionalized over decades only to fall victim to the outside world is the theme of ''Child Bride of Short Creek'' on NBC-TV from 9 to 11 tonight.

title: HOLDOVERS DOMINATE WEEK'S DEBT OFFERINGS
description: Investment bankers announced plans to sell more than $3.9 billion of notes and bonds this week, most of them holdovers from last week when prices gyrated so widely that issuers and investors backed away from the market.

title: Thanks, but no Thanks
description: President Reagan has accepted private donations to help refurbish the White House and to buy a new set of dishes, but he has drawn the line at a proposed fund-raising effort to replace the 18-year-old jeep he uses at his California ranch.

title: Briton Wants to Redraw the Line of Succession
description: There is a woman on the British throne and a woman at the head of the British Government, but to Michael English, a member of the British House of Commons, Queen Elizabeth and Margaret Thatcher aren't enough to assure equality of the sexes in Britain.

title: U.S. IS INSISTENT
description: Libya's ruler, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, denied yesterday that he had plotted to assassinate President Reagan or anyone else. But the State Department said that it had evidence of such plans.

title: KLAMMER TAKES SEASON'S FIRST DOWNHILL
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 6 -Franz Klammer, who two years ago could not ski well enough to make the Austrian Olympic team, came back in remarkable style today by winning the first World Cup downhill race of the season.

title: Bruin Game Falls Victim to Storm
description: A scheduled National Hockey Leaque game between the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Boston Bruins was postponed today because of the worst snowstorm to hit New England in three years.

title: PEOPLE'S WOULD-BE CHAMPIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: JETS LOSE, DROP OUT OF FIRST PLACE
description: The Jets' past caught up with them again today, and this time it was more than embarrassing because the Seattle Seahawks knocked them out of first place.

title: Index; International
description: Inquiries on Sakharovs' situation meet Soviet wall of silence A3 Greek demonstrators call for a ban on nuclear arms A4 West German parties continuing to resist NATO missile plan A5 Greeks on Crete quietly await ac- tion on U.S. bases A6 Many Soviet submarines report- edly carry nuclear weapons A7 Israeli military forces are pulling out of the Sinai A8 Around the World A11 Guatemalan Jesuit, ex-rebel, now preaches rightist cause A14 Government/Politics Oregon faces budget shortfall of $250 million A20 A ''creationism'' law will be chal- lenged in Court in Arkansas A21 Those attending conference on city services get good service B3 Port Gibson, Miss., awaits ruling on boycott there B16 Conference debates role of politi- cal parties D16 Washington Talk Briefing A22 A year out of office, Father Drinan stays near politics A22 New wave of neo-isolationism is spreading in Congress A22 General Pearl Harbor is remembered at a ceremony in Brooklyn A16 Around the Nation A18 Snowstorm strands 200 people visiting festival in Natucket A18 Boston gets a chance to test '78 shoveling technology A18 Cancer surveys reinforce work- ers' fears at G.M. model shop A18 Doctors are found to have a high default rate on student loans A19 New Hampshire reporter resigns from federal consulting job A24 Man found slain in Central Park is identified as an actor B2 SportsMonday Baseball: Shortstops head trade talk at winter meetings C9 Basketball: Russell and Knicks at best in defeating Celtics C10

title: Lesson in Latitude
description: Early on there was a sly dig in the memorandum from Gen. Robert C. Mathis, Vice Chief of Staff of the Air Force, to his opposite number, Adm. W.N. Small, Vice Chief of Naval Operations, about Navy's 30-13 midseason victory over the Air Force. Noting that Navy's offense ''seemed to alternate'' between quarterback and tailback rushes, General Mathis wrote: ''I couldn't possibly help but reflect that a team with College Board scores as high as are required for entrance into an Academy could certainly learn more than two plays, no matter how well those two worked.''

title: HEISMANS' OTHER SIDE
description: ON Saturday night, an hour-long national television program paid tribute to the graven image of the Heisman Memorial Trophy. Paeans were sung to the 25-pound, two-hands-high bronze statuette of a stiff-arming running back with an old-time helmet and impressive calves. The chunky little fellow is supposed to be emblematic of the year's top player in college football.

title: Advertising; Bloom's New York Outpost
description: WITHIN a week or so, the nine-year-old firm of Mathieu, Gerfen, Bresner, billing $24 million, will be the New York outpost of the Bloom Companies, a Dallas holding company in the communications field.

title: Bucs 24, Falcons, 23
description: A 71-yard scoring play from the quarterback Doug Williams to Kevin House, a wide receiver, gave the lead with 9:39 remaining and the Bucs held on.

title: U.S. Aide Cancels Bonn Visit
description: The United States Deputy Secretary of State, William P. Clark, called off a planned visit to Bonn today and returned to Washington after a three-day stay in Ireland. Mr. Clark said that he had been summoned back to Washington by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to discuss a North Atlantic Treaty Organization meeting.

title: Roscoe Mitchell Plays Jazz and Experimental
description: Roscoe Mitchell is one of those musicians who lurk along the border between jazz and the experimental world. Saturday night at The Kitchen, Mr. Mitchell and his Sound and Space ensembles kept crossing from the jazz tonal tradition into expanded freedoms of form, bendings of pitch and blurrings of key. The music often had a chordal, chorale-like texture, with Tom Buckner, a tenor, chanting syllables over descant noodlings from Mr. Mitchell's saxophone and Hugh Ragin's trumpet.

title: 'UNKNOWN' KRIEG IMPRESSES MICHAELS
description: Of course, Dave Krieg was nervous about facing the Jets today. After all, it was his first major-league start for the Seahawks.

title: Split in Udall Base Vetoed in Arizona
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt, a Democrat, Saturday vetoed a Republican redistricting plan that would split the Tucson Congressional district of Representative Morris K. Udall, a Democrat.

title: MANY DOCTORS FAILING TO PAY STUDENT LOANS
description: Many doctors are failing to pay back the Government loans that helped them through school, according to Federal investigators.

title: Old Giant Can Cheer
description: ALL through yesterday's game the old quarterback had rooted quietly for his old team. Charlie Conerly is 60 years old now. White hair frames that leathery Marlboro-man face. But he's still as much of a Giant as he was 25 years ago when he guided the 1956 team to the National Football League championship. And when the cornerback, Terry Jackson, batted down Pat Haden's fourth-down pass with only 86 seconds remaining and the Giants leading the Los Angeles Rams, 10-7, the old quarterback smiled and clapped.

title: Market Place; Power Bonds In Northwest
description: criticized Washington Public Power Supply System are clearly visible from a bluff overlooking the Columbia River several miles south of this town.

title: THE POWER OF MONEY
description: President Reagan and President Francois Mitterrand of France are on opposite sides of the political spectrum. They both won office from an electorate that was fed up with familiar leaders to the point of accepting the risk of experiment.

title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS AND MAIL DON'T MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: THE USED-CAR CAPITAL
description: Should used-car dealers tell buyers the truth about the cars they sell? Forty-one of 100 Senators and 207 of 435 Congressmen don't think so. They are cosponsoring a bill that would overturn a proposed Federal Trade Commission rule requiring the dealers to tell consumers of any defects they know about in their cars and about any guarantees they offer or do not offer.

title: Two Killed, Two Injured As Bus Crashes in Utah
description: A school bus loaded with teen-agers going home from a ski resort overturned today on a steep road southeast of here, killing two girls and critically injuring two others, the authorities said.

title: STEELERS TRYING TO REVIVE GLORY
description: IT happened during the 1970's when the Pittsburgh Steelers were the monsters of the National Football League, winning four Super Bowls in six years, and, with their reputation for ferocity, sometimes making opponents go limp when they thundered onto the football field, 45 large men with black helmets gleaming and black capes flapping.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Salvador Prelate Assails 'Repression' of Junta

title: U.C.L.A. Meeting
description: U.C.L.A. officials will meet Monday to discuss whether they will appeal penalties reportedly imposed against the basketball team by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title: BLUSTERY WINDS TOPPLE ELECTRIC LINES AND SEND TRASH FLYING
description: It rattled windows, whined in the trees, howled down country lanes and swooshed through city canyons. It also toppled tree limbs and power lines, grounded hundreds of small aircraft, set bridges and skyscrapers to swaying and raised cottony whitecaps on the Hudson River and across the amphitheater of New York Harbor.

title: 3 Police Officers Discharged After Taking Drug-Use Tests
description: Nine police officers charged with using drugs, mostly cocaine, have been given punishments ranging from being discharged to suspension, according to the Police Department.

title: M.T.A. SEEKS OVERSEAS AID ON FINANCING FOR NEW CARS
description: Faced with the task of paying for hundreds of new subway cars, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is for the first time enlisting the aid of foreign and domestic manufacturers to help get better deals on the equipment.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TELLS OF ANGOLA RAID
description: The South African Army said today that it had destroyed the central military headquarters of the South West Africa People's Organization in a new attack deep inside Angola.

title: Needham Gets Account Of Washington Post
description: The Washington Post has hired the Washington office of Needham, Harper & Steers to do its advertising.

title: TALKS FOCUSING ON SHORTSTOPS
description: If talk turns into trades, shortstops could become the featured players of baseball's annual winter meetings.

title: RECESSION FEAR IS CENTRAL TOPIC FOR 8 GOVERNORS
description: Amid warnings that the nation's recession could be more severe than predicted, Governors from the Northeast met here today to plan how to keep national trends from wrecking their economies or their budgets.

title: Quick Study
description: She didn't start school until she was 10 years old, but after three months of formal education, Ruth Lawrence is apparently hooked. She has decided to continue her education - at Oxford.

title: Bridge: Wolff and Hamman Rated World's Best Partnership
description: Ask a group of knowledgeable experts to name the world's best player of the 1970's and you would generate a fierce discussion with many names in nomination. But ask for the world's best partnership and there would be a clear consensus in favor of the Dallas experts, Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman.

title: Doctors Cleared in Dispute With Aides Treating Patient
description: No charges will be filed against two doctors who were arrested in a dispute with paramedics about treatment of a heart attack victim, officials say.

title: WHY HUNTERS WON'T RUN SHORT OF PREY
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Ecuadorean Strikes End
description: The Government said today it had negotiated an end to strikes by 30,000 teachers and 2,000 rural medical service workers demanding higher pay, but that troops would continue to run the telecommunications system because talks with striking employees had broken down. A spokesman for the teachers said that they would end the monthlong strike and return to work Monday, and that demands for education reforms had also been met.

title: Joseph Kanarek Weds Robin Bennett, Nurse
description: The marriage of Robin C. Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Bennett of Stamford, Conn., to Joseph Kanarek, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Kanarek of Tel Aviv, took place yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkranz performed the ceremony at Temple Agudath Sholom in Stamford.

title: PRETORIA AND NEIGHBORS
description: One of the oddest international episodes of late was the coup attempted in the Seychelles by a band of white mercenaries. But it was not just a comic-opera affair on some palmy islands. The aftermath in Pretoria threw light on a significant matter: South Africa's view of political stability in its region.

title: Kappa Sport Hires Severin/Aviles Agency
description: Severin/Aviles Associates, an advertising agency that specializes in the promotion of Republican political candidates, has become agency for Kappa Sport, the United States marketer of an Italian apparel manufacturer.

title: Cowboys 37, Colts 13
description: BALTIMORE (AP) - Ron Springs ran for two touchdowns and scored one on a pass from the substitute quarterback Glenn Carano as Dallas handed Baltimore its 13th straight defeat after a season-opening victory. The Cowboys (11-3) opened a two-game lead over the Philadelphia Eagles in the National Football Conference East.

title: CRETE SLOWS DRIVE AGAINST U.S. BASES
description: A local drive to remove the United States electronic surveillance station from this Greek island has slowed since Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was swept into power six weeks ago on a platform demanding the ouster of all American bases.

title: Bills 28, Chargers 27
description: SAN DIEGO (UPI) - Joe Cribbs went 1 yard for a touchdown in the third period to lead Buffalo. The victory gave the Bills a 9-6 record and moved them into second place in the A.F.C. East, a half-game behind Miami.

title: Well Over Par
description: In golf they say the sun never sets on Robert Trent Jones. That's understandable because there are more than 400 golf courses in 32 countries and 43 states that were designed or remodeled by this dean of course architects. Nineteen are in Golf Digest's ''One Hundred Greatest.'' Jones, at 75 years old, logs about 250,000 miles a year to slog through mud, climb mounds, survey target areas, plot bunkers, supervise bulldozer operators and so on. ''My home is a 747,'' he says. As it happens, Jones also is represented by 13 courses in the New York metropolitan area. So the other evening the Metropolitan Golf Association gave Jones its distinguished service award.

title: Visiting Minister Is Slain At Services in Tennessee
description: A visiting Baptist minister was killed and an assistant was wounded tonight when a man at the Webster Memorial Baptist Church went on a shooting spree.

title: GIANTS BEAT RAMS, 10-7, REMAIN IN RACE
description: On a frigid afternoon, in winds that would have sunk a navy, the Giants kept their slight playoff hopes alive today with a 10-7 victory over the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Dow Drops by 5.70, to 886.99; Technology Issues Weak
description: The stock market moved moderately lower yesterday, hurt by weakness in bond prices and uncertainty over the duration of the economic slowdown.

title: CHILDREN'S WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ADIA RIGHTS GROUP GETS GRANT
description: A human rights group in Asia has been given a three-year grant by the Ford Foundation to investigate violations in the region. The Research Institute of the Law Association for Asia and the Western Pacific, called Lawasia, was given $120,639, the Ford Foundation announced yesterday.

title: A PISTOL IS A PISTOL
description: To the Editor:

title: KUHN RULES OUT '82 SPLIT SEASON
description: Baseball's 80th annual business meeting opened today with a report by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn that the sport lost $25 million last year, keeping it in what he called ''a precarious financial condition,'' and with the commissioner's promise that the season would not again be split into tandem pennant races.

title: Palestinian Leader Slain On a Visit to Beirut
description: Unidentified gunmen today shot and killed a Palestinian leader who was on a private visit to Beirut, security officials reported.

title: Nigerian Troops Reach Chad
description: An advance contingent of 400 Nigerian troops flew to Ndjamena today to join a peacekeeping force of the Organization of African Unity in Chad. The Nigerian commander of the peace force, Maj. Gen. Geoffrey Ejiga, said last week that Nigeria's contingent would eventually total 2,000 troops.

title: 8 MINERS KILLED IN BLAST IN SOUTHEAST KENTUCKY
description: An explosion tore through a coal mine near here today, killing eight men who were working half a mile inside a mountain, officials said.

title: LAWYER SAYS CITY FAILS TO COMPLY WITH PACT ON SHELTERING HOMELESS
description: A lawyer representing homeless men charged at a hearing in State Supreme Court yesterday that the city was not complying with an agreement to make clean and decent shelter available to any man who asked for it.

title: A Christmas Wish
description: Her family Christmas decorations are packed away and she is ''getting frantic'' about last-minute shopping, but Nancy Reagan looked like Christmas itself yesterday as she conducted a tour of the gaily decorated state rooms of the White House.

title: 2 South Africans Guilty In Slaying of Lawyer
description: A farm laborer was sentenced to death and another was sentenced to 10 years in prison today on conviction of the murder of a New York lawyer, Katherine Julia Tobin, last summer.

title: QUEEN OF LIGHTS
description: Accompanied by white-robed maids, Carolina Andersson, 17, wore a crown of candles as she was carried in procession in Vimmerby, Sweden. Miss Andersson was chosen as the town's 35th representative of St. Lucy for the celebration, next week on the feast day of the saint, of the Queen of Lights festival.

title: Hundreds Flee Derailment
description: The authorities evacuated hundreds of people Sunday after 16 cars and two locomotives of a 100-car Southern Pacific train derailed, puncturing a hole in a tanker car containing butyl alcohol. No injuries were reported.

title: Plain English Award, Booby Prize Division
description: While it may not always be able to give top service, Chrissie Maher believes that ''a major organization, used to dealing with customers' complaints, should be able to write a clear letter to an aggrieved consumer.''

title: Turkish Refugee Dies
description: A 25-year-old Turk died shortly after swimming the Evros River separating Greece and Turkey, the police announced today. The Athens police said the Turk was a refugee escaping political persecution by Ankara's military regime and that he had died of cold and exhaustion.

title: Spanish Protest on NATO
description: Seven students held a sit-in for four hours today at the entrance hall of the United States consulate here to protest Spain's plans to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The students left voluntarily and were arrested by the police on undisclosed charges.

title: BLOCK, H & R, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Inco to Sell Unit; Expects Large Loss
description: Inco Ltd., the world's leading nickel producer, said in separate announcements yesterday that it was withdrawing from the batterymaking and related-product business and that it would take a $220 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to shut down its 80 percent owned Guatemalan nickel subsidiary, Exmibal.

title: ABUNDANT VARIETY FOR DANES PICKING GIFTS AND GOVERNMENT
description: The city is aglitter for Christmas, with lights strung on trees, red Christmas hearts hung above the walkways and a variety of goods beautifully displayed in the stores.

title: 37 Dead in Thailand Typhoon
description: The Interior Ministry said today that 37 people were known dead from the week of monsoon rains and flash floods that ended Saturday in southern Thailand. Six crewmen aboard the capsized freighter Thida Thara are still missing, officials said.

title: 2 Lawyers in Atlanta Are Held in Contempt
description: A judge upset by apparent violations of his curb on statements about the case filed contempt charges today against the defense attorneys for Wayne B. Williams, who is charged in two of 28 slayings of young Atlanta blacks.

title: O.A.S. Votes to Support Plan For Elections in El Salvador
description: The Organization of American States voted 22-3 today to support the Salvadoran junta's plan to hold general elections in an effort to end the war there.

title: 18TH CENTURY SPARKS GALA FASHION NIGHT
description: For many years it was called, with more wistfulness than accuracy, ''The Party of the Year.'' It was then the fashion industry's annual fund-raiser for the establishment of the Metropolitan Museum's Costume Institute.

title: PENTAGON PLANS ORION CUTOFF
description: The Pentagon has decided to stop buying Lockheed P-3C Orion antisubmarine aircraft. The company complains that this move will jeopardize the existence of the division producing that plane and the troubled Tristar jetliner.

title: 40 YEARS LATER, SURVIVORS, GATHER AT PEARL HARBOR
description: About 3,000 survivors of the Japanese surprise attack on Pearl Harbor and other defense installations here on Dec. 7, 1941, joined Honolulu residents today in solemn ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of the devastating air raid that plunged the United States into World War II.

title: CONSERVATIVES IN GREECE OUST LEADER AFTER ELECTION DEFEAT
description: Former Prime Minister George Rallis, paying the consequences of his party's heavy election defeat to the Socialists six weeks ago, was ousted today from the party leadership.

title: A GREENING OF THE CABS IS WEIGHED
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that a new kind of taxicab, possibly painted green, might be the solution to some of New York City's taxi woes.

title: LITTLE AGREEMENT OVER POLICY AS GOVERNORS' MEETING ENDS
description: The Governors of the Northeast's three largest states today heard business leaders ask for tax and regulatory relief and local officials plead for more revenues to make up for Federal cuts.

title: Coal Slurry Bill Gains; Coal Slurry Pipeline Bill Advances
description: Rejecting efforts to put tighter restrictions on water use, the House Interior Committee today moved closer to approving legislation that would allow pipelines to compete with railroads in bringing Western coal to market.

title: Albertina Jerome, Ex-Director Of Visiting Nurse Volunteers
description: Albertina Pitkin Jerome, a former director of volunteers for the Visiting Nurse Service in New York City, died Sunday at a nursing home in Schenectady, N.Y. She was 91 years old.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $473,000 extraordinary charge

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1981
description: International Polish union leaders were accused by the authorities of calling for the overthrow of the Government. The Warsaw radio transmitted a tape recording made at a closed meeting of union leaders last Thursday in which Lech Walesa, the union chairman, asked for a ''confrontation'' and another labor leader urged the overthrow of the regime. Mr. Walesa confirmed in an interview that he had made his remarks but said they had been taken out of context. (Page A1, Column 2.) Possible measures against Libya were discussed by President Reagan and his top advisers. Such measures might include an embargo against the import of Libyan oil and a ban on travel by Americans to Libya. (A1:1.)

title: Index; International
description: Anxiety about the future grows on the Rock of Gibraltar A2 Pol Pot group says it is disbanding its party organization A3 South Africa delayed reporting Angola raid A3 A pledge by Sakharov comes to light A3 Asian human rights group gets Ford Foundation grant A4 Israeli troops kill a Palestinian teen-ager in the Gaza Strip A6 Around the World A8 Greek Socialists and U.S. open high-level contacts A10 Greece's New Democracy Party ousts leader A12 Nicaragua says U.S. ''lies'' invite attack by neighbors A13 Government/Politics Concern's employees are tied to Rep. Richmond's fund-raising B1 Little agreement on policy as Governors end meeting B2 New York State and unions join to aid day-care centers B3 Washington Talk Briefing A24 Washington follow-up A24 Q&A with Arthur S. Flemming, head of civil rights agency A24 Leonore Annenberg talks about why she's leaving her job A24 Features/Notes Man in the News: John Edward Jacob, new Urban League head A18 Notes on People B21 Going Out Guide C9 Sports People D26 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the Roman Catholic Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking is suspended today in New York City. All other regulations are in effect. Science Times Supernovas that may have started the solar system C1 Education: Emory confronts the pleasant problem of wealth C1 The Doctor's World: literary scientists C2 A restrained science policy for the National Laboratories C2 Science Watch C3 About education: Reading books that make reading boring C5 Science Q&A C5 General Around the Nation A18 T.V.A. analyzed at Vanderbilt U. seminar A19 Press Notes: Media lawyers warned on closed courtrooms A29 Top U.S. officials recall their whereabouts on fateful day B19 Arts/Entertainment Christopher Durang talks about his work C7 Speculum Musicae gives first of three concerts C8 ''Amidst the Gladiolas,'' a drama of Brooklyn, is staged C8 Thomas Mann biography by Richard Winston is reviewed C13 CBS-TV tells ''The Patricia Neal Story'' at 9 P.M. C21 Style Notes on Fashion B22 18th century sparks a gala fashion night B22 Obituaries Fred Feldkamp, movie producer, editor and writer D31 Sports Giants' Taylor uses linebacker skills to create havoc D26 Kuhn rules out a split season D27 Guidry gets three offers D27 Bradshaw hurt as Raiders win D27 Rockies eye move to Meadowlands D27 Antuofermo ends boxing career D27 Jets' Michael stresses positive in belittling Browns jinx D28

title: ROCKIES EYE MOVE TO JERSEY
description: Peter Gilbert, the owner of the Colorado Rockies, said today that he wanted to move his team to the Byrne Meadowlands Arena next season and that he was prepared to challenge the Rangers for that right if the Rangers tried to move there.

title: CITY COUNCIL VS. HOMOSEXUALS' RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: STORMS ON COASTS LEAVE NINE DEAD
description: Late-autumn storms that buried parts of New England under up to two feet of snow and dumped record rains on the Pacific Northwest ended yesterday, leaving at least nine persons dead, dozens homeless and work crews scrambling to restore order.

title: Canada's Imperial Oil Selects a Chairman
description: Donald K. McIvor, 53, deputy chairman of Imperial Oil Ltd. of Canada, will become chairman and chief executive officer on Jan.1, succeeding John A. Armstrong, 64, who will retire. Mr. McIvor, a geologist who joined Imperial in 1950, assumes the top post at a time when the company, Canada's largest integrated oil concern, is facing serious pressures because of its 70 percent ownership by the Exxon Corporation.

title: CITY COUNCIL VS. HOMOSEXUALS' RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated for a stock split

title: SUSPECT IS SEIZED IN CAPITAL IN THREAT AT FEDERAL RESERVE
description: A man complaining of the high interest rates and inflation threatened to take members of the Federal Reserve Board hostage today but was arrested without any shots being fired, a police spokesman said.

title: STAGE: 'AMIDST THE GLADIOLAS,' ITALIAN BROOKLYN
description: IT is no small thing to dramatize a slice of life. What is terribly important to the playwright can be, and often is, a bore to the rest of us. Vito A. Gentile Jr. has set his play, ''Amidst the Gladiolas,'' in a funeral home in Brooklyn. Nothing much happens there, and what does happen won't suprise you. But perhaps this is why the evening is so satisfying. ''Amidst the Gladiolas,'' which the Prism Theater is presenting at the Lion Theater on Theater Row, is absolutely faithful to itself.

title: 60 Families Evicted In Alabama Shanty Town
description: Residents of one of Alabama's last coal company towns have been ordered to vacate some 60 dilapidated shanties at the beginning of the new year. The entire town is being closed by the company that owns it.

title: DAN E. PROVOST
description: Dan E. Provost, a former advertising executive with The New York Times, The New York Herald Tribune, Esquire magazine and the former Bridgeport (Conn.)

title: Seychelles Plotter Cites Intelligence Background
description: A South African arrested in the abortive coup here Nov. 25 said today that he is a senior intelligence officer who took part in the plot as a friend of the mercenary Michael Hoare and to strike a blow against Communism.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Alberto Salazar, winner of the New York City Marathon for the last two years, says he will start running fewer marathons to concentrate on shorter events such as the 5,000-meter and 10,000-meter runs. ''Nobody has ever been one of the top marathoners and one of the top five or 10 in track,'' said Salazar, who ran the fastest marathon in history in the New York race this year.

title: CORRECTIONSS
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the status of the five plants in the Washington Public Power System. None are producing power, but the first three are near completion while Plants 4 and 5 are less than 50 percent constructed.

title: SUIT SEEKS INQUIRY INTO CHARGES OF CRUELTY TO DOGS
description: An animal-protection organization filed suit against the United States Department of Agriculture yesterday to compel it to enjoin a surgical-supply company from using dogs to test operating techniques until the Government can investigate charges of cruelty to animals.

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $298,000 or 24 cents a shr net gain on the sale of real estate; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect 6 percent stock divd paid June 15, 1981

title: ATLANTA
description: AT a time when many higher education institutions around the country are scrambling for funds to maintain the status quo, Emory University has a highly unusual problem: how to spend the income on a $105 million bequest designed to transform the university in fundamental ways.

title: Parley to Aid Women In the Performing Arts
description: An all-day conference aimed at establishing a mutual support system for women in the performing arts will be held Saturday at the Young Women's Christian Association of New York, Lexington Avenue at 53d Street.

title: SOLOMON, SAM, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Talks Break Down In Carting Strike
description: Bargaining between trash-collecting companies and their striking employees broke down yesterday as accumulations of refuse continued to grow. James McCabe, a state mediator, said he had set no date for a resumption of the talks.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 8, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Riot Police Stop Protest On Puerto Rico Campus
description: Club-wielding riot police broke up a demonstration today at Puerto Rico's largest university campus and arrested five students.

title: ANTUOFERMO COUNTS OUT A ROCKY BOXING CAREER
description: He never learned how to duck an opponent or a punch, and yesterday, during an eight-day period in which Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali were attempting pathetic comebacks, Vito Antuofermo, at the age of 28, announced his retirement from boxing with the same straightforwardness that marked his ring style.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE CASE OF THE MISSING GRANDFATHER
description: To the Editor:

title: BL Ltd. Workers End Latest Strike
description: Employees at Britain's stateowned auto maker returned to work after settlement of a monthlong strike over a proposal to cut 11 minutes from their 51-minute rest breaks. Officials said the shutdown by the 6,000 workers had cost BL Ltd. the equivalent of about $195 million.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be distributed Dec 31; yr-ago results have been restated

title: A SUBURBAN TEMPEST
description: Dody Green has lived in her dream house here for 18 years, and through the glass storm door she has observed the changing face of suburbia. She sees more traffic now, more police cars, more women leaving for work and fewer children.

title: BRIEFING
description: P RESIDENT REAGAN called it ''Saturday afternoon at the movies,'' an intimate private showing of ''Reds'' for about 30 guests, among them Cary Grant and Douglas Fairbanks Jr. and their wives, the California businessman Robert Six and his wife, Audrey Meadows, as well as Warren Beatty, the film's producer and director, casual in a herringbone jacket, and his costar, Diane Keaton, in a brown derby and tapered leather pants.

title: Nekoosa to Build Kraft Pulp Mill
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation announced plans to construct with Kymi Kymmene of Helsinki, Finland, a 1,000-ton-a-day bleached kraft pulp mill near Hattiesburg, Miss. The cost of the project, excluding working capital and interest charges, is estimated at $540 million, the company said.

title: Vermeil Perplexed, But Offers No Alibis
description: The theme was this: The Philadelphia Eagles work harder and practice longer than the other teams. That is why the Eagles are successful. It is not that they are so talented.

title: LFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
description: B-After $215,000 loss from discontinued operations for the qr and 6 mos and $2.4 million gain from the sale of real estate in Waltham, Mass for the qr and 6 mos... C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $764,000 for the qr and $1,339,000 for the 6 mos

title: Disabled Get Guide For New York City
description: Copies of a comprehensive guide to New York City's art galleries, theaters, restaurants, hospitals, hotels and libraries for the disabled and elderly were presented yesterday to Mayor Koch and Carol Bellamy, the City Council President.

title: James W. Trullinger Sr., 71, Leading Judge of Dog Shows
description: James W. Trullinger Sr. of Forest Hills, Queens, a leading judge of dog shows for more than half a century, died Friday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: CONSUMER CREDIT UP SLIGHTLY
description: Consumer installment credit expanded by $1 billion in October, the smallest increase since January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
ISRAELIS KILL GAZA YOUTH IN MELEE
description: Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian teen-ager and wounded two others in the occupied Gaza Strip today during violent demonstrations. One soldier was reportedly injured.

title: King Beaten In Bahamas
description: Don King, the boxing promoter, has called off a news conference scheduled for tomorrow to announce the Wilfred Benitez-Roberto Duran fight, apparently because he is unable to face the press after being beaten up Sunday morning in Freeport, the Bahamas.

title: William F. Kellow, 59; Medical College Dean
description: Dr. William F. Kellow, dean emeritus of Jefferson Medical College of Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelpia, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Wynnewood, Pa. He was 59 years old.

title: U.S. PRESSING EUROPE ON STEEL TRADE
description: The Reagan Administration, in an effort to defuse a growing conflict over steel trade with the European Common Market, will seek a commitment from the Europeans to stop shipping subsidized, cut-rate steel to the United States but will not be asking for quantitative export restraints by the Europeans.

title: Murray State 56 Notre Dame 54
description: Murray State shot 60 percent from the floor in the second half and got some key foul shooting from Mike McDuffen in upsetting the Irish on their home court. Notre Dame (1-3) had a chance to tie the game in the closing seconds, but Glen Green of Murray State blocked a layup attempt by Barry Spencer as time ran out.

title: GREEK CYPRIOT TO ASK U.S. TO INTERCEDE WITH TURKS
description: President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus intends to ask President Reagan on Tuesday to intercede with Turkey and support a Greek Cypriot proposal for a federal state on the divided island.

title: Dundee's Sure Thing
description: Angelo Dundee, the trainer and cornerman for Muhammad Ali during most of Ali's career, says he is confident that Ali, 39, will defeat Trevor Berbick in their bout Friday night in the Bahamas.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $19,000 for the qr and $66,000 for the 9 mos and $355,000 gain for the 9 mos and $355,000 gain for the 9 mos from the sale of a hospital in Texas...C-Including extraordinary credits of $10,000 for the qr and $16,000 for the 9 mos

title: CABARET: BOBBY SHORT AT CARLYLE
description: THIRTEEN years ago, Bobby Short began a two-week engagement at New York's Cafe Carlyle, which turned into his regular base of operations until last spring. Since then he has moved out to fill a broad variety of engagements and now, for the first time since 1968, he is back in the room as a visitor for the month of December.

title: MCLOUTH DECLARED IN DEFAULT
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation, hard-hit by the slump in the nation's automobile industry, said yesterday that its secured lenders had declared the company in default under loan and security agreements covering $166 million in debt.

title: Stanley Gibbons Offered for Sale
description: Stanley Gibbons, the world's largest dealer in postage stamps, is for sale, the concern's Swedish owners, Esselte A.B., announced.

title: John Langdon Caskey, Professor of Archeology
description: John Langdon Caskey, professor emeritus of classical archeology at the University of Cincinnati, died Friday of amyotrophic laterial sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's Disease. He was 72 years old.

title: DANCE: 'STILL POINT' AND 'NUTCRACKER'
description: A COMMUTE between the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at the City Center and the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater this last weekend was not quite the exercise in dissociation it might have been.

title: Kansas 86, Arizona 57
description: Kelly Knight and Tony Guy combined for 35 points and paced the Jayhawks. Knight scored 15 of the first 25 points as Kansas took charge early in the game. After mounting a 39-24 halftime lead, the Jayhawks (4-1) turned the game into a rout by outscoring the Wildcats, 12-4, and opening a 53-29 margin.

title: COMPANY'S WORKERS LINKED TO RICHMOND FUND-RAISING
description: Letters and notes from Federal court files give details of how Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn used employees of the manufacturing company he founded and controlled to handle some of his political fund-raising.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Canadian Imperial Bank plans to secure a $75 million Canadian currency seven-year note issued at 99.5 percent and bearing 15.75 percent to yield 15.87 percent through a Eurobond syndicate led by the Hambros Bank, according to market sources.

title: Aid Voted for Lynn Recovery
description: The Massachusetts House moved quickly today to make state money available for the city of Lynn's recovery from the fire that devastated it nine days ago.

title: ABA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 1
WNCN Airing Music Data
description: Radio station WNCN-FM has installed a 24-hour Concert Line for its New York audience. Listeners may call 921-9129 for an up-to-date report of classical music events in the New York area.

title: Benefit Dec. 23 to Assist ReCherChez Studio
description: A benefit for ReCherChez Studio for the Avant-Garde Performing Arts will be held Dec. 23 at the Washington Square United Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: TAYLOR'S SKILLS CREATE HAVOC
description: The opposing team breaks from the huddle. The quarterback lines up behind the center and glances at the defense.

title: Maritime 65, N.Y. Tech 44
description: Maritime prevailed in the teams' first Independent Athletic Conference meeting, leading throughout and by 20 points at one point in the second half.

title: Mental Patient Changes His Plea
description: A mental patient went on trial Monday in the murder of his ex-wife in 1979 while he was free on a one-day pass from a state psychiatric hospital.

title: CYNTHIA BOSTON SENT TO JAIL FOR SILENCE ON BRINK'S CASE
description: Cynthia Boston, who was cleared of complicity in the Brink's armored-car robbery and shootout in Rockland County on Oct. 20, was jailed yesterday for refusing to cooperate with a Federal grand jury.

title: Chess: Old Age, Yogurt, and Now Georgia Has a Third Asset
description: Soviet Georgia is renowned as the place where the population eats yogurt and lives to be a hundred years old, but it is not so well known that the province produces the best female players in the world.

title: NEW YORK STATE AND UNIONS JOIN TO AID DAY-CARE UNITS
description: State and union officials announced today that seed money and rent-free space at up to 20 prisons, psychiatric centers and other state facilities would be provided for day-care centers for children whose parents are employed at the institutions.

title: Doremus in Joint Pact With British Agency
description: Doremus & Company, the BBDO International subsidiary that specializes in financially oriented advertising and public relations, has reached a reciprocal agreement with the Charles Barker Group in Britain to serve each other's clients.

title: ON AFFIRMATIVE ACTION AND DEEDS VS. WORDS
description: President Reagan announced last month that he was dismissing Arthur S. Flemming, a moderate Republican, as chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: Bradley 94 St. Francis (Pa.) 63
description: Barney Mines, with 23 points and Mitchell Anderson, with 19 and 10 rebounds led Bradley. Bradley (3-1) took a 14-2 lead in the first five minutes and was ahead, 44-29, at halftime. Jeff Hamilton, a freshman forward, led St. Francis (1-3) with 17 points.

title: Shaffer, Clarke
description: Although it has not had much advertising for a while, Shaffer, Clarke & Company, marketer of imported food products, intends to change its ways and has hired Stiefel/Raymond Advertising.

title: Third Belgian Will Try To Form a Cabinet
description: King Baudouin asked Wilfried Martens, a former Social Christian Prime Minister, tonight to try to form a new Government, the Royal Palace announced.

title: Cloning Venus' Flytraps
description: The carnivorous plant known as Venus' flytrap has long served as a conversation piece in many American homes. People watch in fascination as the two hinged blades of its spiny leaves attract a wandering insect and, quick as a wink, snap shut when the interloping animal touches the interior spikes. The plant, in effect, is trapping its own fertilizer, for in a few days the insect, dissolved by the plant's juices, supplies it with needed nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium.

title: RAID KEPT SECRET BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: South Africa's announcement that its forces had destroyed another regional headquarters of the insurgent South-West Africa People's Organization in Angola came more than a month after the start of the operation.

title: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
EDWARD H. GOODSTEIN
description: Edward H. Goodstein, an artist, died of cancer at Bellevue Hospital yesterday.

title: DURANG EXPLAINS IT ALL FOR YOU-SATIRICALLY
description: CHRISTOPHER DURANG is a talented 32-year-old playwright with a cherubic face, twinkling blue eyes and a calm, easygoing nature. It's all a front. When he is alone in a room face to face with his typewriter, he turns into a demonic satirist for whom no subject is sacred, not even the Roman Catholic Church. With his latest, and most highly praised play, ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You,'' Mr. Durang has come up with a ferociously funny attack on parochial-school education.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Two gunmen robbed a bank guard and a customer of $500 after failing in an attempt to hold up a teller of the Standard Charter Bank at 10 West 49th Street late yesterday morning. Two shots were fired, one accidentally and one as a warning as the gunmen made their escape.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: ON Thursday, Elias Canetti, who holds a doctorate in chemistry, will receive the Nobel Prize in literature from the King of Sweden in Stockholm. Dr. Canetti will be added to a list of literary laureates who have had scientific backgrounds - among them mathematics (Bertrand Russell and Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn); biology (Frans E. Sillanpaa); archeology (Roger Martin du Gard); agriculture (Gerhart Hauptmann); engineering (Jose Echegaray and Salvatore Quasimodo); and medicine (Johannes Jensen).

title: Bus Line Seeks 7.8% Fare Increase
description: The Short Line Bus Company asked the Federal Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to raise its fares 7.8 percent on all lines.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GUIDRY GETS OFFERS FROM THREE TEAMS
description: While many club executives seemed to be waiting for Whitey, the agents for at least two players busily pursued deals for their clients today at baseball's winter meetings.

title: Agents for French Loan
description: Credit Foncier de France has given Manufacturers Hanover Ltd. and the Banque Nationale de Paris authority to arrange its planned $200 million Eurocredit, banking sources said here today. The loan is expected to have an eight-year maturity and an interest rate spread above London interbank rates of between three-eighths of a percentage point and half a percentage point, they added.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When we are dealing with a question of rights that run back to the Constitution, you don't decide to implement them or not implement them on the basis of how popular they are at a particular time.'' - Arthur S. Flemming, chairman, United States Commission on Civil Rights. (A24:4.)

title: Chock Full o'Nuts Gets New Investors
description: Jerry Finkelstein, the 65-year-old publisher and industrialist, has acquired about 5 percent of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, the coffee and restaurant company with headquarters in New York. Mr. Finkelstein, father of Manhattan's Borough President, Andrew Stein, was joined in the stock purchase by his other son, James Finkelstein, publisher of The National Law Journal.

title: Accounts
description: * Salton Inc. to AC& R Advertising.

title: TRANSIT AIDE ACCUSED OF ACCEPTING BENEFITS GIVEN BY 12 CONTRACTORS
description: A New York City Transit Authority superintendent was indicted yesterday on Federal charges of accepting benefits valued at more than $30,000 from 12 companies involved in a Pullman contract to produce subway cars.

title: TV: PATRICIA NEAL'S VICTORY OVER CRIPPLING STROKE
