description: ''THE Patricia Neal Story,'' on CBS-TV at 9 this evening, is a dramatized account of an episode in the actress's life that generated international headlines. While working on a film in Hollywood, Miss Neal suffered a stroke that left her paralyzed and speechless. Urged on by her demanding husband, the writer Roald Dahl, she undertook a relentless progam of therapy and, quite miraculously, was able to return to work two years later in the film ''The Subject Was Roses.''

title: Indian Wheat Order
description: India is about to announce the purchase of up to 750,000 tons of Australian wheat in an attempt to reduce its dependence on United States suppliers, Government and private sources said here today.

title: MICHAELS BELITTLES BROWNS JINX
description: The Jets face another team they have yet to beat, the Cleveland Browns, Saturday, and Coach Walt Michaels is taking a positive approach.

title: CRITON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $293,000 income from discontinued operations and $4,663,000 gain on the sale of discontinued operations

title: UNITED STATES ANTIMONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Jamaica Seeks $4.5 Billion
description: Jamaica needs a total of about $4.5 billion in investment through October 1983 to get the 12 percent annual economic growth rate it wants, Prime Minister Edward Seaga said here today.

title: PUPILS GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES TO HELP CHILDREN IN DISTRESS
description: Many gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are made expressly to help children who are poor, ill or in distress. Among the early donors in the fund's 70th annual drive were the youngsters in Ada Gross's fourth-grade class at Roaring Brook School in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: A SHIPWRECK IN THE CARIBBEAN LURES EXPLORERS WHO SUSPECT IT IS THE PINTA
description: ON a shallow coral reef in a relatively little-known group in the Bahama chain called the Turks and Caicos Islands, lies a shipwreck that many now believe could be that of the Pinta, one of the three ships that sailed with Columbus in 1492.

title: WHEN A SOCIAL WORKER TURNS PSYCHTHERAPIST
description: To the Editor:

title: SAKHAROV PLEDGE TO FAST TO THE END COMES TO LIGHT
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, wrote a letter before the authorities hospitalized him saying that he and his wife would end their hunger strike only if the Kremlin acceded to their demand that a relative be permitted to emigrate.

title: Arizona Legislators Veto Bill Signed in 'Error'
description: Republican legislators, with the help of four Democrats, overrode a veto of a Congressional redistricting bill Monday, even though they discovered that Gov. Bruce Babbitt, a Democrat, had inadvertently signed the measure into law.

title: Salt Lake City Buses Halted by Labor Dispute
description: About 40,000 bus riders in Salt Lake City and other heavily populated counties were forced to find other ways to get to work today when bus service was shut down in a contract dispute.

title: E.E.C. Steel Accord
description: The foreign ministers of 10 European Economic Community countries agreed unanimously today to ask 14 countries to cut their 1981 steel exports to the Common Market to just over 90 percent of 1980 levels.

title: Northeastern 64, Army 54
description: BOSTON (AP) - Northeastern, led by Perry Moss's 29 points, survived a first half of cold shooting in beating the Cadets. Northeastern (4-0) shot 39 percent from the floor and 58 percent from the foul line in the first half but managed to pull away in the second on the shooting of Moss and Eric Jefferson, who finished with 13 points. Randy Cozzens was high scorer for Army (3-2) with 18 points.

title: Snow Problems
description: The basketball game between Rhode Island and Oregon that was scheduled for last night was postponed until Thursday when the Rams were snowed in at Kingston, R.I., after the heavy snowstorm Sunday in New England.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: READING scores are improving in elementary schools all over the country, but teen-agers' reading skills continue to slip, and so does their interest in reading.

title: KOREAN EMIGRES FIND SUCCESS AMID THE STRESS OF NEW YORK
description: Flushing, Queens, isn't a spot that one normally thinks of as exotic, but Oriental food shops and Korean restaurants are sprouting there among the diners and the delis like cloud mushrooms after a heavy rain.

title: THE CITY
description: Hundreds of special city policemen, members of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, picketed the city's Office of Collective Bargaining.

title: REAGAN LISTS SAVING OF $2 BILLION WASTE IN SIX-MONTH EFFORT
description: President Reagan said today his steppedup effort to root out fraud, waste and abuse in the Federal Government had saved taxpayers more than $2 billion in six months.

title: Cable TV Doing Well In Commercials
description: As far as advertising goes the four major cable TV networks are doing all right for themselves. Ted Turner's Cable News Network is doing the best, according to the Advertising Information Service of 353 Lexington Avenue.

title: FORBIDDEN TO HELP CAMBODIAN CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: The Biggest 'Private' Project Ever
description: It could turn out to be the biggest private construction project in history; it is already one of the biggest Congressional lobbying efforts.

title: Flood of Issues Lowers Prices; 6-Month Bills At 10.772%
description: A heavy supply of proposed corporate and Treasury notes and bonds pushed prices lower for outstanding issues yesterday, although by the end of the day, underwriters were encouraged by investor demand for new issues of the Union Carbide Corporation and the World Bank.

title: Rep. Richmond's Pension
description: It is minimally decent but hardly sufficient for Representative Frederick Richmond, the Brooklyn Democrat, to announce that he will examine his own actions in accepting a $100,000 annual ''pension'' from a company he controls. A Federal judge has ruled that the payments are not genuinely a pension but a salary for services currently being rendered.

title: CONCERT: SPECULUM MUSICAE IN FIRST OF SERIES OF 3
description: ALMOST since the moment of its founding, 10 years ago, Speculum Musicae has enjoyed a reputation as a shield and buckler for the branch of contemporary music known as the academic avant-garde. The group has dedicated itself not only to performing the best works available of this generally difficult genre, but also, more importantly, to performing them with a virtuosity that few other new-music ensembles even approach.

title: Sweepstakes Promotion Planned by G.M.
description: As a way of building showroom traffic for all its (mostly desperate) dealers General Motors will run a sweepstakes promotion that will include the largest newspaper insert program in the history of the corporation.

title: EXPLODING STARS MAY EXPLAIN BIRTH OF SOLAR SYSTEM
description: IT was from the primordial ''big bang'' that the universe is thought to have been born. But that cosmic explosion, 10 or 20 billion years ago, produced only the lightest elements - hydrogen and helium.

title: Sports of The Times; The Ivy League Grows in Stature
description: EVER since the Ivy League teams were bumped from first class to economy in college football late last week, mournful tears have spotted the striped ties of the Yale, Harvard and Princeton traditionalists, who apparently considered it an insult. But if anything, it's a compliment. All the Ivy Leaguers should be cheering instead of weeping.

title: A QUIET FORCE FOR CIVIL RIGHTS
description: About six years ago, immediately after he had announced his resignation as head of the San Diego Urban League to lead the organization's Washington office, John E. Jacob would often play ''very strained '' tennis with Clarence M. Pendleton, who was a candidate to succeed him.

title: A One-Marathon, $50,000 Running Career
description: Richard Mueller had been overweight since his high school days, and no amount of prompting by family, friends and business associates could get the 32-year-old executive to stop eating and start exercising.

title: West Point Post Filled
description: Bernard J. Lasker, for many years an active Republican fund-raiser on Wall Street, has been named to the board of visitors of the United States Military Academy by President Reagan.

title: Market Place; AM Seeking Second Wind
description: THE century-old AM International Inc. may be the biggest name in American business to become a casualty of the high-technology war. Its losses - among the largest in corporate history at an indicated $250 million for the latest fiscal year - have virtually eliminated the company's net worth. AM's survival is in question.

title: Derailment Closes Highway
description: Kootenai County sheriff's deputies cordoned off two miles of highway today because a 54-car Burlington Northern train carrying explosive chemicals derailed in rugged timber country near Rathdrum. Deputy Sheriff Jay Komosinski said one car was carrying metallic sodium and another contained hydrogen peroxide.

title: NICARAGUA CHARGES U.S. 'LIES' INVITE AN ATTACK
description: Nicaraguan Government officials said today that what they termed lies by the United States were an invitation for other Central American countries to attack Nicaragua.

title: BRADSHAW HURT AS RAIDERS TRIUMPH
description: Marc Wilson threw three touchdown passes and Ted Watts, a rookie, scored on a 53-yard punt return that broke a 20-20 tie as the Oakland Raiders beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 30-27, tonight.

title: ROCK: KNACK, LOS ANGLES QUARTET
description: IT seemed almost inconceivable, to watch the Knack, a Los Angelesbased rock quartet, plod through a very dull set at the Savoy on Friday, that only two years ago, this very same group was the great hope of the record industry. On the basis of a catchy hit single, ''My Sharona,'' and a best-selling debut album that was shrewdly packaged to resemble the first Beatles album, record companies jumped on the ''power pop'' bandwagon, investing and losing millions of dollars in similar groups with one-syllable, one-word names.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: As far as young ducklings are concerned, quacking like a duck is more important than looking like a duck.

title: WOMAN WITH 'ELEPHANT MAN' DISEASE CHOOSES BOLD SURGERY
description: PHILADELPHIA FOR most of her 21 years, Lisa H. has been taunted by the children who should have been her playmates, shunned by the people who might have been her friends, and ignored by the employers who could have given her the work she always wanted.

title: A GOVERNOR'S DILEMMA
description: James B. Hunt of North Carolina is a vigorous and active young Governor, the first in modern times to serve two terms in North Carolina, and a tireless pursuer of industry and economic growth for this generally prosperous Sun Belt state.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: P RINCESS Irene Galitzine could not make up her mind what to wear. The Roman fashion designer had just pulled three ball gowns from the closet in her suite at the Westbury Hotel, and all were candidates for the dinner Count and Countess Rudi Crespi were giving for her that night at Regine's.

title: Deer Hunter Killed In Jersey Mishap
description: A Paterson hunter was accidentally shot to death on Monday, 39 minutes before the deer season officially began.

title: Westchester Legislators Back Sheriff Hearings
description: The Westchester County Legislature, facing a proposed budget likely to include major property tax increases, paused today to recommend settlement of an unexpected expense - the lengthy administrative hearings involving the county's top police official, Thomas J. Delaney.

title: Haden Injured Again
description: Pat Haden, the injury-plagued quarterback of the Los Angeles Rams, is ailing again.

title: ACTOR IN PORNOGRAPHIC FILMS HELD IN KILLINGS
description: The Los Angeles Police Department said today that it had arrested John Holmes, an actor in Hollywood's pornographic-movie world, as a suspect in the killing of four people.

title: FREUD AND LA GUARDIA
description: There are so many serious problems around to write about - the Mayor barred his courtiers from attending a conference where in the past criticism of him had been whispered, homeless people in the city are finally getting court-ordered bed and breakfast but there's still no long-range city or state policy about caring for them, Congressman Frederick Richmond, an active millionaire, has been granting himself $100,000 annual retirement payments - that often the little worries go unnoticed.

title: HARASSMENT OF WOMEN FOUND
description: Sexual harassment of blue-collar women by their male co-workers and foremen is widespread in auto plants in the Detroit area and is particularly abusive for blacks and young divorced women, researchers said today.

title: Businessmen in Sinai Town Of Yamit End Their Lockout
description: A self-imposed lockout by businessmen in Yamit, the Sinai town scheduled to go back to Egyptian control next April, was ended this morning when residents allowed Defense Minister Ariel Sharon to enter for negotiations.

title: SIGOURNEY WEAVER TO PLAY LADY MACBETH ON BROADWAY
description: Sigourney Weaver, who has been prominent in films the last two years, will return to the stage as Lady Macbeth opposite Nicol Williamson, who is also director of ''Macbeth.''

title: Press Notes
description: Reporters will find courtroom doors more frequently closed, advertising departments will have to be more careful about verifying the commercial messages they accept and publishers can expect more libel suits for larger amounts, 350 lawyers for newspapers and other news media were told at the recent Communications Law Institute in New York City. Dan Paul, a Miami lawyer, said that the Supreme Court's decision last year requiring that most trials be open to the public had not become the ''watershed case the court said it would be'' because lower courts had simply not obeyed it. The best the press can do, he said, is to make judges and prosecutors sensitive to the First Amendment issues and to train reporters to demand a full legal hearing of any order shutting a courtroom.

title: People
description: * Brian J. Gail has been appointed a senior vice president of Ted Bates Advertising/New York.

title: NATION'S LEADERS OF '81 REMEMBER A DAY IN '41
description: It was forty years ago today that the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor. A day later, the United States declared war. Some of the men who later became national figures were schoolboys. Others had already started their careers. Where were they, and what were they doing when they first learned of the attack on Pearl Harbor? Reagan's Brother Awakened Him

title: Indonesian Gas Find
description: Pertamina, the Indonesian state oil company, said today that it had found a major natural gas deposit in south Sumatra, 150 miles northwest of Jakarta.

title: Disputes Seen Within OPEC
description: One of the organizers of the the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was quoted today as saying that the future of the organization is endangered by political differences among its 13 members.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS ECONOMIC STEPS AGAINST LIBYANS
description: President Reagan and his top national security advisers met today to discuss possible punitive economic and political measures against Libya that could include an embargo on the import of Libyan oil and a ban on travel by Americans to Libya.

title: CONTROLLERS' UNION AND AIRLINES AGREE ON DAMAGES
description: The air traffic controllers' union and 14 airlines agreed in Federal court yesterday that the union's illegal strike cost the carriers a total of $28.9 million in damages.

title: Hofstra 91, Brown 76
description: Dan Rumpf led Hofstra (3-1) with a game-high 25 points, 15 in the second half.

title: RECORD '82 DEFICIT, $109 BILLION, SEEN BY REAGAN'S AIDES
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that new preliminary estimates show the Federal budget deficit climbing to a record $109 billion in the 1982 fiscal year.

title: Advertising; Ad Sector Bridles at High Costs
description: NO matter how efficient the advertising space or time purchases may be in reaching potential consumers, the absolute cost of much of the national mass media is getting prohibitive to some advertisers, according to Herbert D. Maneloveg, executive vice president, director of media-marketing services of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners.

title: WHEN A SOCIAL WORKER TURNS PSYCHOTHERAPIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Rutgers Tops St. Peter's
description: Clarence Tillman broke a 40-40 deadlock with 4 minutes 40 seconds to play tonight and Rutgers went on to score a 46-44 victory over St. Peter's of Jersey City..

title: U.S. Court Stays Execution Planned for Today in Florida
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit today stayed the execution of Alvin Bernard Ford, who was scheduled to die Tuesday morning for the murder of a police officer.

title: PACT OPENS NEW KINDS OF FUTURES
description: A host of new investment vehicles, including options and futures contracts on stock market indexes, are likely to begin appearing within the next several weeks as a result of a landmark regulatory agreement announced today.

title: She Wants to Play
description: The Vermont chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union has taken up the cause of Michelle Chin, a 16-year-old junior at Woodstock Union High School who wants to play on the boys' ice hockey team. Trine Bech, an A.C.L.U. lawyer, has asked the Vermont Headmasters Association to waive its rule barring girls from playing alongside boys in contact sports.

title: BORK, A FORMER SOLICITOR GENERAL NAMED TO KEY APPEALS COURT POST
description: Robert H. Bork, a prominent conservative legal scholar and former Solicitor General, has been nominated by President Reagan to be a judge on the Federal appeals court here.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.M. International Inc. said it had completed the sale of the United States portion of its Addressograph division to D.B.S. Inc., a privately held investment company based in Randolph, Mass., for undisclosed terms.

title: Chairman, President Are Named at Towle
description: At the Towle Manufacturing Company, a Newburyport, Mass., manufacturer of silverware and giftware, Leonard Florence, 50, has been named chairman, effective Jan.15. He will continue as chief executive officer, but will be succeeded as president by Richard C. Brown, 51, who will be leaving the presidency of a unit of the Colgate-Palmolive Company.

title: Threats to Bust of Moscone
description: A bust of the late Mayor George Moscone has been the target of threats and will be taken to a vault for safekeeping, officials say. ''There have been serious threats of vandalism against the piece,'' said Ray Taliaferro, president of the Art Commission, which commissioned the bust by Robert Arneson of the Mayor, who was shot to death in 1978. The base of the bust bears the imprint of a revolver, what appear to be spatters of blood and the words, ''bang bang bang.''

title: Spaghetti-Racquet Ban Is Upheld by Court
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the United States Tennis Association's ban on the so-called spaghetti racquet.

title: POL POT'S PARTY SAYS IT IS DISBANDING
description: The Communist Party organization of the ousted Pol Pot regime in Cambodia has announced that it is disbanding, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: PYRO-MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-the company had no revs for either third qr period or for the latest 9 mos

title: Rangers' Injury Report
description: Steve Vickers, who suffered an eye injury last week and missed the Rangers' last two games, underwent an examination yesterday and was told that he could do some light skating toward the end of this week. He may be available for the game Saturday against the Flyers in Philadelphia.

title: Bridge: Video Terminals Are Used In Two Matches in Taiwan
description: Two unusual matches were played here during the last four days without the use of old-fashioned playing cards. Each of the eight players sat at a terminal and followed the proceedings on a video screen. A controlling computer did the dealing and scoring, and prevented the players from bidding out of turn, leading out of turn or revoking.

title: ARKANSAS LAW ON CREATION FROM BIBLE, JUDGE IS TOLD
description: A Methodist bishop and a Roman Catholic priest testified today that Arkansas's new creation-science law was obviously taken directly from the Book of Genesis.

title: EX-EDITOR OF ATLANTIC SUES ITS NEW OWNER ON ANNUITY DEFAULT
description: Robert Manning, the former editor of the The Atlantic Monthly, filed suit today against the magazine and its new owner, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, a Boston real estate developer. The suit contends that the magazine and Mr. Zuckerman have failed to make payments of $750 a month promised to Mr. Manning in a contract at the time he left the editorship, on Oct. 1 last year.

title: CHINA SETS TAX RATES FOR FOREIGN BUSINESSES
description: The Chinese Government today announced plans to impose an income tax on foreign companies doing business in China, but promised that the tax would be structured so that the companies could offset it against their tax liabilities at home.

title: FRED FELDKAMP, 67, WRITER, DIES
description: Fred Feldkamp, a movie producer, editor and writer, died yesterday at the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Ardmore, Pa.

title: Liverpool Vigil Today to Mark Lennon's Death
description: A concert and candlelight vigil are planned for Tuesday, the first anniversary of the killing of John Lennon, in this industrial city where the Beatles began chronicling by song the changes of the 60's that swept the world.

title: CHANGES ON T.V.A. TRACED AT PARLEY
description: The long romance between liberal intellectuals and the Tennessee Valley Authority, now ended, was a recurrent theme last week among participants in a three-day seminar at Vanderbilt University.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Power System Inc., elected Klaus Bergman executive vice president; John Adams, James E. Davis and Frank J. Eppich senior vice presidents, and Carlon D. Kramer and Stanley I. Garnett second vice presidents, effective Jan.1.

title: Redbook Names New Editor in Chief
description: It is aimed at women, many of those who work for it and write for it are women, and now, for the first time in its 78-year history, Redbook's editor in chief is a woman.

title: CONCERN GROW OVER POLICY ON NATIONAL LABS
description: CHICAGO Many American scientists are apprehensive about the Reagan Administration's emerging science policy and its probable effects on the country's national research laboratories.

title: Well Decorated Retired; Colt Earned $454,836
description: Well Decorated, who earned $454,836, was retired yesterday and shipped to Mare Haven farm in Lexington, Ky., to begin his stud career.

title: Oil and Gas Site Auction
description: The nation's oil companies yesterday put the final touches on their bids for today's auction of rights to explore new and deeper Baltimore Canyon Trough areas in the Government's third lease sale off the mid-Atlantic coast.

title: High Court Ends Stay in Oil Price Case
description: The Federal Government moved a step closer today toward resolving the complex legal problems that have beset last January's termination of price controls on crude oil.

title: FOREIGN ACCOUNTING CHANGE
description: After years of debate and contention, the Financial Accounting Standards Board announced yesterday that it had approved new rules to eliminate the continual fluctuations that have plagued the earnings reports of American companies that have subsidiaries abroad.

title: Broker Rate Cut
description: The Chemical Bank of New York said yesterday that it had lowered its broker loan rate, to 13 1/2 percent, from 14 percent, effective immediately. Broker loan rates, the charge on loans used to finance stock purchases, range from 13 1/2 percent to 14 percent at other major banks.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What are lake-effect snowstorms?

title: OFFICER IN TRAINING WOUNDED BY GUNMAN ON BROOKLYN STREET
description: A probationary police officer was shot and seriously wounded yesterday in Brooklyn when he and his partner attempted to stop two men. The police believe the men were following someone they intended to mug on a street in the Park Slope section.

title: U.S. HAS FIRST HIGH LEVEL CONTACTS WITH NEW GREEK RULE
description: The United States and Greece had their first high-level contacts today since the Greek election in October brought to power the Socialists, who have been making statements putting the country's relationship with the Atlantic alliance in doubt.

title: MOBIL HAS SETBACK ON MARATHON
description: A Federal District Court Judge dealt the Mobil Corporation a major blow yesterday in its bid to acquire the Marathon Oil Company by denying Mobil a preliminary injunction that would have blocked the United States Steel Corporation's rival bid.

title: MFY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated for the effect of LIFO inventory valuations

title: LOCKHEED TO HALT OUTPUT OF TRISTAR
description: The Lockheed Corporation announced today that it had decided to halt production of its L-1011 Tristar jumbo jetliner and take a final $400 million write-off of losses.

title: BOSTON RETAILERS ARE COPING
description: Struggling to attract Christmas shoppers to their lagging downtown stores, Boston's big retailers are trying to entice consumers with a broader range of high-priced designer clothes and a dizzying array of imports rather than relying on a barrage of price promotion.

title: H.J. Heinz Net Gains 3.4%
description: The H.J. Heinz Company reported today that although operating income was up sharply, profits increased only 3.4 percent in the second quarter from the same period last year. The company blamed unfavorable currency adjustments.

title: OAKBROOK CONSOLIDATED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $724,000 for the qr and $578,000 for the yr and $112,000 income from discontinued operations for the yr...C-Net loss after $1,506,000 extraordina loss for the qr and yr and income from discontinued operations of $34,000 for the qr and $119,000 for the yr

title: ZIMBABWE NEEDS AID
description: Senator Jesse Helms and other senators, and Congressmen, are attempting to slash $75 million in development assistance to Zimbabwe from the fiscal 1982 foreign aid bill, precisely when that nation's future is still balancing precariously.

title: Troopers Kill Man Attacking Hostage
description: Michael Deacy, a 37-year-old drifter, was shot and killed by three New York state troopers yesterday when he attempted to kill a man he had taken hostage in the village of Catskill, the state police said.

title: 17 Dead in Indonesian Slide
description: Seventeen people died and 25 others were feared dead in a landslide touched off by heavy rain that struck the village of Dasun in eastern Java early Sunday, the Antara press agency said today.

title: Steel Production Rises
description: Steel production rose to 1.82 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 3.7 percent from the previous week's 1.755 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THOMAS MANN. The Making of an Artist, 1875-1911. By Richard Winston. With an Afterword by Clara Winston. 325 pages. Knopf. $17.95.

title: PROTOCOL CHIEF ANSWERS CRITICS BEFORE LEAVING
description: Leonore Annenberg had planned to leave town quietly. She wanted to spend more time with her husband, she told her friend Nancy Reagan, and so she intended to resign as United States chief of protocol.

title: News Analysis
description: Prime Minister Bulent Ulusu spoke of fostering the atmosphere of understanding, respect and love between Turkey and the United States, while the American Secretary of Defense, Caspar W. Weinberger, reciprocated with words of understanding, friendship and cooperation and promises of more economic and military aid.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE PILOTS RECEIVE DISTINGUISHED SERVICE MEDAL
description: Capt. Richard H. Truly yesterday at ceremony in the Oval Office. Col. Joe H. Engle, the flight's commander, was also honored in the ceremony.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a Mili- tary Analysis article yesterday re- ferred incorrectly to the current phase of the exercise Bright Star. The second paragraph should have read: ''The Egyptian phase of Bright Star was given the maximum publicity by the Defense Department. The present phase, which is being carried out in a critical area near the Strait of Hor- muz, is receiving far less attention in the Middle East.''

title: Wilson Freight Plans Liquidation
description: The Wilson Freight Company, which filed for protection from creditors in July 1980 under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, said it had filed a plan of liquidation under the same act.

title: Pabst Brewing To Remain Open
description: NEWARK (UPI) - The Pabst Brewing Company pledged to keep its beer plant open for as long as it is economically viable. The decision of the Milwaukee-based company, which had announced in September its plans to close, was announced by William F. Smith Jr., president.

title: LANECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
Talking About Terrorism
description: Is it conceivable that Libyan-trained terrorists would enter this country planning to fire a missile at President Reagan's plane or limousine? The President's own evaluation of these reports, sad to say, has been just about right: ''I think in view of the record, you can't dismiss them out of hand.''

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
No Headline
description: POLAND PUBLISHES UNION TAPE URGING OUSTING OF REGIME

title: Inflation Drop Is Forecast
description: Frederick H. Schultz, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, predicted yesterday that the nation's inflation rate would fall to 6 percent or 7 percent in 1982.

title: ISABEL S. DOMBROW
description: Isabel S. Dombrow, a former coordinator of student guidance counseling for the New York City Board of Education, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: CROWN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd in May 1981

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: B-After $140,000 charge from writeoff of investment in a subsidiary...C-Net loss after $260,000 charge from a change in inventory accounting...D-After $498,000 charge from accounting change; 1981 results include operations of Gwaltney of Smithfield Ltd acquired Oct 27, 1981

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $10,000 income from discontinued operations; shr earnings reflect a 6 percent stock divd distribution in Nov

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 7
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1.2 million for the qr and 1.7 million for the 9 mos...C-After $2.5 million loss from discontinued operations and $2 million extraordinary credit

title: JURY BEGINS ITS DELIBERATIONS IN MARGIOTTA'S RETRIAL ON L.I.
description: The jury began deliberating this evening after hearing summations by the prosecution and the defense in the retrial of Joseph M. Margiotta, the powerful chairman of the Nassau County Republican Party.

title: Boeing to Modify 767 for Crew of 2
description: The Boeing Company said that it would modify the first production models of its new 767 series of aircraft to accommodate a flight deck crew of two rather than three.

title: No Headline
description: 3 PLANES HIJACKED FROM VENEZUELA

title: When in Rome
description: Debate on an amendment to the military appropriations bill offered by Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, Dec. 3: Senator Leahy: I do appreciate the kind things said by my colleagues on the other side of this issue. I am reminded a little of the line from ''Julius Caesar,'' when, as you will recall, after Caesar's assassination, Mark Antony said, ''I come here not to praise Caesar but to bury him.''

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-No comparable yr-ago fourth qr results are available because the company, formerly part of Esmark Inc was spun off on Apr 11 1981; yr results are pro forma

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Acquired Allen Rip- ley, pitcher, from San Francisco, for Doug Capilla, pitcher.  MILWAUKEE (AL) - Named Herm Starrette coordinator of player develop- ment.  OAKLAND (AL) - Named Charlie Metro as a coach.  ST. LOUIS (NL) - Purchased Mike Stanton, pitcher, from Cleveland.; BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Placed Robert Reid, forward, on suspended list at his re- quest.; COLLEGE COLORADO ST
description: FORT LAUDERDALE (NASL) - An- nounced that Roy Wiggemansen, defend- er, has retired.

title: TOP URBAN LEAGUE OFFICIAL TO SUCCEED JORDAN AS HEAD
description: John E. Jacob, the executive vice president of the National Urban League, was named yesterday to succeed Vernon E. Jordan Jr. as the organization's president.

title: GOING OUT GUIDEVIEW MIRROR
description: A look through the rear-view mirror often tells you how to move ahead, and that is one reason for those interested in documentary films to observe the celebration of Willard Van Dyke, photographer and film maker who shaped the making of documentaries in the 1930's. ''Representations: The Documentary Film'' starts today and runs through Sunday at the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue and 75th Street.

title: Ski Meet Snowed Out
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 7 (AP) - Less than a week after the opening meet on the World Cup ski tour had been delayed by lack of snow, officials today canceled the meet's two remaining events because of too much snow. The races were both women's downhills, which had been set for Tuesday and Wednesday.

title: Holders Attack Pabst Board
description: A group of Pabst Brewing Company shareholders headed by Irwin L. Jacobs, a 39-year-old Minneapolis multimillionaire, has notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that they plan to start a proxy fight aimed at ousting the brewer's board of directors.''

title: China's New Coke Plant
description: Construction of a Coca-Cola bottling plant in Canton - the second to be built in China - began today, it was announced. The statement said that a ground-breaking ceremony was held in Canton to mark the beginning of construction. Coca-Cola, which resumed sales in China in 1979, opened its first bottling plant in Peking last April.

title: THE VALUE-ADDED TAX: NO FISCAL CURE-ALL
description: The specter of $100 billion Federal deficits has led some economists and legislators to brandish a new debt-paring tool: the value-added tax. They should wield it with care, however, for such a tax would reap needed revenues only by undercutting economic fairness and growth.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 8, 1981; The Economy
description: The Federal budget deficit may hit a record $109 billion for the 1982 fiscal year, Reagan Administration officials acknowledged. New preliminary estimates prepared by the Council of Economic Advisers and the Office of Management and Budget also project deficits of $152 billion in the 1983 fiscal year and $162 billion in the 1984 fiscal year, without any further spending cuts or tax increases. (Page A1.)

title: ANXIETY ABOUT FUTURE GROWS ON ROCK OF GIBRALTAR
description: Both the good news and the bad news are creating anxiety among the 25,000 residents of Gibraltar, who have been living cooped up on their two square miles of mostly vertical land since Spain closed the frontier in 1969.

title: Cement Pricing Studied by Kaiser
description: The Kaiser Cement Corporation is investigating the possibility that West Coast cement import terminals are selling Japanese cement in this country at prices lower than Japanese producers charge their own customers, Walter E. Ousterman, Kaiser chairman, told an international seminar here.

title: G.M. Staff Cuts Due by Christmas
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to put into effect before Christmas an earlier acknowleged plan to lay off about 13,000 white-collar workers, according to an auto industry trade publication. The publication, Automotive News, quoted a company source as saying that Dec. 15 was a ''reasonably fair'' target date for the layoff notices.

title: CRITICISM OF REAGAN BY RELIGIOUS LEADERS RISES
description: Demanding more assistance for the poor and less military spending, leaders of a broad spectrum of religious groups are rallying behind attacks on Reagan Administration policies.

title: Reid Suspended
description: Robert Reid, a starting forward for the Houston Rockets, was placed on the team's suspended list yesterday after he requested a leave of absence last Saturday to attend to what he called ''very pressing personal matters.'' Ray Patterson, the Rockets' general manager, said Reid's request came as a shock.

title: ATTORNEYS CALL HINCKLEY READY TO STAND TRIAL
description: Attorneys for John W. Hinckley Jr. said today that the accused Presidential assailant was competent to stand trial despite his attempt to hang himself at his cell at Fort Meade, Md.

title: Church, State and a Submarine
description: ''Not merely inappropriate but very nearly sacrilegious'' is what Archbishop John Roach, the president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, calls the Navy's decision to name its newest nuclear attack submarine the Corpus Christi. But the Navy declines to rebaptize the vessel, named after the city in Texas, not the Feast of the Eucharist.

title: Horseplay
description: Alamain, the frisky stallion that President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico gave to Ronald Reagan nearly a year ago, is alive and well and, at last report, still kicking up his heels. So much so, according to David Prosperi of the White House press office, that the horse hasn't been taken to the Reagan's ranch in the Santa Ynez Mountains of California.

title: Ski Mask Rapist Faces New Assault Charges
description: grand juries in two cities today added their indictments to a growing string of charges against the ski mask rapist, who confessed to nearly 80 attacks in 12 states.

title: 2 CALIFORNIA FIRMS FIND THAT ATTENTION TO QUALITY PAYS OFF
description: The growing use of quality control circles to improve a company's product has translated into something of a boom for two California management consulting firms.

title: BOYCOTT BY SENATE'S REPUBLICANS EFFECTIVE IN DELAYING JERSEY BILL
description: TRENTON Dec. 7 - Republicans in the State Senate refused to vote on a number of Democratic bills today to underline their displeasure with an ambitious lame duck session of the Legislature.

title: HANDBAGS AND BEAD ROPES; INDIAN CIRCUS FIGURES; 1. Handy Humor
description: Diane Weiss is a painter who has recently turned her talent and sense of humor to making handbags. Miss Weiss hand-tools her envelope bags. She paints an offbeat scene on the outer flap of the bag and then repeats it, sometimes with variations, on the back or under the flap. The bag shown depicts a group of giraffes under a starry sky. Others have amusing barnyard scenes of rosy pigs and rabbits. There are also dinosaurs and bright red roses. The bags are priced at $180 to $230; belts in the same motifs are $75 to $100. You'll find them at Mabel's, 1046 Madison Avenue (80th Street).

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 1
Participants
description: Local 813 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, representing about 2,000 drivers and helpers employed by private carting companies.

title: FANNIE MAE IS SEEKING TAX BREAK
description: The Congressional tax-writing committees will begin considering Wednesday a bill that would double the $450 million in tax refunds from the Treasury now available to a company with a healthy $1.3 billion of capital and surplus.

title: GRAM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $425,000 for the qr and $550,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including $600,000 extraordinary credit

title: Criminal Justice Cube
description: The news item is hardly an eye-catcher: an effort to replicate Manhattan's monthly criminal justice coordinating meetings in the other boroughs. Yet for the criminal justice system, expansion of the meetings - which bring together prosecutors, probation officials, jailers, judges, defense lawyers and the police - may be one of the more important events of the year.

title: SCOTT AS GENERAL IN 'TAPS'
description: ''TAPS,'' which opens today at the Gotham and other theaters, is a solemn, ponderously silly film about the dangers of a military education.

title: LEMON RETAINED FOR '82 AS YANKEES' MANAGER
description: The Yankees, speculation to the contrary, announced today that Bob Lemon, their manager, would continue to be their manager.

title: LENA HORNE IS HONORED IN CITY HALL CEREMONY
description: Lena Horne received New York City's highest cultural award yesterday - the Handel Medallion - in a tribute to what Mayor Koch called ''the strength, the vigor, the beauty and integrity'' that the singer and actress has brought to her music and her life.

title: HOUSE UNIT OPPOSES RULE FOR A WARNING OF USED-CAR DEFECT
description: A House commerce subcommittee voted 3 to 2 today against a rule that would require used car dealers to inform consumers about any known mechanical defects and the availability of a warranty.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES 'PREVENTIVE DETENTION' BILL
description: A bill that would overhaul the Federal bail law and provide for pretrial ''preventive detention'' of defendants believed to be dangerous was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee today and appears headed for Senate passage next year.

title: WILEY H. CRITZ
description: Wiley H. Critz, consulting member of Marts & Lundy Inc., Manhattan fund-raisers, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dow Off 5.24 on Deficit Fears
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday amid investor concern over Reagan Administration estimates of huge Federal budget deficits in each of the next three years.

title: DILEMMA IN THE HORN
description: The Soviet Union has experienced a number of frustrations in the Horn of Africa in the last five years. Faced with several unresolved local conflicts and a variety of ethnic tensions, the Russians find themselves increasingly in a ''no win'' situation. This will remain true as long as the several indigenous Marxist movements in the region are at odds with one another and the Russians persevere in attempting to meet questions of national selfdetermination with rigid Marxist-Leninist answers.

title: Charter to Move Insurance Unit
description: The Charter Company, which announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell six radio stations in a $32 million transaction, said it had also decided to move an insurance subsidiary from Jacksonville to New York to take advantage of changes in the insurance market.

title: 3 at Eastern Kentucky Charged With Rape
description: Three Eastern Kentucky football players were charged by the police today with having raped a 21-year-old Richmond woman.

title: SHELL TOPS OIL BIDS OFF EAST COAST
description: The Shell Oil Company was the high bidder yesterday - offering millions more than any other oil company - as the Government, for the first time, offered leases to drill for oil in deep-water areas at the outer edge of the continental shelf.

title: TETRA TECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Nov 10

title: SPACE FOR FASHION INDUSTRY BEING CREATED ON 7TH AVE.
description: Despite its reputation as the fashion center of the world, the area of Seventh Avenue between Penn Station and Times Square is practically bereft of first-class apparel showrooms, having only two buildings offering such space.

title: Aid for 'People's Opera'
description: Beverly Sills, general director of the New York City Opera, apparently struck a sympathetic chord when she convinced members of the opera's board of directors to cut subscription prices by 20 percent. She had felt prices were too high for an organization that was supposed to be ''a people's opera.''

title: Dry Dock Rate Cuts
description: New York's Dry Dock Savings Bank, the nation's 16th-largest mutual savings bank, said yesterday that it would cut its rate on adjustable home mortgages to 14 3/4 percent, effective immediately, and stop making conventional fixed-term mortgages entirely.

title: CONFEREES AGREE TO A COMPROMISE ON FARM MEASURE
description: A House-Senate conference committee, after more than a month of haggling, agreed today on a new farm bill that would cost taxpayers at least $11 billion in the next four years, mostly for commodity loan and subsidy programs. In addition, consumer prices for milk and peanuts would go up next fall.

title: Aid for Small Businesses
description: The Senate today passed a bill to set aside $68 million in Federal money over five years to help small businesses do research.

title: TOXIC SHOCK TESTS ADD TO CONFUSION
description: Another development yesterday added further confusion to the mystery of toxic shock syndrome, a potentially fatal disorder that has been linked primarily to the use of tampons.

title: 2 Belgian Parties to Meet On Forming a Coalition
description: Former Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, a Social Christian, appeared today to have achieved a breakthrough in efforts to form a government when he announced that prospective coalition partners would meet Wednesday to negotiate on a program.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Economic Scene; 'Lost Chicken' Home to Roost
description: ONE of the classic approaches to economic forecasting is known as the ''lost horse'' method. It was derived from an old joke about how to find a lost horse: Go to where the horse was last seen and ask yourself where you would go if you were a horse.

title: Burroughs Wellcome Fills Combined Post
description: William M. Sullivan, 47, has been named chairman and president of the Burroughs Wellcome Company, a major pharmaceutical manufacturer with headquarters in Research Triangle Park, N.C. He succeeds Fred A. Coe Jr., who retired from the American subsidiary of the Wellcome Foundation, a British multinational corporation, at the age of 65.

title: CUBS SIGN JENKINS, CAMPBELL
description: The Chicago Cubs today signed the pitchers Ferguson Jenkins and Bill Campbell as free agents and were involved in a five-player trade with the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: LORIMAR PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
U.S. PANEL REPORT BACKS HIRING GOALS
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that it still strongly supported affirmative action, including the selective use of numerical goals and hiring quotas, even though the Reagan Administration opposed such remedies for race and sex discrimination.

title: SCREEN: 'CLARENCE AND ANGEL' 2 HARLEM SCHOOLBOYS
description: IT can be done: Robert Gardner's ''Clarence and Angel'' is an imaginative, unpretentious, very inexpensively made movie that really works. Written, produced and directed by a new young film maker, this is a look at two boys in a Harlem grade school, the world around them and the unexpected process by which they become friends.

title: No Headline
description: 3 HIJACKED VENEZUELAN PLANES LAND IN CUBA

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 24
Burroughs Offers New Processor
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it had introduced a document processing system, the b9195, that can process up to 2,600 documents a minute.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four rose by 74 cents to $105.61 in the two-week period ending Friday, according to the city's Department of Consumer Affairs. The increases were slight, a penny here and there, in most of the market basket items, including such goods as canned tomatoes, cookies, cornflakes, rice, eggs, iceberg lettuce and soft drinks.

title: Sports of The Times; Dark Clouds Over Nassau
description: MUHAMMAD ALI may be healthier than some people think; his fight may be sicker than anybody could have imagined. At least Ali has the endorsement of the doctor who examined him most recently. The financial status of the fight seems shaky even to the promoter, James Cornelius, who said yesterday, ''We're just trying to give Muhammad Ali a place to fight. We're just hoping to break even.''

title: U.S. and Soviet Hold 3d Session in Arms Talks
description: The United States and the Soviet Union held the third full session today in their week-old negotiations on the reduction of medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: CHANGES IN A COOKIE AND COFFEE
description: By Florence Fabricant Important changes were recently made in two popular products that are often served together after dinner, but the manufacturers would probably be pleased if consumers were unable to taste the differences. Lazzaroni Amaretti are now being made in America and Medaglia D'Oro espresso coffee has introduced a decaffinated variety.

title: A First (but Not Last)
description: Being first has perhaps become second nature to Dr. Clifton R. Wharton Jr., chancellor of the State University of New York. Dr. Wharton, the son of the first black career officer of the Foreign Service to reach the rank of Ambassador, became the first black president of a major predominantly white college at Michigan State University in 1969. He was also the first black to join the student radio station at Harvard and the first to be elected a director of the Equitable Life Assurance Society.

title: Whitney Slide Show Traces Museum's Past
description: ''An Introduction to the Whitney Museum of American Art,'' an audio-visual presentation, will be shown in the museum's lobby gallery from Dec. 18 to Feb. 21. The multimedia display uses 12 projectors and nearly 300 slides, plus a photographic wall exhibition.

title: CITY ENTERPRISE ZONES ARE A 'WRONG ANSWER'
description: To the Editor:

title: AN OLD STATUE IS DESTROYED AT A CHURCH
description: A limestone statue of Christ, which had stood for 85 years as a symbol of one of New York City's most famous churches, was toppled and smashed a few minutes before midnight Monday.

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
WINE TALK
description: ABONUS that comes with nearly every case of the best Bordeaux is the wooden box that carries it from the chateau where it was produced to the store where it is sold or to the consumer who buys wine in case lots. On the end of each case is branded the name of the chateau, often with the symbol or emblem of the proprietor, along with the vintage of the wine inside.

title: BOTH SIDES IN CARTING STRIKE 'IRRESPONSIBLE,' MAYOR SAYS
description: Mayor Koch denounced the striking private sanitationmen's union and the trash-collecting companies yesterday as ''irresponsible'' for their failure to resume efforts to end the walkout, which is now in its second week.

title: Justice Dept. Expands Investigation of Allen
description: The Justice Department has expanded its inquiry of Richard V. Allen to include his failure to list his consulting company's clients on his financial disclosure form, a Government official said today.

title: Lockheed's Stock Surges
description: The stock of the Lockheed Corporation surged 7 3/4 points, to 49 1/4, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as Wall Street hailed the aerospace company's decision on Monday to abandon its loss-ridden L-1011 Tristar jetliner program. More than 1 million shares were traded.

title: Suspect in Killing Gets 40 Years on Drug Charge
description: A convicted murderer, described as a suspect in the sniper killing of a Federal judge, has been sentenced to 40 years in prison for possession of cocaine.

title: 'Penzance' in Queens
description: The Queens Symphony Orchestra and Manhattan Savoyards will perform ''The Pirates of Penzance'' on Sunday at the Queens College campus in Flushing. David Katz will conduct. The curtain time at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts is 3 P.M. Call 275-5000.

title: Chinaglia Gets 7 as Cosmos Win, 14-10
description: The Cosmos made their indoor debut in the North American Soccer League tonight, and reversed the outcome of their final outdoor game in the league this season.

title: Accounts
description: * Manhattan Cable Television to Leisure Time Promotions, a division of Ash/LeDonne, for advertising and promotions.

title: REVUE: LYNNE THIGPEN IN 'I AIN'T FINISHED YET'
description: AS those who saw last season's ''Tintypes'' know, Lynne Thigpen is a riveting figure on stage. A tallish black woman with a jutting jaw, penetrating eyes and a stern, vibrato voice, she seems to travel in her own magnetic field - one that her fellow performers enter at their own peril. ''Tintypes'' was a revue with a hazy shape, but not when Miss Thigpen got the chance to take charge. Once she came forward to sing Bert Williams's ''Nothing,'' filling it with everrising torrents of anger, everything around her fell away - as if the whole show were a bed of daisies that had been mistakenly planted on top of a volcano. But then the eruption subsided, never to return.

title: SYLVAN LAWRENCE, 66, HEADED REALTY CONCERN IN MANHATTAN
description: Sylvan Lawrence, chairman of the Sylvan Lawrence Company Inc., one of the largest owners of real estate in downtown Manhattan, died yesterday at the Mount Sinai Hospital and Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: F.T.C. FIGHTS MOBIL BID ON MARATHON
description: After a nearly four-hour meeting, the four-member Federal Trade Commission decided unanimously yesterday to sue the Mobil Corporation on antitrust grounds if it proceeds with its $6.5 billion takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company.

title: TANZANIAN ENDS DRIVE TO BECOME HEAD OF THE U.N.
description: The way was cleared today for new candidates to enter the race for Secretary General when Salim A. Salim of Tanzania withdrew his name from further balloting.

title: UNITY BUYING SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Books Of The Times
description: By Le Anne Schreiber A WILD PATIENCE HAS TAKEN ME THIS FAR. Poems 1978-1981. By Adrienne Rich. 61 pages. W.W. Norton & Co. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $4.95.

title: BRIEFS
description: * The Bass family, which operates through several entities, including Bass Brothers Enterprises, said it had increased its shares of Western Airlines Inc. to 8 percent of the company's cumulative convertible preferred stock from 6.7 percent.

title: FORMER GREEN BERETS FOUND TO SELL MILITARY SKILLS TO FOREIGN REGIMES
description: Many former Green Berets, men specially trained by the Army to be masters of the lethal arts, sell their skills to unfriendly governments and repressive regimes, according to Federal law enforcement officials and former Green Berets.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PROFESSOR CONTENDS THAT CREATIONISM IS NO SCIENCE
description: The creation theory of the origins of the universe fails to meet accepted academic standards for consideration as a science, opponents of a new Arkansas law contended today in Federal court. The law requires public schools to teach creation science as well as evolution.

title: KENNEDY GAVE SPECIAL FORCES THEIR EMBLEM
description: The Special Forces were established by the Army in 1952 to provide the United States with an unconventional-warfare unit capable of carrying out commando and intelligence operations, but it was not until the Presidency of John F. Kennedy that the forces really flourshed.

title: 24 Injured in Fire In Perth Amboy
description: Twenty-four people were injured, one of them critically, in a fire that destroyed two adjoining three-story apartment buildings in this community in Middlesex County.

title: HAIG AIDE'S REMARK ON IRISH UNIFICATION STIRS FUROR IN BRITAIN
description: Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark Jr. has said that the American people support the reunification of Ireland, inspiring private expressions of annoyance today from British officials.

title: Chairman Is Named At British Unilever
description: The Unilever Group, the huge British-Dutch conglomerate, has elected Ken Durham, 57 years old, chairman of Unilever PLC, the British component of the organization. In keeping with the usual pattern at the world's largest consumer goods producer, Mr. Durham was also named a vice chairman of Unilver NV, the Dutch arm based in Rotterdam.

title: REAGAN AIDES DEFEND DEFICITS
description: After listening to President Reagan's economic advisers discuss the worsened outlook for the Federal budget, Herbert Stein couldn't resist. Mr. Reagan, he quipped, ''seems to be the only member of this Administration who believes that deficits are inflationary.''

title: UNION BID FOR KAISER
description: The United Steelworkers of America announced yesterday that the union had proposed the formation of a nonprofit corporation to acquire all the common stock of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, or at least a controlling interest in the company.

title: REFORM JEWS TO SEEK CONVERSION OF NON-JEWS
description: The synagogue branch of Reform Judaism has started a vigorous program to invite conversions by non-Jewish partners in mixed marriages and by those Americans who express no religious preference.

title: Western Union Bill Approved in House
description: The House approved a bill today that would allow the Western Union Telegraph Company to enter the international market for the first time in 37 years.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest qr figures reflect operations for only two months due to a change in the fiscal yr

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'll be 62. I've seen the elephant, heard the owl and flown with the screeching eagle.

title: Keep the Angola Amendment
description: The Reagan Administration wants Congress to repeal the five-yearold Clark Amendment, which forbids any aid - covert or overt - to insurgents in Angola. There are some good reasons for removing such a narrowly directed restraint on diplomacy, and they were cited in the Senate when it granted the President's request for greater freedom of maneuver. But at the moment there are better reasons for keeping the law, which the House ought to weigh as it votes today.

title: Flames Beat Nordiques
description: Kevin Lavallee scored two goals tonight to help the Calgary Flames beat the Quebec Nordiques, 7-4. A goal by Willi Plett, on a screened shot from the left circle at 16:23 of the second period, put Calgary ahead for good, 5-4.

title: MAGUIRE ENTERS CONTEST IN JERSEY TO SUPPLANT WILIAMS AS SENATOR
description: Former Representative Andrew Maguire today became the second candidate to announce for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat from New Jersey now held by Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: OPEC MINISTERS TO MEET TODAY
description: The 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries opens its regular biannual ministerial conference Wednesday, and several sources said the main item on the agenda would be how to deal with the world oil oversupply.

title: Speedy British Train Stopped in Its Tracks
description: Britain's new Advanced Passenger Train, which can reach a speed of 160 miles per hour, was halted on the tracks today by a fault in its tilting mechanism during the second half of its first public trip.

title: THE ROAR OF THE AD GIRLS
description: At the urging of Mr. P.G. of Greenwich, Conn., I have been looking at screamers in magazine advertisements. Until he pointed it out, I hadn't noticed how much screaming was going on in these ads.

title: GREG LAKE GOES SOLO WITH SET PIECES
description: BEFORE they fade away completely, older rock musicians from disbanded supergroups usually embark on disappointing solo careers that are based primarily on recycling past successes. A classic example is Greg Lake, the guitarist and lead singer from the English art-rock trio Emerson, Lake and Palmer. Mr. Lake recently released a mediocre solo album, and on Saturday, he appeared with a rock quintet at the Palladium, where he mixed Emerson, Lake and Palmer favorites like ''Lucka Man'' with material from the new record.

title: LOBBYING IS HER LIFE
description: Tip O'Neill says: ''I love her.'' Doorkeepers outside the House chamber offer her their seats. A tiny woman, scarcely 4 feet 11 inches tall, ''Evvie'' Dubrow is nearly as much a part of the Congressional scene as the lawmakers themselves.

title: Mahoning Coal
description: The Mahoning Coal Railroad Company, an 82 percent owned unit of the Penn Central Corporation, said it had set a final liquidation distribution of $120 a share, payable Jan. 7 to non-Penn Central holders of record on Dec. 18. Under an agreement between Penn Central and Mahoning, Penn Central will receive all Mahoning assets above those needed to pay the liquidating distribution. Mahoning, which approved the liquidation plan in 1979, said no additional distributions would be paid unless funds reserved from a previous distribution for certain legal expenses were not required for that purpose.

title: Korda Rand Agency Wins Lever Product
description: The personal products division of Lever Brothers has assigned an important new shampoo entry to Korda Rand Levine.

title: Bridge: Player in 3d Seat Allowed Eccentricity After 2 Passes
description: A player in third position after two passes is permitted some mild eccentricity, especially if he is not vulnerable. He can, and often does, open pre-emptively with a suit that would not justify such action in first or second seat. And he may bid a suit at the onelevel with a hand a point or so weaker than he would have in other circumstances.

title: KOCH'S UNFAIR BLOW AGAINST CHARITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Costly Comments
description: Don Shula, the Miami Dolphin coach, has reportedly been fined $1,000 by the National Football League for literally going too far in criticizing the officials. The Miami News, quoting sources it did not identify, reported that Shula had been cited for exceeding the area permitted a coach, between the 35-yard lines, when he protested a call in the Monday night game against the Philadelphia Eagles last week.

title: Tidbits: Houk Rewarded
description: While the Yankees were announcing that Bob Lemon would continue as their manager, the Boston Red Sox were extending the contract of their manager, Ralph Houk, for two years, through 1984. Houk, 62 years old, previously managed the Yankees and Detroit before joining the Red Sox last season.

title: SOUTHWEST FACTORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Moran Inc.  In Business
description: William T. Moran, a well-known advertising and marketing researcher, has formally announced the existence of his two-year-old firm called Moran Inc., of Greenwich, Conn.

title: CAREY AND STAFF ASSEMBLING 'DOOM AND GLOOM' BUDGET
description: Governor Carey and his staff are assembling what one aide calls a ''doom and gloom'' budget for next year. ''Don't expect the usual election year budget,'' said James Introne, Mr. Carey's director of state operations, ''because we can't afford it.''

title: GIFT TO NEEDIEST CASES MARKS THREE COUPLES' ANNIVERSARIES
description: Elsa Koestler of Rochelle Park, N.J., is among the longtime contributors to the The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund whose donations have helped the poor and distressed of the New York metropolitan area for many years.

title: KUBOTA LTD (JAPANESE CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 15
description: B-Per American Depositary Shares, each of which is equal to 20 shrs; results have been translated at the rate of 229 yen equals $1

title: Mandel Gets a Job
description: He has been ''straining at the bit to get back to work,'' and yesterday, a week after President Reagan commuted his sentence for mail fraud and racketeering, Marvin Mandel, did just that.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny and Western Energy Corp. named Anthony F. Altmann vice president.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 10
ANEFCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Magazines Report Strong October
description: According to the Magazine Publishers Association, October has been the best month of the year as far as month-to-month comparisons with a year ago are concerned for members of its Publishers Information Bureau.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS PLANS TO CUT LOMING BUDGET DEFICIT
description: President Reagan today began the process of deciding which steps he should take to reduce the budget deficit for the next fiscal year from its newly projected level of $152 billion. All the possibilities are politically distasteful.

title: Warriors 122, Blazers 108
description: Lloyd Free scored 37 points and Bernard King added 29 to lead Golden State. The triumph was the Warriors' third in a row and Portland suffered its third straight defeat. The victory also broke a 12-game losing streak in Portland for the Warriors.

title: 2 IN HOUSE WITHDRAW ATOM CURB
description: Members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee backed away today from a measure to cut off aid to any nation that manufactures a nuclear bomb. They acted after Administration officials told them privately that Israel might fall into that category.

title: THE DOWNFALL OF YERTLE THE TURTLE
description: After being criticized by Mayor Koch, Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, decided to pay the Mayor back by giving him a copy of a fitting tale by Dr. Seuss. Here are some excerpts from ''Yertle the Turtle'': On the far-away Island of Sala-ma-Sond, Yertle the Turtle was king of the pond. A nice little pond. It was clean. It was neat. The water was warm. There was plenty to eat. The turtles had everything turtles might need. And they were all happy. Quite happy indeed. They were until Yertle, the king of them all, Decided the kingdom he ruled was too small. ''I'm ruler,'' said Yertle, ''of all that I see. But I don't see enough. That's the trouble with me.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Commodities column in Business Day Monday misnamed the author of a report on oats. He was Christopher Stewart.

title: 17 in Robbery Ring Get 25-Year Terms
description: NEWARK (AP) - Seventeen New World of Islam members were sentenced to 25 years in prison.

title: SAKHAROV'S PLIGHT IS TERMED 'SERIOUS'
description: The president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences was quoted today as having said that Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, was in a ''serious'' plight as a result of his hunger strike, which was apparently ended forcibly five days ago.

title: A UNIVERSITY CURB ON RELIGION UPSET
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 8 to 1, that a public university that permits student groups to meet on campus for secular activities must also allow student religious groups to meet for worship and religious study.

title: Dresser to Add Reliance Unit
description: Reliance Group Inc. announced that Dresser Industries had agreed in principle to acquire the Reliance Standard Life Insurance Company, the largest subsidiary of the Reliance Group, for $105 million in cash.

title: SAFETY UNIT WARNS OF PERIL IN AIR CONTROLLER STRESS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today endorsed the findings of a special investigations group that the strike by 11,500 controllers on Aug. 3 did not lead to the unsafe control of air traffic.

title: STATE DEPT. CITES SOVIET 'FORGERIES'
description: The State Department drew attention today to the appearance in various parts of the world in recent months of forgeries apparently intended to discredit United States foreign policy, and attributed some of the forgeries to the Soviet Union.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PUNITIVE ACTION AGAINST LIBYA DEFERRED
description: President Reagan conferred about Libya with his top advisers for a second day today but sent word to the Senate that he did not favor any anti-Libyan legislation until the deliberations were concluded.

title: Miners in Britain Reject Pay Offer and Pick Chief
description: A fresh Government confrontation with British coal miners loomed today as the miners rejected management's ''final offer'' in a pay dispute and simultaneously elected a left-wing militant as their new president.

title: AND NOW, SEPERATE TV FOR SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS
description: In a logical extension of its theory that racial and cultural groups can flourish only if they are kept strictly separate, South Africa is about to inaugurate a new television channel that will be beamed exclusively at black viewers.

title: COSTA RICA PRESSING TALKS WITH BANKS ON FINANCIAL SNARL
description: Costa Rica, long considered a model of political stability and social welfare, has become a case study of how unfavorable commodity prices abroad and mismanagement at home can turn an affluent economy into a financial debacle.

title: Deere Up 22.6% For Quarter
description: Deere & Company, a diversified manufacturer of farm and construction equipment, said today that it had increased its fourth-quarter profit 22.6 percent over last year despite a slight downturn in revenues. The company cited improved profitability in domestic farm equipment sales and reduced losses overseas.

title: Tiger Report Card
description: Jim Campbell, general manager of the Detroit Tigers, is angered over the publication in eight Michigan newspapers of the team's private evaluations of Tiger players. The evaluations, as published, seemed to show that the Tigers ranked only 12 of their players as better than average, and several -including Rick Peters, John Wockenfuss, Champ Summers and Stan Papi - as below average.

title: SALVADORAN EXILE DERIDES ELECTION
description: A colonel who helped lead the 1979 coup in El Salvador that brought a civilian-military junta to power said today that the Salvadoran Government had no political power base and that its plans for elections were ''madness.''

title: PASTRY: DELIGHTS AT WHITE HOUSE
description: THERE will be no butter cream fillings or frostings this Christmas at the White House. Custard is being sweetened with honey; egg whites have replaced whipped cream in mousses. Sauces are being thickened with fruit purees instead of flour or cornstarch. Has nouvelle cuisine made a belated debut at the Executive Mansion?

title: THE EDUCATION OF A POSTAL SERVICE SUPERVISOR
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: SEASONAL SINGING AND 'ODYSSEY' IN RURAL INDIA
description: THE season of Christmas specials is upon us and, like it or not, just about everybody is singing. Tonight, CBS-TV offers one of the better efforts - ''A Special Anne Murray Christmas'' at 10 o'clock - and one of the worst, ''A Country Christmas'' at 9.

title: Georgia-Pacific
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, a major forest products concern, said it had arranged a $350 million floating rate revolving credit term loan with a group of 12 major European and Canadian banks. The company said proceeds would be used primarily to refinance its long-term debt which matures next year and it would also provide the company with flexibility in managing its debt.

title: DETROIT PLUGS INTO ELECTRONICS
description: Under the hood of every gasoline-powered car that General Motors makes is a small computer continuously monitoring the exhaust. The device, roughly the size of a pack of cigarettes, adjusts the vehicle's carburetor fuel intake and spark timing to meet emissions standards and get the best fuel economy.

title: AMBIANCE: TEA ROOM'S FESTIVE SPIRIT
description: THE Russian Tea Room won't be hanging Christmas decorations this season. They've been up all year. Twenty years ago Faith Stewart-Gordon decided to cover the then out-of-style Art Deco chandeliers with gold tinsel and red balls. Every year the decorations remained a little longer, until they stayed up all year round.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: IHAVE never regretted winter. I am devoted to the sports, the skiing and the shooting. I miss my garden, of course, but I make up for its loss well enough with a greenhouse that extends out from my dining room, although in my mind's eye it extends directly out from my kitchen. I hurry from the stove or the worktable directly into the greenhouse for the fresh herbs that are at the core of my cooking.

title: Cameron Disqualified
description: Cameron University of Lawton, Okla., which scored a 48-27 playoff victory over Central Arkansas last weekend, has been knocked out of the N.A.I.A. Division I football playoffs. Cameron, which was 7-2 in the regular season, was disqualified from further playoff action today for using two scholastically ineligible players during the season. The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics announced the disqualification after its officials visited Cameron Monday to verify records.

title: Aid Voted for Lynn Recovery
description: The Massachusetts House moved quickly Monday to make state money available for the city of Lynn's recovery from the fire that devastated it nine days ago.

title: 3 New Accounts For Kurtz & Tarlow
description: The shy management of Kurtz & Tarlow has just gotten around to reporting on new business the agency received earlier this year.

title: Index; International
description: Even TV will be separate for South African blacks A2 Soviet academy president said to call Sakharov's plight serious A3 Reagan asks Senate to delay any action on Libya A3 Beirut blast, fourth in 2 days, kills man near French envoy's home A4 Exiled Salvadoran Derides Elec- tion A5 Around the World A6 2 in House drop nuclear move that could have affected Israel A8 President urges House members to back foreign aid package A9 State Department gives briefing on what it calls forgeries A11 Polish church seeks to foster new union-government talks A13 Government/Politics Civil Rights Commission comes out for affirmative action A21 Archbishop tells panel that ''voluntarism'' is inadequate A22 Senate panel approves ''preven- tive detention'' bill A25 Abrams sued by American Invsco over evictions from co-op B3 Koch calls Carol Bellamy ''a hor- ror show'' and apologizes B3 Washington Talk Briefing A26 Effort to shoot down C-X cargo plane intensifies A26 Capital setting is popular with novelists A26 Evelyn Dubrow has had a lifetime of lobbying A26 General Around the Nation A16 Oklahoma town is relatively calm about top toxic waste site A16 Senate panel opens hearings on endangered species law A24 A28 Living Section Food Cookies: Sugar, spice and nos- talgia C1

title: SPAIN'S COOKING OIL SCANDAL CRIPPLES ITS SEAFOOD CANNERS
description: A scandal involving adulterated cooking oil, which has killed 215 persons in Spain since last spring, has brought the nation's seafood canning industry to the verge of collapse.

title: GUILTY PLEA IN STOCK CASE
description: A New York investor pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that he participated in a scheme to obtain secret information about imminent corporate takeovers from employees at two prominent investment firms and then used the tips for stock trades.

title: French Aide, in Israel, Belittles Europe's Moves
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France ended a visit to Israel today by saying it was not Europe's business to present peace proposals for the Middle East.

title: Looser Reins for the C.I.A.
description: Could the Central Intelligence Agency, the nation's vital eyes and ears abroad, once again turn back to spy on law-abiding Americans and gather their names in surveillance files?

title: Countdown
description: A pelting rain the other day drove scores of drenched pedestrians into the Times Square subway station in search of dry transportation.

title: Jennings Trophy Replaces Vezina; Jennings Trophy Begun
description: The National Hockey League trophy that will replace the Vezina will be named the Bill Jennings Trophy in honor of the late president of Rangers, league governors decided today. The trophy will be awarded to the goaltenders on the team with the best goals-against average during the season. The Vezina Trophy now will be awarded to the outstanding goaltender, to be chosen in a vote, the means of which will be considered Wednesday.

title: MCLOUTH STEEL IN CHAPTER 11 FILING
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation, a Detroit steelmaker that depends on the ailing auto industry for about 80 percent of its sales, announced yesterday that it had filed petitions seeking reorganization under bankruptcy court protection.

title: Reds, Beds and Bedlam; Radical Cheek
description: Warren Beatty knows the meaning of capitalist risk-taking. He has bet at least $33.5 million - with the help of Paramount Pictures and Barclays Bank - on ''Reds,'' a three-and-a-half-hour epic celebrating John Reed, the journalist who in life castigated the profit motive.

title: Advertising; A New Shopping Promotion
description: year-old former football hero for Cornell and the Buffalo Bills, gets his thrills these days from end runs in the supermarket aisles and shelves rather than on the gridiron. The longer the checkout lines, the happier he is, especially if he is responsible.

title: 2 Shot Near Rock Concert
description: Richard L. Wright, 21, was pronounced dead at a nearby hospital after being shot in the woods adjacent to the Capital Centre shortly before a Rolling Stones concert tonight, the police said. Another man, Andy John Ulsaker, 21, was listed in stable condition.

title: GRANDPARENTS' PLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The rain had started early in the morning, turning the hard, cold ground of Central Park soft, and so the garden spade entered it easily, with a soft, sibilant sound.

title: SYSTEMS ENGINEERING & MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept
Sampson Is Reinjured, May Miss Duke Game
description: Ralph Sampson, Virginia's star center, has reinjured his broken finger and is ''very doubtful'' for Wednesday's game with Duke here.

title: Figure in Scottsboro Case Settles Suit With NBC
description: Victoria Price Street, who charged 50 years ago that the so-called Scottsboro Boys raped her, has settled a libel suit against NBC-TV, her lawyer said today.

title: SCIENCE AND PROFIT NEED NOT BE AT ODDS
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN ASKS HOUSE TO BACK AID PLAN
description: In a personal appeal to all House members, President Reagan sought support today for a foreign aid package, to provide ''needed flexibility for the conduct of foreign affairs.''

title: NO. 1 TOXIC WASTE SITE IS NOT A TOWN'S NO. 1 GRIPE
description: Some of the landscape spreading for 40 square miles around this former mining town has the Mars-like quality of Yellowstone National Park, but not from any long-ago glacial activity.

title: Official in India Dies
