description: India's Minister of State for Communications, Kartick Oraon, died today of a heart attack while attending Parliament, doctors said. He was 57 years old. Mr. Oraon collapsed in the lobby of Parliament and was rushed to a hospital where doctors tried futilely to revive him.

title: Tennis Tempers
description: Arthur Ashe, the United States Davis Cup captain, said he would forfeit a match in the finals against Argentina before allowing officials to declare a default over temper displays. Recalling how the doubles team of John McEnroe and Peter Fleming came within one warning of a default in the matches against Australia, Ashe said, ''The U.S. team has never been defaulted in 81 years, and I'm not going to let it happen when I'm captain, either.'' McEnroe, in response, told The Washington Post, ''I know this is a sensitive issue but I think a coach or a captain should stick up for his players, right or wrong.''

title: Economic Analysis
description: For nearly a decade, the regular December meetings of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have represented bad news for the Western world. The only questions were how high oil prices would go, and how much the overall economy would suffer as a result.

title: Eurodollar Trade Cleared
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today unanimously approved a Chicago Mercantile Exchange proposal to trade futures on three-month Eurodollar time deposit rates.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Giants Sign Hardison
description: The Giants signed Dee Hardison, a defensive lineman released by the Buffalo Bills last summer, to fill a vacancy on the roster caused by the injury to Curtis McGriff.

title: East German Flees by Truck
description: A 26-year-old bricklayer fled from East Germany by driving a truck through the border fence at a highway construction site, the West German border police said today. The man, who was not identified, left his work on the Hamburg-Berlin highway Monday, commandeered a truck and broke through the wire mesh barrier, the police said.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
China Raising Cosmetic Goal
description: China plans to raise its production of cosmetics, most of which were banned as bourgeois until recently, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: SMITH EXCELS AS KNICKS ROUT NUGGETS
description: Randy Smith's 777th consecutive game was one of his best. Smith, a 6-foot-3-inch guard who has been struggling to find a spot for himself since he joined the Knicks before the season, scored 25 points and had nine assists as the Knicks battered the Denver Nuggets, 135-122, at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Q&A
description: Q. In the past you have printed a formula for cooking white rice. Do you have a similar formula for brown rice?

title: 2 More N.H.L. Teams Interested in Moving to Meadowlands
description: Two more hockey teams from outside the New York area - the Vancouver Canucks and the Chicago Black Hawks - disclosed today that they might want to move their franchises to Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Ecumenical Medicine
description: Saved from bankruptcy by a Federal grant two years ago, Brooklyn Jewish Hospital now plans to honor its main obligation by merging with another troubled hospital, St. John's Episcopal.

title: KENTUCKY DEFEATS INDIANA BY 85-69
description: Dirk Minniefield scored 22 points and Jim Master added 17 as Kentucky defeated Indiana, 85-69, tonight. Master and Minniefield combined for 23 points during a 29-11 spurt in the first half that saw Kentucky (3-0) move to a 41-19 lead. The Wildcats led at intermission by 47-25.

title: NICARAGUA NEEDS U.S. TOLERANCE
description: The United States has been much alarmed in recent weeks by what it feels to be an emerging totalitarian face of the Nicaraguan revolution - by the imprisonment of three dissident businessmen and a number of Communists, and the temporary closing of the respected paper La Prensa, which has reopened. What the United States does not realize is that its continuing mistrust of the revolution might be pushing the Sandinist Government to the left and forcing it, in spite of itself, to use just the kind of measures that the United States finds so troubling.

title: White Mountain Hikers Saved Before New Snow
description: By United Press International Two hikers were found in snow-clogged New Hampshire yesterday before new snow hit that searchers feared would hinder the rescue mission. Heavy rains in the Pacific Northwest and fog in California contributed to a death toll that reached 19 on the East and West Coasts.

title: EFFORT TO SHOOT DOWN C-x CARGO PLANES INTENSIFIES
description: Children have long thrilled to the story about the little engine that could. This is about the C-X - the big airplane that couldn't.

title: Leftist Elected Leader Of British Coal Miners
description: Arthur Scargill, a left-wing militant, was overwhelmingly elected leader of Britain's 240,000 coal miners, it was announced today. He hinted at a showdown with the Government over pay.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ''BUCKLE up and live.'' You've undoubtedly heard this or a similar slogan a dozen times if you've heard it once. Yet only one in 10 Americans heeds its advice. If anything, the use of seat belts is declining (one in eight used them as recently as three years ago) at a time when motor-vehicle injury and fatality rates are rising.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RETURN

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1981
description: International Greece's new policy toward NATO was outlined at a ministerial conference of the Atlantic alliance in Brussels. Athens said that it was partly suspending a return to the NATO military command and that it had begun withdrawing from some commitments. An American official, expressing concern, said that the position would probably compromise all Greek involvement in NATO's integrated military structure. (Page A1, Column 4.) Efforts to break a U.N. deadlock improved as Salim A. Salim of Tanzania withdrew his name from further Security Council voting for a new Secretary General. Mr. Salim, who was opposed by the United States in 16 ballots, followed the lead of Secretary General Kurt Waldheim, who withdrew last week after being vetoed 16 times by China. (A1:5.)

title: 19 Vietnam Refugees Drown
description: A Vietnamese refugee boat capsized in a monsoon in the South China Sea off the coast of northeast Malaysia last week, drowning 19 passengers. Refugees in another boat that arrived at the Malaysian state of Kelantan today said that seven children were among the victims.

title: FANS ALL OVER WORLD HONOR LENNON
description: Thousands of Beatle fans paid tribute today to John Lennon at an outdoor concert and vigil in his native Liverpool on the first anniversary of his slaying.

title: DU PONT PLANS TO SELL $2 BILLION OF ITS NATURAL RESOURCE ASSETS
description: The chairman of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, which acquired Conoco Inc. two months ago, said today that his concern would sell natural resource assets worth $2 billion in the next three years to help retire some of its $7.1 billion in debt.

title: JERUSALEM ARTICHOKE: A COLORFUL HISTORY AND VARIETY OF USE
description: One of the most abundant, curiously neglected and oddly named foods in America is the Jerusalem artichoke. Since its inception the name has involved a comedy of errors not only in this country but in France.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE radioactive mess at Three Mile Island still has not been cleaned up, but already that oncefrightening crisis has been reduced to the paper contentions of a lawsuit. The utility company is attempting to sue the Nuclear Regulatory Commission for $4 billion, asserting that it did not regulate the utility well enough to prevent the ''abnormal events'' - the alarming accident - at the nuclear power plant in 1979. N.R.C. officials in the capital reject the argument as ''without merit.'' Some people closest to the abnormal events, such as Kay Pickering, staff coordinator with T.M.I. Alert, a volunteer community group near Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania, contend in grim amusement that the lawsuit lays bare the rationale of the nuclear industry. ''They're saying 'It's up to you to catch us, and if you don't, you pay.' '' The General Public Utilities Corporation, however, argues that the commission, not the utility, was initially lax and could have prevented the accident. The T.M.I. Alert volunteers are concerned, among other things, that whatever Federal funds might come, by suit or agreement, should go directly to the continuing mammoth cleanup problem, and not to utility stockholders.

title: CHEMICAL TIE CONTESTED
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation charged yesterday that the Chemical New York Corporation was breaking the nation's banking laws by trying to acquire control of Florida National Banks of Florida Inc.

title: CITY'S NEW HEALTH CHIEF DIDN'T TELL OF HIS ILLNESS
description: New York City's new Health Commissioner did not tell Mayor Koch when he applied for the position that he had received hospital treatment for alcoholism last year.

title: CORPORATE BONDS SELL WELL
description: Credit market activity centered in the corporate sector yesterday, where investment bankers said sales were good for several new issues recently brought to market.

title: BEIRUT BOMB KILLS 1, INJURES 4
description: A bomb exploded today near the residence of the French Ambassador, killing a man and wounding four others. It was the fourth bomb blast in two days here.

title: SIR HANS KREBS, WINNER OF NOBEL FOR RESEARCH ON FOOD CYCLES, DIES
description: Sir Hans Krebs, a biochemist who won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1953 for discovering the basic pathways by which food is converted to energy in the body, died Nov. 22 in Oxford, England. He was 81 years old.

title: A TALK WITH HAIG (I)
description: During his first year in office, Secretary of State Haig has been the object of intense curiosity, not only in this capital but in many other capitals of the world.

title: EX-REAGAN AIDE'S FIRM IN PIPELINE FIGHT
description: The top executive of the principal company that would build the Alaskan gas pipeline said that he hired the public relations company of a former adviser to President Reagan to help him win White House endorsement of a proposal that would make financing of the project easier.

title: ELECTION LOSSES IN DENMARK FORCE OUT GOVERNING PARTY
description: Denmark's governing Social Democratic Party suffered a major rebuff in general elections today, and Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen said he would resign and remain in a caretaker role ''until a new Government is found.''

title: PROJECTILE TOYS ARE ASSAILED
description: A consumer group today listed a variety of slingshots, darts, toy guns and arrows as the most dangerous toys for sale during the Christmas shopping season.

title: YALE DERMATOLOGIST AWARDED $100,000 FOR CLINICAL STUDIES
description: Dr. Aaron B. Lerner, chairman of the department of dermatology at the Yale University School of Medicine, was named yesterday the winner of an annual award of $100,000 for outstanding contributions to clinical research.

title: HEARINGS OPEN ON ENDANGERED SPECIES LAW
description: As environmentalists and Government scientists complain that the Reagan Administration is failing to protect plants and animals threatened with extinction, Congress is starting formal reconsideration of the sharply debated Endangered Species Act.

title: CITY OPENS HOTLINE TO SPEED ADOPTION
description: To speed the process of finding permanent homes for 3,500 children now in the city's foster-care system, the city has established a telephone Adoption Hotline, whose caseworkers answer the questions of prospective parents and link them with 39 adoption agencies.

title: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ACME PRECISION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after $317,495 loss from the disposal of discontinued segments...C-Net income after $70,824 loss from discontinued operations and $347,139 gain from the disposal of discontinued segments

title: Comings and Goings
description: Marvis Frazier, who was to have fought an eight-round heavyweight bout in Atlantic City tomorrow, withdrew yesterday, complaining of dizziness. Frazier underwent surgery less than a year ago for a pinched nerve in the neck, but his associates could not say if the current problem was related to that injury. ... Anders Kallur, the Islander wing, has a slight sprain of the left knee and will miss the three remaining games on the team's western swing. ... The St. Louis Steamers of the Major Indoor Soccer League announced that they had purchased the contract of Larry Hulcer from the Cosmos.

title: No Headline
description: NETS WIN, 98-88; BUCK WILLIAMS GETS 19

title: TRADING IS POLITICS TO METS' CASHEN
description: To Frank Cashen of the Mets, the business of trading baseball players is like politics: ''you deal in the art of the practical, and you do it by appointment.''

title: St. Regis Paper
description: The St. Regis Paper Company will close its Kraft mill for two weeks on Dec. 17, affecting 570 hourly wage employees, company officials said. The shutdown, the second at the mill in recent weeks, was attributed to a slowdown in demand for paper products, The mill makes heavy Kraft paper for paper bags and cardboard-box liners.

title: Canada's Deficit Rises
description: Canada's current-account payments deficit in the third quarter rose to $2.65 billion (Canadian), seasonally adjusted, from a downwardly revised $2.10 billion deficit in the second quarter, and a $189 million deficit in the third quarter of 1980, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The second-quarter deficit was revised from an originally reported $2.38 billion. The Canadian dollar is worth about 84 cents in United States currency.

title: CUISINE AS AMERICAN AS RACCOON PIE
description: ROARING BULL, war chief of the Narragansett Indian tribe, has not been in a particularly bellicose mood lately. Things have been relatively peaceful around this southern Rhode Island hamlet for some time. In fact, the only weapon the chief has picked up has been a shellfish knife, which he wields with deadly precision while shucking chowder clams at the restaurant he owns with his wife, Pretty Flower.

title: HOW INTELLIGENCE 'OLD BOYS' LOOKS AT RENEGADES
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTENNIAL FETE FOR GIRLS' SCHOOL AT SACRED HEART
description: With coats slung over their shoulders and their arms filled with book bags and knapsacks, chattering high-school students filled the grand entry hall of the Convent of the Sacred Heart school at the end of another day's classes.

title: Wounded Officer In Stable Condition
description: A probationary police officer who was critically wounded chasing a mugging suspect in Brooklyn was taken off a respirator and was able to move one of his legs.

title: ABRAMS SUED AS BLOCKING EVICTIONS
description: A division of the American Invsco Corporation yesterday sued the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, charging that Mr. Abrams had improperly thwarted its efforts to evict ''wealthy cheats'' from a luxury cooperative building on the East Side.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Business People article in Business Day yesterday misstated remarks by Donald K. McIvor, chairman-designate of Imperial Oil Ltd., on the pace of oil drilling. He said it had doubled since 1973 in the United States.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1981; The Economy
description: Agreement on a farm bill that will cost taxpayers $11 billion over the next four years was reached by a House-Senate conference committee, after more than a month of haggling. The compromise was considered a qualified victory for President Reagan's effort to slow Government spending but means higher consumer prices. (Page A1.)

title: Charges of Bribery Studied in Queens
description: A special grand jury in Queens has been impaneled to examine allegations that some police officers and detectives in the 110th Precinct have taken bribes from bar owners in the Corona area to ignore liquor law violations and to help cover up shootings, beatings and other crimes occurring on their premises.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Recently Glenn Richter entered the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to attend a meeting in the Cole Porter Suite. ''I couldn't find the exact location,'' he says, ''so I went to the lobby, where I espied a white-haired, white-shirted, black-slacked gentleman whom I took to be a hotel functionary.''

title: EX-TRANSIT OFFICIAL ACCUSED WITH 5 OTHERS OVER BENEFITS
description: Criminal charges were filed yesterday against John G. deRoos, the former senior executive officer of the New York City Transit Authority, and five other present and former high officials of the authority. They were accused of accepting benefits from companies involved in the manufacturing of a fleet of defective Pullman subway cars.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Man in a Wheelchair Surrenders in Holdup
description: A 21-year-old man in a wheelchair who is suspected of holding up a gas station in Freeport, L.I., last week surrendered yesterday in Nassau County.

title: U.C.L.A. ON PROBATION IN BASKETBALL
description: U.C.L.A.'s basketball team has been placed on two years' probabtion by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for violations ranging from financial arrangements for players to giving a recruit a T-shirt.

title: Bankruptcy in Chile
description: Industria de Radio y Television, a major manufacturer, has been declared bankrupt, Jose Manuel Riera, a vice president of the company, disclosed today.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A condominium at 1642 Forest Hill Road on Staten Island was raided yesterday afternoon, and an estimated $5 million in drugs - including 2,000 pounds of marijuana, 2,000 pounds of hashish, 45 pounds of Thai sticks and 60 pounds of hashish sticks - was confiscated. Richard Esposito, 30 years old, and Barbara McNally, 19, were arrested. ... Fumes from a faulty coal-furnace flue pipe overcame four tenants, four police officers and five Emergency Medical Service workers at 1268 Park Avenue, at 96th Street, just before 8 A.M. yesterday.

title: Swiss Scores Slalom Upset
description: Joel Gaspoz, a 19-year-old from Switzerland, produced the second straight upset of the men's World Cup skiing season today, outracing Phil Mahre of the United States and Ingemar Stenmark, the Swedish ace, in the year's first giant slalom.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IHAVE admitted several times that numerous flavors and seasonings came to my palate reasonably late in my development as a chef. For example, until I arrived in America after having been a practicing cook or chef for more than two decades, I had never had occasion to use basil, so common in Italian kitchens, in my work. Similarly, I have known numerous Italian chefs who rarely if ever use tarragon. It is hard to account for the various ''regional'' uses of herbs and spices. In this regard, I can browse through a book on Indian cookery and find certain required spices -fenugreek, to choose but one example - that are not on my spice shelf.

title: Milk Pact Voted; Prices May Rise
description: Milk prices in central and northern New Jersey are expected to increase soon to offset wage settlements that ended the strike started Nov. 30 by truck drivers and milk processers in Teamsters Local 680.

title: POLISH CHURCH SEEKING TO GET TALKS RESTARTED
description: The Roman Catholic Church said today that it had taken steps to try to foster some sort of understanding between the Government and the Solidarity union, embroiled in a quarrel that has dimmed hopes for national reconciliation.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the 15 most popular television shows of the last week (Monday, Nov. 30, to Sunday, Dec. 6) according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the number households with television sets. Rating Program Network 1 28.9 60 Minutes CBS 2 27.0 Dallas CBS 3 25.3 N.F.L. Football ABC 4 24.9 Archie Bunker's Place CBS 5 24.8 M*A*S*H CBS 6 24.2 One Day at a Time CBS 7 23.3 Brett Maverick (P) NBC 8 21.8 Falcon Crest (P) CBS 9 21.6 Dukes of Hazzard CBS 1 0 21.2 Alice CBS 1 0 21.2 The Jeffersons CBS 1 2 21.1 House Calls CBS 1 2 21.1 Little House on Prairie NBC 1 4 21.0 Lou Grant CBS 1 5 20.9 Dynasty ABC (P) Premiere (R) Repeat (S) Special

title: ARCHBISHOP WARNS PANEL ABOUT CUTS
description: Private charity is inadequate to care for the poor, and the Federal Government is not doing its share, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit told a Congressional committee today.

title: EXPLOSION KILLS 13 IN TENNESSEE MINE
description: An explosion ripped through a coal mine shaft today, killing 13 miners about three miles inside a mountain. It was the third mine accident in the Appalachian coalfields in the last five days.

title: Market Place; Canadian Oils: Wary Outlook
description: CANADIAN oil company stocks, which have been out of favor since the re-election of Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau almost two years ago, are still viewed with suspicion, although the opportunities are believed to be substantial.

title: General Motors Canada Chooses President
description: Donald E. Mackworth, 44, has been named president and general manager of General Motors of Canada Ltd., the Canadian subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation based in Oshawa, Ontario. He was also elected a vice president of the parent corporation and appointed to the huge auto maker's administration committee, one of its major corporate committees, composed of the senior operating executives of the organization.

title: Guidry Talks Continue
description: Ron Guidry's future with the Yankees could be determined in the next two days. John Schneider, Guidry's lawyer, said he had a productive meeting with the Oakland A's today. He plans to meet with John McMullen, the owner of the Houston Astros, Wednesday, and with George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, Thursday.

title: O'Neill Out of Intensive Care
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill was transferred today from the intensive care unit at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center to the postcoronary ''step down'' unit, according to a hospital spokesman, Carole Stasiowski. She said Mr. O'Neill, who underwent open-heart surgery last Thursday, was moved to a private room late in the morning. The 51-year-old Governor remained in satisfactory condition and was eating solid foods, she said.

title: How Long Did It Last?
description: Everybody kept asking Farley Granger why he was not at work, all Rebecca Blasbend wanted to do was hang around Madeline Kahn and Christopher Walken did not even know whose apartment it was.

title: CAPITAL IS POWERFUL LURE TO NOVELISTS
description: They call their small group ''Scribbles,'' and they meet over a restaurant lunch or at one of their homes every few weeks to talk about their work: writing.

title: COOKIES: SUGAR, SPICE AND NOSTALGIA
description: ''I SMELL Christmas,'' my son once announced as he arrived home from kindergarten on a gray and frosted mid-December afternoon. With just five Christmases behind him at the time, he instantly recognized that most special and enticing combination of aromas that mark this festive season. Slowly, silently he tiptoed into the kitchen and in the most ominous fee-fi-fo-fum giant-killer voice that a 5-year old could muster, he boomed, ''I smell cookies.''

title: COUNCIL UNIT VOTES BUSINESS AID PLAN ,
description: A City Council committee approved yesterday a measure that would allow business districts to raise their property taxes voluntarily to finance neighborhood improvements.

title: Careers; New Titles For New Demands
description: THERE are at least five vice presidencies in many large corporations today that did not even exist a decade or more ago, according to Dr. J. Ray Watson, assistant dean for executive education at Duke University's Fuqua Graduate School of Business.

title: CONSOLIDATED ACCESSORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AC/DC EQUATES MUSIC WITH WAR
description: ''THE National Lampoon's'' mid-70's satirical rock revue, ''Lemmings,'' culminated in the appearance of the heavy-metal rock group Megadeath at a make-believe Woodstock, but before their set the audience was coaxed to put their heads against the giant speakers so that they could die from the explosion of sound.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''EVERYBODY loves you when you're six foot in the ground,'' John Lennon sang in 1974 on his album ''Walls and Bridges.'' As usual, he was being trenchant, and as usual, he was right. He was loved by millions when he was alive, but in the year that has passed since last Dec. 8, when he was shot down outside the Dakota, it seems he has been loved by just about everybody, indiscriminately.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $271,000 for the qr and $966,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $359,000 for the qr and $1,555,000 for the yr

title: GREECE CURTAILING ITS RENEWED ROLE IN NATO COMMAND
description: Greece told the Atlantic alliance today that it was partly suspending its return to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's military command and said it had already begun a disengagement process from certain alliance commitments.

title: Faculty Accepts Pact At Boston University
description: Boston University faculty members voted Monday to accept a three-year contract after defeating by one vote a proposal to sign strike pledges, union officials said.

title: Swiss Decide on Two Who Will Rule for a Year
description: Switzerland's Parliament voted in Bern today to designate Economic Affairs Minister Fritz Honegger to be President and Foreign Affairs Minister Pierre Aubert to be Vice President.

title: THEATER: FEIST DIRECTS STRINDBERG DOUBLE BILL
description: WHILE Gene Feist has done plenty wrong, he's also done one hard thing right in his revival of ''Miss Julie'' at the Roundabout Stage Two: he has found an actress capable of playing the tough title role. That actress is Giulia Pagano, the winning center of past Roundabout revivals of ''Heartbreak House'' and ''The Winslow Boy.'' Watching Miss Pagano here is to remember what ''Miss Julie'' meant to the development of the modern theater. Her Julie isn't perfect - she wants for some regality - but the crucial makings for perfection are there: Instead of settling for mere hysterics, Miss Pagano charts the delicate nuances of a woman whose consciousness is on a centrifugal spin.

title: Premier in New Zealand Retains Thin Majority
description: The results of New Zealand's general elections, following the counting of absentee votes, gave Prime Minister Robert Muldoon's National Party a slim parliamentary victory today. The result, originally declared on Nov. 28, appeared to have produced no clear majority.

title: GREECE OBSTRUCTS NATO COMMUNIQUE
description: Greek officials blocked NATO defense ministers tonight from issuing a communique on their two days of meetings here, saying Athens had not received a satisfactory statement guaranteeing against attacks by Turkey.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; South Africa Detains 2 Black Labor Leaders

title: GIFTS HONORING THE BEREAVED KEY PART OF FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: Gifts dedicated to the memory of relatives and friends constitute an important part of the donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Among the contributors in that category this year is Anne M. Mintz of Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Pornography Film Actor Charged in Coast Deaths
description: A pornography film actor, John C. Holmes, was charged today with murdering four persons by bludgeoning them last July at a house in Laurel Canyon, but he won a two-week delay in his arraignment without entering a plea.

title: L.I. MENTAL PATIENT GUILTY OF KILLING EX-WIFE
description: Adam Z. Berwid, a mental patient who had repeatedly threatened to kill his former wife, was convicted today of stabbing her to death in 1979 while he was on a one-day pass from a state psychiatric hospital.

title: Echoes of Watergate
description: Historical news quiz: What do Robert Bork and Maurice Stans have in common? One answer is Watergate, and now there is another one. In the last few days President Reagan has nominated both men for Federal office, Mr. Bork as an appellate judge in Washington, Mr. Stans as a director of a Federal investment corporation. At this point the parallels abruptly stop.

title: Of Mice and ...
description: Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court, opinion in the case of Widmar v. Vincent concerning the right of a public university to prohibit voluntary religious meetings within the campus facilities, Dec. 8:

title: Reagan Is Urged to End U.N. Support of Pol Pot
description: An open letter urging the United States to drop its support of the deposed Pol Pot regime at the United Nations was sent to President Reagan today. The letter was signed by more than 130 prominent people, including politicians, movie actors, writers, academic figures and religious and humanitarian leaders.

title: Accounts
description: * Air Virginia to Siddall, Matus & Coughter Inc., Richmond.

title: Dow Up 6.47 on Price Report
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday after retreating in the previous two sessions. The biggest price moves were posted by Marathon Oil and Pennzoil, both takeover candidates.

title: Charles Rammelkamp, Scientist and Educator
description: Charles H. Rammelkamp, a scientist and educator, died Saturday after undergoing heart surgery at Lakeside Hospital of University Hospitals in Cleveland. He was 70 years old and lived in Cleveland Heights.

title: Corning, Metpath Merger Concluded
description: Corning Glass Works, a leading producer of glassware and high-technology glass and fiber-optics products, said that it and Metpath Inc. had signed a final agreement for a merger in which Corning will absorb the Teterboro, N.J., clinical laboratory concern.

title: 117 Countries Accused By Human Rights Unit
description: Human rights are being violated by governments or extremist groups in 117 countries, including the Soviet Union, China and, because it retains the death penalty, the United States, Amnesty International said in its 20th annual report released here today.

title: FINDING THE REPLACEMENT FOR BROKEN CHINA SETS
description: WHEN pieces shatter or disappear from a favorite dinnerware service, many owners are thwarted in their attempts to replace them because the pattern is no longer produced or readily available.

title: WHITE HOUSE EMBRACES NEWCOMER TO CONGRESS
description: The right faces were there. At the invitation of the White House triumvirate of Edwin Meese 3d, James A. Baker 3d, and Michael K. Deaver, some of the movers and shakers of Washington gathered at the Hyatt Regency Tuesday night for a political fundraising event.

title: Ava Helen Pauling, 77; Peace and Rights Aide
description: Ava Helen Pauling, a lecturer, worker for peace and human rights and wife of the Nobel laureate Linus Pauling, died Monday. She was 77 years old.

title: Italy-Iran Pipeline Deal
description: Italy's state oil company, Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, said today that it had concluded a $200 million contract with Iran to construct a gas pipeline in the south of the country. The 360-mile line will link the port of Kalan with the city of Isfahan, a company spokesman said, adding that the contract marked the reopening of business between E.N.I. and the Iranian Government. The project dates to 1977, the company said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75. ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: PORT AUTHORITY AND CITY REVISE AIRPORT LEASES
description: An agreement to change the leases covering Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports was announced yesterday by New York City and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Danish Prime Minister Gives Up His Post
description: Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen resigned today after an election in which voters rejected his moderate policies for Denmark's economic recovery.

title: PLAN FOR SCHOOL MERGER WOULD BENEFIT THE ARTS
description: Two high schools on the Upper West Side - Louis D. Brandeis and Martin Luther King Jr. - are expected to be merged, creating a school that would include training for backstage jobs in the performing arts.

title: REAL ESTATE CONCERN SEEKING TO PURCHASE THE G.M. BUILDING
description: Corporate Property Investors, a Manhattan-based real estate concern, is negotiating the purchase of the General Motors Building, at 767 Fifth Avenue.

title: The Police Blotter
description: An 18-year-old student at Wingate High School in Brooklyn's East New York section was fatally shot outside the school at 2:20 P.M. yesterday by two assailants during an attempted robbery. The victim, Alphonse Rimple of Brooklyn, died at Kings County Hospital. ... A counterman at a lower Manhattan delicatessen was arrested in the morning and charged with defrauding fellow employees and close relatives of $250,000.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT NETS BY 109-100
description: Just before the Boston Celtics defeated the New Jersey Nets, 109-00, tonight at Boston Garden, three Celtic guards played a playground game called H-O-R-S-E. The players were Chris Ford, the aging guard; Terry Duerod, the bench-warming crowd favorite, and a young newcomer, Danny Ainge.

title: Stoudt Works Out
description: Cliff Stoudt of the Pittsburgh Steelers worked out for the first time since he broke his throwing arm four weeks ago, but Mark Malone was still expected to start against Cincinnati in place of the injured Terry Bradshaw. The Bengals planned to start Jack Thompson in place of Ken Anderson, who has a hyperextended big toe. ... Dan Pastorini will start for the Los Angeles Rams against Atlanta because, according to Coach Ray Malavasi, ''Atlanta does a lot of blitzing and we want an experienced quarterback who can call audibles.''

title: J.L. Donahue, Chicago Priest And Labor Activist, Dies at 76
description: The Rev. Joseph L. Donahue, a labor activist priest who once began an investigation into patient abuse at an Illinois state mental hospital, is dead at the age of 76.

title: TREASURY PRICES FALL SHARPLY
description: Fears that the Federal Reserve will report a rise in the money supply tomorrow afternoon helped to send prices of Government securities tumbling yesterday. One dealer said this factor added an additional worry to what he called ''a gut-wringing market.''

title: Chairman of Comdial Given Additional Post
description: Ted E. Westfall, the 62-year-old chairman of the Comdial Corporation, has been elected to the additional position of chief executive officer. He succeeds Don G. Hoff, 45, who continues as president of the San Francisco-based telecommunications terminal company.

title: TRAGICOMDEY: ACT 1
description: It says something about the state of the Reagan Administration and of the Republican Party when the President's principal ball-carrier in the House of Representatives decides to turn a routine Republican fund-raising luncheon this Saturday in Peoria, his hometown, into an ''appreciation'' of David A. Stockman.

title: College Sues to Stay In Football Playoffs
description: Cameron University officials filed suit today for a temporary restraining order that would allow the Lawton, Okla., school to continue in the football playoffs of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics.

title: SALE OF MACE TO PUBLIC WORRIES CONNECTICUT POLICE
description: Chemical Mace, the tear gas carried by many police officers, is being sold to the public for the first time in a test of the product's appeal as a nonlethal defense weapon.

title: CABARET: CARMEN MCRAE
description: THE image of a tough, salty lady that Carmen McRae cultivated for many years has recently been softening. In her performances at Marty's, where she will perform through next week, Miss McRae is singing with more emphasis on thoughtful interpretation and sensitive shading than she once did.

title: Caterpillar Gets Export License
description: The Commerce Department today granted an export license to the Caterpillar Tractor Company to permit the company to sell $85 million worth of pipeline-laying equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1981
description: International A victory for foreign aid was marked as 97 House Republicans heeded an appeal by President Reagan and joined the Democrats in approving a $5.7 billion assistance authorization for the current fiscal year. The vote was 222 to 184. Many of the Republican supporters had never before voted in favor of foreign aid. (Page A1, Column 1.) A visa for Yelizaveta Alekseyeva was reported promised in Moscow. Miss Alekseyeva, in behalf of whose emigration effort Andrei D. Sakharov had gone on a hunger strike, said she had been told by a state security official that she would be allowed to leave and that Dr. Sakharov, as a result, had ended his 17-day fast. (A1:2-3.)

title: BROWSING AMONG NEW DESIGN BOOKS...
description: NOT too long ago, interior design books were either full of only lovely-to-look-at color pictures or how-to advice, both of which had limited appeal. But if this year's crop of new titles is any indication, the scope seems to be widening. The current selections range from the scholarly ''Building the Dream'' (Pantheon Books, $18.50) by Gwendolyn Wright, one of this season's most thoughtprovoking books for anyone interested in the history of the home, to the spectacular ''Objects'' (Knopf, $75) by John Gruen, a hypnotic collection of 37 photographs of household things.

title: ...AND 2 ON FURNITURE
description: ANYONE interested in the evolution of furniture in this country will benefit from the encyclopedic ''American Furniture - 1620 to the Present,'' by Jonathan L. Fairbanks and Elizabeth Bidwell Bates and published by Marek Publishers at $50. The illustrations of chairs, tables, chests, beds and settees - from the Pilgrim period through post-World War II modern - reflect most of the major developments.

title: Memorial for Arthur A. Leff
description: A memorial service will be held Sunday for Arthur A. Leff, a Yale University Law School professor who taught contracts, evidence and ethics. Mr. Leff died Nov. 2 at the age of 46. The service will begin at 2 P.M. in the auditorium of the law school in New Haven.

title: COURT CURBS REQUEST ON DATA
description: Government agencies may refuse to disclose some documents, particularly internal law-enforcement information, on the ground that the disclosure might help lawbreakers, a Federal appeals court ruled Tuesday.

title: Enez Whipple to Retire From L.I. Guild Hall
description: Guild Hall, the East Hampton, L.I., museum and theater center, has announced that Enez Whipple, executive director since 1950, will retire Dec. 31.

title: PIANO: SERKIN IN CONTACT WITH THE OLD MASTERS
description: THE piano has never seemed a natural extension of his personality for Rudolf Serkin, as it does for many a lesser musician. The music does not flow from his fingertips in the way it does when, say, a great cocktail pianist sits down at the keyboard. Mr. Serkin has never been that kind of virtuoso, and thank goodness for it.

title: New Western Air Head Studies Wien Merger
description: In a move that could result in a radical change for ailing Western Airlines, Neil G. Bergt, 45, has joined the Los Angeles-based airline as chairman and chief executive officer and will attempt, in a twostage maneuver, to have it acquire Wien Air Alaska, a regional carrier with headquarters in Anchorage. His appointment was announced at the same time that the company said it might lose $50 million to $60 million in the fourth quarter.

title: DECISION FILE
description: Every day Federal agencies make decisions that affect the lives of Americans. Here is a recent case: Rule Bumped Off

title: SAKHAROV'S STEPSON HOPEFUL ON EMIGRATION PLEDGE
description: Alexey Semyonov, the mathematics student who has been at the American end of the dispute that prompted Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife to embark on a hunger strike, expressed cautious hope today that his wife by proxy might soon join him, but he voiced concern for the welfare of his mother and stepfather.

title: G.E. Says Theme Grows in Recognition
description: General Electric is probably more abreast of consumer attitudes than most corporations, and the person responsible for this is Herbert Krugman, the esteemed advertising researcher who as manager of public opinion research supervises the quarterly telephone interviews that reach 3,000 people each. G.E. has been feeling the public pulse for 17 years, not only on its own affairs and image but also on other corporations and world events.

title: MINE DEATHS RAISE DEBATE ON RULES
description: The deaths of 24 coal miners in five days, including 13 killed Tuesday in south-central Tennessee in what the authorities called an ''apparent'' explosion, have raised new questions about the Government's commitment to enforcing mine safety.

title: ISLANDERS FALL TO CANUCKS, 4-3
description: Third-period mistakes again foiled the Islanders as the Vancouver Canucks, scoring twice in the final 20 minutes, won by 4-3 tonight at Pacific Coliseum.

title: 2 YOUTHS RESCUE WOMAN IN SUBWAY ACCIDENT
description: Mark Arzoonanian and George Jones, two students at Brooklyn Technical High School, rescued a woman trapped between a moving train and a subway platform yesterday morning and then used their school books to make a splint for her broken ankle.

title: Technology; 'Zoning' Rules For Satellites
description: THE demand for satellite communications facilities is so strong, compared with the present supply, that owning a satellite or the rights to use it has been likened to owning a desirable piece of real estate. That was demonstrated last month when the RCA Corporation decided to auction off leases for seven satellite facilities. The winning bids totaled $90.1 million.

title: U.S. BAPTIST GROUP ENDS ISRAELI VISIT
description: The Rev. Bailey E. Smith, the president of the Southern Baptist Convention who stirred a storm of protest with his statement last year that ''God Almighty does not hear the prayer of a Jew,'' left Israel today after a nine-day visit in which no Israeli official challenged him over the remark.

title: SESSION ON REDISTRICTING CALLED OFF BY ANDERSON
description: The majority leader of the State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, said today that the reapportionment plan drawn by the Assembly's Democratic leadership would ''grossly violate'' the State Constitution.

title: HOMOSEXUALS FOUND PARTICULARLY LIABLE TO COMMON VIRUSES
description: Three studies published today described a cluster of cases in which usually harmless viruses and bacteria can produce fatal illnesses, almost exclusively among homosexual men.

title: The Corporate Wife
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: As a corporate wife, I must take issue with K.C. Cole's article (''Hers,'' Nov. 26), especially where she writes: ''But they (corporate wives) are excluded from what is the most important corporate perk of all: the praise and respect that come with being treated like an important person.''

title: 3 Economists See Recovery
description: The economy will recover in tandem with falling interest rates next year if President Reagan sticks to his current economic policy, three economists said here today at a symposium sponsored by the the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business.

title: Objects for Cleaning
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Concerning those 15 chairs, 17 tables, 88 boxes, two collections of bronzes and 18 pieces of porcelain of Mr. Barrows (''Many Objects in a Small Space: A Collector's Elegant Solution,'' Nov. 26): Who cleans them? How often? How long does it take? WILLIAM A. CLARY Washington, Conn.

title: U.S. Foreign Funds Review
description: The Administration is considering legislation that would give added powers to the Inter-agency Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, Marc E. Leland, Assistant Treasury Secretary for International Affairs, said today.

title: Democrats Now Favor Government Pay Rise
description: Congressional leaders agreed today to give top Government employees a raise of at least 4.8 percent, which for some could be as much as 15 percent. The increase seems sure of approval.

title: CATHOLICS CELEBRATE ANNIVERSARY FOR CARDINAL CODY
description: John Cardinal Cody, head of the nation's largest archdiocese and the subject of controversy over his handling of church funds, today celebrated the 50th anniversary of his ordination with a mass attended by seven cardinals and 142 American bishops and the personal representative of Pope John Paul II.

title: Israel Firm on Aqueduct Plan
description: Energy Minister Yitzhak Berman said today that Israel would go ahead with plans for an aqueduct from the Mediterranean Sea to the Dead Sea despite a United Nations resolution on Monday condemning the project.

title: 'DINOSAUR' ELUDES SIX-WEEK SEARCH IN AFRICA
description: The American biologist who went to Africa in search of a dinosaurlike animal has returned with accounts of what might be a new species of snake and of strange footprints in the jungle, but without success in finding the legendary mokele-mbembe.

title: FOREIGN AID BILL CLEARS THE HOUSE
description: With unusual support from Republicans, the House of Representatives tonight passed a bill that would authorize $5.7 billion in foreign aid in the year that began on Oct. 1.

title: U.S. LIKELY TO ASK SEA LAW REVISION
description: A nine-month policy review by the Reagan Administration has concluded that the United States should negotiate changes in a treaty regulating use of the seas and their mineral resources rather than abandon it, senior Administration officials said today. President Reagan is expected to announce this decision by the end of the month.

title: ON LIBERAL LAW IN THE REAGAN ERA
description: Anthony G. Amsterdam, the principal architect of legal efforts to abolish capital punishment in the United States, offered a primer to civil libertarians Tuesday night on how to deal with what they regard as an increasingly hostile Federal judiciary.

title: Michigan Workers Lose Suit on Toxic Damages
description: The Michigan Court of Appeals today ruled out a claim by former workers at the Michigan Chemical Company for $500 million in damages from the Velsicol Chemical Corporation for exposing them to the toxic substance PBB.

title: Protesters Clash With Police Over a Nuclear Plant in Japan
description: Protesters scuffled with riot policemen in northern Japan today on the third day in a row of demonstrations against a proposed nuclear power plant.

title: Critic's Notebook; SHOULD WE EXPECT MAGIC TO HAPPEN WHEN A THEATER'S LIGHTS DARKEN
description: IN one of the high points of ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' the title character and his best pal, the deformed wastrel Smike, join up with Vincent Crummles's provincial acting troupe. Nicholas and Smike are quite excited to undertake life on the stage - but they're a little disconcerted once they lay eyes on the shabby playhouse where they must make their debut in ''Romeo and Juliet.'' More than a little. Smike is shocked. ''Is this the theater?'' he asks Nicholas, disappointment rising in his frail voice. ''I thought it would be ablaze with light and finery.''

title: INCREASE PLANNED IN MILITARY FUNDS
description: The Pentagon plans to ask for a $6 billion increase in the previously projected 1983 military budget to speed the delivery of two more nuclear-powered aircraft carriers, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: TV Fund-Raiser Taps a Philadelphia Viking
description: Roger G. Hall, vice president of Philadelphia's Channel 12, has been using computerized mailing lists to address fund-raising appeals for the public television station. One such letter, addressed to ''Mr. Leif Ericson'' in Media, Pa., drew the following reply:

title: RICHARD F. HANSER, A TELEVISION WRITER AND NEWSPAPERMAN
description: Richard F. Hanser, an author and prize-winning television writer whose credits included ''Victory at Sea,'' died Monday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. Mr. Hanser, who lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y., was 71 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of Montreal has elected to its board Walther Leisler Kiep, a German businessman.

title: PHOTON SOURCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Oct 1981

title: LAWSUITS CHALLENGE THE NATIVITY SCENE
description: Nativity scenes are being set up throughout the country in town squares, in shopping districts and on public buildings. But some of them are coming down just as the Christmas season gets under way.

title: Kings 5, Oilers 5
description: Mark Hardy scored a controversial unassisted 25-foot goal with 1:43 remaining to give Los Angeles a tie.

title: TRIAL IN 9-YEAR-OLD WILLOWBROOK CASE RESUMING
description: She said she was happy, and she looked it - even in a wheelchair in a hall near the front door of Building 25 at the Staten Island Developmental Center at Willowbrook.

title: Bucks Get Their Man
description: The Milwaukee Bucks got off to a strong start this season and are entrenched in first place. Now there is more bad news for their Central Division rivals. Yesterday, Marques Johnson, who had been holding out since before the season, came to terms on an eight-year contract.

title: Flyers 4, Penguins 1
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Ken Linseman and Bobby Clarke scored first-period goals and Bill Barber added two goals in the third period as Philadelphia ran its winning streak to five games. Pittsburgh lost its third in a row and had an eight-game home unbeaten streak snapped. North Stars 6, Canadiens 6

title: INSYTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Washington Post Loses Bid To Dismiss Philadelphia Suit
description: The Washington Post has failed to prove a lack of malice in the writing of an article critical of Philadelphia police, a Federal District judge ruled today.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE AGE OF WONDERS. By Aharon Ap- pelfeld. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 270 pages. Frontispiece drawing by Nancy Lawton. Godine. $12.95.

title: U.S. ADVICE SOUGHT BY CONOCO ON LIBYA
description: Ralph Bailey, vice chairman of E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company and head of its Conoco subsidiary, said today that he expected to receive recommendations from the National Security Council in the next few days whether American companies should withdraw their employees from Libya.

title: DANCE: 'NIGHT CREATURE'
description: SOME works in the repertory of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater exist primarily to win applause. Others attempt to arouse the emotions. And some try to do both things simultaneously.

title: LIVING WITH MISSION FURNITURE ON THE EAST AND WEST COASTS MANHATTAN
description: THE master craftsman Gustav Stickley turned out his plain, boxy oak furniture, stripped of decoration other than exposed joints, at his factory workshop outside Syracuse.

title: CALENDAR: PAPER AND CRAFTS
description: The National Ephemera and Collectibles Fair, Madison Square Garden Center Exposition Rotunda, Seventh Avenue between 31st and 33d Streets.

title: U.S. STATEMENT ON LIBYA EXPECTED BEFORE WEEKEND
description: Aides to President Reagan said today that the Administration would be likely to have an announcement before the weekend on possible plans for economic sanctions or other punitive steps against Libya.

title: Rockets Lose, 4-3
description: Joe Fink took a pass from Dan Counce and scored 9 minutes 7 seconds into sudden-death overtime, lifting the Baltimore Blast to a 4-3 Major Indoor Soccer League victory over the New Jersey Rockets tonight. Steve Ryan, Neils Guldbjerg and Fred Grgurev scored for the Rockets, who fell to 1-4. Baltimore is 3-1.

title: DUTCH GROUP BUYS KEYES FROM ARCATA
description: The Arcata Corporation said today that it had reached an agreement to sell its Keyes Fiber Company unit, an international manufacturer of molded wood pulp and foam plastic containers, to a Dutch group, Royal Packaging Industries Van Leer B.V.

title: People
description: * Thomas O. Ryder has been named vice president, general manager of CBS Publications.

title: News of Music; A WAGNERIAN OPERA NEVER HEARD
description: ORIGINALITY in the opera house requires one of two directions - either the creation of something new or the disinterring of the buried and the long forgotten. Wagner's ''Die Feen,'' which will be performed in a concert version by the New York City Opera Feb. 24, takes the latter route, and this performance will represent somewhat of a coup for the company. The work was finished in 1834, but this is believed to be its American premiere.

title: Market Begins Trading In Eurodollar Futures
description: More than 2,600 contracts of a new financial instrument that can be used to hedge against changes in international interest rates were traded today on the International Monetary Market of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Garbage Worker Injured in Assault
description: The Sanitation Department, which is making emergency collections in the nine-day-old strike against private carting companies, reported two incidents of violence yesterday. Meanwhile, James McCabe, a state mediator, said negotiators for the haulers and their striking employees had agreed to resume talks at 11 A.M. today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't want to make a romantic story when the life of my parents is still in peril.'' - Alexey Semyonov, stepson of Andrei D. Sakharov. (A16:2.)

title: PARENTS' APATHY BLAMED IN DEATH
description: CAMDEN (UPI) - A young couple were charged with killing their 2-month-old son, addicted to drugs. The indictment charged they were responsible for his death because he had ''failed to thrive.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Putting an end to reports that he might return to Kentucky, his alma mater, Howard Schnellenberger said that he would remain the football coach at Miami. He is in the third year of a five-year contract, but the university's administration had given him permission to listen to Kentucky's offer. ... The Winnipeg Jets obtained the rights to Serge Savard, the former all-star defenseman, from the Montreal Canadiens, and Savard will come out of retirement to sign a two-year contract.

title: 'Judas Maccabeus' Sing Will Be Held Dec. 20
description: The third open sing of Handel's ''Judas Maccabeus'' will be presented Dec. 20 at 1:30 P.M. at the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.

title: RESISTANCE HERO LED ITALY AFTER WAR
description: Ferruccio Parri, an anti-Fascist resistance hero who headed Italy's first postwar Government, died Tuesday in a military hospital here. He was 91 years old.

title: Inmates Protest Jailing Delay For 7 Youths in Drownings
description: County jail inmates skipped weekend meals to protest a decision by a judge that will allow seven teenagers to stay home for Christmas as their attorneys appeal their involuntary manslaughter convictions.

title: THOMAS J. STASINK
description: Thomas J. Stasink, vice president of the Doubleday Book Club division, died of a heart attack Sunday at his Manhattan home.

title: MUSIC: CHRISTMAS SONGS BY THE GAY MEN'S CHORUS
description: THE New York City Gay Men's Chorus filled Carnegie Hall Tuesday evening for its Christmas program. The concert offered traditional seasonal offerings by the guest conductor, Robin Kay, director of the San Francisco Lesbian and Gay Men's Community Chorus, and contemporary settings, antiphonal pieces with brass, a cantata and even a sampling of P.D.Q. Bach conducted by the group's founder and music director, Gary Miller.

title: THE DANCE: AN EVENING OF VAN GRONA
description: IT was 1934 all over again at the Theater of the Riverside Church on Sunday afternoon. That was the year Eugene Van Grona, who had been a dance star at the Roxy and Radio City Music Hall, decided to train black dancers. Although colleagues thought him foolhardy, he persevered. In 1937 his First American Negro Ballet made its debut, and the company remained in existence until World War II.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON 10 BILLION IN SEWER FUNDS
description: House and Senate conferees agreed today on a bill that would provide about $10 billion in Federal funds over the next four years for the construction of sewage treatment facilities.

title: CENTENNIAL COMMISSION IS FORMED FOR ROOSEVELT
description: Governor Carey announced today the formation of a commission to commemorate the centennial of Franklin D. Roosevelt's birth.

title: Officer Appointed, By RKO General
description: Hubert J. DeLynn, 60 years old, has been named vice chairman and chief operations officer of RKO General Inc., which operates four television and 12 radio stations, including WOR-TV, WOR-AM and WXLO-FM in New York. He succeeds John B. Poor Sr., who retired last July at the age of 66 after 29 years with the company, a New York-based unit of the General Tire and Rubber Company. Thomas F. O'Neil, 66, continues as chairman and chief executive officer, and Frank Shakespeare, a 56-year-old former director of the United States Information Agency, remains president.

title: CONGRESSMEN HEAR DOUBTS OF VOTERS
description: In rural Minnesota the weather is turning colder, and so is the public view of President Reagan's economic program.

title: Chiefs Acquire Gaines of Jets on Waivers
description: The Jets took a chance and lost yesterday when Clark Gaines, a free agent rookie in 1976 who became the team's most valuable player that year, was claimed on waivers by the Kansas City Chiefs.

title: MICHAEL NAMED MANAGER FOR 1983
description: One day after they announced that Bob Lemon would be their manager in 1982, the Yankees said today that Gene Michael would be their manager from 1983 through 1985.

title: PRODUCERS' PRICE INDEX MODERATES
description: Producer prices for finished goods, slowed by a drop in food prices, rose only five-tenths of 1 percent last month, providing another sign of the general decline in the rate of inflation this year.

title: SHUTDOWN OF PHILADELPHIA JOURNAL THREATENED
description: The Philadelphia Journal, this city's youngest daily newspaper, will cease publication unless its unions accept drastic cuts in wages, staff and benefits, the paper's editor in chief and general manager, Michel Trudeau, said today.

title: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: the shr earnings for the first qr ended Oct 31 are not adjusted to reflect a previously announced 3-for-2 stock split which will become effective early next yr

title: Transactions; BASEBALL YANKESS (A.L.) - Announced that Gene Michael will return as manager for the 1983 season and extended Michael's contract through the 1985 season. Michael will be a scout this season while Bob Lemon is manager. Sent Freddie Toliver, pitcher, to Cincinnati to complete trade in which Ken Griffey, outfielder, had come to New York. Acquired Mike Lebo, catcher, from Toronto to complete trade in which Aurelio Rodriguez, third baseman, had gone to Toronto; assigned Lebo to Colum- bus of the International League.  CHICAGO (N.L.) - De
description: Meyer, third baseman and outfielder, to Oakland for Rich Bordi, pitcher. Acquired Roy Thomas, pitcher, from Oakland for two minor league players, Rusty McNealy, outfielder, and Tim Hallgren, pitcher; assigned Thomas to Salt Lake of the Pacific Coast League.

title: No Headline
description: HIJACKERS OF A LIBYAN JET GIVE UP AND FREE THEIR HOSTAGES IN BEIRUT

title: PIANO RECITAL: ANIEVAS PLAYS 'MEPHISTO'
description: THERE were moments at his Carnegie Hall recital Sunday afternoon when Agustin Anievas played the piano too well for his own good. Mr. Anievas's ability to execute right notes at incredibly high speeds seemed to hypnotize not only his audience but himself as well. Thus entranced by his own dexterity, he sped untroubled through the most demanding obstacles of Liszt's ''Mephisto Waltz,'' No. 1 and the Brahms ''Handel'' Variations; and in the process, the music became transformed into a racecourse - a racecourse brilliantly traversed but one reeking more of a sporting than a musical event.

title: AIDE SAYS REAGAN SUPPORTS THE ARTS
description: Frank Hodsell, the new head of the National Endowment for the Arts, said Tuesday that despite plans to slash funds for the endowment, President Reagan is firmly committed to supporting the arts.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE'S FRIENDS AT THE PENTAGON
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: DAMIEN LEAKE'S 'CHILD OF THE SUN'
description: DAMIEN LEAKE, who wrote the book, music and lyrics for ''Child of the Sun'' (at New Federal Theater), has a nascent talent as a composer. However, the book of his show, a winner of the prestigious Richard Rodgers Award, is sprawling and episodic, zigzagging through a quarter-century of black urban life. The musical severely lacks focus, shifting from one member of a family to another, with the play's title character not asserting his presence until the second act.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Design Notebook; ARCHITECTS, IF LEFT ALONE, BEGIN TO PROBE THEIR SOULS
description: THE language that architects and designers speak is one they do not always know themselves; it is one of inner meanings as much as outer shapes, one of private musing as much as public declaration. Though the tangible results of architecture are in the shapes and the declarations, the process by which works of architecture are made is more a part of this language of philosophical inquiry.

title: LIVING WITH MISSION FURNITURE ON THE EAST AND WEST COASTS PASADENA
description: whether it was pure Gustav Stickley, Leopold and J. George Stickley, or even Sears Roebuck Stickley - made a philosophical point through form alone.

title: O'Neill Recovering
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Gov. William A. O'Neill's doctors said the incision from his heart-bypass surgery last week was healing ''without complication.''

title: Product Introductions
description: New product introductions in November were down from those of November 1980, making it the fourth month of the year to suffer a dip.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 10, 1981; Companies
description: Mobil said it intended to buy up to 25 percent of U.S. Steel as a tactic to win out over the nation's largest steelmaker in the takeover battle for Marathon Oil. Most of Marathon's shares have already been tendered to U.S. Steel. (Page A1.)

title: Wintry Storm Hits Britain
description: Britain shivered for the second straight day in deep snow and ice. The snow, which blanketed most of the southeast on Tuesday, headed north overnight, hitting Lancashire, Cheshire and parts of Wales.

title: Joseph W. Ostrow Media Person of Year
description: Marketing and Media Decisions magazine yesterday honored Joseph W. Ostrow, 48 years old, executive vice president-director of communications services of Young & Rubicam, as media person of the year.

title: Index; International
description: Reporter's Notebook: East-West rivalry in paradise A2 Greek blocks NATO communique A3 Rightist elected head of Greece's New Democracy Party A4 Turkish military plans to demand death for 52 union leaders A5 Iranian successes reported in war with Iraq A7 Group of U.S. Baptists ends visit to Israel A11 Refugee group reverses policy on Soviet Jews A12 Hijackers of Libyan jetliner sur- render in Beirut A14 At Madrid talks, cutoff date is near but agreement is not A15 Alexey Semyonov, in Washing- ton, hopeful on emigration A16 Government/Politics States warned to expect even deeper cuts in federal aid A24 Anderson calls off session on reapportionment B3 Koch explains his ''centrist'' phi- losophy to Yale students B6 Washington Talk Briefing B8 Required reading B8 Decision file B8 Newcomer to capital has caught President's attention B8 Michael Deaver has subtle, per- vasive White House influence B8 General Around the Nation A18 Mine deaths raise questions on U.S. safety monitoring A18 Fund for children of 8 killed in Iran is lagging A22 The Philadelphia Journal will shut unless cuts are made A29 Mental patient guilty of killing ex-wife while out on a pass B5 B4 Home Section Home Living with Mission furniture on the East and West Coasts C1

title: Hardee's to Buy Burger Chef
description: The General Foods Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Burger Chef Systems unit, a fast-food retailer, to Hardee's Food Systems Inc. for about $44 million. Other terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: CATHERINE CLARKE
description: Catherine Clarke, a documentary film maker for 20 years, died of cancer at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center on Sunday.

title: ARTS AND CRAFTS FURNITURE SOURCES
description: Following is a sampling of shops that specialize in the Arts and Crafts period, as well as books of interest in the field. Michael Carey American Arts and Crafts Furnishings, 107 Spring Street, New York, N.Y. 10012. 226-3710.

title: SAKHAROV SAID TO END PROTEST FAST ON PLEDGE OF EXIT VISA TO WOMAN
description: Yelizaveta Alekseyeva said today that a K.G.B. officer had told her that she would be given an exit visa and that, as a result, Andrei D. Sakharov had ended his hunger strike on her behalf on Tuesday.

title: UNCERTAIN DEMAND AWAITS NEW ISSUE OF COLLABORATIVE
description: Another important chapter in the checkered history of biotechnology on Wall Street is scheduled to be written sometime late next month when Collaborative Research Inc. goes public.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FUMES EMPTY BUFFALO SCHOOL
description: A student dropped a tray of bromine and cobalt nitrate at suburban Grand Isalnd High School today, creating fumes that forced it 1,250 students from the building.

title: MARGIOTTA DOWN BUT NOT OUT, COLLEAGUES SAY
description: In his 13 years as Nassau County Republican leader, Joseph M. Margiotta maintained a political machine so effective, so wellfinanced and so tightly controlled that ''powerful'' became as much a part of his title as ''county chairman.''

title: PIANIST: ROBIN MCCABE
description: ROBIN McCABE'S recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night suggested that she may be developing into a major keyboard artist. And artist is the important word here, since Miss McCabe's technical ability, admirable as it is, would not necessarily distinguish her from the scores of American pianists whose digital prowess is taken for granted.

title: IRANIAN SUCCESSES REPORTED IN WAR
description: Fourteen months after invading Iranian territory, Iraqi forces appear to have lost some ground to regrouped Iranian troops who have reportedly been on the offensive since the end of November.

title: U.S.-JAPAN TRADE OBSTACLES
description: In three days of trade talks between the United States and Japan that began on Tuesday, Reagan Administration officials are presenting the Japanese Government with the grievances of people like Curt M. Rocca Jr.

title: JURY, IN 2D TRIAL, FINDS MARGIOTTA GUILTY OF FRAUD
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican Party chairman of Nassau County, was convicted today of extorting more than $500,000 in insurance kickbacks for his political supporters.

title: DISFIGURED WOMAN HAS FACE SURGERY
description: Surgery on Lisa H., the 21-year-old student with neurofibromatosis, commonly known as Elephant Man's disease, was completed with apparent success at the hospital of the University of Pennsylvania early this evening.

title: NUCLEAR ILLUSIONS
description: A school of hard-nosed nuclear strategists has been arguing for years that nuclear weapons are not only a deterrent: they can actually be used in war, in a carefully controlled way that avoids escalation to a general catastrophe. Accordingly, in this view, we must plan to use them like other weapons for a variety of purposes: to stop tanks, cut supply lines and so on.

title: Phil Mahre Wins Slalom; Stenmark Fails Again
description: Phil Mahre won the first men's special slalom of the World Cup skiing season today, dealing Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden his second setback in two days.

title: A good name is rather to be chosen than, well, the one Archie Outlaw has.
description: That is the view of Mr. Outlaw, who has petitioned for a temporary name change on the ground that his own name would ''prejudice me in the eyes of the jury'' when he goes on trial on a charge of selling heroin.

title: TODAY'S CHINA RECALLS A MISSONARY PAST
description: To the Editor:

title: G. CARLTON JORDAN JR.
description: G. Carlton Jordan Jr., a retired investment counselor and general partner of R. W. Pressprich & Company, died Saturday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. Jordan, who lived in New Milford, Conn., was 70 years old.

title: Profit Reported By Firestone
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday that it earned $14 million, or 24 cents a share, in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Oct. 31. This was in contrast to a deficit of $8 million, after an extraordinary tax credit of $12 million, a year earlier.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company switched to LIFO accounting which reduced the net for the 1980 qr by $2,583,000 or 24 cents a shr and for the full 1980 yr by $3,531,000 or 34 cents a shr

title: BRIEFS
description: * Burroughs Corp. said it had negotiated a $250 million revolving credit and term loan agreement with a group of 16 United States banks led by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Rolls-Royce Ltd.
description: Rolls-Royce Ltd. said that a decsion by the Lockheed Corporation to stop making L-1011 airliners would force some layoffs at its British plants.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
MADRID PARLEY: NO ACCORD AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: With only nine days to go before an informally accepted cutoff date, the Madrid follow-up conference on European cooperation and security appeared today to be far from an overall agreement.

title: Pessimism In Canada
description: Short-term business confidence in Canada is at its lowest point since the Conference Board of Canada first began surveying executives in 1977, the research organization said today.

title: J. CORNELL SCHENCK
description: J. Cornell Schenck, a former vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died of a heart attack Monday.

title: 23 Injured in Explosion At Gulf Plant in Texas
description: Twenty-three men were injured today, two of them critically burned, when a boiler exploded at a Gulf Oil refinery, hurling flames 100 feet into the air, officials said.

title: Chicago Police Accept Pact
description: The city's police officers voted Monday to accept a two-year contract that includes a 20 percent pay increase and improved benefits, the Fraternal Order of Police announced. Starting July 1983, patrol officers with 10 years of service will receive $28,560 a year.

title: RUTGERS GAMBLES AND DEFEATS ST. JOHN'S
description: St. John's lost its first game of the season tonight because Tom Young, the Rutgers coach, found a way to contain David Russell and gambled that Chris Mullins would not continue his hot shooting in the second half.

title: HANNAH E. BERGMAN
description: Dr. Hannah E. Bergman, an authority on classical Spanish literature, died of cancer Saturday at New York Hospital.

title: CREATING PRODUCTS FOR MARKETPLACE
description: It is written in Ecclesiastes that there is no new thing under the sun. But Gerald Schoenfeld has his own idea about that. ''Who's to say what's new?'' Mr. Schoenfeld asked heatedly. ''It's the world's most boring argument.''

title: At the Court of King Edward
description: On a day in December the King took a walk Through the halls of his palace in search of a talk With a lady who, though she did not share his throne, Had nonetheless carved out a realm of her own. His forehead was furrowed with deepest contrition For words said in haste and in need of remission.

title: ENERGY BILL PASSES TEST IN CANADA
description: The House of Commons today approved an energy bill that limits foreign participation in oil production on federally owned lands and gives the Government a vested interest in future revenues.

title: THE MYSTERY IN SOVIET REPRESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: BERBICK FIRST HAS A PRICE TO FIGHT ALI
description: When Trevor Berbick was growing up in Kingston, Jamaica, he listened to the Muhammad Ali fights on the radio. He particularly remembers the ones with Sonny Liston.

title: Air Force Tests Missile
description: The Air Force today successfully launched a short-range attack missile from a Strategic Air Command plane flying over the Atlantic Ocean. Air Force officials said the missile was fired from an FB-111 aircraft and landed in a designated target area on the eastern test range near Grand Turk Island.

title: Transit Slide Halted, A New Report Asserts
description: Mayor Koch and John D. Simpson, president of the New York City Transit Authority, presented yesterday the first of what they said would be a series of monthly public reports on the status of the city's bus and subway system.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TEXAS INDICTMENT PUTS FOCUS ON DILEMMA OF MERCY KILLING
description: In the police photograph, Woodrow Collums looks like a Grant Wood version of the retired rancher he is: leathery face seemingly lined with as many creases as the flat South Texas land where he grew up, bushy eyebrows, steady gaze, firm mouth turned down at the corners.

title: Advertising; Urban League Job Campaign
description: YESTERDAY the 70-year-old National Urban League announced a public service advertising campaign intended to promote employment opportunities for blacks.

title: Home Improvement
description: SQUARES AND LEVELS ARE NEEDED FOR EVEN THE SIMPLEST OF HOME PROJECTS By Bernard Gladstone

title: REGAN PUTS DEFICIT UNDER $100 BILLION
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the Administration hoped to hold the budget deficit in the current fiscal year below $100 billion without rescinding or delaying the reduction in income tax rates that was enacted last August.

title: Harper & Row
description: Harper & Row Publishers Inc. said it had concluded an agreement to buy back all of the 1,017,630 shares of its common stock owned by the Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company at $20 a share. The company's shareholders approved the purchase and the related transfer of those shares to new employee-benefit plans by a wide margin, Harper & Row said.

title: GREEK PARTY SWINGS TO RIGHT
description: Evangelos Averoff, a former Defense Minister, was elected leader tonight of the conservative New Democracy Party. The development will probably result in the opposition party's adopting a more right-wing stance than it had taken under former Prime Minister George Rallis, who was ousted from the leadership on Monday.

title: Kaiser Steel Dismisses ESOP
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation today dismissed an employee takeover plan as unworkable. ''We don't think it would work,'' Kaiser Steel's chairman and chief executive officer, Stephen A. Girard, said of a proposal to buy control of the company through an Employee Stock Ownership Plan (ESOP).

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LIGHT BEER AD CAN BE HEAVY WORK
description: AT dusk outside Feibel's Bowling Alley in Teaneck, N.J., a halfdozen limousines added a touch of glamour to a quiet strip of Palisades Avenue. Inside, under hot lights, the shooting had moved into its ninth wearying hour.

title: Tonka Tenders For Its Shares
description: The Tonka Corporation, a leading Minnesota-based manufacturer best known for its lines of metal toy trucks, announced that it would make a cash tender offer for up to 600,000 shares of its common stock at $34.50 a share.

title: SPANG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After income of $165,890 from discontinued operations... C-After a loss of $229,157 from discontinued operations... D-After a gain of $218,529 from discontinued operations; the 1980 figures have been restated to reflect the closing of the Ft. Pitt Bridge division

title: FRANK IN JEOPARDY IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: The leaders of the Democratic-controlled Massachusetts Legislature today proposed a redistricting plan for the state's Congressional districts that appears to favor a Republican at the expense of a Democrat.

title: CAR WORKERS MAY REOPEN CONTRACTS
description: The United Automobile Workers broke with tradition today and took a step toward reopening its labor contracts with the nation's automobile manufacturers. The move could result in a loss of wages and benefit gains for the 1.2 million union members in the ailing auto industry.

title: Hers; WHITES SAY I MUST BE ON EASY STREET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks it will be written by Nell Irvin Painter, a writer and historian who teaches American history at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

title: DOCTOR CALLS MEDICARE PLAN EASY TO DEFRAUD
description: A cardiologist who has pleaded guilty to filing more than $1.5 million in false Medicare claims told a Senate hearing today that the Government health program for the aged was ''fairly vulnerable'' to abuse.

title: Walesa and Six Aides Meet With Archbishop
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the Solidarity union, and six other top union officials met today with Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland.

title: FIRE-DETECTION LAW: CLEARING CONFUSION
description: Mayor Koch: Hello, I'm here to install your smoke detector. Woman (standing in her apartment doorway): What? A snow director? Mayor Koch: No, a smoke detector. A new law in New York City says all apartments must have a smoke detector installed right away. SO begins a television commercial made last week, part of a citysponsored publicity campaign aimed at clearing up confusion about a new city law that requires the installation of smoke detectors in an estimated two million apartments by Jan. 1. While fire experts and housing groups generally approve of the new law, it has elicited complaints from some owners, anxiety from some tenants and a seemingly endless stream of questions.

title: MOBIL IS SET TO BUY 15% TO 25% SHARE OF U.S. STEEL CORP.
