description: The Mobil Corporation, stymied in its takeover battle for the Marathon Oil Company against the competing bid of the United States Steel Corporation, disclosed yesterday that it intended to purchase ''between 15 percent and 25 percent'' of the steel company, the nation's biggest.

title: CHINA TURNS LOVE AND CHAOS OF 60'S INTO A MOVIE
description: Though it opens on a peaceful residential lane, the bittersweet love story is no prosaic romance. The boy meets and loses his girl against the violent backdrop of China's Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, which brutalizes them in turn and shatters their future.

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 7
Voice of Dissent
description: Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles questions the escalating salaries paid baseball players.

title: Women and Science
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Had K.C. Cole written (''Hers,'' Dec. 3) that science tends to be a search for physical answers to fundamental questions, she would have realized why relatively few highly intelligent women bother ''to stick with it'' and overcome their boredom with science. Women are attracted to fields such as psychology and literature where their successful search for answers to fundamental questions is of a much less mechanical, impersonal nature. Is this to be deplored, or can it be taken as a sign of the unrecognized but vital role women play in human civilization? JOHN E. HELBOK Bronx

title: KOCH BRINGS CENTRIST MESSAGE TO YALE
description: Mayor Koch, who went to Baltimore to criticize liberal Democrats and then went to Detroit to criticize the conservatisim of the Reagan Administration was asked here today which role he preferred.

title: Addendum
description: * Hill & Knowlton Inc., Chicago, public relations subsidiary of the JWT Group, has acquired Dunne & Partners in Chicago.

title: Errico Attorney Accuses Amy of Perjury and Seeks New Trial
description: An attorney for Con Errico, the former jockey who was convicted last year of racketeering for the purpose of fixing thoroughbred races in New York, moved yesterday for a new trial, citing ''startling new evidence'' and ''egregious governmental misconduct.''

title: SOCIAL WORK IS STILL AN AMERICAN GROWTH PROFESSION
description: To the Editor:

title: ANIXTER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
LEGISLATORS TOLD OF DEEPER AID CUTS
description: A Federal budget official told state legislators today that the Reagan Administration was determined to make further deep cuts in Federal aid programs.

title: ANIMAL POWER
description: Animal power could make a contribution toward solving the global energy crisis but is almost entirely overlooked. Few people know, for example, that some 400 million horses, oxen, cows, water buffaloes, donkeys, camels, mules, yaks, llamas, and elephants work for man.

title: LOAN GUARANTEES AS INTEREST ELEVATOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Rededication
description: Muriel Humphrey Brown, the widow of former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, talked of rededication yesterday at a ceremony dedicating a memorial to Mr. Humphrey at the national headquarters of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I had carpet installed over the linoleum on my kitchen floor a few years ago, and the installer put the carpet down with an adhesive. Now I would like to remove the carpet and go back to the linoleum. How can I remove the carpet and adhesive? -J.A.A., Louisville, Ky.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Banco Nacional de Desarollo, the Argentine development bank, has arranged a syndicated loan of $200 million through an international banking group led by Credit Lyonnais.

title: LONRHO LTD. THWARTED IN HOUSE OF FRASER BID
description: One of Britain's bitterest takeover battles in years came to an end today when the Government ruled that Lonrho Ltd. could not buy the House of Fraser, Britain's largest department store chain and owner of the renowned Harrods. The Lonrho bid was worth $440 million.

title: A HOME COMPUTER AS STOCKING STUFFER
description: THIS year, a computer may fit not only your Christmas budget, but your Christmas stocking, too. At least five companies make batteryoperated pocket computers for well under $300, and Sinclair makes a similar-sized computer for $150 ($100 if you build it from a kit), which attaches to your power line and television set.

title: POLITICAL SCIENTIST AND AUTHOR
description: Dr. Joel S. Berke, a political scientist and author who specialized in the problems of financing public schools that serve poor children in urban areas, died Tuesday night at New York Hospital after collapsing at the Cosmopolitan Club. He was 45 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Fighting Qaddafi With a Wet Noodle
description: Boycott Libyan oil? That would be a morally justifiable, and popular, response to Libyan terrorism. At first glance it might seem effective, too. But a closer look suggests that economic sanctions might well generate a backlash, strengthening Colonel Qaddafi's standing in the Arab world.

title: Dutch Joblessness Up
description: Dutch unemployment rose to a post-World War II record of 435,400 in November from 423,300 in October, the Social Affairs Ministry said today. The figure compared with 291,200 in November last year, the agency said.

title: Paine Webber S.E.C. Charge
description: In an unusual move, the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. with illegally arranging the purchase of more than a million shares of the Diamond International Corporation's common stock.

title: PHYSICIANS WARN OF NUCLEAR RISKS
description: The American Medical Association yesterday passed a resolution calling on doctors to inform President Reagan and members of Congress about the ''medical consequences of nuclear war.''

title: Apparent Suicide Follows 2 Killings
description: A man, who had recently arrived with his family from Rumania, stabbed his wife and 14-year-old daughter to death in their Queens apartment before apparently committing suicide by poisoning himself, the police said last night.

title: TRIAL ON CREATIONISM DIFFERS FROM THE SCOPES CASE OF 1925
description: The trial in Federal court here of a challenge to the Arkansas creation science law may have been billed as a repeat of Tennessee's famous Scopes trial of 1925, but there are distinctive differences, not the least of which is the way the trial here is being conducted.

title: Market Place; Theirs Often Is A Risky Trade
description: NCZ COMMODITIES INC., a subsidiary of Niederhoffer, Cross & Zeckhauser, built its $300,000 trading account into a $12 million stake and then lost half the money - all in 30 months. Its experience offers a insight into the risks in commodities, even when the money is managed professionally.

title: THE USES OF PUBLICITY
description: As every aggressor nation knows, the time and place to attack the United States is during the Army-Navy game at Philadelphia. Much of the top brass is there rather than minding the military store. It's almost like attacking Israel on Yom Kippur.

title: Used Car Rule, or Overrule?
description: The Federal Trade Commission thinks that auto dealers should be required to inform buyers about known defects - a leaky radiator, a cracked engine head - in the used cars they sell. Congress, which has the last word on Commission decisions, is now debating the issue.

title: Bridge: A Shaky Bid Can Triumph With Boost From Enemy
description: The winning American team in the 1981 world championships in Port Chester, N.Y., in October included a partnership with an age spread that may be a record for such an occasion. One of its members is effervescent Bobby Levin of Miami Beach, who learned his bridge on Long Island and was once the youngest life master ever. Now, at the age of 23, he is the youngest world champion ever.

title: Caterpillar Plans Layoffs
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced plans today to lay off 2,085 more employees indefinitely at plants in Illinois, Iowa, Ohio and Pennsylvania by the end of March.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After reductions of $757,000 for the latest first qr and $778,000 for the previous first qr from minority interest in the income of subsidiaries

title: REAGAN ENDS BAN ON FEDERAL JOBS FOR CONTROLLERS
description: President Reagan today rescinded his threeyear ban on Federal employment for dismissed air traffic controllers. But he kept the door shut on rehiring them in their old jobs or anywhere in the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: PRODUCERS OF ALASKA GAS WIN VICTORY IN HOUSE FOR PIPELINE
description: The House of Representatives today approved an intensely lobbied series of concessions to sponsors of a proposed natural gas pipeline from Alaska.

title: INDIANS OBTAIN SUTCLIFFE
description: Rick Sutcliffe, the National League's rookie of the year in 1979, was traded by the Los Angeles Dodgers to the Cleveland Indians today in a five-man deal that highlighted a surprisingly mild trading market at baseball's winter meeting.

title: TURKS TO SEEK DEATH FOR UNIONISTS
description: A martial law prosecutor will demand death sentences for 52 leftist union leaders scheduled to go on trial in Istanbul on Dec. 24, it was announced today.

title: CARE OF THE CHRISTMAS
description: IT'S time to think about choosing that centerpiece of holiday decorations: the Christmas tree. The four most popular cut trees in this area are Scotch pine, white spruce, Douglas and Balsam firs.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SOCIALISM COMES TO PARADISE
description: Two Soviet warships are anchored in the turquoise waters off Mahe, the lush, main island of the Seychelles archipelago, symbolizing the strategic upper hand that Moscow seems to have gained in recent years in this part of the Indian Ocean.

title: Gardening; CACTUSES THRIVE ON LITTLE ATTENTION
description: WHAT is an ideal house plant? Some city folk dream of having plants that can be ignored for weeks, hate being watered and rarely get bugs. If this type of plant appeals to you, you're in luck. Such plants do exist in countless numbers - in both beautiful and grotesque sculptural outlines. They are the species known as succulents, which include cactuses.

title: NEW TOPIC FOR OPEC: LOW PRICES
description: OPEC oil ministers today opened a semiannual conference amid reports that some wanted to reduce prices for top-quality crude because of a slowdown in sales caused by an abundance of oil on world markets.

title: Midland-Ross
description: The Midland-Ross Corporation, the nation's largest supplier of freight car couplers and a major producer of other cast steel components, said that it was closing four foundries for the rest of this year because of a continuing decline in rail car orders. The action, which will temporarily idle a total of about 1,100 hourly employees, will shut foundries in Toledo, Ohio; Melrose Park and Cicero, Ill., and Sharon, Pa. Production is expected to resume at all four facilities Jan. 4, Midland-Ross said.

title: LADY MENDL'S LAST TREASURES ARE SOLD
description: Lady Mendl - the name conveys an aura of a golden time long past: Isotta-Fraschinis in the Bois de Boulogne, steamer trunks at the Gare St. Lazare, the Ile de France and the Mistral. Ciro's. The dansants at the Cafe de Paris, Clicquot '28 and the singer Tino Rossi.

title: SENATOR BARS THRIFT UNIT BILL
description: Jake Garn, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, announced today that his panel would not consider Housepassed emergency legislation this year to give Federal regulators new powers to deal with financially troubled savings institutions.

title: 50 SURCHARGE TO END JAN. 1 FOR MOST TAXIS IN CITY
description: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission voted yesterday to revoke, effective Jan. 1, the 50-cent surcharge for night and Sunday rides in 80 percent of the city's taxis.

title: Soviet Jewish Activist Given One Year for Resisting Police
description: Boris Chernobylsky was sentenced today to a year in a labor camp for failing to obey a policeman, informed sources said.

title: DEAVER LOOKS OUT FOR NO. 1: HIS OVAL OFFICE CHIEF
description: Michael K. Deaver could probably be the second most powerful man in the White House on any day he felt like asserting his influence with President and Mrs. Reagan.

title: CHAMBER CONCERT: EASTMAN PLAYERS
description: THE Eastman Chamber Players brought some new songs to Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening. Warren Benson's ''Songs for the End of the World'' were given their first New York performance; Sydney Hodkinson's ''Altes Liebeslieder, Book IV: ''Fingertip Words'' had their world premiere.

title: TV: 'TEENAGE SUICIDE: DON'T TRY IT!'
description: ARMED with decidedly troubling statistics, ''Teenage Suicide: Don't Try It!'' will be shown on WNEW-TV, Channel 5, tonight at 8:30. The Metromedia presentation, produced in association with Alan Landsburg Productions, is narrated by Timothy Hutton, the young actor who won an Academy Award for his performance in ''Ordinary People.''

title: 13 at Nuclear Plant Lose Jobs Over Drug Use
description: Thirteen security officers at the Surry nuclear power station were dismissed or resigned today for violating company rules on the use of illegal drugs, the Virginia Electric and Power Company said.

title: RANGERS LOSE TO BRUINS, 4-3, IN LAST 0:36
description: The Boston Bruins beat the Rangers, 4-3, last night on a goal by Wayne Cashman with 36 seconds left at Madison Square Garden. The Rangers had twice come from behind to tie at 2-2 and 3-3, and they appeared headed for a tie score and a point in the standing. But that slipped away at 19:24. Steve Kasper, the Boston center, started the decisive play. Guarded by Dave Silk, he spun from the left wing at the blue line and passed to Cashman, the 36-year-old left wing and captain.

title: BRIEFING
description: T O Charles B. Rangel, the Democratic Congressman who represents Harlem and parts of the West Side of Manhattan, the heroin problem resembles a vast, somber cloud that never drifts away. Under the Reagan Administration, he says, the cloud seems to be darkening.

title: PACER TECHNOLOGY & RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income after a tax loss carryforward of $14,086

title: VALTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income includes gain of $310,000 from the sale of plant for the qr and 6 mos

title: Home Beat; MARBLE-PATTERNED FABRICS
description: SOME people call the sinuous, watery effect marbled. Others, like Ellen Smith Ashley, a textile designer, refer to the design as ''marbleized.''

title: A SAMPLER OF VIEWS ON THE LAW
description: In a speech at New York University on Tuesday night, Prof. Anthony G. Amsterdam offered civil-rights and civil-liberties lawyers a potpourri of advice. Following are some of his suggestions.

title: Helpful Hardware; ROLLING LADDERS
description: WHEN high shelves are part of your decor, an attractive ladder that can be a permanent fixture is a must. The Putnam Rolling Ladder Company, 32 Howard Street, New York, N.Y. 10013 (212-226-5147), has several varieties made of oak.

title: BOOK SAYS BURGER AND NIXON DISCUSSED HIGH COURT ISSUES
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger discussed issues before the Supreme Court with President Nixon in advance of judicial rulings on them, according to John D. Ehrlichman, who was an adviser in the Nixon White House.

title: TO THE HOME SECTION: K.C. Cole's comments on the difficulties of women in science were indeed sad. How atavistic the scientific community is determined to remain despite its posturing to the contrary.
description: However, there is a point she failed to mention as a major stumbling block and that is the tremendous amount of parental discouragement a scientifically gifted girl still receives at home, and it's usually for financial reasons.

title: OPPONENTS OF THE MOON TREATY TWIST A POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRYSLER TANK UNIT STIRS BUYER INTEREST
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that several companies had ''expressed an interest'' in buying Chrysler Defense Inc., the subsidiary that makes tanks for the Army.

title: Higher Water Rate Granted in Jersey
description: NEWARK (AP) - The Elizabethtown Water Company was granted an 18 percent rate increase Wednesday by the State Board of Public Utilities to raise $7.4 million in additional annual revenues.

title: Tax Plans Voted to Keep Michigan Schools Going
description: After rejecting the proposal eight times since 1978, voters today approved a property tax renewal and increase to prevent the impoverished public school system from closing its doors.

title: REFUGEE GROUP REVERSES POLICY ON SOVIET JEWS
description: An American Jewish refugee organization said yesterday that it had agreed to participate on a trial basis in an Israeli plan to curtail the flow of Soviet Jews to countries other than Israel.

title: Going Out Guide
description: GRAND ILLUSIONS

title: DIXIE WALKER REMEMBERS
description: FRED (DIXIE) WALKER is not particularly eager to talk about the role he played when Jackie Robinson broke the color line in major league baseball.

title: COMTECH TELECOMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $194,414 pretax gain on the sale of land and $95,000 net tax credit...C-After $45,988 loss from discontinued operations and $7,000 tax credit

title: CHINA AND INDIA STARTING TALKS ON BORDER DISPUTE
description: Nearly two decades after they fought a short, fierce border war, China and India took a major step today toward improving relations by opening negotiations on their Himalayan frontier dispute.

title: JERRY WURF, LEADER OF FEDERATION OF MUNICIPAL WORKERS, DIES AT 62
description: Jerry Wurf, president of the nation's largest union of public employees, the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, died of a heart attack yesterday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 62 years old.

title: ARKANSAS HOPES TO VALIDATE CREATION SCIENCE
description: In defense of the Arkansas creation science law, witnesses will contend that the theory that the universe was created is ''at least as scientific'' as the theory of evolution, State Attorney General Steve Clark said today.

title: U.S. Auto Output Down
description: United States auto production last month tumbled 26 percent from November, 1980, to its lowest November level since 1970, Automotive News, an industry journal, said today.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including gains from discontinued operations of $76,000 for the qr and $263,000 for the yr...C-Including $59,000 gain from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been reclassified to conform to 1981 results

title: Ayala Stops Cottrell in 8th
description: Tony Ayala is called El Torito (Baby Bull). But tonight in the ring at Ice World it was his opponent, J.J. Cottrell, who assumed that role for seven rounds in their junior middleweight bout.

title: Berbick Assured by Promoters
description: Having thrown a haymaker at the ''Drama in the Bahamas'' amid the glare of the weigh-in ceremony today, Trevor Berbick said seven hours later that he would, after all, probably fight Muhammad Ali here on Friday night.

title: REAGAN REQUESTS AMERICANS TO QUIT LIBYA IMMEDIATELY
description: President Reagan appealed to Americans today to leave Libya immediately and invalidated American passports for travel to that country.

title: HOUSE DRAFT ON A.T.& T. SUBMITTED
description: A long-awaited draft of a House telecommunications bill was made public today and, as expected, it was tougher on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company than a counterpart bill already passed by the Senate.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $73,000 loss for the qr and $190,069 gain for the yr from the sale of real estate

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
...AND TWO PARTIES MATCH
description: It was a round of parties, as it is most weeks, parties large and small, public and private, for the Bulgaris and the Carimatis. The Bulgaris were invited to a rather special party and the Carimatis gave one.

title: 5 Men Are Convicted In Policeman's Slaying
description: Five men were convicted last night of the murder of Police Officer Robert A. Sorrentino during the robbery of a Queens social club on April 10, 1980, the Queens District Attorney's office said early this morning.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
TAKEOVERS PACE STOCK RISE
description: With the United States Steel Company leading the advance, stock prices moved ahead yesterday as trading interest remained active in takeover situations.

title: FROM OBSCURE VERDI TO 'TRAVIATA' WITH A TWIST
description: Verdi lovers this weekend will be offered two exotic items - a ''Traviata'' that its director says will be ''awash with blood,'' and the United States premiere of what may be the composer's most obscure and even reviled opera, ''Il Corsaro.''

title: 'ODD COUPLE' IS KEY TO MOBIL SUCCESS
description: Rawleigh Warner Jr. and William P. Tavoulareas, leaders of the Mobil Corporation, sometimes seem like an odd couple. The first is smooth, a member of the establishment with a Princeton education. The second is a pugnacious street fighter from Brooklyn. But few marriages have prospered as well as has their 12-year-old business relationship.

title: MONY MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TIME TO RETURN TO THE L.I. OF THE 1850'S
description: Once a year the Museums at Stony Brook transport visitors back to the Long Island of the 1850's by opening the home of the painter William Sidney Mount for Christmas tours.

title: MUSIC: JUBAL TRIO IN OLD AND NEW
description: IN a Merkin Hall program billed as ''A Festival of New York Composers'' Wednesday night, the Jubal Trio presented music by Mozart, Faure, Schubert, William Mayer, Warren Benson and George Gershwin, not all of them well-known New Yorkers. As it turned out, little else held the program together.

title: TIES TO NICARAGUA UNCHANGED
description: The Reagan Administration, which said last week that ''we do not close the door'' to Nicaragua, has received no response to its approaches, a senior State Department official said today.

title: ASTRONAUT TRIP FROM SPACE SHUTTLE PLANNED
description: The first manned excursion outside the space shuttle will be straight out of science fiction: An astronaut propelled by a jet-powered backpack moving out to an ailing $75 million satellite, bringing it into the ship's cargo bay, fixing it and putting it back into orbit.

title: Architectural Illusions
description: ''The Architecture of Illusion,'' at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, at 50th Street, is exhibiting through Jan. 15 photographs, models and drawings of trompe l'oeil paintings on New York buildings by Richard Haas. Included are a picture of the Times Tower as it formerly appeared, which can be seen on the north side of the Crossroads Building, 42d Street at Seventh Avenue and Broadway; a fake Art Deco facade on a building at the very end of Theater Row, Dyre Avenue and 42d Street, and the neoclassical Brooklyn Bridge that spans the wall of a Con Edison plant at the north end of the South Street Seaport restoration area.

title: Campbell Prepared
description: Earl Campbell is putting little stock in denials by the Houston Oilers that he is on the trading block. ''I'm expecting the worst,'' he said yesterday.

title: Tows Collide on Ohio, Causing Fire and Oil Spill
description: Two tows pushing fuel-carrying barges collided in a narrow stretch of the Ohio River, and the resulting explosion and fire forced the Coast Guard to close 15 miles of the waterway, the officials said.

title: BILL TO BAN BUSING DELAYED IN SENATE
description: Supporters of a move to ban busing for racial integration won another important round in the Senate today, but opponents of the measure used parliamentary maneuvers to delay final action.

title: Bangor Punta Net Off
description: The Bangor Punta Corporation, whose products include Piper airplanes and Smith & Wesson handguns, said today that its profit in the fourth quarter ended Sept. 30 fell 60.4 percent, to $1.9 million, or 25 cents a share, from $4.8 million, or 63 cents a share, in the 1980 quarter.

title: CITY TENTATIVELY PICKS SIX APPLICANTS FOR CABLE TV FRANCHISES
description: In a unanimous vote last night, the Board of Estimate made its preliminary selection of six companies for cable television franchise awards in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Ford Motor Restructuring
description: The Ford Motor Company said it was converting its huge steelmaking division, the nation's ninth-largest steel producer, into a wholly owned subsidiary to be called the Rouge Steel Company.

title: No Headline
description: MOSCOW SEES A DIRECT THREAT FROM POLAND'S 'ANTISOCIALISTS'

title: A FIRST FOR 2 CLARINETISTS AT HEAVENLY JAZZ SESSION
description: PHIL BODNER and Kenny Davern are versatile woodwind musicians who have both settled on the clarinet as their favorite jazz instrument. They have arrived at their choice from opposite directions - Mr. Bodner as a result of 40 years as a studio musician, playing for radio and recordings; Mr. Davern after a 25-year career in big bands and traditional jazz groups.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * A.H. Belo Corp. is offering 1,957,835 shares of common stock at $23 each, to be sold through a Goldman, Sachs group.

title: BARGAIN NIGHT WITH DICKENS
description: The intermission had lasted for almost a month, so when the 11 participants got together again the other evening they were eager to pick up where they had left off - at the conclusion of Chapter 29, when Nicholas announces the likelihood of his leaving Vincent Crummles and his theatrical troupe.

title: Joint Grading Set for Cotton
description: The New York Cotton Exchange and the New Orleans Commodity Exchange yesterday jointly announced agreement on a tentative plan to simplify the cotton certification process.

title: Prosecutor's Aides
description: Elizabeth Holtzman, who will take over as Brooklyn District Attorney on Jan. 1, named five top aides yesterday, including two holdovers from the office of the retiring District Attorney, Eugene Gold.

title: CIRCUS HIT BY FIRE PUTS ON ITS BEST FACE
description: A gallant troupe of jugglers, acrobats, clowns and musicians, along with a 4,000-pound baby elephant, offered their talents like holiday gifts last night to children from 11 social agencies and in foster care, many in wheelchairs.

title: SAKHAROVS REPORTED 'IN NO DANGER'
description: The president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences today told the young woman on whose behalf Andrei D. Sakharov went on a hunger strike that the physicist and his wife had halted their fast and were ''in no danger.''

title: VISA RESTRICTIONS HARD TO ENFORCE
description: The passport restrictions on travel to Libya announced today by the Reagan Administration would be difficult to enforce against anyone determined to go to that country, or to remain there, according to legal experts.

title: TENSIONS IN SOUTH ASIA
description: The danger of a new Indian-Pakistan war is looming steadily larger.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE* 15.50 15.50 20.00 DISCOUNT RATE** 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 12.25 12.27 20.14 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 10.66 10.36 17.05 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.30 10.99 15.67 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 14.08 13.96 13.48 30-YR. TREAS. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: OPEC EXTENDS TALKS ON PRICING DISPUTE
description: OPEC oil ministers failed Thursday to resolve a dispute over price differentials - the adjustments that allow members to charge more or less for their crude oil than the group's common base price of $34 a barrel.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss...C-After $551,000 tax charge

title: THEATER: RAQUEL WELCH IN 'WOMAN OF THE YEAR'
description: RAQUEL WELCH is ''filling in'' for Lauren Bacall in a most literal sense. While Miss Bacall has been on vacation, Miss Welch has made her Broadway debut in ''Woman of the Year,'' and she is an 8 x 10 glossy come to life. When she makes her first appearance in a low-cut gold lame gown, her attributes can be seen all the way to the mezzanine, where I sat at Wednesday's matinee to watch a gilt-edged, glamorous performance.

title: News Analysis
description: The Mobil Corporation has built a reputation as the bulldog of the oil industry, plunging headlong into fights that other companies would prefer to avoid.

title: ECONOMIC PANEL OFFERS REAGAN TOUGH CHOICE
description: President Reagan received sharply conflicting advice at a meeting with his panel of outside economic advisers today as the White House struggled to erase the impression that Mr. Reagan's economic recovery program had been crippled by economic stagnation and internal discord.

description: Bulgaria is not just a Soviet look- alike A2 Sakharov reported ''in no dan- ger'' after fast A3 Soviet Union assails Catholic Church in Poland A4 Around the World A6 Costa Ricans face a test of democ- racy A7 In Denmark, the Soviet Fork-and- Knife caper runs into trouble A11 Restrictions on Libyan travel will be hard for U.S. to enforce A12 Government/Politics Senate panel votes to veto F.T.C.'s proposed used car rule A17 Senate opponents block final ac- tion on busing bill A19 Bush aide gets No. 2 post at G.O.P. title: FOR MAYOR KOCH'S BUDGET: A 'HEAD TAX' ON VISITS FROM ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: McLouth Seeks Truck Group Sale
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation, which has sought protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said it was negotiating to sell its trucking operations to a group headed by the truck unit's chairman.

title: Wells, Rich, Greene Loses Citizen Account
description: Wells, Rich, Greene has lost the Citizen Watch Company business, according to Kenneth Olshan, president of W.R.G./East. This was confirmed by Hideo Saji, a vice president in the Lyndhurst, N.J., headquarters of the American operation of the Japanese company, who also confirmed that the agreement with Harshe-Rotman & Druck, his public relations firm, will be terminated Dec. 31. H.-R.& D. is merging with Ruder & Finn, the Timex watch public realtions firm, on Jan. 1.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1981
description: International A plea to Americans to leave Libya at once was issued by President Reagan, who also ordered the invalidation of American passports for travel to Libya. A senior Administration official said there were no immediate plans to halt Libyan oil imports or to impose additional sanctions against the Tripoli regime for what the White House terms its ''current lawless behavior.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) A departure of American technicians, who discovered oil in Libya in 1955 and have been the dominant force in increasing production, will cause serious problems for the industry, Tripoli's oil minister acknowledged. Industry analysts suggested that the withdrawal could prompt Libya to nationalize American oil holdings. (A1:5.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An item in the News of Music col- umn yesterday, on the winter sym- posium to be offered by the Conductors Guild of the American Symphony Or- chestra League, omitted the location. The symposium will be held Jan. 8 to 10 at the Pierpont Morgan Library in New York.

title: REPORT ON BURGER IS DISPUTED
description: A dispute developed today among former Nixon Administration officials over assertions in a book by John D. Ehrlichman that Chief Justice Warren E. Burger had ''openly discussed the pros and cons of issues before the Court'' with President Nixon.

title: Broadway; Eliot's book of cats about to have new life as a musical.
description: ANDREW LLOYD WEBBER came to town this week and confirmed the speculation that has been buzzing through Shubert Alley for weeks: his new show, ''Cats,'' which just received London's equivalent of the Tony Award as best musical of the season, will open on Broadway next fall. ''Cats'' is Mr. Lloyd Webber's musical adaptation of T.S. Eliot's ''Old Possum's Book of Practical Cats'' - a no more unlikely source for a musical than the lives of Jesus and Eva Peron, which Mr. Lloyd Webber and his longtime collaborator, the lyricist Tim Rice, turned into the hit shows ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' and ''Evita.''

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Aguirre Out a Month
description: Mark Aguirre, the leading scorer for the Dallas Mavericks, chipped a bone in the little toe of his right foot Wednesday night and will be sidelined at least a month. Aguirre, the top choice in the pro basketball college draft last June, was injured while driving for a layup in the Mavericks' 113-109 overtime loss to the Kansas City Kings.

title: Digital Closings
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, citing the economic downturn, said it had offered its 28 manufacturing plants the option of closing for four days after Christmas. Digital, which employs 65,000 workers nationwide, said that 13 of its plants employing 11,000 had accepted the plan and would close for four days between Christmas and New Year's. The closings are the first in Digital's 24-year history, the company said.

title: STAGE: 'GROWN UPS' BY FEIFFER AT LYCEUM
description: ''GROWN UPS'' is a new play by Jules Feiffer, and, yes, it is funny - savagely funny. That's Mr. Feiffer's way. But the laughter has a different ring this time - about halfway up the throat it turns into a gasp.

title: Killing of Child Denied
description: A woman who operated an unlicensed day care center pleaded not guilty Wednesday to charges that she killed an 11-month-old boy and abused 20 other children. Eleanor Nathan, 35, was accused of killing Matthew Cromwell, one of the children entrusted to her care.

title: Sports of The Times; Ali's Mystery Promoter
description: AMONG the tourist attractions here is Blackbeard's Tower, a small stone fortress from which the legendary pirate of nearly three centuries ago peered out across the azure sea. His name was Edward Teach, described as a massive man with a thick black beard tied with colored ribbons. Smoke often curled around his fierce face from smoldering ropes hanging from his tricornered hat, giving him a demonic appearance. Those he offered a drink of rum either accepted or risked being shot. Blackbeard and his pirates terrorized the islands here until 1718, when the first Royal Governor of what was then a British colony, Woodes Rogers, established law and order.

title: 2 CRITICS OF KUHN GAIN KEY OWNER POSTS
description: Edward Bennett Williams and Eddie Chiles, the two leading rebels among baseball's club owners in last summer's strike, were elected to important committee positions in the sport's high command today.

title: MR. REAGAN'S MIRRORS
description: After a year's trial, Reaganomics proves only one thing - you can't do it with mirrors. You can't cut taxes, increase military spending, balance the budget and curb inflation, all at once and without economic pain - which was basically the promise that elected Ronald Reagan.

title: RATES SHOW A GENERAL RISE
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday and prices declined as weak investor demand failed to overcome selling by traders and speculators.

title: Sims Honored
description: Kenneth Sims, the two-time all-America defensive tackle from Texas, received the Lombardi Award yesterday as the nation's best college football lineman. Sims finished ahead of Billy Ray Smith of Arkansas, Sean Farrell of Penn State and Bob Crable of Notre Dame in the balloting by coaches and journalists.

title: 3 HELD IN THEFT OF $2 MILLION IN A SHIPMENT
description: Three Brooklyn men were arrested yesterday in the theft of $2 million from a midtown bank last month. The money was being transferred from the Republic National Bank of New York at 452 Fifth Avenue to the Korean Exchange Bank in Seoul.

title: Record Field Tries For N.F.L. Playoffs
description: After 14 weeks of play and with two weeks left in the regular season, a record number of the National Football League's 28 teams are in contention for places in the playoffs. Only two, Dallas and San Francisco, have qualified for the 10 playoff positions.

title: At the Movies
description: EVEN though the Academy members have yet to cast a vote, many movie critics are convinced that Henry Fonda will walk away with this year's Best Actor award for his portrayal in ''On Golden Pond'' of a wry, witty, crotchety onetime college professor compelled to face the loss of his powers and the prospect of his own death.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
KNICKS' OVERTIME SURGE SUBDUES PISTONS, 106-101
description: The Knicks, seemingly headed for an easy victory over the Detroit Pistons, fell apart in the second half, but regrouped in overtime tonight for a 106-101 victory at the Silverdome. It was the third straight victory for the Knicks and their sixth in seven games, bringing their mark to 10-9.

title: Woman Well After Operation On 'Elephant Man' Disfiguring
description: A young woman suffering from Elephant Man's disease was in high spirits and recovering very well today from nine hours of radical and risky surgery.

title: REP. RICHMOND IS CONTRADICTED ON POLITICAL AID
description: Court records show that two employees of a public corporation founded and controlled by Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn acknowleged arranging annual political fund-raising events on his behalf during their regular working day on company time.

title: Guilty Boss, Vindicated System
description: Two systems have been on trial since Joseph Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican leader, was indicted a year ago. One was the system of unofficial government by which Mr. Margiotta fed insurance commissions to politically loyal brokers who did no work.

title: News Analysis
description: The assertion that Chief Justice Warren E. Burger discussed ''issues before the Court'' with President Nixon illustrates a dilemma that faces Supreme Court

title: No Headline
description: IRENE EPPLE WINS AGAIN

title: WOMAN FATALLY SHOT BY ROBBERS IN EAST SIDE APARTMENT BUILDING
description: A woman was fatally shot in the lobby of her East Side apartment house early yesterday morning by robbers who followed her and a male companion into the building, at 400 East 55th Street.

title: PIPELINE BILL GOES TO REAGAN
description: The House of Representatives, forced to vote for a second time on waivers that will allow the Alaskan natural gas pipeline to move to the financing stage, today confirmed the approval it gave Wednesday but by the somewhat smaller margin of 230 to 188.

title: Raiders of the Lost Stock Market
description: The action is on Wall Street, but the script could have been written in Hollywood. Unfortunately, the moral is not uplifting.

title: BRITISH VOTERS FIND AN ALTERNATIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Saturday Review Draws R.J. Reynolds Spread
description: James C. Mason, ad director and associate publisher of Saturday Review, took the pilgrimage to Winston-Salem, N.C., in search of some cigarette advertising from mighty R.J. Reynolds Tobacco.

title: IN DENMARK, POLICE THWART SOVIET CAPERS
description: Denmark's highest point is a 520-foot hill, and the seacoast is a very gradual lowering of the country's flatness into the Baltic and North Seas.

title: Funds' Assets Up $2.68 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $2.68 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 28th consecutive increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The funds' assets now stand at $185.53 billion after an average weekly increase this year of $2.3 billion.

title: A REPORT ON NITRITES FINDS CURED MEATS ARE RELATIVELY SAFE
description: An expert committee assessing the safety of nitrites and nitrates as food additives reported today that eliminating them from cured meats would probably not have a major impact on human health.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes equity in unremitted earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours ' Co of $27,738,000 and currency translation loss of $5,734,000...C-Includes currency translation loss of $6,345,000 income from discontinued operations of $6,802,000 and extraordianry gain on sale of oil and gas properties of $1,222,481,000; because Du Pont and Seagram use different accounting periods Seagram will include in its qrly reports its proportionate shr of Du Pont's earnings for the Du Pont qr ended one month earlier; Seagram's current fiscal yr ending July 31, 1982 will include the company's shrs of Du Pont earnin from Aug 17, 1981 through June 30, 1982

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS AT PEAK, U.S. FINDS
description: Enrollment in the nation's colleges and universities hit a high of 12.3 million this fall, the Government reported today.

title: Market Place; Boesky Plan For Vagabond
description: the-counter company two-thirds owned by the Ivan F. Boesky family, is likely to be four-fifths owned by it soon.

title: ELDERLY, THEN OLD
description: As I look back over 88 years of life, I can see little change in myself. Of course the wrinkles are new, and a mask of sophistication hides many things - but I am the same. I have grown old without really learning: still the same fears, the same vanities, the same lack of a sense of priorities.

title: PATRICIA HEARST SAYS SHE 'JUST PLAIN COULDN'T' FLEE HER CAPTORS
description: After three years out of the limelight, Patricia Hearst, now 26 years old, married to a San Francisco policeman and the mother of a 6-month-old daughter, has returned to center stage as the author of a book describing sensational details of her life with the Symbionese Liberation Army, a revolutionary group.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Economic Scene; Ambivalence About Inflation
description: WASHINGTON THE unauthorized publication of preliminary Administration budget deficit projections has brought to light ambivalence among the President's most senior advisers about how rapidly the Government should try to cool inflation.

title: Mobil Oil Drilling
description: The Mobil Corporation said it had started drilling for oil on Georges Bank, thus joining the Shell Oil Company and the Exxon Corporation in the search for petroleum in the rich fishing grounds.

title: Children's Illustrations
description: If you yearn to turn back the pages to childhood today, you'll be able to find illustrations from 170 children's books published this year at the Master Eagle Gallery, 40 West 25th Street. ''The Original Art,'' an exhibition that runs through February, includes black-andwhite line drawings by Garth Williams for ''Chester Cricket's Pigeon Ride''; a full-color jacket designed by Leo and Diane Dylan for ''Justice and her Brothers,'' and black line and watercolor illustrations by Hilary Knight for ''12 Days of Christmas.'' The gallery is open Monday to Friday from 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission is free.

title: Neal Boenzi A New Effort to Settle Carting Strike Is Begun Conferring before the start of yesterday's negotiating session in the 10-day-old carting walkout were from left: Bernard Edelstein, secretary-treasurer of Local 813 of the Teamsters; Sal Spinelli, attorney for the private carting companies, and James McCabe, state mediator.
description: Negotiators at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East 28th Street, sought to resolve an issue - involving the number of men needed on a truck en route to a dumping site -that has snagged talks. Officials said the issue's resolution could open the way for an eventual settlement.

title: News Analysis
description: All the signs today were that Andrei D. Sakharov had wrung from the Kremlin the immediate goal of his hunger strike, a visa for his stepson's wife by proxy to emigrate to the United States.

title: FOLK DANCE: FROM CHINA
description: ASIA SOCIETY came up with an unusual evening of dance on Wednesday at its Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium, when Xu Shuyin, a teacher at the Peking Dance Academy, gave a lecture-demonstration on folk dance forms from China.

title: CRIME LINKS CITED IN PENTHOUSE CASE
description: The president of La Costa, a multimillion-dollar resort and health spa in southern California, has said in court here that he knew his business partner was a onetime bootlegger and operator of an illegal gambling house in Ohio.

title: KOCH CONSIDERS DRIVE TO RECRUIT PUBLIC ON CRIME
description: Mayor Koch and Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said last night that the city had consulted David Garth, Mr. Koch's media adviser, about a large-scale campaign to ''mobilize the public'' in crime-prevention efforts.

title: FIFTH AVENUE CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HUNGARY'S 'OFFSHORE' BANK
description: One of the most encouraging sights a Western banker or executive will see in Eastern Europe these days lies up two flights of stairs in a squat office building at 54 Bartfai Utca, a dreary street in suburban Budapest lined with workers' apartments.

title: Design Show Honors Century of Architects
description: Architects prominent in the last century, many of them connected with Columbia University, will be remembered in an exhibition at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue, between 89th and 90th Streets, until Jan. 15. The show, called ''The Making of an Architect 1881-1981: Columbia University in the City of New York,'' features four galleries of drawings, models and photographs, many never before on public display.

title: Saudi Crown Prince to Meet With President Next Month
description: Crown Prince Fahd, who runs the day-today affairs of Saudi Arabia, will meet with President Reagan on Jan. 19, the White House announced today.

title: U.S. STEEL LACKING CASH TO FIGHT MOBIL
description: When David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, spoke to a group of analysts last month, someone asked if he was worried about the possiblity of waking up one day to find that his company was a takeover target.

title: Auctions; Stage designs up for bids.
description: EACH December the auction of ballet, theater, opera and film material at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries appears to grow larger. In this year's sale, next Tuesday at 2 P.M., there are more than 200 lots of costumes and scenic designs, books, photographs and posters from the performing arts.

title: COSTA RICA DEBT TALKS TO RESUME NEXT MONTH
description: A two-day meeting between Costa Rican authorities and representatives of a dozen banks, held to discuss a rescheduling of the Central American country's $2.6 billion foreign debt, ended inconclusively yesterday. Further talks have been postponed until mid-January.

title: U.S. ENDS ITS ROLE IN WEST SIDE RENEWAL
description: The Federal Government has informed Mayor Koch that it is ending its 22-year supervision of the West Side Urban Renewal Plan in Manhattan.

title: MINNESOTA FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: the 1980 figures were for the qr ended Sept 27

title: OPERA: 'RIGOLETTO' AT THE MET
description: IN ''Rigoletto'' Verdi demonstrates again and again - from the delivery of the curse to Gilda's approaching death - that dramatic intensity lies in the threat of an event rather than its occurrence. At the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday night, the opera never fully achieved that sense of encroaching doom, but there were a few fine moments along the way. All are likely to be shared with a larger audience, as next Tuesday night the identical cast is being taped for a television broadcast later on PBS.

title: FACE RECONSTRUCTION IDENTIFIES UNKNOWN DEAD
description: Violence took their lives. Then decay erased their faces and any chance they might have had at justice. They are the unidentified dead, found skeletonized, burned or too badly decomposed to recognize, hopeless cases accompanied by no papers, no mementos, no clues.

title: MEXICAN BORDER AGENTS WARNED OF ASSASSIN TEAMS
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has told border agents to be on the lookout for two assassination squads from Libya, including one headed by the notorious international terrorist known as Carlos and dubbed ''the Jackal'' by the British press.

title: HIJACKERS SURRENDER IN BEIRUT
description: Displaying the victory sign, the three gunmen who hijacked a Libyan airliner over Italy on Monday, freed their hos-tages yesterday after landing in Beirut, Lebanon, for the third time. According to officials, the passengers and crew were exhausted by their 7,500-mile, 52-hour ordeal.

title: BRITISH VOTERS FIND AN ALTERNATIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP POST AT GOTTLIEB FILLED BY A NEWCOMER
description: Boyd W. Browne, 51, has joined D. Gottlieb & Company, manufacturer of coin-operated amusement machines with headquarters in Northlake, Ill., as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Robert W. Bloom, 39, who resigned from the Columbia Pictures Industries subsidiary ''to pursue other long-term interests.''

title: PENTAGON LIFTS CONTROLLER BAN
description: The Defense Department, following President Reagan's lead, today lifted a ban on military enlistment of the dismissed civilian air traffic controllers.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Because of the danger which the Libyan regime poses to American citizens, the President calls upon all Americans to leave Libya as soon as possible.'' - Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark. (A12:2.)

title: METRO AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After extraordinary credits of $46,000 for the qr and $80,000 for the 6 mos

title: American Invsco Gets Help From Its Lenders
description: American Invsco, the troubled real estate empire controlled by the Gouletas family, said today that it had reached ''a preliminary understanding'' for financial concessions from its major banks.

title: STEADY, IF DULL, COURSE WINS VOLCKER RESPECT
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is becoming one of the more boring people in Washington. And he admits it.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
GLITTERY WORLD OF TWO JEWELERS
description: Both couples seem to skim along comfortably on the chic crest of New York society. Yet for one pair what is a city of wonder and glitter is at the same time ''like being in a golden jail,'' and for the other it is a pressure-cooker existence that must be fled periodically ''to clear one's head.''

title: BULGARIA A RUSSIAN LOOK-ALIKE? WELL LOOK AGAIN
description: At first glance, Sofia looks like a provincial town in the Soviet Union - gray, sooty, down at the heel, with a huge central square dominated by a Stalin-Gothic building housing Communist Party offices.

title: No Headline
description: NOBEL WINNERS SUPPORT SAKHAROV

title: STYLIZED, OFFBEAT 'PENNIES FROM HEAVEN'
description: THE place is Chicago and the time is 1934, the year of the Chicago World's Fair that celebrated ''a century of progress,'' though the country was then in the midst of the greatest economic depression it had ever known.

title: Broadcast Deregulation
description: The Senate Commerce Committee today approved a bill that would deregulate the broadcast industry and insulate both radio and television stations from certain types of challenges to their licenses. The bill, passed 17 to 0, is designed to put into law a radio deregulation order adopted by the Federal Communications Commission early this year. It would prevent the F.C.C. from ever reimposing old rules requiring minimum amounts of news and public affairs programming.

title: Seagram Net Up 27%
description: The Seagram Company, the world's biggest distiller, said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 27 percent from a year earlier, excluding last year's one-time gain of $1.22 billion from the sale of oil and gas properties.

title: CITY COUNCIL DEFEATS A MOVE TO RESTORE HOMOSEXUAL BILL
description: An attempt to resurrect a proposal to ban discrimination against homosexuals was defeated by the City Council yesterday. The vote was 24 to 18, with one member absent.

title: HARTFIELD-ZODY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: B-Including $1.6 million extraordinary credit

title: TO CURE THE AILMENTS OF AFRICAN AGRICULTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH AIDE NAMED TO POST WITH G.O.P. PANEL
description: Richard N. Bond, an aide to Vice President Bush, was named deputy chairman of the Republican National Committee today, but the appointment, made to repair fissures in the party, has already raised questions among conservative groups.

title: New Unrest Breaks Out In Gainesville Section
description: Stone-@ and bottle-throwing broke out today for a second day in an area here where the shooting of a black teen-ager by a white policeman led to a disturbance, the officials said.

title: All the Trimmings
description: Vice President Bush, remarks on regulatory revision before the International Management and Development Institute, Dec. 7: One measure of what we've accomplished is the number of pages in the Federal Register. We're trying to get the Register down from the size of a copy of ''War and Peace'' to the size of, say, a few issues of the ''Atlantic Monthly.''

title: A NEGLECTED PAINTER GETTING HIS DUE AT LAST
description: THERE are artists who look better and better to us with the passage of time, and the American painter Arnold Friedman (1874-1946) is one of them. The exhibition of his paintings now on view at the Zabriskie Gallery, 29 West 57th Street (through Jan. 2), is therefore a welcome event.

title: MARGIOTTA AND AIDES DISCUSS THE NEXT MOVE
description: Yesterday, the day after his conviction for extortion, Joseph M. Margiotta met with the leaders who had helped him to make the Nassau County Republican Party the strongest in New York.

title: GREECE LIMITS ITS NATO ROLE
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said tonight that Greece was proceeding to limit its military commitments within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to that of ''command cooperation, participation in military staff groups.''

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE former Senate aides came back from California and Boston, from New York and Texas to hear again the voice of Jacob K. Javits on Capitol Hill. Looking frail, Mr. Javits arrived in a wheelchair at the private club down from the Capitol. But then he carefully stood and walked to the platform to address 125 of his own brightest and best, now scattered busily beyond his finished career in the Senate.

title: SENATE PRESSES TRIMMED-DOWN FARM MEASURE
description: The Senate approved an $11 billion farm bill today and sent it to the House, where the Reagan Administration expects a struggle to win approval of the compromise measure next week.

title: FISCHBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PENN'S '4 FRIENDS,' TALE OF 60'S
description: TO get quickly to the point, ''Four Friends'' is the best film yet made about the 60's, that harrowed time of war, prosperity and broken promises, of turning on and dropping out to colors described as psychedelic, when establishment came to be written with a capital ''E.''

title: Rozelle's Plea
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League urged a House Judiciary subcommittee to support legislation that would define the league as a single entity of 28 partners instead of 28 separate interests. Rozelle told the subcommittee that current antitrust laws, which have caused 50 antitrust complaints against the N.F.L. since 1966, had ''tied the league's hands.'' If the legislation becomes law, it would severely hamper such efforts as those of Al Davis, whose antitrust suit against the league seeks a ruling against N.F.L. bylaws that have prevented Davis's Oakland Raiders from moving to Los Angeles.

title: TRIMS FOREIGN AID
description: Republican moderates reversed themselves today and gave President Reagan a victory in the Democraticcontrolled House on an omnibus spending bill to finance the Government through March 31. The $413 billion bill would reduce spending by $4 billion beyond the President's initial budget request last March.

title: N.F.L. Nears Completion Of Inquiry in Stabler Case
description: The National Football League will announce within two weeks whether Ken Stabler, the Houston Oiler quarterback, violated league regulations by associating with a convicted bookmaker from Perth Amboy.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's admission that its economic program is not averting $100 billion deficits is like the Carter Administration's tolerating recession in 1980. From within, each step seemed like a recognition of reality. But to outsiders, each exemplified the great risk politicians take when they appear to abandon central elements of their fundamental philosophy.

title: Restaurants; French dining, fine and festive.
description: AS though it were not difficult enough to keep his first restaurant, Le Lavandou, operating at a consistent two-star level through the years, Jean Jacques Rachou, the chef-owner, bought La Cote Basque on East 55th Street in the spring of 1980. Almost immediately, he brought that much-neglected culinary landmark up to the same rating, and now he has managed to correct so many of the early shortcomings that La Cote Basque merits three stars.

title: MOTOROLA TO ACQUIRE COMPUTER MAKER
description: Motorola Inc., a leading manufacturer of semiconductors and communications equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Four-Phase Systems Inc., a maker of computer systems, for stock valued at about $250 million.

title: Nissalke Ousted by Jazz
description: The Utah Jazz, struggling with an 8-12 record and faced with dwindling attendance, dismissed Coach Tom Nissalke today and replaced him with General Manager Frank Layden.

title: GUIDRY AND YANKS NEAR AN AGREEMENT
description: Ron Guidry, who has been a free agent the past month, is close to returning to the Yankees, his agent said early today.

title: Chandler Keeps Title, Stops Murata in 13th
description: Undefeated Jeff Chandler continued his on-the-job-training as the World Boxing Association bantamweight champion tonight with a 13th-round knockout of Eijiro Murata of Japan.

title: Article 127396 -- No Title
description: Winning out over strong competition from other museums, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired a gift of 60 major works of early Chinese painting and calligraphy. It is from a collection regarded as the world's greatest concentration of such art in private hands.

title: SCM Layoffs Set
description: The SCM Corporation said that its Proctor-Silex division, a maker of automatic coffee makers and other kitchen appliances, would shut its plant here for three and a half weeks and lay off 950 workers because of sluggish sales. The layoffs will take effect on Dec. 23 and last until Jan. 18, the company said.

title: HOLIDAY DANCE STOCKING OFFERS CHOICES FROM CLASSIC TO MODERN
description: COME the first cold day or tinkling burst of holiday music from a nearby store, and dance fans start to think about ''The Nutcracker.'' But the holiday dance season is more than ''Nuts,'' as it is familiarly known. There is dance of a wide variety of styles and personalities around this weekend, from the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater at City Center to an Iraqi folk troupe at Roseland, from Meredith Monk, master experimentalist, at the Public Theater, to a parable about Santa Claus and a unicorn uptown at City College's Aaron Davis Hall.

title: TAX POLICY IS CRITICIZED IN FORECAST BY BUSINESS
description: The economists for the Business Council, which represents the nation's largest corporations, contend that the Reagan Administration's tax cuts to encourage savings could hurt the push for new business investment that is at the heart of the President's program to fight inflation and increase economic growth.

title: PROTESTS GROW IN MANILA SINCE EASING OF LAW
description: More than 1,000 people crowded into the gymnasium of a seminary here today to call for the release of political detainees and the end of purported civil rights abuses by the Philippine military.

title: Pop Jazz; MOTOWN STARS SHINE AGAIN AT PALLADIUM TOMORROW
description: THE story of Motown Records is one of the most astonishing success stories in the history of American popular music. The black record producer and song writer Berry Gordy Jr. started the company in Detroit in 1960 with an $800 loan from his family. By 1963, Motown was selling so many single records that it had only two serious competitors -the corporate giants CBS and RCA. In 1963, Motown's artist roster included Smokey Robinson and the Miracles, Martha and the Vandellas, the Temptations, the Supremes with Diana Ross and Stevie Wonder. It was in that year that Berry Gordy established a traveling show that brought Motown's top stars and its up-and-comers into theaters and stadiums across the United States and Europe. The show was called the Motortown Revue.

title: GULF NUCLEAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: 1981 shr earnings do not reflect shrs issued in a public offering Nov 4, 1981

title: Bankrupt Auto-Train Auctions Off Wares
description: Bargain-seekers packed the Auto-Train terminal Wednesday, snatching up silver dining trays, door locks and even trainmen's uniforms in the second day of a bankruptcy sale.

title: PUBLISHING: NEW INTEREST MARKS ZWEIG CENTENARY
description: Fifty years ago, Stefan Zweig was one of the world's most famous writers, published in more than 40 languages and admired by readers as diverse as Freud, Einstein, Toscanini, Thomas Mann and Herman Goering. His biography of Balzac received a rave review on the front page of The New York Times Book Review and his ''Letter From an Unknown Woman'' was made into a film by Max Ophuls with Joan Fontaine and Louis Jourdan.

title: Holland America Selects Chiat/Day
description: Holland America Cruises, having staged a competition involving some of the nation's leading ad agencies, has selected Chiat/Day, New York, the branch of the Los Angeles agency.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; the 1980 results reflected losses of about $600,000 from discontinued operations

title: Bridge: Test of Analytical Ability Offered by English Writer
description: Players who fancy their analytical ability are often faced with a piece of paper and the challenge ''Look at this hand - would you rather play or defend?'' If you accept the challenge on today's deal, the lead is the diamond queen against a contract of three hearts.

title: Rights Abuses in Africa Reported by U.S. Aide
description: A State Department official told Congress today that there are still serious human rights violations occurring in Zaire, Ethiopia and other African countries.

title: Meriweather Sidelined
description: Joe C. Meriweather, the Kansas City Kings' center, has been lost for the season following knee surgery, the club said today.

title: ANOTHER PUBLISHER FINDS PROBLEMS WITH SECRECY
description: The poet W.H. Auden objected to blurbs on his books because he considered them an embarrassment, but most authors and publishers these days think that blurbs, those brief endorsements by recognizable names, help sell books. A recent three-page release from Doubleday, publicizing Garson Kanin's new book ''Together Again,'' contains blurbs from 31 authors and show business personalities.

title: World Bank Peru Loan
description: The World Bank said today that it would lend $26 million to the central bank of Peru to help increase small enterprise in that South American country.

title: HEARING HALTED FOR JUDGE'S TRIP TO WILLOWBROOK
description: Hearings into conditions at the Staten Island Developmental Center in Willowbrook resumed yesterday, but were interrupted when Judge John R. Bartels suddenly decided to visit the institution.

title: 21 Killed, 60 Wounded In North Lebanon Unrest
description: Lebanon's continuing wave of violence spread today to the northern part of the country, where a bombing and a raid by gunmen left 21 people dead and 60 wounded.

title: '82 BUSINESS SPENDING RISE SEEN
description: The nation's businesses plan to increase their spending on new plants and equipment 1.8 percent - after adjustment for inflation - in the first half of 1982 over the last half of this year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Seton Hall President Inaugurated in Jersey
description: The 17th president of Seton Hall University was inaugurated in ceremonies today at the school's South Orange campus.

title: POP: LYNNIE GODFREY AT SWEETWATER'S
description: LYNNIE GODFREY first made herself known on Broadway in the musical, ''Eubie!,'' when she lay back on a piano, stretched one leg straight up and, gently twisting the foot on the end of that leg, milked the song, ''Daddy,'' for all of its sensuous worth. At Sweetwater's, Amsterdam Avenue at 68th Street, where she will be singing until the night after Christmas, she is reminding listeners of that debut, offering some previews of ''Stringbean,'' a musical scheduled for next spring in which she will play Ethel Waters, and revealing a capacity for both comedy and characterization.

title: U.S. DEFERS ACTION ON DRAFT REFUSERS
description: The Justice Department said today that it would delay seeking criminal charges against young men for failing to register with the Selective Service System until the Reagan Administration decided whether to continue the program.

title: DANCE: OLD STURBRIDGE VILLAGE TROUPE
description: AMID all the hoopla of the so-called dance explosion, the charm of simplicity still finds its place. The latest example comes from ''A Flute, a Fiddle, a Federal Period Dance,'' a program of early 19thcentury American social dances presented Wednesday night by the Old Sturbridge Village Dancers and Musicians at the Abigail Adams Smith Museum.

title: FOR 5TH AVENUE, 2 SUNDAYS OF PARTYING
description: Fifth Avenue is having a party this Sunday and next and everybody is invited, as long as they arrive on foot. Vehicular traffic will be banned from 34th to 57th Streets between 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. on both days and a heady array of free entertainment is in store at three locations: a stage between 54th and 55th Streets, the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral and the steps of the New York Public Library. The occasion is the annual ''Fifth Avenue Holiday Festival.''

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 11, 1981; International
description: President Reagan appealed to Americans to leave Libya immediately and invalidated American passports for travel to that country. But he stopped short of embargoing Libyan oil or seeking additional sanctions against the Tripoli Government. (Page A1.) Several oil companies said they would withdraw their employees but would not end their production contracts. Marathon Oil will remove all its American workers, while Occidental Petroleum and Exxon are offering to evacuate any employees who wish to leave. (A1.)

title: 16 Saved on Danish Tanker
description: Sixteen crewmen from the Danish-owned oil tanker Maersk Angus were plucked to safety by helicopter today as the ship, its engines failed, drifted toward a cluster of islands off western Scotland, the coast guard said.

title: MCENROE, VILAS TO OPEN CUP
description: Military jeeps, high-school bands, majorettes, horse-drawn carriages and politicians paraded through Fountain Square today before John McEnroe and Guillermo Vilas were drawn for the opening singles match in the Davis Cup final between the United States and Argentina.

title: JOHN KIERAN, COLUMNIST, RADIO HOST, NATURALIST
description: John F. Kieran, a sports columnist for The New York Times from 1927 to 1943 and a regular panelist on the popular radio and television programs ''Information Please,'' died yesterday at his home in Rockport, Mass., at the age of 89.

title: Angolan Leader Seeks Talks With U.S. on Ties
description: President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola offered today to hold talks with the United States with a view to normalizing relations between the two countries.

title: PRESIDENT'S POLICIES ON ECONOMY PRAISED BY STATE LEGISLATORS
description: State legislators meeting here expressed support for President Reagan's economic policies today, in sharp contrast to the harsh criticism leveled at the President recently by governors of both political parties.

title: Walker Won't Play
description: Attorneys for Carlton Walker, the offensive guard for the University of Wisconsin who has been ruled ineligible for postseason play because of a recruiting violation, were denied a bid yesterday to restrain the university and the National Collegiate Athletic Association from keeping Walker out of the Badger lineup for the Garden State Bowl on Sunday. The N.C.A.A. had turned down Wisconsin's effort to get Walker reinstated, and the university abided by that decision, but Walker's attorneys requested a temporary injunction that would have allowed him to play. Walker was barred for allowing a Wisconsin alumnus to pay his expenses at a Miami fishing resort for two days in September 1980, during which time he signed with the Badgers.

title: RULE ON USED CARS REJECTED BY PANEL
description: The Senate Commerce Committee voted overwhelmingly today against a rule that would require automobile dealers to inform potential buyers about known defects in the used cars they sell.

title: A ST. NICHOLAS PAGEANT IS OFFERED AT ST. JOHN'S
description: Every December as Christmas approaches, a personnage rather cheerily referred to as ''Saint Nick'' is feted in song and story. He is so closely identified with Christmas and its lore -The stockings were hung by the chimney with care In hopes that St. Nicholas soon would be there - that most people, if asked who or what he was, would probably describe Santa Claus.

title: EPHEMERA FAIR: SWEET NOSTALGIA TIME AT GARDEN
description: Remember the Mickey Mouse watch that lived in your dresser drawer until your parents finally threw it away when you turned 14? What about your doll collection? Or that cache of comic books you forced yourself to give up the day you graduated from college?

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard MIXED COMPANY. Women in the Modern Army. By Helen Rogan. 333 pages. Put- nam. $14.95.

title: Abuses in Gun Control Described to Senators
description: Several persons told sympathetic senators their stories Wednesday about what they called abuse at the hands of agents of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms enforcing the Gun Control Act of 1968.

title: Harold J. Brady, 85, Is Dead; Father of Reagan Press Aide
description: Harold J. Brady, father of James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, died today in St. Mary's Hospital from a sudden illness, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; A FARCE AT THE GUGGENHEIM
description: A farce will unfold in unusual surroundings - the rotunda of the Guggenheim Museum -at 8 tonight through Sunday night, when the museum presents scenes from ''The Magnanimous Cuckold'' by the Belgian playwright Fernand Crommelynck. Staged in conjunction with the museum's ''Art of the Avant-Garde in Russia: Selections from the George Costakis Collection'' exhibition, it recreates Vsevolod Meyerhold's 1922 Moscow production, with its Constructivist stage set of stairs, wheels, windmill blades and geometric patterns. The program will include introductory comments, a demonstration of Meyerhold's ''biomechanical'' exercises and reminiscences by the actress Stella Duff-Ogonkova, who appeared in the original production. At Fifth Avenue and 89th Street. Seats at $5 each are sold out, but limited standing room at $4 a person is still available. GLASS QUARTET IN SOHO

title: Bethlehem Steel Sells Tax Credits
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said it had agreed to sell an unspecified amount of tax credits to the R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company, a Chicago-based printing and publishing company, for about $45 million.

title: Jobless Worker Guilty Of Slaying Ribicoff Niece
description: A jury today found Frederick Jerome Thomas, an unemployed laborer, guilty of murder in the fatal shooting of Sarai Ribicoff, niece of former Senator Abraham Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Herschel Walker, the two-time all-America tailback from Georgia, plans to run in the 55-meter dash at the United States Olympic Invitational meet Jan. 16 at the Meadowlands. ... Gerald Sarama, a leading harness driver at Roosevelt Raceway, was removed from the intensive-care unit at Nassau Medical Center yesterday after spending the night there. Sarama, who is 39 years old, was pinned under a horse in a spill, and doctors discovered that he had internal bleeding. ... Deane Beman, commissioner of professional golf's Tournament Players Association, announced yesterday that a major T.P.A. tournament will be played in Japan next November. It will be the first T.P.A.-sponsored tournament other than the Canadian Open ever held outside the United States.

title: Salvadoran Army Units Start Major Campaign
description: The Government said today that 1,500 troops had begun a major operation in Morazan Province, a mountainous region in northeast El Salvador where rebels control extensive territory.

title: SOME WHO SEND AID TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST CITE SPECIAL INTERESTS
description: Some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ask that their donations be directed toward the easing of problems in which they have a special interest.

title: Knight-Ridder Cable Venture
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. said it had agreed to a joint venture with Tele-Communications Inc., one of the nation's largest cable television companies, to buy, develop and operate cable television systems.

title: GRADING ERROR PROMPTS REVIEW OF VERMONT BAR TEST SYSTEM
description: The Vermont Supreme Court has ordered a thorough review of the system by which prospective lawyers are tested for admission to the state's bar.

title: Cotton Harvest Up 40%
description: The 1981 United States cotton harvest is expected to produce almost 15.6 million bales, 40 percent larger than last year's drought-reduced crop, the Department of Agriculture said today.

title: Qaddafi Talks of Attacking U.S. Warships on Maneuvers
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said in an interview that was televised today that ''our duty requires us to attack the American Sixth Fleet'' when it stages maneuvers near Middle Eastern shores.

title: Six Coal Miners Killed in Two Explosions Are Buried
description: The coffin of Keith Crager being borne yesterday to its gravesite in the snow-covered Appalachian Mountains near Hueysville, Ky. Mr. Crager was killed Monday in an explosion in a mine in nearby Topmost. The seven others who died in the accident will be buried today. Five of 13 miners killed Tuesday in an explosion in Whitewell, Tenn., were also buried yesterday near their homes.

title: U.S. PROSECUTOR MAY WEIGH CHARGES INVOLVING DONOVAN
description: The following article is based on reporting by Leslie Maitland and Michael Oreskes and was written by Miss Maitland:

title: Futures Board Nominee
description: President Reagan intends to nominate Kalo A. Hineman, a Kansas state legislator and cattleman, to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the White House announced today. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Hineman, 59 years old, would serve until 1986. He would succeed Robert L. Martin.

title: KRIS KRISTOFFERSON AND JANE FONDA IN 'ROLLOVER'
description: IS the Arab Euro-dollar really a good subject for movie banter? Somehow, somebody thought so. In ''Rollover,'' Kris Kristofferson and Jane Fonda play a banker and a board chairman who confer incessantly about financial matters at the multi-multi-megabuck level. The dramatic possibilities of the material are weak at best, and its satirical underpinnings are nowhere to be found.

title: A KEY WITNESS AGAINST SCHOOL SEGREGATION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Election Unit Sees Error in Reagan's Fund
description: The Federal Election Commission has concluded that Ronald Reagan's campaign committee made a $1.1 million bookkeeping mistake but that no harm was done and the money did not have to be returned to the Government.

title: Thrift Units Are Merged
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it had arranged the acquisition of two ailing savings and loan associations in Boca Raton, Fla., and Newark by the City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Stones in the Aegean
description: Greece's new Socialist Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, has a problem. He came to power talking neutralism and needs to prove he meant it. So he threatens Greece's ''disengagement'' from NATO unless he gets what the alliance cannot give: a guarantee of Greek territory against ''aggression'' by Turkey, another NATO ally. Mr. Papandreou also knows who will benefit if he pushes too hard - an Aegean nation, but not Greece.

title: ART: THE NEWS IS ALL FROM WEST GERMANY
description: IT would have been difficult to go to the galleries last week and not notice a germination of Germans all over the town. What they will grow into remains to be seen; but meanwhile here they are, sprouting away in ever greater numbers. Do they need watering? Potting and replanting? Cutting down and weeding out? These are pertinent questions.

title: RELIGIOUS GROUPS LUKEWARM TO CITY HOMELESS PLAN
description: A plea by Mayor Koch to New York City's religious leaders to open their churches and synagogues to the city's homeless received a lukewarm reception yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about projectile toys incorrectly identified Ann Brown. She is chairman of the consumer affairs committee of the Americans for Democratic Action.

title: MIDTOWN APARTMENTS WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: The 12-story building at 22 West 26th Street, built in 1916 for light manufacturing and now being converted into a cooperative residence by the Royalex Realty Corporation, has several distinctive features.

title: NICARAGUA'S PATH OF MODERATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes Made At Tracy-Locke
description: Tracy-Locke Advertising and Public Relations, one of the prides of Dallas, has played musical board room chairs that left Norman W. Campbell, 47 years old, still chief executive but now chairman as well.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS STRUGGLING AGAINST SMUGGLERS IN NIGERIA
description: Efforts of the Johnson Products Company to bolster its sagging profits by establishing an operation in Nigeria have suffered a setback from the illegal flow of its products into that country.

title: WILDER'S 'BUDDY BUDDY'
description: ''BUDDY BUDDY,'' Billy Wilder's new farce, is slight but irresistible. It has a screenplay by Mr. Wilder and his longtime collaborator, I.A.L. Diamond (''Some Like It Hot'' and ''The Apartment,'' among others).
