It stars Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau, actors who were obviously made for each other, as, respectively, Victor Clooney, a mild-mannered censor for the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Trabucco (his only name), a grumpy hulk who walks as if his feet hurt and makes his living as a mob hit-man.

title: Have a Baby! Get $14 a Day!
description: When unmarried teen-agers become pregnant, as a startling proportion now do, they can choose abortion, adoption, marriage or welfare. Some people say it is that last option, the Government dole, that is encouraging the tremendous upsurge in children having children.

title: 3 SEIZED IN STAKEOUT AS ABDUCTION VICTIM IS FREED ON EAST SIDE
description: A New York State correction officer and two other men were arrested last night 10 hours after kidnapping the 27-year-old manager of a Manhattan pet shop, the police said. No ransom was paid, and the victim was rescued unharmed.

title: ELECTRONIC EARS SPROUT ATOP SOVIET EMBASSY
description: More than pigeons and sparrows roost on the roof of the Soviet Embassy these days. There are spies up there, too. Not human spies, of course, but high-frequency antennas capable of picking up much of what is said by Government officials over telephones in the nation's capital. At times, the harvest could be abundant.

title: TV Weekend; VIETNAM VETERANS SPEAK; CHRISTMAS SPECIALS BEGIN
description: VIETNAM veterans, described as ''the forgotten warriors of a war America does not want to remember,'' are the subject of an exceptionally insightful and poignant documentary on CBS-TV, Channel 2, tomorrow at 10 P.M. ''Bittersweet Memories: A Vietnam Reunion'' represents an unusual venture for television. It was produced in cooperation with Newsweek magazine, which this week is featuring a cover story on the soldiers of Charlie Company, who saw combat in Vietnam in the 1960's. Of the 80 men interviewed for the story, 30 were brought, along with some of their wives, by CBS News to a threeday gathering in Florida.

title: Princeton Triangle Club Visiting L.I. Tonight
description: The Princeton Triangle Club has dug 50 years into its history to come up with this year's revue, ''Fool's Gold,'' which will be presented tonight at 8 at Weber Junior High School in Port Washington, L.I. .

title: IN CITY WAR ON TRAFFIC, SOME WIN, SOME LOSE
description: The addition of a Queens-bound lane in the Queens-Midtown Tunnel during the evening rush hours, one of several procedures put into effect by the city to cope with holiday traffic, has worked so well that it will probably be kept as a permanent fixture.

title: A BATTLE OVER VIDEO CASSETTES
description: A bitter tug-of-war that could shape the future of the video cassette industry is taking place over how the revenues from the booming business of renting prerecorded cassettes should be divided.

title: RUSSELL BURDSALL & WARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THE EVENING HOURS
description: A FTER a week of parties, dancing slippers are down at the heels, dinner jackets need to be pressed, ball gowns have trampled hems. And sales of headache remedies are undoubtedly up, along with sales of Champagne and caviar.

title: SINGING IN THE RAIN
description: Just when the Atlantic alliance has begun to face up to its serious problem of addressing public opinion, along comes Greece's new Prime Minister to demonstrate the disruption fancy tricks can cause.

title: A CHILLING START TO 'HEAT SEASON'
description: Johnnie Watts is a pleasant man with a deep, reassuring voice and a remarkably patient ear. In short, he is ideally suited to his work as a telephone operator in New York City's busy Central Complaint Bureau.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $2,575,000 or 41 cents a shr gain from the sale of 370,000 shrs of Boston Digiial stock; shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Sept 1980

title: No Headline
description: TEXT OF THE ADMINISTRATION'S STATEMENT ON POLICY TOWARD LIBYA

title: MARGIOTTA JURORS RECALL NO DIFFICULTY ON VERDICT
description: The jury of seven men and five women that convicted Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican Party chairman of Nassau County, of mail fraud and extortion charges on Wednesday did so without acrimonious debate or doubt, according to several of its members.

title: NATO ALLIES REFUSE TO BACK U.S. ACTIONS AGAINST LIBYA
description: The United States actions against Libya today received no allied backing even though Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. had said he would welcome ''their understanding and support.''

title: CON ED FINED $40,000 IN INDIAN POINT 2 RADIATION
description: The staff of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Comission said yesterday that it would fine Consolidated Edison $40,000 for not protecting workers from radiation at its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK NAMES NEW CHIEF
description: J.Carter Bacot, the 48-year-old president of the Bank of New York, has been named to the additional position of chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Elliott Averett, who will continue as chairman until his retirement in January 1983, when he will be 65.

title: FOLK MUSIC: HOLY MODAL DUO RETURNS
description: PETER STAMPFEL and Steve Weber, the Original Holy Modal Rounders, have been an underground folk-music legend for 15 years, and on Wednesday the duo made the second of three local appearances to promote their recent album, ''Goin' Nowhere Fast,'' at the Bottom Line. Stampfel & Weber's music is a singular blend of accelerated old-timey and blue-grass tunes with hip lyrics that have a zany, speed-rapping sense of fun edged with social satire.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: STAGE: 'BROKEN WORDS,' VERSE IN PERFORMANCE
description: THE beauty of the English language is extolled in ''Behind the Broken Words,'' an anthology of poetry devised and performed by Roscoe Lee Browne and Anthony Zerbe. Unmannered and eloquent, the evening opened Tuesday at the American Place Theater.

title: Helping Hands
description: An ailiing Margaret Assuman traveled from a remote village in Ghana last May to see her son, Kofi Atta-Mensah, graduate from the Cornell University Medical College. She is returning home this weekend with a clean bill of health.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anaconda Copper Co., a subsidiary of the Atlantic Richfield Co., said it would change its name to the Anaconda Minerals Co. effective Jan. 1.

title: Immunity of Witness Upheld
description: A judge today dismissed conspiracy charges against a Nashville liquor dealer indicted after receiving immunity for testifying against a former Tennessee Governor. Federal District Judge L. Clure Morton said that there was no evidence that the dealer, Jack Ham, had lied in his testimony against former Gov. Ray Blanton, who was convicted with two others on licensing conspiracy charges.

title: Martin Gets Ready For Cards' Offense
description: This is George Martin's seventh season in pro football and his seventh with the Giants. This one is different.

title: SYLVIA MARLOWE, A HARPSICHORDIST
description: Sylvia Marlowe, the harpsichordist, died of emphysema at Memorial Hospital yesterday. She was 73 years old. Though deeply involved with the music of the 17th and 18th centuries, Miss Marlowe is perhaps best remembered for her commissions of new music - especially chamber music involving the harpsichord.

title: When Last Seen
description: The back of their van was a jumble of blankets and sleeping children so Gary and Mary Karr did not make their usual head check before leaving a rest stop at a St. Louis service station Tuesday night.

title: No Headline
description: Samuel Serrano of Puerto Rico, showering left jabs at Hikaru Tomonari of Japan, scored a 12th-round knockout tonight to retain his World Boxing Association junior lightweight championship.

title: VW Profits Off Sharply
description: Volkswagen, Western Europe's largest auto maker, today reported sharply lower earnings for the first nine months of 1981. It attributed the decline to heavy losses at its Brazilian operation.

title: CELEBRITY VICTIMS OF A DANGEROUS DRUG
description: To the Editor:

title: DECISION FILE
description: Every day Federal agencies make decisions affecting the lives of Americans. Here are some recent cases: New Directions

title: Advertising; Takeover Of Free Is Reported
description: ACCORDING to reliable reports along Madison Avenue, F.William Free & Company, which has billings of around $53 million, is being acquired by Daniel & Charles, a subsidiary of the Mickelberry Corporation since 1972.

title: DANCE: TIMOTHY BUCKLEY
description: Some dance companies with such names as Mary Smith and Friends or John Brown Plus Friends are simply being cute. But the dancers at Thursday night's program by Timothy Buckley With Friends at the Bessie Schonberg Theater did genuinely seem to be friends performing for friends. And their friends included the audience.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Tuesday incorrectly identified the lawyer for Katherine Boudin, a sus- pect in the Brinks armored-car rob- bery in Rockland County on Oct. 20. He is Martin Garbus.

title: CATHOLIC CHURCH ALTERS ITS FILM-RATING SYSTEM
description: The Roman Catholic Church is changing its film rating system, replacing its old ''class C, condemned'' and ''class B, morally objectionable in part for all'' with a single category called ''O, morally offensive.''

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Yr-ago results have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in Oct 1980

title: Notes on People
description: Sheila Rule and Robert McG. Thomas The Modern Child's View of Santa Claus

title: A STEAM PLANT BURNING REFUSE DUE IN BROOKLYN
description: New York City took a significant step yesterday toward building a plant in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard that would burn as much as 15 percent of the city's daily collection of garbage and convert it into steam.

title: Moscow Said to Oust 2 Jews
description: Two Jewish brothers, Isai and Grigory Goldshtein, both physicists from Tbilisi, said today that they were detained by the police and expelled from Moscow when they tried to attend a dissidents' gathering there on Thursday, United Nations International Human Rights Day. The brothers, who have been trying to emigrate to Israel since 1971, spoke to reporters by telephone from the Black Sea city of Sochi.

title: Your Money; Advantages Of Keogh Plan
description: YOU might be an accountant, an author or an art dealer. You could cater meals, repair televisions or play an instrument. But however you earn your living, if you are ''self-employed,'' you may place a portion of your income in a tax-deferred retirement account known as a Keogh plan. And under the new tax law, beginning Jan. 1, you will be allowed to place more money than ever before into a Keogh.

title: THEATER: SPALDING GRAY'S '47 BEDS'
description: In collaboration with Elizabeth LeCompte and other members of the Wooster Group, Spalding Gray has created a series of performance pieces partly drawn from his life. At the same time, he has, on his own, devised a number of autobiographical monologues. The seventh and latest, ''47 Beds,'' is being presented weekends at the Performing Garage. While the performance pieces often sacrifice intelligibility in the interest of visual and aural stimulation, the solo work is as entertaining as it is eccentric.

title: 2 Officials Suspended After a Suicide in Jail
description: The warden of the Union County (N.J.) Jail, Thomas Jefferson, and its administrator, James Scanlon, were suspended indefinitely without pay yesterday.

title: HOUSE APPROVES FOREIGN AID BILL AS G.O.P. DIVIDES
description: With Republicans almost evenly divided, the Democratic-dominated House gave President Reagan a hard-won victory today by adopting its first foreign aid appropriation bill in three years.

title: G.O.P. AND CONSERVATIVES MEET ON A GOVERNOR
description: The first step in an attempt to pick one Republican-Conservative nominee for Governor of New York will be taken today when seven candidates meet privately in Manhattan with Conservative Party leaders.

title: Committee to Study Kuhn
description: An apparent attempt by a group of baseball owners to replace Commissioner Bowie Kuhn resulted today in the creation of a 12-member committee to examine the structure and policies of the major leagues' high command.

title: ARLEDGE FIGHTS, YET REVELS IN, HIS OUTSIDER STATUS
description: Shortly after midnight Dec. 4, Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, picked up the telephone and called Dorance Smith, executive producer of the new ABC Sunday morning news program, ''This Week With David Brinkley.''

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1981
description: International The United Nations has a new leader. After a long deadlock in the Security Council, Javier Perez de Cuellar, a Peruvian diplomat, was chosen as the fifth Secretary General of the United Nations. He succeeds Kurt Waldheim of Austria, who has been Secretary General for 10 years and unsucessfully sought an unprecedented third five-year term. (Page 1, Column 6.) The U.S. defended its Libyan position. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said in Brussels that Western Europe was entitled to its own view of Libya, but that the United States had decided no longer to follow ''a double standard'' and do business with a regime that he said practiced terrorism, ''especially when it is targeted on American officials. (1:4.)

title: 'SPACED OUT,' A COMEDY
description: Aside from a nearly quotable joke about '' 'luudes'' and ''nudes,'' there's not much that can be printed from the film ''Spaced Out,'' a soft-core pornographic space comedy that opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters.

title: Mets Trade Flynn; Expos Get Taveras
description: The Mets, awakening from a seeming weeklong slumber, traded Doug Flynn, their fine-fielding second baseman, to Texas and Frank Taveras, their erratic shortstop, to Montreal tonight.

title: LEON ISRAEL, 75, COFFEE TRADER WORLDWIDE FOR OVER 50 YEARS
description: Leon Israel Jr., an international coffee trader for more than 50 years, died Thursday morning at his home in Millington, N.J. He was 75 years old.

title: POLAND MAY PRESS FOR LAW TO CURB UNION'S GAINS
description: As the Solidarity leadership met in Gdansk to map strategy in its deteriorating relations with the authorities, the Government indicated tonight that it might press next week for an emergency law to curb advances won by the union.

title: Around the World; Five Die in Rail Crash As Snow Covers Britain
description: Five people, including a teen-age boy, were killed when a crowded passenger train crashed into a stationary work train outside London today in a snowstorm that has paralyzed much of Britain.

title: LAWYER WAS EXPERT ON COMMUNICATIONS
description: William D. Greene, a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Greene & Bonaguidi, died of cancer Thursday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital. He was 55 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: JUDY'S FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Justice Dept. Review On Casey Is Reported
description: The Justice Department's criminal division is conducting a review to determine whether William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, violated the law by not registering as a foreign agent while he was representing Indonesia in 1976, Government sources said today.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Australia Ltd. is offering a $75 million seven-year floating-rate note issue through a Eurobond syndicate led by Swiss Bank Corp. International.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $125,000 extraordinary credit...C-Net loss including $100,000 extraordinary credit

title: CAMACHO WRESTS TITLE FROM DICKSON AT FORUM
description: Hector Camacho lived up to neither his nickname, Macho, nor his reputation as New York City's finest young fighter last night. But the 19-year-old high school student from Spanish Harlem scored a unanimous decision over tough Blaine Dickson to win the North American Boxing Federation's superfeatherweight, or juniorlightweight, championship in only his 12th professional bout.

title: MY RATIONALIST UNCLE
description: Not long ago, I received a letter from an old uncle of mine in India that made me ponder about the confusing times we live in. My uncle had written to ask me, among other things, whether it was true that religious fanatics were about to gain political control in the United States. The fame of the Moral Majority and other such groups seems to have penetrated into even the remote small town in southern India where he lives.

title: LA GUARDIA NOW BIGGER THAN LIFE
description: Mention the name of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, and the soft, flattering light of nostalgia immediately begins to glow. The picture may be of the short, stocky Mayor wielding a sledgehammer against a pile of slot machines or racing his firefighters to a fire; the sound, that of a high-pitched voice reading the Sunday comics over the radio during a newspaper strike; the feel, that of a lost time when the streets seemed clean, the schools seemed to teach children better and people seemed to be able to walk almost anywhere without regularly glancing over their shoulders or checking for their wallets.

title: TURKEY ON THE ROAD BACK TO DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: De Gustibus; WASSAIL! FILL UP THE PUNCH BOWL- AND BEWARE
description: Along with holly, Santa Claus and mistletoe, the appearance of brightly polished punch bowls signals the holiday season. As thousands of party-givers across the country check out recipes for eggnogs and punches, it seems timely to point out the possible ill effects of those high-spirited drinks. One cannot help wondering why ingredients that are so delicious alone or in combination can have such stultifying if not downright sickening effects.

title: Around the Nation; 3 Convicted in Scheme To Bribe Federal Judge
description: Three men, including Carlos Marcello, the reputed chief of the New Orleans organized-crime family, were found guilty today of conspiring to bribe a Federal judge in a racketeering case.

title: MOBIL GETS COURT DELAY ON OFFER BY U.S. STEEL
description: The Mobil Corporation, which has been repeatedly outmaneuvered by the United States Steel Corporation in a multibillion-dollar bidding contest for the Marathon Oil Company, won a temporary reprieve yesterday from a Federal appeals court.

title: Columbia, Outlet Merger Terms Set
description: The Outlet Company will have to sell its chain of 70 retail stores and trim its 12 broadcast stations by two before it joins the corporate flock of Columbia Pictures Industries.

title: P.B.A. HEAD DENOUNCES PLAN FOR CIVILIAN ANTICRIME FORCE
description: The president of the police officers' union yesterday denounced a plan by New York City to try to recruit large numbers of citizens for crime prevention efforts as ''nothing more than a facade'' that would not improve public safety.

title: Around the World; Zimbabwe Seizes M.P.  And Reports Coup Plot
description: The Government announced tonight that a white Member of Parliament had been detained in connection with what it said was a coup conspiracy.

title: MONEY SUPPLY IN SHARP RISE
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's money supply grew rapidly during November -a sign that the Fed's lessrestrictive monetary policy since midsummer has begun to work.

title: STATEN ISLAND NEEDS A RESIDENT JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Energy Savings Allow Utility to Delay Plant
description: The customers of the Atlantic City Electric Company are conserving energy so well that the utility is delaying construction of its $550 million, coal-fired Cumberland Generating Station for three years.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 36. 1. Although Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. asked for ''their understanding and support,'' members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization refused to back actions taken by the United States. What actions are they?

title: FUJITSU ACCUSES A.T.&T.
description: In an escalation of a foreign trade dispute, Fujitsu America Inc. asked the Federal Communications Commission today to bar the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from proceeding with construction of sections of a fiber optics transmission line between Boston and Richmond.

title: Notes on People; Hamilton Jordan to Be Wed in Pennsylvania
description: A college chapel in Allentown, Pa., will be the setting today for the marriage of Hamilton Jordan, the former chief of staff for President Jimmy Carter, and Dorothy A. Henry, a nurse, a spokesman at Muhlenberg College said yesterday.

title: Dr. Julius Burstein Dies at 81; A Cardiologist and Professor
description: Dr. Julius Burstein, who had been assistant director of cardiology at Jewish Memorial Hospital and clinical professor of cardiology at Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, both in Manhattan, died Thursday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: SCHMIDT OPENS PARLEY IN EAST GERMANY
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Erich Honecker, the East German Communist Party leader, met in a hunting lodge near here today for the first fullscale talks between leaders of their countries in more than a decade.

title: Bridge: Weak Suits Look Stronger Than They Did in the 30's
description: If you brought to a tournament a player who last played the game half a century ago, he would be considerably surprised by many aspects of modern bidding. One of them would be the general tendency of most experts to bid weak four-card suits.

title: Texas Concern Plans Layoffs
description: Most of the 30,000 employees of Texas Instruments Inc. will be placed on unexpected and unpaid layoffs between Christmas and New Year's Day.

title: THE RETAIL BATTLE IN CHICAGO
description: They are loath to call it a price war. But it would be hard to find another name for the torrent of price reductions at Marshall Field, Carson Pirie Scott, Wieboldt, Sears, Roebuck and the growing number of other retailers that make this city one of the country's most competitive markets.

title: SPLIT REAGAN AIDES SET DEFICIT GOAL
description: President Reagan's senior advisers have settled on a target of $55 billion to $60 billion for the budget deficit for fiscal 1984, the year in which Mr. Reagan had originally promised to balance the budget, Administration officials said today.

title: Patents; Viewers Talk Back To the TV
description: WASHINGTON Dialogue between characters in television movies and human viewers is offered in a system patented this week by a Seattle computer specialist. The inventor, Robert M. Best, was granted patent 4,305,131 for equipment that links the voices and decisions of real people with those of figures in animated cartoons.

title: GRUMMAN GETS 3 MORE MONTHS TO REPAIR BUSES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority agreed yesterday to give the Grumman Corporation three additional months to repair 837 Flxible buses and return them to the streets of New York.

title: SILKWOOD AWARD IS REVERSED
description: A Federal appeals court today reversed a $10.5 million award to the estate of Karen Silkwood, a worker at an Oklahoma plutonium plant who died in a 1974 automobile accident.

title: FASHION GIFTS, PLAIN AND FANCY
description: There are some people around who buy Christmas gifts as the year progresses, whenever something strikes their fancy and their pocketbook isn't too flat. There are others who start prowling around after Thanksgiving, and by mid-December have nothing to do but loll in a bubble bath or actually eat during lunch hours. And then there is everyone else, a sad lot who still have nothing to wrap but good intentions.

title: Hilton Seeks New Hotel Talks
description: Hilton Hotels Corporation officials are willing to discuss ways to salvage a proposed $250 million hotel that would be the centerpiece of the North Loop redevelopment plan, an executive of the company says.

title: DIVORCE AND LOGIC
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION IS BEATEN BY WIDE MARGIN IN DUPONT VOTE
description: The United Steelworkers of America was beaten overwhelmingly tonight in its second major effort to organize industrial workers predominantly in the South.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NEEDIEST RECEIVE ANNUAL GIFT FROM PUPILS IN SADDLE BROOK
description: Schoolchildren in the metropolitan New York area, among the regular contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, often show a special concern for the elderly.

title: Jeanne H. Block Dies; Research Psychologist
description: Jeanne Humphrey Block, an expert on child development and a professor of psychology at the University of California in Berkeley, died of cancer Dec. 4 at the Alta Bates Hospital in Berkeley. She was 58 years old and lived in El Cerrito, Calif.

title: Rochester Digs Out From Under a 25-Inch Blanket of Snow
description: Near the campus of the University of Rochester, Karen Pemstein, center, had help from her friends Karen Tuck, left, and Gayle Nutile in finding her snowbound car. Residents of the city were busy plowing and shovelling yesterday after the season's first storm, twodays of it, left about 25 inches of snow, the most there since 1978.

title: MAYS, J W, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Cameron Fails in Effort To Compete in Playoffs
description: Cameron University's last-minute effort to be reinstated into the N.A.I.A.'s Division I football playoffs failed today in United States District Court after a sixhour hearing.

title: U.S. and Europeans Discussing Trade Differences
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and other high American officials met today with Western European officials in the first of two days of talks aimed at resolving serious trade policy differences.

title: New York; TAXES AND CIVILIZATION
description: ''Lower public expectation'' is the new buzz phrase for the roundshouldered psychology that citizens are being asked to adopt if they are to survive in the age of municipal decay.

title: A PLACE FOR ENTERPRISE ON THE JERSEY SHORE
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Denies Responsibility For Indian Treaties in Canada
description: Britain today ruled out intervening in the constitutional fight by Canadian Indians over treaties made more than two centuries ago.

title: N.F.L. Says 1980 Club Profit Was $1.4 Million
description: Pete Rozelle, the National Football League commissioner, has submitted figures to the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Monopolies and Commercial Law indicating that the annual net profit for each of the league's 28 teams was $1.4 million in 1980.

title: CALVIN HILL A FAN AGAIN AT 34
description: It has been a lost season, probably a last season, but in his 13th year in professional football, Calvin Hill can still like training camp and he can still say that when his career is over, he will again be a pro football fan.

title: OIL COMPANIES TO LET AMERICANS LEAVE LIBYA
description: State Department officials met today with executives of American oil companies operating in Libya and said later that the companies would cooperate in withdrawing American employees from the North African nation.

title: Around the World; Levesque Wins Support From Party Members
description: Premier Rene Levesque won an overwhelming vote of confidence Thursday night from his Parti Quebecois and today appeared certain to remain head of the Quebec provincial government.

title: Mood At Geneva Talks Is Praised
description: Eugene V. Rostow, the head of the American Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, sat in today on the fourth session of the Soviet-American talks on reducing intermediate-range nuclear arms in Europe and said later that the ''atmosphere is very good.''

title: New Leader for the Urban League
description: Civil rights groups searching for chief executives often prefer famous outsiders, so the elevation of John Jacob to succeed Vernon Jordan as president of the National Urban League is a welcome surprise.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75. ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TAYLOR ADAMS
description: Taylor Adams, a writer and account executive with New York advertising agencies, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan.

title: NATO FIRM ON SUPPORT FOR MISSILES
description: The Western allies said today that they were determined, despite dissenting political voices in Western Europe, to go ahead with plans to deploy new intermediate-range missiles in Europe unless the Soviet Union agreed in the next two years to ''a fair and effective arms-control agreement.''

title: Holders Approve Fred Meyer Sale
description: Shareholders of Fred Meyer Inc. have voted overwhelmingly to sell the large Northwest retailer for $435 million to the New York investment banking firm of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: SAKHAROVS REPORT PROTEST HAS ENDED
description: Andrei D. Sakharov sent a telegram to Moscow today telling the young woman on whose behalf he staged a 17-day hunger strike that he and his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, were recovering from their fast and were ''happy beyond words'' at the Kremlin's decision to let the young woman emigrate to the United States.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
A NEW INQUIRY ON RICHMOND IS BEGUN BY U.S. PROSECUTOR
description: The United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York is looking into a Federal judge's findings concerning Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn and the manufacturing company he founded and controlled.

title: POP: MISS FLACK AT TRIBUTE TO LENNON
description: The music of the Beatles has always lent itself to light symphonic treatments, because of the extraordinary richness and variety of its melodies. And in the program billed as ''A Tribute to John Lennon,'' at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday, the Cincinnatti Pops Orchestra, led by Erich Kunzel, reprised many of the Beatles' best-known tunes in a breezy, light-classical format that had very little to do with rock-and-roll, but that was still an effective mode of presentation.

title: Syrians Move to Quell New Lebanon Fighting
description: Syrian troops moved into the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli today to quell a new outbreak of fighting between paramilitary groups that followed a car bombing Thursday in which 12 people were killed and 75 injured. Shops and schools were closed, and a day of national mourning for the victims of the explosion was called for Saturday.

title: The City; Boy, 14, Accused Of Killing Student
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn youth has been arrested in the killing of an 18-year-old high school student who refused a demand for a $150 gold ring, the police said.

title: Square in Venice Is Flooded
description: High tides and stormy weather flooded St. Mark's Square today and other low-lying districts of Venice.

title: SOME ARE SAD TO LEAVE LIBYA
description: Several Americans in Libya said today that they did not feel threatened, and wanted to stay there despite a request by President Reagan that they leave.

title: WHEN EMMA GOLDMAN HIT CUTTING-ROOM FLOOR
description: When E.L. Doctorow's ''Ragtime'' reached movie screens a few weeks ago, most of the historical figures who interacted with the novel's fictional family were missing. The book had been crammed with such titans of the first decade of the 20th century as J.P. Morgan, Henry Ford, Sigmund Freud and Harry Houdini, but critics mourned in particular the loss of the anarchist Emma Goldman.

title: Air Crash Remains Mystery
description: After a year-long investigation, the Air Force has been unable to determine why an FB-111A crashed off the Maine coast 14 months ago, killing both crew members. Col. James J. LeCleir, who headed the investigating team, said the results were inconclusive because divers did not recover enough of the wreckage to establish the cause of the crash.

title: LIBBY SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS CANNING OPERATIONS
description: Libby, McNeill & Libby Inc., the Chicago-based producer of canned foods, said today that it had reached an agreement to sell its United States fruit and vegetable canning operations to two agribusiness concerns, California Canners and Growers of San Francisco and S.S. Pierce of Dundee, N.Y.

title: RUDOLPH J. SCHOLZ
description: Rudolph J. Scholz, a member of two United States rugby teams that won Olympic gold medals, died at his home Wednesday at the age of 82. Mr. Scholz, who was born in Kewanee, Ill., played for the United States teams at the 1920 and 1924 Games, before rugby was discontinued as an Olympic sport.

title: More at Tourister Facing Layoffs
description: American Tourister, one of the nation's leading luggage manufacturers, said it will lay off 40 more workers, put the rest of its 1,000 factory employees on a four-day workweek during portions of December and January and temporarily shut down operations during the last two weeks of this month. Ronald R. Snyder, company human resources director, said reduced sales and a sagging economy were to blame for the company's action.

title: HAIG LINKS MOVES AGAINST QADDAFI WITH MORAL ANGER
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that, while Western Europe was entitled to its own view of Libya, the United States had decided that it could no longer carry on ''business as usual'' with a regime that practiced terrorism, ''especially when it is targeted on American officials.''

title: Around the World; Protestant Inmates Stage 36-Hour Siege in Ulster
description: About 50 Protestant prisoners who said they held 4 guards and 13 Catholic inmates as hostages on the roof of Belfast's Crumlin Road jail ended their protest early today after 36 hours, a mediator said.

title: CONGRESS TO TRY NEXT WEEK TO DECIDE ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Congress will have a final chance next week to preserve the $122-a-month minimum Social Security benefit before payments to three million people are threatened.

title: The City; Board Reported Asked to Resign
description: The Koch administration was reported last night to have asked the four members of the Board of Health to consider resigning so that a new board could be reconstituted for the city's new Health Commissioner, David J. Sencer, who takes office Jan. 1.

title: EVANS-ARISTOCRAT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd declared on Dec 9 and payable Jan 20, 1982

title: Davis Activated by Suns And Will Play Tonight
description: Walter Davis, saying that he was experiencing no pain in his left elbow, which he fractured last month, was placed on the roster today by the Phoenix Suns.

title: MUSIC: DRUCKMAN QUARTET PREMIERE
description: For its 10th anniversary season, the Concord String Quartet is presenting three concerts at Alice Tully Hall, each containing the New York premiere of a commissioned piece by a major composer. The first in the series, Wednesday night, offered Jacob Druckman's Quartet No. 3, which was completed last month. The subsequent concerts Feb. 7 and April 4 will have scores by George Rochberg and Krzysztof Penderecki.

title: BUELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss after $733,000 tax credit

title: STATE SUPREME COURT JUSTICE
description: Edward S. Lentol, a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn who had been a state legislator for 24 years, died yesterday in New York Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: A Perverse 'Freedom' From Pretoria
description: With every proclamation of a ''separate'' new tribal homeland, South Africa gives a cruel twist to the meaning of independence. Although their statehood is ushered in with ceremonies that ape decolonization - the lowering of South Africa's flag, the firing of a 101-gun salute - the policy is in fact a cynical effort to preserve white dominance in the richest regions and to strip South African blacks of their already limited citizenship.

title: HEARNS SUFFERS CUT BUT WINS
description: Despite bleeding over the left eye for most of the fight, Thomas Hearns tonight salvaged a 10-round unanimous decision tonight in his middleweight debut against Ernie Singletary.

title: CONFLICT OF INTEREST CHARGED IN 'CREATION' TRIAL
description: Proceedings in the trial involving the teaching of ''creation science'' were overshadowed today by a controversy that began Wednesday when the Arkansas Attorney General was accused by a television evangelist of having a conflict of interest.

title: URBAN-RURAL DATA: CONFUSING CENSUS
description: A city dweller, seeing Montgomery County's open fields, forests and lonely roads, would have no trouble declaring every inch of it rural. Yet, by the Census Bureau's definition, the county seat and largest town, Troy, which looks to outsiders like a country village, is urban because it has slightly more than 2,500 people.

title: News Analysis
description: The reluctant decision of the executive board of the United Automobile Workers to allow union bargaining councils to reopen contracts is a move of major importance, not only for the nation's automobile workers but also for many other wage earners, particularly industrial workers. For decades American wage and benefits scales, particularly those among industrial workers, have been linked to the automobile industry's wages and benefits. They have risen when the auto workers were able to extract relatively high wages and benefits from what had been a highly profitable industry.

title: HABIB TELLS REAGAN ALL SIDES SUPPORT LEBANON CEASE-FIRE
description: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, told President Reagan today that all parties want a continuation of the four and a half month old ceasefire in Lebanon.

title: TREATING JUVENILE CRIME
description: The juvenile delinquency story is seldom if ever fully and accurately told.

title: The City; 3 Gunmen Rob 4 Of $290 on the IRT
description: Four persons riding a Broadway local train of the IRT subway were robbed yesterday afternoon by three gunmen who boarded the train at the 137th Street station in Manhattan and fled at the next stop, 145th Street, with $290 and a ring, the Transit Authority police said.

title: GUIDRY LEANS TO YANKEES
description: Ron Guidry, retaining a strong emotional attachment to the Yankees, will decide in the next few days whether to return to them for significantly less money than he wanted. Chances seem good that he will.

title: Around the Nation; Pawtucket Loses Appeal On Nativity Display
description: A three-judge Federal appeals court today rejected the request of Pawtucket, R.I., for a stay of an order that barred it from sponsoring a traditional downtown Nativity display.

title: Sports of the Times; MUHAMMAD ALI'S MOMENT OF TRUTH
description: NASSAU, the Bahamas AFTER the timekeeper hit a cowbell with a hammer to end the ninth round, Muhammad Ali stood still on his weary legs. Through glazed eyes, he glared at Trevor Berbick, who had turned and was striding back to his corner. Muhammad Ali watched him go, and then he looked down at Trevor Berbick's legs and quickly looked up at his torso, measuring him with his eyes as boxers do. Then he turned and went back to his corner.

title: Sports People; Bryant Suspends 2
description: Coach Bear Bryant has suspended Thomas Boyd, an all-American linebacker, and Linnie Patrick, a halfback, from the Alabama football squad and said the pair would not participate in the Crimson Tide's Cotton Bowl game against Texas Jan. 1. Bryant said he did not care to make any further comment.

title: About New York; IN THE 'HOLE,' THE TALK IS ALL GARBAGE
description: Deep in a sub-basement of the State Supreme Court building at 60 Centre Street, in a room so dank that it seems to lie below sea level, the shrill ringing continues, unabated. In peeling cubicles sit city workers; like teen-aged girls, they talk constantly on the telephone.

title: Utility Delays Plant
description: The Atlantic City Electric Company said it would delay construction of its proposed Cumberland generating station in Millville, N.J., to 1991 from 1988. The utility noted that while slower demand growth rates had necessitated the delay, the Cumberland plant would still be needed in the 1990's. The utility provides electric service in a 2,700-square-mile area in southern New Jersey with an estimated population of 1 million.

title: RETAIL SALES UP 0.8% IN NOVEMBER
description: Retail sales rebounded a slight but encouraging eight-tenths of 1 percent in November after having dropped sharply in October. The rise apparently resulted from the decline in interest rates last month that encouraged consumers to finance ''big-ticket'' purchases.

title: INTERCOLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd to be paid Jan 20

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AN ARAB LEAGUE-INSPIRED DEBACLE AT FEZ
description: To the Editor:

title: MEESE IS CRITICAL ON SCHOOL POLICY
description: Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, said today that ''neglect and misguided policy, often at the Federal level,'' were to blame for problems of the economy and problems in the educational system.

title: UNION DIME MERGER DUE WITHIN WEEK
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation expects to merge the failing Union Dime Savings Bank into another bank by the end of next week, according to banking sources.

title: Observer; OILIEST OF THE BIG SPENDERS
description: ''Let's go Christmas shopping,'' said the voice on the phone. ''Who's this?'' ''Mobil.'' I hadn't heard from Mobil for a long time. In the old days I'd known him as Mobil Clinkscales and everybody called him Mobie, but then he went into the business of making America great and changed his last name to Oil, and I'd quit thinking of him as my old pal Mobie Clinkscales and started thinking of him as something inhuman.

title: LENTILHON VON FLUEGGE
description: Lentilhon Gilford Von Fluegge, a philanthropist and community worker, died Thursday at New York Hospital. Mrs. Von Fluegge was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DOW FALLS BY 5.52
description: Stock prices edged lower yesterday, but Four-Phase Systems scored a sharp advance as the newest beneficiary of a takeover agreement. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.52 points, to 886.51. In the last 11 sessions, the Dow has fluctuated in a narrow channel above 880 on the charts.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 12, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the United Nations force in Cyprus at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Moscow Reportedly Charges Writer With Anti-Soviet Acts
description: The Soviet police have arrested Yevgeny Kozlovsky, a writer, and charged him with anti-Soviet propaganda, unofficial literary sources said today.

title: Books of The Times; The Cast for Neoteny
description: GROWING YOUNG. By Ashley Montagu. 306 pages. McGraw-Hill. $12.95.

title: THE SPECIAL-PROSECUTOR HITCH
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Clerc Beats Tanner To Even Davis Cup
description: With stunning ease, Jose-Luis Clerc carved up Roscoe Tanner's formidable serve and won, 7-5, 6-3, 8-6, today to even the Davis Cup final between the United States and Argentina after the opening day. John McEnroe had started the Americans on the road to a possible 27th crown with a 6-3, 6-2, 6-2 victory over Guillermo Vilas in the first singles match at Riverfront Coliseum, site of the three-day series that offers $200,000 to the winning team.

title: No Headline
description: AIDE TO KHOMEINI KILLED BY A BOMB

title: Patents; Device on Phone Takes Messages in Writing
description: An electronic telephone answering device records an incoming call in letters and figures instead of taking an audible message on tape. If the calling number is on a list, the caller's name is also displayed.

title: Going Out Guide
description: DESIGNING PEOPLE

title: BOSTON'S MAYOR RULES BY CHARTER, PERSONALITY AND MACHINE
description: When he was first elected Mayor in 1967, Kevin H. White paid a courtesy call on his predecessor, John F. Collins, who had chosen to retire. ''Welcome, Mr. Mayor,'' Mary Collins, the incumbent's wife, said kindly. The Mayor-elect thanked her and laughed sheepishly.

title: Go Slow With Ma Bell
description: Telecommunications is to the nation what the sensory and motor nerves are to a person - critical. And telecommunications technology is changing at a pace that the law has been unable to match. Deregulation has therefore become the slogan for letting the new market define itself and letting engineers take this exciting field where they can.

title: The City; Bush Says Parties Are Weakened
description: Vice President Bush, in a visit to New York City, said Federal campaign-financing laws were weakening political parties, and he called for increasing the amount of money parties can contribute to candidates at all levels.

title: JETS' FRONT FOUR DETERMINED
description: The Jets used to worry about the icy cold, how miserable it was to play in old Cleveland Stadium in winter, with the wind blowing into the open end from Lake Erie.

title: SECURITY COUNCIL ELECTS A PERUVIAN SECRETARY GENERAL
description: The Security Council broke its long deadlock today and chose Javier Perez de Cuellar, a Peruvian diplomat, as the fifth Secretary General of the United Nations.

title: 5 WORKERS KILLED IN CHICAGO PLUNGE
description: A cable lowering a bucket carrying six construction workers at a building site broke today, hurling five of them 80 feet to their deaths and seriously injuring the sixth.

title: CHRYSLER TANK UNIT: $600 MILLION PRICE
description: The Chrysler Corporation has put a $600 million price tag on its profitable defense subsidiary, which makes tanks for the Army, sources in the auto and defense industries said today.

title: THE CZAR IN CHARGE OF NUCLEAR ARMS
description: At one time the Atomic Energy Commission and an 18-member joint Congressional committee were in charge of America's mightly nuclear arsenal.

title: DIVIDED SENATE PANEL PUTS OFF ACTION ON CLEAN AIR ACT UNTIL 1982
description: A divided Senate Environment and Public Works Committee today abandoned plans to amend the Clean Air Act until next year. The decision means that Congress is unlikely to make changes in the antipollution law until next spring at the earliest.

title: FAMILY LEARNS HOW U.S. AIRMAN DIED IN '45
description: The Wohlgemuth family was relieved, if saddened, to learn almost 37 years later what happened to William Wohlgemuth. The family is also puzzled that the military's recordkeepers were unable to find one of the survivors of the young airman until newspaper articles on the matter were published.

title: Patents; Wounded Person's Cells Generate Shield of Skin
description: A person suffering from burns or open wounds can be treated with a sheet of living skin grown from his or her own epidermal cells. The method was patented this week for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology by a physician and a former graduate student from Nigeria.

title: PRIVATE HELP SOUGHT FOR RESTORING ELLIS ISLAND
description: The National Park Service plans to enlist individuals, businesses and private organizations in a multimillion-dollar project to restore about 30 crumbling buildings on Ellis Island, once the entry point for millions of American immigrants.

title: U.S. Steel Layoffs
description: About 1,800 workers at the Fairless Works of the United States Steel Corporation will be laid off for at least two weeks over the Christmas holidays, the company announced today.

title: JERSEY SOUND STUDIO AIMS FOR GROWTH
description: Two years ago, when George Elliott and his son, George Thomas Elliott, produced their first album, the recording industry was not having a particularly good year. Disco had died and record sales in all categories were slumping. In the recording capitals of New York and Los Angeles, executives were conservative about signing new acts.

title: BERBICK DEFEATS ALI ON DECISION
description: Trevor Berbick made sure his money was secure today, then he beat Muhammad Ali badly enough to win a unanimous 10-round decision from the popular former heavyweight champion, who was attempting another comeback at age 39.

title: Index; International
description: Sakharovs report protest has ended and they are well 2 Polish regime indicates it might press for law to curb union 2 Leaders of two Germanies meet for full-scale talks 3 NATO firm on missile plan if no arms accord is reached 3 Special envoy reports to President on Middle East mission 4 Bomb kills Khomeini's representative in southern Iranian city 5 Around the World 7 For some Americans, it's hard to leave jobs and friends in Libya 8 Government/Politics Boston Mayor Kevin White bedev- iled by investigations 10 Divided Senate panel puts off clean air action until '82 11 Committee will discuss the Social Security minimum benefit 12 Meese critical on educational policies of past 20 Fiorello La Guardia's centennial observance begins in New York 29 New York Conservative leaders to meet with candidates 30 U.S. Attorney conducting inquiry into suit on Rep. Richmond 31 P.B.A. head assails Koch plan for civilian crime prevention force 31 F.B.I. seizes secret embassy documents reprinted in Iran 45 Legislators urge U.S. to test ''block grants'' for states 45 Washington Talk Briefing 20 The Government's czar in charge of nuclear weapons 20 Style Consumer Saturday 54 Fashion gifts, plain and fancy 54 De Gustibus: Wassail! Fill up the punch bowl - and beware 54 General Around the Nation 10 Five construction workers die in Chicago plunge 10 After 37 years, family learns where airman died 11 Debate on donation disrupts ''creation science'' trial 28 The L.I.R.R. admitted putting tape recorders in train cabs 30 The City 31 Arts/Entertainment How ''Ragtime's'' Emma Goldman hit cutting room floor 21 Spalding Gray in another autobiographical monologue 21 Roman Catholic Church changes its film rating system 21 Concord String Quartet gives pre- miere of Druckman work 21 Katrina Killian dances the Sugar Plum Fairy 21 Ashley Montague's ''Growing Young'' is reviewed 24 ''Spaced Out,'' a pornographic space comedy reviewed 24 ''A Tribute to John Lennon'' at Radio City Music Hall 24 Timothy Buckley With Friends at Bessie Schonberg Theater 25 Arledge fights, yet revels in, his outsider status 53 Obituaries Edward S. Lentol, State Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn 32 William D. Greene, communications lawyer 32 Sports Nets defeat Hawks, 131-123 14 Iona wins, Columbia is beaten in basketball tourney 14 Berbick scores unanimous decision over Ali 15 U.S. and Argentina tied at 1-1 in Davis Cup final 15 Mets send Flynn to Texas for Kern, and sell Taveras 15 Guidry likely to stay with Yan- kees on compromise offer 15 Calvin Hill, at 34, becomes a fan again with Browns 15 30 Hearns, in middleweight debut, wins unanimous decision 17 Dave Anderson on the travels of Muhammad Ali 17 Jets' front four determined to harass Browns 18 Rozelle says N.F.L. clubs averaged $1.4 million profit in 1980 18 Features/Notes Man in the News: Javier Perez de Cuellar, next U.N. chief 6 Sports People 19 Going Out Guide 23 Saturday News Quiz 25 About New York 31 Notes on People 44 News Analysis William Serrin on auto workers' decision to reopen contracts 13 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 26

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, DECEMBER 12, 1980; International
description: OPEC shaved oil prices by 20 cents to $1 a barrel for many grades of crudes, but the cuts were not expected to affect gasoline and heating oil prices in the United States. OPEC's oil ministers, meeting in Abu Dhabi, also rejected a Libyan request to blacklist U.S. oil companies that withdraw American personnel, as the Reagan Administration has requested. (Page 1.) U.S. oil company executives, at a meeting with State Department officials, said they would cooperate in withdrawing American employees from Libya, but they questioned whether the safety of American citizens in Libya was in jeopardy. (9.)

title: Sports People; Tarkanian Amazed
description: Jerry Tarkanian, the basketball coach at the University of Nevada-Las Vegas, said his reaction to the two-year probation imposed on the University of California, Los Angeles by the National Collegiate Athletic Association was one of ''total disbelief.''Tarkanian, frequently a target of N.C.A.A. investigators at Long Beach State and Nevada-Las Vegas, said, ''For U.C.L.A.'s sake and the sake of the athletes competing, I'm glad the way it turned out.

title: 'NUTCRACKER': MISS KILLIAN
description: Last May, Katrina Killian was dancing in the annual workshop performances of the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet. In September, the 19-year-old dancer joined the City Ballet, where she has appeared in the corps de ballet in a handful of repertory pieces.

title: Capitals Beat Leafs by 11-2
description: Dennis Maruk scored two goals and had three assists tonight as the Washington Capitals set a club scoring record by defeating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 11-2. The Capitals broke their record of 9 goals in a game, set Feb. 15, 1979, against Colorado and equaled March 8, 1980, against Hartford.

title: BURGESS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results have been restated for a recent change in accounting for gains or losses on foreign currency translations; net loss for 1981 reflects restatement of the first 9mos ended June 30, 1981

title: Patents; Fleischmann Award
description: Isaac Fleischmann, who retired this week as director of information services after serving the Patent and Trademark Office for 35 years, was presented by the Department of Commerce with a new public affairs award at a reception in his honor. Called the Isaac Fleischmann Award, it will be granted to others in the future. To get a copy of a patent, send number and 50 cents to the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

title: 1,999 YEARS AFTER VIRGIL
description: To the Editor:

title: 'First' to Close After Matinee Tomorrow
description: ''The First,'' the Broadway musical about Jackie Robinson, will close tomorrow after the matinee at the Martin Beck Theater. The show, which opened Nov. 17, will have played 37 performances and 33 previews.

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After $1.5 million from Canadian operations...C-Net income after $235,000 loss from Canadian operations and $1.1 million gain from the sale of a roofing plant in Little Rock, Ark

title: Notes on People; O'Neill Recovering
description: A week after his open-heart surgery, Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut got his first official visitors Thursday - Lieut. Gov. Joseph J. Fauliso, who has been acting as Governor during his illness, and his legal counsel, Jay Jackson.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Sports in Perspective
description: The Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, the president of Notre Dame, said yesterday that university presidents have to make sure sports do not overshadow the other aspects of their institutions.

title: Lumber Industry Slump
description: The West's lumber industry continued to feel the effects of the housing slump last week, with 52 percent of its 102,000 workers unemployed or working short shifts, an industry report showed. The Western Wood Products Association reported yesterday that 27,416 people, or 27 percent of the work force, were off the job during the week ending Dec. 5. Some 25,472, or 25 percent, were working short or curtailed shifts.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''From now on, it'll be just another parade. It'll take the spirit out of it.'' - James J. Comerford, chairman of the St. Patrick's Parade Committee. (1:2.)

title: PROSECUTORS IN BRINK'S CASE DROP OPPOSITION TO LAWYER
description: Prosecutors in the Oct. 20 Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County dropped their opposition yesterday to any appearance in Federal Court in Manhattan by a lawyer for a black separatist group.

title: ECONOMIC CHANGE IN FRANCE
description: A major dispute over the pace of economic change in France has erupted among the country's new Socialist leaders, just six months after they took power, promising to redistribute the nation's wealth while simultaneously increasing industrial investment to cut unemployment.

title: No Headline
description: OPEC TRIMS PRICES; LIBYAN ASKS IN VAIN FOR ANTI-U.S. MOVES

title: CAUTIOUS, GENTLE PILOT FOR THE U.N.
description: While other aspirants for the Secretary General's job were lobbying here in corridors and nearby restaurants, Javier Perez de Cuellar was at a beach house outside Lima without a telephone but with plenty of books. The lack of tension and almost conspicuous modesty are hallmarks of this graying, gentle 61-year-old diplomat.

title: Notes on People; Safety Official Wins 'Saved by the Belt' Award
description: Raymond A. Peck Jr., head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, was honored yesterday for having been ''saved by the belt.''

title: I'M A JUNK-MAIL ADDICT
description: Postal rates have increased again, and there is panic among the ''junk-mail'' addicts of America.

title: Around the Nation; Billie Jean King Upheld; Judge Hints at Extortion
description: A former hairdresser must move within 30 days from a beach house owned by her onetime lesbian lover, the tennis star Billie Jean King, a judge ruled today.

title: F.B.I. SEIZES SECRET DOCUMENTS REPRINTED IN IRAN
description: Three American freelancers who recently returned from Iran are engaged in a legal tug-of-war with the Federal Bureau of Investigation over 11 volumes of Iranian reprints of secret American documents apparantly taken from the United States Embassy in Teheran.

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $162,400 extraordinary tax credit

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The latest qr includes pretax equity in Alpha Portland Industries earnings and amortization of excess equity of $171,000 compared with a reduction of $119,000 a yr ago; the latest 9 mos was reduced by pretax equity in Alpha's earnings and amortization of excess equity of $136,000 compared with an increase of $374,000 in earlier period; the shr earnings reflect 5 percent stock divds in Apr and Oct 1981

title: Notes on People; City Sidewalks Fit for a Night of Stars
description: Alexander H. Cohen is rolling out the red carpet - literally. Mr. Cohen is producing ''Night of 100 Stars,'' a celebration at Radio City Music Hall of the 100th anniversary of the Actors' Fund of America. For the event, to take place in February, Mr. Cohen plans 8,000 square feet of star-speckled bright red carpet along four blocks of the Avenue of the Americas.

title: IONA WINS BY 59-41 TO GAIN IN TOURNEY
description: Columbia took off like a front-running horse tonight, seeking to steal the race, but its lead was shortlived. Northeastern whittled away at the Lions and emerged with a 72-62 victory in the opening game of the Manufacturers Hanover Classic.

title: 43 Bodies Said to Be Found In Ravine in South Guatemala
description: Peasants found a secret cemetery today containing 43 decomposed bodies in a ravine outside a village in south-central Guatemala, the police said.

title: Consumer Saturday; GIVING A PRESENT OF SERVICE
description: S OMETIMES, the most precious holiday gift of all doesn't come wrapped in tinselly ribbon. If some of your friends already have enough clothing and jewelry and silver pepper mills, you might do something special for them.

title: Ice Show Opens Jan. 19 With Dorothy Hamill
description: Dorothy Hamill, the former Olympic figure skating champion, will be the star of the 1982 Ice Capades in New Jersey's Meadowlands Arena, Jan. 19 to 24, and at Madison Square Garden, Jan. 27 to Feb. 7.

title: Patents; Monitor for Valves
description: A position indicator invented for the Department of Energy will show an operator in a control room whether a valve in a gas-cooled nuclear reactor is closed or open. The invention, patent 4,304,630, was made under a contract with the General Atomic Company, San Diego, by David E. Tanner. The position of a valve or other movable element is detected by reflected light and the information is transmitted through fiber optics to a readout point.

title: Briefing
description: E DWIN MEESE 3D, counselor to President Reagan, is quietly and firmly pressing his effort to phase out the Office of the United States Trade Representative, now headed by William E. Brock 3d, former chairman of the Republican National Committee, and to bring all Government trade functions under the umbrella of Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige. In recent weeks Mr. Meese has asked business leaders for their reaction to the possible shift, but no consensus has emerged.

title: ST. PATRICK'S PARADES WILL BE HELD ON THE SUNDAY BEFORE THE HOLIDAY
description: After 220 years of marching and a decade or so of controversy, the St. Patrick's Day parade is not going to be held on St. Patrick's Day. It will be held on the Sunday before.

title: Japan Auto Output Data
description: In contrast with a substantial increase in recent years, Japan's auto production in 1981 is expected to grow only slightly from the previous year, because of slow domestic demand and export restrictions, industry officials said today.

title: STATE LEGISLATORS URGE U.S. TO TRY PROVIDING FUNDS AS BLOCK GRANTS
description: State legislators called on the Government today to experiment with the idea of consolidating all Federal assistance to each state into a ''block grant.''

title: Sports People; A Long Way Home
description: After 28 years, a Rose Bowl memento lost in a Chicago street brawl has found its way to its rightful owner - an Omaha business executive. The memento is a watch inscribed with the words ''1951 Rose Bowl'' and the name of its owner, R. Allen Wahl, the all-American defensive tackle of the Michigan team that beat California, 14-6, in Pasadena that year.

title: CREW DISCOVERS COVERT TAPING BY THE L.I.R.R.
description: A Long Island Rail Road crew discovered two voice-activated tape recorders aboard its train Wednesday morning, and a union official said yesterday that he would press charges of unlawful eavesdropping with the Nassau County District Attorney's office.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 25. 1. President Reagan's request that Americans leave Libya and the invalidating of American passports to Libya. 2. To make a point about her relationship with the Mayor, Carol Bellamy, the president of the New York City Council, gave him a copy of a Dr. Seuss story in which Yertle the Turtle is a king who commands his subjects to pile up on top of one another so that he can sit on high. Yertle falls when the bottom turtle burps and topples the empire.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Brunswick Corp. and G.D. Searle & Co. announced a joint agreement for Brunswick to purchase Searle's Dover Urological Products division in a cash transaction. Terms were not disclosed.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Gretchen G. Teichgraeber Is Affianced
description: Gretchen Gehring Teichgraeber, a media manager in the circulation division of Time magazine, and John Stanley Neff, a senior treasury analyst with Pepsico Inc. in Purchase, N.Y., plan to be married Jan. 23.

title: Cultural Overload In Western Connecticut
description: While I feel I ought to applaud any private source support for the arts, I simply cannot let the Western Connecticut Symphony Orchestra burst upon the area art scene (''A Musical Bonanza: Three New Groups,'' Nov. 8) without voicing a protest.

title: Westchester Journal
description: TRUE to its word, Westchester's legislative delegation stood firmly in support of Governor Carey's veto of a bill to change the state's current method of property-tax assessments, with only one of the 13 members voting to override the veto. The leadership of the State Legislature, however, was able to muster the necessary twothirds margin to enact the controversial measure.

title: by Nicholas Madigan
description: WITH a steady voice and a casual wave of her hand, Mrs. B., married for 17 years, told her counselor, "I've thrown all his clothes in the basement with the cobwebs - it made me feel good."

title: PORTIA IS ONE OF THE BOYS
description: WOMEN IN LAW By Cynthia Fuchs Epstein. 438 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.50.

title: New Jersey Guide; CHAPLIN IN WESTWOOD
description: In 1928, when the Pascack Theater in Westwood opened, it was a 1,200-seat deluxe movie house with facilities for stage productions and a specially built Wurlitzer pipe organ for accompanying silent films. Among other things, the organ's sound effects included hoof beats, castanets, bells and harps.

title: JUDGE ANNULS SUSPENSION OF A PHYSICIAN IN HOME-BIRTH CASE
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday restored the license of a Kingston, N.Y., physician whose practice includes the delivering of babies at home.

title: THEATER: COLE PORTER'S 'SOMETHING FOR THE BOYS'
description: Even when it was first produced in 1943, with Ethel Merman, Paula Laurence and Allen Jenkins, Cole Porter's wartime musical ''Something for the Boys'' aspired to be nothing more than the lightest of diversions. The preposterous plot, which unfolds mostly in and around an Army camp, centers on the misadventures of three distant cousins. Informed that they are partial heirs to an estate in Texas, they converge on the property, which has become the site of military drills.

title: GAINS AND LOSSES VOTED IN SPENDING MEASURE
description: As in any other complex piece of legislation, the stopgap Federal spending measure that Congress has passed contains nooks and crannies, with both good and bad news for people and organizations that rely on Federal funds and uncertain news for others.

title: OPERA: JUILLIARD CENTER PRESENTS 'LA TRAVIATA'
description: The Juilliard American Opera Center's ''La Traviata'' is, like most of the school's productions, a training ground for young professional singers. As such it offers some good and some not quite so good singers, and a student orchestra in the Juilliard Symphony. On Friday evening in the superbly intimate Juilliard Theater, the musical values were well in hand, Christian Badea,the conductor, shaping a sure if sometimes awkwardly executed performance.

title: EAST GERMANY TELLS SCHMIDT TIES WILL DEPEND ON MISSILES
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, told Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany today that the future of inter-German relations was linked to West Germany's position on its planned deployment of new American nuclear weapons.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: U.S.-ANGOLA LINKS REPORTED CLOSER
description: The United States and Angola are moving closer to normalizing relations, according to State Department officials and the Angolan Government.

title: The Nation; Public's Chance To Help Finance A Gas Pipeline
description: Constructing the Alaska natural gas pipeline still won't be a snap but now, thanks to Congress, it won't be as financially risky a proposition -for the builders.

title: Alan Marks Is Fiance Of Barbara S. Hanzel
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hanzel of Providence, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara S. Hanzel, to Alan D. Marks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Marks of Plainview, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: ALCOHOLICS GET HELP AT WORK
description: THERE once was a time when the personal business of a company's employees was none of its business. But that is changing now, when it comes to chemical abuse - and with good reason.

title: KATHLEEN HOPPER TO BE WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Rabow of Ridgefield, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rabow's daughter, Kathleen Hopper, to Robert Massimilian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic Massimilian of Loudonville, N.Y. Miss Hopper is a daughter also of Allan Hopper Jr. of West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: MOBIL'S SPARROW
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE BOARD CERTIFIES DEFEAT OF BOND ISSUE FOR BUILDING PRISONS
description: The state's Board of Canvassers has certified the defeat of the $500 million bond issue for prison construction and the passage of a constitutional amendment.

title: A PLAN TO ALLOW VANS ON TACONIC IS DISPUTED
description: A controversy has developed in the Hudson Valley about a proposal to permit small vans and pickup trucks to use the northern section of the Taconic State Parkway, which up to now has been reserved for passenger cars.

title: CHINA TRIES TO END LOSS OF ITS FORESTS
description: The Chinese Government is embarking on a nationwide campaign to reverse the widespread loss of woodlands and forests by encouraging the Chinese to plant billions of trees.

title: THE POLITICS OF SPORTS: BRAINS, BRAWN, MONEY
description: Mayor Koch, by his own admission, is not a sports fan. Ritual forced him to make an appearance last spring at the New York Mets' opening game in Shea Stadium. To the despair of his companions, Mr. Koch left the ballpark just as the estimable Dave Kingman was coming to bat in the first inning.

title: PANEL BEGINS HEARINGS ON AID TO RUBELLA EPIDEMIC VICTIMS
description: A State Senate Democratic panel has begun hearings on whether available social services and financing will be adequate to handle the deaf and otherwise handicapped victims of the rubella epidemic of the mid-1960's who will no longer be eligible for services as children but may be as young adults.

title: December 13, 1981
description: NONFICTION AMERICA HELD HOSTAGE: The Secret Negotiations. By Pierre Salinger. 7 ART OF THE OLMSTED LANDSCAPE. Edited by Bruce Kelly. 11 BUILDING THE DREAM: A Social History of Housing in America. By Gwendolyn Wright. 10 CRITICAL OBSERVATIONS. By Julian Symons. 18 THE FBI AND MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR: From ''Solo'' to Memphis. By David J. Garrow. 9 FROM HOUSEWIFE TO HERETIC. By Sonia Johnson. 18 THE HOLY GOOF: A Biography of Neal Cassady. By William Plummer. 18 INSIDE THE IRANIAN REVOLUTION. By John D. Stempel. 7 INSIDE AND OUT: Hostage to Iran, Hostage to Myself. By Richard Queen With Patricia Hass. 7 MAN BITES MAN: Two Decades of Satiric Art. Edited by Steven Heller. 14 THE MIND'S I: Fantasies and Reflections on Self and Soul. Composed by Douglas R. Hofstadter and Daniel C. Dennett. 3 A MINGLED YARN: The Life of R.P. Blackmur.

title: The Region; N.J. Democrats Lose Momentum
description: With an increasing number of Republicans, including a Governor, due in Trenton next month, the Democrats had hoped to make the most of the time they had left and use their legislative majorities to pass some favorite bills. Last week, though, the lame duck legislators seemed to live up to their name.

title: Margiotta's Way Brings Conviction
description: Through two years of trials on corruption charges, Nassau County Republican chairman Joseph M. Margiotta's line of defense was, essentially, not guilty by reason of politics. Last week a jury decided that what Mr. Margiotta called routine patronage was actually fraud and extortion.

title: DANCE: PREMIERE OF AILEY 'LANDSCAPE'
description: The major premiere of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater season is Mr. Ailey's own ''Landscape,'' which was performed for the first time, and to enthusiastic response, Friday night at the City Center.

title: March Wedding For Joan Shlora
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Bernard Shlora of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Marie Shlora, to George Amiel Whipple 3d, son Mr. Whipple 2d of Matawan, N.J., and Hope Auchincloss Whipple of New York and Edgartown, Mass.

title: CUT IN U.S. FUNDS CALLED A DANGER TO SCHOOLS
description: New York State will lose $90 million in Federal aid for elementary and secondary education during the 1981-82 school year and $70 million to $80 million more next year, according to the State Commissioner of Education.

title: Antiques; NOTES OF A WORRIED PARENT; BY FRANCES PHIPPS
description: HARTFORD ABRAHAM LINCOLN'S manuscript notes for a speech he might never have given had his son been a better student were sold at auction earlier this month for $16,000.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Fiction producers. Some bookpeople, we reported here several weeks ago, believe that in the future their business will come to resemble the film industry. Book producers, heading small teams of editors, designers and other craftsmen, will create many, perhaps most of the books that are distributed to the trade by the well-known houses of Publishers Row.

title: SUED ON CURFEW, WESTCHESTER IS SET TO TALK ON AIRPORT NOISE
description: County officials have devised a plan for negotiating, rather than litigating, a solution to the noise problems around Westchester County Airport.

title: The Region; Governors Meet As Best They Can
description: They gave a coalition in Saratoga Springs last week, and nobody coalesced. In fact, with only three of its eight members present, the Coalition of Northeastern Governors could vote on none of the recommendatons made during its two-day session because it lacked a quorum.

title: Theater; OFF BROADWAY ACTOR SHARES HIS QUEST WITH STUDENTS
description: SCARSDALE FOR Mark Blum, all the classroom's a stage and the students - as well as the teachers - are not merely players, but directors, designers and discoverers of the possibilities of the performing arts in school and in life.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, DECEMBER 13, 1981
description: International Poland invoked emergency powers to declare a 'state of war' and impose what appeared to be a military Government. Gen. Wojciech Jarulzelski, the Prime Minister and Communist Party Leader, said in a speech over the Warsaw radio that the Government would be under the direction of an Army Council of National Salvation. He spoke just after troops had taken up positions and sealed off sections of the capital.(page 1, Column 6.) The Pope will send peace missions this week to Washington, Moscow, Paris, London and the United Nations to outline the ''terrifying prospects'' of the use of nuclear arms. The Vatican announcement said that the delegations, mainly composed of scientists from the Pontifical Academy of Sciences, would examine at a scientific level the possibilities of halting the nuclear arms race. (1:4.)

title: IDAHO GROUP TO BUY SMELTER THAT WAS PREPARING TO CLOSE
description: A group of Northern Idaho investors Friday announced plans to buy the ailing Bunker Hill Mining Company, which had begun to shut down operations and to lay off 600 of its 2,100 employees.

title: Practical Traveler; GUIDEBOOKS THAT DON'T WEAR OUT
description: With Christmas and Hanukkah fast approaching, the 1982 editions of the major guidebooks are beginning to appear as publishers and stores promote them as gifts. If a traveler is on your holiday list, however, he or she may prefer not a book that concentrates on the latest hotel and restaurant listings, but a less timely volume that stresses culture, history and detailed descriptions of prominent sights. Some such guidebooks take years to become outdated, and even then they make excellent wintertime reading at home as well as useful companions during a trip.

title: Store Owner Slain in Holdup
description: A store owner was slain here during a robbery attempt, the police said today. They said the victim - Joseph Inturrisi, 36 years old, of 665 Kingsbridge Lane, Ridgewood, N.J. - was shot in the face at the Farmer's Best Market on Route 17 about 10 P.M. Friday.

title: EVEN FOR TEXANS, THE BASSES ARE RICH
description: AMONG oil rich Texans, almost none have a lower profile than the Bass family of Fort Worth, itself a quiet, folksy city of 385,000 some 30 miles west of Dallas. The Basses themselves are unknown even to most Texans, although they are probably among the five or 10 wealthiest families in the United States.

title: ICE-SKATING COURSE FOR BLIND OFFERED
description: OLD BRIDGE THE Department of Parks and Recreation in this Middlesex County community has extended its free therapeutic ice-skating program to include blind residents throughout the state.

title: Affording a Home Strikes a Chord
description: Thank you, Ellen Tashie Frisina, for the article ''We Can't Afford a Home'' (Opinion Page). It expressed the concerns of so many of today's young, professional Long Island couples.

title: KOCH PLAN FOR 2,200 NEW HOUSES IN JEOPARDY, BUILDERS SAY
description: ''We're building affordable homes for working New Yorkers. This isn't just a promise. You'll be able to check on its progress over the next year.'' -Mayor Koch, Feb. 12, 1981, announcing a program to build 2,200 moderately priced, federally subsidized, one- and twofamily homes in troubled city neighborhoods.

title: Katherine Rose Novak Betrothed to James S. Vick
description: Mr. and Mrs. John E. Novak of Medford, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katherine Rose Novak, to James Stockard Vick, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Vick of Penfield, N.Y.

title: Music; NEW HAVEN IS FACING UP TO A BRASSY HOLIDAY
description: AS usual in mid-December, Connecticut is awash with ''Nutcrackers,'' ''Messiahs'' and candlelight carol concerts, some of which will be mentioned below. On Saturday, vistors to New Haven can revel in ''Tubalation,'' the greatest thing that's happened to tubas since Tubby.

title: Mary Roland Bell Engaged to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. A.L. Loomis Bell Jr. of Tenafly, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Roland Bell, to Paul Philip Stemler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Stemler of Newport Beach, Calif.

title: THE SPECIAL STATE OF INDIANA STANDARD
description: CHICAGO F ROM history's perspective, it might be argued that the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) has been on the skids for a long time. At the time of its founding 70 years ago as a result of the busting of Rockefeller's Standard Oil trust, it had no supply of crude oil of its own and has scrambled to remedy this inadequacy ever since. Once it served 85 percent of the lucrative Middle Western gasoline market, a share that has since slipped to 15 percent. It is not one of the lucky four American companies - not coincidentally, the nation's largest - producing oil in Saudi Arabia.

title: 'MY SON'S GOING TO SIT IN WITH US TONIGHT, FELLOWS'
