description: THEY played pinochle every Sunday night. One was a carpenter, one a truck driver. The fellow down the block owned the neighborhood bar. You could always find him there, except on Sunday evenings when he would close up promptly at 6 o'clock, then head straightaway for the game.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our country is on the verge of an abyss. Our economy is a tragedy.

title: Joanne Hanisian to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Hanisian of Wyckoff, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Hanisian, to D. Bruce Brauninger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Brauninger of West Newton, Mass. Miss Hanisian and her fiance are with the Vocational Adjustment Center in Boston. A June wedding is planned.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF V.D.- WITH TACT
description: CLAD in jeans and a blazer, her blond hair hanging to her shoulders, Cathy Sullivan looks at least 10 years younger than her 32 years and sounds a lot like a high school student when she seeks out young people who have contracted venereal disease.

title: RECITAL: JARRETT OFFERS RANGE OF PIANO WORKS
description: Keith Jarrett's solo concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday was a predictably dazzling exhibition of pianistic bravura devoid of stylistic commitment, other than to an inner voice. But that voice has assimilated and blended an extraordinary array of influences.

title: Business Conditions; WHAT SIZE THE MEDIA?
description: Prompted by technological innovation and legal change, few industries are changing as rapidly as the communications business. However, until recently information on the size of the total media market - television, radio, newspapers and magazines -has been difficult to get.

title: A TALK WITH SAUL BELLOW: ON HIS WORK AND HIMSELF
description: ''I SOMETIMES enjoy saying that anybody's life can be encompassed in about 10 wonderful jokes. One of my favorites is about an American singer who makes his debut at La Scala. He sings his first aria to great applause. And the crowd calls 'Ancora, vita, vita.' He sings it a second time, and again they call for an encore. Then a third time and a fourth ... Finally, panting and exhausted, he asks, 'How many times must I sing this aria?' Then someone tells him, 'Until you get it right.' That's how it is with me - I always feel I haven't gotten it quite right, and so I go on singing.''

title: MORE INJURIES ON THE JOB
description: An unrecognized economic epidemic is spreading in the United States. Risks of injury on the job have now reached their highest levels since the days of sweatshops and speed-ups in the 1920's and 1930's.

title: CHILDREN OF DIVORCE AIDED IN SCHOOL
description: YEAR-OLD Johnny had become a nightmare to the teacher of his fifth-grade class. He would start fights with other pupils, throw spitballs and interrupt lessons with angry comments and curses.

title: PRETORIA CHOOSES AMONG CLOAKS AND DAGGERS
description: In the nature of undercover games and excursions, there can never be real clarity on what a government ''knows.'' An agent can report something a prime minister never hears about, or the prime minister may hear of it and be distracted by other things that seem more important. In the recently botched coup attempt in the Seychelles, it would be surprising if the South African Government hadn't known at some level about the caper, given the number of white mercenaries with ties to its various security services.

title: 'EXTINCT' REDWOODS THRIVE IN THE STATE
description: PRINCETON ALTHOUGH it is not the kind of tree anyone might ordinarily want to trim for Christmas, it is spectacular, and its trunk is the biggest of any tree of its kind in New Jersey.

title: CAPITOL HILL 'CLANS'
description: From the tribal huts of the Amazon to Capitol Hill caucus rooms, politics is usually more a matter of family and blood relationship than of ideology. In Washington, as in New Guinea, clans feud over territory and women, while alliances are made and broken through marriage. Brothers unite to battle against other sets of brothers and fathers struggle to pass power on to their offspring.

title: THE ROCKY COURSE OF LOVE IN CHINA
description: One wintry afternoon in 1979, I nervously confessed to the official in charge of my daily life in China that I was in love with a Chinese man. His congratulations came so naturally that I, an American woman who had been living in China for nearly a year, never dreamed that I was embarking on a painful struggle that would be resolved only by the most powerful man in China, Vice Chairman Deng Xiaoping. I was teaching in Changsha, the capital of Hunan Province, a southern region that many Chinese consider one of the most ''bureaucratic and feudalistic'' in China. What most Americans would have regarded as a happy celebration of flourishing Sino-American relations was viewed differently there. The homeland of Mao Zedong is an outpost of outdated thoughts and practices as well as a stronghold for the Gang of Four's extreme views, which include hostility toward foreigners. It was not until I tried to get married that I began to fathom the impotence and frustration that ordinary Chinese people suffer as a result of a complex and slow-moving bureaucracy.

title: SOUNDS OF THE HOLIDAY SEASON
description: TEN versions of ''The Nutcracker'' will be performed in the Westchester area to brighten the holidays, and a multitude of ''Messiahs,'' ''Magnificats'' and seasonal music-making will take place in churches, concert halls and auditoriums countywide. Children will be favored with special performances of such holiday classics as ''Hansel and Gretel'' and ''Peter and the Wolf.''

title: On Fathers' Winning Custody Cases
description: The recent article ''More Fathers Seek Custody'' was sent to me by some Long Island associates. I represent a national organization that is diametrically opposed to the position of the various custodyseeking fathers' groups written about.

title: HEARING IS SET FOR THURSDAY ON KLEINDIENST LAW LICENSE
description: The Arizona Supreme Court will hear arguments next Thursday on a proposed one-year suspension of former Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst's license to practice law.

title: GROWING CENTER FOR FOREIGN-BORN ADULTS
description: RYE IN the last three years, the Cross Cultural Center at Wainwright House here has grown from a one-person tutoring project into an active international gathering place where a variety of programs are provided for foreign-born adults who live in the county and in neighboring areas.

title: THE SPECIAL SOUND OF GERMAN RADIO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Kostelanetz at present lives mostly in Berlin as a guest of the DAAD Kunstlerprogramm. He has written many books about contemporary art and literature. By RICHARD KOSTELANETZ BERLIN One quality that distinguishes German radio programming from American is that many of the best imaginative writers write for it, producing not only commentaries but creative works that are often more than an hour long. These radio productions can perhaps best be defined as being between live theater and literature. The German word for them is Horspiel; the literal equivalent in English is ''sound play.''

title: GOOD POET, BEST CRITIC
description: A MINGLED YARN The Life of R.P. Blackmur. By Russell Fraser. Illustrated. 384 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: JERSEY CITY HOSPITAL POSING PROBLEMS
description: JERSEY CITY OFFICIALS of this city and of the Jersey City Medical Center will have to decide next year whether to replace or renovate the 50-yearold, 18-story skyscraper complex. No matter which way the decision goes, it is bound to stir controversy.

title: CHILDREN OF WORKING MOTHERS
description: With more than half of American married women holding jobs, an image of the career woman/mother who manages job and children with aplomb is fast replacing the ''happy homemaker'' stereotype of the 1950's. One stereotype, however, may be just as misleading as the other. In truth, many working mothers feel guilty about leaving their babies with someone else. They worry about the possible long-term effects of day care. They wonder whether the ''quality time'' spent with their children makes up for the quantity of time spent away from them.

title: YALE TO GET VIDEOTAPED INTERVIEWS WITH HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS
description: Yale will become the first American university to house a collection of videotaped interviews with survivors of the Holocaust. A local group is to donate more than 200 such interviews to Yale's Sterling Memorial Library next week, university officials said.

title: CONCERT: ORPHEUS PLAYS WITHOUT A CONDUCTOR
description: Orpheus, the conductorless chamber orchestra that gave its only New York concert of the season Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, is a musician's wish-fantasy come gloriously true. All musicians resent conductors at some point or another, just as we all resent authority in any form. Conductors justify their function by pointing to the size of any ensemble over a quintet and the complexity of most post-Mozart scores.

title: 400 Freestyle Mark Set By Salnikov of U.S.S.R.
description: Vladimir Salnikov, a double Olympic champion, set a world record in the 400-meter freestyle today and helped the Soviet men's team to first place at the halfway stage of the European Cup.

title: Jewish Museum Names Eight New Trustees
description: Eight new trustees have been named to the board of the Jewish Museum. They are Nathan S. Ancell, chairman of Ethan Allen; Martin Blumenthal, president of A.J. Hollander & Company; Leonard Greenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of Coleco Industries, and Betty Ratner, a member of the advisory committee to the Cleveland Museum of Art and chairman and co-founder of the Ratner Day School and Montessori Pre-school of Cleveland.

title: Corrections
description: John Effren is a doctoral candidate in psychology at Hofstra University, and should have been referred to as Mr. Effren in an article about professional advertising last Sunday.

title: FLORIDA SEEKS TO PROTECT THE MANATEE
description: Ancient mariners used to think that manatees, also known as sea cows, were mermaids. While that belief no longer persists, the ponderous marine mammal has won the hearts of politicians and environmentalists in Florida, as well as that of a rock star.

title: A HOMAGE TO HIS WOMEN
description: FAMILY A Novel in the Form of a Memoir. By Herbert Gold. 192 pp. New York: Arbor House. $11.95.

title: Around the World; Queen Elizabeth to Carry Constitution to Canada
description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip will visit Canada early next year to deliver the country's new constitution, Buckingham Palace announced today.

title: 'BUM' NICKELS
description: Despite the current softness in the numismatic market rare coins remain too high-priced for many hobbyists who have turned, in growing numbers, to areas of collecting where the emphasis is on fun, rather than profit. One such area with particular appeal is the fascinating field of ''bum'' nickels.

title: FRANK SINATRA-CLOSER TO ROCK
description: Is Frank Sinatra still the king of pop ballad singing? His impressive new album, ''She Shot Me Down'' (Reprise SS 2305), in which Mr. Sinatra returns to the mournful saloon style of ''Only the Lonely'' and ''Where Are You,'' shows him in such remarkable control of his baritone that even some bizarre song choices become triumphs of interpretive savvy.

title: ATTACK ON KUHN SHOOK BASEBALL TALKS
description: The Mets traded Doug Flynn, the Yankees kept Ron Guidry, nobody signed Reggie Jackson, the pitchers were told they could blow on cold hands if both managers agreed, the batters were told to wear flaps over both ears and the rebels opened the attack on Bowie Kuhn.

title: ROWAYTON PAGEANT JOINS PRIVATE SECTOR
description: AN outdoor Nativity pageant will be presented in Rowayton next Sunday as it has been every year since 1963, except for one change: This year there will be no direct assistance of the City of Norwalk.

title: WORST DROUGHT IN CENTURY HITS SPAIN'S SOUTH
description: Fausto Lopez, who has a small farm in Spain's drought-stricken south, let his mule rest and picked up brown, dry earth. He watched it trickle between his fingers. ''This is not soil,'' he said, ''it's dust.''

title: LEFTIST PREMIER FACES A TEST AS MALTESE VOTE
description: Maltese voters cast ballots today in a parliamentary election that could decide whether this Mediterranean island nation will move closer to the West or continue to pursue nonalignment.

title: WHO'LL PAY THE BILL FOR HOPE CREEK II?
description: NEWARK THE almost certain decision by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company to abandon its Hope Creek II nuclear-power plant may cost its customers $350 million over the next six or 12 years, according to a high state regulatory official who has been a party to the negotiations.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Kammer Quintet Offers Work by Cambini
description: The young wind players of the Kammer Quintet seemed a little ill at ease with one another last Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. Barber's ''Summer Music'' and the cheerful little Sonatine by Marcel Bitsch demanded a subtlety of expression and a careful blending of sound that these players were simply not able to give.

title: THE COMPUTER AND THE EGO
description: THE MIND'S I Fantasies and Reflections on Self and Soul.Composed and Arranged by Douglas R. Hofstadter and Daniel C. Dennett. 501 pp. New York: Basic Books. $15.50.

title: MARGIOTTA DENIES HE'S SET TO RESIGN
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato says that Joseph M. Margiotta, convicted last week of Federal mail-fraud and extortion charges, plans to resign as chairman of the Republican Party of Nassau County. Mr. Margiotta says, however, that he has ''not yet made any decisions'' about his plans.

title: Around the Nation; Prisoner Charges Police Set a Dog on Him
description: Three members of the police force of Signal Hill, Calif., have been accused of unleashing a dog to attack a prisoner and of spraying him with tear gas in a locked cell.

title: CALIFORNIA FEELS ECONOMIC SQUEEZE
description: The state government and local governments in California are facing an increasingly serious financial squeeze that officials say is rooted in the nation's economic slowdown and a wave of tax-cutting that began in 1978. The financial problems, in turn, are causing political problems for Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.

title: SCHELL'S 'TALES FROM VIENNA WOODS'
description: To the strains of Strauss waltzes, the characters in Maximilian Schell's ''Tales From the Vienna Woods'' demonstrate the proposition (listed on an opening title) that ''nothing creates as strong an impression of infinity as stupidity.'' The line is from Odon Von Horvath, author of the 1931 play on which Mr. Schell's film is based, and it may be something better read than demonstrated.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Sometime in the last few years the Travel section had an article about apartment or house swapping for vacationers; could you supply the names and addresses of agencies or publications that offer such a service? - A.D., New York, N.Y. Answer:One of the largest organizations in the business of home exchange is the Vacation Exchange Club (350 Broadway, New York, N.Y., 212-966-2576). The club has about 6,000 listings, half of which are foreign. Nearly all 50 states are represented, including Alaska and Hawaii. The club's directories (which come out in February and April each year) go to 10,000 people, and the club is affiliated with 17 similar clubs overseas. The charge for being listed and receiving two directories is $21; the deadline for being in the April 1982 directory is Feb. 15.

title: Woman to Head Press Club
description: Vivian Vahlberg, assistant Washington bureau chief of The Daily Oklahoman, The Oklahoma City Times and The Colorado Springs Sun, is the first woman to be elected president of the 73-year-old National Press Club.

title: READING, WRITING AND THINKING
description: THE PSYCHOLOGY OF LITERACY By Sylvia Scribner and Michael Cole. Illustrated. 335 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25. By GEOFFREY NUNBERG

title: No Headline
description: E. KENTUCKY OUSTS BOISE STATE

title: Jim Wilson Security Tight for Visit by Bush
description: Representative Peter A. Peyser, Democrat of the Bronx, being stopped by a Secret Service agent at the Plaza Hotel Friday night, during a fete at which Vice President Bush was a guest. A metal detector alerted the agent to the fact Mr. Peyser was carrying a penknife and he demanded identification. After satisfying the agent's request, Mr. Peyser retrieved his drink and his penknife and joined the party.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Creationism Law on Trial In Arkansas Suit
description: When does science become a religion and religion science? That question, with its implications for issues of academic freedom and public school curriculums, is at the heart of a trial that opened last week in the Federal District Court in Little Rock, Ark.

title: LIVELY BIRTHPLACE OF A FATEFUL WORD
description: JAN MORRIS has written extensively about Venice; among her latest books are ''Destinations'' and ''The Venetian Empire.'' By JAN MORRIS

title: STATE'S ARTISTS FIND NEW HOME
description: HARTFORD TWO months ago, Nikki O'Neill, the wife of the Governor, sent out a request for artwork and books by Connecticut artists, craftsmen and authors to be displayed in the Executive Residence at 990 Prospect Avenue. ''It's been like Christmas here ever since,'' Mrs. O'Neill said last week.

title: Territory for Pioneers
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics' Choices
description: OPERA Verdi's operas are heard often enough these days that news of another performance is likely to be greeted by a yawn, if not a thinly concealed expression of ennui like ''Who's singing?''

title: L.I. TEEN-AGER WINS TV FANS
description: HAUPPAUGE WHEN Hauppauge High's class of '82 voted on the senior most likely to succeed, it bypassed such traditional candidates as the school president and captain of the football team and settled on a student who spends her school hours not in a classroom but in a Manhattan television studio.

title: ALTERNATIVE SCHOOLS POOLING KNOWLEDGE
description: A NEW organization, the Alternative Schools Support Group, is attracting Westchester residents who are employed in alternative education as well as those interested in starting an alternative school. The idea for the group originated with the director of the School Outside School in Elmsford, Betty Walsh, who said that working in an alternative program was a satisfying but often isolating experience.

title: Weinberger for the Defense
description: Hedrick Smith's article seems to rest, alas, on the extraordinary - and, I believe, tragic - assumption that the United States and the Soviet Union have no alternative to preparation for war(s) on a scale far more vast than World War II. What precisely and irrefutably forces us to assume this? Shouldn't political leaders and thinkers on both sides exhaustively explore this question before any other? And shouldn't they search earnestly for peaceful alternatives? My questions may seem naive, but surely their ''realistic'' (Realpolitik) alternatives give new meanings - economically, politically and morally - to words like ''tragedy'' and ''disaster.'' NELSON R. TRENNER JR., Princeton, N.J.

title: THE APPEAL OF BIEDERMEIER FURNITURE
description: Biedermeier furniture, a style that reigned in Germany and Austria from about 1815 to about 1850, has attracted a loyal following in this country in recent seasons. And now, with an exhibition of some excellent examples of this Neo-Classic mode on view through Saturday at Jean Paul Beaujard, 209 East 76th Street, there may be increased interest in the period.

title: THERE'S NO PLACE LIKE HOME
description: BUILDING THE DREAM A Social History of Housing in America. By Gwendolyn Wright. Illustrated. 329 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.50.

title: The World; Papandreou Aims at Turkey
description: Andreas Papandreou last week deepened the doubt over Greek participation in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The display seemed intended largely for domestic consumption, but that was small comfort for Greece's Western allies.

title: DISSOLVING A 'PARTNERSHIP' WITH TEACHERS
description: DESPITE President Reagan's proclamation designating the week of Nov. 15-21 as American Education Week, I did not visit my local school, as all good citizens were supposed to do. If that's sedition, so be it.

title: Topics; CHANGES OF HEART AND VENUE; In Shorts
description: There are singles bars (''I don't usually go to this kind of place but....''). Cocktail parties (''I hate big parties, don't you?'').

title: LOMAX PASSES CARDINALS' TEST
description: ST. LOUIS THE three boys had waited patiently at the head of the line for more than an hour. Now that Neil Lomax had finally arrived at the store, ''like Santa Claus,'' someone jokingly observed, the boys wanted more than autographed pictures of the Cardinals' exciting rookie quarterback.

title: PHILIPS' LAMP DIMS A BIT
description: EINDHOVEN, The Netherlands I T'S a bad time to be an electrical and/or electronics company in Europe. Recession is dragging at traditional markets and productivity is down. Japan Inc., having hopped the Pacific and cut a wide swath in North America, has hopped again, this time across the Atlantic. And its freshly alerted American competition is right on its heels.

title: Prospects
description: Triple-Digit Deficits

title: More Poles Arrive in Austria
description: The number of Polish refugees arriving in Austria continued to increase despite new travel restrictions imposed by the Austrian Government, the Interior Ministry said today. The Government announced last week that Poles would be required to obtain travel visas. The Ministry said that 1,445 Poles sought asylum in Austria last week, about 200 more than the week before, and that there were now 50,000 Poles in the country.

title: Susan Elizabeth Crosbie Is the Bride Of John Fischer Jr., Business Adviser
description: Susan Elizabeth Crosbie, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Robert Mason Crosbie of Mankato, Minn., was married at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in New York yesterday to John Joseph Fischer Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. Fischer of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: One-Man Team on TV
description: The decision by NBC Sports to use only one television announcer for the Jets-Browns game - Dick Enberg, doing the play-by-play - hardly was as experimental as last year's Jets-Dolphins game at Miami. No announcers were employed then, and about half the people who telephoned the network in New York complained.

title: Weinberger for the Defense
description: The question raised in the title - ''How Many Billions for Defense?'' - is whether the nation is willing to pay for defense needs as Secretary Weinberger sees them.

title: G.O.P. STRENGTH APPEARS SOLID IN WAKE OF MARGIOTTA TRIAL
description: THE conviction of the Nassau County Republican leader, Joseph M. Margiotta, for extortion is not likely to turn Long Island voters away from his party, political leaders and observers from both parties said after the verdict became known.

title: Jeanne Kinzer Drewsen Married to Jay F. Sharbutt
description: The marriage of Jeanne Kinzer Drewsen, a literary agent, to Jay Finbar Sharbutt, theater critic for The Associated Press in New York, took place yesterday at the bride's Manhattan apartment. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carol Anderson, rector of All Angels Episcopal Church.; The bride, daughter of Brig. Gen. John M. Kinzer, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Kinzer of Gainesville, Fla., was graduated from Stetson University and the - Yale University Law School. Formerly an associate with the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton -

title: New York Times Magazine December 13, 1981
description: William Safire 16 On Language Woodshed Blues Russell Baker 26 Sunday Observer Getting Serious John Lombardi 37 Nureyev's Fight Against Time Stansfield Turner 42 A New Strategy for NATO R.W. Apple Jr. 52 A New Party Shakes Up Britain Michael Norman 54 Golden Boys of the Ghetto Seymour Topping 72 The Hidden Mongolia Robert Lindsey 96 Al Davis Tackles Pro Football William Severini 108 A Mall Covers the Waterfront Kowinski Judith Shapiro 120 The Rocky Course of Love in China Terry Robards 148 Wine Body-Warming Drinks 150 Fashion Heat-Wave Suedes Craig Claiborne 154 Food with Pierre Franey Soup Inspired by the Bible Marilyn Bethany 156 Design In Santa Fe the Past Is Present 162 Puzzles Answers, Page 166 170 Letters Cover: Photograph by Rene Burri/Magnum Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Around the World; U.S. Reviewing Visa Of Ulster's Rev. Paisley
description: Amid pressure from Congress, the State Department said today that it was reviewing the multiple-entry visa of the Rev. Ian Paisley, the hard-line Northern Irish Protestant leader, who is planning to visit the United States soon.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Seeking a Cure For Dr. Deadbeat
description: When it comes to repaying Federal student loans, graduates of the health professions may be among the most prominent deadbeats, the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee learned last week.

title: Quake Felt in San Francisco
description: A slight earthquake estimated at less than 3.5 on the Richter scale shook the San Francisco Peninsula early today, state officials said. They said there had been no reports of injuries or damage.

title: Rosemary Konner Fiancee of Robert S. Steinbaum
description: The engagement of Rosemary Konner to Robert S. Steinbaum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Steinbaum of Mantoloking, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Joan W. Konner of Palisades, N.Y., and Jack Konner of Ridgefield, Conn. A spring wedding is planned.

title: On Language By William Safire Woodshed Blues Kimble Mead
description: ''My visit to the Oval Office,'' said budget director David Stockman last month, after receiving the dressing-down reserved for inveterate leakers by President Reagan, ''... was more in the nature of a visit to the woodshed after supper.''

title: BALDRIDGE SITS TALL IN THE SADDLE ON ECONOMIC POLICY
description: He was the first Cabinet officer to predict a recession this year, the first to talk about a jobless rate that could exceed 9 percent. And when the Administration was trying to figure out what to do about Japanese cars, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige was also calling the shots remarkably accurately. The Japanese, he said, would have to accept some voluntary limitations on exports. Now, as head of a conglomerate department whose 38,000 bureaucrats manage public works, chart the seas, forecast the weather, count the population, collect economic statistics and control imports and exports, Mr. Baldrige is at the vortex of the budget debate.

title: IN LIBYA, QADDAFI PERSONALITY CULT IS ALL-PERVASIVE
description: It would probably not be the kind of thing that Reagan Administration officials would use to ornament a desk or a bumper, but the faithful here can obtain from the Information Ministry a small printed sticker that says, ''I will live and die with Muammar el-Qaddafi.''

title: SAKHAROV IS A SPECIAL CASE- FOR BETTER AND FOR WORSE
description: Among Soviet dissidents, Andrei D. Sakharov has always been special. Nobody else has challenged the Kremlin on human rights from the lofty station he occupied when he made his first public criticisms 13 years ago. Generally, those ready to sacrifice careers and what there is of freedom have come from lesser castes in the Soviet hierarchy, their courage unblunted by the honor and privilege heaped on Dr. Sakharov for his early work on nuclear weapons. Nor was he spurred into opposition by a personal experience of discrimination or repression, as were many others who struggled for basic freedoms.

title: TO ME THE BUILDING WAS LOVELY, SO I BOUGHT IT
description: John Foreman is a writer of travel guides and health and beauty books whose first novel, ''A Corporate Affair,'' is to be published next year by Fawcett. He has an ownership interest in two Manhattan brownstones, but at one time he owned 88 apartments in brownstones and a larger building on West 157th Street. By JOHN FOREMAN

title: ALBANY LEADERS RESUME REDISTRICTING TALKS
description: The Democratic and Republican leaders of the Legislature have reopened negotiations on reapportionment after a decision by the Senate majority leader to call off a session at which the Legislature had planned to draw new district lines for itself.

title: WHEN A TOURIST IS WORTH A DETOUR
description: RICHARD F. SHEPARD is a reporter for The Times. By RICHARD F.SHEPARD

title: Kathleen Mulhall Engaged
description: The engagement of Kathleen Anne Mulhall to Bruce Henry Kostic, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew H. Kostic of St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., has been announced by Betty A. Mulhall of Morristown, N.J., and Robert L. Mulhall of East Hanover, N.J., parents of the future bride.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Pursuing the Wrong Culprit?
description: After years of worrisome uncertainty, it now seems you can bring home the bacon and eat it, with relative peace of mind. An expert committee reported last week that removing nitrites and nitrates from cured meats would not have a major impact on health - partly because such meats are not a major source.

title: IRAN REBUFFED BY U.S. IN BID FOR PARTS FOR ITS F-14'S
description: Iran has asked to buy spare parts to put its fleet of Grumman F-14 fighter planes into the air. So far, however, the Reagan Administration has stuck to its policy of not allowing military equipment or high technology items to be exported to Iran.

title: Repellent Spray Used To Deter Tree Thefts
description: City officials, tired of seeing their park evergreens chopped down every year at this time for Christmas trees, have decided to douse the trees with a chemical that is supposed to emit a foul odor when the tree is taken indoors.

title: Personal Finance; GETTING AN EXECUTIVE TO RELOCATE
description: M ORE and more executives are finding that even with corporate sweeteners, they cannot afford to accept promotions if it means they have to move to another city. The real estate and mortgage costs are simply prohibitively high.

title: ARMY TESTS DIRT BIKES
description: Some people spend a lot of money to roar through forests and over hills on motorcycles, but for Sgt. Russell Blake it is just a job, one that he enjoys as an Army Signal Corps messenger.

title: The Nation; Mr. Donovan Again Belabored
description: Once again, questions have been raised about how Raymond J. Donovan, the Secretary of Labor, comported himself in the rough-and-tumble New Jersey construction trade before he joined the Reagan Cabinet.

title: HAIG ANKARA VISIT ENCOURAGES TURKS
description: The scheduled arrival here Sunday of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has been welcomed by Ankara as new evidence of a growing recognition in Washington of the importance of Turkey in this volatile region.

title: Crafts
description: HOLIDAY craft shows in galleries and shops around the state focus on two kinds of buyers: The collector looking for an investment and the shopper seeking quality and individuality in useful items.

title: STAFF OF ANTICORRUPTION CHIEF WILL BE CUT A THIRD ON JAN. 1
description: The staff of the state's special anticorruption prosecutor, established nine years ago after the Knapp Commission investigations of police corruption, is being reduced by a third.

title: Food; CHRISTMAS HARD CANDIES: SPIRITED HANDS GUIDE A FADING ART
description: WILLISTON PARK HENRY SCHRIVER, the candy maker at Hildebrandt's in Williston Park, is one of the last practictioners of a dying art. He makes Christmas candies by hand. In December, after all the chocolate turkeys are out of the way, he spends several days a week in the basement workroom of Hildebrandt's cooking up batches of sugar and water, which are flavored and tinted, then pulled, twisted and shaped.

title: Follow-Up on the News; A Pilot's Plunge
description: One day last December, James F. Tobin, a civilian Army pilot, was flying at 9,000 feet over New Jersey, bound for the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland with a load of small weapons. Suddenly, something went wrong with the cabin door of his plane, a Beech Aircraft U-21.

title: About Long Island
description: FOR people who lead busy lives, especially those responsible for other people's lives, there comes a time when the vocation grows too heavy, and they turn to avocations for relief. Churchill and Eisenhower painted.

title: A CORNUCOPIA OF MUSIC FOR THE HOLIDAY SEASON
description: OVER the centuries, Christmas has been a source of inspiration to composers throughout the Western World. The number of carols, anthems, masses and motets, operas and ballets connected with this joyous season has reached gigantic proportions.

title: 400 IDAHO FARMERS CLUB JACKRABBITS TO DEATH TO RESCUE CROPS
description: Hundreds of farmers clubbed jackrabbits to death today in a roundup that had been called to save crops from the proliferating animals.

title: ONE FOR THE BOOKS
description: Although the number of bridge books published annually in the United States is greater than in any other country, no American can claim to be the most prolific author on the subject. The names of Ely Culbertson and Charles Goren may suggest themselves, but they are disqualified since almost all their books were the work of other pens - and very able ones.

title: JABS OF MEANING
description: LIFE SUPPORTS New and Collected Poems. By William Bronk. Woodcuts by Eugene G. Canade. 249 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: North Point Press. $20.

title: A NEW PARTY SHAKES UP BRITAIN
description: R.W. Apple Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The New York Times. By R.W. Apple Jr.

title: AN ARTIST EMERGING FROM THE 60'S COUNTERCULTURE; CHICAGO
description: Ten years ago, or thereabouts, there arose among certain artists of the younger generation a strongly held conviction that art, in order to remain spiritually uncontaminated by the evils of a wicked society, must henceforth take only the most perishable forms. It was assumed, of course, that ours was an especially wicked society, and the whole notion of producing a durable art object, such as a painting or a sculpture, that would, if successful, take its place as a valued part of an established cultural tradition, was therefore rejected as a morally odious compromise with a corrupt and moribund system. Permanence in art was judged to be incompatible with the ideals of the social revolution that many of these artists professed to espouse.

title: SUCCESSORS SWAP LAGUARDIA YARNS AS CENTENNIAL BEGINS FOR 99TH MAYOR
description: Friends and former associates of Fiorello H. La Guardia filled the Terrace Room of the Roosevelt Hotel with memories yesterday at the beginning of centennial celebrations for New York's ''Little Flower.''

title: GOING FOR BAROQUE
description: Insomniacs take note: The annual Midnight Concert at the Metropolitan Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in West Orange on Dec. 26 has been known to keep audiences awake into the wee hours.

title: Greenwich Resident 'Touched' by 62's Loss
description: The depths of human compassion are truly touched when one reads of the soul-tearing and heart-rending embarrassment generated by the loss of ''mystique,'' ''status'' and ''charm'' by the 62 Stamford homes stripped of their Cos Cob (i.e. Greenwich) address.

title: Bombing in Sri Lanka
description: One of two unidentified motorcyclists tossed a small bomb at the headquarters of Sri Lanka's leading opposition party today. The explosion injured a police guard and five bystanders. The attack on the building belonging to the Freedom Party of former Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike came just three days after the Government returned the structure to a breakaway faction of the party.

title: ANDREW D. SILK, 28, EDITOR AND WRITER
description: Andrew David Silk, the editorial page editor of Greenwich (Conn.) Time and the author of a recent article on his struggle with cancer, died yesterday morning in New York Hospital in New York City. He was 28 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: 'CREATION' TRIAL: OLD SOUTH AGAINST NEW
description: Getting ''right'' with the ''Creator' has always been a high priority in the South's Bible Belt, where fire-and-brimstone, hell-and-damnation sermons account for much of the region's character.

title: Fashion; HEAT WAVE SUEDES
description: Time was that leather clothes were hauled out of closets with the first frost and returned with the first thaw.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; 'Free Speech' For Religion
description: The United States Supreme Court last week erected an unusually clear road sign at the point in constitutional law where freedom of speech meets freedom of religion.

title: Herschel Walker, Superstar
description: The ''Scorecard on Heisman Winners'' incorrectly identifies the school of Pat Sullivan (1971 winner) as the University of Alabama.

title: When 'Lock 'em Up!' Means 'Let 'em Go'
description: Draco, a Greek legislator, didn't worry about nuances of justice when he codified Athenian law in 620 B.C. He is said to have prescribed death for most crimes. Asked why, he replied that he felt lesser crimes deserved death, and he couldn't think of a stiffer penalty for the larger ones.

title: JOY DIVISION LIVES ON
description: Joy Division played its last concert a year and a half ago, but in the record stores the British rock quartet lives on. ''Still'' (Factory Records), a new double album of studio and concert performances by the group, vies for shelf space with numerous Joy Division bootlegs and with the band's two previous albums for Factory, ''Unknown Pleasures'' and ''Closer,'' both of which are still on the British best-seller charts. There are not likely to be any more official Joy Division releases. After the singer and lyricist Ian Curtis committed suicide in May 1980, the three remaining members of Joy Division decided they could no longer work under the same name. Within a few months they had re-emerged as New Order, and recently Factory Records released ''Movement,'' the first New Order LP.

title: Dining Out; SUBTLY EXCITING JAPANESE FOOD
description: HAYASAKA opened in Commack about six weeks ago. Housed in a roadside building, the restaurant has a bright, comfortable interior of light wood. In addition to regular tables and chairs, it has a separate tatami room with floor cushions, and there is a large sushi bar in one corner from the dexterous handiwork of the sushi chef be seen. The entire kitchen behind it is open and visible.

title: Realty News; Lease at 535 Madison
description: The newly constructed, 36-story office tower at 54th Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan will lease commercial space to the Gannett Company, a communications concern, and Grindlays Bank Ltd., a large British banking company, it has been announced.

title: IONA SCORES, 80-71, OVER NORTHEASTERN
description: Iona continued to excel at its home arena, the Mulcahy Center, defeating Northeastern, 80-71, in the final of the Manufacturers Hanover basketball classic tonight.

title: ALLA BREVA DEFEATS PEAT MOSS
description: It is said around the race track that weight can stop a freight train. Yesterday at Aqueduct, Peat Moss was derailed under 126 pounds.

title: WHAT'S DOING AROUND TAMPA BAY
description: Tampa, the major city on Tampa Bay - a 25-mile-long irregular arm of the Gulf of Mexico - has seen some big changes in the last few years, and a lot more are in store. In the 1970's, its citizens say, the city went big league. This commercial center and major port on Florida's west coast got a huge new international airport and major sports: the Tampa Bay Rowdies soccer team and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers of the National Football League.

title: SHIFT IS CONCEDED IN SAKHAROV CASE
description: The Soviet Union acknowledged obliquely today that it had bowed to the demand made by Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and rights advocate, when he began his 17-day hunger strike.

title: No Headline
description: Based on exhaustive reporting by The New York Times, ''No Hiding Place'' (Times Books, $15.50) reconstructs the story of the Iranian hostage crisis. The book contains exclusive interviews with 20 of the hostages, President Jimmy Carter, David Rockefeller, Henry Kissinger, the Shah's sister, the doctors who treated the Shah, the Iranian student ''leaders'' and many others. There is an introduction by The Times's executive editor, A.M. Rosenthal, as well as profiles of all the hostages, a chronology of events and illustrative maps.

title: Constance Zeiger Affianced to Antonio Rossmann
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Zeiger of Willis, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Mary Zeiger, to Antonio Rossmann, son of the late Herbert Rossmann of East Orange, N.J., and the late Yolanda Sonsini Rossmann of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Arden Trio, Alumni Of Yale School of Music
description: The piano trio can seem an awkward ensemble, the keyboard overpowering its stringed partners, the cello sawing away at bass lines and the violin distracted by soloistic escapades. But the Arden Trio, at its debut Tuesday at Carnegie Recital Hall, seemed not to be a trio at all, but a single musical instrument, played with eminent virtuosity and sensitivity.

title: YOUNG TOYMAKERS AID YOUNG PATIENTS
description: LITCHFIELD ''IT'S a case of the less fortunate helping the less fortunate,'' said Zandy Thompson, an instructor at the Connecticut Junior Republic here. He was talking about his students, who are building toys and fashioning Christmas ornaments and table decorations for handicapped patients at Newington Children's Hospital.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Marvis Martin Offers American Songs
description: The word ''promising'' is sometimes employed as polite disparagement. Not so with Marvis Martin, a soprano who made her formal New York debut Tuesday at the 92d Street Y. Miss Martin gave an uneven recital. But at her best she displayed a talent and a temperament that could make her into an important singer.

title: England Is Resurrecting Its First Man-of-War
description: As squalls warn of coming winter gales, divers are working against time to raise England's first recorded man-of-war from a grave of mud off this naval harbor where it has lain for more than 400 years.

title: Television Week
description: Live Rock Rod (''Da Ya Think I'm Sexy?'') Stewart is one of the most popular and distinctive rock singers of our day. Now on a four-month tour of the United States and Canada, the 36-year-old British expatriate will pause in Los Angeles on Saturday to perform at the Forum, in a concert that will be broadcast live on more than 100 television stations across the nation. To be seen locally on Channel 5, at 11:30 P.M., the program will be simulcast in stereo on radio station WNEW-FM, 102.7.

title: 2 TOWNS MOVE TO ABOLISH PLANNING UNITS
description: EAST HAMPTON ASSERTING that economics, not politics, dictated the decision, the newly elected Republican majority of the Town Board here intends to abolish the town's Planning Department when it takes office in January.

title: SLOW SALES DRIVE SMALLER BROKERS OUT OF BUSINESS
description: After 17 years as the owner of a small, independent real-estate agency in Norwalk, Conn., Harriet Haffner can no longer afford to go it alone. Like others in the same position, she has found that the slow market of the last two years plus sharp inflation have pushed her overhead, currently running at $4,000 a month, beyond what she can afford.

title: Out of Context
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Looking at Sculpture' At Met Junior Museum
description: ''Looking at Sculpture'' will be on view through Jan. 3 in the Junior Museum exhibition area of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: GARDEN STATE BOWL LOSES REGIONAL LOOK
description: The fourth Garden State Bowl game will be a matchup of the speed of Tennessee against the offensive muscle of Wisconsin.

title: A LITERARY TALE OF TWO PASSAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: Design; IN SANTA FE THE PAST IS PRESENT
description: or centuries it had been the home of the Tewa and the Keres Indians, even before the Navajo and the Apache came. Then in 1610, with the arrival of the Spanish, it became one of the first European settlements in North America.

title: APARTMENT CONVERSION: THE STARK FACTS
description: DIPLOMAT DRIVE, the site of two Diplomat Towers apartment buildings, is not the classiest address in Mount Kisco. The complex has figured frequently but seldom favorably in the news. Reports have ranged from tenant complaints about heat and hot water scarcity to a sensational shootout a couple of years back, involving drug dealers and an alleged ''hit-woman'' who was in an advanced state of pregnancy when she was arrested.

title: UNIONS VOW SUPPORT ON KEEPING THE GARDEN OPEN
description: Leaders of unions representing workers at Madison Square Garden have pledged their support in efforts to keep the Garden ''open and viable'' at a time when it faces mounting fiscal problems.

title: THE BLOND FROM THE BRONX RETURNS
description: Earl is sitting in his easy chair, as he does every night, stolidly watching television, as he does every night, while his wife makes dinner in the kitchen, as she does every night, when the doorbell rings. It is his new neighbor, Ramona, a sultry blonde in a skintight tank top, wrapped in a transparent shawl she flicks like a stripper's boa.

title: Hoboken Gentrification And the City's Poor
description: The Nov. 8 article on Hoboken minimized the reality of gentrification's wholesale displacement of the poor, the elderly and the minorities. The recent acceleration of the ''Hoboken renaissance'' has resulted in a wave of the ultimate tactic of tenant harassment: Acquiring vacant buildings through arson.

title: Business Forum; HIGH MORTGAGE? LOOK AT PRICES OF LAND
description: H IGH interest rates have crippled the home building industry and stifled the home buying aspirations of many Americans over the last 18 months. Although the prime has probably peaked, there is continuing pressure on the Federal Reserve to lower the cost of money more rapidly. But, the nation's preoccupation with mortgage rates has obscured the fact that the rising cost of other housing resources - land, building materials and energy - may present far more important long-term problems for the housing industry.

title: ALLEGATIONS ON DONOVAN NOT ACTED ON 3 YEARS AGO
description: Allegations against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan that are now the subject of a Justice Department inquiry were not acted on when they were first presented to the Federal Government by Mario Montuoro, a former officer of Local 29 of the Laborers' International Union.

title: 51 FOOD PLACES CITED BY CITY HEALTH DEPT. FOR CODE VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 51 food establishments that it said violated the Health Code. The department, in its announcement last week, also gave the names of 10 establishments that had reopened after correcting earlier violations and five that had been closed for failing to do so.

title: STATE DEMANDS YOUTH RESIDENCE UNDER INQUIRY MAKE CHANGES
description: BERNARDS TOWNSHIP ARESIDENTIAL treatment center for children that has been under investigation for two and a half years has been ordered by the state to come up with plans by Dec. 31 to correct ''weaknesses in administration.''

title: CENTRAL AMERICANS ANXIOUS OVER EFFECTS OF REAGAN POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration's hard-line strategy in Central America has sharply divided political opinion in the region between those who share Washington's alarm at leftist expansionism and those who argue that its policy is aggravating the conflict.

title: HISPANIC IMPACT ON THE ARTS: MYSTICISM TO MACHISMO
description: Last month I happened to hear a pair of Hispanic pianists - using the term ''Hispanic'' to cover any nationality south of Texas, and not including Spain - and was struck by the strength of the playing. Horacio Gutierrez, with his power and blazing technique, his formidable sonority and individuality of conception, is already one of the most impressive pianists before the public. Santiago Rodriguez, also Cuban-born, represents a different pole of pianism. His is playing that has temperament, poetry, a canny use of coloristic resource and an extraordinary empathy with the audience. In its way, the playing was as impressive as that of Gutierrez.

title: Westchester Guide; DUELING IN PURCHASE
description: The fencing teams of the State University of New York, College at Purchase and Baruch College will compete at 6 P.M. tomorrow in the state college's gymnasium at Purchase. Last year the two schools tied all eight bouts, but Baruch won on touches, or points.

title: WOOD FIRES AROUSE FEAR OF POLLUTION
description: With hot stoves crackling merrily in a rapidly growing number of homes, air pollution from wood smoke is becoming a problem to be reckoned with in many areas of the country.

title: TEXAS PRESSES BID TO KILL PRISON SUIT
description: The Texas Department of Corrections will go into a Federal appeals court on Dec. 18 to argue that its violence-torn penal system should not be required to make sweeping reforms ordered by a lower court last April.

title: STUDY OPPOSES U.S. ROLE IN CABLE TV ROYALTY
description: A Commerce Department staff study released today calls on the Government to end its control of the copyright royalties paid by cable television systems.

title: The Careful Shopper; Larger-Sized Values Offered in Hartsdale
description: ''The other woman,'' the larger one, is being catered to by designers and major manufacturers despite a common presumption that most colorful, well-made clothing ends with size 12 or 13. The Other Woman, a Hartsdale Plaza shop, has everything discounted and is a hybrid, sharing a roof with Tall Girls Haven, not an off-price store. Each, however, has a nearly storewide 25 percent discount ending today with all sales final. Coat and dress sizes are 14 1/2 to 26 1/2; the sportswear is 36 to 46 and pants are in sizes 30 to 44, and to size 46 in some styles.

title: Gabriel Toys
description: To the Business Editor: The table accompanying your article, ''Christmas Is a Video Game'' (Dec. 6), needs some correcting.

title: WHITE PLAINS LENDS A HELPING HAND
description: Like many young couples, Mary and Gene Toulouse were tired of renting and wanted to buy a house. Money was tight, recalled Mrs. Toulouse, a 33-year-old French teacher who is the breadwinner in her family. She has two children and a husband who is doing post-doctoral studies in solid-state physics.

title: THE 'HILL STREET BLUES' LESSON
description: Anew series is teaching the television business an old lesson. Occasionally, not too often but occasionally, time is needed for a worthwhile series to develop an audience. ''Hill Street Blues'' made its debut on NBC last January and, despite a good many enthusiastic reviews in the national press, proceeded to chalk up the kind of ratings that could only be called disappointing. In this age of rapidly computerized statistics and virtually instant demographic ''breakouts,'' the weekly series should have been a prime candidate for cancellation. Some new series have been yanked off the network schedules after only two or three episodes.

title: AL DAVIS TACKLES PRO FOOTBALL
description: Robert Lindsey is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The New York Times. Robert Lindsey ''Competitive forces are being loosed,'' Joseph L. Alioto, his bald head glistening under the flourescent glare of a Los Angeles Federal courtroom, warned a jury darkly one day last spring, as if he was about to point to an unearthly spirit emerging from beneath a stone. ''And nobody,'' he said, ''knows where they are going.''

title: L.I.R.R. SAYS IT JUST TAPED PUBLIC AIRWAVES
description: The president of the Long Island Rail Road said yesterday that the line's sole purpose in placing concealed tape recorders aboard one of its trains was to monitor what he called ''illegal transmissions'' over the railroad's four radio channels.

title: FRIENDS COLLEGE GETS A BILL
description: LLOYD HARBOR DOES Friends World College owe the Village of Lloyd Harbor $40,000? Robert Loos, a trustee, says yes. And if the village can't collect, he wants it to hold a mortgage on the college's 93 acres.

title: Typhoon Batters East India And Southwest Bangladesh
description: Rescue boats sailed through the coastal waters of southwestern Bangladesh and eastern India today in the aftermath of a typhoon Friday that wrecked homes, uprooted trees, knocked out power lines and communications and destroyed crops in parts of Bangladesh, West Bengal and Orissa.

title: Americans Found to Oppose Any Relaxing of Clean Air Act
description: Americans are hostile to any changes in the Clean Air Act that would lead to dirtier air, a national survey commissioned by the United States Chamber of Commerce has concluded.

title: Connecticut Housing; AVOIDING ERRORS THAT SLOW SNOW REMOVAL
description: LAST Sunday's first major snowfall of the season, which caught many people unawares and unprepared and dumped almost a foot of snow on eastern parts of the state, highlighted the problem that many homeowners face concerning snow removal.

title: Washington; A TALK WITH HAIG (2)
description: Like most Secretaries of State before him, Al Haig thinks the press exaggerates his fumbles, minimizes his problems and ignores his achievements. Looking back on 1981, he seems fairly satisfied -considering what he calls the ''mess'' he inherited from history and Jimmy Carter - with his foreign policy record. And looking forward to l982, he sounds vaguely apprehensive. Here are a few excerpts from our recorded conversation:

title: AFRICA'S 6.3 MILLION FORGOTTEN REFUGEES
description: To the Editor:

title: Herschel Walker, Superstar
description: Well, at least Herschel Walker is not faster than a speeding bullet (''Herschel Walker's Run to Glory,'' by Henry Leifermann, Nov. 1). Mr. Leifermann writes that Walker ''reaches full speed after his first step.''

title: Dance; STEPS IN THE LIFE OF A CHOREOGRAPHER
description: MEL WONG, the choreographer and adjunct lecturer at the State University of New York at Purchase watched his seven dancers rehearse for their performance next Saturday at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck. Sitting on a stool in front of the studio and wearing a white sweat shirt, blue sweat pants and sneakers, Mr. Wong, 43 years old, smiled profusely and joked with his company members: Paul Evans, Sonya Delwaide, Parker Coeley, Gail Zaiks, Patty Neal, Kate Nesbitt and Jennifer Lane.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART There are benefits and benefits, but one of the best and most scrupulous among those known to me is the one now running at the cooperative known as Artists Space, which is at 105 Hudson Street.

title: SALES LAGGING ON STREETS OF EL BARRIO
description: It is a street of cash only, some layaways, no sales tax and lots of haggling over prices. Cowboy boots are strung up on racks like sides of beef, and just inches overhead, dresses and jackets attached to awnings swing to the rhythms of jostling shoppers and pounding salsa music.

title: GOLDEN BOYS OF THE GHETTO
description: Michael Norman is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times. By Michael Norman

title: Bruce Ranes to Wed Lillian Nass, Student
description: Lillian Rose Nass and Bruce Lawrence Ranes plan to be married Jan. 24. Mr. and Mrs. Harold Nass of New York have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Ranes of the Bronx.

title: ART FOR CHILDREN AT RUTGERS
description: ILLUSTRATIONS in children's books are the first art to which most youngsters are exposed and ''can affect them emotionally, as well as influence their esthetic sense,'' says Phillip Dennis Cate, director of the Rutgers University Art Gallery in New Brunswick.

title: Economic Affairs; CHARITY NEEDS COERCION
description: I N its drive to reduce or eliminate Federal programs, the Reagan Administration continues to talk up volunteer efforts to fill at least part of the gap. In doing so, the Administration implicitly admits that some of the cuts it wants to make will cause genuine hardship.

title: WHO CAN DO WHAT ABOUT THE SUBWAYS IN NEW YORK?
description: NOT all subway crime takes place on the trains and platforms. A Federal grand jury last week indicted Edward O'Grady, the Transit Authority superintendent for quality control, on charges that he accepted $30,000 in cash, gifts and vacations from companies that manufactured the faulty R-46 subway cars. Six other former and current officials of the agency, including John G. deRoos, once its senior executive officer, were charged by the state with taking less generous gifts. The undercarriages of the new cars, prone to potentially hazardous cracks, require constant maintenance, one reason given by Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (the T.A.'s parent), for what he concedes is ''lousy'' service. Meanwhile, Mayor Koch, an increasingly vocal critic of Mr. Ravitch's agency, has demanded more of a say in transit decisions, sometimes to the chagrin of Mr. Ravitch. Last week, Mr. Koch and Mr. Ravitch discussed transit management and related issues with Clyde Haberman, the City Hall bureau chief of The New York Times, Ari Goldman, a reporter covering transportaion matters and editors of The Week in Review. Excerpts from their conversation follow. Those Helping Hands

title: 7TH STRAIGHT VICTORY
description: The last time the Knicks played the Milwaukee Bucks and won was three weeks ago, when Junior Bridgeman and Brian Winters were injured and Marques Johnson was a holdout.

title: Essay; ON GETTING EVEN
description: A ''bound galley'' is not, as commonly believed, an enshackled crew of slaves rowing Captain Kidd's pirate ship; rather, it is the printer's proofs of a book bound with glue to allow the publisher to send around advance copies.

title: WASTE-SITE RULES READY FOR HEARING
description: THE complex and, until now, quiet process of finding a method for insuring the safe disposal of hazardous waste will be opened to the public Thursday when the specially created Connecticut Siting Council meets in New Britain to discuss the regulations it has proposed for site selection.

title: GUIDRY AGREES TO TERMS OF YANKEE OFFER
description: Ron Guidry always wanted to remain a Yankee, and now he will. John Schneider, his lawyer, said yesterday that Guidry had agreed to the terms of the offer made by George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner, and would sign a new contract when it is prepared, most likely later this week.

title: NEEDED: STATE-OF-THE-ART MONEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Brooklyn is the place to be for diversity in dance this week. For starters, there is Sunday's performance at 2 P.M. of the Rumanian Folk Dancers and Ensemble at Brooklyn College's Center for the Performing Arts.

title: CASE OF MOUNT KISCO JUDGE IS DELAYED
description: THE case of a judge who has been charged with insulting and harassing two black patrons of a Mount Kisco bar was delayed last week by legal differences between the defendant's lawyer and the County District Attorney's office. The incident, which has galvanized black residents of the area, involved Vincent Cerbone, 51 years old, who has been a Mount Kisco Town Justice for almost 18 years.

title: The Region; Questions About A Congressman's Private Funds
description: It's legal for members of Congress to supplement their incomes with outside jobs, but there's a limit. Did Representative Frederick W. Richmond go too far? A Federal judge thought he did; he ruled that the Brooklyn Democrat did not give up control when he gave up the title of chairman of a firm he founded and that his $100,000 a year ''pension'' therefore violated House income rules.

title: ALI QUITS THE RING AGAIN
description: Muhammad Ali was in his room this morning, making all the gracious and rational statements about his retirement - his latest retirement.

title: ADDING WOMEN TO THE STORY OF MAN
description: IN a recent student editorial taking issue with the Yale College faculty's approval of a major in women's studies, The Yale Daily News complained: ''There are no bounds to an endless extrapolation of women's perspectives to every discipline.'' But is this not to be hoped for? That we will include women's as well as men's perspectives in every discipline. That our understanding of humanity will always and everywhere recognize women's as well as men's presence and outlook. These are the aims of women's studies.

title: South Carolina Drops Carlen
description: Jim Carlen, football coach and athletic director at South Carolina has been dismissed, the university President, James Holderman, announced today.

title: PEYSER'S FIGHT AGAINST SUGAR SUPPORTS
description: WASHINGTON AT first glance, Representative Peter Peyser's offices look similar to those of other Congressmen who have journeyed to Washington while managing to take a bit of home with them: the bright color posters advertising the state's natural wonders, the New York City subway map, the ubiquitous stickers that proclaim ''I Love New York.''

title: HOOKER CO. CASES STILL NOT SETTLED
description: New York State officials are still trying to negotiate a settlement with the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation two years after the state said the company had committed 400 violations of state law by dumping toxic chemical wastes into landfills on Long Island.

title: That Romantic Feeling
description: I read ''Renewing the Spirit of Romance'' (Fashion, Sept. 27) and noticed the article said that such romantic types of dress were intended for young women.

title: Jets Take Control At End
description: When the Jet offensive team assembled on the field for its last series today, with the Jets holding a 1-point lead over Cleveland, the players heard a short speech.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: RECYCLING in New Jersey got a $600,000 shot in the arm last week when the Owens-Illinois Company dedicated a new glass-recycling system at its North Bergen plant. The plant, one of the largest and most modern in the Northeast, can crush 20 tons of bottles and jars an hour while removing metal caps and bands, a problem that hindered most such recycling efforts in the past.

title: HELP FOR HERPES OFFERED BY GROUP
description: ALTHOUGH there is no cure for herpes, there is a national support group for those who suffer from the condition. The organization is known as HELP, and there is a local chapter that meets the second Sunday of each month at the Plainview-Old Bethpage Library at 6:30 P.M.

title: N.Y.U.'S LAW SCHOOL SEEKING $20 MILLION FOR BETTER FACILITIES
description: New York University's School of Law is seeking to raise $20 million to build new facilities, renovate its main academic building and improve its housing.

title: U.S. POLICY TOWARD TURKEY
description: At a time when the United States is offering a large package of military aid to Turkey and calling for increased defense cooperation between the two countries, there is growing concern in Europe over the apparent reluctance of the military junta to take concrete steps toward the restoration of democracy, which it promised from the very beginning of its rule, on Sept. 12, 1980.

title: James Benedict Fiance of Janet Fagal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick F. Fagal of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet E. Fagal, to James N. Benedict, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson H. Benedict of Norwich, N.Y.

title: BOARD LOOKING AT MORE TAXES AND NEW CUTS TO AID BUDGET
description: ANDREW P. O'ROURKE, the Republican chairman of the Board of Legislators, turned to a colleague at one of the daily meetings of the budget committee last week and said, ''If this county had a financial control board, it wouldn't approve this budget,'' the 1982 version proposed last month by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

title: LAW-AND-ORDER IS EASY TO SAY, HARD TO LEGISLATE
description: President Reagan's war against crime, like former President Nixon's, shows signs of becoming bogged down in Congress. To be sure, there is no shortage of crime-busting bills and rhetoric. Some legislation is moving toward probable Senate passage, ushered along by an unusual alliance between Democrats such as Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, who is less liberal on criminal law issues than on other matters, and conservative Republicans such as Strom Thurmond of South Carolina, chairman of the Judiciary Committee.

title: Pontifical Academy Is Given New Impetus
description: The Pontifical Academy of Sciences, which is sending representatives next week to meet with the leaders of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France, was established in 1607 to advise the Pope on scientific issues.

title: A WINNING ESSAY ON SELF-AWARENESS
description: An essay contest for high school students in Rockland and Westchester Counties, sponsored last month by Citibank, drew more than 1,600 essays on the topic ''What is the most critical issue facing high school students today?'' The following essay won the $500 first prize in the 11th- to 12th-grade category. By DONNA TOMAN

title: Mailbox; In Another World
description: To the Sports Editor: When Joe Paterno says the Ivy League is ''in another world'' (The New York Times, Dec. 5, 1981), he is right. Ivy League sports are amateur; Paterno fields a minor league professional team. GEORGE S. LEWIS New York

title: KUNG'S VIEWS MEET POSITIVE RESPONSE IN U.S.
description: The REv. Hans Kung has been tried by the Vatican as a dissident theologian, so the question put to him as a guest on a recent segment of the "Donahue" television show sounded familiar. "Are you," asked the phone-in caller, "a heretic?"

title: POLICEMAN'S DEATH STIRS RACE TENSION
description: The arrest of a black radio reporter for the gunshot slaying of a white police officer has raised tensions between the police and some black groups.

title: Food; THE MUCH-MALIGNED AND VERY WHOLESOME POTATO
description: PITY the poor potato. A famine has been named after it. It has been tried and burned at the stake. For years people thought it was poisonous. French physicians accused it of being a dangerous aphrodisiac, responsible for indigestion along with maladies far worse.

title: ATTACK IN ANGOLA RISKED CLOUD OF POISON GAS
description: Had the recent attack against Angola's sole oil refinery gone according to plan, a gigantic explosion would not only have devastated part of Luanda but could also have released a cloud of poisonous gas over the capital.

title: FRENCH FORUM TOO RIGHT FOR CONSERVATIVES FROM THE U.S.
description: Well-advertised hard feelings can be counted on to enliven the get-togethers of political theorists, as a conference last weekend of right-wing intellectuals in Paris demonstrated. Two days before the conference, which was billed as the first important antisocialist gathering since Francois Mitterrand's Socialists won the elections in May, five American neoconservatives, including Norman Podhoretz, editor of Commentary magazine, withdrew.

title: CANADA'S LINGUISTIC MINORITIES BITTER OVER CHARTER
description: When the House of Commons voted 246 to 24 last week for a proposal to give Canada a new constitution and a bill of rights, those opposed included a representative of a French-speaking suburb of Ottawa and a member from an English-speaking suburb of Montreal.

title: Hartman Leading by 1 In Bowling Tournament
description: Rich Hartman rolled games of 245 and 255 near the end of qualifying to take a one-pin lead over Skee Poremsky today in the Professional Bowlers Association National Resident Pro Championship.

title: The World; Coal Miners Test Mrs. Thatcher
description: Britain's coal miners, the nemesis of Conservative prime ministers past, last week warned Margaret Thatcher they were ready to do battle again. In swift succession, they elected a hard-line new leader, Arthur Scargill, and rejected the Government's ''final offer'' of a 9.1 percent raise.

title: RISE IN CAESAREAN BIRTHS STIRS DISPUTE
description: ONE OF every five babies born in New Jersey in 1980 was delivered by Caesarean section, according to the state's Department of Health. Thirteen years ago, only one baby in 20 born in the state was delivered surgically.

title: Town Imperiled by Mine Fire Invited to Move 3 Miles Away
description: The beleaguered residents of Centralia, where an underground mine fire has been smoldering for 19 years, have been invited to relocate three miles away on a 44-acre tract in the next county.

title: No Headline
description: PERREAULT SCORES 3 GOALS AS SABRES BEAT WINGS

title: Margaret Ford Is Engaged to Emmet L. Cosgrove
description: Mrs. George Bernard Ford of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Margaret Catherine Ford, assistant city editor of The Day in New London, Conn., to Emmet L. Cosgrove, a partner in the New London law firm of Waller, Smith & Palmer.

title: 'CHILDREN'S THEATER' GROWS UP
description: WHAT'S happening to ''children's theater'' on the Island? The term seems endangered. According to theater managers, it's limiting in designation. By critical consensus, it's all too often condescending in performance. A number of theaters appear to be resisting the appellation - for the holiday season, at any rate - and are opting for such more expansive categories as ''theater for young people'' or ''family entertainment.''

title: Dining Out; INFORMAL, INEXPENSIVE AND ITALIAN
description: STAMFORD IF you are on the lookout for small, informal, inexpensive restaurants where you can take your entire family, here is one you might wish to add to your list. Sabia's Open Door, situated near Stamford Hospital in a neighborhood that may have seen better days, is a comfortable, no-frills Italian restaurant where you can eat heartily on well-prepared, freshly cooked, unpretentious food at moderate prices.

title: THREE DAYS ALONG EL CAMINO REAL
description: ROBERT LINDSEY is chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The New York Times. By ROBERT LINDSEY

title: WHEN NAPOLEON CAPTURED THE POPE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Edward Sheehan is the author of ''Kingdoms,'' which opens tonight at the Cort. By EDWARD SHEEHAN

title: Paulette Peters Married
description: The marriage of Paulette Joan Peters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joe Peters of Hysham, Mont., to Andrew Laszlo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Laszlo of Upper Brookville, L.I., took place yesterday in Hardin, Mont.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article about photography in the Pine Barrens on Nov. 29, a transmission error resulted in misquoting Melanie Walzer, a photographer. Miss Walzer, in fact, said that the Pine Barrens was a ''horizontal landscape.''

title: Elizabeth Boles Wed to Eric Gutterson
description: Elizabeth Middleton Boles, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Russell Sage Boles Jr. of Osterville, Mass., and Eric Norman Gutterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Lindsley Gutterson Jr. of Nantucket, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas B. Kennedy performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: POLAND'S LEADER PUTS MILITARY IN CHARGE AFTER UNION CHIEFS CALL A NATIONAL VOTE ON FUTURE OF THE COMMUNIST GOVERNMENT
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, invoked emergency constitutional powers this morning to declare a ''state of war'' and impose what appeared to be a military Government on Poland.

title: WHEN MOVIE STARS TOOK ON THE BARD
description: ''Shakespeare in Hollywood'' is not, as the title suggests, a collection of excerpts from those very few Hollywood movies that ventured into the risky realm of Shakespearean drama. It is, perhaps, an even more remarkable curiosity - a transcription of a longforgotten radio series that the CBS network ran for eight weeks in the summer of 1937, offering one-hour adaptations of the Bard's works.

title: Mary Jo Miles Is Married To John E. Baldino on L.I.
description: Mary Jo Miles, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas V. Miles of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to John E. Baldino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas G. Baldino of Ocean, N.J. The Rev. William L. Willdigg performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Garden City.

title: U.S. EXTRADITING AN ARAB TO ISRAEL
description: The United States decided today to extradite a West Bank Arab sought by Israel in connection with a 1979 bombing. Ziyad Abu Eain, charged with planting a bomb that killed 2 people and injured 36 in Tiberias, was arrested in Chicago in August 1979. Mr. Abu Eain spent the last two years fighting an Israeli extradition request.

title: SOME QUESTION ASPEN INSTITUTE TIE TO RESORT SALES
description: In 1949, a Chicago industrialist, Walter Paepcke, came up with a novel concept. He would invite business executives like himself to what was then the sleepy mining village of Aspen, high in the Colorado Rockies, and there they would sit together and debate the great books.

title: Wine; BODY-WARMING DRINKS; by Terry Robards
description: t was a championship professional football game in the days long before Super Bowls in sunny climes, and the wind-chill factor at ground level in the stadium wac well below zero. A ski mask, wool blanket and pocket flask were little protection from arcticlike blasts of wind that swirled through the seats, dissipating body heat faster than it could be generated.

title: NEWARK CHORUS SET TO PERFORM
description: EARLIER this month, the 24-member Newark Boys Chorus returned home, sleepy-eyed but jubilant, from a whirlwind tour of Japan that took the youths to 24 cities in three weeks.

title: SCOTCH WHISKY AT THE SOURCE
description: WILLIAM BORDERS is a correspondent in The Times's London bureau. By WILLIAM BORDERS

title: CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide yesterday gave the wrong date for the Hanukkah Arts Festival at the Ansche Chesed Synagogue, 100th Street and West End Avenue. The festival will take place next Sunday.

title: CONGRESS TO EASE CURB ON FARMLAND
description: Another step has been taken toward amending the Reclamation Act of 1902 with both the House and the Senate Interior Committees completing hearings on bills to increase the amount of federally irrigated land a farmer may own or lease.

title: Future Events Bill of Holiday Fare
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. I'll Take Manhattan Dec. 16 - Back in 1975, Creative Time Inc. helped the artist Red Grooms realize ''Ruckus Manhattan,'' a loony three-dimensional representation of lower Manhattan. Six years later the nonprofit arts organization is sponsoring a revival of the fanciful walkthrough show at Burlington House, Avenue of the Americas at 54th Street. Join Mayor Koch and artists such as Roy Lichtenstein, Robert Rauschenberg and Jules Feiffer at a gala benefit preview from 5:30 P.M. to 8:30 P.M. There'll be champagne and nibbles in addition to Mr. Grooms's comic-strip renderings of familiar sights. A Statue of Liberty sporting red platform shoes, for example. Two new works have been added: an oversize taxi and a tableau of the sale of Manhattan to the Dutch. Tickets for preview, $35. Sponsor tickets, $50, and patron tickets, $200, include dancing afterward at the Peppermint Lounge and a chance on an original Red Grooms drawing. Creative Time will benefit also from the run of show open to the public from Dec. 18 through March 31. Admission $2 for adults and $1 for children, students and the elderly.

title: Libyan Talks of Oil Shutdown
description: Insisting that ''we are not a terrorist country,'' Libya's Minister of Petroleum, Abdel-Salam Zagaar, said today that his country might be forced to shut down its oilfields if the 1,500 Americans there heed President Reagan's ''unfair'' call for them to return home.

title: SOLID-WASTE PLAN RAISES QUESTIONS
description: TOMS RIVER QUESTIONS remain in the long-standing dispute over the efficacy of Ocean County's solid-waste management plan, which calls for buying two privately owned dumps.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Reform Jews Will Seek Converts
description: Whether Jews can resist assimilation and disappearance as a separate group has been, for American Jews, a subject of long debate. Last week, the synagogue branch of Reform Judaism, in an implicit recognition of the problem, announced a program to encourage non-Jews to convert.

title: ZEFFIRELLI STAGES 'BOHEME AT THE MET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Gary Lipton writes frequently about opera. By GARY LIPTON

title: Home Clinic; TACKLING THE PROBLEM OF A LEAKING FAUCET
description: CONVENTIONAL faucets, more accurately described as compression-type faucets, have replaceable neoprene washers at the bottom end of the stem that eventually wear out and need replacing. The washer stops the flow of water (when the handle is turned to the closed position) by pressing down against a metal valve seat inside the body of the faucet. When this type of faucet leaks or drips from the spout after it is shut off, the problem is usually solved by taking the faucet apart and installing a new washer of the proper size and type.

title: UNIONISTS REFLECT ON LOSS AT DU PONT
description: The decisive defeat of the steelworkers' union in its drive to organize workers at the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company broke the stride of recent union gains in the South. But some union leaders remained publicly confident that Southern resistance to ''big labor'' could be overcome.

title: Westchester Housing; PORT CHESTER RENEWAL PLAN FOUGHT
description: ACOMMUNITY group charged in Federal court Nov. 30 that the village of Port Chester was tearing down housing without providing new homes, shifting families from one delapidated building to another and trying to get rid of minorities.

title: THE 70TH APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was established in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The Times. That year, 117 contributors donated a total of $3,630.88 to be distributed among three private social-service agencies.

title: PLOT TO KILL LETELIER SAID TO INVOLVE NERVE GAS
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been informed that the Chilean secret police manufactured a supply of nerve gas and shipped it to the United States for possible use in the 1976 assassination of Orlando Letelier, a former Chilean ambassador.

title: SUSAN MCCASLIN WILL BE MARRIED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. McCaslin Jr. of Glendale, Ohio, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Richardson McCaslin, to Victor William Henningsen 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henningsen Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y. A summer wedding is planned.

title: NORTH FORK SHORE EXPECTS A BOOM
description: WHILE development pressure mounts in the Hamptons, all is quiet on the North Fork except along the waterfront.
