A representative group of North Fork planners, real-estate investors and realtors said in recent interviews that the moderateto-strong development pressure for prime North Fork locations along Peconic Bay and Long Island Sound is something new, but none see now, or expect to see soon, anything like the second-home and resort boom that is transforming Southampton Town and buffeting East Hampton.

title: DELBELLO INVITES PUBLIC IN
description: A72-YEAR-OLD woman who said she was facing a dilemma. A sales representative who claimed his energy resources company could save the county money on its energy bills. A resident of Peach Lake in North Salem opposed to a proposed condominium development. Two retired businessmen looking for office space to run a volunteer consulting service for small businesses.

title: Dr. Alene Strahan to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald L. Strahan of Richmond, Ind., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Alene P. Strahan, to Dr. Alan S. Ingber of North Woodmere, L.I. A spring wedding is planned. Dr. Strahan is a resident in psychiatry at Beth Israel Hospital in New York. Dr. Ingber is a dentist.

title: Ballet Theater Plans 7 New Productions
description: Seven new productions and three revivals will highlight the American Ballet Theater's repertory for next season. The productions include Kenneth MacMillan's ''The Wild Boy,'' Choo San Goh's ''Configurations'' and Lynne Taylor-Corbett's ''Great Galloping Gottschalk.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: U.S. TAKES DOUBLES
description: In a five-set thriller that reaffirmed the qualities of the Davis Cup, John McEnroe and Peter Fleming outlasted Guillermo Vilas and Jose-Luis Clerc today and gave the United States a 2-1 lead over Argentina in the final.

title: COLLEGE TV SHOWDOWN NEAR
description: The College Football Association, consisting of 61 of the strongest football teams in the nation, will try again tomorrow to get enough of its members to agree to a television contract with NBC Sports to make such a pact acceptable to the network. This may be a difficult thing to do.

title: Texas Woman Is Sentenced Over Her Use of False Name
description: Jo Ann Starr Harrelson has been sentenced to three years in prison for using a false name to buy a rifle shortly before the slaying of a Federal judge, a shooting in which her husband is a suspect.

title: INFANT MORTALITY HIGHEST IN CAPITAL
description: The infant mortality rate in the nation's capital has risen to the highest of any city in the United States, according to a study released today.

title: U.S. OBJECTS TO PROPOSED 'FISHHOOK' DISTRICT
description: When the United States Justice Department overturned a North Carolina redistricting plan this week, it pointed to the ''strangely irregular'' shape of the district drawn for Democratic Representative L.H. Fountain.

title: The Region; Mayor Rants, Then Recants
description: A sharp tongue is one of Mayor Koch's favorite weapons, but sometimes it cuts too unkindly. He so harshly criticized City Council President Carol Bellamy in a newspaper interview published last week that his own aides shook their heads in disbelief and a ceremonious public apology was arranged.

title: The World; China and India Open Talks
description: China under Deng Xiaoping has patched up ties with the faraway West while remaining at odds with many of its neighbors. Last week, it addressed one of those quarrels, welcoming negotiators from India to discuss a Himalayan border dispute that has festered for almost a century and led to a brief, fierce border war in 1962.

title: CAN YOU AFFORD NOT TO VOTE?
description: ON NOV. 3, I went to the polls for the first time in my 20 years as a resident of the United States. With immense satisfaction, I made known my opinion on every issue and candidate on the ballot, and I wondered why anyone eligible to vote would ever deny himself that privilege.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Michael R. Sitton, Pianist, Plays Mozart
description: Too much force and too little finesse went into the playing of Michael R. Sitton, a 23-year-old pianist from North Carolina, in his New York debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday. As a result, a program not particularly well chosen to begin with became a demonstration of how works that might yield expressive ore, if probed with imagination, become mere rubble under the rock-crushing weight of a mechanistic approach.

title: FOND MEMORIES OF THOSE MAGICAL OLD PHONOGRAPHS
description: At Christmastime, memory often takes trips into childhood. The first stop may be the remembrance of some particular holiday, but the paths of recollection branch out from there and one never knows whom or what one might encounter on these sentimental journeys into youth. In my case, not surprisingly, I bumped into some old phonographs I had known long ago.

title: Index; International
description: At U.N., a surprising Ugandan envoy and a new Chinese role 3 British press agrees to respect the Princess of Whales's privacy 3 Around the World 4 Attack on Angolan refinery nearly caused a major disaster 6 Miss Alekseyeva off to visit Sa- kharovs in Gorky 11 Khomeini blames ''superpowers'' for assassinations in Iran 15 Turkey welcomes visit by Haig as sign of U.S. support 17 U.S. proposal hinders rich-poor global talks at United Nations 21 In Libya, Qaddafi's personality cult is all pervasive 22 Worst drought in 100 years hits Spain's south 23 In Mauritius, a poor sugar crop threatens the Goverment 24 Government/Politics Budget squeeze hitting California and Governor Brown 26 Arkansas creation trial pits old vs. new 38 Congress completes hearings on changes in Reclamation Act 45 Albany leaders resume talks on redistricting 46 A momentary break in the se- curity at Gracie Mansion 49 City food centers for the poor are shut 63 Votes in Congress 66 General Around the Nation 26 400 Idaho farmers club hares to death to save crops 27 Slaying of policeman stirs racial tension in Philadelphia 35 Westchester to negotiate on cur- few at airport 48 L.I.R.R. says it monitored illegal transmissions with recorders 53 Florida seeks to protect the manatee 66 Suitability of a casino operator is questioned 69 Industry/Labor Increases in job total on L.I. quickened from 1975 to 1980 76 Idaho group to buy smelter that was prepared to close 88 Education/Welfare John D. Feerick named dean of Fordam Law School 61 Vassar's library acquires papers of Elizabeth Bishop 62 Cut in U.S. funds called a danger to schools 82 Arts/Entertainment Eugene Ormandy is guest con- ductor of the Philharmonic 90 ''La Traviata'' put on by Juilliard Opera Center 91 Orpheus, the conductorless or- chestra, gives concert 92 Keith Jarrett give piano concert at Fisher Hall 93 Cole Porter's ''Something for the Boys'' revived 94 Alvin Ailey Dancers give pre- miere to his ''Landscape'' 95 The debut performances of young musicians reviewed 96 Maximilian Schell films ''Tales From the Vienna Woods'' 96 An adaptation of ''Rip Van Win- kle'' is staged 97

title: SHORT STORIES CAN MAKE LIVELY DISKS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Kresh writes frequently about the spoken word on recordings, and is preparing a book on the subject. By PAUL KRESH

title: Art; MAZUR AT THE RUTGERS GALLERY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ABOUT 100 prints, drawings and paintings by Michael Mazur are on view through next Sunday at the Rutgers University Art Gallery. This is a remarkable show on several counts, not the least important of which is that the gallery, which is in Voorhees Hall, has been able to acquire about 75 of the prints, thanks to the generosity of the Rutgers College Class of 1956.

title: A LIBRETTO HAS TO FACE THE MUSIC
description: Stage musicals are of such elephantine proportions, they eat up so much money, they are so helplessly subject to the hazards of multiple collaboration, and they disappear so rapidly when they're not just right that anyone who decides to fool around with them in any capacity whatsoever will do well to have a backup profession. I notice that the four boys and two girls making a lively racket in ''Pump Boys and Dinettes'' at the downtown Colonnades Theater do have backup professions. When they are not performing, they are able to pick up pocket money working as carpenters, waitresses and sometime hirelings of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra (I don't know what instruments they might play with the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, certainly not the onion graters and large wooden spoons with which they are now beating out rhythms on formica table-tops). In addition, the program note tells us, ''they have been known to perform auto repairs if aided by quantities of time and beer.''

title: ABRAMS AIDE SEES $40 MILLION CON ED REFUND
description: New York State is expected to order the Consolidated Edison Company to refund nearly $40 million that it charged its 2.8 million customers because of an unscheduled shutdown last year at its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant, according to the State Attorney General's office.

title: Dining Out; THREE-STAR DINING IN GRANITE SPRINGS
description: ASUCCESS story is always satisfying, and there is none so dramatic as Damiano's in Granite Springs. From unimpressive beginnings, this restaurant has over the last two years developed a well-disciplined northern Italian kitchen that produces dishes of remarkable dependability. Such constancy deserves particular admiration in light of the pressures brought about by the restaurant's increased popularity.

title: O'NEILL ILLNESS RAISES QUESTION ABOUT TRANSFER OF AUTHORITY
description: HARTFORD FOR the second time in less than a year, Connecticut has had to confront a disability of a Governor, and there is increased concern that the state needs a better mechanism to deal with the problem.

title: No Headline
description: Mirror, mirror, on the wall, who's the fairest of them all? Well, in New York City, the answer might very well be the two young women who share apartment 24H in a luxury building near Lincoln Center.

title: Speaking Personally; TOO MUCH TACT TURNS HONEY TO TREACLE
description: IHAVE always believed in relating to people with courtesy and tact. I grew up on the old maxim that you can catch more flies with honey than with vinegar. To me, being tactful seemed to be a mark of civilization.

title: Joanne Falco Is Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Falco of Baldwin, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Joanne Falco, to David J. Schonfeld, son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Schonfeld of Freeport, L.I. The wedding is planned for the spring. Miss Falco is studying architecture at the Harvard School of Design. Mr. Schonfeld is attending the Boston University School of Medicine.

title: JETS TURN BACK BROWNS, 14-13
description: The Jets moved closer to their first playoff berth in 12 years today by scoring an inelegant but important 14-13 victory over the Browns.

title: Weinberger for the Defense
description: Regarding the cover photograph of Caspar Weinberger wherein the Secretary of Defense is fondling his model airplane, I am reminded that ''the difference between men and boys is in the price of their toys.'' EUGENE M.J. PUGATCH, M.D., Montclair, N.J.

title: WHY NUCLEAR ARMS TALKS ARE A LONG WAY FROM NITTY-GRITTY
description: To the Editor:

title: Barbara L. Arnsten Betrothed to Seth Rosenzweig
description: Mr. and Mrs. Percy Arnsten of Maplewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Louise Arnsten, to Seth Edward Rosenzweig, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Rosenzweig of Freeport, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Susan B. Anthony
description: A bill was introduced in Congress in 1971 - inauspiciously, as it turned out - to put a portrait of Susan B. Anthony on an item of United States currency.

title: POPE TO SEND OUT AIDES IN BID TO END ATOMIC ARMS RACE
description: Pope John Paul II is sending delegations to the United States, the Soviet Union, France, Britain and the United Nations this week to discuss how to end the nuclear arms race, the Vatican announced yesterday in Rome.

title: COMPANIES JOIN CITY IN A VOCATIONAL PROGRAM
description: A new vocational program for students in New York City high schools is proving that private companies can be valuable allies in occupational education, city officials say.

title: Keith Meyers TALKS CONTINUE AS GARBAGE PILES UP
description: Sidewalk traffic is blocked along Canal Street in Chinatown. Contract negotiations continued yesterday, the walkout's 12th day. Garbage is mounting at the rate of 7,000 tons a day.

title: VIETNAM INVITES 4 U.S. VETERANS TO VISIT HANOI
description: The Government of Vietnam has unexpectedly invited a group of American veterans of the Vietnam War to visit the Southeast Asian country next week to discuss such issues as the herbicide Agent Orange and the fate of American servicemen still missing in Indochina.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGE

title: HEADED VAST FAMILY CORPORATION
description: Edgar F. Kaiser, who took the reins of the industrial company founded by his father, Henry J. Kaiser, and directed the empire toward international expansion, died Friday at the University of California's Moffitt Hospital after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: BAY STATE TOWNS THINK THE UNTHINKABLE
description: The snowstorm that backed up unexpectedly from the Atlantic to blanket much of New England last weekend was not quite the measure of a blizzard, but it was very close, and it fell on the streets of Boston at the calculated rate of $30,000 an hour.

title: CAN THERE BE A GREAT PERFORMANCE IN A WEAK MOVIE?
description: ''Tell me,'' says the friend met in an elevator/on the bus/at the bank/under an umbrella, ''what did you really think of 'On Golden Pond'?'' Considering that the friend who asks the question has apparently just read 700 or 800 words in which you've said a great deal about what you think about ''On Golden Pond,'' the temptation is to 1) suggest politely that he read the review again, 2) snarl ''Drop dead,'' 3) wail ''Oh my God, how have I failed!'' or 4) slink home to examine your conscience (and prose) in seclusion.

title: CITY FOOD CENTERS FOR POOR ARE SHUT
description: Three centers that distribute emergency packages of food to some of the poorest residents of New York City have been closed as part of the phasing out of Vista.

title: Justice Orders Inquiry Into Prison Conditions
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered prison officials here to investigate prisoner complaints of threats and assaults by other prisoners because of overcrowding.

title: Babi Yar's Legacy
description: We fully realize that Lucy Dawidowicz has the credentials to write articles on the suffering and persecution of the Jewish people (''Babi Yar's Legacy,'' Sept. 27).

title: 'Miami County' Plan Is Endorsed by Panel
description: The Metro Charter Review Commission has recommended that Dade County, which includes the city of Miami, be renamed ''Miami County'' to improve its image.

title: NO FRILLS REVIEW
description: WESTERN SCIENCE FICTION ROMANCE MYSTERY Each 60pp. New York: Jove. $1.50.

title: The Week in Business; TRIPLE-DIGIT DEFICITS AHEAD FOR WASHINGTON
description: The Federal budget deficit will soar to a record $109 billion in 1982, Reagan Administration officials said - more than twice the $43.1 billion the Administration forecast in September, and substantially higher than the record $66 billion deficit in 1976. The estimates also predict deficits of $152 billion in the 1983 fiscal year and $162 billion in the 1984 fiscal year. President Reagan has yet to approve the preliminary estimate, the most pessimistic 1982 forecast made to date.

title: A RELUCTANT DAVID BEATS A.T.&T.
description: ELEVEN days ago, Fred Cohen, chairman and president of Telesciences Inc., was in California preparing for a stock offering. Mr. Cohen's company, which makes computerized equipment for use by telephone companies, needed money badly. It had been slammed by high development costs and the slumping economy. Five of the last six quarters had shown losses, dividends had been eliminated and the company, traditionally debt-free, had accumulated $7.8 million in long-term obligations.

title: Comment; THE DIRTY AIR BILL
description: R EPRESENTATIVES Bob Traxler, Democrat of Michigan, and Elwood Hillis, Republican of Indiana, have introduced a bill in Congress (H.R. 4400) to relax motor vehicle pollution requirements. Its supporters include the General Motors Corporation.

title: Francis Keyes, a Headmaster At Westminster School, Dies
description: Francis Keyes, a former headmaster of the Westminster School in Simsbury, Conn., died yesterday at College Hospital in Woodsville, N.H. He was 69 years old and lived in Newbury, Vt.

title: Dejected Refugees Fill Miami Health Centers
description: Dejected Cuban and Haitian refugees have drastically increased the caseload at Miami health centers, officials have said.

title: No Headline
description: Pacers Beat Nets On Rally

title: Suzanne Moe Is Married To William F. Humes Jr.
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Moe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel F. Moe Jr. of Wilton, Conn., was married there yesterday to William F. Humes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Humes of Honolulu. The Rev. Stephen D. Parker performed the ceremony at St. Mathew's Episcopal Church.

title: BEYOND CUTBACKS, WHAT'S U.S. GOAL IN EDUCATION?
description: By most standards Robert Stafford, a Republican Senator from Vermont, should be considered a loyalist by the White House. He supported the President's budget program, voted for his nominees and backed him on Awacs for Saudi Arabia.

title: ALTERNATIVES SOUGHT FOR 18 FREIGHT LINES
description: WHEN Conrail, the Federally subsidized railroad corporation, picked up the pieces of several bankrupt carriers in 13 Northeastern states in 1976, it inherited some 18,000 miles of freight track.

title: Reading and Writing; ORDINARY PEOPLE
description: The ordinary doesn't get much attention in serious fiction now. In the 50's, there was a lot of talk about ''the literature of extreme situations,'' and it seems to me that many novelists and short story writers have continued to think of their work as dealing mainly with extreme situations, with people in the throes of metaphysical crisis, rather than with the unspectacular concerns we all more or less share.

title: 'REAL' CHRISTMAS TREES REGAIN HOLIDAY POPULARITY
description: SHELTON DESPITE bone-chilling wind, several hundred families traipsed up and down the rolling hills of the Jones Tree Farm here last Sunday in search of the perfect Christmas tree.

title: You Can't Get to Libya From Here
description: The United States last week invoked measures aimed at restraining Libyan Col. Muammer el-Qaddafi's ''current lawless behavior,'' without, as Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. put it, ''shooting ourselves in the foot.'' For now, President Reagan banned travel to Libya and appealed to 1,500 American workers and dependents there to leave.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 8 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital' 2 2 13 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 4 18 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 4 3 5 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 5 5 32 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 6 6 6 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An Italian princess, in quest of romance, finds frustration, then fulfillment in America. 7 7 10 THE LEGACY, by Howard Fast. (Houghton Mifflin, $14.95.) The Lavette family of ''The Immigrants'' and ''The Establishment'' reaches the turbulent 60's. 8 9 3 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Hill, $22.95.) The most complete study of Pearl Harbor, laying to rest the theory that we were railroaded into war.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE ocean-fishing haul seiners of the South Fork are squaring off against Southampton Village officials, who have said they will haul the fishermen into court if they continue to violate a long-standing but rarely enforced village law that restricts beach access to village and town residents' vehicles with stickers.

title: HOW MUCH CONDUCTING SPECIALIZATION DO WE NEED-OR WANT?
description: London Records has just released a fine new recording of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde,'' and what determines its excellence above all is its conductor, Reginald Goodall. Mr. Goodall's recordings are all of Wagner operas. He is thus a specialist, one of a kind that seems to be making steady inroads into the conductorial world.

title: Mollie Fermaglich, Writer, Wed to Alan Levy, Editor
description: Mollie Fermaglich, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Fermaglich of New York, was married yesterday to Alan Michael Levy, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Levy of Douglaston, Queens.

title: Half of Lord Keynes
description: The Reaganauts are as wrong today as they were a year ago, when they blamed poor economic performance on the Federal deficits. Then, a predicted deficit of even $43 billion was denounced as too high. Now that it is projected at $109 billion (and much higher in 1983 and 1984), guess what they say? Deficits don't really matter.

title: FIGHTING FIRE BY CRUNCHING NUMBERS
description: There are no sirens, Dalmatians or gleaming firetrucks. Instead, there are dots, lines and numbers on a computer screen. Nevertheless, it is a way of fighing fires - through computer modeling.

title: 5 Teen-Agers Arrested In Up to 50 Robberies
description: Five Brooklyn teen-agers were arrested yesterday on robbery charges, and the authorities said they were suspects in 45 to 50 armed holdups in Brooklyn and Queens over a three- to four-month period.

title: Bright Gives Giants An All-Round Back
description: When the Giants beat the Los Angeles Rams, 10-7, last Sunday, their points were set up by Leon Bright's punt returns of 16 and 55 yards.

title: Alice H. Hall Plans February Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry I. Hall of Convent Station, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Hudson Hall, to Robert Julian Koenig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Koenig of Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra Ann Sysol to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore M. Sysol of Garden City, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Ann Sysol, to Jerry Joseph Limoncelli Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Limoncelli of Queens Village, Queens.

title: Soviet Assails NATO Decision To Accept Spain as Member
description: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass today condemned the conditional acceptance of Spain into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and repeated a warning that Moscow might take ''appropriate steps'' in retaliation.

title: Jailed Embezzler Gets A Job and Tries Again
description: Bergen County officials hope a work-release program will not be jeopardized by the arrest of a jail inmate who was accused of having embezzled $190,000 from an employer willing to give him a job.

title: Newlin, a Struggling Shooter
description: As the Knicks waited at the gate for their flight to Detroit the other day, several youngsters, pencil and pad in hand, sought autographs.

title: Headliners Broadside Manner
description: Dr. Richard J. Kones, a cardiologist who has pleaded guilty to filing more than $1.5 million in false Medicare claims, has as much candor as chutzpah. He told the Senate Finance and Aging Committees last week that the claims for services he never performed were ''arrogant and outrageous,'' but that he still collected $500,000 in Government payments for them. Dr. Kones attributed his acts to ''an individual psychopathology not indicative of the medical profession as a whole.'' Some committee members seemed unconvinced. Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, said the Government squanders ''billions of dollars through its inability to stop this abuse'' of Medicare. The health program is ''fairly vulnerable,'' said Dr. Kone, who apparently is not lacking in understatement either.

title: No Headline
description: KENTUCKY DEFEATS KANSAS IN OVERTIME

title: No Headline
description: Young Doctors In Debt As the struggling spouse of a medical student, I found Ron Winslow's article a welcome respite from the constant ''pie in the sky'' rhetoric to which I've become accustomed.

title: Amtrak Says Average Speed Climbed to 55 Miles an Hour
description: Amtrak says the average speed of its passenger trains has increased to 55 miles an hour from 49 miles an hour two years ago.

title: Mailbox; A Potent Weapon
description: To the Sports Editor: More often than not, football announcers, in a tone of finality, refer to a fourth-down punt as ''kicking the ball away.''

title: 'CHERRY ORCHARD' BLOOMS IN MONTCLAIR
description: MONTCLAIR WHEN ''The Cherry Orchard'' was first presented in Moscow in 1904, Chekhov was outraged by Stanislavski's heavy direction. Nonetheless, the Whole Theater's production of Chekhov's last and most beloved masterpiece gives us reason to feel that both artists have made a pact and are smiling in their empyrean.

title: Protest by Workers in Italy
description: Workers protesting the layoff of 2,500 employees by Italy's ailing chemical giant, Montedison, briefly closed down this southern industrial city today. The police said that the workers occupied the airport, sealed the main railroad station, blocked major highways and took over the Montedison plant. They left peacefully in the afternoon.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and sent to P.O. Box 5193, General Post Office, New York, N.Y. 10087, or to any of the following organizations: COMMUNITY SERVICE SOCIETY OF NEW YORK 105 East 22d Street, New York, N.Y. 10010 FEDERATION OF JEWISH PHILANTHROPIES OF NEW YORK 130 East 59th Street, New York, N.Y. 10022 CATHOLIC CHARITIES OF THE ARCHDIOCESE OF NEW YORK 1011 First Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022 FEDERATION OF PROTESTANT WELFARE AGENCIES 281 Park Avenue South, New York, N.Y. 10010 CHILDREN'S AID SOCIETY 105 East 22d Street, New York, N.Y. 10010 BROOKLYN BUREAU OF COMMUNITY SERVICE 285 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11217 CATHOLIC CHARITIES, DIOCESE OF BROOKLYN 191 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11201 STATEN ISLAND FAMILY SERVICE 88 New Dorp Plaza, Staten Island, N.Y. 10306

title: The World; G.O.P. Is Pulled Onto Bandwagon For Foreign Aid
description: Foreign aid, the unloved orphan of American politics, found a new set of foster parents last week: the Republicans. Bowing to vigorous Administration lobbying, 84 of them put aside their traditional distaste for such programs and joined 115 House Democrats in voting, 199 to 166, to spend $11.4 billion on aid this fiscal year.

title: ISLANDERS, TRAILING BY 3-0, TIE FLAMES, 3-3
description: The 7,228 fans at Stampede Corral may have thought they were watching two separate games tonight. The Calgary Flames dominated the first 30 minutes, 3-0; the Islanders prevailed the rest of the way, 3-0.

title: Sailboard Dispute Goes On
description: The boardsailing controversy surrounding patent rights, which could prevent the sport from making its Olympic debut in the 1984 Los Angeles Games, now has spilled over onto the race course as well as in the courts.

title: PETER RABBIT, STILL FRISKY AT 80
description: P ETER RABBIT Nursery Ware. Peter Rabbit's Natural Foods Cookbooks. Peter Rabbit and Family Serving Trays. Beatrix Potter's Coloring Book Featuring Peter Rabbit. Beatrix Potter Wallpaper. The Beatrix Potter Lift-Out Jig-Saw Puzzle ...

title: RESTLESS YOUTHS FIND A GOAD TO ACHIEVEMENT
description: HE is 17 years old and in the 10th grade, and this is his fifth year at Sewanhaka High School. Originally scheduled to graduate ''in 1982 -really in 1983,'' he said, he has now retargeted the date to 1984.

title: GENE STUDIES: FIRST FRUITS, MORE TO COME
description: Within the memory of active scientists, the substance of the genes of all living things has been identified, the universal code of heredity has been deciphered, and specialists have learned how to create genetic messages and get them translated into action.

title: R.O.T.C. MAKING A COMEBACK ON L.I.
description: AFTER a decade of intermittent debate, the Reserve Officers Training Corps is undergoing a resurgence on college and university campuses on the Island, as well as across the country.

title: Around the Nation; Acids Added to Sprays And Eye Drops in Stores
description: Officials are investigating the contamination of eye drops and nasal sprays in at least seven stores with acids and chlorine in solutions strong enough to cause severe pain and possibly to blind users.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: to which, ironically, Joe finally returns to achieve eminent respectability. Our reviewer Robert Towers called it ''fascinating, tantalizing, a work of brilliant parts set in a world of mirrors.''

title: Mary Morrissey, Stefan Underhill To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Daniel Morrissey of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Patricia Morrissey, to Stefan Richard Underhill, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Sands Underhill of Richmond.

title: Sarah S. Winmill to Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bassett S. Winmill of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Starr Winmill, to William Benjamin Ford, son of Dr. William Bert Ford and Yolanda Tomei Ford, both of Pittsburgh.

title: ALISON L. VIETOR WILL WED IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. George F. Vietor of Houston have made known the engagement of their daughter, Alison Lawrence Vietor, to William Labrot Crossman, son of Mrs. Edward B. Simmons of Annapolis, Md., and Edgar O. Crossman 2d of New York. The wedding will take place in May at the Episcopal Church of St. John the Divine in Houston.

title: ONE TIME THE BUREAU DID TOO MUCH
description: THE FBI AND MARTIN LUTHER KING, JR. From ''Solo'' to Memphis. By David J. Garrow. 320 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $15.95. By LESLIE MAITLAND

title: ST. JOHN'S TROUNCES MANHATTAN
description: Chris Mullin was on the bench last night laughing, cheering and slapping palms when the St. John's substitutes finished off an 85-54 victory over Manhattan College the Redmen's biggest triumph in almost two years.

title: WHERE TO TURN FOR INFORMATION
description: Further information on birth by Caesarean section is available from the following parent support groups:

title: Cousins of Howard Hughes To File Motion for New Trial
description: Hundreds of cousins whose claims to shares of Howard R. Hughes's estate were defeated in probate court have hired Melvin Belli, a San Francisco lawyer, to handle their appeal, a spokesman said Friday.

title: W. A. Thomas to Wed Lenore Palmer
description: Lenore Margaret Palmer, an international banking officer, and William Alan Thomas, an assistant representative with the Chemical Bank in Nairobi, Kenya, will be married on Jan. 30 at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York. Their engagement has been announced by Mrs. Lowell M. Palmer of Locust Valley, L.I., mother of the bride-tobe.

title: PREMATURE VERDICT ON BIOLOGICAL WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILHARMONIC: ORMANDY
description: This week Eugene Ormandy, who stepped down as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra two seasons ago, made his first appearance as conductor at subscription concerts of the New York Philharmonic. He was greeted, in Friday's matinee performance at Avery Fisher Hall, by a slipshod showing from the orchestra that marred half the program and utterly disfigured the opening work, Symphony No. 7 (Op. 105) of Sibelius.

title: JOHN D. FEERICK NAMED DEAN OF FORDHAM LAW
description: John D. Feerick, a lawyer instrumental in writing and assuring passage of the 25th Amendment on Presidental succession, is returning to Fordham University, his alma mater, to become dean of its Law School.

title: Moichi Tanabe, Owner Of Bookstores in Japan
description: Moichi Tanabe, a noted Japanese essayist who founded the Kinokuniya bookstore chain, died Friday night of cancer, his family said today. He was 76 years old.

title: NANCY ZARETT TO BE BRIDE OF CRAIG MILLER IN AUGUST
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alex H. Zarett of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ann Zarett, to Craig Franklin Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Miller of Whitestone, Queens.

title: KHOMEINI DENOUNCES SUPERPOWERS AS KILLERS
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today accused the superpowers and their agents of assassinating Iran's political-religious leaders.

title: A Correction
description: An article on Northeast Utilities last Sunday incorrectly described the transaction negotiated by a group of municipal utilities concerning a proposed hydroelectric project in Windsor Locks. The utilities paid $250,000 for an option on the water rights of the Windsor Locks Canal, while studying the feasibility of a proposed $4.3 million hydroelectric project there.

title: SCULPTURE FLIES INTO FACE OF ADVERSITY
description: SOUTHEAST THAT'S not a phoenix rising above the street sweeper, smudge pots, wheelbarrows and shovels in the Highway Department garage here. It's the ''Commodore of Grand Central,'' a cast-iron gray eagle with a 13-foot wing span that once perched on one of the Italianate towers of Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. Today, 70 years later, a committee is searching for a location to place ''The Bird,'' as it is known locally. Last month New York City's Department of Environmental Protection refused to grant permission to have the eagle installed as a memorial on watershed land in Brewster.

title: PRO SPORTS AND THEIR ROLE WITH THE PRESS
description: WHAT'S going on? Can't well-paid athletes, once and future superstars, take a little public criticism and occasional ribbing from sportswriters and broadcasters without getting so upset about it? After all, sports is supposed to be show business and this is the age of investigative reporting. The public has a right to know everything about its sporting heroes, and reporters are just doing their jobs by revealing this information, every last bit of it.

title: Speaking Personally; WEDDING JOY AND SADNESS
description: THERE are certain landmarks in a mother's life - the day she has her first baby, the time her last child goes off to school, and the wedding of her daughter.

title: Miss Sutter To Be Bride Of an Actor
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clifford S. Sutter of Osterville, Mass., formerly of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Michele Cynthia Sutter, to Robert Stephen Bogardus, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Bogardus Jr. of Greenwich.

title: NEW IN JAPAN: THE MANLESS FACTORY
description: each with a pair of yellow tool drums that resemble enlarged roulette wheels - are grinding, boring and fashioning parts for high-technology machines like themselves.

title: Miss McCarthy Bride of Lawyer
description: Patricia Ann McCarthy and Samuel Wilbur Croll 3d were married yesterday in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel F. Miner performed the ceremony.

title: Deep Gas
description: To the Business Editor: Your most interesting article, ''The Man Who Drills the Deepest Wells'' (Nov. 29), had the subtitle ''Robert Hefner proved deep gas could pay. A loophole in Federal price regulation helped.''

title: No Headline
description: The description of the plight of young, ambitious and hard-working folks in achieving their own homes today was most true. Every politician, banker, etc., should be made to read the article. JERRY BOXER, Lake Grove

title: Small California Paper Wins Fight on $400,000 Libel Suit
description: The Santa Paula Chronicle, one of the nation's smallest daily newspapers, has won a court battle against a local real-estate agent who filed a $400,000 libel suit.

title: COMPUTER SERVICE AID FOR COUNSELORS
description: STUDENTS use it, parents like it, even prisoners are excited about it. ''It's fun,'' ''It's fantastic,'' ''It gives me information quickly,'' ''I'm more aware about future possibilities'' are some of the comments used to describe a computer program called Guidance Information Service.

title: SHOW OF HI-TECH JEWELRY
description: When the word spread that the Renwick Gallery was putting together a small show of jewelry made with nonprecious materials, the idea ''mushroomed,'' according to the gallery director, Lloyd E. Herman.

title: Gardening; DWARF CONIFERS EXCELLENT IN SMALL AREA
description: LAST week we discussed the role of the standard-size conifers or cone-bearing evergreens in the landscape and pointed out that many were too large for the average garden of today. As an alternative, we suggested the consideration of the dwarf conifers, the much smaller forms of these same plants.

title: HUGE DEFICITS FORCE REAGAN INTO SOME TIGHT CORNERS
description: WASHINGTON LIKE a house flattened by a hurricane, President Reagan's ambitious economic goals have been splintered by what could turn out to be the worst recession since World War II. Now the master builder is presiding over a construction crew whose members seem to be spending more time swinging their conflicting approaches at each other than in putting the economic - and the political - house back together.

title: SEARCHING FOR THE CHILDHOOD OF EROS
description: SEXUAL PREFERENCE Its Development in Men and Women. An Official Publication of the Alfred C. Kinsey Institute for Sex Research. By Alan P. Bell, Martin S. Weinberg and Sue Kiefer Hammersmith. Vol. I: 242 pp. Vol. II, ''Statistical Appendix'': 321 pp. Bloomington, Ind.: Indiana University Press. Vol. I: $15. Vol. II: $20.

title: COMMON CONSTANT PLEASURES
description: Frederick Law Olmsted was an authentic American genius whose most visible and important bequest to the nation is a series of urban parks, each designed to provide a ''sense of enlarged freedom'' and ''a common, constant pleasure'' to city dwellers. A handsome, twovolume celebration of his work, ''Art of the Olmsted Landscape'' (New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission/Arts Publishers, $35), has been published in conjunction with a traveling museum show.

title: RAISING CAIN
description: THE BABY IN THE ICEBOX And Other Short Fiction. By James M. Cain. Edited By Roy Hoopes. 312 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95. By JOE FLAHERTY

title: Congress Buys A Bit More Time on Budget
description: With White House squabbles over how much deficits matter and Administration projections about how much they may come to making the headlines, $4 billion more or less in 1982 spending seemed hardly worth fighting over. Pillowfighting was more like it last week on Capitol Hill -compared to what was going on down Pennsylvania Avenue (''U.S. Deficit Nightmare'' is how the Chicago Tribune billed the disclosure that $162 billion in red ink is now projected for 1984), and compared to what lies ahead when Congress comes back from its short Christmas recess.

title: Alexandra Bates Wed To Andrew Hoffman
description: Alexandra Ten Broeck Bates, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Frederick Bates of Hinsdale, Ill., was married at the Players Club yesterday to Andrew Bierman Hoffman, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Hoffman of New York. Criminal Court Judge Jerome M. Becker performed the ceremony.

title: HIGHWAY PLAN STIRS IRE ON SOUTH FORK
description: LOCAL opposition to a plan to build a $74 million superhighway on the South Fork has intensified in the weeks following Governor Carey's announcement that the project would proceed.

title: The World; United Nations Finds Its Man
description: The United Nations likes its top dog to be smooth and sharp enough to navigate through international waters without making waves. Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru, who got the Secretary General's job last week, seems to fit the description.

title: BOYS RAISE VOICES IN SONG
description: HICKSVILLE THEY'RE called the Singing Boys of Long Island. And they are: boys from 8 to 18 years old from Douglaston to Shirley who sing. But when the 80 youngsters take to the stage 20 times a year to give concerts - as they will Saturday at the C.W. Post Center and next Sunday at North Babylon High School - they are following a tradition that dates to the 18th century when Johann Sebastian Bach directed the St. Thomas Choir of Leipzig.

title: INCREASES IN JOB TOTAL ON L.I. QUICKENED IN 1975-80 PERIOD
description: The number of jobs on Long Island rose by 125,000 between 1975 and 1980, nearly double the increase of 64,000 jobs recorded for the first half of the decade, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the Regional Commissioner of Labor Statistics.

title: New Moon a Salmon Mover
description: OVER the years, I have been subjected to strange looks and wan smiles when I was sufficiently loose-tongued to reveal that the full moon, even when hidden by heavy clouds, makes me restless and ill at ease.

title: Traveling Woes
description: To the Business Editor: ''The Traveling Life, and the Toll It Takes'' (Nov. 29), indicated the impact of travel on men. Dr. Mel S. Goldsmith, for example, noted that the traveling husband loses his status as head of the household. My discussions with traveling women indicate an opposite problem.

title: Around the Nation; New Charges Expected Against Police Officers
description: A prosecutor says that reckless homicide charges will be issued again against two policemen involved in the arrest of a black man who died shortly after being taken into custody for a rape he did not commit.

title: Exploring Markets
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Transit Aides Preview Rail Project
description: New Jersey transportation officials took a test ride this week on a small portion of electrified railroad track that is to be part of an upgraded commuter link between Dover and Hoboken.

title: STATE A BIG EXPORTER OF WASTE
description: RECENT figures from the State Department of Environmental Protection indicate that Connecticut depends to a significant degree on other states, mainly New Jersey, for the disposal of its hazardous waste.

title: Rep. Garcia Deplores Life at Refugee Camp
description: A New York Congressman who visited a center for Haitian refugees here said he found it ''inhumane.'' The assessment was made by Rep. Robert Garcia, Democrat of the Bronx, who visited Fort Allen, a former military base.

title: A MALL COVERS THE WATERFRONT
description: William Severini Kowinski is a working on a book about shopping malls. By William Severini Kowinski

title: SETON HALL, FORDHAM PREVAIL
description: Seton Hall and Fordham scored 1-point victories tonight. After the undefeated Pirates won their fifth game by edging St. Peter's College, 47-46, Fordham evened its record at 3-3 by beating Syracuse, 79-78.

title: Anachronistic Mottoes To the Editor:$
description: The review by Stanley Hoffmann of ''Vichy France and the Jews'' by Michael R. Marrus and Robert O. Paxton (Nov. 1) was easily up to the mark of the scholarship and compassion Professor Hoffmann has long shown for the tragedy of France under the Occupation.

title: Art; SURPRISES AT PARRISH SHOW
description: SOUTHAMPTON IN past years, the coveted first-place award at the Parrish Art Museum's annual juried exhibition has been a one-person show the following season. The primary criterion for such an accolade is not necessarily that the artist chosen is the ''best'' of the hundreds who submit work for consideration, since it is seldom that such a judgment can be made on the basis of one or two entries out of many excellent submissions. Rather, the jury generally decides that the chosen artist is someone whose work it would like to see more of, whose entry suggests a range, a possible breadth that cannot be expressed in a single example - in short, someone capable of mounting a respectable professional show.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: CRITICAL OBSERVATIONS By Julian Symons. 213 pp. New Haven & New York: Ticknor & Fields. $12.95.

title: U.S. TO DELAY ACTION ON PCB'S PENDING DECISION ON DISPOSAL
description: The administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency says the agency will not take further action on its planned removal of toxic polychlorinated biphenyls from the Hudson River until New York State decides on a waste-disposal site for the chemicals.

title: Violent Crimes in Jersey Show 11% Increase for Six Months
description: Violent crimes reported in New Jersey rose by 11 percent in the first six months of this year from the total in the corresponding period last year, according to the Uniform Crime Report issued by the state police.

title: Appraisers Urge Government To Sell Off Surplus Property
description: The Federal Government could lower the national debt by $100 billion or more by selling surplus real estate, the American Society of Appraisers has said.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: SUITABILITY OF A CASINO OPERATOR IS QUESTIONED
description: Attorney General James R. Zazzali, citing ties to a teamsters pension fund, has questioned the suitability of the Elsinore Corporation for an Atlantic City casino license.

title: Navy Issues Rules for Brigs
description: Eight months after the death of a sailor in a Navy brig, the service has issued guidelines to protect prisoners in ''correctional custody units.'' The rules are intended to insure that prisoners are not harassed, exercised to the point of exhaustion or otherwise abused.

title: Business Conditions; A STUBBORN COMMODITY
description: Although high interest rates and slumping demand have resulted in sharp price declines for major commodities during the past 12 months, oil prices have bucked those trends.

title: Dining Out; MOSTLY FRENCH IN TINY GUTTENBERG
description: BUSY Bergenline Avenue in Guttenberg, where as much Spanish is spoken as English, is an unlikely place to find an engaging little bistro serving imaginative French fare. (Guttenberg, by the way, is so tiny that you might miss it. For the uninitiated, it abuts West New York on the Hudson.)

title: TECHNIQUES OF STUDENT REPORTERS ARE AT ISSUE ON AN ILLINOIS CAMPUS
description: An article in Northern Illinois University's student newspaper that questioned practices at the school's health service has led to an official inquiry and to charges that three student reporters violated the university's judicial code. Those charges were later withdrawn.

title: BIRDS ACCEPT AN INVITATION WHEN THE MENU IS APPEALING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- David M. Emerson coordinates the Connecticut Audubon Society's educational programs. By DAVID M. EMERSON

title: City Sets Lottery Date For Harlem Buildings
description: The Department of Housing Preservation and Development has set Feb. 9 for a lottery for families who want to purchase 12 vacant cityowned brownstones in Harlem.

title: New York Political Notes; A LOUD KNOCK ON SECURITY AT GRACIE MANSION; New York Political Notes
description: Now that it is all over, Mayor Koch says, the story can be told. With fears for the well-being of government officials stirred by talk of a possible Libyan plot against American leaders, his residence, Gracie Mansion, was restudied by the New York City police. He said he was assured that it had been made more secure than ever.

title: HAIG SAID TO MEET WITH NIGERIAN ON POSSIBLE INCREASE IN OIL OUTPUT
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was reported today to have discussed with Nigeria's Minister of External Affairs issues including oil production in Nigeria, which could make up the difference in United States imports if Washington decides to embargo Libyan oil.

title: HUMPBACK WHALE; Megaptera novaeangliae
description: Size: To 50 feet and about 50 tons. Color: Black above, white throat and belly.

title: 'FAMILY PARTY' IS STAGED AT N.Y.U. FOR THE BLACK JUDGES IN NEW YORK
description: They call themselves Judicial Friends, and for the most part they seem to be just that to one another. They are ''homeboys'' who have migrated north from Southern states like Georgia and Tennessee, former colleagues in civil-rights battles, keepers of common law-school experiences and veterans of local political squabbles and backroom wheeling and dealing. But what sets these judges apart is that they are all black.

title: FRENCH A-TESTS SAID TO DESTROY PACIFIC ATOLL
description: The French Government's nuclear test program in the South Pacific over the last seven years has systematically destroyed the atoll where it is being conducted and has released untold amounts of radioactive waste into the sea.

title: FIREMEN FEAR FOR SCHOOLS
description: NEWARK PLAGUED by false alarms, the Newark Fire Department is gambling with the lives of schoolchildren by using improper emergency tactics, some veteran firefighters here charge.

title: SITTING ATOP A HAWAIIAN VOLCANO
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, a retired Times correspondent, lives in Hawaii. By ROBERT TRUMBULL

title: Business Conditions; RATES STAY UP ABROAD
description: Recent sharp declines in American interest rates have done little, if anything, to alter the financial picture in overseas money market centers. With only one or two exceptions, say analysts at Townsend-Greenspan & Company, the economic consulting firm, interest rates abroad are little changed.

title: 'DELAWARE' BOATS EYED FOR TAXES
description: DELAWARE is displayed as home port on the sterns of many large boats seen in Long Island waters, but the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance has discovered, during a two-year audit of these boat owners, that at least 1,300 of them are New York State residents who moor their boats here. They have avoided paying sales tax on the purchase of the boats by documenting them in Delaware, which charges no sales tax.

title: Music: Debuts in Review;  Anne Cavolo Tedesco Gives Ravel 'Miroirs'
description: ''D'un rythme souple'' is the tempo marking on Ravel's ''Une Barque sur l'ocean'' - ''with a supple rhythm.'' Such pliant flexibility involves establishing a form as well as bending it, filling a firm structure with the sort of pulse and shape that comes through relaxed breathing.

title: More Travesty
description: To the Business Editor: I disagree with Benjamin Civiletti's, ''Antitrust Travesty'' (Nov. 15). Some statements are unfair and others need to be supplemented to better understand the position of his client, the Mead Corporation.

title: JOSEPH PAPP'S BIG NEW PROJECT IS FINDING HIMSELF
description: Joseph Papp is pacing around his office - a huge vaulted room painted yellow, with trophies and awards and photographs marching up the walls and a three-foot-tall pink satin flamingo stationed in one corner. Over and over again, the producer is saying that the most important thing in the world to him is not the play, not the reviews, not the acclaim, not the power, certainly not the money, but the ''relationships'' with writers and directors.

title: Food; SOUP INSPIRED BY THE BIBLE
description: [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] ot long ago on this page, we praised the aptness of French terms for the kitchen and table. To our minds, there are few foods in the French repertory more aptly named than the lentil soup referred to on French menus as potage Esau. The reference is biblical, taken from Genesis 25:34: ''Then Jacob gave Esau bread and pottage of lentils.''

title: Correction
description: A reference to ''The B & B Almanac'' in ''Napa Valley High'' (Travel, Nov. 22) quoted the price at $3.50 but omitted the $1 charge for tax, mailing and handling. The book is available through J & J Productions, Box 295, St. Helena, Calif. 94574.

title: Theater in Review; 'WORKING' PAYS OFF AS A MUSICAL
description: OAKDALE THREE and a half years ago, in a cavernous Broadway theater, ''Working,'' an overproduced musical collage of Studs Terkel's much acclaimed book of interviews with workaday folks, was not much acclaimed. It closed up shop in three weeks.

title: Weinberger for The Defense
description: There is no easy way to be an effective Secretary of Defense (''How Many Billions for Defense?'' by Hedrick Smith, Nov. 1). In fact, the measure of success for any Defense Secretary is the degree to which his actions cause counterpressure from groups, such as Congress, the military chiefs and the business community.

title: GALA DAYS FOR THE MET-DESPITE MONEY WOES
description: ''The master plan for the Louvre,'' points out Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, ''took more than three centuries to complete. We aim to finish ours in a somewhat shorter span of time.''

title: A SEASONAL EPISODE EVOKES REFLECTION
description: AUTUMN. If you are like me, you feel a welcome sense of ending and beginning and moving inward toward the hearth and the inside of your coat. Everything pulls together before the winter huddle. It is uplifting. I find that I drive more quickly now.

title: About Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS FOR anyone accustomed to watching cheerleaders at a football game - that is, seeing a mere 15 of them go through their routine - here is a startling sight: 900 teen-agers in short skirts, sweaters and saddle shoes, stamping and kicking and chanting simultaneously. They represent 44 squads, and each squad is doing its own incantation, its own mix of strut and shout. The wooden floor seems to vibrate; the voices echo in wild, jubilant cacaphony; the young women move perpetually in precise, prescribed patterns, till one feels as if this is some ritualistic dance, some spectacular primitive festival.

title: THIRD-WORLD LANDS JOIN RANKS OF ARMS EXPORTERS
description: Some smaller industrial nations and developing countries are emerging as important exporters of advanced weapons.

title: Antitrust Unit Opposes Pact by Seattle Papers
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division recommended Wednesday that a proposed joint business arrangement between The Seattle Post-Intelligencer and The Seattle Times be rejected.

title: Inquiry Into Voters' Motives Barred by an Appeals Court
description: Judges trying to determine whether racism influenced an election outcome have no right to delve into the motives of voters, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: New Jerseyans
description: HER family was full of teachers and, ever since she can remember, teaching was what Lillian Augustine was ''supposed to do.'' Now she has been named New Jersey's ''Teacher of the Year'' by the State Board of Education and, every time she collects her salary check from the Perth Amboy schools, she says, ''it's like frosting on a seven-layer cake''

title: STRIP SEARCH OF 3D GRADERS ANGERS LOUISVILLE
description: Public school officials here in Jefferson County are formulating a policy covering strip searches of pupils in response to an incident in which several third graders were forced to undress and were then searched by teachers.

title: A NEW STRATEGY FOR NATO
description: Admiral Stansfield Turner, U.S.N., retired, is a former Director of Central Intelligence. Capt. George Thibault, U.S.N., head of the military strategy department of the National War College, helped him prepare this article. By Stansfield Turner

title: Antiques; DOLLHOUSE SHOWS AT 2 MUSEUMS
description: NEW CITY, N.Y. AN EXHIBITION at the History Center Museum of the Rockland County Historical Society includes 15 dollhouses ranging from a formal 1840's house to a backwoods cabin and a contemporary survival house.

title: DISPUTE DIMS LIGHTING ON ROAD
description: VALLEY STREAM WILL the lights go on again on Sunrise Highway? This question has become a matter of serious concern to motorists who find themselves in the dark on this heavily trafficked east-west artery for the two miles it extends through this village.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: FOR the last three decades one of the surprising growth industries in Connecticut has been tobacco farming, particularly for cigar manufacturers. About 2,000 acres east of Hartford, in the area from Middletown to Glastonbury, had been developed for this purpose.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Charles Lane, a tenor who is an alumnus of the California Institute of the Arts School of Music, made his New York debut Wednesday at Carnegie Recital Hall as the featured performer in a program of contemporary American chamber music. Mr. Lane sang Ives's ''Sunrise,'' Mel Powell's ''Little Companion Pieces'' and Randall Packer's ''Ariel Settings'' with poems by Sylvia Plath. The fourth work of the evening was John King's Third String Quartet (1981), which, like the Packer songs, was given its premiere.

title: TO CHEER THE EYE
description: MAN BITES MAN Two Decades of Satiric Art. Edited by Steven Heller. Foreword by Tom Wolfe. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: A & W Publishers. $29.95 until Jan. 1, 1982; $35 thereafter.

title: Station Wagons, Revisited
description: OVER the years, a lot of nice cars have lived in my garage, and one of the more useful was a 1965 Pontiac wagon. It was a midsized Tempest, bought used in 1970 for $695, and possessed of a sixcylinder engine, terrific gas mileage and more character than a three-wheeled buckboard.

title: BREAKING THE STEREOTYPE
description: Typing a player as having such and such a style means that he wins most of his games, or most of his best games, in a certain way. With some rare exceptions, it does not mean that he never wins in any other way.

title: Allison A. Mellor, Banker, Fiancee Of Brian Mitchell
description: Allison Annette Mellor, an assistant vice president with the Bankers Trust Company, plans to be married Jan. 30 to Brian Park Mitchell, a partner in Murray Bruce Productions, a division of Columbia Pictures.

title: IN POLAND, WELL-WORN TIGHTROPE SNAPS AT LAST
description: A television viewer here could hardly be blamed last week if he thought the end was just around the corner. The statecontrolled networks piped out hair-raising daily wrapups. Correspondents around the country told tales of workers preparing for a day of reckoning. Some were said to be stockpiling supplies or laying in medical equipment; others supposedly were setting up ''secret'' leaderships in case the current ones were arrested, or organizing squads of ''workers guards'' for self-protection. ''All this is creating an atmosphere of insurrection and tension,'' a television commentator intoned.

title: Sports of The Times; Back to Hockey After 14 Years
description: FOR the first time in 13 years, I attended a hockey game, the Rangers' most recent home game last Wednesday against the Bruins. Thirteen years before, the attraction was Gordie Howe. Then 40 years old, a graying, 23-year National Hockey League veteran, Howe was making what was believed to be his farewell appearance at Madison Square Garden. Little did one know that Howe, who had set many records, would break the one by Sarah Bernhardt for farewell tours.

title: YULETIDE SEMI-POSTALS
description: The Christmas season is not only a time of merriment, it is also a time when the more fortunate think of the less fortunate - the old and infirm, the children in need, the destitute, the handicapped, the many who are long out of work.

title: Mary Bradley Is Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. John W. Bradley of Margate, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Bradley, to Matthew W. Sheprow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph S. Sheprow of Monmouth Beach, N.J. A May 22 wedding is planned. Miss Bradley's father is president of Jack Bradley Inc., an Atlantic City real-estate investment concern. Mr. Sheprow's father is a captain in the Jersey City Police Department.

title: Young Doctors In Debt
description: Dr. Stea and Dr. Kasten are no longer the ''exception'' but are all too quickly becoming the rule (''A Nation of Doctors in Debt?'' by Ron Winslow, Nov. 8). I am in my last year of medical school and have amassed a debt of $55,000, including $10,000 from a HEAL (Health Education Assistance) loan.

title: NUREYEV'S FIGHT AGAINST TIME
description: John Lombardi writes frequently on the arts. By John Lombardi

title: HARRY T. PETERS JR.
description: Harry T. Peters Jr., a dog-breeder who operated the Windholme Kennels in Islip, L.I., and was a longtime judge at shows of the Westminster Kennel Club and at other major exhibitions, died Thursday at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville.

title: A Well-Read Secretary General
description: With a figurative puff of white smoke, the United Nations Security Council finally selected a new Secretary General - a seasoned and soft-spoken diplomat from Peru, Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: DIM FUTURE IS SEEN FOR MASS TRANSIT
description: The American Public Transit Association, the leading mass-transit trade organization here, says that a poll of its members has shown that local bus and train systems will have difficulty weathering the Reagan Administration's plan to suspend Federal operating subsidies by 1985, and that about 28 of the systems could be forced to end service.

title: MAKING LIBERTYLAND A SMASH HIT
description: THERE has been a bit of a flap recently over Liberty State Park, on the Hudson River in Jersey City. Originally dedicated and intended as a green ''lung'' for the most populous part of the country's most densely populated state, it is now the target of plans by Governor Byrne to turn about half of its 752 acres over to Warner LeRoy (of Maxwell's Plum fame), who wants to use it as the site of an amusement park.

title: Music; CONDUCTOR LEAVING FLUTE FOR PODIUM
description: ''WESTCHESTER audiences are sometimes labeled conservative,'' said the flutist-conductor Paul Dunkel, ''but when you call listeners 'conservative,' you're calling them dumb, and I don't think they are, not by a long shot.''

title: Record Cold in England
description: England shivered through its coldest night since records started 93 years ago. The lowest temperature was recorded in Shropshire, western England, at 9 below.

title: U.N. VOTE PROPELS UGANDAN AND CHINA TO CENTER STAGE
description: Javier Perez de Cuellar won the job, but many diplomats here think the big winners in the battle for Secretary General were China and Olara A. Otunnu of Uganda.

title: THOUGH UNPOPULAR, ARGENTINE ARMED FORCES CLING TO POWER
description: When President Roberto Eduardo Viola temporarily turned over the reins of government last month, the sense inside the Argentine regime was that he would not return - less because of his heart troubles than because of the country's deep economic and political ills. Inflation was running at more than 100 percent, unemployment was rising and every announcement of a new economic program seemed to have the opposite of the effect intended, stimulating a scramble to buy dollars. Meanwhile, his Government's contacts with leaders of civilian political parties seemed only to increase the clamor for the military to step down.

title: Travel Advisory; FARE BARGAINS, SPOTLIGHT ON VERMONT; Year of the Castle in Denmark
description: Once upon a time, in the days immortalized in the fables of Hans Christian Andersen, life in Denmark revolved around its fairytale castles. Lords, ladies and knights in armor, attended by footmen and followers, journeyed to the castles' turrets and towers for lordly revels and banquests.

title: VASSAR'S LIBRARY ACQUIRES PAPERS OF ELIZABETH BISHOP
description: The Vassar College Library in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., has acquired the literary and personal papers of the late Elizabeth Bishop, a major American poet and Vassar alumna.

title: HISTORICAL GROUPS OPEN OFFICE
description: THE Westchester County Historical Society and the Westchester Preservation League will hold a joint reception today from 3 to 5 P.M. to mark the official opening of their new headquarters in Hartford House, the administration building of Westchester Community College, at 75 Grasslands Road in Valhalla. The college's library will also house the historical society's extensive collection of books and papers.

title: PREPARING PARENTS FOR A BIRTH
description: PLAINFIELD ''CONTRACTION begins.'' It was a recent Wednesday evening at Muhlenberg Hospital, and, on hearing that signal, 14 pregnant women took a deep breath and exhaled slowly. Their husbands knelt beside them, timing the simulated labor contractions.

title: Patricia Chao Bride at Yale
description: The marriage of Patricia Hui-ch'un Chao to Wayne Clark Lemley of New York took place in New Haven yesterday. The Rev. Arthur Underwood performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Dwight Chapel at Yale University. .

title: Long Islanders; BOOKS AND CHILDREN FORM HER THEMES
description: ''I KNEW, from probably the age of 8, that I was going to be a librarian,'' said Johanna Hurwitz. ''I loved the time I spent in the library, and the thought of being able to stay there all day and get paid for it as a profession seemed ideal. I also thought I'd be a writer.''

title: Rail Union Ratifies Contract
description: The railroad membership of the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks has ratified a new 39-month agreement with the rail industry calling for a 40.2 percent increase in wages and fringe benefits.

title: IN MAURITIUS, A POOR CROP STIRS POLITICS
description: The annual sugar cane harvest has just been completed in Mauritius, and the production figure of 575,000 tons is not much of an improvement over last year, which produced the worst season in many decades because of a cyclone.

title: VIKINGS TROUNCED BY THE LIONS, 45-7
description: Eric Hipple threw two touchdown passes in the last two minutes of a 31-point first half today to pace Detroit to a 45-7 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: PARK BUILDERS TO USE GAS
description: EAST RUTHERFORD CREATING a park out of 26 million tons of garbage, 1,200 acres of marshes and billions of cubic feet of swamp gas may not be the easiest method of providing recreational facilities.

title: Texas Aggies Triumph In Independence Bowl
description: Gary Kubiak passed to Jimmy Williams for two first-half touchdowns and sparked Texas A. & M. to a 33-16 victory over Oklahoma State tonight in the Independence Bowl.

title: Environews
description: STARTING next spring, people who live near the Jersey Central Power and Light Company's Oyster Creek nuclear-power station in Forked River and the Public Service Electric and Gas Company's Salem I and II plants in Lower Alloways Creek Township will be protected for the first time from possible radiation exposure in an emergency.

title: THE HIDDEN MONGOLIA
description: Seymour Topping is the managing editor of The New York Times. Audrey Topping, the author of ''The Splendors of Tibet,'' collaborated in the reporting of this article. By Seymour Topping

title: Catherine Rosen Wed to C. A. Hinnant
description: Catherine Elizabeth Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Rosen of Greenwich, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Charles Asbell Hinnant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Hinnant of Micro, N.C. The Rev. Gary P. Brown of the First Congregational Church in Stamford, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel.

title: Investing; PROFESSIONAL EYES ON $1 MILLION
description: O NE million dollars is a round, respectable sum, large enough for a professional money manager to do something interesting with. It seemed logical, then, to ask the people who earn a living investing the funds for individuals, institutions and their own companies what they would do these days with such a sum. Five randomly selected managers responded, and all proved resolutely orthodox. They would put most of an investor's million into the stock and bond markets, despite the beating that both markets took during most of this year. All also agreed that, if it were their money, they would invest a smaller portion of the windfall in high-yielding money market instruments. Keeping ahead of inflation, at the very least, was a common goal. Following are their individual assessments.

title: The Nation; A Run of Death In the Mines
description: Coal mining will always be dangerous, but last week, after three accidents claimed the lives of 24 miners within five days, some groups contended that the Reagan Administration's budget cuts may make it more risky still.

title: by Philip Coltoff
description: By Thomas A DeStefano Executive Director Catholic Charities Diocese of Brooklyn

title: Around the World; Egypt Frees 17 People Accused of Coup Plot
description: A former Egyptian Deputy Prime Minister and Foreign Minister and 16 other men accused of conspiring with the Soviet Union to overthrow the Government of President Anwar el-Sadat were released today, police officials said.

title: Helene Hare To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. William A.D. Hare of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helene Louise Hare, to Barry Morton Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard M. Rose Jr. of Pinehurst, N.C. The wedding is planned for June 12 in Greenwich.

title: JERSEY CITY WARNED OF A POTENTIAL BLAST
description: JERSEY CITY AN INVESTIGATOR of hazardous wastes for this city has told a Municipal Court judge there is a ''good probability'' that hundreds of drums containing toxic chemicals could explode less than 25 feet from a major commuter rail line.

title: The Region; One Man's Trash Is Everybody's
description: Talks between striking private sanitation workers and trash collecting companies hadn't moved much by yesterday afternoon, and neither had most of the nearly 100,000 tons of garbage the five boroughs have generated during the two-week walkout.

title: RANGERS BEAT FLYERS 3D STRAIGHT TIME, 5-3
description: Dean Talafous scored two goals in the third period today as the the Rangers beat the Phildelphia Flyers, 5-3, in a brisk afternoon game at the Spectrum.

title: Vermont Names Road For Vietnam Veterans
description: An interstate highway that runs half the length of Vermont has been named in honor of Vietnam veterans. The Vermont Board of Libraries on Tuesday unanimously approved the naming of 130 miles of Interstate 89 as the Vietnam Veterans' Memorial Highway.

title: HOW THE FEDERAL BUDGET WAS SHAVED BY $4 BILLION
description: President Reagan faced down a reluctant Congress this week to win a new round of $4 billion in budget cuts that marked the successful conclusion of his yearlong effort to slow the growth of domestic social programs.

title: NEW U.S. PROPOSAL HINDERS RICH-POOR TALKS
description: A new snag has developed here in the long-stalled global talks aimed at shifting wealth from rich nations to poor nations. Developing countries have rejected a proposal by the United States to start ''preliminary'' negotiations rather than fullfledged talks.

title: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF AN IDEALIST
description: WHO KILLED KAREN SILKWOOD? By Howard Kohn. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: Summit Books. Cloth $16.95. Paper $8.95.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Watchlions
description: The New York Public Library, in a double-edged attack on vandalism and budget deficits, decided in 1979 to make its lions roar for Christmas.

title: WHAT WAS CUBISM'S IMPACT
description: The standard gloss on the origins of modernist photography runs more or less as follows: two years after the 1913 Armory Show introduced modern French painting and sculpture (including Cubism) to the United States, Paul Strand made a series of close-up photographs that were crisply lit, dynamically composed and superficially abstract. Alfred Stieglitz, then America's arbiter of art photography, regarded these pictures as a stupendous breakthrough. He renounced the then-prevailing style of gauzy Pictorialism and announced that henceforth photography would be free of the shackles of painting.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ Sam Rivers disliked the term ''loft jazz,'' but whatever one chooses to call the remarkable ferment that came bubbling up from New York's jazz underground in the mid-70's, its epicenter was Studio Rivbea, the downtown performance space run by Mr. Rivers and his wife Bea. While Rivbea was open, one could go there and savor Mr. Rivers's music at length, and there was a certain tendency to take his exceptional talent for granted.

title: Politics; THE SHIFT OF POWER BEGINS IN TRENTON
description: ALTHOUGH Thomas H. Kean will not become Governor until the moment he finishes reciting the oath of office on Jan. 19, the power of the office began flowing to him as soon as it became apparent that he was the winner of the Nov. 3 election.

title: Art; PAINTINGS' GLOW CASTS A SPELL
description: HEMPSTEAD AS one enters Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery, a subtle illumination, a sort of muted alpenglow, becomes apparent. It is the light emanating from the paintings by William J. Lathrop, suffused with the natural and artificial light of the gallery. It is quietly embracing and immediately creates a serene, warm aura and establishes between the paintings and visitors a keen atmospheric rapport.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: A STOCKINGFUL OF DANCE AND SONG
description: CONNECTICUT'S two major ballet companies, both celebrating their 10th anniversaries, will brighten the holiday season in Hartford and New Haven with their versions of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: John C. Conti Jr. Is Fiance Of Elaine Marie Pantages
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Pantages of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elaine Marie Pantages, to John C. Conti Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Conti, also of Upper Montclair.

title: Long Island Guide; ARTIST IN WONDERLAND
description: As an artist attracted to Surrealism, Martin Barooshian of Port Washington has found a natural in ''Alice in Wonderland.'' So natural, that after seeing some of his ''Alice''-inspired work, which dates to 1956, the Lewis Carroll Society of North America commissioned Mr. Barooshian, a former president of the Society of American Graphic Artists, whose works are in the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to do a folio, illustrating each chapter, to commemorate the author's 150th birthday this year. The drawings, paintings and prints are on display for the first time at the artist's hometown library, 245 Main Street, before going on a national tour, and Mr. Barooshian will appear today at 3:30 P.M. at the library for a ''Meet the Artist'' session. Complementing his works are such memorabilia as foreign editions, Carroll letters and figurines, gleaned from the private collection of Stan Marx of Roslyn, former president of the society. Both shows run through Dec. 29. For hours, call 883-4400.

title: TV-IN-COURT PLAN GETS MIXED REVIEW
description: HARTFORD WHEN seven teen-agers from Lenox, Mass., were convicted last month of involuntary manslaughter in connection with the deaths of two other youths, cameras from television station WFSB in Hartford were rolling, recording for viewers of the next news program scenes of families wrenched apart by tragedy.

title: LESSONS LEARNED ON VISITING DAY AT COLLEGE
description: I HAVE consumed my share of cookies and cider on parents night at the Little Village Nursery School and choked down more than my share of three-dimensional projects on parents day at Public School 41. I've limped gamely from nature hunt to softball on visiting day at Camp Winaukee, and I've asked my concerned questions at Mamaroneck High School. I had earned my stripes, my Mother's Day cards, my right to a serene middle age, my right to stop Visiting. I thought.

title: Bradley Backed in California
description: Warren Christopher, the diplomat who negotiated the release of the United States hostages in Iran, announced the formation of a committee Thursday to help Mayor Tom Bradley become Governor of California. Mr. Bradley, a Democrat, has been raising money and traveling for several months assessing his chances.

title: Connecticut Guide; DISPLAY OF MINIATURES
description: When Henry VIII was to be married to Anne of Cleves, he was given a customary miniature portrait of her, painted by Hans Holbein, the Flemish artist, as a token of her affection. In other instances miniature portraits, easily transportable, were exchanged so that prospective spouses who had never met might see what they were getting.

title: AND NOW THE SMURF
description: They're two inches tall and very German. They're blue and they live deep in the forest. In fantasy, there are only a hundred of them. But they've sold in the millions. They're Smurfs - in Europe, Schlumpfen - and according to Wallace Berrie & Company, which distributes the product in America, 30 million have been sold here since the first one crossed the Atlantic in 1979. This year domestic sales will total about $20 million.

title: No Headline
description: NORTH CAROLINA STATE ROUTS MARYLAND

title: IRAN FROM FIVE AMERICAN VIEWPOINTS
description: AMERICA HELD HOSTAGE The Secret Negotiations. By Pierre Salinger. Illustrated. 349 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $16.95.

title: Sanchez Retains Title; Cowdell Loses Decision
description: Salvador Sanchez of Mexico, listless in the early going, rallied in the 11th and 15th rounds tonight and retained his World Boxing Council featherweight championship with a 15-round split decision over Pat Cowdell of England.

title: Around the World; 16 Nicaraguan Guerrillas Said to Die in 2 Battles
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 12

title: Sports of The Times; Ali's Decision: This Is the End
description: ON the first day of the rest of his life, Muhammad Ali surrendered to himself. In other years, he talked about retiring, but when he did, he always had that glint in his eyes that betrayed the inevitability of another comeback. Yesterday that glint was gone. On a sunny morning after having lost the unanimous 10-round decision to Trevor Berbick, the three-time heavyweight champion accepted his age.

title: HOW-TO-BOOKS FOR HOLIDAY GIFTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elinor Stecker is a freelance writer and photographer.

title: THEATER: AN ADAPTATION OF 'RIP VAN WINKLE'
description: In ''Rip Van Winkle or 'The Works,' '' Richard Nelson has taken Washington Irving's slight, anecdotal Sketch Book tale and turned it into a three-and-a-half-hour three-act leviathan about agrarian reform, the Industrial Revolution, the labor movement and family skeletons. No matter how one regards it - and Mr. Nelson's view is prismatic - ''Rip Van Winkle'' is not ''Moby Dick.'' As an archetypal American epic, Mr. Nelson's vessel cannot hold water. The adaptation's chaos is compounded in David Jones's production at the Yale Repertory Theater. This ''Rip'' is less a dream play than a nightmare.

title: FIRST FAMILY GETS READY TO MOVE
description: PRINCETON ''IDON'T want to be remembered as too negative,'' Jean Byrne said at the beginning of an interview in the Gold Room of Morven, the Governor's official residence here.
