The Byrnes, who moved into Morven early in 1974, will be vacating the 18th-century Georgian mansion on Jan. 19, the day the state's next Governor -Thomas H. Kean - is sworn into office.

title: The Nation; More Tales From The Dark Ages
description: That T-shirt slogan may proclaim that living well is the best revenge, but for John D. Ehrlichman, telling all appears to be even better.

title: HOTEL ROOM TAX SOUGHT FOR TOURISTS
description: THE Long Island Tourism and Convention Commission is seeking a tax on patrons of Long Island's hotels and motels to generate revenue for the promotion of tourism on the Island, and little opposition has arisen thus far.

title: AN ESTIMABLE COLLECTION SEES THE LIGHT OF DAY
description: It was thanks to a New York fortune that got away that Count Antoine Seilern was able in 1978 to bequeath to the Courtauld Institute in London what is universally regarded as one of the most distinguished private collections to have been formed in this century. In the case of Rubens, for instance, the Seilern collection, with close on 40 items by the master, was stronger than many a famous museum. It ranged backward in time to a triptych by the Master of Flemalle (c. 1375-1444) and forward to a little drawing of pigs that Picasso had made for Gertrude Stein in the summer of 1906. Sometimes quirky, always illuminating, and catalogued by himself and others on a magisterial scale, the Seilern collection had long enjoyed an almost clandestine celebrity in London.

title: Theater; 'NEW MOON' BRINGS A GLOW TO DARIEN
description: DARIEN WHEN ''The New Moon'' first opened in Philadelphia in 1927, it was considered a disaster and was withdrawn. With a rewritten libretto and an almost entirely new score, it showed up eight months later in Cleveland and went on to Broadway in 1928 to become Sigmund Romberg's longest-running hit - with 509 performances. It has twice been made into a motion picture, the last time as a vehicle for Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy.

title: CHRISTMAS IS WHERE YOU FIND IT
description: The following article, based on suggestions by Times correspondents, was written by Glenn Collins.

title: Young Doctors In Debt
description: One wonders if the Reagan Administration's cutbacks in loan and scholarship programs for medical-school students will affect the quality of future physicians as well as the quantity. The results of cuts in Government-subsidized loans will not only be a nation of doctors in debt, but also a nation of frustrated premed students, some of whom may have the potential for making major breakthroughs in medical research. MARGUERITE S. KRAMER, Sweet Briar College, Sweet Briar, Va.

title: HANDICAPS NO IMPEDIMENT AT RADIO STATION WMNR
description: MONROE STEWART NAZZARO was a 22-year-old graduate of journalism school when took over the management of WMNR-FM two years ago with a commitment to employ the handicapped.

title: DIANA GETS A RESPITE FROM THE PRESS
description: The monarchy-watchers of Fleet Street, under pressure from Queen Elizabeth, have agreed to become somewhat less diligent in watching the Princess of Wales.

title: 94 Horses Sold
description: Ninety-four harness horses were sold for $306,606 in the final Old Glory sales of the year at Yonkers Raceway today. Rosemary's Sugar, a 3-year-old filly, fetched the day's highest price, $14,500. She was purchased by Dave Downey of Calgary, Alberta.

title: DR. PHYLLIS BECKER TO WED APRIL 17
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Jerrold M. Becker of Lake Success, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Phyllis Irene Becker, to Dr. Michael G. Cedars, son of Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Cedars of Stephenville, Tex.

title: SOVIET PROMPTLY REPORTS MOVES BY POLISH REGIME
description: In a clear signal of Moscow's approval, the Soviet news media today announced the declaration of martial law by the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, one hour after Poles heard the news themselves.

title: Mailbox; Right on Target
description: To the Sports Editor: It may seem that Dr. Ferdie Pachecho is punch drunk when he suggests to patients like Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier that boxing is dangerous to their health (''Age is a Boxer's Natural Opponent,'' The New York Times, Nov. 29, 1981). If he says the same to the profithungry promoters and to the hero-worshipping public, then this is unquestionable proof that the doctor is brain damaged.

title: Topics; CHANGES OF HEART AND VENUE; Lions of the Bar
description: John Martin, the United States Attorney for Manhattan, has ended a month of madness on the right-to-counsel issue. Mr. Martin was opposed to Cynthia Boston's choice of a lawyer in the Brink's robbery investigation.

title: BILL OF RIGHTS DAY TO BE 'REAFFIRMED' AT ST. PAUL'S
description: ST. PAUL'S CHURCH in Mount Vernon, declared a national monument last year for its link to the freedom-of-the-press provisions of the Bill of Rights, will come alive again Tuesday with an all-day celebration, including a re-enactment of the libel and treason trial of John Peter Zenger held 248 years ago.

title: CHRISTMAS EVE: WHO NEEDS THE CROWD?
description: AFTER I moved to East Hampton, I didn't see Melanie very often, only when I went into New York City. She hated leaving the city for any reason. I went there less and less as time went by, but always around Christmas, to see the stores and the tree at Rockefeller Center, and to see old friends like Melanie.

title: Chinese Cites Positive Effect Of Talks Under Way With India
description: Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China told Indian negotiators today that the talks now under way on a boundary dispute and other issues would have a positive influence on friendly relations between the two nations, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: VIDEO GAME ROOMS TARGETED BY TOWNS
description: BROOKHAVEN FASTER than a speeding bullet, an army of coin-operated video games has bleeped, boinged and flashed its way across the Island, and, according to school and parent groups, mesmerized thousands of teenagers along the way. Even as local official move to contain the onslaught, the Aliens, Asteroids and Missile Commandos continue to multiply.

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker Getting Serious Patrick McDonnell
description: Conservatives aren't as nice as they used to be. Being in charge of things has taken a lot of the joy out of them, I guess. Until they got elected, conservatives used to be a lot of fun to spend an evening with. Certainly a lot more fun than liberals. Liberals are people whose hearts are in the right place, and I admire that, but it's always heavy going socially. Sooner or later, liberals are going to start poking around to find if your heart's in the right place too. If it isn't, they're going to try to relocate it for you.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; ALBERT GOLDMAN
description: For anyone who grew up as a teeny-bopper adoring Elvis Presley's music, it's going to be impossible to listen to ''Love Me Tender'' without feeling revulsion after reading Albert Goldman's biography ''Elvis.'' Every sordid aspect of the man once idolized as the King of Rock 'n' Roll is here in 598 pages of vivid detail: the drugs, the perverse sex, the penchant for violence, the selfishness, the blind trust in a devious, money-grabbing manager.

title: AILEY'S FUSION OF JAZZ, MODERN AND BALLET
description: Looking at Alexander Godunov expiring in uncounted cubic feet of dry ice as Judith Jamison enticed him into her febrile embrace at Alvin Ailey's most recent gala, one could say, as Brother John Sellers's vocals do in another Ailey piece, ''Yes, there's something strange going on.''

title: New Jersey Housing; KEEPING A GRIP ON TIME SHARING
description: HIS BIG problem, Robert Leichtenberg says, is that he falls in love with all the resorts he is selling. He and his wife have purchased a time share at the Sea Crest Surf and Racquet Club on Hilton Head Island in South Carolina, and he is eagerly awaiting the opportunity to visit Fitzpatrick's Castle, a resort in Ireland.

title: Other Business; FACTS AND FIGURES FOR LAW FIRMS
description: Few people are better at keeping secrets than lawyers, especially when it comes to the business of their own firms. But now comes the Am-Law Publishing Corporation in New York, publishers of The American Lawyer, a monthly magazine about lawyers and law firms, with the most ambitious effort yet to crack the secrecy.

title: Art; CHAIRS AND MORE 'CHAIRS'
description: A QUITE wonderful exhibition of art that has chairs as its subject is on view until Jan. 3 at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill. Chairs in art may sound like an exercise in whimsy, but, though there is wit aplenty in the works of art gathered here, there is nothing arch or silly in the entire exhibition. Indeed, it includes images ranging from electric chairs to easy chairs, from chairs in hotel lobbies to chairs that are part of surreal fantasies.

title: CAREY ORDERS AGENCIES TO SOLICIT MINORITY BIDS
description: Nine New York State agencies have been ordered by Governor Carey to seek bids on contracts from businesses owned by blacks, people of Hispanic extraction and other members of other minority groups.

title: WARMERDAM WAS IN CLASS BY HIMSELF
description: Who was better? Jack Dempsey of Muhammad Ali? Walter Johnson or Sandy Koufax? Sammy Baugh or Joe Namath? Bill Tilden or John McEnroe? Bobby Jones or Jack Nicklaus? Babe Ruth or Joe DiMaggio?

title: ANTI-ABORTION GROUP BACKS HATCH PROPOSAL
description: The National Right to Life Committee, one of the nation's largest anti-abortion groups, today endorsed a constitutional amendment that would empower Congress and individual states to adopt laws regulating and banning abortion.

title: The Nation; Affirmative Word From Washington
description: President Reagan and his Administration have made no bones about their distaste for affirmative action, which they portray as a confusing, unnecessary tangle of federally imposed quotas and timetables. But the United States Commission on Civil Rights said in a report last week that it was often the only way of overcoming years of entrenched ''institutional discrimination'' against job applicants on the basis of race or sex.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S NEW AIM ON WATERSHED
description: Two weeks ago a New York City water official showed up at a Planning Board hearing in North Salem to voice the city's concern over a proposed subdivision that is planned for development on land continguous to watershed property.

title: TV STATION FACING DIFFICULTIES
description: VINELAND SOUTH JERSEY'S first commercial television station, WRBV-TV, has laid off two-thirds of its employees and ceased production of its local newscast, a result of having been temporarily placed under new management by court order.

title: The Convent of Frostian Narrative
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE LAND OF THE LONG WHITE CLOUD
description: R.V. DENENBERG is a frequent contributor to Travel. By R.V.DENENBERG

title: Index; Crackdown in Poland
description: Transcript of Polish Prime Minister's radio address A16 Poles Awake to a Day of Bayonets and Despair A17 Excerpts from Poland's martiallaw decree A17 Polish-Americans react with protests and silent prayers A17 Excerpts from Haig news conference A19 Chronology of events leading to Polish crisis A20 Schmidt stresses East-West ties A20 International For China's parliament, back to the rubber stamp A2 Levesque to put leadership to a vote A3 Two die in London car bomb blast A4 Dispossessed in Indian Ocean grow bitter A5 Malta's course hangs on election result A6 Around the World A7 Iranian names two to new Cabinet A8 Israel's Defense Minister says South Africa needs more arms A9 Extradited Palestinian arrives in Israel A10 Pope appeals to Poles to ''peace- fully build a peaceful future'' A14 Wall St. lawyer seeks justice for murder of nuns in El Salvador B5 Government/Politics Orange County voters satisfied with voting for Reagan A22 New York agencies plan energy-saving greenhouse project B3 U.S. Attorney assesses impact of verdict in Margiotta case B9 Washington Talk Briefing D10 Reagan's story-telling is asset that sometimes needs checking D10 Alexander Barkan retiring from A.F.L.-C.I.O. political post D10 Congresswomen's Caucus at- tracts 46 men as members D10 SportsMonday Basketball: North Carolina rolls on and on C1

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: Though the curtain had to be held for half an hour, the Village Light Opera Group went on with its show Saturday afternoon, presenting Gilbert and Sullivan's ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' in twilight at the Fashion Institute Theater. Even with much of the stage lighting on the blink there was plenty to see - some productions at the Metropolitan Opera have less light by design than this one did by default - and the musical aspects of the performance remained unimpeded.

title: Carpenter's 'A Winner'
description: ON the chalkboard in the Giants' locker room, the message had been written with feeling: ''What you've never had and can't have, you'll never miss. But what you have in your grasp and squander, you'll truly miss.'' It was signed: ''A couple of veterans who've never been.''

title: WASHINGTON WATCH
description: Reagan economists are looking for another reduction in the rate of inflation next year, to about 7 1/2 or 8 percent from this year's expected 10 percent and last year's 12.4 percent.

title: Oil, Gas Lease Put Off
description: The competitive oil and gas lease sale in the National Petroleum Reserve-Alaska, scheduled for Wednesday, has been delayed by the Secretary of the Interior until late January, the Bureau of Land Management said. The postponement is due to uncertainties among potential bidders about antitrust review requirements by the Department of Justice, the bureau said in a statement Friday. These uncertainties could lessen participation in the offering.

title: INTEREST RATE TREND HARDER TO FORECAST
description: Financial economists have honed the skills with which they describe the events that act to raise or lower interest rates, but their skills in predicting how interest rates will move leave much sharpening to be desired.

title: Ketchum, MacLeod Wins Rockwell Account
description: Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove Pittsburgh has become the beneficiary of a decision by Rockwell International, based in that city, to consolidate its advertising in one agency. Trade sources indicate that the total budget is about $12 million.

title: FOR FILM MOGULS, SALARIES IN MEGABUCKS
description: HOLLYWOOD HOW much money do studio heads make? A dozen years ago the question was never asked in public. Now the answer is flaunted. In September, Columbia held a luncheon to announce that its chairman, Frank Price, had signed a new four-year contract that was ''almost certain'' to earn him more than $10 million. If every movie Mr. Price makes is a box-office disaster, he will still earn a minimum of $6 million, plus 100,000 shares of Columbia stock.

title: DANCE: RUMANIAN FOLKLORE ENSEMBLE
description: ''THEY'RE our people!'' a woman said excitedly to a small child sitting near her at a performance of the Rumanian Folk Festival Maramuresul on Saturday at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. By the end of the evening, however, the theater seemed filled with honorary Rumanians, all clapping along and cheering as excitedly as the National Folklore Ensemble of Maramures presented music and dance from nine regions of the country.

title: Bengals 17, Steelers 10
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Ken Anderson passed for two touchdowns as Cincinnati clinched the American Conference's Central Division title. The Bengals (11-4), in winning their first division title in eight years, knocked Pittsburgh (8-7) out of playoff contention.

title: DANCE: 'SPECIMEN DAYS' BY MISS MONK AT PUBLIC
description: MEREDITH MONK is a ''film maker'' who transfers the movies of her mind onto the stage. Film is only rarely involved. Most of the time she is giving us a splice of life in nonlinear theater pieces that are more animated than any cartoon - her performers are live and she uses them with a sharp cross-cutting edge.

title: VOLS WIN IN GARDEN STATE BOWL, 28 TO 21
description: Steve Alatorre's name was misspelled on the back of his orange jersey, but it was the only noticeable imperfection associated with the Tennessee quarterback, who knew exactly how to spell victory for the Volunteers in the fourth annual Garden State Bowl today.

title: Cathy E. Walter, Teacher, Wed to Gene H. Albrecht
description: Cathy Elizabeth Walter, daughter of Carol G. Walter of New York and Richard L. Walter of New York and Old Brookville, L.I., was married in Portland, Ore., yesterday to Gene Harrison Albrecht, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Albrecht of Portland.

title: ARAB EXTRADITED FROM U.S. INDICTED AS TERRORIST IN ISRAEL
description: Ziad Abu Eain, a Palestinian wanted by Israel in connection with a terrorist bombing two and a half years ago, arrived in Israel from the United States today with an Israeli police escort after losing a two-year battle against extradition in American courts and with the State Department.

title: OUTDOORS: WATERFOWLING ON MARTHA'S VINEYARD
description: EVERY other year or so, my oldest son, Steve, and I are possessed by an urge to go waterfowl hunting on Cape Pogue Pond, a salt bay whose riches also include scallops, soft shelled clams and quahogs.

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1981; International
description: More than $500 million in interest payments owed by Poland to Western banks, and an agreement to reschedule $2.4 billion in debt due this year, appear to have been put under a cloud by the crisis there, a United States official said. The Western banks are unlikely to proceed with the debt rescheduling if the interest payment, due today, is missed, the official added. (Page D1.)

title: Magazine Research Panel Is Proposed
description: The media policy committee of the American Association of Advertising Agencies is calling for the establishment of a magazine research committee.

title: EXECUTIVES CALM ON DEFICIT FIGURES
description: After expressing great alarm last summer at the prospect of the Federal budget deficit rising above the Administration's $43.1 billion target, the business community has greeted the latest estimates of a staggering $100 billion deficit with surprising calm.

title: TAX DEBATE STIRS ON LEASING RULES
description: In both Houses of Congress, Democrats searching for 1982 campaign issues have begun criticizing the 1981 leasing amendments to the tax code. Unless changed, these amendments will let corporations reduce their tax bills by billions of dollars a year.

title: POLES AWAKE TO BAYONETS AND DESPAIR
description: After a succession of dismally gray days, the people of Warsaw woke this morning to bright sunshine that made the blanket of snow that covers the city glisten. It must have seemed the beginning of a fine Sunday for most residents of the capital. Then they turned on their radios.

title: STUDENTS IN LAW SCHOOL RAISE COLLUSION ISSUE IN WATT WILDERNESS
description: DECISION By STUART TAYLOR Jr.

title: FESTIVE PEDESTRIANS COME FORTH TO TAKE OVER 5TH
description: It was a 1981 reminder of what festive New Yorkers once looked like to Currier and Ives. But yesterday, on the first Sunday of the annual Fifth Avenue holiday mall, the street scene was a sunlit motion picture in sound and color.

title: GIRL DROWNS AS ICE GIVES WAY
description: An 11-year-old girl died today when she fell through a thin coating of ice over a sump filled with water.

title: AN ASSISTANT D.A.'S IRISH COMMITMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS TRIUMPH, REMAIN IN RACE
description: The defense did it again, and the Giants' playoff hopes are still alive. They beat the Cardinals, 20-10, today in a game in which their offense consisted mainly of Rob Carpenter's running. But the defense, which had pulled them through all season, never let the Cardinals off the hook.

title: 2 SOVIET BLOC ALLIES PRAISE ACTION
description: Czechoslovakia and Hungary today welcomed the decision of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, to declare a state of emergency.

title: POLES IN JERSEY TOWN EXPRESS ANGER
description: They stood around in small knots in front of the Church of the Most Sacred Heart of Jesus in this town 10 miles west of Manhattan where almost everyone is of at least partially Polish ancestry.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Knapp Partnership Buys Home Magazine
description: Home Magazine, which International Thomson Magazines bought from Litton Industries, has now been sold to a limited partnership headed by Knapp Communications.

title: BACK TO THE RUBBER STAMP FOR CHINA'S LEGISLATURE
description: The National People's Congress, China's nominal legislature, wound up its annual session today in a show of virtual unanimity that restored its old familiar image as a parliamentary foil for the Chinese Communist leadership.

title: OTHER DEVELOPMENTS
description: Warsaw mood - Every hour on the hour beginning at 6 A.M., Poles listening to their radios heard Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski speak in solemn tones about having placed the country under martial law. The interludes were filled with music. More cars were on the streets than is usual for a Sunday, particularly in a period of acute gasoline shortage. All telephones had stopped functioning, presumably to keep those who might wish to resist from coordinating actions. Page A17. Washington concern - The Reagan Administration called in the Polish Ambassador and the Soviet Deputy Chief of Mission for discussions. Several allied diplomats were also called to the State Department. President Reagan returned ahead of schedule from a weekend at Camp David to be briefed on Poland by Administation officials. Page A15. Soviet silence - The Soviet Union made no official comment on the declaration of martial law in Poland. The Polish developments were reported in a series of brief and largely factual dispatches by the official news agency Tass. Page A19. Papal appeal - Pope Paul John II asked his fellow Poles to pray for peace and to do everything in their power ''to peacefully build a peaceful future.'' Page A14. German reaction - Chancellor Helmut

title: Sayuri Iida, Pianist, In Faure, Liszt, Ravel
description: A tiny figure when seated at her instrument, but possessing a command of its keyboard that is anything but tiny, the Japanese-born pianist Sayuri Iida devoted her Carnegie Recital Hall program Saturday to music by Faure, Liszt, Scriabin, Prokofiev and Ravel, composers whose works, as an aggregate, exploit a good many of the piano's dynamic and coloristic resources.

title: FOLK: MISS MAKEBA AND JON LUCIEN
description: born folk singer who performed at Carnegie Hall on Saturday, hasn't made a major concert appearance in New York in more than nine years. Certainly one reason for the hiatus has been the absorption of folk and ''ethnic'' music of all kinds into the corporate pop mainstream, to the exclusion of the real thing.

title: A NEW CHIEF FOR SPERRY & HUTCHINSON
description: Following the acquisition this year of the Sperry & Hutchinson Company by the Baldwin-United Corporation, James H. Kelly, 58, has now been appointed chairman and chief executive of S.&H. He succeeds Frederick A. Collins Jr., 66, who had retired in November 1980 but returned a few week later during the merger negotiations. He will now join the law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler.

title: Cowboys Intercept Divisional Title, 21-10
description: The Dallas Cowboys today kept a commitment they had made in training camp. They regained the National Football Conference Eastern Division title from the Philadelphia Eagles, beating them, 21-10, after having trailed, 10-0, in the second quarter.

title: 4-1 Happy Guess Wins by a Head
description: Happy Guess came on in the stretch today to beat Track Robbery by a head in the $107,100 Silver Belles Handicap for fillies and mares at Hollywood Park. The favorite, Glorious Song, was fourth.

title: Guatemalan Kidnappers Kill Wife of Professor
description: Kidnappers shot and killed the wife of a noted university professor and dumped her body in a street in the south side of the capital, the police said today.

title: Angolan Aide Demoted Over Raid on Refinery
description: Angola's Minister of State Security, Kundi Paiama, was demoted this weekend, and Western diplomats said the move was apparently because of the security lapse that led to the Nov. 30 attack on the country's only oil refinery.

title: BARKAN RETIRES, KICKING ALL THE WAY
description: Alexander E. Barkan, a prototype of the campaign-seasoned political warhorse indigenous to this city, is now lumbering noisily and reluctantly out to pasture.

title: Metal Fatigue Indicated In Fatal Crash in Chicago
description: A preliminary investigation has indicated that metal fatigue possibly caused the crash of a construction cage that killed five workers at the site of the new State of Illinois Center.

title: IRAN NAMES 2 TO NEW CABINET
description: Iran's Prime Minister completed the formation of his Cabinet today, nominating a new Foreign Minister and a new Interior Minister, the Teheran radio reported.

title: Celebrating the Artist Who Brought Santa to Life
description: He gave the Republicans their elephant and the Democrats their donkey, but that's not why Regina Infinito was helping her parents and other residents of Morristown, N.J., celebrate Thomas Nast Day yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS WILL SUE G.O.P. OVER VOTING PATROL IN JERSEY
description: The Democratic National Committee said yesterday that it would file a $10 million Federal suit today against the Republican National Committee, charging harassment and intimidation of black and Hispanic voters in New Jersey on Election Day.

title: Dessoff Choirs Offer An A Cappella Concert
description: The Dessoff Choirs concert at the Goodman House Saturday night took a look at how German and Austrian Romantic composers responded to the a cappella motet tradition of Bach and his predecessors. There were five pieces by Brahms from Opus 74 and Opus 110, four from Bruckner, two from Schumann; and to punctuate the beginnings and the ends of Romanticism, there were ''Sechs Spruche'' by Mendelssohn and Schoenberg's ''Friede auf Erden.''

title: Dr. Leonard Davidman Marries Beverly Dyer
description: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue yesterday, Beverly Yvonne Dyer, chairman of the mathematics department at the Creative Learning Community, an alternative junior high school, was married to Dr. Leonard Davidman, chief psychologist in the department of child and adolescent psychiatry at Metropolitan Hospital and an instructor of psychiatry at the New York Medical College.

title: Price of Gold Up About $17 After News of Polish Action
description: The price of gold rose about $17 an ounce on the Hong Kong market today, apparently in reaction to the crisis in Poland.

title: HIRING SHIFTS TO PART-TIMERS
description: The people in the temporary-service industry do not like to admit that they may be profiting from the recession. It makes them feel a bit guilty.

title: Commodities; New Eurodollar Market
description: OF all the financial futures introduced in recent years, none has as much potential for use by the international money market as does the Eurodollar futures contract that started trading last week on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The reason is because Eurodollar interest rates are beyond the control of all central banks, they are the most sensitive in the international money market.

title: Quake Kills 6 in Pakistan
description: Six people were killed and 12 injured when an earthquake destroyed the village of Koshkak last night, officials said today. All 45 houses were wrecked but most were not occupied because people had left for warmer areas to escape a harsh winter.

title: PIANIST: ETSUKO TAZAKI
description: DISPLAYING considerable versatility as well as virtuosity, the pianist Etsko Tazaki appeared at the Metropolitan Museum Saturday night as soloist, accompanist and ensemble pianist, in a program devoted to works of Bartok and Schubert.

title: DISPOSSESSED ON MAURITIUS ARE INFLAMED
description: Yves Jacques held his 7-month-old son in one arm and pointed with the stub of his amputated other arm toward the dimly lit interior of his home in a corrugated tin shack. ''Just look how we are being forced to live,'' he said. ''We are the forgotten people of the Indian Ocean,''

title: SEGREGATION GETS THE GO AHEAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Bills 19, Patriots 10
description: Joe Cribbs rushed for 153 yards and scored on a 39-yard pass play to help Buffalo clinch a wild-card playoff position. The Bills (10-5), who have won four consecutive games, can claim their second consecutive American Conference East crown Saturday by beating the Dolphins at Miami.

title: CORNELL APPOINTS BUSINESS DEAN
description: David A. Thomas, 64 years old, has been named dean of the Cornell University Graduate School of Business and Public Administration. He became acting dean of the school, in Ithaca, N.Y., in 1979.

title: Lakers Capture Fifth in a Row
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 33 points to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 122-118 victory over the Golden State Warriors today.

title: CHICAGO'S WFMT CELEBRATES 30 YEARS OF CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: WFMT, Chicago's premier fine-arts radio station, celebrated its 30th anniversary today with 24 hours of live classical music broadcast from its new performance studio. It broadcasts by satellite to 34 states.

title: Market Place; Scaled-Down Bid on Phoenix
description: THE scaled-down offer by the Texas International Company for the Phoenix Resources Company has piqued some holders of Phoenix's remaining shares. Texas International already owns 52 percent of Phoenix and is offering half a share of its stock for each Phoenix share still in public hands.

title: Corinne Bernard Wed To Richard S. Paroly
description: Corinne Bernard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard S. Bernard of New York, was married at the Pierre yesterday to Richard S. Paroly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Paroly of West Orange, N.J. Rabbis Nisson Schulman and Emanuel Rackman and Cantor Joseph Malovany officiated.

title: Fusako Yoshida Sings And Plays the Koto
description: Saturday afternoon's concert of Japanese music at Carnegie Recital Hall centered on the playing and singing of Fusako Yoshida. Most refreshing for Western ears were the ''Ama'' and ''Ashikari'' episodes, which blended dance, poetry, singing and instrumental music.

title: Packers 35, Saints 7
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) - Lynn Dickey, the Green Bay quarterback, turned in a superior performance, completing 19 of 21 passes for 218 yards and five touchdowns. The victory, plus San Diego's 24-23 defeat of Tampa Bay, kept alive the Packers' faint hopes for a playoff berth.

title: TV: 'TIMON OF ATHENS' ON WNET
description: WORKING on ''Timon of Athens'' is not likely to be an enviable task. For the production on WNET-TV tonight at 8, Jonathan Miller, the director, warns at the outset that this is a ''most peculiar'' play. He admits that if the BBC's project on ''The Shakespeare Plays'' weren't determined to cover all 37 of the dramatist's works, this one ''could've slipped quite easily through the net.''

title: NO SHOW JOBS TO UNION AIDES LAID TO DONOVAN'S COMPANY
description: A New Jersey construction company gave trips, trucks, building materials and no-show jobs to officers of the blasters' union in New York City on at least seven separate occasions while Raymond J. Donovan, now the Secretary of Labor, was a senior executive of the company, according to a former official of the union.

title: Authors' Artwork
description: Publishing a literary magazine is certainly not a novel idea, so Janet Byrne, a freelance editor from Hoboken, N.J., decided to take a different approach.

title: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: What is the ''wishbone'' offense in football and who originated it?

title: L.I. CLAMMERS UPSET BY HARVEST IN RHODE ISLAND
description: A clamor has arisen among the clammers on the Great South Bay because their counterparts in Rhode Island have flooded the market with choice littlenecks and cherrystones and have challenged Long Island's claim to being the most productive clamming area in the Northeast.

title: CRISIS DOES NOT AFFECT SCHMIDT TRIP
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany visited this small East German town today, intent on demonstrating through his presence here that there was no purpose for the West to be too quick to dramatize the situation in Poland.

title: Favorite Is First
description: Andover Way, primarily a grass runner, scored by 7 1/2 lengths on the inner dirt track at Aqueduct yesterday in the $57,600 Busher Handicap. Tournament Star finished second, a length ahead of Madame Premier. Andover Way, a 3-year-old daughter of His Majesty, ran the mile and 70 yards under Angel Cordero in 1:41 4/5 and returned $4.60 for $2 to win as the favorite in a field of 11.

title: THE CASE OF A CORNFIELD THAT WENT FLYING
description: To the Editor:

title: LATE GRETZKY GOAL BEATS ISLANDERS, 4-3
description: Wayne Gretzky scored with 62 seconds remaining, and assisted on three goals to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 4-3 victory over the Islanders tonight.

title: THE DANCE: 'FLOORED' BY LISA FOX
description: IF one looked closely, one discovered that a few stage lights were on - but only barely - at the beginning of ''Floored,'' the 40-minute dance that Lisa Fox presented Saturday night at the Kitchen. However, most of the illumination for the stage came through the windows from street lamps and the headlights of passing cars; Miss Fox let the outside world into the theater. Earthly experience was also acknowledged in a score by Roy West that included everything from ghostly pianos to what sounded like a dump truck unloading.

title: MAX SPIVAK
description: Max Spivak, a ceramic muralist, died on Dec. 5 at the Jewish Home and Hospital.

title: Drifter Arrested in Texas Suspected in 20 Slayings
description: A drifter suspected in at least 20 slayings of young women around the country has been arrested, the police said.

title: SOUTH AFRICA NEEDS MORE ARMS, ISRAELI SAYS
description: The military relationship between South Africa and Israel, never fully acknowledged by either country, has asssumed a new significance with the recent 10-day visit by Israel's Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, to South African forces in Namibia along the border with Angola.

title: Broncos 23 Seahawks 13
description: DENVER (AP) - Denver won its eighth game at home this season without a loss as Craig Morton threw a touchdown pass, Rick Parros ran for another score and Fred Steinfort kicked three field goals.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM MARTIAL-LAW DECREE BROADCAST SPELLING OUT CURBS ON POLES

title: WASHINGTON CALLS IN POLISH AND SOVIET AIDES
description: The Reagan Administration called in the Polish Ambassador and the Soviet Deputy Chief of Mission today for discussions at the State Department on the situation in Poland.

title: COMMUNISM AND BETTER LIFE: POLES FOUND WAIT TOO LONG
description: John Darnton, who has been chief of The New York Times bureau in Warsaw since September 1979, reports in the following article on the problems underlying the crisis in Poland.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, DECEMBER 14, 1981
description: Crackdown in Poland Poland was placed under martial law by its new military leaders. Civil rights were drastically restricted and the operations of the Solidarity union were suspended. The union's activists reacted with an appeal for an immediate general strike. The Martial Council for National Redemption, the new top authority, banned all kinds of gatherings and demonstrations and ordered the internment of persons whose loyalty to the state was under ''justified suspicion.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Communism's failure to deliver its promise of a better life for the Polish working people led to the workers' revolt in the summer of 1980 and the organization of the Solidary union. After three decades of sacrifice, conditions of everyday life had scarcely improved and it was in the area of social welfare that Communism had failed most dramatically. (A1:2-3.)

title: Brenda Kornblau Married
description: Brenda Kornblau, a designer of tennis wear, was married yesterday to Chester Schneider, an employee-benefit consultant and actuary. Rabbi Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony at the Park East Synagogue. Cantor Moshe Geffen assisted. The bride is a daughter of Sara Kornblau of New York, and the late Saul Kornblau. Mr. Schneider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schneider of Valley Cottage, N.Y., is with George B. Buck Consulting Actuaries Inc., a unit of Buck Consultants Inc.

title: Redskins 38, Colts 14
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Joe Theismann tossed two touchdown passes and ran for a score as Washington dealt Baltimore its 14th straight loss. Theismann riddled the Colt defense for 339 yards, completing 23 of 36 passes.

title: LIMITS TO THE GREENING OF THE FEDERAL MONEY TREE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESSWOMEN ADMIT 46 MEN TO THEIR CAUCUS
description: The Congresswomen's Caucus has gone coed. The admission of 46 males into what had been an all-female bastion raised a rash of questions last week on Capitol Hill. Will the Congressional Steel Caucus now start flirting with aluminum interests? Or will the Sun Belt Caucus reach out the hand of friendship to those from the New England Congressional Caucus? Will the Congressional Black Caucus admit whites?

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS ARE RIGHT TO DECLARE AGAINST NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RAISING DICKENS

title: No Headline
description: COMMERCE CHIEF'S JET ASSAILED

title: Archbishop Bids Poles Refrain From Violence
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, appealed to the Polish people today not to resort to violence against what he called the current infringement of civil and human rights, according to the Warsaw radio.

title: Christmas Present For Advertising Types
description: Here it is, folks, the Christmas gift for the advertising person who has everything: a $297 annual subscription to the Advertising Compliance Service.

title: Sports World Specials; Making a Point
description: A year ago, before the first published reports of a Federal investigation of point-shaving at Boston College, Lou Carnesecca convened the annual meeting of his St. John's basketball team at which an F.B.I. agent lectures about the dangers posed by gamblers.

title: GREENHOUSE MAY USE WASTED WATER HEAT
description: Tomatoes may be cheaper, cucumbers may be cheaper and - to revise a Depression ditty - 1983 may be a time to fall in love. Such is the hope in a new venture by the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: A Cold Stare at the Garden Ice
description: Nothing about New York's Madison Square Garden, with its slick, tacky sheen, suggests permanence - but no one thought its owners would close the place after a mere 13 years. That's what the Gulf and Western Corporation now threatens because of mounting losses.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt EVERY SECRET THING. By Patricia Campbell Hearst, With Alvin Moscow. 466 pages. Illustrated. Doubleday. $17.95.

title: OAKLAND PLANS TO SELL, THEN LEASE 2 BUILDINGS
description: This financially strapped city is preparing to sell the Oakland Museum and the Oakland Auditorium to private investors, who will then lease the facilities back to the city.

title: IN 1981, IT WASN'T A VERY GOOD YEAR TO SELL A SINATRA HOUSE
description: Frank Sinatra is this town's favorite son, and the Spaghetti Frank Sinatra at Riccos' Ristorante is just the tip of the iceberg.

title: DONATIONS TO HELP THE NEEDY COME IN FROM DISTANT PLACES
description: ''Even though I live about a thousand miles from New York, I am one person who cares a great deal about your city and your people.'' With those words, Patrick J. Powers of Webster City, Iowa, explained why he was making a $30 donation to the 70th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: MUSIC: GLASS ORCHESTRA
description: THE four musicians of Canada's Glass Orchestra spread their instruments on the floor around them. They are all made of glass - tumblers, tubes, snifters, goblets, fishbowls, bottles, even glass versions of aeolian harps and panpipes.

title: Andrea Beller Wed to K. B. Stolarsky
description: Andrea H. Beller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Beller of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married in Champaign, Ill., yesterday to Kenneth B. Stolarsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Stolarsky of San Diego. Rabbi Isaac Newman performed the ceremony at Sinai Temple.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 14, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M..

title: U.S. ATTORNEY PONDERS TRIAL OF MARGIOTTA
description: Edward R. Korman, the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, bustled about his walnut-paneled office in Brooklyn, moving from one volume to another of trial transcripts that were packed in boxes and strewn about the conference table. His attention was not being expended on an upcoming case or on one now before a jury, but on a case that ended last Wednesday.

title: JUDGE REDUCES WESTWAY SUITS TO SINGLE ISSUE
description: A Federal judge has whittled down the longstanding legal attacks on the Westway highway project to a single issue - the fate of fish in the Hudson River - and he will set a hearing date today for arguments on that obstacle to the roadway.

title: IN THE U.S., POLISH ACTION STIRS PROTEST AND PRAYER
description: With noisy demonstrations and silent prayers, with angry statements and fervent appeals for justice, tens of thousands of Polish-Americans across the nation voiced outrage and despair yesterday at Poland's declaration of martial law and the arrest of Solidarity union leaders.

title: THE REGION
description: NEWARK (AP) - A change in Federal tax laws encouraged to spur business investment could actually cause a $15 million loss in New Jersey's treasury this year, and as much at $100 million two years from now, Governor Byrne said in an interview.

title: LEVESQUE TO PUT HIS QUEBEC LEADERSHIP TO A VOTE
description: Premier Rene Levesque, whose threat to resign as leader of the Parti Quebecois stunned a party convention last Sunday, decided today to put his leadership of both the party and the province to a vote by the party rank and file.

title: THEATER: 'VINCENT' AT OPEN EYE
description: ''= VINCENT'' is such an ingenious idea about how to tell, in a mostly one-man performance, about the life of Vincent van Gogh, and its star, Christopher Consani, rides this vehicle as a formidable performer, that it should be a more brilliant evening at the Open Eye than it actually is.

title: SAKHAROVS ARE DESCRIBED AS EMACIATED BUT ELATED
description: Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife are emaciated and weak as a result of their recently ended hunger strike, but united in a hospital suite and elated at their achievement, according to the woman for whose sake they underwent the ordeal.

title: RISING TO THE JAPANESE CHALLENGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanchez Is Winner On Split Decision
description: Salvador Sanchez of Mexico, the World Boxing Council featherweight champion, admits he never solved the boxing riddle presented to him by the British challenger Pat Cowdell.

title: POTENTIALLY ACTIVE VOLCANOES FILL THE WEST, SCIENTISTS FIND
description: Although Mount St. Helens and its explosive sisters of the Northwest get most of the attention, scientists say all the Western states have volcanic fields that could produce violent eruptions, maybe not for 1,000 years, or maybe tomorrow.

title: French-Soviet Trade Talks
description: As French trade officials prepared for talks aimed at reducing France's growing trade deficit with the Soviet Union, the French External Relations Ministry said it would not seek Western advice about a $300 million computer deal with the Russians.

title: The Talk of San Francisco
description: This is an embarrassing time in San Francisco, relieved by some bright spots, such as the warm sun that contrasts with winter's afflictions in other parts of the country, or the unfailing spawning instinct of a little five-ounce fish, the Clupea Harengus.

title: Bridge: Foreign Experts Made Bid For U.S. Laurels on Coast
description: The recent Fall National Championships in San Francisco were attended largely by players from North America. But there was a handful of visitors from farther afield. They included Benito Garozzo of Italy, a former world champion; Per-Olov Sundelin and Hans Lind of Sweden, both former European champions; Linda Rasmussen of Hong Kong, one of the best women players in the Far East; and the most traveled, Jessel and Carole Rothfield of Melbourne, Australia.

title: REGAN DISPUTES PARKING BUREAU'S EFFICIENCY DATA
description: New York City's claims of dollar savings through greater efficiency in its Parking Violations Bureau were challenged in an audit being released today by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan. He also contended that the overall productivity of traffic enforcement agents had dropped in the reporting period.

title: In a Nuclear Attack, Open the Phone Book
description: To find out what to do in case of nuclear attack, residents of northern Maine will be able to let their fingers do the walking. Telephone books now being distributed in northern Aroostook County and the town of Houlton include four pages telling how to find shelter and where to flee from such high-risk areas as Loring Air Force Base in Limestone if a nuclear attack or serious international crisis occurs.

title: 49ers 28, Oilers 6
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - The San Francisco 49ers got touchdowns on their first four possessions of the second half, with Ricky Patton's 3-yard run opening the scoring.

title: VOTES INFLUENCED BY USE OF RECORDS
description: In the recent Senate debate on the military appropriations bill, a group of Democrats considered proposing an amendment to wipe out the MX missile program. Eventually they decided that the political risks were too great, and settled on a much more modest proposal.

title: Accounts
description: * New Jersey Shore Oldsmobile Dealers to the Zlotnick Company. * Saratoga Water to Lansdowne Advertising.

title: FOREIGN MANAGEMENT LESSONS
description: While British television manufacturers have been leaving the business, an ultramodern plant in an otherwise grimy industrial park here has gradually raised its production to 1,000 sets a day, from 250 a day seven years ago.

title: Cal-Davis Player Collapses and Dies
description: Leon Richardson, co-captain of the California-Davis basketball team, collapsed Saturday night during a game and died an hour later, according to the university's sports information officer.

title: KEAN AND BYRNE WAGE QUIET WAR OVER A NOMINEE
description: Governor Byrne and Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean exchanged volleys one day recently across a tennis net in Princeton. A few days later, they sat down across a desk to exchange thoughts about the transfer of power from the Democratic incumbent to the Republican victor.

title: ACT OF DESPAIR
description: The Polish Government's imposition of martial law followed by just a few days the Soviet Government's backdown in its confrontation with Andrei Sakharov. History is likely to see the two events as signposts in the decay of the Soviet empire.

title: CAROLINA ROLLS ON AND ON
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. WHEN the short, friendly man with the Midwestern accent walked through the door of the Black family residence on that spring day in 1978, Jimmy Black did not really understand the significance of the occasion. Now, if he had grown up in North Carolina and Dean Smith dropped by for a chat, it would have taken a visit from Billy Graham, or maybe Dolly Parton, to cause as big a stir in the neighborhood. But Jimmy Black was a child of the Bronx. ''I didn't know that much about him,'' he said of Smith.

title: Rationing Programs Have Not Succeeded
description: Most foods and many other goods have been rationed in Poland over the last year, but the system has had little success in insuring that there are sufficient or equal amounts for everyone.

title: MARY-ANN ISAACSON
description: Mary-Ann Isaacson, who was active social service groups in New York City and on Long Island, died Saturday at her home in Amagansett, L.I. She was 57 years old. Mrs. Isaacson was a chairman in 1972 of the Lower East Side Committee of the Visiting Nurse Association of New York City and a board member of the Stuyvesant Square Thrift Shop.

title: PRESENTS: HIDDEN MESSAGES
description: T HE holidays were here, and she was seeing a diet doctor and feeling vaguely deprived. No party food for her. Then the dieter's husband appeared with two brightly wrapped presents. She opened the first present and groaned. She opened the second present and groaned again.

title: MCENROE'S VICTORY CLINCHES DAVIS CUP
description: It was unlike anything ever seen at a Davis Cup match in the United States. John McEnroe, clinching the final in five tense sets, hurdled the net, shook hands with Jose-Luis Clerc, his Argentine opponent, and joyously jumped into the arms of Arthur Ashe, the team captain, and Bill Norris, the trainer.

title: Flames 7, Canucks 6
description: VANCOUVER (AP) - Jim Peplinski split the Vancouver defense and scored with less than five minutes to play to give Calgary the victory.

title: The Pipeline Puzzle
description: In 1977, President Carter chose the Northwest Alaskan Pipeline Company to build a 4,800 mile line linking Prudhoe Bay to natural gas utilities in the lower 48 states. Northwest, a consortium of eight energy companies, got the nod because it promised to finish the job without help from Government or consumers. Four years later, Northwest changed its mind; without a Federal guarantee that consumers would bear the cost (whatever it might come to) there could be no pipeline.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BALCOR, Skokie, Ill., has appointed James E. Finley senior executive vice president and chief operating officer. * CHEM-NUCLEAR SYSTEMS, Bellevue, Wash., has named Glenn Bradley to the new position of vice president-Washington, D.C., operations. * CHEMICAL NEW YORK has elected Robert J. Callander and Thomas S. Johnson senior executive vice presidents of the parent company and its Chemical Bank subsidiary. * CHUBB has elected Roger S. Ingalls president and chief operating officer of its principal underwriting subsidiary, Chubb & Son. * COMARCO, Anaheim, Calif., has appointed Robert E. Conger vice president and general manager of its computer text division. * COMMERZBANK, Frankfurt, has appointed Martin Kohlhaussen to the bank's managing board. * DATA TERMINAL SYSTEMS, Maynard, Mass., has named Joseph J. Giordano to the new post of senior vice president of finance and administration, James MacKenzie vice president of distribution development, J. Robert Schiller vice president for field operations and Marvin W. Schenk vice president of strategic planning and analysis. * DELTONA, Miami, has appointed Ronald G. Lewis vice president-Three Seasons Land Development, Norman C. Metz vice president-advertising and William O. Vaughn vice president-construction operations. * ESTEE LAUDER has appointed Saul Magram senior vice president-general counsel. * FLEXI-VAN has elected to its board David H. Murdock, chairman of the Pacific Holding Corporation and International Mining Corporation. * INTERPACE, Parsippany, N.J., has elected as a director M. Kathryn Eickhoff, executive vice president of Townsend-Greenspan & Company. * KAUFMAN & BROAD, Los Angeles, has elected to its board Lester Pollack, who recently joined Oppenheimer & Company as a partner.

title: Headquarters at St. Lucia For Caribbean Bloc
description: The newly established Organization of East Caribbean States has agreed to establish its central secretariat here and its economic affairs secretariat in Antigua.

title: Neither Polish Nor a Solution
description: Yes, this is ''it'' - the long-feared suppression of the Polish people's rebellion against the Communist Party's monopoly on power.

title: Resch Is Winner In Cup Downhill
description: Erwin Resch led a group of five Austrians in the top 10 by winning the men's World Cup downhill race here today.

title: SOLIDARITY ACTIVITIES URGE GENERAL STRIKE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States was ''seriously concerned'' about the imposition of martial law in Poland, and he renewed the West's warning to the Soviet Union not to interfere in the crisis.

title: 10 New Budd Cars For Harlem Line
description: Ten new diesel-powered Budd cars are scheduled to begin service on Conrail's Upper Harlem line today, replacing 40-year-old equipment.

title: Bears 23, Raiders 6
description: Vince Evans threw three touchdown passes, the last two within a minute and a half in the third quarter, as Chicago rolled. The victory improved the Bears' record to 5-10.

title: Erika Hess Wins
description: Erika Hess of Switzerland moved into first place in the women's World Cup ski standing today by capturing the special slalom at this Italian resort.

title: Red Smith To Bed Without Dinner
description: WHEN Gene Michael was rehired as manager of the New York Yankees starting in 1983, George M. Steinbrenner III said: ''It's like a child doing something bad at the dinner table. You send him to bed without dinner, but he's back down for breakfast in the morning.''

title: LEGAL AID CENTERS FOR POOR HAMPERED BY BUDGET CUTS
description: At federally financed neighborhood legal service centers scattered over this city and in cities around the nation, more and more people are seeking help, but there are fewer and fewer people to give it.

title: Merged Agencies To Receive New Name
description: The acquisition of F. William Free & Company by Daniel & Charles, a subsidiary of the Mickelberry Corporation, will result in an agency named Laurence Charles & Free, according to a Mickelberry announcement on Friday, when the expected purchase was announced.

title: ANOTHER 'REBELLION'?
description: Will the ''sagebrush rebellion'' spread to the East? Most states west of the Rockies have been taking part in the ''rebellion'' -the attempt to gain more state control over the Western holdings of the Federal Government, which owns at least a third of the land in many of these states.

title: Salnikov Leads U.S.S.R. to Title
description: Vladimir Salnikov set his second swimming world record in two days today and led the Soviet Union men's team to an impressive victory in the two-day European Cup.

title: CHARGERS TOP BUCS ON KICK
description: A deflected pass that bounced off the hands of the Tampa Bay receiver, Jimmy Giles, into the hands of Woodrow Lowe, a San Diego linebacker, in the closing minutes had a lot of repercussions around the National Football League yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Polish blood must not be spilled.'' - Pope John Paul II. (A14:3.)

title: JOHN HENRY TAKES A BREATHER
description: John Henry, who finished a disappointing fourth in the Hollywood Turf Cup on Dec. 6, is finally getting a vacation after a campaign of 10 starts, eight stakes victories and enough cross-country trips to earn a frequent-flyer bonus from the airlines.

title: Fight Over Auto Is Fatal
description: The police said today that a dispute over an ''ant-sized'' scratch on a sports car resulted in a shooting that cost a life. Francisco Dagness of Hialeah, Fla., 20 years old, was shot in the neck yesterday in an argument with four men after one of them carelessly swung open their car door, striking the car, a Porsche that belonged to Mr. Dagness's father.

title: IMPROVED AIRCRAFT IN THE 30'S
description: Erle Martin, an aviation inventor and retired vice chairman of the United Technologies Corporation, died Saturday at his home in West Hartford, Conn. He was 74 years old.

title: No Headline
description: TEXT OF HAIG'S STATEMENT AT NEWS SESSION AND SOME ANSWERS

title: Dozens Homeless After Trenton Fire
description: TRENTON (UPI) - An early morning fire that authorities have labeled ''probable arson'' destroyed a three-story house here and left at least a dozen persons homeless.

title: POPE, IN POLAND APPEAL, SAYS 'BLOOD MUST NOT BE SPILLED'
description: Pope John Paul II appealed to his fellow Poles today to pray for peace and to do everything in their power ''to peacefully build a peaceful future.''

title: POP: THE STARS OF MOTOWN BRING BACK HITS OF THE 60'S
description: SOME audiences are determined to enjoy themselves. The audience that came to the Palladium Saturday night at 7:30 to hear several Motown stars of the 1960's re-create their hits cheerfully ignored the lack of heat in the building, the occasional meanderings of an apparently unrehearsed backing band and the last-minute substitutions of a non-Motown soul singer, Ben E. King, for the ex-Temptation David Ruffin. They had come for a good time, and they applauded, whistled and filled in background vocals, as required. Their enthusiasm was contagious.

title: MALTA'S COURSE, TO THE WEST OR 'UNALIGNED,' TIED TO VOTE
description: With vote counting from Saturday's election proceeding slowly, politicians from both Prime Minister Dom Mintoff's ruling Labor Party and the conservative Nationalist Party tonight predicted a close contest.

title: Todd Takes a Look At Playoff Picture
description: Richard Todd watched helplessly yesterday as first place slipped away from his New York Jets and a wild-card berth remained unsettled. The quarterback lived a football fan's dream as he sat at a control panel in the offices of NBC Sports and switched to National Football League games across the United States that were unavailable to New Yorkers but affected the Jets' 1981 plans.

title: SOVIET WITHHOLDS COMMENT ON POLES
description: The Soviet Union offered no official comment today on the declaration of martial law in Poland. The Polish developments were reported in a series of largely factual dispatches by Tass, the official press agency, which stuck closely to the explanations and phraseology used by the Polish leader.

title: GREECE TO RAISE PRICES OF GAS, OIL AND WATER
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou announced a series of economic measures tonight that he said would help ease the financial burden of lower-income groups in Greece and revive the country's flagging economy.

title: STUDY OF ENGAGED COUPLES SPOTS POTENTIAL TROUBLE
description: Despite the women's movement and a more flexible attitude toward the role of the sexes in recent years, many young people now getting married have highly traditional views of what to expect from a spouse and how they should act themselves.

title: THE LEADER AT THE 'ABYSS'
description: For the last 10 months, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski pleaded with the independent trade union Solidarity for moderation. He shuffled and reshuffled his Cabinet, but none of his changes halted Poland's accelerating economic chaos.

title: THEATER: 'KINGDOMS' AT THE CORT
description: EDWARD SHEEHAN'S ''Kingdoms,'' which opened at the Cort last night, has loftier ambitions than many Broadway plays. An account of the confrontation between Napoleon Bonaparte and Pope Pius VII, it wants to be a drama of ideas, of history, of larger-than-life emotions. But ambitions, however worthy, are meaningless if a writer can't deliver on them. The author of ''Kingdoms'' never comes close.

title: East Team Takes Soccer Bowl, 3-2
description: Richard Chinapoo of Long Island University produced the only goal in a shootout to help the East defeat the West, 3-2, in the 10th Senior Bowl all-star soccer game Saturday.

title: 5 CHILDREN ABANDONED, BROOKLYN MOTHER HELD
description: A Brooklyn woman was arrested last night after her five young children were found abandoned in a Flatbush apartment that was accidentally set on fire earlier in the day, the police said.

title: BEREAVED CHILDREN SHARE PAIN
description: The mood was anything but morose. Teen-agers and younger children sat in a circle whispering to and poking one another playfully, sometimes making jokes as they ate cookies and drank soda.

title: Maintaining Health - and a Hospital
description: Thwarted in its attempt to close Metropolitan Hospital, the Koch administration now hopes to salvage it with a health maintenance and preventive care program for East Harlem's poor. Yet they have been slow to sign up, unwilling to give up Medicaid's freedom to shop around for physicians and clinics.

title: New Music Consort, From Cowell to Crumb
description: The New Music Consort's evening of the new, the recent and the relatively old created a successful balance at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night. The most vivid and immediately accessible pieces began and ended the program.

title: GEORGIA TECH TRIES TO GET ROLLING, TOO
description: EVEN before he saw his new team on a basketball court, Bobby Cremins knew he had his work cut out for him. ''This will be the most challenging year in my coaching career so far, or that I will have,'' he said of the task of bringing respectability to a Georgia Tech team that last season finished 4-23 and failed to defeat a Division I opponent.

title: ATARI-INTELLIVISION TV BATTLE
description: It has all the makings of a great video game. Atari, ruler of the games universe, is attacked from another galaxy. Atari zaps back, stunning the challenger, who asks the Lords of the Airwaves to intervene.

title: THE REAGAN YARN: GIFT WITH A HOOK
description: A newly polished gem in President Reagan's collection of quips, yarns, parables and jokes is the one about the woman from Illinois.

title: Carl Brenner, Lawyer, Weds Barbara King, Author
description: The marriage of Barbara King of New York to Carl Brenner took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton C. Brenner in San Antonio. District Court Judge Rose Spector of San Antonio performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: WARSAW, Dec. 13 (AP) - Following is a transcript of the radio address today by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Poland's Prime Minister and Communist Party leader, as transcribed and translated from the Polish by The Associated Press:

title: MARQUES JOHNSON: A PRESSURE NEGOTIATOR
description: The stiff midtown breeze had sent a chill through the small entourage as the Milwaukee Bucks stepped off the bus on 33d Street shortly past noon on Saturday. Now, hours before the Bucks would face the Knicks, the group ambled about the corridors at Madison Square Garden before a practice.

title: Gill of Nebraska Will Miss Bowl
description: Turner Gill, Nebraska's sophomore quarterback who has been sidelined since last month, has ruled himself out of the Orange Bowl game against top-ranked Clemson on Jan. 1 because of his health.

title: THE WORKERS' CHAMPION
description: From the moment he scaled the fence at the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk on Aug. 14, 1980, to help striking workers negotiate the establishment of an independent labor union in Poland, Lech Walesa became a charismatic and seemingly invincible leader of a movement that promised to transform the country.

title: POLICE SUSPECT A MIDDLE EAST LINK
description: A bomb exploded in a car in a central London square today, killing two men and seriously injuring a third. The police said no one took responsibility for the bombing.

title: SOLIDARITY ACTIVISTS URGE GENERAL STRIKE
description: Poland's new military leaders issued a decree of martial law today, drastically restricting civil rights and suspending the operations of the Solidarity union. The union's activists reacted with an appeal for an immediate general strike to protest.

title: PLAYOFF SPOTS STILL AT ISSUE
description: The Cincinnati Bengals and Dallas Cowboys joined the San Francisco 49ers as divisional champions yesterday. The Bengals (11-4) eliminated the Steelers from playoff contention in the American Conference Central Division with a 17-10 victory, and the Cowboys (12-3) clinched the National Conference East with a 21-10 victory over the Eagles. The 49ers (12-3) had won the title in the National Conference West.

title: ALMADEN FILLS TOP POST
description: John P. McClelland, the 48-year-old president of Almaden Vineyards, a winery based in San Jose, Calif., has been named to the additional positions of chairman and chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. He succeeds William A. Dieppe, who will retire at 69 from Almaden, a unit of the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation.

title: 5,000 RALLY TO SAVE TOWN JOBS
description: An estimated 5,000 people, including political leaders and union workers, marched a mile here today to protest the planned closing of an 80-year-old plant that makes gears and transmissions for pleasure boats.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF EVENTS LEADING TO POLISH CRISIS
description: Following is a chronology of events that led to the current situation in Poland, beginning with the national unrest that grew out of the Government's decision to increase meat prices on July 1, 1980:

title: News Analysis
description: Poland's soldier-leader, Wojciech Jaruzelski, has struck at what he perceives as the two main roots of his country's current troubles: the radical ''confrontationists'' of the Solidarity labor movement and the still influential members of the Communist Party's old guard.

title: No Headline
description: FAST EXIT IS SOUGHT BY SITTLER

title: CBS Said to Have Hired Mercenaries in Cambodia
description: A former war correspondent has testified that CBS News recovered the bodies of four reporters in Cambodia by hiring a private army after the authorities refused to make the recovery operation.

title: TOO MUCH NOISE
description: Scarcely anyone doubts that Libya's Muammar Qaddafi is a sly, unscrupulous man. His ambition is as vast as his oil money, and he has as little means of achieving it as he has people to spend the money on.

title: BRIEFING
description: S TU Smith, a Federal union shop steward who is attempting to organize the Senate's restaurant workers, complains that some of the same Senators who loudly petitioned the Polish Government on behalf of Solidarity's right to organize workers have been mysteriously silent when it comes to unionizing the people who serve the solons their meals at the Capitol.

title: Sullivan Puts Off Fate of Erhardt
description: William Sullivan, owner of the New England Patriots, said today that Coach Ron Erhardt would learn around Super Bowl time, at the earliest, whether he will be retained.

title: An Olympian Honor
description: Col. Frank Kurtz, a retired pilot and World War II hero who is perhaps better known to the younger set as the father of actress Swoosie Kurtz, presented the first United States Olympian Honorary Gold Medal to President Reagan on Friday at a ceremony in the Oval Office in the White House.

title: Arkansas Students File Suit Over Strip Searches
description: Three junior high school students and their parents have filed a $1.5 million suit against city and school officials over strip searches conducted while the police were searching for drugs.

title: Atlantic Fares Still Unresolved
description: Representatives of airlines from the United States and Europe who have been meeting for nearly two weeks in Geneva failed to agree on a new fare structure for North Atlantic routes, according to a statement Friday from the International Air Transport Association.

title: Edward Gierek
description: Head of Communist Party in Poland from late 1970 to Sept. 6, 1980 ... Ousted in aftermath of workers' uprising against worsening economic situation that led to establishment of Solidarity ... Reportedly hospitalized with heart attack at the time ... Ill health often cited as reason for remaining out of public view ... Failed in attempt at vast industralization coupled with large increase in consumer goods ... Staggering hard-currency debt resulted ... Prices soared, shortages of goods developed ... In July stripped of party membership, awards and other honors ... Conceded he shared some blame for economic crisis, but emphasized he had tried to work for good of country. Edward Gierek (pronounced GHYEH-reck) was born in village of Porabka in southwestern industrial region of Silesia on Jan. 6, 1913 ... Father died in mining accident 10 years later ... Mother took him to France ... There quit school at age 13 and went to work as miner ... Quickly became active in trade union movement ... Expelled from France 1934 ... Returned to Poland, then went to live in Belgium ... Worked in mines ... Joined Belgian Communist Party ... An organizer and leader of Belgian resistance against German occupation ... Began political career in Poland after World War II at age 35 ... Briefly employed as staff member Central Committee Polish United Workers Party in Warsaw in 1948 ... Then struck out for home region of Silesia to develop base that propelled him to national authority ... Appointed to Politburo Central Committee 1956 ... Named first secretary of party in Katowice, major city in Silesia, 1957 ... Replaced Wladyslaw Gomulka as head of Polish Communist Party on Dec. 20, 1970, amid rising protests against economic conditions ... Married, two sons ... Degree in mining engineering Cracow Academy of Mining and Metallurgy, 1954.

title: SNOWDRIFTS AND WIND SNARL TRAVEL ACROSS LARGE PARTS OF BRITISH ISLES
description: Hurricane-force winds and mounting snowdrifts caused chaos in travel today and blacked out large parts of Britain and Ireland. At least one person died in storm-related accidents.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Qaddafi Cancels News Conference

title: DEFICIT DOESN'T RUFFLE ORANGE COUNTY
description: ''I think we have to give this man and his ideas a chance to work,'' said Hancock Banning 3d, whose forebears came west before the Gold Rush and left his family a stake in California land and oil.

title: STRIKING DETAILS OF 'LAST SUPPER' ARE RESTORED
description: Restoration of ''The Last Supper'' is one-quarter complete, and a multitude of striking details of color and shape can be seen for the first time in centuries.

title: OPERA: BACQUIER AS SCHICCHI IN 'IL TRITTICO'
description: ''I HOPE you will applaud the verdict'' - says Gianni Schicchi to the audience after he has swindled the Church out of an inheritance and deeded to himself a fine house in Florence -''Not guilty!''

title: Emmerling Gains Scr Swim Account
description: John Emmerling Inc. has been assigned the account of the FMC Corporation's Sun Swim Pool Products, which is spending more than $2 million for advertising this year.

title: TREASURY STEPS UP OFFERINGS
description: Corporations that did not sell notes or bonds during November or early December will now have to compete more directly with the United States Treasury for investor dollars in coming weeks.

title: GENEVA AND LINKAGE
description: With negotiations between the United States and Soviet Union on intermediate-range nuclear weapons under way in Geneva, and renewed or reinvigorated talks on reduction of strategic arms and of conventional forces in Europe in prospect next year, we should keep in mind some chastening lessons of the past.

title: Lawyer's Parking Ticket a $225 Winner
description: Murray Mayer may not have been the first New Yorker to have objected to a $15 parking ticket, but he must surely have been the first to have parlayed an unjustified ticket into a $225 windfall.

title: No Headline
description: BRUINS TROUNCE ROCKIES, 5-1

title: Woman Dies in Brooklyn Fire; Husband Is Critically Burned
description: A 56-year-old woman died and her 62-year-old husband was critically burned in a fire last night in their apartment near the intersection of Ocean Parkway and Kings Highway, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: F.B.I. TOOK REAGAN CODE CARD
description: After President Reagan was shot March 30, the Federal Bureau of Investigation took from him the secret code card that he would use to authenticate orders for a nuclear strike, a spokesman for the bureau said today.

title: DOLPHINS TRIUMPH, CLINCH WILD CARD
description: By defeating Kansas City today, 17-7, with another impressive display of defensive football, the Miami Dolphins qualfied for the playoffs. They are assured a wild-card berth, and if they beat the Buffalo Bills in Miami on Saturday, they will win the Eastern Division crown in the American Conference.

title: BROTHER SEEKS JUSTICE FOR KILLING IN EL SALVADOR
description: For William P. Ford, a Wall Street lawyer, social activism was never much more than litigating securities or product-liability cases. But much has changed for Mr. Ford since his younger sister, Ita, and three other American nuns were murdered in El Salvador a year ago..

title: News Analysis
description: The civil rights policy of the Reagan Administration is becoming clear, and it represents a profound change from past policies for eliminating job discrimination and school segregation.

title: YOUTHS' SILENT ON MURDER VICTIM LEAVES A CALIFORNIA TOWN BAFFLED
description: To Detective Sgt. Garry Meeker of the Santa Clara Sheriff's Department, it was not the killing of 14-yearold Marcy Renee Conrad that was so unusual, at least not these days.

title: Kentucky Escapes, Remains Unbeaten
description: It was a weekend without major surprises in college basketball, but Kentucky came close to being the most noticeable upset victim. The Wildcats barely escaped with a 77-74 overtime victory over Kansas at Lawrence, Kan., Saturday night and remained undefeated in four games.

title: La Costa President Clarifies Testimony on Tax Problems
description: The president of La Costa, the Southern California resort and health spa, testified Friday that he paid only $646 in Federal tax fraud penalties in 1957-58 and that a 1969-70 Internal Revenue Service tax claim of $1,496,000 against him had been resolved in his favor.

title: 5 Utilities Defend Upstate A-Plant
description: ALBANY (AP) - Five utility partners in the controversial Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant began a publicity counteroffensive yesterday, hoping to persuade the public to demand completion of the plant.

title: TRASH FIRES ARE UP SHARPLY SINCE START OF CARTING STRIKE
description: New York City firemen have been fighting about 200 trash fires daily during the past few days of the private sanitationmen's strike, up from an average of 115 such fires before the walkout began Dec. 1.

title: BUDGET CUTS, WEAK MARKET HURT GASOHOL
description: Interest in gasohol, which has attracted more Government encouragement in recent years than any other energy source, has been fading -the result of an oversupply of crude oil and the Administration's efforts to curb Federal spending.

title: GASIFICATION PLANT FINDS PRIVATE AID
description: Deciding that they could no longer wait for the Synthetic Fuels Corporation to act on their request for $75 million in aid, the private backers of a California coal gasification project have committed themselves to completing the $300 million project without Federal money.

title: Advertising; Somerset Fills Its Rum Void
description: JOHN E. HEILMANN, president and chief executive of Somerset Importers, thinks of the Norton Simon subsidiary as ''the Tiffany of the distilled spirits business.''

title: LOW RATE OF CAESAREANS FOR NEW YORK'S MUNICIPAL HOSPITALS
description: WHILE the rate of births by Caesarean section has almost tripled in the last 20 years for the United States as a whole, now accounting for about 17 percent of all births, New York City's municipal hospital system has succeeded in stabilizing its rates of Caesareans to all births at about 15 percent over the last three years.

title: U.N. Extends Cyprus Force
description: The United Nations Security Council decided today to keep peacekeeping troops in Cyprus for another six months.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL IS CHANGING UNDER FIRM NEW CHIEF
description: Two and a half years after the nation's worst nuclear accident, at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which oversees the industry, is undergoing a profound change.

title: Reporter Says Suspect Told of Freeway Deaths
description: A reporter made an unexpected appearance in the ''Freeway Killer'' trial today and testified that the defendant, William Bonin, had told him of killing 21 boys.

title: Exodus of Jews From Soviet Running at Third of '80 Level
description: The Intergovernmental Committee for Migration today reported a continued drop in emigration of Jews from the Soviet Union, expected to be only about a third of the 1980 total by year's end.

title: Mounties to Be Tried For Quebec Abuses
description: Prosecution and defense lawyers agreed today to hold a test trial in the case of 17 Canadian Royal Mounted Police security men accused of crimes in operations against Quebec separatists in the early 1970's.

title: FRANCE'S LEFT IS SPLIT BY SHOWDOWN IN POLAND
description: The army crackdown in Poland has made a serious crack in the uneasy relationship between France's Socialists and their Communist partners in the Government.

title: TOOTHLESS GEAR IS ON TRIAL
description: Rory F. McFarland, founder and president of Advanced Energy Technology Inc., is an easy target for skeptics. His company's unconventional gear design, called the Anti-Friction Drive, was developed in Boulder, Colo., far from the nation's industrial heartland, without help from any mechanical engineer trained in gear technology. The components of this new device move in ways that are almost impossible to track without a computer. There is no independent evidence that it is as efficient as Mr. McFarland contends or that it can be manufactured at a reasonable cost.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: House Approves Oil Bill
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation late today that would authorize President Reagan to allocate oil supplies and control prices, but prohibit rationing, during any future disruption of United States oil imports. The vote was 244 to 136.

title: Family of Four Dies in Fire
description: A family of four died in a house fire believed to have started in a wood stove, the state police said. The bodies of Edwin I. Walker, 31 years old; his wife, Victoria, 31; and their two sons, Robert, 14, and Louis, 3, were found in the charred ruins of their single-story ranch home in the western Oneida County town of Vienna, the police said.

title: A PATH AWAY FROM NUCLEAR DISARMANENT
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTIS, CONVICTED IN JERSEY SLAYING WITH CARTER, WINS PAROLE DEC.  22
description: John Artis, who was convicted twice with Rubin (Hurricane) Carter of killing three persons in a Paterson, N.J., bar holdup 15 years ago, will be paroled from Rahway State Prison on Dec. 22, the New Jersey Parole Board announced yesterday.

title: Piedmont, N.&W.  Sign Stock Deal
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway and Piedmont Aviation Inc. said jointly that they had signed a definitive agreement for the purchase by N.&W. of 1.2 million new shares of Piedmont stock for $38.4 million.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Pitt Aide Is Reported Involved in Scalping
