description: An assistant football coach at the University of Pittsburgh and a high school coach in the Atlanta area have joined in a scheme to scalp Sugar Bowl tickets, The Atlanta Journal reported today.

title: GROWERS WARNED ABOUT HAZARDS TO TOBACCO SUBSIDY
description: After nearly two decades of preaching resistance to Federal moves against the state's $2.4 billion tobacco industry, political leaders in North Carolina are beginning to warn farmers and factory workers who depend on the crop that something will have to be done to adjust to the new national climate opposing agricultural subsidies.

title: DESPITE HURT, SUBURB WAITS FOR RECOVERY
description: Nobody seems to be thriving on President Reagan's economics in Chicago's near southern and southwestern suburbs, but there is more hope than anger. Few people seem to be ready to write off the President and his policies.

title: CHINA-INDIA TALKS WIND UP IN PEKING
description: China and India ended five days of talks here today without any visible progress toward settling their border dispute. The two sides agreed to continue their contacts.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1981; Markets
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 15.03 points, to 871.48, amid heightened tensions in Poland and the Middle East. It was the index's biggest drop in 14 weeks. Declining issues outstripped gainers by 1,373 to 243 on the Big Board as volume eased. (Page D1.)

title: Japan Posts Trade Deficit
description: Japan today announced a monthly trade deficit for the first time in nearly a year, partly because of a sharp drop in car exports.

title: Great Basins to Sell Canada Mine Unit
description: The Great Basins Petroleum Company said that, as part of its previously reported liquidation plan, it had agreed to sell its Canadian subsidiary, Columbian Northland Exploration Ltd., to Carolin Mines Ltd., a Canadian minerals producer, for 1.4 million shares of the latter's stock, or about $29.9 million.

title: 3 Mile Island Suit Amended
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation said that it filed an amended complaint in Federal court seeking to recover $4 billion in damages from the Babcock and Wilcox Company, a subsidiary of McDermott Inc.

title: KOCH PLEDGES ACTION BY CITY TO SETTLE THE CARTING STRIKE
description: Mayor Koch warned yesterday that the city would take ''appropriate action'' today to end a teamster local's two-week-old strike against New York's private carting companies.

title: 'IF' IS KEY TO DEAL FOR MAY
description: The Yankees have agreed to trade Rudy May to the Kansas City Royals for Hal McRae, but the trade has not been completed because it requires the approval of both players.

title: Villanova 85 Towson State 55
description: John Pinone and Ed Pinckney combined for 47 points to lead unbeaten Villanova to its sixth victory.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Colombian Coal
description: Carbocol, a Colombian state-owned coal corporation, has asked Japanese cement, electric power and steel concerns to import an unspecified amount of Colombian coal under a long-term agreement, Government sources said here today. Carbocol plans to develop the El Cerrejon coal field in northern Colombia jointly with Intercor, the Exxon Corporation's Colombian unit. Production at the coal field is scheduled to start in 1986 and is expected to increase to 15 million tons a year by 1990.

title: Libyan Oil Output Up
description: Libya produced an average of 1.2 million barrels a day of oil in the first two weeks of December, more than double the output of earlier this year, the heavy industries secretary, Omar Mostafa Montasser, said here today. Mr. Montasser said Libya hoped to maintain the new level and he foresaw no problems resulting from the withdrawal of personnel of United States oil companies.

title: U.S. HOPES TO PREVENT MILITARY RULE IN POLAND FROM BECOMING PERMANENT
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to use whatever diplomatic and economic influence it can muster, in collaboration with its allies, to prevent the military crackdown in Poland from becoming permanent, a senior State Department official said today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RELIABILITY OF POLISH ARMED FORCES A CRUCIAL ISSUE
description: The effectiveness of army rule in Poland will depend on the reliability of conscripted soldiers and noncommissioned and junior officers. The expectation is that the military regime will rely on the internal security forces for initial action against strikers or rioters.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE CARDINAL'S LETTER
description: Following are excerpts from Terence Cardinal Cooke's letter to chaplains:

title: THE STAGE: 'TOMFOOLERY,' A REVUE OF LEHRER LYRICS
description: WHEN Tom Lehrer's songs first surfaced in the 1950's, they seemed the last word in witty naughtiness. Much like his contemporary Mort Sahl, Mr. Lehrer had the temerity to be rude about all sorts of sacred cows - from the Boy Scouts to nuclear militarism - but his rudeness always came veiled in charm. However biting his lyrics, he'd still leave you with a winning tune to hum.

title: A Bit of Pelicaniana
description: ''It gives it more class, makes it a more formal party,'' said Senator Russell B. Long. ''The more exclusive you make it, the more they want to come.''

title: Aerospace Sales Up
description: Sales of United States aerospace companies are expected to rise 14.3 percent, to $61 billion this year, with profits totaling 4.3 percent of sales, the same as in 1980, the president of the Aerospace Industries Assocation of America, Karl Harr, said today. Mr. Harr, in remarks to the Aviation Writers Association, said that ''although we expect reduced commercial sales, the decline will be more than offset by increased defense workload.''

title: THE NEW GENETICS BIOLOGY AT A TURNING POINT Third of three articles.
description: FOUR years ago, a tumult of shouted slogans and waving placards shattered the dignity of the National Academy of Sciences' auditorium in Washington. The protesters were denouncing potential harm to human health and individual freedom from something mysterious called genetic engineering. The scene was a public forum held by the Academy on a new field of biological research that had suddenly exploded into public consciousness. Known to scientists as recombinant DNA technology, and to a wider public as gene-splicing, the field implied new drugs, new knowledge, new hazards and eventually, perhaps, the deliberate introduction of new genetic traits into living cells - genetic engineering.

title: POLISH COUNCIL MEMBERS HAVE CLOSE SOVIET TIES
description: The Military Council for National Salvation that has taken over in Poland comprises political generals, key officers within the Ministry of National Defense, and strategically placed military commanders.

title: N.C.A.A. Prevails in TV Fight
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday won, at least for the time being, its battle to retain control over all regular-season telecasts of college football.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Conducts a Rally In Support of the Polish Union
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. held a rally today in support of the Solidarity labor movement in Poland.

title: SPRING CHOICES FROM 3 DESIGNERS
description: For the first time anyone on Seventh Avenue can remember, the position of hemlines is regarded as insignificant. Short clothes coexist with long ones, and both are regarded as valid. This is not just a theoretical situation. In their orders for spring (the styles will begin coming into the stores next month), retailers have made sure that all lengths are represented so that their customers can have wide choices.

title: REVIVING A LONDON LANDMARK
description: The Lyons Corner House is back. To visitors here between the wars, a Lyons Corner House was almost as much of an institution as Buckingham Palace: Plain, good food at reasonable prices in pleasant surroundings. For a strong cup of tea after a day's shopping or sightseeing; a place to meet a friend from the suburbs or to take the children for a holiday treat.

title: LET LONG ISLANDERS RUN THEIR RAILROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Indiana State Planning To Discontinue 7 Sports
description: Indiana State, in a move to save money, will discontinue intercollegiate competition in seven sports, starting with the 1982-83 academic year, it was announced today.

title: Media Lose Plea to Hear Wiretap on Teamster
description: A Federal appeals court on Monday denied a request by the news media to hear wiretapped conversations between a reputed underworld figure and Roy L. Williams, now president of the teamsters' union.

title: BALDWIN BIDS $1.2 BILLION FOR MGIC
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, a diversified financial services company with a growing insurance business, yesterday announced an agreement to merge with the MGIC Investment Corporation, the largest independent seller of residential mortgage insurance.

title: More Jobs for Legumes
description: In a world avid for better food and more renewable resources, too little attention is paid to legumes, especially those of the tropics, says a recent editorial in Nature, the British scientific weekly.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss; results for the qr ended July 31, 1981 have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: CONTEXT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VW to Reduce U.S. Operation
description: Volkswagen of America said it would cut production at its Pennsylvania auto assembly plant, put construction at a second plant on ''deferred schedule'' and lay off about 350 workers because of a continuing slump in domestic auto sales.

title: AGENT ORANGE PLEA IS DENIED IN BLOW TO VIETNAM VETERANS
description: The chances that thousands of Vietnam veterans will ever be able to collect damages for injuries caused by exposure to the chemical known as Agent Orange remained clouded today as the Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal from a lower court ruling that may keep many of the veterans out of Federal court.

title: MUSIC: WUORINEN REWORKS PURCELL
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonia played music from ''The Magic Art'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday afternoon, giving New York its first hearing of Charles Wuorinen's new reworking of Purcell's music. Mr. Wuorinen has cut and spliced Purcellean ideas, reconstituted them according to his own tastes and arranged them to fit modern instruments and modern ears.

title: Best Foot Forward
description: Pedro DeBrito, a forward for the national champion soccer team at the University of Connecticut, was the first player chosen in the North American Soccer League's college draft. He goes to Tampa Bay.

title: NATIONAL Y.W.C.A. WILL SELL MANHATTAN BUILDING FOR $18 MILLION
description: In need of more operating revenues, the Young Women's Christian Assocation has decided to sell its headquarters at 52d Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: Du Pont Products
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said that it planned to phase out the manufacture and sale of its Lucite acrylic molding and extrusion-cube polymers. The big chemical concern said the action would not affect corporate earnings but would allow it to reassign its resources to more profitable products.

title: World Body Approves Payment Plan in Track
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation, taking a first step toward recognizing prize and appearance payments to track-and-field competitors, has approved ''trust funds'' made up of money from sponsors, industries and organizers.

title: WALCO ENDS OFFER FOR GENERAL STEEL
description: Thwarted by questions raised about the ethics of its former chairman, Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, the Walco National Corporation announced yesterday that it was abandoning its takeover of General Steel Industries. At the same time, General Steel agreed to be acquired by the Lukens Steel Company.

title: 7 STOLEN POLICE AND F.B.I. CARS ARE TARGET OF WIDE SEARCH
description: Police officers manned bridges and tunnels around New York City early today and launched a wide and systematic 48-hour search for seven unmarked city and Federal police cars that the police said had been stolen here under unusual circumstances.

title: 2 EMPLOYEES SUE TO GET CITY TO PAY WAGES DEFERRED IN '75
description: Wages that New York City workers agreed to defer during the fiscal crisis in 1975 should now be paid promptly, two city workers argued in legal papers yesterday. The wages add up to a multimillion-dollar package certain to come up in the 1982 municipal labor negotiations.

title: TRUST ANKARA
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger's visit to Ankara has focused new attention on Turkey and raised important questions about United States policy toward that country.

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
Abdullah el-Erian, 60; Judge at World Court
description: Judge Abdullah Ali el-Erian, an Egyptian diplomat and a member of the International Court of Justice, died of a heart attack Saturday, a spokesman for the Court announced Monday. He was 60 years old.

title: Earnings Up 2% at G.& W.
description: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified concern with interests in manufacturing, financial services and entertainment, said yesterday that its profit rose 2 percent in the quarter ended Oct. 31 compared with a year earlier.

title: PUT AN EMBARGO ON ALL LIBYAN OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: KAPLAN'S 'OVER THE EDGE,' ENNUI TO REBELLION
description: BEYOND the images of white, middle-class American tots and teenagers stoned on grass, hash or acid, talking an acquired jive-jargon to express an angst that is both sublimely ridiculous and chilling, there's a vision of America in Jonathan Kaplan's ''Over the Edge'' that is anything but ridiculous. The film is also a demonstration of the real movie-making talents of Mr. Kaplan, the young director whose ''White Line Fever'' was one of the low-budget discoveries of 1975.

title: COMBAT PHOTOGRAPHER WINS $125,000 IN A SUIT AGAINST TIME
description: A Federal jury cast aside a signed release negotiated by Time Inc. with a freelance photographer badly injured while on assignment for Time-Life in the Vietnam War and held that the publisher had an implicit responsibility to ''take care of'' the injured man.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1981
description: Crackdown in Poland Polish workers mounted strikes throughout the country in defiance of martial law as military leaders tightened their hold. Clandestine information services of Solidarity reported strikes and worker resistance in factories, shipyards, steel mills, coal mines and even academic institutions in Warsaw and all other major cities and regions. Lech Walesa, Solidarity's leader, who was technically not detained by police was said by Government officials to be in a Goverment rest house.(Page A1, Column 6.) No widespread unrest in Poland has been indicated by diplomatic and intelligence reports reaching the United States, according to senior American officials. The reports were spotty because of an internal communications blackout in Poland. (A18:1-2.)

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $1,091,000 gain for the qr and $798,000 loss for the 9 mos from pretax equity in Playboy

title: OPERA: 'BOHEME' STAGED BY ZEFFIRELLI
description: LAST night's new production of ''La Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera was a gift for the old guard - for Met conservatives disgruntled by the carefully modernist line taken by the new Met in its repertory and production style. This Franco Zeffirelli ''Boheme'' - he both directed and designed it - is a production for people who come wanting to applaud the scenery. And applaud it they did, throwing in bravos to boot.

title: KEY AIDE SANGUINE ON DEFICIT
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, President Reagan's chief economic adviser, today defended the prospect of sizable budget deficits, saying a balanced budget was not ''one of the fundamentals'' of the Reagan economic program.

title: HOUSE-SEANTE CONFEREES APPROVE FOREIGN AID BILL
description: A House-Senate conference tonight approved an $11.4 billion foreign aid authorization bill that retains a prohibition on aid to insurgents in Angola, but lifts a boycott on aid to Chile, Argentina and Pakistan.

title: HINCKLEY PROSECUTORS PRESS TO USE COMMENTS MADE AFTER HIS ARREST
description: Federal prosecutors argued at a pretrial hearing today that they should be able to use evidence obtained in violation of John W. Hinckley Jr.'s constitutional rights to prove he was sane when he shot President Reagan and three other men March 30.

title: WHOM A PRESIDENT SENDS ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 7
description: B-Including income of $878,000 or 7 cents a shr for the qr and $2.3 million or 20 cents a shr for the 40 weeks from an accounting change and a $1.53 a shr net gain for the 40 weeks on the sale of stock in Aurrera S.A.; C- After losses from discontinued operations of $591,000 for the qr and $1.9 million for the 40 weeks and 7 cents a shr net gain from the sale of stock of Pay Less Drug Stores

title: Futures Tie Backed In Chicago; New York Link Voted
description: The membership of the Chicago Board of Trade approved overwhelmingly today the proposed electronic link between the Chicago board, the world's largest commodities exchange, and the New York Futures Exchange, the struggling offshoot of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DIT-DIT

title: BANKS AND U.S. OFFICIALS HOPEFUL ON POLISH DEBTS
description: Bankers and Treasury Department officials expressed optimism yesterday that an agreement to reschedule $2.4 billion of Poland's debt to Western banks would still be signed, although probably not by the end of the year, as was originally planned.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Continental Properties Inc. has named Daniele D. Bodini president.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $3,259,000 extraordinary gain for the qr and 6 mos and $640,000 pretax gain for the 6 mos on the sale of property

title: HEMPSTEAD TO USE BIDS TO BUY INSURANCE
description: This town will abandon its practice of purchasing insurance coverage through a designated agent and open the process to competitive bidding, its Presiding Supervisor announced today.

title: REAGANS GIVING TREE ORNAMENT TO VISITORS AT CHRISTMAS
description: Thousands of families invited to see the White House decorated for the Christmas season will come away with a glittering memento of their visit: a four-inch, tree-shaped, brass ornament.

title: Toyota Sets Canada Study
description: Japan's largest auto maker, the Toyota Motor Company, is studying the feasibility of building a plant in the Canadian province of British Columbia, company and provincial officials said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: N ORMAN Podhoretz, editor of Commentary magazine, has been appointed by the Reagan Admninistration to head a broadly mandated advisory committee whose aim, he says, is to ''press the American case more effectively and with greater relevance abroad.'' Mr. Podhoretz, a prominent neoconservative, was appointed to the post by Charles Z. Wick, director of the International Communication Agency. ''This is all part of a general effort now for the United States to be more active in the war of ideas,'' says Mr. Podhoretz. Other members of the committee include Michael Novak, the author; Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, and Edwin J. Feulner Jr., president of the conservative Heritage Foundation.

title: U.S. Is Said to Be Reviewing Issuance of a Visa to Paisley
description: The State Department is reviewing the issuance of a visa that would allow the Rev. Ian D. Paisley, a Northern Ireland Protestant leader, to visit the United States next month, a member of Congress said today.

title: CZECHS CALL POLISH ACTION 'UNAVOIDABLE'
description: The Czechoslovak Government, which has been demanding strong action for months, reacted with satisfaction today to the imposition of martial law in neighboring Poland.

title: William E. Sauro Police Academy Graduates 961 Probationary Officers
description: Some of the new officers applauding during ceremony yesterday at the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden.

title: ECONOMIC REVIVAL CALLED POLISH AIM
description: A major goal of the military takeover in Poland, in the view of Western bankers and other experts, is a highly risky bid by the country's authorities to halt Poland's economic decline.

title: Kuwait Sets Oil Price Cut
description: Kuwait announced today, as expected, that its oil price will fall by 70 cents a barrel on Jan.1 as called for in agreements reached at last week's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Ohio Urged to Stop Line Across Amish Farms
description: The Ohio Power Siting Board was urged today to protect ''an endangered human species'' and block construction of a 51.5-mile electric transmission line through the state's Amish country.

title: COURT ENDS CEILING ON GIFTS TO REFERENDUM GROUPS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that governments may not limit campaign contributions by individuals to organizations formed to support or oppose referendums and other ballot measures.

title: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES UP
description: Bond prices rebounded sharply yesterday, with the best gains posted in the long end of the credit markets. The advance lifted prices of long-term Government bonds as much as 2 full points, or $20 per each $1,000 of face value. Prices of high-rated tax-exempts and corporate bonds tended to improve in sympathy with the Government sector.

title: Indiana Routs Tulane, 77-59
description: Ted Kitchel scored 23 points, and Steve Bouchie, who led a second-half surge with six consecutive baskets, scored 18, as Indiana defeated Tulane, 77-59, tonight.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard PICASSO: THE EARLY YEARS, 1881-1907. By Josep Palau i Fabri. Illustrated. Riz- zoli. $160 until Dec. 31; $175 thereafter.

title: PLOWS INTO MX'S
description: In Congress, agricultural plowshares are being t urned into tanks and MX missiles.

title: A Summer in Houston
description: The Houston Oilers are nearing the end of their first losing season since 1975, and all of the players - especially Ken Stabler - are being encouraged to remain in Texas during the offseason to train at the team's new facility. ''You can't force anyone to stay, but it would be in their best interest,'' said Coach Ed Biles, ''and Stabler's future is based on what happens in the offseason.

title: WEST EUROPEANS APPEAL FOR RESTRAINT
description: Western European leaders appealed to all nations yesterday to let Poland solve its problems without interference. While they mentioned no country by name, they clearly were directing their appeal to the Soviet Union, which has troops in Poland, and to other Soviet-bloc neighbors of the Poles.

title: 20 BOOKS VIE FOR '81 PRIZES
description: The National Book Critics Circle announced yesterday its nominations for the most distinguished books published in 1981. They are: FICTION: Rabbit Is Rich, by John Updike (Knopf); A Flag for Sunrise, by Robert Stone (Knopf); Riddley Walker, by Russell Hoban (Summit); Sixty Stories, by Donald Barthelme (Putnam); The Men's Club, by Leonard Michaels (Farrar Straus & Giroux).

title: Marvelous Brothers
description: Steve and Phil Mahre, the twins from Yakima, Wash., yesterday became the first brothers and the first pair of Americans to finish one, two in a World Cup ski race.

title: WHO'S NO. 1 IN TENNIS?
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, Martina Navratilova and Tracy Austin differed today over whether the Toyota Series women's tennis championships, which start at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena Tuesday night, would decide the No. 1 spot for the year.

title: Bless Us Every One!
description: It was an audition, Monica Stratton was recalling the other day, that could have changed literary history. But fortunately, the aspiring actor did not get the part.

title: When Will They Learn?
description: At an all-day teach-in at Harvard University Saturday organized by Working Papers magazine against Reagan Administration economic and foreign policies, the folksinger-activist Mary Travers, of the Peter, Paul and Mary group, sang to prepare the crowd for a talk by the liberal columnist I. F. Stone.

title: Bridge: Trumps May Look Tricky But Still Be the Wisest Bid
description: In normal circumstances a 4-4 trump fit in a major is highly desirable. It becomes less so if bidding by the opponents indicates that the suit will break badly. In such circumstances, three notrump may be a more attractive landing place.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: time characters consists of nonnutritious food and drink.

title: Wife by Proxy Given Visa by the Russians
description: Yelizaveta K. Alekseyeva, who won the right to emigrate after a 17-day hunger strike by Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife, received a passport today and was told to leave the country within a week.

title: Chairman and President Quit American Bakeries
description: L. Arthur Cushman Jr., 52, resigned as chairman of the American Bakeries Company and George P. Turci, 52, resigned as president, effective Dec. 18. Neil S. Leist, 33, who led a proxy battle at the Chicago wholesale bakery last spring that won four board seats and has since become chairman of the executive committee, will assume their duties, but not the titles, according to a company statement.

title: SOVIET SAYS MOVES ARE UP IN POLAND
description: The first official Soviet comment on events in Poland said today that they were ''an internal matter.'' It described any ''different interpretation'' implying Soviet manipulation as an attempt in itself to interfere in Polish affairs.

title: Battle Between Soft Drinks
description: The latest development in the advertising feud between Coca-Cola and Pepsi-Cola has No.2 agreeing to change some of its practices for the sake of more accurate claims.

title: GOLAN AREA LONG DISPUTED
description: The Golan Heights, 444 square miles of rocky land rising to 7,000 feet in the foothills of Mount Hermon at the southwest corner of Syria, has been a political bone of contention since Israel occupied the area in the 1967 war.

title: PRESIDING OVER CHANGE AT CITY COLLEGE
description: WHEN Bernard Harleston walks about the Harlem campus of City College, he takes special note of the massive, laterally jutting lines of the campus's nearly completed North Academic Center with its high marble-clad foundation thrusting outward like the prow of a great ship into Amsterdam Avenue at West 138th Street. He then looks across Convent Avenue, barely 100 yards away to the stark contrast of the neo-Gothic verticality, cloistered ambiance and richly textured surfaces of Shepherd Hall, built in 1910 and long a college symbol as the site of everything from registration to demonstrations.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FAMILY TREE: REAL OR ARTIFICIAL?
description: There are issues that continue to divide this nation, and the plastic Christmas tree is one of them. As Wanda Bryant stood at the checkout counter of a Christmas-tree store here the other day, she noticed a woman with a natural blue spruce and was compelled to speak out on the issue. ''That's a lovely tree,'' she said, ''but how can you stand having it in your house with all the needles and the mess all over?''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Chicago Inc. said it had signed an agreement to buy five Boeing 727 aircraft from Pan American World Airways for $12.2 million.

title: FOSTERS SPELL SUCCESS ON COLLEGE COURTS
description: Shirley Garrison, the secretary in the basketball office at Clemson University, had been in her job for about eight months in April 1976 when an assistant coach asked her to call Bill Foster, the head coach, who was attending an Atlantic Coast Conference meeting. She called a hotel in Myrtle Beach, S.C., and asked for Bill Foster.

title: SAM SPIEGEL SETS FILMING ON 'BETRAYAL'
description: ''Betrayal,'' Harold Pinter's three-character play about infidelity, will be made into a movie by Sam Spiegel, the legendary producer whose ''On the Waterfront,'' ''The Bridge on the River Kwai'' and ''Lawrence of Arabia'' won a total of 23 Academy Awards. Mr. Spiegel intends to make his film on as low a budget as he finds possible in today's era of inflated costs.

title: Phillip D. Doran, 76, Is Dead; Former U.S. Representative
description: Phillip D. Doran, a former United States Representative and chief of flight operations of United Technologies' Pratt & Whitney Aircraft in East Hartford, Conn., died Saturday at Hartford Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Berlin, Conn.

title: RATS CALLED THE MAJOR HEALTH WORRY FROM STRIKE
description: The piles of garbage that are inundating some New York City sidewalks have not yet posed a major health hazard, city health officials said yesterday.

title: Report by Jurists Group Says Sri Lanka Represses Minority
description: A report of the International Commission of Jurists, written by an American and published here today, accused Sri Lanka of repressing its Tamil minority and said the situation could grow into violence.

title: THE GOLAN HEIGHTS ANNEXED BY ISRAEL IN AN ABRUPT MOVE
description: The contested Golan Heights formally became part of Israel today as Prime Minister Menachem Begin pushed a measure through Parliament to annex the strategic zone along the Syrian border.

title: Creighton, 73 St Joseph's, Pa. 72
description: Creighton rallied from a 5-point deficit in the last four minutes. Daryl Stovall led Creighton with 25 points and 12 rebounds in the first game between the teams since a 59-57 victory by St. Joseph's in a first-round game of last season's national collegiate tournament. Creighton fell behind by 70-65 on two free throws by Lonnie McFarlan

title: Esmark Earnings Up
description: Esmark Inc. today reported record net earnings from continuing operations for the fiscal year of $99.6 million, or $7.49 a share, up from $54.3 million, or $1.90 a share, last year. In the fourth quarter, Esmark said, net income from continuing operations was $27.4 million, or $2.10 a share, up from $16 million, or 63 cents a share, on revenue of $849.9 million, up from $758.9 million.

title: Landmark Buses
description: The 160 buses that were too old for Washington but have carried New Yorkers handily since spring are gradually going home. Brand-new buses are taking their place.

title: WHY INCO DECIDED TO DROP BATTERIES: SLUMP KEY FACTOR
description: When Inco withdrew from the battery business last week to concentrate, it said, ''on its natural resources and alloy products businesses,'' some analysts in the industry were not entirely surprised.

title: GIANTS ARE FILLED WITH PLAYOFF HOPE
description: Brad Van Pelt recalled a Giants team meeting in training camp last summer. ''Coach Perkins asked us to write down what record we thought the team would finish with this year,'' he said. ''The players were asked not to sign the paper.

title: Canada Economic Data
description: The indicator used by the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce as a guide to future economic activity fell 0.36 percent last September, its fifth consecutive monthly decline and the largest drop since the measure was set up in 1967, the bank said today.

title: F.T.C. IS ASSAILED ON MOBIL STRATEGY
description: The Federal Trade Commission has taken an unprecedented step in an antitrust suit filed Friday by listing in detail the terms under which the Mobil Corporation could take over the Marathon Oil Company without antitrust problems, a Congressman charged today.

title: Gaynor & Company Acquires Staley Fox
description: Gaynor & Company, which is publicly held, has acquired the Staley Fox agency, billing $3.5 million, and has merged it with its own Gaynor & Ducas, billing $10.7 million, to form Staley, Falcone & Gaynor at 505 Park Avenue.

title: POPE'S SCIENTISTS MEET REAGAN
description: A group of scientists sent by Pope John Paul II to discuss the medical implications of a nuclear war met with President Reagan this afternoon and said afterward that Mr. Reagan was ''very much concerned'' with the threat of a nuclear conflagration.

title: Chess: The Mark of a Champion Is To Win When Winning
description: Billie Jean King once drew a distinction between players who were brilliant in fighting back when they were losing a match and true champions who had the ability - or the courage -to go ahead and win when they were winning.

title: Participants
description: Local 813 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters representing about 2,000 drivers and helpers employed by private carters.

title: Loss for China On Industries
description: China has 13,000 industrial enterprises operating at a yearly loss of $2.8 billion because of waste, poor planning and incompetent management, China's Finance Minister said in a report that was released today.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $17.7 million pretax gain on the disposition of investments and $6.5 million pretax loss from foreign currency translations...C-Including $12.1 million pretax gain on the disposition of investments and $4.8 million pretax gain from foreign currency translations

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A list in SportsMonday yesterday omitted Oregon State University from a ranking of schools with the greatest number of college basketball victories. Oregon State has won 1,207 games, placing it fifth.

title: JURORS ACQUIT SUSPECT AUTOPSY'S EVIDENCE
description: A piece of undigested cake from a victim's stomach helped rebut a key witness and acquit a man charged with murder.

title: UMC ELECTRONICS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Advertising; New Look In Cotton Campaign
description: FOR the first time - starting tonight - Cotton Inc., which is dedicated to increasing sales of cotton products in behalf of 50,000 United States cotton growers, will be advertising on the television evening news. And, as usual, its messages will be aimed at a number of audiences made up of buying decision makers.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 15, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on complaint by the Sey- chelles at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to Nov 15
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid Nov 15, 1981

title: Special Education Found a Problem
description: Special education programs designed to help disadvantaged children overcome learning disabilities may actually interfere with their education, a nationwide study indicates.

title: RICKOVER'S FLAWED IDEAS ON BEING A MANAGER
description: To the Editor:

title: Crocker Raises Prime to 15 3/4%
description: The Crocker National Bank, the nation's 12th-largest commercial bank, raised its prime lending rate today by one-quarter percentage point, to 15 3/4 percent.

title: U.S. Auto Backlog Rises
description: The nation's auto makers had an 83-day backlog of unsold cars on hand at the beginning of December - the highest inventory since 1974, Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry trade publication, reported today.

title: COOKE SEES ATOMIC WEAPONS AS 'TOLERABLE' FOR A DETERRENT
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, in a letter made public yesterday, said that ''a strategy of nuclear deterrence can be morally tolerated if a nation is sincerely trying to come up with a rational alternative.''

title: Overdue Memorial
description: James N. Rowe Jr. was 47 years old and Eugene J. Keogh was 49 when they began work on a project that has been a quarter of a century in the making and is still in limbo: a memorial to Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: Swedish Reporter in Moscow Is Accused of Military Spying
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry summoned the Swedish Ambassador today to hear charges that the correspondent of a Stockholm newspaper had been involved in military espionage, the Swedish Embassy said.

title: Welsh of Navy Is Said To Accept Virginia Post
description: George Welsh, head football coach at the United States Naval Academy for the last nine seasons, has accepted an offer to become the University of Virginia's next football coach, the Richmond Times-Dispatch reported tonight.

title: PIERCE VOWS TO FIGHT CUTBACKS IN HOUSING AGENCY
description: The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development vowed today to fight the budget director's proposed cutbacks in housing agency funds, saying he would take his fight to President Reagan if he had to, and ''We'll see who wins.''

title: Drilling in Liquid Rock
description: For many years, at a few sites in California and elsewhere, electricity has been generated with steam derived from the earth's interior. To achieve more widespread production of geothermal energy, scientists have sought to inject water into rock made hot by former volcanic activity and capture the resulting steam.

title: FOR SENATOR HAWKINS, A DEBATABLE FIRST YEAR
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, explains her problem this way: ''I guess I have my dog in too many fights.''

title: FREEDOM BANK SEES BID TO TAKE IT OVER
description: A dispute has broken out over the Freedom National Bank, with the bank charging that another major black-owned business, Daniels & Bell, a Wall Street brokerage house, is trying to seize control of the 17-year-old institution.

title: N.A.S.L. Is Realigned
description: The North American Soccer League will operate as a three-division, 14-team league for the 1982 outdoor season, Commissioner Phil Woosnam said today.

title: Clemson 96 West Chester (Pa.) 56
description: Six players scored in double figures for Clemson (6-0).Vincent Hamilton led the Tigers with 15 points.

title: BECK FACING 6-GAME BAN
description: The Rangers defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 5-4, at Madison Square Garden last night, but they may have lost their captain, Barry Beck, for six games.

title: No Headline
description: 67 AMERICANS FLY OUT OF LIBYA

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Dwight Jones Fined
description: Dwight Jones of the Chicago Bulls was fined $1,250 by the National Basketball Association for striking World B. Free of the Golden State Warriors with a forearm during a game earlier this month. The fine, which includes the automatic $250 levy for being ejected from a game, follows a league investigation. Free recently had his first name changed legally from Lloyd to World.

title: EX-OFFICER WHO NEVER HAD TO FIRE KILLS A ROBBER WITH SINGLE SHOT
description: A retired police lieutenant who now drives a school bus shot and killed a man who held him up yesterday while he was transporting handicapped pupils in Brooklyn.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $1,012,000 for the qr and $2,751,000 for the 9 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $474,000 for the qr and $1,321,000 for the 9 mos and extraordinary credits of $1,243,000 for the qr and $1,708,000 for the 9 mos; yr-ago results have been re- classified to reflect discontinued operations

title: Flemish Social Christian Forms Belgian Cabinet
description: A Flemish Social Christian named Wilfried Martens announced the formation today of a center-right Belgian Cabinet, ending a three-month old political crisis.

title: New Haven 78 C.W. Post 76
description: Edgar Maull scored 29 points to lead New Haven (6-1). Steve Nitti led C.W. Post with 21 points, 17 in the second half.

title: ESMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses of $5.7 million for the qr and $5.8 million for the yr from operations designated for disposition... C-Including gains of $387.5 million or $16.11 a shr for the qr and $417.1 million or 15.61 a shr for the yr from operations designated for disposition; shrs outstndg reflect a 5-for-4 sto split in July and the retirement of shrs as a result of the disposition of the company's energy business in 1980

title: U.S. SEES ECONOMIC THREAT FROM CUBA
description: The Reagan Administration, in a report on Cuban activity in the Caribbean and Central America since 1978, said today that Havana had created a state of economic as well as political danger in the region.

title: MENTAL PATIENT KILLED IN HOUSTON AFTER CONFRONTING GROUP OF POLICE
description: A 22-year-old mental patient was shot to death here early this morning by officers outside police headquarters. Eddie Lee Johnson, who had been in and out of mental institutions in Austin since 1978, staged a martial arts demonstration in front of headquarters about 5:45 A.M., officers at the scene said. The police were alerted to Mr. Johnson's presence by a dispatcher's call about a man confronting officers in the parking lot.

title: The Countertenor Saga
description: Paul Esswood is a countertenor, and for a while last week, trying to get from London to New York, the singer became something of a counter traveler, too.

title: VENUS COMES INTO CLEAR VIEW
description: For people with a clear view of the heavens, Venus will reach exceptional brilliance in the evening sky tomorrow. It will then be approaching the point in its orbit when, on Jan. 21, it overtakes Earth, passing between this planet and the sun.

title: MALTESE PREMIER HEADS FOR VICTORY
description: Prime Minister Dom Mintoff, who has led this Mediterranean island republic for a decade, appeared tonight to have won a third five-year term as his Labor Party gained a narrow victory over the conservative Nationalists.

title: HUMORIST, NOVELIST AND JOURNALIST
description: Nathaniel Benchley, novelist, humorist and author of 15 children's books, died of a liver infection yesterday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 66 years old.

title: Wall St. Investment Adviser Is Slain in Apartment-Office
description: An investment adviser was found shot to death in his apartmentoffice in the financial district yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: BRZEZINSKI SEEKS LOUD OUTCRY
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski yesterday deplored what he termed the ''too muted'' response of the West to the imposition of martial law in Poland.

title: BYRNE WINS ON CASINO UNIT NOMINEE
description: Governor Byrne won a fight with Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean today when the State Senate, with the aid of a Republican vote, confirmed Mr. Byrne's nomination of Energy Commissioner Joel R. Jacobson to the Casino Control Commission.

title: Gifts, Loans, Contributions; Holiday Tears
description: It's a perverse scenario: perceiving increased danger of crime, people demand arms for themselves. That causes weapons to proliferate, to become more available to criminals and also more likely to be used accidentally or in confrontations with people who aren't criminals.

title: DRIFTER FOCUS OF 9-STATE STUDY
description: Detectives from nine states today worked to assemble a picture of a 34-year-old drifter who was arrested here last week and is wanted for questioning in the slayings of at least 20 young women.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Harassing Planned Parenthood
description: Family planning has not always been such a given in American life. Many people easily remember when birth control information was unavailable or painfully difficult to come by.

title: News Analysis
description: Nuclear power plants cost far more to build than other power plants, but their low fuel cost is supposed to more than offset the initial expense. Recent experience, however, shows that even after a plant is built, the cost of keeping it running includes far more than fuel.

title: Canadiens 6, Capitals 3
description: MONTREAL (UPI) - Doug Wickenheiser returned to the lineup after being benched the last three games and scored two goals for Montreal.

title: HIGH COURT TAKES BANKRUPTCY CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a key portion of the new Federal bankruptcy law, enacted in 1978 to allow consumers to protect a portion of their personal property from bankruptcy proceedings, applies to consumer loans that were made before the new law took effect.

title: THE WORTH OF NEW YORK CITY'S CHILD IMMUNIZATION PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: U.C.L.A. Five Ineligible For Conference Crown
description: U.C.L.A. will be ineligible for the Pacific-10 basketball championship this season under a policy approved today by the presidents and chancellors of schools in the conference.

title: I.B.M. Raising Most Prices
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced price increases for most of its vast line of equipment, services and computer programs.

title: Battelle Memorial Appoints New Head
description: Ronald S. Paul, 58 years old, has been appointed president of the Battelle Memorial Institute, a research institute with headquarters in Columbus, Ohio. He succeeds Sherwood L. Fawcett, 61, who was named chairman of the board of trustees, while continuing as chief executive officer

title: Afghan Refugees Increase
description: The number of Afghan refugees in Pakistan has risen to about 2.5 million and the country is now the ''single largest refugee theater in the world,'' a senior Pakistani refugee official said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As long as our nation is sincerely trying to work with other nations to find a better way, the church considers the strategy of nuclear deterrence morally tolerable; not satisfactory, but tolerable.'' - Terence Cardinal Cooke. (B16:4.)

title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes a person to itch, and why does scratching relieve the discomfort?

title: INVENTORIES UP AGAIN IN OCTOBER
description: Unsold goods held by United States businesses rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in October as sales dropped sharply and the recession took hold, the Government reported today.

title: Posey, Parry
description: Posey, Parry & Quest of Greenwich, Conn., has become agency for the Bostonian division of the Commonwealth Shoe Company, previously handled by the Harvey A. Ford Company of Brockton, Mass. Billings will be in excess of $2 million. The brands involved, in addition to the Bostonian dress shoes for men, include Pacers for Men and Jack Nicklaus Golf Shoes.

title: JOHNSON, JET HERO, MAY RETURN TO BENCH
description: Two days ago, Jesse Johnson, a backup safety playing the unfamiliar role of cornerback, deflected a pass in the end zone and might have saved the Jets' season.

title: Outside the Ring
description: The heavyweight boxer Randy Cobb is recovering from a broken right wrist suffered when he helped a Philadelphia newspaper columnist in a brawl at a city bar.

title: 2 Car Makers In Japan Gain
description: Japan's two largest auto makers, the Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, said today that their production in November rose above 1980 levels for the first time since last April, indicating that the domestic market is improving.

title: Saudi Imports Up 18.5%
description: Saudi Arabia's imports from 18 industrial countries rose 18.5 percent, or $3.6 billion, to $23.1 billion in 1980, the Saudi Arabian monetary agency said today.

title: Waiting for Walesa
description: With Poland sealed off, one can only imagine the fateful conversations between General Jaruzelski and Lech Walesa, the Solidarity leader he holds in ''respected'' custody.

title: STOCKS FALL BY 15.03 IN BROAD DROP
description: The developing crisis in Poland and growing Middle East tensions sent the Dow Jones industrial average plummeting 15.03 points, to 871.48, yesterday - the biggest drop in 14 weeks.

title: Air Florida Plans Layoffs, Pay Cuts
description: Air Florida, a Miami-based airline, said that it will lay off more than 200 workers beginning Jan. 1 and will require pay cuts for all personnel earning more than $40,000 a year. The airline said that the economy measures were being taken because of price-cutting on Northeast-to-Florida routes and the disruptive impact of the recent air traffic controllers' strike.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-After loss from disontinued operations of $436,000 and extraordinary credit from tax loss carryforwards of $632,000...C-Net loss and after loss from discontinued operations of $198,000

title: SAKHAROV'S STEPSON, ONE BATTLE WON, FIGHTS ON
description: Alexey Semyonov was sprawled listlessly on a blue sofa, talking over the telephone to a radio show in Washington. His eyes were closed, and his voice was tired, barely audible.

title: New Orleans 70 Southwest Louisiana 65
description: Mark Petteway scored 22 points and grabbed 12 rebounds to lead New Orleans to an upset. The victory was the third without a loss for New Orleans; Southwest Louisiana is 8-1. Mike Edwards and Oscar Taylor scored 16 points each for New Orleans.

title: MIDDLETOWN, OHIO: A MODEL FOR 'PRIVATE INIATIVE'
description: In the view of many people here, Armco Inc. is Middletown. With about 8,500 employees in its carbon steel, specialty metals, international and corporate divisions here, the homespun enterprise that began as the American Rolling Mill Company at the turn of the century is by far the city's largest employer. Armco provides about one-third of the jobs for a work force of 28,000 that includes several other small cities.

title: Market Place; Developments At Kaiser Steel
description: SHAREHOLDERS of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, the industry's largest integrated producer on the West Coast, have been watching a struggle for control of the company in profitable fascination.

title: MAPLE LEAFS PRESS EFFORT TO TRADE SITTLER
description: The Toronto Maple Leafs continued negotiations today in their effort to trade Darryl Sittler, their captain and leader, after the latest in a series of internal flaps that have characterized the troubled franchise.

title: U.S. CALLS ISRAELI MOVE A PERIL TO CAMP DAVID
description: The Reagan Administration today opposed Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights as inconsistent with the Camp David peace accords.

title: ARAFAT STARTS 3-DAY GREECE VISIT
description: Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, began a three-day official visit to Greece today that underlines the new Greek Socialist Government's commitment to the group.

title: POLICE ARE STEPPING UP ANTI-PEDDLER CAMPAIGN
description: ''Check 'em out, ladies and gentlemen - fi' dollars, $20 in the stores,'' 23-year-old Leon of the Bronx urged Fifth Avenue shoppers at 53d Street. Two skate-wheeled plywood dollies with wholesale-size boxes held his inventory of men's classic-style mufflers labeled ''100 percent imported Australian wool, Made in U.S.A.''

title: LONG DAY IN OPERATING ROOM ENDED IN OPTIMISM FOR 'LISA
description: H.'Lisa H., as she called herself to preserve her privacy, suffered since birth from neurofibromatosis, the disfiguring ailment that was named Elephant Man's Disease in the 19th century. Last week Science Times reported on the 21-year-old woman's decision to go through with a complex operation. The following is an account of the risky, prolonged surgery she underwent last Wednesday. By RICHARD SEVERO PHILADELPHIA AT midnight last Tuesday, Lisa H. called her mother from her private room in the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. Lisa, whose face was badly deformed by the tumor-causing neurofibromatosis, was just hours away from the surgery that she hoped would change her face and her life. Her family knew it would be radical surgery and she was concerned about their apprehensions.

title: Former Nationalists Named To Advisory Council in China
description: China promoted several prominent former Nationalists today to senior posts on a national advisory council.

title: France Comes Nearer To Recognizing P.L.O.
description: France came closer today than it has in the past to recognizing the Palestine Liberation Organization as the sole representative of the Palestinian people.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Friday on traffic movement in Man- hattan during the evening rush gave incorrect speeds for Third Avenue. The Transportation Department said the average rose to 11.9 miles an hour, compared with 6.8 before a Queens- bound lane was added in the Queens- Midtown Tunnel.

title: ANACONDA-ERICSSON TO ACQUIRE CITICORP AXXA OFFICE PRODUCTS
description: Citicorp, which is barred by law from marketing office automation systems it developed primarily for its own use, has sold its office automation subsidiary to Anaconda-Ericsson Inc., a joint venture of the Atlantic Richfield Company and the LM Ericsson Telephone Company of Sweden.

title: Foreign Film Rights Acquired by Warner
description: People outside the United States and Canada will soon be able to watch ''Rocky,'' ''The Pink Panther'' and ''The Raging Bull'' in their homes.

title: PANEL ENDS WORK ON DISCLOSURE ACT
description: A Senate judiciary subcommittee completed work today on legislation that would permit the Attorney General to protect details of Government investigations of organized crime and terrorism, or counterintelligence, from disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Addenda
description: * Better Homes and Gardens magazine increasing its advertising rates 8.25 percent, effective with the April issue.

title: U.S.  POSTPONES ALL PENDING AID
description: The following article is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland.

title: NIXON HELPS NEEDIEST CASES AS A MEMORIAL TO EDITH HEAD
description: A contribution of $1,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has been made by former President Richard M. Nixon in memory of Edith Head, the Academy Award-winning motion picture costume designer who died Oct. 24.

title: BUSY TIMES AT THE F.D.I.C.
description: In a perverse way, this has been a banner year for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Government agency that insures deposits in commercial banks and savings banks.

title: A NEW POLITICAL REALITY
description: Poland under martial law is a tragic reminder of the Soviet system's inability to provide its people with sufficient freedom or sufficient goods, and its consequent dependence upon force.

title: Heavy Rains Follow Snowfall in the City
description: Yesterday afternoon's snow turned into heavy rain last night in New York City, but continued to fall heavily across Rockland County, portions of eastern New York, the Catskills and Connecticut.

title: Heavy Rainfall Forces 1,100 Out of Homes in Puerto Rico
description: Torrential rains forced more than 1,100 people out of their homes and into shelters today, cutting telephone and power lines and virtually isolating neighborhoods struggling with overflowing rivers.

title: UNDAMAGED 3 MILE ISLAND REACTOR GETS RECOMMENDATION FOR TESTING
description: A licensing board of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave conditional approval today for start-up tests at the undamaged twin of the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor in Pennsylvania that went out of control in 1979.

title: TV HIRING PLAN FOUGHT
description: A coalition of 48 religious and civil-rights groups protested today the Federal Communications Commission's plans to consider relaxing some equal employment regulations governing radio and television stations.

title: AVANTE-GARDE: SPACEBOUND
description: HEREWITH, three scenes from a critic's Saturday night out, attending events presented by the downtown ''avant-garde'': SCENE I: A man in a white spacesuit spotted with metallic motorcycle appliques waves a stick in the air and holds an exhaust pipe up to his head. Meanwhile, a woman tap dances on elevated scaffolding; another sways on a swing reading cue cards. The two women also paint brutish faces on clear plastic sheets, fight over a piece of rope, dance around in red plastic helmets and drape across Sony television sets, which converse about their spaceship universe.

title: Boy, 8, Helps Rescue Two in Family in Well
description: An 8-year-old boy helped rescue his mother and 4-year-old brother from the bottom of a 40-foot well. ''I was really scared, but I just kept cool and listened to what my mom told me,'' said Timothy Reagan Jr.

title: 2 on Arizona Death Row Reprieved by U.S. Judge
description: Two convicted killers scheduled to die in the gas chamber Tuesday were granted an indefinite reprieve today. Federal District Judge Carl Muecke ruled that the two, Edward Schad Jr. and Robert Vickers, were covered by his 1980 moratorium on executions unless the state could prove otherwise. Mr. Schad is appealing his conviction and Mr. Vickers says he wants to be executed.

title: NEXUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Plucknett's Life Ban Reduced to 18 Months
description: The International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body of track and field, today reduced to 18 months its bans on Ben Plucknett, the American discus thrower, and Gael Mulhall, a shot-putter from Australia.

title: Talking Business with Robert Anderson of Rockwell; Ready to Go On the B-1B
description: The Rockwell International Corporation received 42 percent of its revenue in its last fiscal year from Federal contracts, and Government business is playing an equally important role again this year. The Pittsburgh-based company is the prime contractor for the space shuttle and the B-1B bomber, whose development has been authorized by the Reagan Administration. Robert Anderson, Rockwell's chairman and chief executive officer, talks about the future of these two multibillion-dollar programs.

title: U.S. BOY, TREATED IN MOSCOW, SAYS HIS SIGHT HAS IMPROVED
description: It was not easy for Todd Cantrell in a distant and cold city where people spoke a strange language. It was not easy without his cat Benji or American hamburgers. Worst of all were the twice-a-day injections into his eyes and hips and the tests to determine if they were helping improve his failing vision.

title: Mr. Jordan, Recognized
description: An editing error confounded our desire to give recognition Saturday to Vernon Jordan's accomplishments as president of the National Urban League. Building on Whitney Young's work to make the League a voice for civil rights issues, he pushed the organization into voter registration drives, tripled the budget to $140 million and expanded and improved its research activities. These include the State of Black America report, now a useful annual assessment.

title: AT THE U.N., CAUTION PREVAILS
description: Official bodies of the United Nations debated a wide array of topics today, including peacekeepers in Cyprus and the rights of women. But none would discuss the imposition of martial law in Poland, an event some diplomats fear may threaten world peace.

title: Limp Progress on Foreign Aid
description: The Reagan Administration deserves some credit for winning House passage of an $11.5 billion foreign aid appropriation, and particularly $725 million for the World Bank's soft-loan window. These compromise sums are far from adequate, however, to support America's wide-ranging objectives around the world.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook Knick Reserves Providing Limited Help
description: The Knicks are getting fewer points from the bottom half of their 12-man roster than most National Basketball Association teams. Mike Newlin, Marvin Webster, Reggie Carter, Larry Demic, Hollis Copeland and Alex Bradley are averaging a combined 25.6 points a game, compared with the 36.8 points that the Atlanta Hawks, the Knicks' opponent tonight, receive from their reserves. The figures are even worse over the last five games, a period in which the reserves combined for an average of only 14 points. Newlin shot 7 for 30 and scored only 14 points in that span. Webster has not played well, and Demic, Copeland and Bradley are getting little playing time. Carter, although he has played well as the reserve playmaker, is not a scorer. General Manager Eddie Donovan, concerned with the problem, has been talking with several teams about acquiring help. ''We have nothing imminent,'' Donovan said yesterday. ''It's very quiet in the marketplace. Nothing seems to be happening. I think that once one team makes a move, it might open things up a bit.'' Actually, the Knicks have little to offer, with Newlin in the worst slump of his 11-season career, and Webster off to a poor start. A possible bright spot could be Toby Knight if he meets his targeted return to the roster by Christmas Day. Knight averaged 16.6 points in 1978-79 and 19.1 the following season before he injured his knee in an exhibition game in September 1980. He has been sidelined since. Richie Adubato, the former Detroit Piston coach who is now scouting for the Atlanta Hawks, wrote in a recent report on Buck Williams, the Nets' 6-foot-8-inch rookie power forward: ''He gets great stats without anyone realizing it. He's all over the boards. Normally, when someone goes from college to the pros, it could be expected his shooting percentage would drop off some, but Buck's shooting continues around his college level. Although his shot is not a pretty one, he almost never takes a shot out of his range. He's much like Cedric Maxwell of the Celtics in that he knows his limitations and stays within them. He scores on a power layup or an offensive rebound, or shoots that 8-10-foot jumper. He takes only good percentage shots.'' Williams, who left the University of Maryland after his junior year, is averaging 15.6 points and 12.3 rebounds, and his shooting average is .565. The Los Angeles Lakers are the only team in the league that has started the same lineup in every game this season - Jamaal Wilkes and Mitch Kupchak, forwards; Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, center, and a backcourt of Norm Nixon and Earvin (Magic) Johnson. The Lakers are 10-2, including five straight victories since Pat Riley replaced Paul Westhead as the coach. Westhead was 8-4. ... In the 959 games Abdul-Jabbar has played since he was the Milwaukee Bucks' top 1969 draft choice, he has has been limited to 10 points or less only four times. The first time he scored under 10 points was in his 508th game, on Jan. 9, 1976, when he got 8 points against the Philadelphia 76ers. He scored 8 points in two other games. The only time he was scoreless was on Oct. 17, 1977, when he ejected from the game in a punching incident with Kent Benson, then playing for the Bucks. Although the Dallas Mavericks are off to a 4-17 start, their plan of building through the college draft offers some encouragement. Mark Aguirre (23.6), Jay Vincent (12.2) and Rolando Blackman (11.9), all 1981 choices, have accounted for 46 percent of the 103.2 points Dallas has averaged. ... Red Auerbach, president and general manager of the Boston Celtics, said of Larry Bird: ''He does things to amaze me in every game, and I don't amaze easily''. ... Kyle Macy, filling in for Walt Davis in the Phoenix Suns' backcourt, is averaging 16.2 points. He is also second in the league in field-goal percentage (.923), third in 3-point baskets (12 for 27) and ninth in steals (2.2 a game). Davis, who fractured an elbow in an exhibitiion game, is almost ready to come back.

title: JUDGE QUESTIONS WHY A LAW IS NEEDED TO TEACH CREATION
description: A Federal district judge hearing testimony on an Arkansas law requiring that ''creation science'' be taught in public schools if evolution is taught, today repeatedly questioned the need for the statute.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON MILITARY APPROPRIATION CEILING
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed tonight on a military appropriations bill for the 1982 fiscal year of about $200 billion, less than $1 billin below President Reagan's budget request last September.

title: Sherwin-Williams Fills Gray Drug Chain Post
description: Two months after the Sherwin-Williams Company, a Cleveland-based manufacturer and retailer of paints and chemicals, acquired Gray Drug Fair, a chain of 358 drugstores, it has named a new president and general manager of the chain, effective Dec. 28. Alvin F. Towle, 44, was appointed president, succeeding Frederick W. Barney, 51, who resigned last week.

title: KELLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BOMBARDIER-MLW LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A RAGING STORM POINTS UP LIMITATIONS IN FORECASTING
description: THIS is already a season of sudden ferocious storms in many regions of the nation. Most storms are predicted with enough accuracy to let citizens, and the authorities, take measures to spare themselves some of the worst effects. But others, like the howling blizzard that struck New England on Dec. 6, are yet beyond the capacity of currently installed technology to announce in advance.

title: IN WRITING 'GROWN UPS' JULES FEIFFER FOUND HE REALLY LIKED HIS PARENTS
description: HAVING drawn hundreds of cartoons about Jewish mothers and sons, having spent ''85 years in psychotherapy,'' Jules Feiffer says he was convinced that he had already come to terms with his family problems. Then, in 1974 his mother died. The day of her funeral, Mr. Feiffer developed bronchitis and a fever of 104, and for the next three months he was unable to continue with a novel he had been working on. He decided that the one way he could go back to work was ''to perform an act of exorcism,'' and he began an autobiographical play - a savagely funny play, which in ripping apart the happy myth of the American family, also expiated his own feelings of love and anger and frustration.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CITY TO USE PITS OF BARBED WIRE IN GRAFFITI WAR
description: In its continuing war against subway graffiti, New York City will provide $22.4 million to build double fences around 18 Transit Authority subway yards, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: BRITAIN FINDS IT CAN'T COPE WITH THE COLD
description: For all the Dickensian images of snow banked against Victorian buildings, entire winters often go by in London now without more than an odd flake settling onto the city's byways.

title: THE WEEKEND THAT COULD
description: WHEN the Giants suddenly needed a center not long ago, they rehired Jim Clack, who had worn No. 56 with distinction for the three previous seasons. But his return created a problem. Lawrence Taylor, the rookie linebacker and the Giants' first-round draft choice, had been issued No. 56 and was wearing it as no other Giant had. The equipment men went to the general manager George Young for a decision.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FURTHER U.S. HELP IS AN ABEYANCE UNTIL POLISH SITUATION IS CLARIFIED
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it was suspending pending aid to Poland, including $100 million worth of feed and food grains, in reaction to the military crackdown on the free trade union movement.

title: G.M. Begins Staff Layoffs
description: The General Motors Corporation, which said earlier that it planned to lay off some 13,000 white-collar employees, or about 7 percent of its worldwide administrative staff, said that some divisions had already pared their staffs and that other employees will get their notices soon.

title: A BIG WEEKEND FOR ANTELOPE WELLS, N.M., POP. 2
description: Normally, Antelope Wells, perhaps the most remote port of entry in the United States, has two residents. Each has a trailer behind the customs station and is employed by the Government to enforce trade and immigration regulations. The number of people entering here averages fewer than three a day.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: 1980 net income per shr for the full yr includes a gain of 40 cents a shr from the sale of an interest in a business unit

title: Falcons Lose, 21-16, to Rams
description: Wendell Tyler ran for two touchdowns, the second with 7 minutes 43 seconds to play, as the Los Angeles Rams defeated the Atlanta Falcons, 21-16, tonight.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: F INALLY it felt like Christmas. There were huge flakes of snow, wet and perishable. The tree in Rockefeller Center was reassuringly bright. Children fogged the window at Steuben on Fifth Avenue as they watched a miniature train pull crystal otter and penguin, mouse, pig and beaver. And fashionable Americans and Europeans mingled and parted on reasonably good terms at a number of dinners where placement seemed to be everything.

title: THE EXPENDABLE PEOPLE
description: Governor Carey and Mayor Koch have come up with New York's version of Calcutta's method for ignoring the homeless people living on city sidewalks: pretend they're not there until a court orders you to act, then fashion temporary warehouses for them in the frigid winter and, when spring comes, they will flee the Dickensian poorhouses for the streets and you can ignore them again.

title: SYRIA CALLS DECISION BY ISRAELIS ON GOLAN 'DECLARATION OF WAR'
description: Syria called the Israeli annexation of the occupied Golan Heights today a ''declaration of war'' and a ''violation of the United Nations charter,'' the state-run Damascus radio said.

title: Wagner 63, Dowling 56
description: Mike Nelson scored 14 of his game-high 18 points in the second half to lead Wagner to a victory at home.

title: REAGAN IS DISPUTED ON A SOLVENCY PLAN FOR BLACK LUNG AID
description: The Reagan Administration said today that its recommended legislation to tighten eligibility for black lung benefits and double the excise tax on coal would make the Federal fund that pays the benefits solvent by 1995.

title: Siemens to Raise Stake in Venture
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation said that Siemens of West Germany, its 50-50 partner in an Atlanta manufacturing concern, would pay $75 million to raise its share in the venture to 85 percent.

title: Alex Is Not Just A 'Dumb' Bird
description: The ability of such birds as parrots and mynahs to mimic bits and pieces of human language is well known. But what few people appreciate, says Irene M. Pepperberg, an ethologist at Purdue University, is their intelligence and ability to actually communicate, not just imitate human language. Dr. Pepperberg has been working with an African gray parrot named Alex.

title: DEBATED BENEFIT IN U.S. PENSIONS IS BACKED TO '82
description: A Senate-House conference committee agreed today to restore the minimum Social Security benefit for all the retired people who now receive it and for those who become eligible before Jan. 1. Both houses of Congress are expected to confirm the action later this week.

title: Rights Group Formed To Stress Iran's Record
description: A group of human rights activists, including former diplomats and lawyers, have formed an organization to publicize charges of human rights violations in Iran.

title: CONDOLENCES FROM POLICE OFFICERS
description: Maureen Faulkner at the funeral for her husband, Daniel, a Philadelphia police officer who was shot to death Wednesday. The police have charged the brother of a man the officer stopped for a traffic violation with murder. Nearly 1,000 mourners attended the funeral.

title: Castles and Fortes
description: The Harvard Lampoon has been accepting women as members since 1972, but until Lisa Henson, a 21-year-old senior, came along, none had made it to the top spot in the 105-year history of the undergraduate humor club and magazine.

title: Index; Crackdown in Poland
description: U.N. debates many things, but Poland isn't one of them A18 Czechoslovak regime backs impo- sition of martial law in Poland A19 West European leaders appeal for restraint in Polish crisis A19 Analysts weigh loyalty of Polish armed forces A20 France's left is split by crack- down in Poland A21 International Sakharov's stepson, one battle won, fights on A2 U.S. says Cuba is an economic as well as a political threat A3 Britons finding they can't cope with the snow and cold A3 Around the World A5 American boy says he sees better after treatment in Moscow A6 Arafat, P.L.O. leader, starts a 3-day official visit to Greece A8 China and India end five days of talks on border dispute A9 Government/Politics Housing agency chief vows to fight proposed cutbacks A27 Hempstead to stop buying insur- ance through designated agent B2 Byrne's nominee to casino panel approved by Jersey Senate B2 Suit seeks prompt payment of de- ferred wages to city workers B8 Supreme Court Roundup B20 Washington Talk Briefing B18 Paula Hawkins has a controver- sial first year in Senate B18 Reagans presenting tree orna- ment to holiday visitors B18 Washington Follow-Up B18 Style Notes on Fashion C7 Spring choices from three design- ers C7 Reviving a London landmark C7 Science Times An unexpected storm illustrates the difficulty of forecasting C1 Biotechnology is no longer a scare word C1 Education: an interview with the new president of City College C1 Science Watch C2 Science Q.&A. C2 About Education: teaching in the electronic revolution C5 Caesarean sections are fewer in New York City's hospitals C6 General Combat photographer wins $125,000 in Time suit A15 Around the Nation A22 Rats attracted to piles of garbage are seen as a health hazard B3 Street peddlers proliferate, and the police give summonses B10 Arts/Entertainment Sam Spiegel to make film of Pint- er's ''Betrayal'' C8 National Book Critics Circle lists award nominees C8 In writing ''Grown Ups,'' Jules Feiffer discovered his parents C9 ''Tomfoolery,'' a revue of Leh- rer's satirical lyrics, staged C9 Jonathan Kaplan's ''Over the Edge'' screened at Public C11 ''Picasso: The Early Years, 1881- 1907'' is reviewed C13 Obituaries Nathaniel Benchley, humorist and novelist B22 Sports Rangers win, 5-4; Beck faces 6-game suspesion for fighting D27 Yanks agree to trade May for McRae, if May approves D27 N.C.A.A. wins television-rights battle with C.F.A. D27 Giants' long-awaited goal is near D27 Fosters spell success on Southern basketball courts D27 Maple Leafs continue effort to trade Sittler D29 No. 1 at stake in women's tour windup event D30 B13 Dave Anderson on the weekend that could D31 Features/Notes Notes on People B15 Going Out Guide C10 Sports People D29 News Analysis Matthew Wald reviews problems of nuclear power B12 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A30

title: WORKS BY REGIONAL THEATERS TO BE SHOWN ON ARTS CABLE
description: Productions of American regional and repertory theaters are to be shown regularly on ABC's cable-television network, Arts, under an arrangement that is being negotiated, a high ABC executive said yesterday.

title: Panel Would Kill Tristate Plan Body
description: The Governors Task Force on the Future of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission has urged the Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to abolish the 10-year-old commission.

title: SCHOOL AID TERMS MAY BE REDEFINED
description: Federal education officials said today that they wanted to redefine ''financial assistance'' in a way that would exempt hundreds of small colleges from civil rights requirements.

title: FEDERAL CUTS INCREASING WORKERS' STRESS LEVELS
description: The holly wreaths and paper Santas are in place as usual along the corridors of the great, gray Federal buildings this Christmas season. But behind the office doors, some strange things are happening.

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: 1981 results exclude foreign currency translation losses of $173,000 for the fourth qr and $1,064,000 for the yr

title: SOVIET BIDS U.S. MIND ITS OWN BUSINESS
description: The Soviet Union used a press commentary today to tell the Reagan Administration that the declaration of martial law in Poland was none of America's business.

title: YE OLDE FETE OF FOODE, DRYNKE & DANSE
description: LAST Saturday evening, at the brownstone manor of Richard the Golden (more familiarly known as Richard Golden) in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, there was a gala medieval fete. The invitations read: '' 'Tis our mete to invite thee to danse and to drynke and ete. Thy presence is most ardently desired, and we ask that if it meets thy favor, ye wille come in Medieval or Renaissance costume attired.'' The assembly of some 40 celebrants was treated to spiced mulled wine and cider, dishes of the period such as meat pies and fruit custards, and a minstrel duo.

title: Ex-NBC Aide Guilty of Tax Evasion
description: A former unit manager for NBC News was convicted yesterday of taxevasion charges in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: GRATITUDE TO U.S. AS A HAVEN INSPIRES GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Memories of those who found refuge in the United States 40 years ago from the terror of Europe continue to inspire contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: F.T.C. Nominee Is Assailed
description: A Senate committee today abruptly ended a hearing on a nomination to the Federal Trade Commission after a Senator asserted that the nominee had lied to the panel.

title: WINE TALK
description: FOR generations of oenophiles, the quality of every succeeding vintage of French, Italian and German wines has been a topic of passionate debate. They know that the wines of each year in each country or region vary in quality according to the weather conditions. One vintage may be far superior to the next, for the weather is the key factor in the ripening of grapes, and European weather is inconsistent.

title: 16 Die as India Train Hits Bus
description: A train smashed into a bus tonight at a crossing 90 miles west of Calcutta, killing 16 people and injuring 20, an Indian railway spokesman reported. All those killed were identified as bus passengers. The accident occurred near the small town of Gokulpur.

title: Market Place; Advice Offered To Thrift Units
description: THE beleaguered savings and loan associations seem likely to continue to lose strength even if interest rates ease somewhat. For decades, the California-based industry leaders made tidy profits in paying depositors 5 percent for their savings while charging homeowners 7 percent for mortgage money.

title: BRIEFING
description: IN some ways, James H. Burnley is the archetype of the Reagan administrator: He has come to Washington from the Republican outlands to close down the Federal agency over which he was appointed director, and he shows a certain enthusiasm for the task.

title: CAPITAL RESTAURANTS: YEAS AND NAYS
description: WASHINGTON IN this city of lobbyists and other assorted pressure groups, it is no surprise to find that restaurants also have their claques. And though all factions might agree that the most fashionable eating scenes are played out in French, Italian and Far Eastern restaurants, opinions differ widely as to which eating place is the best in each category. The conflicting advice presents a frustrating situation to those who care most about eating well and have only a few days in which to do so.

title: The Value of a Life
description: There is a young man who spends his mornings in the lobby of a nursing home. He doesn't know it, because he's in a coma from which he'll never surface, but his nurse wheels him there as she would a baby.

title: LAWYER ASKING CONGRESS TO MAKE HIM A PRIVATEER
