description: A middle-aged local lawyer with a restless spirit, a man who quit the State Department for life outside the pressure cooker, got a whimsical notion last summer to petition Congress for letters of marque and reprisal. He realized, after holding the idea to the light, that he would in effect be asking to be made a licensed pirate, free to rove and legally bound to plunder drug smugglers.

title: THE MOOD AT 96TH STREET IS ANGER AND FRUSTRATION
description: For many New Yorkers, their own two feet and alternative subway and bus routes, along with the usual mixture of resignation and irritation, were the preferred means of coping with the widespread transportation tie-ups caused by yesterday's subway derailment.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HOW COPENHAGEN IS COPING
description: Election morning brought snow, which quickly packed down into slippery ice. Here and there among the avalanche of bicycles sweeping past Parliament, one would skid, pop into the air like a bedspring come loose, and send its rider sprawling.

title: Chad and Its Neighbors' Webs
description: A year ago, troops from neighboring Libya helped Chad's President Goukouni Oueddei consolidate his power. Neighboring Sudan, a target of Libyan subversion, was alarmed. Neighboring Nigeria, sensing Colonel Qaddafi's visions of empire, pressed the Organization of African Unity to protest. France and the United States, with interests of their own, moved to strengthen allies in the region. And last month, President Goukouni seemed to respond to international concerns. He arranged for an African peacekeeping force to come in. The Libyans quickly withdrew, declaring that chaos, not peace, would follow.

title: U.S. FOCUS ON SAUDIS: HOW IT WAS IMPROVISED
description: Although Saudi Arabia has become the centerpiece of the Reagan Administration's approach to the Middle East, several high-ranking officials say the Administration did not plan it that way.

title: CIGARETTES FOUND LOWER IN TAR AND NICOTINE
description: The cigarettes on the market lowest in tar, nicotine and carbon monoxide are Cambridge filters, Carlton filters and Now 100s filters, according to the Government's semiannual rating of cigarettes released today.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The long litany of tales of beer and wine and getting drunk and getting high and burglaries and petty theft and crimes too horrible for them to mention began just after 1 P.M. as the snow began to float slowly past the windows.

title: GIFT LIBRARY WITH 'AN AURA OF ENGLAND'
description: ''IGUESS I was born with an aura of England, after all I do bear the name of Tennyson,'' said Evelyn Tennyson Openhym, which is why Alfred University in upstate New York now possesses a 5,000-volume library of books by and about British authors, about British literature and British social history.

title: HOUSTON, FASTEST GROWING BIG CITY, SHOWING SIGNS OF HAVING HIT PRIME
description: Houston, the fastest rising big city in America in the 1970's, appears to be leveling off at something like a cruising altitude.

title: DEC. 1-10 CAR SALES OFF 27.8%
description: New-car sales by the Big Three domestic auto makers dropped 27.8 percent during the first 10 days of December, as the industry remained mired in the worst sales slump in recent years.

title: CLAUD COCKBURN, BRITISH WRITER AND SOCIAL CRITIC, IS DEAD AT 77
description: Claud Cockburn, a British journalist and social critic whose lively style made him something of a cult figure on the British political left, died yesterday at St. Sinbarr's Hospital in Cork, Ireland. He was 77 years old and lived in Ardmore, Ireland.

title: FYODOROVA, FILM STAR, IS SLAIN
description: Zoya Fyodorova, the Russian actress whose wartime romance with an American navy officer produced a ''love child'' and infuriated Josef Stalin, was shot to death Friday during a robbery at her Moscow apartment, Soviet sources said.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: PROBABLY no other progressive and potentially fatal disease is more often denied than alcoholism. Even members of the alcoholic's family, who may suffer as much as the victim, often fail to recognize or refuse to acknowledge the existence of alcohol abuse by their relative.

title: BURNS, R L, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $545,000 for the latest first qr and $174,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Real Estate; New Office Building In Newark
description: RICHARD WOLFFE'S friends used to laugh when he talked in 1975 about putting up an office building in Newark, and they called his dream ''Dick Wolffe's folly.''

title: BEGIN'S HEIGHTS OF RISK
description: The Begin Government's decision to apply Israeli law to the Golan Heights may ease the Government's internal problems and score a temporary tactical diplomatic gain over Egypt. But it will do so at the cost of breaking up the consensus that has existed in Israel on major national issues and undermining the credibility of Israel's quest for peace. Most dangerously, it well nigh forecloses what may be the most realistic prospect for breaking through the present stalemate toward a settlement that Israel and the principal Arab parties can live with -the prospect of an agreement between Israel and Syria.

title: Antiques Dealer Slain In Greenwich Village
description: A 34-year-old dealer in antiques and old furniture was found shot to death in his Greenwich Village apartment last night, the police said.

title: DEWEY (PIGMEAT) MARKHAM, VAUDVILLE AND TV COMEDIAN
description: Dewey Markham, a comedian who performed on both the black and white vaudeville circuits and was best known for his skit called ''Here comes the judge,'' died Sunday in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx after suffering a massive stroke. He was 77 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Beck Is Suspended Six Games for Fight
description: Barry Beck, the Ranger captain and defenseman, was suspended for the next six games yesterday by the National Hockey League. The suspension was for Beck's having left the bench first during a scuffle between several Rangers and Pittsburgh Penguins in the second period of a game won by the Rangers, 5-4, at Madison Square Garden Monday night. The Rangers were told the suspension would begin with tomorrow night's game here against the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: PALTRY '82 GROWTH FORECAST FOR INDUSTRIAL NATIONS
description: As the American economy slips deeper into recession, and with only an anemic recovery expected in Europe next year, the industrial world appears to be slipping another step down from the high rates of economic growth and prosperity it enjoyed during the 1960's.

title: BUDGET TRUTH
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE FAMILY COURT, THERE IS NO 'CONFUSION' OVER OBJECTIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Business Day article yesterday on video game commercials by Atari and Intellivision incorrectly reported NBC's position. It has asked that the commericials be revised, but has not ordered them off the air.

title: JERSEY UTILITY SEEKS TO DROP NUCLEAR POWER PLANT PROJECT
description: The Public Service Electric Gas Company, New Jersey's largest utility, asked the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for permission to abandon one of two nuclear power plants it is building near Salem, N.J.

title: People
description: * Lew Pringle and John W. Thorne 3d have been elected executive vice presidents of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn Inc., where William D. Badger, John A. Dunning and Ken Rogers have been elected to the board.

title: Armenians Protest in Paris
description: Young Armenian militants occupied the Paris office of Swissair today to protest Switzerland's prosecution of an Armenian accused of attempting to murder a Turkish diplomat. They withdrew after 90 minutes and police did not intervene.

title: L.I.U. 90, Pace 74
description: Russell Davis poured in a career-high 28 points with 14 rebounds as he led Long Island University to victory at the Schwartz Athletic Center in Brooklyn. Pace led at the half, 42-39.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SYRIA DEBATES REPLY TO ISRAEL
description: President Hafez al-Assad conferred with top aides today about Israel's decision to annex the Golan Heights, an area the Israelis seized from the Syrians in the 1967 Middle East war.

title: Doolittle Is Awarded Navy Aviator Wings
description: Lieut. Gen. James H. Doolittle, retired, who led the first American air raid on the Japanese mainland in World War II, has been awarded honorary Navy aviator wings, the Defense Department announced today.

title: May-McRae Trade Is Off
description: A trade that would have sent Rudy May of the Yankees to the Kansas City Royals for Hal McRae will not take place, apparently because the players, both of whom have no-trade clauses in their contracts, vetoed it.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Sept 28, 1981

title: PRELATE IN WASHINGTON URGES U.S. TO SEND POLES FOOD AID
description: Archbishop James A. Hickey of the Washington archdiocese said today that the declaration of martial law in Poland was ''a cause of great concern,'' and he urged the United States to continue to ship food to the nation.

title: PEACE CORP'S SAFE DISTANCE FROM C.I.A., ET AL.
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE BACKS FANNIE MAE AID
description: The House today approved a tax-assistance bill for the Federal National Mortgage Association, a Governmentsponsored private corporation that expects to lose $400 million or more this year and additional sums in 1982 and the first half of 1983.

title: Kuwait Ends Bank Pact
description: The Commercial Bank of Kuwait said today that its 1974 technical service agreement with the Chase Manhattan Bank will expire at the end of this year. Under the agreement, Chase Manhattan, the third-largest American bank, has been providing management services to the Kuwaiti bank, a press release by the Commercial Bank said. The move follows a period of outstanding growth for the Commercial Bank of Kuwait, the release added.

title: One of 3 Officers Freed In Fatal Chicago Beating
description: A judge today acquitted one of three white police officers accused in the beating death of a 51-year-old black man arrested for smoking on an elevated train.

title: World Food Output Up
description: World food and agricultural production climbed to a record in 1981, up nearly 3 percent from the average of the last three years, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: MRS. LLOYD ESCAPES UPSET
description: Victory came easily for Tracy Austin, Andrea Jaeger and Martina Navratilova, but Chris Evert Lloyd needed three sets to subdue Pam Shriver on the opening night of the $250,000 Toyota Series women's tennis championship.

title: Fire Destroys Lagos Ministry
description: The building housing Nigeria's Foreign Ministry was destroyed by fire overnight, and many documents and records were lost. The cause of the fire was believed to be an electrical fault.

title: A WORLD BODY OF BIG SPENDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,460,000 in the qr and $3,539,000 for the yr...C-Net income and after losse from discontinued operations of $112,000 for the qr and $395,00 for the yr

title: SCHOOL BOARD ON L.I. OPPOSES REOPENING OF RECYCLING PLANT
description: The school board in this densely populated community, which lies downwind from the controversial Hempstead recycling plant, demanded today that the plant remain closed.

title: Careers; Helping Students To Decide
description: a so-called mentoring system.

title: ICL Loses $253 Million
description: Britain's biggest computer manufacturer, ICL, today reported a $253 million loss in its latest fiscal year. The loss in the year ended Sept. 30 was in contrast to a $19 million profit in the previous 12 months, the company said. The company did not release fiscal fourth-quarter or per-share results.

title: Loss Reported By Vornado
description: Vornado Inc., which is closing 37 of its 49 Two Guys discount stores, said yesterday that it had lost $20.5 million in its third quarter ended Oct. 31 compared with a loss of $1.2 million in the similar 1980 period.

title: Hobart Ramsey, 90, Is Dead; Served on U.S. Commissions
description: Hobart C. Ramsey, a former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Worthington Corporation, died Monday at his home in Short Hills, N.J. He was 90 years old.

title: BASEBALL STILL NO. 1 GAME TO CARPENTER
description: Ruly Carpenter, who sold the Philadelphia Phillies because of baseball's high operating costs, left the big leagues with spectacular flair the other night: He picked up the tab for 60 of his former colleagues at a $200-a-plate dinner.

title: Fed Names Women As Bank Chairmen
description: The Federal Reserve Board in Washington yesterday appointed its first two women Federal Reserve Bank chairmen. Jean A. Crockett, 62 years old, will serve at the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and Caroline Ahmanson, 63, will serve at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco.

title: POPE EMPHASIZES DOCTRINES ON SEX
description: Pope John Paul II called today for strict enforcement of the traditional doctrine of the Roman Catholic Church on abortion, artificial birth control, divorce and related issues.

title: HARVARD SUSPENDS DOCTOR FOR FRAUD
description: A rapidly rising young doctor at the Harvard Medical School has admitted that he falsified data in a heart research experiment, and the school has instituted a major investigation to decide how to handle the case, according to the school's dean.

title: Ex-C.I.A. Chief Terms Reagan Order Harmful
description: President Reagan's recent order giving the Central Intelligence Agency freer rein to carry on domestic operations will harm rather than help the agency, the man who headed the agency under President Carter testified today.

title: RADIO FREE EUROPE SEES OPPORTUNITY IN THE CRISIS TO BRIGHTEN ITS REPUTATION
description: It was 5 P.M., the time of day when Radio Free Europe broadcasters know they are being heard, the hour when they have what they call ''twilight immunity'' - atmospheric conditions that make their signal next to impossible to jam.

title: ALASKA EXECUTIVE WITH A PIPE DREAM
description: He is not the best-known man in the oil and gas industry. Nor is he, as he puts it with only a hint of a smile, ''the most loved man in the industry.''

title: City Traffic Chief Resigns From Post
description: Thomas J. Guthrie has resigned as New York City's Traffic Commissioner in what City Hall politicians called the first of several changes at the command level of the city's Transportation Department.

title: Petition Spurned On Indian Point
description: A Federal appeals court rejected a petition by a group of scientists and others to review an evacuation plan prepared in case of a nuclear-plant emergency at Indian Point in Buchanan, N.Y.

title: 2 COUNTIES DROP INQUIRIES ABOUT ELECTION IN JERSEY
description: Two county prosecutors in New Jersey said yesterday they had no grounds to file criminal charges over the presence of the National Ballot Security Task Force in polling places in their jurisidictions during the gubernatorial election on Nov. 3.

title: 2 in Jersey Jail Sent to Hospital
description: ELIZABETH (UPI) - Two inmates have been transferred to a state psychiatric hospital after trying to hurt themselves at the Union County Jail, where there have been three suicides and 24 suicide attempts this year, officials say.

title: ISLANDERS DOWN NORDIQUES, 10-7
description: Denis Potvin continued to struggle on defense tonight but he scored two goals, including the deciding one, as the Islanders defeated the Quebec Nordiques, 10-7.

title: CARTING NEGOTIATIONS RESUME WITH A FOCUS ON PRODUCTIVITY
description: Negotiators for the private carting companies and their striking workers returned to the bargaining table yesterday to grapple with critical issues relating to productivity and union concessions.

title: HAWKS TOP KNICKS AS JOHNSON EXCELS
description: For a couple of hours tonight during the game against the Knicks, it was easy for the 5,401 fans at the Omni to remember the good times for Eddie Johnson, the Atlanta Hawks' quick point guard.

title: SOVIET SUCCESS WITH EYE THERAPY IS DOUBTED
description: The reported success of Soviet doctors in treating a blinding eye disease in a child who returned to the United States from Moscow yesterday has aroused skepticism among American doctors familiar with the hereditary disorder and with the Russian therapy.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in Mar 1981; 1981 results include operations of GSE Inc, acquired Dec 1, 1981 on a poolin of interests basis

title: No Regrets
description: After 15 seasons in pro football, Alan Page, the 36-year-old defensive tackle of the Chicago Bears, will retire following this Sunday's season-ending game against Denver.

title: An die Musik Goes On With Last-Minute Help
description: An die Musik, the chamber group, lost one of its players and one of its pieces Sunday afternoon at the Abraham Goodman House. The lastminute substitution of Toby Appel, violist, for the ailing Barbara Hustis, however, did permit the premiere of Jerzy Sapieyevski's Aria for Oboe, Violin, Viola, Cello and Piano to go on.

title: Prices Rise in Light Trading; Treasury Bill Rates Decline
description: Government bond prices rose yesterday, despite a spate of late profit-taking that trimmed the day's best gains. The tax-exempt and corporate debt sectors followed a similar trend, although trading was again extremely light.

title: PROPOSED RESOLUTION ON ISRAEL
description: Following is the text of a draft resolution on Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights that was prepared for Security Council consideration:

title: CLABIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,000 for the qr and $1,255,000 for the 9 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $140,000 for the qr and $3,880,000 for the 9 mos; yr-ago results have been restated for a 5 percent stock divd on Jan 5, 1981 and a 3-for-2 stock split on Mar 16, 1981; results have been restated for the discontinuance of the restaurant and convenience food store segments

title: Colombia Says Troops Killed 4 Rebels in Clash
description: Colombian army patrols killed four guerrillas from a Communist-backed group in a shootout, the Defense Ministry said in a statement today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Inns Inc., an independent operator of Holiday Inns, said it plans to build seven motels at a cost of $51 million in 1982 in the Eastern part of the United States.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE NEW ISOLATIONISTS
description: You can't read the newspapers or listen to the Evening News these days without feeling that something is deeply wrong within the Western alliance.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including minority interest of $680,000; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for compensated absences; yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 5 stock split effected in the form of a 25 percent stock divd to holders of record on Mar 23, 1981

title: DAON DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: The company is also listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouv stock exchanges

title: SHARON VISITS GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon flew to the newly annexed Golan Heights today for a meeting with military commanders amid reports of Syrian troop alerts across the border.

title: A.T.&T. Telectron Bid
description: A.T.& T. International, a wholly owned subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it had proposed to buy 45 percent of the capital stock of Telectron Ltd., an Irish telecommunications company. The purchase price was not disclosed.

title: Mediation Chief Nominated
description: President Reagan has nominated Kenneth Moffett to be director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. Mr. Moffett, 50 years old, would succeed Wayne L. Horvitz. He has been acting director since January.

title: The City Is Picking Up Garbage in Chinatown
description: The mounds of trash along Chinatown's cramped streets are slowly being whittled away, despite the strike by private carting workers. It all began last week when the P. K. Chan, the president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, met with an assistant health commissioner, Charles Reisberg. Mr. Chan suggested assembling a list of Chinese restaurants and businesses desperately needing garbage service.

title: Reagan Signs Pipeline Bill
description: President Reagan today signed special financing legislation for the $43 billion Alaska natural gas pipeline, the world's largest private construction project.

title: A BIG RETAIL GAP IN LOS ANGELES
description: As the big Los Angeles retailers tell it, there is a huge gap in their holiday sales this season. At the top of the line, the goods are moving nicely. Bullock's sold 1,000 men's cashmere sport jackets at $249.99 in one week and 45 women's mink coats at $4,500, also in one week. Neiman Marcus, in Beverly Hills, did strong business in Judith Lieber handbags at $500 each, and Robinson's enjoyed ''very good sales'' in Calvin Klein, Polo and Armani men's clothes, all priced well above the average.

title: TV RATINGS
description: Following are the 15 most popular television shows of the last week (Monday, Dec. 7, to Sunday, Dec. 13) according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the number of households with television sets. Rating Program Network 1 30.2 60 Minutes CBS 2 28.5 Dallas CBS 3 28.3 Burt Reynolds Tribute (S) CBS 4 28.2 Circus of Stars (S) CBS 5 23.7 Monday Night Football ABC 6 22.5 Dukes of Hazzard CBS 7 21.1 Hill Street Blues NBC 8 21.1 Three's Company ABC 9 21.0 Diff'rent Strokes NBC 1 0 20.9 Hart to Hart ABC 1 1 20.7 That's Incredible ABC 1 2 20.1 Falcon Crest CBS 1 3 20.1 Child Bride (S) NBC 1 4 20.0 Real People NBC 1 5 19.9 Love Boat ABC (P)remiere (R)epeat (S)pecial

title: Reagan Aid Defends Detention of Hatians
description: Attorney General William French Smith today defended the Reagan Administration's detention of Haitian refugees, saying: ''Anytime a Haitian being detained wants to walk out the front door, he can do it. As a matter of fact, we'd welcome it, as long as he wants to go home.''

title: Index; International
description: Reporter's Notebook: How Does Copenhagen Cope? A2 Guatemala's high hopes for Rea- gan give way to anger A3 Iraqi President says his nation is ready to end war with Iran A5 Peruvian sworn in as U.N. McMillian a force behind the Alaska gas pipeline A28 Mayor Koch makes, and renews, friendships in the capital A28 Briefing A28 Federal employees experiencing more stress as jobs dwindle A28 General Around the Nation A20 Students learn printing in re- created 19th-century shop B3 Paramedics use bus as ambu- lance for heart attack victim B3 In cramped subway tunnel, work- ers rush to mend tracks B4 Lawyer seeks to be a privateer B7 Psychologist admits perjury B8 The Living Section Food An ideal Christmas feast - Italian-style C1

title: REAGAN DASHES HOPES OF GUATEMALA
description: The euphoria here that followed Ronald Reagan's Presidential victory a year ago has given way to confusion, disappointment and anger.

title: FARMING SMALL
description: Are you seeing more produce stands at the roadside and more farmers' markets? Have you noticed that a fellow worker is ''doing a little farming on the side?'' If so, the Census Bureau commends your powers of observation, because the Bureau too is counting more small farms. We also are counting more farmers who defy an agricultural stereotype: They spend many of their work days in town.

title: COMMON MARKET CAUTIONS MOSCOW
description: The foreign ministers of the 10 Common Market countries today declared their ''profound sympathy for the Polish people in this tense and difficult time'' and implicitly warned the Soviet Union against any intervention in Poland.

title: Carreras to Join Caroling
description: Jose Carreras, Metropolitan Opera tenor, will join choral groups in ''City Singing at Christmas'' at St. Patrick's Cathedral tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. After the choruses sing individually, all present will join in carols and hymns arranged by Dr. Hugh Ross. The public is invited; admission is free.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After provisions for store closings of $17,185,000 for the qr and $20 million for the 9 mos...C-Including tax credits of $1.5 million for the qr and $6.3 million for the 9 mos

title: DELAY SEEN ON ENDING RATE LIMITS
description: Faced with pleas from Congress and the thrift industry for delay, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan will ask postponement of Federal action that could have ended interest rate limits on savings accounts of more than three years' duration, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Credit Accord Signed by AM
description: Financially troubled AM International Inc., a maker of engineering graphics and information processing systems, said it had signed an amended $109 million revolving credit agreement with 20 banks and has resolved its non compliance with certain covenants of the earlier agreement.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1981
description: International The Polish authorities moved quickly to halt strikes and to seize workers defying martial law. A clandestine information service of the Solidarity trade union said large numbers of troops and riot policemen had taken over major factories in Warsaw and other large cities. Sketchy reports in a country plunged into a communications blackout indicated that the authorities were meeting little active resistance. (Page A1, Column 6.) A strong warning to Poland against further acts of repression was issued by the Reagan Administration. The White House said American ''actions will be decided as developments warrant.'' A spokesman declined to elaborate, but officials indicated that stronger economic measures against Warsaw were a possibility. (A1:4-5.)

title: Manhattan Wins, 68-59
description: John Leonard scored 16 points, including 14 in a second-half surge, to lead Manhattan College to a 68-59 victory over St. Francis of Brooklyn at Draddy Gymnasium last night.

title: Mavericks 107, Bullets 102
description: Jay Vincent scored 31 points to help Dallas gain its first road victory of the season after 10 losses. The Mavericks trailed by 59-52 early in the third period, but went ahead, 66-65, with Vincent getting four baskets in the surge.

title: COAL TAX INCREASE IS BACKED IN HOUSE
description: The House today passed and sent to the Senate legislation to double the Federal coal tax in an effort to make up the deficit in the fund providing benefits for miners with black lung disease.

title: Adelphi 95, Pratt 75
description: Buzz Matthews scored 20 points and led Adelphi to a victory at Pratt. Mike Holt netted 19 points and Wayne Bodden netted 12 points to help the well-balanced attack for Adelphi (5-2). Pratt (0-7) was led by Jeffrey Cole, with 26 points, and Izell Cleckley, with 20.

title: New Trading In Eurodollars
description: The Chicago Board of Trade and the New York Futures Exchange were given Government permission today to begin trading in Eurodollar futures contracts.

title: IN THE CAPITAL, KOCH COURTS SOME FRIENDS
description: What does the Mayor of New York City do on a day trip to Washington? Make friends, of course. There are new friends to be made in the White House and there are old friendships to be renewed in Congress, which explains why today Mayor Koch was a very busy man.

title: MET OPERA DRIVE PASSES $54MILLION
description: After 18 months of a four-year drive to obtain a $100 million Centennial Fund endowment, the Metropolitan Opera Association is more than halfway to its goal.

title: 10 ARE HURT, THOUSANDS DELAYED
description: An IRT express train lost a motor and careered off the tracks just south of the Times Square station early yesterday morning, injuring 10 passengers and causing a daylong disruption of subway, bus and traffic patterns for several hundred thousand New Yorkers.

title: Advertising; Chairman At O.& M.  Retiring
description: JOHN ELLIOTT JR., a statesman in the advertising industry, told his fellow workers yesterday that he would be retiring from the chairmanship of Ogilvy & Mather International, the world's fifthlargest agency, early in the new year.

title: PET-FOOD ESTHETICS: A HUMAN CONCERN
description: HOW do we love our dogs and cats? Let the pet-food industry count the ways. We love them enough to spend $4 billion a year to feed them. For, according to market researchers for the pet-food business, we do not regard our pets as mere animals, but as members of the family. With this difference: Researchers found that the woman of the house regards the family dog as a dumb and perpetually immature child.

title: Back to a Small Town
description: For Melvin Van Peebles, the return to Broadway after 10 years is not a return to a city. ''The theater has the old values of a small town where you see people face to face for a long time,'' he said yesterday in the Century Theater where his ''Waltz of the Stork'' begins performances Friday.

title: Macchiarola Asks More School Aid
description: The Board of Education, facing the prospect of declining revenues from the Federal Government, proposed a budget of $3.294 billion for 1982-83 that would require the city and the state to assume a greater fiscal burden in operating New York City's Public Schools.

title: ALABAMA SEEKS TO BLOCK ORDER TO FREE PRISONERS
description: A Federal judge has ordered that 350 state prisoners in Georgia be given early parole next Tuesday because the state had failed to sufficiently reduce overcrowding in its prisons, resulting in a backlog of state prisoners in county facilities.

title: LDB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $747,000 tax credit

title: Bank Board Nominee
description: President Reagan plans to nominate James Jay Jackson, a Port Arthur, Tex., savings and loan executive, to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the White House announced today.

title: Zeal Wins a Pardon
description: Declaring that ''it is impossible to have criminal intent so shortly after a Tiger victory,'' Governor Byrne of New Jersey has granted an official pardon to a Princeton University drum major who led his band on an unauthorized parade following the school's 37-to-14 football victory over Cornell on Nov. 21.

title: CHANGING VOICE PATTERN TO MAKE A POINT
description: On any given day, the appointment book in Dr. Lillian Glass's office might include a mumbling millionaire, an actor such as Dustin Hoffman or a handicapped child.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $59,000 loss from discontinued operations and $1.1 million tax credit...C-After $13,000 loss from discontinued operations and $822,000 tax credit; results for the latest first qr include a gain of 35 cents a shr on the sale of real estate

title: PHILLIPS DISCOVERS GAS OFF IVORY COAST
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that five exploratory wells drilled in the Espoir oilfield off the West African nation of the Ivory Coast had discovered almost entirely gas deposits and little crude oil.

title: Chamber Society Plays Schubert With Repeats
description: Schubert - as everyone knows but few mind - can go on a bit. The String Quartet No. 15 in G (Op. 161), for example, is of massive symphonic proportions (1579 measures).

title: 2-Hour Session Is Held In Geneva Missile Talks
description: United States and Soviet negotiators met again for two hours today to discuss reduction of medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe. No details were given in conformity with a news blackout agreed to by both sides.

title: Turkish Journalist Convicted
description: Nazli Ilicak, a top editorial writer for the right-wing Turkish daily newspaper Tercuman, was convicted of criticizing a court's rulings and was sentenced to nine months in prison, the newspaper reported today. A district court said Mrs. Ilicak ''defamed'' a court in an article she wrote in 1977. An appeals court turned down her plea for a new trial, the newspaper said.

title: C.A.B. Action Upsets Japan
description: A longstanding dispute over aviation rights between Japan and the United States worsened today as Japan said it would file a diplomatic protest against sanctions enacted against Japan Air Lines by the United States Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: James P. Nolan, a Financier Partner in Concern in Capital
description: James P. Nolan, a partner of the investment banking concern of Folger Nolan Fleming Douglas Inc. of Washington, died yesterday at Sibley Hospital in the capital. He was 84 years and lived in Washington.

title: MATSUSHITA IS SUED BY VISUAL SCIENCES OVER TELECOPIERS
description: Visual Sciences Inc., a small Long Island company, has filed suit against the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company contending that the Japanese electronics giant is trying to force it out of a joint venture for marketing facsimile machines.

title: NAVAJOS SAY CUTS IN U.S. AID MAY BRING 'DISASTER'
description: The Navajos, the nation's largest tribe, say that they are facing ''disaster'' as a result of the recession and Federal budget cuts, which are causing widespread unemployment and social problems among Indians across the nation.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated; shr earnings and shr outstndg reflect stock divds paid through Oct 31, 1981

title: Ewbank Says Jets Can Go All the Way
description: Weeb Ewbank sat in the front while the Jets traveled to Cleveland Stadium last Saturday - an old football coach on his thousandth bus ride.

title: Money Scheme Lurks in Baseball
description: ONE of the least appetizing and most probably profitable schemes to attract the baseball intellect since the designated hitter was brought up before the recent convention in Florida and stowed on a shelf until next summer. There it lurks, a menace.

title: EVOLUTION THEORY ATTACKED AT TRIAL
description: Two expert witnesses for the State of Arkansas acknowledged in court today that their approaches to ''creation science'' were basically couched in the tenets of a theory that closely resembles the biblical teachings of the origin of life.

title: NEW COMPUTER FAILS AMTRAK
description: Thousands of travelers were turned away from Amtrak trains because a new computer system erroneously said the trains were full.

title: AN IDEAL CHRISTMAS FEAST-ITALIAN STYLE
description: THERE are few places where Christmas is celebrated more heartily than in Italy. Boisterous and colorful festivals to honor the birth of Christ begin in that country as much as nine weeks before Christmas Day, when shepherds - the zampogniare -come down from the mountains to play Christmas music on their bagpipes, and continue through to the Epiphany, 12 days after, when drivers hang boxes of panettone and nougat on the arms of traffic policemen.

title: Soviet Pipeline Order
description: Creusot-Loire, a diversified French engineering and manufacturing concern, has been awarded a contract valued at 1.3 billion francs, or about $225 million, to supply the Soviet Union with 19 refrigeration stations for use on the pipeline that will carry Soviet gas to Western Europe, the French Foreign Trade Minister, Michel Jobert, said today. He made the announcement at the end of a two-day meeting of the French-Soviet joint commission on economic cooperation here.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SOME DOMESTIC RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS IN POLAND
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts today as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service here:

title: Dow Up 4.47; Amex Off by 4 7/8
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday after having plummeted on Monday in response to the crisis that developed in Poland over the weekend.

title: ISRAEL'S DECISION TO ANNEX GOLAN UPSETS U.S. AIDES
description: The unexpected decision by Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel to annex the Golan Heights drew continued criticism from high United States officials today.

title: A PSYCHOLOGIST ADMITS PERJURY ON HIS DEGREE
description: A psychologist who had been retained as an expert defense witness in two celebrated criminal trials pleaded guilty yesterday to lying under oath about his professional credentials.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 16, 1981; The Economy
description: Sales by the Big Three domestic auto makers fell 27.8 percent during the first 10 days of December. Ford's sales fell 37.7 percent, General Motors' sales slid 26.4 percent and Chrysler's fell 14.6 percent. (Page D1.)

title: Afghanistan's President Arrives in Moscow
description: Babrak Karmal, the President of Afghanistan, arrived in Moscow today, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE most logical manner in which to plan a meal is, of course, to start out with a consideration of the main dish -fish, poultry or meat. Once that is established, one can decide on accompaniments that will complement and enhance the focal point of the meal.

title: MILITARY'S OUTLAY VOTED IN CONGRESS
description: As Congress moved rapidly toward the end of its 1981 session today, both chambers approved a compromise bill appropriating almost $200 billion for the military in the current fiscal year.

title: MUSIC: MICHAEL PARLOFF, FLUTE, PRESIDES OVER AN ENSEMBLE
description: A FLUTE program need not be a collection of baubles and bagatelles. Done well, it can be a satisfying multicourse musical meal in which contrasting styles are harmoniously served up and sampled with delight.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: LIFE is full of small irritations - taxi riders who start digging into pocket or handbag only after the cab has stopped at their destination, gum smackers at the movies, or anywhere for that matter, subway and bus passengers who block doors - the list is endless. But usually the offenders are strangers and little can be done other than withering looks and, in extreme cases, nasty remarks and the occasional poke in the ribs.

title: Appeal for Andretti
description: Mario Andretti, as angry as ever over the United States Auto Club's decision to restore Bobby Unser as the winner of last spring's Indianapolis 500 and place Andretti second, was granted an appeal hearing by the Automobile Competition Committee for the United States.

title: REAGAN SIGNS STOPGAP REOLUTION FOR U.S. SPENDING THROUGH MARCH
description: President Reagan today signed into law a $413 billion omnibus resolution to finance the Government through March 31, declaring that his action was ''another significant step'' toward economic recovery.

title: Bridge: Board-a-Match Play Held The Game's Most Exciting
description: Many experts feel that the most exciting form of the game is board-a-match teams, which has been abandoned on all but a few major occasions. The bidding and play of every deal is totally tense, with none of the relaxation possible in other forms of team play or in rubber bridge when the contract is assured.

title: U.S. WARNS AGAINST VIOLENCE
description: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: ASSAILS DISPARITIES IN WEALTH
description: Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru was sworn in as Secretary General today and called the gap in wealth between rich nations and poor a breach of ''the most fundamental human rights.''

title: Arrest in Threat to Charles
description: A 33-year-old man has been charged with threatening the life of Prince Charles in a letter sent to a London company, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says. Billy J. Nabers of Bakersfield was arrested Monday on a charge of stating in a letter that he had hired an assassin to kill Charles. The letter was sent after Mr. Nabers failed to receive some books he had ordered from the company.

title: Blast Kills Bogota Bomber
description: A woman was killed Monday night when a bomb she was about to place outside a police station here exploded in her hands, the police said today. A man accompanying her was injured by the blast, they added.

title: Steel Output in U.S. Up
description: Steel production rose to 1.831 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 1.820 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Brand, Pianist, Offers 2d in Schumann Series
description: Natan Brand, the pianist, gave the second in his series of Schumann recitals at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening. He played the ''Nachtstucke'' (Op. 23) and ''Carnaval'' as a soloist and joined Yuval Waldman and Lorne Munroe in the F major Trio (Op. 80) for piano, violin and cello.

title: POLAND CLOSES ITS AIRSPACE TO THE WEST
description: Poland closed its airspace to overflights by Western planes Tuesday and remained cut off from outside visitors, with the exception of diplomats allowed to enter by road.

title: Economic Scene; Rich and Poor In U.S. Today
description: A RECENT article in a business publication reported that magazines catering to the affluent have never done better. Town & Country, Vogue and Architectural Digest, whose average subscriber has an annual income of more than $100,000, are bulging with advertising. As Vogue's publisher described the trend, ''Manufacturers and distributors have come to realize that the people they have to talk to are the people with money.''

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Smith Deal In Doubt Ed Gottlieb, the agent for Ozzie Smith, said that Smith would reject even $1 million if the San Diego Padres offered it in an effort to get him to waive the no-trade clause in his contract. That would seem to make unlikely the widely expected trade sending Smith to the St. Louis Cardinals foranother star shortstop, Garry Templeton.

title: Conservatives' Suit Charges Commercials Were Blocked
description: The National Conservative Political Action Committee filed a $5 million lawsuit today against seven liberal members of Congress and 13 television stations that refused to air its commercials.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is a black day. We are occupied, and we are part of the Arab nation.''

title: Dith Pran Trash Fire Forces Evacuation of 1,000 People at Pennsylvania Station
description: Firemen shed their equipment as they took a break in the still smoky waiting room at Pennsylvania Station after putting out a fire in a sub-basement. The fire, which started in a pile of trash stored below track level because of the garbage strike, sent smoke billowing through the station. About 1,000 people were evacuated.

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $62,010 or 5 cents a shr gain from disposition of real estate and mortgages...C-Including $2,343,695 or $1.99 a shr gain from disposition of real estate and mortgages

title: AUTO EXECUTIVES ASK EMISSION CURB
description: Top executives of the leading automobile companies lobbied today to persuade Congress to act quickly to relax standards of the Clean Air Act that apply to tailpipe emissions.

title: CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
PROTESTS OVER POLICE AT ITS EMBASSY
description: The Reagan Administration issued a strong warning to Poland today against further acts of repression. ''The use of violence against the Polish people by the Government would have extremely grave consequences,'' said Larry Speakes, the White House deputy press secretary. ''Our actions will be decided as developments warrant.''

title: SECURITY COUNCIL TO DEBATE THE GOLAN ANNEXATION
description: The Security Council is scheduled to begin debate on Wednesday of a Syrian draft resolution calling Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights illegal but not condemning the Israelis for their action.

title: CITY ORDERED TO PAY $6.6 MILLION IN BLAST FATAL TO PARENTS OF 3
description: A Manhattan jury has ordered the city to pay $6.6 million to three children whose parents were killed during a gas explosion 11 years ago.

title: REAGAN SAID TO CONSIDER SAVING ENERGY DEPT.
description: The Reagan Administration appeared tonight to be on the verge of dropping a plan that would formally abolish the Department of Energy and transfer its remaining functions to other elements of the Government.

title: Fouts and Two Raiders Threatened With Ban
description: Dan Fouts, the San Diego Chargers' quarterback, and two members of the Oakland Raiders must pay union dues to the National Football League Players Association or be suspended from the final game of the season, the players' union said today.

title: Mistrial Declared After TV Program
description: A monthlong trial of 11 persons accused of being members of an international heroin-smuggling ring abruptly ended in a mistrial yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. SEES EUROPEAN STEEL CONCESSIONS
description: American trade officials said today that the European Common Market expects to make concessions to the United States on exports of steel in the hope of warding off threatened antidumping action by American steel companies.

title: KIRSTEIN GETS FRANKLIN MEDAL FROM ROYAL SOCIETY OF ARTS
description: Lincoln Kirstein, general director of the New York City Ballet Company, was awarded the Benjamin Franklin Medal of the Royal Society of Arts on Monday for ''forwarding the cause of Anglo-American understanding.'' The presentation was made by Prince Philip at a dinner in Society House, just off the Strand.

title: End of Curfew Recommended By South Korean Parliament
description: The National Assembly voted unanimously today to end the curfew imposed at the end of World War II.

title: FORT DRUM'S USE AS REFUGEE UNIT DELAYED BY U.S.
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had delayed its decision to use Fort Drum, in upstate New York, as a detention facility for illegal Haitian and Cuban refugees.

title: Scalping Brings Ban
description: Jackie Sherrill, Pitt's football coach, yesterday suspended one of his assistants for a month without pay for having engaged in a scalping scheme involving tickets to the Sugar Bowl, where Pitt is to play Georgia on Jan. 1. Ironically, the suspension means that the assistant, George Pugh, who coaches the tight ends, will himself not be going to the bowl game.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Rossman Arrested
description: Mike Rossman, former light-heavyweight champion of the World Boxing Association, was arrested in Atlantic City early yesterday on charges of attacking two policemen who had stopped his car to give him a speeding ticket. The police also charged him with marijuana possession and possession of a dangerous weapon, a blackjack. Rossman, who last boxed in May, when he was knocked out by Dwight Braxton, was released in his own recognizance.

title: IRAQ AGAIN OFFERS IRAN A TRUCE
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said today that his country was ready to end the 15-month-old war with Iran if the Iranians agreed to recognize Iraq's borders.

title: MITSUBISHI SEEKING EXXON OPTICAL UNIT
description: Mitsubishi Chemical Industries Ltd., Japan's largest chemical company, said yesterday that it would enter the fledgling optoelectronics field by acquiring the Exxon Corporation's Optical Information Systems unit, one of several such concerns Exxon established in the last decade in a bid to exploit space-age communications technology.

title: President Is Elected At AMF Inc.
description: William P. Sovey, 48, has been elected president and chief operating officer of AMF Inc., effective next March 1. He will succeed Ray A. Tritten, who will retire, at the age of 63, from the diversified company, which is based in White Plains.

title: FOR MANY IN GOLAN HEIGHTS, 'IT IS A BLACK DAY'
description: Having demonstrated its political skills Monday night in Jerusalem, the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin now faces a more difficult political challenge in the newly annexed Golan Heights, and one much less sure of swift success - winning the acquiescence of the Arab Druse inhabitants to the incorporation of their territory into Israel.

title: Miami Street Vendors Told to Keep Moving
description: It isn't onions that bring tears to the eyes of a Miami hot dog vendor, but the requirement that he keep his cart moving.

title: GANNETT PLANS NATIONAL PAPER
description: The Gannett Company, which owns and operates the nation's largest chain of daily newspapers, said today that it would begin a nationwide morning newspaper next fall.

title: BOMB WRECKS IRAQI EMBASSY IN BEIRUT
description: The four-story building after the blast. Twenty persons were reported killed and about 100 injured.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of America has named James R. Robinson senior vice president and head of institutional banking of BankAmerica International New York.

title: Gunman Assaulting Woman Slain by Officers, Police Say
description: Two uniformed police officers shot and killed a gunman who was attempting to sexually assault a 66-year-old woman in the parking lot of a gasoline station in Elmhurst, Queens, according to the police.

title: Jordan, Case & McGrath Offers Marketing Study
description: Did you know that half this country's population is over 55 years of age? About 46 million people? More than all of the kids in grammar and high schools? Well you do now, and it is brought to you courtesy of Jordan, Case & McGrath, whose Norman Goldstein, director of marketing services, supervised the preparation of a six-page brochure on the subject of our crowd entitled, ''The 55+ Market: The Marketing Opportunity of the 1980's.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A sampler of writing published alongside the obituary of Nathaniel Benchley yesterday included two pas- sages erroneously. The second and third passages were by his father, Robert Benchley, and were included by Nathaniel in a book of his favorites, ''The Benchley Roundup'' (Harper & Row; copyright c 1954 Nathaniel Benchley). The first passage, from ''The Off-Islanders,'' was by Nathan- iel Benchley.

title: Q&A
description: Q. After giving a couple of festive fall dinners, I now have several large jars of duck fat and goose fat on hand. How long will they keep and to what use can they best be put?

title: MCI TO GO GLOBAL BY BUYING WUI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, a fastgaining competitor in the domestic long-distance telephone service market, today announced an agreement with the Xerox Corporation to buy its WUI Inc. for $185 million, thus moving into the worldwide market.

title: Israel Reports 91.6% Inflation In the First 11 Months of '81
description: Inflation was 91.6 percent in the first 11 months of this year, the Central Bureau of Statistics announced today.

title: SALVADOR LAND PLAN: KEY STAGE
description: The Salvadoran land redistribution program is at a critical stage, and its outcome will affect the course of political development in El Salvador, according to a privately funded study group that has just returned from a visit to that country.

title: WHEN A RECOVERED ALCOHOLIC SEEKS A CITY JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: Guidry Gets 5-Year, $4 Million Contract
description: Ron Guidry, who began his yearlong negotiations by saying he wanted to remain a Yankee, got his wish yesterday when he signed a five-year contract worth $4 to $5 million.

title: Orion Wants Filmways Link
description: The Orion Pictures Corporation, seeking its own distribution arm after an association with Warner Communications, said it had begun negotiations to acquire an interest in Filmways Inc.

title: AVON SETS $750 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: Avon Products, the world's largest manufacturer of cosmetics and fragrances, and Mallinckrodt Inc., a St. Louis-based company with major interests in health-care products, chemicals, flavors and fragrances, announced jointly yesterday that they had signed a merger agreement providing for Avon to acquire Mallinckrodt for $750 million in cash and stock.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt EASY TRAVEL TO OTHER PLANETS. By Ted Mooney. 278 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95.

title: RUFFS, RAINWEAR AND RED BAGS; 1. Chic Around the Collar
description: Need a quick change from office suit to dinner outfit? Just add a ruff. A very pretty one made of black organza shot with silver or gold simply ties on around the neck and could transform even a black sweater into a festive top. The collar can be tied in back or in front and could be worn instead of jewelry with a strapless black dress. The ruff collar is $25 at James T. Clarke, 971 Lexington Avenue (between 70th and 71st Streets). 2. Traveling Rain Gear The sportsman or the commuter who has to catch the 8:22 in the pouring rain should appreciate a new rain parka. Hunting World has an excellent one, in khaki rainproofed nylon, that has a number of special features. For one thing, its length is adjustable with Velcro fastenings at the hem. The front has two large zippers so it can be opened either at the neck or the bottom and the zippers are covered by a flap so rain doesn't leak through. The pocket flaps, too, fasten with Velcro. The parka is $165; matching pants with zippers to adjust the leg width so they can be pulled over shoes are $90. The shop also has a snappy all-weather hat made of rabbit-fur felt, for both men and women, at $85. Hunting World is at 16 East 53d Street.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE cold weather in Florida over the past 10 days will mean higher vegetable prices in the next week. Green beans, cabbage, celery, cucumbers, eggplant, endive, escarole, zucchini and green peppers will all be affected.

title: EX-PUERTO RICO AIDE HAD VARIED INTERESTS
description: Fernando Chardon, former Secretary of State for Puerto Rico, died of a cerebral hemmorage last Wednesday at the Ashford Memorial Hospital in San Juan, P.R. He was 74 years old.

title: HUNT FOR STOLEN POLICE CARS FAILS TO RECOVER ANY SO FAR
description: After a search that began at midnight Monday and continued through the day yesterday, the Police Department said it had not recovered any of seven unmarked city and Federal police cars that were stolen in New York City this year.

title: WARSAW LISTS 27 DETAINED FORMER OFFICIALS
description: The Warsaw radio today named 27 former Government and party leaders that Poland's military Government ordered detained Sunday when martial law was delcared.

title: British Labor Party Appoints Ex-Arbitrator to Key Position
description: The opposition Labor Party, torn by dissension between its left and right wings and losing supporters to the Social Democratic Party, appointed a new general secretary today.

title: CITY TO INCREASE TRASH PICKUPS IF STRIKE CONTINUES
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city would nearly double its pickups of accumulated garbage today if there was no settlement in the 16-day-old strike against New York's private carting companies.

title: MET OPERA: ZEFFIRELLI'S NEW 'BOHEME'
description: The new production of ''La Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera Monday night was a gift for the old guard - for Met conservatives disgruntled by the carefully modernist line taken by the new Met in its repertory and production style. This Franco Zeffirelli ''Boheme'' - he both directed and designed it - is a production for people who come wanting to applaud the scenery. And applaud it they did, throwing in bravos to boot.

title: Michigan County Court Orders Busing Resumed
description: A judge today ordered resumption of student busing in the Alpena school district, which had halted it for lack of money.

title: BUS USED AS AMBULANCE FOR HEART ATTACK VICTIM
description: Two paramedics of the Emergency Medical Service rushed aboard a crowded city bus in Queens yesterday morning and revived a heart attack victim who was ''clinically dead.'' Then, with the help of the police and the driver, they took over the bus and went to the nearest hospital.

title: IN ITALY, FASHIONS KEEP EYE ON CRIME
description: ROME The latest elegant novelty offered by Italy's fashion accessories industry is a piece of ultrathin leather that runs from shoulder to elbow and is worn under the sleeve of a dress or suit to conceal from robbers small items such as house keys, money for a cab, an identification document or even a diamond ring.

title: AT THE FAMILY COURT, THERE IS NO 'CONFUSION' OVER OBJECTIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: New Illinois Tool Chief
description: John D. Nichols, the 51-year-old president of the Illinois Tool Works, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective Jan.1. He will succeed Silas S. Cathcart, 55, who will continue as chairman of the Chicago manufacturer of engineered products.

title: Khomeini Halts Appearances To Observe Mourning Period
description: Iran's revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, has canceled all his public appearances for 1O days, starting Thursday, the Teheran radio said.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Labor Leaders Launch a Fast In Bolivia Over Union Rights
description: Several union leaders have begun hunger strikes in two Bolivian cities to press demands for the restoration of union freedoms in Bolivia, labor sources said today.

title: A WEEKEND OF BUILDING SELF-CONFIDENCE
description: WHAT I was doing standing over a vat of powdered soybeans in the woods - in the cold, in the dark - was trying to remember who I was. Not that I had forgotten. But family illness and other pressures had sapped my usually energetic spirits, and at a friend's suggestion I was spending a weekend ''away from it all'' in the wilds of North Carolina with Outward Bound.

title: Teen-Ager Guilty In Attempted Rape
description: A Queens teen-ager was convicted of trying to rape a 13-year-old neighbor.

title: Artist Bernie Fuchs Illustrates for B.& B.
description: Bernie Fuchs, the sports artist known well to the readers of Sports Illustrated, has been signed up by Benton & Bowles to illustrate a corporate campaign for the leisure-time activities subsidiaries of its client, AMF Inc.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in Apr 1981

title: BOEING AND AIRBUS SELL 14 JETS TO SINGAPORE LINE
description: In a major aircraft sale, Singapore Airlines, a state-owned carrier, signed contracts yesterday totaling $1.56 billion to purchase eight Boeing 747 jumbo jets and six of the smaller Europeanmade A-300's over a five-year period.

title: AT PRINTING SHOP, A VINTAGE LESSON
description: ''Here comes the great moment,'' said 12-year-old Miles Arnone with a hold-your-breath grin. He moved to the 1844 Albion hand press, ready to ink the type he had just handset in a compositor's stick for his first personal Christmas card.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: JOGGING in Riverside Park, I've seen a mother on roller skates pushing a pram, a juggler keeping what looked like four shrunken heads in the air, a midget coiffing a poodle, a Chinese middleweight jabbing a punching bag suspended from a cherry tree, a redhead walking a snow-white skunk on a leash, a blind jogger clutching a string held by his companion .... The only thing that upset me happened the other day when a fellow runner came up from behind and said, ''Nice morning.''

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to place figures on a LIFO basis

title: Persistent Cameraman
description: In 1975, a Federal judge ordered a persistent photographer to keep his distance from Caroline Kennedy and her mother, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, after they complained of being bothered excessively. The judge said the photographer, Ronald Galella, could not come within 30 feet of Miss Kennedy and 25 feet of her mother.

title: A Carey License Suspended
description: Governor Carey's second-oldest son was fined $250 today and had his license suspended for 90 days after pleading guilty to a charge of driving while impaired. The penalty was imposed on the son, 28-year-old Michael Carey, by Judge Thomas Keegan in Albany Police Court. Mr. Carey had originally been charged with driving while intoxicated and failure to keep right, a charge that was dismissed.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: 'TIS the season to be jolly, but how jolly can one be when the airwaves are glutted with ersatz Christmas cheer? Pop music has never been short on sentimentality, but at Christmas time even the mildest ironies get swept under the table along with the odd pine needle; utter treacle prevails. Rock-and-roll fans may kid themselves into thinking they are above it all, but listen to any FM rock station at Christmas time and you will discover otherwise. From Bobby Helms's ''Jungle Bell Rock'' in the 50's to Bruce Springsteen's ''Santa Claus Is Coming to Town'' in the 80's, rock artists have been responsible for some of the direst, most pernicious Christmas records of all time - pernicious because they actually sound cute the first time around and reveal their true colors only after the disk jockeys have repeatedly bludgeoned listeners with them.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1981

title: TV MOVIE: A SECRETARY'S QUANDARY
description: ''LET'S hear it for the secretaries,'' somebody must have shouted one day over at CBS-TV, and the idealized result is ''Isabel's Choice,'' which can be seen on the network tonight at 9 o'clock. A good many women, who supposedly constitute the majority of the audience for television movies, should enjoy watching some of their fantasies brought to living-color life.

title: Low Politics on the Golan Heights
description: There are strong historical and military arguments for Israel's occupation of the Golan Heights, the barren cliffs that were once used to terrorize the northern Galilee. They would certainly support Israel's claim to some of that terrain if Syria ever finds the desire to negotiate peace. But there is no compelling reason of security for Israel to annex the region now, or to do so with haste and disdain. Israel's diplomacy does not profit from such gratuitous acts.

title: STONEWARE PANS
description: WHEN publishers want to get even with authors, they send them out on book promotion tours on which they can wilt publicly everywhere from Dallas to Detroit. It was while wilting in Seattle not too long ago that I met an artisan who raised my spirits with some wonderful stoneware produced in her own large kiln.

title: IN CRAMPED TUNNEL, WORKERS RUSH TO MEND TRACK
description: In the Seventh Avenue tunnel south of Times Square, scores of men in orange vests and yellow or white helmets labored with jacks, air bags and timbers yesterday to lift two 20-ton subway cars and get their 10-ton truck assemblies back in place.

title: Kean Picks Press Secretary
description: Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean has named Carl Golden of Willingboro, his news secretary during the campaign, to be his press secretary in the incoming administration, it was announced today. Mr. Golden, who is 44 years old, has 15 years' experience in public relations and 11 years as a newspaper reporter.

title: Regulators Cited in Futures Report
description: The failure of Federal regulators to share information or react quickly enough permitted speculators in silver to build large holdings and drive up market prices for the metal during 1979 and early 1980, according to a Congressional report released today.

title: Trials of Ex-President
description: Jimmy Carter says that unless Georgia officials can resolve a dispute over a proposed access highway he may not build his Presidential library in Atlanta.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a 10 percent stock divd i

title: No Headline
description: F. Stephen Larrabee's article, ''Trust Ankara,'' on Tuesday's page, said the military probably would return democracy to Turkey in ''another seven years.'' It should have said ''several years.''

title: U.S. TO TRAIN 1,500 SALVADORAN SOLDIERS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it planned to train a battalion of 1,000 Salvadoran soldiers and a group of 500 to 600 Salvadoran junior officers, probably in the United States.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jack Gaver resigned as head trainer for Greentree Farm, saying that John Hay Whitney, the stable's owner, was no longer devoting daily attention to the operation and that Whitney's staff did not have the expertise to give a chief trainer prompt and proper guidance. ... Mark Aguirre of the Dallas Mavericks, pro basketball's No. 1 draft pick last spring, underwent surgery to have a screw inserted into a broken bone in his right foot. Initially expected to miss a month of play, Aguirre is now not due back for two months.

title: 'GHOST STORY' TELLS OF 50-YEAR-OLD MYSTERY
description: ALMOST anyone - film makers as well as imaginative 6-year-old children - can get a ghost story off to a good, creepy start that prompts the listener to ask, ''And then what happened?'' The difficulty is in keeping the suspense building, the complications multiplying until, in two or three or four swift strokes, the mystery is resolved, if not necessarily revealed.

title: PEACE CORP'S SAFE DISTANCE FROM C.I.A., ET AL.
description: To the Editor:

title: SIX FEET HIGH AND RISING
description: My friend Winokur came into New York from Iowa the other day and phoned for help from the corner saloon. Said he couldn't scale the barricade of garbage between his taxi and my front door.

title: KURALT TO BE REPLACED ON 'MORNING'
description: Bill Kurtis, one of the most successful and highly paid local anchors in the country, will replace Charles Kuralt as co-anchor with Diane Sawyer on CBS News' ''Morning'' beginning in March, CBS announced yesterday.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: The state Supreme Court today struck down legislation providing $348 million in state aid to cities and towns that were squeezed by the Massachusetts tax-cutting referendum.

title: PASSAIC'S CAPITOL, 10 ROCKING YEARS
description: THE Capitol Theater, a faded film and vaudeville house in Passaic, N.J., is an unlikely rock mecca. But the promotor John Scher staged his first rock concert there 10 years ago, and Mr. Scher and the Capitol have prospered while the Fillmore East folded, the Paladium on 14th Street shut and reopened, and other rock theaters in the area came and went even more precipitously. Tonight, Mr. Scher is presenting a 10th-anniversary concert at the Capitol that will feature the Allman Brothers Band, Gary U.S. Bonds, Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes, Dave Edmunds, and Jack Bruce, along with many surprise guests.

title: U.S. Sues Yonkers On Public Housing
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Government has decided to continue a suit originally filed by the Carter Administration charging the City of Yonkers with housing discrimination.

title: Court Denies U.S. Steel Plea
description: A Federal appeals court denied a request by the United States Steel Corporation that it lift an order preventing the steel company from buying Marathon Oil Company stock.

title: Moving Mountains - of Garbage
description: Like the kitchen middens of a dead civilization, mounds of 20thcentury garbage have risen on street corners in New York's commercial neighborhoods. At first they seemed merely curiosities; now they are foreboding.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STEP BY STEP

title: 21 California Republicans Ask Judges to Reapportion State
description: The state's 21-member Republican Congressional delegation has asked a panel of Federal judges to reapportion the state's Congressional districts for the 1982 elections.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Traded Larry W olfe, first baseman, to Milwaukee for Gil K ubski, outfielder. NEW YORK (AL) - Re-signed Ron G uidry, free-agent pitcher, to multiyear c ontract.

title: Cable Executives Question Research
description: The people at the top of the cable television industry have asked for a hiatus in audience research accumulated by the diary-keeping method because ''the present method of reporting cable viewing is clearly inadequate and discriminatory to the cable industry.''
To the Editor:

title: A Top Executive Adds Title at Dayton-Hudson
description: Kenneth A. Macke, the 43-year-old president of the Dayton-Hudson Corporation, the country's eighth-largest retailer, will add the title of chief operating officer on Jan. 1. At the same time, Aldo Papone, 49, who joined the Minneapolis-based company a year and a half ago as executive vice president, will be named vice chairman and group officer.

title: Women in Science
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Though I cannot presume to understand K.C. Cole's situation of being a middle-aged woman involved in the male-dominated discipline of physics (''Hers,'' Dec. 3), I can soundly disagree with her insights as they are applied to my generation. Regarding her daughter's inability to cope with freshman calculus at Harvard, instead of blaming her daughter's failures on, perhaps, her very normal difficulties in adjusting to a new school, Miss Cole portrays her daughter as a victim of a male-dominated academic society.

title: THE BALLET: 'WILD BOY' IN PREMIERE
description: Kenneth MacMillan's ''The Wild Boy,'' with Mikhail Baryshnikov and Natalia Makarova, is a highly provocative ballet that will send tongues wagging for the wrong reason.

title: UNARMED POLICEMAN KILLED BY ROBBERS IN FRONT OF WIFE
description: An unarmed and off-duty New York City police officer was shot and killed last night as he foiled a robbery in the driveway of his father-in-law's home in Queens, while the officer's wife watched from a nearby stairway, the police said.

title: PERMITS FALL AGAIN
description: Housing starts rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the first monthly rise since July, to an annual rate of 871,000 units, a rate that still is one of the worst on record. The increase reflected a hefty increase in single-family home starts.

title: 7 DISSIDENTS REPORTEDLY UNDER ARREST IN CHILE
description: Three members of the Chilean Human Rights Commission and at least four other dissidents have been arrested by security agents in Santiago, human rights officials reported today.

title: Afghan Award to Brezhnev
description: President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan, who arrived here yesterday, today presented his country's Sun of Freedom order to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in a Kremlin ceremony. Mr. Karmal later left by air for an undisclosed destination.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: Most wallcoverings can only be hung on relatively smooth walls that have few, if any, irregularities because even small bumps, cracks, and rough spots that are not smoothed out or filled in will show through on the finished job after the material is up. Now, however, there is a cushion-backed vinyl wallcovering available that can be put up over rough or irregular interior ''problem'' walls without having the irregularities in that wall show through on the finished surface. The cushion backing not only enables this vinyl material to bridge defects and cover rough spots, it also helps to absorb noise and even adds a certain amount of thermal insulation to that wall. Called Paris Wall, and distributed in this country (it is made in France) by Forbo North America, Inc., 218 W. Orange Street, Lancaster, Pa. 17603, it is sold through home centers and building supply outlets and has an embossed three-dimensional surface finish with a clear coating that makes it highly resistant to staining and exceptionally easy to clean. Suitable for use over such previously impossible-to-cover wall surfaces as cinder block, ceramic tile, grooved wood paneling and cracked plaster or drywall, Paris Wall is waterproof and fire resistant (it has a Class A fire rating), so it is particularly useful for renovating kitchen, bathroom and laundry room walls - as well as hallways, playrooms and similar areas which get hard wear. It can even be used inside bathroom tub/shower enclosures since water won't harm it (as long as seams are properly cemented down so water can't run behind it). In the kitchen you can use it on the backsplash area behind the stove or around the sink to create a soilresistant, easily cleaned surface that will withstand the hard wear these work areas are subject to. In addition, both Paris Wall and the special adhesive used to put it up are highly resistant to mildew, so there is no need to worry about installing it in places where frequent dampness can often cause problems with other wallcoverings. The material comes in rolls that measure 31-1/2 inches wide and 9-1/2 feet long - enough to cover about 20 square feet of wall area when you allow for the normal amount of waste. It sells for between $20 and $23 per roll (the easiest way to determine the number of rolls needed is to measure the area to be covered, then divide by 20). The special adhesive required will cover about 40 to 50 square feet per quart, so you will need about one quart of adhesive for every two rolls of material being hung. Seven patterns are available, in a total of 18 different colors or shades: there is a brick pattern that comes in four different colors, a floral design that looks like hand-painted tiles that also comes in four colors, three colors of a small hexagonal-shaped tile design, three pastel shades of a leaf pattern on random size rectangles, two shades of a semi-solid texture design, a tan colored cork design, and a tan-and-white design that looks like cane. The edges of each roll are factory trimmed, so strips can be neatly butted together as they are installed - the only trimming required is along the top and bottom of the wall. With normal care in installation, the seams will be almost invisible when the job is done, and since the adhesive is applied to the wall, rather than to the back of the wallcovering, putting the material up is in many ways even easier than putting up regular wallcoverings. You don't have fold or handle paste-covered long strips that tend to stick to everything they touch. Before hanging any wallcovering - including Paris Wall - all wax, dirt, dust and grease must be removed in order to insure good bond. Also, make certain that surface over which you are applying it is sound. Remove all loose or flaking paint, and remove all old wallpaper or other wallcoverings before you start to hang this new material. Otherwise when these materials let go, they may take the new material off with them. For the same reason, when putting the material up over a ceramic tile wall, make sure all tiles are solidly bonded to the wall and fill in any places where tiles are actually missing (Paris Wall will bridge minor imperfections, but very large cracksa and holes should be filled in or repaired before you start). Before hanging the first strip - usually in a corner - you have to establish a plumb (vertical) line as a guide by using a weighted string or plumb line. Drive a small nail into the wall up near the ceiling and 30 inches out from the corner, then coat the string with chalk by rubbing it with some chalk held in one hand. Tie the string to the nail, then tie a small weight to the bottom end. Let this hang till it stops swinging, then hold the bottom end of the string tight against the wall with one hand while you snap the stretched line against the wall with the other hand. This will leave a chalked line on the wall that will serve as a guide for the first strip. The wallcovering is 31-1/2 inches wide, so there will be 1-1/2 inches left to fold around the corner. Now cut the first roll of material to length, allowing an extra inch or so at the top to be trimmed off after the strip is hung. Then start applying the adhesive to the wall, using a short-nap paint roller and a roller pan. The adhesive must be allowed to dry until tacky before actually putting the material up. This takes anywhere from 10 to 15 minutes on most surfaces, but on glazed ceramic tile it may take up to 30 minutes for the adhesive to become tacky. The vinyl is then pressed into place so that its edge lines up with the chalked line on the wall. Smooth it into place so that the excess folds around the corner, but to insure a neat fold in the corner, you will have to score the back with a sharp knife (the kind that uses disposable razor-like blades is best for this). When scoring for this corner fold, do NOT cut all the way through to the face side, just score the back side. Fold the material back on itself so you can use a yardstick or similar straightedge to guide the knife when you do this. Smooth the material onto the wall with a regular wallpaper smoothing brush, working from the middle of the strip out to the edges with a series of up and down strokes that move diagonally out to the edges. Make sure there are no air bubbles left underneath, and bear in mind that if the strip is not accurately aligned you can pull it off and re-hang it. Excess adhesive that oozes out around the edges should be wiped off promptly with a wet sponge, after which the excess at the top can be trimmed off by using a straightedge and a knife along the ceiling line. Hang the second and subsequent rolls in the same manner, butting each one against the one previously installed.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our suffering is that of the entire nation, terrorized by military force.'' - Archbishop Jozef Glemp of Poland. (A18:1.)

title: 'CONSERVATION HOUSE' IS OPENED BY CON ED
description: The Consolidated Edison Company opened its first ''conservation house'' today, a four-bedroom saltbox-style home with an estimated annual heating cost of $400 - half that of a comparable new home, according to Con Edison.

title: ANTI-ABORTION BILL VOTED, 4-0
description: A Senate Judiciary subcommittee gave unanimous approval today to a proposed constitutional amendment that would allow both Congress and the states to ban or regulate abortion.

title: Railroads Receive Project Loan
description: The Chicago & North Western Transportation Company and the Union Pacific Corporation said they had obtained financing for a rail line project estimated to cost $460 million into the coal-rich Powder River Basin in Wyoming.
