title: Estelle Osborne, 80, Is Dead; Leader in Nursing Profession
description: Estelle M. Osborne, a leader in the nursing profession for many years, died last Saturday in Oakland, Calif., where she had been living in retirement. Mrs. Osborne, a former resident of Elmhurst, Queens, was 80 years old.

title: THE KREMLIN'S COSTLY COMMITMENT IN AFGHANISTAN
description: In the two years that Soviet troops have been in Afghanistan, their numbers have increased from the original 85,000 to 110,000 deployed in 11 divisions around the country, according to a senior Asian diplomat here.

title: IN AFGHAN COUNTRYSIDE, BRAVERY AND BRAVADO
description: The following dispatch was written by a freelance journalist who recently spent six weeks in Afghanistan. By JERE VAN DYK

title: SYRIA, IN U.N., URGES SANCTIONS ON ISRAEL
description: Syria urged the Security Council today to impose sanctions if Israel refused to revoke its annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: G.I. HELD UNFIT FOR TRIAL IN KILLING OF THREE BLACKS IN BUFFALO REGION
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Buffalo ruled yesterday that an Army private accused of murdering three persons in the Buffalo area was not mentally fit to stand trial.

title: WELFARE OF CHILDREN STRESSED IN DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST
description: ''Since children are still the hope of the world, please use this small sum to aid a child.'' With that message, Judith G. Handelman of Manhattan sent a gift of $25 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. But she was not alone in asking that her contribution be used to mitigate the distress of the city's poor, lonely or neglected youngsters during the holiday season.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Can you tell us the best way to maintain ''butcher block'' countertops and tables, and how to clean and remove water stains from a top of this kind? - L.A., Madison, Wis.

title: REFORM JUDAISM'S ILL-CONCEIVED PROGRAM TO WIN CONVERTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Names Welsh
description: George Welsh was named football coach at Virginia, becoming the Cavaliers' ninth coach since 1952. After nine seasons at Navy, Welsh has accepted the task of succeeding Dick Bestwick and attempting to reverse three decades of losing. ... In another coaching move, Jerry Claiborne left Maryland to take the job at Kentucky.

title: HEALTH EMERGENCY DECLARED AS TALKS ON TRASH CONTINUE
description: A health emergency was declared in New York City yesterday in the 17-day-old strike against the city's private carting companies. Both sides, meanwhile, continued talks in an atmosphere of optimism.

title: Republic Steel Sets More Layoffs
description: The Republic Steel Corporation said it would lay off 1,700 employees at its Cleveland plant for at least two weeks beginning Sunday.

title: 61 SENATORS BACK HOUSE-PASSED VOTING RIGHTS BILL
description: Civil rights advocates, flexing their political muscle, said today that they had obtained commitments from 61 Senators to support extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 in the form approved by the House of Representatives.

title: Long Lease on Arena Is Offered by Rockies
description: The Colorado Rockies owner, Peter Gilbert, apparently maintaining some hope of keeping his National Hockey League franchise in Denver, has offered to pay a fee of $500,000 per year for a long-term lease at McNichols Arena.

title: One Fairbanks Evokes Memories of Another
description: He hasn't appeared in a movie in more than 20 years but Douglas Fairbanks Jr. is in a picture released this week called ''Ghost Story.'' Mr. Fairbanks, who is 72 now, said that he really hadn't missed being in films -he's been busy with theater and television - but that it was a treat to be back ''working with so many old pros I've known.'' He mentioned Fred Astaire and John Houseman and Melvyn Douglas, who has since died.

title: ARKANSAS LEGISLATURE DEFINES EVOLUTION AND CREATION IDEAS
description: Creation science, as defined by Act 590 of the Arkansas Legislature, closely resembles the biblical story of the origin of the world. The parallel with religious teachings has prompted the law's critics to contend that creation science is a religious rather than scientific school of thought, and should not be taught in public schools wherever evolution science is taught.

title: Guidry Pitches Pay-TV
description: Ron Guidry of the Yankees and four business partners have obtained the rights to deliver pay-TV programming entertainment to the pitcher's hometown of Lafayette, La.

title: Interest Ceiling Ruling Delayed
description: As expected, Federal financial regulators today put off a decision on a plan to eliminate interest rate ceilings on long-term savings accounts.

title: Bridge: Winter Regionals to Start With Team Event Tonight
description: For players and administrators, a year comes to an end with the Winter Regional Championships, which begin tonight at the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: HOME BEAT
description: TO some they may just be old, and not even antique toys.

title: Soviet Selling Of Gold Seen
description: The Soviet Union has been selling increased amounts of gold in the last few days, taking advantage of firmer prices resulting from the crisis in Poland, bullion dealers said today. International gold prices usually rise at times of world tension, attracting investors who distrust currencies.

title: U.S.-EUROPE TRADE PROBLEMS CITED
description: Increasing trade conflicts could have ''poisonous effects'' on United States relations with Europe and on Atlantic security, a high State Department official said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard HEADING WEST. By Doris Betts. 359 pages. Knopf. $13.50

title: Continental Air Default Possible
description: Continental Air Lines Inc., a Los Angeles-based airline, said it expected to go into technical default on some of its $322.2 million in debt by the end of the month unless it received waivers from its lenders. Continental added that it was confident that it would receive the necessary waivers.

title: PITFALLS OF NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: In an industry noted for its grudging reluctance to embrace new technology, the McLouth Steel Corporation has long been a trendsetter.

title: MGIC's President Quits After Merger
description: Gerald L. Friedman, the 44-year-old president and chief operating officer of the MGIC Investment Corporation, who opposed its planned merger into the Baldwin-United Corporation, resigned yesterday, a day after the announcement of the $1.2 billion acquisition.

title: THE THEATER: 'AMADEUS,' WITH 3 NEW PRINCIPALS
description: IT was a year ago today that ''Amadeus'' opened on Broadway, but you'd never know it these nights at the Broadhurst. Though Peter Shaffer's play has lost all three of its original Broadway principals - Ian McKellen, Tim Curry and Jane Seymour - it has lost none of its energy or gripping theatricality. What's the secret of this success?

title: POPE CALLS ON POLES TO TAKE UP AGAIN 'ROAD OF RENEWAL'
description: Pope John Paul II called on the opposing parties in Poland today to return to the road of renewal and negotiation. As a nation, he said, the Poles ''have the right to live their own life and to resolve their own domestic problems in the spirit of their own convictions and in harmony with their own culture and national traditions.''

title: BROCK CRITICIZES BRIBERY LAW
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said today that the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act had become known as ''one of our nation's most serious export disincentives.''

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: WHY THE KREMLIN FEARS THE DISSIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BYARD WILLIAMS
description: Dr. Byard Williams, an internist on the staff of New York Hospital until his retirement in 1976, died Tuesday following a long illness. He was 76 years old and a longtime resident of the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: COURT DEPICTS REP. RICHMOND IN POTENTIAL CONFLICTS
description: Records and testimony in a civil suit in Federal Court in St. Louis provide examples of how Frederick W. Richmond's roles as businessman and United States Representative from Brooklyn have overlapped and come into potential conflict.

title: GREAT GLASSES: A LOT OF SHAPES FOR THE MONEY
description: IT'S the season for entertaining, and while the well-organized among us have been prepared for weeks to give holiday parties, others will have diffi-culty scrounging up even a dozen glasses, least of all matching ones. But in Manhattan, from stands along Canal Street to department stores and restaurant supply emporiums on Fifth Avenue, there is a dizzying choice of reasonably priced, handblown and machine-made glasses. They can be purchased as open stock or in sets.

title: GIANTS' NEW BABY BULLS GET A CHANCE
description: The era of the Giants' baby bulls - the big running backs Ernie Koy, Tucker Frederickson and Steve Thurlow - ended a decade ago, but it may be returning.

title: GOTBAUM QUITS RACE FOR PRESIDENCY OF UNION
description: Victor Gotbaum of New York withdrew from consideration for president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees yesterday, leaving two men campaigning to succeed the late Jerry Wurf as head of the nation's largest public workers' union.

title: GALLERY SHOWS WORKS BY TAPESTRY ARTISTS
description: The works of nearly a dozen fiber artists are now on display at Modern Master Tapestries through Jan. 8. According to the gallery director, Dominique Mazeaud, the show, which is entitled ''Fiber Art: An Uncommon Thread,'' is evidence of the gallery's continuing commitment to a new direction in textile art.

title: DECISION FILE
description: Every day Federal agencies make decisions that affect the lives of Americans. Here are two recent cases: F.T.C. Jawboning

title: POLICE OFFICERS SLAY 2 ARMED ASSAILANTS IN SEPARATE INCIDENTS
description: Two men, one wielding a knife and the other a machete, were shot to death by police officers last night in separate incidents in Manhattan and Queens, the police said.

title: HOUSE BACKS MERGER CURB
description: Over the shouted protests of many Republicans, the House voted 223-107 just before adjournment tonightt to declare a six-month moratorium on mergers among large oil companies.

title: NEED FOR BIG POLISH AID SEEN
description: Poland is likely to need at least $12 billion in Western aid next year, just to keep its economic crisis from getting worse, according to a strongly pessimistic report released here this week. The report was prepared for Societe Generale, one of France's three big state-owned banks, by its chief economist.

title: ZOYA FYODOROVA MEMORIAL
description: A memorial service will be held on Sunday for Zoya Fyodorova, a leading Russian film star of the 1940's, who was shot to death last week during a robbery of her Moscow apartment. Mrs. Fyodorova had a wartime romance with a United States Navy officer, bore him a child and was subsequently imprisoned in the Soviet Union. The service will be held at 1 P.M. at the Russian Orthodox Church, Park Avenue at 93rd Street.

title: KINDS OF SCHOLARSHIP; Gudgeons, Etc.
description: Sometimes you don't know you can use something until it appears; invention can be the mother of necessity. Consider ''What's What,'' a new reference book that just arrived.

title: WATT OFFERS NEW RULES TO EASE COAL LEASING
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt today announced proposed rules that he said would streamline the Government's coal leasing program and speed up the offering of land for leasing.

title: 65 ARABS ARRESTED IN SABOTAGE PLOT
description: Saudi Arabia and Bahrain today announced the arrest of a total of 65 people in what was said to be a plot linked to Iran to disrupt conditions in the Persian Gulf region and bring down conservative Arab Governments.

title: U.S. Group to Monitor Crisis
description: The White House said today that it was setting up a high-level ''special situation group'' to keep an eye on crises such as the present Polish developments. The group, formed by a Presidential directive Monday, supersedes a group known as the crisis management team, according to David R. Gergen, the White House communications director.

title: RULING APPEALED IN HINCKLEY CASE
description: The Government today appealed a pretrial ruling that it had taken evidence from John W. Hinckley Jr. in violation of his constitutional rights. Federal prosecutors want to use the evidence to rebut Mr. Hinckley's defense that he was insane when he shot President Reagan and three other men last March 30.

title: Free Trade Zones Aided
description: Congress approved a bill yesterday that is expected to increase the attractiveness of New York as an international banking center.

title: JUDGE'S CONDUCT OF CREATION TRIAL IS PRAISED
description: Months before he began hearing testimony on the constitutionality of Arkansas's ''creation science'' law, Federal District Judge William Ray Overton was aggressively immersing himself in reams of legal briefs, depositions and literature on theories about the creation and evolution.

title: SMOKERS' CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: GREECE GRANTS DIPLOMATIC STATUS TO P.L.O. OFFICE
description: Greece announced today that it had granted diplomatic status to the Palestine Liberation Organization's liaison and information office here, making it a diplomatic mission but not an embassy.

title: Martin Bitter at Sabres
description: Rick Martin, whose career was cut short by a knee injury, is bitter. Martin once held the National Hockey League record for goals by a rookie and was a member of the Buffalo Sabres' French Connection line with Gilbert Perreault and Rene Robert.

title: CITY MAY ADD 2,000 HOUSES WITH SUBSIDY
description: A measure that would let New York City build 2,000 federally subsized, moderately priced one- and two-family houses in more than a dozen deteriorating neighborhoods was approved in Washington yesterday by the House of Representatives. The Senate gave its approval Tuesday evening, and the measure now goes to President Reagan.

title: For Subways, Time Is Running Out
description: Despite the aura lent it by graffiti, dirt, delays, the proposed construction of razor-edged moats around 18 subway yards and the use of guard dogs, the New York subway system has actually maintained a reassuring safety record.

title: Papers' Ad Revenue Up
description: The nation's daily newspapers were up 10.1 percent in ad revenues, to $1.6 billion, in October, compared with the same month last year, according to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. The best percentage gain came in the national category, which increased 19.1 percent, to $276.1 million. It was followed by retail and classified, which both gained 8.5 percent, to respective totals of $929.1 million and $430.9 million.

title: APPEAL OF THE POLISH ARCHBISHOP URGING END OF MARTIAL LAW
description: Following, according to information received by news agencies from Poland, are excerpts from a communique issued yesterday by the Primate of Poland, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, and the General Council of the Polish Episcopate:

title: E.E.C. Farm Policy Faulted; E.E.C. Farm Policy Faulted
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that it was as a result of the European Economic Community's farm-subsidy policy that the United States government will have to make payments of $400 million to wheat farmers this year.

title: New President Named At Barco of California
description: Michael K. Donner, 38, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Barco of California, a leading uniform manufacturer. He succeeds David S. Grutman, 73, who was named vice chairman of the Los Angeles-based company.

title: J.C. PENNEY WILL OFFER LEVI BRAND
description: Levi Strauss & Company announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with the J.C. Penney Company to sell Levi's clothing through the retailer. The decision marks the first entry by San Francisco-based Levi Strauss, the world's largest apparel manufacturer, into national chain distribution.

title: 4 Die in Helicopter Collision
description: Two Army helicopters collided and crashed Tuesday, killing all four aboard. Herb Strickland, a spokesman at Fort Rucker here, said that the OH-58's collided while on a training mission. The dead, all Army personnel, were George Harrelson, 34 years old, of Flint, Mich.; Eugene Chase, 29, Mikkalo, Ore.; Larry A. Ettinberger, 26, of Alabama, town unlisted; and James F. Clevenger, 26, Cleveland, Tenn.

title: MAJOR QUESTIONS ON C.I.A. ARISE IN HOUSE INQUIRY
description: The following article is based on reporting by Philip Taubman and Special to the New York Times Jeff Gerth and was written by Mr. Taubman.

title: CABLE TV IS 'STUDIED' BY NBC
description: Senior executives of the National Broadcasting Company have been studying the possibility of the network's entering the growing cable-television programming field, an NBC executive said yesterday.

title: LAWMAKERS ARE POISED TO FIND FACTS AND SUN
description: Is the nation better or worse off when Congress leaves town? The question is prompted by Congress's impending departure on a six-week winter holiday, close on the heels of an extended Thanksgiving recess, not long after a week's celebration of Columbus Day, barely a month after a five-week summer vacation.

title: Accounts
description: * Gruner & Jahr USA/Publishing to E.T. Howard Company for Expecting magazine.

title: Marketers Resist Mobil
description: Several independent gasoline marketers have lined up against the Mobil Corporation in its fight in Federal appeals court here to win control of the Marathon Oil Company.

title: By Sports of The Times; Holmes-Cooney and the Purple Mob
description: UP near the microphone yesterday, Larry Holmes and Gerry Cooney were settling into their seats. And with the respect due a champion and a challenger, each of whom is expected to earn at least $10 million from their March 15 heavyweight title fight, Ray Arcel put a finger to his lips.

title: Two Giants in Pro Bowl
description: Two linebackers for the Giants, the rookie Lawrence Taylor and the veteran Harry Carson, have been selected for the 40-member National Conference team that will oppose the American Conference Jan. 31 in the Pro Bowl.

title: OCCIDENTAL IN SOVIET MEAT PACT
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, today announced the start of a business venture with the Soviet Union involving Iowa Beef Processors, Occidental's recently acquired meat processing unit.

title: HID ANNE FRANK
description: Victor Kugler, who provided sanctuary to Anne Frank, her family and four other Jews in Nazi-occupied Amsterdam during World War II, died here Monday night. He was 81 years old.

title: Index; International
description: Syria, in U.N., calls for sanctions against Israel A3 Egyptian leader confers with aides on Golan annexation A5 Around the World A8 U.N. calls on El Salvdador to ne- gotiate with rebels A9 Chilean Government arrests at least seven dissidents A10 Sakharov's wife back in Moscow after hunger strike A12 Peking paper in English finds a niche A13 East-West parley in Madrid wel- comes compromise A14 Soviet force in Afghanistan is said to increase to 110,000 A15 Excerpts from domestic Polish broadcasts A18 Excerpts from Poland's Catholic Primate statement A18 Government/Politics L.A.'s Mayor Bradley has good chance to become Governor A21 Court records depict Rep. Rich- mond in potential conflicts B2 Byrne to let Kean decide future of Liberty State Park B6 Washington Talk Dean Burch is model of the Wash- ington lobbyist B10 Congress set for another ''district work period'' B10 Briefing B10 Decision File B10 General Around the Nation A20 Floridians now heeding author's warnings about water A20 F.A.A. head expects normal air traffic control by 1984 A24 Off-duty police officer foiling rob- bery killed in Queens B3 Industry/Labor Gotbaum withdraws from race for head of municipal workers A23 The Home Section Home Great glasses: a lot of shapes for the money C1

title: CHURCH CHALLENGES REGIME
description: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: WHEN IMPROVING IS BETTER THAN MOVING
description: STEVE SEIFERT and Brian Risley are the kind of tenants landlords dream about. In 1978 the two young men rented a three-bedroom apartment in Manhattan's Chelsea section and immediately knuckled down to work. They scraped wood, patched walls, cast new plaster cornice moldings, sanded radiators and boiled the dirt off light fixtures.

title: THE QUANDARY OF CHRISTMAS TIPPING
description: HILE it's not about to replace the ''Hallelujah'' chorus, there's an oft-heard refrain around town on the subject of Christmas tipping, and it goes like this: ''I'm giving the same as last year.''

title: Study Shows Exercise Curbs Heart Ailments
description: A new study shows that moderate exercise a few times a week will protect against heart disease, at least in monkeys and perhaps in people.

title: Judge Upholds Panel On Mineral Lease Ban
description: A Federal District judge ruled today that the House Interior Committee could order the Secretary of the Interior to withdraw wilderness areas from mineral leasing, but said that it was up to the Secretary to determine the duration of such bans.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 15.50-15.75** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL TO KEEP MINIMUM U.S. PENSION
description: The House gave final and overwhelming approval today to legislation restoring the minimum Social Security benefit for current recipients as President Reagan announced a new 15-member commission to recommend fiscal reforms for the hard-pressed retirement system.

title: The Man Behind the Reindeer Whose Nose Glows
description: The man who wrote ''When Santa Claus Gets Your Letter,'' ''The Night Before Christmas Song,'' ''A-caroling We Go,'' ''I Heard the Bells on Christmas Day,'' ''Joyous Christmas,'' ''A Holly, Jolly Christmas'' and ''Rockin' Around the Christmas Tree,'' was asked if there was anything he hadn't been asked about the flip side of ''If It Doesn't Snow on Christmas.''

title: PORT CHESTER BUSINESS RETREAT DOUBLES AS RESORT
description: It has been called the ''Waldorf in the Woods,'' a four-story luxury hotel with a touch of country elegance, nestled on a wooded promontory in the Town of Rye.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the first paragraph of an article in some edi- tions yesterday on a Federal Court order directing the early parole of 350 prisoners incorrectly named the state affected. It is Alabama.

title: Record World Coffee Crop Forecast
description: World coffee production in the current season will be greater than previously expected and will set a record, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Panic? It's Not a Part of the Islander Style
description: The owner paid a visit today. If this were the Los Angeles Lakers, the coach might have been busted; if this were the New York Yankees, players might have been sent to bed without their supper.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION DROPS 2.1%
description: Industrial production declined 2.1 percent in November, the Government reported yesterday, as the 1981 recession continued to spread through the economy.

title: FORCED LANDING
description: This civilian airplane came to a halt on a street of Glen Burnie, Md., after engine trouble forced it down shortly after takeoff from Baltimore-Washington International Airport. Pilot suffered minor injuries.

title: News Analysis
description: In annexing the Golan Heights, Israel has advanced Prime Minister Menachem Begin's policy of cutting down the options for future territorial compromise with the Arabs.

title: WRONG RATIO
description: To the Editor:

title: WELFARE UNITS FIGHT MONITORING LAW
description: A consortium of social welfare groups has argued that a New York State law requiring family counseling organizations to provide city and state authorities with the names and records of clients is an unconstitutional invasion of privacy.

title: Santa Claus? No, Grandfather Clause
description: Pensioners on Social Security are breathing easier this week. A House-Senate conference committee broke a deadlock and eliminated any possibility that the Social Security system would be unable to mail out checks in 1982. But the minor changes that were made in benefits will save only a few hundred million dollars a year. And the bitter struggle for even these modest changes shows how hard it will be to go further.

title: STARR: STILL ON TRIAL AS COACH
description: In the state of Wisconsin this week, the issue of rehiring or dismissing a football coach, Bart Starr of the Green Bay Packers, overshadows all else. Ice fishing, the spread of censorship in school libraries and the rising unemployment rates in Kenosha and Oshkosh are trivia relative to the Bart Starr matter.

title: IGNORE QADDAFI
description: To underscore its concern with combating international terrorism, the Reagan Administration has chosen to concentrate attention on the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who has long been noted for his generous and uncritical support of what he calls anti-imperialist and national-liberation movements around the world.

title: Both Iraq and Iran Report Gains in War
description: Iraq said today that its troops had made major gains against Iranian forces in the Gilan Garb and Sumar regions of northern Iran, killing 282 Iranian soldiers in the last 24 hours. At the same time, Iran's official press agency, Pars, said Iranian forces had shot down two Iraqi Mirage jet fighters in the Gilan Garb heights.

title: BRADLEY GAIN SEEN IN CALIFORNIA RACE
description: About 1,000 supporters of Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles are to gather at the Century Plaza Hotel here Thursday night for a dinner whose official aim is to ''encourage'' him to run for Governor of California in 1982.

title: HARVESTER MOVES ON PLANT MORTGAGES
description: The International Harvester Company, which reported a $636 million operating loss in its 1981 fiscal year, said today that it had mortgaged its two Quad Cities farm equipment plants. The action is one of the first steps in its plan to restructure $4.15 billion in debts.

title: Players' Group Forgoes Legal Action on Fouts
description: The Players Association will not legally attempt to prevent Dan Fouts, the San Diego Charger quarterback, from playing Monday night against the Oakland Raiders, despite its request for his immediate suspension for nonpayment of union dues.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anta Corp. said it would purchase on the open market up to 100,000 shares of Anta common stock.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1981; International
description: Poland indicated it cannot meet a pledge to pay $500 million by year-end in overdue interest owed to foreign banks. American bankers said Poland has asked a number of lending institutions for an additional $350 million so that the past-due interest payment could be met. But bankers around the world indicated no further loans would be made until the $500 million is paid. (Page A1.)

title: VOLUME DOWN
description: Stock prices drifted lower yesterday as investors remained cautious over the business outlook at home and the crisis in Poland. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.23 points, to 868.72.

title: Collins Wary on Yank Bid
description: The Yankees have made Dave Collins what his agent calls a very attractive offer, but Collins, a free-agent outfielder, is unlikely to accept if he is to be used only as a designated hitter.

title: Rates Up as Bond Rally Halts; 2-Year Notes Bring 13.06%
description: The two-day advance in bond prices came to an abrupt halt yesterday as the credit markets perceived a temporary pause in the decline in money market rates.

title: KINDS OF SCHOLARSHIP; Corporate High
description: ''Public-private partnerships'' and ''bridging the gap between school and work'' may be cliches among educators, but the District of Columbia school system is intent on giving them concrete meaning.

title: DEAN BURCH: ABLE VOICE FOR THE COMMUNICATORS
description: Dean Burch is in many ways the model of the Washington politico-lobbyist. A political operative here for 25 years and a campaigner for the election of Ronald Reagan, Mr. Burch is having a major say about the historic communications legislation now before Congress, and thus a voice in reshaping a vast American industry.

title: EXCERPTS FROM RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS BY POLAND
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service here:

title: CHICAGO AND PARIS SEEK WORLD'S FAIR
description: Eyebrows arched. Chicago's presentation to the Bureau of International Expositions in Paris last week had more razzle-dazzle than had been expected by spokesmen for the French capital, the major rival for permission to hold the next world's fair.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ilie Nastase, the Rumanian tennis player, was fined $3,000 for making objectionable gestures with his racquet during the New South Wales Open. ... Michelle Chin, a 16-year-old student at Union High School in Montpelier, Vt., has won the right to play on the boys' hockey team. Last month she was barred because of a ruling by the Vermont Headmasters' Association, a statewide group of principals that governs interscholastic sports. ... Frank Tanana, the freeagent pitcher, has refused offers from the Milwaukee Brewers and Boston Red Sox, according to his agent, Tony Attanasio, because the offers were for two seasons and not three. ... Tamara McKinney, the defending World Cup giant slalom champion, fell during a training run in Utah and broke her hand. She will miss a two races in Austria this weekend.

title: AMARYLLIS: STEPS TO SUCCESS
description: NO other plant evokes more oohs and ahs at this time of year than an amaryllis. These exotic bulbs with the huge, trumpet-shaped flowers are glorious to behold but easy to grow. Their colors may be bright crimson, apple-blossom pink, candy-striped red and white, soft salmon or white with a tinge of green.

title: FILM BOARD PICKS 'BESTS'
description: ''Reds'' and ''Chariots of Fire'' tied for best picture of 1981 as the National Board of Review chose the winners of its annual David Wark Griffith Awards for outstanding achievement in motion pictures.

title: Conservative Students
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: An Associated Press article that appeared in The Home Section (''Conservatism Is Found in Top Teen-Agers,'' Dec. 3) neglects some important information concerning the sponsor of the survey, ''Who's Who Among American High School Students.''

title: Tokashiki Wins Title
description: Katsuo Tokashiki of Japan captured the World Boxing Association junior flyweight title tonight with a unanimous decision over Kim Hwan Jin of South Korea. There were no knockdowns in the 15-round bout.

title: Angola Reported Ready To Talk With Rebel
description: Angola's Ambassador to Portugal said today that his Government was ready to hold talks with Jonas Savimbi, who has led an armed rebellion against the Marxist Angolan Government for the last six years, the Portuguese news agency reported.

title: How Many Strings on Cordless Phones?
description: Radiophones for vehicles have been around since the 1940's, when newspapers started using them for roving reporters. But the technology remained primitive for years, relying on powerful transmitters and a handful of frequencies. The number of subscribers and conversations were severely restricted. Now a new technology called cellular communications promises to increase users from hundreds to hundreds of thousands. The question is, sooner or later? We vote for sooner.

title: Jets Hail Todd as M.V.P.
description: In his sixth season, one victory from his first playoff, Richard Todd finally received the stamp of approval from his teammates today when he was voted the most valuable Jet. Todd, the quarterback, edged Joe Klecko, a defensive end, and Bruce Harper, the all-purpose back who won the honor last year and finished third this time.

title: NEW STUDY BEGUN OF NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is investigating the possibility of collusion between the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and an independent auditor that the company retained to assess its calculations about the safety of its Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, according to commission officials.

title: 'MARCH OF THE FALSETTOS' FIGHTS EVICTION
description: ''March of the Falsettos,'' the acclaimed musical by William Finn that opened last spring at the Playwrights Horizon and moved in October to the larger Westside Arts Theater at 407 West 43d Street, has received an eviction notice, according to the show's producers. However, talks are under way that may enable the show to continue there.

title: RANGERS LOSE, 7-3, TO FLYERS
description: The Ranger power-play was powerless, as usual, last night at Madison Square Garden, and the Philadelphia Flyers' power-play, as usual, was potent.

title: EGYPTIANS DEBATE GOLAN MOVE
description: President Hosni Mubarak met with key aides today to discuss Israel's annexation of the Syrian Golan Heights, which has created a situation that is regarded here as the new Egyptian leader's first major foreign policy issue with Israel.

title: BYRNE DECIDES NOT TO CHOOSE A DEVELOPER FOR LIBERTY PARK
description: The incumbent administration of Governor Byrne has removed itself from choosing a developer to create a commercial and residential complex or both in Liberty State Park in Jersey City.

title: William Ross Quits at J.W.T.
description: After a brief one-year run, the title of president-international of the J. Walter Thompson Company is being retired.

title: FUND-RAISING THE INNOVATIVE WAY: CHAIN LETTER
description: THERE are moments when life imitates art with highly satisfying fidelity. Take the matter of financing the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, which for many years has been dancing works by Mr. Cunningham that build, with a look of eminent practicality, from everyday movement and are often organized by principles of chance devised by the composer John Cage, the company's musical adviser.

title: Gas Blamed for Mine Blast
description: Methane gas, possibly ignited by a forbidden cigarette, probably caused an explosion that killed 13 men in the Tennessee Consolidated Coal Company's No. 21 mine on Dec. 8, Wayne Farmer, a state inspector, said today.

title: FARM BILL WINS IN A CLOSE VOTE
description: After two hours of emotional debate, the House of Representatives tonight passed a new four-year farm bill that no member supported with enthusiasm.

title: PEKING PAPER FOR OUTSIDERS FINDS A NICHE
description: Anyone who wants his National Hockey League scores along with news of the Xinjiang cotton harvest, the latest results of basketball tournaments in New York and light industry in Shanghai, tips on bridge-playing and bridge-building need look no further than a newspaper called China Daily.

title: U.N. CALLS ON EL SALVADOR TO NEGOIATE WITH REBELS
description: The General Assembly approved a resolution tonight calling on the United States-backed junta in El Salvador to negotiate with its leftist opponents before next year's scheduled elections.

title: Warsaw Will Permit First 8 Flights Today
description: Warsaw television said today that eight airliners would leave Warsaw Thursday, the first since martial law was imposed Sunday.

title: General Steel Pact Approved
description: A Federal judge has approved an agreement under which General Steel Industries would buy 750,000 more of its common shares from the Walco National Corporation and General Steel would be acquired by the Lukens Steel Company.

title: ACCOUNTING CHANGES LEAD TO LOSS AT AM
description: AM International Inc. said yesterday that negative accounting adjustments of $203 million caused most of the loss of $245.1 million posted for the fiscal year ended July 31. The company lost $5.8 million in the preceding fiscal year.

title: Technology; Lag in Market For the Elderly
description: OVER the river and through the woods, or wherever else people go to visit grandmother during the holidays, they are likely to find videotape recorders, state-of-the-art cameras, microwave ovens and other fruits of technological progress. Most elderly people can enjoy many innovations marketed to the general public.

title: POLAND ASKS FOREIGN BANKS' HELP IN REPAYMENT OF OVERDUE INTEREST
description: Poland has indicated that it cannot meet commitments to pay about $500 million by the end of the year in past-due interest owed to foreign banks, American bankers said yesterday.

title: COMPROMISE AT MADRID TALKS WELCOMED BY U.S. AND SOVIET
description: With the military crackdown in Poland casting a shadow over the East-West conference here, the United States and the Soviet Union today welcomed a compromise document presented as a possible basis for successfully ending the meeting.

title: DONALD COOK, EX-CHAIRMAN OF S.E.C., DIES AT 72
description: Donald C. Cook, who was chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission under President Harry S. Truman and head of the American Electric Power Company for 14 years, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: POLAND AFFIRMING 1980 UNION ACCORD
description: Poland's ruling military council said today that, despite the current martial law, there would be ''no turning back'' from the agreements made last year between the Polish authorities and the independent Solidarity trade union.

title: Market Place; How to Avoid 'Wash' Sales
description: WITHERING bear markets for both stocks and bonds have prompted thousands of trades for tax advantage in the waning days of 1981. But there is a major stumbling block. Anyone who repurchases a given security, or a nearly identical one, within 30 days has a ''wash,'' nd wash sale losses are not deductible.

title: Lenders Get Mortgage Aid
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation received Congressional approval yesterday to continue a program under which it accepts old, low-interest-rate mortgages from lending institutions and converts them into mortgage-backed securities called participation certificates.

title: WOMEN'S GROUPS JOIN TO RAISE FUNDS
description: Fifteen women's organizations in the city announced yesterday that they were combining forces to raise funds, and that they were aiming in particular to gain access to the workplace and to payroll deductions.

title: Chevron Deal in India
description: The Indian Government intends to sign a contract with Chevron Overseas Petroleum Inc. for exploration and development of a promising offshore oilfield, the oil ministry said today. In San Francisco, an official of Chevron's parent company, the Standard Oil Company of California, said final details of the contract were being worked out and that exploration was to begin next year. The field, Saurashtra II, is in the Arabian Sea about 200 miles northwest of Bombay.

title: GUIDE BOOKS FOR ANTIQUES AND COLLECTIBLES
description: As might be expected, along with the rising national passion for all sorts of collectibles, has come a spate of guidebooks, catalogues and price lists - many of them helpful, some of them trivial, almost all of them of some interest to collectors of things arcane. The following are a few of the many general guides available and others dealing with specific areas of collecting:

title: SAFETY PANEL UPHOLDS GAS HEATER STANDARDS
description: The Consumer Products Safety Commission rejected an industry's 11th-hour attempt today to substitute a voluntary safety standard for unvented gas heaters to replace the commission's mandatory standard that becomes effective Dec. 31.

title: NETS BEATEN IN OVERTIME, 98-97
description: Ricky Sobers made a 17-foot fadeaway jump shot with one second remaining in overtime tonight to give the Chicago Bulls a 98-97 victory over the New Jersey Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CALENDAR: FLOWERS AND CRAFTS
description: New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard near Fordham Road, Bronx.

title: PROBLEMS OF PRESERVING A HISTORIC ESTATE
description: ''PRETTY'' is not always the word that comes to mind in connection with the stretch of country that runs down to the Delaware River between Trenton and Philadelphia. Looking at the subindustrial wasteland that borders much of the road, we imagine the Pilgrim Fathers rising in wrath. ''We gave you the Promised Land,'' they say, ''and what have you done with it?''

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 17, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: LUCAS SHOT TOPS 76ers BY 117-115
description: The play that the Knicks' coach, Red Holzman, called with less than a half-minute remaining and the score tied at 115-all against the Philadelphia 76ers tonight was designed for Maurice Lucas to do what he had been doing all evening - score inside.

title: Avalanches Isolate Zermatt
description: Two Swiss winter sports resorts, Zermatt and Les Diablerets, were cut off today by avalanches.

title: Military Analysis
description: Many American and NATO intelligence and planning officials fear that Israel's unexpected annexation of the Golan Heights may have sown the seeds of a fifth Middle East war.

title: O'NEILL TO BE RELEASED BY HOSPITAL IN HARTFORD
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill will be released from St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center at 2:30 P.M. Thursday, according to Carol Stasiowski, a hospital spokesman.

title: Japan Acts On Trade
description: The Japanese Government, in a concession to mounting international criticism of its trade practices, adopted a series of measures today aimed at expanding imports and reducing trade friction with the United States and Europe.

title: Griffins Bankrupt
description: Archie and Ray Griffin, former stars for Ohio State and current members of the Cincinnati Bengals, have filed for personal bankruptcy after a three-year venture, involving six athletic shoe stores, failed. The liquidation of the stores in Columbus and Springfield, hio, is expected to produce enough income to pay a $170,000 loan from the Small Business Administration and a $46,000 loan from the Ohio State Bank, according to the players' lawyer. Documents in bankruptcy court show that Archie Griffin has debts of $519,568 and assets of $127,750 and that Ray has debts of $539,100 and assets of $93,350.

title: No Headline
description: Books: Rounding Up Antiques By Rita Reif

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GOOD TASTE

title: LOWER TICKEY COSTS ARE CATCHING ON
description: SARAH CALDWELL, artistic director of the Opera Company of Boston, has announced that the company will cut by 20 percent the cost of all subscriptions for the 1982 season. The announcement comes several weeks after a similar decision was reached by the New York City Opera. The Boston season begins in January with the first American production of ''Die Soldaten,'' an opera by Bernd-Alois Zimmermann.

title: Jordan Gets Loan
description: The World Bank said today that it had approved a $25 million loan to Jordan to support an educational and training project.

title: DEAD END
description: It is exquisite boredom. We arrive for work at 8 in the morning and stuff envelopes until 4:30 in the afternoon. To help get us through another day of mindless labor, my fellow workers and I listen to the radio, discuss our personal lives and interests, complain about the lousy wages, and, by midafternoon, struggle to stay awake. On the slowest days, we vie for a chance to get out and run an errand, like hungry dogs fighting over a scrap of meat.

title: Boeing Reports Aircraft Orders
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday orders for 14 aircraft with a value of $230 million.

title: CHIEF JUSTICE KNOCKS CAMERA TO GROUND
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger knocked a camera off the shoulder of a CBS television cameraman today when a film crew followed him to an elevator to ask questions, film footage showed.

title: N.J. 'Bowl' in August Proposed
description: The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority will ask the N.C.A.A. for permission to stage an annual preseason college football game nine days before Labor Day at Giants Stadium, with two topranked teams from the previous season taking part.

title: WOMEN IN SCIENCE
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Your two recent articles, one by K.C. Cole (''Hers,'' Dec. 3) concerning women in science, and the other by Nell Irvin Painter about the situation of black women in the world (''Hers,'' Dec. 10), were received by me with great interest. It has always concerned me that bright young women tend to shy away from the sciences.

title: CHINA SIGNS AID ACCORD WITH JAPAN
description: Japan and China signed a $1.38 billion agreement today covering Japanese financial aid to key Chinese industrial projects.

title: FARM LEGISLATION VOTED IN CONGRESS AS '81 SESSION ENDS
description: The 1981 session of Congress ended all of its official business and adjourned tonight after the House passed by a two-vote margin, 205 to 203, a bill setting farm price supports for the next four years.

title: FLORIDIANS FINALLY HEED OLD WARNINGS ON WATER
description: The old lady is half-blind now and going blinder, but she works every day, dictating a book part of the time, devoting most of the rest of her time to Florida's principal problem. Neither crime nor narcotics nor unwanted refugees, to mention but a few of the state's best-known woes, trouble Marjory Stoneman Douglas. To her, the issue is water.

title: THE SUBMARINE IN THE SANCTUARY
description: To the Editor:

title: SAUDI URGES PUNISHMENT OF ISRAEL
description: The Saudi Ambassador to the United States, Faisal Alhegelan, met today with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and later called for United Nations sanctions against Israel for its annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: Murder Suspect Freed After Three Hung Juries
description: Nathaniel Lane, who has been tried three times in connection with the beating death of a motorist in Miami's 1980 race riot, left jail today, after prosecutors decided not to bring him to trial again.

title: Mrs. Onassis Asserts Photographer Stalked Her
description: Jacqueline Onassis testified yesterday that ''relentless stalking'' by a photographer had caused her ''confusion, fright and desperation.'' As a result of his ''constant surveillance, '' she said, her summer vacation became ''intolerable, almost unlivable.''

title: Article 135962 -- No Title
description: Five gunmen held up two banks in quick succession in this farming town, escaping with $3.6 million in cash, the police said today.

title: Central Bank In Laker Talks
description: The Bank of England has joined talks aimed at resolving the financial difficulties of Laker Airways, the airline that introduced no-frills trans-Atlantic service, bankers involved with the company said here.

title: No Headline
description: J. Lynn Helms, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, insisted today that the agency would restore the full prestrike capacity of the air traffic control system by the beginning of 1984. But he acknowledged in Congressional testimony that it might take up to another year to get the system back to normal.

title: POLISH DIPLOMATS BEING RESTRICTED BY U.S. IN A RETALIATORY MEASURE
description: The United States today restricted the movements of Polish diplomats and told the Polish Ambassador of its concern about the continuation of martial law and the isolation of Lech Walesa, the union leader.

title: PROBATION GIVEN IN BOMB CASE
description: A Weather Underground fugitive wanted since 1979 when explosives were found in his Hoboken, N.J., apartment, was fined $3,000 today and directed to perform volunteer work in a day-care center and a hospital emergency room.

title: No Headline
description: UNIONISTS AND DISSIDENTS REPORTED HELD IN POLAND

title: 2 Dead in Tanker Fire
description: A fire and explosion ripped through the 20,933-ton Liberian-registered oil tanker Oriental Navigator in Manila Bay early today, killing at least two men, injuring 17 others and leaving 18 missing.

title: BRIEFING
description: H OW could anyone, asked M. Stanton Evans, the conservative columnist, resist an invitation co-signed by a brewer and a Baptist preacher? Mr. Evans was referring to the ''Friends of Dick Allen Luncheon'' yesterday, which was the brainstorm of a number of prominent conservatives, including Joseph Coors, the brewer, and the Rev. Jerry Falwell, head of Moral Majority.

title: Argentine Gas Project
description: A consortium of Argentine and American companies today announced plans to liquefy Argentine natural gas and export it to the United States. The project, valued at $2.3 billion, is subject to final approval by the authorities in Buenos Aires and Washington.

title: U.S. Official Resigning
description: Lawrence Connell Jr. is resigning effective Jan. 1 as a member of the National Credit Union Administration to become head of a mutual savings bank in Seattle, the agency announced today. Mr. Connell, who served for two years as chairman of the three-member agency board that oversees the nation's 12,300 federally chartered credit unions, has been elected president and chief operating officer of Washington Mutual Savings Bank, the agency said. Mr. Connell, a lawyer and an economist, was bank commissioner in Connecticut before being named in 1977 by President Carter to be administrator of the agency.

title: INACTIVE RIFT, TWICE AS LONG AS SAN ANDREAS FAULT, IS FOUND
description: Analysis of gravity measurements, using computer techniques developed for processing data from Mars, has revealed an ancient inactive rift deep in the North American crust that may extend 1,700 miles from Idaho to the southern Appalachians. It appears to be at least twice the length of the San Andreas Fault in California.

title: Massachusetts Approves A Redistricting Plan
description: The Massachusetts Legislature gave final approval early today to a bill that would reduce the state's 12 Congressional districts to 11 in a manner that jeopardizes the reelection chances of Representative Barney Frank, a Democrat.

title: HERS
description: GHANA is one of the best things that ever happened to me, even though it was a long time ago. My family and I lived there for two years in the mid-1960's. Ghanaians impressed me from the moment I stepped off the plane. For aside from a few travelers, everyone was black, an even, opaque, velvety black that I had never seen before in the United States. The customs officials, families greeting passengers, taxi drivers, policemen, they were all intensely and beautifully black.

title: SAKHAROV'S WIFE IS IN MOSCOW
description: A gaunt Yelena G. Bonner returned here today, proclaiming the hunger strike she and her husband, Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist, had undertaken as a ''major victory'' for human rights.

title: Weinberger Bids Japan Spend More on Military
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger warned today of a possible United States backlash if the American people believed that Japan was contributing too little to mutual security in the Far East.

title: INQUIRY PRESSED INTO DERAILMENT ON IRT SUBWAY
description: The head of a Federal panel investigating the derailment of a West Side IRT subway train said yesterday that the accident was the third this year caused by a motor dropping from a moving train onto the tracks.

title: Saudi Oil Reserves
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, might have oil reserves twice as large as those already discovered, the oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said in a lecture today at Jordan University in Amman. The official Saudi Press Agency quoted Sheik Yamani as saying that the kingdom had ''a great potential for new oil discoveries, which could double its oil reserves.'' Sheik Yamani said last month that Saudi Arabia had proven oil reserves of 173 billion barrels, a quarter of the world's total.

title: British Labor Party To Act on Trotskyists
description: Britain's opposition leader won the backing of his Labor Party today for action against left-wing extremists within its ranks.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 17, 1981
description: International Key Polish strikes have been broken by the martial law authorities, according to information arriving from Warsaw. The reports also said the Roman Catholic Church had become a powerful voice in opposition to the new measures. Major military movements were reported under way around the country, including a convoy of about 300 vehicles moving along Warsaw's main road. (Page A1, Column 6.) The rights gained by Polish workers in last year's negotiations between the authorities and the independent Solidarity union were reaffirmed by the new military rulers. In a broadcast statement, the military council said the accords would not be repudiated even though new arrests were announced and further curbs on civil liberties were decreed. (A19:1.)

title: NEVER UNDERESTIMATE THE POWER OF A DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: A QUESTIONABLE RESOLUTION ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN ADOPTS PLAN TO END ENERGY DEPT. AND SHIFT ITS DUTIES
description: President Reagan has approved a proposal to abolish the Department of Energy and transfer most of its surviving functions to the Department of Commerce, Administration officials said today.

title: RATINGS AND CBS NEWS 'UPHEAVALS'
description: WHEN CBS News announced plans Tuesday to replace Charles Kuralt as anchor and Robert (Shad) News Analysis Northshield as producer of its morning newscast, they were just the latest in a series of profound changes that began rocking the network back in March. It was then that Dan Rather succeeded Walter Cronkite as anchorman on

title: YALE WILL ADMIT UNDERGRADUATES PART TIME
description: Yale University will for the first time allow older, part-time students to earn an undergraduate degree from Yale College, beginning next fall. Until now such degrees have been available only to fulltime students.

title: Reagan to Meet Reporters
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference at 2 P.M. today in Washington. It will be broadcast live on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks.

title: On Italian Design
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In the article ''In Milan, the Bizarre Becomes Respectable'' (Sept. 29, 1981) I commented on the present Italian design situation. I would like to explain my position in order to avoid misunderstandings.

title: REAGAN ROLLING OVER
description: On orders from Moscow, Poland's puppet Communist regime has declared war on the Polish workers' bid for selfgovernment, jailing thousands and beginning a crushing military control comparable to the Nazi occupation.

title: Convicted Spy Gets Life Prison Sentence
description: A convicted spy, Marian W. Zacharski, has been sentenced to life in prison for providing stolen national security information to the Polish Government.

title: Deaths Now Put at 30 In Beirut Bomb Blast
description: The death toll in a bomb explosion at the Iraqi Embassy in Beirut, originally believed to have been 20, was put at 30 today.

title: Koch Getting a New Car and an Extra 3 Inches
description: Mayor Koch, who once complained that riding around in the cramped back seat of his 1979 Chrysler Newport, gave him ''bedsores on my knees,'' is finally going to get some more leg room.

title: Sir Adrian Boult, 92, Retires as Conductor
description: Sir Adrian Boult has announced his retirement after 60 years as a conductor.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: THE Baldwin Company, well-known in this country as forgers of highquality solid brass decorative hardware and accessories, has entered upon an unusual marketing venture for a hardware manufacturer. In the past year Baldwin has helped private owners open Baldwin Brass Centers, which stock only Baldwin's large line of hardware.

title: SNARLS IRK KOCH
description: For the second time in three days, a high-ranking deputy in New York City's Transportation Department has resigned. City Hall officials indicated yesterday that other departures could follow, and Mayor Koch said he was unhappy about snarled traffic conditions on city streets.

title: UNEARTHING TREASURES AMONG THE TRIVIA
description: GROUND rules: First, a collectible these days is anything. Second, a collectible is only vaguely classified by such niceties as genre, age and condition. Third, a collector is anyone with a need to accumulate anything in profusion, a need fueled by the conviction that somewhere, sometime, he or she will uncover a treasure among the trivia.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Binney & Smith Inc., Easton, Pa., has named Jack F. Kofoed chairman, succeeding Russell J. McChesney, who is retiring.

title: PROPANE-POWERED CARS TO BE OFFERED BY FORD
description: The Ford Motor Company will begin selling limited numbers of cars fueled by propane rather than gasoline next year to take advantage of propane's lower cost.

title: F.B.I. OFFERS REWARD TO SOLVE KIDNAPPING OF A JUDGE'S WIFE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is offering a $10,000 reward for information leading to the capture of the man who abducted the wife of a Federal judge last October in what the agency said was ''retribution'' for past judicial actions.

title: Unions Rebuff American Airlines
description: Leaders of three labor unions representing American Airlines' 21,000 unionized employees have rejected pay cuts and freezes sought by management in an attempt to save $7 million a month, a company spokesman said.

title: GAS PRICE'S 'CATEGORY CREEP'
description: The price of natural gas is rising faster than had been contemplated under the 1978 legislation that partly decontrols gas prices, mainly because producers have become increasingly vigorous in adapting their operations to qualify for maximum prices from their wells.

title: Golan Annexation Is Assailed By Newspaper at the Vatican
description: The sem@iofficial Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano today strongly condemned Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: ARCO'S FRIGID KUPARUK TRACT OFFERS NEW POTENTIAL FOR PROFIT
description: When the Kuparuk oilfield was discovered in 1969, it was an inhospitable tract of frozen tundra on the Alaskan North Slope containing millions of barrels of crude oil that were simply too expensive to pump out at a profit. Oil experts dubbed the field a geological success but an economic failure.

title: MR. BEGIN'S SURPRISE
description: On Oct. 23, 1956, Hungarians rebelled against their Communist Government. Six days later, by prearrangement with Britain and France, Israel marched on the Suez Canal. The attack, begun while world attention was on Hungary, diffused outrage at the Soviet Union's brutal suppression of the uprising. And it ended disastrously for Britain, France and Israel.

title: AID FOR CONSUMERS: TELEPHONE TAPES
description: QUESTIONS on how to buy furniture, how to select a lawyer, how to arrange a funeral and on 74 other subjects can be answered over the telephone through a tape-recorded information service that was officially put into operation yesterday by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: SUBURBAN HOTELS RISING TO FILL CORPORATE NEEDS
description: The Westchester Marriott opened here today, part of a wave of suburban hotel development that is filling the needs of earlier industrial and corporate growth in the metropolitan region.

title: People
description: * Peter Gridley, senior vice president and general manager of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A.'s Washington office, has been elected to the board.

title: BIG APPLE CIRCUS: AUDIENCE IS ALMOST PART OF THE SHOW
description: DO you remember ''Trapeze''? In that movie, Burt Lancaster and Tony Curtis staked their lives on doing a triple - three somersaults in midair before grasping the hands of a catcher on a flying trapeze. In the Big Apple Circus, Tito Gaona does a triple, and makes it look matter of fact. He and his fellow and sister Gaonas are a spectacular aerial act. What makes them doubly exciting is their proximity to the audience.

title: The Joys (and Headaches) of Snow
description: Youngsters in Dix Hills, L.I., speeding along on sleds yesterday, while a resident of Kendall Park, N.J., got down to more serious business. An overnight squall dumped up to a foot of snow on New York's northern suburbs, and somewhat less on New Jersey and Long Island. Hundreds of schools were closed and morning traffic was slowed. One man was killed when his car slid and hit a tree in West Islip, L.I.

title: Advertising; Ethnic Ad Budgets Holding Up
description: THE traditional cutting of ethnic advertising budgets during recessions does not seem to be happening this time around, according to the leaders of the nation's few black-owned advertising agencies. That news comes from both New York and Chicago, where most of the half-dozen full-service companies operate.

title: OPERA: VERDI'S 'IL CORSARO'
description: THE Verdi revival proceeds apace. Tuesday night at Town Hall saw the first New York performance of ''Il Corsaro,'' which, along with ''Alzira,'' has generally been dismissed as the composer's weakest work. This concert performance followed the American premiere with the same forces Saturday night at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Ideal Basic Charge
description: Ideal Basic Industries Inc. said it would take a $15 million pretax write-off in the current quarter to close its Houston cement plants.

title: MAYORS AND GOVERNORS SEEK A 'SUMMIT' WITH U.S.
description: A coalition of state and local governments urged the Reagan Administration and Congress today to join them in a ''summit on federalism'' that would attempt to reach agreement on the financing and administration of domestic programs.

title: KOCH SUGGESTS USING AUXILIARY POLICE IN SUBWAYS
description: Mayor Koch suggested yesterday that auxiliary police officers be used to patrol subway stations. His proposal drew immediate denunciations from the transit police and auxiliary officers, who said it would endanger the lives of the officers and the public.

title: A.T.& T. Held Aid to Military
description: Former Defense Secretary Harold Brown testified today that a breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would weaken the country's military communications system and could imperil the nation in wartime.

title: Lumley Streak Stopped at 12
description: The Calgary Flames held Dave Lumley scoreless tonight but lost, 5-4,, to the Edo monton Oilers on Kevin Lowe's goal with 51 seconds to play.

title: U.S. Unit in Scotland
description: The Burr-Brown Research Corporation of Tucson, Ariz., said today that it would set up a production and development group near Edinburgh next year that would employ about 700 people by the late 1980's. The company said the presence in Scotland of a highly developed electronics industry and technically trained work force had been key factors in its decision. Scotland has one of the highest concentrations of microelectronics companies in Europe, with about 200 concerns based around Glasgow and Edinburgh.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
RECORD HOUSING BOND YIELDS
description: A flurry of tax-exempt housing revenue bond issues pushed yields in that sector to record highs yesterday, but despite yields as high as 13 3/4 percent and 14 percent for long-term bonds, underwriters described investor demand as modest and said some proposed issues might be withdrawn.

title: GUILTY PLEAS IN O.P.M. FRAUD CASE
description: Five former executives of O.P.M. Leasing Services Inc. pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to charges of defrauding major lending institutions of $190 million in one of the largest fraud cases in the nation's history.

title: 'Messiah' and Other Oratorios; Tomorrow; Colden Auditorium, Queens College,
description: Kissena Boulevard and Long Island Expressway. Handel's ''Messiah.'' Pamela Wood-Fraley, soprano; Constance Beavon, mezzo-soprano; Charles Abruzzo, tenor; Arthur Woodley, bass; Paul Maynard, harpsichordist; Alexander Kouguell, cellist; Queens College Choral Society conducted by Lawrence Eisman. At 8 P.M. Tickets: $4-$6. Information: 520-7200.

title: FROM ROCK TO MUSIC AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: APPROPRIATELY enough for the holidays, the television schedule is generously filled with music - though the appropriateness of individual selections may be questioned in some quarters.

title: CONFESSION FALSE, GUATEMALAN SAYS
description: A Guatemalan peasant leader who was presented on Guatemalan television as a defector from a leftist guerrilla group has escaped and said he was forced to ''confess'' after torture and threats to his family.

title: MOON CHURCH FOLLOWER AGREES TO LEAVE U.S.
description: A 20-year-old Australian woman, who came to the United States for a vacation but spent the last 14 months in the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church, agreed today to leave the country voluntarily rather than face deportation as an illegal alien.

title: DICK HYMAN REVAMPS THE QUINTET
description: WHEN Dick Hyman took a jazz quintet into Michael's Pub seven years ago to play a program of pieces by Jelly Roll Morton, Scott Joplin and James P. Johnson, he was known as a versatile pianist, electronic organist, arranger and composer closely associated with ragtime and stride piano. His group was billed as the ''Dick Hyman Quintet.''

title: N.H.L. Officials Protest
description: The National Hockey League said yesterday that it had received from the N.H.L. Officials Association a formal protest and a request for stiffer punishment than the five-game suspension imposed by the league Wednesday on Paul Holmgren of the Philadephia Flyers, who struck Andy van Hellemond, a referee, in the chest during a game Dec. 9 against Pittsburgh last week. But the league said it would take no action and have no comment on the request until John Ziegler, the N.H.L. president, returns from a trip abroad today.

title: Philadelphia Journal Dead, Its Owner Says
description: The president of Quebecor, the Canadian parent of The Philadelphia Journal, said today that the 4-yearold tabloid was dead. The newspaper, whose unions had rejected cuts in wages and benefits, shut down Wednesday.

title: Arab League Meeting Is Demanded by Syria
description: The Government said today that Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights was taking the Middle East to the ''edge of war'' and it called for an emergency session of the Arab League.

title: NOTHING WRONG WITH THE COINS WE'VE GOT
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN REAFFIRMS CIVIL RIGHTS STAND
description: President Reagan said today that he had no objection to voluntary affirmative action plans by labor and management to expand job opportunities in private industry for members of minority groups.

title: SCIENTISTS' MEETING WITH REAGAN REFLECTS WORRY OVER NUCLEAR PERIL
description: When Victor F. Weisskopf was a young physicist and a refugee from his native Vienna working on the Manhattan Project at Los Alamos in 1945, he had already begun to worry about the danger of nuclear war. With other scientists who were building the first atomic bomb, he helped found the Federation of Atomic Scientists, a group devoted to bringing atomic energy under international control.

title: CARTER DENOUNCES POLICY ON SOVIET
description: Former President Jimmy Carter accused the Reagan Administration yesterday of a ''one-sided attitude of belligerence toward the Soviet Union'' and voiced his deep concern over what he called ''radical changes'' in American foreign policy.

title: Diana T. Michaelis, Producer Of Movies and TV Programs
description: Diana Tead Michaelis, a television and motion picture producer, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Washington. She was 56 years old.

title: Strong Opinion
description: The opinion Whitey Herzog had of Garry Templeton was unmistakable. ''I can't win a pennant with that boy,'' Herzog, the field manager and general manager of the St. Louis Cardinals told a fund-raising dinner in suburban St. Louis.

title: Madrid Intends to Dismantle Franco's Newspaper Empire
description: The Spanish Parliament yesterday approved a plan to sell 27 Government-owned newspapers, virtually dismantling the press network set up under Francisco Franco.

title: IN RURAL ARKANSAS, SOME CALL EVOLUTION A THREAT TO FAITH
description: There is still among us a man, now aging quietly, who grew up in rural Yell County in the early years of the century. He was the orneriest of seven sons, a biter and a hellraiser.

title: ABOUT-FACE: THEY'LL MARCH FOR ST. PATRICK ON HIS DAY, AFTER ALL
description: The St. Patrick's Day parade will, after all, be held on St. Patrick's Day. Six days after after announcing that the 220-year-old New York City march, the city's biggest parade, would be moved from March 17 to the Sunday before the holiday each year, the parade chairman announced yesterday that it had been restored to the traditional date.

title: Personal Income Up By 0.6%
description: Personal income rose a modest six-tenths of 1 percent in November, and spending climbed a full 1 percent for the first time since August, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: NOW CHARITY SELLS OLDIES AS GOODIE'S
description: One good label, it would seem, deserves another. Hitching a ride on the designer jeans fad, Goodwill Industries has begun selling used jeans with its own status label, ''Goodie's.'' Some of the trendiest bodies in southern California may soon turn out in bluejeans somebody else gave away, if the charitable sales organization's hopes do not fall flat.

title: Bridge: Taiwan Defeats Indonesia To Win Far East Tourney
description: In perhaps the most exciting finale ever in international bridge, Taiwan won the Far East bridge championship in Taipei Tuesday after nine days of play.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ART: REDISCOVERING A PAINTER-PHOTOGRAPHER
description: IT looks as if one of the tasks of our art historians in the last decades of the 20th century is going to consist of re-examining the development of American art in the first decades of the century - the years when the ideas and innovations of the European avant-garde were having their first decisive impact on this side of the Atlantic. The scholarly research essential to this endeavor, and the critical revisionism that inevitably results from it, are already in progress, of course, but we are still only at the beginning of what is likely to bring some major shifts in the way the era of early modernism in American art will be perceived in the future.

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $376,000...C-After tax credits of $481,000 in the latest 9 mos and $1,665,000 in the earlier period; the net income amounts include foreign exchange gains of $136,000 in latest qr and $28,000 for the 9 mos against $316,000 for the 1980 qr and $297,000 for the earlier 9 mos

title: Friede Seeking A Full Recovery
description: For the Giants' first 14 games this season, Mike Friede started at wide receiver. This week, as last week, Earnest Gray will start because the right knee that Friede tore up last season still prevents him from doing the things that made him so exciting as a rookie.

title: AN EX-CONGRESSMAN FROM BRONX DISTRICT
description: James C. Healey, a former United States Representative from the Bronx, died Wednesday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Southampton.

title: Racial Abuse Charged
description: The Nevada Interscholastic Athletic Association has begun an investigation into allegations that the Valley High School girls' basketball team was subjected to verbal and physical abuse by spectators at a tournament in Carson City last month. Burt Cooper, executive director of the association, said that a written report to Clark County school administrators would be ready next week. Parents of several members of the basketball team complained to the Clark County School Trustees that black members of the team were the targets of racial insults and that at least one girl was punched by a spectator.

title: Anti-Soviet Protest in Delhi
description: About 500 people, including some Afghans, demonstrated outside the Soviet Embassy here today to protest the presence of Soviet troops in Afghanistan and developments in Poland.

title: 2 Sentenced in Lottery Case
description: Two former Pittsburgh television stagehands were given prison sentences today for their roles in rigging the Pennsylvania lottery last year. Judge William Lipsitt of Common Pleas Court sentenced Joseph Bock, 53 years old, and Fred Luman, 51, to one to five years each at the State Correctional Institute at Camp Hill. Both men pleaded guilty to helping rig the televised April 24, 1980, Daily Number drawing, which produced a $3.5 million payout.

title: Foreign Affairs; WHAT TO DO ON POLAND?
description: The trickle of information from militarized Poland has been enough to make two things clear.

title: JURY WEIGHS A $1.8 MILLION DAMAGE CLAIM BY 7 ACTIVISTS IN CAPITAL
description: A suit for invasion of privacy that seeks $1.8 million in damages from 15 officials of the District of Columbia police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation went to the jury today after an 18-day trial.

title: CALENDAR OF MUSIC FOR THE CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY SEASON
description: Following is a list of some of the musical presentations planned for the Christmas season at churches and concert halls in the metropolitan area. All are free unless otherwise noted. Today Cathedral of St. John the Divine (Episcopal), 1047 Amsterdam Avenue. Christmas concert: Paul Winter and the Winter Consort, Susan Osborn, singer, and Paul Halley, organist (also tomorrow). At 8 P.M. General admission, $7 and $12; reserved seats, $25. Information: 662-2133. St. Ignatius Loyola Church (Roman

title: 2 Workers Killed in Plunge
description: Two workers fell 124 feet to their deaths Thursday when a cable snapped as they were installing a water tank atop a tower at a school for the retarded. The two men, whose names were being withheld, were knocked down by a steel plate that was being lifted by the cable, Ronald Carlson, the city engineer, said.

title: Fort Chaffee Refugees Might Go to Montana
description: The Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to move the remaining 420 Cubans at Fort Chaffee, Ark. to the site of a former Air Force base near Glasgow, Mont., officials said today. None were willing to be quoted by name.

title: A.T.&T. EARNINGS ROSE 23.2% TO $1.96 BILLION IN 4TH QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported a 23.3 percent increase in fourth-quarter net income, its biggest quarterly gain in more than three and a half years. The latest rise was attributed by the company to business growth and higher phone rates.

title: Goldsmith Revises Offer to Diamond
description: The Diamond International Corporation, a diversified wood-products and paper producer, said it had received a revised merger proposal from Sir James Goldsmith, the London financier.

title: FUNK ROCK: SLAVE AT THE PALLADIUM
description: DAYTON, Ohio, has spawned an inordinate number of funk bands, from the Ohio Players to Lakeside, and one of the more promising is the eight-man Slave, which appeared at the Palladium on Thursday. Over the course of five albums, Slave has polished an engaging style of party music that's up-beat and tuneful, though not particularly original.

title: Burger Says Nixon Aide Made Assertion to Sell a New Book
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today that assertions made by John D. Ehrlichman about improper conversations between the Chief Justice and President Nixon were only attempts ''to sell a book.''

title: Around the World; Salvadoran Leader Calls U.N. Resolution Biased
description: The head of El Salvador's junta, responding to Wednesday night's vote in the United Nations General Assembly calling on the junta to negotiate with the leftist opposition, said today that the resolution was biased in favor of the insurgents.

title: New Propane Contract Is Traded in New York
description: With a crowd of onlookers at ringside, trading began early yesterday in a new propane futures contract on the New York Cotton Exchange, where orange juice futures are also traded.

title: INSTRUMENT SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,920,000 for the qr and $6,205,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.9 million for the qr and $13,991, for the yr

title: MRS. LLOYD BEATS MISS AUSTIN
description: In a tense 3-hour-18-minute marathon that went to a decisive tiebreaker, Chris Evert Lloyd defeated Tracy Austin, 4-6, 6-4, 7-6, tonight for a berth in the semifinals of the $250,000 Toyota Series women's tennis championships.

title: REAGAN WARNS SOVIET ON AID
description: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: MILLION AWARDED FOR KILLING IN '58
description: A Federal jury has awarded $1.79 million to the family of a black man slain by a white patrolman 23 years ago, finding that the police had shown racial bias in helping the officer cover up the incident.

title: 3 Get Interim; Appointments To U.S. Election Commission
description: President Reagan signed three appointments to the Federal Election Commission today, allowing the nominees to take office immediately without Senate confirmation because Congress is in recess.

title: Economic Scene; Food Output: Hopeful Signs
description: SCARCITY is reasserting itself and bringing the world back to basics. In barely a decade, economics has jumped from the back pages of the newspapers to a place of central importance. And in this decade, food and agriculture, the most basic activities of civilized man, promise to become as compelling a topic as oil and energy were in the 1970's.

title: Around the Nation; Colorado Bid to Recover Body on Peak Is Delayed
description: Blowing snow and subzero weather today suspended attempts by a mountain team on 14,255-foot Longs Peak to recover the body of an amateur climber who had frozen to death in a blizzard.

title: Agency Change Reports At SSC&B, and B.& J.
description: The hot street report - not confirmed by the client - is that SSC&B, already the agency for Martini & Rossi Vermouths from Renfield Importers, has additionally been assigned Martini & Rossi Asti Spumante, which could bill about $2 million.

title: Court Hearings On Marathon
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit heard oral arguments today on appeals brought by the Mobil Corporation and the United States Steel Corporation in their acquisition battle for the Marathon Oil Company.
