Chief Judge George Edwards said that a ruling would be expedited.

title: Elizabeth Taylor plans dual role as star and producer.
description: AFTER a lifetime in the movies, Elizabeth Taylor, who is nearing her 50th birthday, is suddenly taken with the theater. So taken, in fact, that she plans to return to Broadway next season not only as a star, but as a producer, too. Miss Taylor and Zev Bufman, who presented the actress in her Broadway debut last spring in Lillian Hellman's ''The Little Foxes,'' are forming a company that is to produce a subscription series of three plays a season on Broadway. The series will open next December with Shakespeare's ''Much Ado About Nothing,'' starring Miss Taylor and staged by Franco Zeffirelli, who directed Miss Taylor and Richard Burton in the film adaptation of ''The Taming of the Shrew.'' Christopher Plummer is likely to be the leading man.

title: 'YELLOW RAIN' POWDER TEST FINDS MAN-MADE AND NATURAL POISONS
description: Laboratory analysis of a sample of ''yellow rain'' powder indirectly obtained by ABC News from Hmong tribesmen has detected a man-made chemical that does not occur in nature as well as four poisons that are produced by fungi. Yellow rain is a term coined to refer to chemical warfare agents dropped from the air.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO INC (AT& reports earnings for Qtr to Nov
ITEL, LLOYD'S AGREE ON CLAIMS
description: The Itel Corporation, the company that went bankrupt leasing computer equipment, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to settle all remaining claims with Lloyd's of London, its principal insurer.

title: West Bank Talks Adjourned
description: Israeli, Egyptian and American officials concluded the latest round of discussions on Palestinian autonomy today, apparently without achieving a breakthrough.

title: THE ENEMY THAT MOROCCO FACES IN THE SAHARA
description: To the Editor:

title: C.W. Post 72, N.Y. Tech 60
description: Mike Henderson, a sophomore center, scored 22 points and grabbed 14 rebounds to lead C.W. Post to a 72-60 victory tonight over New York Tech in a Big Apple Conference game.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SOME DOMESTIC RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS IN POLAND
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $7.9 million net gain from the sale of river barges

title: Japan Imports Fewer Autos
description: Japan's auto imports this year are expected to dip below the 40,000-unit mark for the first time in eight years, an official of the Japan Automobile Importers' Association said today.

title: Coach Swings at Fan
description: Tom Watt, coach of the Winnipeg Jets, swung a hockey stick at a fan in the stands during a 4-2 victory tonight over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: President Adds Job At Penn Central
description: Richard A. Voell, the 47-year-old president and chief operating officer of the Penn Central Corporation, will add the title of chief executive officer after the annual meeting in May, the company said yesterday. He will succeed Richard Dicker in the position. Mr. Dicker, who will be 68 years old in March, continues as chairman.

title: Around the World; Angola Envoy Clarifies Remarks on Guerrillas
description: Angola's Ambassador to Portugal said today that he had been misquoted in reports saying that he expressed his Government's willingness to talk with the head of a pro-Western guerrilla group.

title: Around the Nation; Ensign Said to Have Sent Secrets to South Africans
description: A Navy ensign has been ordered to face a general court-martial on charges of sending electronics warfare secrets to the South African Embassy in Washington.

title: Jim Wilson
description: Mariusz Pieniak, second from left, and Rafal Rybzy, second from right, at Kennedy International Airport last night after they arrived on a flight from Warsaw. They are both in the country for heart surgery at a hospital in New Jersey. Wladyslava Pieniak, left, accomanied her daughter, and Thomas Rybzy arrived with his son.

title: STATE SAYS MAINTENANCE PROCEDURE CAUSED SEPT 9. CON ED BLACKOUT
description: A maintenance procedure that Consolidated Edison once used to cause ''an intentional short circuit'' was blamed yesterday for the Sept. 9 fire that blacked out most of Manhattan below 42d Street for four hours.

title: TEXAS ENERGIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: the company west public in Dec 1980 and that yr's figures are pro forma

title: AUCTIONS
description: BREAKING auction of American paintings, drawings and sculpture of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries last Friday at Christie's, Park Avenue and 59th Street, included John Singer Sargent's ''Women at Work,'' which sold for $550,000, an auction record for a work by the artist. The highest estimate for the turnof-the-century Impressionist study of women washing clothes and preparing food was $500,000.

title: 17-DAY STRIKE ENDS AGAINST COMPANIES COLLECTING TRASH
description: Private trash collectors and their striking workers reached agreement early yesterday on a new contract and ended a 17-day strike that had left New York City cluttered with piles of garbage.

title: CAR PHONE POLICY SET BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission today affirmed its decision in April to give telephone companies half of the new cellular radio business in each locality rather than open this new field to any company on an equal footing.

title: MOVE TO LIFT RATE CEILINGS
description: In an action that could benefit the nation's 26 million members of Federal credit unions, Government regulators today took a first step toward lifting interest-rate ceilings on savers' accounts and letting individual credit unions decide what to pay.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $6,765,433 or $2.04 a shr gain from the refinancing of mortgage on Plymouth Tower apartment project in New York...C-Net loss

title: MET: TATE LEADS STRAVINSKY
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's spectacular new ''Stravinsky'' acquired a new conductor, two new singers in ''Oedipus Rex'' and one in ''Le Rossignol'' in the performance given on Wednesday.

title: CENTER FINDING A BOOM IN NON-HOSPITAL BIRTHS
description: In the beginning, couples who went to the Upper East Side town house felt like pioneers, braving grandparents' nervous admonitions and doctors' doomsday scenarios. They were doing something then considered radical - having their babies delivered by nurse-midwives outside a hospital and taking them home within 12 hours.

title: Gain Is Slight In Fund Assets
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed $479 million in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the 29th consecutive rise, but the smallest since the week ended May 27.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
RED BRIGADES KIDNAP AN AMERICAN GENERAL IN VERONA
description: Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, a United States Army staff officer, was abducted today in Verona, Italy, a Pentagon spokesman disclosed tonight.

title: 500 TUBAS IN TOWN FOR A BIG BLOWOUT
description: Tuba players from all over the East coast, more than 500 of them, are expected to converge on Rockefeller Center on Sunday for the eighth annual ''A Tuba Christmas,'' a joyous celebration of the season, as seen from the vicinity of the bass clef. The event, which is the brainchild of Harvey Phillips, a professor of music at Indiana University, lasts from 3:30 to 4 P.M. and will take place whether the weather is clement or not. True to the spirit of the occasion, the tubafest occurs on the lower plaza at Rockefeller Center, just off Fifth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, at the base of the statue of Prometheus.

title: BLIZZARD OF CASES JAMS WINTER DOCKET
description: It may be the beginning of a logjam or it may be just a quirk, but for the first time that anyone can remember, the Supreme Court entered its Christmas recess with its argument calendar for the rest of the term completely filled.

title: Prisoner's Death Under Inquiry
description: An investigation has begun at the Federal prison here into the apparent suicide of an inmate who was a prosecution witness on the 1980 riots at New Mexico State Prison in Santa Fe.

title: The Cry From Poland
description: The unofficial news now trickling out of Poland speaks volumes. The Catholic bishops describe an ''entire nation terrorized by military force.'' The Times's John Darnton writes of a social order shattered by palpable fear. The Polish people are suffering a new kind of ''atomic'' attack - the isolation of every individual from every other so that in lonely desperation, millions might yield up the liberties won only over decades.

title: Notes on People; Sick List
description: There were snow flurries yesterday and a chill in the air, too, and both the Mayor of New York City and the Governor of New Jersey went home sick. The Governor of Connecticut also went home yesterday, feeling better.

title: HONORED BY MOSCOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Melt the Garbage Mountains
description: The differences between private trash contractors and their drivers loomed ever higher for 17 days. Suddenly in the small hours yesterday morning, both sides managed to find a formula to split their differences.

title: U.S. EASES TELEX RULE
description: The Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously today to end the monopoly of the Western Union Telegraph Company over telegram and teleprinter service in the United States.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Restated for a 3-for-2 stock split; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Brookwood Health Services accounted for as a pooling of interests

title: DEPLOYMENT FORCE SEEKS PERMANENT MIDEAST POST
description: The commander of the Rapid Deployment Force disclosed today that the United States had begun negotiations with several Middle Eastern nations to establish a forward headquarters in the region.

title: STAGE: 'SACK' OPENS 6TH ITALIAN FESTIVAL
description: IN the middle of the stage at the Perry Street Theater there is a large, sagging sack, the title ''character'' in a play by Claudio Remondi and Riccardo Caporossi. ''Sack'' or ''Sacco'' in Italian, an avant-garde exercise in the abuse of natural objects, is the opening play in the Sixth Festival of Italian Theater in New York.

title: LATE RALLY PUSHES DOW AHEAD BY 1.81
description: The stock market, after a sluggish morning and early afternoon, rallied slightly yesterday afternoon to close with a modest gain. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 1.81 points, to 870.53. Volume was moderate but up from recent levels, with 47.2 million shares traded, compared with 42.4 million on Wednesday. Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange slightly outnumbered decliners, 742 to 716.

title: LETTER BY COOKE ON ARMS POLICY PROMPTS PROTEST
description: In an unusual protest, a group of priests, brothers, nuns, church officials and members of the laity of the Archdiocese of New York have openly criticized Terence Cardinal Cooke for asserting that nuclear deterrence can be ''morally tolerated if a nation is sincerely trying to come up with a rational alternative.''

title: Real Estate; A Yea Vote For Smoke Detectors
description: LAST August, after three years of study and debate, the City Council passed a law requiring the installation of smoke detectors in partment buildings with three or more units and in hotels and boarding houses - an estimated two million apartments in all - by Jan. 1.

title: A PENTAGON HOSPITAL PLAN'S PECULIAR WAR SCENARIO
description: To the Editor:

title: Chock Full o'Nuts Shift
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, the New York-based coffee and restaurant company, announced yesterday that Dr. Leon Pordy, its 62-year-old executive vice president, had been named president. He succeeds William Black, 79, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: STATE IS URGED TO REVISE LINKS TO U.S. TAX LAWS
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Mayor Koch called on New York State yesterday to rewrite its tax laws so that it does not lose revenue because the Federal Government has cut corporate taxes.

title: Sony Net Falls By 10% in Year
description: The Sony Corporation said today that its fiscal year 1981 consolidated net income fell 10 percent from the previous year because of foreign exchange losses and higher taxes.

title: Chef to celebrities gets even better.
description: IN the past, Alain Sailhac has shown himself to be one of the most talented French chefs working in New York. Now he seems once again to be close to the top form he exhibited several years ago when he was at Le Cygne. As chef of Le Cirque, 65th Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, he is proving himself as dedicated to perfection with such simple, classic preparations as grilled paillard of beef and grilled chicken diable encrusted with crushed mustard seeds and breadcrumbs as he is with more innovative creations. These include a warm salad of scallops and roe on ruffled red-tip lettuce leaves; the firm, white-fleshed fish, lotte, in a rose-gold saffron sauce, and a lusty fricasee of chicken in an herb-scented tomato and white wine sauce, brightened with fresh ginger.

title: TEXT OF CARTER'S SPEECH ATTACKING FOREIGN POLICY OF REAGAN ADMINISTRATION
description: Following is the prepared text of the speech by former President Jimmy Carter yesterday to the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.

title: A Haitian Freeze
description: A Christmas plum to Attorney General William French Smith. His Justice Department has not abandoned the idea of sending illegal immigrants who have fled Haiti to detention at icy Fort Drum, N.Y. But now it says it won't do so, at least not during the dead of winter.

title: LEADERS IN CONGRESS FORESEE HARD TIMES FOR REAGAN IN '82
description: Congressional leaders of both parties indicated today that President Reagan might find it harder to get his programs through the House and Senate next year than he did in the session just ended.

title: NEW HOME, NEW LOOK FOR 'RUCKUS MANHATTAN'
description: He's added a huge, mosaic-pattern Checker cab, whose cigar-chomping driver swivels his head and asks, ''Where to?'' There's a new tableau of the Indians selling Manhattan to the Dutch. And the Statue of Liberty now stands high on a pair of beams, her flashlight torch illuminating the air-conditioning ducts.

title: WHAT BYRNE DID TO SOUTH JERSEY
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Nation; THE NUCLEAR TRAFFIC
description: Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights, a move taken without warning to the United States and timed to capitalize upon the crisis in Poland, raises the specter of a fifth Middle Eastern war. Combined with the Reagan Administration's denunciations of Colonel Qaddafi's support of international terrorism, the Israeli move also revives fear of the uncontrolled spread of nuclear weapons.

title: Around the World; Belgian King Swears In Coalition Government
description: King Baudouin of the Belgians swore in Wilfried Martens today as Prime Minister of a new center-right coalition Government whose first priority in office will be to revitalize Belgium's ailing economy.

title: Oil Shale Plans Delayed
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and the Tenneco Corporation said they had decided to delay for an undetermined period development of their joint Cathedral Bluffs oil shale recovery project in Colorado.

title: SUPER VALUE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 5
Catherine MacArthur, Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: Catherine T. MacArthur, who helped her late husband, John D. MacArthur, build a billion-dollar insurance and real estate fortune, died in Palm Beach Shores, Fla., Tuesday after a long illness. She was 72 years old.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WOOING SHOPPERS: MOBILIZATION IS ON
description: Holiday shopping, a New York spectacle and a magnet for visitors, saw a new wrinkle this week in the competition for proven spenders: a dramatic bit of customer-rustling.

title: OFFICIALS ASSAIL KOCH TAX PLAN FOR DEVELOPERS
description: A Koch administration proposal to change the way developers qualify for tax abatements and exemptions ran into heavy opposition yesterday from numerous elected officials and private groups.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Marvin Hagler announced that he will defend his world middleweight title March 6 at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas against either Fully Obel, the top-ranked World Boxing Association contender; Tony Sibson, of London, the European champion; Mickey Goodwin of Detroit or Caveman Lee of Philadelphia. ... Fernando Valenzuela, the National League rookie of the year and Cy Young Award winner, made his 1981 debut in the Mexican League last night with five strikeouts and three hits in a five-inning outing, and the Navojado Mayos defeated the Mazatlan Deers, 8-1. ... Carlos Reutemann has been promoted from No. 2 driver to the top spot by the Williams Grand Prix racing team to replace the retired Alan Jones. ... Fred Schaus, the director of athletics at West Virginia, said the school's football coaches will receive bonuses of about $14,000 for directing the Mountaineers to an 8-3 record and a Peach Bowl berth against Florida. Schaus said the money was secured from private donations.

title: PENNSYLVANIAN PICKED TO LEAD MUNICIPAL WORKERS
description: Gerald W. McEntee, a Pennsylvania labor union official, today was elected president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the nation's largest public workers' union.

title: BELUSHI AND AYKROYD IN 'NEIGHBORS'
description: THOMAS BERGER'S darkly funny novel ''Neighbors'' certainly wasn't tailor-made for John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd, but casting them in the film version was a good idea. Mr. Belushi makes a stolid and suspicious Earl Keese, a man whose life becomes a shambles when the wrong people move next door. And Mr. Aykroyd is a suitably menacing choice for Vic (called Harry in the novel), the brassy new neighbor who, for no reason that is ever explained, does everything in his power to drive Earl wild.

title: Article 137491 -- No Title
description: A $5,000 reward was offered yesterday for information leading to the apprehension and conviction of three suspects in the murder Wednesday night of an unarmed police officer. The officer was shot in Queens while trying to help his father-in-law, who was being robbed.

title: Advertising; Gathering Intelligence For Profit
description: IN the hard-fought but usually bloodless battle of the marketplace, the G-2, or intelligence service, plays an inordinately large role. In addition to the proprietary data coming into ad agencies, their clients and the media, there are a number of syndicated services profiting from the hunger to know. The advent of the computer has enlarged existing services and brought new ones into being.

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FOR NEW YORK AIR: TROUBLE
description: Neal Meehan, the president of New York Air, smiled wistfully as he watched film clips of more pleasant days for the upstart airline. Just a year ago, the carrier had audaciously challenged Eastern Airlines' popular Washingon shuttle. In February, New York Air added a run to Boston and then struggled to accommodate the throng of travelers the route attracted when it was introduced with a 29-cent promotional fare.

title: More Durability Urged For Army's New Tank
description: The General Accounting Office gave high grades to the new multimillion-dollar M-1 tank today but urged the Army to delay large-scale production until it improved the tank's engine and other components of its power train.

title: U.S. HAD PAYMENTS SURPLUS IN 3D PERIOD
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 17 (AP) - The United States recorded a surplus in its balance of payments for the fifth consecutive quarter during July-September, the Government reported today.

title: ON CHOPIN EXPRESS, POLISH VIGNETTES
description: The Chopin Express, the regular overnight train between Warsaw and Vienna and one of the West's few remaining links with Poland, glided silently to a halt here today in the late morning, about three hours late.

title: Attack in Gdansk Described
description: Two foreigners who left Poland today described the scene in Gdansk in the aftermath of Wednesday night's clashes .

title: FIRST ARRIVALS FROM POLAND TELL OF FEARS
description: Passengers on the first commercial air flight from Warsaw to New York since Saturday arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night, grateful at being able to leave but apprehensive for relatives and colleagues left behind.

title: G.M. to Lay Off 37,500 for Week
description: The General Motors Corporation, hit by bulging inventories and slumping sales, said today that it would temporarily lay off 37,500 workers at eight assembly plants across the country.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
FRIDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1981; The Economy
description: The President said he had no plans to raise taxes in any way, but a White House spokesman later said that ''revenue enhancement'' measures were still under active consideration. Mr. Reagan's emphatic remark at a news conference at first appeared to constitute a major policy statement. But the clarification cast it as chiefly an affirmation of his commitment to reduce income taxes by 25 percent over three years. (Page A1.)

title: DRILLING AND MINING PLANNED IN 5 RECREATION AREAS
description: The Interior Department has decided to open five national recreation areas run by the National Park Service to mining for minerals and drilling for oil and gas.

title: 2 Checks for Fouts
description: Two $1,122 cashier checks, one from a 68-year-old retired butcher, were sent to the National Football League Players' Association yesterday, in an attempt to prevent the threatened suspension of Dan Fouts, the quarterback, from the San Diego Chargers. The union earlier this week, in an official directive, had ordered the Chargers to suspend Fouts for failing to pay his 1981 dues, which amounted to $1,122.

title: Marian S. Collyer, an Actress And Widow of TV Personality
description: Marian Shockley Collyer, who appeared on the Broadway stage in the 1930's, died Monday in Los Angeles. She was the widow of Clayton (Bud) Collyer, the actor and television game-show personality of ''Beat the Clock'' and ''To Tell the Truth.''

title: Briefing
description: T HE White House gleamed in spotlight through the night storm, picturesque as a postcard as the guests arrived with only a moment's pause at the weapon detector. Inside, logs flamed at the hearth. Airs from ''The Nutcracker'' soared up from the military violinists. A mood of success suffused the invited, whose shucked galoshes lolled like Jacksonian Democrats down in the entrance corridor. The guests stepped upstairs to a splendid tableau of seasonal pine and twinkle that easily included the permanently merry smile of Richard M. Nixon, glimmering like the ghost of Christmas past from his newly emplaced portrait by the staircase. Ronald Reagan passed smiling and nodding as the cheerful host before long windows snug-faced to the beauty of a slanting snowfall.

title: Notes on People; Aloft on a New Career
description: Last year she made aviation history when she flew the first solarpowered airplane, the Gossamer Penguin. The flight was only a temporary break in her career as a Bakersfield, Calif., elementaryschool teacher.

title: CREATION DECISION PLEDGED BY DEC. 31
description: The Federal district judge hearing testimony in a trial challenging the consitutionality of Arkansas' creation science law stressed today that his opinion would stick to the narrow question of whether the creation view on the origin of the world was religion and thus barred from public school instruction.

title: PRESIDENT OPPOSES RISE IN INCOME TAX TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: President Reagan said today that he had ''no plans for increasing taxes in any way,'' but a White House spokesman said later that Mr. Reagan did not mean to rule out all forms of ''revenue enhancement.''

title: Around the Nation; Van Crash in South Kills Four Children and Adult
description: A van overcrowded with preschool children slid off a narrow bridge in the rain today and plunged 14 feet into a creek bed, where it burst into flames.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: English Cellist Wins Naumburg Competition
description: A 24-year-old English cellist, Colin Carr, won the first prize on Tuesday in the 1981 International Cello Competition sponsored by the Naumburg Foundation.

title: Xerox French Plans
description: Rank Xerox France, an affiliate of the Xerox Corporation said today that it planned to invest about $18.2 million in its factory near Lille in northern France. The factory, which has been reconditioning photocopiers, will begin manufacturing Xerox 600 electronic typewriters and other electronic equipment. The products, which are manufactured in the United States, will be sold throughout Europe.

title: REELING
description: The modern world's unfreedom brings to mind certain situations from crime films: the telephone rings, the criminal orders the kidnapped victim to pick up the receiver and speak with the caller in a normal, friendly tone of voice. Or, unexpectedly, someone enters a house taken over by criminals. The person who lives there, aware of the hidden bandits' pistols trained on him, receives his guest as if nothing at all were wrong, fixes him a drink, tries to act normal, and as quickly as possible drives away the one person who might have been able to help him. Or, bandits fleeing from a bank push a terrified woman teller out in front of them, using her body as a shield as they run to their car. The woman begs the guardians of justice not to shoot and to let the bandits make a safe getaway.

title: Index; International
description: Vast power clings to a sullied Japanese politician A2 U.S. hopes to set up a rapid de- ployment command in Mideast A3 Red Brigades kidnap U.S. general in Italy A3 Egypt and Israel sign another agreement on tourism A4 Civilians in Israeli Defense Minis- try protest appointment A5 Around the World A6 Text of Carter's speech on foreign policy A8 Reduced London fares struck down by Lords A9 Iraq says its forces opened a new offensive in the war with Iran A10 Guatemalan peasant leader tells of forced confession A11 Some ''interned'' Polish dissi- dents turn up abroad A15 Excerpts from Polish radio and television broadcasts A16 Soviet press agency stops report- ing Polish resistance A16 Czechs optimistic about Polish solution without intervention A17 Vignettes from Poland reach Vienna aboard Chopin Express A17 Government/Politics Koch tax-abatement plan for developers assailed A36 State urged to cut ties with Fed- eral tax laws B3 Con Ed's power failure on Sept. 9 tied to intentional short circuit B3 Washington Talk Briefing A28 Supreme Court's winter calendar is already crammed A28 F.T.C. celebrates holidays with a playful poke at itself A28 General Around the Nation A18 Childbearing Center on East Side overcomes some resistance B3 P.B.A. offers $5,000 reward for killers of unarmed officer B4 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 800 years of puppets on view C1 Where to ice skate in metropoli- tan area C34 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Flyers 2, Sabres 1
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Behn Wilson, who missed the previous 11 games because of suspension and injury, scored on a penalty shot late in the second period to lead Philadelphia.

title: NOBELISTS AT A THEATER PARTY
description: Scientists, not politicians, were center stage at a party in the Atrium of the Kennedy Center Wednesday night in celebration of the opening of the play ''The Physicists.''

title: MOSCOW CUTS BACK ON REPORTS OF RESISTANCE
description: After four days of relatively full reports, the Soviet Government press agency Tass cut back sharply today on dispatches describing resistance to martial law in Poland and actions by troops to overcome it.

title: Toyota in Malaysia
description: The Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest auto maker, announced in Tokyo yesterday that it was consolidating its sales network in Malaysia through the acquisition of shares in Malaysian auto concerns worth about $59 million. Toyota's sales in Malaysia in the first eight months of this year amounted to 11,200 vehicles, or 16.1 percent of the market. The Nissan Motor Company sold 18,600 units, for 26.8 percent of the market.

title: Louisville Defeats Penn in Japan Tourney, 76-68
description: Louisville's highly regarded Cardinals, led by Jerry Eaves's 17 points, shook off a second-half challenge by Penn tonight and won the first game of the Suntory Ball, 76-68. The game was the first of three this weekend involving the basketball teams of Louisville, Penn and Oregon State at the Aoyama Gakuin University gymnasium here.

title: MUSIC HERALDS THE CHRISTMAS HOLIDAY
description: SEASON By BERNARD HOLLAND

title: THE SCREEN: BURT REYNOLDS STARS IN 'SHARKY'S MACHINE'
description: IN ''Sharky's Machine,'' Burt Reynolds establishes himself as yet another movie star who is as valuable behind the camera as he is in front of it. Mr. Reynolds's third and best directorial effort - the first two were ''Gator'' and ''The End'' - is an unexpectedly accomplished cop thriller. There is, as is often the case with movies of that genre, less here than meets the eye: the plot has its unreasonable spots, and the story doesn't come to much in the end. But one measure of the success of ''Sharky's Machine'' is that it's too fast and exciting for those considerations to count until after the movie is over.

title: VAST POWER CLINGS TO A SULLIED JAPANESE POLITICIAN
description: His thinning hair is graying now, and his brow is marked by a deep horizontal furrow. But at 63, Kakuei Tanaka exudes energy with every gesture, every growl and every gravelly-voiced explosion of words - his voice, vaguely reminiscent of Louis Armstrong's, is instantly recognizable to Japanese.

title: DECISION FILE
description: Every day Federal agencies make decisions that affect the lives of Americans. Here are some recent cases: Exposure to Lead

title: Jersey Fare Rises Called Unneeded
description: NEWARK (AP) - NJ Transit announced yesterday that bus and train fare increases anticipated for the end of the year will not be necessary.

title: TEXT OF THE DECLARATION CRITICAL OF COOKE'S VIEW
description: Following is the text of a statement by some Catholics of the Archdiocese of New York in opposition to Terence Cardinal Cooke's views on nuclear deterrence:

title: Iranian, Italian and Yugoslav With Weapons Held in Florida
description: Three foreigners who were being tracked by Drug Enforcement Agency officials were held without bond today after the police found guns, a ski mask, binoculars and other items in their rental car.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alexander & Alexander Inc. has named Joseph J. Stahl 2d an executive vice president.

title: NO SLUMP APPARENT AT LUXURY STORES
description: Despite inflation, recession and erratic holiday buying, luxury apparel stores are thriving across the country. Whether in New York, Boston, Chicago or Los Angeles, these stores, relatively modest in size compared with the nation's struggling department stores, cater to high-income customers who usually are the last to be affected by recessions.

title: THREE KILLED IN MICHIGAN CRASH
description: Firefighters in Jackson, Mich., wetting down the remains of a house hit by a light plane early yesterday. A woman and three children in the building escaped injury, but the pilot and two passengers were killed. The plane hit the house shortly after taking off from a nearby airport.

title: FOR TRADE STAFF, A TIME OF UNREGULATED REVELRY
description: They gave a Christmas party at the Federal Trade Commission the other day. An economist for the Bureau of Economics played the fiddle, two lawyers from the Bureau of Competition sang a song, and staff members of the Bureau of Consumer Protection sat on the cafeteria floor and laughed very hard at this joke:

title: A LETTER FROM WARSAW
description: Following is a letter received yesterday from John Darnton, Warsaw bureau chief of The New York Times, addressed to Robert B. Semple Jr., the paper's foreign editor. Normal communications from Warsaw have been shut by the authorities since Sunday. Dec. 16, 1981 Dear Bob,

title: UNION MAY REOPEN CONTRACT AT AMERICAN MOTORS
description: Union leaders at the American Motors Corporation agreed today to begin exploratory talks on the company's proposal to defer paying employees about $150 million in scheduled raises to help the automobile maker through its financial slump.

title: THE CZECH VIEW: 'GO BACK TO WORK'
description: Senior Czechoslovak officials said today that they were reasonably optimistic that Poland would manage to restore economic and political order without the need for outside intervention.

title: TROTTIER SCORES 2 TO HELP ISLANDERS STOP CAPITALS, 4-1
description: The Islanders rediscovered two missing elements tonight, defense and the power play, and used both to beat the Washington Capitals, 4-1, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Hartford Revokes Race Track Permit
description: The state's Gaming Policy Board revoked a provisional license issued seven years ago to developers of what would have been Connecticut's first horse-racing track, in Wolcott.

title: HELD PENNSYLVANIA JOB
description: Dr. Ethel D. Allen, who as Secretary of the Commonwealth was once Pennsylvania's highest-ranking black woman, died Wednesday at Albert Einstein Medical Center. She was 52 years old.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, DECEMBER 18, 1981
description: International Seven Poles have been killed and hundreds wounded in scattered clashes with troops enforcing martial law restrictions, the Warsaw radio reported. The broadcasts gave the first official confirmation of casualties since the Polish authorities imposed martial law Sunday. The radio also reported that 160 militiamen and 164 civilians were wounded in Gdansk Wednesday night when troops dispersed the demonstrators. (Page A1, Column 6.) Fear has pervaded Poland since the crackdown began Sunday, according to a letter written by John Darnton, The Times's bureau chief in Warsaw. He said the authorities had mounted an overwhelming show of force, isolated demonstrators and slowly wore them down. ''A major factor in the ease with which military rule has been established so far,'' he wrote, ''was the Polish love and respect for the army. The army, like the flag and church, is a symbol of nationalism.'' (A1:3-5.)

title: STAGE: 'DUET FOR ONE,' MUSICIAN'S STORY, AT ROYALE
description: ONE of the most rending true-life tragedies of recent years is that of Jacqueline du Pre, the young master cellist whose playing career was brought to an end by multiple sclerosis. ''Duet for One,'' the British play that opened in an American production at the Royale last night, is a speculative, fictionalized dramatization of that story. Given Miss du Pre's fortitude in the face of her pain - a tale that is moving even in the sketchiest newspaper accounts - one has every right to expect a powerful drama. What we find instead, sadly enough, is a talky, chilly evening that proves, at best, mildly involving.

title: No Headline
description: IRAQ SAYS ITS FORCES IN IRAN RECAPTURED AREAS RECENTLY LOST

title: Tough Prisons, in a Tough Bind
description: Texas prisons stand as symbols of the state's tough criminal justice process. On vast prison plantations, convicts stoop in the broiling sun to cultivate vegetables for dining halls and cotton for uniforms. Only those who do well in the fields move on to vocational education. Wardens adhere to the autocratic, iron-fisted approach most states abandoned years ago.

title: Y Hanukkah Workshop
description: A few hours before Jewish families light candles for the first night of Hanukkah on Sunday, the 92d Street Y will offer families a workshop from 1:30 to 3 P.M. on the basic traditions of the eight-day Feast of Lights. Judy Fagin, who runs Jewish-education classes at the Y, will recount the story of the holiday and point out ways it is practiced today while participants make latkes (pancakes), learn the rules of dreidel (top) games and sculpture menorahs (nine-branched candelabra) from clay.

title: Notes on People; Traditions
description: With ''Sugar Babies'' in its third year, trimming the Christmas tree has become a cast ritual. This week in the cavernous lobby of the Mark Hellinger Theater, the stars, Mickey Rooney and Ann Miller, went through the routine, hanging tinsel and baubles on a small plastic tree.

title: REDUCED FARES IN LONDON REJECTED BY LORDS
description: A committee of the House of Lords, in a decision with wide political repercussions, today overturned the Greater London Council's program of subsidized fares for the city's buses and subways.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is not a case of a broken promise; this is a case of circumstances beyond our control, whose foundation has been laid over the last several decades.'' - President Reagan, on the economy. (B6:4.)

title: UBAF Bank Appoints New Chief
description: Harry F. Martin, 48, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the UBAF Arab American Bank, effective next Jan.18. UBAF is a New York commercial bank with more than $1 billion in assets.

title: Watergate Figure Wins
description: Suit Accusing Newspaper of Libel

title: 8 From a Polish Vessel Seek Asylum in Japan
description: Eight Polish citizens from a vessel sent to Japan to pick up a shipment of rice jumped ship in Nagoya yesterday and sought political asylum, the newspaper Mainichi reported.

title: PAYMENTS TO UNION LEADER LAID TO DONOVAN'S CONCERN
description: Two former bookkeepers for the New York City blasters' union said yesterday that the union's president had frequently received payroll checks from a New Jersey construction company while Raymond J. Donovan, now the United States Secretary of Labor, was a senior executive of the company.

title: Cockburn Services in Ireland
description: Services for Claud Cockburn, a British writer and social critic who died Tuesday in Cork, Ireland, will be held today near Ardmore, Ireland, where he and his wife, Patrica, lived. In addition to his wife, Mr. Cockburn is survived by three sons, Andrew, Patrick and Alexander; two daughters, Claudia Flanders of London, from his first marriage to the former Hope Hale; and Sarah, also of London, from his marriage to the former Jean Ross, and four granddaughters.

title: Calvin Klein Line Goes to Ally & Gargano
description: About 14 months ago, Calvin Klein dropped by Ally & Gargano to talk to a select group there about their work for clients and about his own products for about three hours.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 18, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Another Coach Banned In Sugar Bowl Scalping
description: The local school board has reprimanded and suspended without pay Ray Bonner, the football coach at Columbia High School, for his scalping of tickets to the Sugar Bowl.

title: Errico Is Denied a New Trial
description: A Federal judge yesterday denied a new trial to Con Errico, the former jockey who was convicted of racketeering in connection with the fixing of thoroughbred races in New York in the mid-1970's.

title: SOUTH BRONX INDUTRIAL PARK BEGINS TO TAKE SHAPE
description: What began two years ago as a speculative attempt by the city to spur new economic development in the South Bronx emerged yesterday as the beginning of a new industrial park.

title: 33 Florida Inmates Released On Court Overcrowding Order
description: Thirty-three inmates of the Orange County Jail were set free today by county officials who are under a Federal court order to reduce jail overcrowding.

title: Pageantry, Poetry and Dance; Today; American Museum of Natural History,
description: Hayden Planetarium, Central Park

title: SPOKANE RAPE CASE TAKES FAMILY TOLL
description: Last summer Ruth Coe described this eastern Washington city as ''a sweet, homey town,'' but that was before her son, Fred, was convicted of multiple charges of rape.

title: Fields Among 4 Jets Named to Pro Bowl
description: The baby fat remains on the cheeks, or maybe the appearance came from the smile Joe Fields made no attempt to contain today. He looked more like the pudgy, baby-faced kid who reported as a rookie in 1975 to Bob Fry, offensive line coach of the Jets, than the center who has been named to the American Conference team for the Pro Bowl game Jan. 31.

title: 9 Die as Korean Bridge Falls
description: Nine workers were killed today when a steel suspension bridge under construction collapsed and they plunged about 100 feet into a chasm on the South Korean resort island of Cheju, the police said.

title: U.S. JOINS AS U.N. COUNCIL VOTES TO CALL GOLAN ANNEXATION ILLEGAL
description: The Security Council voted unanimously tonight for a resolution calling Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights illegal and threatening to take ''appropriate measures'' if the decision was not reversed.

title: EMPIRE OIL & GAS reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
THOUSANDS PROTEST IN WARSAW STREETS
description: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: CGA COMPUTER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago figures are before distributions to stockholders of Allen Services Corp and after pro forma tax provisions related to the distributions

title: U.S. Embassy Services In Poland Are Curbed
description: The State Department said yesterday in Washington that the United States Embassy in Warsaw could not provide normal services to American citizens because security forces were restricting access to the embassy and diplomats could not travel in the normal way.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: The U.S. dollar amounts are translated from yen at the rate of 218 to the dollar; the shr earnings are per American Depositary Shrs

title: Transactions; BASEBALL MILWAUKEE (AL) - Named Dick Phillips as manager of Vancouver farm team in Pacific Coast League.  PITTSBURGH (NL) - Sold contract of Craig Cacek, first baseman, to California (AL).; BASKETBALL
description: MILWAUKEE (NBA) - Activated M ike Evans, guard, from injured list. PORTLAND (NBA) - Activated Bob G ross, forward, from injured list.

title: SNOW STORM HITS MIDDLE WEST
description: Students in Richmond, Ind., leaving their school bus after it skidded off the road yesterday morning. The children were trapped in the bus for about half an hour until rescue workers, delayed by the snow, reached the scene. The storm covered parts of the Middle West with up to a foot of snow.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Charter Company said it and others had increased their stake in the Centran Corporation to 254,800 shares, or 6.6 percent, through the purchase of 50,000 shares on the open market between Dec. 1 and Dec. 8 for a price of $1,106,981.

title: N.F.L. Enters a Weekend of Fulfillment
description: Four of the National Football League's 10 playoff positions are still to be filled, and 10 teams remain in contention, including the Giants and the Jets, as the 16-game regular season ends this weekend.

title: WALLACE, SAM P, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DEVELOPING SUBMARINE COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM
description: Last Oct. 8 the Defense Department announced that President Reagan had approved development of an extremely low frequency, or ELF, system for communicating with submerged submarines. Existing ELF test antennas in Wisconsin were to be linked with a new, larger set of antennas on Michigan's Upper Peninsula.

title: POP LIFE
description: and-blues piano ace. Mr. Crawford and Mr. Newman are soulful saxophonists who first played together in the Ray Charles band of the 1950's. The three men have crossed paths many times, most recently when they were working together on a B.B. King record album. But they never performed live together until this weekend, which will find them working under the name Swamp Jam at the Seventh Avenue South jazz club.

title: ANSWERING SERVICE GALA: BELLS ARE RINGING
description: When the clients of the Executive Answering Service phoned in the other day, everyone received the same message: ''We're having a Christmas party and you're invited.'' The clients said they'd be there with bells on.

title: Around the World; Geneva Talks on Missiles Recessed Until Jan. 12
description: The United States and the Soviet Union today recessed their three-week-old discussions on the reduction of mediumrange missiles until Jan. 12 to permit the two delegations to spend the holidays with their families.

title: WHERE TO ICE SKATE, OUTDOORS AND IN
description: When Hans Brinker laced up his silver skates, all he had to do was step outside his house and he was able to take off on the icy canals of Amsterdam. It may not be quite so easy as that in our city, but New Yorkers don't have to go far from home for good skating surfaces.

title: Friday; OPERATIC DOUBLE BILL
description: A Wild West melodrama and a spoof of a 1930's radio show are the double-bill presentation of the Chamber Opera Theater of New York at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street. ''The Face on the Barroom Floor'' by Henry Mollicone - making its New York premiere - is a tale of love and murder set in a saloon. In Gian Carlo Menotti's ''The Old Maid and the Thief'' a diva, a vamp, a character actress and a booze-swilling baritone rehearse for the broadcast of an opera, and all sorts of things go wrong. Both works are in English and both are billed as entertainment for the whole family. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. and on Sunday at 3 P.M. . Tickets are $20 ($15 for the matinee). Reservations: 737-9611.

title: ROBBINS & MYERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
EGYPT-ISRAEL FERRY IS PLANNED
description: Israel and Egypt signed an agreement today to open a ferry line between the Mediterranean port towns of Ashdod and Port Said after Israel's final scheduled withdrawal from Sinai next April.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PROCESS LENGTHENS SHELF LIFE FOR MILK
description: Three regional milk-marketing cooperatives have reached an agreement to collaborate in the distribution of milk treated with a new sterilizing process that permits storage up to three months without refrigeration and with scant alteration of taste.

title: Argentina Has New Air Chief
description: Brig. Gen. Arturo Lami Dozo assumed office today as commander of the Argentine Air Force and a member of the governing military junta. He replaces Brig. Gen. Omar Graffigna, who retired.

title: NEW EDITORS ARE APPOINTED FOR 3 DEPARTMENTS OF TIMES
description: The New York Times has appointed new editors of three departments, it was announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, the executive editor. The three are Richard Flaste, science news director; Michael J. Leahy, travel editor, and William Stockton, assistant to the executive editor in charge of news polls and other statistical news projects.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including pretax gains of $379,000 for the qr and $1,768,000 for the yr on equity in net income of nonconsolidated affiliate pretax foreign exchange losses of $549,000 for the qr and $370, for the yr, other pretax expenses of $728,000 for the qr and ot income of $554,000 for the yr...C-Including pretax gain of $329 on equity in net income of non-consolidated affiliates pretax l of $606,000 on sales of equity securities, pretax foreign excha gain of $64,000 other pretax expenses $815,000 and extraordinar loss of $500,000...D-Including pretax gain of $1,406,000 on equ in net income of non-consolidated affiliates, pretax gain of $12,520,000 on the sales of equity securities, pretax foreign exchange loss of $300,000, other income of $843,000 and extraor gain of $38.5 million

title: REAGAN WARNS SOVIETS ON AID
description: President Reagan said today that the Solidarity movement in Poland was being suppressed with ''the full knowledge and the support of the Soviet Union.''

title: New U.N. Chief Goes Home
description: Javier Perez de Cuellar, the newly elected Secretary General of the United Nations, returned to Peru today to spend Christmas at home before taking up his post Jan. 1.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''I T would be the sort of thing Noel would like,'' said Nancy Winters. ''We'll begin here at the Algonquin, then get on the QE2, cross, get off and go to the Ritz, where Steve will sing 'Our Little Corner of the World.' Then we'll catch the new Venice-Simplon Express to Venice. Noel would like that wouldn't he?''

title: PUBLISHING: CUTTING BACK ON BOOK AWARDS 'HYPE'
description: SOME 90 nominees for the 1982 American Book Awards will be announced on Feb. 3, and the ceremony will be held at Carnegie Hall on April 27. This time, however, there will be no white knuckles among those attending the awards ceremony because the winners will be known in advance.

title: 'IT IS A GRAVE RESPONSIBILITY TO KILL HOPE'
description: Takeovers by military juntas, like the one in Poland, are nothing new in the sad chronicles of our century. Again and again, guns and tanks have been used to silence voices calling for freedom and dignity. Yet, there is something radically new in the current Polish situation, just as the Solidarity movement is without precedent in modern history.

title: MILLER, HENRY S, REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After gains on sales of real estate of $26,703 in qr and $807,014 for the 9 mos...C-After gain on sale of real estate of $33,968

title: JUSTICE SYSTEM IN STATE FOUND NEARING CHAOS
description: A commission appointed by Governor Carey to study crime issued a gloomy report today on the state's criminal-justice system.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Hughes Tool Co. is offering $100 million in 14 1/4 percent notes due Dec.15, 1988, at 99.125 percent plus accrued interest from Dec.15, 1981, to time of delivery, to be sold through a Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt A DICTIONARY OF EUPHEMISMS & OTHER DOUBLETALK. Being a Com- pilation of Linguistic Fig Leaves and Verbal Flourishes for Artful Users of the English Language. By Hugh Raw- son. 312 pages. Crown. $15.95.

title: CONGRESS APPROVES SEWER BILL
description: Hoping to get money flowing to city and state sewer construction projects again, Congress on Wednesday approved legislation intended to meet President Reagan's demands that Federal assistance to the projects be trimmed.

title: ISRAELI DEFENSE MINISTRY WORKERS PROTEST EXPATRIATE'S APPOINTMENT
description: Civilian employees of Israel's Defense Ministry stopped work today for an hour to protest the assignment of the post of coordinator of arms exports to a 36-year-old Israeli expatriate who had risen to the presidency of an American corporation.

title: PERSONAL INCOME RISES
description: American factories operated at less than three-quarters of capacity last month, matching the lowest level of last year's recession, the Government reported today.

title: Three 'Detained' Poles Turn Out to Be Abroad
description: At least three of the 57 unionists and dissidents reported by the Warsaw radio to be interned in Poland are abroad. Two - Miroslaw Chojecki and Wojciech Karpinski - were in New York on Thursday.

title: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $100,000 gain from discontinued operations... C-Net income

title: Support for DMSO
description: In testimony before a committee of the Georgia House of Representatives, June Jones, a quarterback for the Atlanta Falcons, and Stan Cottrell, a cross-country runner, called for the legalization of DMSO, an industrial solvent used by many athletes to treat muscle strains. Jones told the committee that the drug, which is not licensed by the Food and Drug Administration, is commonly used by members of the Falcons and could someday be considered ''a major medical breakthrough, even more than penicillin.'' Cottrell said that DMSO will be in his training kit when he runs across China in 1982.

title: Justice Dept. Firm On Schlitz Merger
description: The Justice Department will not reconsider its Oct. 21 decision to oppose a $494 million merger between the Jos.

title: DISSIDENTS CHARGE A 'SELLOUT' ON TEAMSTER CONTRACT TALKS
description: A group of dissident members of the International Brootherhood of Teamsters accused the union's leadership today of pursuing a ''sweetheart deal'' that would deliver too many concessions to employers in the current contract negotiations and charged that union officials were preparing to rig the ratification vote on the contract.

title: Yankees Closing In on Pact With Collins
description: If minor details involving playing time are worked out, Dave Collins will to sign a three-year Yankee contract that will pay him $750,000 a year, nearly tripling his Cincinnati Reds salary and perhaps jeopardizing the first base job that has been shared by Dave Revering and Bob Watson.

title: REAGAN DENIES OVERREACTION BY U.S. TO REPORT OF LIBYAN ASSASSIN TEAM
description: President Reagan dismissed suggestions today that his Administration had overreacted to reports of threats from Libyan assassination teams, saying that ''the threat was real'' and that it was based on information from several sources.

title: The Shrine by the Lake
description: THE ballot for the Baseball Hall of Fame has arrived, to be returned before Jan. 10. Ballots go to characters who have been members of the Baseball Writers' Association of America for at least 10 years, and a former player must be named by 75 percent of the voters to be dubbed immortal and enshrined on the shore of Lake Otsego in Cooperstown, N.Y. There is space for 10 names to be checked off on each ballot, but to run that many in every year would, it is felt here, water down the distinction.

title: 2 MAJOR PROTESTANT CHURCHES CALL FOR AN END TO ARMS RACE
description: Leaders of two major Protestant denominations, the American Baptists and United Presbyterians, have called for an end to the nuclear arms race and are urging members to work and pray to stop the production of nuclear weapons at home and abroad.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SUPPORT FOR ENERGY UNIT VOICED
description: Key members of Congress indicated today that the Administration's plan to abolish the Energy Department stood little better than a 50-50 chance of passage.

title: 800 YEARS OF PUPPETRY ON DISPLAY
description: THE magical world of puppetry is explored in ''Puppets: Art and Entertainment,'' a comprehensive new exhibition at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum on Fifth Avenue. As Michael R. Malkin says in his introduction to the catalogue for the show: ''With puppetry, as with much socalled 'primitive art,' we discover not simplicity, but primal force, not the periphery of an art form, but its core.'' Entertainment is certainly essential to puppetry, but the cumulative effect of the show is to enrich one's understanding of it as an instrument with a creative, social, political and educational purpose - for adults as well as children.

title: HAPPINESS AND GOOD FORTUNE INSPIRE DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund find in their own happiness and good fortune the inspiration for giving to others. Few, however, could match the elation expressed by Nora and David Tulchin of Larchmont, N.Y., in a note explaining their gift of $75.

title: Chicago Bank Raises Prime; Chicago Bank Raises Prime
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, the nation's seventh-largest commercial bank, raised its prime lending rate today to 15 3/4 percent, the industrywide level.

title: News Analysis
description: Behind President Reagan's stern denunciation of Poland's military crackdown today is an effort to use the leverage of future American economic aid to get the Polish Government to end coercive measures and resume political negotiations with the Solidarity union leadership.

title: IF ANTLERLESS DEER WERE NOT HARVESTED
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW AVANT-GARDE DANCE FROM LUCINDA CHILDS
description: LUCINDA CHILDS looks like her dances: cool, intense, her head all sleek, uncompromisingly sculptured bones under the severely drawnback hair. Only her smile betrays uncheckable emotions as Miss Childs sits over coffee in the spare kitchen of her SoHo studio-home. But, after all, her new full-evening piece, which brings the ''Next Wave'' festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music to a close this weekend, is called ''Relative Calm.''

title: PRICE IS PUT AT $4 MILLION
description: Dodd, Mead, one of the last major privately held, family-owned book publishers in the United States and the longtime American publisher of George Bernard Shaw and Agatha Christie, will be acquired by Thomas Nelson Inc., the nation's largest publisher of Bibles. One well-placed publishing source put the selling price at $4 million to $6 million, subject to final audit.

title: RESOLUTION ON GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: Following is the text of a resolution on Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights that the Security Council adopted unanimously today:

title: New films pour in; so do promoters.
description: HARK, HARK, the dogs do bark, the movies are coming to town. Gluts of them. During the last 10 days, ''Taps,'' ''Four Friends,'' ''Buddy Buddy,'' ''Rollover,'' ''Pennies From Heaven,'' ''Ghost Story,'' ''Tales From the Vienna Woods,'' ''Neighbors'' and ''Heartbeeps'' have arrived in New York, closely followed by junketeering media folk from all over the country.

title: Market Place; Pension Data May Mislead
description: THE many analysts who explain stock market behavior in terms of pension fund activity are often wrong because the data they use are inaccurate.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in the East Room of the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: 'Search for Tomorrow' Leaving CBS for NBC
description: ''Search for Tomorrow,'' the longest-running daytime television serial, will leave CBS for NBC beginning March 29, it has been announced by Brandon Tartikoff, president of NBC Entertainment.

title: ART: HOUSEHOLD OBJECTS DON MYSTERIOUS GUISES
description: THE most original show of the month, and the most difficult to categorize, is by Andrew Lord. It is at the Blum-Helman Gallery through Jan. 16, and it looks at first sight like part of an avantgarde department store. It consists, that is to say, of ceramic sculptures that take teapots, coffeepots, cups, mugs, dishes and saucers as their points of departure. They are set out like sets, though many of them turn out on examination not to go together. The installation is on shelves and tables very like the ones that we find in big stores.

title: Eastern Air Sets Miami Expansion
description: Despite being hit hard by the national downturn in commercial aviation, Eastern Airlines said it intended to proceed with plans to spend $64 million for expansion of its facilities at Miami International Airport.

title: The City; 3 Children Saved In Brooklyn Fire
description: Three small children were rescued from their burning apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn by a neighbor and a mailman, the Fire Department reported.

title: Chicago Man Linked to Nazis Is Killed by Train in Cicero, Ill.
description: The Justice Department filed suit today to revoke the citizenship of a man accused of participating in Nazi war crimes in Europe in World War II. A few hours later, the man was killed by a train.

title: UNITED REALTY INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Notes on People; A $10,000 Season's Greeting for Harlem Hospital
description: ''Poinsettias are only one way to reflect the spirit of giving at Christmastime, money is surely another,'' said Lewis Rudin, a New York City developer and chairman of the Association for a Better New York.

title: Sports People; Oilers Lose Fuhr
description: Grant Fuhr, the rookie goaltender for the Edmonton Oilers, has suffered a dislocated right shoulder and will be out at least a week.

title: Melvin Freud, 76, a Promoter And a Merchandiser of Toys
description: Melvin Freud, an early merchandiser and promoter of educational toys, died Wednesday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: GROWTH, AND RISKS, FOR BOSCH
description: Some people like to think of the Robert Bosch company as a West German auto parts manufacturer with hobbies. Although Bosch diversified into products like home appliances and radio equipment as early as the 1920's, its reputation still rests largely on its sophisticated auto ignitions, fuel injection and lighting systems.

title: TO TAKE THE SUBSIDY OUT OF BIG MERGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: GIANTS AND JETS FACE FINAL HURDLES IN PLAYOFF RACE COWBOYS AN IMPOSING THREAT
description: It will all be on the line Saturday for the Giants. If, as 3-point underdogs, they upset the Dallas Cowboys at Giants Stadium in their regular-season finale, they will be alive in their quest for their first playoff berth since 1963. Then they will have to await the outcome of two Sunday games, hoping that the Jets can beat Green Bay or that St. Louis can topple Philadelphia.

title: WACHOVIA REALTY INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PROTEST RALLY
description: Some of the thousands of demonstrators in Stockholm as they protested the declaration of martial law in Poland.

title: The City; 14 Get New Terms On Criminal Court
description: Mayor Koch reappointed to full 10-year terms all 14 Criminal Court judges whose terms expire at the end of this year.

title: PRINCETON BEATEN BY 39-38
description: Steve Trumbo of Brigham Young said that he did not really think he had been fouled by Princeton during the scramble for a rebound with 1 second to play and the score tied at 38-all. But when Tom Birch, the official, ruled that Trumbo had been fouled by Bill Ryan, Trumbo did not argue. He went to the foul line and made the first of two free throws to give Brigham Young a 39-38 triumph tonight in Jadwin Gym.

title: THE ANTA RENAMED THE VIRGINIA
description: The ANTA Theater, 245 West 52d Street, will be renamed the Virginia Theater next month in honor of Virginia Binger, who owns the playhouse with her husband, James. The renaming will take place after the ANTA's occupant, the Pilobolus Dance Theater, ends its engagement Jan. 10.

title: ITALIANS FIND NO TRACE OF U.S. GENERAL
description: A countrywide search by the Italian police over the last 24 hours has turned up no trace of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, the American who was kidnapped from his apartment in Verona Thursday.

title: Notes on People; Freedom for Mandel
description: There was another homecoming yesterday, this one for former Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland, who became a free man after spending 19 months in prison, still insisting that he had been wrongfully convicted on mail fraud and racketeering charges.

title: NO ONE SEEMS SATISFIED WITH THE NEW FARM BILL
description: The longest continuing drama in Congress this year, the Farm Act of 1981, finally ended with more losers than winners and with nobody really satisfied: not the consumers, not the farmers nor the Reagan Administration.

title: Week's Coal Output Up
description: The National Coal Association reported today that bituminous coal production for the week ended Dec. 12 was 17,250,000 tons, up from the previous week's production of 16,430,000 tons.

title: RAMPART GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LINCOLN INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After extraordinary losses of $278,000 for the qr and $392,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net income which includes extraordinary gains equal to the entire net incomefor the qr and $144,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated

title: INQUIRY ON BALLOT PATROLS IS DROPPED
description: The Essex County Prosecutor said today that he would not bring criminal charges against anyone involved in a Republican Party ballot-security program, although there had been technical violations of New Jersey's election laws.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 49. 1. The Polish Government decreed martial law hours after leaders of the Solidarity union, meeting in Gdansk, made a proposal. What was the proposal?

title: Paul d'Otrenge Seghers, Head of International Tax Institute
description: Paul d'Otrenge Seghers, a tax lawyer and president of the International Tax Institute, died last Sunday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Consumer Saturday; STATE SUES OVER HOME FOOD SALES
description: A COMPANY described as the largest home food service concern in the Northeast used illegal sales techniques and grossly misrepresented the savings to consumers of buying food in bulk from it, according to a suit filed this week by the State Attorney General's office.

title: North Carolina's Subtle Star
description: Matt Doherty was still a high school player at Holy Trinity on Long Island when he realized that descriptions of his running and leaping ability would never be placed at the top of his basketball resume. Dean Smith, the University of North Carolina coach, realized long ago that other contributions, especially the more subtle ones, are just as important to a team.

title: MADRID TALKS ADJOURN WITH WRANGLING OVER POLAND
description: In its last session before adjourning for two months, the Madrid conference on detente and human rights today broke out in sharp exchanges over Poland.

title: Happy Endings
description: The Devil's Work in Vermont

title: COURT NAMES RULING ON MARATHON BIDS
description: A three-judge Federal appeals court in Cincinnati is expected to decide before Christmas whether to permit the Mobil Corporation to go ahead with its $6.5 billion takeover bid for the Marathon Oil Company, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: Bridge: A Brilliant Defensive Move
description: Gets Surprising Response By ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
INSURERS' SHIFT ON INVESTMENTS
description: Less than a decade ago, the Aetna Life Insurance Company put more than 80 percent of its investment cash into corporate bonds and mortgages, the traditional havens for premium income. But today its new investments in that sector have declined by half, and the company is now buying office buildings, common stocks and even coal mines.

title: Pacific Overtures
description: No one can yet say what Hanoi has in mind by inviting four Vietnam veterans for a visit - or what Washington has in mind by welcoming this first mission of its kind. But simply as symbolism, it is splendid news. Who better to explore hopes for genuine peace than Americans who fought there? And what better time of year?

title: KARL STRUSS, 95, CINEMATOGRAPHER
description: Karl Struss, the Academy Award-winning cinematographer who did the camera work in the 1925 version of ''Ben Hur'' and filmed all of Mary Pickford's movies, died of heart failure Wednesday at St. John's Hospital. He was 95 years old.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $228,000 net gain from elimination of a note payable and related accrued interest due to the Small Business Administration as a result of the expiration of statute of limitations

title: Social Security Appeal By Democrats Assailed
description: John Svahn, the Social Security Commissioner, says postal fraud laws may have been violated by a Democratic National Committee fund-raising letter mailed in an envelope that looks like Government stationery.

title: NEWS'S WOES LAID TO SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC SHIFTS
description: The difficulties of The Daily News, newspaper-industry analysts said last night, were caused chiefly by the migration of many of its readers to the suburbs, declining circulation and rising costs.

title: FIRE STRIKES LYNN, MASS., AGAIN
description: Firefighters battling a nine-alarm fire in a plastics factory yesterday 10 miles north of Boston.

title: De Gustibus; LATKES: FOOD FIT FOR A HOLIDAY
description: Although I did not suffer many deprivations as a child, I still harbor a minor but enduring touch of resentment that crops up every year as Hanukkah approaches. For though my family observed that holiday with the traditional weeklong lighting of the silver candelabra, and though potato pancakes were a family favorite in good standing, I never knew those marvelously crisp, hot, onion-scented latkes had anything whatever to do with the celebration that, this year, begins tomorrow night.

title: MISS HOLTZMAN WITNESSES PROSECUTORS AT WORK
description: Shortly after midnight one recent morning, Elizabeth Holtzman sat in a noisy, green-walled room on the fringe of downtown Brooklyn and listened as Police Officer Albert Bagley told Lisa Smith, an assistant district attorney, how he had arrested three men in a Park Slope numbers operation.

title: MANY GIVE TO NEEDIEST CASES TO MARK THE HOLIDAY SEASON
description: With growing frequency, contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are making donations ''in lieu of'' what they might have otherwise spent on holiday greeting cards and gifts.

title: Frenchwoman Wins Ski
description: Marie-Cecile Gros-Gaudenier today became the first Frenchwoman to win a World Cup downhill ski race since Jacquelin Rouvier at Val D'Isere, France, in 1972.

title: PACKAGING THE STUFF OF DREAMS
description: Christmas 1981 hasn't yet arrived, but for Ira Levy and Marc Rosen, it's long gone. In fact, last summer, while other people were sunning themselves, they were busily plotting what Santa might be sliding down the chimney with next year. And now, when ordinary mortals are still wondering what their unopened gifts contain, the two men are seriously flirting with temptations for 1983.

title: THE DAILY NEWS IS FOR SALE, PARENT COMPANY ANNOUNCES
description: The Daily News is being offered for sale, its owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago, announced yesterday. The News, a tabloid, which has the largest circulation in the country for a general-interest newspaper, says it has lost at least $11 million this year. Over the last decade, circulation and advertising income have dropped sharply.

title: McMahon Leads B.Y.U.  In Holiday Bowl, 38-36
description: Jim McMahon threw for 342 yards, including three touchdowns, as Brigham Young withstood a furious secondhalf rally by Washington State for a 38-36 victory tonight in the Holiday Bowl.

title: Required Reading
description: Ahoy, Nebraska!

title: BLAST KILLS 6 AT ZIMBABWE PARTY OFFICE
description: A bomb wrecked the headquarters of the ruling political party here today, and the police reported that at least 6 people were killed and 125 were injured.

title: BONN ACTS TO DEFER AID UNTIL POLISH CRISIS ENDS
description: Parliament called on Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government today to refrain from deciding on further economic aid to Poland as ''long as the repressive measures of the current regime continue to be directed at the Polish people.''

title: MUSIC: THE CONCERTO SOLOISTS
description: The Concerto Soloists of Philadelphia constitute the most impressive small ensemble to come through Carnegie Hall in quite some time. Monday evening, its small complement of strings and added winds played exquisitely in tune and with great agility. They also showed the ability to change the weight of their sound to suit the music - from the angular, combative style of K.P.E. Bach's B minor Sinfonia to the luscious fullness of Britten's ''Simple Symphony'' and Respighi's ''Ancient Airs and Dances.''

title: INTERNATIONAL VIDEO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $125,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $89,000 for the qr and $128,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $27,000 for the qr and $43,000 for the 6 mos; the companysaid that shr earnings figures were based on an 11 percent increase in the outstanding common shrs

title: Rank to Purchase 21% of Telecom
description: The Rank Organization said that it had concluded an agreement for the purchase of a 21 percent equity interest in the Telecom Equipment Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, with the option to increase its shareholding to 25 percent in the next three years.

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CHINA BEGINS TO DISMANTLE AN ELITE SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: Zhao Jianping, a lively seven-year-old in a green sweater, selected another color from his crayon box, shifted his sheet of paper and sketched the white plastic rabbit that the teacher had set out as a model on her desk.

title: IN STEEL TOWN, CHEER AMID TROUBLES
description: The dark and vacant windows of the old Crystal Market stare out on once-busy Franklin Avenue, a raw wind tugs at the corners of old posters on other, shuttered storefronts, and dim night lights outline the going-out-of-business signs placarding Vater's Hardware.

title: HOMOSEXUALS LACK NO CIVIL RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: E.E. HEFFELFINGER, SECRETARY OF G.O.P., DIES IN MINNEAPOLIS
description: Eizabeth E. Heffelfinger, the Republican National Committeewoman from Minnesota from 1948 to 1960 and the secretary of the party's 1960 national convention, died early yesterday at Abbott-Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis, where she lived. She was 81 years old.

title: Grumman Puzzled By Trading Surge
description: The Grumman Corporation, which rebuffed an unwanted takeover by the LTV Corporation last month, said that it did not have any explanation for the sudden surge in trading of its stock yesterday.

title: U.S. AND TEXAS SEEK SETTLEMENT IN PENAL REFORM
description: A top Justice Department official said today that the Federal Government and Texas officials had begun seeking an out-of-court settlement to a Federal lawsuit that has already resulted in a far-reaching order for reforms at Texas prisons.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $183,945 for the qr and $411,725 for the 6 mos...C-Including $567,394 income from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. + Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL SAYS U.S. ACTS TO COUNTER RISE IN SOVIET SPYING
description: Attorney General William French Smith said today that the Reagan Administration's effort to revitalize the nation's intelligence agencies was needed to offset a ''dramatic'' increase in Soviet spying in this country and a growing threat posed by international terrorism.

title: Dresser Net Rises
description: Dresser Industries reported a rise in net income in the fourth quarter, ended Oct. 31, to $94.8 million, or $1.21 a share, from $87.5 million, or $1.12, in the similar 1980 period.

title: Project to Modify 168 B-52's For Cruise Missiles Is Begun
description: A $650 million project to modify B-52 bombers to carry cruise missiles has begun at Tinker Air Force Base, military officials say.

title: JUDGE ALLOWS PURCHASES OF FREEDOM
description: The dispute over control of Freedom National Bank, New York's only bank owned by blacks, took a surprise turn yesterday when a Federal judge, learning that five of the bank's directors had recently purchased a large block of its stock, lifted an order barring further share purchases by Travers J. Bell Jr., the man the directors fear is trying to supplant them.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Billy Budd in the Davis Cup
description: Even those who are indifferent to sports should learn to treasure those moments when, without preparation, they catch and illuminate a moral question that artists struggle so mightily to render. Such a moment occurred a few days ago in the vital doubles match of the Davis Cup finals in Cincinnati. The tale's main character was a teenage ball boy, name unknown, who had to confront the consequences of changing history by an altogether innocent act.

title: TIGHTENS PATROLS JAILINGS ASSAILED
description: The United States publicly called upon Poland's military Government today to free its political prisoners and to let Lech Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity movement, ''speak to his countrymen and to the world.''

title: AN ENDURING SOCIETY
description: In economic terms, the last half of this century divides into two distinct eras that coincide roughly with its third and fourth quarters. During the third quarter, world production per capita of most major commodities -lumber, seafood, beef, grain, oil - rose. In the final quarter, the decline now under way in per capita production of these basic commodities seems likely to continue.

title: SAV-A-STOP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: Results for the latest first qr reflect a change to the LIFO method of inventory accounting for approximately 56 percent of inventory; yr-ago results have beenrestated for the change to LIFO accounting

title: N.H.L. SUSPENDS JETS' MANN
description: Jimmy Mann, a forward for the Winnipeg Jets, became today the second player to be disciplined by the National Hockey League this week for abusing a game official. Mann was suspended three games and fined $500 for shoving a linesman, Gord Broseker, in a game against the Toronto Maple Leafs Dec. 9.

title: 15,000 Protest in Athens
description: About 15,000 demonstrators marched through Athens tonight in protest at the imposition of martial law in Poland. The demonstrators included students, trade unionists and politicians.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, some copies of the Late City Edition on Thursday carried the editorial page twice and omitted page C30, which in- cluded the Bridge column. Readers who wish copies of the missing page may write to Production Quality Con- trol, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: MISSES SHRIVER, AUSTIN GAIN
description: Less than 24 hours after they completed one of the classic matches in women's tennis, a coin toss paired Chris Evert Lloyd and Tracy Austin as opponents in Saturday night's semifinals of the $250,000 Toyota Series championships.

title: BRIEFS
