description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. said it had suspended payment of its quarterly dividend of common stock. The last payment was 25 cents on Nov. 2, half the previous quarterly payment.

title: TIGHTENS PATROLS
description: The Warsaw radio reported today that Poles, worried by the imposition of martial law, were hoarding food, especially bread.

title: Electrical Stimulation Given Through Skin
description: A research associate at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore, who will enter medical school next year, was granted a patent this week for his method of administering electrical stimulation through the skin for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.

title: About New York; TALE OF THE FLASHLIGHTS, NOT THE FOOTLIGHTS
description: Just an usher, says Catherine Eleshewich, lifting her flashlight and her eyebrows at the same time. A job is all, like any other job - no training required, no special skills, no glamour, just a job that happens to be slightly to the left of show business.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: shr earnings have been adjusted for a 4 percent stock divd paid in May 1981

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results include foreign currency translation losses of $705,000 for 1981 and $102,000 for 1980; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split declared in Feb

title: Massachusetts Bank Merger
description: Stockholders of the Shawmut Corporation and Worcester Bancorp have approved the proposed merger of the two bank holding companies at an estimated value of $46.8 million.

title: Sports People; Coe-Ovett Races Set
description: According to a report in The London Daily Mail, Sebastian Coe and Steve Ovett, the world's top middle-distance runners, will finally compete against each other in a three-race series next year. According to the newspaper, the series will be made up of races at 800 meters, one mile and 3,000 meters and will be held in London, Cologne and the United States. Andy Norman, the manager of Britain's track team for the Commonwealth Games, confirmed that there would be a 3,000-meter race involving the two at London's Crystal Palace, probably on July 17, but denied that agreement had been reached for other races.

title: THREE TROUBLED THRIFT UNITS MERGED
description: California's Home Savings of Los Angeles, the nation's largest savings and loan association, was given Government permission today to acquire three financially troubled thrift units in Missouri and Florida. The merger is the latest in a wave touched off by record losses in the savings and loan industry.

title: Index; International
description: China trying to build an egalitarian school system 2 Four Vietnam veterans receive warm welcome in Hanoi 3 Bomb wrecks ruling party's headquarters in Zimbabwe, killing 6 3 Israeli expatriate withdraws from defense post 4 Israeli and Arab reaction to U.S. suspension of pact with Israel 4 Around the World 5 West Germany states its concern about Poland 7 Italian Communist Party voices anger over Polish crackdown 7 Madrid talks adjourn with dissension on Poland 7 Excerpts from domestic radio and TV broadcasts in Poland 7 Austrian calls Polish crisis most serious since World War 7 On 6th day, patrols still roaming Warsaw's snow-covered streets 8 Government/Politics U.S. and Texas seek settlement in prison reform case 10 Reagan cutting funds for state employment agencies 10 Administration's chief adviser on Social Security resigns 28 Albany Republicans reveal part of redistricting plan 31 Excerpts from Attorney General's speech on espionage 32 Washington Talk Briefing 16 Everyone's throwing dirt on the Farm Act of 1981 16 Reading File 16 Industry/Labor John E. Lawe re-elected as chief of Transport Workers local 30 News Analysis John F. Burns examines Soviet view of crackdown 8 Philip Shabecoff on environmental cutbacks 15 General Around the Nation 10 The M.T.A. agreed to more oversight of its actions 29 The News's troubles are laid to economic and social shifts 30 Cynthia Boston was released from Federal detention 31 Philanthropist and financier Jacob M. Kaplan approaches 90 31 Arts/Entertainment Gift establishes Hammerstein Theater Center at Columbia 17 Musical, ''Head Over Heels,'' at Clurman Theater 17 Movie ''Heartbeeps'' features two robots in love 17 ANTA Theater to be renamed for owner 19 ''The Architect,'' a novel about F. L. Wright by Meyer Levin 20 Tom Brokaw and Tom Snyder leave their programs 51 Style Consumer Saturday: State sues over home food sales 52 De Gustibus: latkes, food fit for a holiday 52 Bartering clubs prosper in computer age 52 Obituaries Karl Struss, Academy Award-winning cinematographer 50 Theodore Lightner, contract bridge expert 50 Sports Nets end Bucks' 9-game winning streak, 100-88 22 Jets and Giants face face final hurdles in playoff race 23 Reds trade Knight to the Astros for Cedeno 23 Tracy Austin and Pam Shriver gain semifinals 23 Knicks beat Bulls by 121-106 23 George Vecsey on Earnie Shavers and the punch 24 Brigham Young beats Princeton, 39-38, on last-second foul shot 25 Doherty is North Carolina's sub- tle star 25 50 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 19 Saturday News Quiz 20 Sports People 25 About New York 31 Man in the News: Gerald McEn- tee, leader of employee union 32 Notes on People 49 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 26

title: Chestnuts Roasting
description: Because I shall be on vacation for the next four weeks, I have compiled my holiday gift list early. It's a wish list - what the recipients ought to be getting, even though we know that in real life, they'll probably have to settle for less.

title: Dow Advances 5.23; Defense Issues Gain
description: The stock market, buoyed by strength in the defense and high-technology issues, posted a moderate advance yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: Hess Official I.C.C. Choice
description: President Reagan today announced his intention to appoint Joseph J. Simmons 3d, a vice president of the Amerada Hess Corporation, to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: ITALIAN COMMUNISTS IRATE AT WARSAW
description: The leaders of the Italian Communist Party have vented their anger over the military takeover in Poland in a daily series of condemnations of the action.

title: MAN SHOT BY OFFICER IN 1976 IS AWARDED $7 MILLION FROM CITY
description: Yesterday, five and a half years after Manuel Vega was paralyzed from the waist down by a police officer's bullet that severed his spinal cord, a jury awarded him $7,014,000 in compensatory damages from New York City.

title: CHIEF OF TRANSPORT LOCAL ELECTED TO A THIRD TERM
description: John E. Lawe has been re-elected to his third two-year term as president of the union that represents 33,000 of New York City's bus and subway workers, the union announced yesterday.

title: Sports People; Larouche Clears Air
description: Pierre Larouche, the Montreal Canadiens' unhappy center, met with Irving Grundman, the team's managing director, and apparently was satisfied that Grundman now had a better understanding of his feelings.

title: Around the World; Gambia and Senegal Sign Unification Pact
description: Gambia and Senegal signed a treaty of unification Thursday night, and today Senegalese officials said the document was expected to be debated by the two countries' Parliaments early next week before ratification.

title: Around the World; Bahrain, Charging Plot, Calls Iran Envoy Home
description: Bahrain ordered its Ambassador to Iran home today and accused Teheran of planning a coup in the tiny Persian Gulf island nation as a first step to exporting Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Islamic revolution, the Akhbar al Khaleej newspaper said today.

title: A Boost for Day Care
description: The idea of day care in the workplace once seemed radical; now it's about to receive a major boost from a major employer: the State of New York. A proposal produced by a labor-management committee and recently approved by the New York State Office of Employee Relations will establish day care centers for children of parents who work at state facilities.

title: GIANTS AND JETS FACE FINAL HURDLES IN PLAYOFF RACE WALKER, LAM JONES HEALTHY
description: Wesley Walker and Johnny (Lam) Jones stood side by side today, their slender legs twitching, as they waited for the signal to take off. ''Huh-ut!'' screamed Richard Todd, the quarterback, ordering the snap. And then they were gone, Walker flying down the right side, Jones down the middle.

title: NEWLIN'S 18 HELP KNICKS WIN
description: Mike Newlin rediscovered his jump shot last night as the Knicks scored a 121-106 victory over the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Garden.

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
AUSTRIAN SEES A DANGEROUS CRISIS
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky said today that the crisis in Poland could become the most serious threat to world peace since World War II.

title: TV Notebook; TOM AND TOM BID SHOWS 'GOODBYE'
description: In an odd coincidence, and on two distinctly different notes, NBC-TV's two best-known Toms said ''goodbye'' yesterday to the programs in which they starred.

title: A CHRISTMAS STORY
description: Three decades ago, as I grew up in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, I was aware of three types of holidays: the public holidays, such as Thanksgiving, which meant extra time to play ball; the Jewish holidays, which we observed strictly; and the Catholic (in that neighborhood Protestants were an exotic sect) holidays of Christmas and Easter.

title: G.O.P. DISCLOSES A PART OF PLAN FOR REMAPPING
description: The State Senate's Republicans today disclosed part of a reapportionment plan for the Legislature. It would, among other things, expand the district of one New York City Senator into Westchester County and give another Senator from the city a district that includes parts of Brooklyn, Staten Island and Manhattan.

title: PRESIDENT HEARS CONFLICTING IDEAS ON RAISING TAXES
description: Senate Republican leaders, in an effort to overcome President Reagan's resistance to tax increases and cuts in military spending, today gave him a set of budget estimates showing mounting deficits over the next five years.

title: Inventors Hall of Fame To Induct Four Feb. 7
description: Four inventors are to be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame at the Patent and Trademark Office, Arlington, Va., on Feb. 7.

title: A CRISIS DIARY: FIVE DAYS IN WARSAW
description: There were no Soviet tanks in Warsaw today, and that, to many Poles, was the hardest thing to take about the crackdown that began Saturday.

title: ATTORNEYS DROP CONTEMPT ORDER IN BRINK'S CASE
description: Cynthia Boston, who refused to cooperate in the investigation of a Rockland County armored-car robbery, was released yesterday after Federal prosecutors agreed to drop a contempt order against her.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SOME DOMESTIC RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS IN POLAND
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a Special to the New York Times United States Government agency Bread 10 A.M. Friday, (4 A.M. Friday, E.S.T.)

title: No Headline
description: Foreign News Reports Filed Through Censor

title: Patents; Hybrid Propulsion Of Cars
description: WASHINGTON THE hybrid propulsion of automobiles - powering cars by a combination of an electric motor and a gasoline-driven engine - is promised by patents issued this week. Three New York engineers were granted one patent, No. 4,306,156, for a hybrid system that is computer-controlled.

title: STAGE: HEAD OVER HEELS
description: ''Head Over Heels,'' a new vestpocket musical at the Harold Clurman Theater, is a confection - milk chocolate on the outside and soft at the center. Children and adults with a sweet tooth for musicals might enjoy it, especially at Christmastime. Cynics stand forewarned.

title: Going Out Guide
description: THE 'VILLAGE'

title: Notes on People
description: She had lived in St. Luke's Hospital in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, for all but four months of her young life, with just a few visits home. But when Katie Beckett, 3 years old, left the hospital yesterday morning with her parents, Mark and Julie Beckett, amid a throng of reporters, cameramen and politicians, she was finally ready to live in the normal environment of home.

title: Around the Nation; Sludge Slide in Kentucky Kills Woman as 100 Flee
description: One woman was killed and more than 100 people fled into snow and 20-degree weather today after a wall of thick muck from a coalfield sludge pond rumbled down on the small community of Ages.

title: No Headline
description: ISRAELIS SAY U.S. ACTION CASTS DOUBT ON ITS WORD

title: A 'Solidarity in Exile' Not Seen as Likelihood
description: Those members of Poland's Solidarity labor union who were abroad when the Warsaw Government decreed martial law will decide Saturday whether to give themselves a formal structure, a spokesman for the group said tonight.

title: Sports People; Apple of Jackson's Eye
description: Reggie Jackson's business representative, who spent the last two days with him during the free agent slugger's visit to New York, says it is his ''gut feeling'' that Jackson will return to the Yankees. Matt Merola, who handles Jackson's off-the-field business activities, said that he presumed the Atlanta Braves' offer would be the most lucrative but that playing out of New York might affect Jackson's place in baseball history. ''These questions are so hard to answer,'' Merola said, ''but if he finishes in New York, will he get more Hall of Fame votes? If Joe DiMaggio had been traded at the end of his career, would people in baseball circles still genuflect when they mention his name? Is the status of Ted Williams diminished because he played in Boston?'' Jackson's lawyer, Gary Walker, received unspecified offers from the Braves, the Angels and the Orioles this week and expects a contract proposal Monday from George Steinbrenner, the Yankee owner.

title: Power Plant for Egypt
description: Siemens and Gebruder Sulzer of Switzerland will supply a $159.3 million power plant to Misr Amria Manmade Fibers, Egypt's largest textile factory, a Siemens statement said today. The plant is expected to be in operation by the end of 1983, Siemens said.

title: Sports People; Reid Rejoins Rockets
description: Robert Reid, the Houston Rocket forward and member of the Pentacostal Church, rejoined his team last night at Dallas after a five-game suspension that he had sought. Reid, who scored 10 points in Houston's 112-93 victory, had asked for the unpaid leave in order to resolve conflicts between his religious beliefs and his career. After 10 days at his mother's home in a San Antonio suburb, he sent word to the team of his decision to return and declined further comment until a news conference over the weekend. ... Walter Davis, out since the exhibition season with a fractured left elbow, was reactivated by the Phoenix Suns.

title: Emil Hellebrand Dead; Rocket Expert Was 67
description: Emil A.H. Hellebrand, a recognized authority in rocket design and a member of the rocket team headed by Wernher von Braun, died Wednesday after an extended illness. He was 67 years old.

title: AS JOBLESS RATE RISES, U.S. TRIMS EMPLOYMENT AGENCY FUNDS
description: While the number of people unemployed is rising, the Reagan Administration is making deep cuts in the amount of money available to state employment agencies.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MITSUBISHI FORMS U.S. CAR SALES UNIT
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation announced today that it had established a unit for the marketing of passenger cars and pickup trucks in the United States through its own distribution network.

title: Detection System Enhances Images
description: A heterodyne detection system that enhances faraway images, such as those transmitted by television or radar, was patented this week by researchers for the Massachusetts Institute of Technology at its Lincoln, Mass., laboratory.

title: AMERICAN TURNS DOWN ISRAELI JOB
description: An Israeli expatriate who returned from the United States to accept a sensitive Defense Ministry post announced unexpectedly today that he was withdrawing because of the ''devil's dance'' his appointment had stirred here.

title: TOP REAGAN ADVISER ON SOCIAL SECURITY QUITS
description: Robert J. Myers, the Reagan Administration's chief technical adviser on Social Security, has resigned as deputy commissioner of the retirement system, voicing sharp criticism of the way the Office of Management and Budget has made recent policy.

title: AUTO CHIEFS 'ASSURED' OF REAGAN AID
description: Executives from five major automobile companies met with President Reagan today and came away without his commitment to the changes they seek in the Clean Air Act.

title: News Analysis
description: While proposals to cut back deeply on money and personnel for the Environmental Protection Agency have been receiving wide public attention, the Reagan Administration is quietly putting virtually all the Federal institutions involved in environmental matters on short rations, some to the point of starvation.

title: Home Away From Home
description: The U.S.O.'s new center at Kennedy International Airport joins the General Douglas MacArthur Memorial Center at Times Square and the U.S.O. Shows program at Veterans Administration hospitals and military bases as a sign that the American public has not forgotten their fellow citizens in uniform, or their young families.

title: Notes on People; 55 Times a Fan
description: Marle Becker does not have a set schedule. ''Sometimes, I go twice a week,'' he said. ''Sometimes, I'll miss a week altogether and then go four times the next week.''

title: SWIFT SUBWAY TICKETS
description: To the Editor:

title: Kuwait Refinery Pact
description: The JGC Corporation said today that it had won an order worth about $1 billion from the Kuwait National Petroleum Company to build an oil refinery at Mena al Ahmadi along the Persian Gulf by 1985.

title: Around the Nation; 535 Refugees From Cuba Bound for Montana Base
description: About 535 Cuban refugees remaining in Government custody will be transferred from Fort Chaffee, Ark., and other sites to a former Air Force base near Glasgow, Mont., the Justice Department said today.

title: Around the World; 24 I.R.A. Suspects Named by an Informer
description: Information provided by an Irish Republican Army informer has led to the arrest of 24 other suspected I.R.A. men on firearms and murder charges, Britain's Secretary of State for Northern Ireland said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are particularly disappointed that the Government of Israel took this action just as we were facing a serious political crisis in Poland and only a few weeks after we signed a Memorandum of Understanding on Strategic Cooperation.

title: Solar Collector Intended To Power Spacecraft
description: In addition to half a dozen solar collectors patented this week for use near the ground, one is designed to supply sun power to spacecraft. The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company, Sunnyside, Calif., received patent 4,306,108, obtained by Aram Henesian, a staff engineer.

title: GRAFTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Books of The Times; Building a Novel
description: THE ARCHITECT. By Meyer Levin. 413 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.50.

title: Your Money; Pass-Through Securities
description: BACKED securities have fallen out of the limelight as the slump in home sales and construction has sharply reduced the volume of new issues.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
PARISH APPROVES SKYSCRAPER PLAN IN ST. BART'S VOTE
description: The parishioners of St. Bartholomew's Church voted narrowly yesterday to support the decision by their rector and leaders to supplant the landmark church's Park Avenue community house with a commercial skyscraper.

title: U.S. SUSPENDS STRATEGIC PACT AND ARMS DEAL WITH ISRAEL OVER ANNEXATION OF GOLAN
description: The United States said today that because of Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights it had suspended an agreement signed with Israel less than three weeks ago for military cooperation to counter Soviet threats to the Middle East.

title: The City; Bronx Rapist Gets 16 Years in Prison
description: A 27-year-old Bronx man was sentenced to 16 years in prison after pleading guilty to the early morning beating and rape of a woman in a subway station at Yankee Stadium.

title: Cost of a Child's Life?  $100, Unicef Asserts
description: Seventeen million children around the world died from hunger or disease in 1981, according to the annual report of the United Nations Children's Fund. Unicef said the deaths could have been prevented at the cost of under $100 for each child.

title: Trudeau on Polish Crisis
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that he regretted the imposition of martial law in Poland but could not condemn it if it prevented civil war and if the military authorities did not abuse their power. He rejected suggestions that Canada stop grain sales to Poland at preferred prices.

title: Huddles And Muddles
description: My interest in football normally fades after the first five weeks of the season. That's how long it usually takes for my favorite teams to be eliminated from Super Bowl competition.

title: WHY I REMAIN AN OPTIMIST
description: Not long ago, one of the major television networks was covering a recent demonstration in Europe against nuclear arms. Prominently displayed in the middle of the screen was a banner that said simply: ''No Future.''

title: News Analysis
description: After 16 months of pressure and threats, the Soviet leadership this week finally secured the crackdown it wanted against Poland's independent trade union, Solidarity, and it achieved it without the immediate involvement of Soviet troops.

title: Benefit for Ballet School
description: The New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet will present a holiday celebration this afternoon at 2 o'clock to benefit the school's scholarship fund. The celebration will include a performance of ''The Nutcracker'' at the New York State Theater, after which there will be a ''Land of Sweets'' party in the theater to be attended by the children in the cast, dressed in costume.

title: REDS TRADE KNIGHT FOR CEDENO
description: The Cincinnati Reds today traded Ray Knight, their third baseman, to the Houston Astros for Cesar Cedeno, an outfielder.

title: HAMMERSTEINS DONATE TO COLUMBIA ARTS CENTER
description: Columbia University has received $1 million from the family of one of its most celebrated alumni - the playwright and lyricist Oscar Hammerstein 2d - and will use it to create an Oscar Hammerstein 2d Center for Theater Studies in its School of the Arts.

title: SOVIET ACCUSES REAGAN OF 'INSTIGATION' ON POLAND
description: The Soviet press agency Tass today heatedly assailed President Reagan's assertion that the Polish military acted with Soviet support, and official newspapers stepped up charges that Washington was encouraging a ''counterrevolution'' in Poland.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS TAKE AN EMOTIONAL JOURNEY TO HANOI
description: Four American veterans of the Indochina War, trembling with emotion, stepped off a plane at a bleak Hanoi airport late this afternoon to an enthusiastic welcome by Vietnamese officials.

title: EDWARDS, A G, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for 4-for-3 stock splits paid in Feb 1981 and Nov 1981

title: Sports People; Last of the Sauls
description: Having spent a combined total of three decades in the National Football League, the Saul family appears to be bowing out. Rich and Ron Saul, 33-year-old twin brothers from Butler, Pa., may play their last game tomorrow on opposite sides of the same field, Anaheim Stadium.

title: TO FINANCIER, NEARLY 90, LOVE FOR CITY IS CONSTANT
description: As he approaches his 90th birthday, Jacob M. Kaplan, the financier and philanthropist, says the years have been filled with satisfactions: business coups, a close family life and the use of his wealth to improve the city he loves.

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1981; The Economy
description: The gross national product has declined at a 5.4 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, according to a Commerce Department preliminary estimate. The figure indicated the depth of the current recession. For the third quarter, a new revision put G.N.P. growth at an annual rate of 1.4 percent instead of the 0.6 percent increase announced last month. After-tax corporate profits rose 2.4 percent in the third quarter, to $156.3 billion, rather than the 0.5 percent rise reported last month. (Page 33.)

title: ON SIXTH DAY, BAYONETS ON WARSAW'S STREETS
description: The following dispatch was passed through Polish military censorship.

title: RATES RISE
description: The Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply rose by $800 million in the week ended Dec. 9, an increase that surprised some analysts who had been expecting a modest decline. It was the fourth increase in the last five weeks, for a net gain of $7.3 billion, and touched off a spurt in short-term interest rates and a decline in bond prices that economists termed an ''overreaction.''

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 20. 1. They proposed a national referendum on forming a non-Communist government. 2. Under Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution, Congress can ''grant Letters of Marque and Reprisal and make Rules concerning Captures on Land and Water.'' Mr. Ludacer wants such a letter so he and his band of 100 other men can go after drug smugglers.

title: Sports People; Fouts Free to Play
description: Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said that no further moves would be made to keep Dan Fouts from playing, now that the association has received payment of the Charger quarterback's union dues from two San Diego fans. Garvey said that the $1,122 would be contributed to an inner-city camp program. Fouts, listed earlier this week as a ''questionable'' starter against Oakland next Monday because of a hip injury, is now listed as ''probable.''

title: Around the World
description: The International Press Institute said today that the Reagan Administration had restricted news gathering, posing a ''potentially serious loss of public accountability.''

title: Briefing
description: W HENEVER a crisis strikes a foreign country, the State Department pulls together an emergency team to handle the United States response to it.

title: STRONG GAINS FOR LOW-PRICED COSMETICS
description: Is there any difference between a lipstick that sells for $2.50 in a variety store and one that costs $8 in a department store? Yes, say the premium-priced cosmetic companies. No, there's not, say the manufacturers of less expensive makeup. Whatever the answer, as more and more people feel the effects of a souring in the economy, price differences in cosmetics are being taken more seriously by consumers.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, DECEMBER 19, 1981
description: International The U.S. suspended an agreement with Israel on military cooperation that was intended to counter Soviet threats to the Middle East. The action was in response to Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights. The State Department said President Reagan ordered the suspension because Israel did not notify the United States of its plans to annex the Syrian area and because it did not take American concerns into account. The Israeli and Syrian Governments were notified of the suspension Thursday night, an Israeli diplomat said. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Poles are hoarding food, especially bread, according to the Warsaw radio. Broadcasts monitored outside Poland said members of Communist Party and unarmed civilian volunteers are helping soldiers and police officers in patrolling Warsaw. Resistance to martial law continued in Gdansk and the Silesian coal region, according to reports received in Washington. (1:1.)

title: BUS ACCIDENT INJURES 29 PERSONS
description: A Washington, D.C., Metrobus fell 20 feet from a highway ramp after a collision with a city trash truck. The injured were taken to five separate hospitals after the rush-hour crash.

title: STRATEGIST AT HELM OF PUBLIC EMPLOYEE UNION
description: Gerald W. McEntee, the new president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the nation's largest public employees' union, is not widely known, but that seems likely to change soon.

title: Around the Nation; Indians Groups Sue U.S.  Over Land on Cape Cod
description: A coalition of six Indian groups filed suit against the Federal Government today in an effort to regain land on Cape Cod and Martha's Vineyard that they contend is worth $1 billion.

title: MUSIC: PORTLAND QUARTET
description: Evidence that chamber music has gifted practicioners in Maine was offered Tuesday night at Christ and St. Stephen's Church when the Portland String Quartet played the first of three New York concerts it has scheduled for this season. The ensemble is quartet-inresidence at the University of Southern Maine, and each of its concerts in the city is to feature a work by a composer who lives or has lived in Maine.

title: Around the Nation; Cardinal Cody Is Urged To 'Clear Air' on Dealings
description: More than 2,300 Roman Catholics have signed a letter urging John Cardinal Cody to ''clear the air'' by answering questions raised by a Federal grand jury investigation into his financial dealings.

title: BARTERING CLUBS PROSPER IN COMPUTER AGE
description: When the Manhattan publisher of a tourist guide needed furniture for his new East Side apartment - and he wanted to conserve cash because he was about to get married - he and his fiancee did not hesitate to go out and select what they wanted.

title: HOW ENTERPRISE ZONES CAN BE MADE TO WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Bethlehem Steel Layoffs
description: Bethlehem Steel, the nation's secondlargest steelmaker, will lay off 6,100 employees at its plant in Sparrows Point, Md., for at least one of two weeks beginning Sunday, a company spokesman said.

title: Polish Debt Meeting Set
description: Western banks owed billions of dollars by Poland have called an emergency meeting in Zurich on Monday to discuss their response to Warsaw's request for $350 million to help it pay past-due interest, banking sources said today.

title: DEFIANCE SAID TO CONTINUE: POLES AT WORK DON'T WORK
description: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
4TH-QUARTER G.N.P. RATE DOWN 5.4%
description: In the first tentative estimate of the depth of the current recession, the Commerce Department reported today that the gross national product - the broadest measure of American economic activity - has fallen at an annual rate of 5.4 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: TRUCK DEREGULATION IS UP TO CONGRESS, NOT I.C.C.
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBOTS IN LOVE IN 'HEARTBEEPS'
description: ''Heartbeeps,'' which opened yesterday at the Loews Orpheum Twin and other theaters, is a three-minute television sketch stretched to last nearly 90 unbearable minutes and fitted out with enough futuristic hardware to stock a short trailer for a science-fiction film.

title: M.T.A. ACCORD PAVES WAY FOR CHANGES IN CITY TRANSIT
description: Final approval of a $7.9 billion plan to rebuild the region's transit system was virtually assured yesterday when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority agreed to permit expanded oversight of its actions.

title: TEXT OF AMERICAN STATEMENT ON SECURITY PACT WITH ISRAEL
description: Following is the text of a prepared statement today by Dean Fischer, the State Department spokesman:

title: DIXICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
EXCERPTS FROM THE ADDRESS BY SMITH ON COUNTERING RUSSIANS' ESPIONAGE
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of a speech today by Attorney General William French Smith to the Los Angeles World Council on the threat of Soviet espionage:

title: Sports of the Times; EARNIE SHAVERS AND 'THE PUNCH'
description: SOME athletes have the gift that sets them apart from all their peers. Nolan Ryan has The Arm. Mike Bossy has The Reflexes. Earl Monroe had The Moves.

title: U.S. Increases Energy Aid
description: The Government said today it had freed $350 million additional in low-income energy aid grants to states. The Department of Health and Human Services previously made $700 million available.

title: BUFFALO BANK ACQUIRES UNION DIME
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday merged the failing Union Dime Savings Bank into the Buffalo Savings Bank of Buffalo, the third Government-assisted merger of a large New York City savings bank in the last two months. The merger became effective last night at a minute before midnight.

title: MOUNTAINS OF TRASH BEING CUT TO HILLS
description: New Yorkers, having built hills and walls of their garbage, stored it in attics and basements and dodged it on sidewalks, awaited their private trash collectors yesterday with a mixture of relief and contempt.

title: KRATOS ACQUISITION
description: Kratos Inc., the high-technology instrument and analytical-equipment concern, said that it had agreed to buy about two-thirds of the Keuffel & Easer Company of Morristown, N.J., a maker of drafting and engineering instruments, at $31 a share cash, or about $35 million.

title: CORNELIUS CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $687,000 extraordinary tax credit...C-Including $569,000 gain from an adjustment and $290,000 extraordinary credit

title: THEODORE LIGHTNER, AN EXPERT ON BRIDGE TIED TO CULBERTSON
description: Theodore Lightner, one of the leading figures in the history of contract bridge in the United States, was found dead Nov. 22 in his New York apartment. Mr. Lightner, an 88-year-old retired stockbroker, had apparently suffered a heart attack some days earlier.

title: FIRES NEED FIGHTING, NOT 'INTELLECTUALIZING'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: NETS STOP BUCKS' STREAK AT 9

title: SESSION OF CONGRESS MARKED BY SWEEPING CHANGES
description: The first session of the 97th Congress ended Wednesday amid acknowledgement that it bore the conservative imprint of President Reagan and had reversed a half-century of growth in social programs.

title: THE LESSONS TO BE LEARNED FROM 'NICKLEBY'
description: How do you measure a triumph? In the theater, God may say one thing, while Mammon says another. A triumph is when they don't argue. ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' dear, sweet, rich, plummy, 8 1/2-hour ''Nicholas Nickleby'' (or ''Nick Nick,'' as the boys in its backroom call it) leaves the Plymouth Theater on Jan. 3. It is finished then, its odyssey over. Still, we have learned from it. The first thing we have learned is that people love it, that they talk about it, and that they will pay $100 for a ticket to see it. Give them a chance, in fact, and they will pay a good deal more.

title: CONFORMANCE LAGS ON PINELANDS PLAN
description: NEW LISBON THE year provided by the Legislature for several counties and 52 communities in the Pine Barrens to bring their master plans and landuse ordinances into conformance with the controversial goals of the Pinelands Comprehensive Management Plan has nearly expired.

title: Abalone
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Avrett To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. William L. Avrett of Atlanta, formerly of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Elizabeth Avrett, to Charles Stanard Weiss, son of Col. Charles F. Weiss, Medical Corps, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Weiss of Washington.

title: Carey Moler, M. A. Karlan Are Married
description: Carey Loraine Moler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Moler of Darien, Conn., was married at the Noroton Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Mitchell Alan Karlan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney I. Karlan of Nutley, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Lawrence MacColl Horton, pastor emeritus of the church, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg of the Temple of Universal Judaism in New York.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Not too much remains of the ''swinging London'' that was so much talked of in the 1960's. Some of the friendships formed in London at that time did not always survive the downturn in England's fortunes.

title: HOME ADDING COMPUTERS FOR CHRISTMAS
description: IT was a Saturday before Christmas, and all through the Computerland store here customers were busy testing functions and experimenting with games on a myriad of computers for sale.

title: Marjorie Gaba Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Daniel L. Gaba of Rockville Centre, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Sue Gaba, to Stephen Paul Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Shapiro of Teaneck, N.J. An early May wedding is planned.

title: KEROSENE IS FUEL FOR CONFUSION
description: BERNARD KIENBOCK is doing a brisk business selling kerosene heaters at his hardware store in East Hampton Village, despite the fact that the use of the heaters in homes within the boundaries of East Hampton Town is illegal.

title: ON AFGHAN BATTLEFIELD, A PRAYER BEFORE DYING
description: Two days of fierce fighting in the Kandahar area between Afghan guerrillas and Soviet-backed Government forces ended on Nov. 28.

title: Headliners Blind Justice
description: When he signed a measure throwing the book at those who drink and drive, Governor Carey couldn't have known one of his sons would be among the first to be hit.

title: Around the World; Malta's Premier Gives Up Two Cabinet Posts
description: Prime Minister Dom Mintoff, whose new Cabinet was sworn in today, has given up the jobs of Interior Minister and Defense Minister.

title: The Region in Summary; Tower Power At St. Bart's
description: Money is also the root of much good, the rector of St. Bartholomew's Church has argued, even when it is raised by destroying church property. His parishoners agreed with him by a narrow margin last week in voting to allow a developer to tear down the church's landmark community house and build an office tower on its Park Avenue site.

title: Actors Guild Declines To Give Reagan Honor
description: President Reagan's old union, the Screen Actors Guild, voted overwhelmingly not to give the President its top award this year, guild officials say.

title: BALLET SEEKS A HOME
description: GREENWICH THE Greenwich Academy of Ballet, directed by a former New York City Ballet soloist, Carol Sumner, has lost its lease at the studio in the Mill Pond Shopping Center in Cos Cob and closed yesterday until new space within the school's budget can be found.

title: Elizabeth P. Kent Is Fiancee
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William H. Kent of Greenwich, Conn., and Red Rock, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Patterson Kent, to Peter Adam Nitze, son of Sheila MacNeille Nitze of New York and Peter P. Nitze of New York and Fisher's Island, N.Y.

title: About Long Island
description: NOT long ago, I was in one of those nice little shops at Port Jefferson, a store that sells greeting cards. As usual, I admired the astounding breadth of topics upon which the cards congratulate you, and I neglected to buy any. I always feel that a holiday is too distant and that there is no rush to stock up for it. That is why you won't be receiving any from me at this time when everyone else is sending cards.

title: Other Business; AT MORGAN STANLEY, BANKERS WEAR BEEPERS
description: It isn't just doctors and repairmen who wear them now. Beepers, those one-way paging devices that beckon their bearers from golf courses and meetings, are showing up on the pinstriped suits of Wall Street.

title: Other Business; AIRLINES: GOODBYE TO THE FREEBIES
description: Soaring fuel costs, no-frills competitors, cost-conscious customers, deregulation, controllers' strike - some days it hardly seems worth it to run an airline. The day of the promotional freebee, therefore, is over.

title: CHAIR IS ENDOWED AT COLUMBIA
description: A new professorial chair has been endowed at the Columbia Graduate School of Architecture and Planning. It is the result of the first large gift to the school's new Center for the Study of American Architecture, which is due to open sometime next year.

title: 'GREAT CONCERN' VOICED BY U.S. OVER REPRESSION
description: After the first week of military rule in Poland, the Reagan Administration said today that the United States continued to view the repression there ''with great concern.'' But a senior State Department official counseled that it would be wrong to conclude that there was no hope for ameliorating the situation.

title: Donald D'Alessandro Weds Sara McBratney
description: Sara Wingate McBratney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bruce McBratney of Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday in St. Luke's Episcopal Church to Donald F. D'Alessandro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. D'Alessandro of Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. William Winters performed the ceremony.

title: No Delay in Von Bulow Trial
description: A judge has refused to delay the Jan. 11 trial of Claus von Bulow, charged with twice trying to kill his wife, the former Martha Crawford, known as Sunny. Judge Thomas H. Needham of Superior Court told defense lawyers Friday to submit their case, including a list of witnesses, by Jan. 4.

title: PLAN STIRS DISPUTE ON FARM TAX RATES
description: A controversy has broken out in the agricultural areas of New York State over whether land that produces apples and grapes should be taxed more than land that produces hay, alfalfa, raspberries or strawberries.

title: Kathleen Engel Married to Eric Copage, Reporter
description: Kathleen Anne Engel, a scriptwriter, and Eric Vance Copage, a reporter with The Daily News, were married yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Louis J. De Gaetano.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Say Will Sell N.Y. Daily News
description: With its daily circulation of 1,483,00 and Sunday sales of 1,888,000, the New York Daily News is the largest general-interest newspaper in the country. Why then was its owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago offering it for sale last week?

title: THE CONSUMERS' STAKE IN AN ALASKAN PIPELINE
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN'S ROLE IN COUNTY POLITICS IS CONTINUING TO EXPAND
description: NOW that political candidates have disappeared from train stations and campaign buttons have been discarded, various elected officials across the county will be making history as the first women to hold their respective offices. For the first time, there is a woman presiding in the State Supreme Court in the Ninth District, New Castle and North Salem have their first female supervisors and the second ward in Yonkers has its first councilwoman. Nearly a third of those elected last month - 46 of 159 - were women.

title: To Get More Taxis, Get More Taxis
description: On New Year's morning, most New York taxis will lose the right to charge an extra 50 cents for evening and Sunday service. Ending that eight-month experiment was the right decision by the Taxi and Limousine Commission. There is little evidence that the surcharge brought out more cabs in off-peak hours. But the failure only reinforces what regulatory experts have been saying for years: New York needs more taxis to meet growing demand.

title: ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION SHIFTS POLICY
description: The Rockefeller Foundation, in a move to help the ''most disadvantaged members of our society,'' has undertaken a multimillion-dollar program to assist single minority-group women who head households.

title: Headliners; The Russian Treatment
description: Physicians in this country generally say there is no known treatment for retinitis pigmentosa, a vision-destroying disease. Doctors in the Soviet Union, however, are of another opinion and so is 12-year-old Todd Cantrell.

title: A Questioner Seeks Some Explainers
description: Could someone who understands how things work please be kind enough to explain to me how, in the issue of Nov. 29, I learn on Page 27 of $8 million being given by New York State to owners and breeders of thoroughbred horses ... and on Page 1, I read of imminent county budget cuts of medical and handicap services at both operating and capital expenditure levels?

title: U.S.O. at J.F.K.
description: The U.S.O. has just opened its newest facility at Kennedy International Airport.

title: MORIAL TO RUN FOR RE-ELECTION AS NEW ORLEANS MAYOR IN '82
description: Mayor Ernest N. Morial has officially filed for re-election, qualifying as a candidate, along with six challengers, before the deadline yesterday. The city's mayoral election will be held Feb. 6.

title: Lillian Ashley Ford Bride Of James Lawrence Perry
description: The marriage of Lillian Ashley Ford, daughter of Enfield B. Ford of Darien, Conn., and Margaret W. Cowan of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., to James Lawrence Perry took place yesterday at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. John W. Moody performed the ceremony.

title: MORE JACKRABBITS ROUNDED UP AND CLUBBED TO DEATH IN IDAHO
description: About 600 farmers drove deep into the frigid southeast Idaho prairie today, rounded up an estimated 15,000 jackrabbits and clubbed them to death with baseball bats, ax handles and tire irons.

title: THE DANCE: 'MUSIC PLUS MOVEMENT'
description: Although many choreographers like using contemporary music, there was a sense of constraint about the Brooklyn Philharmonia's Thursday night ''Music Plus Movement'' program at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. An event in the Philharmonia's ''Meet the Moderns'' series, it featured seven solos to 20th-century scores, with conducting duties shared by Lukas Foss and Tania Leon. But the scores appeared to intimidate some of the choreographers, and in only two pieces did choreography become music's equal partner.

title: Careful Shopper; Yorktown Shop Offers Items of Victorian Era
description: The Emporium in Yorktown Heights is a nostalgic trip through Victorian clothes, lightly used linens and laces, antique furniture, lovingly kept Christmas tree ornaments and reconditioned radios from the 1920s and '30s. Selected items are discounted by 10 to 20 percent in honor of the shop's first anniversary. Christmas specials include handknit, lined fireplace stockings, stained-glass frames and ornaments, satin-covered hangers, placemats and imported porcelain gift boxes in various shapes, including animals, fans and hearts, for $5.

title: CITY'S ADVISER ON CABLE IS NO FAN OF TELEVISION
description: The confession came casually, nestled in among references to technical matters, but there it was: Norman M. Sinel, head of New York City's cable television consulting team, does not like television, rarely watches it, does not have cable in his home and, what's more, thinks the Orwellian implications of cable are seeded with danger.

title: The Jerome Avenue Range
description: WHEN the National Finals Rodeo started, Don Gay of Mesquite, Tex., who may be the best bull rider that ever straddled a sirloin, led Bobby DelVecchio of the Bronx by $5,003. Twenty-eight years since he was born into the unruly sport of rodeo, Day was in the finals for the 10th time, looking for his seventh national championship in eight years. It was only the second finals for DelVecchio, 24, who had always thought a bull was a cop from the Ryer Avenue station.

title: No Headline
description: Idaho State Takes Title, 34-23

title: 'AMEN CORNER' AT CROSSROADS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK WHAT can you do with a text that seems longer than the Old Testament and is never so interesting? Or, how can you flatten the apocalyptic puffery of words that cite Isaiah but, like Job, embody more hardships than less sturdy souls could tolerate in one evening?

title: DARK LINING BEHIND SILVER TRANSIT CLOUD
description: NEWARK ALTHOUGH commuters are delighted by the news that NJ Transit, the state's mass-transit agency, will not increase fares on buses and trains again before next July, agency officials already have begun to worry about the bleak financial situation that seems certain to exist by then.

title: Music; AUDIENCE PLAYS A PART
description: THE Philharmonia Virtuosi of New York came into being in 1968 when a group of players from the New York Philharmonic decided to try out some pieces in the chamber orchestra repertory. The ensemble, conducted by Richard Kapp, hit the classical jackpot almost immediately with the first recording in what would become a bestselling series called ''Greatest Hits of ...'' -the year in question being 1792 or some other high point of Baroque or Classical creativity.

title: Sound; STOCKING STUFFERS FOR AUDIO FANS
description: It helps to have some audio fans on your Christmas list; they are so easy to shop for, even at the last minute. A myriad of odds and ends, known collectively as audio accessories, make handy stocking stuffers for hi-fiers, and, for the most part, their cost is low enough to keep any surrogate Santa from going broke.

title: GIFTED CHILDREN MEET THEIR MATCH
description: HUNTINGTON MICHAEL LEFSKY, 13 years old, of North Massapequa, spoke recently to a group of adults, including the director of his school, about difficulties he experienced at a school he formerly attended. It was a school where the educational system emphasized the greatest good for the greatest number, where he failed to conform to the system and where this occasioned problems both for him and for the school.

title: Long Island Journal
description: TODAY at 10 A.M., Archbishop Iakovos, head of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America, will preside over ''Eponomasia'' services at which members of the Greek Orthodox community of the Town of Hempstead will name their new church, on Warner Avenue in Roslyn.

title: MUBARAK TERMS U.S. RESPONSE ENCOURAGING
description: President Hosni Mubarak called the United States response to Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights ''encouraging'' today and said he hoped that ''we can reach reasonable solutions regarding this problem so there will be no further escalation of differences.''

title: Beauty; THE SWEET SCENTS OF LUXURY
description: By Jani Wooldridge ith a season of unusually extravagant - and thus expensive -fashions, it is not sur-prising that the opulent spirit has enveloped perfumes as well. Though there have always been a few fine, very costly scents on the market, the list of fragrances priced at more than $100 per ounce has grown by vials and vials in the past several years.

title: SUSAB FABIETTI ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Victor A. Fabietti of Margate, N.J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ann Fabietti, to James David L. Rosener Jr., son of Mrs. Rosener of Barrington, R.I., and the late Mr. Rosener. A sping wedding is planned. Miss Fabietti is an auditor with the Girard Bank in Ardmore, Pa. Mr. Rosener is manager of financial planning and analysis for the Kennecott Corporation in Avondale, Pa.

title: Festival of Hanukkah To Begin at Sundown
description: The Jewish festival of Hanukkah, which commemorates the successful fight for freedom of Judas Maccabaeus, begins at sundown today with the lighting of the first candle.

title: 'THOSE CALLOUS BANKS'
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM REAGAN TO C.I.A., TO TREAT WITH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Agent Orange Is No Federal Case
description: Thousands of Vietnam veterans claiming injuries from exposure to the defoliant Agent Orange may have lost their product liability lawsuits before they started.

title: CALIFORNIA DRIVE ASKING REAGAN TO END ARMS RACE
description: Along with shopping, trimming trees and preparing for their Christmas dinner, thousands of Californians are circulating petitions this month asking that President Reagan seek an end to the nuclear arms race.

title: Alice Colburn Fiancee of Richard Neff
description: Alice Armitage Colburn and Richard Evan Neff, Washington lawyers, will be married in June. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Armitage of Fairfield, Conn., parents of the future bride. Mr. Neff is a son of Jerome J. Neff of Penn Valley, Pa., and the late Suzanne G. Neff.

title: Mailbox; Ivy Days at Top
description: To the Sports Editor: The headlines show that Herschel Walker may lead Georgia to another national football title and the N.C.A.A. has demoted the Ivy League to minor league status.

title: Theater; 'NEW MOON' BRINGS A GLOW TO THE STAGE
description: WHEN ''The New Moon'' first opened in Philadelphia in 1927, it was considered a disaster and was withdrawn. With a rewritten libretto and an almost entirely new score, it showed up eight months later in Cleveland and went on to Broadway in 1928 to become Sigmund Romberg's longest-running hit - with 509 performances. It has twice been made into a motion picture, the last time as a vehicle for Jeanette MacDonald and Nelson Eddy. Despite its popularity, and that includes five of Sigmund Romberg's best-loved melodies, ''The New Moon'' is rarely performed nowadays. The reason may be that voices good enough to sing operetta are hard to come by, or it could be that the book, subtitled, ''A musical romance of the Spanish Main'' is essentially claptrap.

title: Article 139852 -- No Title
description: In the hours last week before Congress adjourned for the holidays, the first $5 million from a special Federal recreational boating trust fund to be used for state boating safety programs was eliminated.

title: Melon Outpoints Castro
description: Manual Melon, a 160-pounder who holds the Triple Americas middleweight championship, outpointed Pecho Castro, 159, of the Dominican Republic in an eight-round bout last night at Prospect Hall Arena in Brooklyn.

title: Music View; WHAT IF COMPOSERS TURNED THE TABLES ON PERFORMERS
description: Christmas, as any caroler knows, is the one time of year when it's all right, in fact, expected, for ordinary people to perform music. The rest of the year we tend to rely on professionals, who have come to hold a fairly exalted place in our musical life. Indeed, it is hardly stretching things to assert that the main reason most of today's concert-going public goes to concerts is to hear performers, not to hear music. The public craves performers, the more glamorous, the better.

title: A-SOVIET RATHER THAN ANTI-SOVIET
description: NIGHTINGALE FEVER Russian Poets in Revolution. By Ronald Hingley. 269 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.50.

title: WOMEN JOINING RANKS OF VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS
description: ONE day in 1974, Mary Valone of the Somerset County community of Franklin Township watched the fields near her home burn. When a fire engine arrived, it was manned by several elderly men, all volunteers.

title: COMING TO GRIPS WITH THE AMERICAN EXPERIENCE
description: For much of this year we've sat through megamovies based on minicomic strips, through failed comedies at which only the charitable could laugh, and through hideous horror movies about psychopaths who, unlike poor old Thomas Wolfe, go home again and again to do their dirty work. It has sometimes seemed that filmmakers either had lost all touch with the nervous, unpredictable, frequently unfair world the rest of us inhabit or had simply accepted it at its sleazy face value, without question or curiosity.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1981
description: International Summary criminal proceedings against some local activists of the Solidarity union movement have begun, Poland's military authorities announced. The unionists are being charged with seeking to instigate strikes in violation of martial law. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: About Westchester
description: FOR about two weeks now, those who notice such things have welcomed an addition to the county's office building, courthouse, community college, medical center and penetentiary. In the halls of these buildings, on desks, windowsills, anywhere a touch of color and seasonal spirit are needed, are dozens of crimson poinsettias, grown by Minoru Arita, the nurseryman at the Glen Island Park in New Rochelle.

title: Connecticut Guide; VISITING MARK TWAIN
description: Whether the purpose is to introduce children to an important part of their literary heritage, indulge a passion for Victoriana, add to your T-shirt collection or simply fill a void in your holiday calendar, a visit to the Mark Twain mansion and neighboring Harriet Beecher Stowe cottage in Hartford will be worthwhile.

title: Around the Nation; Indiana Gets More Snow, Adding to 2-Foot Fall
description: By United Press International More snow covered northwest Indiana, which already had nearly 2 feet on the ground, and temperatures below zero stung the Middle West yesterday.

title: SCHOOL DEVOTED TO THE ARTS IS STILL A HIT
description: AT a time when many boards of education are scrapping the arts as costly frills, a school in Connecticut is teaching nothing else - and thriving.

title: IN THE LAND OF THE KHMER ROUGE
description: Christopher Jones is a freelance writer who has been reporting on Southeast Asia since 1978. By Christopher Jones The camouflage tent was pitched on a knob of dry ground hemmed in by trees rooted in swamp. Inside the tent, Comrade Kanika of the Revolutionary Army of Democratic Kampuchea (Cambodia) sat at a table, sipping fiery pineapple liquor. As a monsoon rain swept across the Cambodian jungle, the army commissar, a wiry man with short gray hair, talked of the fierce dreams of the Khmer Rouge revolution and its legendary leader, Pol Pot.

title: Jane Frank to Be Bride
description: Raphael H. Frank of Jefferson City, Mo., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Jane Elizabeth Frank, to Lieut.

title: SEVEN LEADING DISSIDENTS SEIZED IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: Seven senior members of Czechoslovakia's dwindling band of political dissidents are languishing in Ruzyne Jail, near the Prague airport, charged with ''subversion of the republic on a large scale and in cooperation with a foreign power.''

title: The Oldest Theater On the Island
description: In a recent article, ''Museum's Growth Tied to Hempstead,'' it was said that the 1922 Hempstead Theater, ''the oldest surviving theater on Long Island,'' is about to be converted to another use.

title: 2 POLISH LEADERS THANK BREZHNEV
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, sent a message to Leonid I. Brezhnev today on his 75th birthday, thanking him for his understanding over the ''dramatic and difficult situation'' in Poland.

title: Fashion; THE NEW STONE AGE
description: Their names sound less than beguiling; all traces of the romance associated with diamonds, sapphires, rubies and emeralds are missing. And yet, these days, such unlikely sounding minerals as kunzite, rubellite, citrine, zircon, tsavorite and tanzanite are being treated by top-flight jewelry designers with all the reverence and pomp once devoted exclusively to the fabulous four.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Laboratory Babies
description: In a series of announcements starting last May, the in vitro fertilization clinic of the Eastern Virginia Medical School in Norfolk said that it @d made four women pregnant through laboratory fertilization. It declined to give further details.

title: The New York Times Magazine; December 20, 1981
description: William Safire 10 On Language Window Shopping Russell Baker 17 Sunday Observer Taking Heroes Seriously Morton N. Cohen 24 A Christmas With Lewis Carroll Alan Cowell 38 Egypt's Friend in Need Tony Schwartz 46 Tom Wolfe: The Great Gadfly Christopher Jones 70 In The Land of the Khmer Rouge Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey 82 Food Keeping Peace With Snails Marilyn Bethany 84 Fashion The New Stone Age Suzanne Slesin 88 Design Framed With a Point of View Jani Wooldridge 90 Beauty The Sweet Scents of Luxury Dena Kleiman 92 Can Black Colleges Survive? 103 Puzzles Answers, Page 106 110 Letters Cover: Detail of the Looking-Glass Biscuit Tin; copy photograph by Lynn Karlin Copyright 1981, The New York Times

title: Barbara Lewis Is Bride
description: Barbara Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lewis of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Marco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Marco of Fort Lee, N.J. Rabbi Nicholas Behrman performed the ceremony at the Rutherford Mansion in Gramercy Park. The bride is story editor for Martin Bregman Productions in New York, where her father is vice president and treasurer of the William Morris Agency. Mr. Marco is a sales executive with DeMarco California Fabrics Inc., of which his father is president.

title: The Region in Summary; Saving Energy Could Cost Plenty
description: More than a few utilities have raised electric rates to complete ever more costly nuclear power plants. Last week, a New Jersey company sought a rate increase to abandon one.

title: December 20, 1981
description: NONFICTION BLAMING TECHNOLOGY: The Irrational Search for Scapegoats. By Samuel C. Florman. 5 THE GIFT OF GOOD LAND: Further Essays Cultural and Agricultural.

title: DEBATE: CAN 1940'S SHIPS PLAY A USEFUL PART IN THE 1980'S NAVY?
description: CONGRESS voted an installment on President Reagan's program to ''rearm America'' last week. Like the program itself, it was hefty. Even before the inevitable supplemental bills that will provide for military pay raises and cost overruns (provision for both was omitted in last week's legislation, mostly for cosmetic reasons), the Pentagon's appropriation for 1982 weighs in at $199.7 billion, or $28 billion more than the fiscal 1981 year's level. That is the largest peacetime increase ever. And despite questions raised in the House and Senate all fall about the appropriateness of such a rise in a time of domestic stringency, it is less than a billion short of the President's revised request. Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who managed the bill, put it with restraint when he called the vote - 334 to 84 in the House, 93 to 4 in the Senate - a ''solid endorsement of the President's initiatives.''

title: Dining Out; FOR THOSE WHO CAN FIND THE WAY
description: FOR the last 16 years, the Pratt family has operated Peter Pratt's Inn, a restaurant in the Croton Heights area. Among the restaurant's dining rooms the 1781 cellar (called The Side Door) with its original hand-hewn beams receives informal diners during the week or later arrivals who come for light suppers, snacks or drinks, to chat or, on weekend evenings, to hear low-keyed entertainment. Upstairs, in the more formal but less-charming dining room of the Colonial house and the later-built Victorian porches, only dinner is served. From Route 118, a subtle sign points the way to the restaurant. Uphill, over some poorly marked terrain, views stretch to woodlands on one side and over reservoirs on the other, making the place more like a private club, a gathering spot for those who know the way. For the most part, the way is worth finding.

title: REAGAN OFFICIALS SEEK TO EASE RULES ON NURSING HOMES
description: Reagan Administration officials want to relax or repeal many of the Federal rules that govern nursing home services, the rights of patients and the qualifications of the staff at long-term care facilities.

title: WRITERS OF THE UNITED STATES GO FORTH TO UNITE
description: ''Everything about being published is disappointing,'' said the novelist Helen Yglesias. ''It's just a very bitter experience today for almost everybody. And because there is such widespread disaffection among writers, I think that for the first time in the history of publishing and book writing there is a strong possibility that a writers union will succeed.''

title: The World in Summary; If It Isn't One Thing...
description: West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and East German leader Erich Honecker ended their first full-dress meeting in 11 years asserting, in the words of Mr. Schmidt, ''that better relations are possible.''

title: Joan Schaff to Be May Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Schaff Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Alice Schaff, to Dr. Victor Paul Terranova, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Terranova of Little Falls, N.J. A May wedding is planned.

title: Margo Levine Is Engaged
description: The engagement has been announced of Margo Levine, daughter of Mrs. Sidney Natter of Brooklyn and Lawrence Levine, to Dr. Allen Motola, son of Dr. and Mrs. Baruch Motola of Providence, R.I. A June wedding is planned. Dr. Motola is a dentist.

title: Dining Out; HIGGINS: A MAINSTAY OF RAWAYTON
description: ROWAYTON HIGGINS Restaurant has long been a mainstay on the Rowayton scene. Now, reopened since a fire, it has a somewhat different interior. The nautical theme is intact, with a big ship's wheel inside the entrance, and rope riggings used effectively as room separators. The bar is now in the room to the right as you enter, the dining room to the left.

title: DAYS OF CRISIS
description: WASHINGTON AT his press conference last week, President Reagan said, ''I've come to the conclusion that there is a worldwide plot to make my job more difficult on almost any day that I go to the office.'' Wry remarks aside, the Administration did seem to be reeling from foreign policy shocks that carried portentous implications for East-West relations and Middle East peace.

title: Long Islanders; A SWEET TOOTH, A FAMILY TRADITION
description: ''WE constantly joke that I'm right back in my bedroom,'' Alfred A. Lepore said, ''because my office now is where my bedroom was when I was a child.''

title: Home Clinic; SAVING TIME AND EFFORT IN PAINTING
description: WHEN tackling the job of painting an entire room, time and effort can be saved if the do-it-yourselfer follows the proper sequence and observes some of the simple work-saving techniques that a good professional painter uses.

title: TAKEOVER WITHOUT VICTORY, DEFEAT WITHOUT SURRENDER
description: PARIS IT still isn't clear whether Poland's new military junta has been able to establish order without law. Overwhelming force and massive arrests may eventually cow the country. But that can only be the end of a chapter in the struggle to reorganize and revive Polish society. The problems ahead for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski and his Military Council of National Salvation are even greater than the challenge quelled by tanks.

title: SOUR CREAM
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region in Summary; City Breathes (And Walks) A Bit Easier
description: Garbage piled up on New York City streets at a rate of 6,000 tons daily while teamsters struck private carting companies. But lastminute pressure from Mayor Koch for a settlement seemed to mount even faster.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan L. Keating Bride of Student
description: Susan Louise Keating, daughter of Mrs. William J. Keating of Hamden, Conn., and the late Mr. Keating, was married yesterday to Thomas David O'Connor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. O'Connor of Loudonville, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I. Msgr. Edward O'Malley performed the ceremony at St. Rita's Roman Catholic Church in Hamden.

title: DOWN 3-0, RANGERS GET 3-3 TIE
description: The Rangers fought back from a 3-0 disadvantage late in the second period to gain a 3-3 tie from the Penguins tonight at the Civic Arena.

title: ON POETS, POETRY AND THE WRITING OF FICTION
description: WHATEVER IS MOVING By Howard Moss. 277 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $15.95.

title: Margaret G. Fisk Bride of Surgeon
description: Margaret Grace Fisk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Fisk of Northbrook, Ill., formerly of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Harold Iles Genvert, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Genvert of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: Some vintage books by outstanding authors that have just become available in trade paperback editions are described below.

title: REAPPORTION PLAN DEBATED IN TEXAS
description: Ever since the Voting Rights Act of 1965 opened the way for broader participation in politics by members of minority groups, blacks have generally reckoned that the most reliable way to bring their influence to bear is to elect more blacks to office.

title: HOW THE CRUNCH STOLE CHRISTMAS
description: CITE the Federal Reserve if you will. Blame President Reagan or David Stockman or the supply-siders or the oil companies. Rail against the banks with their high rates or Detroit with its layoffs or the stores with their prices. Maybe it's the Democrats. Point the finger wherever you will, there's a Grinch out there and it's stealing Christmas.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Fighting Burglars
description: When burglars broke into his house in Vineland, N.J., for a fourth time, Manuel S. Marin was waiting with a licensed .38-caliber pistol. He ordered the two intruders to halt.

title: CHRISTMAS BEGINNINGS
description: The Spirit of Christmas Present is upon the book business - or, more properly, the spirit of Christmas presents, since so many publishers' hopes ride on the fickleness of bookstore gift-seekers. There is more to the season, however, than weekly sales sheets and inventory printouts. In fact, publishing itself has much to do with the Spirit of Christmas Past.

title: DANCE, FOR SOME, A FORM OF RELIGIOUS EXPRESSION
description: NEW HAVEN ''MORE than the preacher's word, it is the musician's touch that is bringing the young to God again,'' said Pedro Arrupe, former Jesuit Superior General, addressing a Jesuit Institute for the Arts in Rome in 1972. Nearly 10 years later, his observations can be applied to the liturgical dance groups that are beginning to win acceptance among the clergy, parishioners, divinity schools and the so-called unchurched, who seek an alternate means of religious expression.

title: Millen Is Rallying At Different Level
description: When Rod Millen, came to this country from New Zealand three years ago, he looked at it as a way station on his path to a rally driving career in Europe. Now, after winning the Sports Car Club of America's PRO rally championship, he sees a bright future for himself in America.

title: Travel Advisory; MUSIC AT SEA, CARIBBEAN BOOKINGS; Annual Shipboard Serenade
description: A music lover's dream come true: 12 days in the company of Maurice Andre, the trumpeter; Daniel Barenboim and Misha and Cipa Dichter, the pianists; James Galway, the flutist, and Yo-Yo Ma, the cellist. Not to mention the Cleveland Quartet and the English Chamber Orchestra. All will be aboard the Mermoz for the 21st Music Festival at Sea in the Caribbean from Jan. 3 to 15.

title: Death and Taxes
description: Ask for new taxes? Not me, says President Reagan; he has ''no plans for increasing taxes in any way.'' And yet, it was quickly explained, his Administration is not above considering something called ''revenue enhancement.''

title: On Language By William Safire  Window Shopping Kimble Mead
description: A plaintive, if syntactically convoluted, message has come to this department from a United States senator. ''My previous occupation, prior to coming to Washington, having been a farmer from South Dakota, I have been curious about two new expressions Washington bureaucrats have expressed to me in the past week.''

title: MESSAGES FROM NO MAN'S LAND
description: A WILD PATIENCE HAS TAKEN ME THIS FAR Poems 1978-1981. By Adrienne Rich. 61 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $4.95.

title: BAGGAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Rate of Migration to Oregon Seems to Have Dropped Off
description: The migration to Oregon that former Gov. Tom McCall complained of a decade ago has apparently stopped. Ed Schafer, director of the Center for Population Research at Portland State University, said the reasons were the economy and the state's high unemployment rate of 11 percent.

title: OFFICES THRIVE IN JERSEY CORRIDOR
description: TROY HILLS, N.J. - Since the mid-1960's, three big interstate highways - 80, 287, and 78 -have sliced straight through the bucolic heartland of Morris and Somerset Counties, luring big money, big ambitions and big developments.

title: COUNSELING FOCUSES ON ABUSE
description: DO you hit when you're angry? Do you smash things? Do you use weapons to show your power? Would you describe yourself as violent? These questions, directed to men, are on a flier advertising a series of confidential workshops scheduled for next month. The workshops, sponsored by the Mental Health Association, employ an innovative approach to teaching alternatives to violent behavior and will be held in White Plains beginning Jan. 5 and in Pelham beginning Jan. 7.

title: Business Conditions; HOW LONG THE OIL GLUT?
description: Demand for oil continues to fall far faster than production, and worldwide oil stocks remain at very high levels. Nevertheless, officials of the International Energy Agency in Paris are warning major importing nations that a resumption of economic growth could make the current glut rapidly disappear.

title: Barbara Hannah, H.W. Marks Wed
description: The marriage of Barbara A. Hannah, North American advertising sales representative for Paris Match, to Henry W. Marks, senior vice president and advertising sales director of Playboy magazine, took place Friday at St. Peter's Lutheran Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John S. Damm, pastor of the church.

title: Jennifer Beth Shatkin Bride of Dr. Frederic Gross
description: Jennifer Beth Shatkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Shatkin of Rego Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Frederic Richard Gross, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Gross of New York. Rabbi Myron M. Fenster performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: TEEN-AGE PREGNANCIES: PROFILES IN IGNORANCE
description: Nicole is 18 years old and five months' pregnant. She is living with her boyfriend's sister in Brooklyn, but she and her boyfriend are breaking up and Nicole must find a new place to live. She cries much of the time, because she has no place to go and does not know what to do.

title: RUTGERS, PRINCTON DEFEATED AT GARDEN
description: There were fewer than 16 minutes to play last night, Rutgers was only 4 points behind top-ranked North Carolina, and James Worthy, the Tar Heel forward, was on the bench with four fouls. The Scarlet Knights, who shocked U.C.L.A. more than two weeks ago, seemed to be in a position for another upset.

title: Miss Dunlop, Dale Favreau Plan to Wed
description: Lucette Colvin Dunlop and Dale Frank Favreau plan to be married Jan. 23 at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn. The future bride is a daughter of Mrs. Whitney Trowbridge Kelsey of Madison, Conn., who has announced her engagement, and the late Capt. Robert H. Dunlop Jr., U.S.A. Her fiance is a son of the late George L. Favreau and the late Mary Stafford Favreau of Charlton, Mass.

title: Kathryn Moser Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Moser of Pearl River, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn E. Moser, to Charles G. Enering, son of Charles H. Enering of Westwood, N.J., and the late Eileine Enering. An October wedding is planned. Mr. Moser is director of public relations for Standard & Poor's Corporation in New York.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: MELITA J. WRIGHT ENGAGED TO MARRY
description: The engagement of Melita J. Wright to William C. Cox 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cox Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Joyce T. Wright of Kingston, N.Y., and Alan H. Wright of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: 'NEVER WORRY,' HE SAID, BUT NOW SHE'S ALONE
description: WHEN she was married in the Bronx 58 years ago at age 19, her husband used to tell her, ''The first 50 years are the hardest.'' But looking back at 77, she says, ''No, that time you were wrong.''

title: Around the World; 14 Salvador Soldiers Die In Clashes With Rebels
description: Guerrillas have killed 14 Government soldiers and a militiaman in three separate attacks in El Salvador since Thursday, the authorities said today.

title: ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: A recent State Department memorandum on human rights has led a n umber of commentators to announce that the Administration is finallyt alking sense about human rights. But reflection on the basic p rinciples of the document suggests otherwise and stimulates anew s ome fundamental questions about trying to use foreign policy to g uarantee human rights.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in this section last week stated that Sam Shepard, the playwright, ''stormed out'' of the Public Theater last December after a dispute with Joseph Papp which led to Mr. Shepard's saying he would never again show one of his plays to Mr. Papp. Actually, Mr. Shepard never appeared at the Public Theater and made his statement by telephone from San Francisco to a reporter for The New York Times.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: AGENCIES THAT FIGHT THE PAIN OF POVERTY
description: By JOYCE PHILLIPS AUSTIN Executive Vice President, Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies

title: EX-LABOR LEADER GUILTY IN USE OF U.S. FUNDS
description: Wilbur Hobby, a former state president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, and Mort Levi, a business associate, were found guilty today of illegally obtaining and misusing job-training funds.

title: Business Conditions; BORROWING SHORT-TERM
description: Short-term corporate borrowings are beginning to rise again, after a brief respite when demand in the privte sector held relatively steady. The increase is a surprise to some economists, who expected the current recession to cut sharply into loan demand.

title: FATEHPUR SIKRI
description: To the Editor:

title: TV View; RONA BARRETT'S DOWNHILL RIDE
description: If a single image had to be chosen this year to represent the glorious lunacy of show business - television or otherwise - a top candidate would be the sight of Rona Barrett leaning out of her studio chair, into a position almost of genuflection, and raising the hand of Rock Hudson to her lips for a kiss of oozing sincerity. The gossip columnist who would be a star was paying heartfelt homage to the kind of star who made her a name in the first place. The entertainment whirligig can sometimes be dizzying.

title: ISLANDERS BEAT RED WINGS, 5-1
description: Mike Bossy and John Tonelli each scored two goals tonight to lead the Islanders to a 5-1 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings at Nassau Coliseum. It was the third straight victory for the Islanders and put them in undisputed possession of first place in the Patrick Division, 2 points ahead of the Philadelphia Flyers, who did not play.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN RIO DE JANEIRO
description: WARREN HOGE is chief of the Rio de Janeiro bureau of The Times. By WARREN HOGE
