title: Convicted Sex Offender Wins Appeal Over Parole Condition
description: A state appeals court, ruling that it is unconstitutional to bar a sex offender from associating with girls under 16, has overturned a man's conviction for parole violation.

title: CHRISTMAS WITH LEWIS CARROLL
description: QUOTATIONS FROM C.L. DODGSON'S WRITINGS AND ALL FACSIMILE REPRODUCTIONS COPYRIGHT c C.L.DODGSON ESTATE, 1982; ''LEWIS CARROLL: FRIEND OF CHILDREN'' COPYRIGHT c MORTON N. COHEN, 1982. Morton N. Cohen, who edited ''The Letters of Lewis Carroll,'' is now writing a biography of Lewis Carroll. By Morton N. Cohen

title: A CHALLENGE IN ONTARIO
description: More than 200 cross-country skiers will awaken before sunrise on the vernal equinox, March 21. They will climb onto the Algona Central "Snow Train" in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, guzzle coffee while debating which klister to smear on their skis for the best kick and glide, gaze at the snowy scenery in the early morning light, disembark at a whistle stop named Wabos (an Indian name for rabbit) and being trekking across frozen lakes and through the densely forested hills of the rugged Algona Wilderness. Many will be doing so for the third year in a row. For most, it will be the final ski of the season.

title: CONGRESS FINALLY ACTS TO STEM THE FLOOD OF FOREIGN DOCTORS
description: Virtually unnoticed amid the last minute foreign aid, farm and pension bills Congress passed last week was a measure that could change the face of health care in the nation's urban areas. The measure, actually a series of amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act, adjusts the requirements and extends the deadline for hiring foreign doctors who wish to practice in the United States. It is Congress's final notice to hospitals across the country that their dependence on foreign physicians must cease.

title: BURT REYNOLDS- GETTING BEHIND THE CAMERA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. By STEPHEN FARBER

title: MUSIC: CHINA NOW
description: If the new compositions presented Monday by the Group for Contemporary Music at Symphony Space had come from a country with a less radical and exotic image than China, the organizers would have tossed most of it into the trash bin with a derisive chuckle.

title: Katherine Ogren Connecticut Bride Of Ronald Beebe
description: Katherine Taves Ogren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Ogren of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Ronald Scott Beebe, son of Leland G. Beebe and Norma J. Beebe of Largo, Fla. The Rev. Thomas Stiers performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: WARSAW STARTING CRIMINAL ACTIONS AGAINST UNIONISTS CHARGE IS INCITING
description: The Polish Government has disclosed that criminal proceedings are being started against union activists seeking to instigate strikes in violation of martial law.

title: Libya Asserts Reagan Is Interfering in Poland
description: Libya's official press agency said today that President Reagan's decision to suspend food shipments to Poland constituted interference in Poland's domestic affairs.

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER Away from Broadway there are two compelling theatrical marathons, each of which earns the expenditure of time.

title: Bombycilla cedorum
description: Size: Seven inches. Color: Buffy brown, shading to gray on rump.

title: SYRIANS PLEASED AT U.S. ACTION AGAINST ISRAEL
description: Government officials expressed satisfaction today with Washington's decision to suspend the strategic cooperation agreement with Israel but noted with concern a buildup by Israel on its northern border.

title: AIR TRAFFIC PASSES BAD-WEATHER TEST
description: The nation's air traffic control system appears to have coped handily last week with the first persistent bad weather since the illegal walkout of controllers began Aug. 3.

title: Art; NEWARK: A MODEL FOR JURIED SHOWS
description: NEWARK JURIED art exhibitions that bestow first, second and third prizes, together with a selection of honorable mentions, are not the most admirable accomplishment of museums and like institutions. Artists are not race horses who win, place and show, and should not be treated as such.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: ACTRESS SPINS OFF HANUKKAH ROLE
description: WOODMERE TO the actress Judith Goldsmith it seems only fitting that she participate in the Hanukkah celebration and candlelighting ceremony on Tuesday at the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor. Her one-woman show, ''The Town of Little People,'' after all, attempts to trace Jewish roots; and when it comes to those roots, Hanukkah, with its account of the Maccabees' triumph over religious persecution, is one of the most stirring chapters in the history of the Jews.

title: Art; WHAT ONE CAN AND CAN'T DO WITH GLASS
description: ST. JAMES GLASS, like clay, is a material with humble origins and a wide variety of uses, from the most mundane to the highly refined. In chemistry class, we learn that glass is made largely of sand, melted with various minerals, such as lime, soda or lead. The resulting liquid may be cast in sheets or blocks, pressed, molded, blown, extruded, rolled, textured or colored with pigments to produce objects as utilitarian as a beer bottle or as exalted as a cathedral window.

title: WHY MOBIL BEHAVES THAT WAY
description: T he Mobil Corporation does not like to be perceived as just another member of the Seven Sisters of international oil. In 1977, one of the company's ads featured a cartoon of seven women, all but one flat-chested. The caption: ''Can't tell the sisters apart? Mobil's the one with the extra dimension.''

title: New Jersey Journal
description: BEGINNING next month, prospective jurors in Bergen County will report to the courthouse in Hackensack on the day they are assigned. However, if they are not selected for a jury, they do not have to return the next day. Put simply, the county is adopting the one-day, one-trial system introduced earlier in the year in Camden County.

title: The Region in Summary; Ring Out the Old, Ring In the Old
description: Before he leaves the state payroll next month, Governor Byrne would like nothing better than to insure that certain members of his administration stay on it a while longer. With the New Jersey State Senate's confirmation of Joel R. Jacobson as a Casino Control Commissioner last week, he had one less to worry about.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Mailbox; Ivy League Has Other Priorities
description: To the Sports Editor: Dave Anderson's column on the Ivy League's sudden demotion by the National Collegiate Athletic Association (''The Ivy League Grows in Stature,'' Dec. 8, 1981) was right on target. It's about time somebody put college football in proper perspective.

title: TOWNS CONSIDERING SELF-INSURANCE IN WAKE OF TRIAL
description: GOVERNMENT leaders on the Island, from the county level on down to the villages, are taking a new look at the way they buy insurance in the wake of the trial and conviction of the Nassau Republican leader, Joseph M. Margiotta, on charges of extorting kickbacks from Nassau's designated insurance broker.

title: Supremacist Is Sentenced
description: A judge has sentenced an avowed white supremacist to 30 years in prison for an attack on two black men who followed him home. Harold Reifsnyder of Clearwater was convicted in September of aggravated battery and attempted firstdegree murder. Circuit Judge Thomas Penick called him a ''danger to the black men he happens to come across.''

title: Investing; HOW TO BET ON A STOCK INDEX
description: T HE seers of trends in the stock market aren't much better than the weatherman, and if there's a seer who disagrees with that, he will soon be able to test his forecasts against his money. The vehicle is the latest wrinkle in the old commodities contract - the stock index future. It is to be traded on the floor of the Kansas City Board of Trade, which at the moment deals only in red winter wheat, the variety most often used in bread, but is bidding for a share of the burgeoning financial futures business.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: READERS of Anthony Trollope's books and viewers of ''The Pallisers,'' the television series based on six of his novels, will remember Trollope as a prolific writer who published some 50 novels and dutifully wrote 2,500 words each day. R.H. Super's recently published ''Trollope in the Post Office'' (University of Michigan Press) reminds us that Trollope also had a 34-year career as a civil servant in the British Post Office.

title: Long Island Housing; TRYING A DIFFERENT WAY TO SELL A HOUSE: 'HOW ABOUT A BID?'
description: BRENTWOOD JOHN HYLAND had come because, he said, in Ireland, where he was born, buying a house at an auction was the only honest way to buy a house.

title: Numismatics; PROOF KRUGERRANDS BEING PROMOTED IN U.S.
description: Despite occasional controversy centering on political concerns, South Africa's Krugerrand has emerged in recent years as the bestselling bullion gold coin in the world. American buyers, who helped it attain that primacy, are now being introduced to a hitherto unheralded variant of the coin: the proof Krugerrand. This time the appeal is not the gold content of the piece, it is the rarity of the piece.

title: POPE SENDS A SENIOR VATICAN DIPLOMAT TO WARSAW
description: A special Vatican envoy left Rome for Warsaw today amid signs that Pope John Paul II and Roman Catholic bishops in Poland were getting ready to try to play a more forceful role in the Polish situation.

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker Taking Heroes Seriously Patrick McDonnell
description: It's a good thing they made ''The Wizard of Oz'' into a movie when they did, because the film business couldn't do it nowadays. The same thing goes for ''A Christmas Carol'' by Charles Dickens. If Dickens had let that one pass so somebody could write it in 1981, it would never have been written. No 1981 writer would touch Tiny Tim with a 10-foot Scrooge.

title: City Hall Notes
description: In less than two weeks, the New York City Council will exist without the benefit of its members having been elected. It is becoming increasingly clear that the earliest the Council will be able to hold an election is next spring - if then.

title: DOLPHINS EARN DIVISION TITLE
description: With two minutes left in the Dolphins-Bills game today, the pronouncement came over the stadium loudspeakers: ''Playoff tickets will go on sale tomorrow!''

title: POLICIES OF MULTIPLE-LISTING SERVICES UNDER SCRUTINY
description: In 1971 the Justice Department won from organized real-estate brokers an agreement to stop prescribing standard commission rates for home sales. The hope was that this would encourage competition in the field, which in turn would make lower rates available to home buyers.

title: GREEN THUMB IN SEARCH OF MIDAS TOUCH
description: THOUGH intended to provide an escape from the ills of urban life, New York City's parks have come to be afflicted with many of them. With that assessment, Gordon J. Davis, the Parks Commissioner, has launched an ambitious program to return some of the city's parkland to its original, and considerable, glory. Mindful of shrinking Federal subsidies and increasingly gloomy municipal finances, Mr. Davis is seeking private sources, including concessions, sponsorship of special events and corporate largess, to pay for much of the work. It is a risky approach, as he learned last week when plans for a restaurant in Riverside Park met heated opposition at a meeting of the neighborhood's Community Board. Still, Mr. Davis is confident such disputes can be resolved and the parks restored. He recently discussed his plans with Deirdre Carmody, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times. Excerpts from their conversation follow.

title: MIRIAM A. GREGG TO WED IN SPRING
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John N. Gregg of St. Davids, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Miriam Ashley Gregg, to Peter J. Matrangola, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frances J. Matrangola of Daytona Beach, Fla.

title: Food; PREPARING AN ISRAELI TREAT FOR THE FEAST OF LIGHTS
description: ''WHY do we cook with oil on Hanukkah?'' asked Corinne Klafter, a second-grade teacher for the religious school at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck. Seven-year-old Jacob Gelber - still full of energy at 4:30 on a recent afternoon - shot up his arm and shouted, ''They had to find oil to relight the light over the Ark,'' and so began an hour-and-a-half class.

title: TAMING THE RENEGADE MONEY SUPPLY
description: T HE Federal Reserve has made any number of enemies of late for forcing up interest rates and, they contend, crippling the economy. But others praise the Fed's monetary policy. By keeping tight control of the nation's money supply, the Government's central bank has made a start toward calming the fury of inflation and bringing about a sustained decline in interest rates.

title: Donna Jean Kanner Is Wed to James R. McGowan
description: Donna Jean Kanner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kanner of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to James Richard McGowan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. McGowan Jr. of Morris Township, N.J. The Rev. Philip Caruso performed the ceremony at SS. John and Mary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Vikings Take Steps To Protect Stadium
description: The Minnesota Vikings announced today that security would be tripled for the team's final game at Metropolitan Stadium Sunday to discourage souvenir hunters who might wish to take a piece of the park home with them.

title: CHINA'S REFORMS
description: China is at a historic turning point. The p resent leadership is in effect dismantling the Soviet Stalinist m odel of rule and replacing it with something radically different. Iti s opening China's doors to the world, the West in particular, and r elaxing political and economic controls at home.

title: Speaking Personally; A CHRISTMAS TALE OF TRAGEDY AND HUMAN KINDNESS
description: IHAD just returned home from work. It was Friday, three days before Christmas and traditional Yuletide weather: cold and cloudy. The sky hinted that it might snow any moment.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ Billy Taylor is the Renaissance man of jazz. Pianist, composer, arranger, conductor, educator, disk jockey, businessman, writer and an articulate spokesman for jazz on the National Council on the Arts and the National Endowment for the Arts is a listing that simply skims the surface of his activities.

title: PROSECUTOR LAW NOT SO SPECIAL NOW
description: In October 1983, unless Congress votes an extension, the much-debated special prosecutor law will expire. That would not be lamented in the White House or at the Justice Department, where Attorney General William French Smith must soon decide whether to seek a special prosecutor to investigate allegations against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan. Though he said last week that he would not seek changes in the law while Administration officials were under investigation, Mr. Smith has led a campaign for its repeal. And while Congress has not rushed to join him, neither has it expressed broad support for the law in its present form.

title: ITHACA COLLEGE LOSES IN BID FOR LIBAL DAMAGES
description: A middle-level appeals court has ruled that calling ''sex, drugs and booze'' the ''staples of life'' at Ithaca College is not libelous.

title: BOARD CLEARS WAY FOR AIRPORT IMPROVEMENTS
description: It took 13 attempts, but the Board of Estimate has finally, and unanimously, approved an agreement to change the city's lease arrangements with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that clears the way for a $500 million development program at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports.

title: Paperback Talk
description: New life for old books. In the storied Fifth Avenue offices of Charles Scribner's Sons, a member of the fifth generation of Scribners to work for the 135-year-old family-owned house sits, busy on a new assignment, at the desk once used by the legendary editor Maxwell Perkins. After a tour of duty handling subsidiary rights, young Charles Scribner III is reactivating the department that publishes a type of book about which some of his forebears had serious doubts -paperbacks. ''When I was a student at Princeton back in the 70's,'' he told us the other day, ''I haunted the section of the university bookstore where paperbacks were displayed. I got hooked on paperbacks then.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CHURCHES FORM GROUP TO FEED POOR IN BRONX
description: The New York City Council of Churches, responding to Federal cutbacks in social programs, has organized a network of 100 churches and private charity groups in the Bronx to distribute food to the poor on a regular basis.

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Truth in Testing'
description: New York State's ''truth in testing'' law requires disclosure of how college and graduate school admissions tests are formulated and what is in them, so applicants can challenge any aspects they deem unfair. On Jan. 21, 1980 - 20 days after the law went into effect - the Association of American Medical Colleges obtained a preliminary injunction against it.

title: New Jersey Housing; WHEN SINGLE WOMEN BUY HOMES
description: INVARIABLY, when single women talk about having purchased a home, the sentiment expressed is: ''I never would have considered this 10 years ago.''

title: MIAMI'S DISABLED FEEL CHILL OF TRANSPORTATION CUT
description: A sad and ugly little fight, a sideshow, really, brought about by budget cuts ordered here this fall, has ended in a draw for Miami's blind people and Miami's crippled people, who could be said to have gone at one another for what little meat was left on the bone.

title: Business Forum; INVITATION TO AN AMERICAN MITTERRAND
description: I F the merger activity of recent years continues - as is likely -our economy will be dominated by a handful of supergiant companies within a few decades. And even if democracy can then survive, it is unlikely that the megacorporations will be able to withstand the next logical step: takeover by the Federal Government.

title: EGYPT'S FRIEND IN NEED
description: Alan Cowell is The Times's bureau chief in Nairobi. By Alan Cowell y the banks of the Blue Nile there is a colonnaded palace whose whiteness dazzles. Fans turn slowly in vaulted ceilings, helpless against Khartoum's listless heat. Broad verandas afford prospects of green lawn and emerald palms and a river that is not really blue, but gray brown.

title: ARBITRATORS KEEP TEMPERS CALM AND CONSTRUCTION MOVING
description: The construction business is filled with war stories. There's the one about the car that sank halfway through the floor of a dealer's showroom because the engineer overlooked an underground storage tank from a brewery. Or the foundation built over an ''almost dry'' underground stream that turned out to be wetter than anyone thought.

title: DANCE: AILEY TROUPE
description: Nine men and women sprawl in a cafe, smothered in heat and teeming with hostility. They dance, flirt listlessly and shoot drugs, until the doors burst open and a young man staggers in, shot, and dies at their feet. The world has intruded, but it makes no difference. It has already done its worst. They return to their chairs, as listless as ever. Nothing has changed.

title: Antiques; QUILTS OF OLD ON EXHIBIT IN CLINTON
description: CLINTON ANEXHIBIT featuring some 30 American quilts opened last week at the Hunterdon Art Center here. The collection belongs to James Gregory and John Puckett, who own Pink House Antiques in New Hope, Pa.

title: OLD RENDITIONS PROMPT NEW INSIGHTS
description: They are the wrong questions to ask, but listening to old recordings always evokes them. Have we grown as musicians and interpreters in 50 years, or even in 25? Do we know more than our fathers or our grandfathers, and do we use what we know with more facility than they?

title: WHERE DOES JUSTICE LIE IN THE TRANTINO CASE?
description: ON Dec. 6, Channel 5 presented a documentary entitled ''The Night of the Devil.'' For those of you who missed the program, it was a one-hour special about Thomas Trantino, the convicted murderer of two Lodi police officers.

title: Jeffrey Boak to Wed Elizabeth Pelgrift
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Elizabeth DeLancey Pelgrift, daughter of Robert Youngs Pelgrift of West Hartford, Conn., and the late Elizabeth Schroeder Pelgrift, to Jeffrey Lynn Boak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Boak of Holmdel, N.J.

title: PARKS SAUSAGES IS BACK FOR MORE
description: H.G. PARKS INC. was one of those companies whose renown stretched far beyond its relatively small size. Its more-Parks-sausages commercials were one reason. Another was its uncommon place among American corporations. It was black-owned and black-run, one of the biggest such companies in the country. Parks, however, became one of the thousands of companies in recent years that were devoured by conglomerates; and its conglomerate owner in turn was devoured by another conglomerate. And in 1980 for the first time, Parks lost money.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Photography View; THE NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY DIGS INTO ITS TREASURE-TROVE
description: No doubt the current interest in photography is long overdue. But is it not possibly beginning to be overdone? Photography has a rich and varied past, the main outlines of which are now beginning to be seen, and its future, one hopes, will be equally rich and varied. But compared to painting, or even etching and engraving, photography's past is very short, its scope is narrow, and its place in human life limited.

title: Art View; CERAMIC SCULPTURE AND THE TASTE OF CALIFORNIA
description: In mounting its current exhibition of ''Ceramic Sculpture: Six Artists'' (through Feb. 7), the Whitney Museum of American Art has performed a useful service for its public. It is not exactly a secret that for quite a few years now the production of ceramic sculpture has occupied an important place on the California art scene. Yet, although we have seen a good deal of this work in New York in recent years - some of it in the Whitney's own Biennial exhibitions - until now none of our museums has attempted to encompass the movement in a definitive survey. In organizing the present exhibition, then, the Whitney has brought us our first interesting account of an artistic phenomenon that has won much national and international attention, and a phenomenon, moreover, that has for us the additional interest of having no exact counterpart on the New York art scene.

title: DICKENS UNITES OLD AND YOUNG
description: IN HIS later years, Charles Dickens could not recall whether, as a child, he had earned 6 or 7 shillings a week at a blacking factory near London's Strand. What he did remember clearly was the brutality.

title: OWNERS' PRESSURE ON KUHN MOUNTS
description: Major league club owners can't officially determine Bowie Kuhn's fate until next year, but nine of them - five in the National League and four in the American - went to the baseball meetings in Florida last week with a letter aimed at inducing the commissioner to resign or at least prompt him not to run for a third term.

title: MICHAEL BENNETT ONCE AGAIN LOOKS BACKSTAGE FOR A HIT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- George Colt is a freelance writer with a special interest in theater. By GEORGE COLT Michael Bennett offers a warning: ''This show is not about dancers. This show is about singers. It is a show in which people sing.'' He peers cautiously from under the brim of his baseball cap. ''No, it is not 'A Chorus Line.' No it is not 'A Chorus Line II.' It's not a black version of 'A Chorus Line.' It's not any of those things.'' Then he leans back in his chair, folds his hands and grins. ''O.K., I got my message across, I'll relax now.''

title: Chess; NO MATTER WHAT HAPPENS, DON'T PANIC
description: It is all very human to become frantic and illogical when your chances are slipping away in a match, but it almost always results in disaster. The wild gamble, the variation you know to be unsound, instead of beguiling the opponent makes your defeat all the more probable.

title: TRADITION WINNING SMITHSONIAN FIGHT
description: What was once delicately described as a mere matter of ''administrative dissonance'' at the Smithsonian Institution has become a full-blown bureaucratic-academic rumble.

title: Elizabeth Tobie Married To Stuart Andrew Irvine
description: The marriage of Elizabeth McKenrick Tobie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan F. Tobie of Lancaster, Pa., to Stuart Andrew Irvine, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander R. Irvine of Los Angeles, took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Lancaster.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly stated the view of Bishop Paul Moore Jr., head of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, on a proposed skyscraper for the site of the St. Bartholomew's Church community house. Bishop Moore, who is consider- ing the matter, has not yet announced his position.

title: ANTARCTIC EXPLORERS SHIFT GOAL TO HIDDEN RESOURCES
description: Antarctica: Contested Continent First of two articles.

title: A SHARED CELL REUNITES SON WITH FATHER
description: Stanley Fletcher was put behind bars 10 years ago and only now is getting a chance to know his son Curtis again. They are sharing a cell in hopes that the son, also convicted, can learn carpentry and use the skills when his sentence is over.

title: Environews
description: HUNDREDS of inner-city youngsters from New Jersey will begin sharing the year-round facilities of the Milford Reservation in Pennsylvania when the new 1,646-acre recreational and environmentaleducation center in the Pocono Mountains opens next month.

title: For Diana, It's Academic
description: Rich Diana of Yale and Darrin Nelson of Stanford, running backs, and David Rimington, of Nebraska, the Outland Trophy winner, were among the players named to the Academic All-America team, announced today by the College Sports Information Directors of America.

title: ROAMER 'CAP TO THIRTY EIGHT PACES
description: Several weeks ago Angel Cordero, in a surprising announcement, said that he was planning to spend the winter riding in New York. He made that decision pay off yesterday by riding Thirty Eight Paces to an 8 1/2-length victory in the $56,000 Roamer Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: BUDGET CUT CRITICIZED
description: WESTCHESTER'S Social Services Commissioner, in a talk last weekend in Tarrytown, described himself as a ''frustrated middle man, forced by the loss of Federal aid to make reductions, while being accused of being insensitive to the needy.''

title: Smut Foe Jailed in Sex Case
description: John F. Gregorio, former president of Taxpaying Parents Against Kiddie Smut, was sentenced Friday to one year in county jail and 10 years' probation for sexually molesting two children. Mr. Gregorio, 46 years old, had pleaded no contest Oct. 12 to charges of lewd and lascivious behavior with an 8-year-old girl and sexual battery of a 17-year-old boy.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title: ANTI-SEMITISM IS SEEN IN SOME GERMAN TEXTS
description: The first book to be reviewed at the conference here brought participants to their feet to protest. This reaction came as the speaker said the book's authors had presented a Jewish biblical image as a forerunner of Nazi theories that some lives were ''valueless.'' The image, he said, was that of the grape vine, which was interpreted as meaning that God chooses some and rejects others.

title: VOTES PAVES WAY FOR ELECTION OF FIRST BLACKS SINCE 1870'S
description: Voters have approved a new election system that virtually insures that blacks will be elected to the City Council for the first time since Reconstruction.

title: BUILDING BOOM OUTPACES A SCALE MODEL OF THE CITY
description: The A.T.&T. headquarters on Madison Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets was completed two years ago, but construction has not yet begun on the nearby Trump Tower. The I.B.M. Building up the avenue is still in the planning stage, but the company expects to finish the 43-story building in about a month.

title: FROM SPIRE TO SPIRE IN YULETIDE LONDON
description: R.W. APPLE Jr. is chief of The Times's London bureau. By R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: LOUISIANA TECH, OLD DOMINION IN FINAL
description: The country's top two women's basketball teams, Louisiana Tech and Old Dominion, will meet in the championship game of the third annual Manufacturers Hanover Christmas Classic at Madison Square Garden today.

title: No Headline
description: KENTUCKY HANDS SETON HALL FIRST LOSS

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The proposed Alaska gas pipeline is a perfect example of the privatization of profits and the socialization of costs.

title: MUSEUMS OFFERING YULE TREATS
description: SOME people might say that holiday celebrations are out of place in museums. However, Christmas is one holiday that seems eminently suited to them.

title: Recordings; HANDEL RECONSTRUCTED: FAMILIAR MUSIC MADE FRESH
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: AFTER 16 MONTHS, REPRESSION CRUSHES 'RENEWAL'
description: POLAND was invaded from within last week. The country's military, acting in the name of patriotism but at the cost of some lives and many hopes, crushed the most far-reaching workers' revolt in Poland's postwar history. Solidarity, the popular movement that launched the country's ''renewal'' 16 months ago, seemed crippled if not destroyed.

title: Westchester Housing; TENANTS UNITING TO FIGHT CONVERSIONS
description: ''AHANDYMAN came around on a sunny Sunday afternoon in August with books that looked like small-town telephone directories, and on the cover, it said 'Eviction plan' '' Sheldon Malev of North White Plains recalled recently. ''That was the first news we had.''

title: FENDING OFF DEVELOPMENT- FOREVER
description: Three years ago, when Dorothy Walker of Salisbury, Conn., decided to sell her 130-acre farm, she first donated all development rights to the Nature Conservancy, a land-conservation group.

title: Karen Anne Schwartz Bride of Edwin John Graf 3d
description: Karen Anne Schwartz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Schwartz of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday in the Wilton Congregational Church to Edwin John Graf 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Graf Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Zdenek F. Bednar performed the ceremony.

title: CALIFORNIA GIVEN NEW VOTING PLAN
description: The political warfare over redrawing boundaries for California's legislative and Congressional districts has taken a new turn with a proposal by Republican state leaders and Common Cause, the public affairs lobby, for a commission to oversee reapportionment

title: The Week in Business; POLAND ASKS AID FROM WESTERN BANKERS
description: Crisis-torn Poland asked Western bankers for a $350 million, sixmonth loan with which to meet interest payments totalling $500 million by the end of the year on credit the bankers had earlier extended. Poland owes about $1.8 billion to 60 American banks.

title: 1,000 Stage Ottawa Protest On Arrest of Polish Unionists
description: About 1,000 demonstrators marched outside the Canadian Parliament and the Polish and Soviet Embassies here today to protest the imposition of martial law in Poland and the arrest of the leaders of the Solidarity union movement.

title: Politics; DISTRICTING BATTLE HAD HARDLY BEGUN
description: TRENTON IN 1812, Gov. Elbridge Gerry of Massachusetts participated in the time-honored political exercise of redesigning voting districts, a move guaranteed to give his party a lopsided advantage in the next election.

title: Q&A
description: Question:As a traveler who carries a considerable amount of film, I am concerned with the increasingly unpleasant response one gets from airport security people, particularly overseas, when one requests having film handled in a manner that does not damage it. How should photographic equipment be inspected so as not to damage the film? - A.H.H., New York Answer:A spokesman for Eastman Kodak says, ''We have examined a great deal of film claimed to have been damaged by X-ray inspection devices. Invariably, our examinations have shown some other problem. In this country the Federal Aviation Administration mandates lowdosage X-ray machines and also allows the option of hand inspection for concerned travelers.

title: Around the Nation; Parents Sue Cub Scouts On Daughter's Exclusion
description: The parents of a 9-year-old girl who ''needs to be taught to be a survivor'' are pressing a suit over her exclusion from the Cub Scouts.

title: THE MILITARY MUSCLE, POLISH AND RUSSIAN
description: SOVIET troops, tanks and aircraft in Poland stayed out of action last week, but awareness of their presence and of Moscow's ability to reinforce them rapidly weighed heavily on Poland as its own troops enforced martial law. The Soviet Army moved two armored divisions into urban areas, believed to be near Gdansk and Warsaw, from their bases at Szczecin in northwest Poland and at Legnica in the southwest. Both are Category I units, meaning their personnel, weapons and equipment are at war strength. A Soviet armored division has 335 tanks; these divisions have T-62's, T-64's and T-72's, the most modern main battle tanks in the Russian arsenal.

title: CHILEAN ECONOMY IS IN A RECESSION
description: The Chilean experiment with free-market economics is stumbling and coming under pressure from unexpected quarters - conservative businessmen and far-right ideologues.

title: IS SUCCESS CHANGING PILOBOLUS?
description: ''It's the idiosyncracies that show a person at his best,'' Jonathan Wolken, a founder of Pilobolus, added. ''We used to jokingly say we should exhibit our deformities: rolls for me, with my rounded back, or a one-legged solo for Moses (Pendleton, co-founder of the company) in his cast.''

title: FOR MIGRANT WORKERS, IT'S A CYCLE OF GRADING AND WAITING
description: THE harvest is in on eastern Long Island. The potato fields are planted in rich green cover crops. Along the main roads, the farm stands have been selling the last of the locally grown cauliflowers, brussels sprouts, cabbages and potatoes before closing for the winter. The Puerto Rican work crews are leaving for home with a season's wages from the nurseries and orchards.

title: Other Business; CHRISTMAS COMES TO THE SUPERMARKET
description: It's Christmas, and can the poinsettia be far behind? No. But as holiday giving habits have changed, so too has the flower market. ''Consumers don't want a lot of services anymore,'' said M. Truman Fossum, founder and sole employee of Marketing Facts for Floriculture, a research firm. Retail florists, who did 80 percent of all cut flower business 30 years ago, do less than half of it today - and the poinsettia, when bought, is more likely to be picked up on the street or in the supermarket than in a flower shop.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Hard Rocks, Hard Knocks
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt is winding up 1981 with a new claim to his title, conferred by environmentalists, as public lands enemy No.1.

title: Around the Nation; Denver, Short of Water, Wants to Buy a Town
description: The city Water Department wants to buy the tiny town of Deckers for $500,000 for use as a 15,000-acre reservoir, officials say.

title: Topics Special Prosecutions  Not Guilty
description: The appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate charges against Raymond Donovan would not mean that the Secretary of Labor is guilty of a crime. President Reagan was right to point that out at his news conference Thursday and to make clear that Mr. Donovan won't be asked to step aside even if the Attorney General obtains a special prosecutor.

title: WHAT POLAND LACKS, HUNGARY HAS APLENTY
description: BUDAPEST IN Soviet-dominated Eastern Europe, only Hungary and Poland permit agriculture based largely on the quest for private profit. Yet, while Hungary has more than enough to eat, near-catastrophic food shortages in Poland helped bring on last week's military takeover. The difference can be traced to Government policies. Polish agriculture collapsed because of official mismanagement and ideological suspicion of three million Polish private farmers. Reacting to official discrimination, shortages of fertilizer and machinery, and unrealistic prices, farmers have reduced production and withheld food.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: NOT MUCH SYMPATHY IN PRAGUE
description: PRAGUE THIS magnificent medieval city was at its wintry best last week. Powdery snow clung to the noses, brows and shoulders of the Baroque sculptures on the 14th century Charles Bridge, to the fantastic Gothic pinnacles, to the tumble of ancient tombstones in the old Jewish cemetery. ''The snow lay round about, deep and crisp and even'' in the countryside, and one almost expected to see Bohemia's beloved and martyred Good King Wenceslaus looking out upon the scene.

title: THE EGLEVSKY TURNS A CORNER
description: WITH the Eglevsky Ballet's annual ''Nutcracker'' performances this season at the C.W. Post Center nearly sold out, the company appears to have turned a corner in its efforts toward economic stability and growth.

title: Personal Finance; A WAY TO GIVE A LOT, FOR LESS
description: T he holiday season may not seem like a time for financial planning, but for those who can make the effort, working out a charitable contribution from now until the end of the year may significantly reduce 1981 tax bills.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THE leading cause of death among young children is traffic accidents, according to two Republican state legislators who are sponsoring legislation designed to reduce the number of child traffic casualties.

title: PESSIMISM INCREASES IN SEARCH FOR HARVARD STUDENT
description: Three weeks ago Joan L. Webster, eager to finish an architectural project, left her Glen Ridge, N.J., home to return to her studies at Harvard's Graduate School of Design. Passengers on her plane from Newark remember seeing the 25-year-old woman, and an acquaintance nodded to her at the baggage claim area in Boston's Logan International Airport. Then she disappeared.

title: IS THERE ACTUALLY AN 'AVERAGE' CHILD?
description: WHO is this statistical marvel known as the ''average child?'' How do our schools meet this student's ''typical'' needs? Our average child is not the figment of a statistician's imagination. This student is not merely the sum of items divided by the total number of cases. Neither is this youngster just another one of the instances that occupy the two-thirds of the space under the middle portion of the normal curve.

title: By John H. Reiss
description: SELLING TOTHE PENTAGON

title: Barbara Ann Sturgis Fiancee of Walter T. Everett
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Ira Sturgis of Rock Hill, S.C., of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Sturgis, to Walter Tripp Everett, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Morris Everett of Holmdel, N.J.

title: DANCE: 'RELATIVE CALM' BY LUCINDA CHILDS
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's excellent avant-garde dance and opera series, ''The Next Wave,'' comes to a close this afternoon with Lucinda Childs's dance piece ''Relative Calm,'' which had its American premiere Friday night.

title: IN DEFENSE OF KNOWHOW
description: BLAMING TECHNOLOGY The Irrational Search for Scapegoats.By Samuel C. Florman. 207 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95. By LYNN WHITE Jr.

title: Ship Lineage
description: To the Editor:

title: SKIING WITH SLED DOGS IN TOW
description: RUTH ROBINSON is a reporter for The New York Times. By RUTH ROBINSON

title: FIVE YEARS LATE, PHILADELPHIA OPENS MUSEUM
description: It was not the first time anyone had ever attended a party in the giant brick Port of History Museum on the waterfront, but it was the first time that anyone had seen an exhibit in a building that had grown notorious as this city's biggest white elephant.

title: Reading and Writing; A GOVERNMENT OF CRITICS
description: Shelley said that ''poets are the unacknowledged legislators of the world,'' but unless people learn to like poetry and to read it, the poet's legislation will probably remain unacknowledged. Thorstein Veblen thought that we should be governed by engineers, because they are experts in structures, and he saw government as a problem of designing structures for the regulation of society. Some of us, though, feel that we have been suffering from too much structure in government, or nothing but structure, based on other structures, innocent of a single human datum.

title: AID OFFERED SEPARATED PARENTS
description: PROFESSIONAL help for parents who are concerned about the effects of marital separation on their children will be offered, free of charge to county residents, during two separate series of group meetings next month. Entitled ''Helping Your Child Cope With Your Marital Separation,'' each series will consist of 10 evening sessions directed by psychologists from the Larchmont-Mamaroneck Community Counseling Center.

title: The World in Summary; Training Here To Fight There
description: Sending 32 United States military advisers and $25 million of weapons to El Salvador hasn't turned the tide, so the Reagan Administration last week announced a new push from the opposite direction. The Pentagon will train 1,000 Salvadoran soldiers, probably at the Fort Bragg, N.C., counterinsurgency school, and 500 Salvadoran officers at Fort Benning, Ga. or the United States base in Panama.

title: ORTHODONTIST OUTLINES BUDGET'S EFFECT ON DENTAL PROGRAM...
description: THE budget cuts proposed by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello will, if approved, eliminate or curtail programs and services that affect life at every level in the the county. Some of the programs are familiar to everyone, others are only known to recipients and providers of particular services. Among the lesser known is a program that provides orthodontic treatment for children with handicapping dental malocclusions.

title: Epileptic Wins a Stay
description: A Superior Court judge has temporarily barred the city from dismissing a probationary police officer because he is an epileptic. Joseph Dyndur, 21 years old, was to have been dismissed Thursday, but Judge Corinne P. Grande granted a stay and ordered a hearing for Feb. 25.

title: Politics; 'FISCAL CONSERVATIVE' MAKES SENATE BID
description: HARTFORD UP to last week, the most publicity that Bradford L. Peery had generated for his campaign for the United States Senate may have occurred last September when he was robbed on a subway platform in Manhattan.

title: Speaking Personally; A TRADITION PUTS FAMILY OUT ON A LIMB
description: FAMILIES over the years build traditions. Loving traditions. Meaningful ceremonies carried on year after year that build lasting memories. Our family, along with many others around the holiday season, has its own tradition. Although it may fluctuate from year to year in different degrees, it will nevertheless be celebrated again this year as it has been for a number of years. We call it the Annual Christmas Eve Fight.

title: COLUMBIA, AS LANDLORD, SEEKS BETTER COMMUNITY RELATIONS
description: Columbia University, whose expansion as a landlord in the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan has often placed it at odds with local politicians and tenant organizations, has drawn a new set of principles to clarify its housing policies and improve its relationship with the neighborhood.

title: City Settles With 2 Doctors Accused of Impeding Rescue
description: Two California doctors arrested at the Gene Autry Hotel on charges of interfering with police officers and paramedics treating a heart attack victim have received $1,150 each in return for a signed release preventing future claims against the city.

title: MACCHIAROLA'S BUDGET SEEKS TO ADD STAFF AND PROGRAMS
description: Children at both ends of New York City's public school system, those in kindergarten and high school, would receive added attention next year under a budget proposal being presented by the Schools Chancellor.

title: THE 70TH APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund was established in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, then publisher of The Times. That year, 117 contributors donated a total of $3,630.88 to be distributed among three private social-service agencies.

title: 200 Safe-Deposit Boxes Looted at Queens Bank
description: More than 200 safe-deposit boxes were broken into and looted at a branch of the European-American Bank in Little Neck, Queens, the police said yesterday.

title: COMMITTEE WANTS RESEARCHERS TO LIST HUMAN SUBJECTS AND INJURIES
description: A Presidential commission has decided to recommend that steps be taken to find out how many Americans serve as subjects of medical and behavioral research and what adverse effects result from such studies.

title: HOLLYWOOD SHIVERS IN A CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE
description: LOS ANGELES Hollywood, like some gigantic reptile, has no internal regulation of temperature. When times are good, it fuels itself with a cockiness drawn from public acceptance. When times are bad, confidence shrivels and the beast simply freezes. It is the talent agents whose bones feel the first chill, whose voices form the first chorus of despair. ''There are more pictures in turnaround today - projects the studios are trying to get rid of - than ever before,'' said one agent, David Wardlow. ''In my 13 years of working in the movie business, I've never seen it like this,'' says Sue Mengers of ICM. ''The studios seem immobilized when it comes to saying 'Yes' to anything.''

title: FAMILY FROM MICHIGAN ADJUSTING TO DECEMBER IN THE SUN BELT
description: This is the fifth in a series of occasional articles following one Middle Western family on its search for a new life in the Sun Belt.

title: MISS ALEKSEYEVA LEAVES MOSCOW FOR U.S.
description: Yelizaveta K. Alekseyeva, who was given an exit visa to leave the Soviet Union after a hunger strike by Andrei D. Sakharov, arrived in Paris today, ending the first leg of a journey to the United States.

title: BOOKS: LIEBERMAN PROFILES JOHN BAILEY
description: THE LEGACY: Connecticut Politics 1930-1980. By Joseph I. Lieberman. Introduction by Jack Zaiman. Cartoons by Ed Valtman. 215 pages. Spoonwood Press. $17.95.

title: Business Conditions; WAGES AND INFLATION
description: Although some economists expect the current squeeze on key union wage rates to result in much lower inflation next year, a recent analysis indicates that progress in reducing the so-called ''core'' rate of inflation is likely to be a much more drawn-out process.

title: 'NUTCRACKER': DRESS-UP TIME
description: The children skip, sprint, scamper, jump, dance, walk or waddle their way past the Lincoln Center Plaza fountain and head eagerly toward the Snow Forest and the Land of Sweets, places some disbelieving grown-ups insist on calling the New York State Theater. It is there, of course, that the New York City Ballet is presenting its annual monthlong outing of ''The Nutcracker.''

title: FEW DRUGSTORES STAYING OPEN AT NIGHT
description: BECAUSE of rising expenses and fear of crime, the all-night drugstore is a disappearing amenity. When a prescription needs to be filled at night, county residents face an often-futile search that may end only at the emergency room of a hospital.

title: Esther Nichol Married
description: Esther Habersham Nichol and Mark Sims Goodman were married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Frederick Bowen Northrup.

title: Alice S. Johnson Wed to Architect
description: Alice Sheridan Johnson and George G. Alexander were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. David Taylor performed the ceremony.

title: BIRDS ON THE LAKE, THOUGHTS ON THE WING
description: FROM the spring when cats uncurl to bask in the sun, through the summer when they lie stretched out on the bare floor, and then in the autumn when they wind around themselves again - these are the months for me to go bicycling around a group of small, gentle lakes near home. Each year, as the branches that overhang the lakes yield their brilliant foliage to the wind, my rides become shorter, until finally they are but a winter reminiscence. But this year the remembering is different, for this was the year when summer slept.

title: On Veterinarian Service In North of County
description: An article appeared in the Westchester Weekly section of the Dec. 6 issue of The New York Times regarding the Westchester Veterinary Emergency Hospital (About Westchester column).

title: New York Legal Notes
description: Civil liberties, like politics, can make for strange bedfellows. The Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church has enlisted several mainstream religious groups and the titans of the public-interest bar - including the American Civil Liberties Union, the New York Civil Liberties Union, the American Jewish Congress and the Catholic League for Civil Rights - to challenge an Appellate Division opinion that the church's involvement in politics disqualified it from tax exemption.

title: Westchester Guide; CRECHES ON DISPLAY
description: Each year at Christmastime Pauline Field painstakingly removes three dozen creches from their storage places around the house and puts them on display for family, friends and neighborhood children to see, managing to put them away again by February or March. This year, 10 of the choicest ones are on display until Jan. 2 in the North Salem Library, on Route 116.

title: THREE YEARS AFTER WATER STUDY, CLEANUP EFFORTS YIELD MIXED RESULTS
description: NEARLY three years after a comprehensive study recommended immediate action to clean up the Island's polluted bays and safeguard its drinking water, major portions of the bays are still closed to shellfishing, and known sources of toxic chemicals still threaten the drinking water.

title: PLAYOFF SPOT ON LINE TODAY
description: The Giants are still alive. In an incredible game in which they wasted one opportunity after another, their defense saved them again in a 13-10 overtime victory over the Dallas Cowboys today.

title: THE VOICES OF THE ELDERLY IS HEARD
description: ON Nov. 29, a Sunday, 97 members of the New Jersey delegation to the White House Conference on Aging headed for the nation's capital to join other state delegations in helping to formulate a national policy on the elderly.

title: Washington; MOSCOW'S CHRISTMAS MESSAGE
description: Two years ago, the Russians gave out the Afghanistan crisis for Christmas, and this year the Polish crisis, both in the name of ''peace and good will toward men.'' You would have thought their timing, if not their policy had improved, but failure seems to have gone to their heads.

title: Food; KEEPING PACE WITH SNAILS
description: If we had to name the single ''best'' convenience food imported from France, it would be the snails that come packaged in tins. The reason is that snails, long considered a great delicacy, require hours, if not days, of tedious preparation; they must be washed several times, ''purged'' in a blend of salt, vinegar and flour, cooked, and so on.

title: Susan Schemel, Banker, Will Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Schemel of Vero Beach, Fla., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Farley Schemel, to Bernhard Hoffmann 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoffmann 2d of Washington, Conn.

title: FIRST WE MUST SPEAK CLEARLY
description: THE UNIVERSITY AND THE PUBLIC INTEREST By A. Bartlett Giamatti. 184 pp. New York: Atheneum. $12.95.

title: BEGIN: THE GUERRILLA AS MASTER POLITICIAN
description: If unpredictability is a virtue for a small and vulnerable country, then Israel's Prime Minister Menachem Begin has performed brilliantly in the last eight months. Threats have been left hanging, dissolving into unexpected flexibility and compromise. Extreme actions have come without explicit warning, stunning adversaries and friends. The old guerrilla-warfare tactics of surprise, practiced so skillfully when he led the Irgun underground in British mandate days, have been elevated to principles of state policy.

title: COUNTRY LIVING
description: THE GIFT OF GOOD LAND Further Essays Cultural and Agricultural. By Wendell Berry. 281 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: North Point Press. Cloth, $16.50. Paper, $8.50. SECOND CUTTING Letters From the Country. By Richard M. Ketchum. 305 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: HOLIDAY SPIRIT IS IN THE CARDS AT JERSEY GAMBLING TOURNEY
description: As the doldrums of mid-December stole upon Atlantic City's gambling casinos last week and the crowds of autumn dropped away from roulette wheels and baccarat, craps and blackjack tables, the thoughts of some high rollers and big spenders did not turn home for the holidays.

title: Why Moscow Is Afraid
description: What is being crushed in Poland is a genuine revolution - exuberant, spontaneous and far from settled in its ideology or program. Solidarity was undisciplined, as protest has to be in a closed society. It was not, however, anarchistic or capitalistic or directly anti-Soviet.

title: Essay; MARSHAL KULIKOV'S INVASION
description: The terrible question everybody is afraid to face is this: as their leaders are being herded into concentration camps, what should the Polish people do?

title: UNIONS AT DAILY NEWS SEEK A MEETING WITH OWNER
description: The unions at The Daily News reacted yesterday to the newspaper's proposed sale by demanding an immediate meeting with its owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago.

title: Long Island Guide; MOZART FESTIVAL
description: It's Mozart Festival time on the Island again, and, courtesy of the Orchestra Da Camera and James Conlon, the acclaimed young conductor who takes time out of his busy international schedule each year to lead this chamber orchestra, the master's music will be heard today. With Young Uck Kim as violin soloist, the concert, at 3 P.M. at West Hollow Junior High, off Route 110 in Melville, will offer Mozart's Violin Concerto No. 1 in B flat (K. 207), the Symphony No. 29 in A (K. 201) and the Violin Concerto No. 5 in A (K. 219) (the ''Turkish''). Tickets are $10, but there may still be some cut-rate subscriptions available to all three concerts (they follow in January and February). For reservations, call 249-7868. VICTORIAN CHILDHOOD

title: HUGH LEONARD'S DALKEY
description: HUGH LEONARD, the Irish playwright, is the author of ''Da'' and ''A Life.'' By HUGH LEONARD

title: 3 Guards Charged in Escape
description: Three Trenton State Prison guards have been charged with neglecting their duties in connection with the Dec. 4 escape of three inmates, according to the state Department of Corrections. The guards - two who worked in the towers and one who was employed in the prison hospital - face administrative disciplinary hearings next week, officials said. Two of the escaped prisoners were recaptured within hours, but a third remains at large.

title: Topics; SPECIAL PROSECUTIONS; Botched Bust
description: A few weeks ago, Dempsey Lee Owen, a fugitive under Federal indictment in New York for selling cocaine, was apprehended in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. But a short time later, Mr. Owen was a free man.

title: STYLE OF O.A.S. IS CHALLENGED BY CARIBBEAN
description: The Organization of American States, Latin in style from its ornate headquarters here in the old Pan American Union to the language of its documents, is facing a cultural challenge from the Caribbean basin.

title: Jane Lewis Dwight Betrothed to Jeffrey H. Seibert
description: Nancy P. Cooke of Baltimore and Robert L. Dwight of Gibson Island, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Lewis Dwight, to Jeffrey H. Seibert, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Seibert Jr. of Somerville and Mantoloking, N.J.

title: CITIZEN COALITION FIGHTS NEWARK ON DEMOLITION BURNED-OUT BUILDINGS CALLED UNSIGHTLY HAZARDS
description: NEWARK IT BEGAN as a coalition of six Roman Catholic parishes, whose members united in November 1979 to try to make their communities better places in which to live.

title: DELAY CRITICIZED IN TRANSFER OF RETARDATION INSTITUTE
description: WHITE PLAINS ATENTATIVE agreement reached last year between the county and the New York Medical College to keep the Mental Retardation Institute in Valhalla has not yet been signed by either side because of ''several unresolved issues,'' including a demand by the college that the county assume any liabilities the institute has accrued during the yearlong negotiations.

title: GENERAL'S CAPTORS ISSUE A STATEMENT
description: The Red Brigades terrorists who kidnapped Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier of the United States Army two days ago issued their first ''communique'' today but made no ransom demands.

title: z; Index; International
description: Despite achievements, Trudeau Government is out of favor 3 Red Brigades issue statement but set no ransom for general 4 Syria expresses satisfaction with U.S. move on Israel 6 O.A.S. title: An Auto Manual for a Holiday Gift
description: GARAGES are places deep in character. If they aren't stuffed with old newspapers and a welter of broken bicycles, they are liable to be the repository of a lifetime's collection of tools, parts for cars long gone, and a raft of well-meant but useless items received as gifts.

title: STAGE: MYSTERY IN VERSE
description: Daniel Mark Epstein's ''The Midnight Visitor,'' a Shaliko Company production directed by Leonardo Shapiro, is a mystery play in verse, and I don't know which is worse, the mystery or the verse. The play is filled with such lines as ''the crux of my desire.'' The crux of my desire was to escape from St. Peter's Hall, the setting for this psychosexual exercise in spiritualism.

title: CLUB'S PLAN STIRS SEA CLIFF
description: SEA CLIFF A COUNTRY club's application for approval of plans for a 20-unit condominium development has aroused some concern among residents of this North Shore village, which is distinguished largely by its Victorian homes and small-town atmosphere.

title: A TRANQUIL OASIS IN BUSTLING MIAMI
description: GREGORY JAYNES is a national correspondent in the Times's Miami bureau. By GREGORY JAYNES

title: TRISTATE UNIT DIRECTOR SEEKS TO STAY AX
description: ABOLISHMENT of the Tristate Regional Planning Commission, which reviews Federal financing for New Jersey, New York and Connecticut projects, was urged last week in a letter to the Governors of the three states.

title: FIREFIGHTER SAVES A MAN, THEN COLLAPSES AND DIES
description: A 36-year-old Staten Island fireman who had received three commendations for valor suffered a fatal heart attack yesterday shortly after rescuing a young man from an early morning blaze.

title: BUYING FUEL OIL AT A DISCOUNT
description: The Citizen's Alliance Fuel Buyers Group, a citywide cooperative organization, is providing discounts in fuel oil to 2,000 residential and commercial consumers in the metropolitan New York area, according to Michael B. Gordon, the program's coordinator.

title: The Nation in Summary; D.O.E. May Be D.O.A.
description: Since President Reagan took office, the main question about the future of the Department of Energy has been how short it would be. The answer will be ''very,'' if Congress goes along with a proposal he put forth last week.

title: No Headline
description: NETS BEAT CAVALIERS; 76ERS TOP CELTICS

title: Constance Hart Will Be Married To an Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Hart 3d of Middlebury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Constance Colburn Hart, to Robert Walkingshaw 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walkingshaw of Sewickley, Pa.

title: SUFFOLK WEIGHS BAY-BOTTOM LEASES
description: UNDERWATER land in Peconic and Gardiners Bays could be leased by Suffolk County for commercial shellfish cultivation as a result of a plan under consideration by the Suffolk County Legislature.

title: New Jersey Guide; MEDIEVAL BALLET
description: A legendary apparition from the Middle Ages will reappear this evening, when the Flower Hujer Dance Theater presents ''The Juggler of Our Lady,'' a medieval ballet set to music of the period.

title: Around the Nation; Ukrainian Killed Himself After War-Crimes Suit
description: A Ukrainian immigrant who was run over by a train Friday, just hours after being accused of war crimes, killed himself, the Cook County medical examiner said today.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Hill, $22.95.) The most complete study of Pearl Harbor, laying to rest the theory that we were railroaded into war.

title: For Guns, Not Bows, In Deer Hunting
description: I was shocked by an article about killing deer with bow and arrow, in The New York Times, Nov. 1 (''Bow Season Opens Amid Deer Debate''). This is unnecessarily cruel. If it is neccessary to get rid of deer, I think guns should be used by excellent marksmen. MARY S. MULLIGAN Scarsdale

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; What Kind of Crack Is That?
description: The space-age technology that helped map Mars has now discovered a down-to-earth geological phenomenon - the Missouri Gravity Low, an ancient rift in the North American crust that extends some 1,700 miles from Idaho to the southern Appalachian Mountains. The rift may be twice the length of the San Andreas Fault in California.

title: VIOLINIST: HENRYK SZERYNG
description: It was good for morale to hear Henryk Szeryng, the noted Polishborn violinist, play Bach's Partita No. 2 in D minor at the Metropolitan Museum Friday night. The work ends with the celebrated Chaconne in D minor, one of the most difficult movements in the literature for solo violin, a piece that can make even a very good violinist sound woefully overmatched and inept. Mr. Szeryng zeroed in on it with the sort of concentration one thought was reserved for chess champions, and gave a gripping performance that projected not only the music's emotive strength but its grand architecture as well.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Polish crackdown against the independent trade union Solidarity may not be as successful as it is pictured in official pronouncements from Warsaw, according to analysts in Washington and at NATO headquarters in Brussels.

title: Solidarity's Exiles Plan Appeal to U.N. Council
description: Members of Poland's Solidarity union who were abroad when martial law was declared last Sunday said today that they planned to appeal to the United Nations Security Council to protect the human rights of the Polish people.

title: Saad Muhammad Stopped by Braxton
description: Dwight Braxton pounded Matthew Saad Muhammad with a relentless right jab and took away Muhammad's World Boxing Council light heavyweight title with a 10th-round knockout today.

title: STAGE: AGATHA CHRISTIE'S 'TEN LITTLE INDIANS,'
description: In Agatha Christie's ''Ten Little Indians,'' characters drop like flies, killed in the most ingenious ways. Inevitably, one survivor turns to another and says, ''Is something the matter?'' Therefore, is ''Ten Little Indians'' camp, tragedy, comedy, campy tragicomedy, or none of these at all? None of these at all, actually; it is a comedy of manners. The Equity Library Theater production is fine when it plays it this way; it is not so fine when it does not. One must be very serious about a comedy of manners.

title: Elizabeth Weintz Bride of Robert Cerf
description: In Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Elizabeth Hunt Weintz and Robert Alan Cerf were married by the Rev. Edward Cobden.

title: JAYCEES CHARTER THREATENED OVER NATIONAL BAR ON WOMEN
description: JAYNE OPFERKUCH is a 24-year-old financial analyst with the American Can Company in Greenwich, Conn., just across the Westchester County border. She is also the president of the Ossining Jaycees, a 35-member chapter of the service organization that has 300,000 members nationwide.

title: Food; CHOCOLATE'S SWEET, SINFUL ALLURE
description: NOW that Christmas is practically upon us, it is time to think of last-minute gifts and inspired desserts for the holiday season. What better than chocolate?

title: 1,500 PROTEST AT POLISH MISSION
description: A labor-sponsored rally protesting the crackdown on the Solidarity movement in Poland drew 1,500 people to the streets outside the Polish Consulate in New York yesterday.

title: Jane O'Keefe Is Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John J. O'Keefe of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Linderman O'Keefe, to Michael Joseph Videtich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Videtich of Leadville, Colo. A spring wedding is planned. Miss O'Keefe and her fiance were graduated from the University of Colorado. She is with the First National Bank in Cortez, Colo., where Mr. Videtich is a petroleum engineer with Texaco Inc.

title: JETS FLYING TO THE FINISH OF THEIR TURNAROUND SEASON
description: THIS used to be the day the Jets brought their suitcases to Shea Stadium. Instead, it is a regular-season finale -and the club has playoff tickets waiting to go on sale at 8 o'clock tomorrow morning.

title: CITY'S PROPOSAL FOR RESTAURANT IN RIVERSIDE PARK IS ASSAILED
description: A proposal to build a restaurant on the Rotunda in Riverside Park at 79th Street has drawn opposition from a West Side theater group that has staged productions there for the last two summers.

title: JAZZ: BOB WILBER PLUS FIVE
description: A program called ''Contrasts in Jazz'' featuring Bob Wilber, the clarinetist and saxophonist, Wednesday at Carnegie Recital Hall was less contrasts in jazz as contrasts within one period of jazz. The focus was the 30's and 40's with segments devoted to Sidney Bechet, Louis Jordan and John Kirby's band.

title: Dining Out; A NEWCOMER TO MORRISTOWN
description: THE Grand Cafe in Morristown opened for business on July 1. However, there was no sign designating the refurbished building, which is near the Town Green, as a restaurant. Neither was it advertised. Realizing that it takes time for a new restaurant to solve its problems, the owners, Desmond Lloyd and Jack Baker, wisely decided to keep a low profile until a certain standard had been reached.

title: CRUISE MISSILES WON'T DO FOR A FIRST STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ORDERLY WORLD OF CHRISTOPHER WREN
description: PAUL GOLDBERGER is the architecture critic of The New York Times. By PAUL GOLDBERGER

title: The Region in Summary; Flipping Out On the I.R.T
description: When a transit official suggested that the cause of a subway derailment under Times Square last week was an isolated failure, he apparently meant isolated to the New York transit system. Breakdowns like the one that allowed a 300-pound motor to drop from the moving train had already caused two other derailments this year.

title: Television Week
description: Controversy An ABC News Closeup documentary unit recently launched its own three-month investigation into the highly controversial subject of whether or not the Soviet Union, or its agents, had used biochemical agents in Southeast Asia in violation of international agreements. Their findings will be broadcast on Monday at 8 P.M. in ''Rain of Terror.''

title: 2 Escape in Navy Crash
description: Two crewmen safely ejected before their Navy jet fighter crashed while preparing to land aboard the carrier Constellation in the Indian Ocean today. A United States military spokesman said the crewmen on the F-14A Tomcat were both uninjured.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: RAID! The Untold Story of Patton's Secret Mission. By Richard Baron, Abe Baum and Richard Goldhurst. 283 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95.

title: A Response From Armand Hammer
description: In my view, Edward Jay Epstein's article ''The Riddle of Armand Hammer'' (Nov. 29) unfairly represents several important aspects in the story of my life. There are some misrepresentations which go beyond the levels of tolerance. These are the ones that by a pen stroke attempt to denigrate or destroy the very meaning of one's life. This I cannot tolerate in silence.

title: Headliners; Time Well Served
description: John Artis was twice convicted with Rubin (Hurricane) Carter in one of New Jersey's most complicated and controversial murder cases. By contrast, last week's decision to parole him seemed clear.

title: Correction
description: We regret that the following two novels were inadvertently omitted from the list of Notable Books of the Year, which appeared in the December 6 issue of The Book Review.

title: Of Christmas And Recession
description: The current recession reminds me of the Christmases I spent in the Depression years of the 1930's while living with my grandmother and ''old maid'' aunt in our large, wooden and drafty house next to the Long Island Rail Road in Bay Shore. Christmas was gluing pretty colored papers in circles to drape on a tree that could hopefully be found by my aunt about 12 P.M. on Christmas Eve, when a seller would take a dollar, or, if possible, 50 cents, rather than throw it away.

title: Smuggling Suspect Indicted
description: A businessman has been indicted on charges of smuggling 185 tons of marijuana into the United States. A Federal grand jury indicted Lloyd Joseph Balliviero Thursday on eight counts of violating Federal drug laws. Mr. Balliviero is president of Lloyd's Industries of Belle Chase.

title: Oaxaca
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance View; REVIVING DIAGHILEV'S AVANT-GARDE
description: The avant-garde of the past is what the Metropolitan Opera has really been presenting for the last two seasons in its new triplebill format. The current entry is an outstanding program simply entitled ''Stravinsky'' and consists of ''Le Sacre du Printemps,'' the composer's most famous ballet score as re-choreographed by Jean-Pierre Bonnefous; Stravinsky's first opera,''Le Rossignol,'' with fresh choreography by Frederick Ashton danced by Anthony Dowell and Natalia Makarova; and a new staging of the opera-oratorio, ''Oedipus Rex,'' directed by John Dexter, who was responsible for the entire program's conception.

title: EASING RULES URGED FOR DRUNKEN DRIVER TESTS
description: Police officers in New York State would be given broadened authority to conduct roadside tests for drunken driving under a proposal made by Governor Carey's Alcohol and Highway Safety Task Force.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Dancers look more like racehorses every day. The accent is on go-forbroke movement or rigorously conceived conceptual plottings of dance.

title: Fat Girls Losing Out On School Drill Team
description: A curriculum committee has voted to keep fat girls off a high school drill team, unless they can show they are losing a pound a week.

title: Writers in Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: WARSAW STARTING CRIMINAL ACTIONS AGAINST UNIONISTS FOOD AID DELIVERED
description: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: PHILHARMONIC: 4 PIECES BY MODERN COMPOSERS
description: Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic are often accused of being too solidly traditional in their tastes. But this past week's subscription program consisted almost entirely of 20th-century music. The ''almost'' is necessary because the program began with Ives's Symphony No. 1, which was completed in 1898. And all four pieces were either very conservative or several decades old or both. Still, it was an interesting program, by and large well played.

title: CREDIBILITY OF MUSTO'S ACCUSER IS ASSAILED AT EXTORTION TRIAL
description: Defense attorneys in the Federal racketeering and extortion trial of State Senator William V. Musto and seven codefendants are expected to continue their attack on the credibility of the prosecution's chief witness, as the trial enters its sixth week Monday.

title: MISTRUST EMBROILING 2 UPSTATE TOWNS
description: While the origins of the natural-gas industry and the temperance movement can be traced to Fredonia, its chief claim to fame may be as the thinly veiled setting for ''The Man That Corrupted Hadleyburg,'' Mark Twain's short story of hypocrisy, mistrust and backbiting in an upcountry hamlet.

title: Dr. Elynne Margulis to Be Bride of Charles Zucker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irving Margulis of Williston Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Elynne Beth Margulis, to Charles S. Zucker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Zucker of Maplewood, N.J.

title: A Car Bomb in Beirut Kills 11 and Injures 30
description: A car bomb exploded in the Moslem section of the Lebanese capital today, killing 11 people, five of them policemen.

title: A LONGTIME CRITIC OF CON ED PUBLISHES BOOK OF HIS VIEWS
description: A retired engineer for New York City, long a critic of the Consolidated Edison Company, says the utility's electric rates - the nation's highest - could be reduced 10 percent by a combination of measures, including tax cuts Con Edison itself has urged.

title: HE MAKES THE HARD CHOICES AT LOCKHEED
description: FOR more than a decade, the giant Lockheed Corporation occupied a constellation of such flickering stars as the Penn Central and Chrysler. Long the nation's No.1 defense contractor, Lockheed was whipsawed by a cost overrun scandal in the production of a huge cargo aircraft and a resulting $200 million write-off in 1971.

title: CONCERT: ORCHESTRE NATIONAL
description: The Orchestre National de France, which is the Paris state radio orchestra, played at Avery Fisher Hall on Nov. 30 under Leonard Bernstein as part of its fourth American tour. Friday night the orchestra returned to New York, but this time its concert was in the supposedly more flattering acoustical environment of Carnegie Hall and it was playing under the baton of its music director since 1977, Lorin Maazel.

title: Camera; HANDHELD METERS ARE STILL NEEDED AT TIMES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Neubart is a freelance writer and photographer and an instructor in photography at Queens College,CUNY.

title: MATURE CARTWRIGHT REBOUNDS
description: After the Knicks had beaten the Chicago Bulls by 121-106 Friday night, Maurice Lucas was talking about the change in Bill Cartwright, the team's quiet and unemotional center.

title: NAME CHANGE: THE AFTEREFFECTS
description: DO you remember the last time you filled out an application for a job? You probably skipped over the easy questions, like your name and address and went on to ponder the more difficult ones like ''Describe your most notable contribution in your last job.'' But what happens when the easy questions, like your name, are no longer easy to answer?

title: No Headline
description: GRETZKY NOTCHES 3 GOALS, 4 ASSISTS

title: Seychelles Newspaper Asks Air Boycott on South Africa
description: A Government newspaper demanded today that the United States and its allies impose a civil aviation boycott against South Africa for releasing mercenaries who hijacked an Air India plane after an abortive coup.

title: Antiques; THE UPS AND DOWNS OF CHINESE CERAMICS
description: The Chinese art sales held last month in New York, Los Angeles, Honolulu and Hong Kong attracted large audiences and enthusiastic responses for some - but not all - types of wares. The market for Chinese ceramics, for example, has become extremely selective. Although the rarities still command strong bidding and high prices, the rest of the offerings fared less well.

title: FREE PERMITS BEING ISSUED BY NEW YORK
description: Because of New York's latest legislative disagreement, the state is currently giving out most required state permits free, at an estimated cost to taxpayers of more than $20,000 a month.

title: CREATING PALESTINE
description: Most Palestinians conceive of a Palestinian state as s overeign, democratic, and non-aligned. Such a state would have to bec reated in stages.

title: Dance Theater Opening Delayed to April 12
description: The opening of the Joyce Theater, the new dance theater that had been the Elgin Theater, has been postponed because of construction delays. The theater was to have opened Feb. 2.

title: 'I JUST KEPT MY HEAD DOWN'
description: USUALLY the players carry their coach off the football field after a stirring victory. But yesterday Ray Perkins, the Giants' coach, lifted little Joe Danelo onto his right shoulder and, with help from a few other players, carried the 166-pound field-goal kicker across midfield at Giants Stadium in celebrating their 13-10 triumph over the Dallas Cowboys that kept the Giants alive for a wild-card berth in the Super Bowl playoffs.

title: ...AND MOTHER MAKES PLEA FOR AID TO THE HANDICAPPED
description: IAM a 24-year-old mother of two boys and have been married for three years. My older boy, Peter, is 2 and the younger, Anthony, is 4 1/2 months. At birth, Peter was diagnosed as having brain damage. As a result he has cerebral palsy. We were told from the beginning that Peter would need therapy and would have to attend a special program.

title: THE GNOME WHO CAME TO DINNER
description: A FEW days before Christmas, Farmer Peavy was standing in front of his house, looking out over his fields. He was thinking about what a good year it had been, how he had sold his cauliflower for twice last year's price, and how his pumpkin and brussels sprout crops had earned him enough profit for a down payment on a new potato harvester.

title: New York's Council Schedules Activities
description: The following City Council activities scheduled for the week of Dec. 21 are open to the public: MONDAY: Dec. 21.

title: DURHAM, N.C., PROGRAMS AID HEART PATIENTS
description: Two or three mornings a week, Larry Rogers goes to the Duke University football stadium, warms up with calisthenics and then jogs around the track.

title: Red (Ink) Alarm
description: To the Business Editor

title: Theater in Review; 'GINGERBREAD LADY' LACKS SPICE
description: EAST FARMINGDALE A UDIENCES seldom see stage and screen versions of the same work in quick succession. In the case of Neil Simon's ''The Gingerbread Lady,'' which is playing at the Arena Players Repertory Theater through next Sunday, and its film adaptation, ''Only When I Laugh,'' being shown in five Nassau and four Suffolk theaters, the chance for comparison is as edifying as it is rare.

title: BEHIND THE HOPE CREEK PLANS
description: NEWARK THE Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which would like to have the state approve its plan to scrap its Hope Creek II nuclear power plant before the end of the year and thus give its stockholders a special benefit, may lose that chance.

title: LABOR GROUP IN JERSEY URGES BREAK WITH STATE DEMCRATS
description: The New Jersey State A.F.L.-C.I.O. has adopted a resolution urging all international and local unions to stop contributing money and supplying workers to the Democratic State Committee.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa-Beth Levine Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. William B. Levine of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa-Beth Levine, to Henry Burton Hawley, son of Marguerite Hawley of Marlboro, Mass., and the late Henry Edwin Hawley. An August wedding is planned.

title: Design; FRAMED WITH A POINT OF VIEW
