description: he dilemma is a fairly common one, at least as far as renovation projects are concerned: How can designers take advantage of the range of modern technologies and integrate them into an interior that has the more traditional look preferred by the clients?

title: Around the World; Thai Leader Shuffles Cabinet to Add Support
description: Acting to strengthen his administration, Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda shuffled 13 of the 40 portfolios tonight and dropped eight Cabinet members, the official radio reported.

title: ALEC GUINNESS DOES A SECOND TOUR OF DUTY AS LECARRE'S SPY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Billington is London theater critic for The Guardian. By MICHAEL BILLINGTON LONDON Lightning, they say, never strikes twice in the same place. It might therefore seem tempting Providence for the British Broadcasting Corporation (in partnership with Paramount Pictures) to be making a six-part, $3 million television film of John le Carre's best-seller ''Smiley's People.'' How, after all, do you follow up the success of the mini-series version of the same novelist's ''Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,'' which earned record viewing figures on American public television last year and which banished forever the idea of moles as short, soft, furry animals? But everyone working on ''Smiley's People'' is adamant about one thing: It is not a sequel. It is a fresh, independent creation.

title: CITIZEN COALITION FIGHTS NEWARK ON DEMOLITION MOTIVES BEHIND ARSON DISPUTED BY FIRE OFFICIALS
description: LAST YEAR, at the peak of the Christmas season, a small group of families living at 68 Montclair Avenue - - a largely abandoned block of apartments - received notice from the city that their building had been condemned. For weeks, they had been without heat and, when the cold burst the water pipes, the building was declared uninhabitable.

title: WESTERN ART AND EASTERN INFLUENCE
description: ''I ... made a new portrait of myself, as a study, in which I look like a Japanese.'' So Vincent van Gogh wrote to his sister about his ''Self-portrait'' of 1888, shown at right with what might have been the inspiration for it - ''The monk

title: Fatehpur Sikri
description: To the Editor:

title: Canonero Left An Impression
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: THE VERY YOUNG THOREAU
description: JOURNAL Volume I: 1837-1844. The Writings of Henry D. Thoreau. John C. Broderick, General Editor. Edited by Elizabeth Hall Witherell, William L. Howarth, Robert Sattelmeyer, Thomas Blanding. Illustrated. 702 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $22.50. By LEON EDEL

title: CALIFORNIA FACULTY IS VOTING ON UNIONIZATION
description: Faced with budget cutbacks that may reach $50 million for the 1982-83 academic year, professors and other workers on the 19 campuses of the California State University and College system have begun voting on whether they will join a union.

title: BOBOTIE: SOUTH AFRICA'S INDIGENOUS CUISINE
description: Food had almost everything to do with the fateful or, as many of their countrymen might now view it, baleful decision of white men to establish themselves in the city that is known today as Cape Town, at the tip of the African continent. In the beginning - that means 329 years ago - the Dutch East India Company was not at all interested in colonizing the Cape of Good Hope, only in setting up the 17th-century equivalent of a truck stop there for its Java-bound ships.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 9 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 14 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 3 19 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 4 4 6 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 5 5 33 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 6 8 5 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 7 6 7 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An Italian princess, in quest of romance, finds frustration, then fulfillment in America.

title: MEMORIES OF A BENCH-WARMER WHO DEVELOPED EGO
description: IWENT out for football my junior and senior year in high school, so I would have an extracurricular activity for my college applications. I was sure I'd make the team. No one was ever cut. I assumed the most impressive position to a college admissions officer would be quarterback - that required mental agility. So, for two years, I was listed on the charts as third-string quarterback, but in fact, the j.v. quarterback would have played before me.

title: HERZOG'S 'LAND'
description: ''Land of Silence and Darkness'' (''Land des Schweigens under der Dunkelheit'') was shown as part of the 1973 New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times on Oct. 9, 1973. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 57 Watts Street.

title: The Wardrobe Trunk Is Not a Steamer
description: Having owned and used a wardrobe trunk in my college years (the 1930's) and for some years afterward when moving from one job location to another, I was pleased to read Elaine Grohman's article (''50 Years of Memories in a Steamer Trunk'') on Nov. 22 about such a trunk, but distressed to find it called a ''steamer trunk.''

title: The Nation in Summary; Those Pesky Circumstances
description: ''This is not a case of a broken promise,'' President Reagan said last week, explaining why a recession has appeared instead of the resurgence the Republicans said would flow from their program. ''This is a case of circumstances beyond our control.''

title: BOOK BANNING IN AMERICA
description: A censorial spirit is at work in the United States, and for the past year or so it has focused more and more on books. Efforts to remove certain titles from school and public libraries, from paperback racks and bookstores, from the eyes of the adults as well as children, have increased measurably.

title: 'NEW DESPAIR' IS EMERGING AMONG POOR
description: THELMA Caplan knows a lot about money. She knows a lot of people who have none, and in 28 years of social work she has seen what was once a liveable income turn into a bare minimum. As director of personal referral services for the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, she tries to stretch dollars for an agency where everything is urgent and everyone has an immediate need. She has been ''in the business'' long enough to see the Y.M.C.A. (''once the housing option for young men with a job'') charging more than $12 a day - ''$300 a month for a room, an unaffordable sum for these men.'' And she has seen what she describes as ''a new desperation'' emerge.

title: EILEEN DENNIS IS BETROTHED
description: The engagement of Eileen Joan Dennis to Mikel Lynn Moore has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dennis of Yonkers, parents of the future bride. Mr. Moore is a son of Dona Moore and Rex Moore, both of Reno. A May 25 wedding is planned.

title: Quake in Turkey and Greece
description: A tremor shook much of Greece and parts of Turkey today, with an epicenter in the Aegean Sea a hundred miles northeast of Athens. Some damage to buildings was reported.

title: A MARKETER OF HIGH FASHION
description: Charles E. Gumprecht, a founding associate and managing director of Nettie Rosenstein Inc., once one of the leading clothing design establishments in the United States, died Friday after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Follow-Up on the News; Door Diplomacy
description: Not long after taking office this year, the Reagan Administration signaled a tougher stance in United States-Soviet Union affairs. One sign, the analysts said, was this: the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, no longer was allowed to enter the State Department through the basement garage; he had to use the front door, as all other diplomats did.

title: Trenton Times to Drop; Its Afternoon Editions
description: The Trenton Times, which has been fighting a losing circulation battle with the rival Trentonian, announced today that it was dropping its evening edition in favor of its recently begun morning edition.

title: RACKETEERING CASE INVOLVING CITY UNION OFFICIAL ENDS IN HUNG JURY
description: A mistrial has been declared in a labor-racketeering case in which Federal prosecutors accused a union official of accepting payoffs in return for promising labor peace at construction sites in New York City and New Jersey.

title: DOPE AND A KIDNAPPING
description: THE LAST SCAM By David Harris. 364 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $13.95. ROCKABYE By Laird Koenig. 246 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $11.95.

title: SILVER SCREEN IS GOLD FOR BERGEN YOUTH
description: OAKLAND ''IJUST want you guys to know that I'm not gonna take any crap from you.'' The line doesn't come from a James Cagney rerun. It's from the tearjerker of the movie season, ''On Golden Pond,'' and a cocky 13-year-old boy played by Doug McKeon says it to Henry Fonda and Katharine Hepburn, who are supposed to be looking after him.

title: CONCERT: THE BOSTON SYMPHONY
description: The Boston Symphony emerged as the hero in Strauss's ''Ein Heldenleben'' on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, but only after it had undergone the trial of accompanying the program's guest soloist, the pianist Martha Argerich, through a flaccid account of Schumann's Piano Concerto in A minor (Op. 54). The original order of the program had the Strauss first and the Schumann last; but in view of the lethargy that gripped Miss Argerich's performance, and the thoroughness with which the orchestra and Seiji Ozawa, the conductor, deferred to her, one was grateful the anticlimax was allowed to precede the climax.

title: Westchester Journal
description: MIRIAM JACKSON, a lifelong New Rochelle Democrat who is 70 years old, spent an exhausting week in Washington recently as a Westchester delegate to the White House Conference on the Aging. Her weariness was compounded, she indicated, by frustration.

title: ECONOMIC ILLS SAP TRUDEAU'S SUPPORT
description: At the end of a year of unusual political achievement, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal Government appears so out of favor with the public that it would probably be ousted in any election held now.

title: PISTONS ROUT KNICKS, 132-104
description: The Silverdome again proved to be a difficult place for the Knicks, who lost, 132-104, to the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: COUP ATTEMPT FAILS IN DOMINICA
description: A dozen gunmen stormed police headquarters and the main prison today in an unsuccessful coup attempt that left three people dead and nine wounded in this Caribbean island nation.

title: Fair Pay Would End Secretary Shortage
description: The article ''Many Offices but Too Few Secretaries'' (Nov. 15) was quite disturbing to many excellent secretaries who reside in Fairfield County. Conversely, many of them agree with the basic concepts set forth in the follow-up letter to the editor (''Temporary Secretary Finds Good Jobs Scarce,'' Nov. 29), but are seeking permanent rather than temporary assignments.

title: The Nation in Summary; First Act Ends Routinely After Remarkable Start
description: As House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. is fond of saying, ''All politics is local.'' And it was local politics, and particularly their re-election prospects, to which most members of Congress turned late last week, as they went home for Christmas.

title: MUSIC: CHAMBER OPERA
description: This weekend's double bill by the Chamber Opera Theatre of New York offers music of vastly varying quality; and at Friday evening's performance, each work received just about the treatment it deserved.

title: ANOTHER KIND OF SCIENTIFIC METHOD
description: THE NOBEL DUEL Two Scientists' 21-year Race to Win the World's Most Coveted Research Prize. By Nicholas Wade. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $15.95.

title: Practical Traveler; IS 'BUSINESS CLASS' FOR YOU?
description: T he advertisements are alluring: special check-in facilities at the airport and sometimes the use of the airline's clublike departure lounge, more space between rows of seats and fewer seats per row, free cocktails in flight and free wine with dinner, a wider choice of entrees, complimentary headsets for the movie or stereo, eyeshades to ease sleeping, disposable slippers and, on some carriers, hot towels and a free toilet kit.

title: OPERA: HANDEL'S 'ORLANDO' AT AMERICAN REPERTORY
description: One of Handel's greatest operas, ''Orlando,'' was given what is being called its American premiere here last night. That is noteworthy, as is the fact that it is being presented by Robert Brustein's American Repertory Theater, for 34 performances in repertory through March 14. And for a third claim to fame, the production is by the enfant terrible of New England opera and theater direction, Peter Sellars.

title: HARK! THE NEIGHBORS SING
description: STONY BROOK THE first year Bill and Geraldine Fuhrmann moved from their apartment in Flushing to their home in the close-knit community of Soundview, bordering Stony Brook Creek, they spontaneously decided to serenade their neighbors, along with a small group of friends, after Christmas Eve dinner. This Christmas Eve, 39 years later, the Fuhrmanns will continue their tradition of caroling for the residents of the 62 homes in their neighborhood.

title: GOVERNOR'S PANEL LOSES ITS FOCUS
description: For about a decade, politicians from the Northeast have been struggling to staunch the flow of jobs, investment, population and political power to the Southern and Southwestern states.

title: Stage View; FEIFFER'S 'GROWNUPS'- THE COMEDY VANISHES
description: In one sense, Jules Feiffer knows exactly what he is doing. He is doing his level, lethal best to drive Bob Dishy nuts - in the most loving, deeply caring fashion possible. In the first act of ''Grownups,'' at the Lyceum, Mr. Dishy is spending an afternoon (Sunday, I think) at his sister's house in New Rochelle. Their parents are also due, like payments on an old mortgage.

title: THERE IS MORE TO HUMPERDINCK THAN 'HANSEL AND GRETEL'
description: Engelbert Humperdinck's ''Hansel and Gretel,'' which returns to the repertory of the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow night, has absolutely nothing to do with Christmas, at least specifically. There is no symbolism about the birth of Christ, and it does not even take place in wintertime: the weather is warm enough for the two children to sleep in the woods all night without fear of frostbite.

title: Elizabeth Andrews Wed To Paul Herzog, Lawyer
description: Elizabeth Peterson Andrews, widow of Paul Shipman Andrews, was married yesterday to Paul M. Herzog, a former chairman of the National Labor Relations Board.

title: Antiques; A CHILD'S CHRISTMAS IN HARTFORD
description: HARTFORD IN years past, the staff at the Wadsworth Atheneum has recreated, as its bow to the season, a Victorian family holiday scene complete with full-size mama, papa and child mannequins busy in the parlor trimming a late-19th-century Christmas tree.

title: TRENTON MAN FIGHTS GHOST OF HIS PAST
description: TRENTON THE only present that Charles Moore and his family want for Christmas is the removal of a threat that he will be returned to a North Carolina road gang to finish serving a 10-year sentence for forgery.

title: Crafts
description: A large gas station once serviced neighborhood vehicles on the corner of Fifth Avenue and Third Street in Pelham. Today, the building still dominates the busy intersection, but it now houses the teaching facilities of the Pelham Art Center, a nonprofit, cultural center and, as one visitor has called it, "the brightest spot in Pelham."

title: ON FEDERALISM, THE WILL AND THE WAY ARE UNCLEAR
description: In the confusion over what President Reagan may or may not be doing to American federalism, one thing is clear. The reduction of grants and services from Washington is leaving the states to decide far more than in the recent past what kind of domestic government the nation will have. As was evident again last week, less clear is the capability and the will of the states to assume responsibilities that the Federal Government used to pre-empt.

title: Comment; TAKE IT WITH YOU
description: A S we near the end of our mortal travail, and usually long beforehand, we are reminded by many constituencies of the ancient adage that you can't take it with you.

title: Cost of Initial Fees At Learning Center
description: I would like to thank you for the item about the Reader's Digest Learning Center that appeared in the Westchester Journal on Nov. 1. The article states that ''initial fees for persons in the individual programs will normally be $150 ...'' We have had some callers inquiring for information for group classes with complaints that the ''initial fee'' for individual instruction is prohibitive.

title: M. J. Chiapetti Jr.  Weds Miss Halper
description: Lydia Roberta Halper and Mario James Chiappetti Jr. were married yesterday in the Thompson Memorial Chapel of Williams College in Williamstown, Mass. The Rev. Stephen Schmidt, a Protestant chaplain at Williams, performed the ceremony.

title: POLISH EMIGRES SAY PARTY STILL RULES
description: A former Polish journalist who is a visiting scholar at Harvard says the Soviet Union has not intervened openly in Poland so far because it recognizes that the situation is different from that in Hungary in 1956 and Czechoslovakia in 1968.

title: A SANTA FEARS HE'S A DYING MYTH
description: IN the corner of a Connecticut department store in the corner of a shopping mall I played Santa. A 23-year-old Santa Claus, the holiday spirit of Christmas wearing a black mustache that showed behind a synthetic white beard. A Santa wearing brown Red Wing boots covered only slightly by black plastic spats. The quintessential holiday figure who is always welcome, or at least I thought so until I met the kids and their parents.

title: The World in Summary; Israel Makes Golan Heights Part of Israel
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin did it again last week, producing a dramatic coup that pleased many (but by no means all) Israelis, infuriated Arabs and confounded the Reagan Administration. In a surprise six-hour power play in the Knesset, Mr. Begin forced through annexation of 500 square miles of strategic, formerly Syrian territory on the Golan Heights that Israel has occupied since 1967. Many of the Golan's 12,500 Arab Druse residents protested; 7,000 Israeli settlers were delighted. A poll showed Israelis as 70 percent in favor of eventual annexation, but 38 percent objected to the timing.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SOME DOMESTIC RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS IN POLAND
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency: Solidarity Leaders Detained 10 P.M. Friday

title: VIEW FROM THE TOP: KEEP SPORTS' PRIORITIES IN ORDER
description: The following is an address given by the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh, C.S.C., President, University of Notre Dame, at the 62d annual football banquet, Dec. 10, 1981.

title: WHY THE ROAD TO MOROCCO IS FULL OF AMERICAN V.I.P.'S
description: If the United States suddenly unleashes a cascade of Cabinet members on a friendly Arab nation, two possibilities suggest themselves. One is that the country is extremely important. The other is that its regime is in trouble.

title: Stamps; TRADITION RULES CHRISTMAS ISSUES
description: Christmas is one of the most traditional of holidays, and most countries have hewed to tradition in issuing their Christmas stamps. Religious paintings by old masters abound, but a number of countries have also taken different and innovative approaches in their philatelic observances to give a special touch to this year's issues.

title: Economic Affairs; THE BUSINESS LOBBY'S WRONG BUSINESS
description: ''M ORE than ever, managers of corporations are expected to serve the public interest as well as private profit.'' So begins the new pronouncement on corporate responsibility of the Business Roundtable. That this message was agreed to by the leading lobby for the country's largest corporations is important in and of itself. The question is just how, and how much, public service should be provided by the corporation.

title: Art; SOUND, A LINK TO PAST AND PRESENT
description: HARTFORD THE arts scene here is getting livelier, or so it seems to this itinerant observer. There are small enterprises that are becoming more conspicuous.

title: L.I.'S CROSS-COUNTRY TRAILS BECKON
description: THIS is the time of year when ''Think Snow'' bumper stickers emblazon many cars. On the Island, where a mere few inches will stop railroad and expressway traffic, keep thousands from work and close schools, shops and offices, who needs snow?

title: RELIGION AND CHINA MMAKE ACCOMMODATIONS
description: During the harsh years of China's Cultural Revolution, a family of Chinese Protestants in Shanghai set out for the old international church every Christmas Eve. It made no difference that the church had been shut down and turned into a warehouse. For an hour, despite the winter cold, the family mounted their silent vigil outside the church, before wending their way home through the dark streets of Shanghai.

title: Prospects
description: The 10 percent Solution?

title: The World in Summary; Making a Name For Violence
description: Their name - al Dawa - means ''the call'' and last week the Iraqi fundamentalist group, now based in Teheran, felt called to violence and intrigue in three Arab countries.

title: AN OPTION: NO-NONSENSE APPROACH
description: SETAUKET THE children in the sixth-grade traditional option class at the Minnesauke School are noticeably well behaved as they trace Egyptian motifs from filmstrips projected on the blackboard as part of a study of ancient Egypt. There is no socializing in class and no daydreaming, and all appear exceptionally neat: no sneakers or jeans, all shirts have collars, slacks have belts.

title: MISS AUSTIN SUBDUES MRS. LLOYD, 6-1, 6-2
description: For Tracy Austin, the challenges of tennis are welcome every day; for Chris Evert Lloyd, those challenges have become increasingly more difficult.

title: Turner Gives Up Pursuit
description: Ted Turner, the Atlanta Braves' owner, said today that he no longer expects Reggie Jackson, a free agent, to join the Braves.

title: IT'S A SMALL WORLD AT GREENWICH CHRISTMAS SHOW
description: GREENWICH ''I'VE always liked little things,'' said Martha Anne (Stubby) Crowe, president of the Greenwich Miniaturists, the group responsible for the Christmas in Miniature exhibition at the Bruce Museum here through Dec. 31.

title: TO THE COUNTY, HOLIDAY CHEER AS WE RECALL THE PASSING YEAR
description: Readers and friends, the moment's here At this, the nicest time of year, To wish to all within our county The finest of the season's bounty. For this brief time, let's bury gloom; Put by all thoughts of nuclear doom, Of cults, inflation, threats of war, Of jobs that shrink while prices soar, Of interest rates and sagging trade (Though not of those who need our aid); And while the holidays impart Their special glow to every heart, Let every grownup, girl and boy take A richly satisfying joy-break. Come, chill the bubbly, pull the cork; Toast legislative chief O'Rourke, Jon Fossel, Jennifer O'Neill, Lee Hanbury and A. Frank Reel. Join the revels bacchanalian With elder statesman Ed Michaelian, Pete Eschweiler, J. Robert Dolan, Bob Van Wagoner and George Bolen. A. Martinelli rates a share- The once and future Yonkers mayor. Call the Pipers, pour them their port, Including Scott, who runs the airport, And pour a bumper full of ale For Daniel Guido and Ken Hale. Steaming wassail bowl in beer's stead For the Pattersons of Merestead.

title: 'FLICKER OF HOPE'
description: To the Editor:

title: BOARD TO WEIGH A REFERENDUM ON GARBAGE PLANWHITE PLAINS THE
description: County Board of Legislators will begin consideration tomorrow of a proposed referendum that throws into question the establishment of a solid waste district and could force costly delays in building a garbage-to-electricity plant in Peekskill.

title: Copenhagen Demonstrators Protest Martial Law in Poland
description: Hundreds of Polish expatriates and other demonstrators gathered on Copenhagen's main square today to protest the imposition of martial law in Poland.

title: ONCE A DOT ON THE MAP WAS CORRECT
description: THE IMAGE OF THE CITY IN MODERN LITERATURE By Burton Pike. 168 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. $15. By LEO MARX

title: No Headline
description: DEPAUL IS DEFEATED BY U.C.L.A., 87-75

title: Raymond Palmer to Wed Joan Starkey
description: The engagement of Joan MacMurray Starkey to Raymond N. Palmer has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. George W.B. Starkey of Brookline, Mass., and Norfolk, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Raymond E. Palmer of Cody, Wyo., and the late Mr. Palmer.

title: Atlantic Salmon's New Voice
description: NORTH AMERICA'S two most prestigious nongovernmental organizations devoted to improving the lot of the Atlantic salmon have agreed to join hands.

title: Gardening; MISTLETOE: THE ROMANTIC PEST
description: FOR the romantically inclined, the reward for being caught beneath the mistletoe is probably sufficient unto itself. But the person with an inquisitive mind may wish to know more of this strange plant, to which mystical powers have been attributed for many centuries.

title: UNDERSTANDING A MISUNDERSTOOD MINORITY
description: ''ISN'T it nice that she knows her name and address.'' A salesperson in a store in Westfield made that comment to a woman as she and her daughter waited to be helped.

title: Eric Patel Weds Catherine Miller
description: Catherine Darling Miller, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Raymond Miller Jr. of Kennett Square, Pa., was married yesterday to Eric Patel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jamshed Patel of Summit, N.J.

title: IN TURKEY, HARD TIMES FOR U.S. CULTURAL UNIT
description: The Turkish American Association may become a victim of the United States Government's sweeping cuts in overseas cultural programs.

title: CAN BLACK COLLEGES SURVIVE?
description: Dena Kleiman is on the education staff of The Times. By Dena Kleiman Each November in Holly Springs, a sleepy Mississippi hamlet near the Tennessee border, as the last leaves fall off the old maple trees, students and teachers walk to a cemetery in the heart of town to honor the white missionary who founded their small, all-black school 115 years ago.

title: Leisure; A NEW WAVE FOR THE LITTLEST EVERGREENS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lois Himes is a writer and lecturer on gardening. By LOIS B. HIMES

title: Around the World; Zimbabwean Police Seek Clues to Bombing
description: Police forensic experts examined the rubble of the Salisbury headquarters of Zimbabwe's governing party today for clues to who planted a bomb that killed 6 people and wounded 85 Friday.

title: A CON EDISON NUCLEAR PLANT IS OPERATING 11 DAYS A MONTH
description: In a year of frequent and lengthy shutdowns, the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant is on its way to doubling the cost of the electricity it produces.

title: HUNT SNARES A PASS AT THE RIGHT TIME
description: His linebacker coach calls him ''Stone Hands.'' In training camp, when trying to make the Giants as a ninth-round draft choice this summer, he never did seem able to hang on to the ball. And it wasn't until overtime of the Giants' 16th and last regular-season game that Byron Hunt got his hands on the ball and the ball finally stuck.

title: Helen DuBose Bride of G. A. de Rohan
description: At Trinity Presbyterian Church in Atlanta yesterday, Helen Louise DuBose and Geoffrey Alexander de Rohan, graduates of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, were married by the Rev. Allison Williams. The Rev. John Fallon, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted.

title: MUSIC: MONTSERRAT CABALLE AND JOSE CARRERAS SING DUETS
description: A singer gets more credit for owning a great voice than a fiddler does for owning a Stradivarius - as it should be. And Wednesday night in Avery Fisher Hall, the audience gave Montserrat Caballe and Jose Carreras in their joint recital the sort of plaudits that great voices can inspire.

title: A Correction
description: Priscilla Derven's name was misrepresented in a Dec. 6 article about an art show at the Jersey City Museum.

title: Around the Nation; Tugboats Sink in Gulf And Mississippi Area
description: Two tugboats sank in separate incidents today, one in a collision in icy waters at the mouth of the Mississippi and the other in 20-foot seas in the Gulf of Mexico. Three men were missing from a tug involved in the river collision near here.

title: POLAND: A CRISIS THAT NEED NOT HAVE HAPPENED
description: To the Editor:

title: TOM WOLFE: THE GREAT GADFLY
description: Tony Schwartz is a reporter for The New York Times. By Tony Schwartz

title: Heddi Siebel Wed To John K. Felix
description: Heddi Vaughan Siebel, daughter of Frederick Siebel of Rye, N.Y., and Winifred Andrade of Greenbrae, Calif., was married yesterday to John Kramer Felix, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Felix of Rockville Centre, L.I. Judge William Johnston of Harrison, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's father and stepmother.

title: Bridge; DEFENSIVE ACTION
description: In one important respect, tournament bridge-players are far worse off than their chess counterparts. If two chess opponents have ratings of, say, 2100, they can be sure that they will be evenly matched; if one has a rating 200 points above the other, he will be strongly favored to win.

title: LOUGHLIN PAIR TAKE 1,000,600
description: Ken Wilson and Alfonso Averhart were each $2 richer after the 28th annual Bishop Loughlin track and field games at the 102d Engineers Armory yesterday.

title: THOSE WERE THE DAYS
description: DREW MIDDLETON is the military correspondent of The New York Times. By DREW MIDDLETON

title: Music; A JOLLY GOOD TIME FOR CONCERTS, AND A NUMBER ARE FREE
description: THE gift of music is brightening this final Sunday before Christmas and Hanukkah, so even if you've spent your last dime shopping, you can still ring in the holiday season at a number of free concerts around the county.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Cardinal's Letter On Nuclear Arms Gets Fast Reply
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, the New York Archbishop and military vicar for American Roman Catholics, gave qualified approval last week to the strategy of nuclear deterrence, ''if a nation is sincerely trying to come up with a rational alternative.'' But the protest from Catholic clergy and laymen in New York that immediately followed reaffirmed the church's increasing concern over the nuclear arms buildup.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We beg you, in God's name, not to raise a hand full of hate against one another. Keep calm, do not cause our country to fall into a greater misfortune.'' - Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland. (22:3.)

title: AN ISRAELI OFFICIAL HARSHLY CRITICIZES U.S. FOR SANCTIONS
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said today that the Reagan Administration's suspension of a strategic cooperation accord with Israel undermined credibility in American international agreements and was an attempt to damage Israeli security. His statement was the harshest criticism of the United States by any high Israeli official in recent memory.

title: POACHING BY ASIAN REFUGEES FRUSTRATES UTAH AUTHORITIES
description: Utah officials say Indochinese refugees are poaching everything from porcupines to woodpeckers, and exasperated game wardens are stumped on how to convince them they are doing wrong.

title: Head of Zambia's Air Force Guilty of Illegal Importation
description: The suspended commander of the Zambian Air Force, Maj. Gen. Christopher Kabwe, has been convicted along with an air force major and a Lusaka businessman of offenses involving the illegal importation of motor vehicles last year, the official Zambian press agency said today.

title: Michael Mazzapelle to Wed Marie Baker on Feb. 14
description: Announcement has been made by Claire M. Baker of Massapequa, L.I., of the engagement of her daughter, Marie Baker, to Michael Mazzapelle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vito Mazzapelle of Lindenhurst, L.I. The wedding is planned for Feb. 14.

title: The Nation in Summary; Mixed Signals On Civil Rights
description: Since last November, civil rights advocates concerned over the Administration's intentions have been waiting for the other shoe to drop. Last week, they were left still waiting.

title: ARMS-FREEZE VOTES LIFT HOPES IN STATE
description: THE overwhelming success in two Connecticut towns recently of a resolution that asks members of the state's Congressional delegation to propose that United States and Soviet Union freeze development of nuclear weapons and begin negotiations on an arms moritorium has buoyed hopes among its proponents that the fledgling movement will expand rapidly in the coming year.

title: SHOPPERS LAY CARD AND GIFT CUTBACK TO 20
description: POSTAGE STAMP AND INFLATION By GLADWIN HILL

title: MERCHANTS RINGING UP A JOLLY SEASON
description: THIS has turned out to be a season of unexpectedly good cheer for many of the Island's malls and merchants, who say they are defying forecasts of a Christmas season of lackluster sales and sharply lower earnings.

title: ST. JOHN'S CONQUERS FORDHAM
description: Coach Tom Penders of Fordham was not happy about having to play St. John's last night, only 21 days after the Redmen had trounced his Rams by 20 points. But a schedule is a schedule and a team has to meet its commitments, Penders agreed.

title: FICTIONS OF RACE
description: A SEPARATE DEVELOPMENT By Christopher Hope. 199 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $10.95. BETWEEN TWO WORLDS By Simone Schwarz-Bart. Translated by Barbara Bray. 270 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.

title: A WEEK OF TRAUMA FOR AREA'S POLES
description: FOR Zofia Sklepinski of New Britain, last week was a time of apprehension, frustration and some anger. On Saturday night, the night before Polish Communist officials imposed nationwide martial law in a crackdown on the Solidarity movement, her husband, Jan, loaded with Christmas presents for his mother and other relatives, flew to Warsaw.

title: Connecticut Housing; BOROUGHS: GOVERNMENT FOR THE FEW
description: RESIDENTS of Georgetown, a small communty at the Wilton-Redding border, as well as residents of a three-block area in Stamford that is on the Greenwich border, recently drew attention to their respective frustrations with government by talking aloud about the possibility of secession.

title: PETER HALL STAGES A LONDON 'ORESTEIA'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale reports regularly for The Times on culture in London. By BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE LONDON When Peter Hall, director of Britain's National Theatre, first glimpsed its new Olivier auditorium, which is designed to resemble an ancient Greek amphitheater, an idea long cooking in his head came bursting to the surface. At last he would have the opportunity to stage ''The Oresteia,'' and in a space not dissimilar to the one Aeschylus actually used when the trilogy won him the annual Dionysian playwriting competition back in March 458 B.C.

title: HEAT COMPLAINTS DOWN DESPITE A NUMBING DAY
description: It could have been conscientious landlords supplying heat. Or it could have been Christmas shoppers out and about, oblivious to the growing chill within their dwellings.

title: No Headline
description: Missouri Winner, 19-17

title: Whose Security?
description: To the Business Editor: I was dismayed by Barbara Daniel's letter ''Pro Bergmann'' (Nov. 29), responding to ''Relax, Social Security Is Doing Its Job'' (Nov. 15). Anyone who really believes that an individual's current payments into the Social Security system provide even a modicum of guarantee that, upon retirement, corresponding benefits will be returned to them does not understand the financial plight of the system.

title: KNEELING BUSES THAT REFUSE TO KNEEL
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GRAVEST LOSS
description: a1PARIS, Dec. 20 - Suppression of the Polish workers' attempt to force reform on a bankrupt regime has profound meanings for Communism everywhere, as Enrico Berlinguer said last week.

title: EX-G.I.'S, IN HANOI, ARE HOPEFUL ON TALKS
description: After six hours of talks with Hanoi officials, four American veterans of the Vietnam War expressed hope today that the emotional issue of the 2,500 United States servicemen still missing in Southeast Asia could be resolved in the near future.

title: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: In a National Football League game, a team scores a touchdown and takes a 23-20 lead with 12 seconds remaining. Instead of attempting the point after touchdown, the holder for the place-kick, after the ball is snapped to him, runs backward until he reaches his own end zone. It is a safety, but he has used up the 12 seconds and his team is still ahead, 23-22. Is this legal and is the game over? What would happen if the offensive team, in a field-goal situation at its opponent's 25-yard line, used up the 12 seconds in similar fashion?

title: Pope Cites Importance Of Poland's Problems
description: Pope John Paul II today expressed gratitude that the problems of Poland were being recognized as ''important to all nations and all societies, to Europe and the contemporary world.''

title: DEPAUL'S 'POISE' FALTERS
description: Kenny Fields led a second-half surge that lifted U.C.L.A. to a 87-75 victory over previously unbeaten De Paul Saturday night, and Coach Ray Meyer of the Blue Demons had no excuses.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES MAY DROP FURTHER
description: Short-term interest rates may decline early next year for seasonal reasons, many analysts say, but beyond then, their forecasts are more uncertain. More accurate forecasts will not be forthcoming until more is known about the condition of the economy and the outcome of this week's meeting of monetary policy makers at the Federal Reserve, according to analysts.

title: Farm Debts Are High
description: The Agriculture Department said Friday that farmers' debts in relation to assets were at a 10-year high.

title: THE AFGHAN RULERS: FIERCELY TRADITIONAL TRIBES
description: In mid-November, in a desert hamlet just across the border in Pakistan, Habibullah Karzai, a clean-shaven man who once represented Afghanistan at the United Nations, explained how the fighting in his country had turned him and almost every other Afghan back into tribal people.

title: Jim Wilson HANUKKAH FESTIVAL BEGINS
description: Rabbi Shmuel M. Butman, director of the Lubavitch Youth Organization, and Robert Abrams, the New York State Attorney General, lighting the 30-foot-tall menorah at Grand Army Plaza in Manhattan last night to mark the beginning of the eight-day Jewish festival.

title: WHEN A BARREL OF OIL IS WORTH UNDER $5
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOTE, CONE NAMED FOR SUNKIST PRODUCTS
description: Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, has been named agency for the fruit juice and confectionary products that will be marketed under the name Sunkist brand name by Thomas A. Lipton Inc.

title: DANCE: 'DAY TWO,' A NEW CREATION BY PILOBOLUS
description: USUALLY, the Pilobolus Dance Theater, which opened last night at the ANTA Theater, does not take bows after each piece. But after their newest work, ''Day Two,'' the dancers come up with the curtain call to end all curtain calls by sliding across the stage on a surface strip suddenly filled with water.

title: ISRAELI ACTS CITED IN GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: The Israelis have stepped up their patrols, increased reconnaissance flights and set up a new military camp at the base of the Golan Heights, according to Syrian security sources here.

title: 32 AMERICAN STUDENTS NAMED RHODES SCHOLARSHIP WINNERS
description: Rhodes Scholarships were awarded Saturday to 32 American college students, including an 18-year-old concert pianist from Oklahoma and a starting guard on the Army football team, for two years of advanced studies at Oxford University in Britain beginning next fall.

title: Soup Kitchen Revival Is Reportedly Considered
description: As the number of unemployed workers reaches its highest total in 41 years, the Salvation Army is preparing to revive the ''soup kitchen'' program it ran during the Depression, the newspaper The Bulletin reported today.

title: New Zealand Fails To Seal Cup Berth
description: New Zealand defeated Saudi Arabia, 5-0, in a World Cup Soccer tournament Saturday in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, but was unable to score sufficient points to be guaranteed a berth in the World Cup finals. New Zealand is tied with China in points, and the two will play at a date still undetermined to decide which will get the final spot.

title: MARY RANSDELL IS MARRIED
description: Mary Louise Ransdell, fashion director of Town & Country magazine, was married yesterday to Thomas E. Norton, a private art consultant and former senior vice president of Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Anglican Prelate To Make a Visit to China
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, leader of the world's Anglicans, will pay an unofficial three-day visit to China next month for private talks with Chinese church leaders, his office announced today.

title: Prolonged Rain in France Kills Livestock and Destroys Crops
description: Eight days of heavy rain have caused flooding across France, killing thousands of farm animals and destroying millions of dollars worth of crops and agricultural equipment, officials said today.

title: MUSIC: PRIMAVERA QUARTET INTRODUCES A SECOND VIOLINIST
description: THE Primavera String Quartet is a quartet with a gimmick, which is that it consists of four very attractive young women. It seems safe to say that, without courting charges of sexism, because the quartet itself in its publicity photos and its carefully color-coordinated stage dress is not shy about stressing it.

title: Bridge: Greenberg Team Holding Slender Lead in Regionals
description: Going into the last 14 deals of the knockout team final at the Winter Regional Championships last night at the New York Hilton Hotel, a sextet headed by Alan Greenberg held a slender lead over John Lowenthal's team.

title: RUSSIANS DENNY THE USE OF ANTENNAS FOR SPYING
description: The Soviet Embassy has denied that rooftop antennas on its 16th Street chancery are used for intelligencegathering. The embassy says that the purpose of the equipment is to maintain radio communication with Moscow.

title: CHARGES AGAINST DONOVAN AROSE FROM ROUTINE AUDIT 5 YEARS AGO
description: The Federal racketeering investigation that unearthed recent charges against Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan began almost five years ago with a routine tax audit of a construction concern and led, authorities say, to a picture of how organized crime can control a union.

title: JETS REACH PLAYOFFS AND BRING GIANTS ALONG
description: Uniting the followers of New York's pro football teams for one glorious Sunday, the Jets swept themselves and the Giants into the playoffs yesterday with a crushing 28-3 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: AS OTHERS SEEK TO EXPLOIT ANTARCTIC, U.S. TAKES THE SCIENTIFIC APPROACH
description: McMURDO STATION, Antarctica -Every so often on these bright summer days, a small dynamite explosion shakes the frozen Ross Sea, sending shock waves rippling across the shimmering ice of McMurdo Sound. The waves are refracted from the earth's crust deep below the sound and are picked up by receivers set up at intervals along the ice by Lyle D. McGinnis, a geophysicist from Northern Illinois University. The goal, said Dr. McGinnis, is to recreate the ''tectonic history'' - the story of the earth's crust and the forces that created it - of this region and its nearby mountains.

title: WHAT I SAID WAS...
description: To the Editor:

title: SAN JOSE HOPES TO EASE TRAFFIC CRUSH BY BUILDING A 20-MILE STREETCAR ROUTE
description: This city, which became a national symbol of the excesses of uncontrolled urban growth in the 1960's and 1970's, has embarked on an attempt to ameliorate some of the sins of its past with an old fashioned solution: a streetcar line.

title: POLISH REFUGEES WAIT AND WATCH
description: Polish refugees gathered at the Church of the Resurrection today to receive news of their homeland, spiritual comfort and donations of food and warm clothing.

title: ZEMP'S NEW NAME; NESTLES'S NEW PRODUCT
description: Other bits and pieces:

title: JOSEPH ZARETZKI, FORMER ALBANY LEADER, DIES
description: Joseph Zaretzki, a Democratic leader in the New York State Senate who represented the Washington Heights area of Manhattan for nearly three decades, died yesterday after a long illness at Beth Abraham Hospital in the Bronx.

title: FEDERAL CUTS CITED IN GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST
description: With a contribution of $200 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Mr. and Mrs. James F. Bell of Darien, Conn., wrote: ''We are fortunate that we are able to increase our donation at a time when the need is greater than ever.'' The Bells are among many contributors to the 70th annual Neediest Cases Fund drive who are responding to what they believe are problems resulting from rising unemployment, an economic recession and reduced Government assistance to the poor.

title: JET AND GIANT FANS UNITE FOR A DAY OF CHEER
description: It was a day for detente, when Jet fans and Giant fans embraced in a common cause, a day for ''Klecko's Klan'' and for ''Lyons Looneys'' and for sack-pack fan clubs.

title: CHRISTMAS SALES PROVE TO BE ERRATIC
description: The last weekend before Christmas - traditionally the busiest period on the retail calendar - drew hordes of shoppers but generated spotty sales, retailers in the New York area conceded yesterday.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Taiwanese Wins
description: Hsu Sheng-san, a veteran pro from Taiwan, shot a four-under-par 68 today for a two-over 290 to win the Taiwan Professional Golfers' Association Open championship at the 7,152-yard Tamsui Golf Course.

title: Lakers Triumph
description: Jamaal Wilkes scored 36 points, a career regular-season high for him, to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 112-94 victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: PRISON REFORMS ORDERED AFTER RIOT COME GRUDGINGLY IN NEW MEXICO
description: In nearly two years since the most savage prison riot in American history, improvements in conditions and security at the state penitentiary here have reportedly been gained grudgingly, if at all.

title: No Headline
description: GRETZKY GETS 2 BUT OIILERS LOSE

title: No Headline
description: U.S. STOPS PROVIDING CENSUS DATA USED BY GENEALOGISTS TO LIBRARIES

title: THE MAIN CAUSE OF THE RECESSION
description: The economy is in recession. The gross national p roduct has fallen in the last two quarters, and is falling faster n ow. Most economic analysts place the blame on cutbacks in auto salesa nd housing starts. Yet, in the first two quarters of recession, e xpenditures for personal consumption rose, even after adjusting for i nflation. Private domestic investment is also up, if only because i t is reflected in inventories that are piling up. Government e xpenditures dipped just a bit. So what is the main cause of the r ecession?

title: Egyptian Official Says 2,500 More Are Detained
description: Interior Minister Mohammed Nabawi Ismail of Egypt said today that the Government had detained 2,500 people in a crackdown on extremists following the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat in October.

title: Canada Signs Nuclear Pact
description: Canada and the European Economic Community have signed a long-term agreement that governs Common Market purchases of nuclear fuel.

title: Shirley Lauro Wins Hull-Warriner Award
description: Shirley Lauro has been chosen as the 1981 recipient of the Elizabeth Hull-Kate Warriner Award, given annually by the Dramatists Guild Council for a play that ''deals with controversial subjects involving the fields of political, religious or social mores of the time.''

title: FUMBLE PUTS BUCS IN PLAYOFFS, LIONS OUT
description: A fumble had a lot to do with deciding first place in the National Football Conference's Central Division yesterday and a place in the playoffs for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers rather than the Detroit Lions.

title: OREGON STATE STOPS LOUISVILLE
description: Oregon State overcame a 14-point deficit in the second half to defeat previously unbeaten Louisville, 62-56, today in the final of the Suntory Ball basketball tournament.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS+ DISENCHANTED DIPLOMAT
description: When Romuald Spasowski stepped up to the State Department microphones today, he walked away from perhaps the most distinguished diplomatic career in postwar Poland. Since 1955, when he arrived as the youngest foreign ambassador in Washington for his first tour here, he has stood at the summit of his country's foreign service. While that fact alone gave added weight to the drama of the moment, Mr. Spasowski's family background, which is widely known in Poland, undoubtedly made his defection even more dramatic for many of his countrymen.

title: 'WAR AGAINST GOD'
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 Missing In High Seas Off Southwest England
description: Sixteen people were missing today after a British coaster smashed onto rocks off England's southwest coast and a lifeboat sank trying to rescue its crew members, Coast Guard officials said.

title: The Talk of Pittsburgh
description: This brawny, rebuilding city, where the most common sound of recent years has been the clang of beams on girders for new office towers, is getting both good news and bad news these days, one of its leaders says.

title: MISS AUSTIN TAKES FINAL, CLAIMS NO. 1
description: There were aces, forehand volley winners and smashes, and this time Tracy Austin was hitting them instead of being on the receiving end.

title: RELIEF SHIPMENTS CONTINUE, U.S. GROUPS SAY
description: American relief agencies said last week that they were continuing most shipments to Poland, but officials of some organizations expressed concern about monitoring the distribution of food, clothing and medical supplies there.

title: Justice Burger's Bail Bill
description: ''It ought to be passed. The Chief Justice is pushing for it.'' With those words, Chairman Strom Thurmond recently rallied his Senate Judiciary Committee to stop delaying a bill called ''Bail Reform Act Amendments.'' Only one senator dissented as the committee voted to scrap the 1966 Bail Reform Act and provide for preventive detention - denying release on bail to accused persons a court finds dangerous.

title: FOUNDER OF FOXHOLLOW SCHOOL
description: Aileen M. Farrell, founder of the now-defunct Foxhollow School and principal the for 40 years, died yesterday evening at her home in Lenox, Mass. She was 83 years old.

title: Zimbabwe Leader Honored
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe today became an honorary citizen of Mozambique, the country which was a base for his guerrillas during the war that led to Zimbabwe's independence in April, 1980.

title: The U.N. Today; Dec. 21, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Conferences - 3 P.M.

title: KLECKO LAUDED BY COACH
description: Marty Lyons had something tangible to show for the Jets' victory yesterday - he wore a Green Bay T-shirt in the locker room. Like an ancient warrior who would carry home the shield of his defeated foe, Lyons said he had made a deal with the Packers' Rich Wingo, his former teammate at Alabama, that the loser would give up a team T-shirt to the winner.

title: HANDLING THE SANTA CLAUS DECEPTION ,
description: It is the little white lie that goes with dreams of a white Christmas: the great Santa Claus deception. How should parents handle their uneasiness about perpetuating this customary Christmas fib? What do they say when children become skeptical? Can this Yuletide fabrication affect a child's development?

title: NEW MUSIC: LARRY AUSTIN
description: LARRY AUSTIN might be called a born-again Texas composer. His rebirth, in his case, means that although he was born and educated in Texas, he won his reputation as a Cageian conceptual avant-gardist in the San Francisco area, where he lived and taught from 1955 to 1972. Then, after six years in Florida, he returned to his alma mater, North Texas State University. There he has apparently been busy both as a composer and as an organizer and catalyst of the local new-music scene - just as he was in San Francisco.

title: Arrest Made Near Mayor
description: A man whose briefcase contained a loaded .32-caliber revolver and news clippings about Mayor Jane M. Byrne of Chicago and the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt was arrested Saturday just before an appearance by the Mayor, the police said. The man, Frederic T. Mack, 58 years old, a self-employed tailor, was released on $100 cash bond.

title: TAYLOR: IN BACK OF THE SURPRISE
description: ''IF it wiggles, I'll hit it,'' Beasley Reece, the senior citizen of the Giants' defensive backfield, had said early in the week before Saturday's must-win game against the Dallas Cowboys. Now, he had come out on the field for the pregame warmups and a few of the Cowboys sauntered over to their former teammate.

title: STUDENTS RIDE TRAIN 175 HOME FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: Train 175 was about 15 minutes out of the New London, Conn., station when, between two cars, Ethan Eichrodt, a Boston University psychology major with a can of beer in one hand, met Seaman Charles Custer, a student at the United States Navy Submarine School at New London, who also had a beer in hand.

title: AT ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S, A TIME TO HEAL
description: In the parish hall of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue, where many a rancorous debate has been held recently over plans to build a 59-story office tower on the site, churchgoers sipped coffee yesterday after the 11 A.M. service and talked hopefully of reconciliation.

title: Not a Peep on Chile
description: Chile's military chiefs have evidently decided that the Reagan Administration will cause them no trouble on human rights. On Dec. 10, which Mr. Reagan had just joined in proclaiming as Human Rights Day, they arrested at least seven dissidents, including three officers of Chile's Human Rights Commission.

title: PLAN BY REAGAN ON ELDERLY STIRS CONCERN IN STATE
description: State officials and nursing home associations reacted with dismay and bafflement yesterday to the Reagan Administration's proposals to relax or repeal many Federal regulations affecting the treatment of patients in long-term care facilities.

title: Cold Moves Into Florida, Damaging Some Fruit
description: By United Press International Arctic cold moved in from the Great Lakes to southern Florida yesterday, @maging some citrus. Heavy rains flooded towns in the mid-Pacific Coast, washed out roads and forced more than 1,000 people to higher ground.

title: HARVARD TO AID IN DEVELOPING PAKISTANI TEACHING HOSPITAL
description: Harvard University agreed last week to aid in planning and developing a teaching hospital under construction in Karachi, Pakistan.

title: Wading for Donations Is Not the United Way
description: Travelers toss from $40 to $50 in coins every month into an airport fountain here, and United Way could have the cash if its workers would collect it.

title: SECURITY SERVICES DISARMING GUARDS
description: While recent studies show Americans continuing their accumulation and use of firearms, the trend is being reversed in a surprising but important sector: the growing private security industry, which now has far more guards on duty than all of the nation's police departments combined.

title: AND NOW THE JOKERS ARE THE WILD CARDS
description: UP in the Shea Stadium stands behind the end zone, a young man in a green and white jersey was shouting, ''The Jets are in the playoffs,'' and next to him a teen-ager in a blue and red stocking cap was yelling, ''The Giants are in the playoffs.'' For two decades, the Jets and the Giants and all their followers have been rivals. But yesterday the twain met.

title: OUTDOORS: GUIDED TO THE WATERFOWL
description: winged teal, streaked by shortly after dawn, I was not ready for it, being engaged in lighting my pipe. ''Shoot,'' our guide, Bob Hester, had said, and the others with us, Jerome Robinson, of Canaan, N.H., and Joel Arrington, of Raleigh, N.C., could not respond because the bird was off my end of the blind.

title: No Energy Department - or Policy
description: The five-year-old Department of Energy must go, President Reagan says, because it stands for ''excessive regulation.'' If Congress agrees, he will parcel out most of Energy's budget and responsibilities to Commerce, sending bits and pieces to Interior, Justice and Agriculture.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRIME MINISTER BEGIN'S STATEMENT TO THE U.S. ENVOY TO ISRAEL
description: Following is a transcript of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's statement to the United States Ambassador, Samuel W. Lewis, as read today by Cabinet Secretary Aryeh Naor and translated from the Hebrew by The New York Times

title: ROSANNA WARREN WED TO STEPHEN SCULLY
description: Rosanna Warren, daughter of Robert Penn Warren and Eleanor Clark, the authors, was married yesterday to Stephen Scully, son of Vincent Scully Jr. of Branford, Conn., John Trumbull Professor of the History of Art at Yale University, and Susannah (Nancy) Keith Scully of Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Andrea Cardon Is Married to Myron Kove, Lawyer
description: Andrea Theodore Cardon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Theodore, was married yesterday to Myron Kove, son of Mrs. Samuel A. Kove of Belle Harbor, Queens, and the late Mr. Kove. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in the chapel of Temple Emanu-El, of which the bride's mother is a vice president.

title: CONCERT: CLEVELAND QUARTET PLUS CLARINETIST
description: FOR a moment it looked as if the concert grand on the stage was, as Walter Mitty might have said, actually a small red herring. It sat there, along with 100 or so members of the audience, waiting for the Cleveland Quartet and David Singer, clarinetist, to appear for a program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday night that listed two works calling for piano, but no pianist.

title: MARKET PLACE
description: In a major marketing disaster, American manufacturers have lost their primacy in semiconductors. Two years ago, Japanese manufacturers brought out new random access memory - RAM - devices twice as powerful as the ones then in use and have since captured the bulk of the market.

title: Colts Win Battle of Losers
description: Football coaches often say the first and last games of the season are two keys to a successful year. The Baltimore Colts defeated the New England Patriots, 29-28, in the opener and defeated them, 23-21, today in the final game, but no one was saying the Colts had a successful year.

title: MAURICE L. HUGGINS
description: Maurice L. Huggins, a structural chemist, died Thursday of heart failure at the age of 84, his family said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What kind of talk is this, punishing Israel? Are we a vassal state of yours? Are we a banana republic? Are we 14-year-olds who, if we misbehave, we get our wrists slapped?'' - Prime Minister Menachem Begin. (A20:2.)

title: POLL FINDS A MIXTURE OF PRIDE AND WORRY FOR CITY'S FUTURE
description: A portrait of a New York City full of contradictions - of pride amid pervasive concern over crime, of slightly improved feelings about city life despite decaying confidence in its services -has emerged from a new survey of New York City residents. The survey found, however, that New Yorkers' hope for their city's long-term future has dimmed markedly over the last four years. While more than three-quarters of those interviewed said they were proud to be New Yorkers, nearly half said they would prefer to be living somewhere else four years from now.

title: DON'T MAKE QUOTAS OUT OF GOALS
description: To the Editor:

title: JETS AND GIANTS MAKE PRO FOOTBALL PLAYOFFS
description: For the first time, the Jets and the Giants have qualified for the Super Bowl playoffs in the same season. The two teams earned wild-card berths in the playoffs as a result of the Jets' 28-3 victory over the Green Bay Packers yesterday at Shea Stadium and the Giants' dramatic 13-10 defeat of the Dallas Cowboys in overtime Saturday at Giants Stadium.

title: Betty Carter Is Singing In New Mood at Club
description: The progress of Betty Carter's career can be seen as a series of 10-year changes. She spent the 50's discovering herself as a jazz singer, finding the singular qualities that represented her personal vocal jazz style.

title: CAVALIERS' OWNER KEEPS PROMOTING
description: Ted Stepien, the owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, is also in the advertising business. Yesterday he was still promoting a team with the worst record in the National Basketball Association (5-20), a team that he said would cost $6.5 million to operate this season. That figure, he said, is among the highest in the league.

title: VANITY, THY NAME IS MINDLESS U.S.A. BOOSTERISM
description: At the beginning of this holiday season, a radio station here tried to list all of the things for which Americans should be thankful. The list was pretty much what can be expected during these weeks of excessive nostalgia and self-satisfaction.

title: NEW TRIAL IS SOUGHT IN ATTACK
description: Attorneys for Eugene Tafoya, a former Green Beret convicted of assaulting a Libyan student, have filed a motion for a new trial, contending the judge committed 52 errors in their client's initial trial.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * Barclay Inter-Continental Hotel New York to Smith/Greenland Inc. * Rockford Furniture Stores to Venet Advertising, New Jersey.

title: U.S. WARNS IT WILL HOLD MOSCOW RESPONSIBLE FOR ANY 'EXCESSES' IN POLAND
description: The United States said today that it would hold the Soviet Union - as well as the Polish military Government - responsible for any ''excesses'' that develop as the result of the martial-law crackdown.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: The Coast Guard suspended a search today for two crewmen whose tugboat sank in the Mississippi River, but the authorities planned to use a specially equipped boat to find the wreckage on Monday.

title: The Economy
description: Aides to President Reagan are seeking $45 billion in new taxes over the next two fiscal years. The request is based on new economic projections and will be presented to the President for his approval in midweek. Unlike past forecasts, the new figures have the support of the Government's top economic officials. (Page A1.)

title: G.M. Cuts Benefits Broadly
description: The General Motors Corporation announced that it had cut vacation, cost of living allowances and other benefits for 138,000 salaried employees in the United States.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, DECEMBER 21, 1981
description: International Prime Minister Menachem Begin charged the Reagan Administration with anti-Semitism and with treating Israel like a ''vassal state.'' His statement came in response to the Administration's indefinite suspension of further discussion on a strategic accord with Israel because of its annexation of the Golan Heights. (Page A1, Column 6.) Despite Israel's bitter reaction to Washington's suspension of further talks on carrying out the American-Israeli agreement, the Reagan Administration said it hoped that the accord would not be canceled. Prime Minister Begin responded to the suspension in terms that no State Department official could ever remember coming from an ally. (A1:4-5.)

title: ALL SMILES AT BUSINESS MAGAZINES
description: Despite the dim economic outlook, the magazines that cover the business scene are doing surprisingly well. Most will be up in advertising revenues from last year. Many are also up in advertising pages.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 5-3, ON 5 IN FINAL PERIOD
description: After going scoreless for the first 44 1/2 minutes tonight, the Islanders scored five times in the third period to beat the Red Wings, 5-3.

title: Pakistan Says Afghans Strafed Refugee Camp
description: Pakistan said today that six Afghan helicopter gunships strafed and fired rockets at a refugee camp in Pakistan on Friday, in the second such incident this month.

title: SCREENING OF KUSH IS DISCLOSED
description: The National Football League confirmed yesterday that, at the request of some of its teams, it has conducted an investigation to determine whether Frank Kush would be suitable to coach in the league. Kush, the former Arizona State coach, is now the coach of the Hamilton Tiger-Cats in the Canadian Football League.

title: TIMES SYSTEMS DIRECTOR IS NAMED VICE PRESIDENT
description: Elise J. Ross, director of information systems for The New York Times, has been appointed a vice president of the newspaper. The appointment, effective Jan. 1, was announced by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times. Miss Ross, 38 years old, will be the first woman to serve as a vice president of The Times and the highest-ranking woman on its business staff. She is responsible for computer operations and systems.

title: A Death in Moscow
description: Everyone has heard of Andrei Sakharov, who put his life at risk so that a young woman could leave Russia and become wife to his stepson. Though banished and disgraced, he finally got his way on so small a matter - in part because everyone has heard of Andrei Sakharov.

title: RIGHTISTS KILL SIX GUATEMALA
description: One hundred heavily armed members of a rightist ''death squad'' raided a village in northern Guatemala and kidnapped 25 peasants, six of whom were found dead later, the police said today.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE STATEMENT MADE BY THE POLISH ENVOY ON HIS RESIGNATION
description: Following is a transcript of a statement by the Polish Ambassador, Romuald Spasowski, at the State Department in Washington yesterday.

title: COLUMBIA UNIT DELAYS DECISION ON COEDUCATION
description: A decision by Columbia College on whether to begin admitting women has been delayed by a continuing lack of agreement with Barnard College over how much more coeducation Columbia would require for it to continue to admit only men.

title: SUPPLY-SIDE BATTLE RAGES ON 2 FRONTS
description: On the surface, these are happy days at the White House. The Yule log is ablaze, and Ronald and Nancy Reagan are welcoming Congressmen, reporters and political allies to the White House hearth for a series of Christmas parties.

title: YALE MAGAZINE'S NEW DIRECTION UNSETTLES TRADITION AND ALUMNI
description: As a showcase for the undergraduate muse, The Yale Literary Magazine has been a fixture on this red-brick and Gothic gray campus since 1836. It has carried the nascent stirrings of such celebrated writers as Archibald MacLeish, John Hersey, Thornton Wilder and Sinclair Lewis.

title: SALAVADOR REBELS SEE OPENING TO U.S.
description: Two leaders of the Salvadoran guerrillas' political organization have had their first meeting with Administration officials here and said afterward that a channel of communication between the rebels and the Reagan State Department had finally been opened.

title: Commodities; Sugar's Pyrrhic Victory
description: DOMESTIC sugar producers won a long-sought victory last Wednesday when Congress narrowly passed the Administration's new farm bill. The measure, which includes higher sugar subsidies, is expected to be signed by President Reagan before Christmas.

title: UNSOLD JORDANIAN ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: BOYCE-ZANE 'GARDEN'
description: ''GARDEN,'' the collaboration that Johanna Boyce and Arnie Zane offered Saturday night at St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery, was both interesting and perplexing - deliberately perplexing, surely, for the dance presented some moral dilemmas.

title: IDAHO'S GOVERNOR DEFENDS FARMERS
description: A potential boycott of Idaho products by conservationists protesting the slaughter of jackrabbits could harm farmers who are already suffering because of the cropeating animals' destructiveness, Gov. John V. Evans said today.

title: U.S. Issues Dominate Financing
description: The United States Treasury will dominate new-issue activity in the credit markets this week with sales of one-year bills and four-year notes, as well as the regular weekly sale of new three- and six-month notes.

title: OCEAN DUMPING OF SLUDGE CONTINUES AS DOES DEBATE
description: Just after 10 o'clock on a recent morning, Capt. William Winchester, chief pilot aboard the North River, one of four in the city's fleet of sludge barges, guided the 324-foot ship past an invisible line in this part of the Atlantic that marks the western edge of one of the world's busiest ocean dumping grounds.

title: Swedes Repeat
description: Sweden defended the Sunshine Cup, an international team-tennis tournament for junior boys, by defeating third-seeded Italy, 3-0, in the final match today.

title: PROCEDURE USED IN TAKING POLL
description: The latest New York Times Poll was conducted by telephone from Dec. 7 through 14 among 1,146 adults from all areas of New York City. The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by computer from a complete list of exchanges in the city.

title: U.S.P. AT TIMES SQUARE
description: Since World War II, the U.S.O. has maintained its busiest and most famous club in the heart of New York, just off Times Square. This facility, the Gen Douglas MacArthur Memorial Center, at 45th Street and Broadway, offers hospitality, information and referral services, free food and tickets to sports and cultural events, and counseling for personal and family problems.

title: GOING OUT GUIE
description: PLAYER PIANO

title: CAPITALS STOP SURGE TO BEAT RANGERS, 3-2
description: The Rangers let the Washington Capitals score three goals in the first period of their game at Madison Square Garden last night, then spent the rest of the time trying to catch up.

title: ROSE C. FELD, WROTE BOOKS AND ARTICLES FOR MAGAZINE
description: Rose C. Feld, a writer whose works included "My Aunt Lucienne," a popular 1955 reminiscence about an urbane French relative, died Thursday at her home in Newtown, Conn.

title: EUGENE CONLEY, OPERA TENOR WITH MET AND CITY TROUPES
description: Eugene Conley, a tenor with the Metropolitan and New York City Opera Companies and the first American tenor to open the season at Milan's La Scala, died of cancer on Friday in Westgate Hospital in Denton, Tex. He was 73 years old and lived in Denton.

title: ICE DANCING
description: Natalya Annenko and Vadim Karkachev of the Soviet Union winning the world junior firgure-skating championship Saturday night in Oberstdorf, West Germany.

title: Expert in Technology To Head Buckbee-Mears
description: Ryal R. Poppa, a 48-year-old high-technology specialist, will join the Buckbee-Mears Company, a manufacturer of precision parts and components and opthalmic lenses, as chairman and chief executive officer. When he arrives at the corporation's St. Paul headquarters in mid-January, he will succeed Norman C. Mears, 56, as chairman, and Everett F. Carter, the 54-year-old president, as chief executive officer.

title: MOUNTAIN CLIMBERS RESCUE 2 MEN HURT IN PLANE CRASH ATOP GLACIER
description: Ed Hommer, a pilot, thought he was hallucinating when rescuers climbed over an icy ridge to save him and another man who survived a plane crash in which two of their companions were killed and four days of blizzard conditions on Mount McKinley.

title: SENTENCING NEAR FOR FALLEN LABOR LEADER
description: In two years, the career of Wilbur Hobby has declined. From a position as head of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations in North Carolina, he is now a cigarette machine operator at the American Tobacco Company here.

title: LOUISIANA TECH WOMEN TAKE TOURNEY
description: Before the championship game of the Manufacturers Hanover Christmas Classic at Madison Square Garden yesterday, the Louisiana Tech players knew that to defeat Old Dominion they would have to contain Anne Donovan, Old Dominion's 6-foot-8-inch center.

title: DEFECTING POLE SAYS 'BRUTALITY' FORCED HIS MOVE
description: Poland's Ambassador to Washington, Warsaw's most senior diplomat, asked for and was granted political asylum today in the United States.

title: PROMOTIONS ANNOUNCED AT VITT AND AC&R
description: At Vitt Media International, one of the more prominent buying services, Roy Munro, a 38-year-old accountant, has been promoted to president and chief operating officer, as Sam Vitt, founder, adds the title of chairman while remaining chief executive.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Mary Cantwell WATCHING ME, WATCHING YOU. By Fay Weldon. 270 pages. Summit Books. $13.95.

title: Tourney to Clerc
description: Jose Luis Clerc of Argentina beat Corrado Barazzutti of Italy, 7-5, 6-4, today to win the Iveco International tennis tournament. Clerc showed no fatigue from playing last week in the tough Davis Cup finals, in which Argentina lost to the United States.

title: Friedan's Haiti Message
description: Vacationing in Haiti after a long promotion tour for her latest book, ''The Second Stage,'' Betty Friedan took a break and accepted an invitation to speak the other day in Port-au-Prince.

title: Human Switchboard Offers 'Punk Classicism'
description: Since it first appeared in New York two and a half years ago, the Cleveland-based punk-rock group Human Switchboard has gained some fervent critical admirers. And at the Peppermint Lounge, where it played Thursday, it was easy to see why. Human Switchboard embodies what might be called ''punk classicism.'' The lineup of guitar, farfisa organ, bass and drums represents basic no-frills punk, with the cheesy-sounding farfisa the key textural element. The two-and three-chord tunes are brief, emotionally direct little slices of life. And vocally, Robert Pfeifer, the chief writer, lead singer and lead guitarist, echoes the sour intensity of punk godfather, Lou Reed. It was Human Switchboard's very orthodoxy and its slavish conformity to a minimal set of rules Thursday that made its music seem almost academically predictable. Human Switchboard's best tunes are its ballads, especially the extended set piece ''Refrigerator Door,'' in which Mr. Pfeifer's vocal resemblance to Mr. Reed becomes almost uncanny, and his sinuous, creeping guitar lines copy the style of Tom Verlaine. But there is a point, however, when being esthetically correct becomes less a matter of self-assertion than of artistic selfeffacement. Human Switchboard's performance seemed much too correct.

title: THEFT OF COLLEGE TEST AIDS LEADS TO 'COACHING' INQUIRY
description: Two persons believed to be Taiwanese have been arrested here on charges of stealing test materials used to determine the admissibility of foreign students to American universities. As a result, the police are investigating the possibility that there is a ''coaching school'' in Taiwan to help young Chinese gain admission to American schools.

title: British Inflation Rises to 12%
description: Britain's inflation rate jumped to 12 percent last month from 11.7 percent in October and now stands at its highest level since April, the Trade Department has announced.

title: AT SUNDAY MASSES, ARCHBISHOP CALLS FOR CALM
description: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: The Debate On Quotas for Fibers
description: American apparel and textile manufacturers call it "the right to participate in our own market." American retailers say it is nothing more than protectionism.

title: SEX AND 'NORMAL' MARRIGES
description: W HAT is there to say about sex in the ''normal'' marriage? ''There's quite a lot to say, but unfortunately not many are saying it,'' said Dr. James O'Hagan, a clinical psychologist who practices in Manhattan. ''These marriages have often been ignored - in fact, I think it's a neglected majority. Attention is frequently given to the treatment of serious sexual difficulties. And yet, for the most part, people in normal marriages don't need sex therapy, although they experience common types of sexual problems.''

title: Heavy Gulf Battles Reported
description: The official Iraqi News Agency said tonight that Iran had suffered 742 casualties in fierce fighting over the last 24 hours in the central sector of the Persian Gulf war.

title: IN THAI HILLS, OPIUM
description: The Karen, an obscure hill tribe of n orthern Thailand, are beginning to grow opium for the first time. T he effect on the world heroin market will be small. The effect on t he Karen could be catastrophic.

title: 4,000 at a Mass for the Poles Hear Cooke Condemn Deaths
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke today denounced the bloodshed and death in Poland and called on lovers of freedom everywhere to express their support for the Polish people.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COMMENTS ON POLAND AND MIDEAST
description: Following are excerpts from texts of television interviews yesterday with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation'' and with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Tahitian King Wins on Coast
description: Tahitian King caught King Go Go at the wire today and won the $226,000 Citation Handicap by a neck at Hollywood Park.

title: HARRY W. BREDEWEG
description: The Rev. Harry William Bredeweg of Indianapolis, conference minister for the Indiana-Kentucky Conference of the United Church of Christ for 18 years, died Friday at the age of 64.

title: CHAD REFUGEES IN CAMEROON BALK AT RETURNING TO HOMES
description: Tens of thousands of Chadian refugees live here in huts of plaited straw and plastic sheeting in sight of the homes they have decided to desert for good.

title: STAGE: 'DREAMGIRLS,' MICHAEL BENNET'S NEW MUSICAL, OPENS
description: WHEN Broadway history is being made, you can feel it. What you feel is a seismic emotional jolt that sends the audience, as one, right out of its wits. While such moments are uncommonly rare these days, I'm here to report that one popped up at the Imperial last night. Broadway history was made at the end of the first act of Michael Bennett's beautiful and heartbreaking new musical, ''Dreamgirls.''

title: GRIM BUDGET FORECASTS MAY BE RIGHT FOR ONCE
description: For several years, New York City's budget planners have been consistently wrong in their forecasts of how much money the city would have available to spend. This year, they think they may be right. That makes them a little nervous.

title: WASHINGTON SAYS IT IS OPTIMISTIC THAT ACCORD WON'T BE CANCELED
