description: The Reagan Administration said today that despite Prime Minister Menachem Begin's vehement denunciation of the United States, it still hoped that the strategic cooperation agreement with Israel would not be canceled.

title: Getting Started in North Carolina
description: Bob Hester's service can handle up to eight parties a day. For two people, the cost is $220 a day, for three, $270 and for four $300.

title: Copper Layoffs Increase
description: Copper industry layoffs in Arizona, the nation's largest copper producer, will rise to about 11,500 next month with cutbacks of about 500 workers announced last Friday by the Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company.

title: United Press International HUMANITARIAN MISSION
description: A convoy of 122 Dutch trucks, which delivered food to hospitals and schools in Poland, crossing the border from West Germany on its return to the Netherlands.

title: TY COBB AND INTERN
description: BASEBALL fans who have been around for a few years or who know how to read must be aware that Tyrus Raymond Cobb was not distinguished for a sweetly companionable disposition. In his autobiography, Ty tells of his days as a Detroit rookie when he fought with his teammates and ''kept a weapon of a lethal nature close by me at all times.''

title: 8 YOUNG OPERA SINGERS PERFORM AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Eight rising young singers filled the East Room of the White House with song tonight and Beverly Sills stepped briefly out of her retirement as a singer. The young people mostly sang operatic arias, but Miss Sills sang ''Jingle Bells.''

title: Big Drop in Death Rate Found in Connecticut
description: Death rates have dropped substantially faster in Connecticut than in the United States as a whole over the last two decades because of an aggressive campaign to control high blood pressure, according to a study released last week by the state's Health Commissioner.

title: TEXAS YOUTH TELLS OF MURDER, BUT JUDGE REJECTS CONFESSION
description: A 17-year-old teen-ager walked into police headquarters and convinced detectives that he killed an elderly man two years ago, but his written confession was thrown out of court.

title: THE 'NARROW ELITE' OF SOCIAL WORKERS VS. SOCIAL SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: A SYMPHONY FOR BASS BRASS IN KEY OF B-R-R
description: Why, on the coldest day of the season, would anyone in his right mind stand outdoors and play the tuba? The brass gets cold, the lips stick, the valves clog and the fingers freeze.

title: REAGAN AIDES PLAN TO ASK HIM TO BACK INCREASE IN TAXES
description: Several senior White House advisers and Administration budget officials plan to ask President Reagan to approve a total of $45 billion in new taxes that would take effect over the next two fiscal years.

title: 6 U.S. Experts Join Italian Hunt for General
description: Six antiterrorism experts from the United States Defense Department joined forces with the Italian police today to hunt for the Red Brigades terrorists who abducted an American army general.

title: BRIEFING
description: S EASONAL gift shopping is way off at Miss Harper, a dress shop only a few blocks from the White House and, whether it's fair or not, the Administration is being held responsible in the latest handbills telling pedestrians of a desperation sale: ''Miss Harper announces the Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reagan's What the Hell Happened to Christmas? Sale''

title: Judge Sets Up 'Viewing' Area For Coverage of Atlanta Trial
description: The murder trial of Wayne B. Williams, charged with killing two of the 29 young blacks slain here, will be monitored by reporters on closed-circuit television, the presiding judge disclosed Saturday.

title: Redecoration of White House Put at $730,000
description: New occupants of the White House are given $50,000 to redecorate their rooms. But when President Reagan took office, he and his wife, Nancy, returned the Federal grant and instead appealed for $200,000 in private donations to do the more extensive job they had in mind.

title: U.S. STUDENTS TURN TO THE PHILIPPINES
description: The Philippines is about as far as a New Yorker can go to attend medical school. Still, hundreds of Americans, mostly from the East Coast, apply to medical schools here every year when they fail to gain acceptance to any in the United States.

title: WOMAN FOR WHO THE SAKHAROVS FASTED 17 DAYS ARRIVES IN THE U.S.
description: Yelizaveta Alekseyeva, the Russian woman on whose behalf Andrei D. Sakharov and his wife waged a 17-day hunger strike, arrived here today to be united with her husband for the first time in more than three years.

title: Index; International
description: Fiercely traditional tribes are real rulers in Afghanistan A2 Salvadoran rebels see opening to U.S. A3 Russian woman for whom the Sa- kharovs fasted arrives in U.S. A4 U.S. seeks to aid South African blacks A5 Strains reported in Soviet-Ethiopian relations A7 Harvard to aid in developing major new hospital in Pakistan A8 Around the World A9 Chadian refugees in Cameroon balk at going home A10 Americans turn to the Philippines for a medical education A11 Polish refugees in Austria can do little more than wait A13 U.S. warns Moscow against any ''excesses'' in Poland A16 Polish-American representatives hearing from constituents A17 U.S. groups say relief shipments to Poland are continuing A19 Transcript of Begin's statement to the U.S. Ambassador A20 Syrians report Israeli moves in Golan A21 Washington Talk Briefing B26 Howell Raines on Administration feuding over tax increases B26 Soviet Embassy denies antennas are for intelligence-gathering B26 General Around the Nation A22 Solar power program brings amenities to Navajo families A22 Private security industry moves toward fewer armed guards A22 Ocean dumping of sludge continues off Jamaica Bay B2 Youth tells of old crime but confession rejected B18 Two men rescued after plane crash on Mount McKinley B19 Auction of unused old hardware lures 600 to Pennsylvania B22 SportsMonday Basketball: Louisiana Tech wins women's tourney at Garden C2

title: EUROPEAN ROCKET IS TESTED
description: Western Europe's Ariane rocket underwent a successful test-firing today from the Kourou space center in French Guiana, northeastern South America, and put two satellites into orbit, the French National Space Study Center said. It was the Ariane's fourth and final test flight, and the rocket is now ready for commercial use, the center said.

title: French Nationalization
description: The French Socialist Government of Francois Mitterrand has approved a bill providing for the nationalization of five industrial groups, 36 banks and two major investment groups. The bill was passed on a 331-to-153 vote at its third and final reading last Friday in the National Assembly. The project, which was rejected by the Senate on Wednesday, now goes before the Constitutional Council, which has one month to decide if the bill conforms with the French Constitution.

title: EXCERPTS FROM BROADCASTS ON POLAND
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency, and a report from the Soviet press agency, Tass:

title: HAIG RETAINS HIGH HOPES FOR PACT
description: In perhaps the harshest statement ever made by an Israeli Prime Minister about the United States, Menachem Begin today accused the Reagan Administration of treating Israel like a ''vassal state.''

title: SOLAR POWER PANELS PROVIDE LIGHT, SHOWER AND TOILET TO 191 NAVAJO FAMILIES
description: Except for the mud-spattered pickup truck parked outside, Bertha and Lorenzo Smith's way of life was little different from that of their Navajo ancestors. Until recently, their 100-year-old log home deep on the reservation here had neither indoor plumbing nor running water, and when darkness fell they lit kerosene lamps so they could see.

title: Oil Price Cut By Iraq Cited
description: Iraq has officially notified Japanese buyers that it will cut the price of its Basrah light crude oil by 50 cents a barrel, to $34.21, effective Jan. 1, industry sources said.

title: Colombia Airline Loan
description: Chase Manhattan Bank said Friday that a group of banks, including Chase, had agreed to extend a five-year, $120 million loan to the Colombian airline, Aerovias Nacionales de Colombia. Chase, acting as agent for the loan, said the money would be used to convert existing lines of credit into a medium-term loan.

title: Trade Talks Planned
description: Trade talks among representatives of Japan, the United States and the European Economic Community will take place in Florida on Jan. 15-16, a spokesman for the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said. The spokesman said the delegations to the talks would be headed by the Japanese Trade Minister, Shintaro Abe; the United States trade representative, Bill Brock, and Wilhelm Haferkamp, the Common Market's commissioner for external relations.

title: GERMAN BANKS SEEK BONN PLEDGE ON POLAND
description: West German banks, which hold the bulk of Poland's estimated $16 billion indebtedness to Western banks, will not grant further credits to Warsaw unless they are guaranteed by the West German Government, the head of the Association of German banks said today.

title: Photos From Poland Carried Out by Dane
description: A set of pictures of scenes in Poland after the imposition of martial law has been smuggled out by a Danish photographer and distributed by United Press International.

title: DEAVER HALTED COMMERCE PANEL NOMINATION OPPOSED BY TRUCKING INDUSTRY
description: Overruling other Reagan Administration officials, Michael K. Deaver, the deputy White House chief of staff, blocked the nomination to the Interstate Commerce Commission of a Senate staff member who was opposed by the head of a trucking organization that had employed Mr. Deaver as a consultant.

title: Senators Oppose Curb On Home Loan Plan
description: Fourteen Democratic senators urged President Reagan Saturday to veto what they called an effort to undermine the home loan guarantee programs of the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration.

title: Wilkison Captures Australian Tennis
description: Tim Wilkison, a left-hander from North Carolina, won the $125,000 New South Wales Open tennis championship today for the second time, defeating Chris Lewis of New Zealand, 6-4, 7-6, 6-3.

title: I.M.F. TEAM VISITS POLAND
description: Washington -- Twenty-four hours before martial law descended on Poland a team from the International Monetary Fund arrived in Warsaw to begin the process of weighing the Polish application to join the 141-nation lending body.

title: 2 People Die as Car Explodes In Palestinian Area of Beirut
description: Two people were killed today when a bomb exploded in a car in an area where several Palestinian and Lebanese leftist groups have offices, Palestinian sources reported.

title: Security Accord Signed By Saudis and Bahrain
description: Saudi Arabia's Interior Minister said today that Iran was ''exporting terrorism'' and announced the signing of a security pact with Bahrain.

title: JAPAN'S ENVIABLE JOBLESS RATE
description: Tadashi Nakamura has a job that government officials throughout the world must envy. A distinguished-looking 46-year-old bureaucrat, Mr. Nakamura has the formal title of Director of the Employment Policy Division of Japan's Labor Ministry. That means he is responsible for coming up with policies to combat unemployment in a nation that, by the standards of most industrial countries, has no unemployement.

title: Kicker, Defense Win for Missouri
description: There was nothing dramatic about Missouri's 19-17 upset victory over Southern Mississippi in the Tangerine Bowl Saturday night.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Applied Materials Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., has elected to its board Alfred J. Stein, president and chief executive officer of the Arrow Electronics Corporation.

title: INFLATION ESTIMATES IN CONFLICT
description: The Congressional Budget Office, in a preliminary, unpublished forecast, anticipates that inflation will cool off much more slowly in the next several years than was predicted earlier this month by Administration economists.

title: PROTESTORS MARCH IN LONDON
description: Thousands of supporters of the Solidarity labor movement marched through London today and petitioned the Polish Embassy for an end to martial law in Poland. Embassy officials refused to accept the petition but met a delegration of protesters inside the building.

title: Zungul's 5 Goals Lead Arrows, 9-4
description: Steve Zungul scored five goals and assisted on three others as he led the New York Arrows to a 9-4 victory over the Buffalo Stallions today before 8,051 in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: Mamby Outpoints Nigerian Boxer
description: Saoul Mamby of Jamaica outpointed Obisia Nwankpa of Nigeria and retained his World Boxing Council junior-welterweight championship Saturday night, the News Agency of Nigeria reported today.

title: IN CONGRESS ETHNIC POLES KEEPING BUSY
description: When she gets to her office on Capitol Hill, Representative Barbara A. Mikulski telephones the State Department to find out the latest developments in the Polish crisis.

title: Kennedy Remarks on Poland
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that the United States should make clear it will not tolerate martial law in Poland. The Massachusetts Democrat also called on the Polish Government to immediately release the Solidarity union leader, Lech Walesa.

title: Mark Murphy Sings Bop to Bossa Nova
description: Mark Murphy, a singer whose voice can be so hoarsely grainy at one moment that it seems to be disintegrating and, in the next moment, soar off on a strong lyrical flight, appeared through last night in an interestingly varied program of bop, bossa nova and ballads at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street.

title: ENVOY TO U.S QUITS
description: The Soviet press agency Tass reported today that Solidarity union activists had blown up the exit from a mine in southern Poland and were holding hundreds of workers underground.

title: Sports World Specials; Old-Timers' Day
description: Clarence Chaffee didn't really get into tennis until he was 70 years old. Eleven years, one heart attack and one pacemaker later, he has accounted for 41 national championships.

title: Post Women Win
description: Liz Stokes, a sophomore forward, scored a career-high 16 points and helped C.W. Post (5-3) to a 75-58 victory over Harvard (1-7). Vera Danner, a junior guard, and Diane Alessio, a sophomore forward, scored 15 and 14 points. Lisa Leithauser, a freshman forward, led Harvard with 16.

title: ETHIOPIANS' LINKS TO SOVIET STRAINED
description: A few weeks ago the Soviet Ambassador to Ethiopia, Boris Y. Kirnasovsky, suddenly left for home. Since most other diplomats here were not aware of his departure, they were surprised when it was announced that Mr. Kirnasovsky was being replaced.

title: Chief Is Selected, By Peoples Energy
description: Eugene A. Tracy, 54 years old, has been elected chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Peoples Energy Corporation, which operates two gas utilities in Chicago and its metropolitan area.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Jack Deitchman, Malcolm End, Rochelle Lazarus, Gerald McGee, Vel Rankin, Jack Reed, Tom Rost, Michael Vaughn and Edward Vick have been elected senior vice presidents of Ogilvy & Mather Advertising.

title: The Receding March of Time on the Met Stage
description: The Metropolitan Opera may not be the Fountain of Youth, but it comes close as far as James Morris is concerned. When Mr. Morris joined the Met 10 years ago at the age of 23 his bass-baritone voice tended to cast him in the roles of much older men.

title: FAMILY SAYS AWARD OF $1.7 MILLION CANNOT MAKE UP FOR 1958 SLAYING
description: Members of the family of Daniel Bell, a 22-year-old black man shot to death here in 1958 by a white policeman, feel good about the $1.79 million awarded them last week by a jury but insist that no amount of money can make up for his death.

title: Japan Growth Put at 3.7%
description: Japan's economy grew at an inflation-adjusted pace of 3.7 percent in the fiscal year 1980, which ended in March, the Economic Planning Agency said in a revised report.

title: HARDWARE FROM STORE SHUT IN '41 IS SOLD
description: Forty years ago, anyone who walked into Wieder's Hardware store here could have bought a new bucksaw for $1.50.

title: REPUBLIC AIR'S NEW AGENCY
description: Republic Airlines, based in Minneapolis, is assigned its $20 million passenger advertising account to Campbell-Mitham, the biggest of the local shops.

title: State of Emergency Imposed In Dominica in Wake of Attack
description: Prime Minister Mary Eugenia Charles imposed a state of emergency today on the Caribbean island of Dominica as police searched for a group of men who fled after a bungled coup attempt.

title: FIRE DIAMOND EXECUTIVES INDICTED IN A MISSOURI FRAUD INVESTIGATION
description: Five executives of the International Diamond Corporation, the largest seller and distributor of investment gems in the United States, are free on their own recognizance after being indicted on charges of theft and securities fraud by a Jackson County grand jury in Kansas City.

title: BUYING MAGNUSON AND ITS PROBLEMS
description: In acquiring Magnuson Computer Systems, the Storage Technology Corporation may get just the product it was looking for. But it will also be buying a company that has been losing money, employees and credibility.

title: Public-Radio Listeners Increase 40% in Year
description: National Public Radio has increased its audience 40 percent in the last year, according to Frank L. Mankiewicz, the system's president.

title: GIANTS AND FAMILIES TOAST JETS' VICTORY
description: Laura Jean Neill, barely 3 months old, and Janna Currier, almost 3 months old, seemed uninterested. Older children were more concerned with ice cream and soda.

title: U.S. ASKS PRETORIA HOW TO AID BLACKS
description: The Reagan Administration is looking for ways to support black education in South Africa without channeling the assistance through the bureaucracy that enforces strict racial separation in schools.

title: Gas Additive's Maker Picks New Leader
description: With Propel, a gasoline additive, rolling out into national distribution, its producer, the North American Combustion Technology Corporation, has appointed Monroe J. Lawrence, 53, president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Richard L. Matthews, 54, who resigned from the Toronto-based company ''for personal reasons.''

title: HOPE AGAINST HOPE
description: Is Poland Czechoslovakia? Yes and no - at least not yet. And the no, the conditional no, puts practical and moral limits on how we in the West should react.

title: Man and His 12-Year-Old Son Critically Wounded in Bronx
description: A man and his 12-year-old son were shot and critically wounded while in their third-floor Bronx apartment last night, the police said.

title: Heller in Hospital
description: Joseph Heller, the author of ''Catch-22,'' is at the Mount Sinai Medical Center recovering from a mild case of Guillain-Barre syndrome, an inflammation of the nerves that causes muscle weakness. His doctors say that he has excellent prospects for a full recovery. Mr. Heller, who is also the author of ''Something Happened'' and ''Good as Gold,'' is now at work on his fourth novel.

title: SNOW AND HOPES ARE HIGH IN SKI AREAS
description: Ski resort operators like to compare themselves to farmers, because both flourish of fail on the basis of what comes out of the sky.

title: SUN BELT IS OVERTAKING NORTHEAST IN SOME WAGE AREAS
description: Many workers in New York and other Northeastern cities, long among the highest paid in the country, have begun to lose that distinction to their counterparts in the Sun Belt.

title: GRAVESEND 'CAP TO LINES OF POWER'
description: Lines of Power ended his racing career with a flourish at Aqueduct yesterday when he won the $54,600 Gravesend Handicap. The 4-year-old son of Raise a Native, out of the Bold Ruler mare Exotic Garden, is scheduled to stand at stud next season at Walmac Farm in Lexington, Ky.

title: IN DENMARK, STRANDED POLES ADOPT 'WAIT AND SEE' OUTLOOK
description: As many as 1,000 Poles have been stranded in Denmark by the crisis at home and no one, including the Poles themselves, knows when or even if they will leave.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any sucharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RICHARDS EXPECTS TO STAY AS REPUBLICAN CHIEF
description: The Republican national chairman, Richard Richards, says he has made some mistakes in his term and probably would do some things differently if he had a second chance but he expects to weather criticism and stay in his job.

title: PPG to Purchase French Concern
description: PPG Industries said that it had reached agreement to purchase control of a French flat glass business for $43 million.

title: CRITICS VOTE 'REDS,' BURT LANCASTER THE BEST OF '81
description: ''Reds,'' Warren Beatty's epic portrait of the Americans John Reed and Louise Bryant and their role in the Russian Revolution, was voted the best film of 1981 yesterday by the New York Film Critics Circle. The group chose Burt Lancaster as best actor for his portrayal of an aging numbers runner in ''Atlantic City.'' Glenda Jackson was named best actress for her performance as the poet Stevie Smith in ''Stevie.''

title: African Trade Pact
description: Only nine of a possible 18 countries signed a treaty today at a conference here to form an East and Southern African Preferential Trade Area.

title: COLS APPOINT KUSH, DROP McCORMACK
description: Frank Kush, discharged as Arizona State's football coach two years ago after the university administration had joined in accusations that he had punched a player and then lied to cover up the assault, was named head coach of the Baltimore Colts today. He replaced Mike McCormack, who was dismissed after compiling a 2-14 record this season, his second at Baltimore.

title: Price Increase For Newsprint
description: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. said that it would follow the lead of eastern Canada newsprint producers and increase prices to its American customers by 5 percent on March 1. That would bring the price of a metric ton to $525.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1981
description: International A strike by 2,800 Polish coal miners in Silesia was confirmed by the Warsaw radio. There were also reports that activists from the Solidarity labor movement had barricaded themselves inside a steel mill in Katowice. The broadcasts, monitored outside Poland, said that the miners had been on strike since last Tuesday. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Pope John Paul II extolled freedom in his annual peace message. He declared that all men should strive to prevent every form of warfare, but he added that ''peoples have a right and even a duty to protect their existence and freedom'' against an unjust aggressor. (A1:2.)

title: Textile Pact Unresolved
description: Participants in trade talks here were hopeful tonight that they could agree Tuesday on terms for the projected renewal for five years of a pact regulating the flow of textiles from developing to industrialized countries.

title: SHE FOUGHT MICHAEL BENNETT AND BECAME HIS STAR
description: EARLY in the first act of ''Dreamgirls,'' Michael Bennett's new hit musical, a talent manager makes an enticing and prophetic remark to Jennifer Holliday, who acts one of a trio of young women trying to make it big in show business. ''You could be a star,'' he tells her.

title: CHRISTMAS AT A PRICE
description: It was nearly 11 o'clock on an uncomfortably cold night, but inside the Toys ''R'' Us store 19 electronic cash registers were chirping like a swarm of June crickets.

title: Advertising; Holiday Success At SFM
description: THANKS to its Holiday Network, the SFM Media Corporation probably has a logo as well known as that of any ad agency. That's because about a dozen times a year since 1978 the company has been setting up independent TV networks to show all-family, old-favorite movies, each of which has run with SFM Holiday Network billboards fore and aft.

title: Rapist in Louisiana Gets 15 Life Terms
description: A man who admitted he was the masked rapist in seven attacks since 1979 was sentenced today to the maximum penalty of 15 life terms and 1,389 years.

title: Schmidt Gets Up There
description: Mike Schmidt, the Philadelphia Phillies' third baseman who for two straight seasons has been the National League's most valuable player, reached new money heights yesterday in signing a six-year contract reported to be worth $1.2 million a year. Schmidt, who is 32 years old, hit .316 last season while leading the league in six batting categories.

title: SOVIET SOLDIERS CAPTURED IN AFGHANISTAN
description: According to a caption provided by The Associated Press, photograph shows three Soviet soldiers after their capture by Afghan guerrillas. The three were shown at a news conference in eastern Afghanistan. The soldiers told reporters that they were being ''kept alive to be shown to journalists,'' and that after their propoganda value decreases ''they will slit our throats.''

title: Energy Audits Called Faulty
description: The head of the Government program investigating complaints that oil companies made billions of dollars in overcharges said today that the Government had been settling cases for about 15 cents for each $1 of reported violations. He called the amounts of the accusations ''grossly inflated.''

title: FUEL CELLS MAY DELAY SHUTTLE
description: The fuel cell failure aboard the space shuttle Columbia last month was caused by unexpected corrosion and, as a result, engineers have removed all the generators from the spaceship, the space agency said today.

title: IN HOSTILE VALLEY, LICHENS POSE ANTARCTIC PUZZLE
description: high terrace that juts out from the steep barren walls of this Antarctic valley in Victoria Land. Winds of awesome power tear at the sandstone floor and winter temperatures sometimes plunge to 75 degrees below zero Fahrenheit.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CONCERT: NATIONAL ORCHESTRA
description: THE National Orchestra of New York is a 100-piece ensemble composed of young gifted instrumentalists brought together under the auspices of the National Orchestral Association. For seven months, three times a week, the musicians rehearse, while presenting a series of concerts conducted by their music director, Alvaro Cassuto, and assorted guests.

title: RECITAL: MARIAN HAHN, PIANIST
description: IT was difficult to find fault with Marian Hahn's piano playing at the Abraham Goodman House on Thursday evening. Not only has Miss Hahn the kind of ear that makes transitions from phrase to phrase with no loss of tension and flow, but she is also able to draw lovely, glowing tone from her instrument no matter what the dynamic level.

title: Judge Orders Release Of Athletic Fund Data
description: A Pima County Superior Court judge today ordered the University of Arizona to release documents from its investigation into an athletic department slush fund.

title: MUSIC: MUSSORGSKY REVISED
description: ORCHESTRATION drew more attention than the music in a program last week at Carnegie Hall. One reason was the American Symphony Orchestra's New York premiere of a transcription of Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' conducted by Leif Segerstam.

title: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1981; The Economy
description: The United Auto Workers might renegotiate current contracts with Ford and General Motors, reversing a stand taken in March against reopening contracts with domestic auto makers. A decision might be made at a Jan. 8 meeting as the manufacturers press the union for wage concessions. (Page A1.)

title: Expansion Planned For Light Wines Amid Surging Sales
description: The tennis-playing couple lay down their racquets and pick up a bottle. ''What a perfect time for your other wine,'' says the voiceover in the television commercial for Taylor California Cellars Light Chablis.

title: Jets Hunting; For Goal Posts
description: The Jets went shopping for a pair of goal posts today and discovered that they are hard to fit. Both posts were torn down by Shea Stadium fans Sunday after the team had clinched a playoff berth by defeating Green Bay.

title: VIEW ULSTER AS ANOTHER RHODESIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Keith Meyers
description: SLAIN OFFICER BURIED: An honor guard of police officers stood at attention yesterday as the funeral cortege of Anthony J. Abruzzo Jr. left St. Andrew's Church in Flushing, Queens. Officer Abruzzo was off duty when he was shot and killed Wednesday as he went to the aid of his father-in-law, who was being robbed by three men.

title: U.S. CANCELS VISA OF ULSTER ACTIVIST
description: The State Department said today that it had invalidated a visa held by the Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant political leader from Northern Ireland.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Centronics Data Computer Corp. said it and its lender banks had executed a formal agreement restructuring the company's credit arrangements.

title: Jury in Ribicoff Killing Deadlocks on Penalty
description: A jury reported today that it could not agree whether the man who killed Sarai Ribicoff should die in the gas chamber or spend the rest of his life in prison, and Superior Court Judge Laurence Rittenbrand declared a mistrial in the penalty phase of the trial.

title: NOVO WARY OF MISPERCEPTIONS
description: Novo Industri A/S, firmly established as the world leader in industrial enzyme production and a major producer of insulin, is wary of the kind of publicity normally associated with biotechnology concerns.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE school of the future may be born in New York City next September when 60 youngsters will take part in an education estimated to be at least 10 years ahead of its time. The key to the experiment is the integration of computers into virtually the entire curriculum. If successful, the project is expected to point the way to the transformation of the nation's schools.

title: Australia Export Study
description: The Australian Industries Assistance Commission has recommended the termination of two export incentive programs that together are worth almost $300 million a year to industry. The largest program was extended earlier this year to the end of the 1982-83, July-June fiscal year and the commission said it should be ended then.

title: Duran to Fight Benitez
description: Roberto Duran of Panama, the former lightweight and welterweight champion, will fight Wilfred Benitez for the super welterweight championship of the World Boxing Council Jan. 30 at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas.

title: A Rose Bowl Kickoff For Honeywell Spots
description: The telecast of the Rose Bowl game Jan. 1 will mark a move into network television by Honeywell, which belives college sports is the vehicle for reaching the kind of business people who make decisions about buying office-automation and computer-system products.

title: Whittaker Net Gains 16.5%
description: The Whittaker Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Oct. 31 rose 16.5 percent, to $19.1 million, or $1.21 a share, from $16.4 million, or $1.09 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues edged up 3.3 percent, to $412.7 million, from $399.6 million.

title: WHY TRY TO MUFFLE A USED-CAR RULE?
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss...C-After $7,458,000 nonrecurring charge for the closing and disposal of facilities

title: Mild Tremor in South Mexico
description: A mild earth tremor shook southern Mexico early today, but the police said there were no immediate reports of damage or casualties. The Mexico City Geological Institute said the tremor measured 4.5 on the Richter Scale.

title: Chess: A Feeling for the Artistic Was Costly for Bronstein
description: When David Bronstein was asked once why he had not played an obvious winning move, the man who played to a tie (and therefore was unsuccessful) in a match for the world championship in 1951 said, ''I do not do such unartistic things.'' The trouble was that his ''artistic'' alternative happened to be worth no more than a draw.

title: 2,800 OCCUPY MINES
description: The Warsaw radio reported today that more than 2,800 Polish coal miners were on strike in Silesia, and there were reports that activists from the Solidarity union movement had barricaded themselves inside a steel mill in Katowice.

title: ISLANDERS' RECALL OF 4TH SUTTER COMPOUNDS CONFUSION IN N.H.L.
description: The Red Wings were leading the Islanders, 2-1, in the third period Sunday night at Joe Louis Arena in Detroit when Bob Bourne broke free and tied the score. A fan who had been out buying popcorn was overheard asking his friend what had happened.

title: TOPPS & TROWERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
Gulf to Obtain General Atomic
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation will become full owner of the General Atomic Company, a partnership of Gulf and Royal Dutch/Shell Group's Scallop Nuclear Inc., under a tentative agreement between the partners, General Atomic said.

title: M & T MORTGAGE INVESTORS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
A CATHOLIC TRIBUNAL IN ROME WILL RULE ON CAREY MARRIGE
description: A ruling on the validity of Governor Carey's marriage to the former Evangeline Gouletas will have to come from Rome, according to a announcement yesterday from the Roman Catholic diocese of Albany and the Governor's office.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't want it to go on long. We're going to do everything we can to see that it doesn't.''

title: 3M to Acquire Tape Company
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company has signed an agreement for the cash purchase of the International Tapetronics Corporation, a producer of tape-cartridge equipment for radio and television stations.

title: Canadian Mail Rates To Increase on Jan. 1
description: Canadian internal and overseas mail rates will nearly double on Jan. 1, the Government announced today. A first-class letter will cost 30 cents, against 17 cents at present, while a letter to the United States goes up from 17 cents to 35 cents. It will cost 60 cents to mail a letter to any other foreign country, against 35 cents at present.

title: GROUP PROPOSES MERGER RULES
description: An informal study group of antitrust experts has recommended that the Government adopt rules to make it clearer when mergers between direct competitors would be allowed. The group has also proposed guidelines that, if adopted, could effectively increase the number of such mergers that would be permitted.

title: THE LOW U.S. RATE OF SAVINGS
description: More than most countries, the United States is a land of consumers. Of every dollar of income after taxes, on average, 95 cents are spent and only about 5 cents are saved.

title: NU-MED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Big Question: Can Giants Keep Intensity?
description: Now that the improbable has become reality and the Giants have reached the playoffs for the first time in 18 years, will they be able to maintain the intensity that got them there? Or is there the danger that they may be overexcited and nervous when they play the Eagles Sunday in Philadelphia.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Elizabeth Taylor and Husband Separate
description: After five years of marriage, Elizabeth Taylor and her husband, Senator John Warner, announced yesterday that they had separated. ''They have agreed amicably to a legal separation,'' said Chen San, a spokesman for Miss Taylor in New York.

title: AN AUTHORITY ON EALRY CHILDHOOD
description: Selma Fraiberg, a professor of child psychoanalysis at the University of California in San Francisco and a clinician who devoted her career to helping troubled children, died of cancer Saturday at the Ralph K. Davies Medical Center there. She was 63 years old.

title: UGANDA BRIGHTENS AS GUNFIRE YIELDS TO DISCO MUSIC
description: A visitor these days can walk through nighttime Kampala, hearing the beat of disco music rather than the rifle fire that was heard a few months ago. According to Government officials and Western diplomats, the change reflects the easing of tensions a year after President Milton Obote's return to office in Uganda.

title: DOCTORS URGED TO WATCH FOR TOXIC SHOCK IN WIDE RANGE OF PEOPLE
description: TOXIC shock experts at the Federal Centers for Disease Control are alerting physicians to be on the lookout for the potentially fatal syndrome in a wide range of people, not just menstruating women who use tampons. A new study by the Atlanta-based centers has revealed that a larger proportion of cases now occurring are unrelated to menstruation.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SOME RADIO AND TV BROADCASTS IN POLAND FROM TASS
description: Following are excerpts from the Soviet press agency Tass and excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency Katowice Miners Strike 9 P.M. Monday, (3 P.M. Monday, E.S.T.)

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After foreign currency losses equal to 8 cents a shr for the qr and 56 cents for the yr...C-Includes foreign currency gains equal to 17 cents a shr for the qr and 13 cents for the yr

title: JIM ENRIGHT
description: Jim Enright, a member of the College Basketball Hall of Fame, veteran professional and college basketball referee and former Chicago sports reporter, died Sunday night.

title: FUTURES UNIT ADDED IN CHICAGO
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange today joined the rush of trading exchanges planning to trade new futures contracts, announcing that it will form a division that will specialize in the trading of futures on options, indexes of stock prices and indexes of other financial instruments.

title: New Head Appointed For Durkee Foods
description: Ron Bowen, 40, will join Durkee Industrial Foods, a refiner of edible oils, on Jan. 4 as president. He will succeed Robert E. Dorfmeyer, 65, who will retire from the Cleveland-based division of the SCM Corporation at the end of that month.

title: Costa Rican Debt Overdue
description: Costa Rica has failed for the fourth time in two months to pay interest promptly on its foreign debt and could face default proceedings, banking sources said today.

title: Unemployment 8.8% in E.E.C.
description: The number of unemployed in the 10 nations of the European Economic Community rose to almost 10 million in November, representing a record 8.8 percent of the Common Market work force, the organization's statistics agency, Eurostat, reported today.

title: DO BRAIN CYCLES ALTER CANARY SONGS?
description: Canary-lovers know that their pets can warble a lullaby one year but may sing a waltz-like tune the next. It has long been known that a canary's song may vary from year to year, but not why or how this can be.

title: COLLIN'S DECISION SEEN TIED TO JACKSON'S
description: Reggie Jackson's willingness to be a full-time designated hitter with the Yankees creates a conciliatory environment for negotiations, Jackson's agent said yesterday as he waited for a specific contract proposal from George Steinbrenner by tomorrow.

title: MICRON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Earthquake in Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake measuring 3.5 on the Richter scale shook south-central Alaska early Sunday, the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center reported.

title: Drop Forecast In Inflation
description: Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates predicted today that the recession that began in August would continue until spring, with uncertainty about interest rates a major contributing factor.

title: 'Small-Savers' Interest Rises
description: and-a-half-year ''small-saver'' certificates, up from the ceilings of 12.95 percent and 12.7 percent for the previous two weeks.

title: WOLF, HOWARD B, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $43,376 for the qr and $88,348 for the 6 mos

title: SCHOOL BOARDS AGREE TO SAVE 9 CENTERS FOR CITY'S TEACHERS
description: A network of nine centers that provide advice, continuing education and materials for New York City's 55,000 elementary and secondary public school teachers has been saved, even though Federal support for the program is ending.

title: WALL ST. BONUSES: FEWER THIS YEAR
description: A number of investment banking houses apparently are paying generous bonuses this year - reflecting big profits during a busy year of mergers and underwritings - while many of Wall Street's major stock brokerage firms are reducing or eliminating these year-end payouts.

title: No Headline
description: 76% IN POLL SAY WAR IS LIKELY IN A FEW YEARS

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Hidden Resource for the Homeless
description: Mayor Koch recently came up with a good idea for helping at least some of the city's homeless men and women: Let each of New York's several thousand churches and synagogues take in a few, thereby dispersing the problem and limiting its cost to the city. But the Mayor tossed off his idea in a letter to religious leaders in a way that made it look like no more than a public relations gimmick. It deserves serious attention.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-There are no yr-ago comparable because the company became public in Jan 1980

title: Florida's Citrus Crop Escapes a Disaster
description: Record low temperatures in Florida caused minor citrus fruit damage in four counties, but the rest of the billion-dollar crop was shielded from what could have been a disastrous freeze.

title: RANGERS' MALONEY, GRESCHNER RETURNING
description: Coach Herb Brooks, drawing on his considerable supply of optimism, says he still feels the Rangers are better than most of the teams that have been beating them.

title: THE ACHILLES' HEEL ON AFRICAS' HORN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COSTLY ARMS TRADE
description: The arms trade has flourished mightily since the oil-price increase in 1973. Rich countries sell weapons to offset the increased costs of their imports; the main purchasers are poor countries all around the world. My extrapolations from 1978 arms-sale data (the latest available) suggest that this boom may have produced as much as $100 billion in international trade. But many poor countries will pay heavily for their buying spree, forfeiting badly needed economic development.

title: Award to Fan Hanover
description: Fan Hanover, the most consistent standardbred performer of the year, yesterday became the first female pacer to win the Roland Harriman award as harness horse of the year since the award's inception in 1947. A 3-year-old filly, Fan Hanover won 17 of 23 races, including the Little Brown Jug, and earned $497,717, a record for a female harness horse. The balloting was by the United States Trotting Association and the Harness Writers Association.

title: Hill, Rams' Receiver, Held on Rape Charge
description: Drew Hill, the Los Angeles Rams' wide receiver, was arrested early this morning and charged with raping a 16-year-old girl.

title: Common Market Joblessness Reaches Record 8.8 Percent
description: The number of jobless people in the 10 nations of the European Economic Community increased by 160,500, to nearly 10 million last month. The figure represented 8.8 percent of the work force, and was a record, it was reported today.

title: BEGIN IS CRITICIZED IN ISRAEL'S PRESS ,
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's vehement attack yesterday on the Reagan Administration received circumspect criticism in the Israeli press today.

title: PURCHASE OF DAILY NEWS BY WARNER IS EXPLORED
description: Warner Communications Inc., the diversified New York-based entertainment company, is conducting preliminary discussions on the possibility of buying The Daily News.

title: Brother Rat
description: At a time when New York City's homeless number in the thousands, it may be instructive to consider the lives of eight million residents who are never without food and shelter; who are so domesticated that a city health official recently described them as ''just like cats and dogs''; who live, literally, off the fat of the land, and never better than in the last week or two. What, in short, can we learn from the rats?

title: General's Kidnappers Leave Leaflets in 2 Cities
description: The kidnappers of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier taunted the Italian police today by planting leaflets about the abduction in several widely separated areas in Milan and Venice, but left no clues about the whereabouts of their hostage.

title: Doris Rosen Wed to Justice
description: The marriage of Doris Rosen, widow of Michael Rosen, to State Supreme Court Justice Charles Margett of the Appellate Division, took place yesterday at Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony. Judge Margett, whose first wife died, is a former president of the Queens County Bar Association and the Association of Supreme Court Justices of New York.

title: CHARGERS WIN AND TAKE TITLE
description: The San Diego Chargers, their championship hopes helped by an upset Sunday, defeated the Oakland Raiders, 23-10, tonight to win their third consecutive American Conference Western Division title.

title: BANKERS DIVIDED ON POLISH DEBT
description: Meeting here in secrecy, representatives of eight major Western banks today began preparing a common response by Poland's more than 500 Western creditor banks to that country's growing debt repayment problems.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $129,000 gain from the anticipated yr-end LIFO liquidation...C-Net income

title: Nissan Decision
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's No.2 auto maker, behind the Toyota Motor Company, said it would decide in January or February whether to build an assembly factory in Britain. Takashi Ishihara, president of Nissan, which makes Datsun cars, told a news conference that ''a survey report has not yet been completed and a decision would be made in January or February.'' A group of leading company officials recently visited Britain for talks with the British Government on the project that envisages a $680 million factory with an annual output capacity of 200,000 passenger cars.

title: Penn State 60, Nebraska 58
description: Dwight Gibson, a Penn State freshman, sank a pair of foul shots with 41 seconds left that broke a 58-58 tie and ended a five-game winning streak for Nebraska (5-2).

title: DONATIONS TO HELP NEEDY SENT IN AS HOLIDAY MEMORIALS
description: The holidays are often times during which the loss of loved ones is most keenly felt, as evidenced by letters from many who have contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: REAGAN STUDIES BUDGET WITH TAX RISES AT ISSUE
description: President Reagan today assembled his top economic advisers to get their predictions on economic growth and inflation rates for the 1983 fiscal year.

title: RISING CONCERN FOUND OVER CRIME IN THE CITY
description: Concern over crime among New York City residents has grown sharply over the last four years, and their confidence in the ability of city authorities to combat it has dropped, a New York Times survey indicates. More than 6 in 10 of those interviewed said that they or someone close to them had been robbed or mugged in New York City in the past year or two. And of those who said they had been a victim or were close to one, only one in 10 said the criminal had been captured.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Debatable Issue

title: A New Song for a Woman of Many Talents
description: It is hard to describe what Maya Angelou does because she does so many things. She has written books. poetry and musical comedy.

title: Japan Plans Tariff Cuts
description: The governmental tariff rate council said today that that it had recommended tariff reductions over the next three years for 1,653 items, beginning next April 1, to help ease trade frictions with other countries.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why are tapeworms harmful?

title: JEWISH SPOKESMEN APPEAL FOR U.S.-ISRAELI CONCILIATION
description: American Jewish spokesmen urged Israel and the United States yesterday to reassert their historic ties in the face of what was widely regarded as the worst crisis in relations between the two allies.

title: OWNERS OF THE WILD-CARD TEAMS
description: WELLINGTON MARA, the president of the Giants, was having dinner Friday night with his friend of three decades, Tom Landry, the Dallas Cowboys coach who was a Giants defensive back and assistant coach on their 1956 National Football League championship team.

title: U.S. Bond Prices Move Lower; 6-Month Bills Up to 11.838%
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds declined slightly - and yields inched upward - in quiet trading early yesterday. Prices then dropped further late in the day after the Treasury announced plans to raise $5 billion of cash through sales of new seven- and 20-year issues.

title: Pitcher Injured
description: Mike Jones, a left-handed pitcher for the Kansas City Royals, was reported in satisfactory condition at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester yesterday after an accident in which he lost control of his car and struck a tree.

title: Don Hogan Charles PATIENCE REWARDED
description: Patience, leonine twin of Fortitude at the New York Public Library, got a replacement from Fred Comas for a wreath worth $1,275 that was stolen Dec. 9. An Urban Park Ranger is on guard at right.

title: Hearing on 'Suitor' Of Miss Kennedy
description: A California man awaiting sentencing for harassing Caroline Kennedy with marriage demands has been examined by psychiatrists and found ''unfit to proceed,'' according to a Criminal Court judge in Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. AIDES HAITIANS' LAWYERS DISCUSS RIOT IN PUERTO RICO CAMP

title: Spreckels Sugar Names President
description: Frederick F. Coons, 58 years old, has been named president of Spreckels Sugar, a major sugar processor and distributor with headquarters in San Francisco, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Guy D. Manuel, 64, who will retire from the company, a unit of the Amstar Corporation.

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
CHINA BLAMES U.S. FOR DIVIDED KOREA
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang has blamed the United States for contributing to instability in Northeast Asia by perpetuating the division of the Korean peninsula, according to reports today in the official Chinese press.

title: 2 Who Aided Patricia Hearst To Sue on Remarks in Book
description: Jack and Micki Scott, who admitted sheltering Patricia Hearst after her 1974 kidnapping, said today that they would file a $6.9 million lawsuit against her for ''falsehoods'' in her recently published book.

title: Louis Azrael, 77, a Journalist In Baltimore for Six Decades
description: Louis Azrael, a Baltimore journalist whose newspaper career spanned six decades, died today. He was 77 years old.

title: O.& M. Gets A.T.&T. Job
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has added another agency to those doing its direct marketing - Ogilvy & Mather Direct. The two assignments are in the WATS and Teleconferencing areas, both of which are aimed at the business community.

title: Theater Wing Awards Grants and Scholarships
description: Annual grants and scholarships to nurture talent have been conferred by the American Theater Wing to recognize commitment to the theater, training of drama school students and creating audiences through its school and hospital program, according to Isabelle Stevenson, the nonprofit organization's president.

title: Hong Kong Economy
description: Hong Kong should achieve economic growth this year of about 7 percent in real terms, Gov. Murray MacLehose said today. In a meeting of the Hong Kong Exporters Association, Governor MacLehose said that he would be surprised if the economy did not continue to show rapid growth in 1982, with continued full employment.

title: Swiss Plan to Vote On U.N. Membership
description: After more than 30 years of hesitation, the Swiss Government decided today to ask Parliament to agree to Switzerland's entry into the United Nations.

title: PRESIDENT WEIGHS STEPS ON POLAND
description: President Reagan conferred with the National Security Council today on imposing sanctions against Poland and the Soviet Union if martial law in Poland is not eased soon, Administration officials said.

title: Martin Goodman, 46, Head of Toronto Star
description: Martin Goodman, president of Toronto Star Newspapers Ltd., which publishes Canada's largest daily newspaper, died here last night of cancer. He was 46 years old.

title: NUCLEAR CHEATING: WHY THE EXPERTS ARE WORRIED OVER SAFEGUARDS
description: CAN the international ''safeguards'' system insure that civilian nuclear facilities and fuels are used solely for peaceful purposes? That question has provoked sharp debate among technical experts in the seven months since Israel declared its own lack of confidence in the system by attacking an Iraqi research reactor that was under safeguards.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE Withdrawn Generation finally came out last week, and it was good to see them again even if they did look as though they hadn't slept for three weeks. A cliquish group of artists and fashion designers aged 20 to 40, they live in the remotest sections of SoHo - and are not living terribly well. Still, about 200 of them turned up at the opening of a new store at 325 Spring Street called the White Columns Christmas Store, where Sophie VDT held a fashion show to celebrate.

title: Executive Changes Set At Harwood Companies
description: Michael Rothbaum, 46, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Harwood Companies Inc., a manufacturer of men's, women's and boys' apparel based in New York, effective Jan. 1. He will succeed Seymour A. Marrow, 68, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: WHEN one thinks of the dangers of alcohol it is almost always as the chronic syndrome called alcoholism, a gradual and often obvious destruction of the organs of the body. But alcohol can be deadly in abrupt and in subtle ways, too.

title: French Union Calls a Strike
description: The Communist-led C.G.T. union called on port workers throughout France today to stop work Wednesday to back demands over working conditions. The union, which represents nearly all dockworkers and other port workers, is demanding a five-hour, 50-minute working day and retirement at 55 on 75 percent of gross salary.

title: Roy F. Duke Sr., Ex-president Of Largest Jersey Bank, Dead
description: Roy F. Duke Sr., a former president of the Fidelity Union Trust Company of Newark, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. He was 86 years old and a resident of Short Hills, N.J.

title: Venezuelan Oil Output
description: Crude oil production in Venezuela averaged 2,100,000 barrels a day through Dec. 16 this year, the Energy and Mines Ministry said in its latest weekly newsletter, released today.

title: PAKISTAN AWAITS INDIA'S 'POSITIVE RESPONSE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Body Found in Lynn Rubble
description: The body of Karl E. Stolle, 53 years old, a foreman who had led firefighters to a factory fire, was found Sunday in the rubble of the building, the police said. Crews had searched for him since Friday, when a fire tore through the Lynn Plastics Company factory, less than a mile from the area devastated by fire last month.

title: Chase Challenges Income Tax Study
description: Chase Manhattan Bank has disputed a private analyst's conclusion that the bank paid no Federal income tax in 1980.

title: A Sobering Reminder From Connecticut
description: News that Connecticut's Gov. William O'Neill is home from the hospital and recuperating well from open-heart surgery is welcome indeed. But it hardly settles a serious issue for Connecticut and other states, including New York: the inadequacy of state succession procedures.

title: TIGHTENED LUNCH RULES GO INTO EFFECT IN SCHOOLS
description: Requirements that restrict the number of children who are eligible to receive free or reduced-price hot lunches in schools went into effect yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Cincinnati Tops Bradley In Record 7 Overtimes

title: Two Common Market Bodies In Dispute on Budget Powers
description: A budget approved by the European Parliament for the European Common Market was declared adopted today despite opposition by the Market's Council of Ministers.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT BLOCKS RELEASE OF 300 FROM PRISONS IN ALABAMA
description: A Federal appeals court today prevented the mass release of more than 300 convicts from Alabama's crowded prisons before Christmas by staying indefinitely a district judge's order.

title: Australia Car Quota Easing
description: The Australian Government said today that it will begin relaxing import restrictions on new cars in 1985.

title: Market Place; Interstate Ties Among Banks
description: IN theory, interstate banking would lead smaller banks to make alliances with larger out-of-state banks so that smaller banks and their local economies could become stronger.

title: No Headline
description: With the National Football League standings nearly set, the Giants opponents have been determined for next season although the dates are not yet settled. The opponents are as follows:

title: Bolivia Asks Debt Time
description: Bolivia has asked private banks involved in its debt rescheduling for an additional 90 days, until April 16, to reach agreement with the International Monetary Fund on a new credit facility, bankers said. Agreement with the fund was a condition of Bolivia's $440 million debt rescheduling with the banks in April.

title: 2 Soviet Dissidents Transferred to Prisons
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky and Yuri F. Orlov, two dissident activists serving long sentences, have been transferred from labor camps to prisons after disputes with camp authorities, friends and relatives said today.

title: TV: AFTER 46 YEARS IN AN ISTITUTION
description: ''BILL,'' another of television's based-on-a-true-story exercises, can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS-TV. Being a ''G.E. Theater'' presentation, the movie can automatically be expected to provide a good deal of uplift and warm afterglow. On that score, ''Bill'' delivers generously.

title: Brazilian Oil Discovery
description: A group of oil companies led by the Shell Oil Company's Pecten Brazil unit has struck oil in a well that Brazilian officials said could eventually produce between 8,000 and 28,000 barrels a day.

title: 7 Gambians Sentenced To Death Over Coup
description: Seven Gambians were sentenced to death today for their part in the attempt to overthrow Gambia's President, Sir Dawda Kairaba Jawara, last July.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MIDWEST BANKS PROPOSE LINK TO MONEY MARKETS
description: An organization representing commercial banks in 13 Middle Western states announced plans today for a financial management account that would link savings and checking accounts with a money market fund.

title: Spanish Utility Attacked
description: One electric pylon was toppled and another was damaged with plastic explosives early today in an attack against a utility company that is building a disputed nuclear power plant.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Re-Insurance Co. has appointed Edward B. Jobe a senior vice president.

title: KEAN BACKS RAISES FOR CABINET MEMBERS IN JERSEY
description: Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean said today that he would accept a $100,000 salary, a raise of $35,000, to make possible salary increases for other cabinet appointees.

title: WARSAW CONFIRMS 2 MINES HOLD OUT
description: The following article is based on information arriving from Poland. The following article is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: HUGE DEFICITS TROUBLE CONSERVATIVES TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: BRINK'S INQUIRY SEIZES FUGITIVE FROM CALIFORNIA
description: Investigators pursuing the Brink's armored-car holdup on Oct. 20 are looking into whether a woman arrested Saturday in Manhattan on unrelated murder and mail-fraud charges played a role in the Rockland County robbery.

title: PACIFIC TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
M.W. Kellogg
description: The M.W. Kellogg Company said it had a contract to design a $4 million fertilizer granulation plant for Bangladesh Chemical Industries. The plant will granulate triple superphosphate fertilizer produced in Bangladesh. Dutch development aid has been allocated for the project, which will be designed by Kellogg Continental, Netherlands, and built by the Hollandse Construction Group, using technology licensed by Stamicarbon, a subsidiary of Dutch State Mines.

title: KEEPING TELEVISION REGULATED
description: ''Full First Amendment rights'' has become the battle cry of the television industry, a cry to which the Federal Communications Commission lent its voice recently when it urged Congress to remove the two cornerstones of broadcast regulation:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BIG SING

title: No Headline
description: EXPOLSION LEVELS ALABAMA LAUNDRY

title: No Headline
description: Most of the Buffalo Bills are not happy about opening the playoffs at Shea Stadium, and none is more outspoken than the linebacker Jim Haslett, who says he dislikes not only Shea but also the stadium's home team.

title: No Headline
description: Strands of Christmas tinsel droop outside barren storefronts, abandoned by merchants who have watched their customers disappear. School enrollment is down 500 pupils from last year.

title: VOICES OF AMERICA LOSES KEY OFFICIAL
description: The director of the Voice of America's news division, a strong advocate of journalistic independence in the agency, resigned today.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HERE are three of them, two men who worked for former Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana and a woman who served in Jimmy Carter's State Department. Unlike many political ''outs'' in this town, they are more concerned with getting even than getting rich. Their cause is to make life difficult for conservative New Right organizations by holding them strictly accountable to the fine print and nuances of Federal laws and regulations that constitute something of a legal reef that can snag even the best lawyers.

title: CLEVETRUST REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $2,331,000 gain from the sale of real estate and $1,804,000 extraordinary tax credit...C-Including $858,000 gain from the sale of real estate and $389,000 tax credit

title: WHERE THE GOOD BUYS ARE IN HIGH-FASHION CLOTHES
description: Department stores' annual postholiday sales have turned into preholiday sales this year. Winter clothes are already reduced anywhere from 25 to 75 percent, and the sales will be expanded come Dec. 26, when they would customarily be just starting.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP 8.9 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose by 8.9 million shares, to 87.8 million, in the month ended Dec. 15.

title: Search for Neptune Rings
description: Shortly after Neptune was discovered in 1846, there were reports that the planet appeared to be surrounded by a ring of particles similar to the rings of Saturn though less spectacular. But these sightings could never be confirmed. Ever since the discoveries of rings around Uranus and Jupiter, however, astronomers have reconsidered the possibility and resumed the search for a ring around Neptune.

title: CITY WILL CONSIDER A PAID MARATHON
description: The question of whether to sanction prize money for next year's New York City Marathon will be discussed next month by city and race officials.

title: Begin to Reagan, Hostage to Hostage
description: The ugly row between Israel and the United States is not just about the ''annexed'' Golan Heights or the ''suspended'' memorandum of anti-Soviet cooperation. As is clear between the lines of Prime Minister Begin's intemperate name-calling, this is a resumption of the argument about the Palestinians and the West Bank. Mr. Begin and President Reagan evaded that issue when they met in September, and are paying the price of their irresponsibility.

title: Restarting of Reactor Not Expected Till March
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's staff estimated today that the undamaged Three Mile Island reactor could not be restarted until March at the earliest, even if some leaky tubes could be fixed promptly.

title: REAGAN CREATES SPECIAL PANEL ON EGUAL RIGHTS FOR WOMEN
description: President Reagan established a special panel today to work on eliminating discrimination against women in Federal and state laws and regulations. He appointed Carol E. Dinkins, an assistant United States Attorney General, to lead the group.

title: Knight-Ridder Pact Approved
description: Directors of Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. said they had approved an agreement to form a joint cable television venture. The joint venture will be called the TKR Cable Company.

title: Japan Stresses Domestic Growth
description: Japan today formally adopted its official outlook for the Japanese economy next year, placing far more reliance on domestic factors than on exports for its expected growth.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL MEETS EUROPEANS ON POLICY TOWARD POLISH CRISIS
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs, began consultations with the European allies of the United States today on a response to the situation in Poland.

title: 3 UNIONS ASSERT L.I.R.R. DETECTIVES TRAIL WORKERS
description: Three Long Island Rail Road unions charged today that for years the railroad had employed detectives to place employees under surveillance.

title: Airco Plant Plan
description: Airco Industrial Gases, a subsidiary of BOC International, said it planned to construct a $15 million, 465-tons-a-day atmospheric gases plant in the Columbia, S.C., area. The company said the new plant would produce liquid oxygen, nitrogen and argon. Completion is scheduled for the second quarter of 1984, according to Malcolm J. Matthews, president of the division.

title: Benefit for St. Mark's
description: More than 100 poets, dancers, musicians and others will appear in the St. Mark's Poetry Project's benefit Jan. 1 and 2 at the Ukrainian National Home Ballroom at 140 Second Avenue.

title: ONLY PSYCHIATRISTS CNA TREAT MIND AND
description: To the Editor:

title: EVENTS IN POLAND KEEPING BUSH BUSY
description: Two days ago, while President Reagan was relaxing at his residence in the White House, Vice President Bush was 100 yards away in the basement Situation Room in the West Wing, conferring about Poland with the Administration's top national security and intelligence officials.

title: Happy in Defeat
description: As one version of the old political saying goes: ''They never go back to Pocatello,'' meaning that once they have tasted the fruits of Washington, few former politicians move back to their home towns, be they Pocatello, Idaho, or Mitchell, S.D.

title: AUTO LABOR GROUPS AGREE TO CONSIDER REOPENING PACTS
description: The United Automobile Workers said today that its General Motors and Ford councils would meet on Jan. 8 in Chicago to consider reopening current labor contracts with the two big auto manufacturers.

title: Iran and Iraq Oil Sale Plans
description: Iran and Iraq, the two warring Arab oil-producing nations, have announced plans to sharply increase their oil exports, the authoritative Middle East Economic Survey reported today.

title: 122 Summonses In Garbage Strike
description: In an eight-day period during the strike by private garbage companies, the New York City Department of Sanitation issued 122 summonses for illegal dumping and impounded 18 vehicles, Commissioner Norman Steisel said.

title: No Headline
description: HEARINGS HELD ON BAN OF VIETNAM WAR BOOK

title: Military Analysis
description: There is nothing militarily spectacular about Forces Command headquarters here. Aside from the uniforms and two brass cannons at the entrance, this quiet building might be the home office of any major corporation. In a sense, that is what it is.

title: For Ex-Louisiana Governor, Mementos Lost
description: ''There's not a picture left, not a chair, a trophy, anything,'' former Gov. Jimmie Davis of Louisiana said yesterday from Baton Rouge as he described a fire that drove him and his wife, both in their 80's, from their home late Sunday. Neither was injured, but some of the items destroyed were priceless, Mr. Davis said.

title: People
description: * Don Thompson, an executive vice president of the J. Walter Thompson Company, has been elected to the board.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: B-Including $57,345,780 gain from the sale of a communications subsidiary

title: The Way It Was
description: For at least 20 years conditions for barnstorming black basketball players were a nightmare, according to Marques Haynes, the former Harlem Globetrotter star. Players slept on a jalopy bus because motels refused to rent them rooms.

title: Texaco Finds Gas In Gulf of Mexico
description: Texaco Inc. said it had made two significant natural gas discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico and was ordering production platforms for both sites.

title: No Headline
description: Wearing an orange knit hat, a brown sweater and heavy yellow rain pants to protect him from the damp, cold and snow that roll 200 miles across Lake Erie onto western New York State, Mike Kobiolka lugged a Christmas tree across his lot and waited for customers who, so far this season, have not showed up in encouraging numbers.

title: TURK SAYS GREECE IS INTRANSIGENT
description: Turkey's Prime Minister said today, in reply to attacks by the Prime Minister of Greece, that it was the Greeks who had refused to negotiate a solution to the problems between the two countries.

title: Doctor Won't Aid Tow- n That Paid for Education
description: A doctor whose medical school expenses were paid by local residents in need of a physician says he will not be moving to Cherokee after all. But he says that he would repay the town.

title: Talking Business with Brown of Brown-Forman; Flat Sales For Liquor
description: November and December are the critical months for the wine and spirits industry. The Christmas holiday season accounts for 20 to 27 percent of the industry's total sales each year. L. Lyons Brown Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, the only major liquor concern that has not diversified into other fields, talks about the current selling season, the industry's problems and future.

title: A Prince's Thoughts
description: Management lacks a sufficient understanding of the human factor in its dealings with employees, Prince Charles writes in the current issue of The Director, the monthly journal of Britain's Institute of Directors.

title: VIKING FANS ON RAMPAGE
description: Thousands of people looking for souvenirs swarmed over Metropolitan Stadium on Sunday, moments after the Kansas City Chiefs had beaten the Minnesota Vikings in the last game ever to be played there. The Vikings and baseball's Minnesota Twins are moving to a nearby domed stadium next year.

title: STAGE: RUSH'S 'ELEPHANTS' BY THE JEWISH REPERTORY
description: DAVID RUSH'S ''Elephants'' (at the Jewish Repertory Theater) is, at least for this month, about as far-fetched a play as one could imagine. An otherwise upstanding, aging janitor in a Chicago synagogue steals cocaine from a children's hospital. In order to finance a trip to Tel Aviv to visit his dying sister, he contrives to sell the drug with the help of a crazy bag lady.

title: Stocks Down Slightly on Rate Worries
description: The stock market, concerned that interest rates might start rising again, declined slightly yesterday in moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed down 2.66 points, to 873.10. In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered stocks that advanced in price by about a 9-to-5 ratio.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
HIGHLY DECORATED STATE TROPPER SLAIN ON I-80
description: A highly decorated New Jersey state trooper wearing a bulletproof vest was killed in a shootout yesterday afternoon on an isolated stretch of Interstate 80 near the Pennsylvania border.

title: AMERICAN VETERANS TREATED WARMLY IN A THREADBARE HANOI
description: Darkness falls quickly in Hanoi now, and by 6 P.M. the steets are silent except for the sound of bicycles wheeling lazily beneath the banyan and pines.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Deltec Panamerica has acquired an interest in Tri-Sell Mortgage Investments Inc. of 802,660 shares, or 18.2 percent, for about $3 million.

title: A STATE TAKEOVER OF HOME RELIEF IS STUDIED BY SENATE REPUBLICANS
description: The Republican majority in the State Senate, which last year resisted Governor Carey's proposal to have the state assume the local costs of the Medicaid program, is considering a series of counterproposals. They include a total state takeover of the home relief program.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt A MOTHER AND TWO DAUGHTERS. By Gail Godwin. 564 pages. Viking. $15.95.

title: NO VERDICT ON STARR
description: Bart Starr's future as coach of the Green Bay Packers remained undetermined yesterday when the team's 44 directors delayed action on whether to renew his contract.

title: Bridge: Greenberg Team Captures Regional Knockout Crown
description: At the conclusion of the Winter Regional Championships at the New York Hilton Hotel on Sunday night, a group headed by Alan Greenberg of New York won a hard-fought final match from John Lowenthal's team to take the knockout team title.

title: ECHLIN MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 20
description: Net income for the latest first qr includes a non-operating gain equal to 9 cents a shr from the sale of 60 percent of the company's Mexican subsidiary and sale of treasury bond futures

title: HUNGARIAN DISSIDENTS' TROUBLES
description: Budapest was the final stop in a three-week tour of Eastern Europe that I took before the crackdown in Poland. I met with dissidents in Prague, Belgrade, and Warsaw, many of whom I knew from previous visits. It was my first trip to Hungary, however, and I was not prepared for what I found.

title: General Mills' Net Off 8.6%
description: General Mills Inc. reported that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1982, ended Nov. 29, dropped 8.6 percent, to $77 million, or $1.53 a share, from $84.2 million, or $1.67 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 7.2 percent, to $1.49 billion, from $1.39 billion.

title: SOVIET PRESS DENIES ROLE OF KREMLIN IN THE CRISIS
description: The Soviet press today offered its first rebuttal of Western charges that the Kremlin was at least indirectly involved in the military crackdown in Poland.

title: U.S.-ISRAEL WAR OF WORDS
description: For months, Israeli officials have underestimated the depth of the Reagan Administration's anger and bitterness toward Prime Minister Menachem Begin and his actions.

title: MANY STATES INCREASING GASOLINE TAX
description: Deteriorating highways and dwindling Federal and state funds for road repair led 22 states to increase their gasoline taxes this year, nine for the first time in more than a decade.

title: The Fall and Rise Of New Year Globe
description: Times Square's globe - dimmed in honor of the Iranian hostages last year and headed for eclipse this year - will fall once more on New Year's Eve. Only this time it will be an apple.

title: No Headline
description: Podborski Takes Downhill Cup Race

title: Former Players Sue
description: Contending that they were subjected to illegal inducements to play football for Clemson University, James Coner and Terry Minor have brought a $12-million suit against Clemson's coach, Danny Ford; Billy Ware, a former Clemson recruiter; Tom Breazeale, a Knoxville business man and Clemson supporter, and the Atlantic Coast Conference and its commissioner, Bob James. As the suit was filed in the circuit court of Knox County, Tennessee, another was filed in Chancery Court against the Southeastern Conference and its commissioner, Boyd McWhorter.

title: MILITARY MEDICAL SCHOOL AIMS FOR CAREER-MINDED DOCTORS
description: BETHESDA, Md. IN a scene like something out of M*A*S*H, four figures outfitted in fatigues and combat boots crouched over the patient, working away furiously with a resuscitator and a cardiac monitoring unit.

title: Saturday Review Begins Cultural Cable Listings
description: With the March issue, Saturday Review will tip its hat in recognition of the new electronic technology by beginning to include a monthly department called Cultural Cable and Television Calendar.

title: U.S. PRESSES JAPAN ON MILITARY ROLE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger urged the Japanese today to acquire enough military power to defend their nation up to 1,000 miles offshore.

title: FRANKLIN'S TRADITION FADES OUT
description: Mention names like Pop Gates, Bobby Wanzer, Emilio (Zeke) Sinicola, Joe Galiber, Earl Manigault, Isaac (Rabbit) Walthour, Gary Springer and Bill Spiegel to Floyd Layne, the City College coach, and fond memories of basketball at Benjamin Franklin High School fill his thoughts.

title: JETS FEEL AT HOME FOR PLAYOFF GAME
description: ''It's going to be our field and our crowd,'' Richard Todd, the Jet quarterback, said with enthusiasm today. But a few months ago, smarting under an 0-3 record, the Jets didn't think of Shea Stadium and its noisy fans in terms of ''our.''

title: MR. REAGAN'S INSTINCT
description: The best and the worst of President Reagan's amiable spirit and relaxed approach to his office were displayed at his last news conference, in answers to two questions of high importance to American blacks.

title: DISSERVING TAXI RIDERS
description: TheNew York City Taxi and Limousine Commission's decision to continue the 50-cent per ride surcharge between the hours of 8 P.M. and 6 A.M. for fleet-owned taxicabs, effective Jan. 1, was based on distortions of data that obscure the profoundly anti-consumer character of the decision.

title: COMPLAINTS ON STEEL UPHELD
description: The International Trade Commission, in a unanimous preliminary finding today determined that imports of carbon steel plate from Belgium, Brazil and Rumania and carbon steel sheet from France may be causing material injury to domestic steelmakers through their sale in the United States at unfairly low prices.

title: John Henry Named Top Horse
