description: John Henry, who sold for $1,100 as an ill-bred, bad-tempered and crooked-legged yearling in 1976, yesterday was named the horse of the year.

title: LET'S STOP BUYING QADDAFI'S OIL
description: To the Editor:

title: White Motor Payment Plan
description: A Federal bankruptcy court judge has approved a plan for reorganizing the White Motor Credit Corporation, allowing the company to start paying back some $193 million in debt.

title: JOHN LOTZ, A LEADER IN THE DEENTRALIZING OF SCHOOLS IN 1960'S
description: John H. Lotz, a former member of the New York City Board of Education who was a leader of the school decentralization program in the late 1960's, died of cancer Sunday at the Sarasota (Fla.) Memorial Hospital.

title: DELAYED CONTRIBUTIONS MADE TO KEEP PROMISES TO NEEDIEST
description: Some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have written that they were making donations for the first time, often keeping previous promises to contribute when their financial circumstances improved.

title: 'INFRA-MAN' FROM HONG KONG, SCIENTISTS VS. MUTANTS
description: A WEEK'S worth of fiddling with the late-night television dial might never turn up a monster movie as deliciously awful as ''Infra-Man,'' which opens today at the Film Forum. ''Infra-Man,'' which was made in 1976 in Hong Kong, is a real find. It's terribly acted, amazingly perfunctory and populated by creatures - wicked mutants, supposedly - who are supposed to be scary but are dressed more or less like garden vegetables.

title: THE OCCURRENCE OF NITROSAMINES
description: It is not known for certain whether nitrites or nitrates, which are converted to nitrites by bacteri, are, by themselves, carcinogenic.

title: A MARRIGE THAT WILL SPEED U.S. MAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN DELAYS TAX-RISE MOVE UNTIL EARLY '82
description: President Reagan will not consider proposals for ''selective tax increases'' until early next year, his White House chief of staff said today. The move was a sign of the President's growing resistance to the urging of his advisers that he raise taxes to reduce budget deficits.

title: No Headline
description: Patriots Discharge 'Nice Guy' Erhardt

title: Warning Plan Dropped For Prescription Drugs
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it intended to drop plans to force drug manufacturers to give consumers cautionary leaflets when they received 10 commonly prescribed drugs.

title: Don Hogan Charles
description: FOR A WORTHY CAUSE: Jane Pickens Hoving, second from left, chairman of the Salvation Army's Greater New York advisory board, sang yesterday to help collect donations at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street. With her were Joan Fontaine, left, the actress, and two former Metropolitan Opera stars, Licia Albanese and Robert Merrill.

title: DURABLES ORDERS UP 1.1%
description: Orders for new durable goods from the nation's factories rose 1.1 percent last month, the Government said today, providing a faintly encouraging sign for the economy after three consecutive months of declines.

title: ITT Telex Offer
description: ITT World Communications Inc., will begin offering telex and other data transmission services next year to 71 cities in the United States, the same cities from which it now is offering international telephone services. ITT World currently is offering domestic telex service in New York State.

title: A.I.A.W. Tries Again To Halt N.C.A.A. Slate
description: The Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women renewed its legal efforts today to halt a National Collegiate Athletic Association women's championship program until its pending antitrust suit against the N.C.A.A. is heard.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: THERE are only two more days to the Christmas shopping deadline and if you haven't checked off every name on your list, don't panic. The worst of the crush in stores is over and there are still some ideas that don't involve worrying about sizes or colors. Herewith, some suggestions for those who've waited until the last minute. 1. A Bundle of Bangles Glass bangles made in China 90 years ago are to be had in a bevy of colors. You can give her an armful; they're only $1 each at Art Asia, 1088 Madison Avenue (between 81st and 82d Streets).

title: ARGENTINE LEADER SWEARS IN CABINET
description: The commander of the Argentine Army, Gen. Leopoldo F. Galtieri, took the oath of office as President today and swore in a Cabinet intended to pull the nation out of an economic slump.

title: CARROLS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After $15,153 loss for the qr and $227,209 income for the 6 mos from discontinued operations and tax credits of $195,000 for the qr and $688,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $27,390 for the qr and $239,869 for the 6 mos and tax credits of $264,000 for the qr and $936,000 for the 6 mos; yr-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations

title: KING INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $32,788 for the qr and $7,665 for the 6 mos

title: POLISH UNIONIST IN SWEDEN PREDICTS SOVIET INVASION
description: A leader of Solidarity, the Polish union movement, said here today that Soviet troops, backed by Czechoslovak forces, would invade Poland soon, possibly as early as the day after Christmas.

title: WILLIAM'S BRIBERY CONVICTION IS UPHELD
description: The bribery conviction of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. was upheld yesterday by a Federal judge. The judge, George C. Pratt, rejected the New Jersey Democrat's contention that he had been illegally entrapped and otherwise made a victim of the Government's Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: Union Plans Fouts Fight
description: The National Football League Players Association said today that it would file labor-relations charges Wednesday contending that the San Diego Chargers ignored the league's bargaining agreement with its players in the handling of a recent dispute involving their quarterback, Dan Fouts.

title: A CHRISTMAS POTPOURRI, WHITE HOUSE STYLE
description: Hundreds of poinsettias, 15 Christmas trees and dozens of tiny twinkling white lights have transformed the White House into a glittering fairyland for the President and Mrs. Reagan's first Christmas in Washington.

title: MUSIC: Y CHAMBER SYMPHONY
description: THE Y Chamber Symphony's program at the 92d Street Y on Sunday began at home in America, lingered a while in Mozart's Austria and then spent the rest of the afternoon in France. The ''Rhythmic Variations on Two Ancient Hymns'' by the late Howard Hanson was written four years ago, but this was the New York premiere.

title: Cylix Communications Elects a President
description: Ralph Johnson, 50, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Cylix Communications Network, a satellite data transmission network based in Memphis. He succeeds James Ziegler, 35, who was named to the new post of chairman of Cylix, a subsidiary of the Data Communications Corporation.

title: SILESIAN MINERS: BACKBONE OF RESTIVE LABOR
description: More than a year ago, when the Solidarity movement was at flood tide in Poland, some 300,000 workers at 30 Silesian coal mines struck to establish self-governing trade unions.

title: LAW ON GENERIC DRUGS UPHELD
description: The Court of Appeals, the state's highest, today unanimously upheld the constitutionality of the 1977 generic drug law, calling it a legitimate and safe way to cut the cost of health care.

title: CONCERT: PRO ARTE AND PIANIST
description: SATURDAY night's concert by the New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra at the Abraham Goodman House was centered, unfortunately, on the solo appearance of the Swiss pianist Evelyne Doubourg. In Mozart's Concerto for Piano and Strings (K. 449), Miss Dubourg wrestled unsuccessfully with Mozart's piano part, and Raffael Adler, the Pro Arte's conductor, could only limp along behind her trying to pick up the pieces created by Miss Dubourg's damaging memory slips and technical miscalculations.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After expenses of $46,000 on the sale of an investment and $104,000 tax credit...C-Including $1,333,000 gain on the sale of an investment and $354,000 tax credit

title: Doctor Pleads Not Guilty To DMSO Bribe Charge
description: Dr. Stanley W. Jacob, an advocate of the controversal drug DMSO who had a financial interest in a company that tested it, pleaded not guilty Monday to making payoffs to an official who approved its use on human beings.

title: McCann-Erickson Keeps Exxon U.S.A.
description: The executives of McCann-Erickson have been breathing sighs of relief since getting the news from Houston yesterday that that they have managed to keep the Exxon Company U.S.A., product advertising account, which may grow to its former multimillion-dollar glory now that gasoline advertising is reviving.

title: Index; International
description: In Siberia, a writer steps into the path of progress A2 Druse families still meet in Golan zone controlled by U.N. A3 Syrian leader flies to Saudi Ara- bia for talks A3 Brezhnev says he still favors meeting with Reagan A4 Salvadoran rebel leader appeals for arms aid A6 Polish regime to relax curfew for Christmas Eve mass A8 Vietnamese Foreign Minister welcomes U.S. war veterans A10 Around the World A11 Catholics in Northern Ireland bit- ter about house searches A11 Government/Politics Bell criticizes Federal rules on colleges A12 Council leaders say plan could lead to elections in spring B3 State agency orders Consolidated Edison refund of $40 million B3 Washington Talk Briefing B4 Embassy row B4 A look at past and present White House Christmases B4 An Administration official speaks for cities and states B4 Energy Panel asks proposed diesel pollu- tion limits be delayed D16 General Ex-Nazi loses citizenship but is al- lowed to stay in U.S. A14 Ex-C.I.A. agent's business associ- ate arrested in Texas A14 Around the Nation A14 Five-year, $7.9 billion transit im- provement plan is approved B7 Health/Science Generic drug law upheld by New York Court of Appeals B3 The Living Section Food The nitrite question: What can you eat? C1

title: STATE LOSES BID TO COURT TO EASE SHIFT OF INMATES
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that New York State must continue to transfer its prisoners from New York City jails to state prisons within 48 hours of completion of processing procedures.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM POPE JOHN PAUL II'S ADDRESS TO THE CARDINALS

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN SAYS MANY NEW DEALERS WANTED FASCISM

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MUSICA SACRA: 'MESSIAH'
description: HANDEL'S ''Messiah'' is as familiar a work as there is in classical music. And with the performance of anything so well known, a thin line should be trod between innovation and confirmation. If a performance is too eccentric, too bizarre, it will do violence to the work itself, as well as jarring a listener into annoyance. If it is too safe, the performance will quickly bore.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J. has appointed James L. Vincent group vice president of the corporation and president of its health and scientific products company.

title: DOUGHERTY BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been restated to give effect to a 10 percent stock divd paid Nov 16, 1981

title: NEW COUNCIL PLAN PRESSES FOR ELECTION
description: The leadership of the City Council, confident that the Justice Department had no objections to its new redistricting plan, yesterday set in motion a process that could lead to new Council elections by late spring.

title: RAMPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $162,000 gain on the sale of property

title: FINGERPRINTS ARE SAID TO TIE RADICAL TO TROOPER'S SLAYING
description: The state police said today that fingerprints linked a man they believed to be a member of an extremist group in New England with the murder Tuesday of a New Jersey state trooper.

title: PLAN TO IMPROVE TRANSIT RECEIVES FINAL APPROVAL
description: A five-year, $7.9 billion transit improvement plan, the most ambitious in the history of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, won final approval from a state review panel yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have seen a reference to something called lye corn, in which dried pellets of corn are soaked in a lye solution to bring them back to an edible state. Are you familiar with this technique?

title: News Analysis
description: State and local officials, in an unexpected show of unity, have taken a step toward achieving a new order of domestic government that the participants say has no precedent.

title: How Ideology Drowns Charity
description: Evidently there are limits to the Reagan Administration's enthusiasm for private charity. The President regularly promotes voluntary giving, but when it comes to letting Federal employees choose the beneficiaries, the Administration views some organizations more charitably than others.

title: Sun Life Assurance In U.S. Venture
description: Canada's largest life insurer, the Sun Life Assurance Company, said that it would pay an undisclosed amount of cash for a Massachusetts money management firm that founded the nation's first mutual fund in 1924.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $3.7 million or 17 cents a shr net gain from the sale of assets of Wilton Enterprises...C-Including $2.1 million or 10 cents a shr net gain from sale of technology for overseas development

title: RATE REQUEST FILED ON BELL TV-PHONE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company today filed the rate structure request for a television-conference service linking several cities. The service, intended mostly for businesses, is offered in some form by several other companies already.

title: Long in Developing, but Worth the Effort
description: She reaches back to grade school in Hempstead, L.I., for an illustration to describe how she felt when the new hit musical ''Dreamgirls'' opened on Broadway on Sunday night.

title: CON ED TO REFUND $40 MILLION
description: The State Public Service Commission said today that it would order the Consolidated Edison Company to refund about $40 million to 2.8 million customers. That is the amount the company collected in higher electricity rates after the shutdown last year of a nuclear power plant.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: IS there life after disco? Nile Rodgers and Bernard Edwards, who are known collectively as Chic, have been asking themselves that question. Mr. Rodgers and Mr. Edwards were among the most consistently successful disco hit-makers during the disco style's commercial heyday. Between 1977 and 1979 they placed high on the pop charts with ''Dance, Dance, Dance (Yowsah, Yowsah, Yowsah),'' ''Le Freak,'' ''I Want Your Love,'' ''Good Times'' and ''Everybody Dance,'' all sleek, apparently simple concoctions with catchy refrains, gently cushioning string arrangements and supple, infectious dance rhythms.

title: DRUSES' REUNIONS CONTINUE IN GOLAN
description: Despite increased tension concerning the Golan Heights, a group of Druses from the Israeli side met yesterday with relatives from Syria in the area controlled by the United Nations.

title: HARVESTER SAYS IT HAS DEBT ACCORD
description: The International Harvester Company said today that it expects to announce Wednesday the completion of its $4.15 billion debt restructuring program.

title: Fairness Action Filed Against CBS and NBC
description: The Democratic National Committee filed a complaint with the Federal Communication Commission today, objecting to two television networks' accepting Republican advertisements supporting President Reagan's economic program without providing contrasting views.

title: 4 Flee West Virginia Jail
description: A man being held on an escape charge and three other inmates who shared his cell dug a hole in the wall of the Berkeley County jail's shower room and escaped Monday, Sheriff William Kisner said today. The four men, termed ''not violent'' by Sheriff Kisner, were Jerome Minot, 20 years old, of Charles Town; Randy McBee, 27, of Berkeley Springs; Richard Stottler, 39, of Martinsburg, who was being held on an escape charge, and Leonard Fraley, 26, of Gerrardstown.

title: ROGERS CABLESYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: B-After $796,000 extraordinary loss...C-Including $3,678,000 extraordianry income; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: HANOI AIDE WELCOMES STUDY OF HERBICIDE IMPACT
description: Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach told visiting Americans on Monday that Vietnam would welcome specialists who wanted to study the impact of the herbicide Agent Orange used during the war.

title: Changes at Koch's City Hall
description: He had been an assistant United States attorney in Manhattan and the deputy commissioner and chief operating officer of the National Basketball Association. But yesterday, Simon P. Gourdine entered another court of experience.

title: Bert Jones Unhappy
description: Bert Jones, the Baltimore Colts' quarterback, said he planned to file with the N.F.L. Players Association a grievance against Robert Irsay, the owner.

title: OBOE: SCHUMANN BY HEE-SUN LEE
description: SUN LEE was not unmusical in his concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon. The Korean oboist often exhibited a sensitive way about the instrument.

title: Betty Prashker to Leave Doubleday for Crown
description: Betty Prashker, associate publisher and vice president of Doubleday, has been named vice president and editor in chief of Crown Publishers. Mrs. Prashker, who has been with Doubleday 21 years, will join Crown early next month. Crown is a division of the Crown Publishing Group, which includes Clarkson N. Potter Inc. and Harmony Books.

title: AMDISCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $90,000 or 11 cents a shr for the qr and $634,000 or 75 cents a shr for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $244,000 or 26 cents a shr for the qr and $6,247,000 or $4.8 a shr for the yr and $636,000 or 49 cents a shr extraordinary tax credit for the yr

title: Making Coal Pay for Itself
description: There's hardly a port in the United States that doesn't hope to profit from coal exports. To qualify as a coal port, however, a harbor must accommodate ships drawing 50 feet of water, a prescription that no American port now fills. The cost of meeting that standard can run $300 million per port. Who should pay?

title: WINE Q&A
description: Q. I have been told that there is a wine with the name of Kirwan. Can you tell me something about this wine and where may I buy it? James P. Kirwan, Manhattan.

title: HAMILTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COAST JURY WILL GET CASE MONDAY
description: The two-month prosecution of William Bonin ended today with a prosecutor imploring that the accused ''freeway killer'' be given ''what he has earned - convictions in 12 murders of young men and boys.''

title: More Rebates By Chrysler
description: Chrysler Corporation will continue offering rebates on some of its cars and trucks for two months after its current rebate program is scheduled to expire Dec. 31, the auto maker said today.

title: Cardinal Cody in Hospital
description: John Cardinal Cody, the embattled Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, was admitted to Northwestern Memorial Hospital today, the archdiocese said. Spokesmen for the Cardinal, who is the subject of a Federal investigation into his handling of church funds, would not say why he had been hospitalized.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: YOU see the adjective often in articles about food: silken. It's a way of describing a dish that has somehow transcended the notion of smoothness so utterly that it demands a word to convey the sensation of tasting it.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 6
description: Revs for the latest qr and 6 mos include LTM Inc and subsidiaries since their acquisition in Oct; revs include pretax capital gains of $1,186,000 for the latest 6 mos and $2,149,000 for the yr ago 6 mos; yr-ago shrs outstndg have been adjusted for subsequent stock distributions

title: Banks Said to Reject Polish Bid for Loan
description: Western banks have decided to reject Poland's request for a new $350 million loan to enable it to pay the interest outstanding on its debts at the end of this year, banking sources said today.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES DIESEL LIMIT
description: A report issued today by the National Academy of Sciences questions whether automobile makers can meet the strict Federal pollution ceiling for diesel cars and light trucks proposed for 1985.

title: REGIME TO EASE THE CURFEW FOR MASS ON CHRISTMAS EVE
description: The Warsaw radio reported today that a nationwide curfew would be lifted on the night of Dec. 24-25 so people could attend midnight mass on Christmas Eve.

title: Continental Ratings Cut
description: Two leading debt-rating services said yesterday that they had downgraded a debt issue of Continental Air Lines Inc., citing the airline's financial problems.

title: DAYTON (6-1) BEATS IONA (7-3) BY 83-78
description: Iona was not in the ideal situation for playing a game. A 13-hour, three-stop, red-eye flight back from San Francisco got the players home at 2 P.M. Monday, just in time for some of them to catch up on studies and take final examinations this morning.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings reflect 100 percent stock divd paid in May 1981

title: Space, Time and Architecture; Spock Market
description: Liz Smith reports in The Daily News that Paramount Pictures has filmed the death of Mr. Spock, the emotionless First Officer of Starship Enterprise.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE of the most important health decisions you'll ever make is the choice of a man or woman to oversee your medical care. Most Americans devote more time and thought to buying a new car than to selecting the physician they will depend on to keep them alive and well. Even those who do some searching around before they decide on a doctor often use the wrong criteria, and, as a result, some end up with a ''lemon.''

title: SYRIAN PRESIDENT VISITS SAUDIS
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria flew to Saudi Arabia today in the first stop of a tour of the Arabian Peninsula to work out a common Arab strategy in response to Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: NO MERE KID STUFF

title: Bridge:; The Day Lightner Held Off On Trying for Slam Double
description: The world of bridge lost one of its greatest figures last month when Theodore Lightner died at the age of 88. Lightner was one of the last surviving links with the earliest days of contract bridge. Half a century ago, he played as partner to Ely Culbertson most effectively during a key phase of the celebrated Culbertson-Lenz match, and he was Culbertson's regular teammate in international challenge matches in England and France.

title: Air Controllers' Grades Were Altered, Panel Says
description: A staff report by a House committee said today that ''there is absolutely no doubt that grades were changed'' on tests given air traffic controller trainees at the Federal Aviation Administration Academy in Oklahoma City.

title: Goodbye, Northwestern
description: With Northwestern having lost 31 consecutive football games, Jim Browne, the team's leading rusher and receiver, sees no future in staying there.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article Monday on a trend to disarm private security guards incorrectly reported a statement by John Horan, head of the Committee of National Security Companies Inc. Mr. Horan said no more than 10 per cent of the guards employed by the large national companies associated with his committee were now armed.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DONOVAN CALLS FOR SPECIAL PROSECUTOR ON HIS CASE ,
description: Raymond J. Donovan, the Secretary of Labor, asked today for the appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate assertions that an official of a company he was associated with passed a bribe to a union official in his presence in 1977.

title: Accountant at Helm Of Vitt Media Service
description: There was a bit of surprise in the advertising community when it was announced that Roy A. Muro, the new president and chief operating officer of Vitt Media International, a buying service, is by training an accountant. Mr. Muro, however, is not surprised.

title: Robert W. Potter Dead at 85; A Former Reporter for Times
description: Robert W. Potter, a reporter and editor at The New York Times for 30 years until his retirement in 1965, died Monday at the White Plains Hospital Medical Center. He was 85 years old and had lived in White Plains for 44 years.

title: Greece Plans a Bill Absolving All Violators of the Press Law
description: The Greek Government said today that it would soon introduce a bill in Parliament absolving all people charged with or convicted of having violated press laws, as well as those facing up to a year's imprisonment for minor offenses.

title: RAGEN PRECISION INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After losses of $640,000 for the qr and approximately $1 million for the yr on a long-term government contract for information systems, both of which include an inventory writedown and a reserve to cover 1982 costs estimated to complete the contract...C-After losses of $334,000 for the qr and $426,000 for the yr on a long-term government contract.. D-Net income

title: BREZHNEV BACKS SUMMIT TALKS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, was quoted today as having said that he favored a meeting with President Reagan as the best means of reviving high-level contacts with the United States.

title: After the Fall
description: As blame was being widely distributed in the wake of the Cleveland Browns' 5-11 record, Brian Sipe, the quarterback, swiftly defended Coach Sam Rutigliano, saying that it was complacency among players that was responsible. ''Instead of looking around the front office for a scapegoat, the fans should look around the bars where the players were enjoying their 1980 prestige,'' he said.

title: News Analysis
description: In the last few days, there were about 350 people on the street in Hamburg to protest the killings, arrests, and marshal law in Poland. Karlsruhe and Saarbrucken had about 100 protestors each. The numbers reached

title: MONITOR SALVADOR'S BORDER
description: The killing in El Salvador is spilling northward across the border into neighboring Honduras with increasing and alarming frequency. The targets are Salvadoran refugees, relief workers, and Honduran civilians.

title: Firestone Stock Purchases Set
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said the Loew's Corporation had announced its intention of buying up to 15 percent of Firestone's voting securities and that Firestone intends to buy up five million shares of its common stock in the open market.

title: New TV Pact for N.B.A.
description: The National Basketball Association has reached agreement with CBS on a four-year contract to television rights, effective next season. The agreement, announced yesterday by Commissioner Larry O'Brien, provides telecast rights to the All-Star game, selected regularseason games and the playoffs.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, the welterweight champion, was named sportsman of the year by Sports Illustrated magazine. . . . Gerry Cooney, the top heavyweight contender who will challenge Larry Holmes next March, will fight a four-round exhibition match against Joe Bugner Jan. 16 at the Westbury Music Fair for the benefit of the Lupus Foundation of Long Island. Cooney will also fight two three-round exhibitions against opponents to be named. . . . The Athletics Conference, the country's governing body for track and field, reinstated four road runners who had been suspended for accepting prize money on June 28 at the Cascade Run-Off in Portland, Ore.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: The company said yr-end adjustments added 21 cents a shr to net income

title: VIEW FROM THE SUPPLY SIDE
description: In the battle for the President's ear, Representative Jack F. Kemp of upstate New York, chairman of the House Republican Conference, has been in the forefront of those urging President Reagan to reject advice that he include revenue-raising measures in the 1983 budget, now being prepared. Mr. Kemp was prominent among the original sponsors of a three-year, across-theboard cut in tax rates, enacted in August as the heart of the President's program.

title: Appeal Is Filed On St. Bart's Vote
description: A committee of parishioners opposed to a plan to build a 59-story office tower next to St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church filed an appeal seeking to void a Dec. 18 vote that approved the proposal.

title: Cathlyn Wilkerson Freed From Prison
description: Cathlyn Wilkerson, the member of the Weather Underground radical organization who was sentenced in connection with a deadly explosion at a Greenwich Village ''bomb factory,'' was freed by a State Supreme Court justice after less than a year in prison.

title: Gasoline Tax Rise Proposed
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis formally proposed today that the Federal gasoline tax be raised to 9 cents a gallon from 4 cents.

title: Golf Life Pleases Pat Sheehan
description: When a photographer summoned Pat Sheehan, the Ladies' Professional Golf Association rookie of the year, to a frosty patch of Central Park last week, she scampered outside without a coat. ''Where I come from,'' Miss Sheehan said as her fellow golfers shivered inside their furs, ''it's really cold.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said its West German unit, Aluminiumwerke, would acquire 95 percent of the shares of a newly formed company that will take over three divisions of Ohler Eisenwerk Theob Pfeiffer. The action will take effect Jan. 1. Terms were not disclosed.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
A TELLER IS FOUND SLAIN IN HER AUTO IN HUDSON
description: A 23-year-old bank teller from Spring Valley, N.Y., was found shot to death yesterday in a car partially submerged in the Hudson River off 38th Street in Manhattan, the police reported.

title: Silesia; Geography
description: Silesia is an region of 15,000 square miles in southwest Poland, drained by the Oder River. Aside from the Sudeten Mountains along the Czechoslovak border, the region consists of Lower Silesia, a rolling plain of fertile land centered on Wroclaw, the former German Breslau, and industrial Upper Silesia, on the river's upper reaches, with its center at Katowice. Economy Since the Industrial Revolution of the late 18th and the 19th century, Silesia has emerged as one of Europe's most important industrial regions, and its people have turned to textile, glass and chemical industries. In Upper Silesia, coal has been undisputed king. With thick seams over an area of 2,300 square miles, Upper Silesia is one of the world's great basins of high-grade bituminous coal. Because coal is a prime means of attracting foreign exchange, mining has been expanded under Communist rule. In 1946, 47 million tons of coal were extracted; last year, 193 million. The coal provides fuel for power stations, coke for the iron and steel industry and raw material for chemicals. Other parts of Silesia yield the lower-grade coal known as lignite, and copper has been

title: EX-NAZI SS OFFICER LOSES CITIZENSHIP BUT IS ALLOWED TO STAY IN U.S.
description: A Federal court today stripped United States citizenship from a former Nazi SS captain who served as an adviser to Adolf Eichmann, but the court allowed him to stay in the United States because he suffers from an incurable ''progressive neurological condition.''

title: FLORIDA CYPRESS GARDENS INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $332,781 for 1981 and $155,061 for 1980; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: DAVID B. STARR
description: David B. Starr, president and founder of the Anglo-American Capital Management Corporation of Manhattan, died Friday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: EMBASSY ROW
description: For the Polish Embassy in Washington, this last week has been a painful one, culminating in the defection of a distinguished Ambassador, Romuald Spasowski.

title: DOGS CAN SNIFF FOR DRUGS IN LUGGAGE, COURT SAYS
description: The use of dogs specially trained to detect contraband in an airline passenger's luggage is not a ''search'' requiring a warrant, the New York Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

title: Ballot Recount Shows Kean and Florio Gain
description: TRENTON Dec. 22 - The final order terminating the recount of 2.3 million votes cast in the Nov. 3 election was released today by the Administrative Office of the Courts.

title: IMC MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Pillsbury Profit Advances 16%
description: The Pillsbury Company today reported a 16 percent earnings increase on a 2.6 percent rise in sales in the second quarter of its fiscal year.

title: LOBBYING AGAINST A.T.&T.
description: Some of America's big corporations are contributing to a multimillion-dollar lobbying fund to push for passage of a telecommunications bill that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company finds too restrictive.

title: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After $269,000 extraordinary charge from the settlement of a lawsuit

title: No Headline
description: Wilbert Montgomery, the Eagles' best running back, has accused the Giants of playing ''dirty ball,'' a charge that the Giants deny.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By David McCullough THE SKYSCRAPER. By Paul Goldberger. Illustrated. 180 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: THE CABLE-TV SCRAMBLE
description: ''GREAT movies are just the beginning.'' That is the new advertising slogan for Home Box Office, the most News Analysis successful of cable television networks. But it also sums up the hopes -and captures the dilemma - of an industry that is evolving at a dizzying pace.

title: 51 NATIONS REACH PACT ON TEXTILES
description: The legal framework governing textile trade agreements between developing nations and the industrialized countries will be extended five years and the industrial nations will have more room to negotiate reduced import levels, under the terms of an accord reached here today by 51 nations.

title: CAVCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Fitting the Crime
description: Embattled RKO General, the broadcast subsidiary of General Tire and Rubber Co. and owner of New York's WOR-TV, can relax a little. Last year, the Federal Communications Commission found the company unfit to broadcast in New York, Boston and Los Angeles because of questionable trade agreements with advertisers and a lack of candor about overseas bribery troubles.

title: THE NITRITE QUESTION: WHAT CAN YOU EAT?
description: THE controversy surrounding nitrites, which began in the early 70's with reports that the chemicals, used to cure processed meats, might cause cancer, was rekindled by a recent report of the National Academy of Sciences. The report said that nitrites in cured meats account for ''only a small proportion of the total exposure to nitrosamines,'' a suspected cancer-causing agent, and that eliminating them ''would not have a major effect on the risk'' of cancer during a lifetime.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $152,000 for the qr and $522,000 for the yr

title: PACESETTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about the awards of the New York Film Critics Circle omitted the name of one member.

title: MILLIKEN TO QUIT POLITICS AT END OF HIS TERM IN '82
description: Gov. William G. Milliken said today he would retire from politics when his current term ended next year. By then, he will have been Governor for 14 years, the longest time in the state's history.

title: REAGAN SEES POLE WHO HAS DEFECTED
description: President Reagan held an emotional meeting today with the former Polish ambassador, who defected to the United States Sunday. And the Administration continued to discuss a range of political and economic sanctions against the Polish military Government and the Soviet Union in response to the crackdown in Poland.

title: THE OLD AND NEW JERUSALEM
description: Relations between the United States and Israel are in deep trouble these days because they are so personal. They have forgotten the old and new Jerusalem. Washington has almost given up on Prime Minister Begin, believing he will not trade territory for peace with the Palestinians. And Mr. Begin clearly believes that there is a conspiracy here in Washington to forget the old U.S.- Israeli alliance and put the security of Israel in jeopardy.

title: Sanitation Dept.  Profited in Strike
description: New York City turned a profit of $532,000 in the recent 17-day strike by private sanitation workers, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the Sanitation Department.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1981; The Economy
description: The Consumer Price Index rose 0.5 percent in November, making it likely that the 1981 inflation rate will be under 10 percent for the first time since 1978. The slowing of inflation results from the recession and from moderating price increases for food, housing and energy. (Page A1.) The index for New York and Northeastern New Jersey edged downward by 0.1 percent. (D5.)

title: COSTLIER JAPANESE CARS LINKED TO EXPORT CURB
description: The auto export restraints that the Japanese adopted earlier this year, at the urging of the Reagan Administration, apparently have resulted in higher prices for Japanese cars sold in the United States, a House trade subcommittee said today.

title: TWO POLISH ACTIVISTS, IN NEW YORK, REPORT EXTENSIVE RESISTANCE
description: Two members of the Polish labor union Solidarity said in New York yesterday that they had received information indicating that the resistance to martial law in Poland had been far greater than the Polish Government had reported.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 5-2, FOR FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: The New York Islanders skated to their fifth straight victory tonight and conceded most of the credit to their scrambling center, John Tonelli.

title: TOWN MAY FIGHT WATER RATES
description: The Town of Greenwich, which is doing battle for its residents with a water company, is considering spending $30,000 for a legal fight against a $1,836,000 annual increase in water rates.

title: CHRISTMAS SPIRIT-ON THE FAMILY PLAN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Harriet McMurray, a wife and a mother of seven children, lives in Hinton, W. Va. By HARRIET McMURRAY

title: Socialist Will Attempt To Form Danish Cabinet
description: COPENHAGEN, Dec. 22 (Reuters) Anker Jorgensen, Denmark's caretaker Prime Minister and Social Democratic Party leader, said today that he had accepted Queen Margrethe's request that he try to form a new minority government.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All in all, we're very pleased with this first year. We would be happy with a second one just like it.'' - James A. Baker 3d, White House chief of staff. (D5:1)

title: Britain to Aid BL
description: The British Government agreed today to finance a $1.9 billion recovery plan for the state-controlled BL Ltd. auto company until the end of the 1983 fiscal year. The Minister of Industry, Norman Lamont, announced the support in Parliament following a review of the struggling auto maker's recent performance and prospects.

title: Suez Oil Well Results
description: Tests on an oil discovery in the Gulf of Suez have proved it is commercial, a group of oil companies said. The group, composed of Deminex of West Germany, the British Petroleum Company and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said extensive tests had been carried on three recently drilled discovery wells, one of which yielded 6,000 barrels a day from two formations. The group said several additional wells would be drilled in the concession area at the southern end of the Gulf of Suez.

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JOHN ARTIS RELEASED
description: After almost serving 15 years of his prison sentence, John Artis was released from Rahway State Prison. Convicted along with Rubin (Hurricane) Carter in the shotgun slayings of a bartender and two patrons in a Paterson tavern on June 17, 1966, Mr. Artis said as he left prison ''I feel alive again.'' Mr. Carter, who is serving two consecutive life sentences, cannot be eligible for parole for 15 years.

title: DESPITE PROBLEMS IN NICARAGUA, JUSTICE PREVAILS
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT THE SYRIANS ARE WAITING FOR
description: To the Editor:

title: O.E.C.D. Forecast On Growth Dimmer
description: Most industrialized countries should experience modest economic growth next year, while the United States remains mired in recession, according to the semiannual economic report of the organization that gathers statistics on the industrialized nations.

title: U.S. GENERAL'S BODY TO BE FOUND SOON, CALLER TELLS ITALIANS
description: An anonymous telephone caller in Beirut, Lebanon, was quoted as saying today that the American general abducted in Verona, Italy, last Thursday had been condemned to death and that his body would be found shortly.

title: Silent Protest in Norway
description: Hundreds of thousands of Norwegians observed five minutes of silence today to show support for workers in Poland. All Government officials stopped work at midday and the Norwegian radio stopped broadcasting.

title: PRICE INDEX DROPS IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The Consumer Price Index for the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area edged downward by one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: TREASURY BOND YIELDS RISE
description: Yields for Treasury notes and bonds rose yesterday as securities dealers cut prices by a point or more in an effort to attract investors to new four-year Treasury notes as well as to an upcoming sale of seven- and 20-year Treasury issues.

title: THEATER: 'TWELVE DREAMS,' OF THE FREUD-JUNG SPLIT
description: ''THINK of Jung, think of Freud,'' sings the psychiatrist in William Finn's musical ''March of the Falsettos.'' James Lapine, the director of that musical, has taken Mr. Finn's lyric to heart in his new play at the Public. ''Twelve Dreams,'' which Mr. Lapine has both written and directed, is nothing less than an exploration of this century's great schism in psychoanalytic theory. And it's such an imaginative - and well-produced -effort that one hates to say that it ultimately falls short.

title: Economic Scene; Mixing Oil And Politics
description: THE general public's attitude toward the Exxon Corporation is perhaps summarized by a T-shirt being marketed by an anti-oil industry group. The shirt says: ''We don't care. We don't have to care. We're Exxon.''

title: Coal Liquefaction Test Results
description: McLEAN, Va., Dec. 22 (UPI)- The Dynalectron Corporation said its proprietary H-coal liquefaction process had passed a series of critical tests at the pilot plant at Catlettsburg, Ky., operated by a subsidiary of the Ashland Oil Company under a Department of Energy contract.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A SHORT while ago a guest in my home dined on a fairly complicated scallop dish made with sliced mushrooms, chopped parsley and a sort of snail butter, all sprinkled with bread crumbs and baked in the oven. She acknowledged that she liked the dish well enough, but she asked, ''Why do you go to all that bother when scallops are so incredibly good if you simply bake them?''

title: Grounding of Soviet Sub Cost Sweden $960,000
description: The grounding of a Soviet submarine on the Swedish coast in late October cost Sweden $960,000 in surveillance and salvage operations, the defense staff said today.

title: THE SEASONING OF A THREE-STAR CHEF
description: IN my early days as a restaurant historian of sorts, I innocently presumed that all the great eating places of Europe had been there since antiquity, operating from generation to generation as family enterprises. I quickly discovered otherwise.

title: A TREASURY OF DICKENS'S DRINK RECIPES
description: ''THERE is nothing in the world so irresistibly contagious as laughter and good humor,'' observed Charles Dickens in ''A Christmas Carol.'' It is Cedric Dickens's favorite line in the writings of his great-grandfather, and it expresses an outlook on life that he has always pursued with zest.

title: A Mother and Her Son, 3, Die In Cobble Hill Tenement Fire
description: A mother and her 3-year-old son died last night when an electrical fire swept through their Brooklyn apartment building, trapping them in a hallway.

title: Advertising; Finding Talent Is Not Easy
description: LOUIS A. MAGNANI, the president of Marsteller, has found a general manager for the Pittsburgh office and a creative director for Los Angeles, but after three months and 30 interviews he has yet to fill the post of top creative director in the agency's largest office - New York.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
CALIFORNIA BUSINESSMAN IS IN LINE FOR FED POST
description: Preston Martin, a California businessman and former public official who served as the state's savings and loan commissioner under Ronald Reagan, will be nominated to be vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the White House disclosed today.

title: CHRISTMASTIME MOVIE BUSINESS: THE AGONY AND THE EXPENSE
description: Paramount's $33 million ''Reds'' is doing poorly at the box office. Universal's ''On Golden Pond'' is doing splendidly. Some Hollywood experts feel that both movies have been marketed improperly.

title: SALVADORAN REBEL LEADER APPEALS FOR WEAPONS TO COUNTER U.S. AID
description: Arguing that many rebel units are still poorly armed, El Salvador's top guerrilla commander has appealed to ''the peoples of the world'' for weapons to counter American military assistance to the Salvadoran junta.

title: BRIEFING ,
description: A S closely as the Washington community has tried to follow the Polish crisis, it has been difficult for many individuals to find a clear way to express themselves on the anxious topic. But the unionized workers at the consulate and chancery of France quietly walked off their jobs for an hour Monday, joining a sympathy strike declared by French workers back home to honor the people of Poland. They left their desks here and stood in the corridors for the hour, then returned immediately to work, according to the chancery office. At least a few, however, turned the occasion into an extra-long lunch hour, with time enough to toast Solidarity.

title: 39 POLES QUIT SHIPS AT PORT IN AFRICA
description: Thirty-nine Polish seamen from a fishing fleet docked at Walvis Bay in South-West Africa have jumped ship and asked for political asylum in South Africa, the South African Interior Minister, J. Chris Heunis, said yesterday.

title: Coors Sues Rights Group It Says Linked It to Klan
description: The Adolph Coors Company has filed a suit against a civil rights group that the company contends subjected it to ''ridicule, disgrace, odium and contempt'' by linking the brewery to the Ku Klux Klan.

title: CATHOLICS REASSESS BELIEFS ON WAR IN NUCLEAR AGE
description: Statements and appeals from bishops, priests, nuns and lay people have provoked a debate in the American Roman Catholic hierarchy over the morality of the stance of the United States and the Soviet Union on nuclear arms.

title: BILLS AROUSE WARD'S ANGER
description: When Chris Ward, the Jets' left tackle on offense, is frustrated, he seethes. On the sideline he has often been consoled by his more composed counterpart at right tackle, Marvin Powell.

title: MUSIC: RENAISSANCE, BAROQUE
description: IN recent years the sacbut and the viol have proliferated on our concert stages; ''early'' music may even be in danger of becoming just another means for creating variety in our tiresomely repetitious music world. But Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, the Ensemble for Early Music brought such music to life, reminding listeners that music -far from being just a repertory art -was once actively expressive. The stylistic premises of the late Renaissance and early Baroque period were thoroughly absorbed, permitting the works to speak with all the elegance, wit and courtly passion their age is famous for.

title: Market Place; Making Profit On Takeovers
description: ONE way to make money in takeovers is to strike before the iron is hot, namely, buy shares before a company becomes a target. This may be easier than it sounds, given that by some measures stock prices are near their lowest point in many years. For example, at about 875 the Dow Jones industrial average is at 6.7 times this year's expected earnings of $130 for the 30 corporations that make up the average - very near its 40-year low of six times earnings reached in 1974.

title: ACID RAIN CAN AND MUST BE FOUGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate; Bank Finds Manhattan Too Dear
description: MANHATTAN office space is getting so expensive that even a major bank cannot afford it. Going against a trend of recent years that has seen banks become a major force in Manhattan real estate market, the European American Bank has decided to erect an office building on Long Island rather than pay prices that are among the world's highest to stay in Manhattan.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including $577,000 tax credit...C-Including $459,000 tax cred

title: BELL ASSAILS ROLE OF U.S. ON COLLEGES
description: Education Secretary T.H. Bell says the Government has been wrong in using Federal financial aid rules to bring small colleges under civil rights rules.

title: BYRNE EXPECTS HISTORY TO BE KIND
description: Surrounded by pictures from past campaigns and the bric-a-brac of a public career that is drawing to a close - the plaques, the gilded shovels, the framed editorials (usually critical) and the oversized baseball bats - Governor Byrne sat in the library of Morven, the governor's mansion, on a recent afternoon.

title: Another Revolution
description: WHEN Bowie Kuhn stood and testified that baseball had lost $25 million in 1980 under his stewardship, not all his employers saw this as a testimonial to the steward. Some of those who pay Bowie's salary could watch with a dry eye if the baseball commissioner were to return to the private practice of law. In fact, some are prepared to smooth his way.

title: POPE SAYS CHURCH IS 'ON SIDE OF THE WORKERS'
description: Pope John Paul II said today, after receiving a briefing on the Polish crisis, that the prospects for peace in Poland and elsewhere were being darkened by ''deadly shadows.''

title: Egypt-U.S. Wheat Deal
description: The United States will sell Egypt 1.1 million tons of wheat and wheat flour worth $200 million at concessionary rates under its Food for Peace program, United States officials said today. The agreement is the largest single element in Washington's civilian aid package to Egypt, now running at more than $1 billion a year. Under an agreement signed here yesterday, Egypt will pay for the wheat over 40 years at an interest rate of less than 3 percent.

title: LATIN EXILES FOCUS ON NICARAGUA AS THEY TRAIN URGENTLY IN FLORIDA
description: In a camp near the Florida Everglades, the military training of exiles to infiltrate and overthrow the Government of Nicaragua has taken on a special urgency.

title: SALESCLERK DOUBLES AS CONFIDANTE
description: It is dark and cold when the alarm goes off at 5:30 in the morning. But there are three big dogs to be walked and fed, a bus to catch, an hour's ride into Manhattan and many sweaters to sell.

title: HOUSE SEARCHES IN BELFAST ENRAGE CATHOLIC FAMILIES
description: One Saturday morning last month, Angela Cairns, a 26-year-old Roman Catholic housewife, was awakened at 7:30 by sharp pounding on the door of her modest little red brick house.

title: A VOICE FOR MODERATION AMID BUDGET CUTTERS
description: In a White House full of seemingly possessed budget-slashers, Richard S. Williamson is an exception. He yields to no Reaganite or conservative when it comes to zeal for getting Federal spending and the economy under control. But lately he has reached the heretical conclusion that some budget cuts have gone too deep or have been in the wrong place.

title: 41 Years of the U.S.O.
description: The U.S.O., founded in New York in 1941, continues to provide its shows, clubs and outreach centers, and a helping hand at bus depots, airline terminals, military bases -wherever members of the military family are apt to encounter difficulty.

title: Leadership Training Of Officials
description: ON the theory that public affairs leadership can filter down from the top, the Coro Foundation has been asked by the New York City Commission on the Status of Women to offer a special training program to improve the leadership skills of its members.

title: BUSINESS ALLY OF EX-C.I.A. AGENT HELD IN TEXAS ON CURRENCY CHARGE
description: Roberta J. Barnes, identified by Federal prosecutors as a close associate of Edwin P. Wilson, a former intelligence agent, was charged today in Federal court here with a violation of Federal currency laws.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City went up 36 cents, to $105.97, during the two-week period beginning Dec. 7. The 41-item market basket cost an average of $105.61 for the two-week period ending Dec. 4. Shoppers paid $4.23 more for food in the later two weeks than at the same time last year.

title: DEAD AS A DOORNAIL
description: Leonid Brezhnev awakes in the wintry Moscow night. In the pitchblack room he senses the presence of someone long dead. He hears it in the rustling of a huge beard, smells it in the faint odor of German sausage cooking in 19th-century kitchens. He calls out, ''Is someone there?''

title: EXCERPTS FROM POLISH RADIO AND TV BROADCASTS
description: Following are excerpts from the Soviet press agency Tass and excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency Mine Strikes Go On 1 P.M. Tuesday, (7 A.M. Tuesday, E.S.T.)

title: Eased Food Cost Rise Seen
description: The Agriculture Department said today that retail prices for food will rise again next year, but by an amount ''well below'' the increase experienced by Americans in 1981.

title: BEGAN MOVIE CAREER IN 1909
description: Allan Dwan, who during his half-century career directed such stars as Gloria Swanson, Douglas Fairbanks Sr., Shirley Temple and John Wayne, died of heart failure Monday at the Motion Picture and Television Country Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 96 years old and suffered a stroke Nov. 12.

title: SURVIVES WEEK IN RUBBLE
description: Mohammed Abbas being rescued unhurt from the wreckage of the Iraqi Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon. He was trapped there when the building was blown up Dec. 15, reportedly by Kurdish rebels. He said he survived by eating chocolate and drinking soda he found there.

title: Controllers Lose Plea To Consolidate Cases
description: The Federal Merit Systems Protection Board has denied a motion by the air traffic controllers union to consolidate the appeals of the dismissed controllers into a single action.

title: The Recession Dividend
description: One impressive consequence of an otherwise damaging recession is the chilling effect it has had on wages and wage demands. The effect, uneven but widespread, will be that wages next year are likely to rise by less than the 9 percent expected for 1981. That is welcome news for an Administration whose only real anti-inflation policy has been the tolerance of recession. It is not yet clear, however, that the gains can be sustained once recovery begins.

title: RECITAL: JUDITH MALAFRONTE
description: TWO musicians with solid talent sang and played Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall under the auspices of the Performers of Connecticut. Judith Malafronte showed a clear, powerful mezzo-soprano voice and made her half of the program - with its Romantic Italian songs, its florid aria from Handel's ''Ariodante'' and its seven lieder from Schubert's earlier years - an original and interesting experience.

title: New Monet Account Goes to Peter Rogers
description: Peter Rogers Associates, an ad agency that is very big in the fashion field, has gotten another assignment from Monet Jewelers, part of the General Mills Fashion Group.

title: VAN PELT TOP GIANT QUESTION
description: When the Giants, in the playoffs for the first time in 18 years, play the Eagles Sunday in Philadelphia, the heart of the team, as always, will be the defense. The heart of the defense, as always, will be the linebackers.

title: PIANO: 4TH IN SHAPINSKY SERIES
description: IAN SHAPINSKY, a pianist who is scheduling 10 concerts this season in Carnegie Recital Hall, is certainly not shy or introspective. Every three or four weeks, he is programming such works as Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' Scriabin's Sonata No. 5, Ginastera's ''Sonata'' and two Prokofiev sonatas.

title: Mexico Lifts Price Of Gasoline 115%
description: The Mexican Government sharply increased gasoline prices Monday night in the hope of reducing subsidies to the state oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, and of slowing the dramatic growth in domestic consumption.

title: WINE TALK
description: HE was a giant of a man, a former heavyweight boxer with facial scar tissue from years in the ring, a slugger of the 1920's who once reigned as the national amateur champion, who once ranked among the top professionals in the sport, who came close to but never won the heavyweight boxing championship of the world.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1981
description: International Scattered groups of Polish rebels on the Baltic coast and in Silesia's coal mines continued to resist the military authorities, according to word-of-mouth reports reaching Warsaw. But sources close to the Roman Catholic Church said they believed that the military leaders were containing the opposition to martial law restrictions. (Page A1, Column 6.) Poland's coal mines are critical to the economy. The coal of Silesia, where at least two groups of miners are holding out underground in rebellion against martial law, provides nearly one-third of Poland's hard currency and is the primary source of its energy. The miners have many economic advantages, but their increasing militancy since the rise of the Solidarity union movement has sharply reduced coal production. (A1:4-6.)

title: Oliveira in a Coma
description: Joao Carlos de Oliveira of Brazil, holder of the world record in the triple jump, was in a coma and listed in critical condition as the result of injuries suffered yesterday in an automobile accident near Sao Paulo. Oliveira underwent surgery at Irmaos Penteado Hospital after suffering what Dr. Nubor Facure said were a skull fracture, two exposed fractures in his right leg, a broken pelvis and a broken jaw.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Appeal by Russian Prelate
description: The head of the Russian Orthodox Church said today that mankind would be endangered until production of nuclear weapons ended. Patriarch Pimen issued the statement in his annual Christmas message.

title: 56 Years Early
description: It was an impressive letter on White House stationery, signed by President Reagan. It was addressed to Anthony Noto in Babylon, L.I., and it said the President and his wife ''congratulate you as you celebrate your 100th birthday.

title: WALDHEIM SEES HOPE IN U.S.-ISRAEL STRIFE
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim said today that the strained Israeli-American relations reflected ''an objective reassessment'' by the United States of its interests in the Middle East.

title: FOR A CARIBBEAN COMPACT
description: The Reagan Administration has admirably tried to address the two difficult issues of immigration and development in the Caribbean Basin - all the countries in and around the Caribbean Sea.

title: Hambros Bank Names Head of New Fund
description: The Hambros Bank Group of Britain, through its United States subsidiary, has established a venture-capital pool called the Hambro International Venture Fund and named Edwin A. Goodman, the 42-yearold head of another of its units, as a general partner of the fund. Yesterday Mr. Goodman - son of Andrew Goodman, the chairman of the Bonwit Teller specialty store - explained the thinking behind the establishment of the new organization, which hopes to raise $50 million.

title: Four Ministers Replaced In Turkish Cabinet Shifts
description: Turkey's military-backed Cabinet was shuffled today amid reports that more changes would come in the near future.

title: Yankees, Collins Are Close
description: George Steinbrenner indicated yesterday that he is on the verge of signing Dave Collins to a three-year contract and that he is not convinced that Reggie Jackson is a necessary or desirable part of the Yankee team that he set out to remodel after the World Series.

title: Y CHORALE: A SLAVIC ACCENT
description: THE Y Chorale presented a program of music with a Slavic accent Sunday evening at the 92d Street Y, offering works of popular and folklike character drawn from a rich repertory of choral settings by 19th- and 20th-century composers.

title: THOUGHTS ON EXITING FROM MY SUBWAY STOP
description: I've developed a new subway phobia I fear for my torso, arms and legs -As I pass through the vertical turnstile I'll emerge like sliced hard-boiled eggs! BETH HOLLAND STEIN

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE IN NOVEMBER BY MODERATE 0.5%
description: The Consumer Price Index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in November, all but guaranteeing that the inflation rate this year will be under 10 percent for the first time since 1978.

title: STOCKS DIP IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Stock prices edged lower yesterday in more active trading with some defense and transportation issues posting the biggest losses. At the final bell, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 1.14 points, to 871.96. Declining stocks on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded rising issues by about an 8-to-5 ratio.

title: Hartford Ballet to Do 'Nutcracker' in Bronx
description: The Hartford Ballet will perform ''The Nutcracker'' in a production by its director, Michael Uthoff, on Jan. 2 and 3 at the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts, Bedford Park Boulevard West, the Bronx.

title: 76ers TOP KNICKS, 112-105, AS CALDWELL JONES GETS 20
description: Scoring is not something the Philadelphia 76ers expect from Caldwell Jones. His role is to rebound, block shots and play defense. Jones, a 6-foot-11-inch forward and center, did all those things last night and more. He had a season-high 20 points as the 76ers defeated the Knicks, 112-105, at Madison Square Garden.

title: IN SIBERIA, A WRITER STEPS INTO THE PATH OF PROGRESS
description: Though hymns to the development of Siberia's immense riches and rivers are sung almost daily in the Soviet press, Valentin Rasputin, a native Siberian, has become one of the Soviet Union's most popular writers with his books of the erosion of values, traditions and land before the rush of progress.

title: BILLY BEER CAN FANCIERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Mud
description: Architects are conspicuous among those preoccupied with a yearning for simpler times. But as two recent exhibitions make clear, it is evidently not enough to renounce modernism for classical columns and renaissance rotundas.

title: TV: A QUADRIPLEGIC REGAINS HIS CHILDREN
description: THIS evening's based-on-a-true-story television experience is ''The Ordeal of Bill Carney,'' on CBS at 9 o'clock. Mr. Carney is a quadriplegic who won a landmark court battle this year for the custody of his children. In something of a departure for this kind of uplifting production, Mr. Carney is not especially saintly. The real hero of the piece is his determined lawyer, Mason Rose, himself a paraplegic. Running true to form, though, the performances are remarkably good, with Ray Sharkey as Mr. Carney and Richard Crenna as Mr. Rose.

title: MUSIC: HARMONIC CHOIR'S EUPHONIOUS CHORDS
description: MUSIC has long been a model both for the well-ordered soul and the well-ordered heavens. A system of tuning, Plato knew, has a moral character. And when Kepler and Copernicus worked out their theories of the universe, harmony was their guide.

title: Time Inc. Plans To Sell 2 Units
description: Time Inc. said it had agreed to sell two subsidiaries, the New York Graphic Society Ltd. and Alva Museum Replicas, to an affiliate of the Paul Hanson Company for a total of $6 million in cash and notes, according to Louis J. Slovinsky, a Time Inc. spokesman.

title: NEEDLESS U.S. BAN ON TRAVEL TO LIBYA
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME CURBS EASED
description: The following article is based on information reaching news agencies from Poland.

title: Grey Medical Receives Its First Revlon Task
description: Grey Medical Advertising, the health care specialty subsidiary of Grey Advertising, has just gotten its first assignments from Revlon, a major client of the parent company for 21 years. Grey does advertising for nine Revlon brands and also works on new products.

title: SURPLUS CHEESE GOES TO POOR AS PRESIDENT SIGNS FARM BILL
description: President Reagan signed into law a fouryear, $11 billion farm support bill today, then gave poor Americans a holiday slice of the cheese surplus piled in Government warehouses.

title: Holly Sugar Board Fills 2 Top Posts
description: With the completion of a bitter two-year proxy battle for control of the Holly Sugar Company, a major sugar manufacturer, a new eightmember board of directors, led by Michael S. Buchsbaum, a 40-year-old investment banker, has changed the top management. John L. Bushnell, 39, has been named president and chief executive officer of the major sugar manufacturer, based in Colorado Springs, and J.E.A. Rich, 52, has been named vice chairman and chief operating officer. Both are former Holly executives.

title: Wuv's Chain Files Under Chapter 11
description: Wuv's International Inc., the Fort Lauderdale-based hamburger chain, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. and has laid off more than half its office staff in the past year.

title: Diverse Cultures, Diverse Media
description: As head of the Israeli-Egyptian Friendship League, Dr. Mohammed Hani el-Kadi, a physician and writer from Alexandria, is accustomed to being in different worlds. He was the first Egyptian writer to enter Israel after the Camp David thaw and has been working to promote relations between the two countries.

title: MET OPERA: FIRST 'HANSEL'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera House wiggled and squirmed a little more than usual Monday evening. It was the first ''Hansel and Gretel'' of the season, and it was a night mostly for the children. They were everywhere, and the adults who accompanied them seemed, quite rightly, to be perceiving this Central European fairy tale of light and darkness through the eyes of their sons and daughters.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The illusion of ordinary domesticity remains intact until one of the girls ''acts up,'' as the counselors call it. Until then, in the large apartment in Lefrak City, it is all maternal platitudes: ''Don't talk with your mouth full,'' ''Put some shoes on your feet,'' ''Hi, baby - how was school today?''

title: Kibbee and Others Granted Raises
description: Salary increases for Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the chancellor of the City University, and other officers of the institution were approved by the university's trustees.

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
Gulf Pact For Kuwaiti Oil
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation of the United States has signed a contract to buy 35,000 barrels a day of Kuwaiti crude oil beginning Jan. 1, but two other companies are seeking lower prices, informed Kuwaiti oil sources said today.

title: Anti-Semitic Attitudes In Poland Questioned
description: State Department officials and spokesmen for American Jewish organizations said this week that they were concerned about reports of a resurgence of anti-Semitism in Poland since the imposition of martial law.

title: ARCHITECT DEFENDED NEW YORK CITY PAST
description: John Barrington Bayley, an architect and defender of New York's architectural past, died Monday in Newport (R.I.) Hospital at the age of 67. He had been a resident of Newport since moving there from New York four years ago.

title: LEADER IN TRANSPLANT SURGERY
description: Dr. Samuel L. Kountz, an international leader in transplant surgery, died yesterday at his home in Great Neck, L.I., after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

title: LEADING POLES SAY MILITARY, NOT THE PARTY ,ISSUES ORDERS
description: An aide of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, and a Roman Catholic cardinal have told a Western embassy that the army crackdown was strictly a Polish decision, dictated largely by the military leadership in Warsaw.

title: Mortgage Growth Chief
description: W. Pierce Coues, 40, has been named chairman of the board of trustees and chief executive officer of Mortgage Growth Investors, a Boston-based real estate investment trust. He succeeds Cornelius C. Rose Jr., 49, who resigned to pursue other interests.

title: GHOSTS
description: This is the season in which, nine years ago, the United States ended its direct military role in Vietnam with a last burst of pointless violence. For 12 days 100 B-52's and 500 smaller planes bombed Hanoi and Haiphong. The Nixon White House called it Operation Linebacker II. To the public it was the Christmas bombing.

title: De Oliveira Is Improved But Remains in Coma
description: Joao Carlos de Oliveira, world record holder in the triple jump, remained in a coma today after being injured in an auto accident.

title: POLAND INCREASING ECONOMIC BURDEN FOR SOVIET
description: It seems certain that the Soviet Union will have to pay a heavy economic price for the steady deterioration of Poland's economy.

title: BUNNINGTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $122,474 loss from discontinued operations...C-After $1 loss from discontinued operations

title: Bridge: Regionals Attracted Talent From Some Distant Areas
description: It seemed like Space Invaders, but it was non-electronic. The Winter Regional Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton Hotel Sunday would normally have attracted most of the best players in the metropolitan area, but this time the field included experts from California and some from other distant spots.

title: DEAN APPOINTED, MOVING CITY U.'S LAW SCHOOL CLOSER TO REALITY
description: New York City's first publicly supported law school moved closer to reality yesterday with the appointment of a dean who will begin preparations for opening the institution in 1983.

title: Second Chance Beckons
description: Ron Erhardt, latest casualty in pro football's open season on coaches, has found that being dismissed by the New England Patriots has not harmed him. Erhardt, after a 2-14 season, said he had been approached by five clubs, and called three of the approaches ''pretty solid.''

title: MRS. FRANKLIN P. ADAMS
description: Esther Root Adams, widow of Franklin P. Adams, the newspaper columnist and panelist on the ''Information Please'' radio program, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Stamford, Conn.

title: WICHITA STATE 79, DETROIT 70
description: DETROIT (UPI) - Tony Martin scored 22 points to lead Wichita State (7-0). The Shockers led by 17 points during the first half before Detroit (3-5) cut the deficit to 7 points midway through the second half. Wichita State then went to Martin and Cliff Levingston, who scored 18 points, to take a 64-48 advantage.

title: ALLEN EXONERATED BY JUSTICE DEPT. ON GIFTS AND FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE
description: Attorney General William French Smith said today that Richard V. Allen had not acted illegally in accepting three watches from Japanese associates or in omitting information from his financial disclosure form, and that a special prosecutor would not be appointed to conduct an independent inquiry.

title: Eastern to Contest Ban on A-300 Jet
description: A spokesman for Eastern Airlines contended today that ''nothing can beat'' the Airbus Industrie A-300 jet for efficiency and safety, after the Federal Aviation Administration banned the wide-body plane from Washington's National Airport.

title: PUNISHMENT RULED OUT FOR HAITIANS WHO RIOTED
description: Haitian refugees and officials at Fort Allen reached an agreement today to ease tension at the detention camp, which had been virtually paralyzed after a weekend riot.

title: REAGAN'S PUZZLING MOVE AGAINST ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Ainsworth, U.S. Judge In 5th Circuit Court, Dies at 71
description: Judge Robert A. Ainsworth Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit died Tuesday at Southern Baptist Hospital, where he had been under treatment for a heart attack. He was 71 years old.

title: John Jay 83, Yeshiva 70
description: John Jay (9-2) was led by Curtis White, who scored 20 points, and Duane Martin, 18. Brian Smith led John Jay with 10 rebounds. Leading Yeshiva (5-5) was Harvey Sheff with 24 points.

title: PAY POOR TEEN-AGERS FOR 'UN-PARENTHOOD'
description: To the Editor:

title: Owner of M.I.S.L. Club Killed in Auto Accident
description: Richard Ragone, the founder, principal owner and president of the Phoenix Inferno of the Major Indoor Soccer League, was one of two persons killed late Tuesday in an automobile accident in suburban Paradise Valley.

title: Dalton's Fine Rescinded
description: Harry Dalton, general manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, whose outspokenness in the baseball strike cost him a $50,000 fine, has confirmed that the fine was rescinded at the owners' meetings early this month. ''I think they overreacted badly in this case,'' Dalton said.

title: TREATS FOR YOUNGSTERS RANGE FROM PLAYS AND PUPPETRY TO TALES AND TUNES
description: There are Christmas treats aplenty in and around New York for children, giving a choice of plays, puppet shows, musical programs and more. The magic of a curtain rising in a hushed, darkened theater can create expectation and excitement for young theatergoers whether they are attending ''Rumpelstiltskin'' for the third time or a production by the hilarious Paper Bag Players for the first. And there is something special about attending holiday performances of ''The Nutcracker'' at Lincoln Center that adults also seem to enjoy.

title: The Evening Hours
description: I T was a classy crowd, no doubt about that. But when someone wondered aloud who had designed Gloria Vanderbilt's claret floor-length dress, another guest confided that she had gone into the bedroom to peek inside Miss Vanderbilt's crushed red velvet cape, which was reposing there, but had not seen a label.

title: Collins Signs for Promise To Play
description: George Steinbrenner furthered the transformation of the Yankees into a speedy team yesterday by convincing Dave Collins that he would be a regular player and signing him to a three-year contract worth at least $2.5 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp., Pittsburgh, has elected Irving J. Berkman vice chairman and Ernest G. Siddons senior vice president, finance and treasurer.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared in May

title: ISRAELI DEFENDS HARSH WORDS BUT SEEKS BETTER TIES
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin had been completely justified in using harsh language against the United States, but he expressed confidence in the American commitment to Israel's security and said he hoped for an early restoration of trust between the two countries.

title: Advertising; Growth Of Mall Promotions
description: WHEREVER you have heavy traffic, be it automotive, pedestrian, visual, or as in the case of radio, audio, you can be sure of one thing: It will attract advertisers.

title: SPECIAL OFFICIAL SOUGHT TO STUDY DONOVAN'S CASE
description: Attorney General William French Smith asked yesterday that a special prosecutor be appointed to investigate an allegation made against Raymond J. Donovan, the Secretary of Labor.

title: Apprentice at Aqueduct Aboard Five Winners
description: Constantino Hernandez, a 24-year-old apprentice jockey, rode Star Gallant to a 2 1/4-length victory in the Alsab Stakes for his fifth winner of the day at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Navy Says Tough Rules Are Aimed at Drug Use
description: Adm. Thomas Hayward, chief of naval operations, today set in motion a ''get tough'' policy aimed at rooting drug users out of the Navy.

title: Columnist Suspended
description: Jim Klobuchar, a sports columnist for The Minneapolis Star, has been suspended for 10 days with pay for fabricating quotations in a story about possible injuries and damage that could result if fans went on a souvenir-seeking rampage after Sunday's game between the Minnesota Vikings and the Kansas City Chiefs at Metropolitan Stadium. The game was the last for the Vikings in the stadium; they will move to a domed field next season.

title: AFGHAN WAR ECONOMY: THIN DIETS, FAST FORTUNE
description: Considering that a guerrilla war has been raging in Afghanistan for more than three years, the rural economy of the largely isolated desert and mountain settlements has survived with remarkable self-sufficiency.

title: Y TO RING WITH 30 'BRANDENBURGS' IN 6 DAYS
description: It is one of the ironies of music history that Bach's ''Brandenburg'' Concertos - which will be played five times in the next few days at the 92d Street Y - are dedicated to a prince who never paid for them, never used them and probably never even looked at them.

title: Broadway; Movie man plans debut as producer on Broadway.
description: BURT SUGARMAN, the Hollywood producer who has acquired the film rights to two highly praised plays on Broadway, ''Crimes of the Heart'' and ''Children of a Lesser God,'' has decided to come to the source. He will make his debut here as a theatrical producer late this season with ''Extremities,'' a new drama by William Mastrosimone, whose ''The Woolgatherer'' had a successful run at Circle Repertory last year.
