The director will be Robert Allan Ackerman, best known for his staging of ''Bent'' on Broadway.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SPECIALIST ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: Mark J. Gayn, a Canadian journalist who wrote extensively on foreign affairs, died of cancer Dec. 17 in Toronto. He was 72 years old.

title: St. Peter's 57, Wagner 44
description: Tyrone Holloway scored 9 of his team's first 14 points in the second half to wipe out an 8-point deficit and lead St. Peter's. William Brown had 16 points and Holloway 15 for St. Peter's (4-5). Wagner (2-6) was paced by J.J. Lewis, who had 18.

title: Union at Western Air Offers Stock Aid Plan
description: Seeking to block the heavy layoffs looming among its members, the pilots union of Western Airlines offered today to raise more than $20 million to purchase new shares of stock in the cash-starved airline, the nation's 10th-largest.

title: PAY POOR TEEN-AGERS FOR 'UN-PARENTHOOD'
description: To the Editor:

title: PACIFIC REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including gains of $179,000 for the qr and $234,000 for the 6 mos on the sale of properties and recoveries on former non-operating assets and also a $600,000 extra- ordinary charge for the qr and 6 mos...C-Net income including $17,000 gain on the sale of properties and recoveries on former non-earning assets...D-Including $601,000 gain on the sale of properties and recoveries on former non-earning assets

title: MILWAUKEE POLICE STRIKE AFTER 2 OFFICERS ARE SLAIN
description: The police began an illegal strike tonight at the urging of union leaders angry at what they called a city official's callous comments on the slayings of two patrolmen early this morning.

title: REDMEN START FAST, BEAT TEMPLE, 68-61
description: As surely as the Temple Owls wear their cherry-and-white uniforms, there is the Temple zone, perfected by Harry Litwack, the Hall of Fame coach, and preserved by Don Casey. ''They've been playing zone for 2,000 years,'' said Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach.

title: Who's Afraid of Ian Paisley?
description: The State Department was at its stuffy worst in explaining why it has barred a speaking tour by the Rev. Ian Paisley, hardest of Protestant hard-liners in Northern Ireland. It said his presence would be ''prejudicial to U.S. public interests.'' What is truly prejudicial is the department's nanny-knows-best attitude about whom Americans may hear.

title: Prudential Unit Sold to Jardine
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell the insurance business of its Bache Group Inc. subsidiary to Jardine Matheson & Company.

title: At the Movies; Chevy Chase up in the air over new role.
description: AFTER 20th Century-Fox decided not to have the usual previews for the New York press, but just to go ahead and open ''Modern Problems'' on Christmas Day, Chevy Chase, the picture's star, and Michael Shamberg, one of its producers, came to town to do a bit of promotion.

title: N.C.A.A. Puts Oregon On Two-Year Probation
description: The University of Oregon has been placed on probation for a two-year period that began Tuesday, the National Collegiate Athletic Association Committee on Infractions announced today. The violations were in recruiting, academic standards, benefits to student-athletes and misuse of funds, the N.C.A.A. said.

title: DANCE: PILOBOLUS EVENING WITH A SHARE OF SURPRISES
description: ONE of the fascinating aspects of the Pilobolus Dance Theater - and one that makes it so entertaining - is the group's ability to serve up images that reveal themselves so surprisingly and variously.

title: SHOEMAKER VOTED TOP JOCKEY
description: Thirty-two years after riding his first winner, 26 years after winning the first of three Kentucky Derbies, and 23 years after being elected to racing's Hall of Fame, Bill Shoemaker, at the age of 50, has won his first Eclipse Award as the year's top jockey.

title: Too Much Team Spirit?
description: Bob King, vice president of the National Basketball Association in charge of team services, said he would check reports that employees of the Detroit Pistons were filling out ballots intended for fans to use in choosing players for the All-Star game to be played at Byrne Meadowlands Arena Jan. 31. King said that each team in the league received 200,000 ballots, and that, in the long run, votes for hometown favorites would be overcome by votes for more qualified players.

title: SEABOARD ALLIED MILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 14
N.H.L. Taking Steps to Curb Violence
description: Procedures for disciplining players who engage in physical abuse of referees, such as occurred recently when Paul Holmgren of the Philadelphia Flyers punched Andy Van Hellemond, the referee, will be reviewed by a panel of players, coaches, officials and league staff, the National Hockey League and the N.H.L. Officials Association announced today.

title: IN CEDAR RAPIDS, IOWA, CHRISTMAS 1981 IS A SEASON OF CONTRASTS
description: This is the fourth of a number of articles that will appear from time to time examining how changing economic conditions affect Americans in one small city.

title: TREASURY BILL RATES UP AGAIN
description: Rates on Treasury securities continued to climb yesterday, rising by as much as a quarter of a percentage point, despite daylong efforts by the Federal Reserve to inject liquidity into the market.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt MEDIA. The Second God. By Tony Schwartz. Illustrated by Nurit Karlin. 206 pages. Random House. $13.50.

title: Beatrice Net Increases 4.6%
description: The Beatrice Foods Company reported today that its profit increased 4.6 percent in the third quarter compared with the similar period in 1980, although sales were up only marginally.

title: TRANSIT GIRDS FOR CHRISTMAS GETAWAY
description: Air and ground transport systems adjusted their schedules and expanded their services in the New York metropolitan area yesterday to handle the buildup of departures for the three-day Christmas holiday.

title: POPE URGES THE ABOLITION OF A-ARMS
description: The Vatican said today, as it published the text of a recent papal message on nuclear war, that Pope John Paul II had sent it to major powers and the United Nations to dramatize his view that there was only one ''conceivable alternative'' to such warfare.

title: DEATH FROM THE GOLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: METAL SCULPTURE BY JAMES ROSATI
description: IF the words ageless and old-fashioned both apply to James Rosati, it's not because his sculpture is in any way contradictory or whimsical. On the contrary, the 19 metal works dated 1972 to the present that are on view at the Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, are each as ordered as a classical sonata. The simile seems especially apt, for Mr. Rosati played violin for the Pittsburgh String Symphony before he turned to sculpture in the 30's. However, the artist, who is approaching 70, did not make his debut in Manhattan until the beginning of the 50's. Since then, he has had nine solo shows, participated in numerous groups and discharged many commissions.

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1981; Companies
description: Sales by the Big Three auto makers dropped 22.5 percent below levels of a year earlier in the middle 10 days of December. It is likely 1981 will be the worst sales year since 1961. (Page A1.)

title: A WIND-LOOSENED SIGN PINS FOUR AT 8TH AND 34TH
description: Four pedestrians were pinned beneath a huge sign yesterday after gusting winds ripped it from a building at the corner of 34th Street and Eighth Avenue and sent it crashing down on Christmas shoppers.

title: Business Executives Support Reagan on Polish Sanctions
description: Reaction within the business and financial community last night to President Reagan's sanctions against the Polish Government were supportive.

title: Sympathy Strike in Bavaria
description: About 100,000 workers in Bavaria were reported today to have staged a five-minute work stoppage in sympathy with ''suppressed Polish colleagues.'' The action, called by the Bavarian wing of the national trade union council, was carried out in a number of factories including the B.M.W. and Audi auto plants in Munich and Ingolstadt.

title: Amax Coal Talks
description: Amax Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., a major diversified natural resources concern, confirmed that it had held discussions with a leading West German coal producer, Ruhrkohle, and other companies on the joint development of Amax's coal reserves. Amax's coal subsidiary is based in Indianapolis. Earlier this year, Pierre Gousseland, the Amax chairman, said that the company was considering joint ventures that would allow more rapid development of its 3.3 billion tons of reserves.

title: A WHITE CHRISTMAS FOR THE MIDDLE WEST
description: A jogger out early yesterday as six inches of snow fell on Detroit. Up to eight inches covered much of the region, making driving treacherous and students happy. Some schools, including Wayne State University in Detroit, closed early for Christmas.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S REMARKS ON SUSPENSION OF SOME TIES WITH POLAND
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address to the nation last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Options Trading Backed on Fixed-Income Issues
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized three exchanges to begin trading what is expected to become a major new financial product: options on United States Treasury securities.

title: BRIEFING
description: I T is Christmas Eve, and so far no one has asked G. William Hoagland to play the role of Ebenezer Scrooge, which, in a way, surprises him. Mr. Hoagland, who grew up on an Indiana farm and followed his dreams to Washington, took the rap, and a bum one, he says, for spilling ketchup on Reaganomics.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Steve Mahre, one of the leading skiers on the World Cup circuit, is resting at home in Yakima, Wash., after surgery to remove some loose cartilage from his right knee.

title: DON'T MAKE THE C.I.A.  K.G.B.
description: President Reagan's executive order issued Dec. 4 a ssigns a domestic-spying role to the Central Intelligence Agency. T his departs radically from the agency's founding principles. It is i nconsistent with statutory law, ignores tradition, and will weaken t he intelligence system while endangering civil liberties.

title: U.S. TO DOUBLE THE PRICE OF CERTAIN OFFSHORE GAS
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has voted to allow higher prices for natural gas produced in deep offshore waters and to consider increasing the price for onshore gas that comes from intermediate depths.

title: STOCKS DRIFT LOWER FOR THE THIRD DAY
description: Stock prices drifted lower yesterday for the third straight session, as volume contracted in advance of the three-day Christmas weekend.

title: American Seeking Boeing Order Cut
description: American Airlines has begun preliminary discussions with the Boeing Company on cutting its order for 30 Boeing 767 airliners valued at about $1.2 billion, a spokesman for the airline said.

title: Notes on People; Hampton Throws a Party for Children He Loves
description: Yesterday, as he has for the last 15 years, Lionel Hampton dressed up as Santa Claus. The occasion was a huge party he threw for hundreds of children at the Gladys Hampton Houses, a housing development for low-income families in Harlem named in honor of the bandleader's late wife.

title: RANGERS STOP JETS EASILY, 5-2
description: The Rangers, unaccustomed as they had become to winning on their home ice, did just that last night, defeating the Winnipeg Jets, 5-2. The victory was only the second for the Rangers in their last nine home games, and most of the 17,422 Garden fans roared their approval when Dave Silk scored his ninth of the season, the one the put the Rangers three goals ahead with less than 10 minutes left in the game.

title: Lupkin Plans to Quit City Post on April 15
description: Stanley N. Lupkin, who told Mayor Koch months ago that he intended to leave his position as Commissioner of Investigation, submitted his formal resignation.

title: JACK ABBOTT ROYALTIES HALTED
description: Income and royalties from sales of the best-selling book ''In the Belly of the Beast'' were ordered withheld yesterday from Jack Henry Abbott, convict-turned-author, pending the outcome of a civil suit charging him with wrongful death.

title: Diamond's Board Favors Takeover
description: Only one of its directors is opposing the $400 million takeover of the Diamond International Corporation by Sir James Goldsmith, a British financier, the paper and forest products company said.

title: Ballplayer's Parents File $62 Million Lawsuit
description: The parents of Ron Settles, a college football player who died in his jail cell more than six months ago, have filed a $62 million civil lawsuit against the city of Signal Hill and several city and police officials.

title: McLouth Steel Loans Extended
description: Major creditors of the struggling McLouth Steel Corp. have agreed to extend due dates on loans they made until Jan. 29, company officials said.

title: CREATIONIST ACTED TO DISSUADE WITNESSES FOR ARKANSAS CASE
description: Several educators who had been scheduled to testify in favor of Arkansas' creation science law were discouraged from doing it by supporters of the law, according to a California lawyer involved. The lawyer said he believed Arkansas had prepared an inadequate defense and that he therefore thought the educators' reputations might be jeopardized by association with the case.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: There was a time in the 1920's when Henry Ford wanted his company to be able to make everything that goes into an auto. In that spirit, he built factories that produced batteries, tires, steel and other parts for the car.

title: LIST OF POLISH RELIEF AGENCIES
description: Many American relief and charitable organizations, some of which have been sending aid to Poland for months, report that they are intensifying relief efforts. Because of the heavy cost of shipping food and other supplies from the United States, most groups are soliciting monetary contributions that will be used to purchase goods in Europe for distribution in Poland. A few organizations are also seeking American sponsors for Polish refugees being resettled in the United States.

title: A SUSPECT GIVES ALIBI IN SLAYING OF JERSEY OFFICER
description: The Superintendent of the New Jersey state police said today that his suspicions had been ''lessened'' about the involvement of one of three men sought for questioning in the slaying of a highly decorated trooper last Monday afternoon.

title: A TREE FOR ALL SEASONS
description: To the Editor:

title: RCA JOINS MICROWAVE APPLICANTS
description: A subsidiary of the RCA Corporation has asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to establish a series of microwave communication networks in major cities across the nation.

title: PUBLISHING: 'REDS' SPURS INTEREST IN JOHN REED
description: ''REDS,'' the movie about the love affair between the American radical John Reed and and Louise Bryant, set against the backdrop of the Russian Revolution, has sparked renewed publishing interest in Reed and in Miss Bryant, also a journalist.

title: Don't Blame the Harlem Community
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL DRESSED UP WITH PLACES TO GO
description: Dressing up seems to be the new order of the day. One senses, at parties and dinner dances, public and private, an urgency to dress, almost to preen. More and more, striking pieces of jewelry appear on the necks and shoulders of women, and dresses seem to rival each other in extravagance. It has become a time and season for ball gowns with formal gloves reaching far above elbows, for genuine jewels to be removed from safe deposit boxes and worn to private parties.

title: CHURCHES' GIFTS TO CITY: FAITH, HOPE AND CHARITY
description: At Our Lady of Loreto Roman Catholic Church, just off the Bowery, a good day is measured in cups of steaming coffee served to hundreds of homeless men and women.

title: THE PROMISE OF THE TRIP TO VIETNAM
description: To the Editor:

title: PERSONAL MESSAGES BROADCAST
description: Radio Free Europe, the American radio station here, has begun broadcasting Christmas greetings and personal messages from Poles in the West to relatives and friends in Poland.

title: DEFICIT MAY EXCEED $100 BILLION
description: In a two and one-half hour meeting with his advisers this morning, President Reagan completed the major spending decisions on a budget for the fiscal year 1983 that will, according to the Administration's internal economic forecasts, run up a deficit of more than $100 billion.

title: VERMELL HAS WINNING WAYS
description: Once, Philadelphia fans gathered behind the Eagles' bench and waved dog bones. Coach Dick Vermeil, who is openly emotional, did not appreciate the premise that his team was nothing but a kennel of canines.

title: REAGAN VIEWS FILMS TO GET THE DIPLOMATIC EDGE
description: The lights go off, the projector rolls and President Reagan settles back in his chair to prepare for his first meeting with a foreign head of state. It is the White House version of ''This Is Your Life,'' and among the film subjects so far have been Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, King Hussein of Jordan and Anwar el-Sadat, the late President of Egypt.

title: THEATER: 'MAGIC TIME'
description: THERE is an artful innocence in ''Magic Time.'' It is set in the dressing room of a summer theater outside Chicago. The actors there are doing ''Hamlet.'' It is the final night of the run, but the stage manager is still giving notes, and the actors are still working on their roles. They love to act. It is Mickey and Judy, and hey, kids, let's do a show, but with a large difference. ''Magic Time,'' at the Actors and Directors Theater on Theater Row, is slick. It is also delightful.

title: MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After $278,100 loss from discontinued operations... C-Including $45,200 income from discontinued operations

title: 2 EXECUTIVES ACCUSED IN AMAX OPTIONS CASE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused two California businessmen of making almost half a million dollars' profit from trading in options after obtaining advanced knowledge of a proposed takeover of Amax Inc. by the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: MEXICO'S FINANCING PROBLEMS
description: The sharp deterioration in Mexico's financial situation this year has provoked conflicting responses of delight and nervousness among foreign bankers who have been helping to pay for this country's oil-based economic boom.

title: WOMAN OFF LIST FOR JUDGESHIP
description: Deputy Attorney General Edward Schmults confirmed Tuesday that Judith Whittaker, 43 years old, an associate general counsel for Hallmark Cards in Kansas City, has been dropped as a candidate to fill a vacancy on the United States Court of Appeals for the Eight Circuit, in Kansas City.

title: NETS BEAT KNICKS, 115-99, FOR THIRD VICTORY IN ROW
description: Skeptics be silent. When the Nets flew off to snowy Milwaukee last weekend and defeated the hottest team in the league by 12 points, some said it was a fluke. And when they beat Cleveland, the worst team, the following night, it revealed little. But tonight, in their 115-99 defeat of the Knicks before 14,823 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Nets proved that they are not to be taken lightly any longer.

title: NOW WILL APPEAL IDAHO RULING TO SUPREME COURT
description: Supporters of the proposed equal rights amendment said that today's ruling by a Federal judge in Idaho would be appealed directly and immediately to the Supreme Court.

title: POLISH REGIME REPORTS END TO STRIKE AT SILESIA MILL
description: Polish security forces brought an end today to a strike at a steel mill in Silesia, but more than 1,000 coal miners carried their protest strike against the martial law regime into the 10th day, the Warsaw radio reported.

title: Restaurants; 2 VERY GOOD PLACES NOW EVEN BETTER; 2 very good places now even better.
description: OCCASIONALLY, we come across a restaurant that seems to fall between two ratings, a little better than the lower one, but not quite up to the higher. In such instances, we generally make the more conservative choice. It is then possible to revisit the restaurant and increase the rating if appropriate, a more cheerful task than having to take away a star already given.

title: POPE IS STILL URGING TALKS TO SOLVE THE POLISH CRISIS
description: Pope John Paul II is still trying to bring about a resumption of negotiations between the Polish authorities and the Solidarity labor union.

title: New Argentine Leader Vows to Cut Spending
description: The new President of Argentina, Leopoldo Galtieri, said tonight that his military regime would cut state spending, firmly ally itself with the West and continue consultations aimed at eventual civilian rule.

title: Exxon Aide Joins Aminoil As Its Head
description: James B. Coffman, 55, has joined Aminoil USA, a petroleum exploration and production company with headquarters in Houston, as president and chief operating officer. As president, he succeeds George E. Trimble, 61, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the R.J. Reynolds Industries subsidiary.

title: ART: AMERICAN PRINTS AND HOW THEY'RE MADE
description: ''AMERICAN Prints: Process & Proofs'' at the Whitney Museum is a teaching exhibition and one that turns out to be a lot of fun. It is based on the idea that many visitors to the museum have no firsthand experience of the complexities of printmaking. To them (so the theory goes), a print is a print, and it exists in one form only. Either you have it or you don't.

title: On Losing a Voice
description: There's long been an uncertain quiver in the Voice of America. Even the name is a little suspect: a plural democracy does not speak with a single voice, much less through an official microphone. Nevertheless, over the decades the Voice has won an enormous audience around the world. It has earned trust because it is rarely strident or tendentious. Yet today, sad to say, that hard-won trust is being put in jeopardy by over-eager ideologues.

title: CURBS CREDIT AND COMMERCE
description: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Normal communications with The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, John Darnton, have been barred by the authorities there since Dec. 14.

title: Trucking Along - Against Deregulation
description: During his campaign, Ronald Reagan proclaimed himself a champion of deregulation. Once he was elected, officious bureaucrats would have to get out of the way and let the economy work.

title: UNC Resources To Buy Swiftships
description: UNC Resources Inc. said that it had agreed to buy Swiftships Inc. of Morgan City, La., a maker of aluminum boats for military and offshore-oil use.

title: PRINCE'S TRIP TO U.S. IS POSTPOENED
description: Saudi Arabia announced full backing today for Syrian efforts to bring about a cancellation of Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights. It warned that if ''peaceful means'' failed, Arabs would collectively ''have to consider what appropriate measures to take.''

title: STATE OFFICIALS DEFIES JUDGE ON TRANSFERS OF RIKERS PRISONERS
description: The state's Commissioner of Correctional Services said today that he would refuse to comply with an order by a Federal judge to speed the transfer of state prisoners held in New York City jails, even if the refusal put him in contempt of court.

title: U.S. PERSONNEL CHIEF CREATES A FUROR
description: The best-known controversies of the Reagan Administration have swirled around such figures as Interior Secretary James G. Watt, David A. Stockman, the budget director, and Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, but the official whom Washington's thousands of Federal employees consider the Grinch of this holiday season is a man whose name is hardly known outside the capital.

title: STAGE: 'NO END OF BLAME,' CYNICAL BRITISH DRAMA
description: HAVING survived world war, civil war, revolution and counterrevolution, Bela Veracek (''Vera''), the cartoonist hero of Howard Barker's acidulous new play, ''No End of Blame,'' arrives in England in 1936. Grateful for what he calls his ''freeness,'' he kisses the ground. At last, he thinks, he will be able to express his savage criticism without fear of censorship.

title: Ex-Owner Savors Jets' Sudden Rise
description: Townsend Martin insists that he has no regrets even though the Jets became a playoff team less than a year after he unloaded his quarter-ownership in them.

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $45,077,000 extraordinary gain on the sale of Dannon Co

title: Technology; Playing Games Electronically
description: THE first electronic computer, Eniac, which weighed 30 tons and filled a sizable room, was built during World War II to compute artillery shell trajectories for the Army. Perhaps it is only natural that 35 years later, some of Eniac's descendants, which fit on a table and have such names as Odyssey, are being used to shoot down imaginary enemy spaceships and invading aliens.

title: Court Faults a Judge Over Closed Hearings
description: A Criminal Court judge was wrong to bar the public from preliminary hearings for two men charged with raping and assaulting an East Harlem nun, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday.

title: VENERABLE MANHATTANS STICK WITH TRADITION
description: POP music has changed dramatically since 1964. A new group called the Beatles took America by storm that year, and another new group, the Supremes, featuring Diana Ross, recorded its first hits. The Manhattans, a black vocal group from Jersey City, also made its first records that year and scored a hit with ''I Wanna Be (Your Everything),'' a lilting soul song written by and featuring as lead singer Winfred (Blue) Lovett.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: TROOPS EVICT STRIKERS
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish here by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency End of Steel Strike 10 P.M. Wednesday, (4 P.M. Wednesday E.S.T.)

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motor Inns Inc. broke off negotiations for the acquisition of four Holiday Inns in Charleston, W. Va.

title: Index; International
description: In Afghan war, quick fortunes and thin diets A2 Soviet said to plan more troops and copters for Afghanistan A3 Around the World A4 Syrian Cabinet official expects U.N. sanctions against Israel A5 Common Market steps up denun- ciation of Warsaw A9 Pope still urging talks to solve Polish crisis A9 Poland becoming a growing eco- nomic burden on Soviet A11 Government/Politics Attorney General asks for special prosecutor in Donovan case B1 Byrne and Kean support Govern- ment pay raises B2 General Around the Nation A12 Jury awards ex-activists $711,000 in damages A12 Nun is mugged and badly hurt near a Bronx convent B2 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Tomorrow is Christmas. Following are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended; Sunday regulations in effect. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Government offices - Closed. Post offices - Closed; only special delivery and express mail delivered. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Subway and buses on Sunday schedules; Long Island Rail Road and Conrail on holiday schedules. Libraries - Closed. Public schools - Closed.

title: REAGAN 'SUSPENDS' ISRAEL
description: You'd think the heaviest cross Ronald Reagan had to bear was the Star of David. With Poland in agony, the President's aides spent a week debating whether the free world's leader should wear a Solidarity button. Unable to speedily counter our superpower adversary, the President vented his spleen on our minipower ally.

title: U.S. JUDGE UPHOLDS ORIGINAL DEADLINE ON EQUAL RIGHTS
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that Congress violated the Constitution when it extended the deadline for ratification of the proposed equal rights amendment. In effect, his ruling meant that the amendment, which prohibits discrimination on the basis of sex, died on March 29, 1979, the original deadline voted by Congress.

title: Money Funds' Assets Drop
description: For the first time in 30 weeks, assets of the nation's money market mutual funds have declined, Donoghue's Money Fund Report said yesterday.

title: REPUBLICANS' NEW BUDGET ROAD LOOKS A BIT ROCKY
description: Gaggles of Republican lawmakers have been trooping down to the White House in recent days and offering President Reagan sharp and often conflicting economic advice: Protect domestic programs, or sharpen the knife for another slice. Pump up the military budget, or let a little air out. Raise taxes or hold the line. Worry more about deficits, or worry less.

title: Sports of The Times; Lessons Not Learned at Harvard
description: JOE PELLEGRINI did not learn these tricks at Harvard, you understand. Ivy Leaguers are not taught to hold and slap and trip, even when they are trying to keep a defensive lineman away from their quarterback.

title: Market Place; A New Offer For Oil Stock
description: AN investment entity is offering Texas International a choice reminiscent of that faced by a widow who can either buy out her husband's business partner or sell out to him for the same money.

title: THE BEST PLACES TO SING CAROLS OR JUST TO HARK
description: Here we come a-wassailing Among the leaves so green Here we come a wandering So fair to be seen Love and joy come to you, And to you your wassail too, And God bless you and send you A happy new year Traditional English carol

title: Notes on People; Despite Criticism, Nancy Reagan Ranks No. 1
description: She has been criticized for buying expensive china, for soliciting more than $800,000 in private contributions to refurbish the White House and even for her expensive clothes. Some critics had even gone so far as to suggest that she might be a political liability to the President and he has said that she has been given a ''bum rap.''

title: P.D.Q. BACH IS OFF ON HIS ANNUAL OCTOOT, WITH NEW FLOURISHES
description: Handbills have been seen around town, and the city waits in anguish. The fliers show Peter Schickele with an extra pair of arms - elbows raised, a finger wisely in each ear as he holds a clarinet with two other hands, playing with cross-eyed concentration.

title: ROPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Notes on People; Quest for Fame She Knew in Her Homeland
description: Shirin Trainer hopes her appearance in ''House Music'' at the 92d Street Y will help make her as famous in New York as she once was in her native Turkey. The show, playing to full houses at every performance, ended its run last Sunday.

title: Officers Guilty in Killing Of Smoker on Train
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Two police officers were found guilty of involuntary manslaughter today in the beating death of a man they had arrested for smoking on a train.

title: MOST COMMUNICATIONS STILL CUT
description: All normal cable, telex and telephone communications with Poland have been shut off since Dec. 14, though the West German Postal Ministry said yesterday that some telex connections, though apparently not with Warsaw, had been restored.

title: SIGN OF NATURAL LEFT-HANDED DNA IS FOUND
description: Scientists have reported finding the first evidence in nature of a kind of genetic material, called ''left-handed'' DNA, that may help turn on and off the hereditary message of genes. The discovery could provide clues to the origins of some diseases, including cancer.

title: Campbell-Mithun Fills President Post
description: Because certain health problems in his family have ''stabilized,'' William D. Dunlap, who decided against taking the presidency of Campbell-Mithun in Minneapolis, in October, took the job last Monday. The 43-year-old executive had been president of MCA Advertising in New York, and before that an Assistant Postmaster General for Consumer Marketing.

title: BYRNE AND KEAN BACKING RAISES FOR TOP OFFICIALS
description: Governor Byrne and Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean reached agreement with legislative leaders today on bills to raise the governor's salary from $65,000 to $85,000 and the salaries of cabinet officers from $56,000 to $70,000.

title: AUSTRIA BRACES FOR FLOOD OF NEW POLISH REFUGEES
description: Gabriele Neugebauer of the Austrian Interior Ministry tried to explain why Austria was now housing, clothing and feeding some 20,000 Polish refugees and why it expected to be looking after at least twice that number soon.

title: Halt to Nuclear Plant In Jersey Is Approved
description: Directors of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company today approved the abandonment of its Hope Creek 2 nuclear power plant, saying reduced electricity demands and excessive costs had rendered the project useless.

title: 4 Are Jailed in France For Slaying Giscard Aide
description: Four men were sentenced to prison tonight for the Christmas Eve slaying in 1976 of Jean de Broglie, a political associate of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing.

title: Holiday Guide; Thursday; SCHNEIDER AT MIDNIGHT
description: Ida Levin, the 18-year-old protegee of Rudolf Serkin, who was seen recently on public television's ''In Performance at the White House,'' will be concertmistress and soloist in Bach's Violin Concerto in E at midnight tonight in Alexander Schneider's annual Christmas Eve event at Carnegie Hall. Each year, some 65 musicians of high school and college age, chosen by audition from all over this country and Europe, spend a working holiday in New York - 11 days of intensive rehearsals and chamber-music workshops under the direction of Mr. Schneider and other artists. Then they give two concerts at Carnegie Hall and one at the Kennedy Center in Washington. Tonight's performance is the first and will include three concertos by Bach and one by Corelli. The other Carnegie Hall performance will be Tuesday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $3 to $7 and can be charged by calling 247-7459.

title: INTRODUCING 'TELE-SHOPPING
description: Robin D. Jackson and Mark J. Penn found a new way to avoid the crush of Christmas shoppers this year. They ordered some gifts by typing on a computer terminal in their homes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Make no mistake. Their crime will cost them dearly in their future dealings with America and free peoples everywhere.''

title: HARVESTER REFINANCING SUPPORTED
description: Archie McCardell, chairman of the troubled International Harvester Company, predicted today that the company would suffer a ''substantial loss'' in the first quarter of 1982, following a loss of $635.7 million on continuing operations for the fiscal year 1981.

title: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: B-Including $376,000 or 26 cents a shr net gain on the sale of a Canadian manufacturing facility during the second qr of fisca 1981; 1981 fiscal yr results have been restated to give effect F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 which increased net income for the 9 m ended July 26, 1981 from the previously reported $1,176,000 or a shr to $1,457,000 or $1.01 a shr

title: SEARCH FOR KIDNAPPED GENERAL CONTINUES
description: Italian paramilitary police enter an abandoned farmhouse in Verona, looking for Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, kidnapped Dec. 17 by Red Brigades terrorists. Investigators have officially discounted a message asserting that General Dozier had been slain by his kidnappers.

title: POP: SONGS BY ARTHUR SIEGEL AT COOKERY
description: ARTHUR SIEGEL, a pianist, singer and songwriter whose songs include ''Love Is a Simple Thing'' and Eartha Kitt's hit ''Monotonous,'' has been singing, playing and talking his way through an adventurous repertory of old pop songs and obscure or overlooked songs from films and Broadway musicals for several years. His delighted and infectious fascination with the songs he sings and disguises enables him to turn a restaurant or nightclub into a semblance of a living room.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
SYRIA PUTS HOPES IN U.N. SANCTION
description: Syria expects the United Nations Security Council to impose ''the required sanctions'' against Israel if Israel does not rescind its annexation of the Golan Heights by the next Council meeting on Jan. 5.

title: 3 in Move Group Convicted
description: Three members of the radical group Move have been convicted of rioting and other charges arising from a siege that ended in a shootout with the police. The three were the last to be tried for actions in a yearlong standoff at the organization's headquarters.

title: Japan Car Output Up
description: Japan's production of passenger cars, trucks and buses, buoyed by a recovery in domestic demand, rose in November from the comparable period the year before for the first time in five months and was a record for the month. The Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said yesterday that production last month of these vehicles rose 5.2 percent, to 941,621 units, from November 1980.

title: No Headline
description: 2 OF AYATOLLAH'S BACKERS SLAIN

title: RULING AGAINST MOBIL'S BID IS UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court upheld today a district court ruling that the Mobil Corporation would violate antitrust laws if it acquired the Marathon Oil Company. But the appeals court also ruled that the competing bid of the United States Steel Corporation for Marathon included two illegal purchase options.

title: COAST GUARD HUNTS FISHING BOAT WITH CREW OF 3 FEARED LOST OFF L.I.
description: A 65-foot fishing trawler with a crew of three was reported missing in the Atlantic Ocean yesterday, and the Coast Guard said it had found debris 27 miles off Long Island.

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock distribution on June 19, 1

title: POLISH RULERS TRY TO COAX STRIKERS OUT OF SILESIAN COAL MINES FOR
description: CHRISTMAS The following article is based on information reaching news agencies from Poland.

title: NUN IS SERIOUSLY INJURED IN A MUGGING AT CONVENT
description: A 56-year-old nun wearing a traditional white habit was attacked and critically injured last night by a mugger on the steps of the Convent of Our Lady of Angels in the Bronx, the police reported.

title: P.O.O.R.
description: Twenty-two world leaders gathered recently in C ancun, Mexico, to discuss how the rich countries might help the pooro nes. They ran into an old labeling problem: how to say poor country w ithout giving offense? The problem has a long history.

title: WHEN DOCTORS DEFAULT ON STUDENT LOANS
description: To the Editor:

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Mutual Fund Sales Up
description: Sales of mutual funds other than short-term rose to $883.1 million in November from $866.5 million in October and compared with $863.6 million in November last year, according to a report by the Investment Company Institute of Washington, D.C. Redemptions, the report said yesterday, increased to $495.8 million in November from $452.1 million in the previous month. They amounted to $630.8 million in November last year. As a result, the mutual funds surveyed had net sales of $387.3 million in November, $414.4 million in October and $232.8 million in November last year, the report said.

title: SOVIET READY TO BOLSTER ITS AFGHAN FORCE
description: The Soviet Union is preparing to send more military forces and equipment, particularly helicopters, into Afghanistan, according to military analysts here.

title: Price Index Dips Abroad
description: New international data strongly indicate that a recession has slowed inflation not only in this country but also in other industrial countries, the Conference Board said yesterday.

title: Suns 118, Warriors 103
description: PHOENIX (AP) - Len (Truck) Robinson scored 30 points and Dennis Johnson added 17 as Phoenix won its third straight. Robinson had 17 of his points in the first half as Phoenix (15-10) built up a 10-point lead and coasted to its 11th home victory in 13 games.

title: U.C.L.A. 83, L.S.U. 76
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) - U.C.L.A. (5-2) won its fourth consecutive game before 28,880 fans in the Superdome, the fifth-largest college basketball crowd in N.C.A.A. history. The Superdome is the site of the N.C.A.A. finals in March.

title: TV Weekend; BIG BIRD, BALLET AND CHURCH SERVICES
description: THE schedule of Christmas programming is relying heavily on old favorites and traditional fare. Beginning at 9 o'clock this evening, WPIX-TV will fill its screen for three hours with the picture of a burning yule log while holiday songs fill the music track. At 8 P.M., WNET-TV is offering another repeat of ''Christmas Eve on Sesame Street,'' in which Big Bird and friends, Muppet and otherwise, set about discovering how fat Santa gets into skinny chimneys. And at 8:45, WNEW-TV is offering an unusual holiday treat in ''The Royal Ballet Salutes the U.S.A.'' Gene Kelly is the host, and the program includes Kenneth MacMillan's ''Elite Syncopations,'' choreographed to the ragtime music of Scott Joplin.

title: President Is Named At Cities Service
description: The Cities Service Company, a major domestic integrated oil company with revenues last year of $7.8 billion, has chosen Robert H. Chitwood, 51 years old, as its new president and chief operating officer, effective Jan. 1. As president, he will succeed Charles J. Waidelich, 52, who will become chairman and continue as chief executive officer.

title: WATT ALTERS OFFSHORE PLAN, ORDERING CURB OF LEASE SITES
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt has ordered a major refinement of his heavily criticized offshore oil and gas leasing program in an apparent effort to reduce opposition without sacrificing significant energy potential.

title: FORMER ANTIWAR ACTIVISTS AWARDED $711,000 IN 'RED SQUADS' CASE
description: A Federal jury today awarded seven former antiwar and civil rights activists and a peace organization a total of $711,000 in damages, to be paid by 14 officers of long-disbanded Federal and city ''Red squads.''

title: Civilian Rule in '85, Liberian Leader Vows
description: The Liberian leader, Master Sgt. Samuel Doe, said today that his country would be returned to civilian rule on April 12, 1985.

title: Acquisition of Currier Is Paying Off for Giants' Defensive Unit
description: According to Bill Currier, it was economics that forced him to spend most of last season on the New England Patriots' bench. Coach Ron Erhardt already had higher-paid athletes for his secondary, and they had to be played.

title: uf1Barnum an Agency For Johnson & Johnson
description: Barnum Communications, which is largely in the health care field, has just been added to the ad agency roster of Johnson & Johnson.

title: Another Spinks Mishap
description: Leon Spinks, who beat Muhammad Ali for the heavyweight championship in 1978 and lost the title to him seven months later, was treated for minor head injuries in a Detroit hospital yesterday after the car he was driving collided with a taxi. Since dropping out of the heavyweight limelight, Spinks has lost a $45,000 fur coat and his dentures in a scuffle outside a bar; been placed on probation for carrying a concealed weapon, and has received at least seven traffic tickets in seven states for driving violations. ... Arturo Frias, the newly crowned World Boxing Council lightweight champion, who got a shot at the title Dec. 5 when Sonny Gonzallo Montellano withdrew from a bout against then-champion Claude Noel, will fight Montellano in his first title defense Jan. 30 at Olympic Auditorium.

title: Chinese Novelist Is Elected Chairman of the Writers Union
description: China announced the election today of Ba Jin, a novelist, as chairman of the Chinese Writers Association amid widespread concern about maintaining newly increased literary freedom.

title: SLAUGHTER BROS INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss after $1,044,000 tax credit

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Nov
Spurs, Cavaliers Agree On Four-Player Trade
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers and San Antonio Spurs have agreed on a four-player trade and will make the formal announcement Thursday, according to a published report.

title: IN WARSAW: CHRISTMAS TREES, NO SMILES
description: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland.

title: LATEST AUTO SALES OF BIG 3 OFF 22.5%
description: As the worst sales year in more than two decades drew to a close, Detroit's Big Three auto makers reported today that car sales in mid-December had fallen 22.5 percent from last December's pace - all but guaranteeing that total 1981 sales would be well below even the most pessimistic industry forecasts. .

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Pop Jazz; FOR CHITA RIVERA, CLUBS NOW HAVE TOP PRIORITY
description: ALTHOUGH Chita Rivera studied at the American School of Ballet for a dancing career and has been a singing star in the musical theater since she played Anita in ''West Side Story'' in 1957, cabaret is now her No. 1 priority. At the New Ballroom this weekend and all next week, she is doing the latest version of a cabaret act that she started seven years ago almost against her will.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
VAN WYCK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: B-Including $5,600 or 1 cent a shr tax credit...C-Net loss

title: VALUES AND TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: HENRY B. STEINBACH, PROFESSOR OF BIOLOGY AND DIRECTOR OF LAB
description: Henry Burr Steinbach, professor emeritus of biology at the University of Chicago and director emeritus at the Marine Biological Laboratory at Woods Hole, Mass., died Monday at Falmouth Hospital in Falmouth, Mass. He was 76 years old and lived in Woods Hole.

title: MARKET NATIONS STEP UP CASTIGATION OF WARSAW
description: The 10 Common Market countries, in a joint statement published today, condemned ''the grave violation of the human and civil rights of the Polish people.''

title: LATINS' TRAINING IN U.S. RAISES QUESTIONS OF CRIMINAL AND INTERNATIONAL LAW
description: Private paramilitary training in the United States by Latin American exiles who say they are planning to overthrow leftist regimes in Nicaragua, Cuba and Panama is raising questions of whether criminal statutes and international law are being violated.

title: 161 Confess Fraud In Weeklong Amnesty
description: Investigators in the State Attorney's office say Florida will recover between $125,000 and $150,000 from 161 persons who confessed to welfare fraud in a weeklong amnesty program.

title: U.S. Customs Agents Are Told to Be Courteous
description: The United States Government is asking personnel at ports of entry to treat all foreign visitors courteously.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CONGRESS LIBRARIAN AND UNESCO OFFICIAL
description: Luther H. Evans, a former Librarian of Congress who served as director-general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization from 1953 to 1958, died yesterday in San Antonio, where he lived.

title: China Forms New Bank
description: The Government of China has formed a new bank specializing in collecting foreign funds for domestic investment and credit, according to the New China News Agency in Peking.

title: 'WRONG KID' IS FATALLY SHOT IN FIGHT AT BROOKLYN SCHOOL
description: A 17-year-old student, bystander to a dispute over a stolen coat in a Brooklyn schoolyard, was fatally shot yesterday morning by a gunman who mistook him for someone else, officials said.

title: U.S. EXPORTS TO POLAND EXCEED IMPORTS
description: The United States sells far more goods to Poland than it buys from that Communist-bloc nation, according to Commerce Department figures, although the totals being shipped in either direction are relatively small.

title: ART: 32 STORIES OVER CITY A 'BOOMERANG' SOARS
description: ''BOOMERANG,'' an elegant sculpture of sky-gray steel pipes and rods, is cantilevered off a set-back corner on the 32d floor of the old McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West 42d Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Its point, thrusting seven terrifying feet over a parapet into thin air, holds an observation platform that looks southeast over Manhattan. The spectacular downtown view is enriched by a giant mirror that forms a flat, boomerang-shape plane set at a right angle to the point. Turning from the platform to look in the mirror, one is all but dizzied by the disorienting relationships it creates among the sculpture, building, street, surrounding edifices and sky.

title: MUSIC: 3,000-VOICE SING-ALONG 'MESSIAH'
description: THERE was once a time, now long ago and barely remembered, when people who wanted to hear music used to make it. Opera lovers would drag out their vocal scores, try to hit a fair percentage of the notes on a family upright piano and warble out a few of their favorite arias. Symphony lovers would do the same, pounding out flute lines and string tremolos on the worn keys, making up for the poor orchestration with musicianly earnestness.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 24, 1981
description: International The imposition of economic sanctions against Poland was announced by President Reagan. In a national televised address, the President deplored the Warsaw Government for ''outrages'' against Poles and said he had warned the Kremlin that if the crackdown in Poland continued, the United States would take ''concrete political and economic measures'' against the Soviet Union. (Page A1, Column 6.) Polish workers' resistance to martial law has been more widespread and persistent than the authorities anticipated, according to information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Knowledgeable sources said that perhaps as many as 20,000 people had been arrested or interned since a roundup began Dec. 13. Many of the prisoners, the sources said, have little food, clothing or heating in temperatures as low as 10 degrees. (A1:4-5.)

title: WALKING TOUR AT CHRISTMAS
description: NEW YORK at holiday time erupts in golds and greens and reds, colors that hint of things special. It is a time of happy anticipation and easing of pace in the gloomy gathering of winter. The Manhattan skyline, as best seen from surrounding boroughs and New Jersey, is a shimmering forest of gilded buildings - Christmas trees in light -the Empire State, the World Trade Center, Con Ed, the Metropolitan Life, all sparkling after dark and easing the pain of waiting in traffic or elsewhere. Like all dreamy things, this beauty may disintegrate on touch, but from afar it is a rare vision of what could be.

title: ATLANTIC OIL CORP (DENVER, COLO) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Auctions; The market slows down.
description: THE five-year international boom in art-auction sales has ended with the worldwide recession finally taking its toll on the auction market. This became evident this week when the London-based artauction houses were expected to announce their midseason totals. Christie's did announce its totals, which are up slightly compared with last season, but Sotheby Parke Bernet did not issue figures.

title: CHRISTMAS SALES TOP PREDICTIONS
description: Christmas retail business, the most important of the year for the nation's stores, is winding up better than expected. But sharp price discounting has held down profits, which normally swell in the outburst of seasonal buying.

title: CORRECTION CHIEF CRITICAL OF WILKERSON PROBATION
description: A Manhattan judge's decision to release Cathlyn P. Wilkerson, a former member of the Weather Underground, after less than one year in prison was criticized yesterday by the state's Commissioner of Correctional Services.

title: DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST REFLECT DONORS' THOUGHTS OF CHILDREN
description: It is often said that Christmas is a time for children. And frequently those who make donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ask that their gifts reflect that spirit and be sent along to those causes and organizations dedicated to the needs of children.

title: No Headline
description: SMUGGLED POLISH LETTER DEPICTS A STREET BATTLE IN THE PORT OF GDANSK

title: News Analysis
description: Although a new survey showed this week that rising crime rates were the No. 1 concern of New Yorkers, Mayor Koch says he will not change his mind about trimming police hiring when he presents his preliminary budget for the

title: IRISH ECONOMY: GROWTH FALTERS
description: As in past years, Christmas shoppers this season thronged the sidewalks of this capital city, particularly the increasingly fashionable areas below the languid River Liffey, where the narrower streets add a touch of charm.

title: TOP POSTS TO ENGINEER AT HATZEL & BUEHLER
description: Hatzel & Buehler Inc., one of the nation's oldest and largest electrical construction concerns, has elected Bernard Finkelstein, 55, as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Robert A. Goeller Jr., 53, who was named chairman of the New York-based corporation.

title: Home Improvement; LEAKY PIPES CAN OFTEN BE FIXED BY DO-IT-YOURSELFERS
description: ALEAKY pipe can cause quite a mess. Regardless of whether the leak is a pinhole caused by the metal rusting through or a split caused by a pipe bursting after it freezes, the flow of water should be quickly stopped by shutting off the water supply - even if it means shutting off the main valve that controls the flow of water to the entire house.

title: RELIGION IS FOUND A STRONG FORCE IN CITY'S LIFE
description: New Yorkers On New York Third article of a series appearing periodically. By KENNETH A. BRIGGS

title: WORKER LOSES ARM BUT REGAINS HAND
description: In what may be a medical first, surgeons said today that they used the hand from a mechanic's severed right arm to replace his mangled left hand.

title: POLISH AMBASSADOR FLEES HIS TOKYO POST AND DEFECTS TO U.S.
description: The Polish Ambassador to Japan has defected to the United States to protest the military crackdown in his homeland, American and Japanese officials announced yesterday.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Best wishes for a happy and joyous Christmas in 1981. Ambassador Zdzislaw Rurarz, somewhere over the Pacific, on the way to a free America." - A note written by the former Polish Ambassador to Japan. (4:4).

title: DEATH PENALTY ASKED AS TURKEY TRIES 52 UNIONISTS
description: Fifty-two leaders of Turkey's Confederation of Revolutionary Trade Unions were put on trial in Istanbul today with the prosecution asking for the death penalty.

title: Primate Urges Ulster Peace
description: Cardinal Tomas O Fiaich, the Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, issued a call for unity today and appealed for a Christmas cease-fire in Northern Ireland's sectarian bloodshed.

title: REAGAN FACES POTENTIAL PROBLEMS, BUT IS VIEWED AS HOLDING STRENGTH
description: President Reagan has come to the end of a year of dramatic political change facing serious potential problems, but many politicians and voters say the difficulties do not yet appear to be punishing him or his party.

title: MAIN LIBRARY TO REVIVE UNUSED EXHIBITION AREA
description: The main exhibition room of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, which was opened in 1911 but has not been used for displays since World War II, will be refurbished as the result of a $1.25 million grant from the D. S. and R. H. Gottesman Foundation.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Circle K Corp. said it intended to purchase up to $3 million of common stock of Nucorp Energy Inc. in the open market.

title: Biggest Event of '81: Ali's Retirement
description: WHAT was the biggest single sports event in 1981? The baseball strike comes to mind immediately, along with a variety of repercussions, including the split season and immoral pennant races, especially if the end result is the departure of Bowie Kuhn as commissioner. The improvement of the football Giants and Jets - if it is improvement and not just the effect of Pete Rozelle's parity scheduling - has had New York in a tizzy for weeks. There was plenty to captivate racing people - John Henry's charge through the $3 million mark, the springtime of Pleasant Colony and John Campo, Before Dawn's irresistible way with fillies.

title: Washington Fills Void In '82 Football Schedule
description: Washington, preparing for a Rose Bowl appearance New Year's Day, announced today that it will face Texas-El Paso as a substitute opponent to open the 1982 season in Seattle Sept. 11.

title: Around the Nation; Defense Is Denied Data In Atlanta Slayings Case
description: Lawyers for Wayne B. Williams lost their bid for police murder records dating back 10 years today when a judge canceled subpoenas seeking the information.

title: Surplus of U.S. Cheese Is Distributed on Coast
description: Thousands of poor people in northern California shared in 168,000 pounds of surplus processed cheese today, the first of 30 million pounds to be given away by Presidential order.

title: THOUSANDS JOIN RITES FOR OFFICER KILLED IN JERSEY
description: Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco's state police career was filled with tributes and on this, the day before Christmas, he received his last.

title: FOR A DU PONT, BUSINESS IS A TOOL IN FOREIGN AID
description: What could be closer to the heart of the Reagan Administration's foreign aid policy than a Bureau for Private Enterprise? And what better name could be found to direct it than a du Pont?

title: Hill's Four Goals Lead Manic Over Cosmos, 8-4
description: Gordon Hill scored four goals and assisted on another, and Frank O'Brien had two goals and three assists to lead the Montreal Manic to an 8-4 victory over the Cosmos in a North American Soccer League indoor game at the Montreal Forum Wednesday night.

title: Auto Makers Iding 100,000
description: The five big American auto makers, with sales at their lowest in 22 years, will lay off nearly 100,000 workers after the first of the year.

title: Body May Be Windsurfer
description: The body of a man found floating off Point Dume today was tentatively identified as that of a windsurfer swept out to sea in stiff winds. The body, wearing a wetsuit, was found by a Coast Guard helicopter after an all-night search for Tom Davidson, 55 years old. He was last seen about 5:30 P.M. Wednesday as he was swept out to sea by 25-knot winds.

title: James F. Engers Dies; A Longtime U.N. Aide
description: James F. Engers, a former Dutch diplomat who worked for the United Nations for 30 years and who was director of its Council for Namibia, died of a heart attack Wednesday night in New York. He was 67 years old.

title: Sports People; Bench Eyes Third
description: Johnny Bench, a catcher with the Cincinnati Reds before his concern for his longevity in baseball led him to play more at first base last season, said he is eager to be the full-time third baseman now that the team has traded Ray Knight. When he took over at first during the summer from Dan Driessen, there were reports of some hard feelings on the team.

title: News Analysis
description: In his new set of economic actions against the Polish Government and warnings to the Soviet Union, President Reagan has walked a middle ground between West European hesitancy and restraint and right-wing domestic pressures for a tougher stand on the crackdown in Poland.

title: A STUBBORN COMPANY TOWN WINS DELAY IN ITS DEATH SENTENCE
description: When the colored people, as they call themselves still, asked the coal company for indoor plumbing three years ago, the company turned them down, explaining that company housing was coming to an end. When the company store was closed a year ago, there was no subtlety in the message that the time was nigh.

title: AVANT-GARDE: FILM SURVEY BY NIBLOCK
description: At Phill Niblock's Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Tuesday night, an electronic bass drone was projected out of speakers, shifting in character every few minutes, while silent films from Mr. Niblock's world travels were projected on a screen.

title: Pennsylvania Governor Kills Measure to Restrict Abortion
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh has vetoed a comprehensive abortion bill that would have made it more difficult for women to have abortions in Pennsylvania.

title: POLICE IN MILWAUKEE RETURN TO BEATS AFTER ILLEGAL STRIKE
description: Police officers returned to their beats at noon today, ending a tense 16-hour walkout that followed the killings of two members of the force.

title: Sara Krulwich CANDLELIGHT MARCH
description: One of the protesters who took part in demonstration in New York last night against the declaration of martial law in Poland. Protesters marched from St. Patrick's Cathedral to the Polish Consulate.

title: Dr. Roland Holloway Is Dead; Directed Emergency Services
description: Dr. Ronald Holloway, a former director of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation's emergency medical services division, which operates the city's ambulances, died Sunday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 47 years old and lived in Pennington, N.J.

title: HARD TIMES FOR U.S. LABOR
description: IT would seem, this Christmas morning, that workers have come a long way since the time of Scrooge, the proprietor of a counting house and a hard-hearted employer if ever there was one.

title: MELVILLE G. MAGIDA
description: Dr. Melville G. Magida, an assistant professor at Cornell University's College of Medicine and clinical professor of medicine at the New York Medical College, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 58 years old.

title: REGAN CONTENDS HE HAS VOTES FOR GOVERNOR RACE
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has told politicians that he believes he has enough pledged votes to win designation as the Republican candidate against Governor Carey in next year's gubernatorial race.

title: POPE URGES POLES TO SET OWN COURSE
description: Pope John Paul II, addressing 300 Polish priests and lay people at the Vatican today, asked them to pray that Poles alone be allowed to determine their future.

title: NEW YORK CARETAKERS' TALES OF LIFE IN HISTORIC RESIDENCES
description: NOT many people in Washington Heights can say that the British Queen made a special trip uptown just to visit their home. But William Seabrooks and his wife, Jennie, who live at West 160th Street and Edgecombe Avenue, recall that day in 1976 well.

title: Jet Crewman Found at Sea
description: An Air Force crewman whose F4-E Phantom jet fighter went down was rescued today after almost a week at sea, the Air Force said. There was no sign of a second crewman who disappeared last Friday off North Carolina. A fishing boat found First Lieut. Thomas W. Tiller, 26 years old, on a raft about 45 miles from Charleston, S.C.

title: N.C.A.A. Puts Oregon On 2-Year Probation
description: Rick Bay, Oregon athletic director, said today that sanctions imposed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association against the school would ''obviously handicap'' recruiting and future revenues.

title: STRIKE OR NO STRIKE, FEWER PEOPLE ARE FLYING
description: To the Editor:

title: Rates for Meters Rise in Manhattan
description: Since last July, parking meters in much of Manhattan have been redesigned on a continuing basis to accommodate a new set of prices.

title: Christmas Beacons
description: Faith and freedom, as President Reagan aptly put it, are the twin beacons that brighten the American sky this day. Faith in the power of love to conquer cruelty; freedom to pursue the potential of every person and community. It was altogether fitting for Mr. Reagan to join his Christmas prayer to a solemn warning that Americans would, without violence, punish the foes of freedom who desecrate this holiday.

title: A TIME FOR JOY IN BURNED-OUT CHURCH IN 'VILLAGE'
description: There was no Christmas tree in the chancel of St. Luke in the Fields Episcopal Church this year. The site of last year's Christmas worship is a muddy hole, where gray concrete footings lie under a cold December rain. The side walls of the 161-year-old landmark, which were left standing when fire destroyed the edifice last March, loom unprotected over the excavation, and a pile of charred bricks recalls the three-alarm fire.

title: Steinberg Bids For Filmways
description: A group headed by Saul P. Steinberg, the financier, has made a bid to get control of Filmways Inc., a producer of motion pictures and publisher of books and magazines, Robert Weingarten, a publisher and member of the Steinberg group, said.

title: ON TRIP BACK, HEAVY HEARTS AND BUNDLES
description: Day after day for the last year or more, Poles have been arriving in the Austrian capital aboard the Chopin Express to seek refuge.

title: Around the Nation; Illinois to Let Residents Purchase Machine Guns
description: Illinois residents will be allowed to buy machine guns effective Jan. 1, in part because a machine-gun manufacturer threatened to move out of the state.

title: YOUTH ARRESTED, SUSPECT SOUGHT IN SCHOOL DEATH
description: A 16-year-old youth was arrested and two other persons were questioned yesterday in the fatal shooting on Wednesday of a student on a high school field in Brooklyn. A fourth individual was still being sought.

title: Arthur Laro of Houston Dies; Led a Newspaper Syndicate
description: Arthur Laro, former president of the Chicago Tribune-New York Daily News Syndicate, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 69.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Because of the holiday, these tables were not available: Foreign Exchange, World Gold and London Metal Market.

title: A Polish Cellist Applies For Asylum in the U.S.
description: A 31-year-old Polish cellist who has been studying at Yale University announced today that she had applied for political asylum in the United States.

title: 4 VETERANS END VIETNAM TRIP NERVOUS ABOUT RETURN TO U.S.
description: Four American veterans of the Vietnam War left here today after a six-day visit, convinced that they had achieved a breakthrough with the Hanoi Government and nervous about the reception that awaited them at home.

title: No Headline
description: Sugar Import Rise Is 11%

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ACERBIC

title: Bradford National Sells a Division
description: The Bradford National Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced the purchase, by the McDonnell Douglas Automation Company, of Bradford Systems and Administrative Services divisions for $11.5 million.

title: Around the Nation; 200,000 Delayed Deaths From Asbestos Forecast
description: A Government study concludes that more than 200,000 Americans will die before the end of this century because they were exposed to asbestos in earlier years, it was reported Wednesday.

title: Symbols Are Important
description: This is the season of symbols. The star of Bethlehem and the chant of peace and good will to men are ancient symbols still full of life because the age-old aspirations remain beyond our grasp.

title: TOP COAST REPUBLICANS HEADING FOR A COLLISION
description: Lieut. Gov. Mike Curb and Attorney General George Deukmejian, California's top Republican officeholders, are on a collision course, their political careers at stake in a confrontation for the Republican gubernatorial primary next June.

title: A VALUE-ADDED TAX IS GOOD FOR THE PEOPLE AND THE COUNTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Explosion Kills Three In a Suburb of Beirut
description: An explosion at a beach resort killed three people today and injured an undetermined number of others. Some of the victims had been attending a Christmas party.

title: Credit Union Merger Talks
description: Talks are under way aimed at merging the San Diego Navy Federal Credit Union with Alaska USA Federal Credit Union, creating the nation's largest Federal credit union.

title: 1,800 Get Pink Slips And a Blue Christmas
description: About 1,800 tin mill workers at the United States Steel Corporation's Fairless Works in Bucks County were laid off today.

title: Assets Fall At Money Funds; Lower Yields Spur Outflow
description: With their yields declining, the assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $1.4 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the first decline in 30 weeks, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: STEAMSHIP CONCERN SELECTS NEW CHIEF
description: D. Ward Fuller, 36 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of the American Steamship Company, a Great Lakes bulk commodities carrier based in Buffalo. The appointment is effective Jan. 1.

title: Helpful Hardware; LOW-PRICE HOLDERS AND CLIPS USEFUL IN THE HOME
description: MANY gadgets designed for professional situations can be put to good use in the home. Turpan Sanders, at 386 West Broadway (between Broome and Spring Streets), specializes in such items.

title: HAIG WANTS ALLIES TO ACT ON POLAND
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that it was ''very important'' for the Western allies to follow the lead of President Reagan and ''apply whatever pressures'' they could to bring about an end to the repression in Poland.

title: Sports People; Paterno Isn't Merry
description: As he has so often in the past when a coaching job opened in pro football, Joe Paterno is being mentioned again. Paterno, who was 55 years old Monday and is in his 16th year as coach at Penn State, was regarded as one of the candidates the New England Patriots' job as soon as they dropped Ron Erhardt earlier this week.

title: Hers
description: MY friend Zora is a black professor at a predominantly white university in the Middle West. A couple of months ago she called to tell me about two conversations she'd had with one of her white male colleagues, a man named Carter. He's a nice man, not so old, not unenlightened. Or so she thought. Because he seemed to understand her way of seeing things, perhaps even to share her views, she had begun thinking of him as a potential ally.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surchages on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Edward O'Gorman Dies at 65; Appellate Justice in New York
description: Edward M. O'Gorman, an acting justice of the Appellate Division of New York State Supreme Court, died Monday at Cornwall (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and a resident of Monroe, N.Y.

title: Mexico Is Buying Japanese Furnaces
description: A major Japanese steel company said it had received a $227 million order for four electric-arc furnaces for Mexico's giant steel project.

title: BRUNNER WILL BE STARTER AGAINST EAGLES JETS FOCUSING ON FERGUSON
description: Joe Klecko recalls a sack that got away. ''I had Joe Ferguson in my mitts on his goal line,'' Klecko said today, remembering the day two months ago when the Jets trounced Buffalo at Shea Stadium, ''and he got rid of the ball. Some guys - Terry Bradshaw's like that - are just hard to sack.''

title: Danish Longshoremen Act
description: Longshoremen here today refused to unload the Polish freighter Wila on the ground that their Polish colleagues were forced to load it at Gdansk ''under the military's smoking guns.''

title: Two Special Washington Cases
description: Richard Allen has temporarily lost his job as national security adviser, but he no longer has to worry about criminal prosecution. Raymond Donovan, meanwhile, keeps his job as Secretary of Labor while a special prosecutor investigates a charge of union bribery dating from his years as a construction industry executive.

title: LOUISE T. NICHOLL
description: Louise T. Nicholl, poet, novelist and an editor at E.P. Dutton for many years, died in Plainfield, N. J. on Nov. 10.

title: A.& P. Reports Quarterly Loss
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the supermarket chain, late Wednesday reported a net loss of $6.9 million for the third quarter of the year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Pepsi-Cola Bottling Co., Baltimore, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Allegheny Beverage Corp., has appointed James P. Sheridan executive vice president.

title: Sports People; Westphal 'Unwanted'
description: Paul Westphal, the free-agent guard recuperating from surgery on his right foot, said he would never again play for the Seattle SuperSonics. ''There is no way in the world I want to be somewhere where they don't particularly want me,'' said Westphal, referring to a $200,000-a-season offer that had been made by Sam Schulman, the owner, to Howard Slusher, Westphal's agent.

title: BIRTH OF A LIGHT FOR POLAND
description: President Reagan's decision to harness the power of the candle to counter the dark ''forces of tyranny'' in Poland had many contributors, former and current White House officials said today.

title: Gardening; SNOW: BANE AND BOUNTY
description: TAXI drivers and commuters may hate snow, but gardeners are free to delight in its magic. Whether on terrace or yard, a fresh dusting of snow envelops the garden in peaceful beauty.

title: PLAYER PIANO: MISCHA LEVITZKI
description: We think of music as an explicitly human activity. So it is eerie, disturbing, comic and even a little frightening to hear an inanimate collection of wood, metal and cloth create sounds resplendent with the subtle nuances that go into musical expression.

title: By Robert Curvin
description: The Editorial Notebook Bad Sports

title: SHELL, Wyo.  44 degrees 30 minutes north latitude, 108 degrees west longitude.  Winter here in Wyoming looks like a fictional place, an elaborate simplicity. Wind howls all night and day pushing litters of storm fronts from Beartooth to Big Horn mountains. And when it lets up, the mountains disappear. The hayfield that runs east from my house ends in a curl of clouds that have fallen like sails luffing from sky to ground. Snow returns across the field to me, and the cows, dusted with white, look like snowcapped continents drifting.
description: A Wyoming winter laminates then the earth with white then hardens the laquerwork with wind. Storms come announced by what oldtimers call ''mare's tails'' - long wisps that lash out from a snow cloud's body. Jack Davis, a packer who used to trail his mules all the way from Wyoming to southern Arizona when the first snows hit, said, ''The first snowball that hits you is God's fault; the second one is yours.''

title: CHARITY DILEMMA FOR BUSINESS
description: Corporate America, under pressure from President Reagan to step up charitable contributions as the Government cuts its own spending, is grappling with just how deeply it should be involved in philanthropy.

title: Cooper-Jarrett Files For Reorganization
description: Cooper-Jarrett Inc., a leading long-distance trucking company with headquarters in Morristown, N.J., announced yesterday that it will file a plan of reorganization next Monday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: JUDGE CLEARS WAY FOR U.S. STEEL BID TO BUY MARATHON
description: A ruling by a Federal judge yesterday would permit the United States Steel Corporation to purchase the Marathon Oil Company for $6.3 billion on Jan. 7, thus ending a two-month takeover battle with the Mobil Corporation.

title: Five Youths Held In Subway Attacks
description: Transit Authority police charged five young men with robbery and assault in a string of 10 subway robberies this month, most of them on the Upper West Side.

title: EMBITTERED ENVOY
description: Zdzislaw Rurarz, the Polish Ambassador to Japan who has been granted asylum in the United States, was a model product of the Communist system and the Polish Civil Service. But Mr. Rurarz was one thing more: a self-made man who achieved a steady upfrom-poverty rise in the Polish bureaucracy.
