title: MOSCOW IS SILENT ON REAGAN THREAT
description: The Soviet press agency Tass today condemned President Reagan's economic sanctions against Poland as an ''abominable intervention'' in Polish affairs but gave only a brief comment on his contention that the Soviet Union bore a major share of the blame for the Polish crackdown.

title: THE CITY
description: One man was killed and three others were wounded when a police officer and a gunman exchanged fire in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, the police said.

title: HOW A RECORDING CAN DEFEAT A DANCE
description: The invention of the phonograph may have changed the course of choreography. Whereas, in the past, choreographers either had to set composers to work writing new music or had to study and arrange existing scores, today's choreographer can simply sit down with a stack of records and choose what sounds best. But if phonograph records can be trusty friends, they can also lead choreographers astray.

title: SIMPSON OF BILLS VALUABLE RETREAD
description: Bill Simpson was content to sit in the stands with pals in the fall of 1980 and watch other people play football. One career had ended for him, an honorable one consisting of 72 consecutive games as a defensive back for the Los Angeles Rams, five straight playoff seasons, some all-star citations and four knee operations.

title: Large Oil Refinery in Rumania Is Seriously Damaged by Fire
description: A fire seriously damaged one of Rumania's largest oil refineries last night, and today the plant manager and two Communist Party officials were ousted from their jobs, the party newspaper Scinteia said.

title: Ford S.&P. Rating
description: Uncertainty over when the automobile industry will return to firmer financial ground today moved the Standard & Poor's Corporation of New York to put the Ford Motor Company and the Ford Motor Credit Company on its ''credit watch'' list.

title: MINNA FIELD
description: Minna Field, a former social service executive at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx, died Tuesday at Memorial Hospital in Hollywood, Fla.

title: Told: Walk, Don't Run
description: A month ago, she made her nationwide television debut as the protegee of the pianist Rudolf Serkin on the inaugural program of ''In Performance at the White House,'' a series presented by the Public Broadcasting Service. Last night,she was on the program as soloist with Alexander Schneider and the New York String Orchestra in the 13th annual Christmas Eve midnight concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Around the World; Civilian Advisory Panel Is Set Up in Pakistan
description: Pakistan's military ruler, President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, said today that he was forming a 350-m@ember Federal Advisory Council as the first step since 1977 toward restoring civilian rule.

title: WOUND SUGGESTS A SHARK ATTACK
description: A body tentatively identified as that of a surfer missing since Saturday washed ashore at Pacific Grove south of here today, the left side torn in a manner consistent with an attack by a great white shark.

title: Harrowing, $7.40, Wins Feature at Aqueduct
description: Harrowing took command in the stretch and beat In Rhythm by 2 1/2 lengths in the $32,000 White Christmas Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: FRY'S WAY PAYS OFF AT IOWA
description: Once there was a crewcut. Now the hair creeps over the tops of Hayden Fry's ears, and there is more hair above his upper lip. The football uniforms worn by the University of Iowa team resemble those of the Pittsburgh Steelers. The logo on the side of the black helmet is not the least bit friendly looking. There is a reason for that.

title: TIMBER SCULPTORS OF POST AND BEAM AND OAKEN FRAMES
description: ''THE world goes to hell in one direction,'' mused Ed Levin, ''and rebuilds itself in another.'' Unusual sentiments for a construction worker, perhaps, but Mr. Levin and his New Hampshire compatriot, Tedd Benson, cannot resist the idiom of evangelists when talking about their businesses. Both men build timber-frame houses, resurrecting the Old World post-and-beam structures that were abandoned in the 19th century for the easily mass-produced stud frames.

title: A TRANSCRIPT OF PRIME MINISTER'S CHRISTMAS EVE RADIO ADDRESS TO THE
description: POLES

title: Coast Guard Halts Search for 3 Men
description: The Coast Guard has discontinued the search for three missing New Jersey men whose fishing boat apparently sank off Fire Island earlier this week.

title: YELLOWSTONE'S BIGHORN SHEEP STRICKEN BY BLINDING AILMENT
description: Officials of Yellowstone Park in northwestern Wyoming are trying to determine what type of disease is causing blindness among a herd of bighorn sheep in the northern portion of the park.

title: MUGGED NUN'S ORDER VOWS TO REMAIN
description: Recent assaults on two nuns have had ''a frightening effect, but we are still determined to stay in New York and do what we can,'' the head of the Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul of New York said yesterday following the assault on one of her nuns in the Bronx Wednesday night.

title: DOMINGO IN 4TH 'MERRY WIDOW' FILM
description: Metro-Goldwyn-May-er, which is producing the film ''Yes, Giorgio'' around Luciano Pavarotti, will get another tenor into the movie act this summer when it begins filming Franz Lehar's ''The Merry Widow'' with a cast including Placido Domingo, the soprano Mariana Nicolescu and Julie Andrews. Barbra Streisand had at one time been mentioned for the role in which Miss Andrews will appear.

title: CHRISTMAS IN RURAL ENGLAND: A GOOSE, FOX HUNT
description: The opportunity to celebrate a traditional C hristmas - like those depicted in Currier & Ives prints and the kindt hat one likes to believe one's parents, or at least grandparents, e njoyed - was provided when I accepted an invitation to spend the h olidays with friends in England.

title: SEVENTH NUCLEAR SUBMARINE DELIVERED
description: The U.S.S. Boston under way on the Thames River after delivery to the Navy from the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics Corporation in Groton, Conn.

title: CONCERT: WOODSIDE LEADS ORATORIO SOCIETY IN 'MESSIAH'
description: The Oratorio Society of New York, under Lyndon Woodside, presented Handel's ''Messiah'' at Carnegie Hall Tuesday night, making a valiant stab at 18th-century style without entirely giving up the armor of large forces, the resonance of a large 19th century hall, or the comfort of modern vocal and instrumental techniques. The results were as good a compromise as one can reasonably hope for in performances of this type.

title: Videotape Venture
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said that it will start full-scale negotiations next month on a joint venture to produce videotape recorders in West Germany.

title: Bridge: A Remembrance of Jacoby And a Christmas Gift Past
description: Half a century ago one of the legendary figures in the game, Oswald Jacoby of Dallas, apparently received an unusual Christmas gift. Playing in a contract of six clubs on the diagramed deal, he received the lead of the heart ace from East.

title: Sports People; Jet, Giant All-Pros
description: Marvin Powell and Joe Klecko of the Jets and Lawrence Taylor of the Giants have been named to the all-pro team selected by the Professional Football Writers Association of America. George Rogers, the New Orleans running back, was not named to the team, but beat out Taylor for the writers' rookie-of-the-year honor.

title: U.S. CONSIDERS PRESSING FOR U.N. POLISH DEBATE
description: The Reagan Administration is actively considering pressing for a United Nations debate on the military crackdown in Poland, Jeane J. Kirpatrick, the American delegate disclosed today.

title: Briefing
description: ''W HO killed my brother?'' The question, and the personal letter that posed it 36 years ago, fairly leapt out of a file of old Government memos and data at the National Archives. By poignant coincidence, the letter, misfiled until now, was from a Polish national complaining of Soviet abuse, a letter written as a cry from the heart in behalf of a brother, a Polish officer reported murdered in World War II in the Katyn Forest massacre. Bohdan Sylwestrowicz was one of thousands of Polish officers who were found shot in the back of the head in 1939 and buried in a mass grave, a deed widely attributed to Stalin's regime but denied repeatedly in Moscow.

title: Conoco Gas Find
description: Conoco Inc. announced a ''highly significant'' natural gas find in the South China Sea about 710 miles off Jakarta, Indonesia.

title: Cody Ends Hospital Stay
description: John Cardinal John Cody was released today, his 74th birthday, from a hospital where he had been under observation since Tuesday. The Cardinal, who has a history of heart trouble, is under Federal investigation for his handling of Roman Catholic church finances.

title: ; Recycling Schools as Housing
description: THE recycling of former office and factory buildings into residences has been under way for years in many urban areas, especially New York. However, in recent years, conversions have begun to include school buildings no longer used for classes because of declining enrollments or new school construction.

title: Allies May Confer on Poland
description: The foreign ministers of the 10 Common Market countries are tentatively planning to meet here on Wednesday to review the crisis in Poland. Lord Carrington, the British Foreign Secretary, suggested to his nine counterparts last night that they ''consider the possibility of an informal meeting.''

title: RKO TV Appeal
description: RKO General Inc. asked for a rehearing of a United States Court of Appeals decision that would take away the company's license to operate WNAC-TV, its Boston television station. A petition filed with the court said the Dec. 4 decision is inconsistent with the court's holdings on other phases of the case and conflicts with a number of prior decisions by the court and by the United States Supreme Court.

title: GREECE'S GRIEVANCE AS A NATO MEMBER
description: To the Editor:

title: HAITIANS AT 2 DETENTION SITES REFUSING TO EAT AND TO TALK
description: Haitians being held at a Federal detention facility here and at a Federal prison in Lexington, Ky., stopped eating and stopped talking to their keepers today.

title: Bank of Canada Rate
description: The Bank of Canada interest rate continued its slow downward trend, slipping to 15 percent from 15.15 percent on Wednesday. Money market specialists say the bank rate, that charged chartered banks for loans from the central bank, would have increased slightly had it not been for intervention by the Bank of Canada in the weekly auction of Treasury bills at which the rate is set.

title: Nets Deal McAdoo To Lakers for Cash And Draft Choice
description: The Nets traded Bob McAdoo to the Los Angeles Lakers yesterday for a 1983 second-round draft choice and cash. The amount depends on how long he stays with the Lakers.

title: COSTS ARE PUT AT $250,000 FOR A REAGAN TRIP TO COAST
description: President Reagan leaves this weekend on his third trip home to California.since taking office. His two-week visit to his Santa Barbara ranch in August cost taxpayers at least $250,000.

title: PRISONS ENJOINED ON OVERCROWDING
description: New York State's prison system was legally restrained today from double-bunking - the practice of placing two prisoners in a cell -and from using prison corridors, recreation areas or dormitories to confine inmates.

title: LAKER AIR AND BANKS IN ACCORD
description: Sir Freddie Laker's bankers announced an agreement today to refinance $359 million in debt held by Laker Airways, which has been losing money in a trans-Atlantic fare war.

title: Court Rejects $25,000 Award As Too Small for Injured Boy
description: A Federal appeals court has rejected as too small a $25,000 award for ''pain and suffering'' for an Indian boy who suffered permanent damage from a morphine overdose while being treated at a Federal hospital.

title: POLES GET AN OUTPOURING OF GIFTS FROM AMERICANS
description: A letter came to the offices of the Polish-American Congress here the other day from a couple whose prayers had been answered.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Salvador Guerrillas Cut Power in Three Cities

title: STOCKS UP IN SLOWEST '81 SESSION
description: Stock prices, holding to a fairly typical pre-Christmas pattern, edged higher yesterday amid the slowest trading of 1981. Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange plunged to 23.9 million shares from Wednesday's 42.9 million. This marked the lowest volume since 16.1 million shares changed hands last Dec. 26, a Friday session that fell between Christmas Day and the weekend.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Miklos B. Korodi, 44, has been appointed to the new post of president of Warner Amex Security Systems, which is selling a home security alarm that operates on a two-way cable television network owned by Warner Amex Cable Communications in Columbus, Ohio.

title: No Better Gift
description: ''In charity,'' wrote Francis Bacon, ''there is no excess.'' What better time than Christmas Day to recall this counsel? The presents are unwrapped.

title: Bishop Moore Makes Peace-Pledge Request
description: The Episcopal Bishop of New York asked members of his diocese yesterday to pledge themselves to world peace on Christmas and to helping to stop the ''dance of death'' caused by fear and arms proliferation.

title: Cunningham Aide Guilty of Perjury
description: The secretary of Patrick J. Cunningham, the former Democratic state chairman in New York, has been convicted of perjuring herself at a trial in which a Rockland County man was charged with lying to shield Mr. Cunningham in a tax-evasion inquiry.

title: Van't Hof, McNamara Gain in Australian Open
description: Robert Van't Hof of the United States and second-seeded Peter McNamara of Australia won openinground matches today in the $400,000 Australian Open tennis tournament at Kooyong Courts.

title: Camden Bid to Sell Land Is Rejected
description: The Camden Municipal Port Authority rejected a proposal to sell 16 acres of prime Delaware River waterfront land for $480,000, leaving the city facing financial collapse for the second straight year.

title: Janet Maslin Wed To B. H. Cheever
description: Janet Reva Maslin and Benjamin Hale Cheever were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Cheever, in Ossining, N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Maslin of East Hills, L.I., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Village Justice Thomas Barnes of Ossining performed the ceremony.

title: Books of The Times
description: KING JESUS. By Robert Graves. 424 pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. Paper, $8.95.

title: The True Spirit Of Christmas
description: The celebration of Christmas at churches in the metropolitan area included decorations and lights in the windows of the Easton Congregational Church in Connecticut, above; the Choir School of St. Thomas Episcopal Church on Fifth Avenue singing at a Christmas Eve service, and a quiet prayer by a parishioner at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church on West 31st Street.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Ackerly Inc. said that adverse market conditions had forced it to withdraw its registration statement filed in July with the Securities and Exchange Commission, in which it asked to sell 500,000 shares of common stock.

title: Tax Forms Will Soon Be Arriving
description: Along with a few late Christmas cards, mail carriers will begin bringing another sign of the holiday season on Saturday: the 1981 Federal income tax forms.

title: Toxic Spill Shuts Thruway Section
description: Westbound traffic was restored on a 38-mile segment of the state Thruway, but eastbound motorists still faced a 26-mile detour as crews continued to clean up a highly toxic chemical spill.

title: And Still No Santa
description: In this season when everyone wishes there were a Santa Claus, here's a good measure of President Reagan's economic and political dilemma:

title: AFRICAN WAR PITS 2 AGAINST AN ARMY
description: At a rough count, there are 10 wars, revolts or insurgencies sputtering across Africa with varying intensity. Among the more obscure is a small conflict in northern Uganda in which two big game experts are taking on units of the Sudanese Army in an effort to save Uganda's elephants from extinction.

title: IRVING GERSHANOW
description: Irving Gershanow, a New York City clothing manufacturer, died Wednesday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Roslyn, L. I.

title: A LAND SACRED TO THREE FAITHS
description: In Bethlehem, Msgr. Giacomo Beltritti, flanked by Mayor Elias Freij and Lieut. Col. Shalom Noni, Israeli military governor, on the way to Christmas services at St. Catherine's Church.

title: BRUNNER WILL BE STARTER AGAINST EAGLES VAN PELT'S ROLE IN QUESTION
description: Scott Brunner is ready, Phil Simms may be, and Brad Van Pelt probably will not be. That summed up much of the Giants' status report today as they prepared for their wildcard playoff game against the Eagles in Philadelphia Sunday.

title: Transcript of speech, page 6.
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, declared in an address to the nation today that there was still a place for independent labor unions in Poland. He also denied that hundreds of Poles had been killed or held in inhumane conditions since the imposition of martial law.

title: LEAVE BACKDOORS FOR PUBLIC-SCHOOL PRAYER SHUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch's Press Secretary Stepping Down
description: After two years as Mayor Koch's press secretary, Tom Goldstein tendered his resignation yesterday.

title: POP: MANHATTAN RHYTHM KINGS GO INDOORS
description: The Manhattan Rhythm Kings, a trio of street musicians who made their indoor debut at Mickey's a little more than two years ago, returned to the club Tuesday evening - they will be there again next Tuesday - with a new member and some fresh voicings.

title: WRIGHT IN STOCK PURCHASE
description: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation said yesterday that it had increased its holdings in the Western Union Corporation to 6.5 percent, and indicated that it would consider trying to gain control of the telecommunications company.

title: A HOLIDAY STOCKING FULL OF CONCERN FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: As they reach for their Christmas stockings this morning, the five grandchilden of Beatrice and Sidney Harris of South Orange, N.J., will not find them bulging with the customary holiday toys and goodies.

title: RECYCLER BENEFITS FROM REFUSE STRIKE
description: Joseph Luzzi does not like to see mounds of smelly garbage covering the city's sidewalks. He also dislikes threading his way past gaping plastic bags of rotting lettuce leaves and coffee grounds.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1981 Companies

title: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1981
description: International Poland's leader sought to pacify the nation in a Christmas Eve address. The military commander, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, asserted that there was still a place for independent labor unions in Poland and he denied that hundreds of Poles had been killed or held in inhumane conditions under martial law. (Page 1, Column 6.) A second Polish ambassador defected to the United States. The top Polish diplomat in Japan flew to this country with his family after declaring he could no longer represent a ''regime which denies the fundamental rights of the Polish people.'' (1:5.)

title: FLORIDA AIR FARE CUT TO $114
description: Delta Air Lines yesterday announced price cuts of up to 51 percent on its normal coach fares between 24 Northern and Middle Western cities and its nine Florida destinations, including a $114 fare between New York and Florida.

title: CONFESSIONS OF A JUNK-MAIL COMPILER
description: To the Editor:

title: Semiconductor Net Declines
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation announced that its net income in the second quarter ended Dec. 13 dropped to $182,000, or 1 cent a share, from $12.5 million, or 56 cents a share, the year before. Sales slumped to $254.9 million from $260.7 million.

title: India Receives Loan
description: The World Bank today announced a $300 million loan to help finance expansion of the Ramagundam thermal power station in India.

title: Robot
description: Neiman-Marcus, the store noted for offering such unusual gifts as a real Chinese junk, his and her mummy cases and a matched pair of dirigibles at $50,000 each, has among its offerings this year a $15,000 robot to do household chores.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Friends have given us a gadget for rolling newspapers into ''logs'' so that we can burn them in the newly installed fireplace in our country house. We still intend to use regular logs, but can you tell us if there is a danger of toxic gases from the newspaper ink if we do burn those rolled-up newspapers? - V.D.F., Manhattan.

title: Sports People; Cosmos Deal Belgian
description: The Cosmos sold Francois Van der Elst, a Belgian midfielder, to West Ham United of the English First Division. Van der Elst, who had made clear that he was eager to leave so that he would be free to play on the Belgian World Cup team in 1982, joined the Cosmos midway through the 1980 season, having served as captain of the Belgian national team that reached the final of the European Nations Cup before losing to West Germany.

title: JERSEY UNIT SEES UPTURN FOR ECONOMY LATE IN '82
description: The New Jersey economy should begin to rebound from the current recession in the second half of 1982 and bring about modest gains in personal income, an advisory group appointed by Governor Byrne said today.

title: Another Side to Steinbrenner
description: The principal owner of the New York Yankees, George M. Steinbrenner, is well known for his rages against the baseball players and managers he employs. But there is a more charitable side to him.

title: 8 PERSONS KILLED IN HOUSE FIRES IN NORTH JERSEY
description: Eight persons, including six children, were killed in separate blazes that swept through multifamily homes in two northern New Jersey cities yesterday. Both fires were listed as suspicious, authorities said.

title: ON THE GRACEFUL ART OF RECEIVING GIFTS
description: WHEN I was very little -young enough to believe in a Santa Claus who brought gifts to children, but not to grown-ups - it occurred to me, one Christmas Eve, that I had nothing to give to my parents. Even if I had had more time, of course, I had no money or means of shopping. I had an idea, however: I would give them a pair of stuffed dogs that sat on one of my toy shelves.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ARCHBISHOP'S LETTER
description: Following are excerpts from a pastoral letter written by Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Primate of Poland, to be read in all Polish churches tonight. An Italian text of the letter, translated from the Polish by the Polish episcopal delegation to the Vatican, was translated by The New York Times.

title: MUSIC: INTERNATIONAL STRINGS
description: The International String Quartet offered a program of unusual interest Monday at Carnegie Recital Hall, and played most of it with conviction if not, in every case, the highest degree of refinement. The group, which is quartet in residence at Brown University, opened with what turned out to be its weakest performance of the evening, an account of Schubert's ''Quartettsatz'' in C minor that lacked the requisite propulsion and tension, and occasionally resorted to gestures too large for the hall.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: SOME MINERS RESURFACE AS OTHERS CONTINUE TO STRIKE
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: REAGAN SIGNS BILL REQUIRING ESTIMATE OF COSTS TO STATES
description: Under the new law, signed Wednesday by the President, the Congressional budget office would have to attach a fiscal note to each bill if the estimated cost to state and local governments exceeded $200 million or if the cost would have an extraordinary regional impact.

title: Books of The Times; Odd Album of Horror
description: THE AUSCHWITZ ALBUM: A Book Based Upon an Album Discovered by a Con- centration Camp Survivor, Lili Meier. Text by Peter Hellman. Illustrated. Random House. $23.50.

title: MUSTERING-OUT 101: HOW TO GET A JOB
description: In a Pentagon auditorium the other evening, a civilian management consultant confronted a gathering of military officers with a sobering thought. ''You're in one world now, but you're going into another world,'' he said. ''We're not talking about the Army now, we're talking about the real world.''

title: Consumer Saturday; ARE REPAIR CONTRACTS WORTH IT?
description: It is your security blanket, the salesman may say, for that cold, lonely night when the car won't start or the scorching day when the air-conditioner dies or the week that the freezer decides it is time to defrost.

title: MINNA FIELD
description: Minna Field, a former social service executive at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx, died Tuesday at Memorial Hospital in Hollywood, Fla.

title: RESTORING WORKS FROM 2,500-YEAR-OLD TOMB
description: Paola Aureli Casagrande, an art expert, working on artifacts discovered in an Etruscan tomb in Veii, 15 miles north of Rome. The tomb appears to be that of a boy, no older than 5, of a royal family. Jewelry and a scepter were found at the site, as well as a four-wheeled chariot.

title: Dutch Nuclear Plant Shut
description: The only commercial Dutch nuclear power plant was taken out of operation last night after a leak was found in one of its cooling pumps, the provincial electricity authority said. The 450-megawatt plant at Borssele is likely to be out of action for about five days, it said.

title: NEW POLISH MILITARY RULERS: AN OLD-BOY NETWORK
description: United States military analysts say that the Polish military council ruling under martial law appears to be a cohesive group of accomplished professional officers.

title: BRITISH PRESS DENOUNCES BAN ON PAISLEY
description: A broad segment of public opinion, both here and in Ireland, has united against the American Government's decision this week to bar a visit by the Rev. Ian Paisley.

title: SHARING FOUND TO BE DECLINING; News Analysis
description: Even before the conviction of Joseph M. Margiotta, the practice of splitting governmental insurance commissions with politicians who did little or nothing to earn them had been declining in New York.

title: Cody Is Hospitalized Again
description: John Cardinal Cody, who left a hospital bed Christmas Eve to celebrate midnight mass, was readmitted to Northwestern Memorial Hospital today for an undisclosed illness. Greg Turner, a hospital spokesman, said that Cardinal Cody returned to the hospital about 5 P.M. and was in fair condition. The 74-year-old cardinal, who was first admitted Tuesday, has a history of heart trouble.

title: SLIPPAGE IN OIL PRICE IS POSSIBLE
description: Although the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has promised to freeze crude oil prices until the end of 1982, oil industry analysts now question whether OPEC will in fact be able to prevent prices from slipping.

title: Small Growth Seen in Travel
description: The travel industry, plagued by a poor economy and the air traffic controllers' strike in 1981, is taking a ''wait and hope'' attitude toward 1982.

title: MARY DEL RIO
description: Mary Washington Morosini del Rio, a direct descendant of Samuel Washington, the elder brother of George Washington, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: Movie Makeup Artists Now Eligible for Oscar
description: HOLLYWOOD (UPI) - The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has a new category for Academy Awards - makeup. Fay Kanin, president of the academy, said a maximum of three nominees for makeup would be chosen by a committee from seven movies picked by all academy members who are active makeup and hair stylists. The panel can also decide whether one movie should be considered or that no award be presented that year.

title: The Region
description: HARTFORD (AP) - The police shot and killed a 56-year-old city resident who had threatened a neighbor and then injured a policeman with a knife, authorities said.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1981
description: International Resistance to martial law was urged on Polish workers by leaders of the Warsaw branch of the suspended Solidarity union. A Solidarity news bulletin clandestinely distributed in Warsaw reported that negotiations were under way between officials of the Polish Episcopate and the country's top Communist Party officials, who were said to be seeking ''a political solution'' to the martial law crisis. (Page 1, Column 6.) Moscow accused the U.S. of fomenting the unrest in Poland in an attempt to pry Poland from the Soviet bloc. A detailed article in Pravda charged that the events in Poland over the last 17 months were part of a long intricate campaign undertaken by the United States. Western diplomats were more impressed by what the 3,600-word article revealed about the Kremlin's insecurity and suspicion than by its claims of American machinations. (1:5.)

title: KENTUCKY THRIVES DESPITE LOSS OF BOWIE
description: Joe B. Hall, the Kentucky basketball coach, said he thought he had solved his team's problem in the frontcourt. Kentucky's problem would have been a fantasy for most coaches: there was Mel Turpin, a 6-foot-11-inch, 240-pound sophomore, and there was Sam Bowie, the 7-foot-1-inch, 230-pound junior, and the most important player on the team.

title: Sports People; Slipping Hawkeyes
description: Hayden Fry is not complaining, not when Iowa's football team is preparing for its first Rose Bowl appearance in 23 years. It's just that the Hawkeyes have not played on natural grass since last season, and they have a lot to learn before the New Year's Day game with Washington in Pasadena, Calif.

title: ON A MOSTLY GRAY CHRISTMAS, CROWDS AND CALLS PROVIDE JOY
description: It was not a white Christmas, to be sure, dulled as it was to a sort of coastal, oyster gray. But in certain spots of the city, something shimmered, if only briefly. For many, the day was bright.

title: SOME REPUBLICANS OPPOSE EFFORTS TO ABOLISH U.S. EDUCATION DEPT.
description: Some Republicans who generally support President Reagan are opposing the Administration's efforts to dismantle the 19-month-old Department of Education.

title: PIANO: BLUMFIELD RETURNS
description: It has been 23 years since Coleman Blumfield, the pianist, made his New York recital debut at what was then the Lexington Avenue Y.M.- Y.W.H.A. For 16 of those years he was absent from the New York concert stage; he resurfaced at Alice Tully Hall four seasons ago.

title: LAWYERS' '80 RAISES SMALLER
description: Salaries of the top lawyers on corporate legal staffs rose 12.9 percent last year, compared with a 13.4 percent gain in 1979, according to a survey.

title: AULD LANG MOSCOW
description: Watching the Russians watching Poland reminds me of old people angry at a world that won't stand still.

title: Mihara to Fight Moore
description: Tadashi Mihara of Japan will defend his World Boxing Association junior-middleweight title against Davey Moore of New York in Tokyo Feb. 2, Mihara's manager, Hitoshi Misako, said Friday. Mihara will be making the first defense of the title he won Nov. 7 at Rochester by outpointing Rocky Fratto of Geneva, N.Y., for the vacant title. Moore, who is 22 years old, is ranked No.10 by the W.B.A.

title: New Jersey Officials Deserve a Raise
description: New Jersey's Governor-elect Thomas Kean says several people he seeks for his administration are reluctant to accept appointment because they cannot afford cuts in pay. That's why he backs a state commission report recommending substantial raises for the Governor, Cabinet members and judges. Mr. Kean, a businessman, knows that talent is costly but worth the price.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: SOVIET MEAT AND FUEL
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: Sports People; Move Over, Gretzky
description: Kathy Lawler, a hockey player at Potsdam State College in New York, is making Wayne Gretzky look like a pushover. As a freshman, she had 74 goals and 46 assists.

title: Dr. J.E. Dunphy, 73; Set Up Trauma Center
description: J. Englebert Dunphy, a pioneering surgeon who began a nationally acclaimed trauma center at San Francisco General Hospital, died Friday at his home.

title: Pennsylvania Legislator Dies
description: State Representative Thomas J. McCall of Summit Hill died Thursday night in Carbondale Hospital. He was 46 years old. Mr. McCall, a Democrat, was serving his fourth consecutive term and represented the 122d Legislative District of Carbon and Luzerne counties.

title: Patents; EQUIPMENT MONITORS PATIENTS IN SHOCK
description: The Institute of Critical Care Medicine, Los Angeles, received a patent this week on apparatus for monitoring the condition of seriously ill patients.

title: Lana Turner to Appear On CBS's 'Falcon Crest'
description: HOLLYWOOD (AP) - Lana Turner will appear in a guest role on CBS-TV's ''Falcon Crest.''

title: Strauss and Jacobi Sign For Animated 'NIMH'
description: Peter Strauss and Derek Jacobi have signed to be the voices of two leading characters in an animated feature, ''The Secret of NIMH,'' to be made by Don Bluth Productions.

title: Around the World; 4 Die in Tanker Blaze In St. Lawrence River
description: Fire broke out on a Canadian oil tanker today, killing at least 4 of the 21 crew members, a Canadian Coast Guard official said. Four others were missing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we display our intention to fight against the regime of Jaruzelski, these negotiations can make possible a way out of this blind alley in which society and the Polish state find themselves.'' - Solidarity news bulletin distributed clandestinely in Warsaw. (1:6.)

title: 'LOST' INDIAN TRIBE SEEKS RECOGNITION AND A HOME
description: The International Bridge linking this dusty South Texas border town of 22,000 with Piedras Negras across the Rio Grande carries commerce worth millions of dollars every month between the United States and Mexico.

title: Patents; DENTAL FILLER USES GLASSY GRAINS
description: A research unit of the American Dental Association, operating out of the National Bureau of Standards in Gaithersburg, Md., has developed glassy filler grains to be used in filling teeth.

title: Patents; A GLOWING ARTIFICIAL GEMSTONE
description: A brilliant crystal gemstone made from Alexandrite, a grass-green mineral that glows red under artificial light, was patented this week for Allied Corporation, Morristown, N.J. Stanley W. Urban of Sparta, N.J., who has long designed gemstones as a hobby, obtained patent 4,306,427 on the jewelry.

title: EX-HEAD OF UNITED AIRCRAFT CORP.
description: William P. Gwinn, former chairman and chief executive officer of the United Aircraft Corporation, predecessor of the United Technologies Corporation of Hartford, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 74 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: BMT RIDER IS KILLED IN APPARENT HOLDUP AT 23RD STREET STATION
description: A subway rider was fatally shot and apparently robbed yesterday morning as he left a deserted BMT subway station at 22d Street and Broadway.

title: WHEN REAGAN TALKS TOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: HOCKEY

title: FERGUSON AND HIS RECEIVERS SEE JETS TOUGHER THAN BEFORE
description: In six games against the Jets over the last three seasons, Joe Ferguson has completed 94 of 152 passes for 1,350 yards. Ten passes went for touchdowns and only four were intercepted.

title: WHY THE HOSTILITY TOWARD BULGARIA?
description: To the Editor:

title: RESCUED AFTER SIX DAYS AT SEA
description: First Lieut. Thomas W. Tiller being brought ashore at Charleston, S.C. Lieutenant Tiller was a crewman of an Air Force F-4E jet that crashed on a training flight Dec. 18.

title: Sports People; Oregon Backs Coach
description: Rich Brooks, who offered his resignation as coach in 1979, when the National Collegiate Athletic Association began its investigation of recruiting violations in the University of Oregon football program, was given a vote of confidence by the athletic director one day after the N.C.A.A. announced that the school had been placed on a two-year probation. ''I don't think Coach Brooks and the other coaches had any any knowledge of some of the charges,'' said the athletic director, Rich Bay.

title: 'EARLY WARNINGS' ON DEBT BY S.&P.
description: Corporations have always feared having the credit ratings on their corporate debt lowered. Now the Standard & Poor's Corporation, one of the nation's leading credit rating organizations, has added a new device for calling attention to a company's potential credit problems.

title: FOCUS OF TRIAL WASN'T PATRONAGE AS USUAL, BUT RATHER ITS MISUSE; News Analysis
description: Did a jury convict Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican leader of Nassau County, for doing nothing more than many other political leaders have done?

title: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 26, 1981; Energy
description: OPEC's ability to keep crude oil prices from slipping is being questioned by oil industry analysts. The 13-nation group has pledged to maintain its base price for crude oil at $34 a barrel through 1982, but worldwide oversupply and recession could force this price downward. (Page 35.)

title: CRISIS IN POLAND PART OF U.S. PLOT, PRAVDA CHARGES
description: The Soviet Union today published the most comprehensive charges to date that events in Poland over the last 17 months were part of a long and intricate campaign by the United States to wrest Poland from the Communist camp.

title: GUYANA AND VENEZUELA
description: There is a strange silence in Washington ington on an issue of critical importance for the United States. The issue is the Guyana-Venezuela border dispute, an increasingly bitter confrontation that could threaten the stability of the Caribbean region.

title: A GUIDE TO BUYING CASSETTE RECORDER TAPES
description: Maybe you're among the lucky ones to whom Santa Claus brought a cassette recorder. These eminently useful and enjoyable marvels of technology certainly rank among the most eagerly wished-for of all gifts, and they come in a great variety of forms, from simple battery-powered portables to the elaborate tape decks whose sonic finesse matches that of the fanciest stereo stystems.

title: The City
description: A man was shot and killed in the Bronx early Christmas morning as he chased two gunmen who had just killed his neighbor, the police said.

title: Polish Bond: Japan Is Cool
description: Officials at the Japanese Finance Ministry and commercial banks here said today they doubted that the Communist bloc would be able to raise money on the Japanese capital market to support Poland.

title: About New York; SO HOW ARE WE DOING? ASK MAYOR KOCH
description: Bouncing down the West Side of Manhattan in the back of the blue sedan was a typical New Yorker, Edward Irving Koch. He was wearing a khaki-colored suit, a Jimmy Carter cardigan beneath it and a wool muffler emblazoned with ''I Love New York.''

title: NETS RALLY TO TOP KNICKS BY 96-95
description: James Bailey's layup from the right side on a pass from Ray Williams with 19 seconds left enabled the Nets to defeat the Knicks, 96-95, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Police Announce First Arrests Of Paisley Paramilitary Force
description: Police reported Friday the first arrests of members of the Rev. Ian Paisley's Protestant paramilitary Third Force.

title: PLAN IS DELAYED ON ASSIGNMENT OF STATE JUDGES
description: A plan designed to eliminate some of the rivalry among judges who want to be assigned to State Supreme Court will not go into effect on Monday, as had been originally announced, but on Jan. 25.

title: DEPENDENCE ON SUGAR WORRIES MAURITIUS
description: Stung by two successive sugar crop failures and plummeting world prices, Mauritius is undertaking major innovations in its cane industry, the country's biggest foreignexchange earner, to increase production.

title: 90 Britons Swim in Channel
description: With the sun shining but the temperature hovering around freezing today, 90 Britons took a traditional Christmas swim in the English Channel. There were 30 swimmers in Hastings, 20 at Brighton and 40 at Bournemouth, where one swimmer was dressed like Santa Claus, according to local reporters.

title: MUGGED NUN'S ORDER FEELING VUNERABLE TO CITY'S DANGERS
description: For the Sisters of Charity of St. Vincent de Paul, nuns who work in New York's hospitals, schools and nursing homes and do not usually wear habits, involvement in the community has meant an exposure to the random dangers of the city. Their order is not a cloistered one, and their convents are in the midst of residential neighborhoods, good and bad.

title: Six Poles Jump Ship In Alaska
description: Six Polish sailors who jumped from their fishing vessel into a tugboat in Kodiak Harbor on Christmas Eve spent Christmas with families of Polish descent on their first full day in America.

title: U.S. CANDLES LIGHTED FOR POLES
description: By United Press International

title: Penguins Recall Ricci To Replace Hurt Dion
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins have recalled Nick Ricci from their Erie farm club in the American Hockey League to replace their injured goalie, Michel Dion.

title: PAKISTANI DROPS ELECTION IDEA AND NAMES ADVISORY PANEL
description: Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq has dropped the idea of having free elections and has instead established a 350-member consultative council to help him rule Pakistan.

title: WARSAW SAYS 1,276 MINERS STILL STRIKE
description: The Warsaw radio reported today that Poles were celebrating Christmas with the usual church services and family reunions but that more than 1,200 coal miners continued a strike protesting martial law.

title: JOHN B. CONDLIFFE, EXPERT ON MONETARY POLICY
description: Dr. John Bell Condliffe, a specialist in international monetary policy and trade relations and professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley and other schools, died Wednesday in San Francisco on his 90th birthday. He was a resident of Walnut Creek, Calif.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 43.

title: Around the Nation; Fire at U. of Michigan Destroys a Landmark
description: The oldest classroom building on the University of Michigan campus and valuable manuscripts and books inside were destroyed by fire on Christmas Eve, the authorities said.

title: ON BANKS' SERVICES
description: It is ironic that just about the only institutions legally barred from offering creative packages of financial services to consumers are banks, savings and loans, and credit unions. All are trapped in a maze of laws and regulations left over from the world of 40 years ago.

title: McAdoo Is Scheduled For Laker Exam Today
description: Bob McAdoo, who was acquired Thursday from the Nets, will join the Lakers on Sunday night if he passes a physical examination scheduled for Saturday.

title: MUSIC: CASTLEMAN GROUP
description: Charles Castleman, the violinist, assembled some friends and colleagues from his Quartet Program at Troy last Sunday evening, and together they gave a concert of chamber music at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Patents; A BICYCLE BUGGY
description: A buggy that can be attached to and pulled by a bicycle was patented this week by William E. Cox of Dallas.

title: Around the World; Lawyers for Ecevit Hopeful on Sentence
description: The Turkish Military Court of Appeal has ruled that the four-month prison term given to former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit is ''too harsh,'' lawyers for the politician said today.

title: CHARITIES ARE SHARPLY CRITICAL OF ORDER ON U.S. FUND DRIVES
description: Agencies that have received donations through a Federal charity drive are voicing sharp criticism of a draft executive order by the Reagan Administration that would establish new eligibility conditions and arrangements for distribution of funds from the campaign.

title: Sports of The Times; Robustelli Looks Back
description: FOR most of the season, Andy Robustelli could ''take football or leave it.'' Sometimes he would catch a glimpse of the game he had played, coached and later planned as general manager of the Giants.

title: The Liberal Member Triumphs at Calder
description: The Liberal Member won the $58,550 Christmas Handicap by 3 1/4 lengths at Calder Race Course today. The Liberal Member, ridden by Jerry Bailey, paid $10, $5.80, and $5.40 for $2 across the board in taking the mile and one-eighth race.

title: ROOKIE REVIVES WINNIPEG
description: Dale Hawerchuk had been acclaimed Canada's greatest junior hockey player, but most citizens of Winnipeg had not seen him until one day last summer, when the Jets staged a signing ceremony with a flourish.

title: ELECTRONICS RESEARCH PROJECTS
description: United States semiconductor companies, beset by labor shortages and stiff Japanese competition, are banding together to finance basic research projects at universities.

title: CHRISTMAS GIFT IS NEW HOUSE
description: John and Josephine Rivas got a brand new home for Christmas. Santa Clauses for the Rivases were some 200 businesses and people in the Phoenix area who donated time, labor, materials and money to replace the family's 10-by-10-foot shack with a two-bedroom frame house.

title: LUTHERAN OFFICES SEIZED IN ETHIOPIA
description: The Marxist regime of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam has rejected the formal protests of Sweden and Norway over the recent seizure by armed soldiers of the headquarters of the Scandinavian-supported Lutheran Church, Ethiopia's major Protestant denomination.

title: Saxophonists to Receive Jazz Tributes on Jan. 7
description: Tributes to jazz saxophonists will be the theme of a ''Highlights in Jazz'' concert at New York University's Loeb Student Center on Jan. 7 at 8 P.M.

title: VOLUNTEER BLOOD FROM HERE AND ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: HEAD OF SOCIAL SECURITY PROMISES MORE RESPONSIVE AGENCY IN 1982
description: John A. Svahn, the Commissioner of Social Security, says Americans will get faster answers to their questions and quicker issuance of new cards from the retirement system next year.

title: No Headline
description: NORTH DEFEATS SOUTH

title: Asking for Nursing Home Trouble
description: ''Social isolation of the aged poor'' is the bureaucrat's term for a problem most families are bound to face sooner or later: grandmother is frail and no longer able to take care of herself on a meager pension or Social Security.

title: HUNGARY, PROSPERING, IS DISCREETLY SELF-CONFIDENT
description: Can Hungary, with only 11 million people, provide a model for the larger, less-prosperous members of the Warsaw Pact, such as Poland and the Soviet Union?

title: CHRISTMAS IN PEKING: FAITHFUL RETURN
description: An old man named Yu in a worn gray jacket guided his grandchildren through the maze of parked bicycles and into the small Protestant church on Meizha Alley.

title: WITNESS IN WILSON CASE FREED
description: A key witness in the investigation of two fugitive former intelligence agents was released from jail today on a reduced bond of $200,000.

title: ESCAPE VALVE
description: A man and woman I know moved in together recently. It was, as such occasions are, a moment of sentiment and celebration. It was also a limited engagement. Before moving in, they had already set a fixed date when they would break up.

title: Carl and Carol Lewis Head Track Meet Field
description: Carl and Carol Lewis head a list of entrants announced Friday for the United States Olympic Invitational meet Jan. 16 at the Meadowlands Arena.

title: Schmidt in U.S. for Vacation; Will Meet With Reagan Jan. 5
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and his wife flew to the United States today for a 10-day vacation on the Florida island of Sanibel in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: The Region; Thruway Section Is Open Again
description: A 26-mile stretch of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway that had been closed for two days was reopened after crews covered the remnants of a chemical spill with two large sheets of plastic.

title: Briefing
description: D ESPITE all the activity in Poland and the effort to forge a Western response to the crackdown against the independent trade union, Solidarity, it is business as usual in one of the more intriguing nooks and crannies of the Government, the State Department's interpreting office. It is not that Cyril Muromcew, the language officer responsible for interpreting in Russian and Polish, has not been busy; he has had his hands full following events closely and monitoring the foreign press. It's just that with the lack of communication with Poland, he has not been called upon to do any onthe-minute interpreting, which is where the action is for those in the translating business. ''We'd be involved in any direct face-toface talk, and that's nil now,'' said Mr. Muromcew, who once was a party to arms talks with a Soviet diplomat in a Helsinki sauna bath. ''They haven't been talking to us, and we haven't been talking to them,'' he said. Mr. Muromcew, who was born on Poland's Russian border, is ready to spring into action at a moment's notice. ''Our time may come,'' he said.

title: DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST A TRADITION
description: Cherished traditions play an important part of holiday celebrations in many families. And for some contributors, donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are time-honored Christmas, Hanukkah and New Year's customs.

title: THE DAY LA GUARDIA KILLED BURLESQUE
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Pan American World Airways said it had sold its tax benefits on McDonnell Douglas DC-10-30 aircraft for about $12.5 million to an unnamed buyer.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: QUEENS SCENE

title: Letter: On Middle East Policy; Focus U.S. Efforts on the Arabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Analysis
description: Not too long ago, the thought of a deep recession in the United States might have sent shivers through industrial and developing countries the world over. However, while America's international economic influence remains vast - the United States generates roughly one-quarter of total global output - analysts say that, unless the depth and duration of the current American recession far exceeds the latest forecasts, its international damage is likely to be limited.

title: 'SADDEST' CHRISTMAS FOR FIBAK
description: The carp soup and noodles were on the table, in the Christmas Eve tradition. But tears formed in Wojtek Fibak's eyes as he began the prayer. Others seated at the table, his wife, children and a few close friends, were also overcome by emotion.

title: ISRAELI CONTENDS ACCORD WITH U.S. IS STILL IN EFFECT
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon said in an interview published today that the strategic cooperation agreement between the United States and Israel still ''formally'' existed.

title: French Feminists Sentenced For Threatening Sex Shops
description: Three French feminists, who said they wanted to attack sex shops with gasoline bombs, have been given 18-month suspended prison sentences, court officials said today.

title: MARXISTS DROPPING SUIT IN CALIFORNIA
description: The organization had contended that the state had wrongfully depicted it as prone to violence. The Spartacists had charged that the action was part of "renascent McCarthyism" and a "murderous effort to set up us up for the same kind of campaign of Government violence that destroyed the Black Panther Party."

title: Your Money; Tax Savings On the Way
description: FOR those who want to fashion personal financial plans that minimize their taxes - and who does not? - 1982 promises to be the best year in decades.

title: TO THE JOBLESS, 1981 IS ENDING IN FRUSTRATION
description: At age 41, Paul Hanson is used to making what he calls ''great money'' as a pipe designer. But in October, he was laid off by the Manhattan engineering company he had been working for, and his situation has become grim.

title: POPE ASKS BETTER FUTURE 'IN LIBERTY' FOR POLES
description: Pope John Paul II, departing from the text of his annual Christmas message today, sent an embrace to ''all of Poland, our common homeland'' and offered a prayer for a ''better future of the homeland, in peace, in justice, in liberty.''

title: For Lisa H., Christmas Gifts and Prayers
description: For many years she was a target of cruelty because she suffered from neurofibromatosis, a disfiguring ailment often known as Elephant Man's Disease. But yesterday, hundreds of well-wishers from all over the United States sent Christmas cards and presents to the woman they knew only as Lisa H., who touched them with her courage in undergoing nine hours of risky and grueling reconstructive surgery on Dec. 9.

title: BELLAMY ADVISERS LEAN TO RACE FOR COMPTROLLER
description: The ''doves'' have become dominant in the coterie of advisers who are helping Carol Bellamy, the City Council President, to decide what post to run for next year - Governor or State Comptroller. The ''doves'' favor Comptroller.

title: Around the World; Clues Are Reported In General's Kidnapping
description: The Italian authorities have discovered ''some useful new elements'' in their search for Brig. Gen. James Dozier, a police source said today.

title: The Region; Vandals Attack Westbury Houses
description: Two houses were spray-painted with Stars of David and slogans during the night, reportedly in retaliation for vandalism of Jewish synagogues by teen-age residents of the houses, the Nassau County police said.

title: The City; Fire Causes Delays At Grand Central
description: A fire yesterday in two out-of-service cars in the yard at Grand Central Terminal sent smoke through the terminal and delayed service when power had to be turned off so firefighters could extinguish the blaze.

title: OFF WHOSE BACK?
description: Remember how Ronald Reagan campaigned on the slogan "Let's get the Government off your back?" Well, it turns out it depends very much whose back you're talking about.

title: DANCE: HEALEY'S 'ACCOMMODATIONS'
description: Peter Healey took his audience on a nutty but never unconvincing trip in ''Splendid Accommodations'' last Saturday at Public School 122. It all started with Mr. Healey's impersonating the most pompously mealy-mouthed of English television-sociologists, setting the mood with a description of some peculiar country.

title: MUSIC: BERLIOZ AND BRAHMS AT COLLEGE
description: Somewhere near the bottom of the 19th century's barrel, having settled there as much from neglect as through any fault of their own, are dozens of lesser works for chorus and orchestra by major Romantic composers. Without quite scraping the barrel's very bottom, the Brooklyn College Chorus and Orchestra, under the direction of Harry Saltzman, managed to come up with a program consisting of six such works by two indisputably major figures - Brahms and Berlioz - which the assembled forces performed last Saturday and Sunday at the college's Whitman Hall.

title: Finally, a Secure Seat on the Bench
description: Mayor Koch swore in 14 Criminal Court judges Wednesday, and one of them was participating in the ceremony for the fourth time in two years. It was not until the Mayor said ''and all of them will receive a full 10-year term'' that Francis X. Egitto, who sits in Criminal Court in Manhattan, could relax.

title: L.I.R.R. Rider Falls to Death
description: A passenger walking between cars of a Long Island Rail Road train fell to the tracks and was killed, the Suffolk County police said today. They said the body of the passenger - William Kennedy, 46 years old, of 42 Sedgewood Drive, Patchogue - had been found here at 12:39 A.M.

title: COMPUTER AID FOR 'NATURAL' BIRTH CONTROL
description: A prototype of a bedside computer intended to improve the accuracy and reliability of ''natural family planning'' is due to arrive in this country in the next several weeks for clinical tests.

title: Day of Thanks for 2 Who've Overcome
description: Despite serious disabilities that impair their mobility, Georgia L. McMurray and Curtis Brewer have been able to improve the quality of life for thousands of young and adult handicapped people in New York City. Miss McMurray is deputy general director for programming for the Community Service Society, which has served the city's needy since 1848, and Mr. Brewer is director of Untapped Resources, a nonprofit organization that provides legal representation for disabled people.

title: NETWORKS EASE INTO CABLE TV
description: Amid a welter of doubts and startup losses, ABC and CBS are embarking on the turbulent waters of cable television programming. Network executives acknowledge the uncertainties involved, but say they have to act now or risk missing out on the future growth of the burgeoning cable television market, which already includes 28 percent of the 81.5 million American households that have television sets.

title: NUCLEAR PLANTS' EDGE IN POWER GENERATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. The speaker was Rev. Ian Paisley, after the United States State Department invalidated his visa because of his militant Protestant politics.

title: F.A.A. Ousts A Critical Aid
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has dismissed a $50,000-a-year employee who said his problems with the agency began when he criticized its programs to avoid midair collisions.

title: Sports People; Ah, the Good Life
description: Listen to Cris Collinsworth, Cincinnati's rookie who leads all the team's receivers with eight touchdowns and 1,009 yards: ''I spend a lot of time trying to make myself believe I'm really playing professional football, that I've really scored a few touchdowns and caught a few passes. To me, it's almost comical.

title: Patents; SOLAR COLLECTOR FOLLOWS THE SUN
description: Howard Natter, vice president of Honatech, Inc., a Yonkers company that manufactures a plastic products, will be granted patent 4,307,710 next week for a solar collector that the company is already producing.

title: ISRAELIS DRIVE BEDOUINS OF NEGEV INTO CLOSED ZONES
description: It was very cold one recent morning in the Negev Desert. Inside the goat-hair tent of Swaylim Abu Bilaya, a Bedouin of the Azazmah tribe, a fire of twigs crackled at dawn, warming his three guests.

title: NEW, SIMPLER STYLE RESULTS IN BIG PLAYS
description: A season ago the Giants were a losing team. Their defense was plagued by injuries, confusion, unhappiness and wounded motivation.

title: POP: MCCLINTON'S BLUES
description: Delbert McClinton, the Texas singer and songwriter who appeared at the Savoy Dec. 18, is one of the last and finest of a vanishing breed. A country-blues shouter who is a 20-year veteran of the East Texas honkey-tonk circuit, Mr. McClinton blends the ''crying blues'' style of black Southern bluesmen with the tougher, more tight-lipped inflections of 1950's rockabilly into a style that's quintessentially American but not self-consciously so.

title: Around the Nation; School Board in Georgia Backed on Klan Meeting
description: A school board was correct in allowing the Ku Klux Klan to meet in a public high school auditorium, according to the director of the state branch of the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: De Gustibus; AROMAS THAT WARM THE SPIRIT
description: Nothing can impart quite the same sense of well-being as the delicious aromas of food cooking when one comes home on a cold winter evening. Some foods send forth such warm and luscious scents that they seem to be fattening even in the smelling and almost sustaining enough without being eaten. In Burgundy, I was told, there is a particularly fine and strong marc that true connoisseurs sniff but never drink. They pour a few drops into a large, warmed brandy snifter, then empty it and press faces into the glass to inhale the residual perfume, a subtler appreciation, they claim, than merely drinking the clear white firewater.

title: Villagers in Southern Lebanon Expelled by Christian Militia
description: Christian militiamen in southern Lebanon expelled 16 villagers from their homes during the night, maintaining that the villagers were supporters of the Palestine Liberation Organization, a United Nations spokesman said Friday.

title: SPARSE CHURCH ROOM
description: To the Editor:

title: VANDALS MAR ITALIAN CATHEDRAL
description: A close-up view of Orvieto Cathedral's 14th-century bas-relief after it was damaged by vandals.

title: ECONOMIC WOES DIM HOLIDAY SPARKLE OF ST. LOUIS
description: It has not been the best of weeks for the city. On Sunday the Cardinals professional football team was clawed by the Philadelphia Eagles, 38-0, and on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday, people were pummeled by rain, sleet and snow and chilled by nippy temperatures.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a Business People item Wednes- day, Andrew Goodman was incor- rectly identified. He is chairman of Bergdorf Goodman.

title: CHRISTMAS IN FREEDOM
description: Rodney (Rocky) Virgil Sickmann and his wife, Jill, at home in St. Louis. Mr. Sickmann, formerly a Marine sergeant, was among 52 Americans held hostage by Iran for 444 days. Mr. Sickmann was a guard at the American Embassy in Teheran when it was captured. He was released last Jan. 20, the day President Reagan was inaugurated.

title: Thompson Suspended For Missing Practice
description: David Thompson, who played only six minutes in the Nuggets' 124-119 loss Wednesday to Detroit, missed practice today and was suspended by Coach Doug Moe of Denver for the game Saturday against Dallas.

title: PUBLISHER-AGENT DISPUTE ENDS LENNON BOOK DEAL
description: A million-dollar deal for a book about John Lennon has collapsed as the result of a dispute between Walter Meade, publisher of Avon Books, and John Hawkins, a prominent literary agent representing the book's author.

title: Around the Nation; Haitians Refuse Dinner In Second Day of Strike
description: About 650 Haitians refused a Christmas dinner of turkey, fried plantains, red beans and rice today as a hunger strike at a Federal immigration camp entered its second day.

title: Top Sprinters Entered In Santa Anita Opener
description: Top sprinters in California will meet in the Palos Verdes Handicap Saturday as Santa Anita opens its 45th season of thoroughbred competition.

title: JETS ARE CONFIDENT IN THEIR ROOKIES, GIANTS IN THEIR DEFENSE
description: The Jets' eight rookies have played in big games before. Kurt Sohn once was in a Long Island high school championship game, and Al Washington was in the Rose Bowl.

title: Dollar Rises Against Yen
description: The dollar rose slightly today against the yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market, finishing at 221.50 yen, slightly above Thursday's closing of 221.20.

title: Robotics Seen Strong in U.S.
description: The United States is ahead of the Soviet Union in the technology of robots, but a lack of engineers is putting this country at a disadvantage, according to a university specialist.

title: Betting on the Jets
description: It is a wager that Mayor Koch cannot lose. When the Buffalo Bills and the New York Jets meet tomorrow at Shea Stadium in a National Football League wild-card playoff game, they will also be playing for apples and kielbasa.

title: Bridge:; 'G.N.P.' Offers a Challenge For the Imaginative Player
description: For economists, the letters G.N.P. stand for Gross National Product. For bridge players, they stand for Grand National Pairs, which for them is also an item of major significance. Those who qualify from preliminary and district competition earn an expenses-paid trip to the national final, which will be in Niagara Falls, N.Y., in March.

title: SOLIDARITY URGING RENEWED PROTESTS TO MILITARY RULE

title: Around the Nation;

title: No More Budget Hocus-Pocus
description: President Reagan's most urgent task in this holiday season is to compose a 1983 budget that will be credible to more than a handful of ideologues.

title: Salvadoran Rebels Raid Army Garrison
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked an army garrison today and blew up a bridge in El Salvador's ravaged countryside.

title: STRIPTEASE FOR JUDGES: CLEARLY, BLIND JUSTICE
description: A professional striptease dancer performed in the halls of justice for judges attending the annual D.C. Superior Court Christmas party, but no one seemed to know who planned the entertainment.

description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, spent their first Christmas in the White House quietly, giving gifts to their children but none to each other.

description: Police patrols entered the campus of Jerusalem's Hebrew University today to prevent a recurrence of fighting between Arab and Jewish students, a police spokesman said.

title: TECHNOLOGY ON BRITISH FARMS
description: One of Britain's few economic success stories can be illustrated dramatically through the simple statistics recorded by farmers such as Oliver Cooper.

title: SOL GOLDBERG
description: Sol Goldberg, a retail merchant and president of Parkside Estates Corporation, which constructed houses and commercial properties in the Kings Park and Elwood areas of Long Island, died Tuesday at his home in Miami Beach. Mr. Goldberg, who also was a resident of Kings Park, was 82 years old.

title: PENNSYLVANIA WELL IS $14 MILLION RISK
description: High in the mountains of northern Pennsylvania, a crew from Texaco Inc. is drilling what may become one of the first deep gas wells in the northeastern United States.

title: Sports People; Ex-Owner Sues Walton
description: The former owner of the San Diego Clippers has filed a suit seeking $17 million from Bill Walton and two Los Angeles physicians who certified Walton's fitness when he signed a five-year, $5 million contract in 1979, according to The San Diego Union, which said it had obtained copies of the legal papers. In a document filed Tuesday in California Superior Court in Los Angeles, the paper said, Irv Levin, the owner, charged that Drs.

title: CONSERVATIVE MEXICAN CATHOLICS FIGHT LATIN TREND
description: In the huge overcrowded plaza, pilgrims decked in the bright costumes and extravagant feather headdresses of Mexico's pre-Hispanic tribes danced to drums and flutes in their annual tribute to the Indian Virgin of Guadalupe.

title: Cable News Network
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, meeting with Archbishop Luigi Poggi, Vatican envoy. Photo was made from a Polish TV broadcast. Archbishop Poggi arrived in Warsaw last Sunday, sent by Pope John Paul II.

title: Queen Praises Courage Of the Forces in Ulster
description: Queen Elizabeth II, in a Christmas message to the people of Britain and the Commonwealth, praised the courage of security forces dealing with Northern Ireland guerrillas.

title: ADDITION NEAR CARNEGIE HALL
description: Several new floors will be built on top of the building that houses the Russian Tea Room next spring, according to James Stewart-Gordon, vice president of the company that owns the restaurant.

title: THE WAY THINGS ARE IN JAPANESE BALLET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- David Raher recently returned from a two-year stay in Japan where he was a visiting professor of drama at Doshisha University in Kyoto. By DAVID RAHER

title: Reading and Writing; WOMEN AND MEN AND ART
description: Since women novelists are often reviewed by male critics, including in a sense their husbands, I asked Erica Jong, author of ''Fear of Flying'' and ''Fanny,'' and Jill Robinson, author of ''Bed/ Time/Story'' and ''Perdido,'' how they felt about these two sources of comment. Here's what they said.

title: 25 CULTURAL FIGURES OFFER WISHES FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: Ahead looms the New Year, its joys and pitfalls unrevealed - a temptation to speculation, wonder, dreams and, perhaps most of all, wishes.

title: A.M. Sheers to Wed Elizabeth Hutner
description: Elizabeth Hall Hutner and Alexander Marling Sheers, who received master's degrees in comparative literature from Princeton University, plan to be married in March.

title: ANDREW G. SIMON TO WED NANCY FLEISCHMAN IN MAY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Leon J. Fleischman of Rye Town, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jill Fleischman, to Andrew Gary Simon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Simon of New York.

title: RICHARD DREYFUSS- REVILED HEROES FASCINATE HIM
description: Once he was a sculptor whose hands could shape lumps of clay into a delicate ballerina or weld steel beams into massive abstract art forms. Now his hands are motionless. Paralyzed from the neck down, he lies still and caged in a hospital bed, tortured by his memories of work and love and life. All he wants is to die.

title: TAKING A FLYER ON STOCK PICKS FOR '82
description: A T the close of 1980, when brokerage houses and investment advisory services were naming their favorite stocks for the coming year, there was a sense of euphoria on Wall Street and lots of chatter about ''the Reagan bull market.''

title: Susan Loney Will Be Bride Of Sales Aide
description: The engagement of Susan Allen Loney to George Henry Oestreich 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oestreich Jr. of Port Washington, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Roosevelt Loney Jr. of New York and Watch Hill, R.I.

title: On Landfills And Ventilation
description: Most curious is the resolute indifference by the authorities to the meteorological aspects of the North Hempstead landfill (''Dump Dispute Stirs North Hempstead''). It is axiomatic that a raw-garbage dump should be located in a well ventilated site.

title: A HUNDRED YEARS AND A HUNDRED BOOKS
description: P.G.WODEHOUSE A Centenary Celebration 1881-1981. Edited by James H. Heineman and Donald R. Bensen. Illustrated. 197 pp. New York: The Pierpont Morgan Library/ Oxford University Press. $65. THANK YOU, WODEHOUSE By J.H.C. Morris. With Contributions by A.D. Macintyre. Introduction by Frances Donaldson. 152 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $11.95. P.G.WODEHOUSE A Literary Biography. By Benny Green. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: The Rutledge Press. $12.95.

title: Crafts; A SATISFYING LIFE IN 'QUIET OBSCURITY'
description: DUMONT EVEN when he's immersed in the problem (''a welcome one'') of filling holiday orders for his jewelry, Aniello Schettino will always take the time for a conversation in his shop here.

title: No Headline
description: For shame, Dr. Uhler! How is it that a former superintendent of schools does not recognize that the ''testing and flex-time'' conditions that he deplores are the direct responsibility of the superintendent of schools? In spite of these and other difficult conditions, there are many, many dedicated, innovative and humanistic teachers who inspire their students daily to reach their individual potentials.

title: Sunday Observer By Russell Baker HEAVY BREATHING Patrick McDonnell
description: Always alert for signs of cultural progress, I was startled to discover recently that it is now possible to dial an obscene telephone call.

title: Cairo Trial of Millionaire Seen as Start of Anticorruption Drive
description: The trial of an Egyptian millionaire and former member of Parliament is seen by many here as an opening shot in an anticorruption campaign by the Government of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: ONE IN 10 PATIENTS INFECTED IN HOSPITAL, AN EDUCATOR FINDS
description: More than two million patients suffer infections in hospitals each year and about 550 people die from them, according to an expert on infection control.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CONSUMERISM IN HUNGARY
description: The array of delicacies at the Vorosmarty Pastry Shop, in the heart of the Hungarian capital's shopping district, is enough to please the most fastidious.

title: OUTING CLUB IS 50 YEARS OLD
description: NEW BRUNSWICK TO MARK the 50th anniversary of the University Outing Club, 38 men and women set out recently on a 25-mile hike along the Delaware and Raritan Canal. Six people - two college professors, two teen-age girls, a homemaker and a physician - made it all the way from New Brunswick to Kingston, near Princeton.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY; CELEBRATING WITHOUT REVELRY
description: AS another New Year's Eve approaches, I look forward to it with a mix of emotions. A good number of years ago, when I was a teenager, I would look forward to the evening as the most important date of the year.

title: BERNARD WALDMAN
description: Bernard Waldman, founder and president of the Modern Merchandising Bureau, which specialized in promoting cinema fashions in the early 1930's, died Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness.

title: William Carlos Williams
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Former Purolator Guard Accused in Robbery
description: A former Purolator security guard was arrested today and charged with felony theft in connection with the $200,000 robbery of a Purolator van in Scottsdale Oct. 10, the authorities said.

title: Out of the U.S.S.R.
description: She called it ''a victory for the Sakharovs,'' but it was also Yelizaveta Alekseyeva who won the right to leave the Soviet Union last week.

title: 36 FOOD PLACES CITED BY CITY HEALTH DEPT. AS VIOLATIONS OF CODE
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 36 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code. The department, in its announcement last week, also released the names of nine establishments that had reopened after correcting earlier violations and three that were closed for failing to do so.

title: SUSAN SECOR HUMES WED TO PAUL AAMODT
description: Susan Secor Humes, daughter of Mrs. Thomas LeBoutillier of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Jay K. Secor Jr. of Perrysburg, Ohio, was married in New York Tuesday to Paul Stewart E. Aamodt of New York and Sydney, Australia. The Rev. Richard Benner, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's apartment.

title: No Headline
description: In response to ''Something Happened at the Office,'' I feel sympathetic to the people who, with significant experience in their fields, were unable to get jobs. The example of ''Jim'' is one of interest to us. We're a placement service, specializing exclusively in the accounting and data processing professions. It is not unusual for us to meet many Jims - a bookkeeper with 16 years' experience with the same firm, out of work and finding it difficult to get an offer to start with another company. In deference to the opinion of age being the main issue in keeping Jim out of work, we feel the problem is broader than this.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: 1,166 MINERS STILL PROTESTING
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency, and an account from the Soviet press agency Tass that was monitored in Moscow by the agency: 'Tragedy' of Miners' Protest 2:05 A.M. Saturday

title: AUTO IMPORT CURBS AREN'T DETERRING THE JAPANESE
description: DETROIT S UBARU OF AMERICA is currently running a television commercial that shows pictures of the company's cars fading slowly into view and then out of view. The announcer reinforces the visual message: ''Supplies of these cars have been short in the past and may be again. Buy now.''

title: BROADWAY CAPITALIZATION AND PROFITS INCREASE
description: The State Attorney General's report for the 1980-81 theatrical season that ended May 31 shows an increase in capitalization as well as profits of long-running shows, compared with the previous year.

title: LEARNING FIRSTHAND; The Best Propaganda
description: If the Reagan Administration had won its way, this country's educational and cultural exchanges with the rest of the world would now be in jeopardy. Fortunately, Congress came to the rescue in its final budget action, earmarking $100 million for the exchanges.

title: NETS' FOUR-GAME STREAK ENDS AS BULLETS TRIUMPH, 105-90
description: The Washington Bullets normally rely on their defense, but tonight they displayed a strong offense as well and defeated the New Jersey Nets, 105-90, at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: IVY WAGNER WILL BE BRIDE IN MAY OF MICHAEL BERKE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wagner of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ivy Wagner, to Michael Berke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Berke of New York and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: FIRST MEETING IN PLAYOFFS
description: For the last 13 years Shea Stadium has been deserted this late in December. But it will come to life at noon today, when the Jets face the Buffalo Bills in the American Conference wild-card playoff. These original American Football League franchises never have met in a postseason game. But it will be the 45th time they have played each other since they performed in their very first A.F.L. game in the Polo Grounds in 1960, when the Jets won convincingly.

title: Jaruzelski Tries Coming to Grips With the Anger
description: Many Poles, stunned by two weeks of police roundups and industrial violence, wished each other ''peaceful holidays'' last week instead of the usual ''happy holidays.'' The country's apprehension was reflected by Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, who warned in his Christmas Eve homily of ''the danger of fraticidal war'' and called for a ''year of reconstruction.''

title: Around the World; Iraqi Oil Flowing Again To the Lebanese Coast
description: After a five-year stoppage, the pumping of Iraqi crude oil to the Lebanese Mediterranean coast resumed today, the Beirut Government announced.

title: Mimi Jones Fiancee of Douglas Hedwick
description: Mrs. Robert Tyre Jones 3d of Nashville has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Frances Jones, to Douglas Frederick Hedwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon William Hedwick of Garden City, L.I. A June wedding is planned in New York.

title: STORMS AND STARS AND SELF-RENEWAL IN A SPECIAL PLACE
description: ANOTHER new year looms, reminding us of people and places that tie us to our past. The cold December moon could never entirely eclipse my memories of a special time and place, where, over the course of several summers, a boy began the long, uncertain journey into manhood.

title: Business Conditions; GOOD NEWS ON THE FOOD FRONT
description: Earlier this year, many economists were expecting that a number of factors, including the aftereffects of the 1980 drought, would send food prices up sharply this year and contribute heavily to the overall inflation rate. Since last winter, those worries have dissipated, as record harvests, larger-than-anticipated meat supplies and good weather have kept a lid on retail food prices.

title: Wendy Goldman To Marry in May
