description: Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Goldman of Houston have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Goldman, to Jeremy Joseph Deutsch, son of Judge and Mrs. Leon Deutsch of Brooklyn and Putnam Valley, N.Y. The wedding is planned for May in Houston.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES EDUCATION LOANS
description: Students with grade averages of D-plus or worse are able to keep their Federal financial aid because of lax monitoring of their academic progress, Congressional investigators report.

title: LEGISLATORS FIGHT SPREAD OF CASINOS
description: A COALITION of legislators from six New England states and New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania has been formed to fight efforts by casino promoters to obtain approval from state officials and the public for new casinos in any of the states.

title: No Headline
description: [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] therapeutic value, is letter writing. In 1958, one of my brothers left home for eight years of prep school and college.

title: LOS ANGELES PLANS LAYOFFS NEXT YEAR
description: The City of Los Angeles, which for generations has had a reputation as a paternalistic, life-time employer, has announced that it will have to lay off nearly 200 employees early next year.

title: By Clara Szathmary
description: To the Editor:

title: MALAISE POLONAIS HAUNTS THE FRENCH
description: PARIS THERE was another country, 41 years ago, where a respected military figure took over to forestall direct rule by a despotic neighbor - only to find himself carrying out in the name of patriotism virtually every repressive policy that the neighbor dictated. When the French look at Poland these days, they think, among other things, of Marshal Philippe Petain and Vichy during World War II, especially in view of scattered reports, which the Parisian press has played up, that Polish military broadcasts have touched on the topics of Jews and national betrayal.

title: Q&A
description: Question: Can an individual travel through the Panama Canal without booking an elaborate or lengthy cruise? I would also like to visit the Canal Zone and the San Blas Islands. - J.S.S., New York, N.Y.

title: MUSIC ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Art; EXPERIMENTS IN COMPLEXITY
description: HEMPSTEAD THERE is one work in the exhibition by Mon Levinson at Famli (the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island) that is innocuous enough in appearance but quite startling in effect. Hung several feet above the heads of visitors in a corner, it consists simply of a rectangular composition board punched with an orderly grid of holes through which a specially placed light passes.

title: THE HOME OF 'JINGLE BELLS'
description: Consider, traveler, perhaps the most famous of them all - Paul Revere, in the very early morning of April 19, 1775, took horse in Charlestown, as we all know, and swiftly set out for Lexington and Concord, giving his alarm on the way, to warn all that the British were coming by land. According to legend, the first place he stopped at - not uncoincidentally my hometown - was Medford, Mass., where, presumably finding the local citizens all fast asleep in bed with their knees in their mouths, he galloped along in full cry past the Isaac Royall House (an early mansion and slave quarters open from May to October, which at this season may be viewed through the wooden gate). Thence, arriving at the corner of the east end of Riverside Avenue (at the other end of which may be found what is reputedly the oldest brick house in America, built by Peter Tufts, whose descendant in the sixth generation, Charles Tufts, donated the land on which Tufts University, also in Medford, stands), he found himself suddenly in the middle of Medford Square.

title: THE NATION
description: Rather than promote ethics in government, Attorney General William French Smith has argued, the Ethics in Government Act has more often been used to harass public officials over relatively trivial offenses. Last week, though, he had little choice but to invoke its provisions for a special prosecutor to investigate accusations linking the Labor Secretary, Raymond J. Donovan, with labor-management corruption.

title: Around the Nation; Farmers in Idaho Snare 10,000 More Jackrabbits
description: About 500 farmers braved zero-degree temperatures today to round up about 10,000 jackrabbits in the third roundup of the hares, which the farmers say have destroyed $5 million worth of crops this fall.

title: Index; International
description: For British Laborites, a bad year and dim prospects 3 State Department report sees stalemate in Afghanistan 3 Stacks of mail await newly elected U.N. chief 4 Around the World 6 West German company halts rocket work in Libya 7 14 opposition figures form new party in Philippines 8 Chinese may export minerals to finance arms imports 9 Poland hopes last mine sit-in will end by New Year 13 Reporter's notebook: consumer- ism has come to Hungary 14 Siberian scientists still worry about Lake Baikal pollution 15 Portugal and Mozambique are putting aside their differences 19 Government/Politics L.A., facing fiscal squeeze, to lay off 200 city workers 23 In a memorandum, Mayor Koch assails the ''new federalism.'' 33 Comptroller Regan seeks 5-year plan on capital spending 46 Work grows while funds shrink for Legal Aid Society 51 Energy Oil workers get contract propos- als from Shell and Gulf 24 General A California county organizes to combat child abuse 26 Around the Nation 27 Interned Haitians spend a cold and lonely holiday season 39 Industry/Labor Japan foresees wide use of robots in many fields 10 Health/Science Report allays fears that pre-1961 polio vaccine is carcinogenic 22 Chemical diet replaces food for patients unable to digest 53 Religion Scientists discuss evolution and the origins of the universe 48 Arts/Entertainment Broadway's profits, capitaliza- tion rose in '80-'81 season 57 Concert by youthful New York String Orchestra 57 Two debut at Met in season's 3d performance of ''La Boheme'' 59 Labiche's ''An Italian Straw Hat'' at the Manhattan Punch Line 59 Bennett becomes interim chief of Endowment for Humanities 60 Style Danielle Mitterrand: A quiet ac- tivist 61

title: Jill M. Weber Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Everett D. Weber of Gloversville, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jill M. Weber to Robert C. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Smith of Miami Lakes, Fla. An April wedding is planned. Miss Weber is an institutional securities trader with Furman, Selz, Mager, Dietz & Birney in New York, where her fiance is a vice president in the corporate finance division of Salomon Brothers.

title: Adria Buss Is Engaged
description: Adria Leigh Buss and Alan Michael Krantz, graduates of Miami University in Ohio, plan a summer wedding. Mr. and Mrs. Howard Buss of Great Neck, L.I., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Krantz of Beechwood, Ohio. Miss Buss teaches in Cleveland, where

title: AN EPILOGUE TO VIETNAM
description: Four American Vietnam veterans walked through the looking glass last week and got a glimpse of what the war had been like on the other side. Whether their visit to Hanoi achieved much toward their main goal - clarifying the fate of 2,500 Americans still listed as missing in action - was questionable. But they said it did help them come to terms with their lingering feelings of anger, guilt and fear.

title: 'LION IN WINTER' AT THEATER FORUM
description: PLAINFIELD WITH a few more performances, the New Jersey Theater Forum's production of ''The Lion in Winter'' should generate enough first-act sparks to match the malicious wit and combative impatience that made James Goldman's play a critical success in 1966 and a staple of nonprofit houses since that time.

title: Around the Nation; F.B.I. Seeks Suspect In Killing of Wife
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has joined the search for a man suspected of killing his wife 17 months ago by injecting her with a muscle-relaxing drug and then faking a horseback riding accident.

title: Food; THE SHORT HAPPY LIFE OF FLORENCE FENNEL IS NOW UNDER WAY
description: FLORENCE fennel is not someone's former neighbor or old girlfriend. Florence fennel is not even a person. It is a vegetable, and it is the Florence part that distinguishes it from the commmon fennel, an herb.

title: Bills on Defense
description: No. 77, Ben Williams, le, 6-3, 245, Mississippi, 6th season. Leads team with 11 sacks; quick, rather than massive. No. 76, Fred Smerlas, nt, 6-3, 270, Boston College, 3d season.

title: NURSES WANT MORE THAN ASPIRIN FOR THEIR PAINS
description: Nurses used to be treated as everybody's handmaidens. Physicians gave them orders and expected no backtalk; hospital administrators kept them running for low pay. But all that is rapidly changing. For quite a while, nurses have shown their discontent by dropping out in great numbers. At the same time, bolstered by the spirit of feminism and by a better bargaining position that has been fostered by greater technical responsibilities and greater need for their services, nurses are making their demands with greater force. And, partly because they must, doctors and hospital administrators are beginning to pay attention. In an era when health care eats up nearly $1 of every $10 in the G.N.P., many nurses are receiving long overdue recognition in the form of higher wages and better work status.

title: AFTER 34 YEARS, JOBS DECLINING IN GOVERNMENT
description: For the first time since the end of World War II, government employment is declining, a development that many experts say poses major implications for workers and the public.

title: Harvard Hockey Team Sees End to a Lean Era
description: The hopeful predictions are finally coming true for Harvard's hockey team. The last time the Crimson qualified for the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division I playoffs was in 1976. Every season since has been a disappointment.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Of course we supply the world with food and manufactured goods, but it happens that we could consume less energy doing it. Of course the Japanese don't think Americans are wasting the gas we use to operate the cars they make: They know we are saving gas, which is why we buy their cars in preference to Detroit's. The question is not how much conservation Americans will be able to ''tolerate'' but rather how much conservation they will be able to get their hands on. DEAN CORREN, Director, Greater New York Council on Energy, New York City

title: 14 IN PHILIPPINES FORM NEW OPPOSITION PARTY
description: Fourteen members of various opposition groups have formed a new party, the Social Democratic Party of the Philippines, to begin building a unified opposition to the 16-yearold rule of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: RECENT HOME SALES
description: Avon 4 Cottonwood Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath condominium $84,900 4 years old; 1980 gas heat: $750 taxes $1,005. Danbury 8 Caisson Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath colonial $130,000 1 acre; two years old; taxes $1,846.

title: CORPORATE PLANES TO HELP FLY CANCER PATIENTS
description: A program for transporting cancer patients to special treatment centers without charge aboard corporate airplanes is taking shape at the Westchester County Airport.

title: THE UGANDA RELIEF EFFORT IS NO EXAMPLE OF U.N. 'MISCONDUCT'
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC Roseland, the celebrated ballroom at 52d Street and Broadway, is opening its doors to post-punk rock-and-roll on Tuesday. The show promises to be an exciting one, with England's barbed, rousing Gang of Four, New York's funk-and-rolling Bush Tetras, and the hard-edged punk-rock of another New York band, the Bad Brains.

title: Music View; ANNIVERSARIES AND OPERAS SCORED HIGH NOTES IN 1981
description: There really is no way we can say with confidence which are the most important musical achievements in any year. If you were a musical chronicler in 1881, for instance, could you have known that one of the important events of that year was the birth on March 25 of a male infant in Nagyszentmiklos, Hungary? Hardly. But that's the way it was. And as a result, one of the highlights of 1981 turned out to be the celebration of Bela Bartok's centenary. Some of the celebrating, predictably, was perfunctory enough - we were awash for awhile in performances of the Concerto for Orchestra and we had not one but two mediocre concert versions of the opera ''Bluebeard's Castle.'' But the six string quartets, which had seemed to be slipping from the repertory in recent years, were brought back by several ensembles that clearly believed in their vitality and lasting significance.

title: OIL WORKERS WEIGH SHELL AND GULF CONTRACT OFFERS
description: Two major oil companies have made proposals for new contracts covering about 55,000 workers in the nation's refinery, petrochemical and pipeline industry. The current contracts, which expire at 12:01 A.M. Jan. 8, are the first large labor pacts to come up in the new year.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE new Yonkers administration has appointed a member of the New York Stock Exchange, Edward S. White, to be the final member of a special review committee that is helping to find a new city manager.

title: Dining Out; CRITIC'S CHOICES ON COUNTY DINING
description: ALHOUGH the county might lack the immense culinarq diversity of Manhattan - in authentic Greek, Korean, Scandanavian, Thai, Brazilian or Russian, for examples - many county restaurants present charms unlikely or wholly impossible in the city. Few Westchester restaurants can boast the professional lambency and subtleties of an experienced dining room staff, but many here can and do offer a luxuriance of space and leisurely dining and, often enough, a gracious generosity of view.

title: RADICAL SURGERY ON WESTERN AIR
description: LOS ANGELES T IMES are good for Neil G. Bergt, a multimillionaire airline executive who travels in a $1-million executive jet, and whose office in Anchorage, Alaska, has a $15,000 desk with an electric motor that elevates it so Mr. Bergt can work standing up.

title: PALTRY PENNIES, LIKE LOWLY PAWNS, CAN WIELD POWER
description: IN THE world of numismatics, the paltry penny literally screams for minority rights. Even in a society deeply concerned about a national debt topping the $1 trillion mark, it takes the penny to rear its puny head and demand recognition.

title: Art View; A YEAR OF TREASURES, REVISIONS AND TRENDS
description: This has been a year crowded with interesting, pleasurable and illuminating art events - in addition, of course, to the usual Niagara of dross and nonsense - and it has even yielded a trend or two likely to have some lasting artistic consequences. Before turning to what, in this writer's view, are some of the outstanding achievements of the year, however, we should note that 1981 also brought an event of another, sadder sort that will long be remembered for historians of the modern period. It marked the death on Aug. 15 of Alfred H. Barr Jr., the founding director of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Ellen Weisberg Will Be Married To Gary Malasky
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Weisberg of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Merle Weisberg, to Gary Alan Malasky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Malasky of Rockville, Md. An April wedding is planned.

title: THE NATION IN SUMMARY
description: While recommending a special prosecutor in the Donovan affair, Mr. Smith concluded the opposite last week in the matter of national security adviser Richard V. Allen.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Transition Town
description: Fishing and a paper mill were the heavy industries in St. Marys, Ga., in March 1979, and for excitement there was wild-hog hunting. But the Navy's Fleet Ballistic Missile Squadron 16 was due to move into the bay near town that summer, and St. Marys, population 3,500, was worried.

title: Genetic Material With a Twist
description: Life often imitates art, and occasionally science does too. So it was that when scientists at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology two years ago manufactured a crystal with a DNA double helix that twisted left - DNA was thought to have an exclusively right-handed twist - the search was on for a naturally occurring left-handed helix.

title: Art; THE MAGNET OF MONTCLAIR: ITS ATTRACTIONS ON VIEW
description: MONTCLAIR ESTABLISHED in 1914, the Montclair Art Museum grew out of an intricate network of personal relationships. These the museum is examining in ''The Montclair Art Colony,'' a selection of paintings, sculpture, drawings, prints, reproductions and photographs drawn from its permanent collection that will continue on view through Feb. 7.

title: States News Service
description: A SPECIAL three-judge panel is expected to rule soon on a plan to divide a portion of Conrail's freight lines in Connecticut and Rhode Island between two New England railroads.

title: ON A STEADY DIET OF NOT GOING ON A DIET
description: IRECENTLY gave myself a 40th birthday present. I stopped dieting for the rest of my life. It was an emotional decision, carrying with it the resolve to also tune out to everyone else's diet. Spare me for all time any further conversation about three moderate meals, or six little meals, or two gigantic meals or one gluttonous meal. The subject is dull (unfulfilling to say the least), and I realize now that it has bored me even back to when I was in my mother's womb, receiving those lifeline/lifetime messages about thinking thin. Perhaps that's why I've been so unsuccessful. When you do something you're not interested in it never turns out right.

title: Speaking Personally; ONLY A STEP AWAY FROM BEING DISABLED
description: AS 1981, the International Year of Disabled Persons, draws to a close, so too does my personal experience with disability. About one in 10 Americans has some permanent disabling condition; I have learned that each of us is only a step away from adding to the statistics.

title: Dr. John Patrick Dolan Dies; Historian of Christian Church
description: Dr. John Patrick Dolan, a University of South Carolina history professor, author and editor of a critically acclaimed history of the Christian church, died early Friday.

title: 3 Die in Philippines Fire
description: Two American servicemen and a woman died today when fire raged through their house in an area near the United States Clark Air Force base 50 miles north of Manila, a base spokesman said.

title: Photography View; THE MEDIUM IS SETTLING IN AMONG THE OTHER ARTS
description: In photography, the 1981 man of the year was John Szarkowski, director of the department of photography at the Museum of Modern Art. Not only did he climax his career at the Modern by launching the first of four exhibitions devoted to the work of Eugene Atget, but he also witnessed the emergence of a new generation of scholars and curators whom he has trained or influenced.

title: Stamps; DR. BUNCHE ON FIRST 1982 ISSUE
description: Dr. Ralph Bunche, the first black to receive the Nobel Peace Prize and the principal architect of one of the most vital activities of the United Nations - its peacekeeping operations - is the subject of the first issue from the United States in 1982.

title: Barbara Galton, Banker, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Eugene B. Galton of Newton, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Robin Galton, to Steven Elliot Hindman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hindman of Brookline, Mass.

title: ISRAEL'S MINORITY IN THE MIDDLE
description: Rafik Halabi is a news correspondent for Israel Television. This article is excerpted from his book, ''The West Bank Story,'' to be published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. By Rafik Halabi

title: A BOMBING SHAKES MUGABE'S DELICATE BALANCE
description: The bomb that wrecked the headquarters of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe's political party in Salisbury last weekend injected new tensions and uncertainty into one of the world's more hopeful experiments. That is the attempt to build a stable and prosperous state in Zimbabwe under majority rule.

title: SOLVING ONE OF AMERICAN LIFE'S PUZZLES
description: FOR a European spectator, not raised on a steady diet of Saturday, Sunday, or Monday night telecasts, football is one of the more intriguing puzzles in American life. Fascinated by the foreign intensity the armored players radiate in each violent exchange, a non-American at first can only watch in silent amazement. A silence punctuated by every roar of approval coming from the fans. What's going on there?

title: Article 147395 -- No Title
description: A challenge grant of $100,000 has been awarded to Ballet Theater Foundation Inc. by the Kresge Foundation of Troy, Mich., toward the $1 million renovation of American Ballet Theater's headquarters at 890 Broadway.

title: THE WAY IT WAS IN THE YEAR THAT WAS
description: ''No one has asked for my resignation, and I have not offered it ... I won't quit. If anyone wants to terminate my employment contract, I am available to anyone who wants to see me.''

title: Riverside Dance Gala To Open Season Jan. 5
description: The Riverside Dance Festival will open a six-month season Jan. 5 at 7:30 P.M. with a gala starring companies that have appeared at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Included will be ''Journey'' and ''Soaring'' by the Joyce Trisler Danscompany, Mary Anthony's ''Eve'' by Yuriko Kimura and Ross Parkes and Pauline Koner's ''Poeme.''

title: 2 SUITS ATTACK CONSTITUTIONALITY OF FINANCING FOR SCHOOLS
description: NEW JERSEY'S system of financing public education may be in trouble again. Two suits filed in Superior Court have attacked the constitutionality of the system, which was created in 1975.

title: Bangladesh Leader on Visit
description: President Abdus Sattar of Bangladesh left today for a four-day state visit to Saudi Arabia. He was accompanied by his foreign and finance ministers and other top officials.

title: SOVIET SHOWS CONCERN AT U.S. ECONOMIC CURBS
description: The Soviet press agency Tass continued today to report what it called ''the gradual normalization of life'' in Poland but indicated in its attacks on the Reagan Administration that the Kremlin remained seriously concerned about the implications of American economic sanctions.

title: Mailbox; Salazar Memory Needs Update
description: To the Sports Editor: In the Dec. 8 New York Times, Alberto Salazar was quoted as saying that ''Nobody has ever been one of the top marathoners and one of the top five or 10 in track.''

title: GUNMEN KILL MAN AND WOUND AN OFF-DUTY OFFICER
description: A Brooklyn man was killed and an off-duty New York City police officer was seriously wounded last night when two men entered a shoe store in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn and exchanged gunfire with the officer, whom they apparently recognized, the police said.

title: How Helping Hands Evolved
description: It may seem like a strange way to support a cause, but last week Wendell Bird, a California lawyer and promoter of creationism, said he had tried to dissuade several educators -in one case, successfully - from testifying in a Little Rock, Ark., trial on behalf of a creationism law.

title: Jets on Offense
description: No. 85, Wesley Walker, 6-0, 179, California, 5th year; Key offensive weapon. No. 72, Chris Ward, lt, 6-3, 267, Ohio State, 4th year; Good runblocker, improving pass-blocker. No. 66, Randy Rasmussen, lg, 6-2, 260, Kearney State, 15th year; Only Jet with playoff experience. No. 65, Joe Fields, c, 6-2, 253, Widener, 7the year. Makes correct calls on blocking assignments. No. 60, Dan Alexander, rg, 6-4, 260, L.S.U., 5th year; Not flashy, but rarely penalized. No. 79, Marvin Powell, rt, 6-5, 271, U.S.C., 5th year; Voted onto his third straight all-star team. No. 83, Jerome Barkum, te, 6-4, 227, Jackson State, 10th year; Makes clutch plays, and is capable blocker. No. 80, Lam Jones, wr, 5-11, 183, Texas, 2d year; Finally a fulltime player. No. 14, Richard Todd, qb, 6-2, 206, Alabama, 6th year; Team leader with 25 touchdown passes and only 13 interceptions. No. 24, Freeman McNeil, rb, 5-11, 225, U.C.L.A., rookie; Most dangerous runner on team with 623 yards and 4.5 average. No. 44, Tom Newton, rb, 6-0, 220, California, 5th year; Good blocker, came off bench to start. No. 5, Pat Leahy, k, 6-0, 189, St. Louis, 8th year. Outstanding season, 25 of 36 field-goal attempts. No. 42, Bruce Harper, kr, 5-8, 177, Kutztown State, 5th year; He led team in receptions, outstanding on punt returns and kickoffs.

title: Saudi Arabian Official to Visit Iraq to Sign a Border Accord
description: Saudi Arabia's Interior Minister, Prince Nayef, left for Baghdad today to sign a border agreement with Iraq and to discuss the security situation in the Persian Gulf, the official Saudi Press Agency said.

title: RESTRICTIONS AND POLITICAL BIASES LEAD TO DISCREPANCIES IN NEWS ON POLAND
description: Since the imposition of martial law in Poland two weeks ago, there has been a wave of contradictory information inside and outside Poland on what is actually happening in the country.

title: Cynthia Barradas, C.P.A., Affianced
description: Mrs. Augustus R. White of Bartlesville, Okla., and Barry Barradas of Escondido, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Maria Barradas, to Donald Brian Elitzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hillard X. Elitzer of East Greenbush, N.Y.

title: NEW TAXES: THE WHY BUT NOT THE HOW
description: HARTFORD THE state is heading toward an $83 million budget deficit and as a result taxes will rise in a few weeks, most legislators agree. Even so, the details are almost as vague as they were five weeks ago, when the General Assembly began its special session to decide where the money would come from.

title: SKI TRAINS
description: To the Editor:

title: GUN-CONTROL ADVOCATES ARE FEELING SURROUNDED
description: One of the darkest hours for handgun control advocates was the election of Ronald Reagan. Suddenly, with Mr. Reagan's inauguration, the battle shifted from winning passage of stiffer handgun control legislation to trying to keep the conservative tide in Congress from sweeping away laws already on the books.

title: Society and The Skyscraper
description: The effort to avoid the plain glass boxes of the 1960's is admirable, but is a return to romanticism and historical styles the answer (''The New American Skyscraper,'' by Paul Goldberger, Nov. 8)?

title: THE BUCK IS OFTEN EASIER TO PASS THAN NEW TAXES
description: When it came time last spring to pass Connecticut's $3 billion budget, the Democratic leadership made an embarrassing discovery: Misjudging its support in the House, it lacked the 76 votes necessary for passage. After some hurried negotiations produced a compromise, the 1981-82 budget cleared by a single vote.

title: EXILES IN FLORIDA PREPARE A COUP - WINK, WINK
description: "It's a matter of interpretation," Hector Fabian said last week at the Cuban and Central American exiles' military training camp in Florida. "Under the Carter and Nixon Administrations, what we were doing was a crime. With the Reagan Administration, no one has bothered us for 10 months."

title: Leisure; FIRST AID FOR WINTER INJURIES
description: Michael B. Trimble is a professional horticulturist and freelance writer. By MICHAEL B. TRIMBLE

title: Cheryl Gotthelf to Be Wed To Daniel Shapiro in June
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Cheryl Annette Gotthelf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gotthelf of Wayne, N.J., to Daniel Bishop Shapiro, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Shapiro of Englewood, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: WINNERS OF INDIVIDUAL AND TEAM CHAMPIONSHIPS DURING 1981
description: Archery U.S. Champions Men - Rich McKinney, Glendale, Ariz. Women - Debra Metzger, Lancaster, Pa. Intermediate Boys - J. Kazak, Aurora, Ill. Intermediate Girls - Becky Liggett, Muncie, Ind. Jr. Boys - D. Stinnett, Mogadore, Ohio. Cadet - Brent Gardiner, Farmland, Ind. Cadet Girls - Katie Blum, Cincinnati. Crossbow Men - Erv Myers, Dallastown, Pa. Women - Carol Pelosi, Greenbelt, Md.

title: De Paul Beats Louisville On a Second-Half Surge
description: Terry Cummings scored 37 points, a career high, and Skip Dillard scored 15 to help De Paul to a 75-68 victory today over Louisville.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE Suffolk County Legislature has approved a $105,000 study of alternate water supply systems for the North Fork towns of Riverhead and Southold. Private wells in both towns are threatened by contamination from pesticides, nitrate fertilizers and salt water intrusion along the coast.

title: BRITISH LABOR PARTY ENDING A BAD YEAR IN DISSARRAY
description: Britain's weary Labor Party has struggled to the end of what some of its members regard as the worst year in its 80-year history. And its prospects for 1982 seem anything but bright.

title: Margaret Nichols Engaged
description: Margaret Sue Nichols, owner of Grand Illusions, a Philadelphia design firm, and Richard J. Green, general counsel for First Federal Savings and Loan of Philadelphia, plan to be married in the spring. Albert L. Nichols of Hagerstown, Md., and Nan Mackey Nichols of Frederick, Md., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Green of Haverford, Pa.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS IN SUMMARY
description: It came late in the long battle over the equal rights amendment, but it was a potentially deadly double-barrelled shot. In the first place, Federal District Judge Marion J. Callister ruled last week, Congress was not empowered to extend the deadline for state ratification of the amendment without a two-thirds majority vote; and in the second place, state legislatures were within their rights to rescind previous ratification votes.

title: U.S. PULLS THE RUG ON PAISLEY
description: Raising a private army was no problem last month for the Rev. Ian Paisley, the Northern Ireland Protestant leader, but raising money in the United States could be more complicated.

title: Bergmann's Coercion
description: To the Business Editor: Because the article ''Charity Needs Coercion'' by Barbara R. Bergmann (Dec. 13, 1981) so badly misrepresented the true nature of American philanthropy and demeaned the contributions to a better society made possible by the generosity of Americans, we the undersigned have joined together in an effort to put the facts straight for your readers.

title: COPING WITH A CHANGING FAIRFIELD
description: ''FAIRFIELD COUNTY'S growth is out of control and something had better be done about it soon.'' This is a standard refrain among businessmen and others in the country.

title: Spanish Cooking Oil Kills 3
description: Three deaths over the Christmas vacation from food prepared with toxic cooking oil brought the toll to 229 lives lost in the eight-month-old scandal, the Spanish Health Ministry said today. A 30-year-old woman from Leon and two Madrid men, aged 49 and 27, were the latest victims of rapeseed oil treated for industrial use and sold as cheap olive oil.

title: THE POLITICAL MERCENARIES
description: THE RISE OF POLITICAL CONSULTANTS New Ways of Winning Elections. By Larry J. Sabato. 376 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.95. THE NEW KINGMAKERS By David Chagall. 419 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: IS HUNTING MOURNING DOVES JUSTIFIED?
description: THE American public's right to enjoy and guard wildlife was clarified in 1863, when the United States Supreme Court established that wildlife belongs to all the people.

title: THE BUSINESS BOOK OF RECORDS
description: 1. The largest operating loss in American corporate history was recorded. What was the amount and the company? 2. Another company recorded the largest quarterly loss ever.

title: AFTER TWO YEARS OF DEADLOCK, WHAT NEXT FOR AFGHANISTAN?
description: Two years ago this weekend, the Soviet Union began dispatching 85,000 soldiers across its southern border into Afghanistan. It described the contingent as ''a limited, temporary force'' sent to quell insurrections instigated and aided by foreign powers.

title: No Headline
description: As one who has kept a daily diary since 1933 and who now operates a small company devoted exclusively to publishing diaries and journals, may I say that I found Patrick Huyghe's article heavy going? If diary writers are really, as he says, turning a new leaf and going in for such tortured self-investigation, such humorless use of the diary, let me beg them to turn back quickly to the older methods. Diaries can serve as therapy, yes, as talking to a friend when in trouble can be therapeutic, but Ira Progoff's workshops sound depressing, all that wallowing in one's self.

title: Audrey H. Ingber, Lawyer, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack S. Ingber of South Fallsburg, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Audrey Helene Ingber, to Steven Alan Bender, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Bender of Harrison, N.Y.

title: PRIDE IN IRISH CULTURE AND STRUGGLE RESURGING ON THE ISLAND
description: FARMINGDALE ''THIS is a baton round, designed to be fired at particular individuals in riots,'' said Nassau County District Attorney Denis E. Dillon, holding the flesh-colored, four-and-three-quarter-inch plastic slug over his head so that the audience at a recent educational symposium on Northern Ireland could see it.

title: Fashion
description: THE NEW SNOWY WHITES Nice and easy still does it every time. These unadorned, uncluttered offerings from the 1981-82 resort-wear collections prove the point.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Spurned Money
description: Ever since Phoenix opened its new Sky Harbor Airport Terminal in November 1979, people have been tossing pennies into a fountain there - $40 to $50 worth every month. When the city's aviation chief invited the Phoenix United Way to rake in the cash, the charity group wasn't interested.

title: 2 Die in Explosion in Korea
description: Two people were killed and about 90 were injured, several critically, in a gas explosion in a basement restaurant here today, the police said. They said the ceiling of the restaurant collapsed after liquefied petroleum gas, believed to have been used as cooking fuel, exploded.

title: WIDENING OF SIDEWALKS URGED IN W. 42D ST. REDEVELOPMENT
description: Wider sidewalks and better subway entrances will be needed for the crowds of people who would be attracted to West 42d Street when it is redeveloped under a proposal sponsored by New York City and state agencies, according to the Regional Plan Association.

title: N. CAROLINA 82-69 WINNER
description: It appears that even Dean Smith, the basketball coach at North Carolina who casts a ballot each week in the United Press International poll that ranks the nation's teams, will have to admit that the Tar Heels should be rated as the best.

title: ARCHIE MCCARDELL'S WOES
description: International Harvester completed a $4.2 billion financial restructuring plan, said to be the largest in American corporate history. Slackening demand for heavy trucks and construction equipment caused a loss of $635.7 million on continuing operations in its last fiscal year, and Harvester's chairman, Archie R. McCardell, (right) is gearing up for what may be a 30 percent drop in the coming decade's demand for heavy machinery as compared with 1970 levels. Harvester plans to ask for $100 million of concessions from the United Autoworkers, but top executives are not expected to return their bonuses.

title: STAGE: LIFE OF ST. FRANCIS IN A MUSICAL FLASHBACK
description: In ''Jesus Christ Superstar'' and ''Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat,'' Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice proved that Bible stories could be the source for musical inspiration. The three creators of ''Francis,'' a new musical about St. Francis of Assisi, at St. Peter's Church, takes the genre back to Sunday-school Biblestudy class.

title: Bills on Offense
description: No. 80, Jerry Butler, wr, 6-0, 178, Clemson, 3d year; His speed has overpowered Jets. No. 72, Ken Jones, lt, 6-5, 250, Arkansas State, 6th year. Yielded 2 sacks to Joe Klecko this season. No. 61, Tom Lynch, lg, 6-5, 250, Boston College, 5th year; Came in midseason trade from Seattle. No. 53, Will Grant, c, 6-4, 248, Kentucky, 4th year; Dependable snapper in shotgun formation. No. 73, Jon Borchardt, rg, 6-5, 255, Montana State, 3d year; Versatile lineman with good upper-body strength. No. 70, Joe Devlin, rt, 6-5, 250, Iowa, 6th year; Bills' most consistent lineman. No. 86, Mark Brammer, te, 6-3, 235, Michigan State, 2d year; Hasn't caught pass last 3 games. No. 82, Frank Lewis, wr, 6-1, 196, Grambling, 11th year; The receiver they go to on third down. No. 12, Joe Ferguson, qb, 6-1, 195, Arkansas, 8th year; Not mobile, but ''reads'' defenses and spots receivers quickly. No. 48, Roosevelt Leaks, fb, 5-10, 225, Texas, 7th year.

title: Toxic Shock's Other Victims
description: Toxic shock, which had been considered a disease of menstruating women who use tampons, is now known to be a potentially fatal syndrome in a range of individuals, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: West German Leader Vacations in Florida
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and his wife and daughter strolled the beach and collected shells at this resort island on the west coast of Florida today, the first full day of a 10-day vacation.

title: MIDWEST SUPER STORE
description: NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr. is a correspondent in The Times's Chicago bureau. By NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr.

title: DECISION NEARS ON REOPENING HEMPSTEAD PLANT
description: HEMPSTEAD FOR almost two years, the $135 million Hempstead Resource Recovery plant has remained idle amid a continuing debate over its viability as a means of disposing of the town's growing mountain of garbage and charges that it poses a health hazard.

title: THE REGION IN SUMMARY
description: When Mayor Koch announced that improving the transit system would be the top priority of his next term, he took on one of the city's most visible problems, but not the one New Yorkers seem to think is most important. The results of a mid-December poll, released last week, indicate that perhaps more than ever, city residents are worried about crime.

title: THE KEY IS MONTGOMERY
description: For 18 years, the Giants have waited to be in a playoff game. They will be there today when they oppose the Eagles at Veterans Stadium at Philadelphia in a wild-card game.

title: Numismatics; COMMEMORATIVE COIN ON THE WAY
description: As the old year draws to a close a new age may be dawning in United States coinage: For the first time in nearly three decades the U.S. Mint is about to produce a commemorative coin, and more such coins may lie ahead.

title: Juilliard Drama Tryouts Planned for 4 Cities
description: The Juilliard School's theater center will hold auditions in February and March in New York, Chicago, New Orleans and San Francisco.

title: WORK GROWS, FUNDS SHRINK FOR LEGAL AID
description: After less than two months as president of the Legal Aid Society, Michael A. Cooper says he is sure of one thing: The organization, which represents indigents in New York City courtrooms, will experience greater demands for its services in the coming year with less financial support from Washington.

title: GARBAGE COLLECTORS AND BARMEN RATE HIGH IN SELF-ESTEEM
description: Bartenders and garbage collectors enjoy considerable self-esteem, despite public opinion polls that have shown a lack of status in their jobs, a Pennsylvania State University study shows.

title: A Bishop in Buffalo Held Up by Gunmen
description: A man armed with a revolver held up the Rev. Bernard J. McLaughlin, the auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Buffalo after the 7 P.M. Christmas eve mass Thursday and took the collection according to the police. The mant escaped in a white car with Massachusetts license plates, they said.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE ISSUES A CALL TO PEOPLE 'HUMILIATED' BY AUTHORITIES
description: Pope John Paul II made an impromptu appearance at his window overlooking St. Peter's Square today and, in an apparent reference to his native Poland, said many people were being ''humiliated'' by their governments this Christmas season.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Taking a Flier
description: The plan outlined by the aviation engineer to the ruling fathers of Hominy, Okla., was as follows: He would build 400-pound helicopters to sell for $12,500 if the tiny city would build the plant. Hominy would gain 400 jobs and millions in income.

title: New Year Awaits Tax Resolution
description: ''When we get into next year,'' House Republican leader Robert H. Michel said of shaping the 1983 budget, ''it's going to be tougher than a son of a buck.'' At the White House last week, it already was.

title: RED BRIGADES LOOK ABROAD
description: After several years of trying and failing to overturn or even seriously disrupt their country's political system, Italy's Red Brigades have turned to a broader target. In leaflets scattered through Italian cities last week, they took credit for the abduction Dec. 17 of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, the top-ranking United States Army officer in NATO land forces in Southern Europe.

title: Susan Petrick to Be Bride of John Nelson in May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. L.M. Petrick of Cranford, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jean Petrick, to John Frederick Nelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. Nelson of Morris, N.Y.

title: New Jersey Guide; VIENNA TO MONTCLAIR
description: The Vienna Choir Boys, perennial favorites of audiences around the world, are coming to Montclair for a concert on Jan. 14. The 24-voice group - it was founded in 1498 as the Habsburg Court Boys Choir - is famous for the purity of its sound, its disciplined singing and professional manner. It is now in its 50th year of concerts in this country.

title: 14 Killed in Filipino Gunfight
description: About 50 Communist guerrillas ambushed a military truck about 175 miles southeast of Manila on Christmas Eve, killing 14 people, the police reported today.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 10 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 15 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 5 34 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 3 20 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 5 4 7 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 6 6 6 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 7 7 8 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An Italian princess, in quest of romance, finds frustration, then fulfillment in America.

title: Giants on Defense
description: No. 36, Mark Haynes, lcb, 5-11, 185, Colorado, 2d year; The key to stopping Carmichael. No. 70, Gary Jeter, re, 6-4, 260, Southern California, 5th year; Strong, secure, especially against pass. No. 53, Harry Carson, rilb, 6-2, 235, South Carolina State, 6th year; All-pro hitter having best season. No. 77, Bill Neill, nt, 6-4, 255, Pittsburgh, rookie; Unheralded, bruising key to front line. No. 55, Brian Kelley, lilb, 6-3, 222, California Lutheran, 9th year; Smart and slick, but little speed. No. 75, George Martin, le 6-4, 245, Oregon, 7th year; Clever pass rusher who makes big plays. No. 29, Bill Currier, ss, 6-0, 195, South Carolina, 5th year; Hard hitter who makes most of ability. No. 24, Terry Jackson, rcb, 5-11, 197, San Diego State, 4th year; Physical and intimidating, sometimes indiscreetly. No. 28, Beasley Reece, fs, 6-1, 195, North Texas State, 6th year; Finally seems comfortable in new job. No. 56, Lawrence Taylor, rolb, 6-3, 238, North Carolina, rookie; A once-in-alifetime talent. No. 57, Byron Hunt, lolb, 6-4, 230, Southern Methodist, rookie, Lifesaver replacing injured Van Pelt. No. 13, Dave Jennings, p, 6-4, 205, St. Lawrence, 8th year; Reliable week in and week out.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT PACERS, 112-106
description: What it took to get the Knicks out of their slump was something simple. What was ironic was that it took an injury to Maurice Lucas to discover it.

title: NEWGATE CALLENDAR'S EUROPE
description: NEWGATE CALLENDAR reviews mystery and detective fiction for The Times Book Review By NEWGATE CALLENDAR

title: CITY SEEKS TO USE STATE TAX RETURNS IN ATTEMPT TO REDUCE WELFARE FRAUD
description: New York City is seeking access to joint state tax returns as part of a widening effort to reduce welfare fraud, but the State Tax Commissioner says that secrecy laws prohibit such a move.

title: LIFERS PROGRAM: DOES IT WORK?
description: WOODBRIDGE THE Rahway State Prison Lifers Group, whose Juvenile Awareness Project retreated almost into obscurity after winning national awards, is once more in center stage, thrust there by two publications.

title: No Headline
description: G.A.O. ASSAILS WATT PLAN FOR OFFSHORE LEASES

title: Food; ONE-STOP GOURMET SHOPPING IN A HIGH-TECH SETTING
description: WOODBURY A NEW style of fancy food shop that may represent the trend for the 1980's is the multiplex emporium that stocks a vast array of select condiments, candies, coffees, cheeses, prepared salads and entrees, smoked fish, cured meats, baked goods, cookware, giftware and cookbooks.

title: FINK THREATENS SUIT OVER STATE REAPPORTIONMENT
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink is threatening to take the Republican-led State Senate to court to force a reapportionment of the State Legislature before next year's elections.

title: Jackson Back On Jet Roster
description: Bobby Jackson, a cornerback and one of the Jets' defensive co-captains, was activated today for Sunday's playoff game after missing the last five games with a broken right arm.

title: COPYING A SOURCE NEED NOT BE PLAGIARISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine; ALL THAT SPARKLES ISN'T CHAMPAGNE
description: he chalky soil and rolling hills of the Champagne district of France have been afflicted with poor weather in recent vintages, creating a shortage of wines and an increase in prices for the celebrated sparkling product of the local vineyards. As a result, Champagne devotees all over the world are finding that last year's $10 bottle now costs $18, $20 or perhaps even more.

title: Official's Conviction Upheld
description: Pennsylvania's Supreme Court has reinstated the conviction of Isadore Bellis, a former City Council leader, for taking $9,000 in kickbacks. The panel reversed a Superior Court ruling in 1980, which found that although Mr. Bellis had received ''improper cash payments,'' he could not be convicted on the malfeasance charges because he had been acquitted of extortion.

title: A BANK, BY ANY OTHER NAME . . .
description: Sears. RCA. Gulf and Western. National Steel. Baldwin United. Greyhound. General Electric. Control Data. Not to mention American Express, Merrill Lynch, Prudential, Beneficial and Transamerica.

title: LONG ISLANDERS EXPRESS FRESH HOPES FOR 1982
description: WITH the approach of the new year, the Long Island Weekly asked a number of well-known Long Islanders in different fields what their hopes and expectations were for 1982. Here are their replies.

title: CREATION DEBATE IS NOT LIMITED TO ARKANSAS TRIAL
description: While the challenge to creationist teaching in Arkansas schools has pitted those supporting what is essentially a Biblical account of Creation against scientists arguing for evolution, the trial has brought to center stage the debate among scientists themselves regarding three aspects of creation: the mechanics of evolution, the origin of life and the origin of the universe.

title: GROUND ZERO
description: Near the end of the film "Dr. Strangelove," the mad physicist pulls from his pocket a plastic circular slide rule and swiftly calculates how many years the President and his Cabinet will need to hunker in a mineshaft after detonation of a Soviet ''doomsday device.''

title: The Pros and Cons Of Nuclear Energy
description: Roger Starr's article ''The Case for Nuclear Energy'' (Nov. 8) provided a splendid overview of the energy problem in general and of the role of nuclear power in particular. It is unfortunate that in the climate of misunderstanding about nuclear power which has developed, Mr. Starr's statements may seem unconventional and even daring. That in no way detracts from the validity of his arguments, but rather underlines the need for more balanced and informed coverage of energy issues. DAVID BODANSKY, Professor of Physics, University of Washington, Seattle

title: Antiques
description: A TOAST TO THE HOLIDAY SEASON By CAROLYN DARROW NEWARK

title: APPAREL AND APPEARANCES
description: THE FASHIONABLE MIND Reflections on Fashion 1970-81 By Kennedy Fraser. 270 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.50.

title: WEIGHING THE REPAYING OF AN OLD LOAN
description: In matters of money, there are few better feelings than the one that comes from unloading an onerous loan. In these recession-shot days, ''most people are going to worry more about putting food on the table than about paying back the bank,'' as Larry F. Hedge, an assistant vice president and director of consumer-credit policy at Citibank, put it.

title: MUSIC: STRING ORCHESTRA GIVES BACH AND CORELLI
description: Alexander Schneider brought his annual assemblage of outstanding young string players, the New York String Orchestra, to Carnegie Hall on Christmas Eve for a midnight concert devoted to works of Bach and Corelli. The New York String Orchestra Seminar, to which the players are devoting their Christmas holidays, is in its 13th year.

title: Around the Nation; Weather Suspends Search for Missing Pilot
description: Rough weather today forced two planes to suspend a search for an Air Force pilot whose F4-E Phantom jet crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off North Carolina's coast eight days ago.

title: Miss Porter To Be Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Philip J. Porter of Brookline, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia McLaughlin Porter, to Thomas Penshorn Ogden, son of Mrs. Charles Clucas of Stockbridge, Mass., and Elliot M. Ogden Jr. of New York.

title: REFLECTIONS ON THE BEST OF 1981
description: AFEW remaining days of 1981 provide time to think back over restaurants discovered and meals especially enjoyed during the year. While the harvest of joyful dining experiences was somewhat thinner than in previous years, there was enough to provide us with vivid memories and even a sense of anticipation for the gustatory journey into 1982.

title: Mary Louise Viscardi Is Engaged to W. Ian Laird
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. John P. Viscardi Jr. of Plandome, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Louise Viscardi, to W. Ian Laird, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Laird Jr. of Wilmington, Del., and Saranac Lake, N.Y.

title: Problem Prisons Scant Reforms
description: When it comes to the sad history of prison reform, theories are many and solutions few. In Atlanta last week, a Federal appeals court indefinitely stayed a judge's order to release more than 300 prisoners, some of them convicted killers and rapists, from Alabama's crowded prisons.

title: A DIM YEAR FOR AUTOS
description: Auto sales dropped 22.5 percent below last year's levels for mid-December, making 1981 a candidate for the Big Three's worst sales year in two decades. Huge layoffs in the industry prompted the United Autoworkers to schedule a meeting with General Motors and Ford in early January to consider renegotiating current labor contracts for wage concessions.

title: Around the World; Egypt Orders Release Of 39 Held 3 Months
description: The Egyptian authorities ordered the release of 39 political and religious detainees today, including Omar Telmessani, senior member of the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood and editor of its magazine, Al Daawa.

title: FUGU
description: To the Editor:

title: IS PT. JEFF. STN.-T'VILLE TOO LONG?
description: WHAT's in a name? To some people who live in a hamlet known as Port Jefferson Station-Terryville, there's a lot - sometimes too much.

title: With Friends Like That, Who Needs Enemies?
description: Environmentalists are becoming much more aware of the need for trade-offs. We know that the economy, as well as the air and water, must be reasonably healthy.

title: WALTERS FAMILY IS FULL OF CHEER
description: Stan Walters, the Philadephia Eagles' offensive tackle, called his father recently. His father still lives in Rutherford, New Jersey, where Stan was born and raised.

title: Stella Ward Is Married
description: Stella Elizabeth Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Ward of Stamford, England, was married yesterday to Joseph Paul Armao Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Armao of Howard Beach, Queens. The Rev. Ignatius A. Catanello performed the cermony at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens. The bride holds degrees from Oxford and Cambridge Universities. Mr. Armao, a student at the Harvard Law School, graduated summa cum laude from Columbia College and Oxford, where he studied under a Euretta J. Kellett Fellowship.

title: MARGARET SMALLACOMBE AFFIANCED TO MARK HILL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Smallacombe of New Hope, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Smallacombe, to Mark P. Hill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Hill of Princeton, N.J.

title: Most Public Workers Laid Off By Revenue Cuts Have Jobs
description: Most of the public workers who were laid off because of tax revenue cuts caused by so-called Proposition 2 1/2 have found jobs in the private sector, according to a report by the Massachusetts Division of Employment Security.

title: NAPA VALLEY TRIES TO KEEP ITS TINY SCHOOLS OPEN
description: A dozen children peer out the door of their one-room schoolhouse at a sick animal nosing through trash in the yard. Cows low on the other side of the fence, but Arlene Samuels remains calm.

title: DANIELLE MITTERRAND: QUIET ACTIVIST
description: -When Francois Mitterrand ran unsuccessfully for President in 1965 and 1974, his wife, Danielle, was presented as the dutiful housewife, surrounded by floppy-eared dogs and wide-eyed children.

title: Black Urban Workers Divided Into 3 Groups
description: In the hierarchy of black industrial castes, the urban work force in South Africa is subdivided at least three ways among workers with a relatively secure right of permanent residence in a black township - now sometimes tagged ''insiders'' - and two types of contract laborers from the black homelands whose permission to be in a white area must be renewed annually.

title: Carter Simpson to Wed Paulette Peters
description: The engagement of Paulette L. Peters, a legal assistant with the Irving Trust Company, to Carter Berkeley Simpson, a lawyer, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Peters of Locust Valley, L.I., parents of the future bride. Mr. Simpson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Simpson of Pittsburgh and Hilton Head, S.C. The wedding is planned for May 1.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE PHYSICISTS By C.P. Snow. Introduction by William Cooper. Illustrated. 192 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $15.95.

title: STORIES AND A NOVEL
SEIZED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: What do you put in a food parcel for a political prisoner in South Africa? Where do you go in New York City to get that sort of information? You try to remember the food he loved as a child. Chocolates - in the shape of a key, perhaps? But levity may not be appreciated by prison officials. At first, there is no levity - the news is always sickening, a shock. This is the third time that my brother Nicholas has been detained without charges, and it does not get any easier to take.

title: Ousted for Complaint, Worker Wins Job Back
description: A civilian dismissed from his job at a Maine Air Force station after he complained about mismanagement has been ordered reinstated.

title: Run and Take The Money
description: As a millionaire businessman, Thomas H. Kean might very well list money as the last thing he wants out of politics. But there were strong indications last week that as New Jersey's next governor, a substantial pay raise will be the first thing he and others will get.

title: SARTRE IN SEARCH OF FLAUBERT
description: THE FAMILY IDIOT Gustave Flaubert 1821-1857. Volume I. By Jean-Paul Sartre. Translated by Carol Cosman. 627 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $25. SARTRE & FLAUBERT By Hazel E. Barnes. 449 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $25.

title: YORKTOWN PHOENIX HOUSE DISPUTE GROWS
description: postcard scenes abound in this northern Westchester land of hills, which is still largely woodland. On Amelia Drive, in an isolated development on a ridge, wreaths and Christmas trees have been placed on the rows of four-bedroom homes. This year, there are new decorations -orange ribbons tied to almost every tree and mailbox. They are a sign of protest amid the traditional signs of celebration - Protests against the presence of a neighbor, Phoenix House.

title: On Language By William Safire Sleazy Does It Kimble Mead
description: About 18 months ago, inveighing against the influence-peddling of a few of President Carter's friends and relatives, I searched for a noun that would encapsulate shoddiness, cheapness, trickiness and generally off-putting behavior. The noun that presented itself was ''sleaziness,'' but I had heard a variant of that word, a shorter and punchier back-formation from ''sleazy'': the unctuous ''sleaze,'' oozing meretriciously from every pore. My chosen headline: ''The Politics of Sleaze.''

title: STACKS OF MAIL AWAIT ARRIVAL OF U.N. CHIEF
description: Stacks of mail - more than 1,000 letters, cards and telegrams bearing postmarks from around the world - await Javier Perez de Cuellar on Jan. 1 when he moves into his new office as Secretary General.

title: THE 'MILLIONAIRESS' OF TAMMY GRIMES
description: STAMFORD ''THE MILLIONAIRESS'' is a play of George Bernard Shaw's old age, written when he was 79. I don't feel completely comfortable going along with Brooks Atkinson, who referred to it as ''a senile play.'' Rather, I find myself more at ease with the comments of Kenneth Tynan, who referred to the play as ''a didactic farce'' in which ''the characters talk interminably, infectiously and almost interchangeably,'' a play in which Shaw is ''grinding an ax, but the sparks refuse to fly.''

title: OPERA: PAIR OF DEBUTS IN 'BOHEME' AT THE MET
description: In the Metropolitan Opera's third performance this season of its new production of ''La Boheme'' - on Christmas Eve - Ermanno Mauro appeared as Rodolfo and Mario Sereni as Schaunard, both for the first time at the Met.

title: Stage View; THERE WAS MUCH TO BEMOAN, BUT LOTS TO PRAISE
description: In looking back on the theatrical year - 1981 or any other - one must always begin by bemoaning the state of the art. So I herewith declare that the theater is once again in sorry shape, that Broadway will soon collapse under the weight of leaden musicals and star vehicles, that Off Broadway has lost its once adventurous way. And yet, in the same breath, I must confess that I didn't have to scrape around and tear my hair to find 10 outstanding productions in this calendar year. The fabulous invalid really does have some life in her yet.

title: PRIVATE BRIDGE BID
description: ABRAHAM and Esther Bronfield may soon become the sole proprietors of the longest private bridge on eastern Long Island. All they need is the permission of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation to build a house on a wetlands site in Remsenburg and construct a link to their retreat.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: GO SLOWLY, COME BACK QUICKLY By David Niven. 327 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $14.95.

title: 5 Die in Madrid Car Accident
description: A car skidded on wet pavement and plunged into the Manzanares River on the outskirts of Madrid on Friday and all five occupants, members of the same family, were killed, the police said today. The victims' ages ranged from 17 to 22.

title: TRIBES WIN BATTLE ON FISHING RIGHTS
description: Three Indian tribes have won a nineyear court dispute over their fishing rights in Lakes Michigan, Superior and Huron. The next step will be negotiations between the three tribes, the State of Michigan and the United States Department of the Interior on a fish management plan.

title: CLASSICAL DISKS: AN ABUNDANCE OF RICHES
description: The year 1981 in classical records was marked by contraction, expansion and anticipation. Contraction, in the continuation of the decline in the number and presence of the major labels. Expansion, in the ever-greater and more confusing horde of minor labels rushing to fill the breach. And anticipation, with the imminent onset of the true digital era, which may trigger further cycles of contraction and expansion of the release schedules.

title: Jets on Defense
description: No. 99, Mark Gastineau, le, 6-5, 276, E. Central Okla., 3d year; 20 sacks and enthusiasm. No. 74, Abdul Salaam, lt, 6-3 269, Kent State, 6th year; Has become excellent passrusher to go with talents against run. No. 93, Marty Lyons, rt, 6-5, 269, Alabama, 3d year; Slowed by injuries, has produced more quarterback pressure. No. 73, Joe Klecko, 6-3, 272, Temple, 5th year; 20 1/2 sacks, 73 tackles, great strength and quickness. No. 51, Greg Buttle, llb, 6-3, 232, Penn State, 6th year; Has become a consistent player. No. 54, Stan Blinka, mlb, 6-2, 234, Sam Houston State, 3d year; Settled down after early season slump; Ron Crosby comes in on pass situations.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title: FRANCHISES SLIP AS BROKERS FIND FEES BURDENSOME
description: Offering brand-names and national advertising campaigns, real estate franchises burst upon the home selling scene in the late 70's. The logos of Century 21, Better Homes and Gardens, Electronic Realty Associates, Realty World and Red Carpet, to name a few, soon became as familiar a sight on front lawns.

title: ALMANAC IS ITSELF A RARE OCCURRENCE
description: SHARON WHEN asked, Robert O'Brien can, without hesitating, rattle off the names and locations of the highest peaks and the largest lakes in Connecticut. He can also tell you how much money the Secretary of the State makes and advise you that Tom Thumb was not a dwarf but a midget, and was not discovered in London but in Bridgeport, by P.T. Barnum.

title: OKLAHOMA SUN BOWL WINNER
description: Darrell Shepard, a quarterback who transferred from Houston three seasons ago, scored two touchdowns today to lead Oklahoma to a 40-14 victory over the Cougars in the Sun Bowl game.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THERE are only four more days left in 1981 and that's all the time left for penny hoarders to pick up a quick 20 percent bounty at any of the 64 branch offices of Colonial Bank throughout the state.

title: Around the Nation; Massachusetts Drivers End a 42-Day Strike
description: Striking transit workers defied their union and voted today to accept a contract offer, ending a 42-day bus strike that affected 23,000 daily riders in an area covering 13 towns.

title: Mailbox; 'The Greatest' Will Live On
description: To the Sports Editor: Alas. The end of the road for Muhammad Ali. ''The Greatest'' is no more. His rivals' fans may now honestly concede, here was a champion amongst champions.

title: OTTO KAHN'S MANSION SET ON CONDOMINIUM COURSE
description: Otto Kahn's chateau here was once one of the country's largest single-family homes. It cost $4.5 million to build in 1917 and had 70 rooms, with ceilings 30 feet high and walls 24 inches thick.

title: Paperback Talk
description: 1981: a post-mortem. Five days from now, 1981 will become just another year that was. What trends and events is it likely to be remembered for by the residents of Publishers Row? Herewith a brief rundown.

title: WOOD STOVE: 'HUB OF THE HOUSE'
description: ''WE'VE become a subculture,'' said Dale Darling of Great Neck, referring to the growing number of homeowners who heat with wood stoves. Mrs. Darling and Julia Van Dyck also cook on their wood stoves and have written a cookbook on the subject.

title: READER COMMENT; ROUNDTABLE REPLY
description: ''T HE Business Roundtable issues this statement out of a strong conviction that the future of this nation depends upon the existence of strong and responsive business enterprises and that, in turn, the long-term viability of the business sector is linked to its responsibility to the society of which it is a part.''

title: No Headline
description: Roger Starr seems to believe that nuclear-generated electricity can save or displace large amounts of oil. Yet, electricity accounts for only 8 percent of our oil use and that amount has been dropping steadily for the past five years. Mr. Starr minimizes the serious problems that the use of nuclear power entails.

title: Around the World; 3 More Canadians Dead In Oil Tanker Fire
description: The bodies of three more crew members from an oil tanker that burst into flames Friday were recovered today.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: women whose faith and fortunes center about a rigidly conservative priest named Father Cyprian - immerses herself in the ferment of Morningside Heights during the late 60's, is courted and betrayed by a radical professor, but ultimately returns with her infant to Cyprian's circle. Our reviewer Francine du Plessix Gray called this second novel by Mary Gordon ''flawed, yet impressive for its purity, ambition and grandeur of vision.''

title: WHERE ARE WE GOING?
description: The hopeful thing at the turn of the year is that thoughtful people all over the world, even in governments, are beginning to question their own prejudices and plan anew for the future.

title: Mailbox; A Tradition That Has Merit
description: To the Sports Editor: John McEnroe took another courageous leap over the net in the Davis Cup.

title: ARID TEXAS TOWN GUARDS ITS WATER
description: Every other day or so, Ellen Wilson hitches a trailer with a 1,000-gallon tank to her truck and drives more than seven miles to the tiny community of Fabens. There she fills her tank with the most precious commodity in the area, water.

title: Slain Trooper, Radical Suspect
description: Though less prominent than the Weather Underground, the Sam Melville-Jonathan Jackson Unit scarcely seemed less violent. It claimed credit for a series of bombings and bank robberies during the 1970s before fading with the decade.

title: Economic Affairs; CREEPING 'ECONOMIC CONSTITUTIONALISM'
description: Caught in the swirling drama of the Reagan fiscal revolution, it is easy to miss slower moving, but more profound, trends in budgetary philosophy. One strand, little noticed in recent months, is to impose on economic decision makers stricter discipline, such as fixed rules or constitutional amendments. I label this trent "economic constitutionlism" because it attempts to place extremely stringent legal constraints on decision makers.

title: By Juliet Goldsmith
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY ONE SCIENTIST'S 'EUREKA' IS ANOTHER'S DEEP FRUSTRATION
description: Akey process in scientific research is the confirmation of one laboratory's important findings by others that repeat and independently reproduce the original results. Such confirmation can prove difficult or, in extreme cases, impossible. The case of Dr. John Darsee, a medical scientist at Harvard who recently admitted to falsifying data in a heart research experiment, points to fraud as one reason for an experiment's being irreproducible. But fraud is a rare occurrence. Two distinguished scientists, Dr. Elliott F. Osserman, a cancer specialist at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, and Dr. Cyril Ponnamperuma, a biochemist at the University of Maryland who specializes in the origin and early evolution of life, discussed the issue with Harold M. Schmeck Jr., a science reporter of The New York Times, and Margot Slade, an editor of The Week in Review. Excerpts follow.

title: Long Islanders; CATALOGUE SELLING TREATED AS AN ART
description: WHEN Lawrence Kamisher of Manhasset was a Brooklyn teen-ager commuting to the Music and Art High School in Manhattan, his homebound journey included a break at 57th Street, where he liked to tour the art galleries.

title: ADVICE ABOUT CRIME FOR MR. KEAN
description: DURING the gubernatorial election campaign, Thomas H. Kean was quoted in the newspapers as saying: Muggings, purse snatching and assaults have become an everyday companion to many seniors. They have been driven into their homes at nightfall and literally barricade themselves until the following morning.

title: IS THERE LIFE AFTER PREMIERES FOR NEW WORKS?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently on musical subjects. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: Marla Jill Kroser to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Drs. Albert and Lila Kroser of Philadelphia of the engagement of their daughter, Marla Jill Kroser, to Stuart Goltzman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Goltzman of Forest Hills, Queens. An August wedding is planned.

title: CHINA CULTURAL UNIT TO OPEN AT PACE
description: "Peace and understanding among people cannot be achieved by governmental actions alone; they require voluntary efforts in studying the best in one another's cultures, in mutual enrichment of the qualities of life and in the fellowship of kindred spirits."

title: Theater in Review; 'FANTASTICKS' GETS FRESH APPROACH
description: HERRICKS THE Nassau Repertory is having an unusually adventurous and unusually good season. One might reasonably wonder why ''The Fantasticks'' is being included in it.

title: CAMONDO MUSEUM
description: To the Editor:

title: STAMFORD PROPERTY UP BY 250 PERCENT
description: STAMFORD ALONG with the New Year, property owners in this city with holdings ranging from small bungalows to the world headquarters of the Xerox Corporation will be getting some chilly news from the tax collector: Their properties have gone up in value over the past decade at what is anticipated will be the greatest increase of any area of the state.

title: Begin's Gorge Rises Sharply
description: ''With friends like that....'' So Washington probably was thinking last week after Israel's Prime Minister Menachem Begin said it out loud.

title: Chess; FROM FRYING PAN TO...
description: No one knowingly jumps from the frying pan into the fire - it's just that you have to get relief from the heat somehow and the flames beneath are not always visible.

title: McAdoo Not Available For Laker Game Today
description: Bob McAdoo will not play for the Los Angles Lakers in their game against the San Diego Clippers at the Forum Sunday night, the team said today.

title: CUTBACKS GIVE PARKING FINES HIGHER STATUS
description: The lowly meter maid is playing an increasingly significant role here and in traffic courts elsewhere in the nation, as cities turn to revenues from parking violations in order to make up for Federal budget cutbacks.

title: CHARITY WITHOUT THE BOTHER OF CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Television Week
description: A Harvest of Culture Since public television has focused so frequently on the arts, it seems natural that their year-end resume would peer into the worlds of theater, film, art, music and publishing. And Channel 13 will be doing exactly that in ''The Brand New Illustrated Journal of the Arts,'' a two-hour cultural summary of 1981 to be shown Friday at 9 P.M. Robert MacNeil, of the MacNeil/Lehrer Report, will be the anchorman of the compilation, which Jack Sameth, executive producer, believes to be a first.

title: ART BOOK CAN FILL GIFT VOID
description: IN THESE days of inconstancy and turmoil, we occasionally seek a solidly stable relationship, and a good book, no matter what its subject, can provide that.

title: WILL VIEWERS 'SEE' THIS 'ELEPHANT MAN'?
description: Aforthcoming television drama about a medical oddity will be uncommon in its own right: rather than presenting the story in cinematic terms, the production will rely on a purely theatrical device.

title: CHINESE MAY TRADE MINERALS FOR ARMS
description: China may have found a solution to its most pressing military problem: how to modernize its army on limited financial resources. The solution, according to a recent study, may be the production and sale of strategic minerals to the United States and other members of the Atlantic alliance to provide the money required to begin in earnest the modernization program the army needs.

title: ART Steward; PORTRAITIST'S VIRTUE WAS FORTHRIGHTNESS
description: HARTFORD AN interesting and significant exhibition devoted to the work of Joseph Steward is on view at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford through next month. A painter and pastellist who worked in Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Hampshire in the late 18th and early 19th centuries, Steward was an important figure as well for his role as owner of the Hartford Museum, which he founded in 1797.

title: Environews
description: REPRESENTATIVE Millicent Fenwick, Republican of Bernardsville, has introduced legislation designed to protect a constituent, the Johns-Manville Company of Manville, and other manufacturers from any new suits that employees may bring against them for asbestos-related medical disabilities or deaths.

title: Mixed Reactions On Losing a Job
description: Re the recent Opinion Page article ''Something Happened at the Office'': Why do high-management men in their 50's expect to fall into the same position or better than the one they held before? Are they not aware that each company they apply to already has its own high-management people in their 50's? If any opening does come up, it can easily be filled from within the corporation.

title: ISLANDERS TAKE 6TH STRAIGHT
description: Playoff hockey can't occur in December, but the Islanders and the Philadelphia Flyers did their best tonight to create that type of atmosphere at Nassau Coliseum in their second meeting of the season.

title: By Mary Ann Justic
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Lordi To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Livingston of New York and Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Livingston's daughter, Georgetta Lordi, to Kim Morque, son of Allan W. Morque of Grand Forks, N.D., and the late Mrs. Morque.

title: Gaye McKintosh Wed to William Ludwig, Banker
description: Gaye Glading McKintosh and William Frank Ludwig of New York were married yesterday in Vero Beach, Fla., at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James B. McIntosh, who also live in Columbus, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by Florida Circuit Court Judge G. Kendall Sharp.

title: Everyone's Jails Are Overbooked
description: A Federal court ruled last year that the New York City jail on Rikers Island was ''unconstitutionally overcrowded'' and last week a judge ruled that the state prison system must speedily transfer to its facilities those Rikers inmates convicted of state crimes. But the state's Commissioner of Corrections said he would rather go to jail himself than comply.

title: CELLIST HOPES HER DEFECTION AIDS ALL POLES
description: Authorities were checking her passport too closely last May in Poland, and Cecylia Barczyk, a cellist, said she had the uneasy feeling that they would refuse to allow her to return to the United States.

title: Article 147595 -- No Title
description: A $5,000 reward was offered by a businessman yesterday for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the attacker of a 57-year-old Roman Catholic nun outside a convent in the Bronx on Wednesday.

title: CANES PASSED DOWN TO AGED KEEP PAPER'S TRADITION ALIVE
description: The year was 1909, and The Boston Post saw an opportunity for a publicity gimmick. One of the newspaper's officials had gone to an auction and bid successfully on an unclaimed shipment of gold-tipped ebony canes. The Post, which had a large circulation throughout New England at that time, decided to promote itself by sending the canes to cities and towns in the region with the stipulation that they be held by the community's oldest man. When he died, the cane was to be passed on to the next man in line.

title: The War Against the Poor
description: Ronald Reagan's anti-poverty program has three fronts. One is the social safety net, protecting ''those with true need.'' A second is voluntarism, private charity to offset Federal cuts. The third and most important is economic recovery, the rising tide that John Kennedy said would lift all the boats. As the Administration ends its first year, the poor are losing on all three fronts - and so badly that a question begins to reverberate: what is Mr. Reagan warring against, poverty or the poor?

title: BRANT; Branta bernicla
description: Size: Averages 26 inches. Color: Black head, neck, chest and bill, with an incomplete white chokerlike collar on upper neck.

title: OPPOSITION GROWS TO AN INCREASE IN SALES TAX
description: HAUPPAUGE OPPOSITION is marshaling against a proposed sales tax increase in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. A couple of weeks ago, a task force on fiscal priorities appointed by Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan recommended that Suffolk raise its current 7.25-cent sales tax to 8 cents on the dollar.

title: Giants on Offense
description: No. 83 Earnest Gray, wr, 6 foot 3 inches 195 pounds; Memphis State; 3d year as pro; Gets open but often drops ball. No. 73, Jeff Weston, lt, 6-5, 280; Notre Dame; 3d year; Strong, surprisingly quick for size. No. 67, Bill Ard, lg, 6-3, 250, Wake Forest; rookie; Improving but sometimes fails to hold block. No. 58, Jim Clack, c, 6-3, 250, Wake Forest, 11th year; Spirit is young, the knees are old. No. 68, J.T. Turner, rg, 6-3, 250, Duke, 5th year; Smart veteran and getting steadier. No. 72, Gordon King, rt, 6-6, 275, Stanford, 4th year; Relaxed and having his best season. No. 87, Gary Shirk, te, 6-1, 220, Morehead State, 6th year; Wily, reliable, a steadying influence. No. 85, John Mistler, wr, 6-2, 186, Arizona State, rookie, Meticulous pass routes and ordinary speed. No. 12, Scott Brunner, qb, 6-5, 200, Delaware, 2d year; Smart, plays within limitations. No. 26, Rob Carpenter, hb, 6-1, 230, Miami (Ohio), 5th year, Intuitive runner who picks holes well. No. 30, Leon Perry, fb, 5-11, 224, Mississippi, 2d year; Fierce blocker but not a gifted runner. No. 18, Joe Danelo, k, 5-9, 166, Washington State, 7th year; Strong leg, more consistent than ever. No. 45, Leon Bright, kr, 5-9, 192, Florida State, rookie; 49 punt returns and still no fair catch.

title: PANDA TOTAL IS STABILIZED, CHINESE SAYS
description: The number of giant pandas, whose survival was once jeopardized by a dearth of its favorite bamboo, has stopped declining, according to a Chinese specialist on the endangered species.

title: Steven Rothberg Weds Elizabeth J. Hoffman
