description: The marriage of Elizabeth Jane Hoffman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Jay Hoffman of New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to Steven Sherman Rothberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Rothberg of New York, took place yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel. Rabbi David B. Kahane performed the ceremony.

title: Music; ONE 'NUTCRACKER' AND ITS ORIGINS
description: ''MY dream is to help people,'' said Grabriela Ionita, artistic director of the Westchester Ballet Company. ''It's almost an obsession with me, so I put all my soul into my work.''

title: IN VIETNAM, TEARS AS THE PAST IS REMEMBERED
description: Christmastime in Ho Chi Minh City is especially sad. The warm air is scented with jasmine and incense, the stores drape silver papier-mache stars in windows, but the downtown streets are curiously lifeless.

title: A TALE OF TWO POWER PLANTS
description: THIS is a tale of two nuclear power plants that were born at the same time but grew on opposite shores of Long Island Sound. On a clear day, the massive block of the Millstone plant on the Connecticut shore can be seen to the west by ferry passengers approaching New London; the top cap of the Shoreham plant can be seen protruding above the bluffs of Long Island to the east by ferry passengers long before they approach Port Jefferson.

title: Crime Update
description: A lone gunman went on a 15-minute, two-block rampage in midtown shortly before 9 A.M. on Oct. 24. He shot out the windows of a passing car and, without warning or provocation, opened fire on Allen Spiegel, a 17-year-old from Westbury, L.I., near the intersection of Madison Avenue and 42d Street. The young man, who had been making a delivery for his father, the owner of a doughnut shop at that corner, was hit in the head and back and died in the street.

title: CALIFORNIA COUNTY GETS TOUGHER ON CHILD ABUSE INVESTIGATIONS
description: Superficially, there seemed to be little to arouse concern about the 15 children of a Laguna Hills family. They lived in comfortable surroundings in the Orange County ''bedroom'' community, where the average house costs more than $150,000. Their father held a secure job as an aerospace engineer.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: COMMUNITIES throughout Essex County are learning that at least one answer to Shakespeare's question ''What's in a name?'' boils down to a simple matter of money.

title: Writer Taken to Task On Teacher Article
description: As teachers, we cannot let the Dec. 13 column by Dr. Sayre Uhler go unanswered. Dr. Uhler, a former Superintendent of Schools in Ridgewood, makes the astounding assertions that teachers (1) are reponsible for the school calendar being ''based on 19th-century agricultural cycles''; (2) are ''bent on measuring a child's worth as a learner against statewide averages'' and (3) ''spawn nonvariable time schedules.''

title: Suat Urguplu, 78, Dies; Ex-Premier of Turkey
description: Former Prime Minister Suat Hayri Urguplu died today, Turkish state television reported.

title: Food; BIRDS OF A MUSCOVY FEATHER
description: There are some foods that are not readily available in supermarkets and grocery stores throughout the country, though they have enormous appeal in areas where they can be found. This is increasingly true of something called Muscovy duck.

title: Speaking Personally; HANUKKAH AND GRANDMOTHER'S BIRTHDAY
description: HANUKKAH, the Festival of Lights, brings potato latkes (pancakes) and the whizzing spin of a child's dreidel. But for someone very special, the menorah's lights also have symbolized birthday candles, and for many years I shared a double celebration with my grandmother.

title: GROUP TO AID SINGLE PARENTS
description: AN effort to bridge what seems to be a serious communications gap between the one-parent family and the community will be made in 1982 by the Single Parents Roundtable, a new group in New Haven of mainly social service professionals from 11 towns in the area.

title: WATCH THE BIRDIE! FOR 15 MINUTES
description: THE AMERICAN DAGUERREOTYPE By Floyd Rinhart and Marion Rinhart. Illustrated. 446 pp. Athens, Ga.: The University of Georgia Press. $55 until Dec. 31, 1981; $65 thereafter.

title: RECALLING COLUMBIA'S STARTLING TRIP TO THE ROSE BOWL
description: THE time was New Year's Day 1934. The game was Columbia versus Stanford in the Rose Bowl. It was the biggest game of the season and it certainly was as big a surprise and an honor for Columbia to be chosen. It was the only bowl game being played that day, and since then many bowl games have come into being. The Rose Bowl, however, remains the granddaddy of them all.

title: HAPPY CLAM DIP, EVERYBODY, WHEREVER YOU ARE
description: THE really remarkable thing about New Year's Eve is the various ways people will find to celebrate the passing of a year that they probably didn't enjoy anyway. We all know folks who seem quite normal until Dec. 31 and who then put on little cone-shaped hats and assume a personality that they keep hidden in the closet all year.

title: NEW YEAR'S DAY OF LONG AGO
description: SOMETIMES solemnly, and sometimes gaily, but always with hope, New Englanders have noted the passing of the old year and have heralded the coming of a new season.

title: Bennett Is Sworn In At Humanities Endowment
description: William Bennett, president of the National Humanities Center in Research Triangle Park, N.C., was sworn in there last Tuesday as the interim chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: LEARNING FIRSTHAND; Yale's New Degree
description: Older students, even part-timers, are welcome on most college campuses, both for their infinite variety and for their tuition. But in the elite Ivy League they are generally treated as second-class citizens, shunted into less prestigious degree programs and denied the sheepskin available to ''regular'' students who start as freshfaced 18-year-olds.

title: ORIENT EXPRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Gremlin Found Aboard Shuttle
description: When the space shuttle Columbia ended its November test flight three days early because of a fuel cell malfunction, engineers could not know that the culprit was as prosaic as the mechanical part it infected. Last week, they announced that the problem was unexpected corrosion of aluminum plates within the fuel cell.

title: The Careful Shopper; Men's Shop Features Gentlemanly Discounts
description: The buying power of 214 stores allows Windsor Men's Shop in White Plains to stock designer names and still call itself the gentlemen's discount center. Post-holiday ''two-fer'' suit, sportcoat, slack and outerwear sales this week makes prices even lower while the usual one-half off on designer ties, belts, socks and handkerchiefs remains in effect and all labels are left on.

title: CAPITAL CELEBRATION
description: New Year's Eve in the state capital should be especially gala, beginning with an 8:30 preview of a new play by Beth Henley, the 29-year-old Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, at the Hartford Stage Company. Then on to the sumptuous Oriental Masquerade Ball at the Wadsworth Atheneum until 1 A.M., winding up with a wacky NuReal Art Ways until 4 A.M.

title: CUERNAVACA
description: To the Editor:

title: COUNTRY: MISS CHAPMAN
description: Marshall Chapman, the country-rock signer who appeared Wednesday at the Lone Star Cafe, has such a singular voice that it's no wonder that her charms have not fully been captured on record. Miss Chapman, who hails from Spartanburg, S.C., projects an outspokenly sexy tomboyishness.

title: CROSS-COUNTRY BY TRAIN- FAMILY STYLE
description: ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. is a reporter in The Times Washington bureau. By ROBERT D.HERSHEY Jr.

title: Victim's Dream Leads Police to His Murderer
description: A murder victim had a nightmare about being slain six days before he was fatally shot in a holdup, and the dream helped investigators find his killer, the police say.

title: CAROLYN WHITTLE REFLECTS ON HER CAREER
description: NOBODY would ever mistake Carolyn L. Whittle for a lame duck. Last week, nearing the end of her eight-year stint as a member of the Board of Legislators, she seemed as involved in the political process - the issue was the 1982 county budget that will be approved tomorrow night - as she had been at the beginning.

title: PROGRAM TO ASSIST BLACKS IS ASSAILED
description: A Federal program designed to provide blacks with the skills to start businesses and to give them priority in getting loans has resulted in only one loan, for $14,000, officials say.

title: SIBERIANS FIGHTING TO PRESERVE LAKE
description: To the Buryat Mongols who lived around Lake Baikal before the Russians came, the lake was home to Burkhan, an angry and jealous god to be treated with deference and care. So great was their respect for his kingdom that they apologized to a tree before chopping it down.

title: Gardening; HARDY HOLLIES, IDEAL NOW OR ANYTIME
description: ON a recent visit to the Arnold Arboretum outside Boston, I spotted a striking group of evergreen shrubs some distance away. A closer look proved them to be the handsome Ilex pedunculosa or long-stalk holly.

title: STATE COMPTROLLER TO SEEK A 5-YEAR PLAN FOR CAPITAL SPENDING
description: Arguing that capital planning in New York State has amounted to an ''ad hoc political exercise,'' the State Comptroller says his top legislative priority next year will be to try to impose ''discipline'' on the way the state borrows money.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PALM BEACH
description: GLENN R. SINGER is a staff writer for The Post in West Palm Beach. By GLENN R.SINGER

title: About Long Island
description: LAST week I saw a Ghost of Christmas Past. I was driving home from Huntington after a day of Christmas shopping, which had, as always, gone on well into the winter dusk.

title: New York Political Notes
description: The political future of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman, will be decided in the next few weeks, with his resignation as county chairman seemingly inevitable, according to Nassau Republicans.

title: DIM SUM
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Warner Wed To E.S. Cooke Jr.
description: Carol Ridgely Warner and Edward Strong Cooke Jr. were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John Crocker performed the ceremony.

title: Fund at Halfway Point For Vietnam Memorial
description: The Vietnam Veterans Memorial Fund has reached the halfway point in its $7 million fund-raising effort and plans to break ground in March for the V-shaped structure on a plot between the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial.

title: ECONOMICS FROM THE BIG BOARD; THE REASONS FOR OPTIMISM
description: T HE pessimists are having a field day. Supply-side economics will not be producing its promised miracles any time soon. Instead, the next few months will see more workers losing their jobs, business profits falling and the Federal deficit climbing - to a projected $100 billion this fiscal year and even more in fiscal 1983 and 1984.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In an article on Nov. 29 on appoint- ments by the Reagan Administration, John A. Volpe's party affiliation was given incorrectly. Mr. Volpe, former Governor of Massachusetts, is a Re- publican.

title: REPORT ALLAYS FEARS ON CARCINOGENIC VACCINE
description: About 20 years ago, scientists became intensely worried when they discovered that a virus that caused cancer in newborn animals had contaminated a polio vaccine given to millions of Americans.

title: THE CHIEF EXECUTIVE'S CHRISTMAS
description: Stock brokers, industry analysts, investment counselors and the myriad crystal-ball gazers trying to fathom the inner workings of America's leading executives would do well to look under the Christmas tree.

title: WEST GERMAN ROCKET COMPANY PULLS OUT OF LIBYA
description: A West German company that has been developing rockets with a potential military application has halted its testing work in Libya, company officials say.

title: Westchester Housing; STUDENTS BUILD MODULAR UNIT TO SELL
description: SOME carpenters of the future are building what their teacher calls a house of the future at the Putnam Technical Center in Mahopac.

title: Reagan's Rush Past '84
description: To the Editor:

title: POP-SOUL: DELLS' 30TH
description: The Dells, who celebrated their 30th anniversary at the Savoy on Wednesday, are one of the longest-running pop-soul groups in history. They are best known for their rock-and-roll ballads ''Stay in My Corner'' and ''Oh What a Night.'' This quintet's modified gospel harmonic style is synonomous with the somewhat mournful Chicago doowop sound that they, along with Curtis Mayfield and the Impressions, helped pioneer in the mid-1950's. Doowop isn't easily updated, however, and the live versions of the Dells' biggest hits couldn't touch the originals in plaintiveness. Still, the quintet's harmonies were at least precise, with John Carter's very dry falsetto cutting keenly against Marvin Junior's husky baritone. The material, however, was not well served by the horn-heavy pop-funk arrangements of the group's band. The beauty of doowop has always been in the rapturous ethereality of its vocal sound. Orchestrated with any but the lightest touch, it becomes lounge music. This is what the Dells offered - a pleasant, genial, but hardly memorable retrospective.

title: A LOOK AT THE YEAR ACCENTED BY 'WITHOUT'
description: I N sports, 1981 too often was the year without: The year without seven weeks of the baseball season because of a players' strike; without the Super Bowl champion Oakland Raiders qualifying for the playoffs; without the Wimbledon king invited to be a member of the host All-England Club; without a winner decided in the Indianapolis 500 for four months; without U.C.L.A. being eligible for the 1982 national college basketball tournament; without Notre Dame having a winning record; without the Cosmos retaining the North American Soccer League title; without a Triple Crown sweep in horse racing; without Jack Nicklaus taking a major golf tournament; without the Madison Square Garden boxing card that dissolved when the promoter Harold Smith was charged in a $21.3 million bank embezzlement.

title: Correction
description: A photograph last Sunday, accompanying an article on Lucinda Childs's new dance series, carried an incorrect caption. The picture showed Lucinda Childs, the dancer and choreographer.

title: ACTOR FINDS A BIT OF MAGIC AS DIRECTOR
description: IN his own variation of a theatrical tradition, Charles Repole went out there a civil engineer and came back a Broadway star. Given his flair for coming up with flukes, it seems only natural that he is directing a supernatural show.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Many brass and woodwind concertos enter the repertory not particularly for their greatness but because virtuosos have only a small repertory to work with and play the pieces available for all they are worth. An exception is the Haydn Concerto for Trumpet and Orchestra in E flat which Philip Smith will perform with Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday at Fisher Hall.

title: ATLANTA MURDER TRIAL READY TO BEGIN AS RESIDENTS TRY TO FORGET THE FEAR
description: The crimes were on virtually everyone's lips for nearly two years, but the trial that begins Monday for the man accused of slaying two of 28 murdered young people in Atlanta seems to be something this city of ghettos and gentility would rather not think about.

title: VIOLENCE DONE, TOO, TO THE POLISH CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: VIOLENCE DONE, TOO, TO THE POLISH CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There are two kinds of people -those who sound the fire gong and those who climb up and down the ladder rescuing people from burning buildings. After seven years of doing that, maybe your clothing begins to smell like smoke and you become identified with the fire and smoke rather than the rescue.'' - Governor Carey. (37:2.)

title: MISS WEINBLATT ENGAGED TO KENNETH S. SCHWARTZ
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jules Weinblatt of Jackson Heights, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margery Weinblatt, to Kenneth Steven Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Schwartz of Brooklyn.

title: About Westchester
description: THROUGH the classroom window, one could see children in the playground, climbing on jungle gyms, chasing each other, tossing a ball back and forth. Contrary to what might be expected, however, the youngsters inside were not gazing longingly at their schoolmates at recess. Their eyes were riveted instead on a videotape playing on a screen in the front of the room, a tape that depicted a jump-rope competition in New York City and that their teacher had told them to watch with one eye turned inward.

title: ANDREW CABOT FIANCE OF STACEY E. MCGREER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Willis McGreer of Walpole, N.H., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Stacey Elizabeth McGreer, to Andrew Hull Cabot, son of Caroline Foote Cabot of Manchester, Mass., and the late Henry Bromfield Cabot Jr. The wedding is planned for Feb. 13.

title: PANEL OVERTURNS CONVICTION ON L.I.
description: In a novel application of a rule barring authorities from using illegally obtained evidence against criminal defendants, the New York Court of Appeals has overturned the conviction of a man who was arrested and searched on the basis of out-of-date information in computerized criminal records.

title: SCHOLARSHIPS KEYED TO ISLAND SEND STUDENTS OFF TO COLLEGE
description: Three wealthy former residents of Block Island near here have dedicated scholarships to help the children of the resort's blue-collar workers go to college.

title: What's in a Name?
description: 1. Reginald H. Jones is a well-known employer, and Reginald I. Jones is a not-so-well-known unemployer. Name their affiliations. 2. They're both chairmen - one of the Rockwell International Corporation and one of the Atlantic Richfield Company.

title: ONE SILESIAN MINE STILL HOLDING OUT, POLISH RADIO SAYS
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. Goldberger might have considered the most important influence on building form over the past decade - energy use.

title: THE YEAR THE BUDGET PROCESS NEARLY CRUMBLED
description: FOR the 97th Congress, shaping the Federal budget for the 1982 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, has been a stormy business. The lawmakers have been torn between the President's escalating demands for cuts in nonmilitary spending and their own sense of political limits.

title: Bridge; THOSE QUIET MEN
description: Aquarter of a century ago the national scene was dominated by a group of players most of whom are now dead or in retirement. About half of them came from New York City, and of these a substantial subgroup consisted of strong personalities, such as John Crawford, Tobias Stone, Philip Feldesman, Alvin Roth and, still active, Ira Rubin. Their forceful presence at the table matched their technical skill, and when they played with or against one another, the sparks flew and the kibitzers had a good show.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Jean Erdman retains a special place in New York's creative circles. A dancer with Martha Graham's company in the late 1930's and early 40's, Miss Erdman went on to choreograph for her own troupe and, in more recent years, experimented with her brand of ''total theater.''

title: The Big Fight of 1982
description: IF Muhammad Ali's retirement was the big event in sports in 1981, there is an excellent chance that the big one of 1982 will feature Gerry Cooney and Larry Holmes. Ali's departure was the end of an era in boxing; the Holmes-Cooney match takes boxing back to the bumptious days when John L. Sullivan invented the ''color line'' and brought on the age of the ''white hope.''

title: Harlem Dance Theater to Open Jan. 12
description: Tickets are on sale for the Dance Theater of Harlem's winter season at the City Center-55th Street Theater from Jan. 12 through Feb. 14.

title: Maureen C. Sager To Wed June 19
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerard A. Sager of Port Washington, L.I., and Stuart, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Carroll Sager, to James Thomas Shea Jr., son of Mr.and Mrs. Shea of Foxboro, Mass.

title: Eagles on Offense
description: No. 17, Harold Carmichael, wr, 6-8, 225, Southern U., 11th year; An imposing threat. No. 75, Stan Walters, lt, 6-6, 275, Syracuse, 10th year; A physical powerhouse. No. 73, Steve Kenney, lg, 6-4, 262, Clemson, 2d year; Lacks strength and quickness. No. 50, Guy Morriss, c, 6-4, 255, Texas Christian, 9th year; A solid, workmanlike technician. No. 63, Ron Baker, rg, 6-4, 250, Oklahoma State, 4th year; Athletic, explosive off the ball. No. 76, Jerry Sisemore, rt, 6-4, 265, Texas, 9th year, Underrated, though one of the best. No. 84, Keith Krepfle, te, 6-3, 230, Iowa State, 7th year; Good blocker, dangerous receiver. No. 85, Charles Smith, wr, 6-1, 185, Grambling, 8th year; Average speed and average ability. No. 7, Ron Jaworski, qb, 6-2, 196, Youngstown State, 8th year; Can control game if he gets protection, No. 31, Wilbert Montgomery, hb, 5-10, 195, Abilene Christian, 5th year; Intense, outstanding, key to the offense. No. 34, Hubert Oliver, fb, 5-10, 212, Arizona, rookie; Good blocker without great speed. No. 1, Tony Franklin, k, 5-8, 182, Texas A&M, 3d year; Unpredictable barefoot kicker with great leg. No. 89, Wally Henry, kr, 5-8, 180, U.C.L.A., 5th year; Quick but with ordinary ability.

title: INSPECTIONS LAG
description: As the February deadline approaches for complying with a New York City statute that requires facade inspections, building owners, architects and engineers say there are serious problems in implementing it. Thus far the indications are that the law cannot be adequately enforced.

title: ISRAELI DIPLOMAT SAYS U.S. ADOPTS THE SAUDIS' VIEWS
description: Israel's next Ambassador to Washington said in an interview broadcast today that the United States had adopted Saudi Arabian views on the Middle East and that it had caused a deterioration in United States-Israeli relations.

title: R.O.T.C. REVIVES ON CAMPUS
description: MAJ. KENT SHOWALTER was talking on the telephone at the meticulously organized desk in his office in the University of Connecticut Reserve Officers Training Corps hangar.

title: Pamela Sperry, Teacher, Is Fiancee Of Harald B. Findlay, an Accountant
description: Mrs. Mark L. Sperry 2d of Woodbury, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Pamela S. Sperry, to Harald B. Findlay, son of Mrs. E. Andrew Deeds of Charlotte, Vt., and David B. Findlay of New Canaan, Conn.

title: By Elaine and Robert Rosenthal
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Agency Freezes Some New York Rates
description: The Power Authority of the State of New York has ordered a freeze on power rates in central New York until next September, while the agency decides how to allocate its lowcost hydroelectric power.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART The huipil, the tzute and the capixay may not answer everyone's clothing needs. But they serve the Guatemalan Indians well - when displayed flat or hung on the wall, they become works of art.

title: KOCH RATED HIGH, CAREY LOW IN POLL OF CITY
description: New Yorkers On New York Fourth article of a series appearing periodically. By RICHARD J. MEISLIN

title: Eagles Are Activating Humphrey for Game
description: The Philadelphia Eagles have added the 37-year-old pass-rushing specialist, Claude Humphrey, to their active roster for Sunday's playoff game.

title: Dance; A MIX OF DANCE AND SCULPTURE
description: AN unusual performance by Holly Fairbanks and Dance Company, created in cooperation with the Yugoslavia-born sculptor Yuri Schwebler, will take place at 3 P.M. today at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers. The dance work is entitled ''Shared Space'' and will be performed within an exhibition of sculpture created by Mr. Schwebler, who worked with Miss Fairbanks, the choreographer, on the installation. The performance will be repeated at 3 P.M. Jan 10.

title: BIG DEALS
description: It was an extraordinary year for mergers and acquisitions. Match the new partners. A. The Bechtel family B. American Express C. Prudential Insurance Company of America D. Dr. Pepper E. Sohio F. Nabisco Inc.

title: IT'S ALMOST 1982! TIME TO ARGUE ABOUT 1984!
description: Ronald Reagan will not have been President a year before the Democrats start making their rules about picking someone to replace him. Looking at it another way, when the Democrats' latest party commission starts voting next month, it will be less than 10 months until the Congressional elections that are the only real barrier to the beginning of the 1984 Presidential campaign. These perspectives remind that whatever other parts of the system anyone manages to change, the ''permanent campaign'' is not going to go away. Once-glimmering concepts such as ''the deliberative convention'' have been forgotten as impractical, and even if most politicians think there are too many primaries, there is a growing reluctance to try to force states to get rid of them.

title: Another Pole Defects From Ship in Australia
description: Another seaman from the Polish cargo ship Artur Grottger defected and plans to seek political asylum in Australia, a Pole said today.

title: MOZAMBIQUE FINDS A NEW FRIEND IN PORTUGAL
description: Mozambique, one of Africa's poorest nations, and Portugal, one of Europe's, have put aside the antagonisms of their former servant-master relationship and are trying to work together.

title: Dining Out; ITALIAN FAMILIARITY IN CLIFFSIDE PARK
description: ADAM'S APPLE in Cliffside Park is one of the many unpretentious corner bars lining Palisades Avenue, the kind one assumes is just another neighborhood lounge. Yet, in the rear of this particular establishment is a small dining room. And behind that is a kitchen that produces some decent, if undistinguished, home-style Italian dishes.

title: LEARNING FIRSTHAND; Loose Siren
description: Sometimes the reality of New York outperforms even the imagination of its anxious residents. Take the case of four tennis players whose concentration was recently broken by an immense caterwauling of sirens.

title: Hard Times for Detroit, Labor
description: With more than 200,000 auto workers already laid off and the industry reporting the worst sales in more than two decades, the United Auto Workers announced a decision that had seemed inevitable ever since the union's executive board cleared the way two weeks ago. On Jan. 8, the Ford and General Motors councils will meet in Chicago to consider reopening their current contracts with the Big Two.

title: TWO PLOTS, TWO HEROES
description: WATER MUSIC By T. Coraghessan Boyle. 437 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $15.95.

title: The Trials of Wilbur Hobby
description: He wasn't a ''broken'' man, ''not even bent,'' Wilbur Hobby insisted last week. But, having lost his job as head of a state labor federation, put his home up for sale, been hospitalized for a broken ankle and a ruptured spinal disk, and facing up to 11 years in prison, he surely was feeling some strain. Mr. Hobby, the former head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.in North Carolina, is to be sentenced this week for his conviction on charges of illegally obtaining $34,000 in Comprehensive Education and Training Act funds. Friends called it a ''personal tragedy'' for a ''great person.''

title: Art; RAGTIME: THE BOOK, THE FILM, THE SHOW
description: NEW ROCHELLE ''RAGTIME'' - first the book, then the movie of the book and now, in a manner of speaking, the exhibition of the movie - at the Castle Gallery, College of New Rochelle, through Jan. 10. And, with the book's author, E. L. Doctorow, living in New Rochelle and his sister, Elly Doctorow, on its City Council, why not? Besides, the gallery has started a drive for ''Friends.'' Accordingly, there's to be a special reception at the gallery on Jan. 9 that, at $25 a head, will include a tour of the show and a buffet supper (call Adele Ingellis at 632-5300 Ext. 423).

title: A GOD WHO MADE WORDS
description: THE MONKEY GRAMMARIAN By Octavio Paz. Translated by Helen R. Lane. Illustrated. 162 pp. New York: Seaver Books. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $7.95. By KEITH BOTSFORD

title: SOCIAL SECURITY AND THE PLIGHT OF WOMEN
description: IN one of his more enlightened moments as a candidate, Ronald Reagan said that Social Security treated women unfairly and that reforms were needed. This gave some hope that this would be a subject he would address himself to after the election. Unfortunately, the ''reforms'' that have been proposed would make an already unfair situation intolerable.

title: December 27, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE AMERICAN DAGUERREOTYPE. By Floyd Rinhart and Marion Rinhart. 7 THE FAMILY IDIOT: Gustave Flaubert 1821-1857. Volume I. By Jean-Paul Sartre.

title: No Headline
description: In his interesting article on diary writing, Patrick Huyghe might have mentioned Queen Victoria, who was a born writer and a compulsive one; all her life, she kept a journal, averaging 1,000 or 2,000 words a day. Her manner was not introspective but she gave vivid, charming, often emotional accounts of her experiences, travels and myriad diplomatic and domestic matters. With Disraeli's encouragement, ''Leaves from a Journal of our Life in the Highlands'' was brought out in 1868 - the first book in 200 years published by a reigning monarch of Britain. JANE WOHLGEMUTH HILL, Toronto

title: Government Begins Mailing Income Tax Forms for 1981
description: Before the last late Christmas card arrives, you may receive a season's greeting from the Government - 1981 income tax forms in which the first effects of President Reagan's tax cuts may be seen.

title: BELIEF IN GOD AND IN EVOLUTION POSSIBLE, DARWIN LETTER SAYS
description: Darwin's theory of evolution has repeatedly been viewed as anathema by adherents of a literal interpretation of the Old Testament account of creation. However, Darwin himself, in a letter recently acquired by his great-grandson, said a person could subscribe to evolution and still believe in God.

title: Architecture View; CHANGES ON THE DRAWING BOARD AND THE SKYLINE
description: Architecture is the one art that has charged full speed backwards and forwards in 1981, depending on how you look at it. In terms of ideas and construction, the achievements have been prodigious; whatever the recession may promise for the immediate future, there continues to be an explosion of building marked by radical changes in style.

title: Free Cathy Wilkerson
description: As a member of the Weather Underground in 1970, Cathy Wilkerson was accused of plotting to use bombs to register her obections to a system she said favored the white and the wealthy.

title: COSTA RICA'S DILEMMA
description: Without generous financial assistance, Costa Rica may soon face either economic collapse or a serious weakening of its democratic traditions.

title: Article 147758 -- No Title
description: THE question of how to care for older relatives when they develop a chronic illness, a problem faced by both social-service agencies and families, has led the W. K. Kellogg Foundation to launch a $1.8 million program to determine how the country's shrinking health-care resources can more efficiently serve the needs of an expanding older population.

title: Travel Advisory; CABLE CARS, ROMAN RUINS; San Francisco Rallies To a Cause
description: San Francisco's cable cars are heading for the barn, and visitors contemplating a journey West had better hurry and hop aboard before the vintage vehicles are laid up for major repairs.

title: 2 Children Die in Rite; Mother, 31, Is Charged
description: A 31-year-old Niagara Falls woman was charged with second-degree murder today in the deaths of two of her children.

title: Unclog the Coal Pipeline
description: The standard way to move coal from mine mouth to power plant is by rail and barge. But it's not the only way. Pulverized and mixed with water, coal ''slurry'' can be efficiently moved by pipe, for hundreds or even thousands of miles.

title: A YEAR OF STRUGGLE - AND INNOVATION
description: ONE may go down as the year when Yankee ingenuity was provided with one of its finest hours. Whether in finding ways around the barrier of high interest rates, bypassing the exorbitant cost of heating fuels or adapting large single-family houses to the reduced-space needs of today's smaller, single-person households, it was a time when Connecticut homeowners struggled to cope.

title: BULGARIAN VENTURE IRKS L.I. FISHERMEN
description: LONG ISLAND fishermen are scanning the horizon for Bulgarian trawlers that are expected to enter United States territorial waters this week to fish for mackerel from their own boats as well as to buy the American catch. The Bulgarians may catch fish, but it remains to be seen whether the foreign fleet will be able to net the Americans, who are less than pleased with the price of 7 cents a pound that the Bulgarians are offering for mackerel.

title: A TIMES SQUARE REVIVAL?
description: In a darkened conference room 52 stories above Broadway, images of a strangely unfamiliar Times Square flash on a projection screen.

title: 'NEW FEDERALISM' ASSAILED BY KOCH
description: When Mayor Koch was in Washington recently to attend a meeting of the Presidential Advisory Committee on Federalism, he gave fellow committee members a 10-page memorandum outlining his position on President Reagan's stated ''dream'' of shifting Federal power from Washington to the states.

title: THEATER: LABICHE FARCE AT THE PUNCH LINE
description: Before Georges Feydeau, there was Eugene Labiche. Labiche wrote many comedies and farces, although he probably is best remembered for ''Monsieur Perrichon's Voyage'' and ''An Italian Straw Hat.'' The latter has turned up in numerous adaptations -by W.S. Gilbert, by the film director Rene Clair, by Orson Welles and Edwin Denby, even by the Santa Fe Opera - and it isn't hard to see why. Accept the original premise in ''An Italian Straw Hat'' (it is absurd, but a farce is a farce) and the rest of the nonsense falls cheerfully into place. The Manhattan Punch Line is accepting the premise now.

title: SHOOTOUT OVER FEDERAL EXPORT POLICY, AND MONEY
description: WASHINGTON O N Thursday, Nov. 12, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige received a memo from David A. Stockman, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, demanding $174 million of additional cuts in Commerce activities mostly affecting support the department provides for American exports.

title: Julie Landau and Michael Schaff, Lawyers, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marc S. Landau of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Ellen Landau, to Michael David Schaff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Harrison Schaff of Elkins Park, Pa.

title: Sarah Van Buren To Be June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin E. Van Buren of Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Jean Van Buren, to Robert Bruce Schramm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Schramm of Exelsior, Minn. A June wedding is planned.

title: MINISTER PLAYS SANTA CLAUS TO POOR YOUNGSTERS OF APPALACHIA
description: The Rev. Charles Keyes of Hickory does not wear a red suit, and he drives a van instead of a team of reindeer.

title: Updating the 'Yellow' Slogan
description: I'd like to take a brisk brush to Russell Baker - and not to his teeth (''In the Teeth of Fanatics,'' Sunday Observer, Nov. 8).

title: Willkie's '40 Campaign Hotel Is Closed for Money Reasons
description: The Durbin Hotel, which was Wendell Willkie's campaign headquarters in his run for President in 1940, has shut its doors for financial reasons.

title: Kimberley Loftus to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Loftus of Glen Rock, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberley Ann Loftus, to Joseph M. Carroll, son of Mrs. Joseph J. Carroll of Lenox, Mass., and the late Mr. Carroll. A September wedding is planned. Miss Loftus is a registered representative with Loomis-Sales & Company, a Boston investment counseling firm. Mr. Carroll is a designer with Architects Collaborative Inc. in Cambridge, Mass.

title: KNOX AND MICHAELS HAVE MUTUAL BOND
description: Chuck Knox and Walt Michaels, the opposing coaches in today's playoff game between the Buffalo Bills and the Jets at Shea Stadium, have been close friends for a long time and are likely to remain so regardless of the outcome. What is one game among many?

title: Home Clinic; THE STEPS TO TAKE WHEN A FLOOR TILE NEEDS REPLACING
description: WHEN a resilient floor tile becomes badly discolored, dented or broken, the only way to repair the damage in most cases is to remove the tile (or tiles) and replace it with a new one of matching size and color or pattern. That is assuming you have or can find a matching tile; if not, you may have to clear enough space so that you can create some sort of geometric or abstract design with tiles of alternating or blending colors.

title: Michael Silverman to Wed Miss Sweet
description: The engagement of Adrienne Grace Sweet to Michael Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Syd Silverman of White Plains, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Francis Earl Sweet of Chicago, parents of the future bride.

title: Crime
description: Early this year Martin Cruz Smith's ''Gorky Park'' caused a great deal of commotion, and MURDER AT THE RED OCTOBER by Anthony Olcott (Academy Chicago, $11.95) is somewhat reminiscent of that book. The security man in the Red October, a second-class hotel, finds the body of what appears to be a murdered American.

title: Long Island Guide; IN THE STARS
description: What the heavens hold always seems to fascinate sky buffs even more during the holiday season, and this year is no exception, what with the Vanderbilt Museum Planetarium in Centerport accommodating various tastes at various age levels. Throughout the period, the planetarium will stargaze in four sky shows.

title: WOMAN HEADS CAR GROUP
description: A WEST HARTFORD woman, Micki Dworin, has been elected the new president of the Connecticut Chevrolet Dealers' Association, making her the first woman to head one of the 84 Chevrolet dealers' associations in the country.

title: TV View; STRONG ACTING RESCUED GENERALLY WEAK SCRIPTS
description: As far as new weekly series were concerned, the year 1981 was not especially dazzling. The failure rate remained high, perhaps because the networks continued to whip new entries off the air before they had a chance to develop audiences. The one exception, and by far the best new show of the year, was ''Hill Street Blues.'' The series, mixing standard police-precinct action with sharper-than-usual characterizations, initially chalked up audience ratings that spelled imminent cancellation. But, encouraged by the enthusiasm of reviewers and trade insiders, NBC stuck with ''Hill Street Blues'' through several schedule changes, despite the dire warnings of some programming experts. Now shown on Thursdays at 10 P.M., the program recently edged up into the Top 10, giving Grant Tinker, Fred Silverman's successor, a solid foundation for improving NBC's dreary ratings position.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Drinking Habits The literary gulf between Mary McCarthy and Mickey Spillane may be wider than the Grand Canyon, but both authors feel strongly about literary symbolism. In "on the Contrary," a collection of essays published 20 years ago, Miss McCarthy noted that the search for meanings in literature had become a socially competitive enterprise. With considerable elan, she told of a college English class that had dissected one of her stories in hot pursuit of nonexistent (or at least unintended) symbols.

title: Correction
description: We regret that the following nonfiction book was inadvertently omitted from the list of Notable Books of the Year, which appeared in the Dec. 6 issue of The Book Review.

title: BEGIN'S OUTBURST SHARPENS DIFFERENCES IN WORDS AND NEEDS
description: The art of delicate diplomacy hardly figures prominently in the repertoires of the Reagan Administration and the Begin Government these days. Both have been operating in a spirit of blunt self-righteousness, which works well when they agree, but creates an abrasive mood, eroding trust and mutual respect, when they don't. The last two weeks have seen more tension than ever.

title: Film View; FOR AMERICAN MOVIES, A MINOR RENAISSANCE
description: In a year that witnesses the release of such dillies as ''Endless Love,'' ''Just a Gigolo'' and ''Tarzan the Ape Man,'' as well as the second attempt in less than 12 months to open ''Heaven's Gate'' in a neither all-new nor improved form, almost anything else is bound to look good, at least in retrospect.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Snake Prejudice
description: Calling timber rattlesnakes victims of human prejudice, a group of herpetologists set out in August 1979 to take a rattler census in New Jersey with a view to protecting the reptiles in sanctuaries. The group, Herpetological Associates of Staten Island, said it would search for rattler dens as part of a $10,000 endangered-species survey authorized by the state.

title: New Jersey Housing; WHEN THE CORPORATE AIDE MOVES
description: TO Jack and Ernestine Goodman of Morristown, it is the family unit that creates a sense of home. Having been moved by corporations from Chicago to Morris County, by way of Baltimore and Connecticut, one can see the wisdom of Mrs. Goodman's philosphy:

title: Williams Loses Entrapment Plea
description: A Federal judge concluded last week that Harrison A. Williams Jr. is too smart for his own good, thereby increasing the odds that the New Jersey Democrat will become the first member since the Civil War to be expelled from the United States Senate.

title: Dining Out; WITH THE GLITTER OF CHANDELIERS
description: THE Talk of the Town in Manhasset is one of the more astonishing restaurants to open on the Island in a long time. It is reported to have cost over a million dollars to construct. The exterior is vaguely nautical, with wood siding, keel-like curves and porthole windows.

title: SUBWAY SAFETY RECORD: MORE THAN 'DUMB LUCK'?
description: The recent derailment of an IRT subway train just south of the Times Square station didn't prompt a chorus of ''I told you so's,'' but it might well have.

title: SLAIN SUBWAY RIDER IDENTIFIED AS PORT CHESTER MAN
description: A subway rider who was fatally shot Christmas morning as he left a nearly deserted BMT station in Manhattan was identified yesterday as a 59-year-old professional guitarist from Port Chester, N.Y.

title: POLLUTION SPEEDING THE DEATH OF LAKES
description: THE natural mortality of New Jersey's more than 1,000 lakes has been hastened considerably by year-round community developments and the heavy burden of pollution that they place on the ecology of these delicately balanced ecosystems.

title: MONTREAL FLIGHTS
description: To the editor: There is an even cheaper way to fly to Montreal than the possibilities suggested by Henry Giniger in "What's Doing in Montreal" (Travel, Nov.22). Both Royal Air Maroc and Aerolineas Argentinas offer $86 round-trip excursions to New York travelers without any advance purchase requirement.

title: The New York Times Magazine; December 27, 1981
description: William Safire 7 On Language Sleazy Does It Russell Baker 12 Sunday Observer Heavy Breathing Rafik Halabi 14 Israel's Minority in the Middle Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights has drawn attention to the divided loyalties of the 900-year-old Druse sect. Here, a Druse discusses his people's - and Israel's - plight. Russell Martin 18 Writers of the Purple Sage As the American West becomes the focus of increasing national attention, a group of writers is quietly building a new and intriguing body of literature examining the modern-day life of this energy-abundant, still largely untamed and fast-changing region. Fashion 24 The New Snowy Whites Marilyn Bethany 26 Design A House Grows in Brooklyn Craig Clairborne with Pierre Franey 28 Food Birds of a Muscovy Feather Terry Robards 31 Wine All That Sparkles Isn't Champagne Ralph Blumenthal 36 A Times Square Revival? 44 Puzzles Answers, Page 32 46 Letters Cover: Painting by Stanislaw Zagorski Copyright 1981, The New York Times

title: UNION CHIEF PLANS FOR TRANSIT TALKS
description: John E. Lawe, who was re-elected president of New York City's bus and subway workers' union earlier this month, is already preparing for next year's transit negotiations. But he said that he wanted to avoid a repeat of the 1980 strike that paralyzed the city's public transportation for 11 days.

title: PATRICIA L. HINES TO BE APRIL BRIDE
description: The engagement of Patricia Lee Hines, daughter of Mrs. Robert Lee Hines of New York and Charlotte, N.C., and the late Mr. Hines, to John Stuart Phoenix, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius W. Phoenix of Short Hills, N.J., has been announced by the bride-to-be's mother. An April wedding is planned.

title: Mancini Stops Abedoy In Atlantic City Bout
description: Ray Mancini moved toward another chance at the lightweight title tonight by stopping Manuel Abedoy in the second round of a scheduled 10-round bout.

title: South Africa: Blacks at Work First of three articles.
description: Timothy Zimu, who has a stereo system and a refrigerator and who is about to buy a house, is near the pinnacle of employment opportunity reached so far by black industrial wage earners in white-ruled South Africa. He takes home about $115 a week.

title: Prospects
description: Breaking Inflation's Back

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Eagles on Defense
description: No. 46. Herman Edwards, rcb, 6-0, 190, San Diego State, 5th year; Smart, tough veteran who seldom errs. No. 78, Carl Hairston, re, 6-3, 260, Maryland State; 6th year; Most talented of the front three. No. 55, Frank LeMaster, rilb, 6-2, 238, Kentucky, 8th year; Classic inside linebacker with enough speed. No. 65, Charlie Johnson, mg, 6-3, 263, Colorado, 5th year; May be the best in conference. No. 59, Al Chesley, lilb, 6-3, 240, Pittsburgh, 3d year; The workhorse who replaced Bill Bergey. No. 68, Dennis Harrison, le, 6-8, 275, Vanderbilt, 4th year; Big, strong, excels against run. No. 41, Randy Logan, ss, 6-1, 195, Michigan, 9th year; Strong and smart but lacks speed. No. 43, Roynell Young, lcb, 6-1, 181, Alcorn State, 2d year. Pro Bowler. No. 22, Brenard Wilson, fs, 6-0, 175, Vanderbilt, 3d year; Average ability but makes big plays. No. 56, Jerry Robinson, rolb, 6-2, 218, U.C.L.A., 3d year; Agile and quick, but not strong. No. 95, John Bunting, lolb, 6-1, 220, North Carolina, 10th year; A wise player with limited ability. No. 4, Max Runager, p, 6-1, 189, South Carolina, 3d year; Ordinary and often erratic.

title: Dance View; FESTIVALS AND INDIVIDUAL PERFORMANCES ENRICHED 1981
description: The packaging in dance was terrific in 1981. Nearly everywhere one looked, one was confronted with a gala (many companies had several) or a newer wrinkle, the festival format. In a year that lacked the previous season's creative upsurge, the anniversary celebration or festival context offered a good framework for reconsideration. If there was a dearth of masterpieces among the premieres, on could always take stock of past achievements through a special presentation.

title: POLES TURNING TO FAITH IN FACE OF UNCERTAINTY IN HOMELAND
description: At first there was only the old woman wearing the kerchief, saying her rosary, gray beads in wrinkled hands. But the pews filled up quickly, and when the 11 A.M. mass in Polish began, there was barely standing room at the back of the Sacred Heart of Jesus Church in Port Chester.

title: BLACK-OWNED TV STATION IN JERSEY IN RECEIVERSHIP
description: New Jersey's first minority-owned television station, unable to meet its payroll or make interest payments on $6.45 million in loans, has gone into receivership after less than five months on the air.

title: TANNER WINS IN 3 SETS
description: Roscoe Tanner, a United States Davis Cup player who was seeded third here, won his opening-round match in the $400,000 Australian Open today, defeating Greg Whitecross of Australia, 6-3, 6-3, 6-3.

title: Westchester Guide; POLISH ARTISTS UNITE
description: Maria Hagadus, a Polish-born artist who came to the United States as a teen-ager after World War II, has organized an art show and sale in her adopted village of Bedford Hills as a means of aiding her country in her own small way. ''In October, when shortages of food and medical supplies became critical, I thought of doing this,'' she said. ''The response was so enthusiastic that I have so far collected more than 200 art works from 16 Polish artists in the New York area.''

title: THE CALM BEFORE THE STORM
description: THE AGE OF WONDERS By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 270 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $12.95.

title: A MUSEUM WITH A POINT OF VIEW
description: PAUL ANASTASI writes about Greece for The Times. By PAUL ANASTASI

title: Dith Pran INTERNATIONAL SPORT
description: A group playing jeux de boules, French version of lawn bowling known in many lands, in Central Park. The game, on a fair if brisk day, seemed a relaxing way to unwind from the Christmas holiday.

title: Stage View; A TIME WHEN THE OLD PROS SHOWED HOW TO DO IT
description: It was not the best of times, it was not the worst of times. It was a time when the old pros walked on from the wings and showed us all how to do it, no hands. The term ''old pro,'' by the way, has nothing to do with age. Mickey Rooney was an old pro at 12; Andy Hardy came later. The term has to do with learning your trade in the first place and making sure you remember it in the second - after you've earned your billing. It's native knack plus continued application, with a ready supply of that high nervous command that permits you to patiently count the house before glancing toward the pit and murmuring ''Whenever you're ready, professor.'' It's being ready whether the professor is or not. Taken in this light, the theatrical year 1981 proved to be something of an education. Let us list 10 of the players and/or playwrights who gave lessons:

title: Floods Subside in France
description: Hundreds of people driven from their homes by floods over Christmas began returning home in southwest and eastern France today as rivers subsided. President Francois Mitterrand inspected damage in the towns of Langon and Macon, a winegrowing center, where 2,000 people were evacuated after the River Saone overflowed its banks. A 71-year-old man drowned while trying to row to his home near Bourg-en-Bresse.

title: POLAND VOICES HOPE MINE SIT-IN CAN END BEFORE THE NEW YEAR
description: The Warsaw radio reported today that efforts to end the strike by 1,166 coal miners at the Piast mine in Silesia through negotiations had been fruitless. The broadcast voiced hope that the strike might by over by the New Year.

title: CHEMICAL DIET REPLACES FOOD FOR PATIENTS UNABLE TO DIGEST
description: Jim Fronk is on a permanent chemical diet, a mixture of proteins, dextrose, vitamins and minerals injected into his jugular vein, that has virtually replaced solid food.

title: Sound; RECALLING THE GENIUS WHO DEVISED FM RADIO
description: Before 1981 slips away and goes wherever the past resides, let us take note of an otherwise unremarked anniversary. It was just 40 years ago, late in 1941, that the first high-fidelity radio programs were beamed over an extended area from a mountaintop in New England.

title: BUT NO ANALEMMA
description: WHAT'S WHAT A Visual Glossary of the Physical World. By Reginald Bragonier Jr. and David Fisher. Illustrated. 565 pp. Maplewood, N.J.: Hammond. $30. By SHERWIN D. SMITH

title: WHY TROOPER DIED DESPITE HIS VEST
description: THE bulletproof vest that Philip Lamonaco, the 32-year-old state trooper, was wearing when mortally wounded in a shootout on Interstate 80 last week stopped three of the bullets, according to an official of the company that manufactures the vest.

title: DRAWING A PRIVACY LINE INSIDE PUBLICITY'S GLARE
description: To Richard V. Allen, it was the television crew that pursued his daughter to nursery school. To Louisa Kennedy, it was the 5 A.M. telephone call from a reporter seeking her reaction to the death of the Shah of Iran. To Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, it was the photographer who sprang in front of her as she came out of a Manhattan movie theater.

title: Camera; PICTURE PROJECTS FOR AROUND THE HOME
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lou Jacobs Jr. is a freelance writer and photographer, and the author of several books on photography.

title: BREZHNEV REPLIES TO REAGAN WARNING
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, has sent a letter to President Reagan responding to his warning about repression in Poland, a high Administration official said today. Mr. Reagan warned the Soviet Union that the United States ''will have no choice'' but to impose political and economic sanctions against Moscow if repression continues.

title: JAPAN LOOKS TO MAJOR GAINS IN USE OF ROBOTS
description: Robots will be widely used later in this decade in Japanese hospitals, in service industries and in agriculture, as well as in manufacturing, where Japan already leads the world in use of robots, according to a report issued here.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Hill, $22.95.) The most complete study of Pearl Harbor, laying to rest the theory that we were railroaded into war.

title: Japan Is Sending Envoy To 3 European Nations
description: Japan will send a ranking Foreign Ministry official to three European nations to coordinate a common stand on the crisis in Poland, Foreign Ministry sources said today.

title: Design; A HOUSE GROWS IN BROOKLYN
description: efore the house was built, the site was surely one of the most agreeable vacant lots in all of New York City: a 45-by-100-foot plot on the Brooklyn Heights riverfront promenade. On the river side, there were the views of the water, the Brooklyn Bridge and the Manhattan skyline. On the street side, there were the mature trees - honey locusts, planes and ginkgoes - and the rows of 19th-century brownstones. And in between, beyond a path connecting the street and the promenade, there was a playground permitting the property unobstructed southern light.

title: J. T. Beckett, Heidi Stamas Will Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Stamas of Scarsdale, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Stamas, to John Thomas Beckett of Los Angeles, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Beckett of Durham, N.H.

title: U.S. STUDY TELLS OF AFGHAN DEADLOCK
description: A State Department analysis made public to mark the second anniversary of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan depicts a deadlock in which both insurgents and the Soviet-backed Government are weakened by internal divisions.

title: CHILLY WINTER HAS BEEN WARM FRIEND TO SKI AREAS
description: FOLLOWING two slack seasons, business is booming at the state's four major ski areas as a result of several relatively early snowfalls, an ample covering of machine-made snow and, perhaps even more significantly, the evidence of snow in the backyards of most Connecticut residents.

title: Keeper of The Diary
description: As a diarist of five years, I found Patrick Huyghe's ''Diary Writing Turns a New Leaf'' (Nov. 8) helpfully revealing of the motivations for personal journalism.

title: Around the World; 3 Italians Won't Answer Questions About General
description: Three people arrested in Milan in connection with the Red Brigades kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier have refused to answer questions and declared themselves political prisoners, the police said today.

title: NOW, A 'COOKIE OF THE MONTH'
description: IT was inevitable that one day some entrepreneurs would dream up the Cookie of the Month to join the Book-of-the-Month, the Record of the Month and the Fruit of the Month. The cookie tycoons? Bourne Welsh and Nancy Elting, weekend residents of Sharon.

title: A Profit With Honor
description: It would seem a safe bet that Hungary's Ministry of Industry would not award its Order of Labor, gold class, for a capitalistic accomplishment.

title: Antiques View; 1981: THE YEAR FOR THE ENGLISH
description: Antiques enthusiasts have had a good year. There have been some major surprises at auction, and there has been some strengthening of trends and superior exhibitions in both museums and art galleries.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: Practical Traveler; A RENTAL CAR THAT'S DIFFERENT
description: T hey call themselves Ugly Duckling or Rent-A-Wreck or something similar to tempt the adventurous, but little is unsightly about what they offer. They are auto-rental networks that specialize in wellworn cars, most several years old. Some are still quite attractive, mechanically sound and rent for much less than most models of the current year.

title: Politics; COHALAN CONSIDERING TEMPERA'S FUTURE
description: SUFFOLK County Executive Peter F. Cohalan is currently weighing the fate of Lou V. Tempera, the county's first and only Labor Commissioner, who has served a total of 18 years under three County Executives.

title: Business Conditions; BANK LENDING ABROAD
description: The conbination of continued economic stagnation in major industrialized nations and a sharp dropoff in oil revenues among members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries led to a marked slowdown in international bank lending during the first half of 1981.

title: FOCUS SHIFTS IN BLACKS' FIGHT ON AT-LARGE VOTING
description: A rural eastern Georgia county with a history of discrimination against blacks has emerged as the new legal battleground for a fight over a Supreme Court ruling that severely limits challenges to at-large election procedures.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, DECEMBER 27, 1981
description: International Resistance to martial law continued among the more than 1,000 miners barricaded in the Piast mine in the Silesian coal district, the Warsaw radio said. This was the only remaining area of resistance to martial law in Poland, the radio said. Meanwhile, additional details were provided by clandestine Solidarity union publications about clashes in Gdansk and Wroclaw. They reported that several people were killed in street fighting in the two cities. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: No Headline
description: Having devoted considerable time to investigating the accident at Three Mile Island for the United States Senate, I am somewhat distressed at how Mr. Starr characterizes what occurred there and why. I find it a bit unseemly to attempt to make a virtue out of the accident while ignoring the continuing controversy in the scientific community about the effects of low-level radiation, cases of posttraumatic shock syndrome among the nearby residents and the possibility (however unlikely) that a real catastrophe could have occurred from a set of plausible alternative events.

title: REAGAN DOES WHAT HE CAN ABOUT POLAND - NOT ALOT
description: WASHINGTON AFTER three days of intensive discussions with his chief advisers last week about how to react to the suppression of freedom in Poland, President Reagan discovered that he was caught in the same bind of anger and frustration as previous Presidents who had to deal with similar crises on Soviet borders.

title: THE YEAR OF THE ROLLING STONES
description: Pop music is a volatile medium that reflects innovation and shifts in fashion even more rapidly than the other popular arts. The nature of the medium encourages change; unlike films or television programs, pop records can be manufactured quickly and relatively cheaply, and they can be enjoyed repeatedly at home until the consumer either wears out the disk or sets it aside in favor of a newer one. And ever since the rise of rock and roll in the 50's, pop music has been young people's music, subject to the sudden enthusiasms and passing fancies of youth.

title: HOW TO GO COAST TO COAST BY TRAIN
description: There are five main passenger-train routes across North America - one in Canada and four in the United States. A trip on any of them can originate in New York, but in all cases a change of trains is required.

title: WRITERS OF THE PURPLE SAGE
description: Russell Martin is a fourth-generation Coloradan who writes about the contemporary West. By Russell Martin

title: Another Increase In Volunteers
description: The recent article ''Volunteer Work by the Employed Increases on L.I.'' has brought many responses from prospective volunteers, and in general I felt it had a bit of a ''new twist.'' My only negative response would be the fact that my name was misspelled. DOROTHY BIRNHAM Director Voluntary Action Center of Suffolk Smithtown

title: THE ROCK BRACES FOR THE RUSH
description: JAMES M. MARKHAM is the chief of the Madrid bureau of The New York Times. By JAMES M.MARKHAM

title: KREMLIN'S SATISFACTION TEMPERED BY UNEASE
description: MOSCOW SOVIET reaction to the repression in Poland has combined detailed reports with high-level silence, public satisfaction with muted anxiety. Almost every day since martial law was declared, the Tass news agency has carried reports of an insidious counterrevolution nipped just in time. The dispatches refer to weapons stockpiled for civil war, to ''terrorist'' resistance to otherwise popular martial law and to a far-reaching American role that included radio transmitters broadcasting from United States consulates. The coverage shifted toward the end of the week, noting some return to normality and a revival of Polish Communist Party activity.

title: Business Conditions; SAFETY ON THE JOB
description: For the first time in five years, the number and rate of work-related injuries showed a decline last year, but that does not necessarily signal a safer workplace or a more careful workforce.

title: Politics; HOW POLITICAL IS A POLITICAL APPOINTEE?
description: THE State Supreme Court has come up with a majority opinion that says, in effect, that some political appointees should refrain from biting the hand that feeds them.

title: CHOPIN BIRTHPLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YEAR'S MESSAGE
description: The President's Christmas message was inadequate to the stormy present. Just as Jimmy Carter left the national Christmas tree dark to protest the seizure of hostages in Iran, Ronald Reagan put a candle in the window to display our flickering resolve at the rape of Poland.

title: Ann Brown Betrothed To Mark K. Schmidt
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Travis Taylor Brown of Washington and Nonquitt, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Ann Shippen Brown, to Mark Kenwill Schmidt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christoph H. Schmidt of Boston and Salisbury, Conn.

title: William Madison, Lawyer, To Wed Catherine Kealey
description: Miriam Wilson Kealey of Milford, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Catherine Ann Kealey, to William H. Madison, son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Madison of New York and Ancram, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: POLITICS; AN UNSETTLING YEAR - MORE UNCERTAINTY FORECAST
description: HARTFORD ANYONE doubting that there was much change in the Connecticut political scene during 1981 has only to look back at a year ago this weekend.

title: CABARET: BLOSSOM DEARIE
description: Blossom Dearie likes to do her singing and piano playing early in the evening. And although it is difficult for someone who is viewed as a nightclub performer to find a room that will accept her concept of her proper working hours, she has found one in the Music Room of the Horn of Plenty, at Bleecker and Charles Streets, where she is singing from 6:30 to 8 P.M. this week and next, except on New Year's Day.

title: Triple Jump Star Is Out of Coma
description: Doctors said today that the triple-jump world record-holder Joao Carlos de Oliveira has come out of a coma and succeeded in saying a few words. Oliveira suffered a fractured skull and other injuries last Tuesday in an automobile accident.

title: CONGRESS IS URGED TO CHECK JUDGES
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today urged Congress to consider trimming Federal judges' power to set aside criminal convictions by state courts.

title: 4TH QUARTER WORRYING RETAILERS
description: Although shoppers were much in evidence on Saturday, many of the nation's merchants, after a difficult Christmas season, are facing the final month of their last 1981 fiscal quarter with discomfort.

title: OUT OF FAMILY, COUNSEL FOR OTHERS
description: ''Why me?'' It is a question asked the world over in times of tragedy. But to Rabbi Harold S. Kushner and A.J. Levinson, it is a futile question, a question without an answer. Worse, it is a question that focuses on the past, on ''What did I do to deserve this?''

title: Henry's 2 Fumbles Costly for Eagles
description: ''What you have to remember,'' Coach Dick Vermeil was saying quietly outside the Eagles' locker room at Veterans Stadium, ''is that Wally Henry has won a lot of games for us on punt returns and kickoffs.''

title: POLAND TO REDUCE THE MEAT RATION FOR MOST CITIZENS
description: The Warsaw radio announced today that meat rations for all Poles except manual workers would be reduced next month.

title: OSAFUNE OF N.E.C. LEADS SILICON VALLEY INCURSION
description: Hiroe Osafune, regarded in his home country of Japan as the founder of the semiconductor industry there, has been living in California's Silicon Valley, the heart of America's electronics industry, for nearly three years. In that time, said the head of the American subsidiary of the Nippon Electric Company, Japanese electronics companies have made great progress.

title: AILING MADAGASCAR SEEKS WESTERN LOAN
description: Faced with a collapsing economy and virtually no foreign-exchange reserves, officials here are appealing to the International Monetary Fund and other Western donors for emergency assistance.

title: Jersey Police Officer Is Wounded in Chase
description: A police officer was shot in the abdomen early today while chasing a ''suspicious person'' in this Bergen County community, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN APPLAUDS THE AFGHAN GUERRILLAS

title: 'SCALE' SEISMOLOGIST LEAVES HOSPITAL:
description: Charles Richter, a noted seismolgist who in 1935 developed the Richter scale to measure the intensity of earthquakes, leaving hospital yesterday in Pasadena, Calif. Mr. Richter was injured two weeks ago in an automobile accident.

title: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING
description: Down in Brazil, the local Foote, Cone & Belding has acquired a "substantial minority interest" in Nucleo de Propaganda, and the two will be merged to form Nucleo/FCB Publicidade with $12 million in billings.

title: Robert Kennedy's Grave Loses Marker to Thieves
description: A marble marker and wooden cross at Robert F. Kennedy's gravesite in Arlington National Cemetery were reported stolen today.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * Executive Shoes to Doremus Direct, the direct response division of Doremus & Company, for mail order advertising.

title: Susan Brockmen Wed To Jordan R. Metzger
description: Susan Osler Brockman, daughter of Grace Sonenblick of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late David Osler, was married yesterday to Jordan R. Metzger of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Martin Zion of Temple Israel performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's office in Manhattan.

title: STOCK-MARKET RED TAPE IN NEED OF A HARD LOOK
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: MANHATTANS' HARMONY
description: MORE often than not, veteran black harmony groups find it impossible to sustain the youthful enthusiasm that brought them together, and instead they settle for nostalgic medleys of familiar material.

title: COMPOSER WROTE 'STARDUST'
description: Hoagy Carmichael, composer of such songs as ''Stardust'' and ''Georgia on My Mind,'' died today at Eisenhower Medical Center. He was 82 years old.

title: WHY ISRAEL CLOSED PALESTINIANS' UNIVERSITY
description: The Israeli military government, on Nov. 4 , ordered the closing, until Jan. 4, of Bir Zeit University, the m ain Palestinian university in the West Bank. The acting president, D r. Gabi Baramki, the entire administration, and a number of faculty m embers and students, including all members of the student council, w ere placed under either house or town arrest, and others were i mprisoned. Later, some were freed.

title: Sunday Globe Price to Be $1
description: The price of The Boston Sunday Globe will be $1 a copy beginning Sunday, the paper announced today. ''Publishing costs have gone up sharply in every category of our business,'' the publisher, William O. Taylor, said. The current price is 75 cents within 30 miles of Boston and 90 cents elsewhere.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can assure you there will be responses to the Soviets specifically, not simply the Polish Government.'' -Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, chief United States delegate to the United Nations. (A12:1.)

title: ISRAELI SETTLERS IN SINAI START FORTIFYING TOWN
description: The Israeli Cabinet today invited the 6,000 settlers in the Sinai Peninsula to reopen negotiations with the Government on compensation for their evacuation from the region, which is required under the terms of the Camp David accords with Egypt. But a committee representing the settlers promptly turned down the offer, saying the proposal contained nothing new, and the settlers began fortifying their positions.

title: Bridge: This Is 50th Anniversary Of Jacoby Rift With Lenz
description: Partnership divorces are very rare during the course of an event, but are slightly more likely to occur if the event is of great length. The most famous case occurred 50 years ago today, when Oswald Jacoby resigned his role in the celebrated Culbertson-Lenz match.

title: 2 Premieres for a Young Actress-Director
description: Despite a more-than-creditable string of dance and theater performances - including ''The Runner Stumbles'' - June Stein is still not a household word. But the young actress, now directing for the first time, has found herself closely involved with premieres by two Pulitzer Prize-winning playwrights, Beth Henley and Lanford Wilson.

title: SIBERIA A REFUGEE OF TRAMPS, TRADERS AND TALL TALES
description: This was once the Klondike of Siberia, a boom town built on gold, fur and trade with Asia, with gambling and boozing to match.

title: Clark 73, C.W. Post 58
description: Mike McGee scored 18 points and Dan Trant 16 as Clark scored an upset in the opening round of the Sacred Heart tournament.

title: Burglary Victim Accused Of Crimes in Taiwan
description: The Taiwan Government has been trying for three years to extradite Wellington Cheng, from whose home in the Bel Air neighborhood here $4.5 million in cash, art works and jewelry was stolen by burglars about a week ago.

title: Warner of Mobil: Still Willing to Buy
description: Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman of the Mobil Corporation, staged two big takeover battles this year. He lost the first, a bid to take over Conoco Inc., the nation's ninth-largest oil company. And oil industry analysts believe Mobil has at least an even chance of losing its current $6.5 billion bid to acquire the Marathon Oil Company, No. 17 among domestic oil companies.

title: SOVIET JEWS POSE U.S.-ISRAEL PUZZLE
description: With the number of Jews allowed to leave the Soviet Union dropping sharply, a dispute has erupted between United States and Israeli organizations helping to settle the emigrants.

title: SIGHTING OF AN 'ODD' GULL STIRS SEARCH BY BIRDERS
description: While some in the city this weekend tried visiting, theatergoing, returning Christmas presents or other holiday pastimes, a little band of bird watchers has been haunting the Hudson River piers around 45th Street pursuing what might well be a will-o'-the-wisp - the first suspected New York sighting of a mew gull in this century.

title: Stars Lose Broten
description: Neal Broten, Minnesota's thirdleading scorer with 33 points, will be out at least a month with a badly sprained right ankle, the North Stars said today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: I seem to remember an N.F.L. playoff game in the early 1970's that ended with a peculiar 5-2 score. Could you please fill in the details?

title: MONDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1981; The Economy
description: Retailers face the last month of their fiscal year with concern. Many fear the early markdowns taken to buoy erratic holiday sales will undercut traditional January bargain shopping, further weakening the most important quarter of the retailing year. (Page D1.)

title: 3 From Northeast Die In Rockies Plane Crash
description: The bodies of two New Jersey men and a New York woman were found today in the wreckage of a twin-engine plane that crashed while trying to make an instrument landing near a ski resort in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Molly Hoagland, Teacher, Married
description: Mary Stanley Hoagland and Clarence Hopkins King 3d were married yesterday in the Dover (Mass.) Church. The Rev. Deene D. Clarke performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: SAUDIS AND IRAQ SIGN PACT ENDING BORDER DISPUTE
description: Saudi Arabia and Iraq have signed an agreement ending a nearly 60-year border dispute amid signs of growing cooperation between the two countries against Iran.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH'S NEW CLAIROL CAMPAIGN
description: On television New Year's Eve, Clairol's Nice 'n Easy haircoloring will be changing its advertising theme from "It lets me be me" to "Make it happen" - with the help of Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: Jail Is Now House Arrest For Bhutto's Daughter
description: Pakistan's military authorities today transferred Benazir Bhutto, daughter of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, the executed leader, from a Karachi jail to her family home in Larkana, 300 miles north of here, prison officials said.

title: P.D.Q.: 'ANOTHER BUNCH' BY THE 'SEMICONDUCTOR'
description: century music are surpassed in crudity only by his ineffective efforts as a ''semiconductor,'' arrived at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, late as usual, for ''Yet Another Bunch of Concerts'' devoted to the works of P.D.Q. Bach, the infamous son of J.S. Bach who lived out his days by sleeping off his nightly binges in Wein-am-Rhein.

title: BONN OFFICIAL OPPOSES STEPS AGAINST POLAND
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany, in an interview that was made public today, warned the West against intervening in Polish affairs and opposed halting food aid to Poland.

title: Fire Aboard Norway Cancels Holiday Cruise
description: Norwegian-Carribean Cruise Lines, owners of the luxury liner Norway, canceled a New Year's cruise for 1,800 passengers last night after a fire in a boiler room buckled deck plates as the ship was docked in the Port of Miami.

title: TAUGHT AT YALE AND AT N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Robert Holt Green, former professor of medicine at Yale University's School of Medicine, died Friday at his home in Madison, Conn. He was 70 years old.

title: Arrau to Open Piano Series
description: Claudio Arrau will perform his only New York recital of the season Jan. 16 in Carnegie Hall. The program, which includes music by Beethoven and Liszt, will open the ''Keyboard Virtuosos'' series. Other pianists scheduled to appear include Bella Davidovich, Feb. 28; Misha Dichter, March 21; Emanuel Ax, April 18, and Vladimir Ashkenazy, April 24.

title: DANCE: JEAN ERDMAN'S WORKS AT THE OPEN EYE
description: JEAN ERDMAN danced with Martha Graham's company in the late 30's and through the mid-40's. As early as 1944, however, she set out on an independent course with her own small company, having choreographed her first solo in 1942. Today she is considered primarily as an experimental theater director and co-founder of the Theater of the Open Eye, with Joseph Campbell, her husband and an expert on world mythology.

title: TWO DIE IN BLAST NEAR TOWER OF PISA
description: Rescue workers searching the rubble of a four-story building that collapsed following an explosion. Police said two persons were killed, 19 were injured and five were miss-ing. The cause of the explosion was not immediately known, but officials said it may have been natural gas.

title: Three Persons Injured at Zoo In Accident at Koala Exhibit
description: Three people were slightly injured Saturday when part of a ramp suspended over an open-air koala exhibit at the San Diego Zoo collapsed.

title: No Headline
description: CAMP DISTURBANCE STAGED BY HAITIANS

title: MUSIC: JOYOUS 'BRANNDENBURGS' AT Y
description: THE Y Chamber Symphony under Gerard Schwarz played the six Bach Brandenburg Concertos at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night. It was the first of five performances this week devoted to the complete Brandenburgs; and if Mr. Schwarz and his ensemble can retain through New Year's Eve the ebullience and concentration they showed Saturday, they will have encapsulated into a few hours of music all the joy and celebration of the season.

title: UTILITIES CUT SPENDING PLANS 37%
description: Capital appropriations made in the third quarter by investor-owned gas and electric utilities fell 37 percent, to $11.2 billion, on a seasonally adjusted basis, from an expansive second quarter, the Conference Board reported over the weekend.

title: Gas Leak Forces Evacuation
description: Almost all the 6,000 people forced from their homes in two Detroit suburbs when chlorine gas leaked from a burning tanker truck have returned home, the police said today. A few residents reported minor chemical burns and one man was treated after inhaling the gas. A chlorine cloud formed over Fraser Saturday night and spread west to Sterling Heights when a truck parked at the Cross Country Chemical Company caught fire.

title: COPING WITH JOKES, GOSSIP AND HIDDEN SOLIDARITY PUNS
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: YUGOSLAV COLLEGE GRADUATES ISLAMIC LEADERS
description: The first Islamic spiritual leaders to be educated in Yugoslavia have graduated from Sarajevo's Moslem theological college.

title: AMTRAK WILL RESUME RUNNING CARDINAL LINES
description: The Cardinal, the passenger train from Washington to Chicago, will resume its meandering route through West Virginia's gorges and across Indiana flatlands Jan. 8.

title: No Headline
description: OLD WASTE DUMPS AND NEW ILLNESS MAY BE TIED IN MASSACHUSETTS TOWN

title: CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: RED BRIGADES SAY GENERAL IS ON TRIAL
description: A photograph of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier was received today by the Milan bureau of ANSA, the Italian news agency, 10 days after he was abducted by terrorists. It was accompanied by a statement announcing that the 50-year-old general had been placed on trial.

title: Lakers 139, Clippers 117
description: Mike McGee, a rookie reserve, scored 27 points tonight and led Los Angeles to its fifth consecutive victory, with Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sidelined by a strained tendon in his right ankle.
