title: 7 Die as New Typhoon Ravages Philippines
description: A typhoon that swept through the Philippines over the weekend killed seven persons, destroyed more than 5,000 homes and left about 26,000 people homeless, officials said today.

title: SPOOF AND SPIRIT REIGN IN THE DOO DAH PARADE
description: The parade was scheduled to begin in less than an hour, and 25-year-old Robyn Parnell was still trying to make up her mind. ''I'm still considering joining in,'' she said. ''That's the spirit of doo dah - spur of the moment.''

title: Market Place; Aiding Hostile Takeover Bids
description: INCO'S recent withdrawal from the battery business after becoming mired in losses raises questions about the wisdom of hostile takeovers. Inco had hoped that ESB, formerly the Electric Storage Battery Company, would help it to exploit what it called a ''monopoly in nickel and extensive research in nickel battery technology.''

title: Red Smith; Rose-Colored Memorabilia
description: WHILE the Hessians of the National Football League flounder through the opening acts in their postseason traffic, Phi Beta Kappas of tomorrow are doing their bumps and grinds in preparation for bowl games to help sell real estate in Pasadena, Calif., and tourism in Miami. The oldest of these is the Rose Bowl, the match between Washington and Iowa Jan. 1 being the 68th. These two culture foundries have never met in the bowl and, incidentally, this is the 40th anniversary of the only Rose Bowl game not played in Pasadena.

title: BUEHNING LOSES ANGRY MATCH
description: Fritz Buehning of the United States was eliminated from the $450,000 Australian Open tennis championships today, then, upset at the crowd and the officiating, said he probably would not be back next year.

title: No Headline
description: GRETZKY GETS 4 IN 10-3 ROUT

title: Fete for a Church Baby
description: Her birth made family history, and yesterday, when she was christened in her father's Manhattan church, All Souls Unitarian, Nina Wynne Church, now 9 months old, was surrounded by the congregation and admiring relatives.

title: The Process Due Senator Williams
description: The excuse the Senate has used to postpone the day of judgment for Harrison Williams is no longer available. Federal Judge George Pratt has now rejected the Senator's motions to throw out his bribery conviction.

title: TRANSITION FOR ACKER OF PAN AM
description: Propelling Air Florida to fame was not enough for C. Edward Acker. From four years as chairman and chief executive officer at the prosperous regional airline to the top post at Pan American World Airways last August, Mr. Acker has made an unusual entrepreneureal journey.

title: N.F.L. 1982 Schedule; AMERICAN CONFERENCE; EASTERN DIVISION; Miami Dolphins
description: Home - Jets, Buffalo, Baltimore, N ew England, Cleveland, Detroit, M innesota, San Diego. Away - Jets, Buffalo, Baltimore, N ew England, Cincinnati, Oakland, G reen Bay, Tampa Bay. Jets Home - Miami, Buffalo, Baltimore, N ew England, Houston, Green Bay, T ampa Bay, Denver. Away - Miami, Buffalo, Baltimore, N ew England, Pittsburgh, Kansas C ity, Detroit, Minnesota.

title: NEW MONEY, PEOPLE AND IDEAS ALTER CHINATOWN OF TRADITION
description: The New Chinatown: Community in Change First of two articles. By EDWARD A. GARGAN

title: BUCK WILLIAMS IS MUSCLING HIS WAY TO REOGNITION
description: ESTABLISHING a playing style, be it meek or mean, is important to a National Basketball Association rookie. It will be his trademark - his brand. Since early this season, Buck Williams, the Nets' 21-year-old rookie, has established himself as one of the most physical and talented power forwards in basketball. But last week, in a game against the Knicks, Williams's reputation reached a new level.

title: Armed Watch Pays Off
description: Yesterday he called it ''out of character,'' but Kahlil Gibran had no regrets about having pulled a pistol to protect two Christmas callers leaving his Boston home. A youth, he discovered, was ''prodding'' William Georgenes, a Boston painter, and a woman friend with a seven-inch knife.

title: HOW NOT TO FIX THE SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Mozambique Reports Abduction in Game Park
description: Guerrillas have kidnapped two foreign teachers at Mozambique's best-known wildlife park, the Defense Ministry has announced.

title: COWBOYS' SYSTEM CORRALS ANOTHER STAR
description: IF the Dallas Cowboys are so smart, what is Everson Walls doing being picked for the Pro Bowl, the National Football League's allstar game?

title: ENVOY OF JOHN PAUL WHO VISITED POLAND RETURNS TO VATICAN
description: A high-ranking Vatican diplomat returned to Rome today from a mission to Poland and said he hoped that Polish authorities and the leaders of the suspended Solidarity labor movement would resume negotiations soon.

title: REAGAN, WITH 1983 BUDGET FINISHED, BEGINS YEAR-END CALIFORNIA HOLIDAY
description: Leaving a rainy, chilly capital for the sunshine of California, President Reagan left for another vacation in Los Angeles and Palm Springs, Calif., that will include a round of socializing with old friends.

title: PENNSYLVANIA TEACHERS LEARN HOW TO AVOID CONFRONTATIONS
description: A step-by-step training program offered by a statewide teachers' union is helping to improve discipline in thousands of grade school and high school classrooms in Pennsylvania.

title: ADDENDUM
description: * Schiller, Ogilvy & Mather in Honolulu is changing its name to Ogilvy & Mather Hawaii.

title: FOR WOMEN IN BUSINESS, NO ROOM IN THE MIDDLE
description: Women in business are doing all right at the very top (on corporate boards) and at the bottom (in the growing number enrolled in business schools), says a Columbia University social scientist who has analyzed 250 studies on how women managers are faring in the business world.

title: Dr. Samuel Kahn Dies; Psychiatrist and Writer
description: Dr. Samuel Kahn, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who had studied with Freud, died Thursday at Westchester County Medical Center in White Plains. Dr. Kahn, who was a resident of Croton-on-Hudson, was 84 years old.

title: Leon Chazanow Weds Dr. Sydne B. Marshall
description: Dr. Sydne Barbara Marshall, an archeologist and adjunct assistant professor of anthropology at Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University, and Leon Haym Chazanow, a freelance editor in New York, were married yesterday.

title: PASSMORE ON 3 WINNERS IN RETURN FROM INJURY
description: Bill Passmore returned to racing today after a three-month layoff because of an injury and won his first three starts at Laurel Race Course. But he was denied a fourth straight winner.

title: Earthquake Shakes Greece
description: A strong earth tremor shook part of the Greek mainland and several Aegean islands today, causing panic but no casualties, the police said. Athens Observatory said the tremor had its epicenter 100 miles northeast of Athens and measured 6.4 on the Richter scale.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Congressional staff estimates of rapidly rising Federal budgets point to the possibility that deficits of more than $100 billion a year and interest rates will chase each other higher and higher in the next several years.

title: 2 REAGAN AIDES ACTED TO SPEED PORTMAN HOTEL
description: President Reagan's top political aide, Lyn Nofziger, and Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt intervened directly last month to further the Times Square hotel plans of the developer John C. Portman Jr. and the City of New York, according to court documents.

title: JUDGES' TRANSFER TO CITY CONTINUING
description: A renewed focus on the growing number of criminal cases has hampered a two-year-old effort to end long delays in civil cases in New York City's major trial courts, and serious backlogs in civil cases still exist in these courts, officials say.

title: CANADA ARRESTS TWO ART DEALERS IN IMPORT CASE
description: Two Manhattan art dealers have been arrested in Canada on charges of bringing into that country a rare and ancient work of African sculpture without an export license from the Nigerian Government. The case is believed to represent the first move by the Canadian Government to enforce a law that bars unlicensed entry of foreign cultural properties.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOLS REPORT RISE IN STUDENT ENROLLMENT IN '81
description: -The number of students enrolled in the nation's medical schools in the 1980-81 school year increased slightly over the previous year, The Journal of American Medical Association has reported.

title: U.S. Bows, 5-4, To Team Canada
description: Marc Habscheid's breakaway goal early in the third period insured a 5-4 victory for undefeated Team Canada over the United States today in the world junior hockey championships.

title: 3 GOALS FOR DUGUAY
description: Just when the Rangers appeared to have blundered into another tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins, Ron Duguay sprinted down the ice and scored twice in the last five minutes for a 5-3 victory at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE FITTEST

title: EGYPT REAFFIRMS PEACE WITH ISRAEL
description: Peace between Israel and Egypt is irreversible, a senior Egyptian official said in an interview here the other day, even as his Government continued its attacks on Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1981
description: International Reduced meat rations for all Poles except manual workers will take effect next month, the Warsaw radio announced. Officials said that the country faced a serious meat shortage and that large quantities of imports from the Soviet Union and other Communist-bloc countries would be needed to maintain the ration for miners and other manual workers at the December level. (Page A1, Column 6.) The U.S. sanctions against Poland threatened by President Reagan in response to the imposition of martial law surprised and distressed the country's military rulers, according to Polish Government sources. They said that the official view in Poland was that Mr. Reagan's restrictions on trade, Western credits and civil air rights agreements, would further isolate Poland from the West and force it to turn even more to the Soviet trading bloc. A major concern among Polish officials was that the American action would further reduce Poland's living standard, leading to extensive unemployment and social unrest and prolongation of martial law. (A1:5.)

title: A YOUNG ENTREPENEUR STARTS DOLLAR MAGAZINE
description: J.D. Allen, a young entrepreneur in the oil business who went abroad frequently, was often asked during his travels to suggest a good magazine that was informative about investment possibilities in the United States. That proved to be so difficult, according to associates, that he started his own magazine.

title: TV: VIENNESE-STYLE 'DIE FLEDERMAUS'
description: JUST in time to welcome in the New Year, in a tradition long established in Vienna, ''Die Fledermaus'' is tonight's presentation at 8 o'clock on WNET-TV's ''Great Performances.'' In fact, the Unitel production was recorded in Vienna, and the journey to public television had the usual number of bureaucratic delays. Two of the principals have died in the interim - Karl Bohm, the conductor, and Wolfgang Windgassen, the Wagnerian tenor, who appears as Prince Orlofsky, a role usually played by a woman.

title: The New York Times/Harriet Gans; A DENUNCIATION OF COMMUNISM
description: Residents of Stamford, Conn., marched through that city to express support for the Polish people and their opposition to Communism in general. Some carried a Cuban flag to mark 23 years of Communist rule in Cuba. Fidel Castro seized power Jan. 1, 1959.

title: MANY MAIL CAMPAIGNS END YEAR
description: If the intense and complex planning that the nation's direct marketing industry has been involved in since last summer is rewarded, then your mail box today should be full of their pitches--weather and the Postal Service permitting.

title: MUSIC: CATHEDRAL OFFERS 'PLAY OF ST. NICHOLAS'
description: THE Cathedral of St. John the Divine seems an unlikely place for combat, but Saturday afternoon, the electronic medium and the concert audience nearly came to blows. This particular audience came to see one of many seasonal performances of ''The Play of St. Nicholas'' apparently unaware it was to be videotaped. The three scenes here are reconstructed from 12th-century literature and music, and each features the magical intercessions of St. Nicholas righting wrongs and undoing dark deeds. Those assembled Saturday could have used his saintly protection against the cameras, cables and creeping technicians that continuously obscured ''St. Nicholas'''s visual charm and spiritual message.

title: POST OFFICE'S MOVE INTO ELECTRONIC MAIL
description: After nearly four years of effort and amid continuing controversy, the United States Postal Service plans to introduce its new electronic mail system for businesses on Jan. 4. The service will be marketed as E-COM, an acronym for ''Electronic Computer-Originated Mail.''

title: GASOHOL'S FUTURE DOESN'T LOOK DIM
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL SPILLED BY VANDALS ENTERS RESERVOIR
description: About 13,000 gallons of fuel oil spilled into an inlet of the Croton Reservoir system in Westchester County early yesterday after the pump of a nearby oil company was vandalized, according to the Yorktown Heights police.

title: Defecting Cellist Skips Tour, Will Raise Money for Poland
description: A Polish cellist who has asked for political asylum in the United States has canceled plans for a concert tour in Brazil so she can concentrate on fund-raising in the United States for the Polish people.

title: Public Radio to Mark Black History Month
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - National Public Radio will celebrate Black History Month in February. In addition to special productions, the weekly ''Horizons'' will cover interests of blacks.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH
description: There are no formal agendas, no negotiations, no protocols, no communiques. U.S. Trade Representative Bill Brock calls it a ''formal mechanism for informal consultations,'' and now, on the quiet, the major industrial powers are again putting it to the test.

title: New York Legal Notes
description: Old and dusty defenses, local transit officials are discovering to their chagrin, may be just as solid as newfangled ones. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, along with the City of New York and the New York City Transit Authority, is attempting to compel the developer Donald J. Trump to grant an easement through his Hyatt-Regency Hotel as part of its plans to enlarge the 42d Street entrance to the Grand Central subway station.

title: W. Illinois 79; Oklahoma 78
description: OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) - Joe Dykstra hit two free throws with eight seconds remaining and scored 28 points over all as Western Illinois (6-1) won its first-round game in the All College Tournament.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN. By William F. Buckley Jr. 233 pages. Doubleday. $13.95.

title: Australia Deports Refugees
description: Chinese who posed as Vietnamese refugees when they arrived in Darwin by fishing boat in October were put aboard a jetliner today and deported to Taiwan and Hong Kong. Officials said 121 Chinese were going back to Taiwan, and six were headed to Hong Kong. One official said the Chinese paid ''substantial sums'' for thier passage to Australia.

title: CANDLE IN THE WINDOW
description: When President Reagan expressed his outrage at what is happening in Poland, he spoke for all of us. To see ''the stirrings of liberty'' crushed by ''brute force,'' as he put it, has touched the deepest American feelings. We wish we could do more than light a candle in the window.

title: South Lebanon Forces Evict Moslem Families
description: Israeli-backed Christian militia forces in southern Lebanon have expelled a number of Moslem families from their villages near the border with Israel.

title: MAKE MINE MYTH
description: Most historians disdain myths, believing that their job is to dispel error by showing how shorthand, mythical interpretations of the past fail to explain all the facts. Yet myth is more subtle than such practitioners admit.

title: UNCHALLENGED BOASTS OF GOVERNMENT THRIFT
description: To the Editor:

title: CHEVY CHASE, TRAFFIC CONTROLLER
description: TWENTIETH Century-Fox knew exactly what it was doing when it decided to open ''Modern Problems,'' the new Chevy Chase comedy, at theaters all over New York on Christmas Day, without advance screenings for the press. It's not that ''Modern Problems'' is so bad, though it is incredibly sloppy, but that it's the kind of movie that doesn't need reviews to find its audience.

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: WARSAW REPORTS A 'FESTIVE' AIR
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government Agency: Report to the Polish People 12:08 P.M. Sunday

title: Wooden Admits Violations
description: John Wooden says that, technically, he broke some National Collegiate Athletic Association rules while he was basketball coach at U.C.L.A. But the violations turned up by the association in its recent investigation of the Bruin basketball program were minor, he said in an interview in today's Los Angeles Times.

title: MOSCOW'S OVERSTATED AFGHANISTAN BURDEN
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW ASSERTS U.S. WANTS END TO ARMS CONTROL TALKS
description: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda charged today that the United States wanted to provoke a Soviet intervention in Poland as a pretext to break off arms control talks.

title: Those 7 Gift Points
description: IN the end, as throughout the 31-27 loss to the Buffalo Bills yesterday, the Jets reverted to what they once had been - the masters of mistakes. In the end, on a play that began at the Bills' 11-yard line with 10 seconds remaining, an interception of Richard Todd's pass tore up the scenario of a Jet victory in the closing seconds after they had trailed by 24-0 late in the first half. But that was only the last of many mistakes.

title: Ostpolitik or Illusion?
description: The docile West German reaction to the crackdown in Poland is a disturbing measure of the cracks in the Western alliance. The Germans can no longer pretend that ''Cowboy Reagan'' is stirring the cold war. Americans need to recognize in trying to coordinate NATO policies that detente lives on as a powerful chimera in German eyes. But gradually, those eyes will have to be refocused on the real world.

title: FOR SALE ABROAD: INFLUENCE IN CAPITAL
description: Those who have to file don't like it very much, but it's the law; and now, in a perverse way, a kind of cachet attaches to the registrants almost as if they were members of an exclusive club.

title: LEO BURNETT COMPANY HAS NEW UNITED ADS
description: United Airlines, for a new campaign breaking next week, will eschew testimonials from entertainers and athletes in favor of those from business executives. That's one way of saving money.

title: STAGE: MILER'S 'A VIEW FROM BRIDGE' REVIVED
description: NEW HAVEN IN Arthur Miller's ''A View From the Bridge,'' given an exemplary revival by Arvin Brown at the Long Wharf Theater, Eddie Carbone offers three words of advice to his niece and ward, ''Don't trust nobody.'' He should have added, especially don't trust Eddie Carbone. The warning resounds like a foghorn through the drama, or as the narrator, the lawyer Alfieri, calls it, the dream.

title: Priscilla Gordon Married to Nathan Smith on L.I.
description: Priscilla C. Gordon and Nathan Smith were married yesterday at the New Hyde Park (L.I.) Jewish Center by Rabbi Leonard Aaronson. Randi Beth and Peter Scott Gordon, the bride's children from a previous marriage that ended in divorce, attended the ceremony, as did Mr. Smith's sons, Howard Steven and Robert Brian Smith.

title: TEXAS WRITERS ASSAILED BY COLLEAGUE GRUDGINGLY ADMIT HE MIGHT BE RIGHT
description: The American literary firmament, it seems, is fairly aglow with Texas writers these days. It is studded with such names in fiction as Larry L. King, Donald Barthelme and Dan Jenkins, to pick but three from a long list of serious, established authors now at work in Texas or as expatriate Texans on the coasts.

title: HANOI, IN ECONOMIC STRAITS, SEEKS TO MOVE TOWARD TIES WITH U.S.
description: Vietnam, facing economic crisis, food shortages and an uneasy relationship with the Soviet Union, is seeking to open contacts with the United States that would lead to diplomatic ties.

title: Ballet Theater Elevates Three to Soloist Rank
description: Susan Jaffe, Elaine Kudo and Peter Fonseca, members of the corps of the American Ballet Theater, have been promoted to soloists. Born in Washington, Miss Jaffe trained at the Maryland School of Ballet, the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet and the American Ballet Theater School and joined the company in July 1980.

title: CONTRIBUTIONS GIVEN FOR AID OF HOMELESS
description: Among the neediest people in New York City are the homeless men and women who wander the streets or huddle in the waiting rooms and restrooms of train and bus stations.

title: YEAR-END FACTORS MAY AFFECT PRICES
description: Unusually heavy year-end Government borrowings continued to weigh on the money market last week, raising short-term rates a point on average and reducing prices of longer-term coupon securities as much as two points, or $20 for each $1,000 of face value. An unexpected rally on Thursday prevented even larger yields being posted for the week.

title: CUNNINGHAM & WALSH NAMED BY MITSUBISHI
description: Cunningham & Walsh, which has been doing corporate advertising for the Mitsubishi Motor Corporation since 1979, has just been named to handle the advertising for the first cars to be sold under the Mitsubishi name in the United States.

title: Search Goes On After St. Lawrence Blaze
description: Helicopters searched the icy waters of the lower St. Lawrence River today for three crewmen missing after a Christmas Day fire on the oil tanker Hudson Transport.

title: NADINE GORDIMER, SOUTH AFRICAN WITNESS
description: IN eight novels and seven collections of short stories, Nadine Gordimer has charted the physical, emotional and political geography of contemporary South Africa. It is a place inhabited by stubborn colonials, well-meaning liberals, disillusioned blacks and importunate revolutionaries, a place blessed with extraordinary beauty and scarred by lapses of moral illiteracy. For Miss Gordimer, this country so filled with promise and fear is home, and her work remains a kind of spiritual guide to its peoples' complicated fate.

title: POLITICAL FACTORS IN '82 OUTLOOK
description: In looking to 1982 and 1983, economists from Otto Eckstein at Data Resources Inc. to Marina Whitman at the General Motors Corporation are making political assumptions about what the Reagan Administration, the Congress and the Federal Reserve Board will do that are as important as their assumptions about capital spending, housing starts, savings and other economic variables.

title: BRADSHAW: CHARTING RCA'S COURSE
description: The RCA Corporation was in the throes of an identity crisis when Thornton F. Bradshaw, former president of the Atlantic Richfield Company, became chairman on July 1.

title: By John Radosta
description: Sports World Specials Cooney's Following

title: SOCIAL SECURITY CHIEF AGAINST RISE IN PAYROLL TAX TO FINANCE SYSTEM
description: The Reagan Administration will not raise the payroll tax or use general tax money to pull Social Security out of its financial hole, even if those actions are recommended by a panel created to study the system's problems, the Commissioner of Social Security says.

title: SMALL FORWARD A BIG PROBLEM FOR KNICKS
description: During Red Holzman's 18 coaching seasons, which include 676 victories, he has often been asked about his starting lineup, and his answer has always been the same.

title: MILITARY RETIREES BUOY SAN ANTONIO ECONOMY
description: There is nearly one retired general for every 100 residents in this affluent San Antonio suburb, nicknamed ''Fort Windcrest'' because of its population of Air Force, Army and Navy personnel.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HERE is no monument in Washington to President Herbert Clark Hoover, whose name became synonymous with the Great Depression, and there may never be. But Congress, before adjourning for the holidays, did see fit to honor Hoover for his service as Secretary of Commerce. It named the Department of Commerce building after Hoover, but not before some House Democrats used the occasion to resurrect Hoover's economic policies and compare them with those of President Reagan.

title: Dance Encyclopedia Set For 1984 by Scribner's
description: Charles Scribner's Sons will publish ''The International Encyclopedia of Dance,'' a multivolume reference work, in 1984.

title: SMITH COLLEGE FIGHTING SUIT CHARGING SEX BIAS
description: The land is overgrown pasture and stands of scrub pine, birch and maple - poor land, the local people say - up above the last remaining farm on a snowy mountain road that no longer leads through to the next village.

title: FOR BUS RIDERS, NO MORE BEEPS BUT SIGNS ARE STILL HARD TO READ
description: There has always been a white line separating the driver from passengers on New York City buses, but nobody ever took much notice. That is, until last summer, when the first of a shipment of new General Motors buses hit the streets.

title: TRANSIENT WORKERS IN SOUTH AFRICA FACE A MAZE OF STRINGENT REGULATIONS
description: The Sugarlands butchery is prepared to pay $15.75 a week to a black who is ''clean and bright.'' A suburban homeowner bids $42 a month for a ''houseboy'' who ''must be clean and not fat.'' The Summer Sands Hotel will pay $97 a month to a cleaning man who ''must be prepared to work very hard'' on the night shift; the words ''very hard'' are underlined heavily on the card filled in by the clerk in the state labor bureau here. And the post office in Durban is sending a truck to pick up 60 men to dig ditches for telephone cables; for the six weeks that the job lasts, the pay will be $3.60 a day.

title: TURN THE PRISON BUREAU INTO A 'THINK-TANK'
description: President Reagan should act forthwith to dismantle the sprawling, costly, largely ineffectual Federal Bureau of Prisons and turn over most of its 42 prisons to state penal systems, whose facilities are bulging. Seventy-five percent of the bureau's inmates have no history of violence,

title: RECRUITERS WANT DOGS FOR MILITARY
description: All four branches of the military service reached their manpower recruiting goals for the last fiscal year, but the Federal Government is still looking for a few good dogs.

title: A DERAILMENT AT W. 96TH ST. DISRUPTS SERVICE ON THE IRT
description: A derailment on the West Side IRT subway line at the 96th Street station yesterday morning caused disruption of express service for nearly four hours. The train carried no passengers and there were no injuries to crew members.

title: U.S. TO PURSUE PHYSICIANS WHO DEFAULTED ON LOANS
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, has ordered that action be taken against doctors and other health professionals who have defaulted on student loans, it was announced today.

title: Commodities; Poland's Crisis Hits U.S. Farms
description: WHATEVER the outcome of the Polish crisis in economic terms, American grain farmers have already paid a heavy price, and may be called upon for even greater sacrifices. All this despite the fact that another curtailment on grain shipments to the Soviet bloc has only been hinted by the Administration since the Polish Government began its repressive moves two weeks ago.

title: Nonfleet Cabs Acting To Exploit Lower Fee
description: Looking to make the best of what they regard as a bad situation, the drivers of independent taxicabs have asked the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission to post a sign in the windows of their vehicles stating, ''This taxicab does not charge the 50-cent surcharge.''

title: SCORE OF WEEKEND MURDERS PUSH '81 TOLL NEAR RECORD
description: More than a score of people were murdered in New York City during the three-day Christmas weekend in robberies, family fights, street and bar disputes and other, more mysterious circumstances, the police said yesterday.

title: Texas Priest Slain in Motel
description: A Roman Catholic priest who failed to appear for Christmas services in his church in Denver City, Tex., was found dead, naked and beaten in a motel, the authorities said today. The body of the Rev. Patrick Ryan, 49 years old, was discovered by a maid Tuesday in a motel here, but the police said he had not been identified until they learned that the priest was missing.

title: G.M.'S SMITH SHARES WOES OF AUTO MAKERS
description: When Roger B. Smith took over as the 10th chairman of the General Motors Corporation last January, he did what any aggressive, financially oriented executive might do: He raised prices.

title: AFTERMATH OF GENETIC ANOMALIES
description: The psychiatrist assigned to the genetics counseling program at Presbyterian Hospital, was describing some of the anguish that his work entails. ''In a psychiatric clinic people have the basic feeling that there is something wrong with them,'' he said. ''But you tell them, 'we can work it through, and you will be feeling better about yourself.' ''

title: IDEA FOR THE AGES: NEW YORK STATE FOSSIL
description: New York, which has a state fish (the brook trout), a state mammal (the beaver), a state bird (the bluebird), a state gem (the garnet), a state tree (the sugar maple) and a state flower (the wild rose), now needs a state fossil, according to the state paleontologist.

title: Adirondack Holme Wins at Aqueduct
description: Adirondack Holme, a heavy favorite, took the lead turning for home and scored a 1 1/4-length victory in the $54,000 Alex M. Robb Stakes at fog-shrouded Aqueduct yesterday.

title: POP-FUNK: CARLTON'S 'MAMA'
description: ONE of this year's catchier pop-funk hit records was a novelty chant, ''She's a Bad Mama Jama,'' celebrating female buxomness. On Saturday at the Copacabana, its singer, Carl Carlton, performed a half-hour version of it that ended up with a good portion of the audience shouting and stamping along with Mr. Carlton who had stripped to the waist. Aside from this moment of high party spirits, however, Mr. Carlton's set was decidedly mediocre. The Detroit-born singer possesses a merely functional pop-soul tenor and has very little in the way of tone, and what he lacks in vocal prowess he tries to make up for in exhibitionistic footwork. Mr. Carlton's crude stridency was underscored by a band in which the synthisizer stood out much too blaringly.

title: Lisbeth Davidow Wed To Miles Mogulescu
description: Lisbeth Davidow, a dancer-choreographer, was married yesterday at the Village Temple to Miles Mogulescu, a film producer.

title: RUSSELL PULLING ST. JOHN'S UP TO HIS LEVEL
description: the one that reads The Skywalker - was trying to explain something that defies gravity and explanation.

title: CHINA ATTACKS FOREIGN POLICY OF U.S.
description: After months of referring to the Soviet Union as the principal threat to world stability, China has resumed its criticism of the United States as a superpower vying with Moscow for hegemony over the third world.

title: A START ON THE NUKES
description: Word in Geneva and in NATO headquarters at Brussels is that both American and Soviet negotiators believe the talks on Euro-missiles have gotten off to a good start. Both sides have judged the first round, recessed now for the holidays, as ''positive.''

title: WHEN IT PAYS TO BE KIND TO ANIMALS
description: To the Editor:

title: CARPENTER CARRIES GIANTS
description: PHILADELPHIA UNDER the floodlights, Rob Carpenter spent the greater part of this dark, misting afternoon running up and down Veterans Stadium with a bunch of people in green jerseys hanging all over him. It was quite a sight.

title: The West Side Without Washington
description: Now that Washington has declared itself no longer interested in New York's West Side Urban Renewal Project, City Hall has total responsibility for sustaining the spirit of this controversial program. The way to do that is to pave a path for more unsubsidized housing and suitable commercial areas.

title: SOME CHURCHES ANSWER KOCH'S BID ON HOMELESS
description: In the two weeks since Mayor Koch suggested that New York's churches and synagogues help shelter their neighborhood homeless, five or six churches have expressed interest in doing so, city officials said.

title: A.T.&T. Plans Billing Change
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expected to ask the Federal Communications Commission Wednesday to approve a more precise merthod of billing of longdistance based on each rate period that falls during the calls. This would be a major departure from Bell's tradition of billing an interstate long-distance call on the basis of when it begins.

title: JET RALLY FALTERS
description: The long, often improbable climb of the Jets to the pro football playoffs ended suddenly yesterday just when it seemed they would complete the greatest comeback in postseason play.

title: HIGH TECHNOLOGY BRINGS SMALL BANK INTO GERMAN HOMES
description: Upstairs, its stuffed leather armchairs and oak wainscoting make it look like any one of the small private banks that for years has financed this port city's shipping industry.

title: Fire in Yonkers Routs Five Families
description: A firefighter leaving a window of an apartment building in Yonkers that was destroyed by a three-alarm fire Saturday night. Five families were left homeless by the blaze and two adjoining private houses were damaged.

title: A Television First for John Cheever
description: John Cheever's first original work for television, ''The Shady Hill Kidnapping,'' will appear on public television Jan. 12. In an article in the current issue of The Dial, the national magazine for public broadcasting, the 68-year-old novelist and short-story writer - who has been home for Christmas weekend in Ossining, N.Y., from Manhattan's Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center - talks about why he was not represented earlier on television.

title: Wrong Move Was a Right Move
description: It took 136 plays before the Jets lost, 31-27, to the Buffalo Bills yesterday. But the next-to-last play, the 135th, proved to be bigger than all the others because it stopped the Jets at the Buffalo 1-yard line, ending their astonishing surge in the final quarter.

title: PEOPLE
description: * Theodore LaMontagne and Joseph A. Prior have been elected senior vice presidents at Backer & Spielvogel. * Edwin H. Grosso has been named executive vice president, operations, and a director of Ingalls Associates. * Wayne Gastman has been named a senior vice president at J. Richard Smith Advertising, Old Bethpage, L.I.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Role of Honoraria

title: No Headline
description: MISSOURI AND U.S. GAIN FINAL

title: Virginia Elysabeth Perlo Bride of Edward Budney
description: Virginia Elysabeth Perlo, an interior-design editor, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Edward Alexander Budney, president of B.&L. Associates, a New York marketer of building products.

title: SENATOR HART TACKLES PARTY RENEWAL
description: Eight years ago, long before it was a fashionable theme for Democrats, Gary Hart wrote that the 1972 Presidential campaign of George McGovern showed that ''American liberalism was near bankruptcy'' because its intellectual creativity had dried up.

title: OPERA: 3 MAJOR ROLES RECAST IN MET'S 'HANSEL AND GRETEL'
description: APPETITE is the big problem in ''Hansel and Gretel.'' For lack of food, the mother exiles her children to the forest.

title: DAYS OF PROSPERITY AT HARVARD REVIEW
description: Tilting its fare more toward people in business rather than lecture halls, the Harvard Business Review is shedding its stuffy academic image with some sharp critiques of American management.

title: Florida's Lawless Armies
description: The Reagan Administration has objected to Nicaragua's military buildup and its provocative purchase of Soviet-bloc weaponry. It accuses Nicaragua of violating international law by permitting a flow of arms to left-wing comrades in El Salvador.

title: Index; International
description: Siberia a refuge of tramps, traders and tall tales A2 China has resumed its criticism of the United States A3 President Reagan praises Afghan resistance fighters A3 Around the World A5 Israeli settlers in Sinai begin for- tifying town A6 High Egyptian official calls peace with Israel irreversible A7 Saudis and Iraq sign pact ending border dispute A9 The Polish airwaves: excerpts from broadcasts A10 High papal envoy returns from Poland A11 Yugoslavia's Moslem theological college graduates first class A13 For transient black workers in South Africa, a maze of rules A14 Washington Talk Briefing B10 Calendar B10 Gary Hart: A Senator and his party are in transition B10 Special list shows who helps out foreign powers and concerns B10 Required reading B10 General Around the Nation A16 Paleontologist seeks naming of a state fossil for New York B1 For New York City bus riders, no more electronic beeps B1 Legal tangle blocking Grand Cen- tral subway project B2 Several New York churches hop- ing to aid homeless B3 Two New York art dealers face charges in Canada B7 Top officials interceded in Port- man hotel plan B9 Texas author's attack on state's writers subject of hot debate B15 Haitian immigrants demonstrate at Miami detention camp B16 Military retirees improve San An- tonio's economy B20 SportsMonday Basketball: Rivalry at small for- ward poses problem for Knicks C4

title: BREZHNEV RESPONSE TO REAGAN'S LETTER IS CALLED 'NEGATIVE'
description: President Reagan said today that a letter received Friday from Leonid I. Brezhnev on the Polish situation was ''negative'' in tone. However, another Administration official later said the Soviet leader's message did not seem to close the door to further discussion on the crisis.

title: JUAREZ SCHOOL EASES U.S. STUDENTS' WAY TO A MEDICAL DEGREE
description: For three years, Ralph Mayberry tried to get into dental school in the United States. Each year, he was turned down. The fourth year, he went to Mexico.

title: POLISH OFFICIALS EXPRESS CONCERN ON U.S. ACTIONS
description: The ruling authorities in Poland were surprised and distressed by the economic restrictions announced by President Reagan in response to the imposition of martial law, Government sources said today.

title: Joan Porter Is Wed to David MacIver
description: Joan Porter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight J. Porter of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to David MacIver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter W. MacIver of Welwyn Garden City, England. The Rev. Dr. Ralph Potter of the Harvard Divinity School performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Bar Association Report Urges Stiffer Gun Laws
description: Stronger gun control laws and better programs to control juvenile criminals are needed to help reduce crime in the United States, according to a report released today by the American Bar Association.

title: Diagnostic Data Elects President-Chief Officer
description: After an extended two-year proxy contest that resulted in the formation of a new board of directors last September, Diagnostic Data Inc. has elected Dr. L. James Strand, 40, as president and chief executive officer.

title: Advertising; A Boom For Drug Magazines
description: IN the good old days when the advertised consumer benefits of Booth & Sedgwick's Superior Medicated Gin included medical efficacy in treatment of obstruction of the kidneys, dyspepsia, gout, incipient dropsy, colic, and pain of the stomach and bowels, the precursor of Drug Topics magazine was already serving the pharmacists of America.

title: SCM Unit Deal
description: The SCM Corporation said that its Allied Egry Business Systems Group of Dayton, Ohio, had bought a forms printing plant at Manchester, Conn., from Continental Forms Inc., for an undisclosed amount. Allied Egry has five plants operating and a sixth under construction. The company's business has increased to $100 million a year, from $50 million, in the past five years.

title: Off Critical List
description: Sister Margaret Franks, who was mugged and nearly killed outside her Bronx convent, was taken off the critical list at Montefiore Hospital, a hospital spokesman said. Sister Margaret's vital signs continued to improve, the hospital spokesman said.

title: Japan-Soviet Loan Pact
description: The Export-Import Bank of Japan said today that it and 23 Japanese commercial banks had signed contracts to supply $206 million in loans to the Soviet Union and East Germany to finance industrial projects.

title: Japanese Trade Deficit
description: Japan posted a $1.06 billion current account deficit in November, according to a Government report, caused in part by a 4.6 percent decline in automobile exports and a sharp increase in overall imports.

title: 2 Troupes Get $25,000 Grants; 2 Stage Troupes Get $25,000 Grants
description: ''In recognition of their outstanding records in presenting classical and modern drama,'' the Exxon Corporation has awarded grants of $25,000 to two nonprofit theaters - the American Repertory Theater of Cambridge, Mass., and the Center Theater Group/ Mark Taper Forum of Los Angeles.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Barnwell Industries has elected to its board Daniel Jacobson, president of Page Mill Group Ltd.

title: Silicon Mystery Solved
description: Chemists have isolated and characterized a new silicon compound, a bright orange-yellow crystalline solid known as tetramesityldisilene. And in so doing they said that they solved a mystery that has puzzled scientists for more than half a century.

title: BOLIVIAN ART BANNED BY LA PAZ ON TOUR OF U.S.
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia THE east coast of South America has historically looked to Europe for its culture, while the west coast looks to the United States. Bolivia, landlocked in the center of the continent, has mostly had to look to itself.

title: AVALANCHES REVEAL THEIR INNER WORKINGS
description: ON a sunny morning in April 1967, Ron Perla found himself on ski patrol perched atop a block of snow, many hundreds of yards wide, that was itself perched above a long, slick ski run.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Savings-Loan Outflow Rises
description: American savers, no longer pouring money into ''All Savers'' certificates, withdrew $1.6 billion more than they deposited in savings and loan associations in November, the Government reported today.

title: MILITARY SPENDING'S DAMAGE TO THE ECONOMY
description: As President Reagan constructs the fiscal 1983 b udget, he should be aware that the Administration's military b uildup will severely damage the economy for decades. Many critics h ave discussed the short-term problems of increased spending on a rms, such as production bottlenecks in defense industries and l arge-scale Federal borrowing to finance militarization. But these f actors pale in comparison to the long-term damage inflicted by the d ecline in capital investment and the misdirection of technological g rowth that accompanies higher military spending.

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: ENVOY'S HOME AS KINDERGARTEN
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government Agency:

title: JURY SELECTION STARTS SLOWLY IN TRIAL ON ATLANTA MURDERS
description: Under heavy security, the tedious selection of jurors began today in the murder trial of Wayne B. Williams, who is accused of killing two of 28 young blacks, mostly children, abducted and slain here from mid-1979 to last May.

title: DESPITE RECESSION, STATE LOTTERIES NEAR RECORD OF $3.6 BILLION IN BETS
description: FOR 1981 By WINSTON WILLIAMS

title: THE LAYOFFS PINCH IN JERSEY
description: ''I took a job in March because our taxes and our bills were going up and up,'' said Carol Baran, who had been a housewife. ''My husband and I were scared about the economy, and afraid things would get worse.''

title: EDWIN H. KNOPF, 82, PRODUCER FOR M-G-M WHO MADE 23 FILMS
description: Edwin H. Knopf, a Hollywood film producer known for the 1953 musical ''Lili,'' died Sunday at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 82 years old.

title: Kennedy Grave Marker Replaced by First Cross
description: Arlington National Cemetery officials today replaced the redwood cross that was stolen from Robert F. Kennedy's grave with the pine cross that originally marked it.

title: NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Output of Steel Down by 9.8%
description: Steel production fell to 1.588 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 9.8 percent from the previous week's 1.760 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: STRICT FISCAL '82 BUDGET IS APPROVED BY JAPAN
description: The Japanese Government today approved its most austere national budget in 26 years. The action is intended to reduce the Government's sizable deficit and thus keep its 4 percent inflation rate in check. But the budget is not likely to stimulate domestic consumption, which officials have been hoping would grow enough to reduce trade surpluses and thus ease trade frictions with other nations.

title: WHEN A SPRAY PAINTER NEEDS A RESPIRATOR
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTERN UNION SETS XEROX UNIT ACCORD
description: The Western Union Corporation, in a move it said would help smooth its way into the international message communications business, announced yesterday that it had settled several legal disputes with a unit of the Xerox Corporation.

title: Market Nations Decide Against Poland Talks
description: Britain said today that the Foreign Ministers of the European Economic Community had decided not to hold a special emergency meeting about Poland Wednesday, as had been considered.

title: PLAY: LITHGOW IS 'KAUFMAN AT LARGE'
description: HAIRED and boyish, John Lithgow ambles on stage at the Phoenix Theater, introduces us to the world of George S. Kaufman, and jokes, ''His resemblance to me is absolutely uncanny.'' The lights dim, the actor goes offstage and he returns as - John Lithgow. In ''Kaufman at Large,'' a one-man play of his own devising, Mr. Lithgow has made an incalculable bit of miscasting. In looks, voice and manner, he resembles Kaufman about as much as Marlon Brando resembles George Bernard Shaw, or Clint Eastwood Truman Capote.

title: Prices Drop in Japan
description: Japan's consumer price index fell threetenths of 1 percent in November, to an unadjusted 106.2, after rising four-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Prime Minister's office said today. The index, from a 1980 base of 100, was up 3.6 percent from the November 1980 level, which was the smallest increase since a 3.1 percent gain from September 1980 to September 1981. November's decline was the first drop from the preceding month in three months.

title: No Headline
description: North Stars Tie Rockies

title: BRIEFS
description: * Circle K Corp. said it intended to purchase up to $3 million of common stock of Nucorp Energy Inc. on the open market but that changing market conditions had resulted in the cancellation of an agreement to purchase 150,000 shares of Nucorp stock at $20 a share.

title: U.S. Defends the Sale Of Arms to Taiwan
description: The State Department said today that a planned multimillion-dollar military sale to Taiwan was a routine transaction involving spare parts, and that no decision had been made on selling new fighter planes to the Chinese Nationalist regime there.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1981
description: International Sanctions against the Soviet Union for its role in the imposition of martial law in Poland are expected to be announced today by President Reagan, according to senior Administration officials. Mr. Reagan, at his California ranch, made decisions on what were described in Washington as ''measured steps'' against Moscow after receiving the recommendations of his advisers by phone. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Key Polish factories remained closed or were working at far below normal production on the first working day after the Christmas holidays, according to reports from Warsaw. Opposition to martial law was apparently persisting despite attempts by the military authorities to restore a sense of normality. (A1:4-5.)

title: CANADA'S GRAVELY DEFECTIVE NEW CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: 'HOLIDAY EFFECT' FOUND MORE BENIGN THAN DEPRESSING
description: THE enforced joy of this season, with extensive visiting among relatives and the evoked ghosts of Christmas past and auld lang syne, has long been blamed for rampant depression and an exaggerated number of attempted suicides. But a new report suggests that the ''holiday syndrome'' is not as widespread or serious as many people believe.

title: Dry-Land Pirates
description: Earlier this year the Cascade Mountain Tee Company in Kent, Wash., negotiated with the Tournament of Roses Association the first exclusive license to produce T-shirts, pennants and other merchandise related to the game. But William Taylor, Cascade's sales manager, says that getting the license was not as hard as protecting it.

title: Citicorp Lights 'Candle' In Response to Reagan
description: Among the more spectacular reactions to President Reagan's Wednesday night call for candles in the windows of America as a testiment of support for the people of Poland was that of Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citicorp, which led to full-page newspaper ads in which the architecturally acclaimed silver Citicorp Building was turned into a candle.

title: ECSTATIC GIANTS GET GOOD REPORT ON REECE INJURY
description: The Giants, ecstatic over their 27-21 upset of the Philadelphia Eagles Sunday in their first playoff game in 18 years, had only one concern today. Beasley Reece, their starting free safety, injured a knee, and after the game team physicians expressed fear that surgery would be required.

title: MAJOR AIRLINES MATCH NEW LOW FLORIDA FARE
description: Major airlines yesterday matched the sharply lower fares announced by Delta Air Lines last week in an effort to increase passenger traffic between Florida and major cities in the North and the Middle West.

title: The Bold Mr. Rouse
description: James Rouse has a knack for reviving moribund urban business districts.

title: The Insults Hurt
description: Any edge helps, and several Navy football players say they now have one for their meeting with Ohio State tomorrow night in the Liberty Bowl in Memphis. The players are upset over demeaning comments by the Buckeyes that have been appearing in print.

title: ON SOUTH AFRICAN FARMS, FUDAL ATTITUDES LINGER
description: When white South Africa boasts of a new ''labor dispensation'' for blacks there is an implied footnote that excludes one of the largest group of laborers: the 1.1 million black farmhands who work and normally live on white-owned farms for wages that are often so low as to leave them virtually outside the cash economy. The cash wages that an ordinary farm worker receives in this sheepfarming district of the Orange Free State seldom amount to more than $21 a month, which is about what an unskilled industrial worker near Johannesburg would expect to get for two daily shifts. What keeps him down on the farm is a combination of legal restraint, subsistence rations and the opportunity to live with his family, as no migrant laborer can.

title: FOR JAMAICA SAVINGS, DIFFERENT IS BETTER
description: Park T. Adikes, chairman of the Jamaica Savings Bank, is no ordinary banker. His attire - he wears a large silver chain draped over his tie and a wide belt buckle with a color picture of a duck flying over water - as well as his banking ideas have made him a maverick in the industry.

title: MUSICAL DEBUT
description: Since he graduated from the University of Chicago with a master's degree in business administration, Paul Streitz has been doing market research for advertising agencies. He wrote musical comedy on the side, and the more market research he did the more he decided he liked writing musical comedy.

title: Bergey Says He'll Quit Unless Knee Improves
description: Bill Bergey, the Philadelphia Eagles' veteran linebacker, said today he would retire unless the knee injury that kept him out this season showed drastic improvement.

title: QUIET CAPITAL:
description: A lone jogger taking an early-morning run along the Mall in Washington, the area where most of the Smithsonian Institution buildings are situated. The Washington Monument rises above the mist.

title: BRIEFING
description: W HEN the size of the Government shrinks, as it has been doing lately, the work of the Merit Systems Protection Board increases proportionately as laid-off Federal employees exercise their right to appeal. This time, however, the board finds itself shrinking with the rest of the Government. With its workload up dramatically and its budget down substantially, the board is short of funds even to pay for transcripts of the hearings it must hold on each case it decides. The budget cutback comes at a time when more than 11,000 air traffic controllers, dismissed by President Reagan for striking illegally, have flooded the board with their appeals, as have other Federal workers who have been tossed into unemployment lines by the Administration's austerity.

title: U.S. MAKES DECISION TO PUNISH RUSSIANS ON ROLE IN POLAND
description: The Reagan Administration decided today on economic and political sanctions against the Soviet Union for its role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.

title: TV'S GRIM NEWS
description: We live in the era of news-media overkill. It isn't enough to acknowledge the ubiquity of barbarism; we are forced to see it in color. Local television news assaults our sensibilities with graphic details of incinceration, rape, infanticide, gruesome murders, and every horror that the well-developed imagination of a masochist can conceive.

title: Brooklyn 75, Pratt 59 John Jay 81, New Paltz 77
description: Brooklyn, led by Dan Brown's 27 points, overcame an 8-point deficit midway in the first half en route to victory in its Kingsmen Christmas tournament. Pratt, without a victory, suffered its 10th loss; Brooklyn is 6-3. John Jay won its sixth straight game.

title: The Snack With a Prize in the Pack
description: ''I never expected to get it back this way,'' said Theodore H. Kelley, who finally retrieved his wallet in Indianapolis yesterday. It all started about three weeks ago when Mr. Kelley, a 26-yearold mechanic for the Chesty Food Division of the Snacktime Company, was working on a new potato-chip packing machine in the company's Terre Haute, Ind., plant.

title: Satellite Contract
description: The Western Union Corporation said it had awarded Arianespace, a French-based consortium of European space companies and agencies, a $22 million contract to launch Westar 6, Western Union's sixth domestic communications satellite. The company said the satellite, being built by the Hughes Aircraft Company, would be available for launching by Arianespace from Kourou, French Guiana, in December 1983.

title: SUBWAY KILLS MAINTENANCE WORKER IN QUEENS
description: A transit worker on a routine inspection of subway vents and drains was struck and killed on the tracks yesterday by a train pulling into the Continental Avenue station in Queens, the Transit Authority said.

title: Attempts to Kill Hares With Gas Stall in Idaho
description: Plans to exterminate jack rabbits in a trench serving as a makeshift gas chamber were jeopardized today when farmers said a mink-feed processor refused to accept any rabbits killed by carbon dioxide fumes.

title: Wife Reports That Sakharov Has Suffered Heart Flutters
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet dissident who recently carried out, with his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, a 17-day hunger strike to obtain an exit visa for a relative, has since suffered palpitations similar to a heart attack, Miss Bonner said today.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.9 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the nation's basic money supply fell $1.9 billion in the week ended Dec. 16, in line with the expectations of credit market analysts.

title: 'Kingdoms' Is Closed After 17 Performances
description: ''Kingdoms,'' Edward Sheehan's play about the conflict between Napoleon and Pope Pius VII during which Napoleon made the Pope a prisoner, closed Sunday after its matinee performance at the Cort Theater.

title: CITY COURTS ADMINISTRATOR NAMED AS STATE APPELLATE JUDGE BY CAREY
description: E. Leo Milonas, who has administered New York City's courts for two turbulent years, was named yesterday by Governor Carey to the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: McVAY ON OTHER SIDE OF FENCE
description: John McVay, who coached the Giants before Ray Perkins, is director of operations for the San Francisco 49ers, the next opponent for the Giants in Sunday's National Conference semifinal game at San Francisco.

title: When to Shelter a Murderer
description: Terrorism is playing havoc with the law of international extradition. Two current cases show the need for tightening America's rules for dealing with fugitives from criminal charges in another nation. In particular, they illustrate the need to curtail the role of American courts in an essentially diplomatic process.

title: Market Place; Index Funds For I.R.A.'s
description: A STOCK index fund may work well for Individual Retirement Accounts, particularly if the owner contemplates monthly contributions. These investment vehicles take an ''if you can't beat 'em, join 'em'' approach to market success through representative investments in each of the Standard & Poor's 500 stocks.

title: WALKER-SCOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
International Loans Up
description: Borrowing on international capital markets increased 53.5 percent, to $183.16 billion, from $119.35 billion in 1980, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.

title: Mail Carrier Found Dead On Arizona Reservation
description: The police on the Salt River Indian Reservation today found the body of a postal worker who was reported abducted over the weekend by at least seven men, women and children, the authorities said.

title: Tourism Dips In City in 1981
description: New York's tourist business was off a bit in 1981, the city's Convention and Visitors Bureau reported yesterday, with an estimated total of 17 million visitors, down from 17.1 million in 1980.

title: 'TEST-TUBE' BABY BORN IN U.S., JOINING SUCCESSES AROUND THE
description: WORLD By WALTER SULLIVAN

title: TV: EILEEN BRENNAN WINS POST AS WESTERN SHERIFF
description: GARY COOPER wasn't the first but he became the prototype of the gritty individualist riding into town to do battle with the bullies and outlaws. ''High Noon'' happened to be a classic of the form. Tonight at 9 o'clock, CBS-TV is offering an updated variation on the same theme. In this case, the hero rides into a Wyoming town in a car. But there is a more fundamental difference. The hero is a woman, being played by Eileen Brennan in a made-for-television movie called ''Incident at Crestridge.''

title: Miss Stough, With 17, Paces Syracuse Victory
description: Connie Stough scored 17 points and led Syracuse to an 83-78 victory over Georgetown in the opening round of the Big East Conference women's basketball tournament yesterday afternoon at St. John's University's Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Soviet to Top '81 Gas Goal
description: The Soviet Union will exceed its 1981 target for the production of natural gas, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

title: Mobil Studies Position in Bid
description: The Mobil Corpoation said yesterday that it was studying its options after losing a court battle last week. The ruling gave the United States Steel Corporation a clear edge in the fight between the two companies to gain control of the smaller Marathon Oil Company.

title: ARTIFICIAL SKIN GIVES BURN VICTIM 2D LEASE ON LIFE
description: In one horrifying moment last fall, Mark Walsh lost 40 pounds of flesh. An explosion flashed through an aerosol can factory and burned the skin off 80 percent of his body.

title: Champlin Wells
description: The Union Pacific Corporation's Champlin Petroleum Company subsidiary said an offshore well on Texas state block 4381, 10 miles off Matagorda County in the Gulf of Mexico, flowed four million cubic feet of natural gas a day from one zone and 1.6 million cubic feet from another from depths of 7,000 feet and 6,700 feet, respectively. Champlin owns a 50 percent interest in the well and TXO has the remainder.

title: A Mortal Kind of Illiteracy
description: In a nation proud of its low, and notably improved, infant mortality rate, it is shocking that a child born in Washington D.C. has less chance of surviving infancy than one born in any other American city or some poorer countries.

title: A New Charboneau?
description: Encouraged by a ''total self-improvement program'' that includes a positive attitude, a mended back and reduced weight, Joe Charboneau of the Cleveland Indians says he wishes the season could begin tomorrow. Charboneau, an outfielder who was the American League rookie of the year in 1980, suffered such a slump in hitting and attitude last season that he was demoted to the club's Triple-A affiliate in Charleston.

title: Legislator Slain in Iran; 3 Executed for Bomb Plot
description: A member of Iran's Parliament was assassinated and a revolutionary guard wounded today in a burst of gunfire from a passing car in Teheran, the official Iranian press agency Pars reported.

title: Dow Falls 3.04, to 870.34, in Dull Trading
description: Stock prices closed moderately lower yesterday in continued dull trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column all day, finished at 870.34, down 3.04.

title: IMMIGRATION SERVICE SAYS OVER 100 FLED FROM HAITIAN CAMP
description: The Federal authorities barred all visitors from a Miami detention facility holding Haitian refugees today and brought in additional security guards after a stone-@ and bottle-throwing incident yesterday in which 110 men escaped from the compound.

title: Machine Tool Orders Down
description: Machine tool orders, an indicator of capital investment by the nation's durable goods industries, fell 10 percent in November from a month earlier, the industry's trade organization said.

title: ITALIANS UNSURE WHETHER PHOTO OF U.S. GENERAL IS A COMPOSITE
description: Italian police experts withheld judgment today on whether the photograph of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier distributed by his abductors yesterday was a composite and possibly retouched picture taken some time ago.

title: COLDWELL HOLDERS APPROVE SEARS PACT
description: Coldwell, Banker & Company said its shareholders voted overwhelmingly today to approve the $215 million acquisition of their company by Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: German Prices Rise
description: The West German cost of living index rose a provisional three-tenths of 1 percent in December after increasing by five-tenths of 1 percent in November, the federal statistics office said today. The index, from a base in 1976, was 6.3 percent above the December 1980 rate after having risen 6.6 percent in November from November 1980. The average increase in the cost of living index for the year was a provisional 5.9 percent from 1980 after a 5.5 percent gain in 1980 over 1979, the statistics office added.

title: ENERGY AGENCY'S LONGER VIEW
description: What does an agency charged with dealing with energy problems do when the only apparent problem is a lack of conviction that a problem exists?

title: OF JEWISH IDENTITY AND RELIGIOUS LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: PACERS SET BACK NETS, 103-95
description: With a surge that gave them a 13-point lead over the Indiana Pacers early in the fourth quarter tonight, the New Jersey Nets were looking like the team that won four straight games last week. Then, just as quickly, they reverted to the form that lost them 10 of their first 12 games this season.

title: CITY CONSTRUCTION PROGRAM IS FALLING BEHIND SCHEDULE
description: New York City is lagging in its capital construction program, with contracts awarded in the first five months of the 1982 fiscal year totaling far less than had been originally planned, according to figures made available by the City Comptroller's office yesterday.

title: Coal Output Record Seen
description: Domestic production, consumption and exports of coal will reach record levels in 1982, the coal industry's trade organization predicted today.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $168,000 for the qr and $220,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including $214,000 tax credit

title: Jules Berman Returns To Liquor Business
description: Jules Berman spent more than 30 years in the liquor business, most of them as a distributor and importer, before he sold his Los Angeles-based distributorship to Hiram Walker Ltd. in 1965 for $8 million.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE SOVIET UNION, in an unintentional program of aid to the United States, has been adding to this country's supply of top-level mathematicians.

title: U.S. REPORTS A RISE IN FARMS
description: The number of farms in the United States increased this year for the first time since the Depression, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: TELEVISION LIBRARY OF JUDAISM IS BEING ESTABLISHED
description: The Union of American Hebrew Congregations will announce today that it is establishing in New York City a $25 million ''television library of Judaism,'' the first of its kind in the world.

title: Swiss Ending Tax on Gold
description: Switzerland is removing a sales tax on gold purchased by central banks, beginning Jan.1, a Finance Ministry spokesman said today.

title: A NEW CENTRAL AMERICAN NATION OF PROMISE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: LETTER FROM BEGIN ASSURES MUBARAK ON SINAI'S RETURN

title: Q&A
description: Q. What causes some people to have allergies?

title: THE SUN BELT AND THE FROST BELT
description: The new conventional wisdom holds that Frost Belt cities of the Northeast and north-central regions are on the decline and that the Sun Belt cities of the South and Southwest are prospering. Increased sectional conflict, Congressional squabbling based on these perceptions, and breakup of the national consensus to use Federal resources to assist in solving urban problems has resulted.

title: EFFORTS BEGUN TO REMOVE OIL NEAR WESTCHESTER RESERVOIR
description: A scavenging company began pumping a thick brown layer of heating oil from the Muscoot River in northern Westchester today to prevent any possible contamination of New York City's drinking water.

title: N. CAROLINA WINS IN OVERTIME
description: Sam Perkins hit two free-throws in the last six seconds to assure top-ranked North Carolina a hardfought 56-50 overtime victory over Penn State tonight in the Cable Car Classic basketball tournament.

title: PEKING IS RE-EXAMINING ROLE OF THE ARTS
description: A writer whose filmscript touched off an ideological debate this year over the Communist Party's relationship to post-Maoist Chinese literature, has publicly apologized for the ''flaws'' in his work and thanked his critics for having pointed them out.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENT OF FORMER POLISH ENVOY
description: Following are excerpts from a statement given today by Zdzislaw Rurarz, the former Polish Ambassador to Japan, to the United States Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe:

title: Arguello of Argentina Captures Junior Tennis
description: Top-seeded Roberto Arguello of Argentina defeated Renato Joaquim of Brazil, 6-2, 6-1, today to win the Boys 18 division of the 35th annual Orange Bowl world junior tennis championships.

title: A LOW-KEY ENDING FOR JETS' HIGH HOPES
description: Reluctantly, as if not wanting to leave a party, the Jet players packed their gear today. John Roman folded a green Jet shirt a fan had given him prematurely. It read, ''Jets Super Bowl XVI.'' ''I'll have to change it to 'Super Bowl 17' for next year,'' Roman said. ''I won't be wearing it this time.'' He and his teammates were packing because their 31-27 loss Sunday to Buffalo knocked them out of the playoffs and sent the Bills to the next round at Cincinnati.

title: THE GOOD NEWS ABOUT INDIAN POINT 2
description: To the Editor:

title: PANEL IN 'FREEWAY MURDERS' ENDS 1ST DAY OF DELIBERATIONS
description: A jury began deliberations today on murder charges against William Bonin, who was accused of killing 12 men and boys and dumping their nude bodies near freeways in this area.

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Yields of New Bills Advance; 6-Month Rate Set at 12.45%
description: Rates continued to climb at yesterday's Treasury auction of threeand six-month bills. The average yield on three-month bills jumped to 11.690 percent from 11.037 a week ago, while the rate on the companion six-month bills advanced to 12.45 percent from 11.84 percent.

title: E.P.A. TO STUDY WATER POLLUTION IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday that $500,000 had been allocated for a six-month study to determine how best to protect Atlantic City's drinking water from toxic chemicals dumped into a landfill a decade ago.

title: TANNER UPSET BY FRAWLEY
description: Third-seeded Roscoe Tanner blew a two-set lead and was toppled by Rod Frawley in the $400,000 Australian Open tennis championships today. Peter McNamara, seeded second, narrowly avoided elimination by Richard Lewis,

title: DAVID NEIDITZ, COMMISSIONER OF BANKING IN CONNECTICUT, 51
description: David H. Neiditz, the State Banking Commissioner and a former State Senator, was found dead this morning in a parking lot near his office. He was 51 years old.

title: New Kentucky Coach Appoints 5 Assistants
description: Jerry Claiborne, the new football coach at Kentucky, said today that he would bring five of his assistants from Maryland with him.

title: U.C.L.A.'s Pruitt Quits;
description: Coach Larry Farmer said today that Cliff Pruitt, junior forward, had left the U.C.L.A. basketball team for personal reasons.

title: DR. MURIEL ROGER, 59, STUDIED STRUCTURE OF DNA MOLECULES
description: Dr. Muriel Roger, a molecular biologist who was senior research associate at Rockefeller University in Manhattan, died Dec. 24 at her home in Bayville, L.I. She was 59 years old.

title: Bodies of 2 Teen-Agers Found in Rural Geogia
description: Parents in this small town are frightened by similarities in the slayings of two teen-age girls whose bodies were found tied with wire, even though the authorities are divided over whether the cases are connected.

title: Naming a Fe/male
description: As a reward for donating $1 million to the New York Zoological Society's Animal Kingdom Fund, Enid A. Haupt, the philanthropist and former magazine publisher, was given the honor of naming the polar bear cub that was born at the Bronx Zoo earlier this month.

title: 45 Leftists Held in Turkey
description: Security forces have arrested 45 people in Kayseri Province said to belong to Revolutionary Path, an outlawed leftist organization, officials said today.

title: Executive Named At Mitsubishi U.S.
description: Richard D. Recchia, 42 years old, has been named executive vice president and chief operating officer of Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc., formed this month as the distributing arm of Mitsubishi Motors of Japan.

title: NAVY ISSUES NEW BRIG RULES BARRING ABUSIVE TREATMENT
description: The Navy will strengthen the staffing of its brigs and it plans to reopen shipboard ''correctional custody units'' that were closed in May after the death of a sailor on a Pacific Fleet carrier.

title: AFGHAN CITY BRISTLES WITH GUNS AND RESENTMENT
description: The doorman at the Khyber Restaurant barred the way of a visitor and muttered ''talashi,'' which means search. As he expertly frisked the arrival, none of the other diners bothered to look. Such searches go on all the time at hotels, movie houses and government offices and the word ''talashi'' has become almost as common a greeting as ''hello.''

title: FANS WELCOME BILLS
description: About 2,000 Buffalo Bills fans waited Sunday night in cold and drizzle near Greater Buffalo International Airport for the team to arrive from New York after its playoff victory over the Jets.

title: Venezuelan Oil Output
description: Crude oil production in Venezuela averaged 2,097,000 barrels a day through Dec. 21 this year, a 3.28 percent decline from an average of 2,168,000 barrels a day for the comparable 1980 period, the Energy and Mines Ministry said in its latest weekly newsletter released today. Average daily production during the week ended Dec. 21 was 2,277,000, a decrease of 1,000 barrels a day from with the 2,278,000 barrels a day output the week before, the newsletter said. Exports of crude and refined products averaged 1,750,000 barrels a day through Dec. 16, a decline of 86,000 barrels a day, or 4.68 percent, from the 1980 average of 1,836,000 barrels a day, the newsletter said.

title: Conrail Sued on Severed Leg
description: A 13-year-old Bronx boy whose left leg was severed by a train last month as he was playing on Conrail tracks sued the rail company yesterday for $13 million. Legal papers filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan charged that the boy, Elpidio Camacho, who was 12 at the time of the accident on Nov. 6, had been ''rendered sick, sore, lame and disabled'' because of Conrail's negligence.

title: PROFESSOR OF ECONOMICS
description: Dr. Ernest M. Fisher, professor emeritus of urban land economics at Columbia University, died Saturday at Englewood Hospital in Englewood, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Leonia, N.J.

title: EX-ENVOY SAYS MARTIAL LAW WAS PLANNED SINCE MARCH
description: Poland's former Ambassador to Japan, who defected to the United States last week, said today that Poland, under pressure from Moscow, had been preparing for martial law since last March.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER SUES TO REGAIN WORKS
description: IN an action that has attracted widespread attention in black artistic circles, James Van Der Zee, the renowned 95-year-old photographer who with his camera pictorially chronicled people in Harlem for more than 60 years, is suing one of the nation's leading black cultural institutions, the Studio Museum in Harlem. His purpose is to regain possession of his collection of 125,000 prints, negatives, plates and transparencies, now held by the museum.

title: Boston Port Ferry Proposed
description: The Massachusetts Port Authority is considering a ferry service across Boston Harbor to Logan International Airport. But, a study forecast, the ferry would lose $810,000 to $960,000 a year and carry only 2 percent of the airport's 54,000 daily travelers. It would connect two projects the authority has under way: Boston's Commonwealth Pier and Bird Island Flats, an air cargo site at the airport.

title: ST. JOHN'S, VILLANOVA TRIUMPH
description: Since 1952, when Madison Square Garden was still on Eighth Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets and eight teams gathered for a Christmas-time tournament, it has been called the Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival. Last night, St. John's and Villanova, the two teams that seemed more likely to meet in the consolation game, gave the 30th Festival championship a new name.

title: COACHES TOLD TO HIDE FUNDS, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: Athletic Director David H. Strack told University of Arizona coaches to find ''their own bag men'' so money from a slush fund could not be traced, according to an allegation in documents released today.

title: ELDERLY ARE GIVEN ASSISTANCE IN DONATIONS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Older people, whose age may account for their infirmities, loneliness or economic difficulties, are often designated as the preferred recipients of gifts made by contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund during the holiday season.

title: Fire on Ship Traced To Fuel on Hot Pipe
description: The engine room fire aboard the Norway did $750,000 damage to the world's largest cruise ship and was apparently started by diesel fuel spilling onto a hot steam pipe, fire officials said today.

title: Bold Start in the Caribbean
description: Secretary Haig can always get a headline when he growls at Cuba or Nicaragua, but he has won little more than a yawn with his program for Caribbean development. In proposing favored treatment for a single region, he is looking beyond the guerrilla skirmishes of the day to preventing blazes a decade hence, and that rates more than a yawn. Much depends on the details, still to come, but in the meantime it appears to be a genuinely bold start.

title: Iraqi Talks On Pipeline
description: Iraq, its crude oil exports slashed by about 75 percent since war broke out with Iran, expects an agreement with Saudi Arabia on a new pipeline to increase exports, its deputy oil minister was quoted as saying today.

title: A SYMBOL, NOT A SWORD
description: Critics are deriding President Reagan's ''candle in the window'' for the Polish people, much as last year they mocked President Carter for refusing to light the White House Christmas tree after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. But it's a wise man who knows when to use a symbol instead of a sword.

title: DANCE: SOME OLD TRICKS REVIVED BY PILOBOLUS
description: THE Pilobolus Dance Theater was up to its old tricks again Sunday night at the ANTA Theater, when it offered a sampling of works from its repertory. These collaboratively choreographed pieces gave a good indication of why Pilobolus is so special. And they also suggested what some of the company's choreographic problems are.

title: RANCHER PRESIDENT:
description: President Reagan boarding a helicopter in Beverly Hills, Calif., for a daylong visit to his ranch near Santa Barbara. The President carries a shillelagh, an Irish walking stick, given to him recently by Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. Nancy Reagan remained in Los Angeles while the President went to the 630-acre ranch.

title: Japan Curbs U.S. Flights
description: Japan, which has long asserted that there are ''gross inequalities'' in its aviation pact with the United States, announced sanctions against United States airlines today in response to American restrictions on its flag carrier.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MERRILL FEE IS FAIR, COURT SAYS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the investment advisory fees charged by Merrill Lynch Asset Management Inc., which manages the world's largest money market mutual fund, were not excessive, no matter how profitable they might have been.
