title: Robbery May Be Motive In Slaying of Priest
description: Robbery is the suspected motive in the death by beating of a Roman Catholic priest whose nude body was found in an Odessa, Tex,, motel room, the police in Odessa said today.

title: WORLD'S MONEY UP $207 BILLION
description: The world money supply rose by some $207 billion in 1981 - the smallest increase in 11 years - and worldwide inflation began falling as many countries pursued tightmoney policies, the Bank of America reported today.

title: TURKEY'S KERCHIEF BAN RAISES OUTCRY
description: Turkey's military rulers, in a move to curb the revival of Islamic fundamentalism, have imposed a ban on the wearing of head kerchiefs by female students and teachers in schools.

title: 6 Writers Named To Intar Program
description: Six Spanish-speaking writers have been named for the four-year playwright-in-residence program sponsored by International Arts Relations, Intar, and supported by a $149,974 Ford Foundation grant.

title: SWISS BANKER SEES POLISH DEBT DELAY
description: In an apparent indication that Poland will miss a year-end deadline for paying $500 million in interest on pastdue loans, a Western banking spokesman said today that signing a new loan-repayment pact before New Year's Day was ''out of the question.''

title: Books: Satiric Art
description: MAN BITES MAN: TWO DECADES OF SATIRIC ART. Edited by Steven Heller. A&W Publishers. 224 pages. $29.95 until Jan. 1; $35 thereafter.

title: No Headline
description: Idaho 71, Oregon State 49

title: Talking Business with Westergaard of Equity Research; Selecting New Growth Stocks
description: Emerging growth companies, especially those involved in high technology, are increasingly attracting the attention of those buyers of stocks willing to invest time as well as money. The leading tracker of these often dynamic issues is John Westergaard, editor and publisher of the Equity Research Associates investment service.

title: ASAIN INVESTORS BATTLE FOR FOOTHOLDS IN CHINATOWN
description: Behind its vegetable stands, restaurants and sooty facades, Chinatown has become a battleground for investors from Hong Kong, Taiwan and southeastern Asia. The surge in Asian foreign investment, beginning three years ago, has pushed Chinatown far beyond its traditional boundaries - into the Lower East Side and far north to Houston Street - and has turned its once placid business climate fiercely competitive.

title: Master Planning; Containing Congress
description: Neither efficiency nor art has slowed down the proliferation of solid marble turkeys on Capitol Hill. The logic that has been lacking in this random expansion is about to be supplied by a master plan prepared for Congressional approval by the Architect of the Capitol.

title: PACKERS GIVE STARR NEW 2-YEAR PACT
description: Bart Starr, whose Green Bay Packers won six of their last eight games, survived nearly three years of controversy about his job status and was given a new two-year contract today.

title: BRITISH LEGAL DEBATE: PREMENSTRUAL TENSION AND CRIMINAL BEHAVIOR
description: Last month, two women walked free from British criminal courts after having killed or threatened to kill. They were released after pleading that premenstrual tension had made them act out of character.

title: COUNCIL WOES PUT MAJORITY LEADER INTO THE SPOTLIGHT
description: By all accounts, these are hard times for New York's City Council. By some accounts, the person primarily responsible is Thomas J. Cuite.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GOOD LOOKERS

title: COOPER-JARRETT FILES IN BANKRUPTCY COURT
description: Trucking deregulation and two recessions have finally taken their toll on Cooper-Jarrett Inc., a small New Jersey-based trucking company.

title: Widener 88, Upsala 83
description: Led by Lou DeRogatis, a junior guard who scored 38 points, unbeaten Widener College captured its opening-round game in the Yule Cup Classic by downing previously unbeaten Upsala in overtime.

title: ISRAEL AND THE HEIGHTS
description: The Golan Heights is especially significant to Israelis. In contrast to their attitudes toward the West Bank, which involve considerations of security mingled with historical attachments and avowals of a supposed divine right of possession, their sensitivity toward the Heights stems from security considerations alone.

title: Danish Trade Deficit
description: Denmark's imports exceed its exports by $93.3 million in November, a slim improvement over its October trade deficit of $93.5 million. The country's trade deficit in November 1980 was $69.2 million.

title: Bridge: McKenney Trophy Winner Still Remains to Be Settled
description: Nearly all the prestigious bridge trophies are won by teams or partnerships. A notable exception is the McKenney, which goes to the player winning the most master points in a calendar year. The winner is usually obvious by December, but this year there is a battle.

title: KEY POLISH FACTORIES STAY CLOSED DESPITE EFFORT TO RESTORE INDUSTRY
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: North Korea War Games A Surprise, U.S. Says
description: North Korea staged large-scale war games without advance warning this month, prompting the United States to send warships steaming toward the Korean peninsula, it was reported today.

title: 'Duet' Closing Saturday
description: ''Duet for One'' by Tom Kempinski, starring Anne Bancroft and Max von Sydow, will close Saturday night at the Royale Theater. Directed by William Friedkin, the drama, about a violinist and the psychiatrist whose help she seeks, will have given 20 performances and 12 previews. It was produced by Emmanuel Azenberg, Ray Cooney, Wayne M. Rogers, Ron Dante, Tommy Valando and Warner Theater Productions.

title: EX-SOILDER IS DENIED DAMAGES FOR ARMY LSD EXPERIMENTS IN 1957
description: A former soldier who contended that Army LSD experiments in 1957 had made him mentally ill is not entitled to damages, a judge ruled today.

title: CARDINAL COOKE'S ERROR ON NUCLEAR DETERRENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: FOUR VETERANS DEFEND VISIT TO VIETNAM
description: Four American veterans of the Indochina war, back in New York from a six-day visit to Vietnam, defended their trip yesterday against charges that they had served Vietnamese propaganda purposes.

title: National Steel Cancels Shipyard
description: The West Coast's largest shipbuilder, the National Steel and Shipbuilding Company, has canceled plans for a second shipyard that would have created an estimated total of 2,000 jobs and an annual payroll of $80 million.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Polish drama which is unfolding before your eyes is not - I emphasize not - of the Polish making, although co-engineered and executed by Polish puppets.

title: Pay Cut Is Urged For Transit Chiefs
description: Assemblyman G. Oliver Koppell called for a rollback of salary increases for 80 top Transit Authority executives whose salaries have been raised an average of 33 percent since 1979.

title: ONCE MORE FOR MAYOR
description: There will be a private ceremony several hours before, mulled wine immediately afterward, and - in between - short speeches. Or so is the promise.

title: EDUCATOR LED 4 UNIVERSITIES
description: George D. Stoddard, a former Commissioner of Education in New York State who headed major universities in New York and Illinois, died last evening at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

title: IN HARSH PATAGONIA, MODERN BIOLOGISTS HAVE FOUND PARADISE
description: often howls - most of the year round. On its eastern edge, the desert drops abruptly into the South Atlantic Ocean in a line of forbidding cliffs and steep shingle beaches.

title: Deficit Called Inflationary
description: Federal deficits do cause inflation, even if the Federal Reserve adheres to a tight monetary policy, Henry Wallich, a Federal Reserve governor, said today,

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Michiko Kakutani THE RETURN TO CAMELOT. Chivalry and the English Gentleman. By Mark Girouard. 312 pages. Yale University Press. $35.

title: Stevens to Shut Textile Plant
description: As part of its consolidation program, J.P. Stevens & Company said that it would close its Taylor, S.C., No.1 plant early next year.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income including tax credits of $363,000 for the qr and $2,796,000 for the yr and $865,000 charge for the yr for idle plant costs...C-After $375,000 charge for idle plant costs

title: Anaconda Sets Layoffs in Butte
description: The Anaconda Copper Company, a unit of the Atlantic Richfield Company, said that it would lay off 200 employees here, effective Jan. 3, as part of a continuing retrenchment to keep the Berkeley Pit copper mine in production.

title: Noranda to Test For Cobalt Deposit
description: Noranda Exploration Inc. of Denver has been given permission to make test borings for cobalt at 10 sites in a watershed area in Baltimore County, Md.

title: Chess: 17th American Open Goes To DeFirmian and Watson
description: Nick DeFirmian, an international master, and John Watson tied for first in the 17th annual American Open Tournament in Los Angeles with scores of 7-1. Each was awarded $1,250.

title: ARMY IS IN CONTROL IN POLAND BUT PARTY IS NOT COUNTED OUT
description: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Normal communications with The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, John Darnton, have been barred by authorities there since Dec. 14.

title: Japan's Video Exports
description: The Japan Electronic Industries Association said today that Japan's export of videotape recorders soared 101.1 percent in November from a year ago because of brisk shipments to the United States and European countries.

title: BLACK JUDGE IN ALABAMA WINS STAFF SALARY CASE
description: A Federal judge has ordered an Alabama county to pay salaries to the staff of its first black probate judge, continuing a practice that, in violation of state law, had been in use for more than two decades. The order is based on a rarely tested provision of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Broadcaster in Trouble
description: On-the-air comments at an Evansville basketball game have meant trouble for Larry Calton, a sports broadcaster. Calton has been broadcasting Evansville games for three years, during which he has gained a reputation for baiting referees.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: W HAT kind of year was it for fashion? It was the year men gave up mustaches, the year leopard prints returned, the year of Calvin Klein, the year we almost drowned in a sea of Lurex, the year Norma Kamali gave sweatshirts mass fashion appeal and the year the White House set a fashion standard for the first time in nearly two decades.

title: Journalist Gets Labor Post
description: Murray Seeger, a reporter for The Los Angeles Times has been appointed to the top public information post in the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Lane Kirkland, president of the labor federation, announced today.

title: N. CAROLINA WINS, 31-27, IN FOGBOUND GATOR BOWL
description: Ethan Horton and Rod Elkins capped long North Carolina drives through a dense fog with 1-yard touchdown runs in the third period, lifting the Tar Heels to a 31-27 victory over Arkansas in the Gator Bowl tonight.

title: POLAND SAYS LAST MINE IS WINDING UP SIT IN
description: The Warsaw radio said today that workers at the Piast coal mine in southern Poland were ending a strike described as the last major protest against martial law.

title: 'VOICE' SAYS PROGRAMS FOR POLES ARE JAMMED
description: Officials said the Polish Government had not interfered with Voice of America broadcasts since the Poznan riots in 1956, but the Soviet Union continued to jam the signal on occasion until 1963. Broadcast officials were unable to determine who was responsible for the interference this time.

title: W.R. Grace Stake
description: Friedrick Flick Industries of Dusseldorf, West Germany, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it now owned 12.9 million shares, or 27 percent, of the common stock of W.R. Grace & Company. Flick, the largest holder of Grace shares, said the total included 447,100 shares acquired between Oct. 30 and Dec. 21 at about $45 a share.

title: Long Island Schoolboy Wins 440, Long Jump
description: Ron Bloomberg of Half Hollow Hills High School on Long Island won the 440-yard dash in 50.69 seconds and the long jump at 22 feet 9 3/4 inches today in the indoor Christmas City Relays at Lehigh University.

title: 'Strategy of Indifference'
description: Prof. James Tobin, recipient of the 1981 Nobel Prize for Economics, in ''Democrats Today'': The Administration is ready enough to liberalize or discontinue regulations of business when opposing values are consumer protection or environmental conservation. It is by no means so devoted to market freedom, competition and consumer interests as to challenge important business, labor and farm constituencies. These politically sacred cows have been around a long time, and no other administrations have mustered the will or power to kill them either. But an administration that claims a popular mandate for counter-revolution should not leave unscathed the most objectionable features of the old order.

title: LOBBYIST PUTS COUNTIES BACK ON MAP OF POLITICS
description: ''County officials,'' says Bernard F. Hillenbrand, ''are like litmus paper. When the public turns sour, they turn blue.''

title: A STALLED TRAIN DELAYS 75,000 ON THE L.I.R.R.
description: More than 75,000 riders of the Long Island Rail Road - the line's entire evening rush-hour crowd that passes through Pennsylvania Station - met delays yesterday after a train carrying 700 people broke down and was stranded for much of the afternoon in a tunnel under the East River.

title: Storms Cause 10 Deaths And Close Ski Resorts
description: By The Associated Press At least 10 deaths have been attributed to snowstorms that dumped two feet of fresh snow across the Rocky Mountains yesterday and sent cars and trucks spinning into ditches across the Middle West.

title: Kuwaiti Oil Search Plan
description: The Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, which spent almost $100 million to acquire leases in nine countries this year, plans a substantial increase in international oil exploration activities, a petroleum newsletter said yesterday.

title: Japan Market For Arkansas
description: Arkansas is finding a growing market for its poultry products in Japan, where poultry consumption has increased 10 times in the past 20 years.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, DECEMBER 29, 1981 Markets

title: Sports of The Times; GIANT FANS PROUD OF 1978 PROTEST
description: THEY weren't terrorists. They hadn't hijacked the plane, merely rented it. And that small plane didn't have any explosives, only a sign fluttering behind it that complained, ''15 Years of Lousy Football....We've Had Enough.'' But that protest by a group of Giants fans three years ago was explosive enough to contribute to the changes that now have the Giants only two victories from Super Bowl XVI.

title: TEACHERS ADJUST SCHOOLING TO FIT STUDENTS' INDIVIDUALITY
description: MOST American schools organize their teaching around books, encourage silence and look askance at the thought of a student dipping into his lunch box for a snack while struggling with the multiplication tables.

title: PREVENTTIVE DETENTION URGED BY BAR GROUP TO CURB CRIME
description: A private legal group sponsored by the American Bar Association has called for preventive detention of a person charged with a violent crime if, after a full hearing, it is found that the person is a danger to the community.

title: MODERN ROMANCE
description: Yesterday was the first wedding anniversary for Alvin and Suzanne Maas, whose romance began in the classified advertisements. Last year Mr. Maas, the president of a California hotel company who had been frustrated in his attempts to find a wife, inserted a personal ad in The San Jose Mercury and News.

title: U.S. CHALLENGES FASHION WORLD
description: Perhaps the most dramatic development in fashion in the past year is the growing acceptance of American designers on the world fashion stage.

title: ENERGY DEPT,'S BACKERS CROSS IDEOLOGICAL LINES
description: At first glance, President Reagan's recent decision to abolish the Department of Energy seemed simple political fare: the fulfillment of another campaign promise.

title: William E. Sauro Koch and Long Island Leaders Press State for Medicaid Assistance Mayor Koch meeting yesterday in Mineola, L.I., with Francis T.  Purcell, left, and Peter F. Cohalan, the Nassau and Suffolk County Executives. They urged Republicans in the State Senate to approve at least a partial state takeover of local Medicaid costs to relieve ''the enormous burden'' on taxpayers in the city and suburbs.
description: Governor Carey proposed a full state takeover, but the Republican State Senate majority refused to consider it.

title: BUDGET IS VOTED FOR WESTCHESTER WITH TAX RISES
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators approved tonight a $471.8 million budget for 1982 that increases county property taxes by 17 percent and raises the sales tax by 0.5 percent effective July 1. The budget vote was 14 to 1.

title: BUSINESS REACTS TO MOVES CAUTIOUSLY
description: Reacting cautiously to President Reagan's economic sanctions against the Soviet Union, American business executives urged the Federal Government yesterday to obtain the backing of its allies so that Moscow could not substitute foreign for American suppliers.

title: LAWYER NAMED U.S. PROSECUTOR IN DONOVAN CASE
description: A New York City lawyer, Leon Silverman, was appointed yesterday as special prosecutor to investigate allegations of corruption against Raymond J. Donovan, the Secretary of Labor.

title: Cards Souring on Smith
description: Whitey Herzog, the general manager and field manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, appears ready to give up on signing Ozzie Smith because Smith, San Diego's all-star shortstop, wants more money than Herzog wants to pay. After a six-hour conference in San Diego with Smith and his agent, Ed Gottlieb, Herzog said: ''Ozzie is a great fielder and baserunner.

title: ONOMASTICS' BIG NAMES AT MEETING ON LANGUAGE
description: What's in a name? If you're an onomastic, a great deal. So every day this week several dozen onomastics have been gathering in the Red Smith Suite at the New York Hilton Hotel to hear the latest word on topics ranging from the origins of Mexican-American first names to the literary significance of the appellations of the characters in Eudora Welty novels.

title: POLAND ANNOUNCES SHARP PRICE RISES
description: Poland's military Government announced today that sharply increased prices for raw materials, energy and transportation would be introduced on New Year's Day.

title: An Almanac For 1982
description: JANUARY: Cold and stormy weather ahead in '82. Unemployment up for the ''truly needy,'' and even yacht sales down for the ''truly greedy.''

title: Finn Admits 'Tanking'
description: Kaarlo Maaninka, the Finnish long-distance runner, acknowledged he had received blood transfusions before the 1980 Olympics in Moscow, but said they had no bearing on his winning the silver medal in the 10,000-meter race and the bronze in the 5,000 meters. Maaninka, who is 28, told the Finnish magazine Hymy: ''I trained hard for two and a half months in the mountains.

title: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Farrell of Holy Trinity Wins Mile at Bethlelem
description: Kevin Farrell of Holy Trinity High School in Hicksville, L.I., won the one-mile run in 4 minutes 22.4 seconds today as the Christmas City Relays ended two days of competition at the Lehigh University field house.

title: REAGAN WILL SEEK MEDICAID CHARGE
description: President Reagan wants Congress to authorize a modest charge for medical care given to poor people under the Medicaid program and has also decided to seek further reductions in the Federal subsidy for school lunches.

title: CALLS FOR SUBWAY SERVICE CUTS RISE AS SYSTEM CONTINUES TO LIMP ALONG
description: Tacked above John D. Simpson's desk at the Transit Authority is a map of the New York City subway system streaked with reds, yellows and greens. Red signifies an underused subway line; yellow, a line with average ridership and green, a heavily used line.

title: Donny Osmond to Star in a Cohan Musical
description: When he was 5, he made his television debut on ''The Andy Williams Show.'' And at age 17, with his sister, Marie, he became the youngest host in television history to headline a weekly one-hour comedy variety series. Today, at the age of 24, with 19 years of show business behind him, Donny Osmond is embarking on what he says is his most exciting challenge yet - the Broadway theater.

title: MOBIL BIDS HIGH COURT BLOCK RIVAL
description: In a last-ditch effort to block the United States Steel Corporation from purchasing the Marathon Oil Company, the Mobil Corporation yesterday asked the United States Supreme Court to halt the acquisition until the High Court acted on an appeal of an antitrust injunction against Mobil.

title: BLACK-EYED PEAS FOR A PARIS NEW YEAR'S
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor is a culinary historian, poet and writer. By VERTAMAE SMART-GROSVENOR

title: RADIOPHONES SHOULD NOT BE MAINLY A.T.& T.'S
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. JUDGE, LAWYER, INDICTED IN BRIBES
description: A Federal district judge here, Alcee Hastings, and a prominent Washington lawyer, William A. Borders Jr., were indicted today on charges of bribery-conspiracy and obstruction of justice.

title: Nuggets 128, Celtics 123
description: DENVER (AP) - Alex English, who scored 10 of his 32 points in the fourth period, connected on two free throws with 10 seconds remaining to secure the victory.

title: Affirmative, at Least for Some Action
description: President Reagan apparently still opposes Government-imposed hiring goals and timetables, but his tolerance toward voluntary agreements is a welcome departure from past Administration hostility to affirmative action in any form.

title: Harold Weill, Lawyer And Business Adviser
description: Harold Weill, senior partner of the law firm of Leon, Weill & Mahony of Manhattan, died suddenly yesterday at his office at 405 Lexington Avenue. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Index; International
description: A Reporter's Notebook: Cold and madness in Siberia A2 U.S. praises Japan's decision to increase its military spending A3 Percy meets Begin and predicts better U.S. ties with Israel A3 Entire defense team in Egypt's assassination trial withdraws A3 Around the World A5 Text of Reagan's announcement of sanctions against Soviet A6 The Polish airwaves: Warsaw re- sponds to Reagan A7 Government/Politics Conservative Party leaders back Lehrman for Governor B1 State imposes cost controls on its agencies B3 State takeover of local probation costs urged by Fink B3 U.S. judge upholds Illinois town's ban on all handguns D16 F.B.I. chief reports rise in terror- ist incidents in year D16 Washington Talk Reagan team on Capitol Hill is key to legislative successes B8 Briefing B8 Jennings Randolph recalls the heady days of the New Deal B8 Newsletters provide fixes for political junkies B8 Energy Oil union officials reject contract offers from 3 companies A12 City officials say reservoir oil spill under control B2 General Around the Nation A10 Year of Handicapped was a year of setbacks for disabled A10 Haitians in Miami detention end their hunger strike A12 Bronx girl who was knifed is recu- perating after surgery B5 Teen-age hunter kills himself after wounding his friend D16 The Living Section Food New York, the New Year and old delights C1

title: A MARXIST THEORETICIAN
description: Murry Weiss, a Marxist theoretician and organizer, died Saturday in Doctors Hospital after a stroke. He was 66 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE RULES ILLINOIS TOWN'S BAN ON PISTOLS IS CONSTITUTIONAL
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the city of Morton Grove did not violate the state or Federal constitutions when it banned the sale and possession of handguns, thus upholding the nation's toughest gun control law.

title: Real Estate; Donating Land for S.I. Park
description: TAXES often have as much to do with real estate transactions as property. Witness the recent decision by the Urban Investment Development Company, a subsidiary of Aetna Life and Casualty, to give away 14 acres of undeveloped land on Staten Island with an appraised value of $1.6 million. The company announced this month that it was donating the land for development as a public park and recreation area.

title: F.F. McNaughton Dies at 91; Illinois Newspaper Publisher
description: F.F. McNaughton, a veteran of 60 years in newspaper publishing and broadcasting, died today at the Yuma Regional Medical Center in Yuma, Ariz., where he had lived since his retirement. He was 91 years old.

title: REAGAN SIGNS $10 BILLION SEWAGE TREATMENT BILL
description: President Reagan, in an action that will enable towns and cities to continue to clean up polluted water, today signed legislation providing $10 billion over the next four years for sewage treatment facilities.

title: EX-CHIEF OF PEDIATRICS ON L.I.
description: Dr. Herbert L. Elias, former chief of pediatrics at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L.I., died Sunday at the hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: 76ers 142, Warriors 135
description: Julius Erving scored 34 points, including 14 in the final period, as Philadelphia took over first place in the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association.

title: ALLIES MOVING OUT OF STEP
description: West Germany's continuing official attitude on Poland is that the situation there remains too fragmented and uncertain for the West to draw conclusions about the country's fate and how to deal with it.

title: Grace Bumbry Will Join Miss Verrett in Recital
description: Grace Bumbry and Shirley Verrett will present a joint recital Jan. 31 at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. The concert will be in honor of the 80th birthday of Marian Anderson, the first black singer to appear at the Metropolitan Opera.

title: KNICKS TOP BULL, 111-108
description: The starting-forward combination of Campy Russell and Sly Williams, reestablished last Saturday night because of Maurice Lucas's knee injury, clicked again tonight in the Knicks' 111-108 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recall reading somewhere that parsnips contain a toxin. Since I am quite fond of this root, can you tell me if this is so?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WINTER WONDERLAND

title: THE EARLY OPPOSITION TO A PALESTINIAN STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWSLETTERS FILL CRAVING FOR POLITICS
description: Want to know the latest on Congressional primaries in Texas, or the odds on whether David A. Stockman will keep his job? Or how about which White House aides are up and which ones are down, or the implications of trends in British politics?

title: 'YEAR OF DISABLED' ERASED MANY GAINS OF NATIONS HANDICAPPED
description: The nation's handicapped are coming to the end of 1981 - designated the International Year of Disabled Persons -worse off, in some legislative areas, than when the year started.

title: Residents Protest Parole Of Murderer of Child
description: Over opposition from the family of a murdered girl, Gov. Hugh Gallen and 21,000 petitioners, the state Parole Board said today that Edward Coolidge, a confessed killer, may go free in 1984 after 20 years in prison.

title: THE STAGE: 'A VISIT,' A MUSICAL TRIP BACK TO 1910
description: ''AVISIT,'' written and directed by Maria Irene Fornes (at Theater for the New City), is a quaint, impossibly cute musical trifle about a licentious weekend in the country. The impulse is to titillate; the impact is the opposite.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: New York City has become an actor in productions of all kinds lately, offering its nooks and crannies as contract players on the small and large screens.

title: PLANE CRASH SURVIVORS RESCUED:
description: A Montezuma, Colo., resident getting firewood from his porch. Up to 35 inches of snow fell from a storm in the Colorado Rockies.

title: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan has approved cuts of more than $30 billion in his projected budget for 1983. Even so, the Office of Management and Budget estimated in a memorandum, there will be a deficit of about $110 billion unless taxes are raised. (Page A1.)

title: S(w)inging Together Again, Albeit Briefly
description: They started performing together professionally when they one was 3 years old and the other was 5, and for the next 26 years Gregory and Maurice Hines sang and danced together. The Hines Brothers went their separate ways in 1973, but this Sunday they will appear together on Broadway again for a rendition of ''It Don't Mean a Thing if It Ain't Got That Swing.''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of my goals in this column has been to make it as wide-ranging as possible where types of food are concerned. There have been recipes for ground beef and chicken, two of the least expensive foods to be found in your local supermarket, and an occasional indulgence in veal chops and racks of lamb, two of the most expensive.

title: Yachtsman Sails to Aid Of Marooned Canadians
description: An American yachtsman is sailing alone to a remote Pacific atoll to pick up a Canadian man and his two daughters who have been marooned for three weeks because neither the United States nor the Canadian government is willing to rescue them.

title: New Building Down by 10%
description: Partly because of continued depression in the housing industry, the value of construction projects started in November fell 10 percent from October, a construction-monitoring concern said today.

title: Surge in Subway Crime Reported for December
description: Violent crime on New York City's subways is running 60 to 65 percent higher this month than for last December, the Transit Police said yesterday.

title: TV: HENRY FONDA AND MYRNA LOY
description: ''SUMMER SOLSTICE,'' an hourlong play on ABC-TV at 10 o'clock tonight, claims the distinction of being the first locally produced dramatic program to be purchased by a network. How was this accomplished?

title: New Year's Eve Jazz On Public Radio
description: National Public Radio will greet New Year's Eve with seven and a half hours of jazz from around the country. ''Jazz Alive,'' to be heard in New York on WBGO-FM, will begin at 9:30 P.M. with the fusion music of Grover Washington Jr. in a pickup from the Ripley Music Hall in Philadelphia.

title: Danish Factory Orders
description: The value of Danish industrial orders, excluding shipyards, rose 18 percent at current prices in October compared with October 1980 orders. Orders rose 20 percent in September, the Statistics Bureau said today.

title: Eastern Savings Bank Elects New President
description: At the Eastern Savings Bank, with assets of $714 million and nine branches in Westchester, Long Island and the Bronx, Edward J. Brown, 49, has been elected president and chief operating officer. He succeeds George W. Coalter, 54, who retired for health reasons but will continue as a trustee.

title: Hoyas Set Back Columbia
description: Pat Ewing scored 14 points and pressured a smaller Columbia team as Georgetown overcame a slowdown and beat the Lions, 38-26, tonight in the Rochester University Basketball Classic.

title: China Questions U.S.  On Taiwan Arms Sale
description: China is asking the United States to clarify its decision to provide millions of dollars in military spare parts to Taiwan, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: TOP CONSERVATIVES PICK LEHRMAN FOR GOVERNOR
description: Lewis E. Lehrman has been promised the Conservative Party nomination for Governor of New York, party leaders said yesterday, even if it would mean splitting the right-of-center opposition against the Democrats.

title: Wife of Black Nationalist Banned in South Africa
description: Winnie Mandela, wife of South Africa's leading black nationalist, has been ordered banned for another five years, her lawyer said today.

title: STUDENTS' KNOWLEDGE OF ARTS FOUND TO DECLINE
description: The musical and artistic knowledge and sophistication of elementary and secondary school students across the country did not generally improve in the 1970's, although the youngsters were often favorably inclined toward both subjects.

title: GOVERMENT BOND PRICES FALL
description: Prices of Government bonds dropped yesterday, reflecting some pressure on the market before the Treasury's auction today of $1.75 billion worth of 20-year bonds.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Mary Cantwell SCENES OF CHILDHOOD. By Sylvia Townsend Warner. 177 pages. Viking. $10.95.

title: CANADIENS STOP ISLANDERS, 5-4
description: The Montreal Canadiens turned in a 5-4 victory over the Islanders tonight, their first triumph at Nassau Coliseum in four years, halting New York's winning streak at six games.

title: Advertising; Emery Air Paints On New Face
description: WITH a brand new name and a brand new look, Emery Air Freight will introduce on Friday an ad campaign aimed at winning back its leadership role from that upstart, Federal Air Express.

title: Business of Baseball
description: Duane Kuiper, the Cleveland Indians' second baseman from 1974 until he was traded to the San Francisco Giants six weeks ago, says he feels hurt.

title: ST. JOHN' WINS BY 94-89, HALTING VILLANOVA RALLY
description: Two nights ago, the St. John's Redmen, the only basketball team in the Holiday Festival not ranked in any top-20 poll, were still searching for an identity. Last night, after a 94-89 victory over Villanova gave St. John's its fifth Festival championship, the Redmen may have achieved more of an identity than they would like.

title: No Headline
description: Kentucky Triumphs By 34-28

title: HUNTER SHOOTS HIS FRIEND, THEN KILLS HIMSELF
description: A medical examiner said today that a teen-ager committed suicide with a .22-caliber rifle after the gun discharged and wounded his best friend as they were fox hunting.

title: CATERERS EVALUATE OLD YEAR AND NEW
description: THE caterers of New York, most of whom have largely been unscathed by the current economic setback, will look on 1981 as a boom year. At the holiday season - their most frenetic period -a few of the leading caterers looked back over a year of changing tastes in food and entertaining, at their own origins and at what 1982 may bring.

title: MGM Hotel Earnings Drop
description: The recession and inability to book convention business slashed the earnings of MGM Grand Hotels Inc. in the first fiscal quarter to 14 cents a share from 26 cents a year earlier, despite a 14.4 percent increase in revenues.

title: News Analysis
description: By invoking a modest set of economic and political sanctions against the Soviet Union today with no guarantee that its allies will do the same, the Reagan Administration is consciously risking damage to the Western alliance without necessarily doing much to ameliorate the situation within Poland.

title: ROBERT ABEL
description: Robert Abel, a former executive editor of Warner Books and a writer and editor who specialized in wine, food and travel, died at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on Dec. 21. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Apocalypse Forever?
description: The Vietnam War is over, but hostilities continue. The intemperate words ''fraud'' and ''total disgrace'' are being unjustly flung at four Americans for becoming the first Vietnam veterans to journey to Hanoi.

title: BRONX GIRL, 17, VICTIM OF KNIFING, RECUPERATING AFTER SURGERY ON LEG
description: A 17-year-old girl who aspires to be a professional tennis champion was listed in good condition at Montefiore Hospital yesterday, a week after one of her legs was seriously injured in a knife attack near her home in the Bronx.

title: POLES MAKE SMALL DEBT PAYMENTS
description: Poland has resumed limited payments of its commercial bank debt for the first time since the declaration of martial law on Dec. 13, West German and American bankers reported today.

title: Jets Seek More Varied Offense
description: Richard Todd returns home today, his finest season as quarterback of the Jets having ended Sunday. But he realizes that his offseason will be interrupted many times.

title: G.& W. Stake; In Brunswick
description: Gulf and Western Industries said that it had increased its stake in the Brunswick Corporation to 15.43 percent from 13.84 percent. Evan Cooper, company spokesman, said the additional shares had been acquired for investment purposes. G.& W., which owns the Paramount Pictures Corporation and has interests in financial services, consumer and food products and natural resources, has bought positions in a variety of companies for investment reasons. G.& W. said it bought 326,200 Brunswick shares at prices ranging from $15.75 to $21 a share, for a total purchase price of $6.1 million.

title: UNION CHIEFS REJECT OIL CONTRACT OFFERS FROM 3 COMPANIES
description: Union officials today rejected offers from three major oil companies for 1982-83 contracts in the nation's refinery, petrochemical and pipeline industry. Current contracts, involving about 55,000 union members and 100 employers, are scheduled to expire at midnight Jan. 7.

title: 2 AIRLINES RAISE FARES ON WASHINGTON SHUTTLE
description: New York Air, which has been challenging Eastern Airlines' New York-to-Washington shuttle with lower fares, said yesterday that rising costs have forced the small airline to raise its fares. Eastern also announced increases in its shuttle fares.

title: LETTERS FROM POLAND RESUME
description: The first letters to arrive from Poland since martial law was imposed on Dec. 13 were distributed here over the weekend with OCENZUROWANO - meaning censored - stamped in red on the envelopes. One of the pieces of mail was a Happy New Year card from Warsaw.

title: COUNTERREVOLUTION
description: The world is concentrating on Soviet involvement in Poland, but what we are witnessing is in fact a counter-revolution, staged and brutally implemented by the Polish ''new class.''

title: Howard Simpson Dies at 53; Lancaster, Pa., Ad Executive
description: Howard K. Simpson, vice president and creative director of Kelly Advertising Inc. of Lancaster, Pa., died Thursday at Lankenau Hospital in Philadelphia.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $129,000 loss for the qr and $73,000 gain for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Including $162,000 gain for the qr and $965,000 loss for the yr from discontinued operation

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $1.4 million for the latest first qr and $1,053,000 for the yr-ago first qr; shr earnings give effect to a 5 percent common stock divd paid in Nov

title: Careers; A Need for Polymer Experts
description: COURSES in polymer chemistry might be a way for many young chemists who graduate in the next few years to win a job in industry. And for chemists with a Ph.D degree, knowledge of polymers may also open the door to a faculty job.

title: NOVEMBER TRADE DEFICIT PUTS '81 PACE ABOVE '80
description: The United States foreign trade deficit totaled $4.41 billion in November, pushing the total for the first 11 months of 1981 past the figure for all of 1980, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Bridge:; Intermediate Players Use Dubious Rule for Bidding
description: Many players of intermediate strength, and a tiny minority of experts, employ a bidding rule of dubious validity. They insist on a four-card holding to raise singly when partner has responded in a major suit: one diamond, one spade, two spades, for example.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1981
description: International Key American economic sanctions against the Soviet Union were imposed by President Reagan, who spoke of Moscow's ''heavy and direct responsibility for the repression in Poland.'' Mr. Reagan ordered the suspension of high technology exports and a halt in negotiations for a new long-term grain export agreement and in Soviet air service to the United States. He also restricted access to American ports by Soviet ships and warned of further actions if the military crackdown in Poland. The Kremlin reacted angrily to the sanctions imposed on Moscow by the Reagan Administration. Soviet officials said that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had forcefully rejected American charges of Soviet involvement in the crackdown in Poland. They also said he had told the American Ambassador, Arthur A. Hartman, that Washington had instigated an attempt to overthrow Communist rule. (A6:5-6.) Lech Walesa has agreed to open talks with Poland's martial law government, according to sources there who are considered reliable. The informants, who have spoken with a relative of Mr. Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity trade union, confirmed that he had been on a two-day hunger strike, but said he ended the fast on Christmas Day when he decided to begin the negotiations. (A1:3.)

title: First Texas Savings Appoints Chairman
description: J. Michael Cornwall, the 46-year-old chief executive officer of the First Texas Savings Association, has been appointed chairman of the $2 billion Dallas-based savings and loan association. Robin R. Glackin, 36, will succeed him as president of the company, a subsidiary of the Beneficial Corporation with more than 70 offices in 40 Texas cities.

title: PLANNED PARENTHOOD'S SUSPECTED OFFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Tea Men Beat Cosmos
description: After the Cosmos dropped their fourth straight indoor game, a 4-3 overtime loss to the Jacksonville Tea Men tonight before a crowd of 13,673 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Coach Erol Yasin centered on his team's basic flaw.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Ann Leslie Kersting Bride Of William Paul Miller 2d
description: Ann Leslie Kersting, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Joseph Kersting of Manchester, Conn., was married yesterday to William Paul Miller 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Farmington Hills, Mich. The Rev. Robert Edwards, assisted by the Rev. Richard Griffis, performed the ceremony at Immanuel Congregational Church in Hartford.

title: NICARAGUA'S REVOLUTION BREAKS MOLD
description: The embattled Nicaraguan revolution is a movement far from the political definitions that outsiders are still trying to force upon it.

title: A TOP PRIORITY FOR NEW YORK CITY: MORE POLICE
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-LABOR LEADER IN CAROLINA GETS JAIL TERM IN FRAUD CASE
description: Wilbur Hobby, a former president of the North Carolina A.F.L.-C.I.O., was sentenced today to 18 months in prison, five years' probation and a $40,000 fine for fraud and conspiracy.

title: Language Group Gives 4 Awards
description: The Modern Language Association, the 99-year-old scholarly society with 30,000 members, has voted the following awards: The 12th annual James Russell Lowell Prize, for a book written by a member of the association, to Benjamin Bennett, associate professor of German at the University of Virginia, for ''Modern Drama and German Classicism.'' The first annual Kenneth W. Mildenberger Medal, for a research publication in teaching foreign languages and literature, to Earl W. Stevick of the Foreign Service Institute of the State Department, for ''Teaching Languages.''

title: 5 Indians Are Sought In Letter Carrier's Death
description: Five American Indians were being sought for questioning today in connection with the slaying of a part-time letter carrier whose body was found at a trash dump on an Indian reservation, the police said.

title: 'Prints' Competition Announced by Pratt
description: A competition and exhibition, ''Prints USA: 1982,'' will be sponsored by the Pratt Graphics Center of the Pratt Institute's School of Art and Design and the Exxon Corporation. The winners will be exhibited at the Pratt Manhattan Center Gallery from next May 29 through June 22.

title: Tensions in Sinai Town Are Said to Be Eased
description: Tensions were eased in the Sinai desert town of Yamit tonight when representatives of the townspeople announced they would try a new approach in negotiations for compensation.

title: Stocks Fall Slightly in Sluggish Trading
description: Stock prices continued to drift lower yesterday in sluggish trading as the long-awaited year-end rally failed to materialize. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, closed off 2.09 points, to 868.25. In the overall market, losers on the New York Stock Exchange outscored advancing issues by a 9-to-5 ratio.

title: CBS TO EXPAND 'MORNING' TO 2 HOURS JAN. 18
description: CBS News announced yesterday that it would expand ''Morning'' from 90 minutes to two hours beginning Jan. 18, putting it into direct competition with ABC-TV's ''Good Morning America'' and NBC-TV's ''Today.''

title: THE U.S. AND ISRAEL
description: Israel's quasi-annexation of Syria's Golan Heights raises questions about whether Israel and the United States can still work together for peace in the Middle East.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $102,000 for the qr and $379,000 for the 9 mos

title: Italy Says It May Reconsider Its Share in Soviet Gas Deal
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini said at a news conference today that Italy's governing parties had agreed to reconsider participation in the Soviet pipeline deal and possibly cut off negotiations.

title: HOW REAGAN TEAM WON IN CONGRESS
description: Earlier this month, Congress was drafting a temporary financing bill for the Federal Government, and the White House wanted to slash most operations by 4 percent. But votes were scarce, and the Administration's aides on Capitol Hill were buying them retail, one by one.

title: PREDICTS BETTER TIES
description: Senator Charles H. Percy predicted today, after meeting with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, that the strain in @Israeli-American relations over the annexation of the Golan Heights would be ended by ''a new spirit, a new beginning'' between the two countries.

title: MORGAN LIBRARY SHOW TRACES 75-YEAR HISTORY
description: THE number of turn-of-the-century buildings in New York that are of significant architectural quality, are accessible to the public and are maintained today in their essentially original condition is a surprisingly small one. Most museums and hotels have been altered drastically, many churches have been torn down altogether, and clubhouses are private.

title: WINE TALK
description: MY meeting several years ago with James Symington, who lives in the hillside city of Oporto overlooking the mouth of the Douro River in northwestern Portugal, was fortunate, for he introduced me to one of the greatest red table wines that I had ever experienced.

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
UNPERSUASIVE DEFENSE OF THE SEA LAW TREATY
description: To the Editor:

title: WALESA SAID AGREE TO TALKS
description: President Reagan, declaring that ''the Soviet Union bears a heavy and direct responsibility for the repression in Poland,'' cut back sharply today on Soviet-American trade and scientific exchange. He warned of further measures if the Polish crackdown is not lifted.

title: Vilas and Pfister Win In Australian Tennis
description: Guillermo Vilas, the topseed-ed player, advanced to the third round of the $400,000 Australian Open tennis tournament today by defeating Larry Stefanki of the United States, 6-7, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4.

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: STRIKE LEADERS HELD
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Citibank has elected Richard S. Braddock and Edwin P. Hoffman executive vice presidents in its individual banking operation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''By our actions, we expect to put powerful doubts in the minds of the Soviet and Polish leaders about this continued repression.

title: FINK OFFERS PLAN TO AID POLICE HIRING
description: New York State would subsidize the hiring of hundreds of additional police officers in New York City and other areas of the state by taking over local probation costs under a proposal made yesterday by Stanley Fink, the Speaker of the Assembly.

title: WALKER WEIGHING PRO MOVE
description: Herschel Walker, Georgia's sophomore all-America tailback, raised the possibility again today that he might turn professional and play in the Canadian Football League before his college eligibility expires at the end of the 1983 season.

title: ETHNICALLY DISTINCTIVE NEW YEAR DISHES
description: FOR those who would like to try some special dishes for New Year's Eve, here are some suggestions. Goulash soup, a Hungarian specialty, is terrific as a midnight pick-me-up or to start the evening meal. This rich, dark-red soup-stew is spiced with paprika and caraway seeds and laced with little dumplings. Use only true Hungarian paprika or the soup will not have the proper flavor. In Hungary hot cherry peppers are often added at the end. Tiny green hot peppers, deveined under cold running water, can also be added. At the Red Tulip Hungarian Restaurant, 439 East 75th Street, connoisseurs always order extra hot peppers, which are served in a small bowl with a spoon.

title: Transactions
description: [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] COLLEGE

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: IN making pie or tart dough, a central skill, as in so many other cooking procedures, is manual dexterity. For instance, one must cut the butter into the flour very quickly before the butter has a chance to soften and melt. The result should be granular, like a coarse meal. If the butter has not retained its solidity, the resulting pastry will almost certainly be rubbery rather than flaky.

title: Pain's Greatest Moments
description: The 1981 Sorehead of the Year Trophy - a life-size plastic replica of former Ohio State football coach Woody Hayes - has been awarded to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel.

title: See How the Steeds Run
description: AN experiment that brought joy to bookmakers in Las Vegas has stirred a commotion throughout the gambling industry. In an innovation considered illegal by some, the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network (ESPN), a cable chain that broadcasts fun and games to sports freaks 24 hours a day, raised a threat to the national morals last Saturday by showing viewers eight of the nine races at Santa Anita.

title: Syracuse Women Win
description: Kim Dick's basket with one second remaining gave Syracuse a 76-74 victory over St. John's last night in the semi-finals of the Big East Conference women's tournament at Alumni Hall, Jamaica, Queens. Miss Dick finished with 28 points and 11 rebounds as the Orangewomen advanced to this afternoon's final against Villanova. The Lady Wildcats defeated Providence, 68-56, in the opener as Lisa Ortlip scored 24 points and 11 rebounds.

title: Robert M. Ellis Is Dead at 80; Career Officer in British Navy
description: Robert M. Ellis, a former management consultant in Manhattan and a former career officer in the British Navy, died Thursday at the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Los Angeles Coroner Faces an Investigation
description: County officials today ordered an investigation of Coroner Thomas Noguchi, the model for the television medical examiner ''Quincy,'' in response to reports that he runs a sloppy operation in which evidence is lost and damaged.

title: SYRIA, IN AN EFFORT TO END IRANIAN-IRAQI WAR, IS SEEKING TALKS WITH TEHERAN
description: Syria has decided to initiate contacts with the Iranian Government for the seeming purpose of trying to end the 15-month-old war between Iran and Iraq and to concentrate Arab and Islamic energies on confronting Israel.

title: 100 ESCAPE FACILITY
description: A five-day hunger strike at a detention facility for illegal aliens here ended yesterday after the fasting Haitians were made to understand they would not be punished for eating, the Federal authorities said today.

title: Henderson Held in Theft
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson, the former Dallas Cowboy linebacker now with the Miami Dolphins, was arrested today and charged in the theft of a $1,200 typewriter from police headquarters. Bond was set at $1,500 apiece for him and a woman companion, Patricia Smith of Richardson, who was also charged.

title: EX-HEAD OF ACADEMY OF SCIENCES
description: Dr. Philip Handler, who retired last June after 12 years as president of the National Academy of Sciences, died yesterday at New England Deaconess Hospital at the age of 64. He had been in the hospital since August. His death was attributed to cancer of the lymph system, complicated by pneumonia.

title: U.S. PRAISES JAPAN'S MOVE FOR BIGGER MILITARY OUTLAYS
description: The Reagan Administration today applauded a decision by the Japanese Government to increase defense spending at a faster rate than the Japanese budget as a whole.

title: WHAT BREZHNEV MIGHT HAVE TOLD REAGAN: 'PERMIT ME TO INSTRUCT YOU'
description: WASHINGTON This is how Leonid I. Brezhnev might have responded to President Reagan's letter on the Polish situation if he had bluntly stated Soviet attitudes that have been reflected elsewhere.

title: RESORT CO-OWNER TESTIFIES ON CRIME FIGURES
description: A key witness in a libel suit against Penthouse magazine testified today that he had no connection with organized crime but conceded that he had a long history of illegal activities and was friendly with many underworld figures.

title: Books: Discount Story; MORE THAN THEY BARGAINED FOR.
description: The Rise and Fall of Korvettes. By Isadore Barmash. Illustrated. 301 pages. Lebhar-Friedman Books/Chain Store. $14.95.

title: CITY TO MAKE A COUNT OF HOMELESS PEOPLE
description: The Koch administration, exasperated by the wide use of a statistic it disputes - that 36,000 homeless people live on New York's streets - has decided to commission a professional count of the city's vagrants and settle the issue.

title: CELEBRATIONS FAR FROM MADDING CROWD
description: EVERYTHING is in the eye of the beholder, but nothing more so than New Year's Eve. It's fun and exciting for some, horrendous for others, and somewhere in between for yet another segment of the population.

title: NEW YORK, NEW YEAR, OLD DELIGHTS
description: The following article is based on reporting by Moira Hodgson and Fred Ferretti and was written by Mr. Ferretti.

title: INDUSTRIAL-AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NICARAUGA'S REVOLUTION BREAKS MOLD
description: The embattled Nicaraguan revolution is a movement far from the political definitions that outsiders are still trying to force upon it.

title: NEW YORK ISSUES GUIDE TO WRITERS' SERVICES
description: ''In New York City, poets, playwrights and writers have a special and privileged rank,'' Henry Geldzahler, the city's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, said. Then he astutely added, ''Unfortunately, not in bankable terms.''

title: BREAKFAST CEREAL: A BUYER'S GUIDE
description: OFTEN in a ''What did you have for breakfast?'' conversation, I've heard the apologetic reply, ''I just had some cereal,'' as if there was something wrong with a cereal breakfast. Cereal, it seems, has gotten a bad name, a consequence in part of the American veneration of animal protein and the torrent of nutritionally questionable sugar-laden products that have glutted the cereal market in recent decades.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agresearch Inc., a subsidiary of Technical Management Inc., announced that it had agreed with O.M. Scott Inc., a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corp., to develop a patented soil conditioner.

title: BL's Market Share Up
description: BL Ltd. reported today that it had increased its share of the British automobile market from 18 percent in 1980 to 19 percent in 1981, despite continuing heavy losses. The auto maker, formerly known as British Leyland, which has been losing $1.9 million a week for the past two years, sold more than 283,000 vehicles in the past 12 months. ''Our achievements in 1981 have reversed the trend of declining sales for BL cars,'' said Tony Ball, a company executive.

title: Beck Will Change Technique
description: Barry Beck, the Rangers' captain and defenseman, plans to stay on the bench if that is where he is the next time a fight breaks out on the ice.

title: A SENATOR REMEBERS HEADY NEW DEAL DAYS
description: Senator Jennings Randolph talks about it as if it had happened just yesterday. ''It was a rainy night, a dreary night. We were taken to the second floor of the White House and there was the President, sitting at a large desk. There was a wood fire burning. I remember it all so well.''

title: STATE IMPOSING NEW COST RULES ON ITS AGENCIES
description: Anticipating further cutbacks in Federal aid, Governor Carey's administration imposed a series of cost controls today on all New York State agencies and departments.

title: JAMES DAVIS, FORMER MEMBER OF CONGRESS AND A PUBLISHER
description: James Curran Davis, a champion of racial segregation who served eight terms as a United States Representative from Georgia and published a conservative daily newspaper in Atlanta, died there Monday at the age of 86.

title: SOCIALISTS CONDEMN MILITARY TAKEOVER:
description: Mario Soares of Portugal, left, and Felipe Gonzalez of Spain at the Socialist International meeting yesterday in Paris. The group, which included delegates of 15 parties, issued a statement condemning ''the seizure of power by the military in Poland and the brutal repression of civil rights that followed,'' which overrode a milder statement made previously by group's leader, Willy Brandt.

title: 24 Prospective Jurors Picked in Atlanta Case
description: Defense attorneys quizzed potential jurors about racism and pre-trial publicity today, the second day of jury selection in the trial of Wayne B. Williams, charged with slaying two of 28 young blacks here.

title: PLANNED PARENTHOOD'S SUSPECTED OFFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Senegal Assembly Backs Union With Gambia
description: The Senegalese National Assembly today unanimously approved the union of Senegal and Gambia into a confederation to be known as Senegambia, but the result of a similar vote in Gambia was not yet known.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of 6.7 million shares of common stock.

title: Hilton in Pact On Webb Hotel
description: The Del E. Webb Corporation has completed an agreement with the Hilton Hotels Corporation for sale of the Sahara Reno Hotel to Hilton for $34.5 million in cash and an option to acquire the Sahara Tahoe by March 31.

title: KDT Names Head Of Ailing Store Unit
description: Robert D. Mandel, a 57-year-old retailer, will join KDT Industries, which operates the King and Barkers discount stores in the Eastern and central parts of the country, as president and chief operating officer of its troubled retail division on Jan. 15.

title: GIFTS TO HELP THE NEEDIEST SET TRADITION
description: To many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, giving is an annual event, as predictable as the holidays. Their gifts in memory of family or friends account for a major portion of the fund every year.

title: TENSION RISES IN MILWAUKEE OVER POLICE CONDUCT
description: As a small group of people neared a downtown intersection, their collars upturned against the breezy, 15-degree weather, the traffic light turned red. When some shivering members of the group started to cross against the light, one said: ''We better not jaywalk because the police might see us and beat us up.''

title: Patriot Bid Denied
description: John Robinson, the football coach at Southern California, denied a published report that he had been offered the job of coach of the New England Patriots. Appearing at a news conference in connection with the Trojans' game against Penn State in the Fiesta Bowl at Tempe, Ariz., Robinson showed irritation when the subject of the New England post came up.

title: CITY OFFICIALS BELIEVE THE OIL SPILL NEAR RESERVOIR IS BEING CONTAINED
description: New York City officials seemed confident today that they had brought under control the remains of Sunday's 13,000-gallon oil spill that had threatened to spread into the city's Croton reservoir system.

title: No Headline
description: TEXT OF REAGAN'S ANNOUNCEMENT OF SANCTIONS

title: Italy's Communists Say Soviet Has Lost Impact
description: The Italian Communist Party said today that the military takeover in Poland meant that the Soviet revolution had ceased to be a vital force in the world.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: COMPILING a list of the year's 10 best albums is one of the most pleasurable and challenging tasks that a pop critic faces. It involves going back and listening repeatedly to albums one liked to begin with - the pleasurable part -and then attempting to evaluate and compare those albums as objectively as possible.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Allegheny Merger With Sunbeam Set
description: The proposed $550 million merger of Allegheny International Inc. and the Sunbeam Corporation was approved by both companies' shareholders in separate meetings today, the companies announced.

title: F.B.I. DIRECTOR SAYS INCIDENTS OF TERRORISM ARE ON INCREASE
description: William H. Webster, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, voicing concern over terrorist activities in Puerto Rico, said today that the nationwide total of terrorist acts jumped almost 50 percent in 1981, to 42.

title: Equal Rights and Unfair Meddling
description: Romping in a political thicket and ignoring all canons of judicial restraint, a Federal judge in Boise, Idaho, has issued judgments enough to kill the Equal Rights Amendment two or three times over.

title: Trade a Sour Note for Flynn
description: Before cowboy hats and the Western look were fashionable in New York, the Mets had a second basemen who sang Bluegrass songs, ate ribs and wore straight-legged Levis. Doug Flynn is still singing, still licking tangy barbeque sauce off his fingers and still choosing his best flannel shirt when he wants to get dressed up.

title: 55 Women Presented At International Ball
description: Fifty-five young women from 17 countries and 12 states made their formal bows to society last night at the 27th International Debutante Ball in the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: COLD AND MADNESS IN SIBERIA
description: Whatever the temperature, Siberians are loath to admit it's cold. But here they have no choice - there simply aren't many colder places on earth.

title: 1.  Coconut-Shell Bags
description: Handbags are being made of fascinating materials these days. Coconut shells, for instance. Bergdorf's has some that are interesting, made by Philippine hill tribes, that start out as coconut shells. Then they're dyed in such colors as purple, red, moss green and pink and are wrapped in matching raffia. Each bag is given a top hand-carved in the shape of a rabbit, a bird or a horse and a raffia handle. The bags are $85 in the store's Port of Call section on the main floor.

title: A Personal Touch in Helping Needy Poles
description: While large relief organizations have been conducting fund-raising drives to send food and supplies to Poland, at least one American of Polish descent has waged an individual effort aimed at reaching reaching thousands of needy Poles. Last summer Wladimir Kochanski, a Texas-born concert pianist, was distressed by the food lines when he visited Poland on a concert tour.

title: NEBRASKA FINISHING STRONG
description: The Nebraska Cornhuskers sat quietly and dejectedly in their locker room last fall at home in Lincoln, Neb. Thunder and rain rolled across the plains, but the weather wasn't the problem. Nebraska was 1-2 -the losses were to Iowa and Penn State - after three games and trailed Auburn by 3-0 at halftime. And the players were shocked at something rarely heard in Memorial Stadium - a few boos.

title: U.S. ENVOY, SERVING NOTICE, IS GIVEN REBUFF BY GROMYKO
description: The United States Ambassador received a blunt response today when he met Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to give advance notice of the economic sanctions imposed by President Reagan.

title: KOCH TAKING STEPS TO CONSOLIDATE HIS CONTROL OVER CITY GOVERNMENT
description: In the weeks since his re-election, Mayor Koch has taken steps to extend his control over a New York City government that sprawls across dozens of municipal agencies and multiple levels of jurisdiction.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SILENT VIGIL FOR THE POLISH UNION
description: Supporters of Solidarity lighting candles outside the Polish Embassy in Paris Monday night during a vigil in support of the embattled labor group.

title: TAX LAW'S ROLE IN SILVER FALL
description: Silver bullion prices continue to hover near their lows for the year, despite the most bullish market conditions since late 1978, when the metal began its dramatic advance to record levels.

title: Von Bulow Trial to Newport
description: The trial of Claus von Bulow, a Newport society figure charged with trying to murder his wife, was ordered moved from Providence back to Newport. Superior Court Presiding Justice Anthony Giannini said he had ordered the move Monday because efforts to obtain larger courtroom space in Providence had been unsuccessful. Pretrial arguments were to begin Jan. 7.

title: Dean Witter Link To Sears Backed
description: Shareholders of the Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc., the large securities firm, approved a $607 million takeover of the company by Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer.

title: DAMSON OIL CO reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
23,450, COUNT 'EM, 23,450:
description: Sgt. Bob Mayfield of the Oregon State Police counting 23,450 pennies found in a metal box on a road near Central Point. A coin collecter, who said they were a gift, later claimed the coins, saying that the box fell from his truck. The pennies had already been counted.

title: Blues 6, Whalers 1
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Ralph Klassen's first goal in more than a month and only his second this season started a four-goal second period, lifting St. Louis to a club-record seventh straight victory at home.

title: NOVEMBER ECONOMIC INDEX OFF 0.3%
description: The Government index intended to forecast broad economic trends fell three-tenths of 1 percent in November, a significantly smaller decline than in preceding months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A.T.& T. Commissions
description: Reacting to pressure from the lodging industry, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has extended for another year its program for paying commissions to hotels and motels on long-distance calls made by guests.

title: Confidence Is Mark Of the 'New' Giants
description: The old Giants were a 4-12 team last year. The new Giants have a 9-7 record, a victory over Philadelphia in the playoffs and a date Sunday with the 49ers in the National Conference semifinals in San Francisco.

title: U.S. and Italy Agree On Red Brigades Policy
description: The American and Italian Governments are in agreement on a policy of not entering into negotiations with the Red Brigades kidnappers of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini said today.

title: PLAZA VIEW
description: Last night a crowd assembled here behind a lank ghost on stilts whose arms of worn-out bedsheets billowed in the cold air. Heralding a new year, it sailed around the fountain, down the darkened avenue where street lights curved in question marks. Skaters on the frozen pond stopped their continuous circles for the fireworks blossoming north of them, and shortly dissolving on the sky. Beneath that panoply we watched the horse-drawn carriages until each grew too small, the hour too late. Something about one carriage stopped at the curb, its dappled gray horse with head bent to feed, something about the driver having a long smoke, his face turned moonward made us know nothing we could see had changed, not inside where we turned our quilted bedcover back, nor out where iceskaters skated in time to the distant inaudible music.

title: Byrne to Post Reward For Killers of Trooper
description: Governor Byrne announced today that he would authorize a $25,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the men who killed a state trooper on Dec. 21.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John McEnroe was designated the world's No.1 male tennis player by Tennis magazine. Chris Evert Lloyd was named the No. 1 women's player for the eighth time in the last nine years.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THOSE looking for inexpensive dishes for New Year's Eve parties will find some bargains in the stores. Eggplant is selling at 39 cents a pound in many markets. A tasty party dip can be made by charring the eggplant in the oven, scraping out the inside and mixing it with lemon juice, olive oil and minced garlic. It can be served with heated pita bread.

title: MRS. WILLIAM F. FYFE
description: Edith L. Fyfe, the wife of William F. Fyfe, retired controller of Pan American World Airways, died Dec. 22 at Stuart, Fla. She was 67 years old and lived in Stuart, having previously been a longtime resident of Maywood, N.J.

title: Huxtable Was Here
description: If New York seems a little less exciting this morning, that is because Ada Louise Huxtable is leaving The Times. If America's most grotesque structures stand a little straighter, that is because she won't be kicking them around in our columns quite as often. And if urban planning and preserving lose out more often to greed, it will be because scholarship has stolen her from journalism. But we come to this moment with pride: after two decades of instruction from such a sharp-eyed, sharp-tongued humanist, the American city is a finer, saner place.

title: ECOMOMIST URGES '83 TAX CUT DELAY
description: Martin Feldstein, a prominent conservative economist, suggested today that the Reagan Administration postpone the 1983 portion of its three-year, 25 percent personal income tax cut for at least a year.

title: REAGAN REPORTED PARING $30 BILLION FROM 1983 BUDGET
description: President Reagan has reportedly approved cuts of more than $30 billion in his projected 1983 budget but has been told by the Office of Management and Budget that there still will be a deficit of roughly $110 billion unless there are tax increases.

title: Lakers 121, Jazz 114
description: Jamaal Wilkes scored 36 points to pace Los Angeles to its sixth straight victory. The defeat was the fifth in a row for Utah.

title: Market Place; Parts Spinoff Urged for RCA
description: RCA may be too unweildy for its own good, or, as James Magid puts it, ''RCA may be worth more dead than alive.'' Mr. Magid, an analyst who follows RCA for L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, means that parts of the empire would be more valuable if sold than if the ailing conglomerate continues to operate them.

title: BRIEFING
description: G EORGE BUSH, who has virtually disappeared from the public eye, is feeling a bit squeamish about the high profile that has been thrust upon him when he leaves the Vice President's House on the grounds of the Naval Observatory along Washington's Embassy Row.

title: DEFENSE LAWYERS QUIT SADAT TRIAL
description: The team of lawyers defending two dozen Islamic fundamentalists accused in the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat abruptly withdrew from the trial today.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE PHYSICAL SIDE OF BANKING
description: European American Bank arrived first. At a few minutes to 10 A.M., three of its young clerks rattled in with a laundry cart on wheels. Then Bankers Trust trundled in with what looked like a black footlocker. Chemical Bank brought five silver-colored bins.

title: Economic Scene; Economic Fact And Fantasy
description: IT is now, in the neverland between Christmas and New Year's, when hard economic fact can catch up with fantasy - or is it the other way around? Who can tell? Dr. Adam Arbuthnot, the leading cliche expert and a sometime White House consultant, has agreed to take questions on the year that was and the year that will be.

title: Union Negotiators Accept Concessions In Uniroyal Pact
description: The willingness of all 10 union locals at Uniroyal Inc. to submit to their members a new contract that calls for $54.9 million in pay and benefit concessions is the latest effort in the rubber industry to offset the decline in tire sales to auto manufacturers.

title: STOCKHOLDERS BACK BUY-OUT CAESARS
description: Shareholders of Caesars World Inc. today approved a plan to buy out the interests of its founders, Clifford and Stuart Perlman, for approximately $99 million.

title: GUNMEN KILL 2 CABBIES IN CITY AND WOUND A 3D
description: Two taxicab drivers were shot to death and another was wounded yesterday in separate attacks in three boroughs. The killings were the first since a new program of increased police surveillance of cabs in crime-prone areas was begun in late October.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: During Brendan T. Byrne's first term as Governor of New Jersey, Charles Carella worked for him as executive secretary. But when Governor Byrne leaves office on Jan. 19, he announced yesterday , it will be to join the Newark law firm of his former aide.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. GAS DEPOT IN BRITAIN AN ISSUE

title: Farm Housing Rules Changed
description: The Farmers Home Administration said today that its regulations had been changed to ''make it possible for more people'' to get housing loans.

title: Nostalgic musical look at parochial schools on its way.
description: ''DO Patent Leather Shoes Really Reflect Up?'' is the title of a musical that originated three years ago in Chicago and is slowly making its way to New York. While one company is still playing in Chicago, another company opened last week in Philadelphia and is due to arrive on Broadway either late this season or early next fall. The show, which takes an irreverent view of education in Roman Catholic schools, has a book by John R. Powers, music by James Quinn and lyrics by Alaric Jans - all newcomers to Broadway. Thommie Walsh, who shared the Tony Award with Tommy Tune for the choreography of ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine,'' has done the musical staging. The director is Mike Nussbaum.

title: Market Place; Curtiss May Be Asset Play
description: WRIGHT, which attracts more attention as an investor than a manufacturer these days, has emerged as an asset play. The Curtiss-Wright Corporation probably reached its peak as an aircraft builder with the famed Curtiss P-40 fighter plane in World War II. The company produced jet engines for a time and has tried without success to market a rotary engine.

title: Bunker Hill Delay
description: The Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation said that it had extended until Jan. 15 an agreement for the possible sale of its Bunker Hill Company copper-mining subsidiary to three private Idaho-based investors. The agreement, which calls for the sale of Bunker Hill to Duane B. Hagadone, H.F. Magnuson and J. William Pfeiffer for $65 million in cash and notes, was due to expire tomorrow.

title: NEW ROCHELLE COLLEGE HEAD
description: Sister Dorothea Dunkerley, a member of the Order of St. Ursula and a former president of the College of New Rochelle, died yesterday at the Ursuline Convent in New Rochelle.

title: NEW YEAR AND 'MASTERPIECE' IN KENYA
description: TELEVISION'S New Year's Eve festivities once again add up to little more than electronic wallpaper, designed to provide holiday parties with background music and a midnight shot of a big apple descending in Times Square. The familiar sounds of the Guy Lombardo Orchestra have been replaced. CBS-TV at 11:30 this evening will offer Donny Osmond as host of ''a celebration'' at the Waldorf-Astoria with Les Brown and His Band, the Pointer Sisters and Dottie West.

title: VW of America Expects Sales Rise
description: Volkswagen of America Inc. predicts sales of 330,000 cars in 1982, up 14 percent from this year's depressed levels, its president, James McLernon, said in a year-end statement. Mr. McLernon also said that production at the company plant in Sterling Heights, Mich., could begin in the spring of 1983 if market conditions improved.

title: A THIRD WORLD EAGER TO BUY ARMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Bonan Married To Andrew E. Adelson
description: Virginia Allegra Bonan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seon Pierre Bonan of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Edson Adelson, son of Mrs. M. William Adelson of Baltimore and the late Mr. Adelson. Algernon Black, leader emeritus of the New York Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Bonan home.

title: Duke Power; Stock Sold
description: In the largest debt-for-stock swap of the year, Salomon Brothers Inc. announced that it had sold 3,744,486 shares of common stock of the Duke Power Company, including a single block of 3,335,800 shares at a price of 20 3/8.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary Tuesday on Edwin H. Knopf, a Hollywood film producer who died Sunday in West Los Angeles, omitted the names of his survivors. In addition to his wife, he leaves a daughter, Wendy Cooper of Los Angeles; two sons, Christopher Knopf of Santa Monica, Calif., and Jonathan Knopf, who lives in the San Fernando Valley; his brother, the publisher Alfred A. Knopf, and 10 grandchildren.

title: FAILING HEARTS SAVED BY SMALL PUMP
description: Doctors at Pennsylvania State University have reported the most successful results to date of a compact heart pump designed to save patients in danger of dying after open-heart surgery.

title: MUSIC, MOVIES, MAGIC AND FIREWORKS
description: Not all the New Year's music will be for dancing and partying. There will be plenty of the traditional, as well. The Wagner Society of New York is holding a concert-party at the Madison Avenue Baptist Church Parish House, 30 East 31st Street. Glenn Rubin will lead a chamber orchestra in a program that includes Wagner's ''Siegfried Idyll,'' Frederick the Great's Symphony No. 3 in D and Brahms's ''Liebeslieder Waltzes.'' The concert begins at 10 and ends just before midnight, when champagne and refreshments will be served. Cost: $20 ($15 for society members). Reservations required. Phone: 666-3436 or 749-4561.

title: GRETZKY SHATTERS 50-GOAL RECORD
