description: Wayne Gretzky scored five times against the Philadelphia Flyers tonight to achieve 50 goals in a record-breaking 39 games.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: PARTY AIDES INVESTIGATED
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency: Food Shortages Reported 10 A.M. Wednesday

title: CABARETS SING OUT THE OLD AND SING IN THE NEW
description: FOR those who want words with their music tonight, the choices include blues, show tunes, funny tunes and pop tunes that have served many a New Year's Eve.

title: Around the Nation; Atlanta Attorneys Clash Over Murder Trial Jurors
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers traded sharp words in the courtroom today over whether any potential juror who says he has an opinion on the murder case against Wayne B. Williams should be disqualified from the trial.

title: ON THIS DAY THE INVASION CAME TO CITY
description: Karen, Julie and Jo Ann Loughney from Wayne, N.J., collected their annual souvenirs: a needle each from the Rockefeller Center Christmas tree and a straw from the St. Patrick's Cathedral creche ''to put in our wallets for luck.''

title: PETER FALK AND OTHER DONORS TO NEEDIEST CITE RISING WOES
description: Peter Falk, the New York City-born screen and television actor, has contributed $2,000 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a donation four times larger than his gift last year because of what he said he considered a greater need.

title: An Ancient Curse, a New Marriage
description: Gypsy curses aside, Justice Burton B. Roberts of State Supreme Court said yesterday that he was getting married after 58 years of bachelorhood.

title: MISPLACED BLAME FOR TRANSIT TROUBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. ERROR ON PAISLEY
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: Sports of the Times; SCULPTOR OF GIANT DEFENSE
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. I N a few minutes the members of the Giants' defensive unit would assemble in Bill Parcells's classroom. Ray Perkins is the coach, but he is the first to acknowledge that Bill Parcells has sculpted the defense that Bill Walsh, coach of the San Francisco 49ers, rates ''if not the best in the National Football League, then one of the two or three best; it has no weakness.''

title: Eleanor Furlaud, Lawyer, Married
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday, Eleanor Jay Furlaud, a member of the New York law firm of Towne, Dolgin, Furlaud, Sawyier & Owen, was married to Laszlo Adam, an investment banker with E.F. Hutton & Company. The Rev. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Knicks Win in Overtime
description: The Knicks had to struggle to become a .500 team tonight against the Cavaliers, who own the worst record in the league. New York needed 12 points from Maurice Lucas in the fourth quarter and his stuff shot with 18 seconds remaining in the five-minute overtime to beat Cleveland, 110-108, at the Coliseum.

title: A BITTER MEDICINE CURES THE HICCUPS
description: A former bartender and a doctor have a bitter cure for hiccups, if the victim can stomach it. They advise hiccupers to eat a lemon wedge of the size served at bars, saturated with Angostura bitters. Sugar can be added to make it go down more easily, they said, and the rind should not be consumed.

title: RADIANT TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: The company said that the magnitude of the losses were attribut in part to unanticipated adjustments to inventory valuations

title: The Evening Hours
description: S OME 2,500 grown men and women, many dressed in dinner jackets, evening gowns and running shoes, are racing into 1982 in the third annual trot of the New York Road Runners Club through Central Park tonight. Precisely at midnight, a horn sounds, the sky lights up with fireworks and the group gallops from the Tavern on the Green through the five-mile course. One runner, costumed as Big Bird, actually flaps rather than gallops.

title: 4 RESCUED AFTER ORDEAL IN ROCKIES
description: Rescuers fought seven-foot snowdrifts today to bring out the fourth survivor of a Christmas Eve airplane crash after a five-day ordeal on a wind-blown Colorado mountain peak. Searchers gave up hope of finding the pilot.

title: Chinese Bank Rates
description: The People's Bank of China, the nation's central bank, said today that it would increase interest rates on deposits and develop broader financial services.

title: BRUNCH IN NEW YORK: A NEW YEAR'S DAY ROUNDUP
description: IF you still have a taste for festivity tomorrow morning, you might consider easing your way into 1982 by going out to one of the special brunches that will be served around town. Fortunately, it will be possible to do so whether your budget is lavish or modest, whether you want to dress up or dress down and whether you are looking for a setting that is spectacular, formal or comfortably casual. Because New Year's Day brunches could not be sampled in advance, the restaurants below were visited in recent months - some for Sunday brunch, others for weekday breakfasts, lunches or dinners, and dishes comparable to those on brunch menus were tried.

title: Presenting: Dorothy Hamill-Martin
description: When Dorothy Hamill appears as a special guest star in the 1982 edition of Ice Capades next month in the New York metropolitan area, she will be Dorothy Hamill-Martin. The champion figure skater will marry Dean Paul Martin, the actor and son of Dean Martin, the entertainer, on Jan. 8 in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Abroad at Home; THERE'LL ALWAYS BE...
description: Roald Dahl, the English writer of macabre fiction and children's stories, complained recently about the letters published in The Times of London. ''Nowadays,'' he wrote to the paper, ''we are lucky to get one frivolous or amusing letter a week. Politics and prisons, atom bombs and arts councils is what most of the correspondence is about.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Fidelity Life Insurance Co. said it had agreed in principle to purchase for $3.2 million the 346,399 shares of American Fidelity stock owned by Alabama Farm Bureau Mutual Casualty Insurance Co.

title: Afghanistan Accuses Reagan Of Interference in Its Affairs
description: The Afghan Government said today that President Reagan's recent statement on Afghanistan was direct interference in the country's internal affairs, Kabul Radio reported.

title: FRANK SAVAGE
description: Frank Savage, producer of the movie ''Raging Bull,'' died Tuesday while vacationing on this eastern Caribbean island.

title: SUSPECT IS HELD
description: An elderly woman was killed yesterday at First Avenue and 65th Street when she was struck by a car that then climbed onto the sidewalk. The driver sped away and was arrested minutes later after a chase by at least two passing motorists, the police said.

title: Virginia Defeats Madison
description: Ralph Sampson led an 11-1 surge over the final six minutes tonight as Virginia defeated James Madison, 57-44, in the championship game of The Richmond Times-Disatch Invitational.

title: To Our Readers
description: As a service to readers planning their holiday, the New Year's issue of Weekend appears today rather than tomorrow. Home, normally published on Thursdays, will appear tomorrow.

title: REGAN ANNOUNCES HE WILL SEEK G.O.P. NOMINATION FOR GOVERNOR
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan announced last night that he was ''a committed candidate for governor for the state of New York.'' His decision to seek the Republican nomination was expected; the timing of his announcement was not. Mr. Regan, who is vacationing in Vermont, telephoned his Albany office late in the afternoon to inform his staff. ''I've decided that I'm going to announce today,'' he told his press secretary, Marvin G. Nailor. Mr. Nailor said that the decision came because ''everything had come together.'' He said that the announcement the previous day that the Conservative Party would support Lewis E. Lehrman for governor had nothing to do with Mr. Regan's announcement.

title: WHERE YOU CAN STILL GO TO CELEBRATE NEW YEAR'S EVE
description: Whether you prefer traditional dining and dancing with champagne at midnight, or entertainment at a jazz, rock or comedy club, or more esoteric celebrations involving magic, old movies or long-distance running, you're sure to find in this issue someplace special to ring in the new year tonight. Here is information about the many places around town that are still accepting reservations - and some that need no reservations at all.

title: Around the World; Salvador Rebels Assert They Killed 25 Soldiers
description: Guerrillas asserted today that they killed 25 Salvadoran soldiers and took six others prisoners in fighting near the Honduran border Tuesday and today.

title: A DIFFICULT DECISION
description: Simon Estes had two ambitions: to make his debut at the Metropolitan Opera and to sing the national anthem when his alma mater, the University of Iowa, made the Rose Bowl. Mr. Estes's professional singing career took off when, in 1966, he won the Tchaikovsky International Competition in Moscow. And since then the bass baritone has performed at most of the leading opera houses of Europe - but never at the Met.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting methods

title: Books: History of a Beloved Ballet
description: GISELLE AND ALBRECHT. American Ballet Theater's Romantic Lovers. Performance photographs by Fred Fehl. Text by Doris Hering. 191 pages. Dance Horizons. $30.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
WARSAW APPOINTS 3 GROUPS TO CHART REFORM PROGRAMS
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: WASHINGTON IS ISOLATED ON ACTIONS AGAINST THE RUSSIANS OVER POLAND
description: The United States remained alone yesterday after imposing sanctions against the Soviet Union for the military crackdown in Poland, but there was little official criticism of President Reagan's actions from Western countries.

title: Sports People; Jackson Talks Resume
description: George Steinbrenner and Gary Walker, the agent for Reggie Jackson, had another conversation yesterday regarding Jackson's future. According to Walker, they discussed new ideas about Jackson's continuing with the Yankees after his playing days.

title: A Sad Loss of Teaching Help
description: The Reagan cuts in Federal aid to education have begun to smart. Among the worthier projects in jeopardy are centers around the country that counsel and train schoolteachers.

title: Around the Nation; Newcastle Bird Disease Discovered in Colorado
description: The Agriculture Department said today that an outbreak of Newcastle disease, which can be deadly to poultry and other fowl, has been confirmed in parrots in Colorado Springs.

title: FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: B-After $220,000 net loss resulting from repossession of stores previously sold...C-Net income including increased depreciation of approximately $970,000; results are for 14 weeks and 53 weeks for the latest periods and 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the yr-ago periods

title: Italian Mayor Slain
description: A feud between two rival families led to an outbreak of shooting that killed the Mayor of this tiny rural town and wounded his mother, father, nephew and uncle, the police reported today.

title: PETITES HAVE THEIR HOUR
description: Little by little the fashion demands of petite women are being heeded. The latest indication is LB for Short, a mail-order catalogue of clothing for women under 5 feet 3 inches that comes from, of all people, Lane Bryant.

title: Around the World; Zia's Foes Call on U.S.  To Press for Elections
description: Eight outlawed opposition parties, likening Pakistan's military regime to Poland's, said today that the United States should lead the West in pressing for free elections here.

title: OHIO STATE CAPTURES LIBERTY BOWL, 31-28
description: Jimmy Gayle, a substitute tailback, scored his second touchdown late in the third quarter to help Ohio State to a 31-28 Liberty Bowl victory over error-prone Navy tonight in George Welsh's final game as the Midshipmen's football coach.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $18,000 for the qr and $57,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $79,000 for the qr and $128,000 for the 6 mos

title: THURSDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1981; Companies
description: Another round of fare cuts swept the airlines serving Florida from major cities in the Midwest and Northeast. The new cuts, led by Air Florida, brought the cost of flying from New York to Florida to $107 on weekdays and $127 on weekends. Eastern, Delta, Pan Am and T.W.A. matched the lower fares. (Page A1.)

title: ORANGE CLEMSON VS. NEBRASKA
description: AT MIAMI 48th game; kickoff, 8 P.M.; NBC-TV. Clemson (11-0-0) Rank: A.P., 1; U.P.I., 1; Times, 2. Coach: Danny Ford Nebraska (9-2) Rank: Times, 1; U.P.I., 4; A.P., 4. Coach: Tom Osborne Players to Watch

title: CHARGE AGAINST LUCE DENIED
description: A controversy arose yesterday over the recent best-selling novel ''The Last Days of America,'' by Paul Erdman, when Henry Luce 3d, a director of Time Inc., denounced the book for what he said were ''outright lies'' about his father, Henry R. Luce, and about Time magazine, which the late Mr. Luce founded. Passages of the Erdman book assert that Mr. Luce Sr. received $1 million from agents of the Shah of Iran and thereafter provided friendly coverage to the Shah in the pages of Time magazine.

title: Sports People; Coe and Ovett Honored
description: Sebastian Coe and Steve Ovett, the British track stars and archrivals who hold four world records from 300 meters to a mile, made Queen Elizabeth's New Year's Honors List. Coe and Ovett, who were excluded last year because they had participated in the Olympics in Moscow, were made members of the Order of the British Empire.

title: Youths Help Save Man In Sinkhole for 8 Days
description: A biologist who was trapped for eight days in an 18-foot-deep sinkhole says he made mud pockets to catch dripping ice for drinking water and tried to build a ladder out of sticks and his long underwear.

title: SOVIET SAID TO JAM RADIO TO WARSAW
description: The United States, seeking to emphasize Moscow's support of the military crackdown in Poland, accused the Soviet Union today of ''heavily jamming'' the Voice of America's Polish-language broadcasts into Poland.

title: ART: SUSAN WEIL GRAPHICS
description: A FREQUENT participant in group exhibitions since the early 50's, Susan Weil did not start showing solo until about a decade ago, and then more often than not in Scandinavia. Fresh from a retrospective in the Helsinki City Art Museum, Miss Weil now presents a handsome 10-year survey of prints and drawings at the Christian Gallery, 110 Greene Street.

title: HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Tomorrow is New Year's Day. Fol- lowing are holiday schedules: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended; Sunday regulations in effect.

title: Bowl Day at Aqueduct
description: Even if you're unlucky betting the horses, you may still be able to win at Aqueduct Racetrack, in South Ozone Park, Queens, on New Year's Day.

title: 'NEW YORK EXPERIENCE'
description: The New York Experience, the multiscreen movie recreating scenes and sounds of New York City past and present, will be open an hour earlier and close an hour later for the holiday season.

title: STOCK OPTION PLANS: CLOUDS ON HORIZON
description: When Congress enacted the new tax law, top executives were overjoyed that it appeared to include more generous tax treatment of stock options, long a favored form of remuneration.

title: Kodak Lists Price Increases
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced price increases ranging from 6 percent to 10.1 percent for professional and amateur still films, instant film and slide projectors.

title: PHILHARMONIC: A NIGHT WITH MEHTA IN VIENNA
description: ZUBIN MEHTA went to school in Vienna, and his best music-making is usually elicited by scores associated with that city. For the New Year, the New York Philharmonic is presenting a largely Viennese program that ends with 35 minutes of waltzes and polkas by Johann Strauss Jr. Mr. Mehta conducts it superbly, with a special lilt and swagger for the Waltz King.

title: Volume Expands As Dow Gains 4.85
description: The stock market snapped out of its recent doldrums yesterday and posted a moderate advance in accelerated trading. The session was highlighted by the sale of the second-largest share block traded in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: COURT REJECTS A SECOND TRIAL FOR MRS. HARRIS
description: Jean S. Harris's bid for a new trial in the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower was unanimously rejected today by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court. Voting 5 to 0, the justices said that although she ''did not receive a perfect trial, she received an eminently fair one.''

title: ROCK CLUBS ARE OFFERING AN ARRAY OF TALENT FOR EVERY TASTE
description: SPECIAL New Year's Eve shows are a tradition in New York's nightclubs, but this year there are some new wrinkles. The enormous number of clubs offering rock, folk, funk, country and soul and the competition that has sprung up among them guarantee an extraordinary array of talent, with something for every taste. And several clubs are offering late, late-late and late-late-late shows for celebrants who are determined to party past dawn.

title: ELECTRONIC MAIL FACES A DELAY
description: The Justice Department filed a lawsuit today asking for a temporary restraining order to prevent the United States Postal Service from beginning its new electronic mail service on Monday.

title: FOR NICARAGUAN BUSINESSES, COURT CASE IS FATEFUL
description: Melchor Prego was one of thousands of Nicaraguans who first learned that the Government had confiscated the large soap factory on the outskirts of Granada when the country's chief of state announced it on television during the second anniversary ceremonies of Nicaragua's revolution.

title: PLEASE, FOR DUDLEY MOORE, PIANIST
description: Dudley Moore, the film actor who has expended so much energy in recent years making people laugh, does not want to hear a chuckle when he steps onto the concert stage at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Sunday night at 8.

title: N.F.L. Sets Record
description: Paid attendance at National Football League regular-season games this year averaged more than 60,000 for the first time in the league's 62 years. The average was 60,745 for 224 games. The total of 13,606,990 was a record, exceeding the previous record of 13,392,230 set last year.

title: Keeping Faith With Solidarity
description: The new American sanctions may only inconvenience the Soviet Union, without significantly raising the costs of its backstage management of suppression in Poland. But the inconvenience is real, as is the sacrifice asked of domestic interests that a business-minded Administration normally favors. By spreading the pain of measured penalties, and threatening still more, President Reagan is keeping faith with those who most need encouragement - the resisting victims of a floundering tyranny.

title: Today Is the Deadline For Minimum Pension
description: Thursday is the last day for most people to sign up for Social Security and get the minimum monthly payment if their contributions do not qualify them for a bigger benefit.

title: WHY SOME WOMEN FORSWEAR FURS
description: Barbara Martz says she first made her decision not to wear fur coats in the late 1960's, when she and her husband would return from ski trips in New England and see dead deer lashed to hunters' cars.

title: Topics; CHUCKLES, ZONES AND BONES; Seeding the Bronx
description: The South Bronx is showing some heartening signs of life. The city has signed 20-year leases with two companies, a spare parts manufacturer and a garment padding concern, which will occupy the first building in the Bathgate Industrial Park.

title: MILTON H. MOSTEL
description: Milton H. Mostel, an accountant and lawyer who was a brother of the late actor Zero Mostel, died Tuesday at New York University Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Passaic, N.J.

title: Canada Gives Asylum To 15 Polish Seamen
description: Canada today allowed 15 more Polish seamen who jumped ship to remain in the country and a representative of Poland's Solidarity union called a strike vote for 200 seamen aboard four Polish fishing vessels.

title: BURGER REJECTS MOBIL BID
description: The Mobil Corporation suffered another major setback today in its determined effort to buy the Marathon Oil Company when Chief Justice Warren E. Burger refused to enjoin Mobil's rival, the United States Steel Corporation, from buying control of Marathon next week.

title: Brink's Defendant Wins Bail Issue
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that Eve Rosahn, a defendant in the Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County on Oct. 20, could be released on bail pending the outcome of her appeal of a contempt-ofcourt order involving her refusal to cooperate with a Federal grand jury.

title: WORSHIP IN LATIN FOUND TO DECLINE
description: Latin masses are still celebrated occasionally in more than 94 Roman Catholic dioceses in the United States, but a survey by the Vatican indicates that the use of Latin in worship is rapidly disappearing from the Catholic Church.

title: RANGERS TOP ISLANDERS, 6-4, WITH 2 IN 3D
description: In an exciting, well-played hockey game at Madison Square Garden last night, the Rangers defeated the Islanders, 6-4, for their first victory over the Stanley Cup champions this season. The Rangers scored twice in the third period after the Islanders had tied the game.

title: Greek Socialists End A Sexist Prohibition
description: Greece's Socialist Government announced today that it was abolishing a rule prohibiting men and women from sitting together in Parliament's public galleries.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard SICILIAN LIVES. By Danilo Dolci. Trans- lated from the Italian by Justin Vitiello and Madeline Polidoro. Foreword by John Berger. 304 pages. Pantheon. Hard cover, $16.50; paper, $6.95.

title: CLUBS ARE OFFERING GALAXY OF JAZZ STARS
description: DOZENS of seasoned jazz musicians and cabaret singers will be headlining New Year's Eve festivities in the New York area tonight. Some have have been welcoming the new year at clubs since the 1940's and 50's, and one - the indefatigable Alberta Hunter - has been singing on New Year's Eve since the 1920's.

title: COTTON/Alabama vs. Texas
description: At Dallas 46th game; kickoff, 2 P.M.; CBS-TV. Alabama (9-1-1) Rank: A.P., 3; U.P.I.,3; Times,7. Coach: Paul (Bear) Bryant Texas (9-1-1) Rank: U.P.I.,5; A.P.,6; Times,8. Coach: Fred Akers Players to watch

title: CLEMSON IS AIMING TO BE THE LAST TEAM TO BE FIRST
description: In September, when Michigan was the overwhelming choice to finish the season as the top-ranked college football team, Notre Dame, Oklahoma, Southern California, Texas and Alabama were considered to be the Wolverines' strongest challengers. No one thought Clemson would be a serious rival for these traditionally powerful teams.

title: Canada Rates Cut
description: The Bank of Canada today lowered its lending rate to 14.66 percent from 15 percent, setting off reductions in the prime lending rate at several of Canada's major commercial banks. The banks - including the Toronto Dominion Bank, the Bank of Montreal, the Bank of Nova Scotia and the Royal Bank -lowered their prime lending rates to 16 1/2 percent from 17 1/4 percent after the central bank's announcement.

title: Atari Reduces Price of Computer
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif., Dec. 30 (Reuters) Atari Inc., a unit of Warner Communications Inc., said that it would cut the retail price for its Model 800 home computer to $899 from $1,080, effective Friday.

title: Advertising; Prosperity At Money Magazine
description: WHEN the old weekly Life magazine shut down on Dec. 8, 1972, John U. Crandell, its ad director, then in his late 50's, had a severe case of the career blues.

title: Surrealism at Thalia
description: On New Year's Day, the Thalia Theater, 250 West 95th Street, will present its sixth annual surrealistic film festival, short films of the 1920's and 30's by Hans Richter, Man Ray, Max Ophuls and others, and including ''Blood of a Poet,'' the first film by Jean Cocteau, and the Luis Bunuel-Salvador Dali ''Un Chien Andalou.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a malfunction in Associated Press receiving equipment, the option prices and commodity future prices in Business Day yesterday included a number of garbled lines. Any reader wishing a corrected copy of the tables may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: Wolverine Plants
description: Wolverine World Wide Inc., the maker of Hush Puppies shoes and other footwear, said it had closed nine of its 22 plants in the United States for up to eight days to reduce inventories, idling about 2,300 workers. The closings, which will extend to Jan. 4, are in addition to normally scheduled year-end vacation and inventory closings, the company said in a statement. Wolverine also said that it expected to report record sales and earnings for 1981 despite a weaker fourth quarter than originally expected.

title: EXECUTIVES BLAME CALIFORNIA HOUSING COSTS FOR DIP IN MIGRATION
description: The great migration of Americans to California is declining, new analyses show, and many business leaders say that the reason is housing costs that are among the highest in the nation.

title: Oil Data Delayed
description: The weekly American Petroleum Institute figures do not appear today because of a Christmas holiday delay. The figures will appear in tomorrow's paper.

title: Peter B. Coffin Weds Ann Buffington Rhame
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., yesterday Ann Buffington Rhame, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold E. Rhame Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., was married to Peter Breckinridge Coffin, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Jarvis Coffin Jr. of Eden, N.Y., formerly of Wilton, Conn.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An obituary Dec. 15 on Phillip D. Doran, chief of flight operations for Pratt & Whitney Aircraft in East Hartford, incorrectly identified his former political position. Mr. Doran, a Democrat, was a member of Connecticut's House of Representatives from 1961 to 1969.

title: Briefing
description: A T a time when David A. Stockman, the Budget Director, is one of the most visible figures in Government, it is not surprising that there should be a newsletter devoted entirely to chronicling the thrusts, parries, maneuvers and feints of the Office of Management and Budget. And on Friday an outfit called Inside Washington Publishers, which already produces two newsletters from the capital, will be publishing the first edition of ''Inside O.M.B.'' The birth of the publication is, in part, a measure of how Mr. Stockman has placed his agency at the center of the controversies that have swirled around the Reagan Administration. ''The implications of what the O.M.B. does touches every aspect of society,'' says Alan Sosenko, chief editor of the publication, which, like most newsletters asserting that they provide an insider's look at Government, carries a steep price tag - $295 a year. Meanwhile, Mr. Sosenko promises that his newsletter will not be devoted exclusively to the doings of Mr. Stockman, whose musings about Reaganomics caused such a sensation when they appeared in The Atlantic Monthly late this autumn. ''I don't know how long David Stockman will be at O.M.B.,'' he says of the man on the bucking Trojan Horse, ''but we expect to be in business for a long, long time.''

title: Nets Defeat Pistons, 130-119
description: In what Coach Larry Brown said was perhaps the best team effort of the season, the Nets handily defeated the Detroit Pistons, 130-119, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beker Industries, Greenwich, Conn., has elected Erol Y. Beker senior vice president-operations and assistant to the chief executive officer, and Lawrence B. Kessler vice president, general counsel and secretary.

title: Dome Official Adds Posts at Hudson's Bay
description: With the minority stockholders of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company scheduled to vote Jan. 13 on the company's acquisition by Dome Petroleum Ltd., William E. Richards, the 55-year-old president of Dome, has been elected to the additional posts of president and chief executive officer of Hudson's Bay.

title: Afghans Release Journalist
description: Afghanistan has released a French freelance photo journalist, Jean Paul Silve, who served more than six months in prison for illegally entering the country, the French Embassy said today.

title: FROM WAREHOUSE TO WHITE HOUSE
description: The old warehouse near National Airport was chock-full of treasures. A French Empire sofa purchased by President Monroe was stored next to 19th-century American painted chairs. There were New York Empire tables, Dutch ginger jars and American eagle wood carvings. A 19thcentury Benjamin Franklin clock wore a mantle of dust.

title: LIFE AS A GRIND NOW BEGINS IN FRESHMAN YEAR
description: Chris Kondo, a senior at Brown University, is worried about the freshmen who live in the dormitory where she is a resident upperclassman. She has noticed that many of the freshmen with scholarships are not turning up for work in the school's cafeterias to earn money, preferring to spend their time studying.

title: Bridge Correct Lead Hard to Find Against Three No-Trump
description: Finding the right opening lead against three no-trump often presents a difficult problem. If no obvious lead presents itself, there are some general principles that apply.

title: PERCY SAYS TIME IS SHORT IN THE MIDEAST
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, ending a three-day visit to Israel, said today that ''time is running out'' in the quest for Middle East peace and said Israel was endangering its ''special relationship'' with the United States.

title: Elizabeth Holtzman Sworn In as Prosecutor
description: Vowing that she will enforce the law ''without fear or favor,'' Elizabeth Holtzman was sworn in as Brooklyn District Attorney yesterday before a crowd of relatives, friends, political associates and dignitaries in a ceremonial chamber of Borough Hall.

title: JOYCE-CAGE 'FINNEGAN' ON AIR
description: A realization of James Joyce's novel ''Finnegans Wake'' in words, syllables, music and random sound will be heard Saturday on WNYC-FM, 94 on the FM dial. The work, by the composer John Cage, is titled ''Roaratorio: An Irish Circus on 'Finnegans Wake.' '' It will be broadcast at 3 P.M. as part of National Public Radio's ''RadioVisions'' series.

title: TASS ASSAILS REAGAN'S SANCTIONS AS A RETURN TO THE COLD WAR ERA
description: The Soviet press agency Tass accused President Reagan today of attempting ''to hurl the world back to the dark times of the cold war'' with his decision to restrict Soviet-American trade and other contacts because of the Polish military crackdown.

title: Maximilian Schell's deed for a writer.
description: MAXIMILIAN SCHELL has come to New York on a crusade. Through the movie version of a play called ''Tales From the Vienna Woods,'' now at Cinema 3, he wants to introduce Americans to the work of the writer Odon von Horvath.

title: U.S. STEEL TO CLOSE BIG PLANT
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would shut down the Edgar Thomson Works near Pittsburgh for an indefinite period, laying off 1,000 steelworkers. It will be the second time that the plant, the first built by Andrew Carnegie, the company's founder, has been shut within 12 months.

title: STRANDED FAMILY DECLINES AID
description: A father and two daughters shipwrecked and marooned on a Pacific atoll for three weeks have rejected an offer of passage home from a yachtsman, the Coast Guard said today.

title: Icahn Accepts Consent Pact
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday the filing of a civil action in United States District Court against the Bayswater Realty and Capital Corporation, Icahn & Company and Carl C. Icahn for various violations of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Mr. Icahn leads the New York Stock Exchange member firm named for him.

title: Life Savers Sold
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. said that it had completed the purchase of Life Savers Inc. from the Squibb Corporation for cash and notes valued at about $250 million. Nabisco Brands also said that it had assumed certain outstanding Life Savers debts but did not elaborate. Life Savers, which makes candies and chewing gums at four factories in the United States, had operating income of $42 million on sales of $342 million in 1980.

title: U.S. Asserts 8 Bahai Leaders Have Been Executed in Iran
description: The State Department said today that they had reliable reports that all eight members of Iran's Bahai National Spiritual Assembly had been executed in a campaign to stamp out the religion.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've lost our combat pay.'' -Howard Fogel, president, Independent Taxi Owners Council. (B1:6.)

title: Essay; OFFICE POOL FOR 1982
description: An annual tradition in this space has been the Office Pool, a device to stretch readers' imaginations, force long-range thinking and slyly slip in my own prognostications about the year ahead.

title: GIANTS FIND 2 MISSING PIECES
description: For years the Giants had a deficiency that glared, an offensive line that could neither protect a quarterback nor sustain a drive.

title: NIELSEN, A C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ECONOMISTS ARE DIVIDED ON UNION CONCESSIONS
description: Economists meeting here disagree about whether 1982's key union contract negotiations will produce the wage and benefit concessions that all say are needed to provide lasting relief from inflation.

title: CANCER RISK CUT BY HORMONE
description: A study from London has confirmed that small doses of the hormone progesterone can reduce the rate of precancerous changes in women taking another hormone, estrogen, as postmenopausal therapy.

title: FOR DRUNKEN DRIVERS, THE TRIP GETS TOUGHER
description: ''He's sober,'' Officer Joseph Delio of the Greenburgh town police said as he ordered the speeding motorist to pull to the side of Route 119 shortly before midnight last night.

title: POLL TEAM CHIEF IN JERSEY LEAVES HIS G.O.P. POST
description: John A. Kelly, who organized the National Ballot Security Task Force for the Republicans in the recent New Jersey gubernatorial election, resigned yesterday from his executive position on the Republican National Committee.

title: Massey-Ferguson Appoints President
description: Vincent D. Laurenzo, 42 years old, has been named president of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the world's largest producer of farm tractors and diesel engines. Massey is undergoing a corporate reorganization in an effort to cope with the depressed farm-equipment market.

title: 2 Earthquakes Jar Alaska
description: Two moderate earthquakes jarred the Fairbanks area early today, rattling windows and awakening some residents.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR OFFICIAL CRITICIZES INDUSTRY PLANNING
description: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has said that some utilities are delaying planning for nuclear power plants because of uncertainty over electrical demand.

title: THE LIBERATION OF WOMEN- AND MEN
description: One reason the effects wrought by the Women's Movement remain c louded in uncertainty is that its goals have been divided between m atters of simple justice and matters of androgyny.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
GLIMPSES OF '81: MOMENTS IN A YEAR OF VIVID IMAGES
description: The year began with a collective sigh of relief. A 444-day siege of spirit ended as the hostages returned from captivity in Iran, and as the cameras caught the images of jubilation, it seemed American hope was liberated as well.

title: BOY FROM UKRAINE LOSES COURT ROUND
description: The state of Illinois should not have intervened in the case of Walter Polovchak, the 14-year-old boy who ran away from his parents here rather than go back with them to the Ukraine, a state appeals court ruled today.

title: How to Get the Jobs Job Done
description: Considering its hostility to welfare programs, the Reagan Administration is certainly behaving strangely toward jobs programs. Jimmy Carter increased spending for jobs and job training for the chronically unemployed to $8 billion a year. This Administration has not only chopped that down to $2.4 billion, but now talks of turning over control of these programs from municipal governments to private business and labor councils.

title: MAYOR SUGGESTS TRANSIT CRIMES GET OWN COURTS
description: Mayor Koch suggested yesterday that the state courts create special trial sections to deal exclusively with serious crimes committed on the city's subway and bus lines.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including income of affillate of $190,,000 or 4 cents a shr for the qr and $895,000 or 19 cents a shr for the 6 mos

title: Hanoi Denounces Israel
description: Deputy Prime Minister Tran Quyhn of Vietnam today denounced Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights as ''an act of expansion and another Israeli violation of the Arab countries' sovereignty and United Nations principles.'' Mr. Quyhn was talking to reporters after seeing the Emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah.

title: 50 SURCHARGES AT NIGHT ENDING IN NONFLEET CABS
description: Beginning tonight at midnight, only fleet taxicabs with special red and white stickers on their doors will be allowed to impose the 50-cent night surcharge for rides between 8 P.M. and 6 A.M.

title: BATTERED BUDGET ACT LIMPS INTO 1982
description: In the short history of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, in which the lawmakers tried to discipline their own penchant for spending, no New Year has seemed more portentous than 1982 nor any Old Year so traumatic as 1981. The Congressional budget process and restraint supposedly created by the 1974 act seem to be foundering.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WHERE IS THE GERMAN LEFT'S OUTCRY OVER POLAND?
description: To the Editor:

title: SSC&B Said to Win Steak & Ale Account
description: Reports from the field have it that SSC&B, one of the more active components of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will become the agency for the Steak & Ale Restaurants of America, which the Leo Burnett Company resigned in October to take the McDonald's account.

title: Reagan Says U.S. Will Avoid Direct Role in the Resistance; United Press International
description: President Reagan said in an interview broadcast yesterday that he wants to avoid sparking bloodshed in Poland by giving workers there false hope for direct aid in their resistance.

title: SUGAR GEORGIA VS. PITT
description: AT NEW ORLEANS 48th game; kickoff, 8 P.M.; ABC-TV. Georgia (10-1) Rank: A.P., 2; U.P.I., 2; Times, 3. Coach: Vince Dooley Pitt (10-1) Rank: Times, 6; U.P.I., 8; A.P., 10. Coach: Jackie Sherrill Players to watch

title: ITALIAN EXPERTS SAY DOZIER PHOTOGRAPH IS NOT A COMPOSITE
description: Experts at the Interior Ministry, who examined a photograph of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier made public Sunday by the Red Brigades in Milan, said today that the photograph was not a montage, as the police had suspected earlier, and that General Dozier had in fact been holding a placard bearing anti-American slogans.

title: FIRST COINVESTORS INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30

IF you'd like to dine and dance into the New Year, there are many restaurants and clubs that are still taking reservations. There will be dancing, of course, at Roseland, 239 West 52d Street (247-0200), from 9 P.M. to 5 A.M. Three bands will play: Don Glasser's Big Band, Emilio Reyes's Latin Band and the Seioto County Band (country and western). A disco beat will take over at midnight.  For $25, including tax, you get hats, noisemakers, balloons and a glass of champagne at midnight. Food is available at the restaurant in the back.
description: The Grand Ballroom at the Waldorf-Astoria, 301 Park Avenue (872-4997 or 4998), will be celebration headquarters from 9 P.M. to 3 A.M. The price of a table for two starts at $125 (on the periphery of the dance floor), and rises to $200 for a table nearer the orchestra and $225 for a spot in the ''Diamond Horseshoe,'' which is closest to the band - and the television cameras. The $125 covers the show (Donny Osmond with Peter Duchin and his orchestra), a bottle of champagne and at 1 A.M. scrambled eggs, toast and coffee. The higher-priced tables include a filet mignon dinner. Hats, noisemakers and balloons come with both.

title: Topics; CHUCKLES, ZONES AND BONES; I H Eurypterid
description: Let the State of New York tip its heraldic lid And add to its symbols the

title: Sports People; Interview at Navy
description: Gary Tranquill, the offensive coordinator at West Virginia, disclosed that he had been interviewed for the position of coach at Navy.

title: Around the Nation; Ralston Purina Indicted In Louisville Sewer Blast
description: The Ralston Purina Company was indicted today on four counts of violating Federal laws in connection with sewer explosions that caused millions of dollars in damages in Louisville Feb. 13.

title: JOHN PAUL SPEAKS OF 'TREPIDATION' ABOUT FATE OF THE ARRESTED POLES
description: Pope John Paul II deplored the continuation of the state of siege in Poland today and expressed his ''anxiety'' and ''trepidation'' over the fate of those who have been arrested and interned.

title: Sports People; Big-Fish Story
description: For two hours Eric Soderholm, the Yankee third baseman and designated hitter; his brother Kurt, and another companion had been trolling for gamefish eight miles east of Miami without a nibble. So they started a game of Scrabble.

title: Carting Concerns Ask Rise in Rates
description: The carting companies that haul trash and garbage from commercial establishments in the five boroughs asked the city to grant a rate increase that would allow them to charge their customers more for their services.

title: No Headline
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the last week (Monday, Dec. 21, to Sunday, Dec. 27), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets.

title: Soldiers From Tanzania Help Defend Seychelles, Aide Says
description: Tanzanian troops are helping man airport and coastal defense positions after last month's coup attempt by mercenaries, Maj. James Michel, the Seychelles Information Minister, said today.

title: TURKS PRESENT SCHEDULE FOR RETURN TO DEMOCRACY
description: Turkey's military leader announced a timetable today for a return to democracy, with general elections to be held in the fall of 1983 at the earliest and the spring of 1984 at the latest.

title: Topics; Chuckles, Zones and Bones; Strangling Language
description: The Dictionary of American Slang has been banned from 21 elementary and junior high schools in Colorado because it is ''very explicit'' in its definitions of words that the Board of Education in Westminster doesn't like -especially regarding sex and race.

title: BEHIND A SURGE IN JOB ACCIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: INDICTED U.S. JUDGE DENIES BRIBERY-CONSPIRACY CHARGE
description: A Federal district judge indicted Tuesday on charges of bribery-conspiracy and obstruction of justice today denied any wrongdoing, and the judge's 11 colleagues on the Federal bench here disqualified themselves from involvement in his trial.

title: Paris-Algiers Gas Talks
description: The state-owned utility Gaz de France said today that it would begin talks next month with the Algerian state company Sonatrach aimed at ending a two-year-old gas price dispute that has shut off Algerian shipments of natural gas to France. The talks, the first formal contact between the two companies for almost a year, follow a visit by President Francois Mitterrand of France to Algiers last month and a subsequent agreement between the two Governments on the political framework for a settlement of the dispute. Sources said that France had agreed in principle to a price increase for Algerian gas, which is already above world market levels.

title: DR. MAX MEYER
description: Dr. Max Meyer, who had served the Free Synagogue of Flushing, Queens, for more than 50 years as rabbi and rabbi emeritus, died last Saturday in Jensen Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: 'GIFT' EXPOLDES, INJURING UNION LEADER
description: An international union president was seriously injured yesterday when he opened a Christmas package delivered to his office and a bomb exploded in his face.

title: NORTHWESTERN SECURITY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
NEW BURDENS FOR GRAIN BELT
description: The sagging farm economy, burdened for the last two years by curtailed grain shipments, a drought, high interest rates and bumper crops, may be facing even harder times as a result of President Reagan's new economic sanctions against the Soviet Union.

title: GETTING TASTE OF ACADEMIA AND FINLAND
description: Not all American diplomats are found in embassies. Some are not even found in the State Department. This year, five career Foreign Service officers are scattered, for a variety of reasons, across the United States as ''diplomats in residence'' at five universities.

title: ROSE IOWA VS. WASHINGTON
description: TV. Iowa (8-3) Rank: U.P.I., 11; A.P., 13; Times, 14. Coach: Hayden Fry Washington (9-2) Rank: U.P.I., 10; A.P., 12; Times, 18.

title: ARCHITECTURE: 100 YEARS AS SEEN BY COLUMBIA U.
description: THE School of Architecture at Columbia University is where John Russell Pope, architect of the National Gallery of Art and the National Archives, learned his trade as a member of the class of 1894. It is where exquisite Beaux-Arts drawings were produced by such architects as T. Merrill Prentice in the 1920's and where Max Abramovitz, partner in the prominent modernist firm of Harrison & Abramovitz, graduated in 1931. It is where the student upheavals of the 60's led to a major thrust toward a socially conscious architecture, where one of the country's leading programs in historical preservation is based and where the faculty contains ardent modernists rubbing shoulders with leaders of the so-called ''postmodern'' movement.

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS ARE TAKING ON THE CIVIL SERVICE
description: Greece's Socialist Government is proceeding to purge the Civil Service to end what it describes as a heavy bureaucracy and patronage system ''preventing the development of a modern state.''

title: A SIZE 55 GUARDS PENN STATE
description: Each jagged range of the red-crusted mountains that lie amid the haze is named for its look or for its history.

title: A FULL-TIME CRACKDOWN IN SUFFOLK
description: The Suffolk County Police Department said today that it would inaugurate a permanent overnight drunkendriving patrol on Friday, with 11 cars assigned to the task force every night of the year.

title: CONCESSIONS BY TEAMSTERS EXPECTED IN NEW PACT
description: Concessions by the teamsters' union on wages and work rules are likely to be part of a contract settlement expected soon between the union and the financially ailing trucking industry, knowledgeable sources say.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, DECEMBER 31, 1981
description: International Disarray in the Communist Party in Poland has followed the ascendency of the military Government, according to information arriving from Warsaw. As a result, the reports said, Gen. Woljciech Jaruzelski, the leader, has set up at least three groups to present proposals for social, economic and political reform. Each group is headed by a prominent party leader and each represents a potentially rival faction. (Page A1, Column 6.) The United States accused Moscow of ''heavily jamming'' the Voice of America's Polish-language broadcasts to Poland. The State Department made the charge in an effort to underscore Moscow's role in the imposition of martial law in Poland. The Reagan Administration stepped up efforts to persuade American allies of its contention that the Kremlin is largely responsible for the crackdown. (A1:5.)

title: POLAND REPORTS A SHORTAGE IN FOOD SET ASIDE FOR WINTER
description: Poland's military Government, while broadcasting reassurances that economic life was returning to normal, said today that the stockpiling of winter food supplies had fallen far short of projected needs.

title: Thursday; CONCERT FOR CARNEGIE HALL
description: Some musical luminaries will herald the new year tonight at 8 with a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall - including Isaac Stern and Arnold Steinhardt, violinists; Leonard Bernstein and Eugene Istomin, pianists; Leonard Rose, cellist, and Benita Valente, soprano. They will be helping the hall and the Musicians Foundation, which is the philanthropic arm of the Bohemians, a fraternal club of New York musicians. On the program are Schubert's Piano Trio in B flat and ''Shepherd on the Rock'' for soprano, piano and clarinet, Mozart's Sonata for Violin and Piano in E minor (K. 304), Villa-Lobos's Bachianas Brasileiras No. 5 and works by Giovanni Bottesini, Josef Lanner and Johann Strauss. Benefit tickets are $50 to $100 (which includes a champagne reception on stage with the musicians). Information: 397-8766. Regular tickets are $7.50 to $25. To charge, call 247-7459.

title: Free Museum Recital
description: The Museum of the City of New York will present a free recital by Judith Unland, soprano, in its auditorium Sunday at 3 P.M. Miss Unland, who recently appeared at Lincoln Center, will sing arias and bel canto songs by Mozart, Cavalli, Pergolese, Granados and others. At Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

title: For Elizabeth Taylor, Separation Not Divorce
description: After a series of denials that anything was amiss, Elizabeth Taylor and Senator John W. Warner of Virginia finally announced last week that they were separating.

title: SUPER FOOD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 21
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid Dec 15; Yr-ago results have been restated for a change to LIFO accounting for inventories

title: TO DEFEAT A COMA
description: To the Editor:

title: 2D ROUND OF CUTS REDUCES AIR FARE TO FLORIDA TO $107
description: The Florida air fare war intensified yesterday with a new round of cuts that will bring the cost of flying between New York and Miami down to $107 one way, one of the lowest fares in years during the peak tourist season.

title: JAZZ: HENDRICKS PLAYS NEW CLUB
description: ANEW jazz club, Lush Life, named for Billy Strayhorn's song, opened last weekend at the corner of Bleecker and Thompson Streets, with Jon Hendricks and Company as its first attraction. Mr. Hendricks, who will be at Lush Life through Saturday, is known best as a member of the singing trio of the 1950's - Lambert, Hendricks and Ross - for whom he wrote lyrics for vocal interpretations of Count Basie band arrangements and instrumental jazz solos.

title: News Analysis
description: Presiding Justice Milton Mollen's 55-page opinion upholding the murder conviction of Jean S. Harris ostensibly deals with the many issues Mrs. Harris's attorneys raised to show what she regarded as the unfairness of the case against her.

title: People
description: * James Aucone has joined David Deutsch Associates as executive vice president, director of account services, and Kevin Buckley has been named a senior vice president.

title: VATICAN GUARDIAN OF THE FAITH
description: Franjo Cardinal Seper, an influential figure in the Vatican hierarchy, died today, the Vatican Radio announced. He was 76 years old.

title: THE SIMPLE ISSUE OF HOMOSEXUALS' RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: FIESTA PENN STATE VS. U.S.C.
description: TV. Penn State (9-2) Rank: Times, 4; U.P.I., 6; A.P., 7. Coach: Joe Paterno U.S.C. (9-2) Rank: U.P.I., 7; A.P., 8; Times, 11.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Rates Down in Slow Session By H.J. MAIDENBERG

title: Funds' Assets Off $1.3 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined $1.3 billion in the week ended yesterday, with $1.1 billion of the decline attributed to institutional investors, the Donoghue Money Fund Report said.

title: CORE AND STATE REACH ACCORD ON USE OF FUNDS
description: The Congress of Racial Equality has reached agreement with the State Attorney General's office to settle charges that the organization misused nearly $500,000 in charitable contributions.

title: Vilas Toppled by Pfister
description: Hank Pfister of Bakersfield, Calif., upset top-seeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, 6-3, 6-4, 6-4, and reached the quarterfinals of the $450,000 Australian Open tennis championships today. Vilas has won this Grand Slam event twice.

title: Dr. Karl Schaefer, 69, A Researcher for Navy
description: Dr. Karl E. Schaefer, a medical researcher who carried out studies on carbon dioxide for the Navy, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Old Lyme, Conn. He was 69 years old.

title: IRAQ REPORTS ISRAELI AIRCRAFT INTRUDED INTO ITS AIRSPACE
description: Iraq said today that two Israeli fighter planes had penetrated 30 miles into southwestern Iraqi airspace near the Saudi Arabian border but had been intercepted by Iraqi planes and forced to withdraw.

title: Technology; Game Playing: A Big Future
description: IF the children already seem to be growing bored with the video games they received for Christmas this year, it might be time to look ahead. Five years from now, electronic games promise to be more realistic, complex and, perhaps, more frightening than those now on the market.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results for the latest qr and 9 mos reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 which provides new rules for foreign currency translation

title: Around the Nation; F.B.I. Arrests Woman In Death of Letter Carrier
description: Federal Bureau of Investigation agents arrested a woman tonight whom they said was one of four suspects being sought in the killing a letter carrier abducted last weekend.

title: FUNNIEST THINGS HAPPENING TONIGHT
description: RODNEY DANGERFIELD, put upon by foe and friend, henpecked, a living, breathing target of opportunity, who draws abuse the way a hive attracts bees, finally appears to have gotten respect. The selfcriticizing comedian, who has fashioned a career by describing his losing battles with life, is taking over Radio City Music Hall for a New Year's Eve party beginning at 9:30 tonight. This is a long way, indeed, from one of the tiny clubs he played early in his career, a club so far outside the usual nightclub circuit ''that my act was reviewed by Field & Stream.''

title: Kaiser Aluminum Closing 4th Line
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's third-largest aluminum producer, announced today that it was shutting the last of four aluminum-producing lines at its Ravenswood faclity in West Virginia.

title: WHY BIRTHING NEEDS A HOSPITAL SETTING
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO WEIGHS PLANS 'INDEPENDENTLY'
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has no plans to meet with Governor Carey before he decides whether to seek re-election or to challenge the Governor. He said he would make his decision ''independently'' of the Governor.

title: Sports People; Ditka's Ambition
description: The Chicago Bears are interested in Mike Ditka as head coach, and Ditka is interested, too. Tex Schramm, the president of the Dallas Cowboys, said that George Halas, the owner of the Bears, had requested permission to interview Ditka, who has been the Cowboys' receivers coach for nine years.

title: 25,000 POLES IN THE U.S. ARE TRYING TO GET HOME
description: ''The question is always the same,'' a ticket agent of the Polish national airline said yesterday of the many telephone calls she receives.

title: Cemetery Workers Authorize a Strike
description: About 500 cemetery workers gathered in the Roosevelt Auditorium on East 17th Street voted to authorize a strike against 70 cemeteries in the metropolitan area on Saturday.

title: BONN MAY PROCEED ON SOVIET GAS LINE
description: The West German Government apparently remains committed to participating in the natural gas pipeline from the Soviet Union to Western Europe, despite Tuesday's announcement by the United States of economic sanctions against the project.

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Around the Nation; 7 Massachusetts Youths Released in Slayings
description: An appeals court judge today freed seven teen-agers convicted of manslaughter in the deaths of two graduates of a rival high school, saying the attorneys for the convicted youths had raised legitimate questions on the fairness of their trial.

title: PUBLISHING: BULLISH DAYS FOR BOOKS ON ECONOMY
description: ITS advocacy of supply-side economic theory helped make a hardcover best seller of George Gilder's ''Wealth and Poverty,'' and the book will have a new life as Bantam's lead paperback title for January. Another book on economic theory that is enjoying an unexpected new life is ''Paternalistic Capitalism,'' a critical look at how the economy is shaped by the corporate managerial elite, published by the University of Minnesota Press 10 years ago.

title: Photo sales follow trend.
description: THIS season's photography sales have followed something of the same pattern as the rest of the art-auction market -exceptional material brought exceptional prices, and the rest sold for moderate prices or did not find buyers. At Christie's East, Christie's second house, at 219 East 67th Street, a sale on Nov. 10-11 saw several records, the most important of which was the $26,000 paid for ''Nautilus,'' Edward Weston's famous picture of a shell, the highest price ever paid for a Weston or indeed for any 20th-century photograph. The sale offered 431 works, of which the 268 sold brought $460,250, quite a bit below the expectations of $650,780 to $870,100. Records for other photographers included the $19,000 paid for Gertrude Kasebier's 1899 ''Blessed Art Thou Among Women''; $18,000 for Edward Steichen's 1901 print ''Solitude-F. Holland Day, Paris,'' and $7,000 for Andre Kertesz's 1930 ''Untitled, Still Life.''

title: Ives Names President
description: Thomas G. Cavanagh, 45, has been named president of Ives Laboratories, one of the three ethical pharmaceutical companies owned by the American Home Products Corporation. He succeeds Sidney Elston, who assumes the vacant post of chairman at the New York-based company until his retirement at the age of 65 next July.

title: Around the World; Chile Seals Off 2 Areas In Search for Criminals
description: National policemen, backed by army and air force units, cordoned off two working-class neighborhoods and arrested about 700 people, the Government said today.

title: JOSHUA RIFKIN RESOTING BACH B MINOR MASS AT Y
description: For anyone who thinks he has heard Bach's Mass in B minor, Joshua Rifkin and the Bach Ensemble have a surprise. Saturday night at 8, they will perform what they are audaciously calling the work's ''original'' at the 92d Street Y, using a chorus of five. Not 500, not even 50, but 5.

title: THE AFGHAN WARRIORS: MANY OUTLOOKS, ONE CAUSE
description: Photographs of the turbaned guerrilla fighters of Afghanistan have been widely seen in the last two years and in general they reflect images of fierce, even fanatical men who are willing to make heavy sacrifices and may even be eager for martyrdom as they fight the Soviet soldiers and struggle against alien beliefs.

title: AT MODERN, LUMET'S LOVE AFFAIR WITH NEW YORK
description: ''I don't know if people realize what's been happening in New York for close to 20 years, but, it's one of the great periods of the city,'' the film director Sidney Lumet said the other day. ''I know about the subways, the garbage and all that, but I'm talking about creativity - the people that have been coming out of this city for 30, 40 years now. It's unbelievable.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ART: PHOTOS OF ARTISTS BY HANS NAMUTH
description: FOR anyone with a keen interest in contemporary art, photographs of the artists themselves - and most especially of artists in their studios - are almost always irresistible. The more famous the artist, of course, the better. But even photographs of the less famous are likely to have their charms. An interest in the art naturally induces a certain curiosity about the person who has created it. We want to know what our favorite painters and sculptors look like, and how they live, and in what conditions their works are conceived and executed.

title: NOVEMBER NEW-HOME SALES UP
description: In a modest late-year gain, sales in November of new single-family homes rose 11.3 percent from a month earlier, to an annual rate of 403,000, the best level since July, the Government reported today. It was the second consecutive monthly gain of more than 10 percent.

title: A COUNCIL PANEL OFFERS NEW PLAN ON REDISTRICTING
description: Members of a City Council commission announced a new redistricting plan yesterday that they said would create 12 predominantly black and Hispanic districts.
